column2: Senator Lonergan of Connecticut, an opponent of the President's Supreme Court and Government Reorganization Bills, received virtual endorsement for renomination today from Attorney General Cummings.

The thirty-first annual flower show will take place here July 27 and 28 in the auditorium of the parochial school in Hill Street under the joint S auspices of the Garden Club of Southampton and the Southampton Horticultural Society.
A banking group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., will offer today $4,500,000 of bonds bf the Board of Administrators of the Charity Hospital of Louisiana, in

Automobile production increased sharply last week as plants returned to normal schedules after holiday shut-downs or curtailments. Daily average output showed a marked gain, countering a seasonal easing, and the adjusted index spurted more than 13 points to 48.0. This compared with 34.3 for the preceding week and 131.7 for the week ended July 17, 1937.
Toronto packed a lot of poor baseball into the eighth inning of tonight's game and Jersey City chipped in with two timely blows in a five-run outburst which gave the Little Giants an 11-to-7 triumph.

French holders of Chilean foreigndebt obligations announced today acceptance of the government's plan for resumption of partial payments as embodied in the law, the text of which recently was the subject of a long discussion in New York when an advisory committee withdrew its recommendation to holders of Chilean bonds,

Baron Horder, physician to King George, headed tonight a brilliant array of medical talent backing Dr. Aleck William Bourne, one of London's foremost obstetricians, in his Old Bailey trial for keeping a 15-yearold assault victim from motherhood.

Advancing for the second consecutive week from the low point of July 4, steel operations in the United States this week at 36.4 per cent are the best for this year and about 16.8 per cent above the average rate of 31.17 per cent of capcity registered for the first six months of 1938. Throughout that
Representatives of five maritime unions met yesterday to map a campaign against the government's so-called hiring hall, the Sea Service Bureau. This agency, with an

German Stock Exchanges suffered today their worst day since Chancellor Hitler came to power. Despite rigid control prices tumbled four, five, six and in individual cases up to nine points in what some German newspapers themselves call a sensational collapse.

Last June Miss Josephine Roche palitely but firmly served' notice on the American Medical Association, assembled at San Francisco, that organized medicine was expected to present a program of medical relief at a national health conference to be held at Washington. That conference is now

Errol Flynn today threatened Warners with a new rebellion when he advised the studio that he would not submit to a happy ending for Myron Brinig's "The Sisters," in which he is-- starring with Bette Davis. The conclusion of the book
At least ten new plays are to betried out in the Summer theatres of the-East next week. With several more likely to be added between now and Monday, the list reads;
The Reichsbank's statement as of July 16 shows the following changes from the preceding week, in thousands of marks:

Poker-faced Frankie Parker, who has never lost a tournament match on the clay courts of the Bathing and Tennis Club, annexed his fifth final match in the six-year history of the club's invitation tennis tourney today with a straight-set victory over hard-hitting Archibald Henderson of Chapel Hill. N. C.

The biological survey announced today it would increase by fifteen days the hunting season this Fall on ducks and other migratory fowl. The season will' start that much earlier on ducks, geese, jacksnipe and coot. This will allow

Although traffic accidents, injuries and deaths decreased last week compared with the same period in 1937, the number of accidents:and injuries during the weekend showed a slight increase over last year, it was reported yesterday by the Safety Bureau of the Police Department.

Klinger Rehaut Construction Company has been awarded the general contract for alterations in the building at 569-71 Bergenline Avenue, West New York, N. J., in preparation for its occupancy by the Fisher-Beer Company, department store chain. Abraham Davis,

Angelo B. Oliva, 31-year-old savings teller in the Straight Street branch. of the Second National Bank, left the bank for lunch today and went to police headquarters to confess that he had robbed his employers of at least $100,000 over a period of seven years.

The Cardinals evened matters with the Phillies in their rain shortened series today, winning by 5 to 3 as Max Macon halted a ninth-inning rally that gave Jimmy Wilson's men their only runs. Curt Davis, who allowed only six hits until the ninth, received credit for his eighth victory.

Judge Peter J. Brancato, yesterday in Kings County Court, sentenced Julie Gerber, 22 years old, i of 209 Chester Street, Brooklyn, the t only survivor of three bandits who attempted to hold up a Brooklyn tobacco store on May 3, to thirty to sixty years in Sing Sing.

Final subscription and allotment figures on the approximately $200,000,000 of Reconstruction -Finance Commission 7/8 per cent notes sold last week were announced today by Roswell Magill, Acting Secretary of the Tresaury as follows:

" A strong national association" is what the Securities and Exchange Commission has in mind as representative of the over-the-counter investment field under the Maloney Act, William O. Douglas, chairman of tai the commission, said in a letter answering an inquiry by Wallace H. Fulton, director of the Investment Bankers Conference.

Walton Ave, 2,332 (11-3183): William L. Halfman to Dorothy H. Abramson, 2,860 Valentine Ave; mtg, $37,500. 163d St (10-2677), s s, 38 ft e of Union Ave, 50x100; Annie Yasgur to Joseph Yasgur, 1,487 Teller Ave.

The pro-amateur tourney of the Westchester division of the Professional Golfers Association, held at the Old Oaks Country Club today, e drew a starting field of sixty-eight. The field played through showers and hot. sunny weather.
The two days from July 18 to July 20, 1918, when Foch flung in a division of Algerians and two divisions
Miss Elizabeth Smith Alison, daughter of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Alexander Alison Jr., will be married here to Walter Earle Witsil of this city on Aug. 27 at the home of her parents. Dr. Alison, pastor

State, county and city police pressed a widespread search today for Adrian Lawrence Dudley, alias Harry Baxter, a Federal prisoner who escaped from a passenger train here while being transported from Los Angeles to Scranton, Pa.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt and her son, James, alighted here late this afternoon from a plane which brought them from Rochester, Minn., where young Roosevelt had been undergoing treatment since June 21 for gastric ulcer.

A Japanese local patrol commander in Korea has handed a Soviet patrol commander a document reading: "Your country's border guards have invaded Manchukuo territory in the neighborhood of Changchih and have been constructing fortified positions, which can never be permitted. From the standpoint of our

Commissioner Charles V. Halley Jr. of the Board of Transportation announced yesterday that, at the request of many citizens of Irish birth or descent, he was forming a committee of lawyers to intercede with the aviation authorities in Washington on behalf of Corrigan and to act for the flier if legal difficulties should arise from his flight.

Given a hand ride down the stretch to withstand the thrilling bid of F. H. Williamson's Inviting, the Greentree Stable's Birthday today scored by a head in the Derry Purse, mileand-a-sixteenth feature at Rockingham Park, to pay $4.90 for $2.

Herman Schapansky, who lives nine miles from town, listened in on the radio this morning and heard good news. It was about an Irishman named Corrigan who had spanned the Atlantic in a "flying crate," without permits.

Back again, after two weeks of Nantucket, in which we did very little fishing, we seem to have arrived in the height of the tuna season. The bluefins seem more numerous than ever this year' and it is beginning to look as though a number of the charter captains will be able to buy new boats this Fall.

Stoutly maintaining that he was "real embarrassed" when he found he had flown to Ireland, Douglas G. Corriga explained in his soft, pleasant voice yesterday that he had thought all the time he was heading for California, but that he had made a mistake in setting the dial of his compass.
The international stock market indices for July 16, with comparisons, are as follows, the basic figure of 100 representing conditions on the last Saturday in 1927:
With buyers' arrivals yesterday augmented by heavy arrivals of representatives of homewares departments, buying activity was headed toward its initial seasonal crest this week.

George Benson Hodge, for many years volunteer director of the Bureau of Records of the Y. M. C. A. and publisher of the organization's year book, died here today. Mr. Hodge, a former member of the National Council and of the International Committee of the Y. M. C. A., lived at 78 North Eighteenth Street.

A form covering the, industry's specifications on the purchase of $2,000,000 worth of women's and children's apparel by the WPA was worked out yesterday at a meeting of a committee of three comprising Samuel Klein of the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers; J. L. Dubow of the Merchants Ladies Garment Association and C. Baker of the Infants and Children's Coat Association.

The general average of returns for the shirt and pajama industry is from 3 to 4 per cent -of sales, according to a survey completed yesterday by the National Association of Shirt and Pajama Manufacturers. The rate of returns ranged

The Rev. Dr. Rivington David Lord, president of the American Baptist Home Mission Society and pastor for more than fifty-three years of the First Baptist Church of Williamsburg, Lee Avenue and Keap Street, Brooklyn, died yesterday in Clifton, Mass., after an illness of about one year.
Two farm tracts of twenty-one acres each in Hicksville, L. I., were purchased by one buyer in transactions reported yesterday.
Rain caused postponement of a boxing show at Meadowbrook Bowl tonight after one bout had been completed. The show, featuring Pittsburgh's Zivic brothers, will be staged tomorrow night.

Wilmer Allison of Austin, Texas, former national tennis champion, started his defense of the historic Longwood Bowl today against the most attractive field to gather in years on the turf of the Longwood Cricket Club.

In a communication to Mayor La Guardia, made public yesterday by the Toilet Goods Association, Hugo Mock, counsel of the organization, urged that no action toward enactment be taken on Bill No. 313, now before the City Council.

Manhattan Alterations Baxter St. 145: to 1-story office and shop: Bessie Finkelstein. 355 Brown St; Bklyn, owner; T. R. Feinberg, architect; cost, $12.000. 5th St, 520 E; to 5-story tenement and stores; Milton M. Mitchell, 260 E 161st St. Bronx, owner; G. G. Miller, architect; cost. $9,000.

Hungary's Premier, Bela Imredy, and her Foreign Minister, Koloman de Kanya, arrived in Rome this morning for a three-day stay during which an effort will be made again to pick up the threads of Italian policy in Central Europe severed by the disappearance as an independent State of Austria, the third partner, together with Italy and Hungary, in the 1934 Rome Protocols.

MANHATTAN BBETT, LILLIAN H. (July 1). Estate, more than $25,000. To Shelden Abbett, son, North St., Greenwich, Conn., $3,000; Andrew Lord, 42 Tuxedo Rd., Montclair, N. J., executor, specific bequest; Leon Abbett, son, executor, Glen Cove, L. I., specific legacies, one-third residue outright and life estate in two-thirds residue; the American National Red Cross, National Headquarters, Washington, D. C., remainder in two-thirds residue.

O. C. Hulett, president of the Burlington Liars' Club, solemnly affirmed he was telling the truth tonight when he said Douglas Corrigan, who flew to Ireland under his avowed belief he was headed for California, had been made a life number of the club.
From that largely vanished world of iron etiquette and custom to which she was born, this, granddaughter of Queen Victoria somehow succeeded in escaping and became herself.

Judge Ralph J. Dady of the Circuit Court at Waukegan today found ten North Chicago strike pickets guilty of contempt of court. The men, all affiliated with a C. I. 0. union, were ordered to jail for periods of twenty to 120 days.
Rain turned the mile track into a quagmire today, causing postponement of the Grand Circuit light-harness horse-racing program.

Herman G. Loew, for many years a New York lawyer and former national chairman of the Single Tax party, died Saturday in the New York Masonic Home at Utica, N. Y., E where he had recently made his home. His age was 81.

If the banks of the United States hope to preserve their place in the national scene they must "cease frightening potential borrowers away" and seek new lending business on terms--which are suitable to the needs of business men, Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, told all directors and managing officers of State and national banks in a circular letter today.

Shareholders of R. Hoe Co., Inc., have been called to a special meeting on Aug. 17 to consider a proposal to ?? the business of the British subsidiary to R. W. Crabtree Sons, Ltd., for approximately $2,280,000.

The receivers of the Seaboard Air Line Railway applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to finance the purchase of nine Diesel-electric locomotives from the Electro-Motive Company, a subsidiary of the General Motors Corporation, for a total price of $1,675,875. The locomotives will be used

After the arrest of two men charged with selling pistols to detectives posing as gangsters, it was revealed yesterday by Commissioner Valentine that the police had been conducting a confidential check-up on the sources through which gunmen have been obtaining their weapons.

Vincent Astor of New York has arrived for a stay at his St. George's home, Ferry Reach. Sir Reginald Hildyard, Governor of Bermuda, Lady Hildyard and their son, R. J. Hildyard, have joined him. They will be at Ferry Reach for a month.

A drop of almost 1,000,000 barrels in the amount of fermented malt liquors produced in June, compared with the same month last year, was reported today by the Alcohol Tax Unit. Production in June was 5,503,839 barrels, compared with 6,444,534 in June, 1937.

With the exception of a stoning incident at Haifa, in which two Jews were slightly wounded, the situation today in all urban communities of Palestine was relatively normal. People are once again venturing into the streets and all shops are now reopened.
The Constitutional Convention tonight informally put its stamp of approval on the free transportation by the State of parochial school pupils from their homes to the schools and back again.

The Title Guarantee and Trust Company of New York reported for June 30 total deposits of $17,234,323 and total resources of $39,455,014, compared, respectively, with $18,462,375 and $42,165,697 on Dec. 31 last. Cash on hand and due from
A committee of shipping men seeking abatement of unnecessary noises on the bays and rivers of the port has been formed as a result of an appeal from Mayor La Guardia.

President Roosevelt tried out his luck as the nation's first fisherman today and was rewarded with a thirty-eight-pound yellowtail. The big fish nipped at his bait in Magdalena Bay, near the tip of Lower California, where the Houston dropped anchor this forenoon.

Mrs. John F. Ducey of New York and Boston entertained with a large dinner party for the younger set at Skyview in Northeast Harbor, in honor of Miss Mary Ryerson of Chicago, before the weekly dance at the Kimball House tonight.

Under a powerful ride by Nick Wall, who is having one of the best seasons of his career, Gustave Ring's Lady Maryland got up in the stretch to take the featured Oakhill Handicap for Class C sprinters at Empire City yesterday.
Matt Kowal assistant pro at the Philmont Country Club, posted two 1-under par 71s today to lead at the halfway mark in the Philadelphia open golf tourney.

E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. stated yesterday in its preliminary statement for the first half of this year that the company earned $1.36 a share on the common stock. In the corresponding six months of last year $3.41 a share was earned.

A noticeable easing in "sales resistance" on the part of retail store buyers, as contrasted with the hesitancy which started to develop last year at this time, was named by corset manufacturers as an outstanding trait of activity when Fall Corset Week opened yesterday.

Four times winner of the Pennsylvania State junior tennis championship, Isadore Bellis of the University of Pennsylvania entered the third round today in quest of his fifth title, defeating Bert Silberstein of Philadelphia, 6--0, 6-3. Tom Kruger of Santa Barbara, Calif., reached the second round by halting John Dwight of Reading, 6--1. 6-3.

Miss Catherine McNelis, who once was rated as one of America's ten leading business women; her brother, John P. McNelis, who was affiliated with her in the management of Tower Magazines, Inc., which she headed, and two other officers of that corporation pleaded not guilty yesterday to indictments charging them with mail fraud.
Four New York City wrestlers, returning by automobile from bouts in Atlantic City, were injured tonight when their car left the road on a curve of Route 39, six miles north of Hammonton.

The third year of the Spanish civil war dawned today with Valencia in great peril, a peril which, however, is not immediate, since the Rebels are still far distant, but which is none the less real for the coming days.

Debits to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended July 13, aggregated $7,700,000,000, or 6 per cent below the total reported for the preceding week, which had only five business days, and 13 per cent below the total for the corresponding week of last year.

Four hundred and fifty persons, 1 most of them members of the backto-work movement, returned to their jobs at the Maytag Washing Machine Company here today as production started for the first time since May 9, when C. I. O. union men went out on strike in protest against a 10 per cent wage reduction.

Stocks rallied and closed active and strong, with leading shares up 1 to 3 points; turnover, 1,557,330 shares. United States Government bonds easier and dull, corporation issues higher, foreign loans firm and mixed transactions, $6,166,900.
The board of directors of the Hearn Department Stores voted to declare the regular quarterly dividend of 75 cents on the preferred stock. It is payable Aug. 1 to stockholders of record July 28.

The employs representation plan, which the National Labor Relations Board held was company-financed and company-dominated and illegal under the National Labor Relations Act, and which the Board ordered disestablished, cost the Republic Steel Corporation $392,120 between June, 1933, and April, 1937, according to testimony today before the Senate Civil Liberties Committee.

GOVERNORS ISLAND Ordered to Camp Dix, N. J. Each of the following Reserve Officers, effective July 24: 2d Lt. Edward J. McCormick Jr., Inf.-Res., 96 Gordon St., Perth Amboy, N. J. 2d Lt. Irwin Mend, Inf.-Res., 654 Lyons Ave., Irvington, N. J. 2d Lt. Bernhard W. Maute, Inf.-Res., 2,177 Edwin Ave., Fort Lee, N. J. 2d Lt. Clarence M. Morfit Jr., Inf.-Res., Harrison Ave., Old Bridge, N. J.
The Trane Company reported yesterday that its backlog of unfilled o orders has increased from $695,313 on Dec. 31, 1937, to $852,416 on June 30, 1938, an increase of $157,103.

The involved suit for damages against William R. Davis of New York, who recently completed a deal for supplying to the German Government a large quantity of Mexican oil, appears likely to be so drawn out that the New York oil operator today was excused from attending further sessions of the trial.
Mayor La Guardia, seated in the cab of a steam shovel at Dwight Street and Visitation Place, Brooklyn, at noon yesterday, jerked a lever and a scoop of dirt poured into a truck.
Miss Elizabeth Banks, American newspaper woman and author, most of hose career was in England,-died today in the Surrey County Hospital at the age of 68.
Freight-carrying motor trucks in Pennsylvania, New Jersey, Delaware, Maryland and New York have operated at a loss of $1,321,447 since 1936, the Interstate Commerce Commission was told today.
Claude Atlan Launoy, also Eugene A. Darling, in 277 Park Ave; Sidney R. Geist, in 1,230 Park Ave; Brown,.Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc, brokers.
The Japanese navy in a colorfullyworded communique announced that its air arm scored two daring victories yesterday over the Chinese.

Crown Prince Gustaf Adolf, touring the Twin Cities, leaped out of his motor car today and hurried half a block afoot when a motor cycle policeman, part of his escort, was thrown from his machine while the party was traveling forty miles an hour.

Douglas Corrigan's flight from New York to Dublin did not startle Harman Edwards, a 24year-old employee of the Consolidated Aircraft Corporation of San Diego, Calif., who helped the transatlantic flier install the motor and resurface the wings on his Curtiss-Robin plane.

Wholesalers serving agricultural districts have experienced a sharp upturn in sales in the last few weeks, and their orders for dry goods in the primary market here have been accompanied by requests for rush shipments, resident office executives reported yesterday.

The marriage of Miss Helen Wallace Palmer, daughter of Professor and Mrs. Frederick Palmer of Haverford, Pa., to Dr. William Hinckley Avery took place here this afternoon in the Palmer cottage on Gull Pond. The ceremony was

Miss son, Marie LeMoyne Noyes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. DeWitt Clinton Noyes of New York and Sharon, and Andrew Douglas Hall, son of Mr. and Mrs. Emlen Trenchard Hall of wer Mantoloking, N. J., and Summerville, S. C., will be married at St. Bernard's Church here on July 30.

Hester St, 183-5, 42.1x99.8; Marmear Realty Corp to the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank, p m mtg, demand, int as per bond; $22,375. Same property, same to same, building loan, pr mtg, $22,375, demand, int per bond, $3,000.

HE Giants and Pirates were battling away, With the National League lead at stake. With a four-hit decision over the Bees, J. Herman Dean ceased being Dismal Dean and became 01' Dizz again. The Cleveland Indians were advancing on the Yankee Stadium to keep an important engagement. Two tall, tanned fellows walked in and began arguing about men on horses.
If Douglas G. Corrigan is to be punished for failure to observe laws and regulations in his unheralded flight to Irelan'd, it appeared here today his chastisement would be extremely light.

IT was raining that morning, as usual, outside the Hotel Liberty in Jacksonburg, Ishmaelia. Inside, too, more or less, for the hotel's tin roof leaked The newspaper correspondents had been awake since dawn.--Boot of The London Beast,. Corker of The Universal News, Pappenhacker of The Daily Twopence, Shumble, Whelper Pigge and the Frenchmen. They hadn't been able to sleep,

Mr. and Mrs. Sydnor Barksdale Penick of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Henry Penick, to Philip Everngam Nuttle of Glen Ridge, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank L. R. Nuttle of Denton, Md.
Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Milton J. Raisbeck of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Joan Marcelle Raisbeck, to Hector A. Escobosa, of Kansas City.

Protests by Catholic laymen against the Boston showing of "Blockade," the motion picture about Spain, scheduled to open at Loew's State and Orpheum Theatres Thursday, was followed today by the unanimous passage of an order by the Boston City Council asking Mayor Tobin to ban it.

Joe McCluskey of the New York A. C., veteran steeplechase champion, yesterday announced his withdrawal from the American track and field team, which is scheduled F to depart for Germany a week from today. His place will be taken by an alternate, either Tommy Deckard or George DeGeorge.

ANDERSON-On July 18, 1938, Maybelle E., of 26 Fremont Ave.. Grant City, S. I., beloved. wife of Nils E. Anderson and devoted mother of Francis Anderson; survived also by two brothers, Walter H. and Earl F. Albert. Services at her home on Wednesday, July 20, at 3 P. M. Interment Valhalla, on Staten Island.
Magistrate Jenkin R. Hockert of Jamaica Estates was named candidate for District Attorney on a primary slate chosen last night by the Queens County Republican executive committee.

Optimistic over Fall prospects after a period of declining unit sales, wall paper manufacturers, wholesalers, dealers and decorators gathered yesterday at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria for the 1938 wall paper style show and preview of 1939 wall papers, sponsored by the Wall Paper Institute.

Despondent at their inability to find work so that they could get married, George Scherer, 30 years old, and Mrs. Mary Hughes, 29, killed themselves yesterday by inhaling illuminating gas in a furnished room at 104 West Eightyfourth Street.
The Vacation House at Stockbridge, Mass., of the New York Exchange for Woman's Work was the beneficiary of a supper dance given last night at the Versailles.

Politics is playing an important part in the matter of relief in this railroad city. With thousands of men out of work since late last year, payments have about ceased from the unemployment compensation fund for all Pennsylvania Railroad shopmen.

Segregation of broker-dealer functions on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange held the spotlight yesterday at a meeting of a "round table" attended by William 0. Douglas, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission; John W. Hanes and members of the commission's staff.

Representatives of Class I railroads and offi- i cials of the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen, meeting today in volun- t tary negotiations to discuss the t joint demand of the nation's carriers for a 15 per cent wage reduction affecting 900,000 workers, re- i mained deadlocked.

One point, reliable as the North Star, stands fixed among the fluctuating currents of European policy, and it is this point of stability that is stressed and sealed by the visit to France of the King and Queen of England. The pageantry Paris puts on to

In the course of a debate over a credit of 170,000,000 leva for the purchase of seventy-nine vessels for the Bulgarian Danube fleet, Deputy M. K. Stoyanoff demanded that the government should secure Bulgaria's independence from Germany. The Reich, he said, dictated
Grey Gold came from far back today to catch Mower, favorite from the Millsdale Stable, for a head decision in the feature at Arlington Park. C. E. Davison's Chance Ray was third.

The twelfth successive day of maximum temperatures of 80 degrees or above caused one heat prostration in the city yesterday. The high was 86 degrees at 5 P. M. and the low 71 at 6:50 A. M. The average, 78 degrees, was 4 above normal.

The Rev. John van Burk, a Congregational minister for more than twenty years and a former leader in the Young Men's Christian Association, died yesterday morning in 'Housatonic, Mass., after a long illness at the age of 74.

Contributing a cool, summery note to the stagnant air of Mayor La Guardia's Summer City Hall, Police Captain James Harten and Patrolman Edward Vitale of the Mayor's staff bloomed forth yesterday in crisp white gabardine suits, white shirts, white shoes and white ties.

George D. Hess Jr., 19 years old, was shot and seriously wounded late last night by one of three thugs who held up his father's candy store at 3,440 Fulton Street, Brooklyn. According to neighbors, Hess was alone in the store, which is underneath the apartment in which he and his family live.

Showing a flash of the golf that carried him to the Professional Golfers Association semifinals last week, Jimmy Hines tore par apart today at the Rockville Country Club to win with Frank Strafaci the amateur-pro championship of the Long Island Golf Association with a best-ball card of 66.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are July 18 unless specified: At Chefoo: Finch, July 16; Augusta, Alden, Barker, J. D. Edwards, Whipple. San Francisco to Portland: Arctic, Perry, Zane. At Hong Kong: Sacramento, July 17; Blackhawk.

Another chapter in the long-drawnout $9,535,261 William Fox bankruptcy case was started here with the filing of a $500,000 cash offer by Mrs. Fox and their two daughters to settle a part of the litigation.
Reinhold Wulle, publicist and Nationalist who hid Adolf Hitler for weeks in 1923, has been arrested with his wife and several members of his publication staff, it was disclosed today.

With an initial attendance of 450 buyers, an increase of 8 to 10 per cent over last year, the New York Lamp Show opened yesterday at the Hotel New Yorker. A total of 175 manufacturers displayed their lines for the coming season.

Feeling a bit jaded after their strenuous efforts in yesterday's tempestuous double-header, the Giants today were forced to beat a rather embarrassing retreat as the Pirates sent them tumbling to a 7-to-4 defeat in the series final.

Arthur A. Ballantine, trustee of th the Continental Securities Corporation in reorganization proceedings, obtained permission yesterday from Federal Judge Patterson to examine eighteen former directors of the corporation and more than 100 officers, directors and employes of other organizations concerning an alleged depletion of assets suffered by Continental since Oct. 25 last.

The Boerse opened the week with one of the worst slumps in its records. Sales pressuree was much increased and here were few buyers. All the principall issues lost heavily, declines reaching 9 per cent.

Joe Fishbach, 18-year-old St. John's University sophomore, started the defense of his Eastern junior tennis championship and battled his way through three rounds to arrive at the quarter-finals at the West Side Club in Forest Hills yesterday.

Governor Lehman, in a special message read to the Constitutional Convention tonight, announced his unequivocal opposition to the Feinberg proposal which would bar, for the next twenty years, the diversion of gasoline tax revenues from highway purposes into the State's general fund.

Barnet Hodes, Chicago's corporation counsel, predicted today that New York City, Philadelphia and Chicago may "be forced to break away from the States and petition to be established themselves as States." Mr. Hodes addressed the Institute of Municipal Law Officers, holding its midyear meeting.

The Rev. Dr. Lemuel Call Barnes, retired Baptist clergyman and former secretary of the Department of English Speaking Missions and Indian Work of the American Baptist Home Mission Society, died today at St. John's Riverside Hospital here after a short illness.

Commander Charles E. Rosendahl, commandant of the Naval Air Station at Lakehurst, declared upon his return from Germany yesterday that he still favored distribution of American helium gas to foreign nations building lighter-than-air craft.

Trading opened very slow, both in the local wholesale markets and slaughter houses yesterday. The entire beef market was steady, veal weak to lower, lamb weak to slightly lower, fresh pork cuts slightly uneven. Early trading in kosher meats indicated lamb to be higher and other classes steady. Conditions as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated July 15: LIEUTENANTS Schaede, F. B., orders of Feb. 5 modified: to VP-8 instead of VP-18. Martin, H. V., Civil Engineer Corps, St. Thomas, V. I., about Sept. 1 to 11th Naval District, San Diego, Calif. Malpass, B. L., Med. Corps, to Naval training Station. San Diego, Calif.

The Treasury bill rate shot upward again this week, the average interest rate for $100,000,000 of ninety-one-day bills sold today reaching 0.054 per cent, compared with 0.038 per cent for the issue sold a week ago, the Treasury announced tonight.
The Canadian Legation at Washington will take up the seizure of eight Canadian cows on the northern boundary of Maine by United States customs officers.

Lefty Raffensberger, rookie southpaw ace of the Red Wings, ended the domination of Newark over his club tonight with a six-hit shut-out. Raffensberger became the fifth pitcher to blank the Bears this season and his 4-to-O conquest ended a string of six consecutive losses by Rochester to Newark.

Wheat prices held within a range of about 1 cent a bushel today in light trading. An advance of 1/2 to 3/4 cent at the opening on the Board of Trade here was followed by a recession which carried all deliveries except the September to a new low price on the current downturn.

Miss Dorothy Suzanne Behrens, whose parents, Mr. and Mrs. John Behrens of Weehawken, have a Summer home here, was married at noon today to Herbert B. Davison, son of C. Herbert Davison of Princeton and the late Mrs. Maude Outcalt Davison.
Mayor La Guardia was among more than 3,000 persons who sat through the rain last night on the Mall in Central Park listening to a concert being given by the Goldman Band.

Two days before the eleventh an niversary of the death of her husband, King Ferdinand, the Dowager Queen Marie died /at 5:38 P. M today in the royal castle at Sinaia where her husband also died. She was 62 years old.

Pensioned ON POLICE SURGEON'S CERTIFICATE: To take effect 12 Noon, July 16: PATROLMAN-Louis Gommenginger, 103d Precinct, at $1,032 per annum. Appointed Dec. 2, 1924. Temporary Assignments SERGEANT-Charles T. Fischer, from 106th Precinct to 18th Division, duty in District Attorney's office, Queens County, for 1 day, from 4 P. M., July 13.
A new delay in the Chaco peace negotiations arose today when the Paraguayan delegation made certain reservations to the proposed treaty as initialled here previously.

Douglas G. Corrigan, ocean-hopping Los Angeles aviator, has wanted to be an airline pilot for more than au year-and now he may get his wish. His application for a co-pilot's position has been on file with American Airlines since 1937, it was disclosed here today.

Peggy Wood, American actress and widow of- John V. A. Weaver, poet and writer who died on June 15 at Colorado Springs, arrived yesterday from London on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary to carry out her husband's wish expressed in his poem, "When I'm Through."

Douglas G. Corrigan, 31-year-old daredevil who flew the Atlantic on a whim, "just doesn't know what fear is." Such was the comment today of his uncle, the Rev. Fraser Langford, pastor of the First Baptist Church of Santa Monica, when informed of the aviator's amazing "dead reckoning" flight over Atlantic waters in an antiquated airplane.

A new plan for the reorganization of the Utilities Power and Light Corporation which provides for payment in cash of all claims ranking above the outstanding debentures and also for pro rata cash payments for accrued and unpaid interest on debentures and other claims of the same parity, has been filed with Securities and Exchange Commission by the Atlas Corporation, the commission announced today.

The number of commercial and industrial failures in the United States for the week ended July 14, was 219, which compares with 187 for the preceding week, which had five days, and 152 for the same period a year ago, according to figures released yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

The three-story main factory building and the two-story annex, formerly occupied by the Russell Playing Card Company, on Washington Avenue, Milltown, N. J., has been leased by J. I. Kislak, Inc., to Metalfield, Inc., metal goods manufacturers.

FRUIT IN SEASON, by Anthony Thorne (Random House, $2.50). A novel about an old English manors house and its owners. OLD MOTLEY, by Audrey Lucas (Macmillan, $2.50). A novel with an early nineteenth-century London background.

Steel -production is scheduled at 36.4 per cent of capacity this week, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute, a gain of 4.1 points, or 12.7 per cent, over last week. It is the second consecutive weekly advance from 22.4 per cent recorded for the week of July 4, a gain of 62.5 per cent for the two weeks.

Andy Kerr, who will coach the AllStars for their charity game against the New York Football Giants at the Polo Grounds on Sept. 7, today announced that Merrill N. Davis Jr. and Warren C. King, both of Dartmouth, have accepted invitations to join the squad.

As much as anything else, the news at midday yesterday of a further sharp increase in steel production schedules rallied a hesitant stock market and brought the list to a strong and active closing. Leading stocks finished with net gains of 1 to 3 points, or the best advance since last Tuesday, and the highest closing level since October. The day's turnover
The C. M. T. C. regiment participated in the "Organization Day" exercises of the Twenty-sixth Infantry here today.

Charles F. Noyes, founder and chairman of the board of the realty concern of Charles F. Noyes Company, Inc., who last March turned control of the company over to his employes, will be 60 years old today.

The Earl of Portsmouth has left the Madison for Big Horn, Wyo., to visit his son and daughter-inlaw, the Hon. Oliver M. Wallop and Mrs. Wallop. Mrs. George Wadsworth, wife of the United States Consul General in Jerusalem, has left the Plaza to visit her mother, Mrs. Norman E. Mack, in Buffalo.

Denouncing heirs of large fortunes who dissipate their heritage in "jumping from one matrimonial venture to another," Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo yesterday awarded Mrs. Martha Barkley Ryan a separation from Basil Allen Ryan, grandson of Thomas Fortune Ryan, fixing alimony at $833 a month and counsel fees at $7.500.

Twenty-five tables have been taken thus B far for the bridge party to be given at the home of Mrs. Walter Belknap James on Wednesday afternoon in aid of the American Merchant Ma- C rine Library Association. Mrs. B LeBrun Rhinelander is chairman.

Tenants who have been forced to vacate condemned buildings in the path of three Brooklyn highway improvements leading to the World's Fair, who have had trouble finding other low-rent dwellings, will have another week to find new quarters,

Major John E. Borden, owner and principal of the Mohegan Lake Military Academy near here, died suddenly at the academy today of a heart attack. His age was 50. Born in Lowell, Mass., Major Borden received his education at St. Dunstan's Academy, Prince Edward Island, and McGill University, Montreal.

At the opening ceremony of the fifteenth International Geographical Congress here today honorary memberships in the Royal Dutch Geographical Society were conferred on Professor Elmer Drew Merrill of Harvard for his work in botanical geography and on Professor Carl Otwin Sauer of Berkeley, Calif., for research in physical and social geography.

Al Reid, 126, the Bronx, outpointed Nat Litfin, 125, also of the Bronx, in the feature eight-rounder before 4,000 persons at Dyckman Oval in the rain last night. Because of the weather the main event was put on after the first bout and thee remainder of the card could not be completed.
Douglas Corrigan landed his now-famous crate" at Norfolk's city airport last Winter with the cool assertion that "one of these days I'm going to fly this thing across the Atlantic."

Douglas Gorce Corrigan,. 31-year-old Californian, added a unique chapter in the history of lone Atlantic fliers today when he completed a trip from New York to Baldonnel Airfield, Dublin, in his 9-year-old Curtiss Robin plane in 28 hours 13 minutes.

Cottongrowing experiments by Italians in Abyssinia have been successful and Italy will no longer have to import cotton from abroad, according to a report from Cairo made public today by the Department of Commerce.

With the Larchmont Yacht Club's fortieth annual Race Week series resumed today, a south-southwest breeze to start with fluffed away and left half the fleet of 323 craft floundering. Some did not finish until dark.

Percy L. Kynaston of Brooklyn, a leading tournament campaigner a dozen-years. ago, stole the spotlight in the Eastern clay court championship at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club yesterday by his unexpected elimination of J. Gilbert Hall, top ranking, Eastern player.

Four cars of a lightly loaded, six-car northbound local train on the. Sixth Avenue Elevated were derailed at 5:25 o'clock last night just north of the Rector Street station, above Trinity Place, when the rear truck of the second car apparently split a switch.

A notice to the 20,000 EndicottJohnson shoe workers posted today said: "It is a real pleasure for the management to notify the workers and their friends that there is a decided improvement in our orders. Some of the factories will feel it more than others, but all will feel itspeaking broadly."
Japanese beetles, Public Enemy No. 1 for gardeners, have invaded Times Square this Summer for the first time within the memory of those who inhabit the asphalt desert. The bronze-green pests that

Mayor Frank Hague sent a telegram of protest today to the Interstate Commerce Commission requesting it to suspend the fare rise to 8 cents on the Hudson and Manhattan tubes for thirty days. Similar telegrams were sent by Representatives Mary T. Norton and Edward Hart.

Packy and Danny Paul, the Richdale, Alta., brothers who campaigned with success in Europe, were defeated tonight in preliminary bouts to a feature boxing match which saw Orville Drouillard of Windsor, Ont., take a ten-round decision over Phil Zwick of Milwaukee.

John Andosca, known as "Papa John" and described as an important figure in the taxicab racket which stemmed from Charles (Lucky Luciano) Lucanla, was arraigned yesterday as one of ten named in a new indictment obtained by District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey's office.

" Mussolini's Roman Empire," by Geoffrey T. Garratt, which will be published by Bobbs-Merrill on Aug. 8, went through three editions in eikht weeks in the Penguin edition in England, where its sales now exceed 150,000 copies.

Assemblyman Carl Pack, who has represented the Third Assembly District in the Bronx since 1931, has been, designated by the Bronx Democratic County Committee to run for State Senator from the Twenty-second Senatorial District, it was announced yesterday. He replaces Senator Julius S. Berg, who resigned.

Dr. George M. Falion, director of Townsend Harris High School, Twenty-third Street and Lexington Avenue, since 1929, died yesterday in his apartment at the Hotel Towers, Brooklyn, after an illness of two months. He was 56 years old.
Turkish-Syrian negotiations for a treaty of friendship and "goodneighbor relations" have been interrupted and postponed till September for reasons that can be revealed now for the first time.
Announcements of the "Committee of 430," the rebels of organized medicine, that they will set up an independent group to fight for less costly medical care, were in the mails today.

Sam Fishman sold two pounds of tomatoes for 15 cents at 6:30 yesterday morning, starting a business day that the new Paddy's Market hailed as sensationally successful when it was time to cover the tilted carts thirteen and one-half hours later.
Within the next twenty-four hours issue should be joined in the Constitutional Con- the vention on the closely contested subject of reapportionment of legislative and Congressional districts.

Dr. Arthur E. Morgan, deposed by President Roosevelt as member and chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority this year, testified before the Congressional investigating committee today that many of the policies for which his fellow-directors on the TVA board are now criticizing him were the ideas of President Roosevelt, expressed to him in the early days of TVA or before it came into existence.

Due to the great interest shown in the bout between Al Davis and Bernie (Schoolboy) Friedkin scheduled for Dexter Park which was rained out again last night, it will be staged at Madison Square Garden on Thursday night under the promotion of Mike Jacobs.
Senator Wagner, minority leader in the Constitutional Convention, appealed to the 'delegates tonight to pass the antiracial discrimination proposal reported by the committee on the bill of rights.

Commonwealth President Manuel L. Quezon said today in a broadcast to America that Japanese statesmen seemed unanimous in their sympathy with the idea of neutralizing the Philippines when the islands receive their independence, presumably in 1946.

Driving home the Nazi principle that the private individual counts for nothing; the state for everything, the government today published a de aid of the country's armed forces upon all citizens as a preparedness measure in the event of war.

As the site for two apartment houses, a builder has purchased from the Schulte Real Estate Company two plots, each 150 by 100 feet, on the east side of Cruger Avenue and the west side of. Holland Avenue, 100 feet south of Lydig Avenue, in the Bronx. Jerome Eisner

Miss Jane Allen, daughter of Mrs. Freeman Clarke Allen of this city and the late Mr. Allen, was married here to Robert Ayres Messler 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin E. Messler of Montclair, N. J., this afternoon in St. Paul's Episcopal Church.
The text of Governor Lehman's message on diversion of gasoline taxes, read at the session of the Constitutional Convention tonight, follows:

Mr. Douglas Corrigan certainly is an irrepressible young man. Refused a sanction last year to fly the North Atlantic, he secures an X, or experimental, license for his nine-year-old fabric-covered Robin and calmly flies non-stop from Los Angeles to Roosevelt Field. Then, while the tumult and

After breaking below. 8 1/2 cents a pound for October at one time yesterday prices n the New York Cotton Exchan e recovered the entire loss, in sympathy with a strong stock market, and ended with net gains of 2 to 4 points.

What is commonly referred to in baseball as a "crucial" series will get under way today at the Stadium, where the Yankees will meet the second-place Indians in the first of a four-game set. Single contests are on tap for this afternoon and Thursday, while tomorrow the teams will engage in a twin bill that is likely to attract 50,000 fans.

The German press features the transatlantic flight of Douglas G. Corrigan as the senseless escapade of a foolhardy youth. Corrigan's first statement that he might fly back to California is printed. The Lokalanzeiger states

Progress toward settlements of the disputes which led to two sitdown strikes in Edgewater, N. J., last week was reported yesterday. Several hundred sit-down strikers vacated the plant of the National Sugar Refining Company soon after the management announced that it was ready to resume negotiations for a new contract.

The concert of the PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra last niht in Lewisohn Stadium, at which Massimo Freccia made his second appearance as conductor, was cut short by rain. When Mr. Freccia and his men had reached the second movement of Dvorak's "New World" symphony, the first number on the list, the downpour began.

The Constitutional Convention tonight adopted a compromise proposal on the costs of grade-crossing elimination work, after the Associated Railroads of the State had pledged themselves to go to work under that compro-' mise, and the Long Island Railroad in particular had promised to complete as rapidly as possible the Atlantic Avenue elimination in Brooklyn and to end other crossings in Queens and Long Island.

Saldted by booming guns at Dover and escorted into the English Channel by an imposing fleet of warships, King George and Queen Elizabeth will leave tomorrow morning on their long-heralded state visit to the President of the French Republic. This is the first state visit abroad of the British sovereigns.

Thomas Worth Olcott, former secretary and treasurer of the Union Railway Company of New York, operating street cars in Westchester County and the Bronx as a part of the Third Avenue Railway System, died here last night in his home at the age of 82. He retired about twenty-five years ago.

The Constitutional Convention today advanced to third reading the anti-racial discrimination proposal. In doing so by a overwhelming vote it rejected an appeal by William J. Wallin, vice chancellor of the Board of Regents of the University of the State of New York and Republican delegate from Yonkers, for a continuance of the right of individuals to exercise prejudices which Mr. Wallin termed "God-given."
The Constitutional Convention, holding the first of a series of special night sessions, became involved tonight in the intricate question of public utility rates.

Fresh from Shawnee, where he just missed playing Paul Runyan in the final round of the P. G. A. tournament, Jimmy Hines, sturdy Lakeville pro, today had to take a back seat, temporarily at least, in the first round of the Long Island open championship at the Rockville Country Club.

About 22,000,000 less proof gallons of ethyl alcohol was produced in the fiscal year ending June 30 than in the preceding fiscal year, the Alcohol Tax Unit announced today. The comparative figures were 201,033,857 for 1938 and 223,181,228 for 1937.

The New York Stock Exchange has admitted to the list 50.000 additional shoe's of Sears, Roebuck . Co. capital stock, no par value. United Stockyards Corporation fifteen-year collateral trust 4 1/4 per cent bonds due in 1951, with common stock purchase warrants attached, .and convertible 70-cent cumulative preferred stock, no par value, will be admitted to the list today.

Operations in the steel industry increased more than seasonally last week and the adjusted index spurted almost ten points to 47.7, falling less than one point short of the year's high. The figure was 37.8 for the preceding week and 124.6 for the week ended July 17, 1937.

A "story spot" marker designed to be posted on poles a mile apart from St. Joseph, Mo., to Sacramento, Calif., to show future highway travelers they are traveling on or close to the trail of the old Pony Express riders, was shown yesterday at a meeting of members of the Oregon Trail Memorial Association at the Bankers Club, 120 Broadway.

The First Congregational Church in Old Greenwich was the setting this evening for the marriage of Miss Verna Mae Timinins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry L. Timmins of Milbrook, Greenwich, to Donald Teague, son of Edwin Teague of New Rochelle, N. Y., and the late Mrs. Teague. The Rev. Alden S.

Cincinnati swept a double-header with Boston today, taking the first game, 3 to 1, behind the two-hit hurling of' young Whitey Moore, and the second, 7 to 2, with the aid of a trio of fourth-inning homers and a single and double, good for six runs.

Eldress Anna Case, who had been responsible for the affairs of the Shaker colony in the town of Colonie for twenty-six years, died yesterday at the age of 83. She had been a member of the settlement for more than seventy years. Her death leaves the responsibilities of the large farm on the shoulders of three aged women --Sisters Frieda Sipple, Grace and Mary F. Daum.. The colony has been in existence for 162 years.

Two winning streaks clashed here today and the seven-game string boasted by the Cubs was demolished by the Dodgers, who have no respect for any club when on the road. They beat the Bruins soundly, 8-3, and ran their own victory string to five, tops for them this season.

Representatives of trainmen and railroad executives continued deadlocked today on the companies' 15 per cent wage cut proposal. After a meeting lasting from' 10 A. M. until 12:55 P. M. spokesmen for both groups declared they would not budge from their respective stands.

Buyer attendance at corset showrooms was rather light yesterday morning, because many store representatives in town for the Fall market week attended the Warner Brothers Company fashion show held at the Hotel Astor.

The War Department appointed Brig. Gen. Barton Kyle Yount today as assistant chief of the Army Air Corps for a four-year term. General Yount, a native of Troy, Ohio, was recently wing commander of the Eighteenth Composite Wing in Hawaii.

219th St, 839 E, 25x114.4; Ida Maurer against Antonio Scafuta, due, $6,418; to plaintiff for $500. By JAMES R. MURPHY Webster Ave, 2,989, 1-story store, 25x120.11; Wm. J. P. Griffin, trustee, against R. N. Quinn Realty Corp, due; $6,726, taxes, etc, $1,600; to plaintiff for $1,000.

A baseball game between the Adventurers Club of New York and the Circus Saints and Sinners Club at Frank Buck's Jungle Camp, Amityville, L. I., will be witnessed today by 450 underprivileged boys of New York City, who will enjoy a day's outing at the camp as guests of the Adventurers Club, according to an announcement yesterday.

Captain Alexander Papana of the Rumanian Royal Air Force escaped uninjured this afternoon when his specially built twin-engined monoplane, in which he hoped to span the Atlantic, crashed into a stone wall' skirting a private airport here.

The ups and downs of the Dodgers almost became the aubject of judicial review yesterday in Flatbush Court, Brooklyn. Joseph Epstein, 24 years old, of 24 Attorney Street, Manhattan, was before Magistrate Matthew J. Troy on a charge made by Plainclothes Patrolman Sidney Kaminsky,

Shipping men in New York are awaiting with interest the opening of bids in Washington today for the purchase or charter of ten freighters of the American Republics Line and the three former Panama Pacific liners California, Virginia and Pennsylvania.
There was another victory at Empire City yesterday for the Carolina-trained representatives of Clarence and Merritt Buxton, the horse trainers who formerly were first-flight jockeys.
Harry Balsamo, the slugging brakeman from Harlem, will oppose Mario Caroselli of Italy in the feature eight-round bout at the Queensboro Arena in Long Island City tonight.

Four out of every five doctors in this country have already notified the government what services they are willing to render in the event of war, it was announced today at a meeting of the British Medical Association at Plymouth.

In sympathy with a strong stock market and an advance in foreign quotations, prices on the Cotton Exchange improved 8 to 9 points yesterday. Tension in the European political situation not only halted selling but stimulated foreign buying.

Although New York City still possesses the largest school system in the world, the upward trend has been checked and now there has begun a shrinking of the huge educational plant, Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, disclosed yesterday in the statistical section of his thirty-ninth annual report.
John M. Schaack, a member of the Chicago Board of Trade since 1897, died today in the Edgewater Beach Hotel, where he had lived for years. He was 67 years old.

Despite a day of freakish doings overhead, 296 craft were out today for the Race Week competition of the Larchmont- Yacht Club, and while many gave up the ghost after hopeless druifts, most of them came through.
At a meeting of the Republican State Committee here this afternoon the office of secretary, held for many years by Clarence G. Willard of New Haven, was declared vacant at Mr. Willard's suggestion.
King George and Queen Elizabeth of Britain were welcomed by France today with a warmth rivaling that accorded them by their own subjects on the day of their enthronement.

Prince Alexis Davidoff, 35 years old, son of Princess Marie Obolensky, a relative of the former Russian Imperial family, was discharged by Magistrate Brough in the Homicidp Court yesterday when the court was informed the grand jury had dismissed the charge against him in the automobile death of Mrs. Margaret Abrams, 22 years old, on April 26.

Howard R. Hughes, who returned last Thursday from his record flight around the world, and his crew of four remained in seclusion all day yesterday. Their next public appearance will be at a dinner in their honor tonight by the officials of the New York World's Fair to be held at the fair grounds in the Flushing Meadows.

More than twenty policemen were rushed to the Kingston Avenue Contagious Hospital, adjoining Kings County Hospital in Brooklyn, at 7:30 o'clock last night after many of the 200 women confined in a building for venereal diseases went wild in a panic of shouting and screaming. Order was. restored within an hour.

The buying enthusiasm that characterized the stock market in the first two weeks of the present bull market that began on June 20 returned yesterday. Leading stocks were bid up 1 to 3 points and more to new highs for the year and transactions on the Stock Exchange reached 2,942,000 shares, the largest turnover since Oct. 21. Stocks were strong from the start and closing quotations were at or near the day's best levels.

Mrs. Eugenia Reithler Gorski, who, with her husband, Stanislaus Gorski, was active in many literary and professional movements in France, died in her home here yesterday. She was in her seventy-ninth year.
Ivan Billiard a Canal Zone customs officer, dived into Panama Bay today to seize a bottle of cocaine for evidence in an arrest he was making with Charles Martin, a customs guard.

That Canada has in Boris Blumin of Montreal a chess player worthy of the Dominion championship was again shown when he succeeded in defeating I. A. Horowitz of New York in the open championship of the American Chess Federation at Boston.

An olive branch from Germany in the form of a personal message from Chancellor Adolf Hitler was delivered to Viscount Halifax, the Foreign Secretary, on the eve of King George's departure for Paris, it became known today.

Although Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels is vacationing unofficially this week in the Alpine provinces triumphal receptions await him wherever he appears. In the smallest villages inhabitants gather to see Great Germany's little Propaganda Minister.

Two Japanese messengers who were dispatched to a Soviet commander at an unnamed point on the SovietManchukuo border yesterday in order to conduct negotiations for a settlement of the incident at Changkufeng have not yet returned, according to a Domei dispatch from Seoul, Korea.

Plans for a great civic celebration were started today to welcome back to Los Angeles Douglas G. Corrigan. Charles S. Crail Jr., director of the Los Angeles Junior Chamber of Commerce, said he had cabled Corrigan at Dublin to make a date for the welcome.

Ten members of the Second World Youth Congress, an organization denounced as communistic in the City Council recently, got a friendly welcome yesterday from Mayor La Guardia, who received the delegation in his Summer City Hall in the City Building at the World's Fair grounds.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith became the first Democratic delegate today to preside over the Constitutional Convention, sitting as the committee of the whole. His appointment by the convention president, Chief Judge Frederick E. Crane of the Court of Appeals, was greeted by loud applause from both Democrat and Republican delegates.

The British medical profession believed that it had won a notable victory in the acquittal today of Dr. Aleck William Bourne, prominent obstetrician, who had performed an operation to prevent a 15-year-old girl, victim of an assault, from becoming a mother.
Rain curtailed play yesterday the Eastern- clay court championships at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club.

The Commonwealth Edison Company has under consideration plans for refunding about $73,000,000 of its outstanding debt, it became known yesterday. Chicago investment bankers who participated. in the utility's last refunding program a month ago are preparing for the next step.

Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens announced yesterday that he had just signed a five-year lease for the use of the recently completed Queens Community . Center at Queens and Horace Harding Boulevard, Elmhurst, as headquarters for the Seventy-seventh Division, Reserve Corps, United States Army.

A banking group composed of Blyth Co., Inc.; R. H. Moulton Co., and Kaiser Co. has received the award of an issue of $3,656,954 of registered warrants of the State of California. The group paid a premium of $2,934 for the warrants on a 0.75 per cent interest basis. They will mature on or about Nov. 30.
Mrs. Helen Buck, widow of George R. Buck, died yesterday in the home here of her mother, Mrs. Anna M. Dunham, at the age of 53.

Fireman 1st grade Fred J. Supaneic of Engine Co. 13 died July 18. Funeral will take place from Traynor Funeral Parlor, 131 Morningside Ave., Manhattan, at 9:30 A. M., Thursday, July 21. Interment at St. Ravmond's Cemetery.

Three parcels on the southeast corner of Vanderbilt Avenue and Plandome Road, Manhasset, L. I., have been assembled as a building site by Fred A. Weeks Co., Inc., brokers, for the Morlef Holding Company.

Supreme Court Justice Edward J. McGoldrick dismissed yesterday on technical grounds an application by the Flying Eagle Coach Company in behalf of itself and other operators of interstate buses for a. temporary injunction restraining the city from collecting about $85,000 a year in fees from them for the privilege of using the city's streets.

Japanese planes inflicted yesterday on Hankow, Wuchang and Hanyang, the "Wuhan Cities," the most frightful air bombings suffered by them. More than 500 were killed and about 500 were wounded, Chinese leaders estimated.
" To organize the name burned in the clouds by Douglas G. Corrigan," Chicago bearers of it today formed the first chapter of the Honorable Society of Corrigans.

A banking group headed by Brown Harriman Co., Inc., will offer today a new issue of $7,500,000 of Industrial Rayon Corporation firstmortgage 4 1/2 per cent bonds, Series A, maturing on July 1, 1948. The bonds will be priced at 99 and accrued interest.

In a metaphorical sense Mr. Roosevelt is incomparably the best fisherman on land the world has seen. He has a fine collection of flies and is subtly expert in casting them. Often enough he needs no bait. He has only to look at the fish.

Having previously failed in a direct request for the use of an automobile in Bermuda where private cars are forbidden, the Governor has tried a new line of approach, an Assembly committee report disclosed today.

The battle of Paddy's Market is over. The historic Produce Dealers and Merchants Association has hauled down its flag and marched with all the honors of war from its next-to-last line of defense on Ninth Avenue to its new reservation on West Thirty-ninth Street.

Sales billed by the General Electric Company during the first six months of 1938 amounted to $130,910,638, compared with $171,076,645 in the 1937 period, a decrease of 23 per cent, it was announced yesterday by Gerard Swope, president of the company.

The Bituminous Coal Commission started work today on the final stage of determining the cost of producing coal for the purpose of establishing new minimum prices. Statisticians began analyzing the evidence submitted in June at a

The ten-year-old Dowd Municipal Natatorium at East Jersey Street and Staten Island Sound, here, was closed this morning by order of the Board of City Recreation Commissioners following disputes between white and Negro boys at the pool.

Featuring a brilliant double-century by Wally Hammond, Gloucestershire made a remarkable recovery to take first-inning points from Lancashire today, forcing the northern county to surrender second place in the county cricket table to Middlesex.

The Rev. Dr. Paul Rader, evangelist, former pastor of the Dwight L. Moody Memorial Church in Chicago and founder of- the Chicago Gospel Tabernacle, died today in a Hollywood hospital after a long illness. He was 58 years old.

Delegates to the Constitutional Convention got their first glimpse today of the long-awaited proposal of the Committee on Organization of the Legislature providing for a readjustment of Senate and Assembly districts, overdue since 1926, the year following the 1925 State census.
Kimon Nicolaides, artist and instructor at the Art Students League, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street, died Monday night in the Post-Graduate Hospital after an illness of six weeks. His age was 46.

The leading judges and lawyers in the Constitutional Convention, members of the twenty-one-man Judiciary Committee, split wide open today on the extent to which the proposed new State Constitution should attempt to check the growth of administrative law, or "bureaucracy."
Conforming to amendments of the Merchant Marine Act passed by the last Congress, the Maritime Commission has completed plans to establish seamen's training schools on the Atlantic and Pacific coasts.

Trading was very slow on practically all classes of locally dressed meats in the markets yesterday. The cow and lamb markets were lower, other classes were mostly unchanged. Early trading in kosher meats. indicated prices to be steady and demand slow.
Loomis J. Grossman has purchased from Frederick Brown's Cabin Holding Company the sixstory apartment house at 1,720 University Avenue, the Bronx, formerly owned by the Prudential Insurance Company.

Leases of several large apartments by business executives and professional men were reported yesterday. A twenty-room suite was taken by Guido Pantaleoni Jr., lawyer, at 527-41 East Seventy-second Street, where a group of buildings close to the East River is being remodeled.

Patrolman William Kenny, 40 years old, received a flesh wound in the left side at 11 o'clock last night in an exchange of shots with a suspected robber on Jamaica Avenue near 175th Street, Jamaica. The wounded patrolman was taken to the Mary Immaculate Hospital, where his condition was reported not serious.

Witnesses told the Senate Civil Liberties Committee today that armed Republic Steel Corporation guards drove out of the gates of the Berger Manufacturing Company, a subsidiary corporation, in Canton, Ohio, during the May, 1935, strike, indiscriminately shooting tear gas and bucks or at pickets and sympathizers, roamed about the town, shooting as they went, and almost ran down police officers with whom they exchanged shots.
The American Federation of Investors made public tonight a compilation showing that taxes of 150 major corporations for 1937. were 34 per cent greater than the total of their common stock dividends.

An autopsy revealed yesterday that Ira May, 44 years old, who died in Kings County Hospital Monday night, soon after his arrest by a detective attached to District Attorney Dewey's staff, had swallowed a capsule containing cyanide of potassium.
8th St, 328 E; Joseph J. Smith to Mac Lapchinsky, 73 Rodney St, Brooklyn ($4.50). 45th St, 126 E, 18.9x70; Miami G. Minturn to Henry E. Grove, 170 W. 85th St; mtg $30,000 (50 cents).
Governor Nelson G. Kraschel tonight ordered National Guardsmen to Newton, Iowa, and established martial law. Adjt. Gen. Charles H. Grahl immediately began mobilization of a battalion of 250 men here.

Edward J. Kavanagh, first assistant in charge of classical languages at George Washington High School, who more than fifteen years ago was coach of the school's football team, died on Monday night in his home at 2,328 University Avenue, the Bronx, after an illness. of five months. He was 60 years old.

The Securities and Exchange Commission issued an order today suspending the effectiveness of a registration statement filed under the Securities Act of 1933 by the Unity Gold Corporation, a Montana corporation, contending that the statement had various deficiencies.

Having played through six rounds without meeting defeat, David S. Polland of Brooklyn, champion of the American Chess Federation, finally met his match in Isaac I. Kashdan, champion of the Manhattan Chess Club, in the seventh round of the open championship at the Hotel Touraine tonight.

The difficulties experienced by slum and low-income families in finding new living quarters when their old homes are torn down are illustrated in the case of about 400 tenants in three Brooklyn areas soon to be cleared for highway improvements.

Many members of the Summer colony of Mount Desert Island's resort centers, including Northeast Harbor, Seal Harbor and Southwest Harbor, turned out for the annual flower show of the Garden Club of Mount Desert today.

A faint ray of hope was seen yesterday for the thousands of dejected gardeners and orchardists in the Eastern States whose flower beds and fruit trees are under attack this year by one of the worst Japanese beetle infestations since the pest was first discovered in this country at Riverton, N. J., in 1916.

The League of New York Theatres and the Actors Equity Association agreed in principle yesterday on a basic agreement stabilizing producing conditions for next season and on a code outlawing ticket speculation.

The indications are for showers and moderately warm weather today, becoming cooler tonight. Tomorrow will be fair with moderate temperatures, according to the map charted at the United States Weather Bureau at 7:30 o'clock (Eastern standard time), last night.
The young American pianist, Elizabeth Travis, received an enthusiastic reception at her first recital here last night. The Cervantes Theatre was sold out, which is unusual for a first performance.

The Oklahoma Power and Water Company, Sand Springs, Okla, subsidiary of the Middle West Corporation, has filed a declaration under the Holding Company Act covering $748,000 of 5 per cent promissory notes, due for Sept. 15, 1938, to July 15, 1943, to be issued in exchange for an equal amount ot 5 per cent notes which the Securities and Exchange Commission said
The Mercury and Maia, two units of Britain's pick-a-back plane, flew separately today to Foynes, Ireland, for the Mercury's take-off from the back of the Maia tomorrow on an Atlantic crossing.

For the last six weeks 2,000 pieces of city office furniture, ,some of them forty years old or more, have been undergoing repair at the cityowned Pier 72, at the. foot of West Thirty-second Street and the Hudson River.

An offer by Barcelona authorities to exchange fourteen Italian "Legionarios," who were fighting as volunteers in the Nationalist (Insurgent] infantry when taken prisoner, for fourteen of eighty Americans in a concentration camp at San Pedro de Cardena is under consideration by Burgos authorities.

The Bureau of Mines reported today stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the close of the week ended July 9 totaled 290,469,000 barrels, a net decrease of 1,197,000 barrels, compared with the previous week. Stocks of domestic oil decreased 1,648,000 barrels for the week and foreign crude increased 451,000 barrels.

Policemen and Lake County deputy sheriffs, using tear gas bombs, routed C. I. O. strike pickets today who had blockaded the Chicago Hardware Foundry Company in North Chicago for seven weeks. The action was taken to enforce a court order that had been defied by the pickets.

Jacob Emil Leitner, Inc., with Wm. A. White Sons as co-brokers, placed for Samuel Derfner a loan of $210.000 for years on the 6-story apartment house recently completed at the northwest corner of 162d St. and Sheridan Ave.

A young robber wearing dark glasses, a dark hat and driving a black automobile held up five stores in and near Maspeth, Queens, between 2:15 and 2:45 P. M. yesterday and escaped with $270.77. He entered a sixth store, but left hurriedly because it was crowded.

Alexander Calder and his son Stanley of Montclair today dethroned August F. Kammer and his son Lowrey as New Jersey State fatherson golf champions. The Kammers, winners of the title for three of the past four years, foundered in the rain and mud at the Echo Lake Country Club in the afternoon and posted a 36-hole total of 173 to finish well down the list.

Creation of a third class of membership is being considered by one of the committees studying New York Curb Exchange reorganization. Proponents of the scheme believe the plan would yield $??0,000 annual revenue for the Curb, double business originating outside the circle of regular members and educate the investing public of the country for the advantages of trading on an organized Exchange.
Miss Laddie Irwin of Glen Ridge, New Jersey, recorded a 40, 40-80 to take low gross honors in a oneday tournament of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association at the Hempstead Golf Club today.
The invasion of Times Square by Japanese beetles is undoubtedly an undeclared war. Perhaps even more sinister is the descent

Despite the increase in merchant shipbuilding of the last year the construction volume is not yet large enough to reduce appreciably the average age of the country's merchant marine, it was declared yesterday by J. Lewis Luckenbach, president of the American Bureau of Shipping.

The Mexican Sugar Trust is reported considering a barter deal with Germany exchanging 51,000 metric tons of sugar and 20,000,000 liters of alcohol and molasses for tin plate usually purchased in the United States. The government has a large voice in the sugar trust, being represented on the board by the Secretary of Economy.

Professor Frederick Wolff Ogilvie, 45-year-old economist, who since 1934 has been president and vice chancellor of Queen's University, Belfast, was today appointed head of the British Broadcasting Corporation.
Eight major railroads and subsidiary lines protested to the State Board of Tax Appeals today against taxes for 1938 aggregating $20,464,053. The board set Sept. 14 for a hearing.

A brief asking the Supreme Court to appoint a special judge to investigate and clear up press reports that an agreement was made between Cuban railroad companies and Congressmen involving the distribution of newly issued public works bonds prior to the passage of the Public Works Conversion Bond Issue Law has been presented by Dr. Manuel Perez Pico, it was learned today.

Virginio Gayda, Fascist editor, said today that Jews of the United States, France, Great Britain and Russia were responsible for the Fascist race policy. This policy, announced July 14, declared Italians were "Aryans" and that Jews did not belong to the Italian people.
A seventy-two-hole score of 286 gave Ted Turner of Pine Valley, N. J., the Philadelphia open golf championship today, the second time he has held it in three years.

Joan Crawford and Franchot Tone, movie stars, issued a joint statement tonight saying that they had separated, that Mr. Tone was moving to separate quarters and that they were parting the best of friends.

An exhibition of work by teachers of the art teaching division of the WPA Federal Art Project opened with a preview yesterday afternoon at the Federal Art Gallery, 225 West Fifty-seventh Street, where, beginning today, it may be visited by the public. The show will be current until Aug. 11.

In a move to prevent the sale of frozen South African crawfish tails as fresh lobster, the Department of Markets has caused the arrest of three fish dealers for misrepresensation, William Fellowes Morgan Jr., Markets Commissioner, said yesterday.

Each of the following reserve officers, assigned or attached to the 303d Chemical Regiment, is ordered to active duty July 31 at Edgewood Arsenal, Md., for training: Col. Joseph D. Sears, C.W.-Res., 425 Franklin St., Bloomfield, N. J.

Twenty-one men gathered in Woodlawn Cemetery yesterday to pay tribute to the memory of Mayor John Purroy Mitchel under whom they served two decades ago. The men stood in a semi-circle while taps was sounded, a prayer read, speeches delivered and wreaths laid.
Consumption of Lake Superior iron ore during June was 1,471,660 tons, the lowest since May, 1933, the Lake Superior Iron Ore Association reported today. May, 1933, consumption was 1,265,000 tons.

Mrs. Lewis Perry of Exeter, N. H., has joined Mrs. Seth E. Thomas at the Berkshire. Mr. and Mrs. Samuel J. Reeves have come to the Ambassador from Philadelphia. Mrs. James W. Scully of Sewickley, Pa., is at the St. Regis.

Serving notice that she is out to win the Elizabeth Wheeler Trophy a third time, Mrs. Henry H. Dietrich of Green Meadow today took the lead at the end of the second round in the ninth annual women's open golf championship of Fairfield and Westchester Counties at the Wee Burn Club.
Auburn prison officials, headed by Warden Joseph E. Brophy, today were investigating a fist fight in which Ivan Poderjay, principal in the Agnes C. Tufverson disappearance case, lost his right eye.

Although the number of out-oftown buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday' was less than in the preceding week, the total was well ahead of the corresponding week a year ago according to the listings in THE TIMES.

Notice was served upon Assistant District Attorney Lindsay R. Henry of Suffolk County today that representatives of the German-American Settlement League and its six officers would appear before County Judge L. Barron Hill in Huntington on Friday to apply for a new trial in connection with their conviction last week of violation of the State Civil Rights Law.

Sears Roebuck and Montgomery Ward mail order catalogues went into the mails today with prices reflecting both the lower commodity prices prevailing in the raw materials market during the Spring and the increasingly keen competition between the two houses.

Horace W. Watts, a member of the electrical contracting firm of McNutt, Watts . Tankard, 420 Lexington Avenue, was sentenced yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora to thirty days in Tombs prison for contempt of the extraordinary grand jury investigating allegedly collusive bidding in the electrical contracting industrv.

Exchange difficulties, aggravated by the preponderance of American exports over imports in trade with Latin America this year, have adversely affected credit and collection conditions in many South and Central American markets,

The Jureau or Navigation released the following orders today, dated July 16: COMMANDERS Clay, A. T., Long Beach, Callf., to Naval Gun Factory, Washington, D. C.; orders relieving from all active duty revoked. Goodhue, W. E., to duty as District Materiel Officer, Instead War Plans Office, 13th Naval District.

Business activity in the United States in June rose slightly for the first time since August, 1937, according to a review of domestic business conditions in The Annalist's current mid-year review and forecast number. The Annalist's index of business activity accordingly rose to 74.1 (preliminary) from 73.8 (revised) in May, and is now back to the level of April when it also stood at 74.1.
Movements of vessels follow, all dates are July 19 unless specified: New London to New York via West Point: Badger, Decatur, Fairfax, Herbert, Leary, J. F. Talbott.

The one hundred streamlined buses that the Exposition Greyhound Lines will operate in its intramural system at the New York World's Fair of 1939 will be the largest motor passenger vehicles in the world and will be of the pusher type with engine in the rear, it was disclosed yesterday by Ralph Bogan, assistant to the president of the Greyhound Corporation and president. of the Exposition Greyhound Lines.
