The second anniversary of the opening of the Spanish civil war was observed at a mass meeting at Madison Square Garden last night as the first step in a program to send 5,000 tons of supplies to the Spanish Loyalists in September. The meeting was under the auspices of the Medical Bureau and North American Committee to Aid Spanish Democracy and the Confederated Spanish Societies to Aid Spain.

Plans were being made today to sign the peace treaty between Bolivia and Paraguay Thursday afternoon. Bolivia, however, has not instructed her delegates here to sign the instrument in its newly revised form.

A supplemental summary of transactions in equity securities by officers, directors and principal stockholders in May made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission showed that George Whitney, a director, sold 1,000 common and 250 of $5 cumulative preferred stocks of General Motors Corporation.

The Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary is leaving at noon today for Cherbourg and Southampton. passengers are Lawrence A. Steinhardt, United States Ambassador to Peru, Mrs. Steinhardt and Miss Dulcie Ann Steinhardt;

Planes from Majorca got another si British ship in Valencia harbor today. The vessel was set afire but by quick work it was saved from sinking. The ship was the Standland, with two non-intervention observers aboard--Albert Wijker, a Netherlander, and Salvador Cirrincione, an Italian.

Larry Dee, the San Franciscan who is rated as the chief contender for the Pennsylvania State junior tennis crown worn by Isadore Bellis of Philadelphia, had to put in more than two hours of gruelling play today to survive the third round.

The downfall of the 400-mile Rutland Railroad, which is now in the hands of a receiver and likely to be abandoned, is due not so much to lack of patronage as it is to high cost of operation, its general auditor, Clayton H. Maurice of this city, told Judge Harland B. Howe in the United States District Court here today.
The salt-water angler doesn't have to worry about selecting a good fishing port these days, for they seem to be taking plenty of fish up and down the coast.
Dr. Bernard Leo O'Donnell of 321 East Fifty-fifth Street, for thirtyeight years a practitioner in this city, died Monday in St. Francis Hospital after an operation. He was 65 years old.

Former Alderman James B. Allen, who was recently elected Democratic leader of the -Eleventh Assembly District in Brooklyn, was honored at a dinner last night in the Brooklyn Knights of Columbus Clubhouse at 1 Prospect Park West.

The advance in bond values continued yesterday under the leadership of the secondary railroad and selected industrial and utility issues in heavier trading on the New York Stock Exchange. The increased activity and strength was traceable directly to the /impressive demonstation given by stocks.

Several leases of homes and business property in Manhattan were reported yesterday. Among the dwellings involved in the trading was one at 221 East Sixty-second Street, rented by C. D. Jackson, general manager of Life Magazine, through Potter, Hamilton Co., and Douglas Gibbons Co., brokers.

James J. Hines, the Tammany district leader charged with being a member of the Arthur (Dutch' Schultz) Flegenheimer gang in the policy racket, won a victory in Supreme Court yesterday when Justice Ferdinand Pecora granted the most important items in his demand for a bill of particulars from District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey.

Charles Boyer was assigned today to appear opposite Irene Dunne in an untitled romantic drama by Dore Schary and Leo McCarey at RKO. When the actor left Walter Wanger's some weeks ago it was announced he would appear with Ginger Rogers in "Perfect Honeymoon," which has since been abandoned in favor of the film which McCarey will produce and direct.

Stebbins Ave (11-2973); s e s. 150 ft n e of 169th St. 50x128; 1,274 Stebbins Ave, Inc. to Leonat Holding Corp, 778 Trinity Ave; mtg $47.000. 180th St (11-3124); n s. 70 ft e of Mohegan Ave, 37x118; Cardinal Investing Corp to Selfree Realty Corp, 1,114 Westchester Ave; mtg $32,200.

The skeleton of the now famous case of Duncan Sandys, which is popularly supposed to rest in Secretary Leslie Hore-Belisha's cupboard at the War Office, received another rattle in the House of Commons this afternoon.

Things were taking another wrong hop with the Giants today, and the hop was not taking Colonel Bill Terry to Ireland either. It was, in fact, driving the old colonel pretty close to complete distraction when matters suddenly righted themselves and by dint of great perseverance the Giants brought down Frank Frisch and feet his equally distracted Cardinals, 7 to 6, in the opening clash of a fourgame series.

The Bureau of Air Commerce today suspended the experimental license of Douglas G. Corrigan in the fear that the intrepid aviator would attempt the hazardous westward flight across the Atlantic from Dublin.

A "Test Pilot" on a smaller, less fatalistic scale, is what the Rialto's "Sky Giant" seems to be. Once again the screen is dedicating itself to those heroic pioneers who made the airways safe (or safer) and mapped a new transarctic route to Moscow.

A tract of 194 acres in Millington, N. J., has been sold by David S. Meister, Inc., to a group of developers for improvement with one-family houses. The parcel comprises a large section of the town and has a frontage of one mile on Springfield Avenue.

Insurance requirements covering liability of truckmen and brokers operating under a new law giving the Public Service Commission jurisdiction over trucks transporting merchandise for hire were announced today, effective Nov. 1.
An agreement whereby 40 per cent of the tickets for the annual Rose Bowl football game in Pasadena will be made available to the public was announced today.

Refusal by the United States District Court here today to grant an injunction to the Resources Corporation International, Chicago, which sought to restrain the Securities and Exchange Commission from continuing stoporder proceedings in connection with a registration statement filed by the company under the Securities Act of 1933, was interpreted as an important victory for the SEC.
Operations in the first half of 1938 of the William Wrigley Jr.

Gerhard Kuehne, Inc., acted as brokers in the recent sale of the ten-family house at 69 West 118th Street by Seventy-ninth Management, Inc., to an investor, for cash above a mortgage of $17,000 held by the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank.

Officials of the International Secretariat for the Fourth International, an organization of followers of Leon Trotsky, obtained a warrant here today charging Russian secret police had kidnapped their secretary, Rudolf Klement, a German exile, and "probably had taken him to Loyalist Spain."
The Constitutional Convention at Albany advanced to third reading a clause barring New York City and other municipalities from levying their own special taxes.

Stocks closed strong at best levels of current movement with leading shares up 1 to 3 points: turnover, 2,942,210 shares, largest trading since Oct. 21, 1937. Corporate bonds higher, rails strong, United States Government and other issues irregularly lower; transactions, $10,382,850.

Nothing else that the Constitutional Convention does will have such deeplying importance as what it does about reapportionment. The amendment submitted yesterday by the Committee on Legislature goes to the very roots of the democratic system in this State. More than two decades have gone by since we adjusted our legislative representation to fit the inevitable changes in population.
Six different types of masonry walls have recently been tested by the National Bureau of Standards for their reaction to compressive, transverse, concentrated, impact and racking loads,

In warning bankers of the nation that unless they are more liberal in their lending policies the Government will be forced to "go further into the banking business," Chairman Jones of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation sounds again a note that has been echoing from Washington since the Autumn of 1933.

Crown, Prince Gustaf Adolf and Crown Princess Louise of Sweden were guests of honor last night at the concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony at the Lewisohn Stadium. The major responsibilities of the program were borne by the eminent violinist Mischa Elman, who appeared as soloist in two concertos.

A new apartment house in West Twenty-first Street to cost $140,000 and another multi-family building 'for Brooklyn, estimated to cost $170,000, were among the plans filed yesterday. The list of new projects follows:

Miss Alice Van Zandt Owens, daughter of Mrs. Herman Suter of Bronxville, will leave here on Monday for Berkeley, Calif., where, on the afternoon of Aug. 3, she will be married to Richard Tomfohrde Kennett.
HOW to get aboard a freight ship, where freight ships go, how much they charge, what kind of food they serve, what sort of accommodations they have-all this is in Larry Nixon's "Vagabond Voyaging."*

With the receipt of the signed contracts of Taldon (Tillie) Manton, expert place-kicking fullback, and Tony Sarausky, former Fordham star, John V. Mara, president of the New York Football Giants, announced yesterday that he now has seventeen veteran players in the fold for the 1938 season.

As a result of official intervention and several indications suggesting a possible change in financial policy and moderation in the treatment of Jewish security holdings, the Boerse staged a strong recovery in futures today that wiped out at least part of yesterday's sensational slump.

An emergency fund of $300,000, to chap which 4,500 individuals and organinations in this country have contribute, has been raised and will be forwarded to China to make it possible for thirteen American-supported colleges In that country to continue in existence, it was announced yesterday by Paul D. Cravath.

Attorneys for the Busch Jewelry Company, Inc., and the United Optical Workers Union, a C. I. O. affiliate, agreed yesterday to set aside a default judgment obtained by the company against the union under which Gerald F. Finlay was appointed referee to assess damages against the union and its members for allegedly breaching a collectivebargaining agreement by striking.

IF they ever have Oscar Vitt up for murder--well, just a moment, now. It isn't likely that the amiable and even jovial leader of the Cleveland Indians will be hauled up on a charge of homicide in any degree, but it must be remembered that he is a baseball manager and the temptations are pretty severe at times.

Under cover of darkness the Indians raided the Stadium yesterday and wrought havoc on the Yankees. The darkness almost obliterated the players and field for four innings as storm clouds gathered over head.

The long-awaited- Congressional investigation into the conduct of the Tennessee Valley Authority is now under way at Knoxville. It will be followed closely throughout the nation and carefully assayed.

Despite a drop in the average temperatures yesterday, high humidity kept New York City's residents and visitors sweltering for the thirteenth successive. day. Showers within the city brought little relief.
Pittsburgh's Pirates maintained their grip on first place today in the heated National League race when they mowed down the Phillies, 8 to O, behind the five-hit pitching of Southpaw Ed Brandt.
While sustaining the guilt of only five of thirty individuals and twelve of sixteen corporations convicted in January to raise mid-Western gasoline prices,
Douglas G. Corrigan, impromptu transatlantic pilot, will have no necessity to fly back to the United States, according to the best available information last night.

Mrs. Margaret Frueauff Meredith, known on the stage as Margaret Perry, received a divorce today from Burgess Meredith, actor, with the restoration of her maiden name. This was her second Nevada divorce.
" No one should wear black -for me, but my favorite color-mauve. All flowers placed on the coffin should be red." These requests were made in Dowager Queen Marie's will, which was dated June, 1933.

Miss Rosemary Demarest is treasurer of the committee in charge of arrangemrets for a masquerade dance to be held here Saturday night at the Belle Haven Beach Club. Crippled children in New York will be the beneficiaries of the event.

The stock market here was quiet but generally firm today and small gains were registered in most sections. Gilt-edge issues were inactive, although their tendency was good, while among the foreign bonds Austrian, German and Czechoslovakian loans improved.

Finland this evening decided to hold the Olympic Games in 1940, accepting the invitation issued by Count Henri de Baillet-Latour of Belgium, president of the International Olympic Committee, after he had received an official notification from the Japanese Ambassador at Brussels of Japan's decision not to stage the names.
Probably it was because of the longstanding belief in a national stock market as indicator of threatening war that the first news of Monday's severe collapse on the Berlin Boerse caused apprehension.

Sire; I am infiriitely happy to be able to interpret to Your Majesty, and to Her Majesty, the Queen, the feelings of sincere joy shown today by the people of France in welcoming the august sovereigns of the nation which is our friend.

Six Manhattan properties were sold at auction in the Vesey Street Rooms yesterday and the scheduled sale of a seventh was adjourned to a later date. Among the parcels sold was the sixteen-story CassardRomano Building, at 305-11 East Sixty-third Street, and the tenement and store building at 499 Third Avenue, long the home of McMahan's Oyster and Chop House.

The National Health Conference being held by the President's Interdepartmental Committee to Coordinate Health and Welfare Activities heard this-morning-a dramatic statement by Dr. Irvin Abell, president of the American Medical Association, assuring the conference of organized medicine's "wholehearted cooperation in any of the efforts which you make for betterment in the health care of the people of this country."

In the belief that consumer response to August fur sales will be better than their initial buying budgets called for, a substantial number of retailers have returned to the market here during the last few days to increase their orders, it was reported here yesterday.
Two statements issued today by Konrad Henlein's Sudeten German party form a gloomy prognosis for any hope of agreement between them and the government.
Commercial organizations requiring larger space for expanding businesses accounted for a number of the rentals listed by brokers yesterday.
The American Potash and Chemical Corporation reduced its dividend with the declaration yesterday of $1 a share on the common stock. Last year the company paid $1.50 in June and $2 in September.

The War Department announced today the award of a Soldier's Medal to Thomas D. Porter, private of Company B, First Quartermaster Regiment, who lives in Ventnor City, N. J., for heroism displayed in rescuing a woman from drowning in New York Bay the night of April 21.

A sentence of ten years' silence concerning the private life of Simone Simon, French film actress, was imposed on Sandra Martin, the star's former secretary, when she was saved from a State prison term today by Superior Judge A. A. Scott.

Mrs. Verona E. Roach, widow of Senator William N. Roach of North Dakota and mother of Channing Pollock, author and playwright, died in a private hospital in Bayside, Queens, yesterday, after a long illness. Her age was 76.
The protests of two New England Governors were added today to Northern arguments against a Southern demand for lower rail freight rates on northbound goods.

Nearly 150 actors, singers and dancers, with cries of "We want our jobs!" stormed the headquarters of Actors Equity Association, 45 West Forty-seventh Street, yesterday afternoon, and succeeded in forcing Equity Council to give tentative approval to salary reductions which might result in the resumption of the operetta seasons at Jones Beach and Randalls Island.
A new ground-floor facade for the store of James McCreery Co. will mean the passing of the old Thirtyfourth Street marquee of the building.
Six thousand families, including about 22,000 persons, will be able to move out of slum quarters into healthful, modern apartments when the Red Hook and Queensbridge housing projects are completed.

There has been an improvement in business sentiment during the advance in stocks which began a month ago today. This is in part the reverse of the picture last August, when business optimism yielded reluctantly after the sharp market decline had been under way for nearly an equivalent period.

The Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation has notified the New York Stock Exchange that $22,352,713 of promissory notes of affiliated companies are on deposit as collateral under the indenture of the mortgage securing the company's first mortgage 4 1/4 per cent bonds, Series A due 1961, of which $29,387,000 are outstanding.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It was with regret that I read THE TIMES'S editorial "The Lag in Building." Ever since the President set the example of making the building industry the scapegoat for lagging business revival, newspapers everywhere have taken up the theme in articles and editorials.
Senator Walter F. George, opponent of the President's court and reorganization programs, praised the Chief Executive and items of the New Deal program in a campaign speech today.
American women, although the smartest in the world in their general dress, have tastes inferior to those of British women in millinery, Nellie Kaufman, proprietress of Kaufman's Millinery Shops.

For the first time in the history of the wallpaper industry, manufacturers, wholesalers, retailers and salesmen of wallpaper met last night at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria to discuss promotion plans for the industry. J. C. Eisenhart, president of J. C. Eiisenhart Co. of
A censorship was enforced today on foreign press telegrams and local newspapers were warned against publishing false rumors. The last censorship was imposed in 1936.

Governor Earle announced tonight that he would call the Legislature into special session Monday to "consider publicly" the graft and corruption charges made against himself and thirteen Democratic colleagues.
The Bolivian Congress, which was convened with the powers of a constitutional convention, passed a law yesterday granting the President power to suppress Rightist newspaoers.

Cracking out a double and four singles in five trips to the plate, Heinie Manush, veteran outfielder, sparked the Maple Leafs to a 7-4 triumph over Jersey City tonight as Toronto won the series by a 3-1 margin.

Dr. Arthur E. Morgan, former chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority, charged before the Congressional investigating committee today that the TVA board of directors had wasted millions of dollars in its power and agricultural programs.

William C. Merrill, president of the E. R. Merrill Spring Company, manufacturers of automobile springs, died yesterday in St. Vincent's Hospital from injuries he received when he was knocked down by a runaway milk wagon horse near his office Friday.
WASHINGTON, July 19.-The War Department released the following orders dated July 16: COLONELS Vories, A. C., Signal Corps, Fort Monmouth, N. J., to retirement. Williams, G., Cavalry, to retirement.

Mrs. Emily F. Thompson Griggs, who was active in war relief work in France and was the wife of Herbert Lebau Griggs, former president and former chairman of the board of directors of the Bank of New York, died on Friday in Paris, according to word received here yesterday.

Fed steers and yearlings sold steady on a very stubborn, slow market. Prime Nebraskas uncovered a new top for the year at $12.85, and Illinois fed long yearlings reached $12.50. the United States Department of Agriculture reports. Both hogs and lambs worked lower, with choice Washington grass lambs selling at $9.25.

About 6,000 men returned to construction work at the World's Fair yesterday following settlement of the general strike called late in June by the Building Trades and Construction Council, but the terms of the settlement remained a mystery.

The Cabinet today authorized the creation of a belief "foreign exchange revolving fund." It will export abroad 300,000,000 yen of the Bank of Japan's gold reserve, leaving 500,000,000 yen in the bank's vaults.

Accused of murdering his wife, Mrs. Frances Tuzzolino, 48 years old, in the presence of her brother and a son, in her home at 634 Kosciusko Street, Brooklyn, at 2:10 P. M. yesterday, Charles Tuzzolino, 49, a former barber, who escaped from the Pilgrim State Hospital, Brentwood, an institution for mental patients, on July 10, was booked in the Ralph Avenue police station, Brooklyn.

The estate of Lewis Charles Ruch, former president of the Philadelphia National League Baseball Club, has a gross value of $300,608, according to a transfer tax appraisal report filed yesterday in the Surrogate's Court in Brooklyn.

Victor W. Knauth of Wilton and New York City became publisher of The Bridgeport Times-Star today by acquiring about 60 per cent of the common stock, the interest of H. S. Talmadge, and a large block of the preferred stock of the company.

At a hearing today on the application by the Utilities Power and Light Corporation, Ltd., to use about $12,000,000 of its funds to buy debentures of its parent company, the Utilities Power and Light Corporation, Commissioner Jerome N. Frank of the Securities and Exchange Commission sought to determine the reason for lengthy cross-examination by counsel for the Associated Investing Corporation regarding testimony as to the valuation of the property.

Five truck horses, a billy goat and a gray donkey stepped out of the largely motorized traffic at West and Hubert Streets yesterday morning and, nuzzling into the full water pails set out by the Humane Society of New York, helped to. make official the opening of a new watering station at that corner.
Dr. Emanuel Friend, senior attending surgeon of the Michael Reese Hospital, died today of a heart attack in his suite in the Hotel Windermere. He was 68 years old.
Lauson H. Stone, son of Associate Justice Harlan F. Stone of the United States Supreme Court, was named yesterday by Mayor La Guardia as a member of the Board of Higher Education.

A streamlined answer to the "World of Tomorrow's" problems in high-speed traffic and super highways will be offered by General Motors Corporation, when the World's Fair opens next Spring, in an exhibit designed by Norman Bel Geddes, the company announced yesterday.

73d St, 125 E, 24x102.2; Layton Realty Company to Manufacturers Trust Company; pr mtge, $40,000; installments, int per bond, $12,469. Lexington Ave, 135, 22.4x80; Katie C. Lawrence to Walter Andresen, 125 Lexington Ave; pr mtge, $30,000; Installments, 6 per cent; $3,500.

Reconsidering his decision not to join the Giants as a coach, Travis Jackson, recently dismissed as manager of the Jersey City farm, agreed yesterday in a conference with President Horace Stoneham here to cast his lot with Manager Bill Terry when the Giants return to the Polo Grounds.

The Massachusetts Investors Trust reports a net asset value of $20.13 a share on 5,621,857 shares outstanding on June 30, compared to $15.56 on 5,400,267 shares on March 31 and to $18.64 a share at Dec. 31. At June 30 the company had 50,537 stockholders, a record.

Jacob Frederick Brown, member. of Brown Howe, a Boston wool firm, and president of the Wuskanut Mills, Inc., of Farnumsdale and the Roxbury Carpet- Company of Saxonville, died here today at the George F. Baker Memorial of the Deaconess Hospital.

A nationwide plan under which disaster refugees will receive immediate dental care on the scene of the emergency has been perfected by the American Dental Association and the American Red Cross, Dr. Harry B. Pinney, secretary of the association, announced today.
A $5,000,000 sewing project to give employment to 3,000 unemployed union dressmakers and cloakmakers will be started by the WPA in this city within a few days, it was announced yesterday.

Speaking at a meeting of State and municipal officials at Linz, August Eigruber, Gauleiter for Upper Danube Province, formerly Upper Austria, said all persons known to have been informers before the revolution, persons who had denounced Nazis and since had professed to be ardent Nazis, must be rooted out of the public service.

The report of the United Corporation for three months to June 30, issued yesterday, shows a net income, after all operating expenses, taxes and charges, of $1,194,304. This was equal, after preferred dividend charges on the $3 cumulative preferred stock, to less than 1 cent a share on the outstanding common stock, and compares with a net of $2,662,670, or five cents a common share, earned in the June quarter of 1937.

Funeral services for Milton V. Snyder, former foreign correspondent and retired exchange editor of The New York Herald Tribune, who died'Saturday, were held yesterday afternoon at the Campbell Funeral Church, 1,970 Broadway. Former newspaper associates and friends. were present.

There will be another pay-off window in addition to the pari-mutuels when Washington Park opens its thirtyday race meeting on Aug. 1, one that will distribute $30,000 to the everyday race fan and handicapper.

At no time did wheat prices today drop below the finish on Monday, but there was no snap to the buying and an upturn of 1 cent a bushel at the extreme was due largely to buying induced by the strength in securities and the refusal of Liverpool to show any weakness.

Police Commissioner Valentine accepted yesterday from another Valentine who was once a member of the old Brooklyn force a gold badge which the latter wore as a chemist attached to the chief surgeon's office in the days when the metropolitan and Brooklyn police were separate agencies.

After hearing members of the League of New York Theatres protest against unfair competition from the Labor Stage, producers of the musical show "Pins and Needles" in a theatre at Thirtyninth Street and Sixth Avenue, Mayor La Guardia withheld action yesterday on a local law designed to exempt the organization from. payment of an annual city license fee of $500.
President Roosevelt has shown that he is as strong as he was in 1936, Senator Thomas of. Oklahoma said today in commenting upon the reception given to the President in his transcontinental tour.
Mrs. Cornelia Stratton Parker entertained the Williamstown Garden Club this afternoon at her home, I Swiss Meadows, South Williamstown.

Allan Marquand, son of the late Professor Allan Marquand of Princeton University and grandson of the late Henry G. Marquand, founder of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, died yesterday morning at his home in Alma, Col., according to word received here and in Princeton. He was 26 years old.

BLADGEN, LINZEE (Sept. 23, 1936). Gross assets, $960,548; net, $735,886. To Dorothea Bladgen, widow, residue; John L. Dexter, Stanton W. Satterlee, Richard S. Russell Jr., and Christopher Longcope, $5,000 each; Robert McPherson, $2,500; two specific bequests. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $586,217.

BLADGEN, LINZEE (Sept. 23, 1936). Gross assets, $960,548; net, $735,886. To Dorothea Bladgen, widow, residue; John L. Dexter, Stanton W. Satterlee, Richard S. Russell Jr., and Christopher Longcope, $5,000 each; Robert McPherson, $2,500; two specific bequests. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $586,217.

A net income of $5,046,623 is reported by the Corn Products Refining Company and its subsidiary sales companies after deductions for taxes, reserve for depreciation and other charges, according to the statement for the six months of this year made public today.

Transactions in Manhattan realty announced yesterday will lead to the demolition of a group of seven buildings to make way for a large new apartment in the Chelsea section, as well as alterations to buildings near Corlears Hook and on the upper West Side.

The recent sharp improvement in the sales of women's specialty shops here and out-of-town, putting their sales from 5 to 1-2 per cent above the corresponding period last year, is being reflected in increases in the initial Fall budgets of these shops for a wide range of higher grade apparel,

Rick Ferrell's double in the tenth inning with two on broke a tie today and gave Washington a 4-to-3 decision over the Tigers. Detroit had evened the score in thee ninth when Jo-Jo White scored on a single by Pete Fox.

President Roosevelt went after the big fish off Cape San Lucas today, but all he and his party caught were some little fellows and deeper coats of tan. This was the first day since the fishing excursion started, last Monday in Magdalena Bay, that the big fish have refused to nibble at the Presidential bait.

Continuing the fine brand of tennis which has carried him far this season, Dan Canale of Memphis accounted for the first upset of the Eastern junior championship when he defeated Harry Van Rensselaer of Danbury, Conn., seeded No. 4 player, 6-3, 4-6, 6-2, on the courts of the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills yesterday.
As a result of the flood of orders. in recent weeks, men's covert suits and topcoats will be among the outstanding sellers for the Fall season, manufacturers reported yesterday.

Mayors of Hudson County, N. J., municipalities protested to the Interstate Commerce Commission today against an eight-cent "tube" fare between New York City's Hudson Terminal and stations in Jersey City and Hoboken.

Mrs. David Wagstaff of Tuxedo Park gave a luncheon yesterday in the Starlight Roof of the WaldorfAstoria for Mrs. E. Roland Harriman, Mrs. Walter Roessler, Mrs. William Ewing, Mrs. Morgan Belmont and Mrs. J. Gould Remick.

The Southern Railway Company applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to extend for five years the maturity of a $12,475,204 loan from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and to borrow from the RFC an additional $11,795,000.

COFFEY, ANNA C. (July 12). Estate. more than $10,000. To Captain Philip Thayer Coffey, son, executor, 57 W. 58th St. GRAHAM, JOSEPHINE L. J. (July 5). Estate, more than $10,000. To Manuel S. de Moya, 160 Hartsdale Rd., Hartsdale, N. Y., 9.45 per cent residue;

Daily average gross production of crude oil in the United States last week was 3,343,100 barrels, compared with 3,296,250 in the preceding week, an increase of 46,850, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday.

Dead from thirst, the body of Herman E. Van Thijn, 38, Los Angeles mining engineer, was found today on the sands of the Mojave Desert. Van Thijn and his companion, Robert L. Wicks, left their homes Sunday night for Owl Hole Springs, near Shoshone, to inspect mining properties.

Looking fresh and spruce after a good night's sleep, Douglas G. Corrigan, hatless and still in his flying togs, drove with United States Minister John Cudahy from the American Legation this morning to the Government Buildings in Dublin.

Miss Barbara Kidder, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Alfred Vincent Kidder of Boston and the Red House, Beverly Farms, was married this afternoon to Will Max Theodore Buse of Guatemala City, Guatemala, son of Franz Buse of Hamburg, Germany, in the Ascension Memorial Church' in Ipswich. The Rev. Richard A.

President Lazaro Cardenas asserted tonight that the activities of the United States Government with reference to the Mexican expropriation of foreign-owned oil properties had been devoted exclusively to trying to get the United States oil concerns to. deal directly with the Mexican Government.
The Italian press ignored the Paris visit of King George and Queen Elizabeth today. One Rome paper published a four-line dispatch saying they were on their way to Paris. Others printed nothing.

Representative Jerry J. O'Connell of Butte took a 3-to-2 lead over his closest rival, Payne Templeton, Helena educator, for the Democratic nomination for Congress in the First Montana District on the basis of scattered returns early tonight.

Dr. Paul Zucker, authority on the history of art and architecture and ?? well-known practicing architect in Germany until his voluntary exile eight months ago, has been appoint??d a member of the faculty of the Cooper Union Art School, according ??o announcement yesterday by Guy Gaylor Clark, art director of the union.
General Robert E. Wood, president of Sears, Roebuck Co., was elected yesterday a director of the National Life Insurance Company of Montpelier, Vt.
The Exchange Telegraph reported from Athens tonight that an earthquake shook the city at 10 P. M. and caused a panic over a wide area.

Two brothers whose father is dead and whose mother is in a State hospital were turned over to the Department of Public Welfare yesterday by an uncle, no longer able to provide or them. Rather than enter different institutions the boys ran away, and last night a general alarm was out for them.

Newspapers apparently will be the chief beneficiary from the increased advertising campaigns which leading corset manufacturers will launch this Fall. On Monday the Form-Fit Company announced a budget 25 per cent larger, most of the increase going to newspapers, and yesterday two other large companies made known extensive campaigns.
A report that, Frau Dollfuss, widow of slain Chancellor Engelbert Dollfuss of Austria, intended to emigrate to the; United States was denied today by her children's governess.

The principal foreign exchange continued weak yesterday in terms of the dollar in relatively quiet dealings here. Interest was centered again on the pound sterling, which dipped to its lowest price in more than a year, selling at one time during the day at $4.91 1/2, lowest since April 16, 1937. It closed at $4.919-16, for a net loss on the day of 1/2 cent.

Many members of the Summer colony attended the exhibition of sculpture by Wheeler Williams, the first in a series of artistic events for this season, which opened this afternoon with a reception and tea at Four Fountains, the studio of Mr. and Mrs. Lucien Hamilton Tyng. At the tea table were Mrs.

P. C. Staples, president of the Bell Telephone Company of Pennsylvania, reported yesterday that during June the company had experienced more than a seasonal decline in the number of telephones in operation, the net loss being 4,415. The preceding five months had shown a gain of 8,304 telephones, he said, and the total number in service on July 1 was 1,209,000.

THE report from the Yankee Stadium yesterday was that Charley McManus, the streamlined superintendent, couldn't come to the phone because he was engaged in a spot of tarpon fishing away out in left field. The office boy didn't know whether they would open the gates or not.

The American Federation of Labor tonight endorsed Senator Alben W. Barkley, the Democratic majority leader, in his fight for renomination and re-election in Kentucky, where he is opposed by Governor A. B. Chandler.

The Rev. Dr. John Russell, the oldest priest in Connecticut in point of service and believed to be one of the oldest in the United States, died tonight in the rectory of St. Patrick's Church, of which he had been pastor for fifty-five years.

Will H. Hays, president of the Motion Picture Produoers and Distributors of America, issued this statement: Motion picture producers, wholesale distributors and leading exhibitors of the nation will generally welcome the prospect of a comprehensive, fair and conclusive endeavor to clarify the application of existing laws to the trade customs inherent in the development of the motion-picture industry.
Trading continued very slow for traefer meats in the local markets yesterday. Fresh pork cuts sold uneven. The cow market was weak and all other classes weak to lower.
The lightweight bout between Al Davis and Bernie Friedkin, neighborhood rivals from the Browns-ville section of Brooklyn, will be held at Madison Square Garden tonight, barring fire or flood.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. H. Stanley Horn of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Beauchamp Horn, to Robert Milbank, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Milbank, also of South Orange.
At the opening session today of the convention of the American Society of Civil Engineers President Henry Earle Riggs of Ann Arbor, Mich., cautioned the members against unionization.

Eight of the nation's major motion picture companies, controling the production, distribution and exhibition of 65 per cent of all films in the United States and from 80 to 90 per cent of all quality pictures; ...

Frederick S. Hills, who for more than forty years wrote biographical sketches of prominent State residents, but never one of himself, died last night at the age of 79. He published several volumes on "New York State Men" and at his death was at work on private biographical sketches of local civic leaders.
Seventy-five one-family dwellings will be erected in Lawrence, L. I., where a tract of more than twenty acres on Broadway has been purchased by Henry Greenberg and Louis Goldschmidt.

A campaign to make parents aware of the health needs of their children will be undertaken when. the city's schools reopen in the Fall. Plans have been completed to bring 2,500 parents into the schools to help the nurses and doctors with the health registration of the 40,000 boys and girls who will enter the elementary grades for the first time.

Whisky production in the fiscal year which ended June 30 amounted to 102,889,065 tax gallons, which was 120,568,785 tax gallons les than the 223,457,850 produced in the previous fiscal year, the Alcohol Tax Unit announced today.
Governor Lehman today appointed former Supreme Court Justice James P. B. Duffy of Rochester and Platt K. Wiggins of New York City as members of the State Probation Commission.

Kermit Roosevelt, son of the late President and a leading figure in the American merchant marine, issued a statement yesterday announcing his resignation as vice president and director of the International Mercantile Marine Company as well as his posts in other steamship affiliates.

Close of play scores in English county cricket matches started today follow: Gloucestershire 373 for four (Emmett 102 not out, Allen 98, Crapp 80) vs. Surrey, at Bristol. Hampshire 199 (Wilkinson seven for 68) Yorkshire 123 for three (Barber 80 not out). at Bournemouth.

American Labor party leaders, who have been wrangling over the party's endorsements of candidates seeking re-election on major party tickets, have decided to approve several Republican and Democratic candidates for the State Senate and the Assembly, it was disclosed yesterday.

A special "chemists committee" to handle technical problems arising under the new Federal Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act will be created by the Associated Grocery Manufacturers to help members of the association, Paul S. Willis, president, announced at a meeting of Midwest members of the group today.

Skippered by A. R. (Dude) Moyer of the Youngstown (N. Y.) Yacht Club, Erne today won the first race of a series of three for the George Cup by 1 minute and 27 seconds over the defending Aphrodite of the Royal Canadian Yacht Club, Toronto.
Rain yesterday again postponed the final round of the Meadow Brook Club Cups polo tournament and plans to play the repeatedly postponed match between Templeton and Gulf Stream had to be rearranged.

The British pickabackk" seaplane Mercury, which took off yesterday from a "mother plane" off Foynes, Ireland, passed over Cape Bauld, Nfld., at 4:28 o'clock this morning, New York time, after a westward span of the North Atlantic in less than fourteen hours. The plane was expected to land here at about 9:30 A. M. before continuing on to New York.
In observance of his eighty-fifth birthday today, Charles Bulkley Hubbell gave a luncheon at his Summer home, Brookside Farm, in Williamstown.

The decline in commercial bank loans is to be attributed to the depression rather than to any reluctance on the part of commercial banks to extend loans, Orval W. Adams, president of the American Bankers Association, declared yesterday in a statement issued here.
Dr. Janith Stewart Rice and Dr. Raymond Francis Smith, both of this city, were married here this afternoon in the Cathedral of the Incarnation by the Rev. Frederic F. Bush.
The Assembly today sustained the report of a committee that rejected the Governor's request for an exception to the ban on private automobiles.

Northern interests which are fighting a Southern proposal for lower freight rates made an unsuccessful attempt today to insert into the records a newspaper advertisement boasting lower living and production costs in the South.

The appointment of Milton Weinstein as general merchandise manager of the Hearn Department Stores, a newly created post, was announced yesterday by Leonard Ginsberg, president of the company. Mr. Weinstein joined Hearn's in April, 1937, as assistant to Mr. Ginsberg, who was then general manager.

Word of price advances averaging 10 to 15 per cent on lumber and veneers used in furniture production reached the New York Furniture Exchange here yesterday afternoon and brought a stiffening in quotations on Fall furniture lines being displayed there this week in the semi-annual trade show.
AMERICAN REGIONALISM, by Howard W. Odum and Harry Estill Moore. (Holt, $5.) Subtitled "A Cultural-Historical Approach to National Intergration."

Although all Turkish official spokesmen exert themselves to convince one that their relations are most friendly with all other powers, one does not require a super-intelligence to detect that Turkey will in all foreseeable eventualities throw her lot in with Britain.
A sportsman pilot, father of five children, and two women passengers lost their lives today when a biplane crashed in an early-morning fog in an oat field near here.

Edward Lyons, president of the Brevoort Savings Bank of Brooklyn, died today at his home in Belle Terre here after a brief illness. He was 73 years old. Mr. Lyons, a Brooklyn and Long Island real estate man for many years, was elected president of the bank in 1926, having served as a trustee since 1904 and a vice president since 1907.
Stebbins Ave (10-2692), s e s at s s Home St., 52x32; Bowery Savings Bank to Anna Chieco, 883 Home St. Holland Ave, 2,749 (16-4510); Morris Nashelsky to Mary Garafalo, 1,815 White Plains Rd.

Nelson A. Milne, former City Councilman and a Republican leader in the northwestern section of Rochester for more than twenty years, died today. He was 54 years old. Born in Aberdeen, Scotland, Mr. Milne came to Rochester when a child.

Throughout a stormy day thousands made their way to Sinaia to pay homage to the Dowager Queen Marie, who died on Monday. Robed in white, the body is lying in state in the Chapelle Ardente with a cross in the hands of the Queen and an ikon of the Virgin and child on her breast.

The "pay-off" headquarters of an interstate gambling syndicate at 200 West Seventy-second Street, reputedly headed by George McManus, who was once tried and acquitted of the murder of Arnold Rothstein, were raided yesterday by Police Commissioner Valentine's confidential squad.

Edward E. Bartlett Jr. was elected yesterday chairman of the board of the New York Stock Exchange to succeed William McC. Martin Jr., who resigned as chairman on July 1 upon his appointment as president of the Exchange.

Plans for a new home for Oliva Dionne's family, to be built on an estate with a chapel, school, playground and swimming pool, were discussed here today by Attorney General Gordon Conant and other Ontario Government officials in conference with the quintuplet guardians.

Retail credit collections declined 1.5 per cent in June, according to the twenty-store index of the Credit Bureau of Greater New York. For the first half of the year a decline of 1.37 per cent was reported for sixteen stores.

The Umbrella Manufacturers Association was formed by representatives of several of the larger manufacturers of umbrellas in the country at a meeting in the Hotel Astor Last night. They signed an agreement expressing a desire to compine, mentioning in particular that they wished to advance the interests of producers in connection with the Wages and Hours Act.
Mrs. Lorene, Cowgill of Madison, Wis., niece of John Ringling, today asked the. County Court to probate
Gentlemen who wear suspenders may again appear coatless on the Boardwalk without fear of get-ting a summons for what was classified here as sartorial indecency.
In a change yesterday from a protracted heat wave to an excess of rain, fog and floods afflicted parts of the North Atlantic Coast but left the city unscathed.

Ben Johnson of Columbia and Ray Malott of Stanford and the Olympic Club led a team of United States track and field athletes to victory today at the opening of the three-day .international meet with athletes from all over Europe.

Electric power production increased last week, and on a daily average basis showed a sharp contra-seasonal gain. The adjusted index advanced to 93.8, its highest point since the week ended March 5. The figure was 89.3 for the preceding week, and 109.0 for the week ended July 17, 1937.

Price reductions ranging -up to $26 on the Standard coupe were announced here today. by Willys-Overland Motors, Inc. The lower prices, which cover current production and future production of 1938 models at the factory, will be immediately available on all passenger cars in dealer stocks through out the country, and apply to the entire line.
Mrs. Lillian Alexander of New York City was appointed by Governor Lehman today as a member of the Commission on Urban Colored Population to succeed the Rev. John H. Johnson, who resigned.

A banking group composed of Schmidt, Poole Co., Butcher Sherrerd of Philadelphia, - and Chace, Whitside Co., Inc., Boston, received yesterday the award of a new issue of $400,000 bonds of Washington Suburban Sanitary District, Md.

So that a broad base can be laid for the determination of the legal principles and formulae to be used in evaluating the claims of investors in guaranteed real estate securities against the assets of the guaranteeing companies, Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler adjourned yesterday until Oct. 19 a scheduled hearing on four minor claims against the closed New York Title and Mortgage Company.

Mayor La Guardia issued a warning yesterday that the city was facing bankruptcy if the Constitutional Convention put through its proposal to compel the city to ask the Legislature's permission to levy special taxes each time they were needed.

Willard Long Thorp, Director of Economic Research for Dun and Bradstreet since 1935, when he resigned as economic adviser to the NRA advisory council, has accepted the task of directing the investigations which the Department of Commerce will conduct as part of the administration's current study of the national economy, it was learned today.
The Rev. Dr. James Garland Hamner, retired pastor of the West Caldwell (N. J.) Union Church, died in the Timerest Sanitarium here today after an illness of two years. He was 76 years old:

The report of the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey and subsidiaries for twelve months to June 30, issued yesterday. shows a net income after operating expenses, taxes and other charges, of $22,574,570.

Taking action for the first time under powers granted by Section 11 of the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935-the "death sentence" provision-the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that on Aug. 8 it would begin hearings for the formulation of a plan of reorganization for Utilities Power and Light Corporation which would comply with the act's requirements for geographic and economic integration of utility holding companies.
In accordance with its previously announced policy of making public the grounds for each important proceeding instituted, the Department of Justice today issued the following statement:

The Italian liner Rex, due today from Mediterranean ports, has on board Augusto Rosso, Italian Ambassador to Soviet Russia, and Signora Rosso; Mgr. Joseph Corrigan, Mgr. Charles Fitzgerald, Mrs. Emma Davio, Mario Caruso, Albert A. Teeter, Mr. and Mrs. H. W. Low, W. R. Costello and Max Blatt.

Extended negotiations between officials of the Dollar Line and the United States Maritime Commission are about to end in an agreement under which the veteran steamship company will pass into the hands of the government, it was reported yesterday.

Nehring Brothern, Inc, have arranged a five-year extension with interest at 4 per cent, of the mortgage of $470,000 on 500 Southern Boulevard, the Bronx, for 500 Southern Boulevard, Inc, Alfred Savinelll, president, with the Prudence Bonds Corp.

Reserved off the pace set by the Paragon Stable's Selmalad, the Greentree Stable's Cherry Jam scored a comparatively easy victory today in the fifth running of the Maplewood Stakes for juveniles at Rockingham Park at $7.02 for $2.

Copper prices abroad crossed the 10-cent level yesterday. Sales were made at 10.03 cents a pound c. i. f. European base ports, compared with 9.94 cents on Tuesday. The domestic price was unchanged at 9.75 cents a pound.

Myron Colbert, operator of Le Poissonnier, Inc., a restaurant at 121 East Fifty-second Street, has leased the property at. 12-14 East Forty-ninth Street from the Greenwich Savings Bank, it was announced yesterday.

The scarcity of firstclass reserves is beginning to make itself felt on both sides in Spain, although the calling up of fresh classes fills many gaps. Casualties have been heavy, but at present each side is estimated to have a total strength of about 600,000 men.

If Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt met the British Queen should she curtsy? Mme. Albert Lebrun, the French President's wife, did, yesterday, when the Britsh royal couple arrived and now a most heated public discussion rages as to whether she should or should not have done so.

The Longwood Bowl tournament, one of the grass court classics of the tennis season, was driven indoors today as the nor'easter that set in on Monday buried the turf of the Longwood Cricket Club under pools of water.

A bust of "Mother" Ella Reeve Bloor, known throughout the United States for her activity in many labor struggles in the last twentyfive years, was exhibited privately yesterday afternoon in the studio of Mrs. Susan Woodruff, 150 West Eleventh Street.

Railroad labor and railroad management settled down today to what may be a fairly short debate on the railroad's proposal to cut the wages of 914,000 rail workers 15 per cent before the issue goes into the procedure of the Railway Labor Act.
The Rev. John Martin Petter, Rochester-born priest, who devoted much of his life, to the study and teaching of sacred music, died early today in St. Mary's Hospital. He was 62 years old.

The square rigger Nantucket, 62-yearold training ship of Massachusetts cadets sailed in today, twenty days out of Funchal, Madeira, with all well aboard, according to Captain C. A. Abele. He entered a strong denial that this was the old vessel's last cruise.

Dr. W. L. Robinson, in charge of an autopsy on Mrs. Maybelie Horlick Sidley, said today that the immediate cause of her death on July 6 was an acute condition of the spinal cord which probably developed a short time before death.

When Pageboy, carrying the colors of Paul B. Codd, won the Mamaroneck Handicap yesterday at Empire City, he caused the defeat of the thirteenth consecutive favorite. Knight's Haven, the choice, could do no better than third behind the son of The Porter, who scored by four lengths.

The interstate Commerce Commission denied today an application by the Brotherhood of Railway Clerks for reconsideration of the commission's decision granting the Railway Express Agency, Inc., authority to carry on the business of the Southeastern Express Company.

The trial record in the recent conviction of six directors of the German-American Settlement League will be submitted tomorrow to United States Attorney Michael Walsh in Brooklyn for study as to whether there is ground for revocation of their naturalization papers.

The Mount Desert Garden Club concluded its annual flower show today with a large representation of the Summer colony attending. Awards in the twenty-four classes were made today, with a number of New York Summer residents placed among the winners.

Contracts for $43,458,000, to be lent to thirteen cities to cover not more than 90 per cent of the cost of proposed slum clearance and low-rent housing projects, were approved by President Roosevelt today upon the recommendation of Nathan Straus, administrator of the United States Housing Authority.

Dr. Daniel I. Skidmore, 54-year-old veterinary surgeon,. chief of the virus-serum laboratory of the Bureau of Animal Industry, of Washington, and his wife, Virginia, 49 were seriously injured today when their automobile left the Fort Edward-Schuylerville highway, a mile south of Fort Edward, went down a twenty-foot embankment and stopped near the edge of the Champlain Barge Canal.

Corporation Counsel William C. Chanler ruled yesterday that a vacancy has existed on the Board of Transportation since July 13, when the retirement application of Commissioner Charles V. Halley Jr. became effective.

A favorable report on the Republican reapportionment program for the State was presented tonight to the Constitutional Convention, following a vote of 12 to 5 in the committee. The report immediately precipitated a Democratic battle against the entire proposal as "vicious, unjust and discriminatory."

The suggestion that the members of the Legislature form a union to prevent their leaders from overworking them in the closing days of a session was offered tonight on the floor of the Constitutional Convention by former Governor Alfred E. Smith.

Thousands of persons lined East Side curbstones and leaned from windows and roof parapets yesterday afternoon as the funeral cortege of Louis De Metro, 20-year-old member of a gypsy tribe, who died on Sunday in Bellevue Hospital after suffering from a rare throat infection, passed through the streets.

Mrs. Caro Shaw Coddington of New York was married at noon today to William Liseter Austin Jr. of New York, son of Mrs. William Liseter Austin of Highfield, Rosemont, Pa., and the late Mr. Austin, president of the Baldwin Locomotive Works.

This community of 12,000 persons operated under the command of National Guard officers tonight, after early morning street fighting around the Maytag washing machine factory sent one person to a hospital and a score home with cuts and bruises.

One hundred members of the colony attended the bridge party and tea given today at Rockhurst, the Summer home of Mrs. Waiter Belknap James, for the benefit of the American Merchant Marine Library Association.
Mr. and Mrs. I. G. Pessin of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Annette Elaine Pessin, to Marvin Chaucer Gold, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herman Gold of New Haven.
Among the three Manhattan properties sold at auction in the Vesey Street rooms yesterday was the twelve-story Oregon apartment house on the southeast corner of Seventh Avenue and Fifty-fourth Street.

A group representing insurance companies and savings banks, headed by Dwight S. Beebe, vice president of the Mutual Insurance Company of New York, filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission today a plan of reorganization for the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railway which would wipe out the company's preferred and common stocks.
It is a pleasure to report that the Governor of Bermuda, Lieut. Gen. Sir Reginald John Thoroton Hildyard,

After undergoing the severest training for many weeks, the Chilean military team composed of Captain Eduardo Yanez, Captain Augusto Silva and Lieutenants Izurieta and Vigil will depart for New York in August to take part in various horse shows in the United States, with the National the main event.

EXACTLY a year ago I spent a few days in a little Austrian village about four hours from Vienna. There was a bronze plaque to the memory of Dollfuss let into the outside wall of the village church, and some one decorated it with flowers every morning-fresh field flowers crossed with a pair of small red-and-white Patriotic Front flags.
Jew baiting was resumed here this week on a rather extensive scale, while some young Nazis extended their operations to include Czechs apparently out of sympathy with the Sudeten Germans.

A monoplane, with a twenty-four-gallon fuel capacity, arrived at Balboa today without a permit from Glendale, Calif., via Mexico, Guatemala, El Salvador, Nicaraugua and Costa Rica. R. M. Resseller, the pilot,

Whether James J. Hines, Tammany leader, will be tried on the indictment in the Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer policy lottery monopoly will be decided late next week by Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora.

Led by sterling, the foreign exchanges recovered yesterday from their weakness of the previous day. The pound sterling rose 9-16 cent to $4.921/8, the franc went up % point to 2.76 5-16 cents, the guilder gained 5 points to 55 cents, and the Swiss franc 2 points to 22.90 cents.

The Bureens of Navigation issued the following orders to day dated July 18: CAPTAIN Woodruff, J. W., Boston, Maas., to Board Inspection and Survey, Long Beach, Calis LIEUTENANT COMMANDERS Gilbert, W. C., Pensacola, to duty Inspestor Navy Aircraft Curtiss-Wright CorpBuffalo, N. Y.

Federal Judge Henry W. Goddard granted yesterday allowances of $83,500 to attorneys and others for services rendered in recently terminated reorganization proceedings for the Consolidated Textile Corporation. Allowances totaling $237,725 had been requested.

A contract has been awarded to the General Electric Company for the propelling machinery for a third turbo-electric, 18,500-ton welded tanker to be built for the Atlantic Refining Company by the Sun Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company at its Chester, Pa., yards.

The first steps to carry out the national health program proposed by the government's technical committee on medical care before the National Health Conference this week will be taken at the next session of Congress, it was learned at the closing sessions here today.
Long lists of new apartment tenancies were submitted yesterday by brokers and agents. They covered rentals in buildings in a wide area of the city, and included a number of large suites.
Public financing by the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company will materialize in late Summer or early Fall, it was disclosed in financial circles yesterday.

Blanche Reid, alias Blanche Simms, 29 years old, a Negro, of 1,925 Seventh Avenue, was arraigned on a homicide charge yesterday in connection with the fatal stabbing Monday morning of Fireman Frederick J. Supancic, 30, of 4 Moylan Place.
Upset. 11 to 0, by the Phillies today, the Pirates came back in the second game of a double-header to win, 4 to 1, and increase their lead over the Giants for first place.

A premature explosion of 450 pounds of dynamite killed ten members of a crew of eighteen workmen blasting a water tunnel through solid rock 200 feet below the surface near the city pumping station today.

The San Diego Water Supply Company has made arrangements 77 through Smith, Barney Co. to issue and deliver to six Eastern insurance companies $2,800,000 of first mortgage 33/4 per cent bonds, due Nov. 30, 1955.
The stock market received the news of the Federal action against the motion picture industry badly, although some members of the industry appeared to have expected it.

Suppressed for 150 years, the French diaries of Gouverneur Morris are to be published this Autumn by Houghton Mifflin in unexpurgated form. Entitled "A Diary of the French Revolution," they fill two volumes and have been edited by Morris's great-granddaughter, Beatrix Davenport.

The one-story brick building at 152 to 160 Sixteenth Street, between Broadway and Hudson Avenue, West New York, N. J., has been sold by the New Jersey Title Guarantee and Trust Company to the 1,706 Federal Street Company, which in turn leased it to The Food Fair, Inc.
A Kuo Min (Chinese) News Agency dispatch from Kweiyang, Kweichow Province, reported today that 2,000 persons had been killed or injured in floods following heavy rains in Southeastern Kweichow.

John E. Hollaman, 51 years old, of this village, who helped establish planning and zoning in Brookhaven Township, shot himself to death, according to police, while sitting in a parked car this afternoon at the foot of Pine Neck Avenue, here.
Shortly before the primary Tuesday The Montana Standard, published at Butte, Representative Jegry O'Conne capital, filled us with gloom. Its heart bled for the fate of the direct primary.
Charles Leo (Gabby) Hartnett has been named manager of the Chicago Cubs, replacing Charlie Grimm, owner Phil K. Wrigley announced late today. Hartnett will take charge of the club tomorrow.

Finland's decision to accept the Olympic invitation to play host in 1940 is good news indeed. It means that no national jealousies will be aroused, that there will be no ominous parade of military force, that no contestant will have to salute any persons or any symbols he does not respect.
It remained for Herr Hitler to confirm the significance of the visit of the British sovereigns to France. Paris prepared a gay and typically Gallic welcome for its royal guests.

A decision of the American Horse P Shows Association to enlist further cooperation of exhibitors in the conduct of its affairs, in an effort to extend its usefulness, was announced yesterday by Adrian Van Sinderen, president.

Building projects submitted yesterday included plans for several houses in Brooklyn and the Bronx. The plans were filed as follows: Manhattan 31st St, 456-8 W; 41.8x107.8; for one-story garage; Jacob Forst Packing Co, Inc. 218 E 38th St, owner; William Shary, architect; cost, $6,000.
The GermanBrazilian trade war declared on June 12 with the suspension of purchases in Brazil ended today
After it had spent hours yesterday chewing its way out of a good, strong crate, it seemed pretty tough to the young German shepherd dog that people still wanted to interfere with its freedom.

Paris laid all its treasures of natural beauty and art before King George and Queen Elizabeth today, while in Foreign Minister Georges Bonnet's room at the Quai d'Orsay a dialogue, went on between M.. Bonnet, with Premier Edouard Daladier beside him, and Viscount Halifax, Britain's Foreign Secretary.

Mrs. Roy Foster Anthony of Ballantine Parkway has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Doris Whitehead Anthony, to Courtland Ninde Smith Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Smith of Glen Ridge and Bay Head.

Although it strongly condemned the persons responsible for the egging of Norman Thomas at the Socialist meeting in Military Park here June 4, the Essex County grand jury reported in a presentment today that charges of police laxity in handling the disturbance were without foundation.

The Agricultural Adjustment Administration announced today State allotments under a crop-control program designed to keep next year's wheat acreage within 55,000,000 acres and prevent accumulation of greater surpluses of the grain.

Cigarettes made with a transparent tobacco wrapper instead of the conventional white paper were shown here yesterday by Istvan Tamas, inventor of the wrapper and Hungarian author and playwright, who announced that conferences were being held with leading tobacco companies, makers of cigarette papers and a leading cellulose company.
Fierce government resistance at Raguda Pass on the Teruel highway to the sea was reported today to have diverted the Spanish Insurgent drive on Viver, Segorbe, Sagunto and Valencia.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. and her 1-day-old son were "doing nicely" tonight at the Pennsylvania Hospital. The father said he and his wife had not yet decided on a name for the eighth grandchild of the President.
Max West hit a home run into the rightfield bleachers with two on in the ninth to give the Bees a 4-to-3 victory over the Reds in a floodlight game tonight.
Sales of houses by savings banks featured realty trading in Manhattan yesterday. Two of the properties will be modernized.
Stocks closed irregular, with utility and railroad shares higher; industrial and moving picture issues declined; turnover, 2,509,440 shares.

Representatives of sixty religious, frater nal, social, labor and veteran organizations met last night under the chairmanship of John Abbott, director of the Film Library of the Modern Museum, to start a nationwide campaign in behalf of "freedom of the screen."

Rain forced the postponement of two local tournaments yesterday, the men's Eastern clay court championships at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club and the Eastern junior and boys' championships at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills.

Amendments to Rules and Regulations Section 253 is amended to read as follows: Applications for transfers shall be made in writing, over the signature of the applicant, on forms provided (Form 300-f); reason therefore must be fully stated. Under no other conditions shall requests for transfers be considered.

Many recent improvements that line the perimeter of Manhattan land were surveyed yesterday in a five-hour boat trip by more than 100 members of civic organizations pledged to spruce up the city for the World's Fair.
Joint government - labor leader direction of all expropriated petroleum properties, with the government having a decisive voice, was decreed today by President Lazaro Cardenas.

State Senator Robert C. Hendrickson of Gloucester County has been chosen as the recipient of the State American Legion's medal of valor for risking his life in an attempt to prevent the drowning of his friend, William H. Sutton.

The removal of the seven spikes from the crown of the Statue of Liberty, now in progress, is only part of a larger plan of reconditioning the statue and the entire park area at a cost of about $1,700,000, it was revealed yesterday by George A. Palmer, superintendent of the Statue of Liberty National Monument of the National Park Service.

A lack of suitable living quarters in New Jersey is causing rents throughout the State to increase, according to a report contained in a new cost of living series prepared by the State Department of Agriculture.

Counsel for twelve oil companies and five individuals who were found guilty of violating the Sherman Anti-Trust Law yesterday by Federal Judge Patrick T. Stone filed formal notice of appeal in Federal District Court here today.
The Henlein newspaper Die Zeit reports that two more important industrial concerns owned by Jews are leaving the Sudeten German area for Prague.

Jeopardized from the outset by delays in the projected Anglo-American trade pact, the attempt to remodel the system of preferential duties that Britain and Australia grant to each other's products broke down today after two months of negotiation.

Virtually full-time operations at all major clothing manufacturing plants here was predicted for the middle of August, following receipt today by company officials of telegrams confirming the purchase by Federal relief agencies of surplus manufactured clothing stocks.
Clyde L. Day, who for forty-eight years was a practicing attorney in Chicago, died at St. Luke's Hospital this morning from a heart malady. He was 69 years old.

Representative Thomas A. Jenkins, Ohio Republican and most outspoken anti-TVA and anti-New Deal man on the Congressional investigating committee, made a bitter attack on Francis H. Biddle of Philadelphia, chief counsel for the committee, during today's testimony by Dr. Arthur E. Morgan, deposed chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority.
Two bids for the charter for three years of the government-owned American Republics Line and its fleet of thirteen vessels were received today by the United States Maritime Commission.

MANHATTAN KELLY, MARY (July 9). Estate, $8,500. To John F. Kelly, husband, 217 W. 15th St., interest in real property and $50 per month; Francis J. Kelly, son, same address, one-half income from real property after above payment; Mary K. McCullough, daughter, executrix, 217 W. 15th St., household, personal effects, securities and one-half income from trust after payment of specific bequest; two remainder bequests.

A group of banks, headed by the Guaranty Trust Company of New York, has under negotiation a bank loan of $25,000,000 to the Cities Service Oil Company of Delaware, it was announced yesterday by the Guaranty.

Conflicting price movements characterized active trading yesterday in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange. Buoyancy in railroad issues and continued improvement in selected industrial loans, however, managed to lift the combined price average for domestic corporate issues 0.25 point on the day.

Edward F. Cadley, a former Brooklyn Democratic district leader, who was in the city's service in various capacities for more than thirty-five years, died yesterday at his home, 135 New York Avenue, Brooklyn, after a long illness. His age was 65.

The Giants' desperate dash in the wake of the pace-setting Pirates suffered something of a compound fracture today as Onkel Franz Frisch's deflated Gas House Gang, apparently steaming along on borrowed gas, rode right over Colonel Bill Terry's band wagon in both ends of a doubleheader.

Overseas Securities Company, Inc.As of June 30: Net assets, based on market quotations at close of period, were $1,741,269 before deducting outstanding debentures, equivalent to $1,903.03 per $1,000 of debentures.

At Knoxville on Tuesday Dr. Arthur E. Morgan revealed before a joint committee of Congress the evidence on which he bases his charges of mismanagement of the affairs of the Tennessee Valley Authority.

According to researches by Dr. Voss, city archivist of Neuwied in the Rhineland, reported in the Boersen Zeitung today, John D. Rockefeller's ancestors were South German farmers named Rockenfeller who emigrated to America about 1723 and members of the same family are still living in the Neuwied district.
Mrs Nettie Dill, who, under her maiden name of Nettie McCabe won fame as a circus bareback rider, died in her home here after a three-month illness, at the age of 48.

Church St, 327, 22x75; Sally F. Manley to Ruth M. Cutler, Morristown, N. J.; onehalf Interest. 81st St, 129 E, 17x102.2; Ruthedna Realty Corp (Meyer Delisky, pres) to Frederick H. Smith, 361 Scotland Rd, So Orange, N. J.; mtg, $20,000 ($2).

The National Association of Insurance Brokers, through its executive committee meeting here today in its annual session, went on record as unalterably opposed to "political insurance producers" whose qualifications are solely the fact that they or relatives are political officeholders.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: "The London press * * * publishes far more from Wall Street than from Washington, and practically nothing from anywhere else but Hollywood," writes Anne O'Hare McCormick in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are July 20, unless specified: At Navy Yard, Mare Island: Drayton, Flusser, Mahan, Lamson, Porter. At San Diego: Clark, Holland, Perch, Permit. Plunger, Pickel. Pollack, Porpoise.

Bishop John Mark Gannon of Erie, Pa., chairman of the National Catholic Welfare Conference press department, sailed last night on the liner Queen Mary for Spain, where he said he expected to obtain first-hand information concerning the persecution of the Catholic clergy by. the Barcelona government.

Francis A. Bonner, vice president of Blair, Bonner Co. of Chicago, investment bankers, has accepted a three months' appointment as adviser to the Securities and Exchange Commission in connection with the organization of over-thecounter brokers and dealers under the provisions of the Maloney act.

Rabbi Jonah B. Wise, national chairman of the American Joint Distribution Committee, declared on his return from Europe yesterday on the Holland America liner Nieuw Amsterdam that his and other American agencies working for the welfare and relief of distressed peoples abroad were "Americans first of all," and that if ever the needs at home overshadowed those abroad America would receive first attention.

Through letters marked "personal and confidential," and attested as correct by Republic Steel Corporation officials, the Senate Civil Liberties Committee put in the record today testimony indicating pressure used on behalf of the corporation
Montana Democrats renominated the State's two "freshmen" members of Congress for second terms, unofficial and incomplete returns from yesterday's primary elections indicated today.
Pictures and part drawings composing the collections of the Royal Bourbons of France, many of which formerly hung in the Tuileries Palace, brought [Pound]5,127 at Sotheby's today.

Many out-of-town guests will arrive on Friday for the wedding here on Saturday of Miss Phyllis B. Thompson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Phillips B. Thompson, to LieutComdr. Jerauld Wright, U. S. N., son of Major Gen. William Mason Wright, U. S. A., retired, and Mrs. Wright of Washington.

Little Bee Bend from the Widow Duck on down to the littlest pickaninny mourned today for Giles Arnold, the plantation foreman Roark Bradford made famous as a fiction character in stories of Negrolife. He died Sunday, at 53,

Another chapter in the checkered career of the Kansas City Southern Railway is being written through negotiations to merge it with the Louisiana Arkansas Railway, it became known in Wall Street yesterday.
Customs agents at Coblenz today arrested a mother and daughter named Rothschild,' from Frankfort on the Main, for attempting to smuggle money across the Luxembourg border.

Fish were so plentiful off picturesque Socorro Island today that President Roosevelt and the other fishermen aboard the Houston called it a day after three hours of strenuous work with rod and reel, and the cruiser steamed southward.

Bequeathing an obituary filled with the "good things you can say of me" to the newspapers, State Senator Julius S. Berg of the Bronx killed himself in his office at 1,650 Broadway yesterday while a New York County grand jury -held back an indictment charging him with seventeen counts of grand larceny and embezzlement awaiting his appearance.

Hiram F. Connor, 38 years old, secretary of the Department of Finance who started working for the city in 1934 as an employee of the old CWA attached to the old City Chamberlain's office, was arrested last night when, according to Almerindo Portfolio, City Treasurer, he admitted the misappropriation of more than $40,000 from funds in the custody of the City Treasurer over which he had immediate supervision.

One of the biggest days of the Yankee season was ruined yesterday when rain washed out the scheduled double-header between the McCarthymen and the Indians. Not only did the rainfall cause a revision of pitching plans by Manager Joe McCarthy and Oscar Vitt, but it brought disappointment to some 70,000 baseball fans who promised to fill the Stadium almost to capacity.

The Southampton Town Board adopted unanimously today a resolution to oppose the proposal of the Long Island Railroad to discontinue service over the fourmile stretch of track between Bridgehampton and Sag Harbor.

Daniel J. Doherty, national commander of the American Legion, who protested against Teachers College's recent publication of a monograph by Professor William Gellermann attacking his organization, will address a Columbia University audience tonight at the college's invitation.

The second of the three groups of American track and field athletes that will compete in Europe during the Summer sailed for England yesterday aboard the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary. Nine athletes, Coach Peter L. Waters and Manager Harold Anson Bruce made up the party, which sailed at noon.

Because of the attention she attracted in her first substantial role, that of Susie in "Boy Meets Girl," Marie Wilson is to be featured in George Kaufman's "Dulcy" at Warners. The picture was made in 1923 with Constance Talmadge in the title role.

The estate of the late Frank B. Kellogg, former Secretary of State and justice of the World Court, was valued at $1,429,679 in an inventory filed in Ramsey County Probate Court today. He died Dec. 21, 1937.

The Lawrence Gas and Electric Company (Mass.) obtained yesterday at least seven bids from banking firms for its new issue of $1,500,000 of thirty-year bonds. Bidders were to name the rate of interest.

Howard Hughes envisioned giant airplanes of the future, predicted that the day would come when luck would be eliminated from aviation and when flying would be not only the fastest but the safest and cheapest means of transportation, and said the luxurious ocean liner of today would be no more, in a speech last night.

President Roosevelt has approved a recommendation by Secretary Morgenthau that domestic silver mined before midnight, Dec. 31, 1938, and delivered to mints after that hour, be regarded for payment purposes as having been received before that hour, the Treasury announced today.

In a resolution adopted by the board of directors of the New York County Lawyers Association, made public yesterday, all political parties of the Bronx were urged to nominate Municipal Court Justice Matthew M. Levy to succeed himself and to work for his election.

Mayor La Guardia left for Washington last midnight to see PWA Administrator Harold L. Ickes on pending projects, and during his absence electricians at the city building in the World's Fair set about putting the building into shape for his return.

The Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company has called a special meeting of stockholders for Aug. 30 to consider a proposal to waive for one year the stockholders' pre-emptive rights on 500,000 common shares in conjunction with plans to raise about $30,000,000 of additional capital.

Crown Prince Gustaf Adolf and Crown Princess Louise of Sweden remainedd on board H. Edward Manville's yacht Hi-Esmaro yesterday, and last night sailed from City island to Glen Cove, L. I., for dinner with Mrs. Robert Bacon. She was a hostess to the royal couple on their previous visit twelve years ago.

J. P. McEvoy, who hasn't been around the theatre since "Americana," and Arthur Schwartz have written a show called "Swing to the Left," which Dwight Deere Wiman will produce in the coming season. In fact, will produce for a Broadway opening in the middle of December, Jo Mielziner first designing the settings and George Balanchine (probably) doing the choreography.

MANHATTAN ABRAHAMS, HENRIETTA (Feb. 26, 1938). Gross assets, $21,776; net, $18,786. To six charitable institutions share in $6,881; 25 persons receive varying bequests. Chief assets, mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $21,217. Charles A. Strauss, attorney. 270 Broadway.

George H. Earle, Pennsylvania's flying Governor, was grounded tonight by Colonel Camille Vinet, chief of the State Aeronautical Bureau, as an aftermath of a forced landing made by Mr. Earle during a solo flight in a State-owned biplane earlier in the day.

Harry Balsamo, 163 1/2, Harlem, scored a technical knockout victory over Mario Caroselli, 166, Italy, in the feature bout scheduled for ten rounds at the Queensboro Arena in Long Island. City last night.
