New York State farmers now market about $64,000,000 worth of dairy products a year through cooperative associations, according to a national survey of dairy cooperatives made public today by the Farm Credit Administration.

Democrats in the Constitutional Convention, headed by Robert F. Wagner and Charles Poletti, began today a battle for the inclusion in the proposed new State Constitution of a bill of rights for labor.

Realty activity in the Bronx was marked by two quick turnovers and the sale of a vacant plot in the Riverdale section. After a brief ownership Loomis J. Grossman resold to the Bamford Holding Company the six-story elevator apartment house at 1,720 University Avenue.

The War Department issued the following orders today, dated July 19: MAJOR GENERALS Cole, W. E., U. S. A.; 2 months' leave, Aug. 1. Herr, J. K., Chief Cavalry; 7 days' leave, July 25. COLONEL De Armond, G. W., F. A.; 7 days' extension leave.

An alleged communistic school here and the office of Louis Kon, secretary of the Friends of the Soviet Union, were closed for one year today on the orders of the Attorney General's department, acting under Quebec's "padlock act."

The German Government is doing everything possible to make the Salzburg Festival a success. It begins Saturday, and the programs, quantitatively and qualitatively, are said to be equal to anything in the past.

The charge that Leon G. Turrou, former agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, allowed Dr. Ignatz T. Griebl to go to Germany during the inquiry of a Federal grand jury, which later indicted him and others on charges of espionage, was described yesterday by Federal Judge Vincent L. Leibell as "too fantastic for belief."

Rivers Peterson of Indianapolis, editor of Hardware Retailer Magazine, has been named managing director of the National Retail Hardware Association. Glendon Hackney, mapaging editor, replaces him as editor.

Pensioned ON THEIR OWN APPLICATIONS-To take effect 12 midnight, July 19: PATROLMEN-Louis B. A. Payez, 73d Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Feb. 16, 1909. To take effect 12 midnight, July 20: John F. Witzman, 45th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed March 12, 1910.

Teasdale P1, 657 (10-2632); Peter H. Mane to Bronx Savings Bank; extends mtg to July 18, 1943, at 5 per cent; $40,000. Palisade Ave (13-3420), center line at Cleveland H. Dodge property, 80x152: Alderbrook, Inc. to Railroad Federal Savings and Loan Association, 441 Lexington Ave; installments, 6 per cent; S16.000.

Railroads of Pennsylvania were authorized today by the Public Utility Commission to increase passenger coach fares within the State from 2 cents a mile to 21/2 cents a mile for an eighteenmonth trial period.

War Minister Seishiro Itagaki called an emergency conference of the vice chief of the general staff, the director of the Military Affairs Bureau and other high army men at his official residence last night in order to discuss measures to cope with the present Soviet - ManchukuoKorea border situation.

Daniel T. Pierce Jr., member of the New York Stock Exchange, will be admitted today as a general partner in Hirsch, Lilienthal Co. E. K. McLaughlin has joined Brailsford Co. in Chicago, according to Walter Brailsford, president of the firm.

The Rev. and Mrs. Harold N. Arrowsmith have come to the Commodore from Baltimore. Miss Florence Cluett and Scott Cluett have joined their parents, Mr. and Mrs. George Alfred Cluett, at the Cluett home at Sea Island, Ga.

Relatively easier foreign markets brought selling pressure on the Cotton Exchange yesterday and prices ended with losses of 5 to 7 points. With the Liverpool parity on the January delivery the rowest of the season, a prominent spot house put out a block of contracts against purchases abroad and heavy arbitrage transactions featured the morning trading.

Established experimentally last December during the reorganization of the State Employment Service, the offices at Canandaigua, East Aurora, Gouverneur, Ossining and Potsdam will be discontinued this month and their activities taken over by offices in adjoining jurisdictions, announcement by Paul Sifton, executive director of the Division of Placement and Unemployment Insurance of the State Department of Labor, said.

German telephone interests have developed a system whereby persons traveling on the motor roads of that country may receive telephone messages at any of thirtyseven gasoline stations, the Commerce Department reports.

The National Biscuit Company showed increased earnings in its report made public yesterday for the quarter and six months ended with June. Net profit for the three months ended on June 30 amounted to $2,984,565 after depreciation, Federal income taxes and- other charges.

The Iron Age calculates steel output this week at 36 per cent of capacity. It has advanced to that figure from the 23 per cent of the July 4 week and from 25 per cent estimated a week later, which was the lowest percentage of any full week in the downward reaction.
Luncheon of the Rotary Club of New York, Hotel Commodore, 12:15 P. M. "The Situation in Spain Today," John Eoghan Kelly.

Isaac I. Kashdan, champion of the Manhattan Chess Club, gained first place in the American Chess Federation open title tournament at the Hotel Touraine today. Reaching the top by defeating Harold Morton of Providence, R. I., and Jack Moskowitz of the Bronx in adjourned games, Kashdan went into the eighth round tonight and played an uneventful draw with I. A. Horowitz in twenty-three moves.

At a tumultuous meeting here this afternoon members of Local 118 of the United Automobile Workers of America expelled from union membership five men who had been their principal officers until a week ago when the international board undertook a "purge" of "disruptive and communistic elements" in the local. All the men denied being Communists.

" What is essentially required for speedy recovery," says the League of Nations Financial Committee in its report just made public, "is a period during which private industry can carry on its affairs with reasonable expectation of reasonable profits and with minimum disturbance from fluctuations in costs and fears of international complications.
The big Idaho-Maryland Mines Corporation had Federal court authority today to ignore an order of the National Labor Relations Board to reinstate sixty-one discharged C. I. O. gold and silver miners.

If a New Yorker were immune to every cause of death except the direct effects of high temperature he would live, on the basis of last Summer's figures, to the ripe old age of approximately 2,500 years.

The Jersey City Giants bowed to the Buffalo Bisons in the opener of their series tonight, 8 to 3. Tom Baker, allowed to withstand a six-run assault in the third which was dotted by Ollie Carnegie's twenty-eighth homer of the year and Woody Abernathy's twentyfirst, was the principal victim of the setback.

ALEXANDER-Suddenly, on July 20, Alfred H., beloved brother of Frank J., Louise and Dr. Hugo Alexander, in his fortyfourth year. Services at residence, 616 River Terrace, Hoboken, on Friday at 2:30 P. M. BAUER-Frank M., devoted husband of Edna Warner Bauer, July 20, 1938, at his residence, 419 Beach 122d St., Rockaway Park, L. I. Notice of funeral hereafter.

Hope for resumption of the operetta seasons at Jones Beach and Randalls Island was virtually abandoned late yesterday after officials of Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians and Theatrical Protective Union No. 1, the stagehands' organization, assailed Lee and J. J. Shubert and Fortune Gallo, producers of the shows, for allegedly misrepresenting the extent to which the unions tried to make possible the continuation of the outdoor performances.
A treaty of peace between Bolivia and Paraguay will be signed here tomorrow afternoon by their Ministers of Foreign Affairs and delegates to the Chaco peace conference.
Thirty years of public life are enough for A. Harry Moore, who doesn't want any more of it after 1941.

Mayor La Guardia refused to commit himself yesterday on whether or not he would oppose the Council's investigation of relief, after he had discussed a $55,000 budget for the inquiry with Councilman Abner C. Surpless, chairman of the relief investigating committee.

Judgment on the appeal of Clyde A. Armstrong, chief counsel in the Weirton Steel Company case, from the disbarment orders issued against him by Edward Grandison Smith, trial examiner, was reserved today by the National Labor Relations Board after an all-day session, at the end of which Mr. Armstrong declined to accept an opportunity to apologize.

Mrs. Herbert H. Lehman, wife of the Governor, yesterday urged women to rededicate themselves to the Constitution and the Bill of Rights, to which she said they were indebted for improvement in their civil status.
Moriz Rosenthal the pianist will make his first outdoor concert appearance when he plays as soloist tonight at Lewisohn Stadium with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra. Massimo Freccia will conduct.
The liner Lady Somers left here tonight, having among her passengers John Roosevelt, youngest son of F. D. Roosevelt, and his bride, the former Miss Anne Lindsay Clark of Boston.

Gustav Bergman, who had been in the undertaking business for more than sixty years, both with his father and independently, died in his home yesterday at the age of 77, after a week's illness. His residence and business were at 51 East Ninetieth Street.

On the desk beside which Senator Berg shot himself yesterday was found a sheaf of mimeographed biographical sketches, of three pages each, and on top of them a hand-written note to newspaper men. The note follows:

The Constitutional Convention tonight approved, by advancing to third reading, the new conservation section of the proposed State Constitution, in which the principal change is that the Legislature is no longer mandated to spend $20,000,000 over an elevenyear period for the acquisition of lands for reforestation purposes.

Amsterdam Ave. 2,380, 100x00 .Charles M. Radice to Fifth Ave Estates, a Corp, 70 Broadway, p m mtg due July 1, 1943, 3-31/2%; $120,000. Broome St, 362-6, 65.1x111.2x irreg; 362 Broome Corp to Central Savings Bank, p m mtg, demand, int per bond, $50,000. Same property, same to same, building loan, pr mtg, $50,000, int per bond, $40.000.
Funeral services for Miss Rowena Long mire, for thirty-two years a member of the faculty of Florida State College for Women, who died early Monday morning, were conducted here yesterday afternoon.

Miss Kitty Wickes of 14 Sutton Place South and Ralph H. Poole Jr. of Lake Forest, Ill., whose engagement was announced in April, obtained a license yesterday at the Municipal Building for their marriage, which will take place the early part of September in Harrison, N. Y.

P. R. Dreyer, Inc., perfume supplies, floor with 18,000 sq ft in 111-19 W 19th St; Abe Fagan, Inc, millinery, floor in 51-7 W 39th St; Max Smilowitz, millinery, in 63 W 38th St; Aaron-Rothchild, millinery, in 49-57 W 37th St; Amor Hat Co, Inc, millinery, through the Cross Brown Co, in 57 W 38th St; Adams Co. Real Estate, Inc, brokers.

Edward Milles Nelson, a leading microscopist whose use of instruments of the highest powers resulted in new discoveries in the extreme limits of microscopic vision, died in Bristol today. He was 87 years old.

With the meeting in Washington this week of leading executives of the steel indutsry, called by the government, the wage question is the dominant issue in considering the future course of steel markets and the matter of profits and losses for steel producers, The Iron Age says in its current summary.

As a primary fault in an otherwise- smooth and satisfactory melodrama, we have Edward G. Robinson being "The Amazing Dr. Clitterhouse" at the Strand. Mr. Robinson plays him well enough,- but hardly as effectively as Sir Cedric Hardwicke did in the play.

Chancellor Hitler's overture to Britain for better relations shaped up yesterday, not as an isolated step but rather as part of a train of conversations that have been carried on for weeks between him and Prime Minister Chamberlain through intermediaries.
The text of the Democratic report on the Reapportionment Bill made tonight to the Constitutional Convention was as follows:

The Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company announced yesterday that it had closed a contract covering the sale of gas to the Kentucky Natural Gas Corporation for resale to the latter company's markets in Indiana and Kentucky.
This hero business is rapidly turning sour to the taste of Douglas G. Corrigan, and he does not want anybody to give him an airplane.

Stabilization of wages paid steel workers was predicted today as representatives of the industry, employes and government officials met in a preliminary conference looking to the setting of pay standards on government contracts.

Turpentine firm, 231/4c; sales, 9 barrels; receipts, 716 barrels;; no shipments; stock, 39,977 barrels. Rosin firm: sales. 577: receipts, 2,762: shipments. 316; stock, 180,320. Quote: B. $3.50; D, $3.85; E, $4.15; F. G, H. I. K. $4.40: M, $4.45; N, $5.25; WG, $5.75; WW, $6.30; X. $6.40.
Refusal of railroad unions to participate in a drastic economy program to save the Rutland Railroad caused an abrupt adjournment of today's session of a hearing in Federal court here.

Sir Samuel Hardman Lever, financing secretary of the British Treasury and chief of the British mission for the purchase of airplanes in Canada, arrived yesterday on the Holland-America liner Nieuw Amsterdam.

Pirates, Buccaneers, Bulldogs, Meteors, Comets and what not held sway on Long Island Sound today. It was the thirteenth annual junior regatta, a part of the Larchmont Yacht Club's Race Week, open to craft skippered and manned by young salts who had not reached their eighteenth birthdays.
Mrs. Helen G. Stelling received a divorce here today from A. Carl Stelling on the ground of cruelty. Under an agreement she received the custody of the couple's two children.
Frnancial circles here were deeply impressed today when they received a report of a private communication sent by the president of the central bank of Chile to the Chilean Minister of Finance.

The Senators came up with base ace. In hits when they were most needed today to back up Wes Ferrell's pitching for a 7-to-2 victory over the Tigers. It was Ferrell's twelfth victory of the season against eight defeats. The game was played in a steady drizzle.

After Long Jim Barnes, a disciple of the old school to whom golf rules were and still are sacred, had completed one of the best rounds he or any one else ever played under conditions similar to those that existed at the Rockville Country Club today, he was informed by officials of the Long Island Golf Association that it was ?? dice."

A transatlantic flier takes out every unnecessary piece of furniture from his plane, reduces his food to a few sandwiches, installs extra fuel tanks, fills these with every drop that they can hold, then barely clears fences and telegraph poles as he slowly climbs into the blue.

The Presbyterian Hospital of New York, which a year ago purchased the seven-acre home of the New York School for the Deaf on Riverside Drive, paid $1,500,000 for the property, according to revenue stamps on the deed of transfer recorded yesterday.

Governor Lehman has written letters to the Mayors of New York, White Plains, New Rochelle and Mount Vernon and the town boards of Pelham, Scarsdale, Rye, Harrison, East Chester and Mamaroneck asking them to submit names for an unofficial committee to consider a plan to restore service on the New York, Westchester Boston Railroad. The railroad suspended service last Dec. 31.

Additional declines in fat grass lambs put most of the crop at $9 downward, only choice 88-pound Washington springers selling at $9.10. Meanwhile, light hogs worked 10 to 15 cents higher, top standing at $10.15, according to the United States Department of Agriculture.
The Class I railroads bought, built or rebuilt 6,260 freight cars in the first six months of the year, against 34,187 in the same period a year ago and 11,604 in the same period two years ago.

Mayor La Guardia delivered his annual lecture on city government yesterday afternoon to nineteen career students who are spending their Summer working in various city departments on city scholarships of $50 a month.

Shooting a remarkable 87 over the raindrenched Wee Burn layout today, Mrs. Henry H. Dietrich, defending champion of Green Meadow, annexed the Elizabeth Wheeler Trophy for the third time as she won the ninth annual women's open golf championship-of Fairfield and Westchester counties with a grand total of 255 strokes for the threeday tournament.

While most manufacturers of home furnishings now showing their Fall lines have not yet completed advertising and promotional plans, indications are that budgets will be somewhat larger than had been expected a month or so ago.
The regulations for the coming waterfowl season, made public in Washington on Monday, seem to have been received by hunters with the usual amount of praise and complaint.

North Amerlean wheat prices were on the downgrade today following a short-lived rally. Buying was not aggressive and trade was light, but sufficient hedging pressure and local selling developed to carry the market off 11/2 cents a bushel from the early high prices, with all deliveries on the Board of Trade here and at Kansas City selling close to the lowest level of the season.

SECOND MILITARY AREA So much of paragraph 3, Special Orders 81, dated June 15, 1938, as pertains to 2d Lt. Wenfoo G. Woo, C.A.-Res., 2,473 Elm P1., New York, N. Y., is revoked. Each of the following Reserve officers, unassigned, is assigned to the organization indicated:

Disregarding adverse weather reports because their vacation funds were running low, two youths from suburban Philadelphia took off in a small monoplane from this airport shortly after noon today and were killed two minutes later when the plane went into a spin near the rising turrets of the Roosevelt Raceway grandstand.

Amishfarmers of East Lampeter Township, Lancaster County, who have fought for a year to retain eleven "little red schoolhouses" as the seats of learning for their children, threatened today to "secede" from the township's school system and set up one of their own.
The Brooklyn deals announced yesterday by brokers principally involved. residential parcels. Several of the buildings were small apartment houses.
A study of the vast new inventory of Manhattan real estate, just completed by the WPA and the Tax Department, discloses some rather surprising data on private dwellings in Manhattan.
Miss Marie Snyder, daughter of Dr. Rex Garfield Snyder of New York, was married to Dr. Ernesto Vallenilla y Diaz of Caracas, Venezuela, here today.

Gross assets, $50,968; net, $45,461. To Minnie L. Owen. Lydia Scheer, Rose Bardo, sisters; Henry Maurer, brother, specific bequests, interests in annuity contract and life estates in one-fourth residue each; sixteen varying bequests.

Thomas Harvey Dougherty Jr., a retired investment banker, died in Bryn Mawr Hospital today of a disease diagnosed as malta faver, a fever contracted from animals. He was 56 years old. His home was Fair Hill. Wayne.
The District Court for the District of Columbia today held unconstitutional a local gross business receipts tax imposed in 1937 on the ground that it was a burden to interstate commerce.

William McIntyre, 40 years old, who described himself as a homeless bookkeeper, was arrested late yesterday afternoon and booked in the East Fifty-first Street police station charged with petit larceny after a young woman store detective had trailed him from Saks Fifth Avenue Store, Fifth Avenue and Fiftieth Street, where he allegedly had stolen a man's suit valued at $85.

The New York Chapter of the Loyal Order of Moose has leased two floors, comprising about 6,000 square feet, in the building at 254-56 West Fifty-fourth Street, through O'Gara Co., Inc., brokers. Upon completion of alterations the new quarters will be used for meeting rooms.
Our favorite neighbors, the Hardys, are visiting again, this time in a felicitous little comedy which goes-and goes delightfully-at the Capitol under the name "Love Finds Andy Hardy."

Mrs. Aninha Carver Livingston and Frederick C. Havemeyer, whose engagement was announced last week by her mother, Mrs. Alexander Burton Carver of 70 Park Avenue, were married secretly on Tuesday in Elkton, Md. The couple are now in Southampton, L. I.

Net assets of $17,418,574 are reported on June 30 by the American Cities. Power and Light Corporation, equivalent to $63.05 a share of both series of class A preferred stock and to 95 cents a share for the class B stock, compared with $15,845,699, or $55.44 a class A share and 26 cents a class B share, on Dec. 31, 1937.

Two airplanes will be among the lots sold at public auction in the Customs Seizure Room, 311 Appraiser's Stores, 201 Varick Street, next Friday at 10 A. M. by order of Collector of Customs Harry M. During, according to an announcement yesterday.
Constance Rourke's study of the Pennsylvania artist Charles Sheeler will be published, with forty-eight illustrations from Mr. Sheeler's work, by Harcourt, Brace on Aug. 11.

George W. DeLanoy, vice president, traffic manager and a director of the Southern Steamship Company, a freight line between Philadelphia and Houston, Texas, and a subsidiary of the Atlantic, Gulf West Indies Steamship Lines, died here last night at his home, 718 Madison Avenue,

Alfredo Salmaggi, director of the New York Hippodrome 'Opera Company, which recently ended a season at the Hippodrome, signed a contract yesterday with officials of the Park Department for the presensation of grand opera at the Randalls Island Stadium.

The plans and work of six years reached fruition yesterday afternoon when the Mercury, smaller unit of the British pickaback aircraft, landed safely on Manhasset Bay at Port Washington to complete its initial crossing of the Atlantic Ocean.

Cooperation of Columbia University with the University of Puerto. Rico in the School of Tropical Medicine, threatened by recent legislation eliminating Columbia's representation on the board of trustees, is to be continued, according to a message received today by Governor Blanton Winship from Frederick Coykendall, chairman of Columbia's board of trustees.

All men's wear fabrics of American Woolen Company were withdrawn at the close of business yesterday and, while company officials were unable to estimate the probable advance likely to be named, it was reported in the market that prices will be reopened at at least 5 cents a yard higher than previous levels.

Albert H. Morgan, superintendent of buildings in the Department of Public Works, who has charge of all the city's buildings, posted notices yesterday that all elevator operators must wear new gray uniforms by Aug. 1.

Probably readers of the official statement made by the Department of Justice in bringing Anti-Trust law suits against the major motion-picture companies were most impressed by its absence of truculent language or imputation of motive.

Two suits for damages totaling $2,622.70 were filed today against Sally Rand, fan and bubble dancer, accusing her of descending into a theatre audience to "maliciously, unlawfully and willfully bite, scratch and tear" at a young couple.

American sales in China will increase rather than diminish as a result of Japanese dominance there, according to Chonosuke Yada, former Japanese consul general in New York and present chairman of a group of fourteen business men who arrived here yesterday in the course of a world tour.
Newark consolidated its already strong hold on the International League lead tonight, ending the Royals' nine-game unbeaten streak with a double victory.
Starting Monday, persons claiming the $100 personal customs exemption on Canadian goods brought into the United States must prove that they have spent at least forty-eight hours in Canada.

Senator Thomas C. Desmond of Newburgh was unanimously endorsed for the Republican nomination for Governor by formal resolution of the Sullivan County Republican Committee tonight at its annual convention here.

The great political enigma of New York is young Thomas E. Dewey, the mass production St. George, who has been mowing down the dragons of the racket at the rate of about one a week. He was elected District Attorney of New York County for a four-year term.

The foremost expert on the subject of the Japanese beetle in the Ministry of Forestry and Agriculture says: "Although the Japanese beetles cause much damage to agricultural products in Japan yearly it is not so great as in America.

For three years the country has heard discussed the pros and cons of the famous "death sentence" clause of the Holding Company Act of 1935. Now, for the first time, the Securities and Exchange Commission is making use of the power granted it in that section of the law.

A further step in reorganizing the State Department was announced today through publication of an executive order signed by President Roosevelt on July 14, establishing "Foreign Service Regulations of the United States."

Tammany's New York County Democratic Executive Committee, met last night at its headquarters, East Seventeenth Street, and designated its candidates for the House of Representatives, State Senate and the Assembly without offering any surprises in its list of designees.

Renting of apartments in buildings in the East and West Side areas of Manhattan continued yesterday and was marked by a good demand for suites in buildings on Fifth and Park Avenues, Riverside Drive and West End Avenue.
Mayor La Guardia was in conference here today with Secretary Ickes and Jesse Jones, RFC chairman, in the interest of the proposed Battery Tunnel Project.
Indiations that the Treasury might seek to broaden the income tax base as a means of reducing the Federal deficit were given today.

Congress by a large majority approved definitely this afternoon a contract between the Costa Rican Government and the United Fruit Company to develop the banana industry on the Pacific Coast. The industry for many, ears, has been confined to the Atlantic coast.
The Democrats of the Constitutional Convention have decided not to present a counter proposal of their own for a new Senate and Assembly district map. Instead,
Mrs. Katherine Mackay O'Brien, daughter of Clarence H. Mackay, was married this evening to Robert Zeimer Hawkins, Reno lawyer, a few hours after plans for the wedding had been announced.

All maritime labor unions must be prepared to cooperate against "reactionary" groups of employers, Joseph Curran, general organizer of the National Maritime Union, declared yesterday at the fourth national convention of the American Communications Association at the Hotel Victoria.

For the first time within the memory of school officials, a situation has arisen in which the Board of Education will be called to order for three special meetings within a ten-minute period this afternoon.

Substantial gains last week in nearly all lines of economic activity advanced the index of business in the Pittsbrugh district to the highest levels since late April, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh.

A revised Federal-State milk marketing agreement designed to fix minimum prices to be paid to milk producers was scheduled today to be submitted to New York's dairymen for rejection or approval by Aug. 15.
Six Jews were murdered in Northern Palestine and three in Southern Palestine today by Arab brigands, who have again resumed operations throughout the country after a brief period of inactivity.

Fred Wolcott, Rice Institute's sensational hurdler, paced the touring United States track and field forces today as the invaders again took five out of seven events on the second day of the international meet.

Investors in railway stocks received today a severe blow from the Southern Railway Company which, with a total capital of [Pound]114,102,400, halved its preferred interim dividend to 1 per cent, compared with 2 per cent this time last year, and at the same time revealed its net revenue had fallen [pound]574,000 as costs had increased [pound]456,000.

A tale of how speakers who discussed met Vermont's venerable quarries are improving being outsold at their very backdoors by bustling young Southern rivals was unfolded today at the Interstate Commerce Commission's freight-rate hearing in this city.

Supporting his conviction that checkers is a game to be played scientifically, or not at all, Milton Loew, 14 years old, "checker prodigy" of the Bronx, won the city championship yesterday in the annual tournament of the Park Department.

With the increase in lumber production last week greater than seasonal, the adjusted index was raised to 67.5, its highest point this year. For the previous week it was 61.2 and 102.7 for the corresponding one last year.
Yugoslavia took a 2-0 lead over Belgium today in the opening singles matches of the semi-final round of the European zone Davis Cup competition.

Mr. and Mrs. James N. Wallace gave a dinner tonight at their home for Miss Phyllis B. Thompson and Commander Jerauld Wright, U. S. N., whose marriage will take place here Saturday noon in St. Andrew's Dune Church.

The partial defeat of Brazil in her recent trade war with Germany illustrates the difficulties faced by the agricultural countries of Latin America and Eastern Europe in resisting German economic penetration.

Miss Jean Bauer of Providence, R. I., defeated Miss Virginia Guilfoil of Syracuse, N. Y., on the twenty-first hole in the semi-final round of match Play in the women's international golf tournament on the Hotel Champlain golf course today.
Arthur W. Cowles, who for twenty-six years was chief of the United States Patent Office, died at his home today after an illness of several months. His age was 78.

The Lehigh Power Securities Corporation, New York City, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an application for an order de- Tw claring the Mauch Chunk Heat, Nort Power and Electric Light Company, Mauch Chunk, Pa., not to be a subsidiary of Lehigh Power Securities, the National Power and Light Company or the Electric Bond and in R Share Company.

William Kilcullen, who has written a couple of plays, though not for Broadway, has bought the rights to Stanley Young's "Bright Rebel" and expects to produce it here early in the Fall. John Cromwell will have the role of Byron.

Warners cabled their London office Criterion today, today seeking to open negotiations End" enters its with Dr. Sigmund Freud to bring the psychologist to Hollywood to aid in the preparation of "Dark Victory," in which Bette Davis will star.

In conducting its seventy-second year of continuous water service for horses in the city, the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals appealed yesterday to the public to refrain from throwing litter into the granite water fountains which the society operates, in addition to auxiliary water troughs and pail service.

A sincere compliment one can pay to autocratic governments is that they put on effective parades. Democracies sometimes seem too loose-jointed for that sort of thing. Yet when they take the pains to dress up they can stage a show that would be good box-office anywhere.

Police Commissioner Valentine said yesterday that no action was contemplated against Inspector Louis F. Schilling, commander of the Third Division in midtown Manhattan, in whose territory an alleged gambling establishment was raided Wednesday.

At 2 A. M. yesterday a party of d motor-cyclists was riding the wind- r ing roadway of Interboro Parkway a near the Brooklyn-Queens line when f the motor-cycle of Robert Jordan, f 33-year-old motor-cycle agent, of r 1,269 Bushwick Avenue, Brooklyn, skidded, hit the curb and the railing and fell back in the road after Jordan had been catapulted about fifty feet. He was killed instantly.

Playing through a rainstorm, Dr. J. H. Harris today won the New York Athletic Club golf tournament at the Canoe Brook Country Club with a score of 79. Dr. R. L. Blackmon was second, two strokes behind, and Bob Goffe third with 84.

Bank clearings in twenty-two leading cities of the United States for the week ended on Wednesday were $5,368,845,000, against $5,715,380,000 in the corresponding week last year, a drop of 6.1 per cent, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. Clearings for the latest period were $372,186,000 above those for the week ended on July 13.

Twenty-three men, including Lieutenant Governor Frank Hayes, Mayor of Waterbury, pleaded not guilty to charges of conspiring to defraud the city of more than $1,000,000 when they were arraigned in Superior Court today before Judge Ernest A. Inglis. All except one chose a jury trial.
A newwork program for the rural South to add 200,000 to the Works Progress Administration employes in that area was announced today by Harry L. Hopnkins, Administrator.

The Congressional committee investigating the Tennessee Valley Authority impounded this afternoon all the minutes of the TVA board of directors since the first meeting on July 16, 1933, and a special file of "changed" minutes, consisting of the original and altered versions of the records of fifteen or twenty board meetings.
The pound sterling turned down again in the foreign exchange market yesterday and led most of the other currencies with it toward cheaper prices.

Rain yesterday again washed out the scheduled double-header between the Yankees and Indians at the Stadium. Twin bills have been arranged for the teams Aug. 25, 26 and 27, the next time the Indians visit New York.

The session of the Supreme Soviet (Legislature) final of the Russian Socialist Federated Soviet Republic, which began last Friday, ended yesterday with the election of the Council of Commissars of this, the largest, republic in the Soviet Union.

The War Department awarded the Mackay trophy today to two Army Air Corps officers, Captains Carl J. Crane and George V. Holloman, for developing "the first entirely automatic landing in aviation history" at Wright Field, Dayton, Ohio."
The Czechoslovak Fascist party, which has six representatives in Parliament, has decided to join the other Czech parties in the defense of the republic.

Emanuel Weitz, for the last four years night circulation manager of THE NEW YORK TIMES, died of a heart attack yesterday in Ellenville, N. Y., while on vacation, according to word received here last night.
Richard Henry Swartwout, retired broker, who was former chairman of the board of the Fisk Rubber Company, died tonight in Southampton. Hospital following an appendicitis operation. Mr. Swartwout,

Charged by his former adjutant with drunkenness and conduct unbecoming an officer. Lieut. Col. Stewart S. Giffin, U. S. A., went on trial yesterday before a twelveofficer general court-martial at Governors Island, with dismissal from the service the mandatory

Count Court Haugwitz-Reventlow, Danish nobleman, and his wife, the former Barbara Hutton, were reported reliably tonight to be seeking a quiet, private separation. This could be transformed into a divorce by certain legal steps.

Contract awards for engineering construction this week, with $45,035,000, are 47 per cent higher than in the corresponding period of last year, when lettings totaling $30,695,000 were made, according to The Engineering News-Record.

With Versailles for a background, King George, on this next to the last day of his visit to France, saw a cross-section of the modern French Army and then, together with Queen Elizabeth, witnessed how Louis XIV might have; entertained them. It was the strangest contrast that could have been imagined.
Mrs. Mary McCormick Farrell, wife of Eugene W. Farrell Sr., died last night from a heart attack at her Summer home in Spring Lake, where she had lived for the last forty-one years.

Seventeen - year - old Melvin Schwartzman, recent graduate of Poly Prep and winner of the private school championship for the past two years, scored the greatest tennis triumph of his brief career when he eliminated Frank Shields, eleventh ranking player in the country, from the Eastern clay court title tournament yesterday.

Sales of securities in odd lots on the New Yark Stock Exchange exceeded purchases by 52,544 shares in the week ended on July 16, but the value of the securities bought was grater than that of those sold by $276,968, the Securities and Exclange Commission reported today.

The division of the technical staff of the Bureau of Internal Revenue designated for duty in New York will open offices in the new Federal office building at 90 Church Street on Aug. 1, the Treasury announced today.

William E. Carey, president and treasurer of the Schenley Distributors of New England, Inc., and formerly president of the old Eastern Baseball League, died Wednesday night at his home, 1,180 Beacon Street, Brookline, Mass., according to word received here last night.
Fire, sabotage and heat wrought havoc and tragedy in the Pacific Northwest today. Scores of fires raged across the region, which in some spots was almost bone dry.

The Federal Surplus Commodities Corporation said today it would buy about 1,000,000 barrels of wheat flour for States to distribute to families on relief. The corporation in the last two months has bought 2,902,225 barrels of wheat products, including flour and cereal, at a cost of $11,751,000.

Corporation Counsel of towns and cities of Westchester County formerly served by the New York, Westchester Boston Railway were notified today that the Federal District Court in New York would hear an application on July 29 by majority bondholders of the company for immediate foreclosure of the mortgage bonds.

India has a great opportunity to better its trade at the present time because many world markets are closed, James A. Keillor, vice president of B. Altman Co., asserted last night at a dinner meeting of the Indo-American Association of Commerce at the Aldine Club, 200 Fifth Avenue. However,

The quality of salesmanship of silk producers "has deteriorated badly in the last ten years," A. J. Fuqua, piece goods buyer of A. Harris Co., Dallas, asserted yesterday morning at a Fashion and Silk Merchandise Forum held at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria under the auspices of the International Silk Guild, Inc.

A group of bondholders of the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railroad offered evidence to the Interstate Commerce Commission today in support of their proposal for reorganization procedure which would wipe out present stock holdings in the company.
North China's rainy season has arrived with a record downpour that is swelling rivers and canals, causing fears of devastating floods.
Morris Michtom, toy manufacturer, died yesterday morning at his home, 180 Winthrop Street, Brooklyn, after a long illness. He was 68 yearsold.
It is officially announced that about one-third of the Jewish property in Austria has been "Aryanized," partly confiscated.
The opening-day program of the Jersey Shore Horse Show was conducted successfully today at Boxwood Farm despite several deluges which threatened to wipe out the competition.

Mayor La Guardia will lead the third annual "sky-parade" of the Inter-American Escadrille, consisting of twenty-one planes representing each of the American republics, tomorrow, according to an announcement by Commander Alfredo de los Rios.

Hector, Giron consul general of Guatemala, pointed out yesterday that a law referred to in a dispatch last Monday, with reference to restriction of ownership to Guatemalans of all lands within ten miles of the frontiers, was not new and had been in force or "many years."

Colonel Robert Phinney, U.S.A., of Fort Logan, Denver, and Mrs. Phinney have announced to friends here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sarah Kathleen Phinney of this city, to Frederic McMichael Kirkland, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic R. Kirkland of Wynnewood, Pa.

John Stevenson Jr., associate of Andrew Carnegie and the man who negotiated the first steel merger and who once moved a mansion, brick by brick, for twenty miles as a gesture of reprisal after a dispute with torn officials, died last night at his Summer estate at Beaumaris, Ont. He was 90 years old.
Stroke by stroke the golfing natators competing in the Long Island open championship are steadily approaching the finish line.

The Associated Investing Corporation asked today the Securities and Exchange Commission to adjourn the hearing on the proposal to have Utilities Power and Light Corporation, Ltd., use 12,000,000 of its funds to buy debentures of its parent, Utilities Power and Light Corporation, in view of the action of the commission yesterday in calling a hearing for Aug. 8 to formulate a plan for the integration of the latter.

The general level of wholesale prices rose in the week ended on July 16, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The bureau's index, based on the 1926 average, was 78.9, compared with 78.3 on July 9 and 87.8 on July 17, 1937.

The owner of the pistol with which State Senator Julius S. Berg shot himself was being traced yesterday by detectives of the Homicide Squad at the request of District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey's office.

The city, in cooperation with the WPA, will use the ferryboats Murray Hill and City of Queens for daily recreational trips for children and for mothers and babies during the Summer, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday.
W. Stanley Grinsted, supervisor of the safe-keeping department of the new Federal Reserve Bank, died at his home here today at the age of 42.
Isadore Bellis, University of Pennsylvania star and defending champion, won his way into the semifinal round of the Pennsylvania State junior tennis tournament
Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins and A. D. Lewis return today on the United States liner Washington from the International Labor Office Conference held in Geneva last month.

Clipperton Island, 675 miles off Acapulco, Mexico, was examined in the interests of science and navigation today by members of President Roosevelt's party, while the Chief Executive added to his laurels as a fisherman.
Commander Charles E. Rosendahl issued a statement tonight reiterating that "in general" he believed the export of helium could be satisfactorily controlled to restrict it to non-military uses.

The Census Bureau reports that 111,681 tons of flaxseed were crushed in 3 the quarter ended on June 30, produring 77,513,277 pounds of linseed oil, compared with 144,709 tons crushed and 100,118,519 pounds of oil produced in the corresponding period last year.

The Rev. William Devlin, S. J., Catholic educator and executive, former rector of St. Ignatius Loyola Church in New York City, former president and dean of Boston College and rector of the Novitiate of St.

Correspondence introduced at a hearing before the Senate Civil Liberties Committee indicates that a public relations firm retained by the Republic Steel Corporation attempted to influence Birmingham newspapers to take a "correct" view regarding that company's labor problems and its attitude toward the C. I. O.

Professor Richard M. Smith of the Harvard Medical School, one of America's best known physicians, was elected chairman of the Committee of Physicians yesterday at the first annual meeting of the committee at the Cornell Medical College on York Avenue.

The Right Rev. Mgr. Joseph Corrigan, rector of the Catholic University, Washington, arrived yesterday on the Italian liner Rex after a visit to Vatican City where he was received on July 12 by the Pope, whom he found "remarkably well and almost as strong as ever."

Charles P. Howard, president of the International Typographical Union, died of a heart attack in the Hotel Antlers here tonight. He was 58 years old. His body was found in his room by his wife, Mrs. Margaret Howard.

Deep mud reduced all of the fields through scratches yesterday at Empire City but did not prevent Jockey Carroll Bierman from getting a double, one of his winners being Early Autumn, who was first in the featured Mount Pleasant Handicap.
The appointment of David Frankel, sales manager and stylist of the Goodall Company, makers of Palm Beach clothing, as vice president of the organization was announced here yesterday. Mr.

Mrs. Minnie De Long Illingworth, widow of Robert H. Illingworth, who was vice president of the Crucible Steel Company at his death in 1922, died at her home here today after a long illness. Born in Jersey City,

As a result of the sharply increased advertising campaigns launched on Palm Beach clothing last week, sales of this product have increased, stocks are being reduced rapidly and reorders are coming into the factory, Arthur Goodfriend, associated with L. S. Goldsmith of the L. C. Gumbinner Agency, handling the account, reported yesterday.

Arbitration of the agrarian land controversy, involving the expropriation of American-owned lands in Mexico over more than a decade, was proposed by the United States in a strong note delivered by Secretary of State Cordell Hull today to Francisco Castillo Najera, the Mexican Ambassador. While dealing specifically with the agrarian question, the note by clear implication extended also to the oil disputes.

A Kings County jury which reported that it was hopelessly deadlocked in the robbery case of Harry Schechtman, 32 years old, of 1,336 Fiftieth Street, Brooklyn, was rebuked yesterday by Judge William O'Dwyer for failing to return a verdict of guiltY.

Relief Pitcher Dutch Leonard doubled in the ninth and scored his own winning run on Rookie George Case's single today, enabling the Senators to sweep a three-game series with the Tigers by winning the finale, 4 to 3.

Joseph H. Hayden, secretary of the Hewitt Rubber Corporation of Buffalo, has been elected a member of the board of directors of the company, according to Thomas Robins Jr., president. William S. Carleton and Lester D. Bigelow have been elected vice presidents.

Dr. John Edgar Bowman, for forty years head of the Bowman Sanitarium here, died at his home on Stanwich Road tonight at the age of 79. He had been ill for two years and had been confined to his home for the last eight months.

Chancellor Hitler's special emissary to London, Captain Fritz Wiedemann, renewed assurances "already given by the German Government of its desire to achieve a peaceful settlement of outstanding questions," Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain told the House of Commons today.

Close of play scores today in English county cricket matches started yesterday follow: Gloucestershire 487 for five declared (Emmet 165 not out, Allen 98, Crapp 80); Surrey 286 for six (Gregory 81); at Bristol.

The Board of Estimate, at a meeting in City Hall yesterday, authorized the issuance of $937,835 in serial bonds to pay the city's share of the cost of four PWA projects for which the government has allowed grants totaling $794.115.

Former Mayor James J. Walker of New York City filed suit here today to regain possession of a carved wooden plaque presented to him by Dr. Carlos Miguel de Cespedes, former Secretary of Public Works of the Republic of Cuba, when Mr. Walker was Mayor in 1927.

Stocks eased. and closed steady and mixed, after gains of 1 to 2 points, motion-picture shares continued weak; turnover, 1,811,805 shares. Corporation and United States Government bonds irregularly higher, rails strong, movie and Polish bonds weak; transactions, $10,076,500.

The captain and three members of the crew of the eighty-one-foot cruiser Sazarac received severe burns today following an explosion in the yacht's engine room while it was cruising in Long Island Sound off Faulkner's Island, near here.
Three gunmen walked into the First National Bank here this noon, fled hastily when a girl teller sounded an alarm, but had scooped $10,000 from the cash tills before they escaped.

Ray Hanken, husky end from George Washington, and Orville Tuttle, former Oklahoma City University guard, have sent in their contracts to play with the New York Football Giants this Fall, it was announced yesterday by John V. Mara, president of the National League club.

Domninion Government and chartered bank deposits and reserve 36 in sterling and United States dollars with the Bank of Canada all recorded increases last week, it was reported today in the bank's weekly statement. Dominion Government and chartered bank deposits in- 9% creased $730,000 and $1,193,000 re- 73 spectively and sterling and United States dollars were up $2,770,000.

Charges by Republican legislative leaders that Democratic political workers rather than relief clients were getting preference in WPA employment were discredited, so far as Trenton is concerned, in a report on the local situation submitted today to the Unemployment Relief Commission by Chester I. Barnard, who directed an investigation.

Charges that the defense in the Harlan County conspiracy case resorted to perjured testimony, bought and paid for on the installment plan with the connivance of one of the attorneys in the case, were made today from the witness stand before Federal Judge H. Church Ford and a jury which has heard 595 witnesses since the trial opened May 16.

The trial record in the recent conviction of six directors of the German-American Settlement League at Riverhead, L. I., was submitted yesterday to United States Attorney Michael F. Walsh of Brooklyn for study as to whether there is ground for revocation of their naturalizetion papers.

The Federal Surplus Commodities Corporation spent approximately $54,000,000 in fiscal year just closed to divert price-depressing crop surpluses from regular commercial channels, the Agricultural Adjustment Administration announced today.
Following is the text of the Chaco Peace Treaty signed by Bolivia and Paraguay in Buenos Aires today, as given out by the State Department:
On dull days Rex II had nothing much to do except to lie on the sidewalk outside the "house" at165 East Fifty-first Street and be petted by the firemen of Engine Company 8.

An order for 125 forty-passenger single-deck motor coaches powered with Diesel engines and having automatic hydraulic transmissions has been received by the Yellow Truck and Coach Manufacturing Company of Pontiac.

A banking group composed of Blyth Co., Inc.,-the Citizens State Bank of Sheboygan, and Harley, Hayden Co. received yesterday the award of a new issue of $180,000 of highway improvement bonds- of Ashland County, Wis., on a bid of 105.10 for 3s. The bonds will mature on May 1, 1940 to 1943.

The Constitutional Convention approved today by advancing to third reading the proposal of Attorney General Bennett, which would make the present pension systems of the State and all localities in the State a contractual obligation, starting Jan. 1, 1940.

Sunshine, filtering through scattered heavy clouds, brought a few hours of pleasant relief late yesterday afternoon to 200,000 or more men, women and boys and girls who for five days have been rainbound in muddy and flooded Summer camps in the Palisades. Interstate Park and other near-by recreation centers.

Playing to a draw with Jack W. Collins of Brooklyn in the ninth round, David S. Polland, the titleholder, also of Brooklyn, regained the lead in the annual open championship tournament of the American Chess Federation at the Hotel Touraine tonight.

With the production of 15,000 garments scheduled for the first year, completion of plans whereby recently organized Consumer Wholesale Clothiers, Inc., will assume management of the "co-op" garment factory now in operation at the Jersey Homestead, Federal housing project near Hightstown, N. J., was announced here yester- fourth day of day. R. N. Benjamin,
Representative Jerry 'J. O'Connell, Democrat,. victor in t?e first district--primary race for renomination, held a lead of 6,293 votes today over his nearest opponent in the final unofficial figures.
The desperate plight of the Rutland Railroad was held up to the railroad brotherhoods today as an example of the peril facing all other American railroads and their 914,000 workers.

Newspaper readers accustomed to getting late editions early had an unexpected treat last evening, when copies of British papers of the day before, carried here aboard the British transatlantic pick-a-back plane Mercury, were put on sale at points in midtown.

As a result of the impetus given to the men's clothing field by the government's $10,000,000 purchasing" plan for surplus stocks, New York manufacturers are now working at 70 per cent of capacity, Julius Levy, secretary of the New York Clothing Manufacturers Exchange, reported- here yesterday.
Bobby Locke, youthful South African professional, today won the Irish Open golf championship with a seventy-two hole score of 292.
COLORADO SPRINGS, Col., June Snow and hail ranging up to ten inches in depth blanketed the upper slopes of Pikes Peak today, the worst Summer storm in years.

The Federal Surplus Commodities Corporation reported today that it spent $54,000,000 in the last twelve months to divert surplus farm products into relief channels, export markets and new domestic markets.
There was a southwest clearing blow that hauled west and churned up white-splashed water for the resumption of the Larchmont Yacht Club Race Week competition today.

The General Foods Corporation reports for the second quarter of 1938 net earnings of $2,817,851 after provision for dividends on the new $4.50 cumulative preferred stock which was issued on May 9, this year.

Rate revisions that would provide uniformity in New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Delaware, Maryland and Virginia and add almost $21,000,000 to annual gross revenues of $225,000,000 were sought by -Middle Atlantic States truck- operators here today at a hearing before the Interstate Commerce Commission.

Defending Champion Wilson Flohr of Canoe Brook today reached the second round in the fourteenth annual New Jersey State junior golf title tournament. Flohr defeated Fred Rowe of Bloomfield, 7 and 6, this afternoon after capturing the qualifying medal this morning over the Echo Lake Country Club course with a 76.

Four six-round bouts will precede the fifteen-round encounter between Henry Armstrong and Lou Ambers for the lightweight championship of the world at the Polo Grounds on Aug. 10. In the semifinal Salvy Saban, hard-hitting Greenwich Village welterweight,

Mrs. Alice Offmeister Cassidy Whaley, 33 years old, a waitress, of Linden was held in $1,000 for the grand jury today in the Union County Domestic Relations Court and and her four stepchildren were committed to the custody of the State Board of Children's Guardians after she was accused of burning one of the children, Eleanor, 12, by holding her on a hot radiator. The formal complaint,

After living with cannibalistic natives of Dutch New Guinea in one of the last remaining "frontier areas" of the world for two months, S. Dillon Ripley, a zoologist with the Denison-Crocket expedition, returned here yesterday with more than 1,250 tropical birds.

Carl T. Steiner, an assistant engineer in the Queens Highway Department, became an unwilling hero yesterday morning when Borough President George U. Harvey singled him out for praise at exercises opening the $1,500,000 extension of Beach Channel Drive bordering Jamaica Bay from Beach 116th Street to the Marine Parkway Bridge.
Bernard H. Kroger, who founded the Kroger Grocery and Baking Company, died tonight of a heart attack at his Summer home at Wianno, Mass., on Cape Cod. He was 78 years old.

Speaking to 200 ecclesiastical assistants of Italian Catholic Action associations the Pope today renewed the condemnation he uttered Friday of exaggerated nationalism, extending it this time to all racist theories and all separatist formulas.

Douglas G. Corrigan's now famous nine-yearold plane is on its way back to the United States, and the flier himself plans to sail for New York on the liner Manhattan from Queenstown, Ireland, July 30. [He is to arrive here Aug. 4.]

Tenement houses without elevators-mostly "old-law" multi-family houses-still outnumber the elevator apartment buildings in Manhattan by more than ten to one, despite the fact that in recent years the number of new residential buildings erected with elevators has exceeded the new "walk-ups" in this borough.

The best information now available is that steel prices will not be changed in the near future and probably not for several months, and this is true both with respect to prices as such and to the maintenance of uniform prices at virtually all basing points. In fact,

To take effect 8 A. M., July 22: PATROLMEN Patrick J. Daly, from office of the police commissioner to Emergency Service Division, assignment to duty in plain clothes discontinued. Stephen Sullivan, from 18th Precinct to 80th Precinct.

Although the dressed beef market was reported sluggish, De the live cattle trade ruled generally strong Eli to 25 cents higher, due to small runs and Eli consequent competition. Prime steers such Es as sold up to $13 Wednesday were absent, but choice to prime light offerings made Ga $12.50, the United States Department of Agriculture reports. Ligh hogs worked higher, heavy butchers sold off. Lambs strengthened.

Activities of the Federal Government in purchasing clothing stocks from manufacturers for distribution to the destitute were discussed yesterday by the executive committee of the Nationl Retail Dry Goods Association in a conference with Corrington Gill, assistant national administrator of the WPA.

Moriz Rosenthal, the eminent Polish pianist, was the soloist at last night's concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at Lewisohn Stadium. Massimo Freccia was the conductor. Because of the uncertain weather the audience was not large. The same program will be repeated tonight if it does not rain.

Jerome N. Frank, member of the Securities and Exchange Commission, appealed today to the Interstate Commerce Commission to increase the $16,000 compensation awarded him for special legal services on behalf of the Missouri Pacific Railroad by $25,821.

The ten best French chefs combined their culinary skill today to fete King George and Queen Elizabeth. The result, something to marvel at, was the gastronomic highlight of the royal visit of state. Served in the brilliant Hall of Mirrors of Louis XIV in Versailles Palace, it made every French restaurateur and gourmet sigh with envy.

Six Main Street buildings were burnedat 12:30 A. M. today, causing the death of one man, injuring nineteen persons, thirteen of whom were firemen, and damages estimated by Fire Chief James L. Brett at $200,000.

Lee Handley clouted a booming triple to right field with the bases 'loaded in the ninth inning today to give the Pirates a 5-to-4 victory over the Phillies, thereby keeping the Bucs a game and a half in front in the National League race.

Princess Beatrix left today for her first trip to a foreign country. Her parents took her by automobile to Germany for a threeweek visit at Heilgendamm, on the Baltic coast, country seat of the Grand Duke of Mecklemburg, Princess Juliana's cousin.

Members of the executive council of the International Wool Publicity and Research Fund, formed to advance the interests of producers in Australia, New Zealand and South Africa, have returned from a tour of Germany.

Sales of flats in scattered sections of Manhattan were announced yesterday by brokers, who reported plans for modernizing some of the buildings. An alteration will be made in the Chelsea section, where the three and four story buildings at 202 and 204 West Nineteenth Street were sold by the 216 West Twentieth Street Corporation to the Seventh Chelsea Corporation, representing Philip E. Goldfein and Julius Perlbinder.

Railroad bonds continued strong yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Fractional to 4-point gains ruled over a broad list of carrier issues, while a few selected loans rose 5 and 6 points in fairly active dealings.
General tor Vuillemin, chief of staff of the French air force, is going to visit Germany. The announcement evokes no surprise here because on his visit to France last year Lieut. Gen. Erhard Milch,

Regarding rumors of the alleged resignation of Edward Johnson as general manager of the Metropolitan Opera Association, the following statement was made yesterday by Paul D. Cravath, president of the association:
The body of Samuel Insull, former Chicago utilities head, who died Saturday, will be sent to London tomorrow for burial either tomorrow or Saturday in the Putney Vale Cemetery.

Spanish Government war bulletins reported tonight that Italians fighting with the Insurgents had broken defense lines northwest of Viver, thirty-four miles northwest of Valencia. Advices from Valencia said the attackers were held from entering the town when the defending militiamen laid down a heavy barrage.
Death Announced Retired fireman William A. Mann (1), formerly a member of Engine Co. 265, residing at 129 Third St., Troy, N. Y., died July 15.
Following is the text of the note delivered by Secretary of State Cordell Hull today on the agrarian controversy with Mexico to Francisco Castillo Najera, the Mexican Ambassador to the United States:

The Gatineau Power Company 6 per cent debentures, called for payment on July 29, may be presented beginning today to any of the paying agents for immediate payment at the full redemption price and interest to July 29.

Sears, Roebuck Co. report sales for the sixth Royal Baking period of the fiscal year, June 20 Brands product to July 16, at $35,901,536, against $42,035,960 in the same period in and 1937, a decrease of $6,134,424, or the 14.6 per cent.

Mrs. Charles S. Penwarden of 761 Carroll Street, Brooklyn, vice president of the Chiropean Club, died on Tuesday after a short illness at the home of her sister, Miss Elizabeth Whitney of Honesdale, Pa.
Leon K. Stevens, inventor and former consultant on steam apparatus installations on battleships and commercial buildings, died here yesterday at his home after a long illness. His age was 69.
A treaty of peace and friendship between Bolivia and Paraguay, terminating their Chaco dispute, was signed here this afternoon.

At long last Paraguay and Bolivia have agreed to accept a frontier in the Chaco which is still to be fixed by arbitration. It is easy to understand the gratification of Secretary Hull at this settlement, which he hails as "an outstanding triumph for the spirit of peace and the principles of order based on law over the doctrine of force and aggression."

An investing client of Seymour M. Tannenbaum, attorney, has purchased from the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company the two-story apartment building with stores on the northwest corner of Wilson and Bedford Avenues, Bellmore, L. I.

Max Marston of Philadelphia, defending the Marston-Shenecossett Trophy he has wont seven times, today fired a 76 on a rain-soaked, wind-swept course to share in a triple tie for the medal in the qualifying round of the nineteenth annual Shenecossett men's invitation golf tournament.

Visiting Swedish royalty spent a E day of varied engagements yesterday, with Crown Prince Gustaf Adolf and Crown Princess Louise filling a number of social engagements and Prince Bertil visiting police headquarters to study the methods of the criminal line-up.

A small band of eight hardy women golfers braved a drenching rain today to venture forth over the fairways of the Bonnie Briar Country Club course in the weekly one-day tournament of the Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association, with Mrs. Edward Stevens of Round Hill coming home with 43, 42-85, a remarkable score under the circumstances.

The Committee for Industrial Organization has won more collective bargaining elections under the National Labor Relations Act than has the American Federation of Labor, were according to a report made today by the NLRB.

Desperately short of provisions and water the 82-ton brigantine, Florence C. Robinson, commanded by Captain Donald McCuish of Gloucester, Mass., with a crew of six Ceylonese and Alexis Doster Jr. of Lichfield, Conn., put in here today after a forty-one-day voyage from Gibraltar.

Harrison, Collector of Internal Revenue, moved today to collect more than $400,000 from Harley L. Clarke, deposed head of the $169,000,000 Utilities Power and Light Corporation, and his wife, Mrs. Hildur Clarke. The amount is alleged to be due as income taxes for 1924 and 1925, plus interest and penalties thereon.
The first padlocking of a private home in this Province for alleged cummunistic activities took place today at an apartment occupied by F. X. Lessard.

Twenty-eight Spanish Sisters of the Sacred Heart--all who were left in war-torn Barcelona--will reach a sanctuary in England tomorrow as the result of the combined humanitarian efforts of Ambassador Joseph P. Kennedy, Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain, Viscount Halifax, Foreign Secretary, and the British Navy.

Many music lovers of the Summer colony gathered tonight at Chateau SurMer, home of the Misses Edith and Maude Wetmore, for the second in the series of chamber music concerts given under the direction of Mrs. Lewis A. Armistead.

Mrs. Adele Naidoff, 53 years old, the proprietor of a dress shop on the eleventh floor of the Columbia Broadcasting System Building at 485 Madison Avenue, was found dead yesterday in her office. She had hanged herself from the transom of a door, according to detectives of the East Fifty-first Street station.

Bernard H. Christenson, Town Councilman of North Castle and advertising executive of the New York woolen goods firm of S. Stein Co., died last night at his home near here. He was 52 years old and had been ill four months.

Automotive News, noting the closing of several plants, today estimated this week's output of the motor-car industry at 30,185 units, compared with 39,957 a week ago and 89,989 in the comparable week last year.

The German catapult seaplane Nordmeer left the Azores yesterday at 4 P. M., New York time, and is expected at the Pan American Airways base in Port Washington at about 9 o'clock this morning, according to reports last night.
Attorney General David T. Wilentz today urged United States Senator John Milton, Jersey City lawyer, to become a candidate for the Democratic nomination to succeed himself.

Jersey City walloped the Bisons, 18 to 1, tonight and squared the series. Scoring their second victory of the trip, the Little Giants made twenty-three safeties, good for thirty-five bases. Only Myatt failed to get more than one hit.

During the week ended July 20 member bank reserve balances decreased $71,000,000. Reductions in member bank reserves arose from increases of $96,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve Banks and $6,000,000 in Treasury cash and a decrease of $11,000,000 in Reserve bank credit, offset in part by decreases of $11,000,000 in money in circulation and $21,000,000 in nonmember deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts and an increase of $10,000,000 in gold stock.

Owen Wister, the novellit, who has spent the last several Simmers here, died today less than tvo weeks after his arrival for the season at his Summer home, Crowfeld. Seventy-eight years old, he suffered a cerebral hemorrhage yesterday.
William Boyd, former vice president of the Curtis Publishing Company, who died in 1937, left an estate of $1,000,000 to his immediate family, it was disclosed in Orphans Court today.

The engagement of Miss Jane Burr Dailey, daughter of Mrs. William J. Dailey of 720 Riverside Drive and the late Mr. Dailey, to Donald Schoeffel Frost, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick A. Frost of Rochester, N. Y., has been announced by her mother.

OLD ORCHARD BEACH, Me., The Grand Circuit, held back by rain three days running, managed to run off eight of twelve scheduled dashes today, including a 2:001/2 one-half mile by the pacer Lone Ace, before being washed out.
The report of the Southern California Edison Company Ltd., for the twelve months to June 30, issued yesterday, shows a net income after operating expenses, taxes and charges, of $11,451,011.

Queen Marie left Sina?a for the last time this morning and amid the thunder of guns of the Bucharest garrison and the tolling of church bells her coffin was carried to Cotroceni Palace, where she will lie in state until Sunday when she will be placed in the royal mausoleum beside King Ferdinand.

Taking issue with the suggestion of James Marshall, president of the Board of Education, that teachers be assigned to administrative posts on a rotating basis, the Board of Superintendents has countered with the recommendation to create thirty new positions, totaling nearly $120,000 in annual salary.

It is beginning to appear that the Freeport Tuna Club's open invitation tuna derby is going to be quite an affair, and now the rumor has it that the World's Fair for 1939is going to have a hand in the contest.

The sale of an apartment house in Bayonne featured the deals in New Jersey realty reported yesterday. The twenty-four family house at 44-46 West Thirty-third Street was bought by the Harmin Realty Corporation for investment from the Greenfeld Realty Company, through Julius A. Rose, Inc., brokers.

VINCENT SHEEAN'S new novel, "A Day of Battle,"* is a spirited pageant costumed in the period of Louis XV, yet written as a parable for a later day. It is a grand story - though it has more of the velocity of a good novel than the weight, or the invention. It is,

Thomas Mellon of Pittsburgh entertained at dinner last evening in the Royal Palm Roof of the Biltmore. Among his guests were Mr. and Mrs. Harlow Merryday, Mr. and Mrs. Arthur W. Macpherson, Mr. and Mrs. Andre E. Gross and Mrs. Walker G. Park.

Several large residential properties in lower Westchester County were involved in the deals in that section announced yesterday. Mrs. Esther Caplin, widow of the late Harry Caplin, president of the Union Card and Paper Company, sold the eleven-room house- with three baths, at 65 Winfield Avenue, Mount Vernon, to Max Pestronk, president of the Post Manufacturing Company.

A rise of $1 a bale occurred in prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday as a result of three days of consecutive heavy rains in several important producing States. After touching 8.47 cents a pound on Monday, October advanced to 8.85 cents and the list ended with gains of 14 to 15 points.

Despite payments of more than $30,000,000 in inheritance taxes to New Jersey and Pennsylvania after several years' litigation, the value of the estate of Dr. John T. Dorrance, late president and founder of the Campbell Soup Company of

John Chester Warner, vice president of the RCA Radiotron Company, Inc., and general manager of that concern's Harrison, N. J., plant, died early this morning of injuries suffered in ar automobile accident here.

Supreme Court Justice Lee Parsons Davis dismissed today the complaint in a $220,661 suit brought by the City of Yonkers against the Yonkers Railroad Company for money spent in paving between trolley tracks from 1922 through 1930.
Came the deluge at Longwood today and a new record for rain in a New England tennis tournament.

Definite sentiment for the designation of Representative John J. O'Connor, Democratic incumbent, as the Republican candidate from the Sixteenth Congressional District was shown yesterday at a conference at the National Republican Club, 54 West Fortieth Street, between Kenneth F. Simpson, New York County Republican chairman, and a group of leaders of Assembly districts lying wholly or partly within the Congressional district.

There will be general commendation of the plans of the roadside committee of the Long Island Association, not only to remove unsightly billboards, dilapidated structures and other manmade scars upon the face of nature, but to plant and further beautify the roadsides in Nassau, Suffolk and Queens County.

Weakness in Wall Street yesterday caused a setback on the stock market here today. Business was on a small scale. Gilt-edge issues lost ground, while among the foreign loans there was a reaction and German bonds weakened. Transatlantic stocks, including United States Steel and International Nickel. sagged.
Joey Ferrando, 140, Jersey City, outpointed Ray Napolitano, 142, veteran Williamsburg battler, in the main event of six rounds at the Fort Hamilton Arena last night.

The name of Columbia University "is besmirched from time to time when preachments containing unAmerican doctrines emanate from those who identify themselves with this institution," Daniel J. Doherty, National Commander of the American Legion, asserted last night.

Howard Hughes and his companions on the around-the-world flight were welcomed here today by high officials of the government and members of the National Press Club. They received spontaneous greetings everywhere after they arrived by airline from New York.

Mrs. Marius de Brabant has closed her home at 7 East Fiftyfirst Street and has gone to Plaisance, her Summer place in Centerport, L. I. Irving Brokaw, who is passing the Summer in East Gloucester, Mass., will return to New York in September.

Dr. and Mrs. Herschel C. Walker of Philadelphia, who are spending the Summer at Chesterwood, Stockbridge, opened the studio of the late Daniel Chester French there this afternoon for the first of a series of lectures by the Rev. Edmund Randolph Laine on "Milestones in Christian History." Sixty persons attended.
The two sons of Mrs. Arabella Horlick, widow of the malted milk manufacturer, will share the bulk of her estate, estimated at between $4,000,000 and $5,000,000.

Methods by which the National Association of Manufacturers and leading steel corporations were accused of seeking to influence public opinion and the press regarding organized labor while the Committee for Industrial Organization was pushing its drive in the steel and rubber industries in 1936 were read into the record of the Senate Civil Liberties Committee today.

Liberal and word?" Labor peers startled the House of Lords out of its usual somnolence today by demanding that Britain He reopen the question of war debts in the interests of Anglo-American friendship. One of them,

Despite President Roosevelt's intimations that he wishes to retire in 1940, a substantial number of voters throughout the country think he will run for a third term, and an even greater number--approximately half the electorate-think he will win if he does run.

Net gold imports in the second quarter of the year. were valued at $124,590,000, reversing the outward movement which started last Fall after the stock market decline and continued through the first quarter of this year, the Treasury announced today.

Of all sad words of tongue or pen, The saddest are these: It rained again! The moguls moaned with wilted collars: "There goes sixty thousand dollras!" Be as nasty as you can And you'll grow up a Weather Man.

Al Davis, Brownsville lightweight with the crushing left hook, knocked out Bernie Friedkin, his bitter neighborhood rival, in the fourth round of their scheduled six-round bout at Madison Square Garden last night.

Long Island and Burnt Mills open play Sunday in the national junior polo championship at the Burnt Mills Club in New Jersey, according to the draw announced yesterday by officials. Five teams, two from New Jersey and three from Long Island,

The Calhoun-Robbins Sales Corporation, an outgrowth of CalhounRobbins Co., wholesalers and jobbers, has been formed to act as sales agents for mills and manufacturers. Offices are at 358 Fifth Avenue.

The Bernstein proposal prohibiting the use of State armories and buildings by organizations purporting to owe allegiance to any foreign government or "advocating the overthrow of our republican form of government" was defeated today by the Constitutional Convention, sitting as the committee of the whole.

Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine announced yesterday that he had ordered Deputy Chief Inspector Joseph J. Reynolds in command of the Bronx to conduct an investigation to determine if any member of the department was "guilty of misconduct or negligence" in arresting a Bronx rabbi Wednesday for peddling when the man was carrying ice cream for children of a camp.
Contracts for the building of homes to be occupied by the owners have increased steadily in the thirty-seven Eastern States since Jan. 1, according to the F. W. Dodge Corporation.
The cornerstone of what is to be the smallest exhibit hall at the exposition, but which will house its most valuable group of exhibits, was laid yesterday at the New York World's Fair grounds.

Although Moore McCormack, New York steamship operators, offered the high bid for charter of the three reconditioned Panama Pacific liners and the ten freighters of the American Republics Line, it was reported yesterday that the low bidders, C. H. Sprague Son of Boston, still might obtain the fleet for operation by invoking a clause of the Merchant Marine Act of 1936.

Trading showed some slight improvement in local markets yesterday, Cooler weather brought a somewhat firmer undertone into some classes also. Slaughterers have reduced 'their kills rather sharply this week on both steers and lambs. and both of these markets appeared in slightly better condition Trading was light on kosher meats and prices showed little change from Wednesday's close: Conditions as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture 'follow:

Sixty business men and advertising executives arose early yesterday morning to eat ham and eggs (at $10 a plate) and get "straightthinking" advice on how to improve their sales or better their business relationships.

While loans continue to decline, investments of the reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City advanced in the week ended on Wednesday with the result that the total of loans and investments of the Panks was up $88,000,000, according to their condition statement issued yesterday.

Brooklyn realty transactions reported yesterday largely involved multi-family dwellings in various parts of the borough. The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company sold to Max Gelles's Selmax Realty Corporation the fourstory house on the northeast corner of Eighth Avenue and Fortyfourth Street, known as 807 Fortyfourth Street, for cash above a tenyear first mortgage of $46,500.

England and Australia will make another attempt tomorrow to break the deadlock in the 1938 cricket test series. After drawn contests at Nottingham and London rain caused abandonment of the third test at Manchester without ball being bowled.

Assurance that the Federal Government's purchases of men's and women's clothing for WPA distribu- the tion among the needy will be so directed as not to dislocate private trade and industry was given yesterday to the executive committee of the National Retail Dry Goods

Lamb and poultry are the weekend's best buys in meats, according to the city Department of Markets. Although pork, veal and beef remain substantially at the highest levels since last December, lamb shows reductions now in all cuts except shoulder chops, which are 33 cents a pound.

One slight lapse prevented Luke Hamlin from putting a perfect game on exhibition before 31,130 North Side fans at Wrigley Field today. As it was, the 32-year-old right-hander hurled eight flawless frames for a two-hit, 1-0 Dodger triumph over the Cubs in the second game of a doubleheader.
