Mrs. Margaret Lardner Fowle, sister of W. Mifflin Large of Stony Hollow, Malvern, was married to Caleb Cresson Roberts today at Chestnut Hill by the Rev. William Kepler. Mrs. Roberts is the former Mrs. George D. Fowle.

In the three days since their arrival here members of the United States labor commission have had an opportunity to watch the actual conduct of labor relations in Sweden by two city-wide strikes-one of which tied up the photoengraving industry so completely that Stockholm newspapers had the greatest difficulty in getting pictures of the delegation itself in print.

Estate, less than $10,000. Will bequeaths $15,000 to Fanny Tenenbaum of 240 W. 98th St: Harry Abrahams. son, 5,101 13th Ave., Brooklyn, temporary estate in onehalf residue; Jeanette Sakol and Mirian Sakol, 240 W. 98th St.. one-fourth residue each. Aaron Honig. 575 West End Ave.,

Settlement of the strike at the Edgewater, N. J., plant of the National Sugar Refining Company was announced yesterday in a joint statement issued by Allen S. Haywood, regional director of the C. I. 0., and Charles D. Bruyn, president of the company.

Harsh words were exchanged last night between the Japanese Ambassador, Mamoru Shigemitsu, who recently returned by plane from his Scandinavian holiday, and the Soviet Foreign Commissar, Maxim Litvinoff.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The following may be of some assistance in helping Wyndham A. Bewes, whose letter was printed in THE TIMES of July 20, to understand the legal situation with regard to the sale of munitions by American firms to Japan.

Four hundred underprivileged boys and girls between 8 and 12 years old will leave at 9 o'clock this morning to spend three weeks at Camp Sussex, Glenwood Lake, N. J., maintained by Camp Sussex, Inc., a charitable organization.

The directors of the Owens-Illinois Glass Company declared today a quarterly dividend of 50 cents a share on the 2,661,204 shares of $12.50 par value common stock, payable on Aug. 15 to holders of record of July 30.

With Carl Hubbell once again performing one of his old-fashioned heroic roles while his colleagues collaborated to the extent of wrenching four runs from left-handed Roy Henshaw in the seventh inning, the Giants today bagged the final game of the series with the Cardinals, 5 to 2.

A letter from Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt commending the New Rochelle Board of Education for having appointed its first Negro school teacher was received here today by Herold C. Hunt, Superintendent of Schools. The letter, on White House stationery, said:

The Argentine Republic filed a registration statement today under the Securities Act of 1933 covering $25,000,000 of sinking fund external loan 41/2 per cent bonds, due on Aug. 15, 1948, to obtain funds here to advance to Buenos Aires for use toward the payment of the city's short term and floating indebtedness, and toward payment for property acquired by the city for the widening and construction of streets.

Miss Shirley Jager, daughter of Mrs. Arthur F. Jager of Mount Vernon and the late Mr. Jager, was married this morning to Granville S. Gilpatrick of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Gilpatrick of Old Orchard Beach, Me., in St. Catherine's Roman Catholic Church here.
The Los Angeles Railway Corporation announced today an amended bond refunding plan in a supplementary application filed with the California Railroad Commission.
Here in New York we know well enough that our persistent spell of rain was due to an unfortunate conjunction with St. Swithin's
According to The Financial Times, the price of newsprint in London will be reduced next April-the first reduction since 1934.

Thomas J. Lynch, assistant general counsel of the Securities and Exchange Commission, in charge of litigation, probably will be selected by the commission as chief counsel in the studies assigned to that agency under the Administration's general monopoly inquiry, including the study of insurance companies, it twenty-five will be deli was learned today.
The first five railroads to report Souti showed an aggregate decline of 39.2 per cent in net operating income for June. This compared with a drop of 43.7 per cent in May.

The broad principles of home rule for New York and other cities, as outlined in the bill presented by the cities committee to the Constitutional Convention, were abandoned today in the face of strong opposition among delegates.

Theodore Keller died yesterday in his conductor's uniform. He slumped to the platform of the City Hall station of the Third Avenue elevated railway, the road on which he had served for fifty years, just as a smiling group of fellow-employes strode forward to congratulate him on his long record.

The appeal of Secretary of State Cordell Hull for American manufacturers of munitions to refrain from selling bombing planes to belligerents, in order to discourage attacks on open cities and towns and casualties to women, children and other noncombatants, will not bear fruit for several months.

" No feminine entanglements," Douglas G. Corrigan announced momentously today-but a couple of hours later the ocean flier was almost gasping for breath as hero-worshiping Irish colleens closed in on him in a gay autograph hunt.

The Japanese steamer Tatekawa Maru is scheduled to arrive on Monday at a Mexican port on the Gulf of Mexico to take on a cargo of 12,000 tons, about 85,000 barrels of fuel oil, according to information received in shipping circles here yesterday.

Unfavorable weather conditions again affected retail trade this week, resulting in a larger sales decline under the corresponding period last year. Department store executives put the average drop for local establishments at about 9 per cent under the 1937 period, which compared with a decline of 6.4 per cent for the week ended July 16.

Hua Chung (Central China) College at Wuchang, China, was struck by five bombs during Japanese air raids on July 19 and the institution is being transferred to Kweilin in the Province of Kwangsi, 300 miles southwest of Wuchang.

Bert Kirkman, as president of Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, filed yesterday in Supreme Court an action to restrain Isaac Penner, president of the Penner Electric Company, from violating an alleged contract with the union.

The Securities and Exchange Commission is enlarging its staff of trial examiners to avoid the necessity, resulting from the increasing volume of the commission's work, of employing them in other capacities or of drafting attorneys to act as trial examiners, the SEC announced today.

Held to a draw by Burton O. Dahlstrom of Chicago, last in the competition, Isaac I. Kashdan, champion of the Manhattan C. C., with a score of 8-2, was tied for the lead by I. A. Horowitz, also of Manhattan, in the tenth round of the American Chess Federation's open championship at the Hotel Touraine tonight.

The Argentine Government has appointed a committee to improve the quality of commercial radio broadcasts, which have been sharply criticized in an official report, the Commerce Department announced today.

Crown Prince Gustaf Adolf of Sweden, Crown Princess Louise and Prince Bertil sailed for home aboard the Gripsholm last night after a twenty-six-day visit in commemoration of the landing of the first Swedish and Finnish settlers near Wilmington, Del., 300 years ago.

Fred Bowden, mason materials dealer and banker of Newark, died last night at his home here after a long illness. Mr. Bowden was born 74 years ago in Barnstable, England, and was brought to this country by his parents when he was 5 years old.
The News Chronicle today successfully contested in the High Court a libel suit brought by Wladimir Poliakoff, 73-year-old owner of the Pariser Tageblatt.

Reports from steel-producing centers indicate that the Chicago and Pittsburgh areas will start next week at rates well above those of the current week, and that Youngstown will continue unchanged. At Chicago, the United States Steel subsidiary is adding two blast furnaces, making eight active out of twenty-three available.

John Hamilton, chairman of the Republican National Committee, today denounced the "intolerant" views of the Rev. Gerald B. Winrod, evangelist and pamphleteer, seeking the Republican nomination for the Senate in Kansas, and declared that his nomination would put the State party on the "wrong side of a vital issue."

A heavy downpour of rain shortly after noon today forced postponement of the second session of the Jersey Shore Horse Show at Boxwood Farm and a readjustment of the program for the remaining two days of the exhibition.
Rain drowned out the second day's Metropolita exhibitions at the third annual horse show here today but failed to interfere with the horse show ball at the Monmouth Hotel. Hundreds attended.

The Rules Committee of the Constitutional Convention has been discussing a proposal for the limitation of debate on the convention floor, it became known today. The proposal, if it should be adopted, would be certain to bring cries of "gag rule" from the Democratic side.

Jersey City hammered twelve hits tonight to back up the six-hit pitching of Rollie Stiles to score its second straight victory over the Bisons, 6 to 1. Five of the Little Giants' hits were doubles and one a homer by Jack Winsett.

Facing stern opposition all the way, Max Marston of Philadel- A phia today came through two rounds of match play as he launched his campaign for his eighth victory in the Shenecossett n men's invitation golf tournament.
The Western railroads today decided that they would not go along with the Eastern railroads in advancing fares in passenger coaches.

A. M. Kidder Co. will take over all the business and a large part of the personnel of Jenks, Gwynne Co., including all general partners of that firm, on Aug. 1, it was announced yesterday in connection with the proposed dissolution of Jenks, Gwynne Co.

Five Negro swingsters climbed into the back of a fruit and vegetable truck on West Thirty-ninth and Cleveland Ind Street yesterday, shook the rain off their instruments and proceeded to make their impromptu bandstand nee business. sound like a Harlem night spot. A little knot of people sloshed through puddles to stand beside the truck tre, too, starts a n and listen.

Plans for a 250-foot parachute Liszt's "Le tower, to be the second tallest structure at the New York World's Fair, were announced yesterday by Jordan L. Mott, vice president of International Parachuting, Inc.
The two-story building being erected by Robert Walton Goelet at 61 East Fifty-third Street has been leased to Louis D'Arclay, interior decorator, now in East Fifty-first Street.

The share of the United States in French imports of cigarettes increased from 143,220 pounds in the the first two months of 1937 to 349,800 pounds in the same period this year, the Commerce Department reported today.

The Interstate Commerce Commission voided today schedules proposing increased freight rates on fresh meats, in carloads, from packing points in the interior of Iowa and Southern Minnesota to destinations east of the Illinois-Indiana line and north of the Ohio and Potomac Rivers.

President Lazaro Cardenas arrived extremely early at the National Palace this morning to study and confer upon the United States note, transmitted yesterday, asserting the principle that the Mexican Government must pay full indemnity at the time of the expropriation of foreign-owned properties in conformity with accepted international usage.

Joseph B. O'Connor, Acting New York Regional Director of the Social Security Board, yesterday cautioned banks, stores and other business concerns that cash checks for the public against depending upon Social Security account number cards for identification purposes.
A gain of $40,613,867 in net working assets is shown by E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. for the twelve months ended on June 30, with cash and marketable securities $42,653,000 higher.

Holders of bonds of the International Railway Company were asked today to accept interest of 3 per cent instead of the regular 5 per cent as a means to avoid reorganization under the Federal Bankruptcy Law.

Summonses Summonses served by members of this department are returnable in Richmond, during the month of August, as follows: Courts are open from 9 A. M. to 4 P. M. Week of Aug. 1, Central Court A. M. and P. M., Traffic Court A. M. and P. M.; week of Aug. 8, Traffic Court A. M.,

When the twelve-meter sloop owners came in after their Larchmont Race Week session today, it was learned that there was a movement on foot to send the four international ones to England next Spring for a series of races with the same type of canvas creations of the European countries.
Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of the Interior, plans to visit Alaska this Summer, to inspect PWA projects and proposed routes for an international highway through Canada to Fairbanks.

An application for an injunction restraining the Hudson Manhattan Railroad from raising the tube fare between Jersey City and Cortlandt Street, Manhattan, from 6 to 8 cents on Monday was made by Jersey City today before Federal Judge John Boyd Avis here.

Oratory and music broadcast from every available radio station filled the Texas atmosphere tonight as the daffiest primary election campaign in the history of the State came to a close. Tomorrow 800,000 to 900,000 Texans will go to the polls to make a choice between twelve aspirants for the Democratic nomination for Governor.
To Sports Editor of The New York Times: I was very happy to read what John Kieran had to say in connection with the now settled controversy on the 1940 Olympic Games in Japan.

The redistricting bill which a committee dominated by Republicans has placed before the Constitutional Convention has been labeled by its Democratic opponents as "vicious, unjust and discriminatory." It is certainly a partisan measure. It is certainly unfair to New York City and other urban areas.

Several dinners will be given tomorrow before the masquerade dance at the Belle Haven Beach Club here for the benefit of the crippled children of New York. Mrs. Clarence Hillyer, Mrs. Charles E. Armstrong, Mrs. Thomas A. Kenny and John Newington are among those who will entertain at their homes.

The Bank of Brazil resumed today the purchase of German compensated marks. Purchases were suspended a month ago. When the suspension was ordered it was understood it was temporary to allow the bank of get rid of about 20,000,000 marks. Only 3,000,000 marks remain.
Mrs. Grace Foster Herben of Maplewood, long prominent in missionary work and widow of the Rev. Stephen J. Herben, died today at the Orange Memorial Hospital at the age of 74.

A further decline of about 100,000 in nonagricultural employment last month, a reduction smaller than those which occurred in April and May and due primarily to factory lay-offs, was reported today by the Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics.

The League of Nations announced today that the Chinese Health Administration's recent application for 6,000,000 doses of cholera vaccine to meet the growing danger of an epidemic had been more than filled by the first ten gifts.
The Department of Commerce disclosed today that Mexico had shipped more than $10,300,000 of gold to the United States in the last three weeks.

Vickers, Inc., of Detroit, Mich., has arranged hospitalization benefits for some 550 employes who have been insured under a group program which provides them with a total of more than $1,100,000 of life insurance, supplemented by sickness and accident protection.

A hearing has been set for Aug. 5 under the Holding Company Act on the application of the Toledo Edison Company with reference to the issue and sale of $30,000,000 of 3 1/2 per cent first-mortgage bonds due in 1968 and $6,500,000 of 4 per cent sinking fund debentures due in 1948.

The British and French Governments today rejected a German suggestion that Great Britain should sponsor international arbitration of the Sudeten German problem in Czechoslovakia by the four great Western European powers.
Muley Abdel Aziz, former Sultan of Morocco, accompanied by his wife and daughter, sailed for Naples, Italy, last night aboard the Conte di Savoia.

The Seamen's Church Institute of New York, one of the largest shore homes for merchant seamen in the world, will be the beneficiary of a performance of the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo on Oct. 13 at the Metropolitan Opera House.

Walter G. C. Otto, Mayor of New Rochelle from 1930 to 1935 and County Judge of Westchester in 1928 and again in 1935, was designated tonight as the Democratic candidate for the County President under the new charter.

In a continuation of the see-saw movement that has characterized it lately, the foreign exchange market rallied slightly yesterday from its declines of Thursday. The advances, as a rule, were only about half as large as the previous day's losses and indicated no change in the downward trend.
Charges that a Federal officer in Georgia had been ousted, apparently, because he proposed to vote for Senator George, were made to the Senate Campaign Expenditures Committee by the Senator today.

Domestic corporate bonds continued strong; Japanese dollar obligations broke rather sharply, and United States Government loans worked irregularly lower in a rather confused bond market yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.

Mrs. Arthur Norwood Bingham of this place and New Rochelle, N. Y., has announced the marriage of her daughter, Miss Eleanor Rosalie Bingham, to Dr. Florence Sullivan Hassett, son of J. John Hassett of Elmira, N. Y., and the late Mrs. Hassett.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The failure of labor to accept President Roosevelt's "forty weeks" annual wage plan proposed some six months ago is only one of the causes of "The Lag in Building" referred to in an editorial in THE TIMES. Labor is suspicious, and properly so,
Secretary of State Cordell Hull read today of the visit of King George VI to France in The London News Chronicle of Wednesday.
Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on July 16 amounted to 602,300 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

Edwin S. Smith, member of the National Labor Relations Board, defended the board last night against charges that it was interfering with freedom of speech and the press by forbidding employers to distribute to their employes literature which the board found to be anti-union.
Four-year-old Jean Dirks of 210 East Eighty-eighth Street was left by her parents last night at the home of her grandparents, Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Hauser, at 964 Fox Street, the Bronx.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated July 21: BRIGADIER GENERAL Hartshorn, E. S., seven days' leave, July 22. COLONELS Foster, G. B. Jr., Med. Corps, one month and fourteen days' leave, Aug. 1.

MANHATTAN BAKER, MAURICE WILLIAM (June 7). Estate, more than $10,000. To John G. Auradou, Route 2, Box 66, Healdsburg, Calif., $10,000; Marguerite Philippine Roche, 40 Rue Condorcet, Paris, France, , residue. Chase National Bank of New York. 18 Pine St., executor.
The Pan-Maryland, an oil burning tanker, slid today down the ways of the Federal Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company, a subsidiary of United States Steel.

R. W. Crabtree Sons, Ltd., one of the leading makers of multicolor litho machines, contracted today to acquire the British printing press business of R. Hoe Co., Ltd., a subsidiary established in 1863 by R. Hoe Co., Inc.. New York.

Other things being equal, the man whose shirts last longest is the man who shaves most frequently, J. Fred Oesterling, research assistant in textile chemistry at Pennsylvania State College, said today.

A business property near the site of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company's housing development in the Bronx was acquired for investment yesterday when a client of Armstrong Brothers, brokers, bought 2,138 Westchester Avenue, just north of Castlehill Avenue.

Byrnes MacDonald, deputy police commissioner and head of the police youth activities, is seeking the Republican and the American Labor party nominations for Representative in the Sixteenth Manhattan District, where John J. O'Connor, Democrat and chairman of the House Rules Committee, is his party's candidate for re-election, it was learned yesterday.

Automobilists and campers were marooned, bridges were washed away and parts of a railroad and State highway were closed by flood waters in Sullivan and Ulster Counties, N. Y., yesterday, as rair continued to drench the east coast From the vicinity of Boston south to Washington.

Michael Lerner, big-game angler and hunter and field associate of the American Museum of Natural History, leaves New York today for Louisburg, N. S., where he will complete plans for the museum's expedition to make further study of the broadbill swordfish.

Prodded at long last into action, the slowmoving British public no longer regards air raid precautions as a "bad joke or tiresome bore" and in the last six months has contributed 500,000 volunteers to the proposed army of 1,000,000 that the government hopes to have equipped with fire-fighting, anti-gas and ambalance appliances before many more months.

A further drop in the volume of new bond financing took place this week with a total of only $12,805,000 in new loans reaching the market. This was the smallest total since the final week in June, and compared with $36,399,000 new bonds offered last week.

The Agricultural Adjustment Administration made public today recommendations for a proposed marketing agreement to regulate handling of milk in the metropolitan New York area and invited producers and handlers to file arguments for or against the program.

Arrested this afternoon in New York City after he left a steamship from Cuba accompanied by a young Philadelphia woman, Stanley Jensen, 37 years old, married and the father of a 5-month-old child, was brought here this evening and lodged in a cell at Police Headquarters to await arraignment tomorrow on a charge of embezzling $24.000
Two hundred single jobless men opened a downtown office today and appealed for contributions of food and clothing.
Yugoslavia's crack Davis Cup tennis team clinched a place in the European zone final today by defeating Belgium, 3--0..

Mr. and Mrs. William H. La Boyteaux early next week will go to Saratoga, where they have taken a home for the season. Mr. and Mrs. Charles F. Chadwick of 277 Park Avenue are sailing today on the Champlain for the French Riviera.

Dr. Joseph S. Wheelwright gave a dinner tonight at his home on the ocean for Dr. James Ewing, director of the Memorial Hospital in New York, who is visiting Mr. and Mrs. Harry Pelham Robbins at Pelham Farm.

Celestin Durand Jr. of the Garden City Golf Club, turning in a score of 38, 36--74, captured the qualifying medal as the Rockaway Hunting Club's annual invitation golf tournament got under way today in a Dr. dreary rainy setting.

Bettering two world's records in successful defense of her titles, Mrs. Katherine Rawls Thompson of Florida dominated today's program of opening events in the women's national outdoor swimming and diving meet.
Further reports of crop deterioration in the Canadian Northwest and firmness in Liverpool resulted yesterday in a higher level of prices on the active deliveries of wheat on North American Exchanges.

A total of 99,909 zlotys, or nearly $20,000, was received by Jewish cooperative loan funds in Poland in June from the special "iron fund" sent to Poland by the American Committee Appeal for the Jews in Poland, 225 West Thirty-fourth Street, the committee's executive director, Zelig Tygel, announced yesterday.
One hundred families fled before a forest fire on Vancouver Island today, abandoning their homes in the small settlements of Headquarters and Doug Creek.

Joe Turnesa of the Rockville Country Club is the new Long Island open golf champion. Taking a three-stroke lead with a two-under-par 70 in the third round, Turnesa, who looked like a national open winner at Scioto in 1926 until Bobby Jones came along, annexed the title today by two strokes with Jim a total of 291, three over par for his home course.

The Navy Department will award contracts for the construction of two torpedo-boat destroyers to the Bath Iron Works Corporation at Bath, Me., and two to the Federal Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company at Kearny, N. J.

Two-ton Tony Galento, who trained on beer and cigars for every fight but his biggest one--a scheduled fifteen round meeting with John Henry Lewis at Philadelphia next Tuesday night--was removed to Orange Memorial Hospital tonight seriously ill with pneumonia.
A report which indicated a rapid growth of the nationalist "protective spirit" in leading countries of the world was sent to Congress today by the Federal Trade Commission.

Moriz Rosenthal, Polish pianist, was again soloist with the Philharmonic-Symphony last night at Lewisohn Stadium. He played the Liszt fantasia on Hungarian folk melodies, with Massimo Freccia conducting the orchestral accompaniment, and, for piano solo, his own "Viennese Carnival" on themes of Johann Strauss.

Architects filed yesterday plans for dwellings and multi-family buildings in Queens to cost several million dollars. The operations involve the erection of numerous small homes in many communities of the borough.
Hostile crowds demonstrated here tonight against cadets from two Italian training ships and several minor clashes resulted before the police succeeded in scattering the demonstrators.
A survey by Standard Statistics, Inc., indicates growing opposition to the Patman Chain Store Bill and suggests that it is likely that the measure will not be passed by Congress at the next session.
The text of the speech made by King George VI of England today at the dedication of the Australian World War memorial follows:

Five members of the so-called weaker sex turned policewomen for a short time yesterday and contributed their share to capturing a man who was later charged with assault and robbery and held in $10,000 bail in connection with a hold-up of a busy downtown restaurant just before the noon hour.

Eleven prosecution witnesses, most of them openly in sympathy with the defendant, testified yesterday at Governors Island before the general court-martial of Lieut. Col. Stewart S. Giffin, charged with drunkenness and conduct unbecoming an officer.

Players from the metropolitan area, with one exception, dominated the quarter-finals of the Eastern clay courts tennis championship yesterday after another day of upsets as the tournament was staged both indoors and out in order to bring a rather scrambled scheduled up to date.

Ray Malott of Stanford University and the San Francisco Olympic Club set a local record for the 300-meter dash and came close to a longstanding world record today as he won the event in 33.4 seconds in the final day's competition of a three-day international track and field meet.

Deputy Mayor Henry Curran's star English student, Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx, became a teacher of the language in his own right yesterday and attempted to impart to the Women's City Club of New York a knowledge of its elements.
The twenty-story Trafalgar apartment house at 2,620-22 Broadway and seven other Manhattan realty parcels were sold at auction in the Vesey Street rooms yesterday.

Counsel for bondholders of the Rutland Railroad Company served notice today that the road's 400 miles of line in Western Vermont and Northern New York would be junked if the bondholders took possession of the line.

Hundreds of public officials and friends attended the funeral services yesterday morning for Edward F. Cadley, former Brooklyn Democratic district leader. in the Catholic Church of St. Gregory, Brooklyn Avenue and St. John's Place. Mr. Cadley, who was in the city's service for more than thirty-five years, died Wednesday at the age of 65.

The Italian liner Rex sails today for Mediterranean ports with the following listed among the passengers: Giovanni Host Venturi, Gaetano Vecchiotti, Italian Consul General in New York; Judge Daniel J. Kenefick, General Jose Marti and Madame Marti, Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Baer, Vincenzo Collucci and Mme. Collucci, Alfonso B. Rivas,
The league-leading Newark Bears scored their third straight victory over Montreal today, defeating the Royals, 8 4, with a fifteen-hit attack.

Edwin R. Albertson, the former Frock residence on Bedford Rd. Bedford, Westchester, from George A. LaWare; James F. Greene, broker. George Anscomb, in 611 1st St, Mamaroneck; Douglas F. Winnek, in 8 Harold St; Peter C. Doern Jr. Inc., brokers.

Intensification of the Japanese attack against Kiukiang, 135 miles down-river from Hankow, is indicated by reports from the Yangtze front. Japanese warships and planes are subjecting the Chinese positions east and southwest of Kiukiang to frequent bombardments.

Charlie Grimm, deposed manager of the Cubs, has been engaged as a regular sports staff announcer for Station WBBM, Chicago outlet in the Columbia Broadcasting System, it was announced last night at CBS headquarters here.
The Foreign Ministers of the seven signatories of the Oslo convention in 1930-Norway, Sweden, Denmark, Finland, The Netherlands, Belgium and Luxembourgwill begin a two-day conference here tomorrow.

C. Jay Goodnough, veteran State legislator who was twice Speaker of the House and who was chairman of the Public Service Commission when it was abolished a year ago, died last night in Cleveland following art operation. He was 71 vears old.
The fourth series of wool auctions ended today with offerings totaling 8,144 bales, including 1,537 from South America, and of this total 6,459 bales were sold.

" Unfit to Print" will be Joan Blondell's first picture when she returns to Warners. The studio expects to get the newspaper yarn under way during August and today abandoned the tentative casting of Humphrey Bogart and Leo Gorcey and substituted Pat O'Brien and Bobby Jordan, one of the "Dead End" boys.
J. Henry Deane, senior member of the firm of Deane Deane, Catskill undertaking and furniture firm, died last night after a long illness at the age of 83. He had resided here for the last fifty years.
J. Edgar Hoover figured today that the activities of his G-men last fiscal year were worth $7.64 for every $1 they cost.

Heavy hogs and packing sows were under considerable pressure today, most 400 to 600 pound sows selling at $6.10 to $6.85 and light hogs reached $10.15, suggesting a wide price range on the two-way market which has featured the hog trade this week, the United State Department of Agriculture reports. Lambs strengthened at the close, Idaho springers reaching $9.45; fed cattle sold fully steady.

An order requiring the city and William F. Carey, Commissioner of Sanitation, to show cause on Monday why they should not be en joined temporarily from proceeding with a plan to dump refuse in Jamaica Bay was granted yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Meien Steinbrink in Brooklyn.
Between 300 and 400 residents of this Southwest Texas town were driven from their homes today as the San Saba River, nominally two to three feet deep, rose to record height of forty-three feet.

When a report came from Paris last month that "certain friends" had described Romain Rolland as "broken in body and spirit," doubt was expressed on this page that the words could be wholly true. It is pleasant to have that doubt confirmed by a letter from M. Rolland himself, which we publish today.

Apartment houses on the West Side, from Greenwich Village to Riverdale, drew many of the new tenants listed in yesterday's rental report. In the building at 325 West Eightysixth Street Manfred I. Behrens Jr. leased a six-room suite from Frederick Zittell Sons through Frances R. Jaffin, broker.

Operators and investors were active yesterday in deals involving properties on the West Side. The West Forty-seventh Street Realty Corporation bought for investment the vacant plot, 50 by 100 feet, at 306-308 West Sixty-ninth Street through the HaggstromCallen - Davis Company, broker.
Temporary Assignments Lieutenant Carl Handwerg, Precinct P. assigned in command, for thirty-five days, from 8 A. M., July 29, during the absen e of Captain on vacation and with leaye.

Funeral services for Charles P. Howard, president of the International Typographical Union, who died here last night, will be held here Tuesday morning at the First Christian Church. Dr. John H. Sheen, pastor of the First Baptist Church of Colorado Springs, will officiate.

The Italian Government has ordered the expulsion of Edward Kleinlehrer, Rome correspondent of the Jewish Telegraphic Agency. Mr. Kleinlehrer, a Jew and a Polish citizen, was asked to leave the country within eight days and no reason was given

Twenty-eight Spanish nuns, the last of the Sisters of the Sacred Heart left in Loyalist Spain, arrived at Victoria Station today and went to three convents of their order in the London area. They will remain there until the Spanish civil war is over.

Marshall Chambers of Cincinnati, top-seeded entrant in the Eastern boys' outdoor tennis singles championship tourney, defeated Richard Cooley of Rye. 6-2. 6--4, indoors at the River Club courts yesterday and moved into the final.

Ernest Downey, 8 years old, of 62 S Wyckoff Street, Brooklyn, recently d sent to a boys' camp here by the y Warren Street Methodist Episcopal P Church of Brooklyn, disappeared today after he and thirty-seven other youngsters had gone to a bathing beach on Peconic Bay in South Jamesport for a swim.

After battling stiff head winds the greater part of the 2,397-mile nonstop flight from Horta, the Azores, to New York, and never flying higher than 600 feet, the four-engined, Diesel-powered monoplane Nordmeer of the Deutsche Lufthansa landed at the Pan American

A pair of blondes were the conquering queens yesterday at the annual beautiful baby contest of the Educational Alliance at 197 East Broadway. They pushed the redheads almost out of the picture and completely scuttled the brunettes.

Bobby Riggs, the nation's secondranking tennis star, yesterday was seeded No. 1 in a field of forty-eight men who will compete in singles in the fifty-first annual invitation tournament opening Monday at Seabright, N. J., The Associated Press reported.

A pamphlet issued by the City Club of New York, an organization long interested in municipal reform, is being used in Albany by the opponents of home rule to defeat the demands of the administration for wider self-governing powers in New York City, Newbold Morris, president of the City Council, asserted yesterday.

The Department of Agriculture reported today that stocks of old wheat in interior mills, elevators and warehouses on July 1 amounted to 31,833,000 bushels. This compared with record low stocks of 11,942,000 in such storage a year ago and 38,107,000 for the 1927-36 ten-year average.

THE antic McKenney sisters are, as Ogden Nash once remarked about another character, sui generis to a fault. They are dumfounding in a quiet way. Not to mention other ways that are far, far from quiet. For some time the glittering and improbable chronicle of their adventures has been unrolling in The New Yorker.

Cotton-mill activity increased sharply last week, but daily average output rose less than seasonally, and the adjusted index slumped to 102.5 from 114.3, the revised figure for the preceding week. The figure was 134.0 for the week ended July 17, 1937.

The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "The wool market has taken another upward swing this week. Prices are 3 to 5 cents a pound higher, on a clean basis. The greater advance still is in the West, and the farther one gets from the sheep the less strong the market.

An estate valued at $473,202 was left by James E. Beach, a florist here for many years, according to an inventory filed in Probate Court today. Real estate amounts to $70,500 of the estate, with $214,075 in mortgage notes, $31,393 in bonds, $122,307 in stocks and a cash balance of $31,773.

Governor George H. Earle opposed today a proposed increase of anthracite freight rates within Pennsylvania, asserting higher rates would "add to the misery of many thousands of families" in the hard coal field.

The Maritime Commission has awarded to the Bethlehem Shipbuilding Corportion, Ltd., of Quincy, Mass., contracts for the construction of four cargo vessels at a cost of about $2,559,000 each for the American Export Lines for use in the Mediterranean and Black Sea service.
Southern interests took one quick parting shot at existing freight rates today in the first phase of an offensive to widen the door to Northern markets.

Regulations governing the administration of the new Food and Drug Act were promulgated today -by M. L.. Wilson, acting Secretary of Agriculture. The new act denies the channels of interstate commerce to dangerous drugs, injurious cosmetics and inadequately tested drugs.
General R. E. Wood, president of Sears, Roebuck Co., said today that the company is placing orders now for some lines of Spring merchandise.
Eddie Shore, stalwart member of the Boston Bruins team of the National Hockey League, was being praised for heroism today. He saved three persons

An irrepressible desire to be near airplanes, inspired by Douglas Corrigan's flight to Ireland, led Clifford Dammeyer, 10 years old, of 254 Manhattan Avenue, Union City, to run away from home Monday and live for three days without eating at the Newark Airport, according to the story the youngster told police tonight between sandwich bites.

The Weston College seismograph tern station reported its instrument today recorded a "strong" earthquake at 3:55:32 A. M. (E. S. T.) approximately 2,670 miles southwest of Boston, which would place it "around Panama or northwestern South America."
The elements-rain and wind during a terrific electrical storm-stymied the $5,000 Chicago open golf championship and a field of the nation's ranking fairway stars today.

Department store sales in the week ended July 16 were 8 per cent lower' than for the corresponding week in 1937, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. For the four weeks ended July 16, the sales were 9 per cent lower than for the same four weeks one year ago.

New York Stock Exchange committee on admissions is to consider admission of John Chester Botts; Arthur C. Gwynne and William P. Jenks to A. M. Kidder Co. Aug. 1, of John H. Brown to Reynolds Co. Aug. 1, and of Benjamin D. Sokolow to Engel Co.

Charges that our Government has been remiss in protecting American property rights in Mexico should be disposed of by Secretary Hull's vigorous note of Thursday. The Administration has leaned over backward in its effort to avoid accusations of Yankee imperialism.

The State of New Jersey cannot impose franchise taxes upon the stock of domestic corporations that merged with out-of-State corporations before the assessing date, the State Board of Tax Appeals ruled today.

Harold S. Vanderbilt is to race his Class M sloop Prestige on the cruise of the American Yacht Club starting Aug. 4, it was learned today. This will be the first time the Ms have raced as' a class since 1936. George Lauder also has entered his Windward for the cruise.
The Phillies dropped a ball game to the Reds today, 5 to 2, but made fourteen hits in the second contest for an 11-to-10 victory, despite a sevenrun Cincinnati rally in the eighth.

The Interstate Commerce Commission refused today to require the Hudson Manhattan Railroad to give thirty days' notice before increasing "tube" fares between Hudson Terminal, New York City, and stations in Jersey City and Hoboken, N. J., from 6 to 8 cents.

Partition actions started in Nassau County Court months ago to clear titles to the ownership of 20,000 parcels of land throughout the county have been concluded and sale-of the delinquent tax property will be started next September, according to announcement made today by Eugene R. Hurley, special counsel appointed by the Board of Supervisors to work with County Treasurer Harry Hedger in preparing the list.

The Dowager Countess of Hardwicke was fatally injured today aboard the liner Windsor Castle and was buried at sea. The Dowager Countess, who divorced the eighth Earl of Hardwicke, was married seventeen days ago to W. E. L. Jennings, district officer of Dedza Roma, Nyasaland, but was traveling to England alone.

Pinochle playing on WPA whitecollar projects must stop, Mrs. Sara V. Ackerman of Hillside, district supervisor of the Works Project Administration, declared in a "friendly lecture" before more than 200 Union County WPA workers in Thomas Jefferson High School last night.

Segregation of the activities of brokers and dealers on the New York Stock Exchange, an idea seemingly dead for more than a year, has been revived by William O. Douglas, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

C. E. Olmsted and J. S. Leach have been elected vice presidents of the Texas Corporation. Mr. Olmsted, who will make his headquarters here, formerly was president of the Texas Company of California, a Pacific Coast subsidiary. Mr. Leach,

Robert L. Riggs of Los Angeles and Chicago, the country's second ranking amateur, had a narrow escape from defeat today as play in the Longwood Bowl tennis tournament came down to the quarter-final round at the Longwood covered courts and the Brookline Country Club.

A welcome similar to those extended by New York to Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh and Howard Hughes when they returned from their epic flights was in the offing yesterday for Douglas G. Corrigan, who flew the North Atlantic nonstop "by mistake."

Allan Haywood, regional director of the C. I. O., disclosed yesterday that he had written Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local WPA Administrator, seeking to arrange a conference for a committee of C. I. O. unions to discuss the recent wage cuts among white-collar workers put into effect by the WPA.

Mr. and Mrs. John C. Martin of Syracuse, N. Y., formerly of Plainfield, have sent out invitations for the double wedding of their daughters on Aug. 6 in Trinity Reformed Church here. The Rev. John Y. Broek, the pastor, will officiate.

Dr. and Mrs. George Parkman Denny of Indian Meadow, this place, have announced the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Miss Charlotte Denny, to Oscar M. Schloss Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Schloss of New York. The marriage will take place Aug. 20.

The appearance of a new lawyer at the defense counsel table and a simultaneous influx of Clay County visitors brought the ten weeks' old trial of Harlan County coal operators and former peace officers close to a mistrail today and evoked a threat from the bench to jail any one even suspected of trying to influence the jurors.
Colonel Wilmot Edward Ellis, a retired Coast Artillery officer, died Tuesday in his home in Summerville, S. C., after a long illness, according to word received here yesterday. He was 70 years old.

By what was described as an "overwhelming majority," members of the student body and faculty of Columbia University have voted that they are in favor of the production of motion pictures devoted to social problems.

THERE was no game, as usual. Manager James J. Dykes of the Chicago White Sox, who is called "Pudgy" by one G. Stanley Cochrane of Detroit, selected one of a battery of six cigars blossoming in his breast pocket, applied a match to it and began talking through a smoke/screen.

Mr. and Mrs. William K. Vanderbilt gave a dinner dance tonight at Eagle's Nest, their estate overlooking Northport Harbor, in honor of Miss Phyllis Stevenson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Stevenson of Glen Cove, and George Whitney Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Whitney of Old Westbury, whose marriage is to take place tomorrow afternoon at the Stevenson home in Meadow SDrings.
While Governor A. B. Chandler, candidate for the United States Senate, lay ill in a hotel room here today, his wife and Judge Brady Stewart, his campaign manager, kept his speaking engagements here.

Common stock of United States Steel Corporation was 22.54 per cent in brokers' names on June 30, with 77.46 per cent held by investors, or 1,961,495 shares and 6,741,757 shares respectively, compared to 2,062,461 shares, or 23.70 per cent, held by brokers on March 31, when 6,640,791 shares, or 76.30 per cent, were in investors' hands.

Wilson Flohr of Canoe Brook was dethroned as New Jersey State junior golf champion today at the Echo Lake Country Club. The chunky Dartmouth sophomore was eliminated, 3 and 2, in a semi-final match by burly Chester Sanok, 19year-old public links golfer from Branch Brook.
Isadore Bellis of Philadelphia and Dick McKee of Miami Beach, Fla., will meet again for the Pennsylvania junior tennis championship. Bellis beat McKee last year.

The appeal of Dorothy T. Francis, president of the Association of Substitute Teachers of Shop Work in Vocational Schools, to the Department of Education was dismissed today by Commissioner Frank P. Graves.

The Boston Museum of Fine Arts was bequeathed two violins from the estate of Francis Jay Underhill, one of which was described in his will, filed for probate yesterday in the Surrogate's Court in Brooklyn, as being "an Antonio Stradivari violin of 1732, known as the Red Diamond."

Miss Marie Kiely and James M. Snowden, who are to be married in September, are here for a short visit with Mr. and Mrs. H. Jackson Starke on Jones Road. Tomorrow afternoon Mr. and Mrs. Starke will give a cocktail party for them be guests of honor at a dinner given by Mr. and Mrs. Harold O. Barker.

Fred Gutman, 21-year-old golfer from Berlin, Germany, captured the medal in the qualifying round of the annual Leewood Golf Club invitation tournament today. The youthful European registered a score of 35, 37--72 over the par 71 course to lead the list of fifty-three players who participated in the first day's activities.

Ending his second visit in eight years, the Right Rev. Edward Rodhe, Bishop of Lund, Sweden, who sailed last night on the Gripsholm in the royal party of Crown Prince Gustaf Adolf of Sweden, said that on this trip he had sensed in the United States an "uneasiness in the atmosphere."

After a delay until Aug. 1 had been refused to her because she was "completely broke," Mrs. Julia Donahue Higgins, cousin of Countess Barbara Hutton Haugwitz-Reventlow, paid a fine of $50 today on a charge of speeding seventy-five

Neither Miss Pam Barton nor Mrs. Marjorie Ross Garon will ac- Te company the British Curtis Cup golf team to this country, the United States Golf Association was informed yesterday, according to The Associated Press.

For the first time this week the afternoon newspapers today minimized the alleged invasion of Manchukuo near the Korean frontier by Soviet troops. It was reported the new policy was suggested by the Japanese Government, which feared the public was reaching a dangerous state of alarm.
Vince DiMaggio's home run with Max West on base in the ninth inning wasn't enough to win a ball game today, and the streaking Pirates took the first game of the series from the Bees, 4 to 3.

Life with the Giants these days being one "crucial series" after another, it was with considerable relief that Colonel Bill Terry and his somewhat harried champions saw a deluge wash out the first contest of their three-game set with Gabby Hartnett's Cubs today.

Casper L. Mink, a retired sergeant major of the United States Army, in which he served from 1885 to 1914, and for thirteen years head of police for the Remington Arms Company and later for the General Electric Company, died yesterday in Bridgeport Hospital of a cerebral hemmorhage. He was 72 years old.
Paul W. Stewart, 18, of Haworth, N. J., a Summer student at Clarkson College, died today of injuries suffered when he fell off a cliff at Aliens Falls, seven miles north of here.
Retail hardware store sales in June increased 6.5 per cent over May, after seasonal adjustment, according to a summary of figures of stores reporting to the National Retail Hardware Association.

Federal Judge Grover M. Moscowitz of Brooklyn reserved decision yesterday on a motion for permission to amend the reorganization plan submitted recently by the Prudence Company, Inc., which petitioned to reorganize under Section 77b of the Federal Bankruptcy Act on Feb. 1, 1935.

At the meeting of the Commonwealth Gas Corporation here today a board of directors was elected without opposition. This action came after two days of controversy by opposing factions, both of whom sought to win control of the management.

A suggestion that the National Mediation Board might take a hand in the railroad wage dispute was made today. H. A. Enochs, chairman of the Carriers' Joint Conference Committee, on leaving a meeting with the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen, said he would not be surprised if a Federal mediator was called in soon.

The round of week-end entertaining got under way today and will reach a climax tomorrow evening with a dance to be given by Mr. and Mrs. Francis Taylor to introduce to society the latter's daughter, Miss Fernanda de Mohrenschildt.

The Bureau of Mines reported today 1937 production of Portland cement was 33 per cent greater than in 1936. It put production at 116,174,708 barrels and shipments at 113,804,782. Shipments gained 1 per cent.

Here, where twenty years ago-from April until August, 1918 - Australian troops formed the spearhead in defense and in attack during the almost continuous battle to protect Amiens and the whole system of inter-allied communications, King George today dedicated Australia's national monument to her dead there, and said farewell to President Albert Lebrun and to France after what has been a very memorable four-day visit to France.
Three Jews and eight Arabs were killed and five Jewish workers were wounded in a series of clashes in widely separated districts today.

J. R. A. Hobson, 68 years old, of Richmond, Va., died suddenly last night at Broadway and Forty-fourth Street. Death was believed due to heart disease, but in falling Mr. Hobson's head struck the sidewalk and he received a severe wound. He was pronounced dead by an ambulance surgeon from Metropolitan Hospital.
Thirteen men, arrested on Thursday in a raid on a reputed pay-off headquarters of a gambling syndicate at 200 West Seventy-second Street, were arraigned yesterday in West Side Court.

Spruille Braden, United States delegate to the Chaco peace conference, told a joint session of the Argentine Congress today the Chaco settlement between Bolivia and Paraguay demonstrated that "the good-neighbor policy is a reality."

The American International Corporation reports a net asset value of $18,832,259 on June 30, equal to $1,883.22 for each $1,000 of debentures and to $8.83 a share on 1,000,000 common shares, compared to $17,453,422, or $1,745.34 and $7.45 respectively at Dec. 31, 1937.

Alfredo Salmaggi, director of the New York Hippodrome Opera Company, completed arrangements yesterday with the Long Island State Park Commission for the presentation of grand opera on the marine stage on Zach's Bay, Jones Beach, on two nights a week, Friday and Saturday, for the rest of the Summer.
Because German duties on tea, coffee and cocoa superseded the Austrian duties on July 15 the prices of these beverages have been reduced considerably.

The Department of Agriculture estimated today that farmers received $559,000,000 in June from sale of their products, plus government benefit payments. Similar receipts for June of last year were estimated at $631,000,000.
Foreign inquiries for American-made goods continue to exist in volume and great variety, the Commerce Department reported today.

Buying for Fall selling increased in the principal wholesale markets this week as inventories at most retail stores reached so low a point that more buyers revised their budgets upward, according to the weekly review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.
Canadian industrial labor conditions are comparatively stable and Western crop conditions are relatively favorable compared to July, 1937, according to the Bank of Montreal.

American Store Equipment and Construction Corp., in 549 W. 54th St.; Cross Brown Co., broker. Arcade Malleable Iron Co., in 342 Madison Ave.; F. Talsim, A. Bernstein, P. Stenenman, in 381 4th Ave.; Charles Bauer, in 3 .W. 22d St.; Herbert McLean , Purdy Management Corp., broker.

Sir Nowroji Saklatvala, chairman of the important Indian industrial company of Tata Sons, Ltd., died here during the night of a heart attack at the age of 64. In 1921 he represented Indian employers at the international labor conference in Geneva.

The judicial officers involved in the case against James J. Hines, Tammany district leader charged with being a member of the Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer policy racket gang, will be named by District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey.

In the cargo holds of airliners plying the domestic airways and the far-flung router of the international lines strange cargoes of increasing variety are finding their ways over thousands of miles of land and sea.
In the rapid upswing on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on June 25, when total volume in round lots jumped to 11,011,040 shares sold from 1,903,805 in the week ended on June 18,
Ward's Automotive Reports reported today "an increasing dearth in used cars in key points," resulting from buying "so aggressive that a marked acceleration in price ranges has occurred."

Much to the amazement of board attendants and members of the secretarial staff, the Board of Education, hurrying along at a dizzy speed, broke all school records yesterday when it held three special meetings within five minutes. Only six items, relating to PWA grants, were acted upon. Visitors who arrived a few minutes late found the hall at 500 Park Avenue empty.

Miss Hazel Hurst, a blind girl who lives at Oneonta, N. Y., part of the time but spends most of the year traveling over the world encouraging people with physical handicaps, sailed yesterday for London on the United States Lines steamship American Merchant, accompanied by her 3-year-old seeing-eye dog, Babe.
Wet fields forced cancellation today of next Sunday's opening match for the national junior polo championship and delayed the start of the tournament until next Thursday.

Governor Earle issued a formal call late today for a special session of the Legislature to convene Monday night to take action on charges of graft and bribery that have been brought against his administration.

Copper producers advanced the price yesterday of the metal in the domestic market from 9.75 to 9.875 cents a pound. This is the first change since July 5, when the price was advanced from 9.50 to 9.75 cents a-pound and it reflects the improved price for copper abroad. On July 1, the price was advanced from 9 to 9.50 cents a pound.

As the site for a modern factory building, a tract of about three and one-half acres on the west side of Broad Avenue, near the corner of Broad- Avenue and Pleasant View Terrace, Ridgefield, N; J., has been purchase by the Jenter Displays

The last-place Browns won today, 9 to 7, and broke the Senators' four-game victory streak. Outhitting the Browns, 13 to 11, the Senators could not bunch their blows with the same consistency, however.

Complaint about what he termed the difficulty of getting posts for veterans with the World's Fair was made last night by Jeremiah Cross, State commander of the American Legion, in a speech at the twentieth annual convention of the Queens County American Legion at Public School 150, Forty-third Avenue and Fortieth Street, Long Island City, Queens.

Vice President Larry MacPhail flew from Chicago today, hoping to see his Dodgers continue their progress against the Cardinals. But the Flatbush boys went up in the air shortly after their boss came down, and when they finally descended their hopes were shattered almost beyond repair.

John Bruce Thornton was convicted today on four counts for planning the abduction of Viscount Nuffield, British automobile manufacturer. Thornton, who is 50 years old, was sentenced to seven years' imprisonment.

Net asset value of United States and Foreign Securities Corporation on June 30 totaled $33,635,926, equivalent to about $160 a share for 210,000 shares of first preferred stock compared with $25,656,532, or $122.17 a share, on March 31.

Mayor Wilson's series of proposals for rehabilitation of the Philadelphia Hospital for Mental Diseases appeared today to be facing Councilmanic opposition in consequence of disclosure of conditions at Byberry by the Shapiro joint legislative committee.
Bernard H. Kroger, who died on Thursday, began his career with a poor job I and a good idea. When he retired six years ago

David S. Murden, the only Westchest County Republican leader to oppose the recent designation of William F. Bleakley for County President, was removed as Republican leader of the town of Cortland at a meeting here last night township, it was announced today by Charles F. Lent, the new leader.

James Marshall, president of the Board of Education, said in a speech yesterday that democracy is faced with many challenges, one being excessive armaments that result in increased taxes, increased resistance from the taxpayer and the lessening of the social services upon which democracies depend.

The will of Mrs. Maybelle Horlick Sidley, daughter of William Horlick, founder of the malted milk fortune, was filed in probate today by her brother, William Horlick Jr., a beneficiary of the $2,300,000 estate.

More than 1,000 persons, including members of both branches of the State Legislature and representatives of veterans' organizations, attended yesterday morning a funeral service for .State Senator Julius S. 'Berg, who shot himself in his office here last Wednesday.
Mount Robson, 12,972 feet, highest peak in the Canadian Rockies, has been climbed again. Hargraves Camp, outfitters here, announced today that William R. Hainsworth and Howard Carlson,

Automobile linage, which has been sharply curtailed this year under that for 1937, is expected to taper off further from now until the introduction of the new models in the Fall. With a few exceptions,

GOVERNORS ISLAND Each of the following Infantry Reserve officers, assigned or attached to the 392d Infantry, is ordered to active duty Aug. 7 at Plattsburg Barracks, New York, for training with the 392d Infantry: ...

Bromley Wharton, member of one of Pennsylvania's oldest families and active in State and city Republican politics for many years, died tonight at the home of his daughter, Miss Alice Taylor Wharton, in Ventnor, N. J. He was 74 years old.
Tass to (Russian Official News Agency) reported today that the Soviet Em- is bassy in Warsaw had protested to mo the Polish Government against a "blockade" of the embassy.

The Park Tilford Import ?orporation has acquired sole distributing rights to the wines produced and bottled by Beaulieu Vineyard at Rutherford, Calif., in the Napa Valley. The announcement marks Park Tilford's entry into the domestic wine trade on a large scale.

Numerous government reports occupied the attention of President Roosevelt today as he cruised toward the Galapagos Islands. The Houston is due Sunday afternoon for a week's visit among the islands, more than 500 miles west of Ecuador, to which they belong.

Thirty-six years ago "The Virginian" was selling like hot cakes. Some critics said that it came near being the longexpected "great American novel." Wister knew Wyoming and the cowboy. His Virginian cowboy, the soul of honor,

President Roosevelt has appointed John C. Wiley, now Consul General at Vienna, to the post of Minister to Latvia and Estonia. This is an advancement in rank for Mr. Wiley. It is richly deserved. For it is given to an unusually able and experienced member of our diplomatic corps,

A sharp reversal of the trend in building construction awards in the metropolitan district, particularly with respect to residential and public projects, took place in the final weeks of the first half of the year.

Fairly sharp increases in employment in New England have resulted from the upturn in general business which began a month ago, and moderate gains have been registered in the South and in the Middle Atlantic States, according to selling agents in several major lines who were interviewed here yesterday.

Delegate Robert T. Murray of Troy has introduced in the Constitutional Convention an amendment reading as follows: Nothing in this Constitution shall prevent the Legislature from permitting religious instruction, under the direction of a duly constituted religious body, for pupils in the free common schools by instructors of the same religious faith as the pupils instructed.

Demand for steer hinds and ribs, veal hindsaddles, lamb and pork loins improved in local markets yesterday. Steer cuts, cow and bull continued to move slowly. Steer hind and rib prices were uneven, lamb higher, bull lower, other classes mostly unchanged. Early trading in kosher meats indicated beef to be higher and other classes strong to higher. Conditions as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture follow:
William Jay Madden of Brookside Drive, Greenwich, died at the Greenwich Hospital today following a month's illness caused by an intestinal infection. His age was 47.
The Red Sox found Bobby Feller no mystery today and defeated the Cleveland Indians, 7 to 4, dropping the Tribe a full game behind the American League lead.

Miss Sarah E. Scott, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles J. Scott, was married to George Irvin Trull, son of the Rev. and Mrs. George Harvey Trull, also of this city, in the Westminster Presbyterian Church here tonight.
Little business was done in the stock markets here today, but the undertone was fairly firm. Gilt-edges were steady and foreign bonds were irregular.
A convict staged a chimney sit-down strike for six hours today at Bleak Dartmoor Prison, scene in 1932 of England's greatest prison mutiny of modern times.

Rex Flag, who ran such an improved race to take second in last week's Butler Handicap, is likely to rule the favorite today at Empire for the $10,000 Yonkers Handicap, which has attracted ten starters.

Income Estates of America, Inc., a periodic payment investment trust or "thrift plan." consented yesterday in United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania to a permanent injunction restraining it from violating Sections 17 and 5-b of the Securities Act of 1933 in the marketing of its securities.

The umbrella peddler has not been alone in his thanks for this week's incessant rain. Box-office men report a substantial rise in receipts as a result of the weather, at least one show having been saved from the warehouse.

The Soviet Army newspaper Red Star, describing alleged espionage activities of the clergy and of religious leaders, expressed alarm today over the fact there still are 30,000 religious organizations in Soviet Russia.

Senator Alva B. Adams, opponent of the bill to enlarge the Supreme Court and other New Deal measures, received an overwhelming vote over Supreme Court Justice Ben C. Hilliard, a New Deal adherent, for the designation for renomination today by the State Democratic Assembly.
J. E. Pridday, president of Frederick Loeser Co., yesterday announced several promotions within the organization to take over the duties of Charles Witzel, furniture buyer, who died recently.

The German press reports an interview in Manchukuo between a representative of the Berlin newspaper Angriff and the former Soviet General, G. S. Lushkoff, in which he allegedly said that Joseph Stalin's fall was imminent and that either Premier Vyacheslaff M. Molotoff or War Commissar Klementy E. Voroshiloff would succeed him.
Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of carded gray goods as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers. Association, Inc.:

In an old Protestant church at Nykerk, a small Zuider Zee town where several tombstones bear names now well known in the United States, a short ceremony was held today in the presence of Miss Florence Van Rensselaer of New York, who went there to honor two ancestors.

One of the four candidates for the Republican nomination for United States Senator from Kansas is the Rev. Gerald B. Winrod of Wichita. If there is anybody in Kansas, or out of it, who speaks with a more authentic voice for religious, racial and social bigotry he has yet to be found.

The Federal Circuit Court of Appeals voided and set aside today a finding of the National Labor Relations Board made last September, which upheld C.I.O. sit-down strikers in their seizure of the North Chicago plant of the Fansteel Metallurgical Corporation.

Homer Martin, international president of the United Automobile Workers of America, sent a letter today to each of the four suspended vice presidents of the U. A. W. in which he made known the nine charges on which they will be tried by the executive board Monday.
Secretary Ickes today approved fortyeight more non-Federal PWA projects in seventeen States and Puerto Rico, at an estimated cost of $14,608,023.

Three real estate operators were here for trial today on grand jury indictments which charged that they defrauded Mrs. Laura J. Starke Bel- Despi knap of Hollywood and New York of $178,000 and Mrs. Ida Troxel of Beverly Hills of $12,164 through investment enterprises. Trial was set for Sept. 22 in Superior Court.

About one American in every twentyfive of voting age pays a personal income tax to the Federal Government. A proposal is now being discussed in Washington, as it has been discussed many times before, to increase the number of taxpayers by lowering the exemptions granted in existing law. There are sound reasons for such action.

Yesterday's rain brought the third successive day of idleness to the Yankees and disappointment for the ladies' day throng planning to attend the opening of the series between the champions and the White Sox.

The Rev. Edward P. Dickle of the faculty of St. Mary's College, University of St. Andrews, Scotland, will end a preaching engagement tomorrow morning at the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Twelfth Street. He will preach at 11 o'clock.
The Detroit baseball club, its catching staff crippled by the accidental "beaning" of Rudy York, cleared the way today for possible return of Manager Mickey Cochrane to active duty.

A government check for the first farm tenant land-purchase loan in the Northeastern section of the United States will be presented Tuesday at a public ceremony to Leon H. Adams of Burlington, N. J., the Farm Security Administration announced today.

David E. Lilienthal, director of the Tennessee Valley Authority, in charge of power, who has been the chief target of Dr. Arthur E. Morgan's attacks, defended and extolled the TVA cost-allocation procedure and its yardstick at today's session of the Congressional inquiry.

George H. Chinnock, a radio operator born in Brooklyn and "all my life" a resident of New York City, has been rejected by Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine as ineligible for patrolman under the Lyons residence law, it was learned yesterday.

A special committee of investment bankers from all sections of the country, headed by Nevil Ford of the First Boston Corporation, New York City, has been appointed by B. Howell Griswold Jr., chairman of the Investment Bankers Conference, Inc.,

After repeatedly denying that he had received any written reports from undercover men engaged in labor espionage work and insisting that all such reports had been made orally, J. L. Williams, superintendent of Republic Steel Corporation's police

In a test case to determine if it has jurisdiction over the extension of the maturity date of investment certificates, the Securities and Exchange Commission began an action yesterday in Federal court against the Associated Gas and Electric Company, top holding concern in a $500,000,000 public utilities system.

The War Department announced today the coming voluntary retire- in two-seate ment of Colonel Upton Birnie Jr., 61 years old, until recently the army's chief of field artillery. In this post he held the temporary Building at rank of major general and will hold it in retirement.

Thirty thousand persons watched England put up a grim struggle for runs in the opening day's play of the fourth cricket test with Australia today. Mastered by a clever battery of bowlers the Englishmen batted for five hours to score 223, the Antipodeans in 34 minutes batting making 32 for one wicket in reply.
Emilio Romano, former Deputy Police Commissioner in charge of the Political and Social Order Department at general Police Headquarters, was arrested today by order of Chief of Police Filinto Muller.

Arnold Zimmerman, 18-year-old Princeton freshman of Bath, N. Y., led the way to the semi-finals through two rounds of match play today and established himself as favorite in the annual Finger Lakes Association golf tournament.

Central Duverny Gold Mines, Ltd., Montreal, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement under the Securities' Act of 1933 covering 800,000 shares of $1-par value common stock to be offered at 60 cents a share.

It was estimated that 10,000 persons, a large number of them invalids and war veterans, marched past the coffin of Queen Marie today. Shop windows, homes and street lamps throughout the city were draped in her honor.

Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins returned yesterday on the United States liner Washington. She spent six weeks in Europe, attending the International Labor Conference at Geneva, Switzerland, on June 15. She was the official delegate of the United States Government and said she was very pleased with the results.

The King and Queen were on parade in Paris this week, and the only complaint of the French, whose love of a royal spectacle equals that of their fellow-republicans in the United States, is that so few of the populace, crowding the streets as the cortege flashed by, were able to catch a glimpse of the visiting Majesties.
Six thousand Mormons from many States gathered today in this village for the annual conference of the Eastern States Mission of the Church of Jesus Christ and LatterDay Saints.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market - is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

A memorial service for Dowager Queen Marie of Rumania will be held at 4 o'clock on Monday afternoon at the Protestant Episcopal Cathedral of St. John the Divine, 112th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. The Right Rev. Policarp Morusca, Missionary Bishop of the Orthodox Rumanian Churches of North and South America, will conduct the rites of his church.
The Phillips Petroleum Company has about completed plans for the sale of $25,000,000 ten-year 3 per cent convertible debentures, it was announced yesterday by Frank Phillips, chairman of the company.

Election of the following certified public accountants as members of the American Institute of Accountants was announced yesterday: Ralph Noel Apple, William Kennethe Donald and Neville Craig Gee, all of Lybrand, Ross Brothers and Montgomery;

The conquerors of Seabiscuit and War Ad- poor ra miral-Stagehand and Menow--meet tomorrow in the tenth renewal of the $30,000 added Classic at Arlington Park in what may develop into nothing more than a two-horse race.

A promise of favorable consideration for a new $4,000,000 project in the city's housing program and an attack on "the rubber-yardstick" method of comparing public and private housing will be features of the Buffalo visit Today of Nathan Straus, United States Housing Administrator. The attack was made in an address at a luncheon sponsored by the Chamber of Commerce.

The committee acting for the first mortgage bondholders of the Warner Sugar Corporation has filed with the Chase National Bank as trustee objections to the expenditures of managers and has requested the bank to engage independent accountants to examine

The first nine railroads to report for June showed a decline of 49.6 per cent in net operating income from June, 1937. Increased freight traffic and reduced maintenance made the result favorable compared with May, when net operating income dropped 55 per cent from May, 1937.
Francis W. Estey, retired Boston attorney and a member of the Massachusetts Ballot Law Commission for the last thirty-five years, died today at his home in Malden. His age was 70.

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks 1,157,000 bales, against 1,133,000 a week ago, 1,138,000 two weeks ago, 1,130,000 three weeks ago and 855,000 a year ago; of which American 696,000 bales, against 707,000 a week ago, 723,000 two weeks ago, 730,000 three weeks ago and 301,000 a year ago.
Dorothy Hewlett's biography of Keats, "Adonais" (Bobbs-Merrill), has won the Rose Mary Crawshay prize of [Pound]100 for 1938 awarded by the British Academy. This award may be given annually

Henry Morgenthau Jr., Secretary of the Treasury, who will arrive in Paris tomorrow evening, will, according to present arrangements, spend three days in Paris before leaving with his family for a holiday in the South of France.
Spanish Insurgents, aided by Italian units, pounded against the Western gates of Viver today in an effort to open the way for, a new advance to the Mediterranean.

Stocks closed irregularly higher in dullest trading of week; turnover, 1,222,140 shares. United States Government and foreign bonds irregularly lower, Japanese and Italian issues weak, corporate group irregular; transactions, $7,840,500.

R. B. F. Barr's Aphrodite of the Royal Canadian Yacht Club kept a one-point lead for the George Cup when the third and final race of the series was called off today because the yachts failed to complete the course within the time limit.

MANBATTAN BENEDICT, HANNAH (Sept. 10. 1936). Gross assets, $22,637; net, $17,945. To Yetta Baum, sister, $3,033: Reake Oppenheimer, sister, $2,998; Brabra Rothschild, $1,000; Howard Oppenheimer, $1,000; Susanne Lieblich, $1,150; Ruth Rothschild, niece, specific personalty and $2,000; fifteen varying bequests. Chief assets, mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $18,679. Louis Klatzko, attorney, 299 Broadway.

The city of Chicago, Ill., will offer for sale on Aug. 5 through R. B. Upham, controller. $2,200,000 of water-revenue certificates, for which bidders have been asked to name the rate of interest. The certificates will be dated Aug. 1, 1938, and are to mature in equal amounts on Aug. 1, 1956, and 1957.

The 150 delegates attending the fourth national convention of the American Communications Association, C. I. O., at the Hotel Victoria engaged in a lively debate over the Spanish Loyalists yesterday afternoon. After the clashes the delegates,

There was a round of entertainment throughout the day for guests at various estates in the colony. Miss Ethel Wickham gave a dinner tonight at Bonnie Bourne, her home on Lake Agawam, in honor of Major Gen. William Mason Wright, U. S. A., retired, and Mrs. Wright of Washington, who are passing the week-end with her.

The Summer educational program of the Museum of the City of New York has been adapted to suit the needs of the public playschools, just as the Winter program is direacted to regular classes. Material is presented in a less pedantic fashion so that the children feel that they are really on vacation.

TOKYO, broadcasting direct reports of recent Japanese drives up the Yangtze River toward Hankow, was dialed on a recent evening when a new and powerful Oriental beam was pointed toward America's Eastern shores on sixteen-meter waves.
An analysis of the Federal Housing Administration's insured-mortgage system for 1937 shows that 108,738 mortgages were accepted, representing an aggregate sum of $447,519,716 for the year.
The government of Guatemala today announced its delegation to the Pan-American Conference at Lima, Peru, in December as follows: Forrel Carlos Salazar, Minister to Peru, chairman;
Bruised and exhausted but happy, three women tourists were found today in the Western New Mexico lava badlands, where they had wandered four days without food and with little water or sleep.

The Crossett Lumber Company, which owns the town of Crossett,. Ark., is reported today by the National Labor Relations Board as citing Scripture to justify espionage against an American Federation of Labor union in 1935.

The movement to nominate President Roosevelt for a third term was denounced by State Senator Thomas C. Desmond tonight at the banquet which closed the State meeting of the Columbian Republican League.

Miss Marguerite Verreau was at liberty in $500 bail today pending grand jury action on a charge of impersonating another young woman in a marriage ceremony. Miss Verreau waived examination when arraigned on the charge yesterday before Justice Frank Warner at New Berlin.

This Fall Hofstra College of New York University at Hempstead will enter its first year as a fouryear college and will present its First group of candidates for degrees next June at the 107th annual commencement of the university.

While torrental rains swept the Eastern Seaboard, the Lake States, with the exception of parts of Michigan, were today enjoying ideal weather. Temperatures throughout this area ranged from 72 here and in Northern Michigan to from 86 to 90 in Southern Illinois and Indiana. The only area to experience any rain today was that part of Michigan along Lake Huron, where the Weather Bureau reported a "good rain."

The body of Samuel Insull was buried in Putney Vale Cemetery today in the presence of twelve persons. The Rev. John M. Bird, curate of Putney, led the Church of England burial service in the little whitewashed, oak-seated chapel.

TO the stay-at-home collector and to the interior decorator as well as the lover of antiques paying a Summer visit to New York, an at-, traction is offered in the exhibition of some newly acquired decorative art of yesterday in the Recent Accessions Gallery of the Metropolitan Museum.
The Automobile Merchants Association of New York expresses the fear that the city's new occupancy tax, due on July 30, may become a yearly tax instead of just a temporary or one-year tax.

The Marine Midland Trust Company has placed a $590,000 building loan, guaranteed by FHA, on a project for a seven-story fireproof apartment covering an entire block at Oakland and Elwood Avenues in Mount Vernon, known as Pennwood Apartments and sponsored by Paul Braude.

WASHINGTON. NOTHING else is so vicious as a first-class family fight. It is something which no true sportsman can really relish. When two unrelated antagonists come to blows they ordinarily square off in open fashion and go at each other with at least some deference to Queensberry rules.
The Phillies took advantage of four errors for a five-run splurge in the fifth inning today, but failed to withstand a strong attack and the Reds won, 10 to 9.

The Automobile Club of New York, the Automobile Club of America and the American Automobile Association reported yesterday that their telephones were busy all day with calls of motorists who wanted to learn the condition of roads in New Jersey, Pennsylvania and upState New York after the hours of rainfall.

So far as the Constitutional Convention is concerned the controversy as to the best way of getting rid of grade crossings is over. The crossing elimination mandate will be in the new Constitution when it is submitted to the voters.
