" WHEN I get out of bed I have paid Egypt a compliment in two reaspects " remarks Mr. Crawford in his study of our cultural evolution. "In the first place the idea of a bed was first conceived by a Nile craftsman; second, Time was an invention of an Egyptian mathematician.

A new proposal for the solution of the Palestine problem has been advanced by the Iraq Government on behalf of itself and the Governments of Saudi Arabia and Yemen. This proposal was brought to Palestine by an official messenger from Iraq and was submitted to Ragheb Bey Nashashibi,

As Kentucky's tense primary race heads for a roaring finish two weeks from today, a new survey of public opinion in that State shows Governor A. B. (Happy) Chandler gaining on Senator Alben W. Barkley, the New Deal favorite and the man President Roosevelt went into Kentucky to help early this month.
AS Summer reading, this book serves a purpose. The critical faculty is in abeyance, there is a vacant hour to be whiled away,

The Athletics and the Tigers will play a double-header here on Monday to replace the twin bill rained out today. Monday was originally an open date. The postponement today kept the Athletics idle for the sixth consecutive day.

Evidences of encouragement for real estate owners are becoming more apparent, according to H. Adams Ashforth, president of the firm of Albert B. Ashforth, Inc., in calling attention yesterday to some of the sales and rental activities during the first half of the present year, particularly in respect to apartment houses.

In modernizing a home built several years ago having the old-fashioned formal parlor which was seldom used, an FHA official points out that the practically useless parlor may easily be combined with the living room of the house, thereby making that room all that the name implies.

The Chamber of Commerce of the United States asserted today that government competition with private enterprise was "one of the gravest present threats against economic freedom" and was "retarding recovery."
From virtually all sections of the country, it appeared tonight, will come the college all-star eleven which will start against the professional Washington Redskins Aug. 31 at Soldier Field.

The World Conference for Action on the Bombardment of Open Towns and the Restoration of Peace today began its two-day parley to consider means to achieve the aims implied by its name. Speakers at the opening session included Bishop G. Ashton Oldham of Albany and Theodore Dreiser, the author.

MICKEY ROONEY, when In a reminiscent mood, confesses that his youthful ambition was to become a chemist. This solemn reflection on diverted objectives always brings with it a corollary to the effect that he now wants to be a director.
Government regulation and control of the Winnipeg Grain Exchange was supported by directors of the Western wheat pools at an inter-provincial conference here today.

Vines with bright colored fruits are more scarce than those with vivid flowers. An annual vine with showy fruits is especially to be noted. Bryonopsis has cherrylike fruits, green with white markings, which turn red when they are ripe.

J. Richard (Dixie) Davis, former attorney and spokesman for the late Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, alleged to have been the head of the policy racket here, although a prisoner in the Tombs in default of $75,000- bail since his arrest in Philadelphia last February, has made frequent visits to the home of Hope Dare, 36 East Sixty-fourth Street, and elsewhere, it became known yesterday.

Dr. Lemuel Caro of New Rochelle was among the fourteen passengers killed yesterday in an airplane crash near Czernowitz, Rumania. He called himself a "flying doctor" in a recent interview here and said he was making a European trip in behalf of the New York World's Fair Art Department.

A Pacific Coast team, Tom Kruger of Santa Barbara, Calif., and Paul Wilson of Ventura, Calif., today won the Pennsylvania State junior doubles tennis championship by beating Larry Dee of San Francisco and Dick McKee of Miami Beach, Fla., 6-3, 6-2, 6-3.
The Southampton Horticultural Society will hold its annual flower show on Wednesday and Thursday. Paul Heetman of Southampton is secretary of the society.

Although many large cities still have little to show in the form of homes costing less than $4,000, dwellings in that price class have constituted nearly one-third of the single-family residential units constructed in the nation this year, according to an analysis of reports comprising the thirty-first semiannal realty market survey recently completed by the National Association of Real Estate Boards.
VINCENT SHEEAN'S new novel is the story of the battle of Fontenoy, fought between the French and the English by the village in Flanders on May 11, 1745.
Ligarotti, South American horse owned by Bing Crosby and Lin Howard, won the $5,000 Aloma Handicap, the closing feature race of the Hollywood Turf Club's initial thirty-three-day racing meet today.
Mr. and Mrs. John G. Nelson of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Vivian Wilbour Nelson, to Dr. Frederick Albert Wies, son of Mr. and Mrs. John P. Wies of Orange, Conn.

NEWPORT, R. I.-The Newport Casino Theatre is to open its six-week season on Tuesday evening as another diversion for members of the Summer colony and their guests. A revival of the old comedy "Fashion" is to be presented as the opening bill; Dorothy Sands and Jeanne Casselle will have the featured roles.

Rains continued throughout the entire central and eastern portions of the Cotton Belt yesterday and, with nervousness over their effect on the crop increasing, prices on the Cotton Exchange advanced 7 to 10 points.
Columbia University's distant past is recalled with the presentation to the university of three pairs of iron gates dating from preRevolutionary days and one from 1830.

FRANZ JOSEF, who at 32 became the ruler of the independent principality of Liech tenstein on March 30, will enter philately's gallery next month when 2-franc and 3fr stamps bearing his portrait will be released as part of his country's formal celebration of his elevation in succession to the elderly Prince Franz I.

Poor weather cut fairly deeply into retail trade last week and the losses from a year ago were increased in most districts. The peak selling season on Summer merchandise was completed, and, while store executives were shaping plans on Fall merchandise, they anticipated a lull through August, unless both weather and industrial conditions improved.

To get well-trained and intelligent young men as employes, business men will do best by going directly to the colleges to fill vacancies, A. L. Rose, manager of the student employment bureau at City College declared in his report to the faculty committee for- student employment, made public yesterday.

The conclusion of the match between Miss Eunice Dean of San Antonio, Texas, and Miss Helen Bernhard of New York to decide the New Jersey women's tennis championship will be played at the convenience of both, Louis Shaw, chairman of the tournament committee, announced today.

Pearl White, heroine of a thousand breath-taking adventures in the blood-curdling mystery serials of the silent-movie days, was reported to be in grave condition tonight at the American Hospital, where she is being treated for a liver ailment.
The Villa Mille Fiori, estate of the late Morgan J. O'Brien, was sold for $16,500 at auction this afternoon. The seller was the Neirbo Realty Company, controlled by the O'Brien family,

Winslow Shelby Pierce, retired senior member of the New York law firm of Pierce Greer, who was formerly Mayor of Bayville for ten years, died here today of heart disease at his home. Dunstable. He was 80 years old. In ill health for two years, he retired last October from law practice and various important railroad connections.

Russo-Japanese tension is a matter of record for almost two decades. Every now and again a new incident marks the steady progress of hostility between the two nations. Since both Japanese and Russian leaders hold theoretically that war between the two countries is inevitable, the latest incident along the Russo-Manchurian border-the Russian occupation of a hill near Changkufeng-has added new fuel to an already dangerous fire.

The Rockaway Hunting Club's annual invitation golf tournament, which is rapidly turning into a week-end swimming meet, reached its semi-final stages late this afternoon with four hardy survivors of two eighteen-hole rounds of match play advancing into tomorrow morning's semi-final bracket.

The fans cheered when First Baseman Ed Hartness of Americus hit a long home run over the wall of the new baseball park here in a Georgia-Florida League game with Thomasville on Thursday. Today club officials groaned when they counted the cost of that home run.

The old Schlesinger estate, consisting of six acres with an eighteen-room house on Ninth Avenue, College Avenue and 119th Street, College Point, L. I., has been sold by the Guaranty Trust Company and Kate M. Stone and Harry S. Bandler, as executors of the estate of Anna Schlesinger, and will be developed into a residential center.

SUMMER evening fetes have never been so thrilling as this season. A summary of the season's evening galas reveals some interesting style trends. There is a strong tendency to define and accentuate the waistline wherever it is placed, high or low. Accessories are colorful and individual;

THE Munich Festival opens today with the world-premiere of Richard Strauss's new one-act opera, "Friedenstag" (Peace Day). Joseph Gregor, director of the Vienna National Library, wrote the text for this work, which deals with a dramatic episode of the Thirty Years' War.
THE Museum of Costume Art hopes ultimately to establish a complete record of clothes, in the flesh, as it were; to make a collection of costumes of every nation in every period.

Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney left Montauk today on the Adventure for Martha's Vineyard. He will return next week. John Pratt Jr., here fishing today on the Sea Puss, had Rodman Wanamaker Jr. as his guest.

The Federal Savings and Loan Associations of Metropolitan New York received deposits "far in excess of expectations" in the first half of 1938, Harold N. Brodhead, chairman of public relations, reported yesterday.
The strife in Palestine continues unabated and hopes for an improvement of conditions seem scant. One need not be a confirmed pessimist to despair of a possible return to normalcy in the near future.

Guy K. Bard, State Attorney General, busied himself today preparing legislation to be submitted to the General Assembly when it opens its special session Monday night to take up charges of graft and corruption against the Earle administration and to consider a score of other matters.

SHANGHAI.-Astronomical figures must be used to describe the loss of life and property suffered by China since the beginning of the undeclared war with Japan on July 7, last year. If official Japanese estimates of Chinese military casualties are to be accepted, the loss of Chinese lives must be put at about 1.300,000, and this figure does not take into account the as yet undetermined losses occasioned by the Yellow River floods.

The FHA insured mortgage systern has been responsible in removing, to a large degree, the prejudice against long-term real estate mortgages in many sections of the country, points out a housing official.

The political partnership between Great Britain and France which was formally celebrated by the King's and Queen's visit to Paris this week is far closer and more binding than the entente to which George VI's grandfather was credited with contributing thirty-four years ago.

Three hundredd and eighty-five loans to idustry, aggregating $10,849,960, were authorized in June in the program intended particularly to aid mall businesses, the Reconstruction Finance Corporation reported today.

Although Sullivan and Ulster Counties suffered most from the floods of the past week, the area affected extended from the lower Catskill Mountains and along the Pennsylvania border into the Adirondacks and to the Great Lakes. Western and Central New York had a severe rainstorm, accompanied by lightning and high winds, last night.

Acquisition of 750 acres of additional land near Yorktown, Va., to enable preservation of the entire area of the Yorktown siege which ended the Revolutionary War will be possible under legislation enacted at the last session of Congress.
Among those who gave dinners tonight before the ball given by Mr. and Mrs. Francis Taylor were Mr. and Mrs. John Jacob Astor, Miss Julia A. Berwind and Mrs. Drexel Dahlgren.

Within the space of two weeks we have witnessed four spectacular achievements of that new species of humanity-the flying man. Howard Hughes and his companions have circled the globe in less than four days.
Domestic wheat markets opened steady today in sympathy with Liverpool and Winnipeg, but turned easy later on scattered professional selling and hedging pressure.

Perhaps the average citizen, wiping his brow, cannot appreciate it, but the last seven days of prolonged rainfall is due to a "cold front" which has remained stationary over this area for the last few days, condensing into rain the warm air flowing in from the sea.

Settlement of the strike at the Chicago Hardware Foundry Company in near-by North Chicago was announced today by Harry E. Scheck, Federal Department of Labor conciliator. Mr. Scheck said that the strikers would return to work Monday under a 5 per cent wage reduction.

IN COMMEMORATION of the rededication of the restored Rheims Cathedral, which was almost ruined by German shells during the World War, France has issued a 65-centime plus 35c blue illustrating the edifice and inscribed "Reims 10.VII.1938" (Rheims July 10, 1938). The rededication services were held on that date.

THE CUT DIRECT. By Alice Tilton. 286 pp. New York: W. W. Norton Co. $2. BESIDES being a mystery story with enough bafflement to make it well worth while, this is an uproarious farce comedy setting forth the happenings of one busy day in the life of Leonidas Witherall and a few other people, each of whom is in danger of being arrested for murder and quite possibly convicted.

The Surry Players will give their first performance on Mount Desert Island at the Building of Arts next Friday. The play, which is being given for the benefit of the Island Young Men's Christian Association, will be an advance showing of "Hedda Gabler."

For the first time since April last year general business conditions have improved in all parts of the United States, the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents reported yesterday in its monthly summary of industrial activity.

The Seaboard Oil Company of Delaware and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for the quarter ended on June 30 a net profit of $437,157 after deductions for Federal income taxes, depreciation, depletion, amortization, intangible drilling and development costs, provision for contingencies and other charges. This was equal to 35 cents each on 1,244,383 shares of no par capital stock.

Bonds called last week for redemption before maturity were in slightly larger volume than in the preceding week. Again the dates of payment were mostly in future months. The list of new retirements was fairly well diversified; they included several Land Bank issues,

To extend protection to dealers and purchasers of General Electric appliances and air-conditioning apparatus against loss from various causes during the financing period, the General Electric Contracts Corportion yesterday announced a new customer-insurance plan.

THE AUTOBIOGRAPHY OF A PURPOSE. By William Alanson White, M. D. Introduction by Ray Lyman Wilbur. 273 pp. New York: Doubleday, Doran Co. $3. By PERCY HUTCHISON WHEN the late William Alanson White, director of the great government hospital for mental cases, St. Elizabeth's, in Washington,

WESTPORT, N. Y.-Several hundred admirers of the late Rev. Dr. S. Parkes Cadman, coming from various vacation centers of the Adirondacks and the Champlain Valley, are expected to join with members of the Westport colony this morning for dedication of a memorial to Dr. Cadman before the Westport Methodist Church, in which the minister, then a guest preacher in Westport's annual union religious services, preached his last Sermon on July 5, 1936.

The combined track forces of Princeton and Cornell, surprising English critics with their balance and good form, drew even in their international rivalry with Oxford and Cambridge by winning today's meet, nine events to three, at White City Stadium.

(Time Is P. M., Eastern Daylight-Saving, Unless Otherwise Indicated) TODAY 12:30-1:30--Music Hall of the Air: Perole String Quartet-WJZ. 1:30-2:00-Daniel J. Doherty, Commander American Legion, Speaking at Legion Convention in Cincinnati-WOR. 1:30-3:00-Federal Symphony Orchestra Concert-WNYC. 2:00-3:00-Philadelphia Orchestra, Eugene Ormandy and Charles O'Connell, Conductors; Edward Roecker Jr., Baritone-WJZ. 2:30-3:00-Paul Bellamy, Editor Cleveland Plain Dealer, at American Bar Association Meeting, Cleveland-WEAF. 3:004:00-Chautauqua Symphony, Albert Stoessel, Conductor; Ernest Hutcheson, Pianist-WEAF.

WHEN Antonia Brico directs the Philharmonic - Symphony at the Lewisohn Stadium tomorrow night it will be the first time in the orchestra's history that a woman ever has held the baton over this organization.
A divorce was granted today to Mrs. Helen G. Stelling from A. Carl Stelling. They were married June 8, 1935. An agreement was reached as to the custody and support of their two children.

SHIPS AND SAILORS: THE STORY OF OUR MERCHANT MARINE. By William H. Clark. Illustrated. 322 pp. Boston: L. C. Page Co. $3.50. OPTIMISM as to the American merchant marine recurs about every once in so often. It is much the same as outcroppings of pride in the scion of a once powerful family looking back to better days.

WRITERS George Thomas in "My Mind a Kingdom" anent novels, news and dustmen, or street sweepers, as they are called here: "A novel of itself is not news, and neither is a dustman-there are too many of both. But if a dustman wrote a novel that was published, that would be news."
Dennis F. Kelly, former president of the Fair Store and long one of Chicago's civic leaders, died today in a hospital at Bergen, Norway. He was 70 years old.

The Automobile Club of New York announced yesterday that it had appealed to WPA Administrator Harold L. Ickes to approve Mayor La Guardia's request for a grant to cover 45 per cent of the cost of constructing the proposed $70,000,000 vehicular tunnel between the Battery and Hamilton Avenue, Brooklyn.
A policy of peaceful collaboration with world powers was endorsed today by statesmen of the seven so-called Oslo neutrality countries meeting here to review foreign relations.

Three outmoded tenements have been turned into a modern elevator apartment building at 152 East Eighty-fourth Street, and rapid renting of the suites is reported by the Lexanne Realty Corporation, owner.

Charging a frameup and failure to get a fair hearing, the four suspended United Automobile Workers vice presidents hit back today at Homer Martin, U. A. W. president. The four, Richard T. Frankensteen, Walter N. Wells, Ed Hall and Wyndham Mortimer, will go on trial Monday morning before the union's executive board.
In spite of the ruling of the Bank of Brazil that yesterday reopened the purchase of German compensated marks, observers here see possible future trade advantages for the United States.

The possibility that the British Government would eventually have to train every one to fill a particular post was expressed in a recent speech by Sir Thomas Inskip, Minister for the Coordination of Defense, at Dean Close School in Cheltenham.

CASTAWAY BOATS. By Victor Slocum. 311 pp. Color illustrations by Charles Rosner. Maps by the Author. New York: Lee Furman, Inc. $3. THIS is the time of year when books of adventure make more than a wonted appeal.

Foreclosures on non-farm real estate during the first five months of this year were 23.1 per cent below those recorded during the corresponding period of 1937, according to the Federal Home Loan Bank Board.
At the recent conference in Washington of Southern spokesmen, the poverty of the South compared with other sections of the country was attributed by implication to the effects of the Civil War.

Bob Feller admitted today his fast ball, which made him the boy wonder of baseball, is gone. The Cleveland pitcher, knocked out of the box here the fifth time in four weeks, said he didn't know what was the matter.
Miss Frances A. Gerster, daughter of Mrs. Frank Gerster of Rye and the late Mr. Gerster, was married to the Rev. Charles W. Wilding, son of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Wilding

The signing of the treaty of peace and friendship by Bolivia and Paraguay here on Thursday after three years of difficult diplomatic negotiations terminated the longstanding Chaco dispute, which has been the most dangerous of South America's several troublesome border conflicts.

The mere suggestion that income tax rates be reduced while the Federal Government is facing a current deficit approaching the huge sum of $4,000,000,000 would probably appear to many as almost unpatriotic. Any such condemnation, however, would reflect only a most superficial view of taxation policies.

WITH their books for the first half of 1938 closed, aircraft manufacturers in the Los Angeles area, comprising four of the nation's major factories, last week counted more than $68,200,000 worth of unfilled orders-and announced that this figure marks an all-time high in backlogs. Several items do not appear on the company's official audit sheets.

JOSEPH CONRAD was that rare phenomenon on the literary scene, a foreigner who taught Englishmen how to use their own language. In revenge readers of English prose have come to ignore him. Conrad was caught in a trap from which there was no escape.
MY SISTER EILEEN. By Ruth McKenney. 226 pp. New York: Harcourt, Brace Co. $2. TRUTH may be stranger than fiction but isn't often fun nier. According to Ruth McKenney, it is.

EXCEPT for "Maritza," a heavily Anglicized and much devitalized version of a successful Continental musical comedy, there have been no new plays in London this Week. There was only one last week, not many more in the week previous to that:

New building operations characterized many of the Long Island suburban sections in Queens and Nassau Counties last week and plans were reported from several centers for the opening in August of additional residential communi ties.

Miss Aimee Outhouse of Ossining chairman of the garden bridge party to be held here at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur J. Morris, The Trees, for the benefit of the Christ Child Day Nursery and Bethany home on Wednesday.
Elimination of waste space is one of the features of the new residence of Albert J. Quinby, built at 85 Old Mill Road in Strathmore-at-Great Neck, L. I.

The names of 460 students in the day and evening divisions of the New York University School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance who had attained the honor roll for the second semester of the 1937-1938 academic year were made public yesterday by Dean John T. Madden.

The cotton producers' pool established in connection with the first AAA program is ready to start buying up all outstanding participationtrust certificates in order to liquidate the pool's activities, the Deapartment of Agriculture announced today.
The Fire Department here began early tonight the unprecedented operation of ferrying residents of homes along the usually tiny Mamaroneck River to higher ground in rowboats.

Miss Jean Derby Ferris, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Henry Ferris of Tide Crest, this place, and Glen Ridge, N. J., has completed the plans for her marriage next Saturday to Nils Anderson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Anderson

LONDON.--Now that the Hong Kong silver dollar has come to an end, the famous old Maria Theresa dollar is the only "trade dollar" which survives. It ceased to be legal tender in its own country, the old Austro-Hungarian Empire, in 1854,
Pronouncing the intergovernmental meeting on political refugees Evian-les-Bains, France, "a success," Rabbi Jonah B. Wise, in a sermon at Central Synagogue, Fifty-fifth Street and Lexington Avenue,

Water lilies--gems of the garden pool--are at their height of bloom now during the heat of Summer. Above the floating leaf pads open rosette flowers of gay reds or yellows. There are also indescribably delicate hues of palest pink and clear yellow.

Seeking to rally employes to boycott illegal bolita gambling, business men of the Tampa area are attacking an evil that has become an economic parasite all over Florida. Other communities are watching Tampa's effort and several already are planning mass meetings to arouse public sentiment.

Buildings with little or no ornament, and of the simplest materials, may often be more beautiful than those of the most expensive marbles "tricked" over with the most lavish carving of ornament and sculpture, declares Talbot F. Hamlin, librarian of the Columbia University School of Architecture.

Mrs. John C. Norris of Chestnut Hill, Pa., is general chairman of the annual Narragansett Horse Show which will take place on Aug. 20, at the Point Judith Polo Field, which has been lent by Mr. and Mrs. Philip S. P. Randolph for the event. The horse show this year benefits St. Peter's-by-the-Sea Episcopal Church.
The greatest steel-polishing job ever undertaken, to insure accurate pointing of the 200-inch eye of the world's greatest telescope to be set up on Mt. Palomar, Calif., is finished.

The award of seven scholarships, given by five American branches of the English-Speaking Union and by the education committee of the union, was announced yesterday by Frank S. Coan, general secretary. The scholarships will enable five Americans to spend a month in England and two Englishmen to spend the same period in the United States this Summer for travel and study.

AMERICAN stamp collectors are watching with interest a movement inaugurated by the Swedish Philatelic Society to have the hobby's leading groups in Europe and America "unite and make an organized campaign" against "unnecessary" and "speculative" issues, including commemoratives.

Miss Fernanda de Mohrenschildt, daughter of Mrs. Francis Taylor and the late Ferdinand de Mohrenschildt, who had been an official of the Russian Embassy in Washington, made her debut to society here tonight at a colorful dance given by Mr. and Mrs. Taylor at their Summer home on Annandale Road and the Cliffs.

THEIR small metallic voices admonish great waters. With cocky assurance they whir along dark tropic rivers and white Arctic bays. They carry laughing boys and girls -on Summer lakes. They range with lonely fishermen into the silences of fjords.

The engagement and approaching marriage of Miss Dorothy Agnes Hand, daughter of Mrs. Thomas Hand of this city and Mantoloking, and the late Mr. Hand, to Desmond Lockhart-Mummery of London has been announced by her mother. The marriage will take place early next month.
Through last Thursday the Commodity Credit Corporation had made advances on 5,464,137 bales of cotton from the 1937 crop, according to information received yesterday by the New York Cotton Exchange.

Seward H. Mott, chief of the land planning section of the Federal Housing Administration, reported yesterday that the demand is steadily increasing for the cooperative services of the FHA land planning consultants. This indicates, he holds, the rising activity in the building field.

According to figures issued today coincident with the opening of the World Anti-Bombing Conference in Paris, 16,532 noncombatants were killed and 21,752 were wounded in China by Japanese planes from July, 1937, until June, 1938. Heavy casualties in the recent bombings of Wuhan, Canton and Swatow would materially increase those totals.

WHILE almost a quarter million Boy Scouts will be having some kind of camping experience this Summer, there will be many other lads who will not be able to get away for vacation. For such Scouts a wide range of activities is being carried out under troop leaders in many cities and towns.

The horse that had finished eleventh defeated the horse that had run second in the Butler Memorial a week before when they again met yesterday in the $10,500 Yonkers Handicap, getaway feature which attracted 15,000 persons to Empire City despite atrocious weather conditions.

The first veteran of Scotland Yard to enroll in the Federal Bureau of Investigation's "National Police Academy," Henry Arthur Leslie,, a detective inspector, completed the regular three-month course today and was graduated with 258 others. He went at once to New York and will sail for Glasgow Wednesday.

For the first time since the Millinery Stabilization Commission initiated its practice of holding cooperative millinery shows, popularprice hats are to be included in the Aug. 2 event, according to Walter K. Marks, chairman of the trade promotion committee.

IT is altogether too soon to wonder about the possible outcome of the Federal action begun last week against the eight major producing companies accusing them, in the most polite terms of an equity proceeding, of being consistent and flagrant violators of the Sherman Anti-Trust Law.

A steady movement back to the farm, which began about 1930, is continuing, according to a recent Census Bureau survey. In the 19201930 decade the survey shows that the cities drew from the farms an estimated 6,000,000 in excess of the number that the farms drew from the cities.

The fourth England-Australian cricket test match has developed into a stern battle between two evenly-matched teams. Unless rain intervenes there is every prospect that the deadlock, resulting from two drawn encounters and abandonment of the third game, will be broken in the present test.

Barcelona has virtually accepted the newest proposal for an exchange of military prisoners with the Insurgents, in which fourteen Americans figure, it was learned here today from American Ambassador Claude G. Bowers, who is acting as intermediary.

Golf's sensational sophomore, Slammin' Sam Snead, slapped his brand on the game's all-time record book today. Almost "burning up" Olympia Field's difficult No. 1 course, the 26-year-old star from West Virginia scored an eight-under-par 64 to spreadeagle the first-round field in the $5,000 Chicago open championship.

Stocks and bonds did well last week and most commodities were steady to firm. After experiencing indecision in midweek, the stock market pushed ahead and reached a new high level for the year yesterday, its highest level since Oct. 9.

A CONCERT will be given by the Naumburg Orchestra in memory of Elkan Naumburg, founder of the annual series of concerts bearing his name, next Sunday afternoon, on the Mall in Central Park. Walter W. Naumhave augmented the original series burg and George W. Naumburg of three outdoor free events by a fourth presented yearly on July 31, the anniversary of their father's death.

Nedayr, a 15to-1 shot, tossed the 3-year-old championship of the American turf into a tangled mess today by racing to a surprise victory in the $35,025 Classic Stakes at Arlington Park. The little brown colt, owned by Willis Sharpe Kilmer, Binghamton, N. Y., publisher, won by a length from Bull Lea; entry of Warren Wright of Chicago. Townsend B.

George Zengaras, popular GreekAmerican lightweight from the East Side, will apear in the star bout of eight rounds at the New Dyckman Oval tomorrow night. His opponent will be Johnny Rinaldi of the Bronx, who has quite a following in his home section.

THE program of the fifth annual Bennington Festival has just been made available in its complete form. In previous years it has been the practice of the Bennington School of the Dance at Bennington College, the sponsoring organization, to have one leading dancer and his company in residence through the school's six-week term preparing a new work for presentation

One man was killed and nine persons were injured, two seriously, a few miles from here today when a Chicago-bound bus with twenty-four passengers on board skidded down a steep, rain-swept hill, struck a concrete bridge abutment, crashed into an embankment and turned over in the road.

Dizzy Dean, the $185,000 enigma of baseball and perhaps the most talented performer of his time when putting a serious mind to it, swept back today as the most commanding figure of the National League pennant race.

Trips to points of interest in metropolitan New York, now in full swing as part of Summer school activities, have become an established part of the curricula of many of the city's colleges. Started originally to give out-of-town students an opportunity to see New York on guided tours, the programs have been revised to help to adapt the school to the community in many cases.

Members of the Congressional investigating committee questioned David E. Lilienthal, TVA director in charge of power, closely today about the Authority's fixing its wholesale and retail yardstick rates for the sale of electricity in 1933.

Carmine Napolitano, 32 years old, whose police record dates back to 1918, was shot and killed at 9:15 o'clock last night at Mulberry and Hester Streets. Passers-by told the police that the slayers fired about twenty shots and escaped in two automobiles.

THOUGH the contingency of our being cast ashore upon a desert island is growing more arid more remote, we have often thought-prodded thereunto by booksellers-what hundred books we should take along, but more often still on what kind of person we should like to have clinging alongside of us to the raft.
A graduated schedule of fees for planning housing projects has been presented by the American Institute of Architects to Nathan Straus, as administrator of the USHA, "for one year's trial."
Grand Circuit horsemen, beset by rains which-washed out five days of light harness racing here this week, pulled stakes tonight and headed for Agawam Park, Springfield, Mass.

SYDNEY.--For years past the once prosperous Australian pearling industry has been poor, but now comes a pearl valued in Paris at nearly $50,000--a bit of luster that is worth 5,000 times its weight in gold.

Some 170 midshipmen of the second class at Annapolis arrived yesterday morning on six navy destroyers after a training cruise that took them into several Atlantic ports. The ships dropped anchor in the Hudson off Fifty-ninth Street.

The clouds on the Montauk horizon seem to be dark, both literally and figuratively, according to letters and telephone calls we have received in the past few days. The question that seems to be bothering both sportsmen and commercial fishermen is again the matter of "sportsmanship in fishing," and the bone of contention seems to be the broadbill swordfish.

To the world at large motionpicture directors are known, if at all, by their names only. Rarely, if ever, are they photographed by a motion-picture camera, since most of them are not particularly photogenic and definitely not in the same eyefilling class as their more symmetrical stars.

LONDON, Ky., July 23.--With an investigation under way into rumors of the existence of a plot to influence the jury in the Harlan conspiracy trial, court recessed for the week-end today after the government closed its counter-attack on the defense case.

Invitations have been accepted by Andy Stopper, left halfback, and John Mellus, tackle, two outstanding performers on the undefeated Villanova team last Fall, to play with the Eastern College All-Stars, who will meet the Football Giants in the third annual New York Herald Tribune Fresh Air Fund game at the Polo Grounds Wednesday night, Sept. 7,
A wedding that was attended by members of society of the North and South Shore colonies and New York took place this afternoon in the gardens of Meadow Spring,

The Real Estate Association of the State of New York states Ray Hofford, executive vice president, is seeking support in the Constitutional Convention for the creation of a State Department of Real Estate and Mortgages.

In a setting of garden flowers, Miss Phyllis Blagden Thompson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Phillips B. Thompson of New York and Southampton, was married to Lieut. Comdr. Jerauld Wright, U. S. N., son of Major Gen. William Mason Wright, U. S. A., retired, and Mrs. Wright of Washington,

A series of Monday night entertainments for the benefit of various philanthropic and social organizations, entitled "Cruise 'Round the World," will be inaugurated at the Hotel Bossert, Brooklyn, on Aug 1, when a "Night in Italy" will be presented on the Marine Roof in aid of the Little Italy Settlement.
Dublin's reaction today to the attacks last night on Italian cadets and sailors of the naval training ships Amerigo

Fifty-seven new one-family dwellings were constructed at a total estimated cost of $804,750, in Greenwich, during the first six months of 1938, according to building reports just made public by Building Inspector Charles D. Crosby. The total construction for the six months amounted to $1,814,995.
WITH this book England's wittiest novelist sets a new standard for comic extravaganza. The novel reads as though it had been formed with a slapstick but given its final shaping with a lancet.

Flood-burdened streams swept the valleys of the Southwest Texas hill country tonight, forcing additional persons from their homes and adding to property damage over an area of about 100 miles long and 50 miles wide. Rain, which in five days totaled 12 inches, continued to fall over a large section of the flood-ravaged area.

Heavy rains, nearing cloudburst proportions in some places, fell on the Philadelphia area for the seventh consecutive day and left in their wake today uptorn highways, washed out bridges, ruined crops and flooded buildings. A score of streams in Pennsylvania and the Philadelphia Tri-State district left their banks.

Richard L. Bamford, who retired in 1928 as superintendent of telegraph service of the New York Stock Exchange, with which he was associated continuously for forty-five years, died today at his home here after a two months' illness at the age of 74. His widow, Julia E. Bamford, survives.

Tennis Week starts here tomorrow at the Sea Bright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club and brings with it a round of entertaining by residents of Sea Bright and Rumson. A luncheon will be given on Tuesday by Mrs. Clement L. Despard at her home in Rumson for women entered in the tournament.

Japanese airmen reported tonight that the waterfront of Kiukiang, immediate barrier to the Yangtze River offensive against Hankow, was in flames. Foreign naval advices from the area declared, however, that the situation was unchanged from that of recent days-calmness in a city that for weeks had been within earshot of Chinese shore batteries and Japanese naval guns.

Radio telephone communication between Puerto Rico and Haiti was opened today when Governor Blanton Winship talked with representatives of the Haitian Government in Port au Prince. This link, established jointly by the Puerto Rico Telephone Company and the West Indies Telephone Company,

The marriage of Miss Lucille Holmes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Max L. Holmes of East Orange, to Hugh Wallace McLeod Jr., son of Mrs. Grace F. McLeod, also of East Orange, took place this afternoon in Munn Avenue Presbyterian Church here.

Mrs. Ella Boole, world president of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union, will celebrate her eightieth birthday Tuesday in the town where she was born, Van Wert, Ohio. She left her Brooklyn home, 377 Parkside Avenue, Friday night, accompanied by her daughter, Miss Florence A. Boole.
As evidence of activity in apartment leasing on upper Riverside Drive, Mark Rafalsky Co. report 100 per cent occupancy for three large buildings there.

The board of directors of the United Wall Paper Factories, Inc., at a meeting yesterday elected Albert J. Browning, president of the company. Mr. Browning, formerly group merchandise manager of Montgomery Ward Co., will assume his new position on Aug. 1. His headquarters will be at the company's general offices in Chicago.
Frederick Ayres Lorenz, steel executive, died today in Passavant Memorial Hospital at the age of 52, after a long illness. His home was at 7,000 South Shore Drive.
John Schumacher, 55 years old, of 82 Columbia Avenue, here, a city fireman, dropped dead tonight when Engine Company 18, to which he was attached, responded to an alarm at 44 Girard Place.

Reports that there will be an effort to force through the Constitutional Convention the Murray proposal permitting religious instruction in the schools by instructors of the same faith as the pupils are denied by those who first considered the subject.

WHEN Harwood L. Childs, Associate Professor of Politics at Princeton, was abroad on a Guggenheim fellowship, he secured a copy of the "Nazi Primer," which is used as required reading in all German schools to instill the principles of Hitlerism into the rising generation.

The United Automobile Workers of America, having engaged in battles on many fronts since its organization, will open a new phase of its biggest intramural war next Monday at Detroit when it puts on trial five of its officers, now suspended, for allegedly working against the union's interests.

Decreases of 26.8 per cent in China's imports and of 33 per cent in exports during the first half of 1938, compared with the same period in 1937, were disclosed today in figures issued by the Customs Administration.

Deacon Danny MacFayden's pitching arm and the timely hitting of Elbie Fletcher and Rabbit Warstler gave the Bees a 4-to-2 victory over the Pirates today, ending Pittsburgh's three-game winning streak.
ON his first visit to America, Massimo Freccia, the 32year-old Italian conductor who recently made his debut at Lewisohn Stadium, is most impressed with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra.

ROBERT LOUIS STEVENSON in 1883 wrote "Treasure Island," because his young stepson, after looking through several of his books, asked him to write something interesting. That he hit the mark set by the boy in a great story of adventure

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J.-Midsummer finds bathing, Boardwalk strolling and bicycling, fishing, boating, tennis, trapshooting, golf and pier, theatre, night club and hotel grill entertainments all receiving their share of attention.

STOCKHOLM.-Football pool betting has been made a State monopoly in Sweden, and the profits, expected to reach $1,125,000 this year, are devoted to national fitness-sports, gymnastics, athletics and physical training generally.

The American people have become so accustomed to the idea that they live in the richest nation on earth that for the most part they regard with complete indifference the staggering sum of $5,658,385,125 in taxes collected by the government in the fiscal year ended on June 30.

VAGABOND VOYAGING. By Larry Nixon. Illustrated. 314 pp. Boston: Little, Brown Co. $2.25. IT is quite true, as they say, that the roundest superlatives of freighter travel belong to the world cruises, which take from four to six months and cost round about $6 (maybe less) a day.

LITERATURE THE LEADING EDUCATOR. By Francis P. Donnelly, S. J. 278 pp. New York: Longmaans, Green Co. $3. "BY literature," writes Francis P. Donnelly "I understand the expression of experience in language which adds beauty to truth."
ENOUGH: Hungary, his native land, received word last week from one of the most incredible characters of modern history. A Buddhist nun arrived from China
The National Labor Relations Board, in a precedent-setting ruling, held today that a company discharging workers for union activities was liable for expenses they incurred in hunting new work.
AMERICAN and English radio men continue to exchange visits in New York and London, with much scientific and artistic significance attached to their chats. Both are seeking "the answer to television."
WITH Finland instead of Japan host for the Olympic Games of 1940, the eyes of the world are turning to the small land of lakes, islands and good fishing tucked away in a corner of Northern Europe.

The Holland America liner Nieuw Amsterdam, under command of Captain Johannes Bijl, commodore of the line, sailed from her Hoboken pier forty minutes behind schedule yesterday after awaiting the arrival of four passengers from Philadelphia who had been delayed by a washout on the highway.
Manufacturers of metal windows are providing three standard types of screens for additional comfort to the home in the warm weather season.

The National Labor Relations Board will be urged by its chief counsel and by the Committee for Industrial Organization to appeal the decision yesterday of the Circuit Court of Appeals in Chicago voiding a finding of the board that a sit-down strike of a C. I. O. union

There are times, it has been said, when a political party and politicians "must rise above principle." The statement is never more true than when applied to the question of apportioning to the various cities and counties of the State the number of representatives they are to be allowed in the Senate and Assembly of the State of New York.
Miss Merrie Ethel Sackett, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William W. Sackett of St. Petersburg, Fla., was married here this afternoon to John Winthrop Truslow,

WESTFIELD, N. J., July 23.--John F. Wulff, for many years division chief in charge of reproduction of blueprints at the Western Electric Works at Kearny, died last night at his home here after a short illness. Born in Germany, he came to this country as a child and started with the Western Electric Company shortly after his graduation from Northwestern University in 1905.

Mrs. Elizabeth V. Robinson has leased the residence of George A. LaWare in Mount Kisco, N. Y., through Hames F. Greene, broker. J. Edward Breuer, auctioneer, has been appointed by Frank B. Hall Jr., executor of the Frank B. Hall estate, to sell ninety-seven lots in the Weybridge section of Great Neck.

Despite Johnny Mize's thirteenth home run and Joe Medwick's twelfth of the season, the Dodgers today found a way to reward Bill Posedel's excellent pitching by outscoring the Cardinals, 4-3, before a ladies' day crowd of 8,699.

Russia through her newspapers pictured Japan today as so entangled in trying to conquer China that her "diplomatic forces had to be called in to rescue the militarists" from trying to touch off a conflict with Russia.
A world record in wheat production and a near-record in world wheat supplies are indicated for the 1938-39 crop year, the Department of Agriculture announced today.
Pillars of fire danced madly through virgin Vancouver Island timber today as the worst forest fire in the island's history burned uncontrolled and dangerously close to several communities.

FORTH WORTH, Texas, Sunday, July 24.--W. Lee O'Daniel, hillbilly flour salesman, came within less than 1,000 votes of getting a majority in the midnight tabulation of the votes in yesterday's primary election in the contest for the Democratic nomination for Governor, which he may win without a runoff.

B. TRAVEN, that pseudonymous internationalist, is one of the mysteries of contemporary literature and one of its minor joys. He has brought a song of social significance into the jungle, etched supple Rivera prints out of hot grass, hard tack and the tepid democracy of the forecastle.

High school curricula are in need of change and "the fourth year in high school is just so much wasted time to no small percentage of students," according to a report by Dean J. J. Oppenheimer of the College of Liberal Arts, University of Louisville, on students allowed to enter the college as regular freshmen after only three years of high school work.

Seven days of rain with two severe cloudbursts in Sullivan County have resulted in damage well above $150,000, it was estimated today. Rivers and streams overflowing their banks carried away seven highway bridges and many small buildings. Truck farmers report that Summer vacationists were forced to flee from camps and Summer bungalows, leaving most of their clothing behind.
After the ceremonies of the official visit of King George and Queen Elizabeth of Britain this week, Paris has turned its attention-and its curiosity-to the reception of two unofficial visitors.

FOR many years Mr. Lawrence C. Wroth has been librarian of the John Carter Brown Library of Providence, R. I.--one of the rich repositories of Early Americana. Studying the Colonial American imprints, of which his institution has a particularly important collection, his interest was early attracted by the printers who made them.

S. Ellsworth Davenport of Forest Hills, N. Y., today gained the White Mountain and New Hampshire tennis championship by defeating Don Meiklejohn of Hanover, N. H., member of the Dartmouth faculty, 7-5, 6-1, 6-2. Earlier in the day's program, which was interrupted by showers, Meiklejohn qualified for the final by eliminating the 1937 winner, Robert H. Decker of Miami, 6-3, 6-3.

Representatives from fifty civic and taxpayers' organizations in Queens, meeting last week at a meeting called by John H. Morris, chairman of the Real Estate Taxpayers Federation of the State of New York in the rooms of the Long Island Real Estate Board, Jamaica, unanimously approved the three points submitted by the Taxpayers Federation to the Constitutional Convention for the protection of real estate.

FOLKSONGS FROM THE SOUTHERN HIGHLANDS. Collected and Edited by Mellinger Edward Henry. 449 pp. Illustrations. Indices. New York: J. J. Augustin. $5. SO many collections of ballads culled from the mountains of the South have been put forth in recent years it is difficult to keep track of them all.

The French liner Champlain sailed yesterday for Europe with 547 passengers. The list included George R. Van Namee, member of the Public Service Commission of New York; Ignace Paderewski and Ralph Hitz, president of the National Hotel Management Company of New York.

Among 40,000 individuals estimated by executives to have visited the doll show in the Spear auditorium at 22 West Thirty-fourth Street in the two weeks since it opened, only 18 per cent were children, and not all the rest were women. Men have flocked in, according to a statement by the sponsoring group, the National Doll and Toy Collectors Club.
Old Man Weather won the Solomon's Island Yacht Club's second annual regatta hands down today with a dismal downpour that discourage everybody but a few daredevil speed boat drivers.

A fire last night in an oil separator in the basement of the Brooklyn Bridge Garage, a three-story brick building at 229 Washington Street, Brooklyn, necessitated four alarms. It was put out after a four-and-ahalf hour fight.

Dr. Arthur P. Keegan, a City Councilman, threatened today to seek the impeachment of Mayor S. Davis Wilson as responsible for conditions existing at the Philadelphia Hospital for Mental Diseases, better known as Byberry.

Men at Teachers College, who are outnumbered by women more than two to one, will retreat en masse next- Thursday into the campus grove along West 120th Street to celebrate their annual independence day with a steak dinner at which knives, forks and women will be barred.
Brig Gen. George H. Spaulding, who from June, 1936, to March, 1938, was assistant chief of staff in charge of the supply division of the War Department General Staff, will retire on July 31.

The following is the chart showing how Arlington Classic was run at Arlington Park today: SIXTH RACE-The Arlington Classic; $30.000 added; 3-year-olds; one mile and a quarter. Start good; won driving; place same. Went to post 5:15 1/2; off 5:15 1/2. Winner, br. c., by Neddle-Sunayr. Trainer, W. A. Crawford. Value to winner, $27,500;

Residents in and around New York City will not have to go to Niagara Falls to see a spectacular waterfall for the next few days, for a huge cataract is roaring over the 1,200-foot-wide spillway of Cornell Dam of the New York City waterworks in Croton. Today twelve inches of water was sweeping into the rock gorge 150 feet below.

The heavy rain that has covered Atlantic City and other sections of the country in the last week has' retarded the normal resort business. Hotel men generally were of the opinion that the business for the week was from 5 to 10 per cent below last year but amusement men believed the percentage was somewhat higher, perhaps up to 20 per cent.
J. G. Kasai, member of the Japanese Parliament, asserted here today that the Japanese people were capable of waging "conflict with both China and Russia simultaneously."

Thousands of campers throughout the Palisades Interstate Park have been forced indoors or under shelter for the last week. Directors have employed every resource to amuse the small children through what has been the longest rainy spell remembered here.

ANNOUNCEMENT during the past week of the commercial availability of a form of hydraulic transmission for use on buses is bound to result in renewed interest in its possible application to passenger cars. Such application would mean banishment of the gear shift lever and the clutch.

Assignment Ordered To take effect 8 A. M., July 25: PATROLMAN-Edward Nuoffer. 83d Precinct, assignment to duty as attendant discontinued. Leaves Without Pay PATROLMEN-Francis E. Toner, 18th Precinct, 1 day, 4 P. M., July 21; Francis J. McKay, 18th Precinct, 1 day, 12:01 A. M., Aug. 4: Angelo Saltalamasshia, 41st Precinct, 1 day. 8 A.. M., Aug. 20; James Higgins, 110th Precinct, 3 days, 12:01 A. M., Aug. 7.

Machine tools, packaging and canning machinery and railroad equipment, in the order named, will constitute Soviet Russia's major purchases in the United States-in the coming twelve months, according to foreign traders who inquired into Russian buying plans last week.

WORKMEN are rapdily changing the present system of approach ramps on the Manhattan side of the George Washington Bridge. This work rill provide new and more spacious roadways as well as a new cross-town tunnel, first of its kind in Manhattan.

CHINESE CEREMONIAL PAPER. By Dard Hunter. 84 pp. text, 16 illustrations and 50 specimens of ceremonial papers inserted. Edition limited to 125 numbered copies, each signed by author publisher Chillicothe, Ohio The Mountain House. $37.50.

The cherished campaign cry of "Immediate, absolute and complete independence," upon which political candidates in the Philippines have ridden into office for a quarter of a century, has lost its punch.

IF they can't do anything else with the Yankee Stadium, they might sow it with wild rice and use it as a duck preserve for Fall shooting. Furthermore, if the weather at Saratoga is to be anything like that of the past week at the Empire City track, those turf followers so deeply interested in "improving the breed" should concentrate on producing a strain of web-footed horses.

The Mexican Constitution of 1917 promised a redistribution of the country's rich farmlands, which had been worked but never owned by centuries of peons. For the past two decades Mexican Governments have been confiscating large estates, expropriating foreign-owned lands and turning these over to more than 1,200,000 rural families.

FOUR totally unknown songs of Debussy were sung for the first time anywhere at a recital in the Salle Chopin given recently by Mme. Claire Croiza, who, in certain respects, is a Parisian counterpart of Povla Frijsh and an uncommonly fascinating artist.

THE Norwegian-American Line's new flagship, the M. S. Oslofjord, was in port here last week-her first call following the maiden voyage. A deferred tour of inspection yielded many delightful impressions and, to the great surprise of this visitor, proved that steps toward the fulfillment of what one may term a "dream ship" are not so impractical and fantastic, after all.

Fifteen passengers on the Cayuga, a northbound New York Central passenger train, were cut by broken glass and twice as many were splattered with mud and water at 8:45 A. M. today when the embankment at the foot of Point Street gave way during a near cloudburst and slid against two coaches of the passing train.

Racing at Saratoga will get under way tomorrow to continue for thirty days until Aug. 27, during which time close to half a million dollars will be distributed to horsemen. It is in tradition, however, that President George H. Bull feels that Saratoga is richest.

Steady growth in the number of participants in WPA recreation and cultural programs is reported by Colonel Brehon B. Somervell, WPA administrator, as evidence of "constructive use of increasing leisure." Colonel Somervell's report covered the period between Jan. 1 and June 30.
Announcement has been made of the engagement of Mrs. Margaret Glover Vigeant, daughter of Mrs. Fred Brown Glover of this city and the late Mr. Glover, to William Turell Andrews of New York.

Heavy rains continued in New England for the ixth successive day, with no indication of clearing weather. The propertyy damage is figured at many thousands of dollars. In the twenty-four-hour period ending at 8:30 tonight, the weather bureau recorded 1.37 inches of rainall, making the total for the six lays 6.72 inches.

Appointments of J. W. Hutchins and Emerson J. Poag as assistant general sales managers were announced yesterday by Forest H. Akers, vice president of the Dodge division of Chrysler Corporation. Mr. Hutchins has served the company since 1925 in various executive capacities, Mr. Poag, who for more than five years served in the capacity of director of merchandising and advertising, now assumes the post of assistant general sales manager in charge of these activities.

WASHINGTON, July 23.--The Export-Import Bank agreed today to discount notes of the Haitian Government to finance a $5,000,000 public works program. The notes will be issued to the J. G. White Engineering Corporation of New York, which has a contract to build roads, bridges and irrigation works, and install municipal water systems in Haiti in the next three or four years.

The leading foreign exchanges ended the week with a burst of strength yesterday. The pound sterling was up 9-16 cent to $4.92 7-16, the French franc 5-16 point to 2.76 1/2 cents, the guilder 5 points to 55.02 cents, the belga 1 1/2 points to 16.92 1/2 cents and the Swiss franc 21/2 points to 22.91 1/2 cents.

Frank S. O'Hara, president of the Real Estate Association of the State of New York, announces that a "comeback convention" will be held in Syracuse Sept. 15 to 17 inclusive. He points out that the association was organized in Syracuse in 1905, and the Syracuse Real Estate Board, which will act as host, is urging all realty members to "come back to Syracuse."

Heading a committee whose objective will be a modern hotel for Freeport, is W. Sargent Nixon, cashier, of the Freeport Bank. Chester A. Fulton, chairman of the general committee, has named Horace E. De Lisser, president of the Nassau County Association, as head of the finance committee. The prospective hotel will cost about $100,000. There is only one hotel in Freeport at present, the Crystal Lake Hotel on Grove Street.

The value of real property which has been made exempt from general taxation in 1936 reached a total of $443 per capital in fifty-two cities, each with more than 100,000 population, according to a recent report of the Bureau of the Census.

AT the age of 80 J. A. Hobson should be able to look back upon his career with peculiar satisfaction. For a full half century he has been turning out a steady stream of volumes expounding his "heretical" ideas on economic and other social questions.

The Interstate Commerce Commission today rejected requests by Mayors of several communities in Hudson County, N. J., to suspend its order permitting the Hudson Manhattan Railroad to charge an 8-cent fare on its downtown lines between Hudson Terminal, New York City, and stations in Jersey City and Hoboken, N. J.

WE were in the dressing room allotted the "Haitian Citizens" and it was hotter than the hinges of Haiti. Rex Ingram threw one leg over the bench, balanced hiss huge frame on the far enid of it and see-sawed back and forth.

The flood waters of Red Clay Creek swept away bridges, crops, trees and livestock in a wide Delaware area today. They caused havoc and property loss in Wilmington's southwestern suburbs and inundated sections of a fifty-square mile area northwest of the city. Yorklyn, Mount Cuba, Ashland, Marshallton, Greenbank, Faulkland, and The Cedars suffered greatly from the highest water in thirty-five years.

Miss Antoinette Treadway, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lauris G. Treadway of Lynde Lane, was married to William Cooper Fowle, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Fuller Fowle of Winnetka, Ill., at Thompson Memorial Chapel this afternoon. White gladioluses, cybotium ferns and candelabra were used for decoration. The Rev. Roy B. Chamberlain, chaplain at Dartmouth College, officiated.
THE Marx Brothers have been subdued. For the first time in their screen careers they are being confined to the plot and dialogue fashioned-by a playwright.
Weston B. Hillard, vice president of Harold Van Buskirk, Inc., developers of Oak Hill Park, in the Scarsdale area of Westchester County, commends the results of the FHA on new home appraisals.

Henry F. (Pa) Schulte. veteran track coach at the University of Nebraska and member of the coaching staff for the American team in the 1928 Olympics. retired today because of poor health. Schulte, who directed the development of such world record-holders as Roland Locke and Bob Simpson, will be succeeded by Ed Weir, freshman football coach at Nebraska and former Cornhusker allAmerica player.

The curtain rose tonight on the first Nazi staging of the celebrated Salzburg Festival with Wilhelm Furtwaengler conducting Wagner's "Die Meistersinger." There was a notable absence of foreign visitors, who in previous years had been the backbone of attendance.

The C. I. O. announced today that it would sponsor amendments to the Walsh-Healey government contracts act even broader than those which House committees bottled up at the last session despite two visits to the capital by John L. Lewis.
THE MARTYRDOM OF SPAIN. Origins of a Civil War. By Alfred Mendizabal, Professor at the University of Oviedo. With a Preface by Jacques Maristain. 277 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $3.
HOWEVER it may apply to other relief activities, boondogglingg" is emphatically not the word for the New Deal program for salvaging poverty-stricken and despairing youth.

Mexico failed to get the award in the recent bidding for the sale of gasoline to the Costa Rica gasoline monopoly, although she was the lowest bidder on 1,400 drums for delivery at the Atlantic port of Limon.

A photograph reproduced in an early edition of THE NEW YORK TIMES on July 12 in connection with the death at Monrovia of Arthur Barclay, former President of Liberia, was not that of Mr. Barclay, but of his nephew, Edwin James Barclay, now President of Liberia.

Arden Post, mechanical engineer, of Port Washington, died last night at Little Silver, N. J., at the age of 70. He wasthe son of the late Richard Bayley and Eliza Deane Post of Garrison, N. Y., where he was born. He attended St. Paul's School, Concord, N. H., and Stevens Institute.

While war clouds hovered over the Old World, natives of twentytwo countries in the Western Hemisphere celebrated yesterday at Floyd Bennett Airport the peaceful ties that bind the two Americas on the eve of the birthday anniversary of Simon Bolivar, the "Liberator."

There was pageantry in Paris last week as King George and Queen Elizabeth of Great Britain paid their first state visit to the capital on the Seine. The spectacle symbolized Franco-British solidarity; behind it moved the less spectacular wheels of diplomacy, as representatives of both nations conferred, seeking a formula to insure Europe's peace.
Senator Harrison, chairman of the Finance Committee, said in an interview here that there was little likelihood of a general revamping of the tax structure by the next Congress.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: With the death of Dr. Frederick Peterson, eminent neurologist, alienist, psychiatrist, poet and humanitarian, this country has suffered the loss of a great personality.

THERE is always ample room in the human heart for any one who attempts the unusual, the daring or the sensational. And when success caps such attempts-be they flagpole sitting, marathon dancing or ocean flying-there is no measuring the dizzy heights of popular acclaim. Everybody loves heroes. But it is unfortunate that in hailing them we see only the romantic aspects of their feats.

A "good-will and friendship" youth delegation" will come to this country from Czechoslovakia on Aug. 13 for a month's visit to demonstrate the need for solidarity among the democracies and to stimulate American interest in the preservation of the independence of their country, the United Czech and Slovak Societies announced yesterday.

TO Webster, a library was a collection of books and the building, apartment or room housing it; to Shakespeare, it was "dukedom large enough" and to Sheridan, "an evergreen tree of diabolical knowledge." To Hollywood, a library is seldom any of these.
The Agricultural Adjustment Act of 1938, a measure embodying most of the farm-problem curatives favored by Secretary Wallace, is being put to the test in its first year by a critical wheat situation.

Polling twenty-three prominent economists of the country, The Associated Press has found a consensus that business will be better in the remainder of 1938, that the recover will last at least until Christmas and probably longer, and that government spending and fiscal policies aid recovery.

Use of soap in baking cake has been developed by the Procter Gamble Company of Cincinnati, it is revealed in a patent (No. 2,123,880) granted to Herbert S. Ccith, Albert S. Richardson and Verling M. Votaw of Wyoming, Ohio.

The double-headers that confront the Yankees and may jeopardize their American League pennant chances became a cause for alarm yesterday when the rain for the fourth successive day washed away a twin bill with the White Sox at the Stadium.

A private dramatic society and a suburban repertory company keep the flag flying in London next week. The first offering is "My Mercury," by Peter E. Rogers, which the Arts Theatre is producing on Sunday.

Julius Ochs Adler Jr. and William Williams, both of New York City, have qualified for the national junior tennis tournament, scheduled to begin on the clay courts at the Culver Military Academy Aug. 1.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I.-One of the outstanding events of the season here will take place during this week when the thirty-first annual flower show under the auspices of the Garden Club of Southampton and the Southampton Horticultural Society will be held on Wednesday and Thursday in the auditorium of the Parochial School in Hill Street.

The Soviet Government has assigned 100,000,000 rubles (about $18,900,000 at the official rate of exchange) for work this year on the gigantic palace of the Soviets being built on the site of St. Saviour's Cathedral in Moscow. It has also announced that the palace will be opened on Nov. 7, 1942, the twenty-fifth anniversary of the Bolshevist revolution.

After active intervention by President Arturo Alessandri, labor difficulties at the Teniente mines came to a satisfactory close today when an agreement was signed by the workers' syndicates and representatives of the Braden Copper Company, controlled by Kennecott Copper.

Torrential rains poured down yesterday along more than 1,000 miles of the Atlantic seaboard, the Gulf States and as far West as West Texas, causing at least eight deaths and property damage estimated in the hundreds of thousands of dollars.

FOR the first time in four years there has been cheer in Paris. All through the city bands have been playing, streets decked in flags, banners and ribbons. Large and shiny emblems, illuminated at night, have filled the squares and avenues. Students have danced in the streets. When Parisians have gone to bed-which is always early -there have been bright fireworks to bid them good night.

A "twister" tore big chunks of roofs off buildings, felled a brick chimney disrupted telephone and electric service and uprooted trees in Jersey City late yesterday afternoon and a similar high wind tore away the roof of one building in Elizabeth, N. J., about 3 P. M. No one was injured in Jersey City, but an unidentified boy was slightly hurt in Elizabeth.
Preparations are in full swing for an early Parliamentary election in the Free City of Danzig as the 'result of the recent trip to London of the Nazi district leader Albert Foerster.

A children's world's fair within the New York World's Fair was assured yesterday when Grover A. Whalen, president of the fair, signed a contract for "the largest, most elaborate children's entertainment center in exposition or amusement Park history."

STAUNTON, Va.-For the sake of keeping forever sharp the country's memory of President Wilson, a group of Virginians and other Democrats have set themselves the task of raising $25,000 to purchase The Manse, the gray stucco house here where Woodrow Wilson was born, and to turn it into a national shrine.

The body of Mrs. Sarah Ann Daniels of Southampton, England, who died on Tuesday at the age of 65 in the North Country Community Hospital, Glen Cove, while visiting relatives on Long Island, was taken aboard the Georgic today shortly before the ship sailed for England.
PITTSFIELD, Mass. - Berkshire County's only horse show this season will be the two-day event starting next Friday at historic Holmesdale, the Pittsfield estate of Mr. and Mrs. Donald M. Weston.

So much of Par. 31, Special Orders 154, dated July 5, 1938, as orders 1st Lt. Edward A. Lautenschlager, Ch.-Res., to active duty with the C. C. C., effective July 12; 1938, and relieving him therefrom effective Jan. 11, 1939, is amended so as to order 1st Lt. Lautenschlager to active duty with the C. C. C. effective July 12, 1938, and relieving him therefrom effective July 22, 1938.

Improvement this Fall in general retail trade will be quickly reflected in larger credit sales, and installment volume may approach parity with the figures for the last half of 1937, with a corresponding improvement in 30-day charge account business, it was reported in retail credit circles yesterday.

LATELY the South has been obliged to defend the integrity of fried chicken-Southern style. It seemed impossible that any one should question the merits of fried chicken as it is put on the table by Southern cooks,

IT takes the annual output of ten tropical rubber trees to produce enough crude rubber to equip the average American motor car with five tires, according to Colonel Charles E. Speaks, president of the Fisk Tire Company. Ten pounds of the concentrated latex, five from each of two trees, are necessary for a single tire, he said last week.

Henry Ford, who generally shuns public appearances, becomes the central figure next week in a series of observances which reach their climax on Saturday. On that date Mr. Ford, vigorously active and looking forward to further industrial accomplishments, will observe his seventy-fifth birthday anniversary.

Mrs. Ann Alberts fell to her death shortly after 9 A. M. yesterday from the roof of the seventeenstory building at 720 West End Avenue, at Ninety-fifth Street, where she and her husband, Leon, occupied a two-room apartment.

THE controversy over block booking, seemingly the root from which all distribution evils arose, has raged for several years between theatre men and producers. Yet it only recently came to the attention of the moviegoing public through the Senateendorsed Neely Anti-block Booking Bill.

The American League for Peace and Democracy announced yesterday that both C. I. O. and A. F. of L. union spokesmen were represented among the leaders of New York's maritime, food and shoe workers unions who have joined with fiftyfive other unions in endorsing the Peace Parade to be held on Aug. 6

Attorney General Homer S. Cummings, a voter in Connecticut aid for years a leader of the Democratic party in the State before he became a New Deal Cabinet officer, apparently has called a halt to any Administration effort to purge Senator Augustine Lonergan, who opposed both the Supreme Court and reorganization bills of the President.

Princeton University's program of independent study for undegraduates took a major step forward today with the announcement by President Harold W. Dodds that the calendar for the academic year would be revised in 1939 to allow reading periods for underclassmen and engineers and to expand the existent reading period for academic upperclassmen.

MR. ELLIOT has written the book on Berlioz that has long been wanted. He has produced a wellbalanced critical estimate of Berlioz's music as well as a perspicacious study of a man who was certainly one of the most singular figures in the whole history of music.

A definite trend toward the consolidation and "typing" of corset lines and an effort on the part of manufacturers to produce innovations with "selling" appeal were apparent in the Fall corset showings which were held last week.

One of the most interesting developments in plant hybridizing in recent years has been the improvement in red raspberries. Not only have size and quality been greatly improved, but the bearing season has been extended from the strawberry season until frost.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., July 23.--The last of 1,200 mules, once employed by the Lehigh Valley Coal Company in 22 anthracite collieries, was sold today to Lee Wentzel, farmer of Lehman, after sixteen years' service at Prospect colliery.

For the second day in succession Virginio Gayda, who is regarded as Premier Benito Mussolini's mouthpiece, devotes a long article in the Giornale d'Italia to the race problem, and seeks to show that recent experiences in other countries make it imperative for Italy to prevent an infiltration of "non-Aryan" elements.

N. A. McDougall of Toronto is going to ask the Ontario Highways Department to place dummy "speed cops," realistic figures of wood and paint mounted on motorcycles, on the roadside at every curve, hilltop and dangerous highway stretch in the Province.
Many entertainments today marked the third day's showings of the third annual Jersey Shore Horse Show. The exhibition closes tomorrow.
CAUSE: Dr. Thomas A. Gonzales, Chief Medical Examiner of New York City, reported last week on his department's first comprehensive survey of the relation between highway accidents and alcohol.

The stock market had a slow start and a strong finish yesterday. Leading industrial stocks were up 1 to 2 points on the short day and a few issues made wider gains. Railroad shares edged higher and utilities showed little change.

Many of the players here for the two-day men's invitation doubles tennis tournament at the Maidstone Club were entertained at the club's dinner dance tonight. Visiting Mr. and Mrs. Julian Myrick are Gilbert Hall, Watson Washburn, A. L. McPherson and Ned Herndon;

Close-of-play scores in English county cricket championship matches started today follow: Glamorgan 170; Warwickshire 131 runs for six wickets (Croom 57); at Newport. Northamptonshire 199 (Brookes 58, P. Smith four wickets for 79 runs,

The following Foreign Service changes since July 15 were announced today by the State Department: George V. Allen of Durham, N. C., consul at Cairo, Egypt, now in the United States on leave, assigned to the Department of State. Theodore J. Hohenthal of Berkeley, Calif., vice consul at Bombay, and now in the United States on leave, assigned vice consul at Vienna.

WHITE MOUNTAINS, N. H.-The White Mountain theatres are changing their bills, the Barnstormers on Monday at Tamworth presenting "The Torchbearers," George Kelly's comedy. Other performances will be given at Old Mill Theatre, Conway, on Tuesday and Wednesday nights; at Poland Spring, Me., on Thursday; at Wolfeboro, N. H., on Friday and again at Tamworth on Saturday.

BONSTON, July 23 (AP)--Manager Joe Cronin of the Red Sox decided tonight to leave Bob (Lefty) Grove behind when the Boston club departs tomorrow or Monday night on its third western trip of the season.

Announcement was made here last night of the sudden death yesterday at Forte Marni, Italy, of the wife of Andrea Geisser Celesia di Vegliasco, former third secretary of the Italian Embassy at Washington, who is now in the propaganda department of the Italian Foreign Office.

Mayor La Guardia charged yesterday that "cities have been hamstrung" by recent changes in the proposed home rule amendment before the Constitutional Convention in Albany, and renewed his demand for broader home rule powers.

The annual Village Fair, which takes place Friday afternoon on the Herrick Memorial Playground on Newton Lane, is enlisting the aid of the Summer colony and permanent residents under the leadership of Mrs. William R. Maloney, for the fifth year fair chairman.
The Maidstone Club's annual invitation tennis doubles tournament opened today, with the nearest resuit approaching an upset being the defeat of John H. Doeg, rated No. 1 nationally in 1930,

OPERATING dude ranches are multiplying all over the holiday belt of the Rocky Mountain States, where hundreds of livestock farmers become technical dude ranchers by taking in a few boarders. Such ranches are vacation resorts for those who think they want to live the life of a cowboy.
Greatly restricted use of the theme of "Buy Now Before Prices Rise" will feature August fur and furniture promotions which retailers will launch shortly, it was indicated here yesterday.

The fleet for the annual Rodman Wanamaker regatta of the Barnegat Bay Yacht Racing Association today was the smallest for many years, as severe wind and rain squalls kept scores of yachts from the starting line.

Colonel Alvar L. Bournique, Chicago's dancing master for the last half century, died today at the age of 72 in Leland, Mich., after an illness of three months. A graceful, courtly little man whose nimbleness belied his age, Colonel Bournique had taught ballroom decorum to society's children since 1880.

After almost 150,000 persons had passed before Queen Marie's coffin it was sealed this evening in the presence of King Carol and all other members of the royal family. This morning a Protestant service was held at the request of Princess Ileana, who attended with her husband, Archduke Anton of Habsburg, and several Protestant members of the household.
The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Caroline Moran, daughter of Mrs. Jeremiah J. Geagan of 420 West End Avenue and the late James J. Moran, to Edward A. Kennedy Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Kennedy

FOR some years Columbia has promised us a first recording of Mozart's piano sonata in C minor (K.457) together with the related fantasia in the same key (K.475). The first half of the contract is now fulfilled, though the player is not the one originally announced.

Postmaster General Farley and his party trudged into Anchorage singing lustily "I've Been Working on the Railroad." The rubber-tired, flange-wheeled gas car carrying Mr. Farley had two flat tires yesterday. There were no spares, so the trip was continued on the flats. Then a wheel came off, derailing the car.
