Formal opening of a recreation center to be known as "Judge Frankenthaler's Kiddie Playground," in the rear of the apartment property at 750-60 Pelham Parkway South, in the Bronx, will be held at 3 P. M. today.

Clifton's Beau, hunter champion here last year, was well on his way today to capturing the title again in the third annual Jersey shore horse show at Boxwood Farm. With only one more day of the exhibition left, he has three blues to his credit, having appeared to be the outstanding hunter in all his competitions .

Putting on a terrific stretch drive, W. L. Brann's Challephen captured the sixth running of the $4,000added Granite State Handicap, oldest stake in New England's young turf history, at Rockingham Park today before a rain-drenched crowd of 12,000.

ANY one taking a look at this page should, at a glance, sense the 1938 Fall style change. There is a renaissance of the ultra-feminine. The bare nape of the neck with curling tendrils at the base of hair brushed up; sleeves that mount in harmony with high-piled puffs;

Miss Eleanore Robinson Jones, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. William Jones of this place, was married here this evening to Dr. Thomas Benton Lane, son of Dr. and Mrs. Hiram H. Lane of Kenosha, Wis., in Christ Church by the rector, the Rev. Harold Longley.

The D. Herbert Hostetter Estate, owner of a 350-acre tract of land on the east side of Los Angeles, Calif., is to utilize part of its holdings for the erection of a rental housing project, to be known as Wyvernwood, for 1,100 families at a cost of about $6,000,000.

Continued rain last night drove the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra into the shelter of the Great Hall of City College, where Alexander Smallens conducted for a few hundred hardy souls. The program, different from the one originally announced, consisted of the Brahms "Academic" Overture, the Mozart "Haffner" symphony, and the Beethoven "Fifth."
The tiny mountain republic of Switzerland, intent on maintaining its independence, come what may, is redoubling efforts to make itself safe from possible acts

The schooner General A. W. Greely of the MacGregor Arctic Expedition was caught in the Baffin Bay ice pack four days ago. Dense fog and heavy snows mixed with sleet have prevented us from getting free of the ice. Considerable damage has been done to the ship by the ice pressure.

Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Cornell of Grymes Hill, S. I., have Miss Elsie Rau of Rydal, Pa., and Robert Farnham of Philadelphia, Miss Rau's fiance, as their guests. Mrs. Joseph C. Bell of Montclair and her daughter, Miss Betty Bell,

Union County Democratic leaders this week named Richard F. Green, an Elizabeth attorney, as their choice for the nomination to the House of Representatives for the Sixth Congressional District. Mr. Green would oppose the Republican incumbent,

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are July 23 unless specified: At New York: Badger, Decatur, Fairfax, Herbert, Leary, J. F. Talbott. Portland to San Clemente: Perry. Zane. Arizona, at San Francisco, July 22. Arkansas, at Portland, Maine, July 22.
Mr. and Mrs. John Wallace Riddle of the Drake and Avon Old Farms, Conn., sailed on the Nieuw Amsterdam for Gloucestershire, England, where they have taken a house for the rest of the Summer.
THE Adirondack skyline begins to form rather definitely as the motorist approaches Saratoga, New York's spa, racing's rendezvous and one of the most unusual communities in America.

THE title and general get-up of this book may suggest that it is just the thing for Summer reading. Perhaps it is, provided one does not prefer to put away the upper portions of one's brain in moth-balls during the hot season and do all one's thinking with the medulla oblongata.

Buying of Summer merchandise was quite dull last week, and mail orders for goods for current selling diminished, according to a summary of conditions in the New York wholesale market prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevy, Werring Howell Company, resident buyers.

TREASURE TRAILS IN ART. By Anna Curtis Chandler. Introduction by Helen Ferris. 223 pp. Boston: Hale, Cushman Flint. $2. BEGINNING with Giotto, who lived two hundred years before Columbus discovered America, Miss Chandler tells the story of twenty-one famous painters down to Vincent Van Gogh.

During the month of August the greatest troop concentration and the most extensive manoeuvres in our peacetime history will be held in various parts of the Southwest, with the greatest number of soldiers concentrated in and around San Antonio. Not less than 30,000 officers and men will go through three weeks of exercises here. Other thousands will be concentrated at various places stretching along the Southwest border almost from the Mississippi to the Pacific.

MUSIC being the backbone of broadcasting, few if any have done more to strengthen the melodious vertebrae than Irving Berlin, writer of more than 600 songs who is celebrating a quarter of a century in Tin Pan Alley, of which he is called the king.
Another day has passed and the Loyalist lines along the eastern front have held firm. Confirmation comes daily that the Loyalists are resisting tenaciously.

The amaryllis-or to use its more correct botanical name, hippeasstrum-is a favorite plant of the window gardener. Given intelligent care it continues, even under somewhat difficult conditions, to thrive for many years and to produce each late Spring or early Summer its stout scape, which terminates in an umbel of from one to four or more gorgeous lily-like blooms.
A damp two-week field training period for the Fifty-fourth Infantry Brigade of the New York National Guard came to a close at Camp Smith here this afternoon and the 2,100 members, of the brigade,

This is the first account of the American Karakorum expedition to K2, or Mount Godwin Austen. This letter gives the story of our progress from Skardu, Baltistan, to the base camp, about the last eighty miles of our 300-mile march.

Successful low-cost housing, in the opinion of William Lescaze, architect, will only grow out of planning and designing the dwelling units in terms of the people which they are Intended to servo, rather than constructing them as smaller-size imitations of structures already standing.

The annual Stockbridge golf tournament ball tonight was attended by more than 200 persons. On the ball committee were Mrs. William Marshall Bullitt, chairman; Mrs. David Lincoln Luke, Mrs. Lowell M. Clucas, Mrs. Shaun Kelly, Mrs. George K. Livermore, Mrs. Ramsay Hoguet, Mrs. John H. P. Gould and Mrs. Henry W. Dwight.

IN PRAISE OF SWEDEN. By Maswell Fraser. With 16 Plates and an Endpaper Map. 315 pp. New York: Dodge Publishing Company. $2.75. SWEDEN, ANCIENT AND MODERN. Illustrated. 240 pp. Published by the Swedish Traffic Association. $1.50.

Mr. and Mrs. Harris B. Fisher and children, Peter and Bertram Fisher, of Rumson, N. J., are passing the Summer with Mrs. Fisher's mother, Mrs. Harold R. Talbot of New York, at Wyndmere, her cottage here.
A survey of new building in June in the Chicago suburban region by the Greenbaum Investment Company of that city shows that construction work in sixty-six communities aggregated $3,052,930.

Germany today earned the right to meet Yugoslavia in the final round of European Zone Davis Cup competition as Henner Henkel and Georg von Metaxa defeated the French doubles team of Yvon Petra and Jean Lesueur, 4-6, 6-4, 2-6, 10-8, 6-4.

Charles Del Prete, 14 years old, was wading with a chum last night in a swollen creek at the base of the Palisades near Englewood Cliffs, N. J., when he stepped into a deep hole and was swept 350 feet down the steep course of the creek and twenty-five feet through a closed culvert into the Hudson River.

Mr. and Mrs. Bernard J. Appel of 1,336 Sixty-sixth Avenue, Philadelphia, suffered burns of the face and hands in an explosion and fire aboard their thirty-foot cabin cruiser soon after it had been refueled in the back waterway at Washington Avenue, Margate, this afternoon.

The cloud hanging over Camp Siegfried at Yaphank threatens to assume darker proportions, because on Monday Lindsay R. Henry, Chief Assistant District Attorney, will go before County Judge L. Barron Hill to seek the appointment of a receiver for the German-American Settlement League, Inc.,

THOUGH the art of translating books, especially great epics, has greatly improved within the last twenty years, there are still many lovers of great literature who prefer to read the leading authors of our time in the original. Those German authors who had to leave their Fatherland after Hitler came to power and whose books were burned on that unforgettable 10th of May, 1933,

A youthful camper was in a hospital in a serious condition here today after a fall from a cliff in a blinding rainstorm last night. Walter Stoll, 18 years old, of Kenmore, N. Y., who was found unconscious at the base of a precipitous escarpment in Zoar Valley along Cattaraugus Creek, was carried up the side of the cliff in an improvised rope stretcher by police and volunteer rescuers.
Eight persons in two New York automobiles were injured, one seriously, today in what State troopers described as "one of the worst head-on collisions in which no one was killed outright."

The Iowa National Guard Military Commission announced today it has jailed two C. I. O. union members for street fighting at the closed Maytag Washing Machine plant Wednesday morning. The commission is already holding a third man.

By remaining in session through the Summer, ready to hold hearings and conduct investigations, the Senate committee on Campaign Expenditure hopes to check abuses in the primaries yet to be held in thirty-two States and in general elections.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today dated July 21: COMMANDERS Hicks, W. A., Washington, D. C., when discharged from treatment at Naval Hospital, to home, relieved all active duty.
The gardener who wants his Tall Bearded irises (the usual garden type) to continue giving an abundance of full-sized blooms year after year divides and transplants them frequently.
LONDON, July 23--Great Britain strongly appealed today to Czechoslovakia for liberal concessions to her clamoring minorities to help the promising new European appeasement prospects.

Something besides sunburn may be brought back to metropolitan anchorages next month by New York- yachtsmen home from vacation cruises. Many who will be voyaging to Narragansett Bay, Newport, Providence and near-by points will be lured by the State of Rhode Island to compete in a new predicted-log race for power boats Aug. 19, and an attractive array of official and privately donated prizes and trophies has been offered to the best navigators.

DANIEL-OSK--Mr. Barnett Osk announces the marriage of his daughter, Roselle (Rollie) Osk, of 161 West 75th St., New York City, to William Daniel of Brooklyn, July 21 1938. FRIEDBIERG-ROSENBERG--Mr. and Mrs. Irwin G. Rosenberg of 20 West 84th St. announce the marriage of their daughter, Ethel H., to Mr. Jack A. Friedberg of San Francisco, Calif.
An early resumption of apartmenthouse construction in the First, Third and Fourth Wards of Queens is predicted by Edwin J. Dunn, manager of the Jamaica realty fice of the Bulkley Horton pany.

Swamped with 150,000 ragweed plants turned in by twelve ambitious youngsters, the Demarest Garden Club has had to call off its anti-ragweed campaign and let the residents of the community do their own weed-pulling.
With the calling of the Legislature into extraordinary session at Harrisburg next Monday night the State Capitol is about to become the setting for an unusual chapter in Pennsylvania history.

JEAN SIBELIUS has three radios in his home. When he plays one, or all of them, he uses the maximum volume and twirls the dial rapidly until he gets what he wants. Every one else leaves the room, or the house.

TEANECK, N. J. July 23.--From a financial standpoint, it is possible to reduce the fifty-cent automobile toll on the George Washington Bridge, William Genser, president of the Washington Bridge Toll Reduction Association, declared in a recent letter to the Port Authority. The letter, addressed to John E. Ramsey, general manager of the Authority,

IT seems that the New Friends of Music, to whom depression and recession are dictionary terms, is looking for new fields of conquest. How else would you interpret the following slightly cryptic paragraph?

The Citizens Union, in a letter sent to Judge Charles B. Sears. chairman of the State Constitutional Convention's Judiciary Committee, demanded that the committee include in its recommendations some check on the "unlimited power" of judges in making appointments and increasing salaries of court employes.

Although the rain failed to erase the Eastern clay court tennis championships completely from the metropolitan sports calendar yesterday, the weather did force another postponement in a week already marked by many delays.
Two championships were retained and two passed into new hands today as a capacity crowd of 1,800 turned out for the second day of the National Amateur Athletic Union outdoor aquatic meet for women.

Training children to hear music as it should be heard is a part of courses. in school music which are being given at the Smith College Summer School of Music. Students of Miss Edna MeEachern and Miss Priscilla E. Rose are working with thirty-one children from Northampton

To the astonishment of the anthropologists but not of political observers Italy has gone "Aryan." Before the Rome-Berlin axis was created, Mussolini scoffed openly at "racial purity." On his North African tour some of his speeches disturbed "non-Aryans."

This department is designed to assist in the location of complete versions of poems and their sources, the names of authors, , which cannot be found through the usual channels of anthologies and books of reference. THE TIMES receives a great many more queries than it can publish. It endeavors, therefore, to select those of the greatest general interest. Queries should be addressed to the Editor of Queries and Answers, NEW YORK TIMES.

George E. Foster of Wausau, one of Wisconsin's leading lumbermen of the early days, died here today at St. Mary's Hospital at the age of 72. Mr. Foster was the father-in-law of Ben Alexander of Chicago and Wausau, who is president of Masonite Corporation.
When the Japanese beetles suddenly appeared last week in the heart of Manhattan, New York City became acutely aware of a pest that has long bothered the suburban gardener.
Mr. and Mrs. Jan Pieter Spaens of this place have announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Virginia Murray Griggs, to Hugh Campbell Barrett Jr. of East Orange.

Tony Galento's murderous. fists, which have brought him many a victory inside the roped prize ring, were valueless today, but a rugged heart was calculated to give him a 50-50 chance to survive a sudden attack of broncho-pneumonia.

The German Stock Exchange, as behooves it in a National Socialist State that emphasizes its socialism and talks about "dying" capitalism, has led a quiet, sheltered life in all the years since Adolf Hitler came to power, protected from both bulls and bears by a strict official controller.

Within this week the monetary gold stocks of the United States will rise above $13,000,000,000. The current total is about $12,996,000,000, and two shipments of bullion from Japan, aggregating $11,600,000, are scheduled to arrive late in the week.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah.-Before the Forty-niners, came the Utah pioneers, and on Covered Wagon Day tomorrow a grand parade will file over almost exactly the same course that Brigham Young followed here on July 24, 1847, from Emigration Canyon and said when he saw the valley, "It is enough, this is the right place. Drive on."

NEW YORK to London in twenty hours in a passenger plane! That is the dream of aviation engineers and airline operators who look upon this stretch of treacherous air over the North Atlantic as the last link in their globe-circling communications system. When Howard Hughes spanned the Atlantic in sixteen and a half hours, flying from New York to Paris, it was a prevision of what is to come.

Professor J. Francis Coad, vice principal of Charlotte Hall Military Academy, died today at University Hospital. He had come from his home in St. Mary's County last Sunday for treatment at the hospital.

In rain squalls the Larchmont Yacht Club's annual race week came to an end today, and long will be remembered as having been sailed-in the worst weather ever. Starting off with its record fleet of 368 craft a week ago, there were 1,666 starters over the six days.

Milwaukee today settled a $4,977,000 judgment for $818,000, ending a long court fight over patents on sewage disposal. This gave hope to officials of the Chicago Sanitary District, which is faced with a bill for about $7,500,000 in a similar case.

It is Sunday. Although the stock has to be fed and the cows have to be milked, all the enterprises of the fields are suspended and the countryside takes a deep sigh of relief. For six days the work has been heroic.

Carrying a large leather suitcase, in which there was believed to have been a weight, a well-dressed man about 45 years old walked off the stern of the municipal ferryboat Tompkinsville as she was proceeding from St. George, S. I., to the Battery at 2 P. M. Yesterday.

The gross operating revenues of the 141 Class 1 team railroads in the United States. in May were $272,665,025, compared with $352,542,542 in May, 1937, according to a compilation by the Interstate Commerce Commission.
The chantry of St. Thomas Church in this city was the setting for the marriage yesterday morning of Miss Ann Doherty, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Doherty of Passaic, N. J., and St.
In a unanimous decision the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals ruled invalid today the Charles A. Kaufman "ringless hosiery" patent owned by Julius Kayser Co. and the Textile Patent Corporation.

The government, through the procurement division of the Treasury Department and the Works Progress Administration, is engaged in an unprecedented clothes-buying project. In a major extension of the controversial "buy-and-give" program, millions of dollars' worth of men's and boys' Winter coats and suits have been ordered for Fall distribution to the needy.

Although comment in the local apparel market indicates rising optimism, this feeling has not yet been reflected in volume of orders, according to resident buyers here. Buying in practically all major lines is at least slightly under a year ago, it was said yesterday, and a number of retailers have delayed regular Fall trips until early in August.

Robots are going to make Uncle Sam's weather flights now, displacing aviators who brave danger daily to get data at high altitudes. Federal air weather reporting stations have started to substitute radio meteorographs,

President Roosevelt today exchanged wireless felicitations with Crown Prince Gustaf Adolf of Sweden while the Houston approached the Equator on its move to a new fishing area for the Chief Executive.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated July 22: BRIGADIER GENERAL. Spalding, G. R., Gen. Staff Corps, to retirement. COLONELS Martin, C. F., Inspector General's Department, two days' leave, July 23. Twaddle, H. L., Inf., Fort Wayne, Mich detailed as a member of the Gen. Staff Corps, Aug. 16, and ordered to Washington, D. C.

Establishment of a school of government and public affairs at the Louisiana State University, which will offer the first comprehensive training in foreign and domestic government services ever given in the South, was announced yesterday by Dr. James M. Smith, president of the university, through Dr. Fred C. Frey, dean of the College of Arts and Sciences. The new unit will become operative at the opening of the 1938-39 academic year in September.

MARCUS WHITMAN. CRUSADER, Part II. 1839 to 1843. Edited by Archer Butler Hulbert and Dorothy Printup Hul bert. 8vo. Denver, Col.: The Stewart Commission of Colorado College and the Denver Public Library. $5. The second volume of the life and letters of Dr. Whitman. Volume 7 in the Overland to the Pacific series.

The former Lee estate. on Heathcote Road, Scarsdale, Westchester County, has been purchased by Dr. Millar McClintock. The property contains two and one-half acres with a large frame house, which is being remodeled, and it will be ready for occupancy early in the Fall.

HOLD THAT TIGER. By Mabel Stark in collaboration with Gertrude Orr. Illustrated. 248 pp. Caldwell, Idaho: The Caxton Printers. $2.50. MABEL STARK decided to train tigers because, as she puts it, "no other woman had specialized in that field." "Tigers," she adds, "were considered too dangerous for a woman to handle."

Insured Investors, Inc., Kansas City, Mo., an investment trust, has filed under the Securities Act of 1933 a registration statement covering investors' series C certificates as follaws: 3,500 insured plan to be offered at $500 each, 4,500 non-insured plan at $500 each,

" Color, silhouette and fabrics all lend themselves this Fall to coordinated promotional effort based on quality appeal," Miss Ada Kay Price, fashion adviser of Kirby, Block Co., resident buyers, says in a special fashion analysis prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES.

THESE are sailing days, and along each of New York's three great water avenues, the bay, the river and the Sound, impressive flotillas of yachts glide in and out of coves and inlets, providing the photographer with many opportunities for increasing his collection of marine prints.

William O. Douglas, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said today that the advisability of segregation of the broker-dealer functions on the New York Stock Exchange and treatment that should be accorded specialists in that connection were being studied as part of a broad program of Exchange reorganization, but that no decision had been reached.

THE year's two principal contract bridge events will be included in the annual national championship tournament of the American Contract Bridge League. The tournament begins Monday, Aug. 1, in the convention hall at Asbury Park, N. J., and will occupy the entire week.
The State Department made public announcement today that American consular officers in Germany, because of legal reasons, cannot accept funds from Americans for transmission to non-Americans.

Considerable confusion has been caused here by insufficient and reportedly inaccurate accounts of what passed yesterday in London between Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain and the German Ambassador, Dr. Herbert von Dirksen. Amid that confusion the French Foreign Office is taking a very cautious line.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Several weeks ago THE TIMES published a letter in which I described the workings of the new Civil Aeronautics Act of 1938. I expressed the naive hope that when the President came to appoint the six men empowered to administer the law he would eschew politics sufficiently to include in the commission men of long experience and with detailed knowledge of the complicated problems of modern aviation.

The report of the Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit System, including the Brooklyn Queens Transit System, for the fiscal year ended on June 30, issued yesterday, showed a net income of $578,168 after expenses and taxes. This was equal to $2.32 a share on the outstanding $6 cumulative preferred stock.

Funeral services for Owen Wister, author of "The Virginian," were held today in the Church of St. James the Less. The 78-year-old novelist died Thursday at his Summer home, North Kingston, R. I. Burial was in North Laurel Hill Cemetery.

LANDSCAPES predominate in the exhibition of fifty watercolors by members of the Silvermine Guild of Artists now in progress at Guild Hall. Among the painters represented are Richard Daggy, Howard Hildebrand, Revington Arthur, George Shellhase, Alexander Couard, Nancy Petitmermet, Howard Heath, J. M.

The culmination this week of another Democratic primary election campaign-this one in Montana-served to keep the national spotlight wellfocused on this particular part of the current American scene, even after President Roosevelt, his crosscountry swing completed, had put out to sea to fish.

BANK--Mr. and Mrs. Mac A. Bank (nee (Kublanow) announce birth of Barbara Ann, Saturday, July 16, 1938. BANER--Mr. and Mrs. Harry Banner (nee Stella.Altman) announce the arrival of Barbara Joan's brother, on Friday, July 22. 1938. at French Hospital. BARNETT-Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Barnett (Frances Gold) announce birth of a son, Jay Gold, brother to Serena Reve, July 20, at Leroy Sanitarium.

LONDON. RECENTLY in the House of Commons a Labor member slapped the face of a colleague and emphasized the fact-not always acceptedthat the "Mother of Parliaments" is a less decorous body than her American daughter, the House of Representatives.
In THE TIMES Magazine today the philosopher king of industry sets forth his views of life and one thing and another, informally and unsystematically. He has "never laid out a system of life."

Continued buoyancy of railroad loans featured active trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. After a somewhat hesitant start, the upswing gained momentum in the second of the two hours, bringing gains of fractions to 3 points over a broad list of carrier

SLANTING off in a normal seasonal decline, production during the past week dropped to about 30,000 units from the level of approximately 42,000 in the previous week. This lessening in output had been anticipated and was occasioned by several plants closing for Summer inventories and retooling.
The petition of Mrs. Gloria Morgan Vanderbilt and her twin sister, Lady Thelma Furness, to dissolve the dress business of Gloria Vanderbilt-Sonia Gowns, Inc., 23 East Fifty-sixth Street,

Banks and other lending institutions are making marked progress in disposing of foreclosed realty, particularly outmoded Manhattan tenement properties. Striking evidence of the extent of their liquidations in recent months is to be found in a study of the open-market deals recorded during the first half of 1938.

Sumner Pease, proprietor of a local grocery store which had been operated by three generations of the Pease family in succession since 1812, died at his home here today. He retired from the management recently.
Mrs. Joseph P. Kennedy, wife of the United States Ambassador, accompanied by several of the Kennedy children, left London yesterday to spend some time at a place the Kennedys have taken in Cannes.

Conditions were quiet in the foreign exchange market today and the principal curnencies showed only small alterations. The dollar reacted after several days of pronounced strength arid the rate weakened to $4.92 1/3 to the pound sterling, although the movement was not accompanied by much business.

Miss Helen Stell, daughter of Mrs. John Stell and the late Mr. Stell of this village, and Roger Elton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick G. Elton, also of Sea Cliff, were married this afternoon at the home of the bride's mother.

The announce ment of an Italian racial policy which has created an entirely artificial Italian-Jewish problem has drawn attention once again to the importance that Italy attributes to the Rome-Berlin Axis.

ON next Thursday in more than sixty cities throughout the United States children and adults will take part in exercises honoring the memory of an outstanding figure of American life, Joseph Lee of Boston, for twenty-seven years president of the National Recreation Association until his death on July 28, 1937.
More than 400 guests attended the masquerade supper dance held this evening at the Belle Haven Beach Club in aid of the Crippled Children's Fund of New York. Many dinners were given before the dance.

Homeowners who are considering the replacement of the old-type wooden: dumb-waiter having no protection against -fire are advised to install one of the. new metal units and fireproof the shaft, carrier and door units.

AUDREY LUCAS, the daughter of E. V. Lucas, practices a highly traditional order of story telling. "Old Motley" could be described as an oldfashioned novel-and probably .will be so described-but it is also a kind of novel which never goes out of fashion.

With no mother plane to launch her, the Mercury, English pickaback seaplane, will take off under its own power from Port Washington, L. I., tomorrow morning at 9 o'clock for the return trip to England, Paul E. Bewshea, American representative of Imperial Airways, announced yesterday.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., July 23.--Three navy fliers were killed this afternoon when their bombing plane nose dived into the vegetable garden of Charles H. Carpenter at Woodbridge, four miles from here, in a blinding rain squall.

Sidney B. Wood Jr., former Wimbledon tennis champion, underwent his first stiff test in his comeback campaign today at the Longwood Cricket Club and went down in defeat at the hands of the player who hopes to eliminate all rivals for the No. 2 singles berth on the American Davis Cup team.

Starting this week, prices on a number of men's furnishing lines will be advanced by leading manufacturers, mainly as the result of rising quotations of raw materials and also because of the recent rush of orders, reports in the local market indicated yesterday.

Supply $2 contracts valued at $6,400,919 were awarded in the week ended on Thursday by sixteen Federal agencies under the provisions of the Public Contracts Act, the Department of Labor announced today. A total of 139 orders was placed, of which thirty-four, valued at $1,736,189, went to bidders in New York State; three, for $610,743, to New Jersey, and five, for $105,702, to Connecticut.

The scope of the service maintained by the Seamen's Church Institute for seamen and other marine workers is outlined in detail in the organization's report for the first six months of 1938, made public yesterday by Leslie C. Westerman, business manager.

To satisfy a number of entrants, the date for the inboard speed-boat races at Northport, L. I., has been changed from July 30 to Aug. 13. David Cerli and others of the Northport Yacht Club found that there was a serious conflict with the Chester River regatta this week and that several of the 91s and 135s wanted to be in two places at once but couldn't figure a way to do it.
A fund of $5,000 has been raised as an eightieth anniversary addition to Susquehanna University's endowment fund, according to announcement made last week by President G. Morris Smith.

Data on construction activity for the country as a whole presented a brighter picture last month, when permit valuations for all types of projects registered increases. Figures on permits issued in June in the principal cities indicate that residential work was 12 per cent higher than in May, according to a statement yesterday by Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor.

William C. Darling, nationally known in the canning industry, died at his home in Sycamore last night of a heart attack. He was 82 years old. Mr. Darling had been general manager of the Sycamore preserve works for twenty-eight years.

Dr. D. Sutherland Davidson, Assistant Professor of Anthropology at the University of Pennsylvania, will leave for Western Australia early next month to direct a field expedition seeking light on problems relating to the origin and development of Australian culture and the antiquity of man on than continent.
America's World War veterans spent 82 per cent of their bonus payment in two years, and may pay out the rest in a few more years.
LAST Sunday we investigated the fortunes of our American artists represented in the Museum of Modern Art's exhibition at the Jeu de Paume in Paris.

The hardest thing left in the Alps-the Eigerwand itself-is near being mastered now. The Eigerwand in the Jungfrau range is the highest rock wall in the Alps. It rises almost straight for 6,300 feet. Only 500 feet from the top of that terrifying wall four young men are climbing, huddled tonight in stormclouds at an altitude of 12.700 feet.

Shipping officials and harbor authorities were conferring last- week on two of the port's so-called nuisances, fog and noise, and it appeared at the end of the week that these traditional appurtenances of water-borne commerce would remain effective,

SCUTTLING between "Pins and Needles" companies here and on the West Coast, Louis Schaffer, overlord -of Labor Stage, found time to drop off in Chicago to see an author. He is Harry Barnard, and he now has a commission to dramatize his "Eagle Forgotten" for the uses of Labor Stage.

Dr. Ernest W. Brown, for a quarter century Josiah Willard Gibbs Professor of Mathematics at Yale and last year winner of the James Craig Watson medal of the National Academy of Science for distinguished contributions to astronomical science, died late last night at the age of 71 in New Haven Hospital of heart disease. He had been ill for three days, but suffered from asthma for several years.

Mr. and Mrs. James Lawrence McKay of the Bronx and Babylon, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Stephanie Florence McKay, to Alexander Nikita Troshkin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nikita Troshkin of the Bronx and Old Lyme, Conn .

Price advances averaging about 5 per cent are being asked by fur manufacturers on merchandise for August sales, but the move has resuited in some price resistance on the part of buyers, reports here yesterday indicated.

SOME 300 artists are at present employed as instructors in the local teaching division of the WPA Federal Art Project and from the bulk of their off-project creative work more than a hundred examples have been chosen (oil paintings, water-colors, drawings and sculpture) for an exhibition that opened last week in the Federal Art Gallery, 225 West Fifty-seventh Street, there to remain through Aug. 11.
DUBLIN, July (AP)--Douglas G. Corrigan declared today, "my career is in the air." as a growing assortment of commercial offers became annoying.

To many it may seem a waste of effort to build a garden on rented property, but Mr. and Mrs. Spencer Marsh Jr. of Fairview Avenue, of Madison, N. J., have found that the creation of beauty in their surroundings is well repaying them for the time and effort they have put into their temporary home.

COHEN-DUBROWIN-Mr. and Mrs. Julius Dubrowin, 671 West 193d St., take pleasure announcing the engagement of their daughter, Helen Marjorie, to Ralph Jerrold Cohen, on of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Cohen of New York City. GLAUBMAN-SACKS--Mr. and Mrs. Reuben R. Sacks, 2,115 Avenue M, Brooklyn, announce the engagement of their daughter. Beatrice Edith, to Milton M. Glaubman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Glaubman ot 468 Crown St., Brooklyn.

Norman Hartnell designed all of Queen Elizabeth's wardrobe for the royal visit to Paris, including even her hats and furs. All-white ensembles with diamonds or pearls were selected to set off her lovely coloring.

Dom Soccoli, New Britain, Conn., gas station owner and former New England public links champion, tonight stood as the last obstacle in Max Marston's path to his eighth triumph in the Shenecossett men's invitation golf tournament.

Money spent for building construction in the country during June was 5.5 per cent greater than in May and 16.5 per cent less than in June last year, according to the current issue of the magazine Building. June was the third consecutive month during which construction activity increased over the previous months.

Miss of the Caroline Schroeder Johnson, daughter of Mrs. Moulton K. Johnson and the late Captain Johnson, U. S. N., and a granddaughter of the late Rear Admiral Seaton Schroeder, is to be married on Aug. 6 to Gardiner Emmons of Boston, son of Mrs. Robert Wales Emmons Sr.

The Office of Arms and Munitions Control, set up within the State Department for the control of the shipment of arms, ammunition and implements of war to foreign countries, issued in the fourteen months ending June 30, last, exactly 200 licenses for the shipment of finished war materials to Japan and China, the value of which, as disclosed in the records of the State Department, was $23,180,000.
THIS, then, is the real Pacific: Softly rippling water, like molten nickel-steel, under a sky of fiery yellow and blue. Vast plains of quicksilver at night, with a huge half-moon of placid,

SIX years of experiment came to a successful end on Thursday afternoon when Mercury, the upper component of the Mayo composite airplane, landed at Port Washington, L. I., after an Atlantic crossing from Foynes, Ireland, by way of Montreal. For the first time a heavily loaded aircraft had made a long-distance flight after being carried aloft to attain flying speed by a larger and more lightly loaded porter plane, the flying boat Maia.

The recent appointment' of five women among 144 arbitrators, named by the New York Stock Exchange to handle disputes on a national basis, has drawn attention to a little known field of activity for women.

AS a feature of their Summer program, dealers are holding sales of photo albums in popular snapshot sizes. Among the types selling fastest are inexpensive leatherette pocket-size folders for carrying six or eight snapshots between home and the office, and cloth-covered albums for prints up to three and one-quarter by four and onequarter inches.
A sharp drop in the number of non-medical drug addicts for the fiscal year just ended has been reported to Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau by H. J. Anslinger, Narcotics Commissioner.

Both victorious in the eleventh and final round of the open championship finals of the American Chess Federation at the Hotel Touraine, Isaac I. Kashdan, champion of the Manhattan C. C., and Israel A.

SONNENPTHAL. SALLIE (July 10). Estate, more than $10,000. To Jane Sonnenthal Mayer, grandmother, Corpus Christi, Texas, $13,000 and one-eighth residue; Anne Sonnenthial, granddaughter, 40 E. 88th St., same bequest; Mary Anne Sonnenthal, granddaughter, Dllas, Texas, one-eighth residue and one-half of $57,000; Fred A. Levy, grandson, San Francisco, $26.000 and one-fourth residue;

Amid heavy showers which drenched spectators and contestants alike, the sixty-sixth national rowing regatta began a two-day stand on the North Shrewsbury or Navasink River today with James Russell from Toronto's Argonaut Rowing Club triumphing in his senior sculls event, feature of the opening program.

An interesting report was presented yesterday by Preston Delano, governor of the Federal Home Loan Bank System showing a sharp increase in the proportion of private to government funds invested in the twelve Federal Home Loan Banks.

RICHMOND. Va. SITUATED on the edge of Thomas Jefferson's classic campus, hardly a hundred yards from the rooms occupied by Edgar Allan Poe and Woodrow Wilson during their undergraduate days, the University of Virginia Library is now completed.

The boiler room of the Orange Memorial Hospital was flooded to a depth of four feet about 11 o'clock this morning, the water putting the heating and steam system out of commission for nearly three hours.

A contract was awarded by the Navy Department today to the Bethlehem Shipbuilding Corporation of New York for the construction of three Diesel-driven fleet tugs of 1,150 tons each, at a cost of $1,226,000 each.

The initial invitation regatta of the Domino Yacht Club, "baby" member of the Great South Bay Racing Association, was marked today by high winds, veering from south to southwest, white-capped seas and lowering clouds.
Margot Grahame, English motion picture star, today was in Reno to establish residence so that she may start divorce proceedings against her husband, Francis Lister, an actor.

Corwin A. Fergus, chief of the division of research and statistics of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, voices the belief that life insurance companies are in a position to shift $4,000,000,000 to the real estate mortgage field "if investments there become sufficiently attractive."
Evidences of improvement in general business activity are flowing into the Department of Commerce in increasing volume, according to Colonel J. Monroe Johnson, Acting Secretary.
The Interstate Commission on Crime elected Judge Richard Hartshorne of Newark, N. J., to the newly created position of president at its final session today.
Federal Judge Frederick H. Bryant faced today the difficult task of deciding whether Anson Stark's bull has a legal right to be in this country.

LONDON. TIME was when the decease of The Saturday Review would have been a major literary event. In Bryce's opinion, there was never a journal which enlisted so much and such varied literary talent as The Saturday did between 1855, the date of its foundation by John Douglas Cook, and 1863. Certainly none could boast of more distinguished contributors.

If Lloyd Harbor is somewhat deserted this Sabbath morning, if the anchorages at Croton, Zachs Bay and Hamburg Cove have more swinging room than usual, it means one thing. Scores of cruising weekenders, like the modern Magellans they are, have gone down to explore the Shrewsbury Rivers.

Miss Hope Larkin and Miss Shirley Jane Larkin, daughters of Mr. and Mrs. Sylvester Larkin of Greenwich, will be introduced to society at a supper dance to be given by their parents in the garden of the Larkin estate on Sept. 12, it was announced today.

THE SILVER MAGNET: Fifty Years in a Mexican Silver Mine. By Grant Shepherd. lustrated. 302 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton Co. $3. HAVING a story to tell is more important than being able to give literary finish to a book of this description. "Silver Magnet" is a good deal like the ore that Mr. Shepherd dug out of the Batopilas mines in Mexico.

UNLIKE T. A. Bisson's volume which has been lately reviewed in these columns, the book of Professor Emil Lederer and Emy Lederer-Seidler is neither an exposition of recent factual material, relating to the Far East nor a. picture of the situation there resulting from the Sino-Japanese war.

President Roosevelt applauded the signing of the peace treaty between Bolivia and Paraguay today. Responding to a message from President Roberto M. Ortiz of Argentina, he cabled the Argentine President as follows:
The third annual convention of the Dancing Teachers Business Association, Inc., will open tomorrow morning for a five-day session at the Park Central Hotel.

Twelve projects in New York State and three in New Jersey were included in 109 grants of PWA funds covering twenty-seven States announced today. The total grants amounted to $12,601,078 and brought the value of the PWA heavy construction program this year to $883,278,068.

THE beautiful ball given by Lady Mendl at her Versailles home undoubtedly struck the highest note in the style-prelude to the royal visit. The hostess received in a Mainbocher creation of white organza woven with pastel-tinted plaid stripes.
If we were in the habit of celebrating anniversaries of the Great War, the closing fortnight of July would be among them.

The belief that Japan's invasion of China could be stopped without a resort to force "if the United States, Great Britain, Russia, France and other nations interested in the Pacific" would make a joint display of "firmness and solidarity" against Japanese aggression was expressed by Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek today in an interview with the writer.

The giant twin-motored flying boat Guba, flown by your correspondent and manned by the regular crew of five, made a safe descent and take-off a few days ago at Lake Habbema, a small, isolated body of water at approximately 11,000 feet altitude in the heart of the mountainous section of unexplored New Guinea.

CONTINUING improvement in the motor vehicle accident and fatality record is indicated by the daily traffic accident reports of the Connecticut Department of Motor Vehicles. As of July 16, this year showed 8,282 traffic accidents, as against 10,178 to the same date last year; 154 fatalities, against 208, and 4,918 injuries as against 7,234.

Chairman Sheppard telegraphed members of the Senate Campaign Investigating Committee today to hurry to Washington after he had received a complaint from Governor William Langer of North Dakota that relief workers in his State had been intimidated politically.

Mrs. Heinz Warneke of this city and the Mowings, East Haddam, Conn., has announced the engagement and forthcoming marriage of her daughter, Miss Delight Dawson Hall, to Tyge Ernst Rothe of Copenhagen, Denmark. The ceremony will take place next month in Denmark.

The marriage of Miss Carol Woodcock Wood, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. J. Wood Jr., to Michael A. Graybill son of Dr. and Mrs. Guy Graybill of Jenkintown, Pa., took place this afternoon in the Saugatuck Congregational Church.

Arthur L. Bates, retired president of the Union Mutual Life Insurance Company, died tonight at his home here at the age of 87. He was a brother of the late Katherine Lee Bates, author of the hymn "America the Beautiful."

THE Biltmore Hotel's Hawaiian spot, the Royal Palm Roof, is now Hawaiian. Thanks for that state of affairs belong to Harry Owens, of Honolulu, and his orchestra, the most polished of its kind in town. When the Royal Palm Roof was opened Horace Heidt and his band were present, but their radio type of showmanship, good as it may be, did not befit the new authentic island setting at the Biltmore.

President Roosevelt's reported determination to invade Wisconsin, stronghold of the La Follette clan and cradle of their new party, National Progressives of America, has added a new note of confusion to an already bewildering political campaign here.

Over the private practice of medicine in this country for the last decade there has been increasingly pictured as looming a threat variously known as "socialized medicine" or "State medicine," with so-called "group medicine" also at times included in the "menace."

According to word received from Philip J. Roosevelt, chairman of the selection committee for this country's representatives, the probable make-up of the British sixmeter team for the British-American Cup match, which will be held off the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club, Oyster Bay, L. I., beginning Sept. 7, has been made known by J. H. Maurice Clark of the invaders.

The hope that the new Real Estate Taxpayers Federation, Inc., eventually would be able to exert a wide influence in keeping down taxes on realty property throughout the State was expressed by speakers who attended Charles F. Noyes's annual outing last week at his home in Huntington, L. I.

Emergency facilities of this city were called upon to their utmost capacity today to cope with the wide ruin spread by torrential rains that stalled traffic, flooded homes and shop and ruine construction jobs. The United States Weather Bureau at Newark airport reported a rainfall of 1.28 inches for six hours compared with 1.34 in this area in the previous twelve hours. Traffic at the airport was reported uninterrupted.

TWO schools of thought about Baltimore's status as a show town prevail among theatrical producers, actors and authors. The first view, held by those whose offerings have been despised and rejected in this locality, deounces Baltimore as a community of dolts and misers.

The national council of the C. T. M. (Mexican Federation of Labor) met tonight in an attempt to spur organized labor's drive for exclusive control of the nation's press by naming the Mexican newspapers to be boycotted and subjected to union troubles, including strikes.

Frank O. Lowden, former Governor of Illinois, has opened Castle Rest, his Summer home on Pullman Island. With him are his daughter, Mrs. John B. Drake Jr. of Chicago, Mrs. Elizabeth Taylor of Greenwich, Conn., and Mrs. Drake's children, Barbara, George and John B. Drake 3d.

PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT, aboard the cruiser Houston, is fishing his way southward to what is generally recognized as a fisherman's paradise. Socorro Island, Cocos Island and the Galapagos are names that stir the imagination, and the waters roundabout provide anglers with mighty tales-and true ones.

Funeral services for John Chester Warner, vice president of the R. C. A. Manufacturing Company, who was killed in an automobile accident Thursday, will be held here at 10 A. M. Monday at the Home for Services, 56 Park Street. His age was 42.

In a penthouse, atop a midtown office building, there opened last week a permanent exhibition of a glass kitchen, representing the combined efforts of manufacturers of many kinds of glass and glass containers.

One of the largest real estate transactions for several months in the Orange section of Essex County, N. J., was announced yesterday in the purchase by J. A. Darwin of East Orange and an executive of the Wurlitzer Corporation of New York City, of the thirty-acre estate owned by the late Moreau Delano in West Orange.
Plans to see that every new student at the University of Oklahoma receives individual attention this Fall are now being considered by the university's administrative officials.

The Giants come tramping home this week weary of the road, smarting under the treatment they received in the hostile West and seeking some measure of revenge for a campaign on foreign soil that impaired their National League flag chances.

COLORADO'S sinuous mountain highways leading to Central City these days are thronged with cars carrying theatre enthusiasts to the Old Opera House, which today may be seen exactly as it was sixty years ago when it was first opened.

The National Association of Credit Men yesterday published "The Bankruptcy Law of 1938-A Comparative Analysis," a section by section analysis and comparison of the new Bankruptcy Law by Jacob I. Weinstein of the Philadelphia bar.
The National Bituminous Coal Commission today announced completion of its hearings to determine the weighted average cost of producing bituminous coal in the United States.

Harold R. Lhowe of the United Knitwear Manufacturers League said yesterday that it was the hope of members of the league, now under contractual regulations, to avert a strike by negotiating a fair and reasonable renewal agreement. The contract with the union expired on July 15.

The Committee for Industrial Organization announced plans today to establish a farm-equipment workers' organizing committee, which will seek 100 per cent unionization of the industry and the obtaining of collective-bargaining contracts.

One of the largest and most important public educational meetings to be held in New York City during the coming year will convene in the Fall to consider the forthcoming Report of the Regents' Inquiry into the Character and Cost of Public Education in New York State.

Several new homes in the Wychwood community of Westfield, N. J., have recently been sold to aviators flying planes to and from the Newark Airport, reports Arthur R. Rule, president of the developing company.

To meet the steadily increasing demand for homes in the suburban areas of Bergen County, N. J., a new residential community in Ridgewood will be formally opened this week and four model houses will be ready for inspection.

To meet the steadily increasing demand for homes in the suburban areas of Bergen County, N. J., a new residential community in Ridgewood will be formally opened this week and four model houses will be ready for inspection.

With all but one of its components advancing for the week ended July 16, THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity has spurted almost four points and now stands at 81.4, its highest point since the week ended Jan. 29. The figure for the preceding week was 77.6 (revised) and a year ago it was 110.1.

SIR JOHN REITH, director-genseral of the British Broadcast ing Corporation since 1927, has resigned to become chairman of the Imperial Airways. First as general manager of the BBC in 1922 and then managing director in 1923, Sir John saw the number of licensed listeners increase from 36,000 to 8,631,150.

BAR HARBOR, Me.-The coming fortnight will see a great deal of combined sports and social activity on Mount Desert Island and its various resort retreats, including Bar Harbor, Northeast, Seal and Southwest Harbors.
Miss Kathleen Maria Gibbs, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George William Gibbs of this city, was married in St. Mark's Episcopal Church here today to Norman Dudley Johnson of Boston and New York.

Perole String Quartet in the first of a series of guest appearances on the "Music Hall of the Air" program; Jan Peerce, tenor, will be the soloist: WJZ, 12:30-1:30 P. M. String Quartet in A major, Op. 33, No. 6.

GEORGE PEABODY GOOCH is probably the foremost living authority on modern diplomatic history. Educated at London, Cambridge, Paris and Berlin, he has devoted most of his sixty-five years to a scientific search for the truth of what has happened among governments and diplomatic circles since 1870.

THREE of them were mad! These visionaries-prophets of the music of today-were discovered by the Count Andrea Marcosini, a young Milanese nobleman, an amateur musician, a writer of poetry, a pluralist but a connoisseur as well of women.
WEATHER conditions in important areas of the country affected retail trade last week, with the result that the decline under a year ago was larger than that which featured recent weeks.

AS soon as we heard that the Flea Circus had received an offer from Paramount Pictures we hurried across Forty-second Street in order to be the first to interview our lucky neighbor, Professor Roy Heckler, whose trained fleas are the oldest and most stable theatrical institution in that kaleidoscopic thoroughfare.

A twenty-acre tract has been set aside at Lake Mohawk, near Sparta, Sussex County, N. J., restricted to ranger-type cabins for. Summer residents who prefer something of the old-fashioned rough-and-ready atmosphere for their vacation outings.

While rains have been deluging Eastern States during the past week, the Pacific Coast has been experiencing a heat wave, Portland, Ore., and several California cities reporting many deaths from prostration.

The Commodity Research Bureau, Inc., through its president Harry Jiler, advised business men yester day to accumulate raw materials and finished goods in anticipation of a major business recovery in the Fall.

IN a village called Salybia in the mountain fastness of Dominica in the British West Indies are people whose ancestors ate the first Caribbean travelers. The matriarch of the tribe-a pureblooded Carib named Katarou-remembers the day when wives flung themselves in the grave of their common husband and were buried alive with the dead.
Five days of intermittent rains have drenched the Cotton Belt, causing damage to the staple and to fruit, but in general proving a boon to other crops.

A series of demands affecting hours and working conditions were adopted yesterday for presentation to the Postal Telegraph and Cable Company by the convention of the American Communications Association, C. I. 0. affiliate, at the Hotel Victoria. Negotiations for a new contract with the company will begin late in October.
The Rev. Patrick Kelly, parish priest of Banagher in the diocese of Derry, Ireland, died today at the home of his brother, James Kelly of this village. at the age of 67.
Dick Chapman of Greenwich, Conn., today won the Bald Peak invitation golf tournament, defeating Ray Lenahan of Providence, R. I., 5 and 4.
A hint of counter-charges of communism against leaders of the Martin faction in the United Automobile Workers of America was seen today in statements by four suspended officers of the union.

Periods of disbelief are perfectly normal for all Christians, the Rev. Dr. W. Theodore Taylor declared yesterday in his sermon at the morning service of the Central Baptist Church, Amsterdam Avenue and Ninety-second Street, of which he is the pastor.

A man who gave his name as Isaac Leifer and said that he was a "Grand Rabbi" of Brooklyn, is in jail here charged with trying to smuggle heroin and other narcotics into the United States, hidden in the bindings of copies of the Talmud and of Hebrew prayer books.

A lease involving rentals of more than $400,000 was made in the garment center area, where the sixteen-story structure at 252-54 West Thirty-eighth Street was leased by John B. McCaffrey, as trustee, to a client of Spear Co., Inc.

God is our judge because He cannot be trifled with and He acts severely, reckons with and condemns us because He expects big things of us, the Rev. John A. Bell said in his sermon yesterday at Grace Protestant Episcopal Church, Tenth Street and Broadway.

A repeat victory by eight husky young oarsmen from Buffalo enabling that city's West Side Rowing Club to retain the Julius H. Barnes Point Trophy, featured the final session of the national rowing regatta on the North Shrewsbury, or Navesink, River today.

The great monument of the Belgian people to their soldier-king, Albert, was dedicated at Nieuport today on the site of the advance post which defended the last tiny strip of Belgium that was not invaded in the World War.
Priests of St. Patrick's Cathedral have been circularized by the Communist party, the Rev. Robert E. Woods, a member of the cathedral staff, revealed yesterday.

Advertising has not made the most of its opportunities to win definite consumer favor by pointing out what it has accomplished, according to Col. Ralph K. Strassman, vice president of the Ward Wheelock Company.

President Roosevelt crossed the Equator today and tonight he rested aboard the Houston, anchored in Sullivan Bay, San Salvador or James Island, one of the smaller isles of the Galapagos. The cruiser, bearing the President on a fishing cruise, reached the Equator at 12:53 P. M.

Mrs. Edwards Spencer gave a dinner last night at Shipton Court, Lenox, for Major George Ross Rede of Fort Ethan Allen, Henry Wesserman of New York, James Stillman of Rosland, N. Y., and John Drury of Princeton, N. J. Later they went to the Stockbridge golf tournament ball. Mr. and Mrs.
Slammin' Sam Snead felt "the pressure" from golf's greatest stretch finisher today and barely withstood it to capture the $5,000 Chicago open championship at Olympia Fields.

A serious stage in the protracted Anglo-American trade pact negotiations has been reached with the report by the British delegation that the United States refused to make further concessions on several major categories of goods, it was declared tonight in quarters close to the government.

The principles of the proposed amendment to the Constitution of this State, placing a limit on the bonded indebtedness of each county, city, town or village, which has been reported by the committees on counties and towns, on cities, on villages and on State finance, have the endorsement of the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York,

Twenty young Roman Catholic priests went out from Maryknoll Seminary here this evening to go to China, Japan, Manchukuo and Korea as missioners. Their departure for the troubled areas, where they will share in the work of ministering to 20,000,000 nonChristian Orientals, was preceded by colorful ceremonies in which several hundred of their friends and relatives took part.

Dr. Angler Bailey Hobbs, who retired in 1932 as medical director of the New York Life Insurance Company, died here today of a heart ailment at the Gramatan Hotel, where he had lived for twelve years. His age was 74.

Cesare Sodero Jr., 11-year-old violinist, made a sensational debut at the concert of the New York Civic Orchestra conducted by his father, Cesare Sodero, last night at the Federal Music Theatre. Master Sodero was heard in the exacting Mendelssohn concerto.
What's going on below the surface in the swarming cities of Japan is almost as mysterious as what lies behind and beyond the purges that plow through the farthest Soviet republics.

On the possibility that Walter H. Wiley Jr., 18 years old, suspect in the "red circle" murders of Frances Hajek and Lewis Weiss, might have given some information relative to the slaying to Joseph Foster, alias Buckley, 22, Queens detectives left yesterday for Cincinnati, where Foster is held on a charge of burglary.
The world assembly for peace voted today to open a world-wide campaign to halt the bombing of unfortified cities and to bring relief to victims living in bombarded areas in Spain and China.

The universal quest of mankind for happiness will end successfully only when man learns to surrender his will to the higher will of God, the Rev. Dr. Frank S. Fry of the Port Richmond Reformed Church, Staten Island, declared yesterday in a sermon at the West End Collegiate Church, West End Avenue and Seventy-seventh Street.

Mr. and Mrs. Percy Montague. Jr. f this place have announced the engagement and approaching mariage of their daughter, Miss Franes Lee Montague, to Phillip Nance ?oachim of Washington, son of Mrs. Carl A. Joerissen of Chevy Chase, Md.

This capital of the former Austrian Province of Carinthia, a few miles from the frontiers of Italy and Yugoslavia, was ablaze with swastika flags and the green and gold banners of the province for the commemoration ceremonies this morning for the Nazis who losttheir lives in the uprising of July, 1934, when Chancellor Engelbert Dollfuss met his death.

Representative Clare E. Hoffman addressed a letter to the National Labor Relations Board from his home here today informing it that he was furnishing for distribution to employers, employes or others copies of his speech in Congress assailing the policies of the C. I. O. and the part played by Communists in sit-down strikes.

On the eve of the fortieth anniversary of the United States occupation of Puerto Rico by General Nelson A. Miles on July 25, 1898, the Puerto Rican Treasurer, Rafael Sancho Bonet, announced that general revenues for the last fiscal year exceeded $16,600,000, the highest on record and exceeding the total external trade of Puerto Rico at the beginning of the United States regime.
John Williamson Ziegler, vice president and a director of the John C. Winston Company, publishers, died today while vacationing at Point Pleasant, Pa., at the age of 69. His home was in Landsdowne.

Striving desperately to salvage something from the wreckage of a disastrous expedition and calling upon Carl Hubbell for one of his most heroic relief roles, the Giants battled the Cubs almost to sunset today before a roaring crowd of 35,078 pennantcrazed enthusiasts.

Thomas Lelen, 20 years old, of 49 India Street, Brooklyn, swam the East River unintentionally last night. He and several companions, clad in shorts, went bathing at Greene Street, Brooklyn, at 9 o'clock, and Lelen went out too far and was caught by a strong tide.

The Midtown Real Estate Associtation will meet Wednesday night at the Hotel Newton, 2,528 Broadway, near Ninety-fourth Street, to protest against efforts to increase the 10 per cent debt limitation on real estate.

There will be an exhibition of rare antiques and family heirlooms in the famous old Warner House here from Aug. 1 to 13 under the auspices of a group of Summer colonists in Eastern New Hampshire and Maine, including a number from New York.
Business and employment in New York State's "second city" have taken a "decided turn for the better," an Evening News survey showed.

Mr. and Mrs. William Mowat Flook of the Weylin and Stoneleigh, Ossining, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret R. Flook, to James Jeffrey Roche, son of the late Arthur Somers Roche, the author, and his first wife, the late Mrs. Ethel Kirby Rowell Roche.
Labor and capital are cooperating in Europe, former Mayor John F. Fitzgerald said today on his return aboard the Cunard White Star liner Carinthia.

A flat declaration that the covenant of the League of Nations does not require any member to apply sanctions against an aggressor was adopted today at the closing session of the conference of the Foreign Ministers representing the seven "Oslo powers."

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Ada Gertrude Michenfelder, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward George Michenfelder of Montclair, N. J., to Colton Miller Tuttle, son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Colton Tuttle of Glen Ridge, N. J.

Roy Weitz, guard on the champion Illinois football team of 1927 and graduate of that university in 1930, has been appointed line coach at Vermont, the athletic council announced today. Weitz replaces Cliff Kuhn, who resigned.
The Northern New Jersey tennis championships, scheduled to begin yesterday, started late this afternoon at the Westfield T. C. and competition continued until darkness halted play.

Surgical treatment which John J. Lapman says was refused to him until he performed his own operation, will be provided tomorrow when the 66-year-old sufferer from "hammer toes" will enter Mercy Hospital

Headquarters of a Federal survey of all the varied types of profit-sharing plans in the United States was set up in Chicago three weeks ago, it became known today, and now is ready to begin real work which will continue for the next six months.
Shortly before his departure for Sweden, Crown Prince Gustaf Adolf decorated Dr. J. Bentley Squier, his physician during his stay in this country, it was learned yesterday.

Frankly amazed at their own survival of four days and nights on Western New Mexico's desolate lava beds, three courageous women tourists today ate the first solid food they had tasted since breakfast last Tuesday.

Close to 1,000 men, women and children picnicked at Camp Siegfried here today, with no outward signs of action by county officials to obtain a judgment against the GermanAmerican Settlement League, operators of the Nazi center.

The Constitutional Convention tomorrow enters the week originally marked by its leaders as the final one of its session. To the dismay of the leaders, the session seems only a little nearer an end than it did a month ago.

Those skippers who felt they needed more competition after a week at Larchmont turned out fiftyseven strong for the Sunday special conducted by the Echo Bay Yacht Club today, with the busy International Class heading the list in one of its Bermuda Trophy series tests.

Moreland Maid, 6-year-old chestnut mare owned by the Fair City Stables of Mrs. L. Victor Weil of Elberon, N. J., today added another championship to her many conquests in the show ring by taking the title for three-gaited saddle horses as the third annual Jersey Shore horse show came to a close at the Boxwood Farm.
Leslie HoreBelisha, British Secretary of State for War, said today that France and Great Britain now are united under what seems to be "one general staff and one flag."

Tony Galento, heavyweight boxer who was scheduled to meet John Henry Lewis in a fifteen-round bout in Philadelphia Tuesday, is a "very sick man," according to Dr. Joseph Higi, his personal physician. At the Orange Memorial Hospital, where he is being treated for lobar pneumonia under an oxygen tent, it was said that, while he was conscious, his breathing was hard and his condition could be described as serious.

John F. Riddell Jr. of the Garden City Golf Club captured the annual Rockaway Hunting Club invitation golf tournament for the third time today when he defeated Sumner Waters of the Nassau Country Club, 3 and 2, in the final.

Eighty Boy Scouts and leaders, representing each of the five New York City borough divisions of the Ten Mile River Scout Camps in Sullivan County, N. Y., will leave today on a five-day "good-will tour" of the camp reservation.

Jerome D. Greene of Boston has been elected a trustee of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, its board of trustees announced yesterday. Mr. Greene became secretary of the Harvard University Corporation in 1905.

The third and last group of American track and field stars that will tour Europe this Summer under the auspices of the A. A. U. will leave tomorrow when twentythree athletes will embark for Germany on the North German Lloyd liner Europa.

Judson Van Arsdale, 59-year-old widower, made his selection last night between the two women who took turns at housekeeping in his Jackson Street residence while he attempted to determine which of them he wanted for his mate.

Vast crowds filled this city to overflowing today for the colorful opening of Greater Germany's first "Gymnastic and Sports Festival," in which 200,000 Germans and many from abroad are expected to participate.

Forest fires in Western Washington were under better control today as winds. died down and fire lanes were cleared. The 100,000-acre fire on Vancouver Island 100 miles north of Victoria, B. C., was still out of control, but officials of the Provincial Forest Branch said it was quiescent during the night.

An average increase of 35 per cent in the salaries of 27,000 clerical employes in 207 corporations in the period between May, 1937, and May, 1938, was reported yesterday by the Merchants Association of New York on the basis of a survey made by its industrial bureau. This increase, the announcement emphasized, occurred despite a recession in business during the period.

Edison Brothers Stores, Inc.-Six months to June 30: Consolidated net profits, $503,268, or $1.21 a common share, compared with $581,511, or $1.43 a share, for the same period in 1937; net sales, $12,100,641, against $11,779,464.

Christianity is not good advice but good news, and the good news is the availability of God, the Rev. Dr. C. Leslie Glenn, rector of Christ's Church, Cambridge, Mass., said in a sermon at the 11 A. M. service yesterday at the -Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

Radio cars in North Queens patrolled yesterday the length of the Astoria and Flushing elevated lines of the I. R. T. and B. M. T. following reports of the finding of an eight-foot towing chain on the tracks 200 feet east of the Court Square station and the stoning of another train near the Junction Boulevard station.

The Pennsylvania Legislature will convene here tomorrow night in a special session that may last for weeks or months, with chief interest centered on its action regarding charges of corruption against the Earle Administration.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 81.5, which compared with 81.7 the week before, 81.2 two weeks before, 80.9 three weeks before and 81.1 four weeks before.
The seasonally adjusted index of general merchandise sales in small towns and rural areas increased 2.3 points in June, compared with May, the Department of Commerce has reported.

Clouds that had been alternately dripping and pouring water on the metropolitan area for eight consecutive days released a final sprinkle yesterday morning at 8:40 o'clock and then began to disperse as State, county, township, village and city workers and householders began mopping up the debris of overflowing streams and landslides.

Federal Judge Robert P. Pattersbn will hear argument today on a motion for appointment of a special master to take testimony on claims of bondholders and stockholders of the Manhattan Railway Company arising from any disaffirmance of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company's lease of the elevated lines.

The State Tax Commission today reported the 1938 State equalization table which puts the assessed valuation of $25,623,867,926 on taxable real property, a sum $75,062,943 higher than for 1937, when the total was $25,548,805,083.

A more friendly tone toward Germany and a corresponding coolness toward Czechoslovakia, which may be a significant in view of the approaching crisis over the Sudeten Germans was noticeable this morning in the editorials and news stories of the London press.

There never will be peace until the world accepts the belief that the dominance of man by man is as fatal to world order as would be defiance of the law of gravitation, the Rev. Dr. Frederick W. Norwood said yesterday in a sermon at the Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street.

Twenty persons marooned by the flood waters of the San Saba River, near here, were rescued today by volunteer boatmen and swimmers who fought the dangerous current. Among those rescued were the fourteen members of the Jose Jamanay family, including ten children.

Ernst Lubitsch and Myron Selznick have announced the formation of a partnership under the name of Ernst Lubitsch, Inc., for the production of films. It is said to be the first of a series of organizations in which Selznick will be the financial partner with stars, directors and writers,

First Croatian Catholic Day was celebrated by the members of the parish of the Roman Catholic Church of Saints Cyril and Methodius, 552 West Fiftieth Street, yesterday with high mass and a parade here and a picnic in New Jersey The day also marked the twenty-fifth anniversary of the church, of which the Rev. Zvonko Manduric is rector.

(Figures in parentheses indicate par) Brookville (72)-Mixed foursomes: Miss Ann Kramer and Joseph McGough, 82-1468; Miss H. Miller and Nat Kramer, 87-15--72; Mrs. W. Hinkle and George Meredith, 84-12-72. Glen Oaks (72)-Final of best-ball tournament, first flight: George Markelson and Sam Nirenberg defeated Robert Santel and Dr. Joe Morse, 3 and 1.

Stephen J. Cushing Jr. of Brooklyn was elected to a second consecutive term as chairman of the Long Island Chapter, Knights of Columbus, at a meeting yesterday afternoon in the Institute, 81 Hanson Place, Brooklyn.

Although Fall buying in the New York wholesale market was considered to have reached its peak last week, manufacturers and resilent representatives commented upon the continuing conservatism which marks purchasing.

THE advice to young ball players is to keep out of the pitcher's box and avoid the outfield, too. Study to be a catcher or an infielder. Of the infield positions, third base is the best. Catching and playing third base may lead to something in the end, something profitable when the legs are buckling, the arm is a bit weary and the old batting eye is becoming dimmed a trifle.

A list of additional contributions to the Greater New York Fund, headed by a gift of $10,000 from the Cities Service Company, was made public yesterday by Douglas P. Falconer, executive director of the fund.

A total of 579 students at Princeton University, one-quarter of the total enrollment, attained honor - roll standing for the second term of the academic year 1937-38, according to the statistics announced today by Wilbur F. Kerr, registrar of the university.

More than seven hundred attended a memorial service for Senator Royal S. Copeland this afternoon in the Roscoe P. Copeland Auditorium of Dexter High School. The auditorium was named for the Senator's father.

A committee was named today by B. Howell Griswold Jr.. chairman of the Investment Bankers Conference, Inc., to conduct an educational program directed toward acquainting investment bankers and security dealers throughout the country with the provisions and objectives of the Maloney act.

At least thirty-four persons were killed and 150 were injured today when a stunting war plane crashed into part of a crowd of 50,000 watching a review at the opening of Bogota's great new Campo de Marte, a field designed for military exercises.
About 4,500 coal miners have started strikes at Sabinas Mining Company and Mexican Mining Corporation properties at Nueva Rosita in the State of Coahuila.

An increase in industrial activity in the first three weeks of July, customarily a period of considerable decline, was reported today in the monthly statement on general business and financial conditions by the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System.

Despite a substantial recovery after Monday's culminating panic, the stock market here remained the focus of this week's business interest. Unquestionably, confidence was shaken and those investors, mostly nonJews, who sold at the lowest prices after many frightened Jews had unloaded at tolerable prices, gave voice to sharp complaints.

Mrs. J. Garfield Buell of Tulsa, Okla., will be joined at the St. Regis today by her daughter, Miss Betty Jane Buell, who is expected to arrive on the Europa. Mrs. J. A. Lowell Blake will come to the Weylin today from Malt Hill, Beverly Farms, Mass.

IN the world of the average Northern reader, it is safe to say, the-paper called The Dallas News bulks hardly larger than the leading dailies in Butte, Jefferson City or Tallahassee. The News is nevertheless one of the nation's most influential papers, and its remarkable history parallels the history of the American Southwest.
Onehalf the construction work which can be initiated directly under the new PWA program has been authorized, Administrator Ickes announced today.

Robert L. Riggs of Chicago and Frank Kovacs of Oakland, Calif., reached the final round of the Longwood Bowl tennis tournament today, and Miss Helen Bernhard of New York carried off the honors In the women's singles.
The report of the North American Company and subsidiaries for the year ended on June 30, issued for publication today, shows a net income of $16,212,549 after all expenses and charges.

Foreign Bond Associates, Inc.--Net asset value for each share of common stock on June 30, last, $6.64, compared with $5.88 on March 31. According to Robert S. Byfield, president, this value had risen to $7.08 on July 19. On June 30 capitalization was in 102,822 shares, carried on the balance sheet at $949,170.

Bronx insurgent Democrats will present a full slate of candidates against those backed by the county machine led by Secretary of State Edward J. Flynn in the primary this September, it was revealed yes- ACC terday.

The pickaback seaplane Mercury, which flew the Atlantic from Ireland last Thursday after taking off in midair from the back of its mother plane, the Maia, is well protected by patents in this country, a search of Patent Office records here discloses.

Motorcycle Policeman Barnet Cohen sped through thirty miles of congested city streets last night on a mercy errand for Angus Beaton Jr., 27 years old, the son of a policeman, who is suffering from spinal meningitis.

Challenge the frustrations created by yourself and your environment if you want to master them, the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman urged the congregation at Christ Methodist Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street, in a sermon yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. George L. Wrenn gave a luncheon today at Zee-InDuin, their place on the ocean, for Major Gen. William Mason Wright, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Wright of Washington, who are passing the week-end with Miss Ethel Wickham at Bonnie Bourne.
Johnny Wittig pitched six-hit ball against Newark to score a 2-to-O shut-out after the Bears had defeated Baltimore, 11 to 5; in the opener today. Wittig fanned five and walked three.
Commodity prices were slightly lower last week although stocks reached a new high level for 1938 and there was a feeling of optimism in almost all markets.
J. Richard (Dixie) Davis, lawyer for the late Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, was not permitted to leave the Tombs yesterday for his daily visit outside.
The 950th anniversary of the adoption of Christianity by Russia was celebrated today by 3,600 persons of Russian birth or descent at Rova Farms, the Russian agricultural settlement near here.

Tom Bostock, 37 years old, of 436 East 147th Street, the Bronx, found himself yesterday in the unenviable position of being the laziest burglary suspect in town. According to Detective Otto Franz, Bostock and Jack Mooney, 49, of 620 East 147th Street, the Bronx,
