The city will be faced with a $27,750,000 deficit in its budget for the first full fiscal year under the new charter from July, 1939, to July, 1940, unless "a solution is found," Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick informed Mayor La Guardia and other members of the Board of Estimate in a report made public yesterday.

A special mass was held on the steps in front of the Porta Coeli Church at San German commemorating the 400th anniversary of its erection. Bishop Aloysius J. Willinger, formerly of Brooklyn, officiated.

The New York, Chicago St. Louis Railroad Company (Nickel Plate) is asking the holders of its 6 per cent unsecured notes, of which $15,000,000 is outstanding, to consent to a three-year extension of the issue, which matures on Oct. 1 next, according to a letter being sent to stockholders. George D.

The week's stock market here opened with the heaviest collapse in prices witnessed in the five years of the Nazi regime, the typical high-priced issues falling almost 5 points and individual stocks declining substantially. All groups suffered; Reichsbank shares dropped to 185 and the Steel Trust went below 100 at one time.

Thirty-five thousand young athletes paraded in Red Square today in the blaze of multi-colored flags, costumes, floats and emblem-banners that make the annual "physical culture parade" one of the most picturesque ceremonies in the Soviet Union.
Some measure of the importance of foreign buying in the stock markets here is afforded by the quarterly reports of the United States Steel Corporation on how its stock is held, the report for June 30
Former United States Senator Obadiah Gardner died of a heart attack at the home of his daughter here today. He was 87 years old.

Canadian domestic exports for May amounted to $67,769,500, an increase of $16,500,000 from the previous month, but a decline of 34 1/2 per cent from May last year, the Department of Commerce reported today.

About sunset last Thursday a completely misinformed rainbow arched hopefully over this city. But before another day dawned the rain was monotonously falling again, and it kept at it continuously until yesterday afternoon brought a respite. Our continuous precipitation would have upset Noah himself.

Effective on Aug. 1, commission rates on the Baltimore Stock Exchange will be changed, generally upward. Minimum rates charged to non-members will start at 1 cent a share for stocks selling at 10 cents a share or less.

Dr. Rufus D. Smith, provost of New York University, announced yesterday that five. college graduates, including two women, will receive tuition scholarships valued at a total of $1,500 for study. in the university's Graduate Division for Training in Public Service.
Thomas H. Bevan of Baltimore, American Consul General at Warsaw, died here this morning following a kidney attack on Thursday while returning to his post from a vacation. His age was 51.
Mason Shehan Jr, of Easton won the J. Rulon Miller Jr. trophy series for Star Class yachts today for the fifth time in the history of the event sponsored by the Gibson Island Yacht Squadron.
Mr. and Mrs. Henry R. Sutphen have as their house guests on Dunemere Lane Captain and Mrs. Luis Aubry of Lima, Peru. Captain Aubry has been Naval Attache from Peru in Washington and Paris.

The church is in danger of losing inc its hold upon multitudes of people me because of the assumption of reresponsibility for relief by government, the Rev. C. Everett Wagner, pastor of the Union Methodist vid Episcopal Church, Forty-eighth Street just west of Broadway, dedared in his sermon there yesterday morning.
Mrs. Lewis Fox Frissell, Mrs. John H. Prentice, Mrs. Roger W. Cutler, Mrs. Ogden H. Hammond and Miss Julia Berwind were among those who had luncheon guests today.

The Ninety-third Infantry Brigade of the New York National Guard, comprising the 165th Regiment of Manhattan and the Fourteenth of Brooklyn, arrived at Camp Smith today by truck and train to start a two-week period of field training.
The Lambs Club of New York held its annual "wash" at the home of Percy G. Williams here today. Athletic contests, including potato, relay and swimming races, were held during the afternoon.

A tea and fashion show will be held at the Claremont Inn, 134th Street and Riverside Drive, on Sept. 17 in aid of St. Christopher's Inn, Graymoor, N. Y., one of the charitable institutions conducted by the Franciscan Friars of the Atonement at Garrison, N. Y. Mrs.

Balancing the chances of an armed clash over the Czech problem, Lieut. Gen. Horst von Metzch, well-known writer on military topics, declared in a recent article that both Britain and France are decidedly opposed to courting warlike entanglements on a large scale in view of the still obscure military situation in Spain and the Far East.

Many mistakes in construction of old school buildings are not corrected in the new structures, and as a result costly errors are duplicated, a school survey conducted by the Joint Committee on Education disclosed yesterday.

That the entente between Great Britain and France-' is complete has been demonstrated by the visit of the British sovereigns and the cordiality of the words exchanged. This understanding is considered in financial circles here to be a real guarantee of the maintenance of peace.

The local District Nursing Association will be aided by the proceeds of the fifth annual Mount Holly Horse Show on Aug. 13 on the estate of Robert B. Lamb. Mrs. Lawrence Smith, Mrs. Stephen L. Porter and Richard Carver will be the judges.

Employes of the division of placement and unemployment insurance of the State Department of-Labor, handling -insurance and social security benefit administration, have served notice on Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner, that effective today the 1,400 members of the clerical and interviewing staffs involved would no longer work overtime.

The general upward trend in French prices was interrupted in the week ended on July 16, the index dropping to 657 from 658 for the preceding week. Two weeks earlier the index was at 656. Native products fell from 689 to 683 in the week, accounting for the slip in the general average for all commodities.

With President George Bull of the Saratoga Association highly optimistic, the traditional meeting at this up-State watering place will get under way tomorrow with a seven-race program, including two stake events.

Several parties were given here tonight and yesterday as the Cottage Colony made ready for the opening of the racing season tomorrow. Mrs. Silas B. Mason of Lexington entertained with a dinner at her cottage for Mrs. Julius Walsh of New York, who is her guest.

There can be no doubt that in trade and industry there has begun a gradual but noticeable upward trend. Steel output, despite the handicap of wages, made in the present week the largest increase in more than two years, rising to 36 per cent of capacity, against 25 per cent four weeks ago.

Chancellor Adolf Hitler, accompanied by Frau Winifred Wagner and the Minister of Propaganda, Paul Joseph- Goebbels, and the Minister's wife, attended the opening jubilee festival today marking the 125th birthday anniversary of Richard Wagner.

Miss Patti Warfield Edmonston, daughter of Mrs. Edgar Davis Edmonston of this city and the late Mr. Edmonston, has completed plans for her marriage to First Lieutenant Thomas Leslie Crystal /Jr., Sixth Field Artillery, U. S. A., which will take place here at Guilford on Saturday afternoon in the Edmonston home.

Ignoring this age of speed in which airplanes roar over the Atlantic to set new travel records, J. G. Kuijt, a retired planter of the Dutch East Indies, scanned the cloudy skies today from his 38-foot sailboat anchored off the Montauk Yacht Club and decided to "take off" Wednesday on a return trip to Holland.

Establishment of the New York Hotel Trades Council, composed of six A. F. of L. local unions, to carry on jointly the drive to organize the 100,000 employes in New York's hotel industry, was announced last night by Jay Rubin, president of the council, at its headquarters. 801 Eighth Avenue.

Monroe St, 105; J. Daniel Dougherty, referee, to Emigrant Industrial Savings real estate. Bank, foreclosure ($5.50). 28th St, 403 W, Michael Toner to Michael and Theresa A. Toner, 403 W. 28th St. 44th St, 352 W, Lawyers Trust Co, trustee of William H. Walker, to 352 W 44th St Corp, 19 W 44th St.; purchase money mtg $21.000 ($25).
The Japanese are believed to have succeeded in landing approximately 2,000 men below Kiukiang, 135 miles down the Yangtze River from Hankow, the temporary capital.
Killed "in the line of duty" Wednesday, Rex II, Dalmatian mascot of Engine Company 8 at 165 East Fifty-first Street, Manhattan, received a ceremonial burial this afternoon.

The Federal anti-trust action brought last week against eight major film producers will not stop the Work of the recently formed producers' conciliation committee, Sidney R. Kent, chairman of the committee and president -of Twentieth Century-Fox, announced yesterday.

The establishment of an international committee among Japan, Manchukuo and Soviet Russia, in order to settle not only the Changkufeng incident but all border disputes of the past and present, may be proposed by Japan, Domei, Japanese official news agency, asserts.
Proud parents today watched their boys in the second formal regimental review of the 2,020 members of the C. M. T. C. here today, commanded for the first time by cadet officers. Regimental Commander
Australia's production of cotton yarn for the year ended on June 30 was 11,275,000 pounds, compared with only 5,417,000 pounds four years ago, the Department of Commerce reported today.

With the weather fair and clear, the Citizens Military Training Camp' regiment of 1,600 young men participated this morning in an impressive church parade to outdoor chapels in the pine. groves bordering Lake Champlain.

Mist Evelyn Cary Haskell will be introduced to society Sept. 16 at a dinner dance her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Edward Kirk Haskell will give at Fox Hollow, their estate in Morristown. Miss Haskell was graduated in June from Garrison Forest School, Green Spring Valley, Md.,...
The visit to Rome of the Premier and Foreign Minister of Hungary, while overshadowed by the visit of the British sovereigns to Paris, fits into the same picture of European flux and fear.

Ahead all the way, Henry Steingass, Middle Atlantic titleholder from the Penn A. C. of Philadelphia, captured the 100-yard freestyle race that featured the A. A. U. swimming meet yesterday at the Broad Channel Bathing Park in Queens.

Elections will be held at all radio stations in the Columbia Broadcasting System, except KMOX at St. Louis, to determine whether technicians and engineers desire to be represented by American Communications Association or by Associated Broadcast Technicians, the National Labor Relations Board announced today.

Peter Nistico, 26 years old, of 23 Bedell Avenue, Tottenville, S. I., was killed at about 1:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon when the automobile he was operating ran into a pole at Hylan Boulevard and Sharrott Avenue, Prince's Bay, S. I. The car, the police said, appeared to have got out of control in a flooded portion of the roadway.

Decrying the cleavages that exist among the church sects of the Gold, the Rev. Dr. Henry Smith ??, executive secretary of the American Section of the Universal Christian Council for Life and Work, sounded a call for greater ?? among denominations of the Christian Church in his sermon at be Broadway Tabernacle ?? Church, at Fifty-sixth street yesterday. et yesterday.
LONG, LONG SUMMER, by Warren Howard (Arcadia, $2.) A romantic novel. ON JEWELED WINGS, by Barbara Hedworth (Arcadia, $2). A light novel.

Amassing 1,600 points, Frank Muzzey Jr. of Philadelphia took top scoring honors of the Solomons Island Yacht Club's second annual regatta today, putting his speed boat Nittany Lion II across the finish line first in two races.

Outstanding in financial London this week have been the rise of the dollar to the highest sterling value since April of last year and the largest turnover of gold in any similar period for more than a year.

It has become known that, in his conversation with Premier Edouard Daladier and Foreign Minister Georges Bonnet of France last Wednesday, the British Foreign Secretary, Viscount Halifax, declared the British Government would be ready to lend its good offices to the Czechoslovak Government and the leaders of the Sudeten Germans and act as a mediator between them if they could not succeed in reaching an agreement.

Both dams of the Clinton-Guilford town reservoir gave way early this morning, loosing more than 120,000,000 gallons of water and washing away four concrete bridges with stone abutments, including one main bridge on Route 80 from New Haven to Deep River.

Governor Frank Murphy indicated in an address today that he favored a third term for President Roosevelt. "The nation comes first," the executive told 2,000 Northern Michigan Democrats at a rally here, "and it may be necessary for the President to accept a third term.

Cotton prices were irregular last week but showed in general an upward trend. At the close of the market on Saturday, active future deliveries on the New York Cotton Exchange were up 23 to 26 points from the close of the preceding week.

From the West Coast yesterday came a report that D. A. Doran had been named to head the play and story departments of the A. and S. Lyons agency of New York and Hollywood, which in turn would finance Mr., Doran's theatrical productions.

Two Democratic Representatives described by President Roosevelt on his recent visit to Texas as his "good friends," Maury Maverick of the Twentieth District and W. D. McFarlane of the Thirteenth District, appeared tonight to have been defeated as further returns from yesterday's primary election were tabulated.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It was apparent at the recent health conference that the government is at least toying with the idea of compulsory insurance as one method of providing adequate medical care for the needy and for the low-income groups.
Members of the younger set in the camps and cottages and at the hotels will be among competitors in ice dancing on skates, to take place next Saturday at the Olympic Arena.

It seems obvious that business is off "dead center" and there are many indications of revival in the Autumn which will be stimulated by large crops and by the government's spending program, the Guaranty Trust Company declares in the current issue of its monthly publication, The Guaranty Survey; issued yesterday.
Figures showing a steady rise of foreign currencies in relation to the sol are contained in the monthly bulletin of the Central Reserve Bank for June.

Final preparations and plans for his fourth expedition to the South Polar regions are described here by the distinguished explorer whose epochal flight across Antarctica two years ago made polar history.

The Pirates strengthened their grip on first place in the National League today with a double triumph over the Bees, 5 to 4, in the first game, which went fifteen innings, and 4 to 2 in the nightcap, abbreviated to six by Pennsylvania's Sunday curfew law.

In these. days of class antagonisms and international hatreds, Christians would do well to practice the principles of Christ-in their own lives and avoid following "namecallers," the Rev. Robert H. Dolliver said yesterday in his sermon at the John Street Methodist Church, 44 John Street.
The Federal Maritime Commission, which will come here on Tuesday for a three-day hearing, will be asked to eliminate restrictions that hinder commerce between Great Lake ports and Europe.

The Green Room Players gave their second production of the season last night, when "Petticoat Fever," by Mark Reed, was presented at the Onteora Club here. William B. Kip played the leading role, supported by Mr. and Mrs. Peter C. Wright-Clark, W. Macy Chamberlin, Miss Fugi Yanase, Clvde Brown and Brent Woolcott.

Charles Bolte, treasurer of the New York Furniture Exchange, 206 Lexington Avenue, since its organization, died here today at his home, 17 Irving Place, after an illness of five months. Born in Bremen, Germany, 60 years ago, he had lived in the United States since childhood.

Kenneth D. Hull, Earle Wilkie Grant. in 444 E. 57th St.; Allan Kadell, In 4 E. 70th St.; Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens. Inc., broker. William W. Law, Mrs. Jay Holmes, Charles C. Wright, Carolyn Kelsey, Mrs. Albert Buchanan, in Hamrshire House, 150 Central Park South; Douglas L. Elliman Co., brokers.

With the wheat and other small-grain crops in the northern hemisphere virtually safe from damage except in the extreme Northern areas, traders have started to take stock of the supply and probable demand in the 1938-39 season.

Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, served notice on the nation's banks today that when they have turned down a potential borrower, and the borrower's loan application has been favorably considered by the RFC, agents of the Federal banking corporation hereafter will approach the local bank to obtain its participation in the loan.

Matthew Woll, vice president of the American.Federation of Labor, and Louis K. Comstock, president of the Merchants Association of New York City, will address the Republican National Program Committee in Chicago on Aug. 2.

Conditions confronting the lumber industry on the West Coast occupied attention from two' quarters today. William Green president of the American Federation of Labor, issued a statement calling attention to curtailment of lumber purchases by Japan and suggesting the negotiation of a reciprocal trade agreement to remedy the situation.

The American Federation of Labor accused the National Labor Relations Board, in an editorial in its monthly magazine, The Federationist, of giving aid to insurgency within the labor movement and of favoring the Committee for Industrial Organization as against the federation.

Rodrigo Samayoa, Minister'of Finance, announced today that E1 Salvador would not participate in the World's Fair at New York but would have an exhibit at the San Francisco fair, because the latter city buys 80 per cent of El Salvador's coffee.

Plans for remodeling several houses in Manhattan were announced over the week-end in connection with sales of the properties. Three five-story walk-ups at 1,789 to 1,793 First Avenue will be altered as a result of their. sale by the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank to an investing client of Stang Boxer, attorneys.

Richard Seaman of Great Britain won the German auto Grand Prix today over the Nuremberg course before 350,000 spectators. Driving a Mercedes-Benz, Seaman covered the 311 miles of the intricate course in the Eifel Mountains in 3 hours 51 minutes 46.1 seconds, averaging 80.4 miles an hour.

The Temporary National Economic Committee created by the last Congress will soon begin its studies of monopolies. It differs both in its organization and in its avowed objective from similar legislative investigating bodies of the past.

Healing of the breach in American labor was predicted by Frank Morrison, secretary of the American Federation of Labor, in an address today before the quarterly meeting of the Union Printers' League of New Jersey, at the Jewish Community Center.
The week's heavy industry report here was satisfactory, but traffic congestion impeded the movement of coal and iron and goods needed by agriculture.

Harbor police grappled until 9:30 o'clock last night without finding the body of Paul Eric Grandi, 27year-old electrician's mate second class, who was drowned after falling from the boom of the U. S. S. Fairfax, one of six destroyers anchored in the Hudson River near Fifty-ninth Street.
The index of German wholesale prices on July 13 stood at 105.5, unchanged from the week before.

Lawyers arriving here for sessions of the American Bar Association and affiliated organizations, opening tomorrow, were served today with a "bill of particulars" entitled "What the public thinks of you."

Officials planned to stage the first two singles rounds tomorrow in the Seabright invitation tournament as many of the nation's ranking stars, including the 1937 winners, Bobby Riggs of Chicago and Miss Alice Marble of San Francisco, headed here for the Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club's fifty-first annual event.

Robert Koller has been appointed Eastern division manager of Seagram-Distillers Corporation, with headquarters at Rockefeller Center, it was announced for publication today by Howard H. Hoyt, general sales manager.

The lard market was little affected by the relative strength in cottonseed oil last week. A strike which involved some of the smaller packers resulted in a sharp recession in prices of hogs, which, with the weakness in corn, had a depressing effect on lard.

It stopped raining long enough for the third annual Leewood invitation golf tournament to be completed today after yesterday's deluge had forced a postponement. Because of lack of time match play was canceled and the competition was decided on a thirty-six-hole medal play basis.

Outstanding in Peruvian foreign trade for the first four months of 1938 was a decline of 11,353,233 soles in the value of exports compared with the corresponding period of 1937. Imports jumped 20,176,160 soles.

Edwin Ginn, chairman of the race committee of the Beverly Yacht Club of Marion, Mass., on Buzzards Bay, sent word yesterday to members of the Thirty Square Meter Association that the club's ,International Challenge Cup and Roosevelt Bowl events were being scheduled again after being called off because of the withdrawal of the European challenges.
Charles D. Coburn, who with his late wife founded the Mohawk drama festival here in 1935, disclosed today that he plans a permanent repertory company and dramatic school in New York.

The first Strauss premiere in Munich occurred tonight with the performance of Richard Strauss's "Der Friedenstag." It has been the composer's custom to stage premieres of his works in Dresden. Explaining the change, he said "Der Friedenstag" is not entirely a repertoire opera, as were his other works, but more especially a festival opera.

Mr. and Mrs. Albert Addison Lewis of this place and Roslyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ruth Mary Lewis, to James Christian Hill 3d, son of Dr. and Mrs. Emory Hill of Richmond. Va.
A specially elected committee of the Jewish population in Palestine for organizing means of defense against continued Arab terrorism met today in the offices of the Tel Aviv municipality.
Shakespeare's "Julius Caesar" was televised tonight in a version Bri showing the men in modern civilian garb and in uniforms. One was in sport coat and white flannels.

With a British air mission due for conferences in Canada to discuss a large program of bomber construction and pilot training in the Dominion, the question of military air development in the vast realm of our neighbor to the north gains new relevancy.

The Yankees came out from their flood shelter at the Stadium yesterday to play a double-header with the White Sox, but the sun came out too for a while and the experience proved too much for the champions.

Clearing skies at sunset tonight presaged an end to menacing flood conditions in Massachusetts and Rhode Island, hardest hit of the six New England States, after a seventh consecutive day of heavy rain which brought the week's total at the United States Weather Bureau in Boston to more than seven inches and carried the month's total fall to -nearly nine inches.

Loft, Inc., announced yesterday that it had written a letter to Jesse Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, replying to the recent demand upon the RFC by the Committee for Industrial Organization that it withhold the granting of financial assistance to the company because of its alleged unfair labor practices in fostering a company union.

Two prizes of $100 each will be awarded to L. R. Pedemont of St. Mary's College, California, and Harlan A. Howard of Massachusetts State College, Amherst, Mass., the New York Cocoa Exchange announced yesterday.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $3,689,865,650. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and noninterest-bearing discount bills.

Magistrate Matthew J. Troy disclosed last night that he had issued a warrant earlier in the day for the arrest of William F. McGuinness, an assistant district attorney of Kings County, and George Murphy, an elevator operator in the Brooklyn Central Courts Building, on charges of conspiracy.
Willem van Hoogstraten made his first appearance of the season as conductor of the PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra at last night's concert in the Lewisohn Stadium. An audience of 6,000 attended.
Wallace H. Smith, often described as the most wounded man in the World War, died of a heart attack today as he drove his automobile homeward from an American Legion meeting.
Continued decline in employment and payrolls of New York's retail stores was reported today for the mid-May to mid-June period, with a 1 per cent reduction in forces and 0.5 per cent less wages paid.

The Mexican Congress has scheduled a discussion early this week of the cases of General Ramon F. Iturbe and Colonel Bolivar Sierra, who were expelled late last night from the official Party of the Mexican Revolution in a labor-directed party purge.

Mrs. Horace M. Van Slyke of this city and Ocean Grove, N. J., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Isabel M. Van Slyke, to Lieutenant Frederick J. Clarke, U. S. A., son of Edward J. Clarke of Little Falls, N. Y., and the late Mrs. Clarke.

The cotton market here last week was less active than in several preceding weeks. Slower securities markets in the early part of the week and a growing belief that the crop about to be harvested would be larger than expected earlier caused liquidation, and there was also some hedge selling resulting from the movement of new cotton in the far south of Texas.
Members of the Civilian Conservation Corps have just completed training in fighting forest fires in all camps in or adjacent to timbered areas, Robert Fechner, director of the corps, announced today.

Last week organized medicine, labor, hospital executives, industry, farm federations, women's organizations, public health officials, social workers, New Deal administrators discussed in Washington the extension of medical care to millions of families now unable to pay for it.
Giovanni Manera, Italian speedster, captured the opening race in the series for the national professional motor-paced bike championship last night at the Coney Island
The Economist's index of British commodity

Barnard L. Crozier, chief engineer of Baltimore, died last night at the age of 48. He was stricken last week at his Summer home near Round Bay with what at first was described as an intestinal ailment. He was removed to the University Hospital.
The Phillies won the second game, 5 to 1, from the Reds today after dropping the opener of a double bill, 7 to 5.

We are all willing to become good Christians but our willingness is not b great enough to overcome the desire of living but for today, the Rev. Philip Cowell Jones said yesterday d morning at the Madison Avenue n Presbyterian Church, at Seventythird Street.

Miss Marjorie Ruth Grossman, laughter of Dr. and Mrs. William Grossman of 111 East Eighty-first Street, was married to Eugene H. Gordon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin L. Gordon of Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon in the Central Synagogue, Fifty-fifth Street and Lexington Avenue, by the Rev. Dr. Jonah B. Wise.
Henry Morgenthau Jr., Secretary of the Treasury, was received by President Albert Lebrun today and will dine with Raymond Patenotre, Minister of National Economy, tonight.

The First Baptist Church of Ocean Park was filled to capacity today as the Rev. S. Fraser Lang- On June 15 ford, uncle of Douglas Corrigan, a $500 rise in preached a sermon on his flying nephew, who spanned the Atlantic in an antiquated plane.

Washington and St. Louis divided a double-header today, the Browns winning the opener, 4 to 2, and the Senators the second game, 11 to 1. St. Louis landed on Chase and DeShong for fourteen hits in the first game.
Albert F. Hochwalt, a writer of books on bird dogs died at a hospital here today at the age of 68.

Through this capital's streets, lined with 250,000 mourning Rumanians, Queen Marie's body was carried to its last resting place today. During the night the coffin was moved from Cotrecini Palace on the outskirts of the city, to the Palace in Calea Victoriei. The Queen's children kept watch by the bier during part of the night.

The stock markets here, still almost bound hand and foot to Wall Street, continue faithfully to reflect the varying moods of the markets in the United States. Business generally has been quiet, because of the growing influence of the holiday season, and markets show a lack of initiative.

The North German Lloyd liner Europa is due to arrive today from the Channel ports. Among her passengers are George McAneny, Sir Frederick Peek, Mr. and Mrs. Charles Edwards, Mr. and Mrs. W. R. Davis, Helen Wills Moody, the Rev. J. V. Haynes,

An adjourned game from the eleventh and final round between George Shainswit of the Bronx and Burton O. Dahlstrom of Chicago brought to a close today the annual open tournament for the championship of the American Chess Federation at the Hotel Touraine.
Emergency rationing of water was decreed tonight in Ambler, a suburb, as flood waters kept the borough's water pumps submerged and produced a critical situation.
Fashions for men may be profoundly affected by the activities of authorities at Great Neck and Long Beach.

Rear Admiral Emory S. Land, chairman of the United States Maritime Commission. has accepted chairmanship of the Twelfth International Lifeboat Race to be held in the Narrows on' Sept. 10, it was announced yesterday by the International Lifeboat Racing Association, Inc.

Major and Mrs. Gist Blair of Washington entertained at the opening of the Pot and Kettle Club today, giving a tea for a large representation of the Summer colony in honor of Dr. and Mrs. Montgomery Blair Jr. and Mrs. Nathan C. Wyeth of Washington.

From the heights of Caudiel, about three miles northeast of Viver on the Teruel-Sagunto Road, where the Nationalists [Insurgents] today captured positions, I could plainly see Segorbe in the distance.

Fog, rain and calms marred the regatta of the Seaside Park Yacht Club today. The Stars sailed a windward and leeward course. Most of the time the way was obscured by a heavy fog rolling in off the ocean.
After a tense ninth inning, the Dodgers scored a 3-2 triumph today behind Vito Tamulis to break even in a double-header and in the series with the Cardinals.

An exchange of greetings between sister universities of royal foundation took place yesterday when Professor S. H. Prince of King's College, Halifax, N. S., spoke in the chapel of Columbia University, which was formerly King's College, New York.

Investigation today into the crash of a navy bombing plane at Woodbridge, which yesterday caused the death of the crew of three, disclosed that apparently Lieutenant James McDonough, the pilot, realizing that the plane had descended too low, had tried to rise suddenly.

As straws show which way the wind blows, so Chancellor Hitler's overtures this week are regarded here as another attempt to cultivate better relations with Great Britain. For what this gesture may be worth it is welcome and it did not go altogether unnoticed by the markets, but where Germany is concerned distrust dies hard and the City has not been much impressed by this seemingly obvious counter-blast to the King's visit to France.

Dom Soccoli, 37-year-old New Britain, Conn., gas station owner, today defeated Max Marston of Philadelphia, 1 up, in a 36-hole, rain-soaked final to win the nineteenth annual Shenecossett men's invitation golf tournament.

The British team which will compete with the American and Cuban teams in the international tuna matches to be held at Liverpool, Nova Scotia, late next month, has been named and will include three of the anglers who fished on the British team last year.

Anatol, Friedland, song writer and composer, who scored a series of hits about fifteen years ago, died here this afternoon in his apartment in the Ritz-Carlton Hotel, where he had been living for the last two years. He had not been active professionally during this period and his health had been poor, partly as the result of the amputation of a leg.

Civilian aid will be enlisted on a large scale to provide the greatest test yet made of radio networks as a defense against air attacks in exercises that will be conducted by the army at Fort Bragg, N. C., Oct. 3-17.

The French team took the last two matches of its series with Germany today but the Germans clinched victory yesterday and will meet Yugoslavia in the finals of the European Zone Davis Cup competition.
Mrs. Katherine Rawls Thompson of Florida swam to a world record-breaking victory in the 880yard free style event today as the women's national A. A. U. outdoor championships came to a close.

The cloud curtain that fell last night over the drama on the Eigerwand--"the wall of the ogre"-never lifted today. Behind that curtain the ogre stormned all day with cold white fury against the four young men who had dared to put under their heels all but the last few hundred feet of its unsealed 6,300 foot almost-sheer wall.

Miss Marjorie Murphy of Boston will be the attendant of Miss Mary Stack, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Stack of Brooklyn, at her marriage to Charles Henry Phelan on Saturday morning in the Church of the Good Shepherd in Brooklyn.

The City Club of New York made public yesterday an open letter to the delegates to the Constitutional Convention demanding rejection of the reapportionment program recently reported out to the full convention.
A broad program for rehabilitation of unattached, jobless and penniless women, especially those over 40 years of age, was submitted to Secretary of Labor Perkins today by Miss Mary Anderson,

Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 37 per cent of capacity, a rise of 5 points from the rate of the preceding week and the highest rate since that in the second week of last November.
The St. George Dragon Club of Brooklyn and the Shelton Dolphin Club of New York today held the men's and women's championships respectively in the State A. A. U. outdoor swimming meet.

George Bernard Shaw, who is recovering at his country home from his recent illness, plans to pass tomorrow quietly, ignoring his eightysecond birthday. "The worst of being 82," the author said last night, "is that people will come and congratulate one. I see no cause for congratulation on being 82."
The United- States replaced Great Britain as the chief supplier of Argentina's imports in the first half of this year, according to official statistics made public yesterday.

Edward Marshall, 41 years old, a vacuum cleaner salesman, of 88-27 162d Street, Jamaica, Queens, was held in $500 ball yesterday in Felony Court, Ridgewood, Queens, by Magistrate Jacob R. Hockert for further hearing Aug. 3 on a charge of grand larceny.

Don Francisco, executive vice president of Lord Thomas, national advertising agency, has been elected president to succeed Albert D. Lasker, principal owner, who has retired after serving the firm for forty years.

The Tigers ended a seven-game losing streak today by taking a double-header from the Athletics, 7 to 6 and 7 to 3. A six-run rally in the fifth inning, of which Hank Greenberg's twentyninth homer, with the bases full, was the climax, won the first game.
Messner will publish in October George Seldes's "Lords of the Press," a study of American newspapers and news services. Mr. Seldes is the author of "Sawdust Caesar" and "You Can't Print That."

Perhaps by coincidence, Field Marshal Hermann Goering arrived in Denmark aboard the yacht Carin II with an escort of two warships today, almost at the very moment that the Conference of the Oslo Powers was holding its final meeting. His visit was characterized as completely unofficial.

The one great duty of a minister of God is to preach Christ, "not to spend his time attacking the abuses of the social order," it was declared yesterday by the Rev. John H. McComb, the pastor, in. his morning sermon in -the Broadway Presbyterian Church, at 114th Street.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are July 25 unless specified: At Drake Bay: Arizona, Idaho, Maryland, Oklahoma, Pennsylvania, Tennessee, West Virginia. Santiago to Boston: Babbitt, Dickerson, Roper, Tillman, Tattnall.

The illness which forced Governor A. B. Chandler to abandon temporarily his speaking campaign for the democratic nomination to the Senate was caused by poison traced to water he drank in his hotel room Thursday night, according to a statement made today by Dr. J. W. Bryan.

Japanese newspapers this morning report that the government is working out a four-year industrial expansion plan which probably will be adopted in September. The plan .will embrace Japan, Manchukuo and China, and will cost the Tokyo government 10,000,000,000 yen.
Contrary to earlier forecasts, the Czechoslovak Government today accepted the British proposal of mediation between itself and the Sudeten Germans. The proposal was accepted
Total revenues of manufactured and natural gas companies in May was $62,282,900, compared with $64,574,600 in May, 1937, a decrease of 3.5 per cent, according to the American Gas Association.

Action on rezoning of the entire Jamaica Bay area to prevent any further industrial uses there will be sought before the City Planning Commission within the next two weeks, Park Commissioner Robert Moses said yesterday.

Chance Ray, under a powerful ride by Al Robertson, conquered Cardinalis by a head in the Cary Handicap at Arlington Park today. Chance Ray, racing for Clarence E. Davidson, and Cardinalis, from the stable of Paul L. Kelley, battled from the head of the stretch to the wire.

A new policy, which aims to make naval architecture conform with the customs of the country and at the same time "reduce the cost of architectural embellishment to a minimum consistent with dignified appearance, durability and utility," has been approved by. the Naval Bureau of Yards and Docks.

Warner Wilcox of Raritan Bay led four crews of junior yachtsmen in two races today, establishing a commanding lead in the eliminations for the Sears Bowl championships. His fellow New Jersey sailor, Douglas McNitt, was second in both contests, the local boats trailing. Two more races are to be sailed.

Determined to fight "racketeers" in the dancing school business and to elevate the teaching of dancing to the rank of a profession, 400 dancing teachers from all parts of the country, including several former show girls, opened their third annual convention at the Park Central Hotel yesterday.

A technicality that might have assessed an extra fare from subway passengers on the upper White Plains Road line of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company was adjusted yesterday in Federal Court when counsel for the city brought it to the attention of Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson.

Earnings of the National Dairy productss Corporation for the first ix months of this year amounted o $4,845,134 after provision for inerest, depreciation and Federal income taxes, according to the semimnnual report issued for publication today.

Surfman Lloyd Young, on lookout duty at the Rockaway Point D'Auria, Coast Guard station at about 4 Public S o'clock yesterday afternoon, stared trial to unbelievingly at a parachute with teach wa a figure dangling beneath it almost as far out as he could see.

The State. Public Service Commission overruled today the contentions of four railroads operating in Wisconsin in a test case challenging its right to assess them with the costs of rate investigations.

Mrs. Cornelia Townley Johnson, who would have celebrated her 101st birthday here today, died late Saturday at her home here. She was the mother-in-law of Richard Earl, president of the Hillside Trust Company and former Mayor of Hillside. Mrs. Johnson,

Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt, with his bride of a few months sitting in the historic stands beside him, watched his colt Airflame set a new track record of 1:23 1-5 in the American Legion Handicap before 10,000 persons at the opening of the Saratoga Association meeting today.

Charles Q. Sherman has organized the Charles Q. Sherman Company, with an office at 11 West Forty-second Street, to merchandise a new-type case for frosted foods. An advertising and promotion campaign is planned.

The appeal of Mrs. Angela D'Auria, a former New York City Public School teacher, for a court trial to determine her fitness to teach was denied yesterday in a de- Mayor, Mr. Moses s creational value ofcision handed down by Supreme Court Justice Edward J. McGoldrick.

There is sunshine again in Hungary after some days of intermittent rain, and out in the broad Hungarian plain, peasants are toiling to garner the harvest while the weather holds. It is a good harvest this year.

The report of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., and subsidiaries for the second quarter of this year, issued yesterday, shows a consolidated net income after operating expenses, taxes and charges, of $7,664,532.

The French liner Ile de France is due this afternoon from Havre via Southampton. Her passengers include Baron Silvercruys, Belgian Minister to Canada, and his sister, Mme. Suzanne Silvercruys; S. E. A. de Lens, French Minister to Haiti; Morris Gest, theatrical producer; Feodor Chaliapin. son of the late Russian opera singer; E. Harold

Final preparations are being made here this week for the formal opening next Monday of the wholesale and manufacturers' Fall market trade shows. Approximately 15,000 merchants and buyers are expected during the two weeks. Based on past records,...

Adopting a special series of mass formations, the 1,600 students of the C. M. T. C. regiment, commanded by Lieutenant Colonel Lucien S. Breckinridge and officers of the 308th Infantry Reserve, staged a retreat parade this evening which won the acclaim of regular army ofifcers of the post.

The proposed harbor tunnel between the Battery and Hamilton Avenue, Brooklyn, to cost $70,000,000, would be "a very vital and important link in the city's highway system," William J. Gottlieb, president of the Automobile Club of New
Mrs. Willis D. Wood of the Cold Spring Harbor Beach Club had a lead of threequarters of a point after two races today for the women's sailing championship of Long Island Sound.

Shareholders of the Michigan Oil and Gas Corporation approved at a special meeting yesterday a proposal of the directors to increase the authorized preferred stock to 100,000 shares from 10,000 shares, and to change the par value to $10 from $1,000. It was voted also

Miss Evelyn Keyes, "Miss American Legion," arrived here yesterday to invite Governor Lehman and Mayor La Guardia to the national convention of the American Legion in Los Angeles, Calif., in September.
A Gainer, New Haven Negro, punched Dominick Ceccarelli, lightheavyweight champion of Italy, to the canvas tonight in the fourth round of a scheduled ten-round bout.

MANHATTAN CELLA DAVIDE (Nov. 12. 1937). Gross assets, $107,163; net, $94,743. To Virginia C. Harriman and Emma Ardito, daughters; David and Atillio Cella, sons, one-fourth residue each. Chief assets, real estate, $75,104. Wessels Ryerson, attorney, 132 Nassau St. COHEN, SOLOMON (Feb. 1, 1914). Gross assets, $19,500; net, $19,500. Strauss Abrahams attorneys 18 E. 41st St.

Miss Lillian J. Weygandt, for the last seventeen years director of the James Children's Center of the Children's Aid Society at 154 Hester Street, died suddenly early yesterday afternoon of a heart attack in her apartment at that address. She was 44 years old.

The Maritime Association of the Port of New York issued an appeal yesterday to steamship and towboat operators to curb whistling on their craft while in the harbors and rivers of the metropolitan area. The appeal followed adoption of a resolution, a copy of which was sent to City Hall for the perusal of Mayor La Guardia and Deputy

J. P. Morgan, although still the largest individual taxpayer in this city, will pay taxes this year on $366,340 less in assessed valuations, according to the assessment rolls f opened to the public today at City Hall. Mr. Morgan's holdings on f East Island, including his mansion, a other buildings, stone bridge, under-water lands and small parcels

The Roney Press, Inc., leased for the printing of magazines and other periodicals the- one-story business building at 259 Purchase Street, at Blind Brook Place, Rye, N. Y. The property was leased for three years from the Mutual Trust Company of Port Chester through Prince Ripley, Inc., brokers.

Modernization of the seventyeight-year-old Mercer Street police t station will start next week, it was I announced yesterday at police headquarters. While WPA workmen overhaul the building the precinct will operate from 301 Mott Street, the rear of the Chief Magistrate's Court building, before 1909 t New York City Police Head- c quarters.

General Luis Altamirano, who once headed a provisional Chilean government, died today. General Altamirano was a former Premier, War Minister and Minister of Interior. He headed a junta government in 1924 when the resignation of President Arturo Alessandri was rejected and Alessandri took a leave of absence.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: May I amplify the letter of Aller Taylor, printed in THE TIMES of July 22, to obviate possible erroneous inferences? Under the Kellogg-Briand pact the signatories relinquished their sovereign right to make war. Thenceforth war became an "illegal thing." A nation which employs it as an instrument of national policy, or which refuses tc settle disputes amicably, is an aggressor.

A large public garage, costing $315,000, and two six-story apartment houses were added yesterday to the planned improvements on Holmes Airport and adjacent land, in Jackson Heights, Queens, by the filing of specifications with the Department of Housing and Buildings on behalf of the Airport Land Corporation, N. K. Winston, president.

Miss Ruth Margaret Wilde, daughter of Mrs. William E. Wilde of this place, has chosen Aug. 9 for her marriage to Luke M. McKenny Jr. of East Orange, son of Mrs. McKenny of Trenton. The ceremony will be performed in the chapel of Munn Avenue Presbyterian Church, East Orange, by the pastor, the Rev. Dr. Robert Brewster Beattie.

After their most disastrous Western trip in a number of years, a band of forlorn Giants returned from Chicago last night hoping the home stand would prove more fruitful. When the New Yorkers left on July 13 they were a half game ahead of the Pirates. Today they trail the Corsairs by four lengths.

Barefoot boys with wet heads and wet bathing suits scampered about in West Sixty-seventh Street yesterday in high glee at the prospect of long, cool showers for the rest of the Summer as the Police Athletic League opened St. Matthew's playground for the use of the neighborhood.

With further strength in prices abroad, copper producers advanced yesterday the domestic price of the metal from 9.875 cents a pound to 10 cents. This followed an increase last week from 9.75 to 9.875 cents. At the close of the day the market was firm at the new level, the highest for the current movement. Since July 1 the price has been advanced 1 cent a pound.

A new crop of reports from London, Geneva and Washington has raised doubts as to the early signing of an Anglo-American trade treaty. It is certainly premature to assume from the delay that no agreement will be reached. but the fact that more than

Encouraged by optimism expressed at the recent Summer market show here, the furniture industry has decided to repeat National Furniture Week, Sept. 17-24, for the fourth successive year. Sponsors of the event

Why did they do it-these four young or men who fought their way inch by inch up the Eigerwand in the face of a blinding snowstorm and of cold that pierced them to the marrow, while a world wondered at their hardihood and hoped against hope that they would not only be swept from their perch?

The twentieth anniversary of the consecration of the Right Rev. Thomas J. Walsh, Archbishop of Newark, N. J., was observed today at the Glen Springs Retreat, where the Archbishop is spending three weeks. In the afternoon more than a hundred persons attended a musical given by Sisters Anna, Victoria and Annunciata of the Fillippini Order, Morristown, N. J.

Carleton Smith, radio commentator for the Stadium concerts and music editor of several periodicals, has leased a suite in the recently completed apartment building at 25 East Eighty-third Street, according to Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., agents, who also rented a sixroom unit in 25 East Eighty-sixth Street to Louis Etra, and suites in 350 East Fifty-second Streetto William Rose and in 136 East Thirtysixth Street to John H. Sheehan.

The Bureau of Mines reported today that stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the close of the week ended on July 16 totaled 289,312,000 barrels, a net decrease of 1,157,000 compared with the previous week. Stocks of domestic oil decreased 1,145,000 barrels for the week and foreign crude decreased 12.000.

In a signal recognition of his long and distinguished service for a little country that no longer exists, Baron Georg Franckenstein, last Austrian Minister to London, was knighted by King George VI in an audience today only two days after the Baron became a British subject.
Governor Earle opened a special session of the Legislature here night with a declaration to both houses in the General Assembly that they were called to "repel an unprecedented judicial invasion."

Twenty physically handicapped youngsters from St. Giles Home for Crippled Children in Garden City, L. I., were disappointed yesterday when Mayor La Guardia said he was too busy at the Summer City Hall to see them.

Recent charges by the American Federation of Labor that the National Labor Relations Board aided insurgency within the labor movement and favored the Committee for Industrial Organization as against the federation were answered yesterday by John Brophy,

Henry Forbes, executive secretary of the Communist party of New York County, renewed his invitation yesterday for discussions and mutual cooperation between Communists and Catholics. A similar appeal, made recently, was characterized by the Rev. Robert E. Woods in St. Patrick's Cathedral Sunday as an indication that the Communists "have seen the handwriting on the wall and are attempting to make friends of their enemies."
Eight additional deaths today brought to forty-two the number of victims of a stunting military plane that crashed yesterday into a crowd of 50,000 watching a military review.

Republicans of the Sixteenth Congressional District, Manhattan, now represented by John J. O'Connor, Democrat and chairman of the House Rules Committee, split yesterday at a meeting in the National Republican Club, 54 West Fortieth Street, on the question of giving Mr. O'Connor a Republican endorsement this Fall.

The Lord's Day Alliance, representing more than twenty religious bodies, will attempt to prevent "operations inimical to the Christian Sabbath" at the New York World's Fair and the San Francisco Fair, the Alliance announced yesterday.

Robert C. Wagner, for a half-century district superintendent of the Pullman Company, died yesterday at the age of 86. He was a nephew of Robert C. Wagner, inventor of the Wagner palace sleeping car, and was a close friend of Robert T. Lincoln, son of President Lincoln, and president of the Pullman Company.

The second-ranking Bobby Riggs ot Chicago advanced a step nearer his United States Davis Cup team goal today by capturing the forty-sixth Longwood Bowl tennis tournament with a one-sided 6-4, 6-0, 6-4 victory over Frank Kovacs, 18-year-old Oakland, Calif., youth.

A pair of spin bowlers subdued England's batsmen today and paved the way for Australia's five-wicket victory in the fourth cricket test match. The decision was the first of the 1938 series between the two countries.

Stocks eased and closed irregularly higher after advancing to new high levels; turnover, 2,106,500 shares. Corporation bonds higher, United States Government and foreign issues firm and mixed; transactions, $9,439,600.

Mrs. Julius F. Workum will give a luncheon today at Bayberry Hill, her home in Mount Kisco, N. Y., for a committee of the board of managers of the Women's-Auxiliary of Union Settlement, this city, at which plans will be made for the settlement's annual Autumn theatre benefit. Mrs. Howard F. Shattuck is chairman of the committee.

Dry goods wholesalers have begun to sell fairly good amounts of Fall merchandise, notably in percales, sheets, pillowcases and other staples, it was reported yesterday. Until last week, rural retailers had been concentrating their buying on goods for immediate selling.

In his address opening the special session of the Legislature tonight Governor Earle said: To the Honorable the General Assembly of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania. Ladies and Gentlemen of the General Assembly:

The marriage of Miss Ruth Gibbons of this city, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Oliphant Gibbons of Buffalo, to Dr. Boris Petroff of this city and Montclair, N. J., took place yesterday noon in the West End Presbyterian Church. The ceremony was performed by the associate pastor, the Rev. Dr. Paul C. Warren.

Henry Morgenthau Jr., Secretary of the United States Treasury, closed a day of conferences with leading French financial experts by attending a dinner given in his honor tonight by Ambassador William C. Bullitt.

At no time today did wheat futures on domestic exchanges sell as high as Saturday's finish. Selling developed at the opening and continued until the close, with all deliveries at new low levels for the season and since 1933.

Charles F. Moore, head of the technical department at the Newark Central High School for the last twenty-six years, died of a heart ailment yesterday at Orange Memorial Hospital after an illness of several weeks. He was in his sixty-third year.

Frank Channing, Kane County banker, Republican leader and former State official, died last night at the age of 72. He had lived in Hampshire, near Elgin, for sixty-six years and was village president for thirty years, 'president of the First National Bank, and a retired employee of the Milwaukee Railroad.

Twenty-one social workers from nine States are enrolled at the two weeks' seminar on "The Application of Psychoanalytic Concepts to Social Case Work," which is being conducted at Smith College by the Smith College School for Social Work. The seminar is under

Four sons of Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company employes were announced today as winners of War Memorial Scholarships given by the company for twenty years to honor more than 5,000 of its employes who entered military service during the World War.

The trial of five suspended officers of the United Automobile Workers of America began in lively fashion today in the union's headquarters here with the presence of about fifty uninvited unionists. There were fist fights,

The first test case involving the validity of the State unemployment insurance tax levy was decided in fax or of the State yesterday by Acting Chief Magistrate Alexander Brough in Homicide Court when he found an employer guilty of evading payments of the tax.

Freddie (Red) Cochrane, 142, of Elizabeth decisively outpointed Jackie (Kid) Berg, 146, of England tonight in a furiously fought tenround bout. The 23-year-old Cochrane handed the former world junior welterweight champion a two-fisted trouncing in almost every heat before the second largest crowd of the local outdoor season.

About $1,000,000 worth of Japanese arms and munitions went up in smoke during a series of explosions at an arsenal at Mukden, Manchukuo, on Saturday morning, it was stated in apparently well-founded reports reaching here today through a strict press censorship.

Trading in steer beef was slow, fresh pork good and other classes only fair to slow in local markets yesterday. Early trading in kosher meats indicated the beet market to be strong with last Friday's advance of about $1; veal steady, lamb higher. Conditions as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture follow:

Two persons were slain and more than thirty wounded in an attempt to assassinate Governor Blanton Winship today in the city of Ponce, which in 1898 welcomed General Nelson A. Miles and his American soldiers and the retirement of Spanish troops without the firing of a shot after 400 years' rule.

The Federal Government's administrative organizations, popularly known as the "alphabetical" boards, were assailed and defended before the American Bar Association at its annual meeting which opened here today.

Thirty-four miners sentenced to prison for bombings in the Central Illinois coal mine war of 1932-36 appealed their conviction today to the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals. The appeal charges that John L. Lewis, as head of the United Mine Workers of America, and the Peabody Coal

August fur sales have gotten off to a good start, with results so far exceeding expectations, trade reports here yesterday indicated. Consumer demand has been stimulated by a retail price level averaging 25 per cent under a year ago, and while this decline is a stiff handicap for retailers in meeting their 1937 figures, it may be offset

The 100-foot mackerel seiner Uncle Sam ran into jagged rocks as she was entering the harbor today and tonight was reported a total loss by the Coast Guard patrol boat Harriet Lane, which went to her assistance.
Two persons were burned to death and seven others were injured when two sedans crashed head-on in a heavy fog on State Highway 29 here at 6 A. M. today.

Syracuse captured both ends of its double-header with Jersey City tonight, 2-0 and 3-2, the second game going ten innings before a crowd of 14,441. The Chiefs got only one hit from Glen Gabler and Bob Carpenter in the opener, but romped off with the decision when Babe Herman dropped a fly ball in right field in the third, two unearned runs resulting. Ted Kleinhans went

Eigerwand--"the wall of the ogr"--has been no conquered. Two Austrians, Harrer and Fritz ist Kasparek, and two Germans, Voerg and Heckmaier, finished scaling the 6,300-foot precipitous rock wall during yesterday's blinding snowstorm that hid them from view and caused Swiss guides to give them up for lost. They reached Eiger glacier station at nightfall.

The sixth of seven youths named in a first-degree murder indictment in the shooting of Detective Michael J. Foley in a restaurant hold-up pleaded not guilty yesterday before General Sessions Judge 'Donnellan, and was remanded to the Tombs for trial. He is Benjamin
Net asset value of Fundamental Investors, Inc., on June 30 was $9,405,624, equal to $16.46 each on 571,526 capital shares, compared with $6,790,670, or $12.20 each on 554,203 shares, on March 31.

Mrs. Julia W. Lacey, who led Morris County women in suffrage affairs twenty years ago, died here yesterday at the home of her son, R Merritt Lacey. Mrs. Lacey, who was 80 years old, resided until recently in Morristown. She was born in Ireland. but had lived in Morristown for sixty-five years. For many years she assisted

Miss Katherine Rhoads, Richmond painter, died today in Stuart Circle Hospital from a heart attack. She had been ill a week. Miss Rhoads had exehibited in Richmond and elsewhere and her work was seen last Winter at the Studio Guild in New York.

German exporters of hardware are meeting with strong competition in foreign markets despite the fact that exports of iron and steel hardware showed an increase in the first few months of this year over the same period last year, says a report to

THE complaint is-well, anyway, one complaint is-that there has been nothing but baseball banter in this corner for some days. All right. How about a spot of football? Strange as it may seem, football is already under way.

The 155th anniversary of the birth of General Simon Bolivar was celebrated by the Pan-American Society with colorful ceremonies at the base of the equestrian statue of the Venezuelan soldier and statesman in Central Park, at West Eightythird Street, yesterday afternoon.

With six of the first ten ranking players of the country entered in both the men's and women's divisions, in addition to four former national and British champions, the fifty-first annual tournament of the Seabright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club got under way today on schedule despite the heavy rains of the last ten days.

Colonel William H. Kelly of East Orange, who two months ago was forced to resign as internal revenue collector because of his activities in Democratic politics, turned in his resignation tonight as chairiman of the Essex County Democratic Committee at a meeting of 350 county committeemen and Democratic leaders in the Essex House here.

The Labor Relations Board nullified today a closed shop contract between the Ward Baking Company of Baltimore and a union affiliated with the American Federation of Labor. The board said the company's action in signing the contract was an unfair labor practice because the A. F. of L. union was not the freely
Samuel M. Greer and Linus C. Coggan have been elected directors of the Commercial Solvents Corporation, it was announced yesterday by Theodore P. Walker, president of the company.

A vigorous racist campaign aimed at safeguarding the "Italian race" from "nonAryan" infiltrations was announced this evening by Achille Starace, secretary general of the Fascist party, in the course of a meeting with the university professors responsible for the drafting of the racist report that, since its publication la week, has been the foundation for Italian theory and practice on this subject.

Workmen on the new Sixth Avenue subway placed their wet clothes yesterday over an electric heater in a wooden shack in the excavation at Sixth Avenue between Forty-first and Forty-second Streets. In the drying process the clothes took fire and the flaming apparel set the shack ablaze.

Simpson St, 1,098 (10-2727 and 11-2976); also Wilkins Ave, 1,356; Herman Cohen to Conbro Realty Corp. 1,356 Wilkins Ave. Morris Park Ave, 3,116 (15-4197); Mary Heider to Joseph Walakovics, 752 E 138th. 239th St. 417 E (12-3393); Marion I. Peecook to Henry M. Hofmann, 2,985 Briggs Ave: mtg, 05.000.

J. Howard Mecke Jr., a real estate developer, died last night of a heart attack at his home in Cynwyd at the age of 45. Born in Ardmore, he was educated at local schools and Waldron Academy, Merion; served under General Pershing on the Mexican border in 1915 and was in the navy during the World War.

One out of every thirty-seven persons in the United States, a land in which 200,000 citizens will commit murder before they die, is a criminal, the law enforcement committee of the American Bar Association reported today.

Judgment was entered in the amount of $10,000 today, in Suffolk County against the German-American Settlement League, Inc., in default of a fine in that amount imposed on July 12 by County Judge L. Barron Hill, after conviction of the league and six of its leaders charged with violating the State's Civil Rights Law.

David Lyon Dolan, postmaster of Ogdensburg for the last two years, a member of the Borough Council, and for six years a Democratic Township Committeeman from Ogdensburg, died last night at the Medical Center Hospital in New York at the age of 48.

Charges that resale prices for portable typewriters, established under the Feld-Crawford act, are being disregarded by colleges, universities and many high schools in and around this city, were voiced yesterday by dealers attending a forum discussion of price maintenance acts yesterday.

Against the advice of some of his associates Governor Earle has called a "vindication session" of the Pennsylania Legislature, which met last night. Its proceedings will be watched throughout the country not only because they mark the opening of a battle for political control of the second most populous State but because the basic legal system under which we live may be at issue.

The question of the constitutionality of New Jersey's new Fair Sales Act moved toward court today when Harry Lief of Newark, president of the Retail Grocers Association of New Jersey, filed a complaint in Third District Judicial Court against Packard Bamberger Co., of Hackensack for violating the act.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, who will make the opening address of the second World Youth Congress at Vassar College, Poughkeepsie, on Aug. 16, discussed world youth problems for an hour yesterday at Hyde Park with Miss Elizabeth Shields-Collins, the English girl

The direct and indirect debt of the Dominion of Canada on March 31, 1937, together with the direct and indirect debts of the Provinces for the same year, and the direct debts of the municipalities for 1936, made a total of $7,162,163,113, according to a review released today by the Dominion Bureau of Statistics.

The National Boxing Association announced today that it would not recognize the coming fight between Jackie Jurich of San Jose, Calif., and Peter Kane of England as being for the world's flyweight title.

Dr. James B. Conant, president of Harvard University, was one of a party which this week-end scaled North Twin, 12,085 feet high, third highest peak in the Canadian Rockies It was the fourth ascent of the peak, the last having been made in 1927.

Taking the expressions of thirty-three American Mayors as a representative cross-section, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday that American sentiment was overwhelmingly against the bombing of open towns in various parts of the world.

George Crosman Sedley-Brown, radio and theatrical figure known professionally as Sedley Brown, was found dead at 7:40 A. M. yesterday in the living room of his apartment at 75 Central Park West under circumstances that caused the ordering of an autopsy. Mr.

United States Steel common stock crossed Bethlehem yesterday for the first time in several months, reaching a high price of 631/4 compared to one of 631/8 for Bethlehem. The former closed only 1 point below its top price of the day, however, while Bethlehem ended 11/2 points below the best level and 5/8 below its big rival. With directors'

Charles Bruehl, 23, filling station attendant, put together rounds of 79 and 77 to lead today in the Buffalo sectional qualifying event for the national public links championship next month in Cleveland. Bruehl's 156 was best in a field of 113.

Tonight's final callover at the Victoria Club for tomorrow's running of the Steward's Cup at Goodwood showed F. L, Johnson's Gunboat the favorite at 8 to 1. Lady Ralli's Mixture was second choice at 10 to 1.

Three alpinists plunged to death today when a sudden storm swept them from a 650-foot cliff, on the south wall of Mount Marmolada in the Dolomites The rescue party that -found the bodies expressed the belief the climbers were swept from the precipitous cliff by rock loosed above them by a lightning bolt.....

A memorial service yesterday for Dowager Queen Marie of Rumania in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, was attended by consular representatives of Great Britain, France, Sweden, China, Egypt, The Netherlands, Yugoslavia and Czechoslovakia, in addition to the consular corps of her own country.

The general situation in Palestine, if judged by the security of life and property and interracial relations, has progressively deteriorated since February. Any slight amelioration that some profess to observe from time to time in some aspects of this complex problem is negatived by the persistence with which the troubles continue to recur, while certain recent new factors have alarming possibilities.

A misreading of a map in feet instead of meters was responsible for the near mishap of Howard Hughes while flying over the Siberian mountains on his recent around-the-world flight, Mr. Hughes was understood today to have explained to Soviet officials here.
John Theofel, former Democratic leader of Queens, has applied for retirement on pension from his post as chief clerk of the Surrogate's Court of that county, it became known yesterday.
The rate on Treasury bills was higher again this week at 0.059 per cent, compared with 0.054 per cent for the issue sold a week ago, the Treasury announced today.

Price increases on fabrics and other garment components during the last two weeks confront the coat and suit industry with the necessity of establishing "intermediate" price points as a permanent feature of marketing procedure, Samuel Klein, executive director of the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, Inc., said in a statement yesterday.

Three American girl stow- seek aways were taken off the liner Queen Mary today and lodged in the Southampton police station. They will be returned home on the Aquitania, leaving here Wednesday. The girls said they
How many words does a smart dog know? Dr. Wilfred J. Funk, the lexicographer, who has been conducting an

The Brooklyn Democratic organi zation's judicial slate for the coming election campaign was designated yesterday at a meeting of the Kings County Democratic Executive Committee in the party's headquarters, 4-5 Court Square, Brooklyn. The designations were voted without opposition.

A suit to collect $36,905 allegedly due for printing of campaign material for candidates in the Democratic primaries preceding last year's Mayoralty election was disclosed in Supreme Court yesterday when the plaintiff, Mollie Furman, moved to examine three of the defendants.

The correspondence bureau of the Police Department last night received a radio message from the D ' roit police stating that Davis Emmons Smith, 46 years old, "disappeared or left" Wayne County (Mich.) Airport in his own airplane "506" at 4 P. M. on June 29, "and we have not heard from him since." "He may have headed

The semi-annual statement of conlition of the Barnsdall Oil Company and its subsidiaries, issued yesterday, shows that for the six months through June there was a net profit of $1,690,039 after interest, Federal taxes, depreciation and intangible well drilling and development and ease costs written off.

LeRoy Latham, chairman of the board of directors of the Latham Lithographing Company, Long IslandCity, died suddenly at his home here today of a heart attack. He would have been 64 years old on Aug. 17.

Mr. and Mrs. William Stiles Bennet of 290 Riverside Drive have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Florence Bennet, to Allin Hugh Pierce of New York, son of Mrs. Charles S. Pierce of Fort Dodge, Iowa.

The fortnightly statement of the Central Bank of Argentina for July 15, issued today, shows that the gold reserve ratio to notes in circulation was 122.59 per cent, compared with 123.45 per cent on June 30.
When Raymond Rhine, new Syracuse University English instructor, read in a newspaper that search was being made for him today he inquired at the registrar's office for an explanation.

The eighteen-month trial period during which one-half cent additional fare per mile will be colelected from coach travelers on Eastern railroads went into effect yesterday, and, at the same time, the fare on the Hudson Manhattan Railroad operating between Hudson Terminal, in Manhattan, and Jersey City and Hoboken was raised from six to eight cents.

The Constitutional Convention, at 12:25 this morning, defeated the Feinberg proposal making it mandatory for half of the gasoline tax and automobile license revenues to be used for highway purposes. The vote was 57 for and 85 against advancing the proposal to third reading. The decisiveness of the vote

Coalition between the Republicans and the American Labor Party has been effected in Manhattan and Brooklyn as a result of which each political group will endorse a number of the other's candidates for seats in the State Legislature, it was learned yesterday.

James H. McKnight, chairman of the grievance committee of the Civil Service Forum and president of the Interboro Attendants Council, No. 12, of the Forum, died yesterday in the Veterans Hospital, Kingsbridge Road, Bronx, of heart disease. Mr. McKnight, who was

The will of Mrs. Gladys M. Pulitzer, wife of Herbert Pulitzer, son of the late Joseph Pulitzer, publisher of The New York World, was filed in Surrogate's Court last Friday evening, it was revealed yesterday. The estate was formally valued at "more than $10,000."

Denying all rumors of feuds, retirement and matrimony, Mrs. Helen Wills Moody, who recently gained her eighth Wimbledon tennis championship, returned yesterday aboard the North German Lloyd liner Europa intent upon continuing her "comeback" campaign. Apparently in excellent condition, except for a back strain, Queen Helen was anything but difficult to interview.
The National Fertilizer Association's wholesale commodity price index registered a small decline last week, dropping to 74.6 from 74.7 in the preceding week.

The Long Island Golf Association held its annual amateur-pro Scotch foursome tournament at the Oceanside Golf Club today, with Al Brosch, red-headed Bethpage professional, sharing two of the three prizes for the teams carding the lowest net scores.
Government armies on the Catalan front in Northern Spain crossed the Ebro River today and smashed forward in a surprise offensive into Insurgent territory.
Senator Vandenberg of Michigan expressed the opinion today that President Roosevelt will seek a third term. "I expect him to try," he said in a letter, "but I do not expect him to succeed."

The condition statement of weekly repbrting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended July 20: A decrease of $34,000,000 in
Firing while sprawled on a sidewalk, Policeman James H. McFadden today fatally wounded Louis Fullin, 40, a former asylum inmate, who had knocked him down with an iron pipe.

The Danish State Railways are negotiating with the German State Railways for the introduction of a direct bus service between the two countries, according to a report to the Department of Commerce from Copenhagen, made public today.

The communique issued by the so-called Oslo Powers after their Copenhagen conference is considered disappointing by the influential liberal press of this country. It is contended that the only positive result of the meeting was that the Oslo Powers will stand together at the next League of Nations session and make a joint move to reduce the covenants in Article XVI to a dead letter by making sanctions optional.

Many cities can take a leaf from the advertising and sales promotion methods of private business and, by selling more water during off-peak times, can make the water plant a more profitable undertaking, according to R. E. McDonnell, consulting engineer of Kansas City, Mo., in a report to the American Water Works Association.

Four hundred children were guests of the city yesterday on the first of a season of picnics to Owl's Head Park, Brooklyn. The recreation program was arranged by the city, with the Education, Health. Welfare and Dock

THE NEW YORK TIMES acknowledges receipt of a contribution of $5 in the name of Alexandria Anne to apply toward a child's vacation in the country. The money has been forwarded to the Fresh Air Fund of the Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor, 105 East Twenty-second Street.

ALLEN-Rachel, 645 Putnam Ave., Brooklyn, widow of Alexander, beloved mother of Betty Rothschild, Hettie Pocinki and Harry. Services Gutterman Chapel, 153 East Broadway, today, 10 A. A. Interment Mount Zion. BAKER-At Mount Vernon, N. Y., July 25, 1938, Caroline, wife of the late Charles L. Baker. Funeral from Burr Davis Mortuary, 15 Fourth Ave., Thursday
Eighteen innings of baseball will be used to "sugar-coat" two Congressional campaign speeches by Joe Morrison and Kenneth Coffelt.

Tennessee entered this week the final phases of the bitterest primary election campaign in its colorful political history, marked by a knock-downand-drag-out fight between the State Democratic organization headed by Governor Browning and a coalition of the Memphis City, Federal patronage and WPA forces formed by Edward H. Crump and Senator McKellar in an effort to defeat the Governor and his political ally, Senator Berry.

After the queerest campaign that even Texas has ever had, W. Lee O'Daniel, a Fort Worth flour merchant, has won the Democratic nomination for Governor by a clear majority. A carpetbagger from Ohion he sold flour in Kansas and Louisiana before settling in Texas.

Joseph Fishbach, the defending titleholder and Eastern intercollegiate ruler from St. John's University, advanced to the final bracket in the annual Eastern junior tennis championship .yesterday at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills. He won by default from Dan Canale of Memphis, who had departed to compete in the Western junior open.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated July 23: Powell. Commander J. G.. Med. Corps, granted two months' sick leave upon discharge from treatment at Naval Hospital, Brooklyn, N. Y.

Kramer Brothers and the Freud- ton enberger Realty Company sold to 353 the Six-Sixty-Seven.Bergenline Avenue Company the three-story store and office building at 665-67 Bergenline Avenue, corner of Thirty-fourth Street, Union City, N. J.
It is beginning to appear that unless conditions change practically overnight the rivalry between Newfoundland and Nova Scotia is going to assume Freeport-Brielle proportions.

For the first time this year, business for the majority of wholesale grocers submitting weekly reports to the American Institute of Food Distribution, Inc., showed a gain last week, compared with the correspending period of. 1937.

In a sudden reversal of an earlier decision, District Attorney William F. X. Geoghan of Brooklyn announced last night that he would personally conduct, "from the Magistrate's Court all the way through," the prosecution of his staff assistant, William F. McGuinness, who...

The Na- $13 tional Labor Relations Board today upheld the action of Edward G. Smith, trial examiner, in excluding Clyde A. Armstrong, general counsel for the company, from hearings in the Weirton Steel Company case and stated that the hearings would be resumed in Pittsburgh Aug. 24.

News of the death at Burgos, Spain, on July 5 of Xavier VidalQuadras y Villavecchia, son-in-law of Leonard Liebling, editor of the Musical Courier, was received here yesterday by his wife, the former Viva Liebling. The son-in-law, who

Coach Andy Kerr completed his guard department of the Eastern College All-Star team which will oppose the New York Football Giants at the Polo Grounds on Sept. 7, when Joseph Drulis of Temple accepted his invitation today. Drulis was recommended by Fred Swam, Temple line coach, who again will be in charge of the AllStar line. The other guards
