Frank Harsch of 230 Tuscan Road, president of the M. Harsch Company, Inc., oil burner nozzle manufacturers, died in Frankfort, Germany, Thursday, it was learned I here today. He was 32 years old. Mr. Harsch had left for Germany last Feb. 14 to undergo treatment for his health. His widow,

Homer H. Higley, president of the Chenango County National Bank and Trust Company of this city, died at St. Luke's Hospital, Utica, of last night following an operation. His age was 77. Born in Bainbridge, N. Y., he had lived in this city nearly half a century. Sixteen years ago

Declaring -that the only way to prevent "power grabs" in the future was to write a provision into the State Constitution reserving the State's power resources for public use, Mayor La Guardia wrote last night to the Utilities Committee of the Constitutional Convention asking it to protect the public through legislation.

Getting up in the final stride, F. Mallory's Baby Sweep today gained a nose decision to pay $7.08 for $2 in the feature at Rockingham Park. Second was F. J. Vollmer's Sun Antioch, who returned $4.02 to place after leading until the last jump. A length and a half back was D. J. Sullivan's -Learned, at $5.82 to show.

Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. announced this afternoon that he and his wife, the former Ethel du Pont, had named their 6-day-old son Franklin Delano Roosevelt 3d. With a grin he told reporters at Pennsylvania Hospital that he supposed that was "a surprise to everybody."

Delivery delays of serious proportions will develop next month on comfortable and on some types of bedspreads, exhibitors said at the national domestics and linen show, which opened at the Hotel New Yorker yesterday.

The manuscript of Winston S. Churchill's latest book, "While England Slept," has been received by Putnam, which will publish it late in September. The book deals with European affairs during the last six years and with rearmament in Germany. The author is arriving
Although the Changkufeng incident is not yet settled, the most recent developments make an amicable solution in the near future almost- certain.

That Berlin housewives have not been completely persuaded not to buy in Jewish-owned shops is charged by the newspaper Angriff today in connection with the storming of "non-Aryan" shops during midsummer sales.
Whatever is thought abroad about the necessity or justice of the Soviet purge, there is no doubt that it cut a deep furrow through every phase of national life.

The Steel Workers Organization Committee and a group of steel corporation took opposite sides today before the Public Contracts Board of the Labor Department when a hearing was held on the former's proposal to fix specific minimum wage rates for common labor in those mills bidding on government contracts. The Walsh-Healey Act permits the board to fix minimum rates in case of those bidding on more than $10,000 worth of contracts.
Fortytwo officers of the National Guard in States have been commissioned as officers of the National Guard of the United States.

Peter Van Santvoord Rice will be honored at a dance which his parents, Mr. and Mrs. William Thompson Rice of Greenwood Hill, this city, will give on Wednesday night at the Pittsfield Country Club. Their house guests are van Santvoord Bowen of New Rochelle, N. Y., and the Misses Doris Campbell of Bennington, Vt., and Marion Gifford of Kinderhook, N. Y.

Each of the following Medical Corpe Reserve officers, is ordered to active duty Aug. 6, at Pine Camp. N. Y., for training with field artillery units: Capt. Samuel Grubin, 158-19 Laburnam Ave., Flushing. L. I.. N. Y. 1st Lt. Victor H. Rosen, 50 W. 90th St., New York. N. Y.

John D. Rockefeller Jr., accompanied by his wife and their youngest son, David, returned yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Europa after a vacation in Europe. In a brief' interview as the liner was coming up the bay, Mr. Rockefeller gave his opinions on the outlook for business, employment and peace. He said that while

In the weekly one-day pro-amateur best-ball tournament held under the auspices of the Westchester County Golf Association, Scotty Phimister, professional at Gedney, and Sal Sava of Tamarack captured top honors with a fine score of 32, 32-64 over the Hudson River Country Club course today.

A OTHER Down Easterner with some yarns to tell is Richard Hallet, whose "Rolling World"* is waiting in the bookstores for customers today-350 pages of hairy-chested autobiography, most of it grand reading. Back about 1910 or 1912, the author admits, he was merely a Harvard man, a graduate of the college and the law school and a clerk in Judge Learned Hand's law office. Then something

Opponents of billboard advertising along our highways have failed to convince the Constitution-makers at Albany that the objective of their cause should be written into the State charter. Wise friends will approve this decision, since the Constitution ought not

The prosecution In the general court-martial on Governors Island of Lieut. Col. Stewart S. Giffin on charges of conduct unbecoming an officer and a gentleman yesterday called its only friendly witness of the three days of -the trial, then unexpectedly rested without summoning the chief complaining officer, James O. Smith, a lieutenant in the reserves.
Basing its order on testimony taken during a nine-day hearing here early in May, the State Banking Commission suspended today the Wisconsin securities license held by H. M. Byllesby Co., Chicago.
The tenth annual report of General Mills, Inc., issued yesterday, showed consolidated net earnings of $4,110,631 for the fiscal year end

Louis Ogden Condit, New York lawyer, died today at his home here after a long illness. He was 55 years old. Mr. Condit, who had been associated with the law firm of Sherman Sterling, 55 Wall Street, for twenty-seven years, was born in Parsippany, N. J.

Mr. and Mrs. J. Macy Willets will come to the Carlyle today from Great Barrington, Mass. Mrs. A. Mitchell Palmer of Washington is the guest of Mrs. Henry L. Doherty at the Waldorf-Astoria. Mrs. James Ford Johnson Jr. has returned to the Ambassador from Bermuda.

Joseph V. Connolly, president of King Features Syndicate, was appointed general manager of the Hearst newspapers yesterday, it was announced by T. J. White, chairman of the board of American Newspapers, Inc. Mr. Connolly is to take charge of an expansion program scheduled to start immediately, it was announced.

Tony Galento showed definite improvement today in his fight against pneumonia. Attending physicians said his temperature was lower and his general condition good, and the always talkative Galento, No. 1 heavyweight title challenger, showed it.
A throng of followers of the turf, many of them prominent in the social world, saw the racing season opened this afternoon with ideal weather prevailing. Many New Yorkers occupied boxes.

Isidore Belsky of 197 Brookside Avenue, Irvington, died suddenly today of a heart attack in the waiting room of Dr. S. Bernard Kaplan of 847 South Twelfth Street. Mr, Belsky had sold baby carriages for the last thirty-five years in his store at 247 Springfield Avenue.

Battalion Chief William C. Miller (2). 36th Battalion, died July-24. The funeral will take place from his late residence, 406 St. John's Pl., Brooklyn. at 9:45 A. M., Wednesday, July 27. Interment at Holy Cross Cemetery.

John Roosevelt and his bride have leased a cottage at Paget until Aug. 12. They were met on their arrival by Harold L. Williamson, United States Consul. Mr. Roosevelt said a position awaited him in the United States, but he declined to divulge its nature. He declared he "never was

President Roosevelt watched more than 300 men on the cruiser Houston get "the royal works" today as they were changed from pollywogss" to shellbackss." Tonight the Houston, a 100 per cent shellback ship, dropped anchor off the west coast of Albemarle Island, largest of the Galapagos group.
Victorious over Susex by an innings and five runs today. Lancashire moved into second place in the Enlsih county cricket championship behind the Yorkshire eleven.

The complete casts have been announced by Alfredo Salmaggi for the inaugural operas to be presented by his company at Randalls Island, "Aida" will be given Saturday night with a personnel composed of Anna Leskaya in the title role, Hilda Kutsukian Kosta as Amneris, Gina Castro as the Priestess, Sydney Rayner as Radames, Mario Cozzi as Amonasro, William Wahlert as the King and Silvie Giorgini as the Messenger.

Debits to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities for the Ka week ended July 20, aggregated $8,161,000,000, or 6 per cent above the total reported for the preceding week and 8 per cent below the total for the corresponding week of last year.

The Increasingly favorable trend in the foreign trade of the United States was shown by a net balance of merchandise exports of $631,074,000 for the first half of 1938, the Department of Commerce reported today.
A number of residences of all types in scattered sections of Brooklyn were among the parcels in that borough reported yesterday as having been sold by the Dime Savings Bank of Brooklyn.

Production of wool from milk, now being studied, will center in Wisconsin, where hundreds of creameries have installed plants for making casein from the residue of milk, according to a report yesterday by the Milwaukee section of the American Chemical Society.

Edward Lovering Ingram, who was Professor of Railroad Engineering and Geodesy at the University of Pennsylvania from 1911 until his retirement in 1932, died at his home here today at the age of 75 after a long illness.

Domestic corporation bonds moved forward yesterday under the aggressive leadership of railroad loans in fairly active trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Speculative demand lifted a long list of carrier liens up fractions to 4 points, with a few selected issues showing gains of 5 to 9 points. The groups price

The navy announced today assignment of Lieut. Commander Augustus D. Clark, commanding officer of the Presidential yacht Potomac, to duty in connection with the fitting out of the new cruiser Phoenix and on board as its navigating officer when the vessel is commissioned.

J. Richard Davis, the young disbarred lawyer who rose to underworld power as the adviser of Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, is expected to enter a plea of guilty and testify against James J. Hines, Tammany district leader,

Albert Goldstein, 27 years old, of Perth Amboy, who is suffering from tuberculosis and is not expected to live more than six months, was sentenced today by Common Pleas Judge Adrian Lyon to life imprisonment after he had pleaded non vult to first degree murder.

American delegates negotiating for the formation of a permanent organization to assist the emigration of German refugees are trying to enlist the cooperation of Germany in the plan already sponsored by thirty-two nations.
Teddy Yarosz, former world middleweight champion, turned the tables tonight on his two-time conqueror, Billy Conn of Pittsburgh, beating Corn in a heated twelve-round grudge fight.

The army teams from Governors Island and Fort Hamilton will play their Eastern Polo League e matches postponed from June 26 on Sunday, it was announced yesterday. The Governors Island Yellows will oppose Fort Hamilton at Morris Memorial Field and the Governors Island Blues will meet the First Division at the Fort Hamilton Reservation in Brooklyn.

A committee has been appointed by James Marshall, president of the Board of Education, and Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, to "study and evaluate the services of the present Teachers Council, its method of election, and to make such recommendations as the study may warrant."
Gabriel de Lautrec, well-known writer and "prince of humorists," who first translated Mark Twain's novels into French, died today at the age of 71.

The national average construction cost index of the American Appraisal Company, computed yesterday, showed a decline of 1 point for June, making a total drop of 3 points, from 184 to 181, in the index since December, 1937. The reduction in construction material prices resulted mainly from the readjustment of steel prices and rating points, the company reported.

Ernie Gesell of Inwood won the feature event of twenty-five laps from Ed Stanek of Mountain Tabor, N. J., and Tom Hinnerschitz of Laureldale, Pa., in the midget auto races tonight at the Cedarhurst Speedway. His time was 7:18.41.

Of 349 A. B. C. and C. C. A. class, trade and technical publications, 285 increased their circulations in 1937 over 1936 and sixty-four decreased circulation, according to the fourth revised edition of "A Rate and Circulation Study of 358 Class, Trade and Technical Publications," just issued by the Association of National Advertisers.

Mr. and Mrs. Vincent Charles Arguimbeau of Glenbrook, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Suzanne Hough Arguimbeau, to William Norris Hubbard Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Hubbard of 515 Park Avenue, this city.

Miss Kerstin Hesselgren, Swedish women's leader and a member of the New Sweden Tercentenary delegation now visiting in this country, will be the guest of honor today at a luncheon of '500 women representing more than thirty American women's organizations at the Delmonico Hotel, 502 Park Avenue.

The Marine Midland Trust Company has been appointed registrar for the first and second preferred and common stocks of C. C. Gunther's Sons. Gerald Whitman of Estabrook Co. is sailing today on the Europa for a business and pleasure trip of several weeks in Europe.
The United States Maritime Commission has granted to the Dollar Steamship Lines a thirty-day extension of its temporary operating subsidy contract, which expired today.

Erastus M. Cravath, a partner in the New York Stock Exchange firm of Chisholm and Chapman, 52 Broadway, and a brother of Paul D. Cravath, died at his home here to day after an illness of several months. He was 65 years old.

Castle Hill Estate, Inc., sold a plot 50 by 90 feet, on the south side of Cincinnatus Avenue 200 feet east of Castle Hill Avenue, Bronx, for J. Holtzman of Paris, France, to Peter Schneider for improvement with a one-family dwelling. Edward B. Shanahan, sales manager, arranged the deal.

The hog market remained uneven but weighty butchers and sows got better action. Light hogs ruled about steady topping at $10.10. Strictly grain-fed steers and yearlings predominated in the cattle yards and sold unevenly steady to 25 cents lower. All fed heifers got active outlet, topping at $11 against a $13 top on prime steers. Lambs sold steady, the United States Department of Agriculture reported.

Twenty-four men were arrested at 5 P. M. yesterday in a raid on alleged horse-racing betting quarters on the third floor of 167 West Forty-eighth Street. Three of the men were charged with bookmaking and the others with disorderly conduct.

A banking group composed of the Illinois Company of Chicago, the First of Michigan Corporation, Bartlett, Knight Co. and Blair, Bonner Co., received yesterday the award of a new Issue of $500,000 of electric plant revenue bonds of the city of Springfield, Ill.

The annual Southampton horse show will take place Aug. 6 on the grounds of the Southampton Riding and Hunt Club. Joseph Bradley Murray, who heads the horse show committee, has announced that the pet show which was a popular feature last year will be held again this season. There also will be

Railroad labor represented by the Railway Labor Executives' Association today started to present its side in the arguments over the railroads' plan to cut wages 15 per cent. George M. Harrison, chairman of the association, spoke for the eighteen railroad unions represented by the association at the Palmer House.

Carlo Alfonso Nallino, one of Italy's foremost authorities on philology and Islamic history, died today at the age of '66. Mr. Nallino was a member of the Academy of Italy and had been a royal commissioner for the Oriental Institute at Naples and a member of the Superior Council on Public Instruction.

The league-leading Bears pounded four pitchers for 20 hits tonight to rout the cellar-dwelling Orioles, 19 to 3, and take the series, two games to one. Joe Witek led the onslaught with a homer, a double and three singles, driving in six runs. Kelleher, Newark left-fielder, also poled a homer, a prodigious drive that

Mrs. Henry O. Tallmadge and Mrs. George Batcheller were joint hostesses at tea this afternoon at the Kebo Valley Golf Club after the weekly putting tournament. Mrs. D. Crawford Clark of New York entertained with a luncheon at Green Court today in honor of Mrs. Elliot Smith.

First Round Miss Alice Marble defeated Miss Jean Burritt, 6-0, 6-0; Miss Helen Germaine defeated Miss Laura Morgan, 6-2, 6-2; Miss Helen Pedersen defeated Mrs. E. M. Crane, 6-0, 6-2; Miss Norma Taubele won from Miss Margaret Osborne by default; Mrs. Dorothy Andrus won from Miss Helen Bernhard by default;

WVPA workmen began yesterday to recondition the Duffield Street average Public-Bathhouse in Brooklyn. The WPA will spend $205,407 to rehabil- during itate the thirty-four-year-old build- A. M. ing, which served more than 500,000 ter dro persons in 1937. Of the total advanced by the Federal Government, reached at the the city will repay $75,000 out of its capital outlay budget.

Miss Zelina de Macklot Comegys of 320 East Fifty-third Street, daughter of the late Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Parsons Comegys of this city and Rock Island, Ill., was married to Captain Roger E. Brunschwig of the French Army Reserve yesterday afternoon in St. Boniface's Catholic Church, Second Avenue and Forty-seventh Street, by the Rev. James J. Weber.

In another effort to avert an open. rupture between Germany and Czechoslovakia over the Sudeten problem, Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain has asked Viscount Runciman, former President of the Board of Trade, to go to Prague and urge further concessions upon the Czechoslovak Government.

George J. Weppler, a clerk in the Fourth District Municipal Court, Manhattan, has worked for three years without pay, it was disclosed yesterday. Weppler, a political appointee, was named to the clerkship by three Democratic justices in November, 1934, several months after the Municipal Civil Service Commission ruled the jobs were to be removed from the exempt class.

Henry G. Barbey, president of the board of governors of the Society of the New York Hospital, died Sunday night at his home in Katonah after an illness of more than two months. He was 67 years old. Mr. Barbey was born in Geneva, Switzerland, son of Henry Isaac

Nearly all of the 1,400 employes in the Division of Placement and Unemployment Insurance of the State Department of Labor refused yesterday to work overtime in accordance with the decision of Local 28 of the State, County and Municipal Workers of America, C. I. O.

La Salle St, 74, 27x100.10; Lind Realty Corp to Louis H. Pink, Supt of Ins; pr mtge; 5 yrs, 4-4 4/2 per cent; $16,000. 144th St, 1-11 W., 202.6 to Exterior St and 202.8 to 145th St (12-18 W) x irreg; Edward A. Thompson, Inc, to Public Fuel Service, Inc, 3-5 W. 144th St; installments, 6 per cent; $25,000.

Men's and boys' clothing valued at $1,431,436.11 was bought by the Procurement Division of the United States Treasury over the week-end for the account of the Works Progress Administration, in furtherance of the WPA's plan to purchase $10,000,000 worth of garments for distribution to the needy.

Opinion favorable to the United States is at such a gratifyingly high level today that it is needless for ,this country to consider embarking on a counter-propaganda program to offset the pressure of authoritarian nations in Latin America, it was declared yesterday by Edward Tomlinson, author, lecturer and an authority on South American affairs, who returned on the Grace liner Santa Barbara.

Clyde E. Elliott, who directed "Bring 'Em Back Alive" and recently completed "Boolo" for Paramount, will leave this Fall to film "Road to Asia," in Australia, Celebes and Burma. The picture will concern itself almost wholly with animals with few human actors. Harry Smith, who filmed Elliott's other pictures, will be the cameramen.

Outclassing his rival throughout, George Zengaras, East Side lightweight, easily gained the decision over Johnny Rinaldi of the Bronx in the principal bout of eight rounds last night at the New Dyckman Oval. A crowd of 2,500 saw

Shirley Temple, child film star, returned from Bermuda yesterday after a week's vacation there, accompanied by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. George Temple, and two bodyguards. The party went to the Waldorf-Astoria.

National chairmen of both major parties will lend their presence next month to campaigns for the Sept. 12 State election. J. Fred O'Connell of Bangor, State Republican chairman, announced that John D. M. Hamilton would confer with the State committee at Augusta Aug. 16 and speak at Portland that night.

The Japanese Army reported it had completed occupation of the city of Kiukiang at dawn today, the vanguard of the Japanese forces having entered late last night, thereby breaking Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's strong defense lines extending from the mountains on the northern bank of the Yangtze to Nanchang, capital of Kiangsi Province.

The winners of 204 New Jersey State scholarships to the various divisions of Rutgers University were named today by Dr. Fraser Metzger, dean of men at Rutgers and chairman of the State scholarship committee. All but twenty-one are for young men and women residents of this State who will begin college in September.
The British pickaback plane Mercury landed in the harbor here at 4:28 P. M. today, after flying from Boucherville, Que., in four hours and thirty-eight minutes.

The stock market here was cheerful on the whole today and most sections went ahead. Gilt-edge issues were firm, while among the foreign bonds German loans were in good demand. Transatlantic stocks were active at higher levels and United States Steel was prominent.
Howard Goldstein, 15 years old, was shocked fatally yesterday in the basement of his home at 926 East Forty-eighth Street, Brooklyn, while he was taking apart a radio set. The boy, a sophomore at

Ohio Salt Company, in Time Life Building. Rockefeller Center. Keller Bros., luggage, in 752 Broadway; Benjamin Komarow, coats and dresses, in 395 Broadway; Sidney J. Wolff, display advertising, in 274 Madison Ave.; Madge Morey, artist's studio, in 333 4th Ave.; Jacob Lamport, luncheonette, store in 17 W. 20th St.; Carstens, Linnekin Wilson, Inc., brokers.
Fiftythree persons were killed and fifty- pe eight wounded in Palestine today as th Haifa experienced the most serious as episode of the present terroristic campaign.

Thomas Henry Manning, British explorer and scientist, and Ella Wallace Jackson of Halifax, N. S., were married today aboard the Arctic patrol ship Nascopie. Right Rev. Archibald Fleming, Anglican Bishop of the Arctic, performed the ceremony, and John Buchan, son of Canada's Governor General. was best man.

As a step designed to simplify its financial structure, the Lone Star Gas Company announced yesterday its intention to apply to the Securities and Exchange Commission for permission to issue and sell approximately $20,000,000 of fifteen-year debenture bonds and to place about $11,000,000 of installment bank loans.

Sir Thomas Gardner Horridge, a justice of the King's Bench for twenty-seven years until his retirement last year, died at Hove today at the age of 80. As a Liberal candidate in the general election of 1906 he defeated Lord Balfour, then Prime Minister, by a majority of 2,000 votes.

Some 1,400 members and delegates assembled here today for the second annual convention of the New York Restaurant Liquor Dealers Association. The board of governors and various committees held meetings today and their reports will be submitted to the convention tomorrow. John J. Daly, president

The Federal Court of Appeals ruled today that the Societe Suise pour Valeurs de Metaux (Swiss Corporation) should pay the United States Government $14,000,000 in restitution of a fraud linked to the alien property scandals of 1921.

Mrs. Andrew J. Steelman of Montclair has "regretfully resigned" as Federal Jury Commissioner in the New Jersey district, it was announced today by Federal Judge Guy Fake. He named Mrs. Marie H. Katzenbach of Trenton to succeed Mrs. Steelman, who said that her resignation had been requested.
Luncheon meeting, Lions Club, Hotel Astor, 12:30 P. M. "America and the World," Paul R. Cook. Metropolitan Museum of Art, 3:30 P. M. "The Gothic Cathedral," Harry D. M. Grier.
The net income of the Pacific Lighting Corporation and subsiddiaries for the twelve months ended on June 30, according to the company report issued yesterday, was $7,116,483. This was equal after

American contributions disbursed to both sides in the Spanish civil war have passed the $1,000,000 ma: . the State Department reported today. Since May, 1937, when Congress passed a law requiring the registration with the State Department of all sums collected for use in Spain, until July 1 of this year, $1,018,067.01 had been spent in Spain by thirty American organizations.

More than 7,000 automobiles and other vehicles were blessed today in front of St. Christopher's Roman Catholic Church on Merrick Road here. License plates from many parts of the country were in evidence and there were three masses, at 6. 7 and 9 o'clock this morning.
AND THIS Is BOSTON, by Eleanor Early. (Houghton Mifflin, $1.75.) A new edition of the guidebook. CHEDDAR GORGE, edited by John Squire. (Macmillan, $3.) Essays by various hands on English cheeses.
Miss Walther, whose engagement to George de Braux of Paris was announced recently by her parents, is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John L. Walther of this city and

The results of investigations by agents for the Senate Committee on Campaign Expenditures into charges of WPA activities and the distribution of old age pension checks in Kentucky, together with the alleged misuse of campaign and public funds in Tennessee, will be given to the public late this week in advance of the primary elections in the two States.

The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, which has a backlog of orders aggregating $21,300,000, reported yesterday that deliveries of fourteen transport planes in June, with a net value of $1,079,900, marked an increase of 158 per cent over business in the same month last year.

Transfers and Assignments To take effect 8 A. M., July 26: SERGEANT-Edward P. Barth, from 71st Precinct to Telegraph Bureau. PATROLMAN-Joseph F. Schoppmeyer, from Traffic Precinct C to Mounted Squadron 2, assigned to clerical duty. Temporary Assignments LIEUTENANT-William F. Maley. from Grand Central Parkway Precinct to Police Academy, for 21 days, from 8 A. M., July 26.
A warm medium green was introduced yesterday by the Dress Creators League of America, Inc., as suitable for Fall and Winter fashion promotions in retail stores.

An unsuccessful application was made yesterday before Federal Judge T. Whitfield Davidson for a bill of particulars in behalf of Otto Herrmann Voss, mechanic employed in the Seversky airplane factory at Farmingdale, L. I., who was indicted as a German spy.

Production of the steel industry is scheduled at 37 per cent of effective capacity this week, a gain of 0.6 point, or 1.6 per cent, over last week, the American Iron and Steel Institute announced yesterday. This is the highest rate since

Henry H. Curran, deputy Mayor, will present the greetings of Mayor La Guardia at the luncheon to be held today at the Empire State Club in honor of J. Howard Denny, the new president of Franklin Simon Co. In addition to Mr. Denny, the following retail executives will attend: Major Benjamin H. Namm,

There is no Princess Baba of Sarawak. Au- Pr thority for that statement came today from the angry white Rajah of Sarawak, C. V. Brooke, 'whose daughter's wedding to Bob Gregory, an English wrestler, has put the little British protectorate on the coast of Borneo and its ruling family in the limelight.

Moscow paraded 35,000 athletes in Red Square last Sunday; Berlin will have to parade 50,000 to catch up. Considered all by itself, this is fine. We have had plenty of instances of geniuses in sick or feeble bodies, but the majority of men are more useful to society when they are well and strong.

Many varsity sports captains -and more than half of the men on the varsity crew roster attained honorroll standing at Princeton University for the past term, according to the list announced yesterday by Wilbur F. Kerr, registrar. Charles H. Toll, '38, of Amherst, Mass., captain and 220-pound tackle on the 1937 eleven, is among the sports leaders listed.

Over the objections of Mayor S. Davis Wilson of Philadelphia, the Public Utility Commisison granted today a new permit to the Delaware River Tunnel Corporation to build a vehicular tunnel under the Delaware River between Hog Island, Pa., and Mantua Creek, Gloucester County, N. J. The tunnel is expected to cost about $17,000,000.

Teaching in American colleges and universities is being stultified by a reverence for academic degrees and titles that has made the degree of Doctor of Philosophy a fetish worshiped at the expense of "real teaching and real research," an educator argued last night, deploring the "mass production of Ph. D. degrees."

Douglas G. Corrigan, who a week ago today flew across the Atlantic without permit or passport, was the guest of United States Ambassador Joseph P. Kennedy today. The 31year-old flier came to England from Ireland by commercial plane.

The death toll in motor accidents L in New York City rose sharply last week and week-end compared with the corresponding periods of 1937, figures made public yesterday by the safety bureau of the Police Deapartment showed.

After two pitching duels, the Indians and Red Sox remained just where they had been before they started today's double-header-Cleveland in second place a game back of the Yankees and Boston in third position another game and a half to the rear.

The defeat in the Texas Democratic primary of Representatives Maury Maverick and D. D. McFarlane, who were described by President Roosevelt as "My friends," caused diverse comment in political circles today. Republicans hailed

The Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway loaded 20,980 cars of grain between July 1 and 21, against 21,000 cars in the same period last. year, B. T. Bledsoe, president, said yesterday. He added that passenger traffic was holding up well.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith used to talk about the State budget in a way that would keep audiences sit- a ting on the edges of their seats. A ba government, as he saw it, wasn't much r different from a family. Its total income was like the workman's total co wages. Some of the income went for

Eddie De Gray of Brooklyn, second seeded player, gained the quarterfinals of the Northern New Jersey tennis championship by defeating David W. Hoppock of Maplewood, former Lehigh captain, at the Westfield Tennis Club today, 6-4, 6-1. Hoppock provided stubborn resistance, keeping De Gray on the court more than an hour.

Employes of the Bankers Club of America, 120 Broadway, yesterday selected the Hotel and Club Employes Union, an A. F. of L. affiliate, as their sole collective bargaining agency, at an election held in Public School 29, Albany and Washington Streets, under the auspices of the State Labor Relations Board. The club employs 240

Automobile production dropped sharply last week as shut-downs became more numerous. Daily average output slumped against a rising seasonal trend, and the adjusted index receded to 36.3 from the preceding week's level of 48.0. The index was 99.7 for the week ended July 24, 1937.
S. Dillon Ripley, zoologist of the Denison-Crockett expedition to New Zealand, returned here today with 1,200 bird skins and other specimens for the Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia.

With Representatiye Charles Wolverton, New Jersey Republican, continuing to heckle him bn TVA rates today, David E. Lilienthal, director of the power program, admitted that he had announced the famous "yardstick" in 1933 without notifying the rest of the board of directors of the Tennesee Valley Authority.

Ligaroti, Argentine-bred racer owned by Bing Crosby and Lin Howard, went to Del Mar today for light workouts preparatory to a match race with Seabiscuit on Aug. 12 for a purse of $25,000. C. S. Howard, Lin's father and owner of Seabiscuit, agreed to his son's proposal for the match race after they had argued long on relative merits of the horses.

KAUFMAN, DAVID PEARL (July 16). Estate, $15,000. To Fred Kaufman, husband, executor, 1,112 Park Ave. POWELL, FRANCIS EDWARD (June 2). Estate, more than, $10,000. To Gertrude Greene Powell, widow, Hale Farm, Rudgwick, Sussex, England, life estate in residue: Francis E. Powell Jr., Rattling
Sidney R. Kent, president of Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation and chairman of the motion picture industry's committee organized last month to work out a program to solve trade problems,

Afanasiy Gnevshin, a former captain of the bodyguard for Czar Nicholas II of Russia and a former member of the armored guard of the Federal Reserve Bank in New York, died today at his home here following a short illness. His age was 52.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Christina Margaret Andreae, daughter of Herman A. Andreae, famous British yachtsman, to Richard Ely Danielson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Danielson of Boston and Groton, Mass. His father is an editor and clubman.
D. R. Thompson, assistant general Eastern freight agent of the Erie Railroad here, has been promoted to assistant general freight agent with office in Pittsburgh, it was announced yesterday.

Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain fought off determined Laborite attempts in the House of Commons today to find out his plans about putting the Anglo-Italian pact into force before Parliament adjourns Friday.

After a little more than a day and a half of clearing skies which brought respite after eight days of at the clouds and rains, the Weather Bu- Broad S reau reported last night that rain discussion might fall again within the next ing was twenty-four hours.

Otto B. Reimer will retire from Reimer, Terry Co. as of July 31. The Lone Star Cement Corporation has notified the New York Stock Exchange that 246 of the 16,400 shares optioned to officers of the company and subsidiaries at $34 a share were taken up on June 30.
Although the combination of continued heavy rains in eastern sections of the Cotton Belt and a strong stock market brought an advance in prices on the Cotton Exchange again yesterday, buying

John Ryan bought from the Savings Bank of Utica, N. Y., the twofamily house at 47-17 Thirty-eighth Street, Long Island City. He paid cash over a first mortgage of $6,000, according to William Adam Schulz Co., brokers in the sale.
The trial of Harlan County's leading citizens on charges of hiring deputy sheriffs to defeat the Wagner act by force and violence came to an end today, except for closing arguments.

The charge that Vicente Lombardo Toledano, Labor leader, had threatened to form a new "Labor party" if the Revolutionary party did not expel General Ramon F. Iturbe and Colonel Bolivar Sierra from tne party for seeking to form a "Demo.cratic Front" was made today by the two officers.

Manitoba wants to buy motor cars, farm implements and other manufactured articles at prices similar to those enjoyed by United States consumers, and the Provincial Government is urging the Federal Administration to lower the tariff barriers.
The British frigate Lutine yielded a number of Spanish coins today to salvagers seeking her rich treasure of gold and silver.

Allen St. 123, 25x87.6; Max Kessler to Jennie Weinstein, 282 Beaumont St, Brooklyn; one-half interest ($1). 47th St, 446 W. 25.6x100.5; Mortgage Commission Realty Corp. trustee, to Sterling National Bank and Trust Co, trustee; quit claim.
The railroads are establishing records in the transportation of the Winter wheat crop to market, the Association of American Railroads announced yesterday.

The architects' plan for the Apparel and Accessories Building at the World's Fair has been filed with the board of design, it was announced yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, president of the Fair Corporation. Joseph Love, president

Allen St. 123, 25x87.6; Max Kessler to Jennie Weinstein, 282 Beaumont St, Brooklyn; one-half interest ($1). 47th St, 446 W. 25.6x100.5; Mortgage Commission Realty Corp. trustee, to Sterling National Bank and Trust Co, trustee; quit claim.
The railroads are establishing records in the transportation of the Winter wheat crop to market, the Association of American Railroads announced yesterday.

The architects' plan for the Apparel and Accessories Building at the World's Fair has been filed with the board of design, it was announced yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, president of the Fair Corporation. Joseph Love, president

Nobel Prizeman Sinclair Lewis made his professional stage debut in the Town Hall tonight. Indulging himself in a little type-casting, he offered himself as the Vermont country editor in "It Can't Happen Here," put on for a Summer

A most compleatt angler," Professor William McTavish of New York University went all the other anglers one better yesterday. Instead of telling one fish story, he told two fish stories, and what is more important, the fish in question were both on the same line.

Warren Wright, patron of Chicago racing and one of the few Western members of the Jockey Club, completed a double today in .the Seneca Claiming Stakes with Taxes. This 3-year-old, a brown son of Eternal, was entered to be claimed for $4,000, but he was back in the Calumet Farm barn again tonight.
Resting fast on rocks and mud with water flooding her engine room,. the Brazilian training ship Almirante Saldanha tonight was high out of water with an observable list to port.

Changes in New York Stock Exchange rules, announced yesterday, allow member firms to pay security traders on a commission basis. The rule also allows commission or contingent methods of payment for foreign exchange traders, commodity traders and other brokerage house employes in difficult-to-classify categories.
The stock market here was generally quiet today and prices dropped in most sections. Gilt-edge issues were dull, and an easier tendency was evident among the foreign bonds.

The Citizens Budget Commission, commenting yesterday on the report by Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick that the city faces a deficit of $27,750,000 in its 1939-40 budget, declared that "the financial condition of the city at this moment is as alarming as it has ever been in its history."

A rejection of the demands of maritime unions seeking union control in the hiring of personnel on government-owned ships has been sent to the New York Maritime Council by Admiral Emory S. Land, chairman of the Maritime Commission, it was announced yesterday.

A resolution was adopted by the Suffolk County Board of Supervisors today instructing County.Attorney Edgar F. Hazelton to take any "necessary steps" in opposition to the application of the Long Island Railroad to discontinue service on its five-mile spur between Bridgehampton and Sag Harbor.

Each of the following Field Artillery Reserve officers, assigned or attached to the 5th Field Artillery and 25th Field Artillery. is ordered to active duty Aug. 7 at Madison Barracks, New York, for training with the C. M. T. C.:

The Interstate Commerce Commission today granted authority to the Kalamazoo, Allegan Grand Rapids Railroad Company to extend from July 1, 1938, to July 1, 1968, the maturity of $840,000 of 5 per cent first-mortgage bonds.

The PepsiCola Company of Canada, which was recently declared to have-infringed the trade name of the CocaCola Company.of Canada, obtained from the Exchequer Court today an order for a ?tay of execution of judgment for fifteen days, pending an appeal which will be taken to the Dominion Supreme Court.

A commuter's seaplane in which Henry P. Davison, a partner in J. P. Morgan Co.; William Frazer, a friend; and the pilot, Nelson Miles, were riding at 9 A. M. yesterday struck the tugboat Joseph J. O'Brien as it taxied toward the seaplane ramp at the foot of East Thirty-first Street, after landing from Port Washington, L. I.
The names of 148 high school students in the State to whom have been awarded Cornell scholarships as a result of examinations were announced today by the University of the State of New York.

Warning that wage reductions might be the necessary alternative to higher prices in the steel industry, E. S. Ballard, counsel for the Inland Steel Company, told the Public Contracts Board of the Labor Department today that his company reserved the right to contest the validity of the Walsh-Healey act tinder which the board has held hearings for two days.

Trading was fair to slow in local markets yesterday. Markets on traefer meats little changed from Monday. The local slaughter was below normal on most classes of livestock. Early trading in kosher meats indicated beef to be higher, other classes steady to weak.

For the first time since the Triborough Bridge was opened two years ago the lift spanning the Harlem River failed to function properly yesterday morning. As a result for nearly an hour traffic to and from Manhattan was rerouted across the Bronx section.

The Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway declared yesterday the interest on the company's 4 per cent adjustment-mortgage bonds for the year ended on June 30. The first installment of 2 per cent on the stamped bonds will be paid on Sept. 1.

Bonds were highly irregular yesterday in sharply curtailed trading on the New York Stock Exchange. The main body of speculative favorites in the corporate list was subjected to considerable profittaking in early dealings and, in most cases, the late recovery movement did not eliminate the earlier declines.
Emerging from the realm of mere possibility, Herman J. Mankiewicz's "The Meal Ticket" is definitely due for a production by George Abbott next season, Mr. A.'s office admitted yesterday.

Deposits in the mutual savings banks of the United States, which operate in seventeen States, amounted to $10,167,241,377 on June 30, and depositors numbered 15,129,874, it was announced yesterday by Henry R. Kinsey, president of the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks and president of the Williamsburg Savings Bank, Brooklyn.
From far away Galapagos Islands, President Roosevelt today sent greetings to Poughkeepsie neighbors who celebrated the 150th anniversary of New York's ratification of the Constitution.

Two owners and two employes of the Mishkin Coal Company, 137 Varick Avenue, Brooklyn, were found guilty and fined yesterday by Magistrate Edgar Bromberger in Municipal Term of Magistrate's Court, Brooklyn, for violating the administrative code in delivering short-weight coal.

Close on the heels of the announcement that the British Government will send Viscount Runciman to Prague as an "adviser," the Czechoslovak Government at last released today the details of the draft of the nationalities statute and the draft of the language statute, which are to serve as bases in the forthcoming negotiations.

One of the most important points under discussion during the early stages of the TVA investigation at Knoxville is the question of power development vs. flood control. The question was raised by Dr. Arthur E. Morgan when he testified before the joint Congressional committee that the great dams which public funds have built could be operated simultaneously for power and for flood control,

In the fiscal year ended April 30, 1938, the Court and Remsen Streets Building, at 22 Court Street, Brooklyn, showed earnings at the rate of 31/4 per cent annually on the $2,980,000 first mortgage bonds outstanding, according to Amott, Baker Co., Inc.

Mr. and Mrs. H. Lester Cuddihy will celebrate the twentieth anniversary of their marriage with a dinner dance on Saturday at Canoe Place Inn. They will entertain a large house party at their home in Water Mill for the occasion. Guests will be Mr. and Mrs. Walter E.

Dominant in the New York World's Fair will be the theme center, the perisphere and trylon. Dominant inside the 200-foot sphere will be a magic carpet-a magic de carpet that will make Aladdin's seem a puny bit of legerdemain.

Miss Nancy Patricia O'Brien, daughter of Mrs. Florence Mills O'Brien of 333 East Fifty-third Street, formerly of Chattanooga, Tenn., was married yesterday morning in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church to Jackson Chapman

James Gardner Lock, who for many years headed the firm of Thomas J. Lock Son, interior decorators, retiring in 1921, died on Monday of a coronary thrombosis in his home at 611 King Avenue, City Island. His age was 76.

The prolonged period of rainfall, heat and relatively high humidity probably accounted for the increased general and infant mortality rates during the week ended Saturday last, according to Thomas J. Duffield, Registrar of Records of the Health Department.

The final codicil of Napoleon's will, dated April 27, 1821, and thought to contain his last written words, was sold to Gabriel Wells of New York for [Pound]820 at a. sale of rare books and historical documents held at Sotheby's today.

The will of B. H. Kroger, capitalist who died last week at the age of 78, was filed in Probate Court today, disposing of an estate unestimated in value but said by court officials to aggregate millions of dollars.

Miss Gertrude M. Groves, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Aloysius J. Groves of Newark, will be married to Sanford Atwater Farrand, son of Mrs. Herbert Underwood Farrand of this place, on Aug. 6 at the Groves's home.

John Roxborough, co-manager of the world heavyweight champion, Joe Louis, said tonight he had cabled the United States Ambassador to Germany to protest the showing in Germany of a "patched-up" motion picture of the second Louis-Max Schmeling fight which he said was giving German fans the "Wrong impression."

J. Howard Denny, who came from St. Louis to become the new president of Franklin Simon Co., Inc., was welcomed into the ranks of local merchants by heads of New York and Brooklyn department stores at a luncheon held yesterday at the Empire State Club.

Heeding the advice of Governor Lehman, sent to its members a week ago, the Constitutional Convention has killed the proposal to enforce through the Constitution a twenty-year expenditure of half our automobile and gasoline taxes on State highways.

Following the familiar pattern of many sessions recently when prices were without rallying power, the stock market turned dull on the decline yesterday. The final tone was heavy, with losses ranging from fractions to 2 points.

District Attorney William F. X. Geoghan of Brooklyn declared yesterday that his personally conducted prosecution of his staff assistant, William F. McGuinness, and George Murphy, city-employed elevator operator, charged with conspiracy to obstruct justice by attempting to "fix" a perjury case for $100, "will be followed to wherever the ramifications may lead, regardless of who is affected."
Governor Kraschel tonight rejected a formal demand by the Maytag Company that National Guard troops maintaining martial law in Newton permit the washing machine plant to operate.

A man giving his name as Vincent Brown, 30 years old, of 134 West Eighty-fourth Street, was in Beekman Street Hospital last night with a bullet wound in his left leg, following an alleged attempt to rifle the desks in The Times of London offices, Rooms 707-709, The New York Sun Building.

Major Alfred Vernon Dalrymple, who came here five years ago from Califfornia to serve briefly as the last Federal prohibition director, died last night in Emergency Hospital of a crushed chest and other inJuries suffered in an automobile accident Saturday night. He was 62 years old.

Plans for houses in three boroughs were filed by architects yesterday. Most of the new housing units will be erected in scattered communities in Queens. Much of the activity in Manhattan and Brooklyn was confined to plans for changes in existing structures.
The Port of New York Authority announced yesterday the beginning of a campaign to eliminate troublesome marine "grade crossings" in the New York area.

Judge Donnellan of General Sessions denied yesterday without comment the motion of counsel for Assemblyman Edward S. Moran Jr., a ranking Democratic member of the Assembly from Brooklyn, for an inspection of the minutes of the New York County grand jury which, on June 24 last, indicted him.
His clothing enveloped in flames, Robert Woods, 23, leaped from a 60-foot oil derrick to his death last night when the Pyramid Oil Company's No. 2 well caught fire.
The Official News Agency announces today that by the time limit for taking the oath of allegiance to the State by evangelical ministers has been extended until Sept. 30.
With Fred Wolcott of Rice Institute again leading the way, United States athletes won six of eight events in a track and field meet today.

The big field in the Canadian amateur golf championship swung through the first round today, leaving sixty-two survivors, including a half-dozen from the United States, for the second round tomorrow morning.

156th St. 763 E, 5-story tenement, 45x100; Amelia Ruter against Alboric Realty Corp, due $41,486, taxes, etc, 2,738; to plaintiff for $4,000. By HENRY G. WALTEMADE 133d St, 740 E, 3-story tenement. 16.8x100; Home Owners Loan Corp against Elvira Minano; due $6,713; to plaintiff for 4500.

Officials of the Royal Canadian Yacht Club announced tonight that with forty of fifty craft in a 105-mile Freeman Cup race on Lake Ontario safely in harbor, the sloop Patricia was the leader on corrected time. The final standing will be determined tomorrow.

David E. Lilienthal, TVA director in charge of power, admitted today under cross-examination by Representative Charles Wolverton, New $ Jersey Republican, that TVA was still in the red and operating at a loss in its sale of electricity at the yardstick rates established soon e after it was established in 1933.
The body or a man Identified by State police as Wayne Marshall, Ri missing Philadelphia publisher, was found today beside his automobile on a little-used road near this place.

United States Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. received from Foreign Minister Georges Bonnet today information regarding the general European situation, particularly concerning Spain, Czechoslovakia and the operation of the Anglo-French entente.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated July 23: Capehart, Cmdr. W., 11th Naval District, to command Fleet Air Base, San Pedro Calif. McKenzie, Lt. Cmdr. E. R., Philadelphia, Pa., to Bureau of Supplies and Accounts, Washington.

While a magnesium flare cast an eerie light on the scene and thousands of persons watched in horror, John W. Ward, 25 years old, ended eleven hours of agonizing suspense at 10:38 o'clock last night by plunging to his death from a seventeenth floor window ledge of the Hotel Gotham, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street.

The Tide Water Associated Oil Company showed a net income of $5,992,705 for the six months ended on June 30, after all charges and estimated Feueral income tax, according to the semi-annual statement issued yesterday by William F. Humphrey, president.

Federal Judge H. Ford and counsel for the government, and the fifty-five defendants accused of conspiring to deny to labor the rights guaranteed by the Wagner act, sat around a table today in an informal session which provided a sort of preview of the charge the judge will deliver to the jury.
John J. Daly of New York was re-elected president of the State Restaurant Liquor Dealers Association at its second annual convention here today.
Although Deere Co. declared the regular quarterly dividend of 35 cents on the preferred stock, action on the common dividend was postponed until adjourned directors meeting on September 20.

Yorkshire, Lancashire and Middlesex are providing cricket followers with one of the closest races the English County cricket competition has experienced in years. After two and a half months of keen play Yorkshire and Lancashire are deadlocked in first posito, while Middlesex is close behind.
ALLEN-At Minneapolis, Minn., on July 24, 1938, Charlotte M. Allen, formerly of New York City. Services at the Greenwood Cemetery Chapel, Brooklyn, Thursday at 2 P. M.

Fifty-four pictures will be released by RKO on the 1938-39 schedule, one of the largest programs in the history of the studio. Besides forty studio-made films, the company has acquired Herbert Wilcox's "Sixty Glorious Years," with Anna Neagle and Anton Walbrook, to be made in England in color.

Arthur C. Nickell Jr. of this place has announced the engagement and forthcoming marriage of his daughter, Miss Mary Anna Nickell, to George Calhoun Wells, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Miller Wells of Upper Montclair, N. J.

D. Frederick Burnett, State Alcoholic Beverage Commissioner, denied today the application of a New Jersey match company for approval of an advertising tie-up on match books between a whisky distributing company and an amusement park.

Directors of the Detroit Edison Company, at a special meeting held here yesterday, voted to retire the company's outstanding issue of $15,000,000 of 5 per cent bonds, series E, due Oct. 1, 1952. The issue was called for payment on Oct. 1, next, at 105.

Word was received here last night of the death yesterday in Beverly Hills, Calif., of Olive May, a retired actress, 65 years old, known in private life as Mrs. Olive May Albaugh. She had appeared in support of Maude Adams and was in the cast of "Arizona," among other productions of the last generation.

The engagement of $1,263,000 gold t in England for shipment here was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. This was the first gold to be taken in London for shipment to this country since June 8. Details concerning the shipment were not available, but it appeared to involve special conditions as London's gold price continued above the level at which profitable transfers ordinarily can be made.

Lieut. Col. Stewart S. Giffin, U. S.A., yesterday took the stand before the twelve-officer general court at Governors Island which is trying him on charges of drunkenness and ungentlemanly conduct to deny that he had been under the influence of liquor

Charges that Federal office-holders are being assessed 5 per cent of their salaries to aid Senator McAdoo were made in a telegram sent to the Senate Committee on Campaign Expenditures by James W. Mellen of Los Angeles, an anti-New Deal Democratic candidate for the Senate.
The Reichsbank's statement as of July 25 shows the following changesfrom the preceding week in thousands of marks:

William L. Crow Construction Company has been awarded the contract for construction of the new two-story faculty apartment house for the New York Institute for the Education of the Blind, the corner of Waring and Colden Avenues, the Bronx.

The present arrangement under which the Association of Japanese Exporters of Cotton Piece Goods agrees to limit yearly exports to the Philippines has been continued for a year in modified form, the State Department announced today.
Mr. and Mrs. William B. Trowbridge have returned from their ranch in Oracle, Ariz., and are at the Plaza. Sir Orme Rowan-Hamilton, Chief Justice of Bermuda, is at the New Weston.
The coalition of the Republicans and the American Labor party, a move which threatens continued Democratic control of the State Senate, threw the local political arena into an uproar yesterday.
A hysterical woman stood at a fourthfloor window of the San Carlos Hotel for fifteen minutes today threatening to jump, while a crowd watched at downtown Fifth and Olive Streets.

Rear Admiral H. A. Wiley, retired, told Great Lakes Port Authority officials today of the Maritime Commission's program to revive the American merchant marine and operate it with skilled men carefully trained in government schools.
Secretary Ickes announced today PWA loans of $137,000 and grants of $12,586,928 for 161 non-Federal projects in twenty-nine States, having an estimated total construction cost of $27,972,314.

The National Association of Attorneys General, meeting here concurrently with the American Bar Association, adopted a resolution today providing for the appointment of a committee to "prepare and report a study of the fields of governmental activity in which encroachments of Federal authority on the sovereignty of the States are threatened."
Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick sold yesterday an issue of $10,000,000 of New York City revenue bills on a 0.40 per cent interest basis. The bills are dated July 27 and will mature on Oct. 26.
At the Harvard Summer session a former, Rhodes scholar from Oregon whose poems have been published by

Neglect to appeal within the required time from a decision of the Board of Examiners of the New York City Board of Education has caused dismissal of the application of Miss Toby Rein to the State Department of Education.

" One of the troubles with business today is that misleading propaganda has caused a good many people to doubt the efficacy of the present system," Louis K. Comstock, president of the Merchants Association of New York,

Word has been received by relatives here of the birth of a daughter on July 20 to Sir Hugh Carnaby de Marie Haggerston, Bart., and Lady Haggerston, at Ellingham Hall, their home in Chathill, Northumberland, England.
The suspension of Cletus Elwood Poffenberger, young right-handed pitcher, has been lifted and he will remain with the Tigers, Walter O. Briggs, owner of the Detroit Baseball Company, announced today.
Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain, who answers many questions about the government in the House of Commons, had this one tossed at him today:

The atmosphere in all of Palestine today is charged with tension. No one has yet been apprehended in connection with yesterday's bomb outrage in the Haifa market, but the Arabs insist that the bomb was placed there by Jews.

Twenty-three athletes, comprising the last of the United States teams to invade Europe this Summer, sailed for Berlin on the North German Lloyd liner Europa early this morning. They were in charge of Emmet Brunson of Rice Institute, manager of the team, and Ward Haylett of Kansas Agricultural College, coach.

Despite an aggregate increase of $1,005,569,999 in internal revenue collections in the fiscal year 1938 over those of the preceding year, the recently ended twelvemonth showed a drop of more than $83,000,000 in those taxes which reflected business conditions in that period, according to a fiscal-year-end statement by the Bureau of Internal Revenue today.

Unhappy home relationships and inability of children to adjust themselves to their environment are found to be frequent causes of school failure, Dr. Frank J. O' Brien, director of the Board of Education's child guidance bureau indicated yesterday in making public his five-year report.

A request for additional information concerning the character and volume of trading on the New York Curb Exchange in twelve bond issues for which unlisted trading privileges were granted in January, made by Abner Goldstone, counsel for the Securities and Exchange Commission, enlivened a hearing today before Robert Reeder, trial examiner, on applications by the Curb for authority to trade unlisted in four more issues.

Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., has addressed a letter to holders of optional 6 per cent convertible debentures due Sept. 1, 1939, of which $29,400,000 are outstanding, asking them to deposit their debentures under a plan of exchange providing for the delivery of an equal principal amount of new 6 per cent debentures maturing in 1948.

North Beach Airport, the $22,000,000 air terminal for domestic and international airlines which New York City is building in Queens, won the endorsement yesterday of a group of engineers, technicians and pilots representing commercial aviation companies that probably will use the field when it is finished early next Spring.
The eleven-story Cluett Building at 22-8 West Nineteenth Street running through to West Eighteenth Street was bought in at auction yesterday by the New York Life Insurance Company for $410,000.

Endorsement of Julian S. Myrick for trustee and Robert L. Jones for treasurer of the National Association of Life Underwriters has been announced by the Life Underwriters Association of the City of flew York.

The Community Power and Light Corporation and its subsidiary, Southwestern Electric Company, both of New York City, have filed an application with the SEC for approval of the sale of $300,000 of New Mexico Utilities Company 5 per cent general mortgage bonds. Series A, due on Nov. 1. 1955.

Plans for the annual Chesapeake Bay Fishing Fair are progressing rapidly and according to all reports the dawn of Aug. 27 will find more anglers at Rock Hall, Md., than have ever been seen at that fishing center.
Turpentine firm, 231/2c; sales 29 barrels; receipts 629 barrels; shipments 100 barrels; stock 42,548 barrels. Resin firm; sales 197; receipts 3,514; shipments 1,576: stock 189.806.

Attorneys for Harrison Williams, public utilities operator, and the New Empire Corporation moved in Supreme Court yesterday to require the plaintiff in a $5,474,353 stockholders' suit against them and other defendants to submit a "more definite" complaint.

The Constitutional Convention's Committee on Industrial Relations reported out by a 9-to-5 vote today a proposed constitutional amendment which would guarantee labor the right to organize and bargain collectively.

Clansmen moved down from the hills into this sleepy little village tonight to attend the biggest event in its history-the wedding tomorrow of Miss Louise Miller of New York, granddaughter of the late Andrew Carnegie,

Every part of the country will share in an upswing in the automobile business in the Fall, according to members of the executive committee of -the American Finance Conference of the Independent Automobile Finance Trade Association, who met here today.

A total of thirteen persons had been arrested tonight in connection with yesterday's attempt to assassinate Governor Blanton Winship. Among them was Elias Escobar, arrested today after an all-night search.
Bob Pastor, New York heavyweight, was indefinitely suspended today from fighting in New Jersey by Abe J. Greene, State Athletio Commissioner.

Commemoration services marking the 150th anniversary of New York State's ratification of the Federal Constitution were held today in the Assembly Chamber by the Albany Constitutional Observance Committee, headed by Representative William T. Byrne.

The most drastic code in stage history to outlaw speculation in the sale of theatre tickets, under which actors will refuse to work for a producer who countenances gouging of the public, was signed late yesterday afternoon by the League of New York Theatres, the organization of producers and managers, and the Actors Equity Association.

Governor Moore announced today he had written to Secretary of Agriculture Henry A. Wallace asking for the establishment of a Federal regional experiment station in New Jersey to study the marketing of food products, as provided under the new Farm Act.

Approximately two-thirds of all the daily newspaper publishing houses in the country have contracted for the AD and OD advertising series of the American Association of Advertising Agencies, according to the organization yesterday.

A. S. Kirby, head of a syndicate which operates the Drake and Blackstone hotels here and the Town House in Los Angeles, announced today the signing of a new tenyear lease for the Blackstone. At the same time Mr. Kirby disclosed that a $235,000 remodeling program has been started at the Blackstone.

Representatives of three up-State New York counties suggested today to Federal Judge Harland B. Howe that they be authorized to negotiate with receivers for the Rutland Railroad "with a view to working out an equitable plan whereby the road may continue operation."
Sir Stanley Leathes, a distinguished civil servant and a member of the triumvirate which edited the Cambridge Modern History, died yesterday. He was 77 years old.

The three-story and basement house at 640 St. Marks Avenue and the two-story one-family house at 416 Crown Street, Brooklyn, have been sold, M. C. O'Brien, Inc., broker in both deals, reported yesterday.

Dr. Joseph E. Higi issued a bulletin late tonight in which he stated that Tony Galento's condition is very encouraging, and that the outlook is now better than at any time since the pugilist entered the hospital.
George D. Aiken, the Governor of Vermont, has delivered his completed manuscript, "Speaking From Vermont," to Stokes, who will publish it on Sept. 22.

J. B. PRIESTLEY must have been in a terrible rush to write a novel about the American Southwest. That is about the kindest thing to say of his latest work, a harmless business (he calls it a "fantasie") entitled "The Doomsday Men."*
Willem van Hoogstraten made his season's second appearance at the Lewisohn Stadium last night conducting a program which featured the Sibelius Second symphony in D major.

Roy C. Johnson, 23 years old, of 665 Eighty-eighth Street, Brooklyn, told the police he was robbed yesterday afternoon of $700 in cash belonging to the real estate and insurance firm of the John F. James Company, 193 Montague Street, Brooklyn, for which he works as cashier, by two men who forced him into an automobile and drove him through Brooklyn for about an hour.

Declaring that the naming of streets after certain World War veterans while others were ignored was discriminatory, Mayor La Guardia refused to sign fourteen such bills yesterday after holding public hearings on them at the Summer City Hall in the World's Fair grounds.
Ernest J. Martin, a pioneer scenic artist in the motion picture business, died today in the New Rochelle Hospital after a long illness at the age of 69.

On arriving from Boston after winning the Longwood Bowl, Robert L. Riggs started his defense of the Seabright Bowl by dropping the opening set of his match with John Shostrom of Chicago today at the Seabright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club.

William Gillespie, former Scarborough School ace, who will enter the University of North Carolina in the Fall, battled his way into the final round of the Eastern junior tennis championship by disposing of William Umstaedter of Millburn, N. J., in a thrilling three-set struggle, 6--1, 8-10, 7-5, on the courts of the West Side Tennis Club at Forest Hills yesterday.

Directors of the United States Steel Corporation met briefly yesterday to vote the regular preferred dividend, indicating no small degree of encouragement over business prospects for the Fall and Winter.

Plans for further development of communications between French IndoChina and China's southwestern provinces were understood to be involved in a journey that T. V. Soong, former Chinese Finance Minister, is making through those areas.

Thomas Hamer Stokes, former postmaster of Lincoln, Ill., and former editor of The Lincoln Times, died today at the age of 90. In 1880 he entered the newspaper field as editor of the Times and in 1893 he sold the paper and left the Democratic party because he was not in favor of "free silver."

President Roosevelt today appointed seven authorities on public health to attend the tenth Pan American sanitary conference at Bogota in September. Surgeon General Thomas Parran of the Public Health Service was appointed chairman of the delegation.

Led by groceries and meats with a rise of 18 per cent, seven divisions of local department stores scored sales increases in June, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

A mass search for records of personal funds that might throw light on the operations of a racket in the electrical industry has been undertaken by District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey's office, it was learned yesterday.

The dollar volume of retail financing of new passenger automobiles for June this year was 61 per cent below June, 1937, and about 64 per cent below June, 1936, the Department of Commerce announced today.

It was learned today that the Italian Government had issued an expulsion order last Thursday against Dr. Paul Cremona, Rome representative of The Christian Science Monitor, a resident of Italy for seventeen years and dean of American correspondents here.

Prince Franz I of Liechtenstein, ruler of the tiny principality between Switzerland and Austria, died last night in his Czechoslovak castle at Feldsberg at the age of 85. His grandnephew, the Regent Franz Joseph. succeeds to the title.

Frank Werner, a former deputy Internal Revenue collector, attached to the Third Collection District at 341 Ninth Avenue, Manhattan, pleaded not guilty yesterday before United States Commissioner Edward E. Fay, in Brooklyn, on a charge of bribery. Werner was held in bail of $5,000 to await a hearing on Aug. 10.
Boxed gift sets, which were unusually successful last year, were featured again in a preview of the Cannon towel line for Fall, shown yesterday at the Cannon Mills office at 70 Worth Street.

New York City and the United States Government will have to wait for taxes and interest totaling nearly $500,000 so that a reorganization plan for the Steinway Railway Company, one of the last street car lines operating in Queens, may be effected as contemplated by a bondholders' committee, Supreme Court Justice Peter H. Daly ruled in Queens yesterday.
Captain E. W.' McKee, director of athletics at the Naval Academy, today announced that Max Bishop, former Philadelphia Athletio star, had received a three-year contract as Navy Baseball coach.

A hare and a tortoise had a race yesterday afternoon just three blocks from Wall Street. Their contest was the leading event in the "animal Olympics" held by the Boys Athletic League at its 26 Washington Street Playground. As in Aesop's fable, the tortoise won.
Chairman John D. M. Hamilton of the Republican National Committee asserted today that another war would bring the United States "under as rigid a dictatorship as the world has ever seen."
Police chiefs of the State in convention here opposed today the passage of proposals now before the Constitutional Convention, which they say would practically nullify police work.
Mrs. Maude Middledith Tremaine, wife of State Controller Morris S. Tremaine, died tonight at Saratoga Springs. Her age was 63.

Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain expressed the emphatic belief today that the European situation had taken a turn for the better and that the war clouds were not so menacing as they had been a few months ago.

Former Mayor James J. Walker of New York recovered today the good-will plaque that he received in 1927 from an official of the Cuban Government. The plaque, mounted on a heavy wooden base, contains a link of the anchor chain of the battleship Maine, blown up in Havana Harbor in 1898.

On the anniversary of Austria's declaration of war against Serbia which started the World War twenty-four years ago tomorrow, a large majority of Americans in a national survey say they would sympathize with England and France if those two powers went to war with Italy and Germany.

Following is the text of salient passages in thee address of Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain on foreign affairs before the House of Commons today: I cannot imagine any one in any part of the House who would disagree with what we have so frequently declared to be the main aim of the government's foreign policy, namely:

The Phillies gave the National League-leading Pirates a 6-to-5 setback today by a ninth-inning rally which netted two runs. The Phils' triumph came as a result of an error by Arky Vaughan on Atwood's roller,

One of the most brilliant meteors seen in modern times flashed across the northern sky at exactly 10 o'clock last night in a spectacular display of cosmic fireworks. Many persons who saw it wondered if it was an explosion, a crashing airplane or a fireworks display.

A successful business organization cannot be conducted without an efficient sales staff, Colonel Jacob Ruppert told 200 members of the Sales Executive Club and their guests yesterday. The colonel was host to the club at luncheon at the Ruppert Brewery, 1,639 Third Avenue.

Blasting his thirtieth and thirty-first home runs of the season, big Hank Greenberg led Detroit to a 6-to-5 decision over the Washington Senators today to celebrate the Tigers' homecoming from an unsuccessful eastern invasion.

A few minutes after sending his secretary to the bank, Meyer Marlow, 48 years old, an attorney, shot and killed himself about 10 A. M. yesterday in his offices at 225 West Thirty-fourth Street. He was discovered by the employee when she returned from the errand.

William O. Douglas, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, told the American Bar Association today that the commission and the utility industry were just getting started on the problems of corporate simplification and geographical integration, but that they were now seriously preparing to tackle them.

The immediate settlement of a large estate and the payment of a $100,000 legacy to a 30-year-old man, who during a two years' disappearance washed dishes and drove trucks to keep from starving, was made possible today when Donald L. Chase, the heir, was found in Los Angeles.

The plight of the foreign community of nearly 100, including more than fifty Americans, in Kuling, a Summer resort and missionary center on Lushan Mountain, ten miles southeast of Kiukiang, is causing grave concern here.

Because consumer acceptance of color coordination in accessories has spread to all price ranges, merchants are offered an unparalleled opportunity this Fall to promote multiple sales of costume accessories, according to Miss Ruth Niclas, stylist for Kirby, Block Co., resident buyers.

Ray Fabiani, wrestling promoter, has brought suit for $25,400 against the Twentieth Century Sporting Club, Inc., for alleged breach of contract in failing to install a cooling system in the Hippodrome at Sixth Avenue and Forty-third Street.

Harold P. Farrington was elected president of the Commonwealth Gas Corporation yesterday. Other officers elected were J. Truman Bidwell, vice president; Ronald M. Craigmyle, treasurer, and J. Bay Robinson, secretary.
The German Government apparently does not consider itself responsible for the appointment of Viscount Runciman as mediator of the Czech-German conflict.

Jockey Fred Scheih gave Ral Parr's King Pharamond a handy ride today to complete a double in Rockingham Park's six-furlong feature. King Pharamond scored by two and a half lengths over W. H. Denham's Mama's Boy, who placed a length ahead of Mrs. P. A. Shaw's Foggy Morn.

Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine, riding from his Brooklyn home toward his Manhattan office, stopped at 9:20 A. M. yesterday to supervise the freeing of a man wedged under the front of a trolley car in Grand Army Plaza, Brooklyn.

The Jersey City Giants breezed to a 9--1 victory over the Newark Bears tonight with Roy Joiner allowing nine hits and blanking the league leaders until the ninth inning. It was the first triumph of the season for the Little Giants at the local park.

No official explanation can obscure the significance of the almost unprecedented role an Englishman is cast to play in Central Europe. Mr. Chamberlain told the House of Commons yesterday that Lord Runciman, the former President of the Board of Trade, was not going to act as arbitrator in the triangular dispute over the German minority in Czechoslovakia.

The' British transatlantic seaplane Mercury departed for Lisbon at 1:05 A. M. today (New York Time). The Mercury, upper half of a new pickaback plane combination, arrived yesterday from Botwood, Nfld., and is completing her first round trip between Foynes, Ireland, and New York.
The American and British oil companies' petition for an injunction against President Lazaro Cardenas's expropriation decree was denied by the Supreme Court late last night.

Among the contracts for residential space reported by brokers yesterday were a number for space in buildings in Park Avenue. Included was one for ten rooms and four baths at 911 Park Avenue taken by Arthur Smadbeck through the Morgenthan-Seixas Company, Inc., broker, and Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., agent.

THE National League, like the American Leagdle, maintains a Service Bureau. The difference is that the National League Service Bureau is located in this city whereas the American League Service Bureau is in Chicago. That makes the National League Service Bureau a bit handier.

The Greenwich Orchestra of the Federal Music Project will be heard in concert this evening at the Federal Music Theatre. John Barnett will conduct. The first American performances of nine Gaelic songs will be given tonight in Philosophy Hall, Columbia University, in a lecture-recital by Professor Eileen O'Reilly of Hunter College, and Julia Lennon, soprano.

Mrs. Muriel Edwards of 436 West Twentieth Street died Monday at the Summer home of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. John Costello, in East Paterson, N. J. Born twenty-six years ago in East Paterson, Mrs. Edwards attended Pomona College in California and New York University, being a member of the women's swimming team at the latter.

Donald Hawley of Orange, former New York University captain, gained the quarter-finals of the Northern New Jersey tennis championship in defense of the title he won a year ago, when he defeated Robert Kerdasha of Clinton, S. C., 6--3, 8--6, at the Westfield Tennis Club today.

A funeral service for Archibald E. Henderson, one of the first Americans to drive an ambulance in the World War, who was killed Sunday night in an automobile accident at Jones Beach, will be held tomorrow night at the Forbell Funeral Parlor here.

In an opinion handed down yesterday Judge Clarence G. Galston in the United States District Court in Brooklyn for the second time held that the Spanish steamship Navemar is the property of the Compania Espafiola de Navegacion Maritima,
Frances, Countess of Warwick, a famous beauty of the Edwardian era and the first British Countess to become a Socialist, died today in her home in Dunmow, Essex, at the age of 76.

The increase in maximum interstate passenger fares on Eastern railways, from 2 cents a mile to 21/2, went into effect this week. Its effect on the railway situation will not be of the first importance.

Industrial unrest in the United States cost this country $5,000,000,000 last year and $300,000,000 the year before, Dr. Allen A. Stockdale, head of the speakers' bureau of the National Association of Manufacturers, told members of the National Typewriter and Office Machine Dealers Association at the group's annual convention in the Hotel New Yorker yesterday.

Knocking the daylight out of a long afternoon, as well as the Browns, who seemed to be short of everything except pitchers who could not pitch, the Yankees opened their third drive of the year through the West today by bowling over Gabby Street's forlorn tailenders in both ends of a double-header.
