EATON, MINNIE G. (April 11, 1938). Gross assets, $15,282; net, $13,621. To Marion Jones Kimbrough, niece, specific bequests and one-half residue; Fred G. Jones, nephew, one-half residue. Chief assets, -mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $10,659. Dunn, Daly Bain, attorneys. 176 Broadway.

Stocks drifted in narrow range at lower levels and closed heavy in less active trading; turnover, 1,252,470 shares. United States Government issues steady and higher, corporation and foreign bonds irregular; transactions, $7,114,150.
Behind a guard of 150 men appointed by President Homer Martin of the United Automobile Workers of America, the secret trial of four suspended officers got under way today. Little headway was made.

Lone Star Gas Corporation, Wilmington, Del., and five of its subsidiaries have filed declarations with the Securities and Exchange Commission under the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935 covering the issuance and sale of about $45,000,000 of debentures and notes as follows:

The Procurement Division of the United States Treasury placed orders yesterday for the account of the Works Progress Administration for a total of $1,010,822.23 in men's and boys' clothing. The purchase is one of several contemplating a total expenditure of $10,000,000 for garments to be distributed to needy persons.

A repudiation of a quotation ascribed to it by Virginio Gayda, editor of the Giornale d'Italia, who is regarded in Italy as the mouthpiece of Premier Benito Mussolini, was issued yesterday by The American Hebrew.

The eleven young men who will line up on floodlighted Soldier Field the night of Aug. 31 to battle the Washington Redskins, champions of the National Football League, were named tonight from a national poll that produced a record vote of 8.526.328.
Colonel Sir Henry Streatfeild, formerly equerry to King Edward VII and private secretary to Queen Alexandra for fifteen years, died today in his home in Chiddingstone, Kent, at the age of 81.
Bob Feller's father, William, came from Iowa today and watched his 19-yearold son regain control to turn in his eleventh victory of the season against five defeats.

The engagement of Miss Elsie Lindenbaum, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Lindenbaum of 229 East Seventy-ninth Street, to Elihu A. Novick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis P. Novick of this city, has been announced by her parents.

The battle which opened here yesterday between the Democratic Legislature and the Republican judiciary of Pennsylvania was enlarged today by Joseph F. Guffey, Senator and political boss, who brought the State under Democratic control in 1934 for the first time since the Civil War.
Luncheon, Kiwanis Club, Hotel McAlpin, 12:30 P. M. "The Forgotten Children of Spain," Eric G. Muggeridge.

Carding a 72, one over regulation figures, Frank Strafaci of Lakeville won low gross honors in the Long Island Golf Association's oneday amateur tournament held over the Sound View Golf Club's course today. Sixty-one plavers competed.

Sheriff Jacob S. Dreyer of Suffolk County technically seized Camp Siegfried here today in a step to collect the $10,000 fine imposed the German-American Settlement League, Inc., operator of the camp, for violation of the State Civil Rights Law.

Ex-Governor Alfred E. Smith again took the center of the stage today at a crowded session of the Constitutional Convention and engaged in protracted discussion of the proposal of Joseph Clark Baldwin, New York City Councilman, for low-cost housing, slum clearance and the contracting of State and local debts therefor.

The Spanish Government announced tonight that its forces had captured ten villages, seven strategic hills and 3,000 prisoners in a smashing thrust across the Ebro River on the Catalan front in Northeastern Spain.

Directors of the United States Steel Corporation voted yesterday to pay the regular quarterly dividend of $1.75 a share on the preferred stock, in the amount of $6,304,919, despite the net loss of $5,010,426 sustained in the second quarter of 1938, which is compared with a loss of $1,292,151 in the first quarter and contrasts with a profit of $36,173,682 in the second quarter of 1937.

Rather than submit to a demand by strikers that a 15 per cent wage cut posted July 14 be taken down, directors of the Vaughan Furniture Company, capitalized at $400,000 and employing nearly 300 workers, voted today to liquidate.

The German. Embassy asked the State Department today to permit a German plane to land in Alaska on a projected round-the-world flight. Embassy officials said the plane was a Focke Wulf multi-motored craft carrying a crew of four.
Mrs. Dodge Sloane gave a dinner last night at her villa here for Mr. and Mrs. Morton L. Schwartz, Mr. and Mrs. Jackson Dyckman, Douglass W. Paige and Herbert Bayard Swope. Mrs. Wesson Seyburn,

Frederick W. Neumann, a lawyer with offices in Jersey City, died this morning at Homeopathic Hospital in East Orange after an operation for appendicitis. He was born fifty-five years ago in Jersey City and had lived here twenty-six years.
Sammy Luftspring, 146, Toronto welterweight, outpointed Vincent Pimpinella, 148, Red Hook, in the feature eight-round bout before 2,500 persons at the Canarsie Arena last night.

The fourth capacity audience of the season last night witnessed the opening of Philip Barry's "The Animal Kingdom," presented here at the Chase Barn Playhouse by the Forty Niners. The leading role of Tom Collier was taken by Everett Ripley.

Assemblyman W. Allan Newell of St. Lawrence County announced from a hospital today his withdrawal, "on advice of physicians," as a candidate for the Republican nomination to Congress to succeed Bertrand H. Snell in the Thirty-first District.

Park T. Winslow, president of the Camp Fire Outfitting Company, former editor and soldier of fortune, died yesterday in his home at 4,711 Fieldston Road, Riverdale, after a year's illness. He was 60 years old.

A slight decline in notice or savings deposits was shown in June by Canadian chartered banks, their statement today disclosed. Demand or current deposits increased. Both call and current loans in Canada showed increases. A summary of the statement, with comparative figures, follows:

Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt came here today to see her eighth grandchild, Franklin D. Roosevelt 3d, at the Lying-In Hospital. A broad smile was her reply when she was asked what she thought of the week-old baby.
Two brothers, riding a bicycle to a near-by dahlia farm where they expected to earn a few cents pulling weeds, were killed on the Sunrise Highway thin morning by a truck.
Excavations conducted by archaeologists of the University of Chicago at Armageddon have disclosed that the ancient city was preparing for trouble centuries ago.

The Junior Champion Stekes for 2-year-olds, to be run at the Autumn meeting at Aqueduct, has been increased from $7,500 to $10,000 added, it was announced yesterday by the Queens County Jockey Club, which is sending out entry blanks for stakes at the coming session.

Deputy Mayor Henry H. Curran, it was learned yesterday, has saved Robert Moses, Commissioner of Parks, from the artistic mistake of floodlighting the monument to Henry Hudson that stands atop a 100-foot Doric column near Mr. Moses's double-decker bridge for the Henry Hudson Parkway.

A decision by the Circuit Court of Appeals in Chicago has overruled the National Labor Relations Board in the first case in which that agency ordered reinstatement of sit-down strikers. The case is an important one in the evolution of judicial opinion concerning the Wagner act and raises some interesting questions.

Mr. and Mrs. Edwin H. Denby of New York were luncheon hosts at the Bar Harbor Club today to Mr. and Mrs. Henry 0. Tallmadge, General and Mrs. J. W. Kilbreth, Dr. and Mrs. Ulrich Dahlgren, Mr. and Mrs. J. C. Gerndt, Mr. and Mrs.

Al Hostak, 1584, Seattle, won the world middleweight title from Freddie Steele of Tacoma with a knockout in the first round of their scheduled fifteen-round fight tonight. Steele weighed 159 pounds. The triumph was Hostak's sixteenth in a row by the knockout route.

New York State's highways, in many places ravaged by storms and heavy rains of the last two weeks, have been restored completely for use by motor traffic, it was announced yesterday by Earnest B. Bearnarth, travel director of the Automobile Club of New York.

The manner in which Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc., is sectionalizing its current newspaper campaign is described in "Tailormade, by TWA," fourth in the new series of Advertising Facts, issued to advertisers, agencies and member newspapers by the Bureau of Advertising,

The first thirty-five railroads to report showed a decline of 49.5 per cent in net operating income in June, compared with June, 1937. The figures indicated that railroad revenues in July were the highest for any month this year.

Mrs. Joseph P. Kennedy, wife of the United States Ambassor to Britain, today cabled Dr. Jordan of the Lakey Clinic in Boston for advice on the illness of her son Jackie. Dr. Jordan previously treated the child and is familiar with the case.

Mayor La Guardia denounced yesterday the "political cooties" who sell legislation when he told 129 taxicab drivers and civilians at the Summer City Hall that no person in the taxi industry need pay for any measures beneficial to the industry.

Swing music was characterized as "a degenerated form of jazz" and its devotees were described as "the unfortunate victims of economic instability" yesterday by Donald Grant, president of the Dancing Teachers Business Association, at the third annual convention of that organization at the Park Central Hotel.

Morris Gest, theatrical producer, returned yesterday on the French liner Ile de France from Europe, where he said he had acquired a midget show for the New York World's Fair of 1989. The show will be entitled "Little Miracle Town."
The Commonwealth Edison Company moved today to sell an additional $72,241,595 of securities in connection with its program of refinancing. The company sold $72,083,195 of securities last month.

Supervised Shares, Inc., announced yesterday the appointment of the State Street Trust Company, Boston, as custodian of securities and transfer agent. The Commercial Trust Company of New Jersey formerly was the custodian, while the Corporation Trust Company, Jersey City, formerly was transfer agent.
In Tennessee the Democratic primary campaign now nearing its end has had all the passion and virulence of a fight for control. Governor Browning, seeking re-election, has a powerful State machine.

Mrs. Rosemarie Meehan Casey, wife of J. Schuyler Casey of 211 Central Park West, president of M. H. Treadwell Company, Inc., 140 Cedar Street, manufacturing engineers, died Monday at Eaton's Ranch, Wolf, Wyo.

Henry Percival Biggar, author and chief archivist for Canada in Europe, who, in 1926, discovered a bust of General James Wolfe, was found dead today outside the door of his home here. Death was attributed to a heart attack.

Manager Bill Terry of the New York Giants had a chance yesterday at a professional role, but he played hooky from his own class in "Coaching of Baseball (Advanced)" at Teachers College, disappointing twenty-one students and four photographers.

Pop bottles and hard words, with Vice President Larry MacPhail, Manager Burleigh Grimes and Captain Leo Durocher tossing most of the verbal brickbats, flew about the confines of Ebbets Field yesterday as the embattled Dodgers opened their home stand before more than 11,000 fans by dropping a 10-to-8 decision to the climbing Cubs.

Polo emerged from the flood today and the long-postponed final of the Meadow Brook Club championship was completed, with Winston Guest's Templeton team defeating Gulf Stream,. 10 to 4, at Phipps Field.
Designing and executing the plans for the New York World's Fair Perisphere and Trylon theme center created a number of unusual and difficult architectural and engineering problems.

About twenty Soviet infantrymen and thirty cavalrymen are reported to have crossed the Manchukuan -border yesterday near Hunchun, about twenty-five miles north of the scene of the recent alleged invasion near the Korean border.
Mrs. Carlos M. de Heredia was a luncheon hostess today at Wheatleigh, Lenox. Her guests included Mrs. Johannes A. L. van de Bosch, who is staying at the Lenox Club; Mrs. William Penn Cresson,

Steel ingot output increased more than seasonally last week, and the adjusted index spurted to 53.8, its highest point since the week ended Nov. 20, 1937. The figure was 47.7 for the preceding week and 123.2 for the week ended July 24, 1937.

Lieut. Comdr. Lincoln Ellsworth, flying conqueror of the North and South polar regions, sailed last night on the North German Lloyd liner Europa for Southampton, with Mrs. Ellsworth, on his way to Cape Town, South Africa, for his fourth expedition into the Antarctic.

The demand for unimproved real estate in the vicinity of the site in the Bronx acquired by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company for a housing project continued yesterday when an owner extended .his frontage on Westchester Avenue.

Lord Essendon, chairman of the huge shipping concern of Furness, Withy Co., Ltd., today bitterly attacked the United States Maritime Commission for its decision to sponsor increased competition with his concern's ships on the runs from the United States to South America and South Africa.

There is some comment here on the fact that Joseph Buerckel, Nazi Commissioner for Austria, made no formal speeches at Sunday's and yesterday's celebrations of the 1934 Chancellery Putsch in which Chancellor Engelbert Dolfuss was killed.
Paul Derringer kept the Bees away from first base for six and two-thirds innings today while pitching a fivehitter that gave his Cincinnati Reds a 6-2 victory in a series opener.

Thomas L. Manson ' Co, member New York Stock Exchange: Gordon L. Chapline Co, municipal bond dealers, in 67 Broad St; Wladyslaw Trzetrzewinski, in 89 Broad St; William B. Robinson, investment counsel, in 33-5 South William St; Schlang Brothers Co, agents.

Michael J. McNamara, a native of Ireland and father of three priests, died here yesterday at the age of 68. The priests are the Rev. Thomas P. McNamara, rector of St. Francis Xavier Church, Baton Rouge, La.;

Garfield Charles, Master in Chancery, authorized today attorneys for the creditors of Insull Utility Investment, Inc., to draw up an order for distribution of $3,000,000 of the bankrupt corporation's assets.

Members of the Summer colony turned out in large numbers this evening for the opening of the twelfth Casino Theatre season and the first performance by the Casino Players of the comedy "Fashion," with music, in which Dorothy Sands,
Ernest W. Brown, Professor of Mathematics and Astronomy at Yale, left the bulk of his estate to the university. The will, filed today, does not state the value of the estate, but it is large.

An alarm for the arrest of four persons named in a taxicab racket indictment charging fifty-five counts of extortion and a conspiracy was sent out through eight States yesterday by police at the request of the office of District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey.

The Queens delegates to the Constitutional Convention stated today that they were prepared to vote for the Republican reapportionment bill on the grounds that only a bill sponsored by the majority party would be adopted and that they must accept any reapportionment measure which gave to their home county the additional representation that it merited.

Colonel William Murray Connell, U. S. A., retired, died on Monday in his home, 29 East Ninth Street, after a long illness. Formerly chief of staff of the Sixty-first Cavalry Division, United States Army Reserve, with headquarters here, Colonel Connell had retired in 1935. His age was 66.
Miss Dorothea Darlington entertained at a luncheon yesterday in the garden of the Ambassador for Mrs. Clinton.Pelham Darlington of Fanwood, N. J., and Miss Aura Smith of Kansas City, Mo.

Returning to civilization, Bradford Washburn, noted Cambridge, Mass., explorer. reported today the successful ascent of Mount Sanford, which he described as the highest peak hitherto unclimbed on the North American continent.

With five of seven races sailed for the women's championship. of Long Island Sound, which is really qualification for the national competition, Mrs. Willis D. Wood of the Cold Spring Harbor Beach Club had a clear lead tonight. She won two of three contests held today, the last with darkness coming on.
The "outstretched hand" of the Communist party toward the Roman Catholic Church received additional rebuffs yesterday from two organizations affiliated with the church.

The United States' official refugee observer arrived in Berlin today and started work on an assignment that German official sources believed would involve first of all an attempt to win freedom for Jews in concentration camps.

Wheat futures declined about 1 cent a bushel at the extreme today to new seasonal levels, but rallied late in the session in sympathy with corn and on short covering. Closing trades on the Board of Trade here were at net losses of 1/8 to 3/8 cent.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The recent editorial in THE TIMES "Religion in the Schools" and comment upon the constitutional amendment introduced by Delegate Robert T. Murray of Troy, permitting religious instruction without discrimination in the public school buildings, presents some familiar objections and arrives at some conclusions which in the light of recent events are open to challenge.
By seeking to borrow $2,000,00 from the State's General Education Fund, Governor Moore took steps today to avert a threatened relief crisis that might result in defaulted State payrolls.
A syndicate headed by Jacob Feder recently bought from the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank the two houses at 148 and 150 West Seventeenth Street and rented them up following alterations.

On reconsideration of the hours of service safety regulations for the trucking industry promulgated by its Division 5, the Interstate Commerce Commission largely upheld today the original findings of its motor carrier division, but made some modifications. These were the first nation-wide rules of the kind ever prescribed by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

Supreme Court Justice Aron Steuer in a ruling yesterday upheld the State Labor Relations Board in requiring the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company to bargain collectively with the C. I. O. Industrial Insurance Agents Union.

Estate, less than $1,500. To Joseph Breyer, husband, 2,720 Broadway, residue. Lillian B. Steuerman, 390 Riverside Drive. and Joseph Breyer, 2,720 Broadway, children, executors. BRINCKERHOFF, FANNY L. (May 10). Estate, less than $1,500. To Walter Wyckoff Brinckerhoff, son, executor, 340 Weaver St., Larchmont, N. Y., entire estate.

Illinois formally signed a contract for participation in the New York World's Fair yesterday after a luncheon on the fair grounds given for the Illinois commission by Grover A. Whalen, president of the fair corporation.

An appeal to the world's periodical press for "objectivity, truthfulness, dignity and decency" in its reports was issued today by Willi Bischoff, German president of the Federation Internationale de la Presse Technique et Periodique.

As part of its manoeuvres program for 1938, the greatest in the peace-time history of the country,. the War Department stated today that the Second Army, of which Major Gen. Hugh A. Drum is the commander, would engage in large-scale command post exercises in September.

There is apparently a well-authenticated report here tonight that the entire equipment of the former Austrian Army has been disposed of to Hungary and that the Austrian contingent of the German Army will be rearmed by German sources.
A large gathering, including John L. Lewis, attended the funeral today of Charles P. Howard, president of the International Typographical Union, who died on Thursday.

Heavy hogs shot upward 15 to 25 cents, light hogs 10 to 15 cents, top $10.25 today. Fed steers and yearlings were slow, but best steers sold at $13.00. Fat lambs moved upward 10 to 15 cents to $9.40 for best, the United States Department of Agriculture reported.

The misfortunes that seem to have attached themselves to the Giants transformed what was eagerly awaited as a happy home-coming to the Polo Grounds yesterday into a painful affair for the Terrymen and the 5,784 followers of the club who braved threatening skies

New orders booked by the struc tural steel fabricating industry in June amounted to 97,546 tons, the largest for the year. They com- lows for pared with 77,499 tons in May and 175,552 in June, 1937. Orders for the six months were 488,127 tons, against 918,799 in the first half of 1937.

Labor must assert its strength in the coming elections or it will lose the National Labor Relations Act and may lose the Wages and Hours Act, social security and other progressive legislation, Eli L. Oliver, executive vice president of Labor's Nonpartisan League, warned yesterday.

The daily average gross crude-oil production in the United States last week was 3,349,050 barrels, compared with 3,343,100 in the previous week, an increase of 5,950, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

Thirty-three parcels of Westchester realty, assets of various certificated mortgage issues of the Westchester Title and Trust Company, will be offered for sale at auction by John R. Sweeny, county auctioneer, in the Westchester County Center, White Plains, tonight, on behalf of the trustees for the certificate owners.

Supreme Court Commissioner Alfred B. Denham took testimony today in the suit of the New Jersey Detective Association to nullify the 1938 act repealing a law of 1871 authorizing creation of the organization.

Walter S. Gifford, president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, filed a letter today with the Westchester County Board of Supervisors opposing all requests to have the county purchase, develop and operate the airport at Armonk. The landing field, adjoining an orchard where four persons were killed in a plane crash July 10, is near Mr. Gifford's estate.

A sweeping investigation of the Federal Theatre and Writers Projects by the Dies Committee created by the House of Representatives to investigate un-American and subversive activities will be demanded by Representative J. Parnell Thomas, Republican, of New Jersey, a member of the committee.
To Report to Chief Medical Officer The following ununiformed firemen shall be directed to report to the chief medical officer, at these headquarters, at 11 A. M., Wednesday, Aug. 3:

Mrs. G. Farrand's Harmachis, 5-year-old by Roidore out of Maqueda, today won the Stewards' Cup, defeating H. G. Blagrave's Old Reliance by a head. Miss Rachel Parsons's Davy Dolittle was third in the field of twenty-five, two lengths behind Old Reliance.

Lou Lombardi of Jersey City, 38, scored his fifth consecutive victory, the most spectacular of his comeback campaign, tonight when he won by a technical knockout from Billy Beauhuld, 138, also of Jersey City, in the third round of a scheduled eight-round boxing bout.

Holders of $4 cumulative preferred stock of the Standard Gas and Electric Company elected Benjamin L. Allen and John K. MacGowan directors at an---adjourned meeting in Wilmington, Del., yesterday. The election of the other seven directors, as provided in the plan of reorganization, was announced on July 1.

The Metropolitan Opera Association, Inc., and the American Guild of Musical Artists announced yesterday that "after many interesting conferences both sides have reached an agreement which was signed today by Edward Johnson and Edward Ziegler for the Metropolitan, and by Eva Gauthier and Leo Fischer for AGMA."
Allegany County's Democratic Committee suggested a Gubernatorial nomination today for Mark Graves, State Tax and Finance Commissioner, who was once an Allegany County farm boy.

The Washington of the United States Lines will sail today for the Channel ports. Among the passengers will be P. A. S. Franklin, chairman of the International Mercantile Marine Company, and Mrs. Franklin; James Marshall,

Bush Terminal Company common stock, 518,461 shares of $1 par value, has been approved for listing on the New York Stock Exchange. Voting-trust certificates for 34,454 additional shares of Columbia Pictures Corporation common stock, no par value, also have been approved for listing.
Governor A. B. Chandler was recovering in Frankfort today, while controversy waxed warm over what caused his illness.

To take effect 8 A. M., Aug. 1: LIEUTENANTS-William J. Cowan, from 44th Precinct to 7th Division, assignment changed from desk duty to supervisor of patrol in uniform. Assignment to desk duty continued: Thomas J. Daly. from 7th Division to command 44th Precinct; Salvatore G. Romano, from 14th Division to command 15th Division.

Labor and management continued in debate today on the railroads' proposed 15 per cent wage cut for their 914,000 employes, the talks being between A. F. Whitney, president of the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen, and his committee and H. A. Enochs and his carriers' joint conference committee.

A verdict of $124 damages was awarded by a New York County Sheriff's jury against Burleigh Grimes, manager of the Brooklyn National League baseball club, in a suit brought by Harold Greenberg, 16 years old, of 1,583 Fifty-eighth Street, Brooklyn.

Mrs. G. Farrand's Harmachis, 5-year-old by Roidore out of Maqueda, today won the Stewards' Cup, defeating H. G. Blagrave's Old Reliance by a head. Miss Rachel Parsons's Davy Dolittle was third in the field of twenty-five, two lengths behind Old Reliance.

Lou Lombardi of Jersey City, 38, scored his fifth consecutive victory, the most spectacular of his comeback campaign, tonight when he won by a technical knockout from Billy Beauhuld, 138, also of Jersey City, in the third round of a scheduled eight-round boxing bout.

Holders of $4 cumulative preferred stock of the Standard Gas and Electric Company elected Benjamin L. Allen and John K. MacGowan directors at an---adjourned meeting in Wilmington, Del., yesterday. The election of the other seven directors, as provided in the plan of reorganization, was announced on July 1.

The Metropolitan Opera Association, Inc., and the American Guild of Musical Artists announced yesterday that "after many interesting conferences both sides have reached an agreement which was signed today by Edward Johnson and Edward Ziegler for the Metropolitan, and by Eva Gauthier and Leo Fischer for AGMA."
Allegany County's Democratic Committee suggested a Gubernatorial nomination today for Mark Graves, State Tax and Finance Commissioner, who was once an Allegany County farm boy.

The Washington of the United States Lines will sail today for the Channel ports. Among the passengers will be P. A. S. Franklin, chairman of the International Mercantile Marine Company, and Mrs. Franklin; James Marshall,

Bush Terminal Company common stock, 518,461 shares of $1 par value, has been approved for listing on the New York Stock Exchange. Voting-trust certificates for 34,454 additional shares of Columbia Pictures Corporation common stock, no par value, also have been approved for listing.

The number of out of town buyers registered in the market during the Week ended yesterday fell well below that of the preceding week, but was slightly higher than the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings in THE TIMES.

Leon H. Adams received formally today a $5,050 loan from the Federal Government to become the first tenant farmer in the Northeastern States to buy his own land through aid from the Farm Security Administration.
The Commonwealth and Southern Corporation reported for the six months ended on June 30 a net income of $5,576,287, or 3 cents a share on the common stock, against $8,122,997,

GOVERNORS ISLAND Each of the following Field Artillery Reserve officers is ordered to active dutyAug 7. at Pine Plains Military Reservation. N. Y., for training: 352d Field Artillery Major Joseph M. Neville, 41 West 69th St.. New York. N. Y.
Many dinners were given tonight at the Atlantic Beach Club before the July dance, given under the chairmanship of Mrs. James W. Maitland of Lawrence, who, with Mr. Maitland, was a dinner host.

Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain and Secretary of State Cordell Hull are in agreement concerning the basic value of an Anglo-American reciprocal trade agreement, Mr. Hull made plain at his press conference today in commenting on Mr. Chamberlain's speech in the House of Commons yesterday.

The Procurement Division of the United States Treasury placed additional orders yesterday for the account of the Works Progress Administration for $747,295.03 in men's and boys' clothing. The purchase adds to several previously made in the WPA plan to spend $10,000,000 for clothing for the needy.

The stock market here became generally cheerful again today and most sections went ahead. Gilt-edge issues were quiet and steady, but among the foreign bonds German issues lost ground. Transatlantic stocks were in good demand and United States Steel advanced.

Mrs. Stuart McNamara gave a luncheon yesterday in the outdoor Japanese Garden of the Ritz-Carlton for Mrs. William O'Donnell Iselin, Mrs. C. Frank Reavis and Mrs. S. Fullerton Weaver. Miss Ruth Boyd was a luncheon hostess at the Stork Club to Mrs. Richard E. Thaxter and the Misses Dorothy Gerster, Martha Stephenson, Barbara Shewan and Renee Schanck.

The Rev. S. Fraser Langford, the mild, gray-haired uncle of Douglas Corrigan, transatlantic flier, arrived in New York yesterday morning to serve as "a sort of buffer" for his nephew and incidentally to greet the truant airman when he lands in New York on Aug. 5. The clergyman flew here by plane from California.

Through his attorneys James J. Hines, Tammany district leader, sought yesterday a trial before a jury made up of the common people as opposed to the kind of a jury that might be drawn from a special blue ribbon panel.

The Arab town of Ramleh, which lies on the main road connectingJaffa andTel Aviv with Jerusalem and is the route of the heaviest passenger and commercial traffic in Palestine, was the source of much worry to the authorities today. Stones were again

The fifty-acre estate of A. A. Pinto at Purdvs. N. Y., has been purchased by Joseph Lewis through Kenneth Ives Co. Reed Clark of White Plains represented the owner The property includes a stone residence of twelve rooms, two garages, lodge, swimming pool and a private lake.
Federal Judge William H. Holly authorized the Securities and Exchange Commission today to intervene in the bankruptcy case of the Utilities Power and Light Corporation.

Blaming the Republican party for the ills which beset farmers six years ago, Secretary Wallace hailed "six years of genuinely glorious achievement on the part of the Democratic party," in an address made tonight at the Iowa State Democratic Convention here.

Warren Charles Fairbanks, president and publisher of The Indianapolis News, died today of a cerebral hemorrhage in an Indianapolis hospital. He was 60 years old and was the son of Charles Warren Fairbanks, former United States Senator and Vice President of the United States from 1905 to 1909.

Accompanied by allegations that Governor Kraschel, who has been endorsed for re-election by the C. I. O., is favoring the organization's strikers at the Maytag factory in an effort to win the State-wide support of labor, appeals were sent today to Democratic leaders to take cognizance of the Executive's action in keeping the Maytag Washing Machine Company plant closed under martial law.

The index of the value of retail sales of automobiles, as adjusted seasonally and for the number of days in the month, declined from 57 in May to 50.5 in June, the Commerce Department announced today.
Secretary Ickes announced PWA loans of $93,000 and grants-of $4,915,122 today for fifty-seven additional nonFederal projects, including two in New York and one in New Jersey.

Robert F. Straub, president of the New York Produce Exchange, announced yesterday that the Exchange was preparing again to establish securities trading on its floor. Mr. Straub said that at a meeting of the board of managers held yesterday afternoon a tentative plan of organization of a securities market had been received and adopted. Membership in the

The Interstate Commerce Commission approved today $25,000 as the maximum annual compensation of G. W. Webster and $18,000 as the maximum annual compensation of Joseph Chapman, as trustees of the Minneapolis, St. Paul Sault Ste. Marie Railway Company.

The American Bar Association in convention here paused today in its consideration of the difficulties of the railroads, better methods of selecting the judiciary and changes in the tax laws to prepare a resolution condemning Nazi persecution of minorities in Germany and Austria. It is expected to come before the general assembly tomorrow.

Honeywell Ave. n e cor 178th St (905), 4-story tenement, 24.11x88.8; Benjamin Rosen against Alar Realty Corp. due. $2,821, subject to mortgage of $16.000; plaintiff for $17.000. By B. HOLLANDER SON Edison Ave. 1,939, 25x95; New York Suburban Federal Savings and Loan Assn against Clro Mazzella and ano, due, $1,670, taxes, etc., $311; to plaintiff for $500.
It was learned from inside sources at Metro today that Norma Shearer was expected to withdraw from the leading role in "Idiot's Delight," in which she is scheduled to appear with Clark Gable.

Appleton-Century announces that "Submarine," the autobiography of Simon Lake, the American inventor, as told to Herbert Corey, has been chosen as the August selection of the Scientific Book Club. The book will be published tomorrow.

Mrs. Carrie Chapman Catt came perilously close yesterday to monopolizing the spotlight she shared with Miss Kirsten Hesselgren of Sweden at a luncheon in tribute to the Swedish legislator at the Hotel Delmonico, when she went on record as favoring alimony for husbands as well as wives.

When handsomely is buried every man In equal, leaf-cathedraled solitude, The crows once more will banter in the corn, The lizard jest, the hawk remove his hood, The dead will come to bear away the dead:

The famous James A. Patten mansion, one of Ave: the most notable residences in suburban Evanston, soon will fall under the wreckers' axe and in its place will rise a restricted residential park, containing nine homes.

The 36-hole pro-amateur prelude here today to the New Jersey State Open golf Championship tomorrow over the long Braidburn Country Club course, ended in a deadlock when a drenching rain caused the tied teams to toss a coin for first honor and thus obviate a play-off.

The shipping of drugs and serums from the plant of Sharp Dohme, Inc., pharmaceutical chemists, was halted today by a picket line of the Warehouse Employes Union, an American Federation of Labor affiliate. Truck drivers, members of

Dr. Lawrence Kolb, formerly chief of the Public Health Service Hospital at Lexington, Ky., has been appointed assistant surgeon general in charge of the division of mental hygiene, the Treasury announced today. He succeeds Dr. Walter L.

Governor Blanton Winship of Puerto Rico reported to Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of the Interior, today that gunpowder granules had been found on the hands of thirteen Nationalists arrested and charged with attempting to assassinate him at Ponce Monday.

Minister of the Interior Wilhelm Frick officially opened the first German gymnastic-sport festival here today. "Sport," he declared, "is a battle, and where there is a battle there also are wounds and victims.

Stephen Lewis Taylor, president and director of James Taylor Sons, lumber dealers, of 544 West Twenty-eighth Street, died yesterday in his home, 431 West 162d Street. Surviving are his widow; two sons, James A. and Gordon H. Taylor; a daughter, Mrs. Eric y Singer; a brother, John W. Taylor, and three sisters, Miss Charlotte E. Taylor, Mrs. George Morrison and Mrs. Mary Taylor Nelson.

George Sydney Freeman, deputy editor of The Times of London from 1914 to 1922 and editor of The Times educational supplement since he founded it in 1910, died yesterday in his country home in Sussex. He was 58 years old.

For the first time in the history of the tournament a defending champion was able to add the Eastern junior clay-court tennis trophy to his collection for the second year in succession when. Joseph Fishbach, tall, young St; John's University sophomore, romped home

The City Planning Commission approved a street layout yesterday for the $65,000,000 housing development planned by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company on property formerly occupied by the New York Catholic Protectory in the East Tremont section of the Bronx.

Like all other industrial data, the report of the United States Steel Corportion, covering the quarterly and half-yearly period ended last June, paints a picture with vivid contrasts. In the first six months of 1937 the company's earnings In excess of operating charges, depreciation and interest were $64,735,000; in the same months of 1938 the result was a net loss of $6,302,000.

The Rev. John B. Prosseda, a member of the Vincentian Order attached to the Province of Rome and founder of several churches in Brookly and New Jersey, died on Tuesday night in St. Peter's Hospital. Father Prosseda,

A light southeast wind this morning opened the ice surrounding the schooner General A. W. Greely, with the MacGregor Arctic expedition aboard. The ship has been caught in the Baffin Bay ice pack since July 18. We were able to move about ten miles to the northeast before fog settled upon us again.
Although more than $6,000,000 of State money is lying idle in a special bank account, Attorney General Wilentz advised Governor Moore today that none of it could be borrowed for relief purposes.

Merchandising, promotion, style problems in connection with the retail sale of millinery will be discussed at an all-day session of the Millinery Merchandising Executives Association at the Waldorf-Astoria next Tuesday. Miss Virginia Pope,

There will be at least 100 persons at the dinner to be given tomorrow evening at the Newport Country Club for members and the players in the annual invitation golf tournament, the qualifying round of which will get under way in the morning.

President Roosevelt, viewing Charles Island today from the Houston, sent fresh food and other gifts to the few inhabitants. The President reached the outermost point of his equatorial Pacific fishing cruise when the cruiser dropped anchor in Postoffice Bay, Charles Island.

Following the discovery of the body of the, Rev. Charles Raymond Barnes ina the library of his home, his cook, William Rodney, a Briton, was de-i trained by the police for questioning today. The police said Mr. Barnes had been killed by blows on the head.

The suggestion of former Governor Alfred E. Smith that the State Constitutional Convention avoid any increase in the tax burden on real estate to promote lowcost housing was opposed in a statement issued yesterday by the CityWide Tenants Council of 425 Fifth Avenue.

After hours of debate the Constitutional Convention in committee of the whole voted just before midnight to advance the housing proposal sponsored by Joseph Clark Baldwin to the order of third reading, thus placing it in line for final adoption.

While wheat futures declined around 1/2 cent a bushel in the early trading today, largely in sympathy with securities and easiness in Liverpool, there was no material pressure on the market. The break was checked

Attorneys for Northeastern Water Companies, Inc., of Ithaca asserted today in Federal court that a sale of securities pledged by the corporation to secure a $2,100,000 note would defeat plans for its reorganization under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act.

Miss Mary Elita Cason of Lakeland, Fla., and Lowell Wadmond, former assistant United States district attorney in New York, were married here today at Grove Park Inn. The bride, daughter of Mrs. John Morgan Cason and the late Mr. Cason of Lakeland, was given in marriage by her brother, Dwight S. Cason of Birmingham, Ala.

As these columns were indicating last Sunday, the Group Theatre has found way out of what threatened to be a dilemma in Londoni. e., while its "Golden Boy" is a hit over there, the players acting it are due to open an American tour on Sept. 11. It was a matter of ending the engagement or assembling a new company, and the Group chose the latter course.

A report that the Northwest Airlines plane. crash near Billings, Mont., July 8, which killed one of the eight passengers, was probably due to a stall, at low altitude following a take-off, was made today by an investigating board of the Bureau of Air Commerce.

The Board of Higher Education adopted budgets last night calling for the spending of $10,200,000 in the next six years in a program for the physical improvement of the four colleges operated by the cityCity, Hunter, Brooklyn and Queens Colleges.

James L. Williams, chief of the Republic Steel Corporation's Police Department, asserted at the end of a lively hearing on labor espionage before the Senate Civil Liberties Committee today that he had paid $300 to a volunteer organizer for the Steel Workers Organizing Committee to stop his union activities in the Summer of 1936.

The semi-annual report of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company and subsidiaries, released yesterday by A. W. Robertson, chairman of the board showed a net profit of $4,500,602, after depreciation, Federal income taxes and other charges for the first six months of this year.

Magistrate Edgar Bromberger in Municipal Term of Magistrate's Court, Brooklyn, imposed Tuesday a total fine of $450 on Capitol Fuels of Queens, Inc., of 34-66 Lawrence Street, Flushing, for violating regunations of the administrative code and not for delivering short-weight coal, as reported in Wednesday's editions of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Summing up the government's case against Harlan County coal operators and their hired deputies, Welly Hopkins called upon the jury of mountain men today to send all the defendants in this trial to prison and deDrive them of their civil rights.

Slingin' Sammy Baugh, shortstop with the Rochester International League baseball club and one of football's outstanding passers, still was a holdout tonight in the eyes of the Washington Redskins professional football club.

By court order the Board of Education was called upon yesterday to grant a jury trial to an applicant to determine his fitness to teach in the New York City schools. This is the first time in the history of the school system that the board's appointive powers have been challenged by judicial decree.

J. G. Kuijt, retired planter, of the Dutch East Indies, who had planned to start across the Atlantic today in a thirty-eight-foot sailboat for Holland, said he was delaying his departure until later to have a chance to visit with his friend Anthony Fokker, airplane builder.

Rochdale Institute, a training school for prospective managers and educational directors of cooperatives,.. will open its third term on Sept. -26,. according .to announce-men tyesterday-. by Dr. James P. Warbasse, president of the Cooperative Laegue of the U. S. A. and director of the institute.

The Hayden'Planetarium of the American Museum of Natural History was flooded with telephone calls all day yesterday from residents of New York and New Jersey reporting on the fireball type of meteor that flashed across the northern skies Tuesday evening.

Electric power production increased slightly last week, but daily average output declined more than seasonally, and the adjusted index dropped to 93.4 from 93.6, the revised figure for the preceding week. The index for the week ended July 24, 1937, was 106.5.

The Baltimore Ohio Railroad announced yesterday that it had contracted with the Pullman Company for the streamlining of the Capitol Limited, the only all-Pullman train between Washington and Chicago. The decision to redesign

Tobacco growers in Georgia and Florida, challenging the constitutionality of agricultural adjustment administration marketing quotas, obtained State court orders today restraining collection of penalty taxes at auctions opening -tomorrow.

Miss Marion Lauren Pendleton and the Rev. Victor Obenhaus, whose engagement was announced in May, obtained a license yesterday at the Municipal Building for their marriage, which will take place on Saturday in the Riverside Church, this city.

The reign of terror in the Holy Land has reached the fever pitch of violence and horror as bombs explode in buses and crowded market-places. Fundamentally it is a fight of two extreme groups, on one side the Jewish Revisionists who want complete Jewish domination of Palestine, and on the other the fanatical Arab nationalists who want complete Arab domination and would drive out the Zionists if they could. These extremists reject any

Mrs. Hallie Flanagan, director of the Federal Theatre Project, said today that she would be glad to answer any questions Representative Thomas of New Jersey might wish to ask her about the project and her own activities in it. She said she had

The Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company is notifying holders of St. Louis Southwestern Railway Company 4 per cent first-mortgage bond certificates due on Nov. 1, 1989, that, pursuant to a court order filed last Friday in proceedings for reorganization of the company, funds have been received to cover the May 1 installment of interest on the certificates.
The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated July 25: CAPTAIN Maddox, C. H., the Raleigh, about Aug. 1, to instructor Naval War College, Newport.

The taking of testimony and summarizing of opposing counsel were completed yesterday in the general court-martial on Governors Island of Lieut. Col. Stewart S. Giffin, charged with violation of the ninety-fifth article of war covering the conduct of an officer and a gentleman.. Six specifications allege he was intoxicated and disorderly on as many occasions.

Mrs. Theodore G. Bilbo, divorced wife of Senator Bilbo of Mississippi, said today that she was considering opposing her former husband for the Senatorial nomination in 1940. "Long before the divorce," she said, "I was thinking of running against him. I don't know yet what my

Mrs. Harry McNaughton of Sound View, present holder of the women's Long Island golf crown, scored a 78 today to win the low gross prize in the women's Long Island one-day handicap tourney at the Deepdale Golf Club.

The Indians won a slugging match from the Athletics today, 12 to 11, to remain a game and a half behind the league-leading Yankees. The Tribe used five pitchers and Philadelphia used three. Willis Hudlin, who started for Cleveland, was chased in the first inning after he had given a walk and three hits. Rookies Zuber, Humphries and Milnar followed and Mel Harder came in for the last out. Milnar was the winner.

Grain millers and dealers in such strategic centers as Minneapolis, Duluth, Sioux City, Omaha and Kansas City lost a long fight today for more favorable freight rates. The Interstate Commerce Commission rejected their plea that railroads be compelled to grant them stop-over rights on grain shipments for milling or storage purposes without application of a combination tariff which, in some instances, is considerably higher than the through charge.
Baltimore Transit Company and Baltimore Coach Company-June and six months to June 30:

A new issue of $3,413,000 of general construction certificates of indebtedness of the State of Maryland was awarded yesterday to a banking group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., which bid 100.182 for bee the securities as 1 1/2 per cent obligations.

The Associated Real Estate Corportion sold to a client of Armstrong Brothers, brokers, a plot 75 by 106 feet on the south side of Westchester Avenue, 100 feet from the corner of Virginia Avenue, the Bronx.

A $1,000,000 publicity campaign in behalf of the motion picture industry was announced yesterday morning at a meeting of 300 producers, distributors and exhibitors at the Hotel Astor. The campaign will start Sept. 1 and continue until the end of the year.

Jesse Jones threw resources of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation behind the Public Works program tonight, making possible a large expansion of the pump-priming operations through which the Roosevelt Administration hopes to hasten economic recovery.

Senator George L. Berry stands in real danger of losing his seat in the Democratic primary election Aug. 4 unless his conservative appeal to Main Street business is having more effect than is apparent on the surface.
A 5-month-old boy arrived at Newark Airport tonight on an American Airlines plane from Rochester, N. Y., in the custody of the stewardess, Miss Dorothy Travis.

War Admiral won the Wilson Stakes through Saratoga's mud by six lengths today to raise his total earnings to $241,475 and settle some of Owner Samuel D. Riddle's doubts about the mud-running ability of his crack son of Man o'War. It was only a three-horse

The War D*partment issued the following orders today, dated July 26: COLONEL Steger J. O. Adj. Gen. Dept., 3 days leave, July 26. LIEUTENANT COLONELS Brown, R. D., (C. A. C.) Gen. Staff Corps. now on duty American Embassy, Brussels, Belgium, assigned duty as military attache to Luxembourg.

Two American singers, Franca Somigli and Frederick Jagel, achieved a triumph last night in the first performance here of Ildebrando Pizzetti's opera "Orsolo." It was the first time in the history of the Colon Theatre that two Americans had appeared in leading roles.

Tribute to George Foster Peabody and other pioneers who laid the foundation for the development of the mineral water cure here was paid today by Pierrepont B. Noyes, chairman of the Saratoga Springs Authority, as a portrait to Mr. Peabody was unveiled at the Hall of Springs.

Returns to date indicate that the aggregate net operating income of the railroads in June was about $25,000,000, the largest total for any month this year, but a drop of 57.6 per cent from the $58,939,875 reported for June, 1937. The net operating income of the railroads in May was $16,496,701, against $44,239,456 in May, 1937, a decline of 62.7 per cent.

A bolt of lightning struck and killed George Current, 42-year-old farmer, on his farm in Sparta Township, Sparta, N. J., during a storm yesterday afternoon. Current was riding on a wagon. The storm, lasting for thirty minutes, was confined to North Jersey.
When a huge meteor flashed over the city Tuesday night many people did not know what it was. Some wondered if it was an

Fingertip pressure on an electric button tomorrow will launch the new liner Mauretania, designed to cater to the lower-priced transatlantic tourist trade. Lady Bates, wife of the Cunard Line chairman, Sir Percy E. Bates, will perform the ceremony and 50,000 spectators are expected to be present as the black, white and red hull glides down the ways over seven tons of tallow into the Mersey estuary.

Transfers and Assignments To take effect 8 A. M., Aug. 1: SERGEANT-Daniel A. McGuinness, from Mounted Squadron 2 to Mounted Squadron 1, assignment to mounted duty continued. PATROLMEN-From precincts indicated to Juvenile Aid Bureau:

Unsettled by the best weather of the last ten days and a break in the stock market, cotton prices lost ground again yesterday, but, after selling within 10 points of recent low figures, a recovery left the list 1 to 3 points lower than on Tuesday.

The United States Government possessed on Monday approximately $13,000,000,000 of gold, the greatest amount of the precious metal ever held by any nation in history, the Treasury Department reported today.

Senator Donahey of Ohio, chairman of the Congressional committee investigating the Tennessee Valley Authority, stated tonight that he had invited Wendell L. Willkie, president of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation; C. E. Groesbeck, president of the Electric

Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Grand of Millbrook, N. Y., and Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Grand, to Edwin Thorne, son of Mr. and Mrs. Landon K. Thorne of 740 Park Avenue and Thorneham, Bay Shore, L. I.
Joey Ferrando, 138, Jersey City, fought his way to a clean-cut victory over Pete Mascia, 146, Brooklyn, last night in the featured eightround bout at the Queensboro Arena before a crowd of 2,000.

John Henry Lewis, world light heavyweight champion, was summarily dethroned yesterday, as far as New York State is concerned, at a meeting of the State Athletic Commission. The action was taken because of repeated refusals of Lewis to meet Tiger Jack Fox of Spokane, Wash., who had been designated the No. 1 challenger.

Collecting sixteen safe blows good for twenty-six bases, the Newark Bears handed the Jersey City Giants a 13-to-8 drubbing today. Seven pitchers were paraded to the mound in the contest, with Marius Russo, the Newark starter, getting credit for his thirteenth victory of the year.

A plan to help the railroads in their-present financial straits was suggested to-. day by George M. Harrison, chairman of the Railway Labor Executives Association, who urged that railroad management, labor, investors, shippers and others interested in the carriers get together to frame a bill providing for the reorganization of the roads.

Harry Nager. in 118 Roosevelt Ave., J. Lieberman. in 137 Atlantlc' Ave., Harry Magon, in 141 Wilson Ave.; Long Beach rentals by Potter Hamilton Co., Inc., brokers.

The Federal Music Project announces a new series of five chamber-music concerts to be given Monday evenings in August at the Master Theatre, 310 Riverside Drive. The concerts, beginning next Monday, will present modern and classic chamber music, vocal and instrumental. The Forum String Quartet.

Seeking to increase the profitable Philippine onion growing industry, the Philippine Bureau of Plant Industry has distributed 1,135 pounds of yellow Bermuda seed and 1,300 pounds of red globe seeds from India, the Commerce Department reports.

An attempt to put the National Typewriter and Office Machine Dealers Association on record as distiller favoring only the sale of American- the fac made typewriters, office appliances and supplies by its members was overwhelmingly defeated following a sharp debate on the subject at the closing session of the group's annual convention at the Hotel New Yorker yesterday.

Miss Isabel Griffith Eaton, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. William Henry Eaton of New York, was married here at noon today in the garden of her home to Dominique Homan of Westport, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. John Augustus Homan of Cincinnati.

Surrogate James A. Foley' refused yesterday to accept jurisdiction in the application of Mrs. Elizabeth Munn Glazebrook, wife of T. Truxtun Glazebrook of Hampton Bays, L. I., and Louisine Munn Jackson, wife of Berkeley W. Jackson of Huntington, L. I., grandnieces
George Givot, dialect comedian of radio and motion pictures, known as "the Greek ambassador," is being sued for $65,000 damages in Supreme Court by Herman Bernie, his former manager.
The ever amazing Dodgers made a bit of history at Ebbets Field last night and. in the making sent an overflow crowd of more than 35,000 rabid fans into an almost hysterical demonstration of joy.
A revised guide for retail advertising and selling will come before the national convention of Better Business Bureaus to be held at the s Grand Hotel, Mackinac Island, Mich., on Aug. 8 to 11.

Led by Ven Savage, Magna (Utah) Trans-Mississippi champion, four United States golfers swept through the second and third rounds of the Canadian amateur championship over the London Hunt and Country Club's rolling fairways today.

Contending that unlisted trading in its common stock on the New York Curb Exchange was detrimental to the company because sales on the Curb were generally at a price below true market value as quoted by the local over-the-counter dealers, the Providence Gas Company, at a hearing before Charles Lobinger, trial examiner for the Securities and Exchange Commission, asked today that the unlisted trading privilege be revoked.
The additional engagement of $6,800,000 gold abroad for shipment here-$5,800,000 in Japan and $1,000,000 in England-were reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Employment and wage payments in the Seventh per cen Federal Reserve District declined in June as a result of reduced activity in durable goods industries, the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago re- decline ported today. Employment of 12,

Mrs. Mary Sack sold to the Jersey-Hanover Corporation, Isidore Wolff, president, for a consideration shown as $80,000, the two store buildings at 167-69 Newark Avenue, Jersey City, on a plot 40 by 118 feet. The sale also included

Thomas O'Connor, 49 years old, who has been secretary to General Sessions Judge George L. Donnellan since the latter took office in 1927, was fatally injured when he fell from a third-floor window yesterday morning while walking in his sleep. The accident occurred

Stocks weakened 1 to 5 points and closed nervous and sharply lower in heavier trading; turnover, 1,973,440 shares. Corporate bonds lower, United States Government loans irregularly-higher, foreign mixed; transactions, $8,092,850.

Senator Claude Pepper of Florida sailed yesterday on the Washington to attend the parliamentary conference at The Hague. Replying to a question on the possibility of President Roosevelt running for a third term, he said:
Tony Galento's physician talked optimistically today of the heavyweight fighter's condition, but wouldn't hazard a guess on how long it would be before he could return to the ring.

The French liner Normandie lost half a day on her voyage to New York to put back to her home port for an emergency stomach operation on a member of her crew. The liner left here at 1:40 P. M. yesterday and after a stop at Southampton, England, at 7:45 P. M., returned to Havre at 2 A. M. today.

Britain Issued an unusually blunt warning to Japan yesterday against infringement of her rights in China. The warning came in a speech in the House of Lords by Foreign Secretary Halifax, who said that the government was considering "possible action" for protection of its interests.
The government is attempting to end the share-pushing racket by a new bill that would make it an offense to give dishonestly misleading forecasts or promises of the prospective position of a company.

With Danny Macfayden and Lou Fette pitching five-hit ball in their respective games, the Bees today won a double-header from the Reds, 1 to 0 and 5 to 1. In the first game Deacon Danny, avenging the hand injury he had suffered when the Reds last visited Boston, made it his eighth victory for the year at the expense of big Jim Weaver, who was replaced by Gene Schott in the eighth inning.

Mr. and Mrs. William K. Vanderbilt will give a supper dance in the St. Regis Roof on Nov. 18 to introduce Mrs. Vanderbilt's daughter, Miss Rosemary Warburton. Leslie, Lady Doverdale, who arrived on the He de France, is at the Ambassador.

By defeating John Foreman of Plainfield, fourth ranking player, today, Billy cGehee of New Orleans, unseeded, earned the right to meet the defending champion, Donald Hawley of Orange, in the semi-finals of the Northern New Jersey. tennis championship at the Westfield Tennis Club.

Mel Hein, all-National League center for the past five years, again will play with the New York Football Giants. Hein, who had written President John Mara that he would not return, wired yesterday that he would be on hand when the club begins training Aug. 15 at the Blue
The Chinese-Japanese war rolled today into Hupeh Province, the thirteenth of the twenty-four Chinese provinces to be afflicted by land combat in a struggle just one year and three weeks old.

Chancellor Adolf Hitler's confidential adjutant, Captain Fritz Wiedemann, may return to England this week-end, it was reported here tonight, in furtherance of Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's plan for a sweeping Anglo-German settlement by the end of this year.

Hugh M. Clarke, first vice president of the Armstrong Cork Company, died last night in the Lancaster General Hospital after an illness of several months. He was born forty-six years ago in Pittsburgh.

President Lazaro Cardenas asserted today that Mexico was prepared to pay her creditors in all fields if she could obtain cooperation abroad in selling Mexican products, including especially petroleum.
Commodore T. K. Wade's Patricia of the Royal Canadian Yacht Club, Toronto, today was declared winner of the cruising race across Lake Ontario from Big Sodus, N. Y., for the Freeman Cup.

Supreme Court Justice Thomas J. Cuff will be asked in Mineola today to appoint a receiver for the Lido Club Hotel of Long Beach, a 167acre resort noted for its golf course, according to John Holley Clark Jr., attorney for certificate holders in the hotel's mortgage.

Governor Lehman today directed Bernard Botein, general attorney of the State Insurance Fund, who has been investigating rumored payroll audit frauds in the fund, to submit his evidence to District Attorneys for presentation to grand juries in those counties where fraud has been uncovered.

Miss Constance Benedict Torney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry W. Torney of 134 East Seventieth Street, was married to William S. McCornick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis B. McCornick of Salt Lake City, yesterday afternoon in the Perroquet Suite of the WaldorfAstoria.

Supreme Court Justice Francis G. Hooley held in Brooklyn yesterday that the action of seven large New York City banks in bonding their employes with Lloyd's of London was unconstitutional and void and a violation of the provisions of Section 50-a of the State Insurance Law.

The Constitutional Convention, by a vote of 134 to 9, this morning adopted on third reading the proposal to permit the Legislature to provide free transportation to children attending denominational schools. This is commonly called "the Catholic Bus Bill."

Republican leaders revealed their position today in the fight between the Democratic Legislature and the Republican judiciary of Pennsy They reversed the opening declaration of Governor Earle on Monday night that he had summoned the special session

The hunt for apartments in this city yesterday continued equally heavy in the East and West Side areas. A few suites were leased from the plans in buildings under construction. Mrs. William Woodward Phelps, widow of Admiral William

Governor Lehman sent a message to the Constitutional Convention today urging the delegates to adopt the Poletti proposal which would grant constitutional protection for the State's water-power resources on the St. Lawrence and Niagara Rivers against exploitation by private interests.

The 1938 marketing quota for the Hawaiian sugar industry was set sept. at 951,753 tons under the last fixing of tonnage to be shipped to the United States, according to the Sept. Wells Fargo Bank of San Francisco.

Dr. Charles B. Hobrecht, chairman of a San Francisco Citizens Committee, announced here yesterday that his committee had launched a drive to raise $15,000 to meet material costs to build a gigantic statue of Saint Francis of Assisi, comparable in size to the Statue of Liberty, to be erected on Christmas Tree Point just north of San Francisco's Twin Peaks.

The Argentine Boxing Federation announced today that the Amateur Athletic Union of the United States had agreed to send a team of boxers to Argentina in October to compete in the Pan-American championships.

With his ship fast aground for fortyeight hours on a rocky shoal more than a mile to the west of the harbor entrance, Commander Washington Perry continued today to refuse to abandon the Brazilian training ship Almirante Saldanha.

The Phillips Petroleum Company, New York City, filed today a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering $25,000,000 of 3 per cent convertible debentures, due on Dec. 1, 1948, and an undetermined number of shares of common capital stock, no par value, to be reserved for conversion of the debentures.

Miss Anita C. Pohndorff, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederico G. Pohndorff of New York, gave a luncheon at her Summer villa here today before the races. Highlighting the first card of a tenday Grand Circuit meeting at Agawam Park, Long Key, Winter book favorite for the Hambletonian, today won the American Stake for 3-year-old eligibles for the Goshen (N. Y.) trotting feature, two weeks away.

Federal and State expenditures to combat depression and unemployment have totaled nearly $22,000,000,000 since 1932. Treasury figures announced today showed $16,647,365,754 in Federal emergency appropriations available up to July 1. State expenditures for relief were set last Spring at $5,100,000,000 by a Senate committee investigating unemployment.

Action tantamount to expulsion was taken by the New York Stock Exchange yesterday against Edwin Weisl, a general partner in Edwin Weisl Co. Actually Mr. Weisl was not expelled, but the Exchange agreed to withdraw charges against him only on his agreement to transfer his membership and never again to have any association with a Stock Exchange firm in any capacity.

Miss Miriam Prentice, daughter of Mrs. James Howard Prentice of this place and the late Mr. Prentice, was married tonight in the garden of her mother's home to Hugh Vincent Wyman -Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Wyman of Aiken, S. C. The Rev. Cecil W. Derivan of the Presbyterian Church of Ridgewood officiated.

Shipments and orders booked by the furniture industry in June narrowed previous declines from a F year ago, indicating that the industry, in line with other major industries, "is beginning to feel the stimulus of increased demand," according to a report issued yesterday by Seidman Seidman, certi- t fled public accountants.

The dollar value of sales on national securities exchanges rose precipitately in June, amounting to $961,991,344, an inicrease of 40.9 per cent over the value of sales in May, but 17.6 per cent lower than in June, 1936, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

The status of about 5,000 foreigners who entered Brazil under six-month tourist visas and remained in the country after their expiration is to be definitely decided by President Getulio Vargas, it is revealed.

Several leases of ground floor space for occupancy by restaurants were among the business rentals reported yesterday. A number of clothing and textile firms also appeared in the lists. The drafting of the Republican reapportionment bill has brought to the surface the underlying hostility between two prominent Republican political leaders and emphasized the friendly feelings existing between the first of them and the American Labor party on one side and good-will between the second and the Democratic party leadership on the other.

Beginning in August, Lima will have to pay twice as much-as heretofore for its three leading morning newspapers. The Comercio, the Prensa and the Cronica simultaneously announced that their price will be raised from 5 to 10 centavos because of the rise in the price of newsprint.

A new competition was officially Introduced at Madison Square Garden last night with the staging of two softball games among women. In a Metropolitan League contest, the Trevoc Girls of Brooklyn vanquished the Newark Poppy Mills team by a score of 6 to 1 in seven innings. The feature game, however, though not a league affair,
Luncheon, Rotary Club, Hotel Commodore, 12:15 P. M. Carl G. Preis presiding. Metropolitan- Museum of Art, 3:30 P. M. Egyptian Collection, Edwin L. M. Taggart.

Colonel Andrew S. Rowan, 81, who threaded his way through Cuban jungles with President McKinley's "message to Garcia," was decorated today by the Cuban Government. The Carlos Manuel de Cespedes Award was bestowed upon Colonel Rowan for "eminent service rendered to the Republic of Cuba in its fight for independence."

A private funeral service for John W. Warde, 26 years old, who killed himself by leaping from the seventeenth floor of the Hotel Gotham late Tuesday night, will be held at 2 o'clock tomorrow afternoon at the New York and Brooklyn Funeral Home, 187 South Oxford Street, Brooklyn. Burial will be in the Warde family plot in Evergreen Cemetery.
In their [pound]500 ($2,500) challenge golf match over 72 holes, Henry Cotton and Reginald Whitcombe of England today defeated A. D. Locke and Syd Brews of South Africa, 2 and 1.

Ten Junkers (German-made) bombing planes this afternoon heavily bombed Tarragona, on government Spain's east coast, fifty miles south of Barcelona. The big planes dropped both explosive and incendiary bombs. Several buildings were set afire. The number of casualties was not immediately available.
John O. Exley, stroke oar of two of the Vesper Boat Club's Olympic championship eights, died at his home in Milford, Del., yesterday in his seventy-second year.

Dr. Ben M. Cherrington, chairman of the Department of International Relations in the University of Denver, was appointed today to be chief of the new division of Cultural Relations of the State Department.
Miss Kate Jane Adams, one of the best known of Chicago's pioneer social workers, died on Monday in the home of Miss M. L. De Bost. She was 68 years old.

Dr. Polyvious N. Coryllos, director of surgery at Sea View Hospital, Staten Island, for the last eight years, died on Tuesday evening at Manhattan General Hospital, where he was a member of the staff of visiting surgeons. He was 57 years old.

A. G. Wright, newly appointed vice president in charge of personnel of the New York Telephone Company, was appointed a director of the company yesterday at a special meeting of the board. Mr. Wright entered the employ of the company in 1907 as an installer, and two years later was made chief foreman. After holding various
The Securities and Exchange Commission revoked the registration of Ernstrom Co., Inc., 41 Broad Street, New York City, as broker or dealer in the over-the-counter market.

It is in much the same spirit of hope, tempered by skepticism, with which they regarded the Anglo-Italian agreement that the French as a whole are regarding Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's effort, by the use of Viscount Runciman, to find a peaceful solution of the Czechoslovak issue.

Brig. Gen. Joseph Patrick O'Neil, known to his soldiers in the Indian campaigns of nearly a half century ago as Fighting Patsy, died today at the age of 74. He retired in 1926. Born in Brooklyn, N. Y., the son of Major Joseph O'Neil of General Nugent's staff in the suppression of the New York draft riots early
Tournament polo was at a standstill in this sector today, but players were out taking part in fast members' matches at Meadow Brook and on the J. S. Phipps estate in Old Westbury.

The British pickaback seaplane Mercury completed tonight an 8,000-mile transatlantic round trip during which she never deviated from her schedule. The Mercury, smaller unit of a unique composite aircraft, landed here at 8:12 P. M. (3:12 P. M. New

The Spanish Government announced tonight that its three-day Ebro River ofpensive had carried Catalan shock troops into the streets of Gandesa, Generalissimo Francisco Franco's headquarters in Southern Catalonia since April 2.

Beethoven's Third ("Eroica") symphony, always a favorite, demonstrated again its enormous popularity when it was vigorously applauded at the conclusion and between movements last night at Lewisohn Stadium. Willem van Hoogstraten was the conductor.

Soviet school authorities are again voicing anxiety about children outside school hours. At a meeting of the presidium of the Moscow Soviet yesterday the directress of the city educational department, Eugenia Sergeyeva, spoke about poor discipline and seemed inclined to put the blame on lack of proper home influence.

The Japanese Foreign Office spokesman said tonight that the "government keenly feels the importance of definitely redemarcating" the ManchukuoSoviet Russian boundary, a longstanding point of friction in the Far East.

Judgment for $45,734 was filed in the County Clerk's office yesterday against P. Hal Sims, bridge authority and tournament player. The judgment was obtained by Lorence Larke, Inc., of Exchange Place, Jersey City, and John D. Lazarus of 1,617 Ocean Avenue, West End, N. J.

Although most manufacturers of men's robes increased the price of their base number from $3.25 to $3.75 this week, some goods were said yesterday to be still, available at the lower quotations. These offerings, however, are not expected to last very long, because of the 5-cents-a-yard advance in robe cloth.

Directors of the Chrysler Corporation declared yesterday a dividend of 25 cents a share on the common stock, payable on Sept. 14 to stock of record of Aug. 16, compared with 50 cents a share paid on June 14 and none in March, 1938. A year ago a dividend of $3.50 a share was declared payable in September, compared with $2 paid in June and with $1.50 paid in March.

The police rescued a 24-year-old woman at noon yesterday who, they say, was contemplating a jump from the parapet of a sixteen-story building at Thirty-second Street and Fifth. Avenue, a little more than a mile south of the Hotel Gotham, where John Warde spent eleven hours on a seventeenth-story ledge before leaping to his death Tuesday night.

A television telephone designed to enable a person to see the one with whom he is talking was patented today by Alexander McLean Nicolson of New York. Nicolson said the system was primarily for interoffice communication in a single building.

An application by the Detroit Canada Tunnel Corporation to purchase certain easements from the Detroit and Windsor Ferry Company, a competitor in carrying traffic across the Detroit River between Detroit and Windsor, Ont., was dismissed today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The failure of Congress to define "unfair methods of competition" has reduced the anti-trust laws to a question of 'judicial discretion. Instead of preventing detriment to public welfare, these laws "require the demonstration of detriment as a prerequisite to control." They have always been punitive in character. Through modification,
The draft of the nationalities statute released yesterday by the Czechoslovak Government was promptly rejected here today as an inadequate basis for negotiations with the Sudeten Germans.

John L. Lewis's name was brought into the trial of four suspended vice presidents of the United Automobile Workers of America, C. I. 0. affiliate, today, and a defense attorney promptly alleged that Homer Martin. president of the U. A. W. A.

Mrs. George Roberts, president of the Garden Club of East Hampton, and members of its executive committee gave a buffet supper tonight in Guild Hall, before the talk in the John Drew Memorial Theatre by the Rev. E. Russell Bourne on Red House, Sheffield, Mass. The committee included Mrs. William A. Lockwood, Clifford H. McCall,

Despite his having been served Tuesday in Harrisburg with a demand for appearance before the grand jury investigating the Democratio administration in Pennsylvania, Senator Joseph F. Guffey sailed yesterday in the United States liner Washington for a vacation in Europe.
The Securities and Exchange Commission has granted an application by the New York Stock Exchange to delist the following securities, effective at the close of the trading session on Aug. 4:

A plea to offset legislation which handicaps police work, by the abolition of "third degree" methods was made by Speaker Heck of the Assembly to the State Police Chiefs Association here today. Major John A. Warner of the State Police scored legislation that would force police to effect an immediate arraignment of persons arrested.

That General Francisco Franco plans a plebiscite to show the world that he has the civilians and the balance of the rearguard supporting his policies is the news received in circles here supposedly close to the Rebel leader.

Miss Lucy Liveright of 22 East Thirty-sixth Street and Sigmund Koch of 370 Riverside Drive took out a wedding license yesterday at the Municipal Building and said they would be married on Saturday at the home of the prospective bride. No announcement had been

The first class of the Military Academy, 458 strong, accompanied by seven West Point instructors, left this afternoon on the army transport Chateau Thierry for their annual tour of Southern army posts. They will observe and participate in demonstrations of large groups
With a borrowed boat and a crew that never had worked together before, Mrs. James Brickell, the former Allegra Knapp, sailed today into the women's championship of Long Island Sound.

Fire Captain Wesley Williams, the only Negro officer in the Fire Department, will attain the rank of battalion chief today when Fire Commissioner John J.- McElligott promotes him and seventy-three other officers.
Sixty-two gold star mothers living in Manhattan, the Bronx, Brooklyn Queens, Nassau County, and points in New Jersey, held their annual Summer reunion at Far Rockaway Queens, yesterday.

Julio Alvarez del Vayo, Spanish Government Foreign Minister, announced today that the government had sent a note to Britain accepting in the main the Non-Intervention Committee's plan for the withdrawal of foreign volunteers from the Spanish war.

The Congressional campaign will be fought by the C. I. O. on three issues. Any amendment of the Wagner act is to be resisted. The other two are passage of the "blacklist" legislation which failed at the last session of Congress, designed to bar from government contracts, loans or grants any employers guilty of violating the Wagner act, and democratization of Congress rules, Lee Pressman, general counsel for the C. I. 0., declared yesterday.

With a splendor that would have gladdened the heart of the steel master himself, Miss Louise Carnegie Miller, 18-year-old granddaughter of the late Andrew Carnegie, was married here today to J. F. Gordon Thomson, Edinburgh lawyer.

Any one with half an eye can see that there are flaws in the kind of cities in which we now live. Mr. Henry Dreyfuss, designer of the Perisphere exhibit for the World's Fair, proposes to show us in six minutes how matters could be improved. His "Democracity" is no inventor's pipe dream. It is,

The Manufacturers Trust Company has sent to all commercial banks in the country a tabulation giving the average prices for the eighteen months prior to July 1 of all bonds listed on the New York Stock Exchange and New York Curb Exchange which qualify as belonging in "group 2" under the new investment and examination regulations.

When it comes to weather prophecy it looks as if Harold Hoffman of The Anchorage at Brielle, N. J., has it down to a system. We'd been planning to investigate the rumor that there was "plenty of tuna" off Brielle, and Hoffman said Tuesday would be a good day, so we were hammering on his door at daybreak.

The Browns, being in about the same mood as yesterday, had little, if anything, to offer today in the way of checking the forward march of the Yankees to another pennant, and had events been allowed to take their normal course it is quite likely the world champions would have clicked off two more victories.
