In its widest decline since the start of the bull movement on June 20, the stock market yesterday went back to the approximate closing level of July 18. Leading stocks were down 1 to 3 points on the day, although at the lowest level the list was down about 1 to 5 points. A few issues showed greater losses.

The General Motors Corporation announced yesterday for the second quarter of 1938 a net profit of $24,786,002, equal after preferred dividends to 52 cents a share earned on 42,920,744 average number of common shares outstanding.

The debenture holders committee for Midland Utilities Company has amended the plan of reorganization for Midland Utilities Company which it filed on Aug. 26, 1937, with the Securities and Exchange Commission under the Public Utility Holding Company Act.

The contract for construction of a new one-story store building to be occupied by F. W. Woolworth Company at 155-63 Main Street, White Plains, Westchester, has been awarded to H. L. Fischer, Inc., according to Brown's Letters, Inc. The Hanbury Corporation

The number of deaths resulting from automobile accidents in the city in the first six months of this year totaled 414, a decrease of nineteen compared with the same period last year, while 14,334 persons were injured, compared with 15,317,

Mayor La Guardia took a day off from his official duties yesterday and spent it with his wife and two children at his Summer home in Northport, L. I. According to information at the downtown City Hall, the Mayor's children have complained recently

Disturbed by charges of Major William E. Lane, Democratic Supervisor of State wil Cortlandt, that the Westchester County Park Commission was incurring annual deficits of $750,000, although its financial statements "purport to show profits," directors of the Park Association of West- of way. chester County voted today at their learn wh organization meeting here to demand a complete analysis of park revenues and expenditures.

Declaring that he would help any man he considered deserving who sought his aid, Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens said yesterday that he had enabled former Borough President John A. Lynch of Richmond to qualify for a city pension by employing him as a

Sales of copper were made abroad yesterday from 10.325 to 10.45 cents a pound c. i. f., European base ports. This compares with a range of 10.28 to 10.325 cents on Tuesday. The domestic price was unchanged at 10 cents. The price of No. 1

The Hotel Elysee, fifteen-story structure at 56-60 East Fifty-fourth Street, was bid in for $300,000, the upset price fixed for the sale, by William L. Carnes on behalf of the bondholders' committee, at the auction in the Vesey Street rooms yesterday.

The government's weekly report of crop condition was issued yesterday as follows: Much uf the greater portion of the cotton belt had a cool, wet week. While rainfall was heavy over the eastern and much of the central portion of the belt, it was lighter over the northwest and much of the west. Except in the central north, the
MANHATTAN BUTLER, HELEN M. (June 16, 1937). Gross assets, $12,828; net, $9,640. To William M. Butler, husband. one-half residue; Barbara Maloney, niece, and Catherine Begg. one-fourth residue each.
Many members of the Summer colony and their guests attended the thirty-first annual flower show which opened this afternoon in the auditorium of the Parochial School on Hill Street.

Any doubt of the real meaning of Field Marshal Hermann Goering's decree compelling Jews to register their property with the government was dispelled today when the Berlin police president, Count Wolf Heinrich von Helldorf, issued detailed instructions regarding the legal formalities for the "Aryanization" of Jewish business enterprises.

In a keynote address yesterday at the Democratic State Convention in Iowa, Secretary Wallace advanced the theory - revolutionary, perhaps, to many of those who have watched with increasing concern the huge deficits of the Roosevelt Administration- that "the debtor position of the entire United States today is stronger than at any time since the early Twenties."

The Willys-Overland Motors Company's recently discontinued practice of picturing and advertising for $395, plus freight and taxes, of an automobile which in fact sells for more money was today formally forbidden by the Federal Trade Commission. The commission explained

Mr. and Mrs. William McNair of New York entertained with a dinner at Leeward, their estate here, tonight. Among the guests were Colonel and Mrs. Wyndham W. T. Torr, Mr. and Mrs. DeForest Grant, Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Stevenson, Mr. and Mrs. Arden M. Robbins,

Joe Hunt of Los Angeles, Hal Surface of Kansas City, Mo., and Mrs. Carolin Babcock Stark of New York, all first ten ranking players, were eliminated from the invitation tournament at the Seabright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club today as favorites were sternly challenged throughout the long session under a stinging sun.

The Social Service Auxiliary of the New York Hospital will receive the residuary estate of Mrs. Josephine Scoville Treadwell, according to her will, filed in Surrogate's Court yesterday. Her estate was formally valued at "more than $10,000."

Despite a very liberal run today of choice and prime steers, the cattle market ruled steady to 15 cents lower. Strictly prime Nebraskas again sold up to $13, with numerous loads at $12.25 to $12.75. Hogs weakened a little, dropping to $10.15. Meanwhile, lambs sold 15 to 25

Savings banks disposed of housing and business parcels in Manhattan in deals announced yesterday. Plans for a gasoline service station were announced in connection with the sale by the Metropolitan Savings Bank of the property at Street and West Broadway.

IN his essay "Of Studies," Francis Bacon wrote that "Reading maketh a full man." Full of what? Full of wonder, sometimes. A glance at the newspapers yesterday brought the information that there was a new world's middleweight champion named-just a minute for. another quick look-Al Hostak.

Due to lack of a quorum the directors' meeting of the United States Leather Company, scheduled for yesterday, was postponed indefinitely. OBrion, Russell' Co., insurance brokers of Boston, have announced that Robert J. Dunkle Jr., Robert IT. Forrest and Julius F. Haller I have been admitted to partnership.

A suit was filed today in Federal court here by former United States Senator Daniel O. Hastings, special trustee of the Standard Gas and Electric Company, against a group of public utility and securities firms and their officials.

Close of Play scores in English first-class cricket matches started today: Worcestershire 406 for nine (Gibbins 178, Howarth 100) vs. Surrey, at the Oval. Warwickshire 238 for nin (Wyatt 66) vs. Hampshire, at Bournemouth.

A scheduled landing of sixty-six United States tourists at Leningrad was delayed today because of a mix-up in connection with a debarkation list. The sixty-six passengers on the liner Reliance telegraphed the United States Embassy here for help when they were told they would not be able to land.

A brief challenging the jurisdiction of the Federal Trade Commission in the field of intoxicating liquors and the trade practices of their manufacturers and purveyors was filed with the commission today on behalf of the Raritan Distilleries Corporation of Perth Amboy, N. J. It is said to be the first test of the commission's jurisdiction in this field to be carried this far.
Dr. Charles Holmes Herty, chemist who has evolved new and improved uses for pulp from Southern pine, died this morning in a local hospital of a heart ailment. He was 70 years old.

Decision was reserved here today by Leo Cluesmann, Deputy Director of the Newark Department of Public Safety, after a departmental trial of Edward P. Reilly, a mechanic's helper in the Fire Department, charged with conduct unbecoming a member of the department at a meeting June 4 in Military Park, during which Norman Thomas, Socialist party leader was attacked

Reporting to Governor Moore today on a survey of living costs for women in industry in New Jersey, John J. Toohey Jr., State Labor Commissioner, estimated that at least 100,000 of the 170,000 to 200.000 women and minors gainfully employed in

The American Labor Party's endorsement has been given to two Brooklyn Representatives, Thomas H. Cullen, Democrat, of the Fourth District, and Emanuel Celler, Democrat, of the Tenth, it became known yesterday.

Taking their cue from the stock market, bond prices declined in somewhat more active trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. Railroad issues were especially weak, having previously scored the best gains, while convertible and speculative issues were hit by the influence of the falling stock market. Losses in the general

The Netherlands Government has decided to appoint a representative in Insurgent Spain and to admit an agent of General Francisco Franco to this country. It was explained that this action was taken in view of the fact that General Franco controls a considerable part of Spanish territory.

Job Nixon, the artist, died today. He was 47 years old. Mr. Nixon attracted a great deal of attention when one of his paintings, "Notre Dame de la Garde," after being shown by the Royal Academy in 1931, slipped by the seelection committee a second time and was shown again by the academy in 1932. The error was
Shipments of tires in June are estimated at 4,025,018 units, as compared with 3,372;118 in May and 5,389,274 in June last year, according to the Rubber Manufacturers Association.

According to statistics compiled here between May 21 and July 1, the Central German Broadcasting Station attacked the Czechoslovak Republic 922 times, criticized President Eduard Benes or the Prague Government 194 times, made attacks on Czechoslovak officials and law courts 172 times, and insulted the honor of the Czechoslovak Army 106 times.

A summons calling for the appearance in Yorkville Court this morning of a representative of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company was served at 11 o'clock last night on Harold Jones, a foreman employed at the subway system's power sub-station at 110 East Nineteenth Street.

Announcement was made here last night of the death yesterday at his home in Woodstock, Vt., of Henry Stanford Brooks, for many years with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and formerely vice president of the 195 Broadway Corporation and the 205 Broadway Corporation.
A 3-year-old girl stole the show yesterday at the annual convention of the Dancing Teachers Business Association at the Park Central as 400 teachers became, for the time being, the pupils of a child.

Floyd Young batted Pittsburgh to a 4-to-2 victory over the Phillies today, the Pirate second sacker driving in all four runs with a single, homer and fielder's choice. Young drove in the first Pirate run in the-second when he singled after Vaughan had walked and stolen second. In the fourth,

Concern over the possibility of a depreciation in the Cuban dollar was expressed by export credit executives participating yesterday in the regular round-table discussion of foreign credits and collections sponsored by-- the foreign credit interchange bureau of the National Association of Credit Men at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Five hundred lots in Bay Shore, L. I., near the Sunrise Highway, were sold by an estate represented by Gordon S. P. Kleeberg, attorneys, to a client of Edwin Goodwin. They were sold through the Kempner

Plans for altering two public school buildings in Manhattan were among projects submitted yesterday by architects. Architects also filed plans for two large apartment houses in Brooklyn. The projects follow:

Word was received here yesterday of the death of Eleazar Pool, a retired business man, father of the Rev. Dr. David de Sola Pool of the Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue, Central Park West and Seventieth Street. Mr. Pool died in his home in Hove, England. He was 81 years old.

The many sold-out bulls and traders who "missed the boat" who have been sitting around lately loudly hoping for a reaction in stock prices which would enable them to get into the market seemed likely yesterday to get their desire. But it often happens on such occasions that those who are quite positive that they would buy on a reaction lose their courage when the time comes.

MANHATTAN BOGGS, VIOLA C. (May 20). Estate, more than $10,000. To Thomas Brandon Boggs, son, executor, 549 Riverside Dr. FISHEL; OLGA RAE (July 17). Estate, less than $10,000. To Marcus Kallman and Emily Kallman, nephew and niece, 815 Park Ave., jewelry, one-fourth residue and remainders in one-fourth residue each; Louise F. Kallman, sister,

Mr. and Mrs. Lewis B. Hendershot of Pittsfield gave a dinner tonight at the Curtis Hotel in honor of Colonel Byron Q. Jones of the War College in Washington and Mrs. Jones. Other guests were Mr. and Mrs. Fred H. Rhodes, Mr. and Mrs. Harrison L. Amber, Mr. and Mrs. Clifford F. Martin and Dr. and Mrs. Erwin H. Taylor.
The Texas Election Bureau today said complete returns from the Third Congressional District showed Representative Morgan Sanders, veteran member of the House, had been unseated. Lindley Beckworth,

At the request of the United States Polo Association the opening date of the Northeastern intracircuit championship to be held at the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club has been shifted to Sunday. Originally the competition was to have begun last Sunday.

Leaves With Pay Special leave of absence, with pay, for seven days, from 8 A. M., Aug. 20, is granted to Fireman 1st grade Gustave C. Marousek, H. L. Co. 40, for the purpose of attending the 39th national encampment of the Veterans of Foreigns Wars of the U. S., to be held at Columbus, Ohio, as a duly elected delegate of Hendrik Hudson Post, 3300 Veterans of Foreign Wars.

A quiet wedding ceremony in New York on Friday will unite Mrs. Laura Merriam Curtis, prominent Washington and New York society leader, and John Messick Gross of York, Pa., vice president of the Bethlehem Steel Company.

Mrs. Winnie Ruth Judd, "trunk murderess" once condemned to the gallows, was under a physician's care at the State Hospital today after swallowing a strong sedative. Dr. B. M. Berger, hospital superintendent, said she obtained the tablets yesterday without the knowledge of attendants.

BEFORE YOU SIGN THE ADVERTISING CHECK, by Mark Wiseman. (Harper, $2.50.) A handbook of advertising analysis for executives. THE BOOK OF INSECT ODDITIES, by Raymond L. Ditmars. (Lippincott, $2.) Entomology for children, illustrated by Helen Carter.

Trading continued fair to slow in local markets yesterday. Steer binds and ribs showed more action than at any time in about two weeks and prices were strong to 50c higher with advance on prime heavy-weights. Fresh pork cuts sold irregular

Hank Greenberg, big first baseman, hit his thirty-second and thirty-third home runs today to lead the Tigers to a 9-to-4 victory over the Senators. The Detroit slugger also hit two for the circuit in the series opener yesterday.

Net asset value of the Utility Equities Corporation on June 30 amounted to $7,210,876, equal to $80.12 each on 90,000 shares of priority stock before deducting the $1 dividend payable on July 15, compared with $6,737,536, or $74.86 a share, on Dec. 31.

The situation at the Polo Grounds yesterday went from bad to worse as the home forces, finding it difficult to obtain base hits let alone runs, suffered the tortures of a 7-0 shutout at the hands of the seventhplace Cardinals.

Charges that records presented by the New Haven Railroad were "phony" came today from Edward A. Pecce, assistant attorney general, in opposing the road's abandonment of eighty-eight stations in Massachusetts.

The French liner Ile de France is sailing today for Havre via Plymouth. Passengers are Mary Boland, Prince and Princess Dominique Radziwill, Princess Cantacuzene, Mrs. Francis Taylor, Mr. and Mrs. Ira Nelson Morris, Marchioness Andree di Bagno, Mr. and Mrs. Harold N. Arrowsmith.

An agreement whereby the New York Hippodrome Opera Company, Inc., recognizes the American Guild of Musical Artists, an affiliate of t he American Federation of Labor, as the sole collective bargaining agent for its artists was reached yesterday by Alfredo Salmaggi and Felix W. Salmaggi, artistic director and general manager of the company, and Leo Fischer, executive secretary of the Guild.

Directors of the Atchison, Topeka Sante Fe Railway took no action again yesterday on the preferred stock dividend usually paid at this time. The fiscal year on which earnings are calculated for dividend purposes by the Sante Fe ended on June 30.

In addition to the plans for the first four buildings of the Queensbridge low-rental housing project in Long Island City, specifications were submitted yesterday by architects for a six-story cold-storage and warehouse building in Jamaica, Queens, to cost $300,000.

Turning a moment from his duties as custodian of pure English, Deputy Mayor Curran tells Commissioner Moses that the statue of Henry Hudson at Spuyten Duyvil "is the ugliest in New York and that's saying a lot." He also derides the Pulitzer Fountain and the Saint-Gaudens monument to General Sherman.
A plea that the Dramatists Guild become a party to the code outlawing ticket speculation was voiced yesterday by two leading independent producers, Jed Harris and John

15th St, 426 E. 25x103.3: David W. Blumenthal, ref, to Dry Dock Savings Bank, foreclosure; ($2). 76th St, 435-7 E, 50x140.9, irreg; Henry W. Herrman to Leo Iscar Herrman, 401 E 76th St: mtg not to merge in fee.

Benjamin Reiss, 45 years old, president of the Master Electrical Contractors Association of Brooklyn, and owner of the Berkshire Electrical Company, Inc., at 50 Court Street, that borough, was found guilty of second-degree perjury yesterday in Special Sessions.

Thirteen striking employes of the Eagle Pencil Company, Fourteenth Street and Avenue C, were arrested yesterday by deputy sheriffs and brought before Supreme Court Justice Peter Schmuck on charges of committing contempt of court by violating a temporary injunction issued on July 15 by Justice Aron Steuer.

Three United States golfers and C. Ross (Sandy) Somerville, the perennial title winner, filled the semi-final brackets of the Canadian amateur golf championship today after two turbulent rounds which saw Canada's best fall before the advance of the little-known American trio.

Linus Frey's two-base smash with the bases full in the fourth inning today gave the Reds a 4-to-2 victory over the Bees and an even break in the four-game series. Frey's hit scored three mates and spoiled Bobby Reis's first start.

Over the roughest track of the meeting, which was the natural result of yesterday's deep footing, Black Wave won the fourteenth running of the Test Stakes that attracted one of the biggest fields of top-notch 3-year-old fillies this season.
The House of Representatives tonight passed the bills for which Governor Earle summoned it in special session on Monday night.

Twenty-nine New York City emPloyes bearing the proud name of Corrigan will play a prominent part in the official reception to their namesake, Douglas Corrigan, transatlantic flier, if plans discussed yesterday in the Mayor's office work out.
The State Executive Committee of the American Labor party, meeting last night in the Hotel Astor, unanimously approved the Republican-Labor party coalition so far as Brooklyn is concerned.

Scores at the close of play today in first-class cricket matches started yesterday follow: Worcestershire 406 for nine declared: Surrey 114 (Parker 65, Perks seven for 58) and 160 for six, at the Oval. Warwickshire 238 for nine declared and 16 for four; Hampshire 423 for seven declared (McCorkell 136, Creese 59, Paris 72 not out). at Bournemouth.

The total of loans and investments of reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City fell $47,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, according to their condition statement issued yesterday. This decline followed an advance of $88,000,000 a week ago.

Some German citizens have incurred the displeasure of the ruling clique by an injudicious choice of ancestors. But this situation, dramatized recently by the systematic destruction of all that was gay, humorous and gemutlich in the city of Vienna, must not be allowed to create the impression that ancestry is the only crime in Greater Germany.

The Constitutional Convention today rescinded the resolution it adopted a month ago calling for adjournment of the convention tomorrow sine die. The resolution was then sent back to the rules committee.

Germany's Four-Year Plan for domestic raw material production is beginning to gain slightly on her growing raw material consumption, which gain promises to increase henceforth, according to a survey issued today by the Business Research Institute.

The National Labor Relations Board today directed the Eavenson Levering Company of Camden, N. J., to offer immediate reinstatement to twentyeight employes named in a stipulation agreement approved June 16 and to place on preferential employment lists a second group of twenty-four and a third group of fifty-four employes.

A convention of Allied Printing Trades Unions of New York adopted a resolution today condemning the American Labor party and proposing that the State Federation of Labor establish a non-partisan committee for rewarding "labor's

WHEN Charles Leo Hartnett, called Gabby and also Leo the Lion, was recently appointed manager of the Cubs, one baseball bystander said: "Well, Gabby's had his last laugh. From now on he'll be just another of those Weeping Willies who manage ball clubs.

The Bronx Bombers dropped three imposing homers upon the roof of the rightfield pavilion today and each landed with a loud and solid thud. But for a reason which presently became utterly inexplicable to Marse Joe McCarthy, the three shots, unloaded by Joe DiMaggio, George Selkirk and Lou Gehrig, failed to disconcert the Browns.

New Yerk Giants vs. Cincinnati Reds, at Polo Grounds, 157th Street and Eighth Avenue ....3:15 P. M. Brooklyn Dodgers vs. Pittsburgh Pirates, at Ebbets Field, Bedford Avenue and Sullivan Place, Brooklyn..........3:15 P. M.

The law at last has caught up with one-eyed Lampeao, Brazil's "Public Enemy No. 1" and long considered the most ruthless bandit-killer in the Western World. Dispatches received today by the Department of National Telegraphs

A number of residences in scattered sections of Brooklyn comprised the properties in that borough reported yesterday by brokers as having changed hands. Among them were the six-family house at 156 Twelfth Street and the four-family house at 1,020 Carroll Street.
Kentucky's Health Commissioner gave his support today to the diagnosis of Governor A. B. Chandler's physician that the Governor drank "poisoned" water here last week.

Communal rioting resulting from a dispute between Burmese Buddhist monks and Indian Moslems over a new Moslem book grew worse today. In three days forty have been killed and 250 injured, mostly Indians. The dead include five.

So much of Par. 1, Special Orders 90, dated July 7, 1938, as pertains to 2d Lt. Albert K. Britten, Q. M.-Res., is revoked. Each of the following Reserve officers, unassigned, is assigned to the organization indicated: 77th Division-1st Lt. Albert K. Britten, Q. M.-Res., 100 W. 85th St., New York, N. Y. 2d Lt. Angelo J. Villios, Inf.-Res., 402 85th St., Brooklyn, N. Y.

The auction sale of plots at Brentwood - in-the- Pines, L. I., which started last week, will be continued Saturday and Sunday, T. F. Archer, auctioneer, announced yesterday. The plots offered adjoin the Brentwood Country Club and the sale is being held under the instructions of Herold Salee, attorneys, of Huntington.

Charging that the Communist administration of the Furriers Joint Council of the International Fur Workers Union, C. I. O. affiliate, was using "Hitler methods" in the union election now in progress, an opposition group in the union appealed yesterday to John L. Lewis, C. I. O. chairman, and other leaders to intervene and help assure an honest ballot.

The report of Stone Webster, Inc., and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on June 30, issued for publication today, shows a consolidated net income after operating expenses, taxes and charges of $576,525, compared with a net of $1,232,020 in the twelve months to June 30, 1937.
Business in the Pittsburgh district last week continued the pronounced upswing which began early in June, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh.
Bert E. Collyer, veteran Chicago sports writer, turf handicapper and publisher of Collyer's Eye, died in Chicago Memorial Hospital tonight, following an extended illness. He was 61 years old.

The fireman in the police property clerk's office at the foot of Thirty-sixth Street, Brooklyn, will start a $125,000 fire at 10 A. M. today. The fuel will consist of 2,975 pounds of raw marijuana weeds picked by policemen throughout the city.

Edward John Penn, 18 years old, and Werner Fred Luck, 23, both of North Pelham, were sentenced today in the Westchester County Court to serve three years and nine months to seven years and six' months in State prison for their attempt to extort $30,000 from Murray Levine of New Rochelle.

A prediction that the next Congress would pass laws to check the use of government money or patronage in political campaigns was made by Senator Walsh, a member of the Senate Campaign Expenditures Committee, as he left for his home in Massachusetts tonight.

A group of bus companies was permitted today, by an order of the Interstate Commerce Commission's joint board for the States of New York and New Jersey, to go under the Hudson River by way of the new Lincoln Tunnel. Most of them previously had operated on routes which carried them across the river on ferries.

The general level of wholesale prices declined in the week ended July 23, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The bureau's index, based on the 1926 average, was 78.7 compared with 78.9 on July 16 and 87.5 on July 24, 1937. A decline in farm product prices primarily accounted for the drop.

Three aeronautical arrangements between the United States and Canada were completed today through an exchange of notes between Secretary Hull and Sir Herbert Marler, the Canadian Minister. They will come into force Monday, superseding a single agreement negotiated in 1929.

Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City in a carefully phrased statement today recommended the nomination of Senator John Milton as the Democratic candidate for the unexpired term of Governor A. Harry Moore in the United States Senate.

Hiram F. Connor, 38 years old, of 1,803 Schenectady Avenue, Brooklyn, former CWA attache of the old Finance Department who rose in four years to be supervisor of a fund in the office of Almerindo Portfolio, City Treasurer, pleaded guilty yesterday in General Sessions

Millard E. Tydings, one of nine Democratic Senators who were active in the fight against the Supreme Court enlargement bill, is decidedly in the lead in the party Senatorial race in Maryland, according to observers.

The National Labor Relations Act was assailed as unfair to employers, the United Mine Workers were called "Red" and Harlan County was painted as a place where men were free to "join or not to join" labor unions today when lawyers for the defense summed up the evidence in the trial of fifty-five coal
The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:
Secretary Ickes told reporters today that he "didn't ask papa" for permission to make an indirect reference to a possible Roosevelt third term in a radio broadcast Monday night.

Violence broke out twice yesterday as the counting of the ballots in the election of the National Maritime Union, which has been hotly contested between Communist and anti-Communist factions, neared completion.

Miss Mary Elizabeth Marcellus, daughter of Dr. and' Mrs. Mott V. Marcellus of Manasquan, was married here this afternoon to Dr. W. Glenn Speicher, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey Speicher of Cumberland, Md., in the Church of St. Uriel the Archangel by the Rev. T. Jerome Hayden.Jr.

Mr. and Mrs. T. Markoe Robertson gave a dinner with dancing tonight at Wyndcote for Mrs. Robertson's son, Anthony Drexel Duke, to celebrate his twentieth birthday. Many additional guests, including older friends of the family and younger members of the Summer colony, came in later for supper and dancing.

Wallace E. Pierce, former Assemblyman, announced today his candidacy for the Republican Congression nomination in the Thirtyfirst district, now represented by Representative Bertrand H. Snell. Mr. Pierce's candidacy again brings to three the aspirants for the nomination.
Reports of a satisfactory response to mid-season furniture promotions spurred buying at the wholesale furniture market here yesterday.

Five hundred and fifty men in Teachers College, celebrating their annual retreat from pedagogy by grappling with T-bone steaks without cutlery, shattered a twenty-twoyear-old tradition at the event yesterday.

The National Maritime Union and the American Merchant Marine Institute, formerly the American Steamship Owners Association, came to an agreement on wages and working conditions yesterday after a long period of negotiations.

The establishment of a new "National Organization of Jews of Germany" for a united front in dealings with the government was announced here today by German Jewry's official organ, the Centralverein Zeitung.
THE BEAST MUST DIE, by Nicholas Blake. (Harper, $2.) A mystery novel. EMILY, by Sally Benson. (Covici, Friede, $2.) Short stories.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles Rockhill were dinner hosts tonight at Crane Hill, Great Barrington, in honor of Mr. and Mrs. Burrows McNeir of Creedmoor, Warrenton, Va. Later the guests attended a performance of "Best Dressed Woman in the World," at the Berkshire Playhouse in Stockbridge.

Steadily increasing costs for the maintenance of the New York City school system, culminating in a record high of $189,955,247 last year, are disclosed in the Board of Education's financial report, made public yesterday. With WPA educational funds added, the total school expenditures were above $200,000,000.

City realty deals announced yesterday centered in sections close to the Triborough Bridge, in the northern part of Manhattan and in the southern part of the Bronx. The six-story apartment house for forty families, at 1,970 Lexington Avenue, on the northwest corner of 120th Street, close to the' Manhattan approach to the bridge, was sold -to a client of Darling McDonald by the Hatikvah estate.

James Thornton, who wrote many of the popular songs when mother was a girl and who brightened the American vaudeville stage for more than half a century, died Wednesday night in his home at 25-30 Thirtieth Road, Astoria, after an illness of fifteen months.

Herbert Mygatt Wilcox, manager of the new products division of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company, with headquarters at East Pittsburgh, Pa., died of a heart attack at 12:45 P. M. yesterday while walking at Thames Street and Trinity Place.
An unprecedented number of postponed games may mean a treat for the baseball fans who like their thrills in daily double doses, but it's a headache to William Harridge, American League president.

The contract for the construction of the Henry Street Settlement and Administration Building at 262 Madison Avenue has been awarded to the Rheinstein Construction Company, according to Brown's Letters, Inc., construction reports.

The International Student Service opened its week of annual conference here tonight with 185 student delegates from twenty-one countries. Professor Clyde Eagleton of New York University is the session's vice president.

In the belief that it would aid the national culture, the Dance Educators Association, which is holding its third annual convention at the Hotel Park Central, went on record yesterday in favor of a national academy of the dance, to be patterned after the old Imperial Russian Ballet Schools.

The Committee on Public Utilities of the Constitutional Convention will reconsider its action in failing to report the proposal by Justice Charles Poletti of New York City, which would prevent alienation of the State's water power resources for the benefit of private power interests. The committee some time ago voted against reporting the Poletti proposal.

Export premiums for grain and a processing tax to keep the price of rye at 20 zlotys for 220 pounds were voted by the Senate yesterday at the close of the extraordinary session in an effort to aid agriculture, which faces a surplus of 1,000,000 tons of the four principal grain products.

Continuing its $10,000,000 program for purchase of surplus clothing to be distributed among the needy, the Procurement Division of the United States Treasury placed orders yesterday for 158,127 garments, valued at $1,358,518.42, according to announcement at the local office at 70 Columbus Avenue.

The twenty-three-family apartment house at 581 Palisade Avenue, West New York, N. J., has been purchased from the Hoboken Bank for Savings by an investing client of the Joseph J. Garibaldi Organization, Hoboken brokers, it was announced yesterday.
Light steel rails were reduced $3 a ton today, but producers made no change on the heavier sections. The new price is $40 a ton, compared with $42.50 a ton for standard sections at the mill.
James P. Lardner, 24-year-old son of the late Ring Lardner, was reported today as among the wounded on the Ebro River front.
The Red Sox moved within two games of the second-place Indians today by slugging their way to a double victory over the White Sox, 13 to 8 and 8 to 5.

The farmer gets the largest share of the housewife's food dollar, prooessors and manufacturers get the next largest share and retail grocars come in third, according to a statistical analysis in "Who Gets Your Food Dollar?" by Hector Lazo and M. H. Bletz, published yesterday by Harpers. This yesterday by Harpers.

When a branch of the Federal Government moves for relief of the taxpayer it is news. The announcement eighteen, he said that the Treasury is establishing here a division of the Internal Revenue De- tending to sustain apartment to consider and pass on con- jury" as applying tested income-tax cases, previously reviewed only in Washington, will be particularly well received in this State, which pays so large a part of the total amount collected.

The new local agency where tax payers may appeal over-assessments on their income tax returns, as announced in Washington last week, was opened informally yesterday for a preview. On Monday its experts will take up 1,500 protested cases involving $110,000,000.

A. E. Duncan, chairman of the board of the Commercial Credit Company, reported yesterday a net income of $5,148,195 for the first half of 1938 after all charges, minority interest and taxes, except possible surtax on undistributed profits.

Lumber production increased last week. Daily average output declined, but less than seasonally, and the adjusted index rose to 67.8 from 67.5, which was a new high for 1938. The figure was 91.2 for the week ended July 24, 1937.
MANHATTAN ACROYD, LAURA R. (Nov. 8, 1937). Estate, $5,000. To Edgar Robie, brother, and Grace Robie, sister, executrix, 875 West End Ave., $200 each; Nellie Kaber, sister, $100.

AS a short story writer Sally Benson's place, if one might venture to suggest it, is midway between the earliest work of Katherine Mansfield and the latest work of Dorothy Parker. Those two bound an epoch of continuing technique that has been enormously influential for some time and that still has its course to run.

A 28-year-old mother of two-chil- BLINI dren was arrested early yesterday morning with an ex-convict and accused of having carried a pistol for him and assisted him in at least one hold-up. The two were charged with assault and robbery and an additional charge of violating the Sullivan law was made against the woman,

A short but violent freak thundershower at 6 o'clock last evening, following a hot humid day in which the temperature reached 88.6 degrees, cut a swath across the metropolitan area, halting a subway line for three-quarters of an hour, blowing down trees, wires and poles, damaging two churches, setting fire to a street car and terrifying pedestrians.
The designation of Jonathan C. Pierce of this city as the Socialist candidate for President of Westchester County was announced here today by members of the Socialist County Committee.

Grain markets showed an easy undertone today, with wheat and corn holding within a range of 1 cent a bushel for the seventh consecutive session. There was scattered buying of in wheat futures in the early trading attributed to export interests, but and as soon as the order was filled prices declined. September closed not unchanged, while the deferred months on the Board of Trade here less were 1/2 cent lower.
KINGS ALPERN, BENJAMIN (May 27, 1937). Gross assets, $12,859; net, $12,859. To wife, Rose Alpern. Chief assets, real and personal property, $12,859. William Alpern, attorney, 353 Stone Ave.

Operating expenses of management investment companies absorbed about 20 per cent of ordinary income from 1927 to 1936, according to Chapters I and II of Part Two of the Securities and Exchange Commission's investment trust and investment company study, submitted today to Congress.

Renewed weakness yesterday overcame the foreign exchange market under the influence of reports, later denied, that Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau, who is now abroad, was discussing a new monetary agreement with Great Britain and France.

Senatorial elections will be held Oct. 23, the Cabinet decided today. These elections, though under restricted suffrage, will be specially important this year because of the conflict between the Senate and Chamber, resulting from the Popular Front victory.
Miss Patsy McWhorter, representing the Newark Women's A. C., retained her title as New Jersey Women's A. A. U. 440-yard free-style swimming champion tonight, winning in 5 minutes 58 seconds.
After holding the league-leading Pirates to one hit for six innings, Al Hollingsworth blew up today and Pittsburgh scored seven runs in the seventh to beat the Phillies. 9 to 2.

The Hamburg-American liner Hansa, arriving today from Hamburg and Channel ports, has among her passengers Mr. and Mrs. George Folwell, the Rev. Charles L. Atkins, the Rev. and Mrs. D. Dolman, Baron Albrecht von Schroeder, Mr. and Mrs. Paul Lux, Christopher Story, Mr. and Mrs. A. E. Burke, Mr. and Mrs. W. H. McCrum, E. F. Altenbein, Mr. and Mrs. Edward H. Heilmann and Mr. and Mrs. Bernhard Segui.

The Day and Meyer, Murray and Young Corporation, 1,166 Second Avenue, New York, applied to the Interstate Commerce Commission today for authority to issue $571,500 first mortgage 3 per cent income bonds and 8,500 shares of $1 par value common stock in consummation of a corporate reorganization.
Summer residents of the Rockaways were warned by the Park Department yesterday against responding to solicitation of funds by. park employes "for any purpose whatsoever."

Miss Isabelle Lawrence Franklin of Flushing, Queens, and Paight's Point, this place, made her debut here tonight at a dance given at the Wee Burn Club by her parents, Dr. and Mrs. Lewis Battelle Franklin.

The will of William Childs of Bernardsville, who founded the chain of Childs restaurants with his brother, the late Samuel Childs, was filed for probate today with Surrogate William R. Sutphen of Somerset County.

Johnny, Kinder, twice winner of the title, came in with a sub-par 70 in the New Jersey State open championship over. the Braidburn Country Club course today, while a lot of other players went out in a thunderstorm.

The previous week's loss in excess reserves was not recovered in the week ended on last Wednesday, the total for the country being unchanged at $3,040,000,000. Memberbank reserve balances actually declined $14,000,000 in the week,

Stung by the contrast between the $3,200-a-year city pension asked by former Borough President John A. Lynch of Staten Island and the $17.44 that the Board of Estimate proposed to give to a city laborer's widow yesterday,

The Canadian Pacific Railway Company earned $2,681,028 in the first half of 1938, against $8,260,153 in the 1937 period. The statement, issued today, listed 1938 gross earnings at $61,287,528 with working expenses at $58,606,499, compared with 1937 gross earnings of $66,790,261 and working expenses of $58,520,107.
The waters about Hood Island, present anchorage of the cruiser Houston, yielded President Roosevelt and his party today bigger fish than they had found elsewhere during the past several days.

What appears to be an amusing development of Mexico's tangled international situation developed tonight when the Foreign Office published the text of a project for modification of the Buenos Aires interAmerican agreement of 1936 on good offices and mediation which will be offered to the Pan-American Conference in Peru in December.

Although sightless, Richard Huber, resident at the clubhouse of the New York Association for the Blind, 605 First Avenue, at Thirtyfifth Street, printed out a farewell note before committing suicide by hanging early yesterday morning in his room. He was 45 years old.

The six-minute tone poem which will company the presentation of a City of Tomorrow in the World's Fair perisphere has been written in fresh, melodious music understandable to the great mass of visitors rather than in modernistic or futuristic idiom, it was disclosed yesterday.

George W. Alger, who was appointed a special master last May to pass upon an amended plan for the reorganization of the RadioKeith-Orpheum Corporation, submitted a report to the court yesterday approving the plan, subject to certain small modifications.
Advances of 2 to 3 cents a pound were announced last night, effective today, on viscose prooess rayon yarns by American Viscose Corporation.

A $285,000 building loan on the new 287-room apartment house under construction on the South side of Thirty-fifth Avenue from Seventy-eighth to Seventy-ninth Street, Jackson Heights, Queens, has been arranged by Ivor B. Clark, Inc., broker, with the Guardian Life Insurance Company of America.

Charles P. Bowen, president and general manager of the Colonial Optical Company, 62 West Fortyseventh Street, died of a heart attack while motoring to Washington on Wednesday, according to word received here last night.

Barbara M. Statler, 21-year-old exdentist's assistant, won a divorce today from Ellsworth M. Statler, 25, A one of the Statler Hotel family heirs. In the brief hearing she merely answered "yes" to some 18 questions based on her complaint and "no" to two or three others.

The number of shares ordered sold in odd-lots on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on July 23 exceeded the shares ordered bought by 63,618, but the aggregate value of the shares bought was $849,954 greater, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

Plans for a four-story building to house a Youth Center on the lower East Side were discussed yesterday with Borough President Stanley M. Isaacs of Manhattan and Newbold Morris, president of the City Council, by a group of six East Side mi residents.

The board of directors of the National Association of ?? Manufacturers voted yesterday, to hold the annual Hosiery Industry Conference in January, instead of October as in former years, and chose Jan. 18 and 19 as tentative dates.

A dispute between pacifists here and in England over the visit here last year of the late Canon H. R. L. Sheppard of St. Paul's Cathedral, London, reached the stage of a legal battle yesterday with the filing of a suit in Supreme Court against Mrs. J. Sergeant Cram,...

Conflict between the Board of Estimate and the City Planning Commission established on Jan. 1 under the new City Charter developed in City Hall yesterday when the board members split on the question of approving two important zone changes sanctioned by the commission.

The Commodity Exchange Administration issued today an order requiring members of the New York Wool Top Exchange to report their daily transactions in wool futures contracts. The order will be effective on Aug. 1. The Exchange is the only wool futures market in this country.

Citing active demand for both shoes and gloves, and reflection of that demand in better call for leather, traders in hides yesterday declared that the lower trend which has developed in hide futures this week has largely ignored the strong position of spot hides.

Fifty officers of the Daughters of the American Revolution, representing nearly every chapter in New Jersey, were honored at a special review of the C. M. T. C. Regiment here at 5 P. M. today. After the parade of the 2,020 youths from New Jersey, New York and Delaware five D. A. R. medals were presented to the outstanding students of the regiment.

A new method of treating arthritis, by substituting "airplane dope" for plaster of paris in making casts to support the legs of afflicted patients, was reported today by Dr. Robert J. Joplin of the Harvard Medical School.

James J. Hines, Tammany district leader, lost yesterday his fight against a trial by a blue ribbon jury. Justice Ferdinand Pecora ruled against him in Supreme Court at the end of an extended hearing enlivened by a clash between Lloyd Paul Stryker, counsel for Hines, and District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey.

complying with a request of the Wisconsin State Board of Agriculture and Markets, members of the National Cheese Institute, including Wisconsin and Chicago dealers, today named nine representatives to a proposed emergency price fixing committee to take the place of the Wisconsin Cheese Exchange of Plymouth, Wis.

Dr. Harcourt A. Morgan, chairman of the TVA board since President Roosevelt removed Dr. Arthur E. Morgan for contumacyy," testified today in defense of- the board's action in paying the International Agricultural Corporation $680,000 for about 550 acres of phosphate lands in Middle Tennessee, for which the company had paid only $125,000 a short time before.

Three men were found guilty by Magistrate Irving Ben Cooper in Long Island City Court yesterday of doing electrical work without having proper certificates from the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity.

The National Boxing Association will recognize Al Hostak of Tacoma as world middleweight champion despite the action of the New York commission in declaring the title vacant, said Edward C. Foster, executive secretary of the N. B. A., today.

It was found in a check-up of the entries last night for the Bayside Yacht Club's Block Island race that thirty of them were prepared to set sail at noon today on the 225-mile voyage around Block Island and back. It will be the eighteenth annual event of the kind, and at a dinner in the clubhouse in Bayside, Queens, final instructions and time allowance handicaps were announced.

Engineering construction awards for the week amounted to $48,716,000, which is 8 per cent above last week and 3 per cent above the volume for the corresponding period of 1937, according to Engineering News-Record.

Joey Fontana, 130 pounds, Bensonhurst, scored a technical knockout over Jerry Mazza, 129, Bensonhurst, in 12 seconds of the fourth in the scheduled eight-round feature bout before 5,000 at Fort Hamilton, Bay Ridge, last night.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total bills discounted for the system as a whole to be at the lowest point of the year to date.
The Dollar Line signed off the entire crew of the liner President Harrison at her Jersey City pier yesterday and made arrangements to ship them on to San Francisco by rail.

The National Safety Council reported today that growing realization of the tragedy and economic cost of automobile accidents as well as other factors had resulted in the saving of 3,670 lives on the country's streets and highways in the first half of 1938.
Registration statements covering securities for about $270,000,000 became effective in June, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

Witnesses before the Senate Civil Liberties Committee testified today that they were beaten by Republic Steel Corporation policemen as they distributed union literature in the vicinity of plants but not on company property.

Appointment of M. Quinn Shaughnessy as assistant director of the registration division to succeed Robert O'Brien, recently appointed assistant general counsel, was announced today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Railroad management and the Brotherhood of Trainmen ended today the second week of debate on a 15 per cent wage cut just where they started on July 18. Each side declared that it would not budge from its original position.

Premier Hepburn of Ontario took a train and boat today as the next step in his tour of Western Canada, while his plane took off on a direct flight to Vancouver. The Premier and Benjamin Smith, New York broker, boarded the afternoon train of the White Pass and Yukon Route for the eightymile rail trip to Skagway.

The housing program in the Constitutional Convention has come through its first real test with flying colors. Former Governor Smith, Robert Moses and others, whose opposition was formidable because of their recognized integrity, failed by the close vote of 66 to 61 to get a provision into the Baldwin amendment which would have exempted real estate from taxation to support new housing projects.

Jesse R. Salmon, former chairman of the Essex County Republican Committee, died this afternoon in the Franklin Memorial Hospital where he was taken last Wednesday for treatment of an intestinal ailment.

Loans by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation in conjunction with the Public Works Administration's loans and grants may increase the construction program by $250,000,000, Secretary Ickes said today, making possible a construction cost of $1,917,000,000 by the middle of 1940.

The estate of Howland Spencer at Krum Elbow in the town of Lloyd, Ulster County, located opposite the estate of President Roosevelt at Hyde Park, has been bought by twenty followers of Father Divine. Gaius C. Bolin Jr., Poughkeepsie attorney, confirmed tonight reports of the transaction, which was completed through his office.

Brisk sales and slightly better prices than the 1937 average marked today the rep opening of the 1938 tobacco auction season in fifteen cities in Georgia. Prices ranged as low as 4 cents and as high as 52 cents a pound. Although official figures were not available,

The $315,000,000 transit unification amendment won bipartisan approval in the Constitutional Convention today. Amendments were few in number, and politics was absent for the most part as the convention indicated beyond a doubt that the proposal would be adopted and submitted to the people for ratification In the Fall.

A second note was presented to the Mexican Government today protesting the seizure of oil fields in which Netherland nationals have interests, it was announced here. The note sets forth juridical considerations designed to show that the seizure was unconstitutional.

Judge George L. Donnellan, in discharging two of the three New York County grand juries for the July term, announced from the bench yesterday unanimous opposition by the nine judges of General Sessions to Mayor La Guardia's plan, now under consideration in the State Constitutional Convention
Isaac Leifer of Brooklyn, who is being held here on charges of narcotic smuggling, was questioned today by a French magistrate and professed to be the victim of a fraud.

Dowager Queen Marie's dying wish for a reconciliation between her estranged sons, King Carol and former Prince Nicholas, was disclosed in her will published today. "Submit without discord to my last wishes," the testament implored her children, and called on God to bless Carol in his work for peace and prosperity in Rumania.

Two books of New England poetry soon to be published by Macmillan are "Maine Ballads," by Robert P. Tristram Coffin, and "The Bright North," by Abbie Huston Evans. Mr. Coffin's book is scheduled for Aug. 23 and Miss Evans's for Tuesday.

The directors of the Baldwin Locomotive Works voted today to pay in preferred stock . instead of cash coupons due on Sept. 1 on the company's refunding-mortgage bonds, 6 per cent convertible series, due in 1950.

Average daily sales in 400 men's wear chain stores in June were about 15 per cent lower than in June, 1937, the Commerce Department reported today, although it found June sales 22 per cent higher than those in May. In June last year the increase over May was only 7 per cent.

Buying of men's worsted suitings was on a moderate scale this week, although the better prices and disappearance of some inside trading levels tended to discourage operations in some quarters, the New York Wool Top Exchange Service reported yesterday in its weekly review of the wool goods markets.

After rejecting several resolutions including two aimed at Nazi persecutions and the appointment of Hugo L. Black to the Supreme Court, the American Bar Association today approved the recommendations of its special committee on administrative law.
National magazines, which are good indices of advertising trends because space is sold so far in advance of publication, continue to give definite indications of a decided upturn in Fall linage.

Two young men who became known as the "hillbilly bandits" lost a chance for another songfest early yesterday when a prospective victim lunged at one of them, grabbed his wrist, and put up a fight which resulted in the capture of both the vocalists.

Before one of the largest midweek galleries to fill the stands here in years, Sidney Wood, Frank Parker and Bryan Grant made their exits today from the invitation singles of the Seabright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club which, in one and the same afternoon, said adieu to a former Wimbledon champion and the third and fourth ranking players of the country.

General Enrico Aginari, Marquis of San Marzano, died yesterday at the age of 69. General Asinari was a Senator and Minister of State, an honorary position, and had been decorated with the Cross of the Military Order of Savoia for energetic command of Italian troops during the occupation of Fiume in 1919.
Mr. and Mrs. Gerard W. Betz of this city gave a luncheon here today, at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Weld Betz, to Hollister Sturges Jr. of Stone Ridge, N. Y.
The following Marine Corps changes for the week ended July 28 were announced today: BRIGADIER GENERAL Upshur, W. P. appointed Brigadier General.

A suit to enjoin the officers and directors of the Ludlum Steel Company from holding a stockholders' meeting on Aug. 10 to vote on the proposed merger with the Allegheny Steel Company was brought in the Supreme Court here yesterday by Lilly and Henry Bijur, acting individually and as executors of the estate of the late Supreme Court Justice Nathan Bijur.

Round table conferences between William O. Douglas, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, and William McC. Martin Jr., president, and other representatives of the New York Stock Exchange, were resumed here today when the officials of the Exchange were the guests of Mr. Douglas at luncheon.

The promotion of R. Kenneth Fairman, '34, acting graduate manager of athletics at Princeton, to the position of full graduate manager was announced today by Professor Burnham N. Dell, '12, chairman of the University Council on Athletics.

No word has been received by the w Treasury of any monetary negotia- w tions between this country and fe France or Britain, Roswell Magill, Acting Secretary of the Treasury, said at his press conference today. He made the statement in commeeting on press reports of meet- it ings in the last few days between Secretary Henry Morgenthau Jr. and French officials in Paris.

A picture of how the "largest garden apartment community in the country" will appear was given yesterday by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company as the street and drainage plans were approved by the Board of Estimate and permission was granted for the closing of streets on the 129-acre site in the Bronx preliminary to starting grading and construction.

Hotel men, as hosts to visitors from this country and abroad, play an important role in the life of the city, Courncilman Joseph Clark Baldwin declared last night at a dinner given at the Hotel Astor in honor of Robert D. Howard, director of sales and business promotion and former banquet manager of the hotel.

The constitutionality of the 1938 law setting a tax on the privilege of doing business in the District of Columbia is being tested, but no decision can be obtained in pending cases affecting this law until the Fall,' Hugo Mock, counsel, has advised the members of the Toilet Goods Association.

A Japanese force of unreported strength is attacking Hwangmei, Just inside Hupeh Province on the Anhwei Province border, according to official sources here. How the Japanese reached Hwangmei, which is southwest of Taihu and only 100 miles from Hankow, was not explained.

Continuing the whirlwind pace set last week when it sprinted through three special meetings in five minutes, the Board of Education again startled old-timers at 500 Park Avenue yesterday by completing two meetings in three minutes.

The Spanish Republicans' offensive across the Ebro River is still making headway, although its progress has slowed down in the last forty-eight hours. The Republicans yesterday reached positions a few miles north of Gandesa, about twelve miles south of the Ebro.

Emmett Hay Naylor, prominent lawyer who since 1914 was counsel for the Writing and Cover Paper Manufacturers Association, died here yesterday of a heart attack while in swimming at his Summer home, Greenbriar.

Finishing play a few minutes before a heavy thunder shower descended, the Long Island polo four turned back the Camels, 9 to 5, on the Phipps's old field today as both teams inaugurated their Hempstead Cups tournament schedules.
Five more aviators late last night were added to France's long list of victims of military aviation accidents.

Deals on Long Island as reported by brokers yesterday involved a number of residential properties, a vacant plot and two industrial buildings. The Kennedy Agency, broker, reported that it had sold the onefamily dwelling with two-car garage at 189-29 Forty-fifth Avenue in the Auburndale section of Flushing for Olaf Olsen to Herbert E. Carey, who will occupy the property.

Jascha Heifetz was the soloist with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night at the Lewisohn Stadium. This was the fourth consecutive year the violinist had appeared at these concerts. He had always attracted huge audiences there, but never before as large a one as that of yesterday evening, Which was estimated at almost 19,000 persons.

An unidentified vandal, who apparently wielded a sharp lead pencil, went through a corridor in the west wing of the New York Hospital last Monday slashing and puncturing five valuable oil portraits of .physicians and surgeons, long dead, who were associated with the hospital, which is the second oldest in the country.
Ninety guests attended the golfing dinner of the Newport Country Club tonight, marking the close of the first day of play in the twelfth annual invitation tournament of the club.
Early letters of George Bernard Shaw, written in a frank and intimate vein and revealing the playwright as not always as sure of himself as he now appears to be were sold at Sotheby's today.

The following Coast Guard changes for the week ended July 27 were announced today: LIEUTENANT COMMANDER McCabe, G. E., headquarters, to Hoffman Island, N. Y., in connection with establishment of maritime service training station.
Japan's veteran tennis stars, Jiro -Yamagishi and Fumiteru Nakano, smashed out straight-set victories to send Japan away to a 2-0 lead over Canada in their North American zone Davis Cup match today.

A career in the British Army, hitherto almost a closed preserve for the privileged classes, was thrown open to talent by a series of sweeping reforms announced in the House of Commons today by Leslie Hore-Belisha, War Secretary.
Great Britain's move to mediate the Czechoslovak minority quarrelwith German consent-promises to lead to broader political talks between Britain and Germany.

Active cooperation of the fur trade in the Apparel and Accessories Building at the New York World'. Fair was pledged at a meeting yesterday of the World's Fair Committee of the Associated Fur Coat and Trimmings Manufacturers, Inc., according to announcement by H. Irving Arnheimer, chairman.

A hearing has been set for Aug. 15 by the Securities and Exchange Commission on a declaration by Eastern Utilities Associates with reference to the issuance of an unsecured 3 per cent promissory note of $1,625,000 due on Aug. 1, 1941, to the First National Bank of Boston to refund an outstanding note.

An attack on the Federal Government's crop control program was made today by the Corn Belt farm dailies, composed of four publications of the livestock industry. "The production control business travels round and round and becomes more difficult with each revolution," the dailies asserted.

Miss Emma D. Huebner, president of the Hunter College Alumnae Association, 1914-18, and for many years identified with civic and charitable work in New York, died yesterday at her home, 340 Riverside Drive, after a long illness.

Chess and checker tournaments for men and women more than 50 years old will be conducted during August at various Park Depart- "1. Resolved, th ment playgrounds in the city, Park Commissioner Robert Moses announced yesterday.

Lieut. Col. Stewart S. Giffin, Coast Artillery Corps, U. S. A., yesterday was found not guilty by a twelve-officer general court on Governors Island of conduct unbecoming an officer and a gentleman, but was found guilty on the lesser charge of discrediting the service

Sir Hubert Wilkins, explorer, said today he would join the projected Lincoln Ellsworth expedition to the Antartic. Sir Hubert flew west to interview physicians in Denver, Seattle and San Francisco to select one for expedition doctor.
The Detroit Tigers won their fifth straight game today, hammering three Washington pitchers for a 12-to4 victory and a clean sweep of the series here.

Special deputy sheriffs may not possess or carry a revolver without a license, except when they are performing the acts for which they are especially deputized, Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. ruled today.

A large part of the leasing activity reported yesterday involved apartments in the section east of Central Park. In the house at 655 Park Avenue, Desiderio Parreno leased a large suite through Culver, Hollyday Co., Inc., brokers, who also announce the rental of quarters in 147 East'Seventy-second Street to Morgan S. A. Reichner and in 356 East Fifty-seventh Street to William S. Koenig.

Tennessee was startled today to find itself squarely in the spotlight as a result of the declaration by the Senate Campaign Expenditures Committee in Washington yesterday that questionable devices to influence votes and raise funds were being used on a wholesale scale by the two major sides in the Democratic primary.

Mrs. Joseph F. Holleran of Greenwich led a field of sixty-one players in the weekly one-day tournament of the Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association with a 43, 39-82 over the Rye Country Club course today.

Frank Silvio, veteran sprinter of the New York A. C., scored the outstanding singles victory today in the senior quartermile dash as crews from Western Canada and the United States divided honors at the opening of the Canadian Henley regatta.

Nibble Hanover today won the American Stake 2-year-old trot, carrying a purse of $4,485 in the feature race of the second day of Grand Circuit racing here. The son of Calumet Chuck, with Harry Whitney driving, easily captured the event in straight heats.

A program of wide expansion of local and long distance telephone systems in Argentina was announced yesterday by Colonel William F. Repp, vice president of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, in charge of the company's operations in South America.

The National Labor Relations Board today invalidated an A. F. of L. closed shop contract between the International Association of Machinists and the Serrick Corporation of Muncie, Ind. The board also ordered the company to reinstate eighteen employes discharged for not joining

There are at least 23,000,000 cutover acres and 5,000,000 more of abandoned farms in the South. Thanks to the chemical researches of the late Dr. Charles H. Herty they have become a Promised Land on which pulpwood suitable for paper-making can be grown more rapidly than in Canada. And if paper, including newsprint, is possible, why not other cellulose products and hence a whole industry based on cellulose?

An increase of $2,519,000 in Dominion Government deposits over the previous week was reported today in the Bank of Canada's statement for the week ended on July 27. Chartered bank deposits decreased $14,000. The ratio of net reserve to notes and deposit liabilities was 56.40 per cent this week, 56.51 last week.

The Interstate Commerce Commission granted today authority to the Boston Albany Railroad to issue $3,015,000 of main line 41/2 per cent first mortgage bonds, Series B, to be delivered to the New York Cen- to tral Railroad in discharge of obligations incurred by lease arrangement.
Except in special cases, men in Germany will not be allowed to marry until they have completed their labor and army service. No exceptions will be allowed when the woman is older than the man.
The volume of bank clearings of the twenty-two principal cities throughout the country for the week ended on Wednesday declined 14.6 per cent from the corresponding week a year ago.
The news service of Konrad Henlein's Sudeten German party says tonight that a wide gulf separates the Germans and the Czechs and that it is most unlikely to be bridged.

During the week ended July 27 member bank reserve balances decreased $14,000,000. Reductions in member bank reserves arose from increase from $7,000,000 in Treasury cash, $8,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve Banks and $29,000,000 in non-member deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts and a decrease of $2,000,000 in reserve bank credit,

Touring United States track and field athletes won five out of six events today as a two-day interhational meet opened. Ben Johnson of Columbia started an American sweep of the track events when he captured the 100-meter dash in 10.4 seconds.

The Federal Trade Commission today announced that Standard Brands, Inc., 595 Madison Avenue, New York, has agreed to discontinue certain misleading representations in connection with the sale of Flieschmann's compressed yeast.

Johnny Levinson's knack of sinking long putts when he needed birdies today enabled the New England amateur golf title defender to gain a 2-up victory over Joe O'Connell of Nashua, N. H., in their firstround match at The Country Club.

There is no rest for the man or woman who aspires for higher rank in the academic world. They teach during eight or nine months of the year and then must attend Summer school. There they pile up credits with which to impress boards of trustees. Yet their work at this season is light compared with the labor of those school-men who feel under compulsion to write books.

Mr. and Mrs. Marshall Langhorne of Washington entertained with a large tea at Saltair today in honor of Baron Mario Bucovich. Guests included Major and Mrs. George G. McMurtry, General and Mrs. J. W. Kilbreth, Mr. and Mrs. William McNair, Mr. and Mrs. William I. Moore, Prince and Princess Burhaneddin,

Pensioned On their own applications, to take effect 12 midnight, July 31: PATROLMEN-Daniel Reynolds, office of the Fifth Deputy Police Commissioner, old record room, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed April 11, 1905. Peter Cassidy, 104th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Oct. 21, 1907.

The life story of Mr. and Mrs. Vernon Castle, tentatively known as "Castles in the Air," has been placed on RKO's schedule as the next Ginger Rogers-Fred Astaire vehicle. It had been designed for Astaire alone, but the studio has found it advantageous to feature the two dancers.

Many residents of the Summer colonies at Lake George are indignant over an automobile accident which occurred near here Saturday night, July 6, and resulted in the death of two young women and the injury of six other persons, four seriously.

A reviewer in The 'Times -"of London loosed a critical barrage today against Compton Mackenzie's book, "The Windsor Tapestry," which energetically takes former King Edward's side in discussing the events that culminated in his abdication. The review declared that the book was "a glaring example" of the dictum that autobiography was "the only tolerable biography of a living person."

The first week-end of racing will see many guests arriving at villas of the Summer colony, and some came here today, among them Mr. and Mrs. Ewing Butler Hawkins, who have been on their wedding trip in California. They are guests of Mr. and Mrs. John Clinton Clark at Chestwood.

A regular membership on the New York Produce Exchange was sold yesterday for $900, an increase of $300 over the last previous transaction. The sale established a new high price for the year and compared with the low last April, when a membership changed hands for $250.

Plinio Salgado, supreme chief of the Integralist (Brazilian Fascist) party, which was dissolved by the government last November, was officially charged today before the Security Tribunal with having abetted the Integralist uprising last May 11.

Stuyvesant Wainwright, who is at Gull Crest, the Summer home of his father, Carroll Livingston Wainwright, for the season, entertained at a dinner there tonight for forty young people. There also were a scavenger hunt and a dance.

The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation expects to begin on Aug. 8 payment of insured claims of depositors in the Winooski Savings Bank, Winooski, Vt., James E. Markham, counsel for the corporation. announced tonight.

Floyd B. Odlum, president of the Atlas Corporation, at a Securities and Exchange Commission hearing today, opposed a plan proposed by Associated Gas and Electric interests for reorganization of the Utilities Power and Light Corporation on the ground that it runs counter to all rules of fairness laid down by the courts in reorganizations under Section 77b of the Federal Bankruptcy Act, as well as all rules of equitable treatment.

The former fishmonger who wrote "It's a Long, Long Way to Tipperary," the song with which Great Britain and America marched to war, died today-the twenty-fourth anniversary of the outbreak of the World War.

Governor Lehman was announced yesterday as one of a number of public officials who will serve on the reception committee to greet delegates to the second World Youth Congress, to be held Aug. 16 to 24 at Vassar College, Poughkeepsie. The representatives of Chile, China, Argentina, Uruguay, Africa and the Near East are already on their way to New York.

In promoting seventy-four firemen to higher ranks yesterday, Fire Commissioner John J. McElligott cautioned members of his department against taking unnecessary risks in trying to reach the scene of a fire a few minutes early. Present traffic conditions make it imperative, he said, for drivers to have complete control of their machines at all times and to slow up at intersections.

An increase in June operations of 11 per cent over May and 15 per cent over June of last year in the shirt and pajama industry was reported yesterday in the monthly survey of the National Association of Shirt and Pajama Manufacturers.

These are the new shows that the Summer theatres will be seeing next week- new in the sense that they have never been produced on Broadway, though one or two of them have been done on the rustic stages in other seasons:
Justice Thomas J. Cuff in Supreme Court here promised today a decision on the proposed receivership for the Lido Club Hotel property at Long Beach when an adjourned hearing is held Aug. 8.

Due to the refusal of a real estate agent to produce records regarding a proposed site in Branch Brook Park for the slum clearance program in Newark, it was announced here today by Fred W. Ehrlich, director of the State Housing Authority, that he had revoked his approval of the site, which was submitted by the Newark Housing Authority.

Eldrige St. 138, 25.10x87.6: Frank Goldman to Abr. Madruss. 1,268 Etratford Ave; P trig $20,000; due etc as bond $5,975. Hester St, 60, 66.9x80.6x irreg; Abr. Margulis to George L. Allin. 124 No. Broadway, White Plains, N. Y., execr C. Field Bishop; p mtg due Jul 15, 1948, 4-4 1/2% $33,500.

Merchandise inventories in department stores in the local Federal Reserve district declined more than seasonally during June and at retail valuation were 11.6 per cent lower at the end of the month than at the end of June, 1937, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

More than three years after his original defeat in the Supreme Court, John M. Perry of New York returned today his fight on the government's gold policy to the highest court. He filed a brief appealing from a Court of Claims decision of last May in the same case where the Supreme Court held he had not shown he had suffered damages through abrogation of the gold clause.

Three railroads-announced yesterday that they would meet interest payments due on Aug. 1. The Baltimore Ohio Railroad notified the New York Stock Exchange that it will meet the interest payments, amounting to approximately $2,500,000, on its bonds due on Aug. 1.

Tony Galento, well on the road to recovery from a serious attack of broncho-pneumonia, settled down to a long siege of card playing in his hospital bed today by taking his manager, Joe Jacobs, in a twohanded rummy game.

Major Gen. Frank R. McCoy, commander of the Second Corps area for more than two years and known as a diplomat and one of the army's outstanding officers, will be honored with a formal military review at Governors Island at 10:30 A. M. today.

The Indians went three scoreless innings with the Athletics today before a thunderstorm caused a postponement. The Tribe, clinging to second place, did not get a hit against Edgar Smith, youthful southpaw, but did receive three walks. Philadelphia nicked Denny Galehouse for three singles and two passes.

Marcel Lachevre, a secretary aboard the French liner Normandie, died on the operating table today after the liner had turned back from Southampton, England, and transferred him at Havre to a tug that rushed him ashore.

Bernard Botein, general attorney for the State Insurance Fund, announced yesterday that evidence he had obtained that the fund had been defrauded through manipulated payrolls and bogus records would be furnished next Monday afternoon to District Attorneys Thomas E. Dewey of Manhattan, Samuel J. Foley of the Bronx and William F. X. Geoghan of Brooklyn.

Mr. and Mrs. Francis A. Brewer of Brookline and Bass Rocks, Gloucester, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mrs. Constance Brewer Reyburn, formerly of New York, to Cyrus Brewer of Cambridge, Mass., and Eastern Point, Gloucester, son of the late Mrs. T. Chittenden Hill of Boston.
A major upturn in iron and steel production in Alabama was indicated today by the announcement that two additional blast furnaces would be blown in within a week.

Things are looking much better for the surf anglers these days, particularly on the Jersey coast. A number of inquiries have been received in connection with various points along the stretch of beach, so we'll report on the results of the last three days in this area.

William J. Callahan, Mayor of Keene and dean of the New Hampshire House of Representatives, died here yesterday of a heart attack at his home at the age of 77. He was serving his first year of a two-year term as Mayor.

The Siberian newspaper, Pacific Ocean Star, tells of a "great purge" in the Soviet Russian Far East to frustrate what the newspaper terms Japan's efforts "to destroy our strength from the inside." "In the past few months a great purge was carried on, and it still continues," the newspaper says.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Abraham Fishbein in his letter in THE TIMES has permitted an understandable dislike of the policy of this country toward aggressor nations to lead him into several false conclusions.

The story of a Brooklyn woman who was ordered out of bed at 1 A. M., taken to a police station and ordered to post a $500 bond, because she had failed, through haste, to pay a hotel bill of- $4.50 in Monticello, N. Y., was heard yesterday before Magistrate Nicholas H. Pinto in Flatbush Court.

An irregular opening was followed by a moderate recovery in bond values yesterday in slower trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Speculative interest was centered on second and intermediate grade railroad issues, the market for those loans being stimulated somewhat by announcements by officials of several border-line
Canadian manufacturers, according to the British Air Mission to Canada, which arrived here today, may be producing heavy bombing planes for the British Government this Autumn.

After being postponed for nearly a week because of wet fields, play in the national junior polo championship is slated to start today at the Burnt Mills Polo Club in Bedminster, N. J. The four teams entered in the tournament are all to see action this afternoon, starting at 5 o'clock. The opening match will pit the Bostwick Field quartet,

The trial of fifty-five defendants for conspiring to deny to labor in Harlan County, Ky., the rights guaranteed under the Wagner act is about to go to the jury, with the Government demanding that the individuals accused be sent to prison. It will be interesting to watch, in the verdict finally handed down, whether the jurors appear to have discriminated as to guilt among the defendant coal operators, corporations and county officers.

The most astonishing and most humiliating 6pen charge of bad faith yet made against the Japanese military in Shanghai developed yesterday afternoon when Colonel Charles F. B. Price, commanding the Fourth United States Marines here, re-established control posts on Bubbling Well Road through the American defense sector.

Another Mauretania glided down the slipways of the Cammell Laird shipyard here today. A strong northwest wind and the inrunning Mersey tide swung her stern around as she came to anchor, her bow headed for the Irish Sea and the Atlantic, over which her famous predecessor ruled for twenty-odd years.

The National Labor Relations Board contended today in a petition filed with the Supreme Court that men who strike in connection with a labor dispute retained the status of employes even if under contract not to strike.

Mr. and Mrs. George Whitney Jr., who are on their wedding trip, sailed yesterday from Los Angeles for Honolulu. Mrs. Whitney is the former Miss Phyllis Stevenson. Mr. and Mrs. Wladimir W. Bouimistrow of Oyster Bay, L. I., are at the Chateau Frontenac in Quebec.
