The late Benjamin N. Cardozo, associate justice of the United States Supreme Court, bequeathed his residuary estate to Columbia University with the request that it be used to found or maintain a chair of jurisprudence in the Law School.
Briggs Cunningham sailed his SixMeter Fun to a clean sweep in the opening trials today to determine the four yachts that will represent the United States against the British next month.

Ball players and swimmers staged a debate before the Board of Estimate yesterday on the future use of Hudson Park, in lower Manhattan, and the swimmers won when Park Commissioner Robert Moses got an $80,000 appropriation from the board for the pool and other improvements.

Featuring the contracts for commercial space reported by brokers yesterday was one for twenty-one years signed by Stouffers-Fifth Avenue, Inc., for the entire third floor and half of the fourth floor in the five-story Cullman Building, 538-40 Fifth Avenue.

The old maestro, Carl Owen Hubbell, checked the backward flight of the Giants yesterday at the Polo Grounds. His famed screwball working to perfection, his pitching inspiring his mates to an exhibition that was flawless, at times even highly exciting, Hubbell interrupted the losing streak of the Terrymen after five straight as he beat Frankie Frisch's Cardinals, 2 to 1.

The War De, apartment released the following orders to' day dated July 27: COLONELS Philoon, W. C. (Inf.), General Staff Corpm, 16 days' leave, Aug. 12. Jordan, H. B., Ord. Dept., Wahington, D. C., to Nansemond Ordnance Depot, Virginia.
The weekly statement of the Bank of France, issued today, shows the following changes, in francs:

Women of Arkansas to a greater extent than ever before will participate in the Democratic primary election on Aug. 9 on the issue of whether Mrs. Hattie W. Caraway, the only woman member, is to be returned to the United States Senate.

Eight new species of snakes, mostly from Africa, have been added to the collection of the Barrett Park Zoo of Staten Island, which now houses twenty-eight species of poisonous reptiles, according to an announcement yesterday.

Thomas J. Watson, president of the International Business Machines Corporation, announced yesterday that net income of the corporation for the six months ended on June 30 amounted to $5,065,803 after deducting $385,768 blocked foreign net profits, but before providing for Federal taxes.

The eighth decennial meeting of the International Missionary Council will be hed in Madras, India, Dec. 13 to 30, it was announced yesterday at the offices of the Foreign Missions Conference of North America, 156 Fifth Avenue.

An amended plan of reorganization of the Midland Utilities Company, just filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission in Washington, provides for an increased allotment of stock in the new company to holders of Midland Utilities prior lien and preferred stocks and to the Midland United Company, which not only controls Midland Utilities but which also is a large unsecured creditor.

The highest temperature of the year--90 degrees--a slight earthquake and a thunder shower, which brought the mercury down eight degrees in half an hour, combined to give New York another meteorologically exciting day yesterday.

Ralph Flanagan of Miami, Fla., carried the colors of the Miami Biltmore Club to victory in the onemile swim at the national A. A. U. men's swimming championships tonight. Flanagan's time of 21 minutes 6.3 seconds failed to approach his national record, 20:42.6, set

Judge Albert H. Holland of Morris County today sentenced Ira F. French. 21 years old, and Henry Winters, 25, both of Hoboken, to life imprisonment for the hold-up murder of Gilbert Y. Hopler, 60year-old general storekeeper, at Chester, N. J., last Feb. 26.

Bonds worked irregularly higher yesterday in relatively quiet trading on the New York Stocx Exchange. After a brief period in the background, local traction issues staged another of their characteristic flurries as speculative interests

Many dinners were given tonight for week-end guests at estates in the colony. Mrs. Joseph F. Stillman entertained at Mayfair Cottage for Mrs. Henry Pendleton Rogers and Mr. and Mrs. Frederic F. de Rham of Tuxedo Park, who have joined Mrs. Rogers at Cherisol for the week-end.

Mrs. Mathilde McCormick Oser, granddaughter of the late John D. Rockefeller, her daughter Anita and the governess had a narrow escape from death today when the automobile she was driving in a suburb of Geneva struck a pole projecting from- a truck.

Mrs. Laura Merriam' Curtis of this city and Washington, daughter of Mrs. William R. Merriam of Yarmouthport, Mass., was married here yesterday in her apartment at Hampshire House to John Messick Gross of York, Pa., a vice president of the Bethlehem Steel Company.

Premier Benito Mussolini had something today that he didn't like-his fiftyfifth birthday. Italian newspapers, usually lyric about any occasion involving the Premier, were silent. In the Mussolinian concept, Fascist Italy personifies youth and Mussolini personifies fascism; hence any notice of his advancing age is taboo.

Celebrating her birthday today Mrs. Cecelia Welch McConnell arranged to take her first ride in an airplane. She said she would fly next week to Turner, Kan., to visit relatives. She formerly lived in the Middle West and among her recollections are those of Abraham Lincoln campaigning for the Presidency and Brigham Young trekking across the prairies of Iowa on his way to Utah.

Whether or not War Admiral will start tomorrow in the Saratoga Handicap was one of the main subjects of conversation today, following the entry of the famous son of Man o' War in the mile and a quarter test which will be the most important of tomorrow's three stakes. Samuel D.

What is believed here to be a West-East' transcontinental speed record for army planes was established yesterday by Lieutenant H. L. Neel in making a flight from San Francisco to Mitchel Field in 9 hours and 55 minutes, flying time.

Sergeant Joyce Kilmer Post of the American Legion held a memorial service at its headquarters, 1,609 Kings Highway, Brooklyn, last night, to mark the twentieth anniversary of the death of the soldierpoet for whom the post was named. About 200 members attended.

Eight teams will compete in the Northeastern intra-circuit polo championship starting tomorrow at the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club in Purchase, according to the draw announced yesterday. The winner of the tournament will go to Chicago to meet other intra-circuit clubs for the national title.
Johnny Allen had a field day today. The Indians' mound ace toyed with the Senators until he held a commanding lead, and clubbed a home run and a double in a 12-4 triumph, his thirteenth of the year.

Many visiting clergymen will preach tomorrow in the city, including a number of the leading theologians of non-conformist churches in England, Scotland and Australia. Prayers in hundreds of Protestant churches in this and other countries will be offered for a blessing upon the convention of the World Christian Endeavor Union which will be held in Melbourne, Australia, opening on Tuesday. In churches everywhere

Department store sales in the country for the week ended July 23 were 12 per cent lower than for the same week a year ago and for the four weeks ended July 23 were 9 per cent lower than for the same period last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Oarsmen from Western Canada spurted today but the big navy from the West Side Rowing Club of Buffalo and Toronto's Argonauts continued to show the way in team scoring as, the fifty-sixth Royal Canadian Henley regatta cleared the way for tomorrow's major finals.

A gold bar weighing seven pounds was brought to the surface today by scoops of the dredger Karimata from the floor of the North Sea where the wreck of the British frigate Lutine has lain for 139 years.

In 1787 the Founding-Fathers wrote a Federal Constitution which, without the subsequent amendments, came to about four thousand words. This document has lasted 151 years, and with twenty-one amendments, two of which (prohibition and repeal) cancel each other, is in good working order.

Duck hawks, bird of prey treasured in the ancient sport of falconry, have an eyrie in the cornice of Florence Court, an apartment built in 1901 at 187 Hicks Street, Brooklyn Heights. This rare city hideaway. of creatures noted for their speed and rapacity was discovered yesterday afternoon by L. J. Saftler, a trade secretary of the Brooklyn Federation of Jewish Charities.

Dr. G. M. Johnstone Mackay, director of research at the Stamford, Conn., laboratories of the American Cyanamid Company, died here today at his Summer home of complications following an attack of pneumonia. It was his fifty-fifth birthday.

Miss Emily Lanfear Norrie, who died on Jan. 3, 1936, left a net estate of $2,091,772, of which $25,000 goes to the Lewis Gordon Norrie Playground in Staatsburg, town of Hyde Park, N. Y., it was shown yesterday when the transfer tax appraisal was filed. Miss Norrie was the descendant of an old New York family.

The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "The wool market evidently has come to a resting place after a spectacular rise which has lasted over some six weeks, during which prices have risen 25 to 30 per cent.

Of 39,500 motor vehicle deaths last year in the United States, 15,400, or 39 per cent, cost the lives of pedestrians, it was reported yesterday in a bulletin of the Greater New York Safety Council. In 67 per cent of these

A high official of the Securities and Exchange Commission said today that the commission was considering the creation of a new regional office, either in Cleveland or in Detroit. He disclosed that the staff of the SEC's Chicago office had been heavily burdened.

The twelfthcentury Mittersill Castle, a few miles from the noted Winter sports center of Kitzbuehel, was almost destroyed by fire after it had been struck by lightning last night. Valuable antique furniture was burned. In recent years the castle has been a country club.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: Now looks at what they've gone and done: I mean the New York State Athletic Commission. In defiance of all the natural laws of pugilism, our sage fistic fathers have taken it on themselves to hand down one of the most arbitrary rulings ever made by a group with any pretense of authority and intelligence.

237th St (12-3368); n ?w cor of Oneida Ave, 100x66: Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank to Cincinato G. B. La Guardia, 268 E 241st. Kingsland Ave (16-4396)1/2 w s, 118 ft n of Pelham Parkway, n, 50x100 ft; Richvale Holding Corp to George Fried, 1,431 Pelham Parkway N.

Market closed fractions to 2 points lower following earlier strength; turnover, 1,204,240 shares. United States Government bonds firm, foreign issues steady, traction and prime rail groups higher; transactions, $6,371,400.

The Pan-American skiing championships which were scheduled to commence tomorrow have been postponed until Aug. 7 on account of the unfavorable conditions in the snowfields at Farellones, it was announced tonight.

The American Theatre Council is expected to come back to life to celebrate the Signing of the new ticket code, which becomes effective Sept. 1. At least there will be a meeting at 11 A. M., Tuesday, to consider the idea of a brief session in September.
Mr. and Mrs. Walter L. Goodwin entertained at luncheon at the Gideon Putnam today before the racing for Mrs. Henry McComb Bangs of New York and Mrs. Ivan Marty of Baltimore.

With his brother, Angel Marchand, as counsel, Carlos Marchand Paz, a young Nationalist convicted of second degree murder and sentenced to twenty years' imprisonment, has won a new trial by order of the Supreme Court on the ground of the misconduct in his trial of the prosecutor, now Judge Marcelino Romani.

The Interstate Commerce Commission ordered today freight reductions approximating 25 per cent on cotton shipped from Oklahoma to New Orleans. The New Orleans Cotton Exchange and other port and commercial interests of New Orleans had complained that the old rates were too high. Their petition

Many of the Constitutional Convention delegates went to the races Thursday, but those who. stayed on the job did a good day's work. They made it fairly certain that a reasonable method for unifying New York City's rapid transit facilities will be submitted to the voters next Fall.

Niagara Share Corporation of Maryland and subsidiaries report a net asset value of $11.73 a share for the Class B common stock on June 30, compared with $8.30 a share on March 31 and with $11.19 a share at Dec. 31, 1937.

The Rev. and Mrs. William E. Patterson gave a dinner at the rectory today in honor of the Rev. Arthur T. Stray of Brunswick. Guests included General and Mrs. J. W. Kilbreth, Mr. and Mrs. Edwin H. Denby, the Rev. and Mrs. A. H. Lucas, Mrs. Platt Hunt, Mrs. Burridge Butler, Mrs. R. P. Buchanan and John M. Scott.
Visiting golfers were among the guests at dinners here tonight and the evening terminated with a dance at Seaweed, Summer home of Mrs. Clarence W. Dolan, who has Mrs.

Chinese troops are putting up a spirited resistance against Japanese attempts to drive them from the mountains south of Kiukiang, 135 miles down river from Hankow. The Japanese are attacking south and southwest of Kiukiang and west and southwest of Kutang.

Mrs. E. Read Somes of Boston and Ogunquit, Me., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Shirley Read Northgraves, to Charles E. Littlefield of Chambersburg, Pa., son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Littlefield of Montclair, N. J.
Miss Margaret Stone Hardwick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Huntington Reed Hardwick of Brookline, will be married on Sept. 23 to Edward Ball Simmons, son of Mr. and Mrs. George
The general feeling here that an Anglo-American trade treaty will be signed soon was reflected today during the House of Commons debate on the adjournment of Parliament.

Boas, in 502 Park Ave; Morgenthau-Seixas Co, broker. A. L. Helfrich, in 330 E 43d St from Fred F. French Co; Dorothea Doctors, in 138 E 36th St; Cecil M. The report of the American Gas and Electric Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on June 30, issued yesterday, shows a net income after all operating expenses, taxes and charges, of $11,998,007. This was equal,

Representatives from Springfield, New Haven, Providence and Boston are expected to attend a provincial hockey league meeting here on Monday, when plans to broaden the league into an international amateur circuit will be discussed.

The bitter marital troubles of Count and Countess Haugwitz-Reventlow have been ended "amicably" with a deed of separation as a prelude to a Danish divorce. The Countess, the former Barbara Hutton, American-born heiress to $40,000,000 of the Woolworth dime store fortune, settled an undivulged sum upon their 2-year-old son Lance, solicitors for the couple said in a statement today announcing the separation.

Frank H. Patton, New Mexico Attorney General, held today that a $500,000 hospital benefit lottery plan, sponsored by Mrs. Oliver Harriman of New York, was illegal. He based the opinion on the grounds that an 1889 statute was not intended by the Territorial Legislature which passed it to cover so broad a scheme as that outlined by Mrs. Harriman. Mrs. Harriman.

Bo Mc- F Million of Indiana was setting the a pace tonight in the poll to name a coach for the college all-star football squad which will oppose the professional Washington Redskins at Soldier Field Aug. 31. Latest returns gave McMillin 875,004 points. Second was Harry
Mrs. Helen Lyman, widow of William Pratt Lyman of Boston, died this morning after a brief illness at her home on Garden Street, where she had resided since leaving Boston twenty years ago.

Ross (Sandy) Somerville, veteran Canadian star, and Ted Adams, an "unknown" from Columbia, Mo., turned back a pair of golfers from Magna, Utah, today to reach the final round of the Canadian amateur championship. They meet tomorrow in a thirty-six-hole final over Somerville's home course, the London Hunt and Country Club.

The so-called Federal anti-racketeering law under which Local 807 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and seventy-two individuals, including the Iocal's officers and delegates, were indicted recently, is applicable to labor unions, Federal Judge Vincent L.

Rallying for three runs in the ninth to tie the score, the Phillies went on to win, 5 to 4, from the Cubs in twelve innings today. An error by Shortstop Bill Jurges gave the Phillies the winning run. With two out, Jurges missed Chuck Klein's hard grounder. Buck Jordan scored from second.

The formation of a preferred stockholders' committee to defend the position of preferred shareholders of the Postal Telegraph and Cable Corporation was announced yesterday by Edward S. Menapace, secretary of the committee. Members of the committee are James A. Beha, Herbert P. Dammes, F. L. Rossmann and Charles J. Williams.

The Batavian Oil Company, at whose request 10,000 tons of petroleum from Mexico was seized in Hansweert Harbor on July 18, was sued today in Middleburg Court by the Mexican Government and the Japanese Shipping Company, which had chartered the Swedish tanker for conveyance of the oil.

Greyhound, world trotting champion, waltzed off with the American free-for-all-trot today in the feature event of the Grand Circuit racing program at Agawam Park. Trotting amazingly well over a slow track, the gray gelding, owned by the Baker Stables of St. Charles, Ill., covered the last quarter-mile

Howland Spencer, wealthy Dutchess County neighbor of President Roosevelt and one of those who voted for him in 1932, and now regrets it, turned over today to Father Divine, Negro evangelist, his 500-acre estate across the Hudson River from the Roosevelt family seat at Hyde Park.

Police Inspector Louis Rosenfeld, who was on leave at his Summer cottage in Madison, Conn., in an effort to recuperate from a nervous condition dating back to a siege with pneumonia in 1936, killed himself with his service revolver yesterday morning. He was 46 years old and had been a member of the force since Nov. 20. 1913.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The statement of the chairman of the British North Borneo Company, Major Gen. Sir Neill Malcolm, issued last month, marks a very important step in the development of British colonial policy on opium smoking.

Shanghai foreign traders see difficulties in the announcement that the currency and trade policies of the new Peiping Provisional Government have been changed by an import and export licensing system jointly devised by Japanese advisers and Peiping officials.

Wheat futures on the Board of Trade here declined 2 to 3/4 cent a bushel in the early trading today to new low levels for the season on all deliveries except the September. Persistent selling attributed to hedging operations by the Southwest was the main factor. Houses which
John H. Meehan, musician and uncle of Chick Meehan, former Syracuse, New York University and Manhattan football coach, died here last night at the age of 66. He suffered a stroke last Sunday.

Importers Commission Co, Inc, importers, in 120 Wall St; Edward R. Parker Co, investments, in 165 Broadway; Carl E. Lucke, importer, in 29 Broadway. American Automatic Typewriter Co, in 320 Broadway; Prudence Bondholders Protective Association, in 295 Madison Ave; Charles F. Noyes Co. Inc, brokers.

Approach of the bank holiday week-end restricted business on the stock markets here today. Gilt-edge securities were steady. Foreign bonds were firmer, but other sections were quiet. Among transatlantic stocks,

Brig. Gen. Samuel G. Barnard, who retired today after forty-six years as a member of the New Jersey National Guard, was honored with a review here this evening. More than 2,000 young men of the Citizens Military Training Corps filed past him as the field music of the Sixteenth United States Infantry

Slr Cecil Allen Coward, attorney, died here today at the age of 92. He acted for Cecil Rhodes at the inquiry following the Jameson raid into the Transvaal in South Africa in 1895 and was president of the Law Society in 1927-28.

MANHATTAN LURCH, CHARLES. E. (June 5, 1937). Gross assets, $77,179; net, $72,127. To Matilda Lurch, widow; Charles H. Lurch, son, and Angelica Horn, daughter, onethird residue; Frederick Lurch, brother. and Edward Hirschfeldt, stepson, $1,000 each. Chief assets, mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $58,708. Skutch, Meyer Burton, attorneys, 40 Wall St.

Joseph A. Padway, counsel for the American Federation of Labor, denounced today as "a prejudiced interference with the rights of craft workers unworthy of respect," the decision of the National Labor Relations Board invalidating a contract between the International Association of Machinists, an A. F. of L. union. and the Serrick Corporation of Muncie.

Officials of the National Maritime Union declared yesterday that peace reigned along the city's waterfront, and that no punitive action would be taken against the men who had participated on Thursday in a shortlived insurrection against alleged Communist domination of the union.
Oliver K. Bovard, managing editor of The St. Louis Post-Dispatch, resigned today, effective Aug. 13, because of "irreconcilable differences of opinion" with Joseph Pulitzer, owner of the newspaper.

The failure of the Hawaii Clipper to report after being many hours overdue is the first untoward incident to mar the record of the transpacific mail and passenger service operated by Pan American Airways.

A drive has been started by some insurance company executives to defeat the proposal of the Constitutional Convention's committee on social welfare which would open the way for the Legislature to establish a Statewide system of health insurance.

An average reduction of 10 per cent from 1937 in prices of merchandise is shown in the Fall and Winter catalog of the Chicago Mail Order Company. The greatest reduction is made in domestics and yard goods, which are quoted at 17 per cent under a year ago. Sheets and sheetings

Another appeal for German cooperation in the refugee problem was made in the House of Commons today by Earl Winterton, who headed the British delegation to the conference on refugees at Evian-les-Bains, France, It was the last speech by a Cabinet Minister in the Commons before both Houses of Parliament adjourned until Nov. 1.

The seven-story LaScala apartment house at 464-65 Central Park West was bought in at auction in the Vesey Street rooms yesterday by the Chase National Bank with a nominal bid of $10,000. The property was sold to satisfy a judgment of $142,447 and taxes and other liens of $16,500 against Mary Turner. It occupies a plot 49.7 by 100

It usually rains in Waynesburg on July 29--and it did today, for the sixty-second time in sixtyfive years. Byron Daily, who has won ten hats and lost a shirt in eleven years of betting on rain for the day, added two more hats to his collection.

Sigrid Undset's new novel, "Images in a Mirror," is announced for publication on Aug. 22 by Knopf. In this work the Norwegian Nobel Prize winner tells a story of modern marriage, and of a woman whose happy life is threatened by memories of her glamorous past. It is Mrs. Undset's sixteenth book under the Borzoi imprint.

The inevitable battle between the Catholic Church and the Fascist regime over the new Italian racist theories began in earnest yesterday when Pope Pius, speaking to the students of the collegee of Propaganda of the Faith, revealed that the Italian authorities had threatened to declare membership in Catholic Action associations incompatible with membership in the Fascist party.

The stock market attempted a cautious advance in the forenoon yesterday, but succumbed to moderate pressure in the late trading and finished irregularly lower. Losses ranged from fractions to about 2 points. The day's business

Louis Weber, 39-year-old "policy king" of Brooklyn, and thirteen of his henchmen were convicted yesterday in Special Sessions Court, Brooklyn, of conspiracy to maintain and operate a policy racket with an estimated annual income of $1,500,000. They were remanded

There is no evidence here that Henry Morgenthau Jr., Secretary of the Treasury, in his talks with French Ministers, had any discussions about war debts. On the other hand, it seems clear that the conversations were not entirely unofficial and that they dealt with something- more than asking information about the best places to spend a holiday in France.

Judge A. E. Hawkins of the Circuit Court, who presided over the original "Scottsboro" trials, threatened today to postpone sentencing of criminals until the present State administration is out of office.

The Rev. Orville C. Jones, former pastor of the Pymouth Congregational Church of Youngstown, told the Senate Civil Liberties Committee today that the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company, during the Steel Workers Organization Committee unionization campaign of 1936, gave a dinner to the thirty members of the local Ministerial Association and sought to "coerce" them into opposing the union.

George Booth Prest, who had served in the National Lank of Commerce for sixty-five years, died today at his home here. His age was 80. He was born in this city April 15, 1858, the son of Mr. and Mrs. George Prest. His father was a well known building contractor.

Large scale Russial naval manoeuvres in the Gulf of Finland, comprising over forty units collaborating with the coast fortifications of the air force, have deeply annoyed Estonian public opinion because the Russians are alleged to have frequently violated Estonian territorial waters.

Clarence E. Baxter X of Pontiac, Mich., held the provincial 1938 tuna-fishing record tonight after landing 645 pounds of fighting blue-fin tuna, largest fish taken off Nova Scotia's coast this year. Another United States fisherman, W. Gratin of Miami, Fla., landed a 520-pounder.
Two men who showed no weapons but acted "tough" took Eugene Scarmellino, 48 years old, for a trip yesterday morning in his own automobile as he left his home at 412 Forty-fifth Street, Brooklyn.

Led by the pound sterling, the leading foreign exchanges continued to slump yesterday and reached their lowest prices in more than a year. The declines were, for the most part, not large, but they extended the downward trend past levels where resistance had formerly been met.

Government rules and regulations in industry are costing the corporations of the United States "hundreds and hundreds of millions of dollars," drawn from their normal purposes of production and employment, Louis K. Comstock, president of the Merchants Association of New York, said last night in a radio address.

The Pennsylvania Senate convened here this morning and after 2 o'clock voted the final passage of bills which had already passed the House, setting aside a grand jury. The Democratic-controlled Legislature was thereby equipped for the task for which Governor Earle called it in special session on Monday night, when he explained that the Legislature was here to repeal an invasion by the Republican judiciary.

There will be no coalition by the American Labor party with either the Bronx Republicans or Democrats, the Labor party announced last night in making public a full slate of candidates for elective posts to be filled in the borough this Fall.

The New York Roverettes bowed to Kaufmann's Maids of Reading, Pa., 5 to 2, in the feature game of the women's softball double-header at Madison Square Garden last night. A crowd of 3,500 saw the New Yorkers suffer their first setback in two starts. The game was a non-league affair.

An investment client of the C. Grant Keck Organization has purchased the Christman Lumber Yard, at Twenty-third Street and Forty-second Avenue, Long Island City. The property includes a plot of about 21,000 square feet, with storage sheds and a brick office building.

Two new "honeymoon bridges" to replace the famed span which ice destroyed last Winter were projected here tonight-one by private interests and one by a public agency. The International Railway Company, owner of the'old bridge,

The Federal Power Commission approved today the sale of the facilities of the Tennessee Public Service Company to the Tennessee Valley Authority, the city of Knoxville and the Appalachian Electric Power Company.

Senator Sheppard, chairman of the Senate Committee on Campaign Expenditures, today telegraphed to ten candidates for the Senate demanding that they answer immediately the committee's questionnaire covering funds received, expenditures and other questions involved in their primary campaigns.

The New Jersey Council, created by the 1937 Legislature to publicize the State's industrial, agricultural, residential and recreational advantages, appointed today as its director Amory L. Haskell, wealthy Red'Bank sportsman, at $1 a year.

The Association of American Railroads reported today that Class I carriers had net operating income of $70,289,305 in the first half of this year. This compared with $299,466,034 in the first six months of 1937 and $369,416,250 in the same period of 1930.

A sentence of fifteen to thirty months in Sing Sing was imposed in General Sessions yesterday on Charles McGrath, 25 years old, of 65 Cherry Street on his guilty plea to second-degree assault. He had shoved a young woman into he East River at the foot of Fulton Street at dawn on June 5.

Military authorities have seized control of some 600 back-to-work cards which are the subject of controversy in the C. I. O. strike at the Maytag Washing Machine Company plant. The cards were signed by men who want to return to work in the factory.

The body of a man found floating in the Raritan River here yesterday was identified today as that of Harold F. Hovey, Rutgers University graduate, class of '08, and a four-letter athlete during his college days. He was a classmate

GOVERNORS ISLAND So much of Paragraph 29, Special Orders 168, dated July 21, 1938, as relates to the following Field Artillery Reserve officers, is revoked: 1st Lt. Robert G. Humphrey. 2d Lt. Robert M. Richmond.

The fifty-five coal operators, their com panies and the former peace officers on trial here in Federal court for conspiring against union labor were victims of a plot by the United Mine Workers to use the strong arm of the United States to end defense attorneys charged today.
Abbott, Eben G. Baldwin, Helen R. Blossom, Mabel T. Bowen, Charles P. Brooks, Henry S. Crager, Louis Cramer, Marguerite Crowell, Harry C.

William Hooker of 105-13 Martense Avenue, Corona, was fined $15 and ten others were fined $9 each by Magistrate Anthony Savarese In the Queens traffic court yesterday on charges that they had operated without having proper permits.

Buying for Fall increased in the principal wholesale markets this week and the peak apparently is still to be reached, according to the weekly review of Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The rise in retail sales was helped by resumption of buying in districts in which totals had been sharply cut by heavy rains.

The North Shore D. A. R., reinforced by several other women, got the better of a local WPA crew this morning in what promises to be a rousing controversy between the exponents of pedestrian safety, led by the Village Board, and the exponents of civic beautification, led by the D. A. R., the Sea Cliff Garden Club and local members of the roadside committee of the Long Island Association.

Release of the ground log of the Hawaii Clipper last night by the San Francisco office of Pan American Airways indicated that whatever happened to the big Martin flying boat must have taken place very suddenly.

The French Cabinet named an Inspector General for Passive Defense today as measures were speeded up to protect France from air raids in the event of war. The Ministers,. meeting with. President Albert Lebrun, appointed General Jean Aube to supervise the defense preparations.

Two persons were killed today in a train explosion in the State of San Luis Potosi, which railway officials laid to Cedillo rebels. A number of persons suffered slight injuries in the blast, which wrecked a second-class coach of a Mexican National Railways train on the San Luis Potosi-Tampico division.

Yesterday was ladies' day at Ebbets Field, but several Dodger moves witnessed by the 2,582 fair fans and 7,105 paying patrons led to the belief in some quarters that it also was "being-kind-to-the Pirates" day, especially since the league-leading Buccos won the ball game, 7-6.

The Milwaukee works of the International Harvester Company, shut down for a month, will resume Monday, E. J. Leiser, superintendent, said today. About 2,700 will go back to work. This number corresponds to the payroll at the shutdown on June 30.

Three-Platoon System The deputy chiefs of the 4th and 15th Divisions are placed under the threeplatoon ten-group system, effective at A. M., Aug. 1. The deputy chiefs of the 5th, 7th, 13th and 14th Divisions are placed under the two-platoon ten-group system, effective at 12:01 A. M., Aug. 1.

Federal Judge John C. Knox yesterday denied motions to set aside or revise some of the awards made by a committee of attorneys to survivors and relatives of victims of the Morro Castle disaster. "In the greater number of cases," Judge Knox wrote, "I am in entire

Unlawful payment and acceptance of brokerage fees in violation of the Robinson-Patman act was charged by the Federal Trade Commission today against the Mississippi Sales Company, Inc., of Meridian, Miss., and a group of concerns for which it acts as intermediary in either the purchase or sale of merchandise, particularly foodstuffs.

Major William McGinnis, former State commander of the American Legion, died today at the Soldiers' Home in Chelsea at the age of 48. He was wounded in 1918 at Ch Born in Leith, Scotland, he came to Lawrence at an early age. When the United States entered the World War he was a corporal in the 102d Field Artillery and went to France with Battery C.

Mayor La Guardia and Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, WPA Administrator, made an unannounced inspection tour of a dozen WPA projects yesterday afternoon. They found thousands of WPA employes at work, many of them stripped to the waist because of the heat.

While Theodore Assisi, caretaker, slept peacefully near by, safe robbers took $825 from the Country Playhouse here last night. The sum represented the proceeds of the Ethel Barrymore production of "The Constant Wife."

The New York, Chicago St. Louis Railroad Company (Nickel Plate) has applied to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to issue $15,000,000 of 6 per cent promissory notes, maturing Oct. 1, 1941,

Manhattan Alterations 10th Ave, 3,870, and 501-5 W 207th St, n w cor 207th St. and 10th Ave.; to 2-story restaurant and offices; Scotts Square Realty Corp, Inc, 115 Central Park W, owner: Moore Landsiedel, architects; cost, $10,000. 9th Ave, 191; to 5-story store and dwelling; Dora Lindenbaum, 191 9th Ave. owner; MacManus Gleich, 125 W 45th St, architects; cost, $3,500.

Howard Hughes and his four globe-circling companions received an enthusiastic welcome from Chicago today. Several thousand admirers were at Chicago airport when the fliers landed in their Lockheed plane. After being greeted by Mayor Edward J. Kelly and other representatives of the Mayor's New Century Committee, Mr. Hughes and his party were escorted to waiting automobiles for a parade to the city.

The Governor of Pennsylvania "may on extraordinary occasions convene the General Assembly." The extraordinary occasion of the extraordinary session which began Monday night was the fact that on Aug. 8 a grand jury was to start in Dauphin County Court an investigation of charges of graft and bribery against Governor Earle and thirteen other officials. Governor Earle

The National City Bank, through its attorneys, Wingate Cullen of Brooklyn, it was revealed yesterday, has filed in Federal court, Brooklyn, an affidavit opposing the discharge from bankruptcy of Charles V. Bossert, son of Louis Bossert, founder of the Bossert ,
With good initial response to August sales, retail trade here made a better comparative showing last week than in the preceding week. Department store

Creed opens the Winter fashion shows with a stunning tailored collection, featuring natural feminine lines. Waistlines are normal or higher and skirts are very short. Jackets are buttoned high over high-necked blouses with. stock effects. One suit silhouette has a fullpleated skirt and a loose box jacket with narrow double-breasted buttons. With a fitted hip-length

An uprising, evidently of Venizelist partisans, broke out on the island of Create 'today, but was suppressed. According to official reports, a group of 400 armed men, led by Cyriakos Mitzoakis, a nephew of Eleutherios Venizelos, profited by the seasonal reduction in the garrison at Canea, capital of Crete, seized the radio station and arrested local authorities.
Harold N. Rust, Grand Secretary of the Grand Lodge of Pennsylvania, Free and Accepted Masons, died today of a heart attack while visiting a friend at Mount Pocono. He was 65 year old.
Ham- De mering Hank Greenberg kept ahead of Babe Ruth's record home-run pace with two circuit blows, driving in four runs as the Tigers beat the Athletics, 9 to 2, in the series opener today.

Lefty Gomez, the Yanks' quaint pitcher, who once remarked he would rather be lucky than good, had a quantity of both elements in his favor today as he once again triumphed over his lefthanded adversary, Thornton Lee, to down the White Sox, 4 to 3, in the opening contest of a four-game

As a result of the unexpected postponement of the offering of two major corporate loans, the volume of new bond financing this week declined to $6,828,000, and for the first time in about a month was restricted exclusively to tax-exempt issues.

When the Board of Transportation opened bids yesterday for the installation of interlocking signal and safety equipment for the World's Fair spur of the city's Independent Subway System it was disclosed that the Union Switch and Signal Company and the General Railway Signal Company had failed, for the first time in the history of the city's rapid transit construction, to submit proposals.

Denmark's 19-year-old swimming star, Jenny Kammersgaard, who entered the Baltic Sea at Gedser, South Denmark, Wednesday evening, this morning reached the German coast at Nienhagen, about five miles west of Warnemuende after being in the water 40 hours and 9 minutes.

Development of a new bristling filament for use in toilet brushes was announced today by the plastics department of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc. Present production is limited and the entire output is used in du Pont tooth brushes. The filament is said

Harry Clifford Crowell, assistant to the chief engineer of the Pennsylvania Railroad, New York zone, and a leader in civic affairs in Manhattan, died yesterday at his home, 42-20 Kissena Boulevard, Flushing, Queens, of apoplexy. He was 55 years old.
The war Department released the following orders today, dated July 28: COLONELS Gruber, E. L. (F.A.), General Staff Corps, ten days' leave. Aug, 1.

A six-story elevator building for fifty-three families at 2,020 Avenue O, corner of East Twenty-first Street, in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, was sold by the Manufacturers Trust Company to a client of Hy. D. Agar, Inc., brokers, for investment.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that the committee on admissions would consider on Aug. 4 the application of E. Coyne Maloney to become a partner on Aug. 5 in the firm of Block, Maloney Co. On Aug. 11

Again asserting his rights to swim in his own pond, even if it does flow into a reservoir, William Heller of Easton, with Mrs. Mary N. Boyle of Newtown, began a Superior Court action today against the Bridgeport Hydraulic Company aid Dr. Stanley H. Osborn, State Commissioner of Health.

Colors for women's shoes and gloves and men's shoes adopted for Spring were announced yesterday by the Textile Color Card Association, Inc., which chose the shades in cooperation with committees of producers and retailers.

Affiliated Fund, Inc., Jersey City, an investment trust, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering $3,000,000 of 5 per cent ten-year secured convertible debentures to be offered at par and 425,000 shares of $1.25 par value common stock reserved for conversion of the debentures.
For the first time since reaching the Galapagos Islands, President Roosevelt had indifferent luck to-day on a fishing excursion.

Reporting that, at present dollar valuation, gold in the United States Government's vaults has for the first time passed $13,000,000,000, the Treasury Department adds that, even when measured purely by ounces, not by dollar valuation, our Government holds 54 per cent of the world's entire stock of monetary gold.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

Senator Holt of West Virginia, a Democrat who is a frequent critic of the Administration, said today he would introduce a resolution at the next session of Congress similar to the La Follette anti-third term resolution which applied to President Coolidge. His purpose, he said,

Elwood Cooke Jr. took another step up the tennis ladder today as he followed up his victory over Frank Parker by adding Wilmer Allison, former national champion, to his list of conquests for the season. He thereby gained the final round of the invitation tournament of the Seabright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club, in which he will meet Robert L. Riggs tomorrow at 3:30 o'clock.
David L. Frank, real estate operator and former chairman of the Democratic committee of the town of Cortland, died last night at his home here of a heart ailment.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has granted, with certain conditions, an application by the Sew York State Electric and Gas Corporation for exemption from the requirement of filing a declaration under the Public Utility Holding Company Act in regard to the issuance and sale of $2,903,200 principal amount of ten-year 5 per cent notes due on March 1. 1948.

An allotment n of $200,000 from PWA funds to New York State will be used by the Conservation Department for wild life projects, it was stated today. Calvin Scofield, district representative at Binghamton of the Bureau of Agricultural Economics of the Federal Department of Agriculture, will be in charge of the administration of the funds, which are immediately available, Commissioner Lithgow Osborne said.

Chancellor Adolf Hitler's confidential agent, Captain Fritz Wiedemann, who is awaited in London for week-end talks with Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain, turned up in Paris today. He has been in France at least twentyfour hours and has had talks with some French political leaders. He left tonight, supposedly for London.

Trading in steer cuts was only fair, other classes generally fair in local markets yesterday. Steer beef sold strong veal and calf higher. lambs steady to lower, fresh pork mostly unchanged. The kosher- markets opened slow; steer chucks and plates lower, plates higher, veal and calf higher lamb about steady. Conditions as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow;
The nation's fairway aces, with "dark horses" matching the marksmanship of favorites, gave par a merciless first-round bombing in the $7,500 St. Paul open golf tournament today.

After three days in the Tombs for driving while . intoxicated, John Grimm 3d, 23 years old, of 1,120 Park Avenue, the son of John Grimm Jr., vice president of Leach Brothers, bankers, was placed on a year's probation yesterday by Magistrate Brodsky in Traffic Court.

William T. Marshall, who has served as private librarian to Presidents in the White House since 1899, will retire tomorrow at the age of 72. As the official in charge of the books of the Presidents, he has had supervision of both the regular bookshelves in the Executive Mansion and the private libraries of the Chief Executives.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated July 27: CAPTAIN Coffman, R. B., the Salt lake City, to Branch Hydrographle Office. San Pedro, Calif., as officer in charge, about Oct. 15.

Yorkshire retained first place in the English County cricket championship today with a sixwicket decision over Northamptonshire. Worcestershire surprised with a 10-wicket victory over the fourthplace Surrey eleven and Hampshire improved its standing by an innings and 62-run triumph over Warwickshire. First-innings points

Mr. and Mrs. Olney B. Mairs gave a dinner dance tonight at the Devon Yacht Club for Miss Patricia Peale, who, with her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Rembrandt Peale, is spending the Summer in the Tillinghast house.

Captain and Mrs. Roger Wisner will give a tea dance on the roof of the St. Regis on Nov. 26 for their debutante daughter, Miss Ann Lawrence Wisner. Mrs. Julius Walsh of the Plaza will leave today for Saratoga Springs. Her mother, Mrs. Arthur Cary, is returning to her home in Lexington, Ky.

The Sudetenland's profession of loyalty to Adolf Hitler and Great Germany was vociferously acclaimed tonight when made by Konrad Henlein, leader of the Sudeten German party in Czechoslovakia, at a monster mass meeting at the Breslau gymnastic festival.

The Spanish Government's People's Army clung close to Gandesa tonight, despite severe counter-attacks by land and air and a manmade flood in the Ebro River Valley designed to sever supply lines and cut off retreat.

Tenders will be considered on Aug. 29 by officials of the Orleans Levee District, La., for $2,000,000 of refunding bonds, to be dated Sept. 1, 1938, and to mature serially on Sept. 1, 1939 to 1962, optional for call after five years. No bids will be accepted, it was announced, which give a cost basis in excess of 4 per cent a year.

Beneficial rains over a large part of both Oklahoma and Arkansas, the only important region of the cotton belt still in need of moisture, dropped prices sharply on the Cotton Exchange yesterday but a recovery left the list 3 points higher to 2 points lower. As October

Morgan Co., 23 Wall Street, New York, have been authorized by the State Banking Department to operate as private bankers, it was announced today. This new authorization was made necessary by the death of two partners.

PERHAPS all the underwater traveling you ever did was to read Jules Verne. Or a walk down that drowned, lucent path at the Bermuda aquarium, where the man at the pump stands ready to gaff you out if you trip over a polyp, and the angel fish sneer openly at your helmet.

Japan's Davis Cup stalwarts, Jiro Yamagishi and Fumiteru Nakano, took their third straight match from Canada today and qualified to meet either Australia or Mexico in the North American zone final next week.

A demand for housing properties on the upper West Side was indicated yesterday when sales of buildings there were announced. Two six-story tenement houses accommodating forty-four families at 2,525-29 Amsterdam Avenue, near West 185th Street, were bought by Schack Schack, attorneys, from a client of Etra Etra. There are four stores in the

Douglas G. Corrigan, Atlantic "by mistake" airman, left here by mail train this evening for Cobh [Queenstown] on the first stage of his journey back to the United States. He will board the liner Manhattan early tomorrow morning and is due in New York next Friday.
The report of the Procter Gamble Company for the fiscal year ended on June 30 shows a net profit of $17,439,194 after depreciation, Federal income taxes and surtax on undistributed earnings.

Total wholesale trade in the first six months of 1938 declined 15 per cent below the same period in 1937, the Department of Commerce reported today. The estimate comes from the reports of 1,700 wholesalers who reported total sales of $846,000,000 for the first half of 1938, as against sales totaling $993,000,000 for the 1937 period.

Soon after convening his "jury" of eighteen members of the union's executive board, who are trying four suspended vice presidents of the United Automobile Workers. of America, President Homer Martin announced the adjournment of the board until Aug. 6.

Big Ralph Guldahl apparently wasn't spoofing when he made the threat to throw away his set of golf clubs if he didn't win the New Jersey open. After yesterday's first round in the tourney, which is being played between showers and lightning bolts on the wringing wet Braidburn course, where he hangs

A report by Dr. Charles E. Thompson of the General Sessions psychiatric clinic yesterday saved Harry Golop, 24 years old, of 598 New Lots Avenue, Brooklyn, from being sent back to State prison on a theft indictment returned in that court before his sentence in a Brooklyn robbery in April, 1935.

With Atley Donald yielding only three hits, the Newark Bears registered an 8-to-0 victory over the Buffalo Bisons in the first game of a scheduled double-header tonight. The second tilt was postponed on account of rain.

MANHATTAN BLUMENKROHN, ADOLPH (July 1). Estate, less than $10,000. To Hannah Blumenkrohn, widow, executrix, 20 Crescent St., Hewlett, L. I. CIAFFEY, CATHERINE (June 17). Estate. less than $20,000. To Joseph R. Castlepark, nephew, care of P. J. O'Flynn, Main St., Vallinasloe, Galway, Ireland, $3,000; two specific bequests;
Negotiations between railroad managements and labor regarding the roads' proposal to cut the wages of 914,000 workers 15 per cent moved near to an end today. After two and a half hours

A bit of country on wheels, a seven-ton trellised trailer, seventeen feet long and seven feet wide, carrying plants, garden implements and other reminders of country life, will begin a tour of the city's playgrounds next Monday, it was announced yesterday by the Department of Parks.

Dr. Hubert E. Van Norman, who was in charge of the dairy exhibit at A Century of Progress, died yesterday at his home of a heart ailment at the age of 66. Born in Tilsonburg, Ont., Dr. Van Norman was the son of George Tilson Van Norman and Julia Bright Everett Van Norman.

Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora filed an order yesterday directing the selection of a blue ribbon panel of 300 talesmen from which to pick a jury to try James J. Hines, Tammany district leader, on a charge of being a part of the Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer policy lottery gang.
A small audience attended last night's concert of the PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra, which, because of the rain, was held in the Great Hall of the College of the City of New York.

Politics makes strange bedfellows, but it is not often that this community has witnessed anything quite so strange and so wonderful as the coalition now being formed between the Republicans, who have set themselves up as champions of all that is meant by individualism, and the American Labor party, which is to usher in the new collective day. Arrangements are being

Miss Frieda S. Miller will be appointed by Governor Lehman as Industrial Commissioner to succeed Elmer F. Andrews, who is to resign soon to become Administrator of the Federal Fair Labor Standards Law.

Appointment of a World's Fair Committee for the blouse industry was announced yesterday by Abraham, Rosenthal, president of the National Association of Blouse Manufacturers, Inc. The committee comprises Marcus Helitzer, chairman Helitzer Brothers Co.,Inc.;

Plans for the second unit of the Red Hook housing development in Brooklyn were filed yesterday by the New York City Housing Authority. They call for the erection of eighteen six-story apartment houses to cost $7,600,000. Several additional buildings for utility purposes will add 4300,000 to the cost of the new unit.

In a move designed to make those on relief take available jobs as pickers of fruit, tomatoes and beans on surrounding farms, thereby reducing relief expenditures, Welfare Commissioner Fred B. Nidd of the Town of Ramapo divulged today he was conducting a drive to seize the license plates of relief recipients who use their cars for pleasure.

The Pittsfield Riding and Polo Club, of which Brenton Crane Pomeroy is president, tonight had more than 200 guests at its horse show dinner dance. Judges and exhibitors at the twoday event, which opened today, were in the company.

Directors of the Chesapeake Corporation, the link through which the Alleghany Corporation controls the Chesapeake Ohio Railway, are to resume next week the consideration of a dissolution of the Chesapeake Corporation, proposed by Robert R. Young, chairman of Alleghany. The specific plan to be

Ray Malott of Stanford University and the San Francisco Olympic Club, chief record-breaker on the American track and field team touring Sweden, smashed a world record that had stood for four years when he ran 500 meters in 1 minute 1 5-10 seconds on the second day of a two-day international meet here. His time bettered Ben Eastman's performance at Oslo in 1934 by a half second.

Because of the unplayable condition of the first half of the course due to recent rains, the fifty-six starters in the New Jersey Women's Golf Association one-day tournament at the Forest Hill Club today were obliged to play the second nine holes twice, with the result

The governments of Ecuador and Cuba signed contracts yesterday with the New York World's Fair for space in the Hall of Nations. Pablo Suarez, Consul General of Cuba in New York, and Grover A. Whalen, president of the Fair Corporation, signed the Cuban contract for 10,000 square feet of floor space.

Holy Trinity Memorial Church here was decorated with white birch trees, gladioluses and lilies for the marriage tonight in a candlelight service of Miss Margaret Faber, a great-granddaughter of the late United States Supreme Court Justice David J. Brewer and a descendant of the late Cyrus W. Field, who laid the first Atlantic cable, to Morton Frederick Judd Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Judd of Stratford.

John W. Warde,. demented young man who killed himsef on Tuesday night in a leap from the seventeenth floor of the Hotel Gotham, was buried yesterday morning four hours ahead of the time previously arranged.

Two soldiers, hoisted by block and tackle from a narrow canyon ledge on which they were marooned five days after attempting to ride flood waters of the Rio Grande on automobile inner tubes, agreed today that "another day and we'd have had to jump back in the river."

Charges by Dr. Arthur E. Morgan, former chairman of the TVA, that he had been approached by John B. Blandford Jr. with an offer to join forces to control the TVA were denied by Mr. Blandford, now general manager of the Authority, at today's public hearing of the Congressional investigating committee.

Helen Arden, soprano, will be soloist with the City Amateur Symphony Orchestra this evening on the Central Park Mall. Justice Leopold Prince will conduct. The last concert of the orchestra's Summer series will be given tomorrow at 3 P. M. in Prospect Park, Brooklyn.

Lieut. Col. ' Stewart S. Giffin, Coast Artillery Corps, U. S. A., who was acquitted'Thursday by a courtmartial at Governors Island of conduct unbecoming an officer and a gentleman but found guilty on a lesser charge and sentenced to a reprimand and loss of 100 files on the promotion list, was released from custody yesterday and restored to active duty.

Returning to his home at 4 Lafayette Road, Mamaroneck Township, with two friends shortly before last midnight, Philip S. Cummings, president of the Big Rapids Furniture Company of New York, was confronted by two heavily armed burglars as he snapped on the electric lights.

The team which will face the British in the six-meter races for the British-American Cup was half chosen today. Two of the six yachts that sailed in the trials conducted by Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club became definite members of the four-boat team when the selection committee, headed by Philip J. Roosevelt,

Reports from Brielle and Freeport indicate that the tuna are still plentiful off-shore, and although we had a report of a 150pounder being taken at Scallop Ridge, we have been unable to verify it to date.

Payrolls of the steel industry remained substantially at the May levels in June, despite a drop of 9.5 per cent in output from one month to the other, the American Iron and Steel Institute announced yesterday. Payrolls amounted to $46,706,000 in June, compared with $46,757,000 in May.

The Board of Governors of the New York Curb Exchange has adopted an amendment to the constitution permitting members or member firms, although holding memberships on other Exchanges, to charge the prescribed rates of commission on the other Exchanges instead of the Curb rate, as heretofore.

An earthquake shook New York City, Westchester County, Long Island and part of New Jersey at 3:44:15 o'clock yesterday morning. It was estimated that about a million persons, asleep, at work, or seeking pleasure, experienced the shock.

I now know how Noah and his gang felt when the weather cleared and the sun showed itself. Ever since leaving New York around June 20 it has been rain, and now we are crossing Melville Bay and- for the first time in days have seen the sun for a few hours.

Dr. Earl Baldwin McKinley, Dean of Medicine at George Washington University, and Dr. Fred C. Meier, plant pathologist of the Department of Agriculture, missing on the Hawaii Clipper, were en route to Manila in search of the answer to the puzzle of the trans-oceanic spread of disease germs and plant pollen.

Airline representatives expressed dissatisfaction today with conditions at Newark Airport and several hinted of an interest elsewhere, possibly North Beach in New York City. The representatives objected to complicated leases, airport operating costs, lack of a "responsible head" with whom to do business and failure to complete work on a new hangar.

Two navy fliers met death today in the crash of a torpedo plane in San Diego Bay. A third man landed uninjured in a parachute jump. Divers recovered the body of Radioman J. R. Pyffer, 22, of New Cumberland, Pa., from the wreckage of the plane late this afternoon. The body of Naval Aviation Pilot J. O. Rose, 27, was taken from the bay soon after the crash.
Pensioned ON HIS OWN APPLICATION-To take effect 12 midnight, July 31: SERGEANT-Charles Braun. 111th Precinct, at $1,750 per annum. Appointed Feb. 10, 1913. Temporary Assignments

Against a background of lightning and thunder and in a downpour that continued through the last three periods, Bbbby Gerry poked in a last-second goal that gave Bostwick Field a 9-8 victory over Burnt Mills today in the opening match of the junior polo championship. Few games have been

Only a few changes were made last-year in the security holdings of the Rockefeller Foundation, it was disclosed yesterday. Ownership-of stocks and bonds on Dec. 31 last represented a book value to the foundation of $172,073,541, compared with $172,546,008 at the end of 1936.

Canadian Government, provincial and municipal financing in July exceeded the total for that month in any of the last five years, amounting to $80,570,024, according to figures compiled by Wood, Gundy Co., Ltd. This compares with $76,

A national campaign for Florida canned citrus will be started by the Florida Citrus Commission on Monday and will continue every weekday through August. Two national weekly newspaper supplements and fourteen magazines, with a total circulation of 37,126,309, are to be used. Some seventy-six radio

The underlying cause of the current weakness of sterling and the corresponding strength of the dollar is the trade balance. Sterling has been moving downward by stages since early this year, when it sold at close to $5.04.

With a fair wind and fair tide, the fleet in the Bayside Yacht Club's eighteenth annual auxiliary handicap race of 225 miles out around Block Island and back started from the mouth of Little Neck Bay yesterday at noon.

A war debt settlement based upon cancellation of all interest charges was proposed publicly tonight by Baron Catto, director of the great AngloAmerican banking house of Morgan Grenfell Co. and chairman

A Jersey City landmark that had been part of the Blair estate for forty-three years changed hands with its purchase by the Jersey Carlton Corporation from Mary Sack. It consists of a three-story structure with two stores at 167-69 Newark Avenue and 154 Railroad Avenue, part of which was occupied by the late Joseph T. Sack for the sale of house furnishings.

Charles Ruggles's return to the screen after a year's absence has been announced by Universal. The mild-mannered comedian will be featured in "Adam's Evening," for which a screen play has been written by Pat C. Flick and Eric Taylor. The cameras will turn Aug. 15.

Mrs. Helen Runyon Baldwin, widow of William Delavan Baldwin, for many years president of the Otis Elevator Company, died yesterday at her Summer home in Eastport, Me., after a brief illness, according to word received hero last night. Born and educated here,

Glenn L. Martin, who built the Hawaiian Clipper, missing in the Pacific, said today "she may be down, but unless there was a crash she will ride the water indefinitely." The Clipper, the first of three built in the Martin plant here, was launched in 1934. At that time Mr. Martin said:

Violation of the Wagner act was charged against the Ford Motor Company today in a report to the Federal Labor Relations Board by a board trial examiner, who recommended reinstatement by the company of fifty workers, with back pay since their discharge last year from its Buffalo plant, and discontinuance of company "interference" with the unionizing activities of the United Automobile Workers of America.

It was confirmed as the House of Commons recessed for the Summer this afternoon that the British destroyer n Hero witnessed the sinking of the bombed British freighter Dellwyn at Gandia, Spain, Tuesday without taking action against the single low-flying Insurgent aircraft that attacked her. This led a Laborite to shout:

Week-end livestock prices did not change much. Hogs topped at $10. most weighty packing sows selling at $6.25-$7, with butchery light kinds up to $7.85. according to the United States Department of Agriculture. Butcher barrows and packing sows are higher for the week, but light hogs lower. No choice weighty steers showed up and medium to good light steers sold steady to weak. It was mostly $9.40 down on fat lambs.

The huge flying boat Hawaii Clipper, unreported since 12:11 P. M. yesterday (12:11 A. M. Friday, New York time) on a flight from Guam, was the object today of one of the most intensive sea searches ever undertaken in Asiatic waters.

A new dance with "an unusual personality," which emphasizes jaunty grace. was demonstrated last night at the annual dinner of the Dance Educators Association by a teacher from Europe, where it is said to be the "current craze."

Construction of a $2,000,000 State home for epileptics was halted today by a strike called by a Federation of Labor union against the employment of nonunion labor. R. C. Schwoerer, timekeeper for the contractor, said that 200 union

The Cardinals allowed only two Bees to reach third base today, but both scored and beat them, 2 to 1. Debs Garms laced a single in the sixth to score Johnny Lanning and Vince DiMagglo. Lanning reached first when Don Padgett dropped his hit, and DiMaggio walked.

A contra-seasonal increase In cotton-mill activity last week raised the adjusted index to 104.4 from 102.5. The figure was 128.6 for the week ended July 24, 1937 Gray goods sales this week were small and print cloth volume was

After holding Johnny Levinson of Kennebunk, Me., the defending champion, even for nine holes today, 17-year-old Joe Monahan Jr. of Sandy Burr was beaten, 4 and 2, in a third-round New England amateur golf match at the Country Club.

The Raymar Farm of Mrs. Miriam L. Cohn, one of the sponsors of the exhibition, today gained the second leg of the West Long Branch Chal? Trophy for saddle horses on the opening day of the fifth annual Long Branch horse show at Raymar Farm.

The Rev. Dr. Joseph P. McComas will retire Sept. 19, his sixty-eighth birthday, as vicar of historic St. Paul's Episcopal Chapel, Trinity Parish, Broadway, between Fulton and Vesey Streets. He will become vicar-emeritus, with a pension from the parish.

Edward A. Gill Wylie, for many te years a practicing attorney in New York, died here today in his Summer home of a heart ailment. Mr. Wylie, who lived in New York at 470 Park Avenue, was 51 years old.

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks, 1,174,000 bales, against 1,157,000 a week ago, 1,133,000 two weeks ago, 1,138,000 three weeks ago and 819,000 a year ago; of which American 685,000 bales, against 696,000 a week ago, 707,000 two weeks ago, 723,000
The Bureau of'Agricultural Economics reported today that local market prices of all farm products except grains had advanced an average of about 3 per cent between mid-June and mid-July.

Charges of irregularities in the conduct of the election for officers, business agents and delegates, completed last night by the Furriers Joint Council of the International Fur Workers Union, Communist-led C. I. 0. affiliate, were denied yesterday by Irving Potash, candidate for. re-election as manager of the council, and his two fellow-candidates, Joseph Winogradsky and Harry Begun.

The Procurement Division of the United States Treasury placed $1,044,709.05 in orders in the WPA program for purchase of $10,000,000 worth of surplus clothing for distribution among the needy, it was announced here yesterday. The number of garments called for is 182,186.

IT was Gabby Hartnett who said that the Cin cinnati club had power and pitching and the Red Peril was a real one in the National League race. If so, Mild Will McKechnie would know something about it, Mild Will being the man who took a club that finished in last place last year and put it in the thick of thin year's pennant parade.

Harold E. Wettyen, Passaic County Agricultural Agent for twenty years, died last night at the general hospital of a cerebral hemorrhage at the age of 43. He also was active in Rotary Club work. His widow and two children survive.
Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Arlene B. Gardner, daughter of Mrs. Blanchard J. Gardner of Dunellen and the late Mr. Gardner, to Morgan Fitch Pearsall, son of Mr. and Mrs. J.
News from Paris that Pearl White is ill in the gay city where she sought surcease from her career of hairbreadth escapes evokes the hope that she will recover to face no more of them. It also brings

Richard Bennett, starring at the Players Theatre here in "They Knew What They Wanted," went back to the truly rural stage tonight when the electric power went out because of a thunder and lightning storm.

Imports of gold declined from $21,489,337 to $18,983,304 in the week ended on July 22 and exports dropped from $24,829 to $1,575, the Department of Commerce reported today. Imports of silver fell from $5,540,422 to $3,466,851 and exports from $69,238 to $24,034.

James S. Manning, former Attorney General of North Carolina and former associate justice of the State Supreme Court, died at his home late last night. His age was 79. James Smith Manning, who was born in Pittsboro, N. C., received an A. B. degree from

Perhaps nobody ever told Johnny Vander Meer about the desirability of keeping his shirt on when a crisis threatens. And even if the youthful hero of no-hit fame ever heard this sage advice, he paid no attention to it yesterday.
Movements of vessels follow, all dates are July 29 unless specified: At San Francisco, Arizona, Idaho, Maryland, Tennessee, West Virginia. At Boston, Babbitt, Dickerson, Rober, Tattnall Tillman.

The second installment of the report by the Security and Exchange Commission's experts on investment trusts is, like the first installment, mostly factual, its purpose evidently being to bring up nearly to date the actual history of these organizations.

Major Gen. Frank R. McCoy, commanding general of the Second Corps Area, who will retire from active service on Oct. 31 because of the 64-year age limit, started yesterday on a leave of absence that will continue until his retirement.

Anticipating that organizations reprezenting over-the-counter dealers will submit concrete suggestions designed to prevent manipulative activities in that market, the Securities and Exchange Commission postponed today until Nov. 1 the effectiveness of Rule GB4, which would have applied to over-thecounter trading the anti-manipulative provisions of the Securities Exchange Act now applicable to the Stock Exchanges.
While women at tea parties in London try on gas masks and Dutch farmers are instructed how to flood their farms at an hour's notice, it is foolish to pretend that the European outlook grows brighter.

Francis H. Baldy, counsel for the Securities and Exchange Commission, requested today that Howard Hopson, former chief executive of the Associated Gas and Electric System, be summoned to testify about the make-up of the general protective committee of the Utilities Power and Light Corporation.

Johnny Burke of Newport, national intercollegiate champion, and Jess Sweetser of New York, former national and British amateur titleholder, today qualified for the semifinals of the twelfth Newport Country Club invitation golf tournament.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Ray E. Mayham of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Grace Terrill Mayham, to William A. Stuiber Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Stuiber of Plainfield.

The appointment of John F. Cassidy of Long Island City as chief clerk of the Queens Surrogate Court to take effect on Monday, the date upon which the resignation of John Theofel from the same office is effective, was announced yesterday by Surrogate John Hetherington.

The Italian motorship Vulcania is sailing today for Mediterranean ports with 1,150 passengers. Among them are Fulvio de Suvich, Italian Ambassador to the United States; Dr. and Mrs. Seymour L. Bonwit, Dr. and Mrs. E. C. Kendall, Mr. and Mrs. Carl Davis, Judge and Mrs. Lawrence D. Groner, Joseph Hergesheimer, Mr. and Mrs. Milton Lowenthal and Mr. and Mrs. Henry G. Stevenrs.

Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on July 23 amounted to 580,882 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 21,418 cars, or 3.6 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week, 186,588 cars, or 24.3 per cent,

The experience of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York with direct loans to industry indicates that the income received, even at rates as high as 6 per cent, is not adequate to cover expenses and losses, the bank says in a discussion of its industrial loans in the current issue of its monthly review of credit and business conditions.

Creation of a committee on defense of civil liberties to protect the poor and rich alike was recommended to the American Bar Association as his first official act today by Frank J. Hogan of Washington, the new president.

Charles J. Pannill, president of the Radiomarine Corporation of America, a subsidiary of the Radio Corporation of America, announced yesterday the inauguration of a market quotation service by radio to passenger ships and yachts at sea at special rates.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that, as a result of cooperative efforts by the New York Stock Exchange and the Curb Exchange, it was able to make available statistics on member trading in round lots for their own account one week earlier than heretofore, reducing from four to three

Forrest to Jacob D. Goodman, 271 W 125th St; p m mtg and pr mtg $7,400, due Aug. 1. 1943 5 per cent; $3.600.

A SUNDAY in the market square at Darjeeling, framed by the mighty Himalayas, rewards the visitor with a scene out of medieval history, a scene that will be remembered long after the trip down to India's plains on the jittery little train of the Darjeeling-Himalaya Railroad is ended.

Miss Mary Lancaster, daughter of Mrs. Ellsworth Gage Lancaster of North Conway and the late Dr. Lancaster, was married at noon today to Alexander Leitch, son of Mrs. Charles McKechnie Leitch of Rutherford, N. J., and the late Mr. Leitch. The ceremony was performed at the home of the bride's mother in the presence of the two families by the Rev. William Thompson Rowe of Boston.

The Federal Housing Administration has compiled a series of booklets dealing with home ownership and modernization. In addition to explaining the operation of Titles I and II of the National Housing Act, the booklets contain other helpful information.
ATLANTIC CITY.--The South Jersey open golf championship tournament on the course of the Atlantic City Country Club at Northfield on Monday heads this week's list of sports attractions here.
-Members of the Yacht Racing Squadron of the Country Club of Westhampton Beach sailed a splendid regatta on Moriches Bay today.

Frank S. O'Hara of Jackson Heights, president of the Real Estate Association of the State of New York, has appointed a committee consisting of one representative from each member real estate board in the State to take charge of the management activities for the association's annual convention in Syracuse. SeDt. 15 to 17 inclusive.

Play will begin Monday afternoon and continue for a week in the twelfth annual Summer session of the national championship tournament of the American Contract Bridge League in the Convention Hall here. Seven important bridge championships will be determined. The contestants will include such players as Ely Culbertson, Josephine Culbertson, Oswald Jacoby, David Burnstine, Howard Schenken, Waldemar von Zedtwitz and Samuel Fry Jr.

According to statistics recently announced by the United States Labor Department, 15,300 dwelling units were erected in May in cities of 10,000 population or more, being an increase of 500 over April and 600 more than in May, 1937.

Father Divine, the Harlem evangelist whom Howland Spencer has chosen as a champion against the economic activities of President Roosevelt's New Deal, disavowed yesterday any intention of carrying on a controversy. In a speech in the "banqueting hall" of his "heaven" at 152-60 West 126th Street at about 1 A. M. he told his followers that he was not in conflict with anybody.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated July 29: MAJOR GENERAL Reynolds. C. R., the Surgeon General, one month leave, Aug. 8. COLONELS McCain, W. A., Q.M.C., relieved from additional duty with the Organized Reserve, Third Corps Area.

Developers of rental housing projects at the present time do not have to contend with the pressure of economic forces which produced bad housing in the past, declares Miles L. Clean, deputy administrator of the FHA, in The Insured Mortgage Portfolio, the official FHA publication.

ABOUT five weeks ago the Pirates were in fifth place in the National League and, when they passed this way, the large and amiable Pie Traynor, their manager, was being left severely alone. Nobody knocked on his door. Nobody phoned him. Nobody stopped him on the street to shake hands and say, "How are you,. my good man?"

TO say it's an ill wind is too sardonic, and yet since Germany has abandoned its artists there has been fresh interest in German art. The New Burlington Galleries, London, are reproducing the twentieth century German section of a show entitled "Degenerate Art" that was opened a year ago. The identical works are not necessarily hung, but there are works by the same men.

A bill of complaint charging Police Commissioner William P. Lawson with using the mails to defraud in connection with the sale of securities by his brokerage company was filed today in Federal Court by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Twelve persons were injured when a mustard gas bomb exploded in the Tremont Theatre tonight during a-showing of the film "The Prisoner of Zenda." The blast scattered an audience of 900 persons as fumes spread through the auditorium.

New York State drivers have become slightly more careful during the last year, women drivers apparently have fewer accidents and the most dangerous day on which to drive an automobile is Saturday, according to an analysis of automobile accidents in the State during the first half of 1938.
Jones Beach State Park will be the scene of the sixth annual Southern New York State archery championship for men and women today. The contests will be held adjacent to the east bathhouse.

Acting Secretary of the Treasury Roswell Magill, the Treasury's tax expert, stirred renewed interest in the Federal tax situation last week when he stated that the Treasury's tax studies are proceeding on several fronts.

IN August a goodly number of sun-tanned girls will leave their Summer fun and come to town to help in the about-to-be-opened college shops. They are the old guard who will advise rookies about the togs to be taken with them on the big adventure.

Two members' games, one at Phipps and the other at the No. :4 field of the club, were played here. today, with: Ivor Balding going-;w.ellon a White. side to pull it through att 7:to 5 in the game at Phipps On the club grounds the teams:galloped to a 7-7 tie, then halted play because of the intense heat.

Miss Helen W. Parker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jesse L. Parker of this place, was married in Glen Ridge Congregational Church tonight to George Henry Alexander, son of Mrs. M. H. Alexander of Rochester, N. Y. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. William Weston Patton.

The Pittsburgh Glass Institute announced its second annual competition for photographs of executed examples of glass in architecture, decoration and related subjects. Entrants in the contest must submit photographs of completed work and not for projected designs.

" The Road is dead: long live The Road." Herewith the case history of the last lingering hours for The Road in a one-night-stand town. 1937-38: The "sex-ational" (as billed) "Mulatto." 1936-37; "Tobacco Road." 1935-36: "Tobacco Road." 1934-35: Walter Hampden in "Richelieu"; "Roberta"; George M. Cohan in "Ah, Wilderness!" Eva Le Gallienne in "L'Aiglon."

Texas, in the century since she broke from Mexico, has had plenty of colorful and unorthodox politicians. But the Lone Star State has had none to outdo in dramatic flavor W. Lee O'Daniel, who today is the main topic of conversation from the Panhandle to the Rio Grande.

The Mott Haven Business Men's Association has started a campaign for the improvement of the Third Avenue blocks from 130th to 148th Streets. Elmer Freund, chairman of the association's committee points out that the immediate neighberhood has deteriorated rapidly in recent years with most of the buildings in a dilapidated condition.

Almost 67,000 officers and men of the Regular Army, National Guard and Reserves will begin to concentrate this week at five assembly points in the South and West for the largest single related manoeuvre in our peace-time history.

Improved business conditions in Netherland India in June and early July are credited by the United States commercial attache at Batavia to similar improvement in the United States, the Department of Commerce said today.
