Most of the members of the Summer colony and their week-end guests apparently were at the Newport Country Club this afternoon to watch the final match in the annual invitation golf tournament.
Production of electric energy for public use amounted to 113,316,000,000 kilowatt hours in the year ended on June 30, the Federal Power Commission reported today.
TODAY Perole String Quartet presents an hour chamber music recital on the Music Hall of the Air series: WJZ, 12:30 P. M.

Six United States youths will start tomorrow from here in quest of another aviation title for the United States-the nonstop mark for toy planes. The American entrants are James Cahill of Indianapolis, James Bohash of Detroit; George Matern of Oneonta, N. Y.; Ted Just of Johnstown, Pa.; G. J. Wisniewski of Milwaukee and their leader, Frank Zaie of New York.

The report of the Standard Gas and Electric Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on May 31, issued yesterday, showed after operating expenses and charges a consolidated net income of $2,700,118, compared with a consolidated net of $4,744,017 in the twelve months ended on May 31, 1937.

A canvass of individual seamen among the militant maritime unions of the New York area disclosed last week that the government's new merchant marine school, once the object of bitter protests from organized sea labor, has been accepted by the unlicensed personnel with only slight reservations.

CHINA plans to pay President Roosevelt postal honor, according to reliable information from the Far East. His likeness and that of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek are to appear on 5-cent, 25c, 50c and $1 stamps with

THAT a bird can live is a thing I can conceive very well: it has no notion at all that it exists before God-and I can well conceive that a man can endure the experience of existing before God when he himself does not know it.

The movement toward railroad consolidation, which ended abruptly following the stock market crash in 1929, would seem from recent events to be due for a revival, according to informed views in Wall Street. However, the methods used to bring about consolidations in the immediate future are expected to be in marked contrast to those followed in the pre-1929 era.

The most surrised people in the world were the alians when a report drafted by several anonymous but allegedly minent fascist university professors warned them last week that 11 sorts of grave, though unspecified dangers threatened them owing to the presence in their midst f an almost imperceptibly small ewish minority.

The Hudson Manhattan Railroad Company today asked the Interstate Commerce Commission to deny a petition by representatives of New Jersey municipalities to reopen the case involving an 8-cent fare from the company's Hudson Terminal to Jersey City and Hoboken.

For two years the Senate Civil Liberties Committee has delved into the seamy side of American industry, disclosing aspects of industrial relations existing in some companies that usually are kept tightly concealed from public view.
Stocks of domestic and foreign refinable crude petroleum in the United States on July 23 amounted to 287,585,000 barrels, the Bureau of Mines reported today.

SALLY BENSON is a gentle satirist. She deals no brutal blows that leave ugly bruises, but with greater art strips her subject of all pretences and affectations and lets her stand naked, not as God made her but as time and friends and circumstances have made her. Sometimes the creature that remains is likable, sometimes not, but always she is human and understandable.
Australia's Davis Cup doubles team crushed Mexico today and gained the right to oppose Japan in the American Zone finals at Montreal next week.
Adding his efforts to Tokyo's attempts to appease the growing third-power impatience with the continued disregard of neutrals' rights in China, Masayuki Tani, Japanese Minister at Large,

Mr. and Mrs. H. Lester Cuddihy gave a large dinner with dancing tonight at Canoe Place Inn to celebrate the twentieth anniversary of their marriage. Mrs. Cuddihy is the former Miss Julia Murray. The guests included members of their week-end house party at their country place in Water Mill, Mr. and Mrs. Walter G. Distler of Washington, D. C.; Mr. and Mrs.

On the promise that he would plead guilty and testify for the State, J. Richard (Dixie) Davis, former attorney for Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, slain head of the policy racket here, was released yesterday from the Tombs prison, where he had been held in default of $75,000 bail, and paroled in custody of District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey.
Stocks eased and closed irregularly higher after moderate gains, with trading the slowest since June 18; turnover, 358,940 shares.

WASHINGTON. -- If Douglas Corrigan's $900 "crate" in which he made his unauthorized flight of the Atlantic ever reaches the Smithsonian Institution's National Museum, as has been suggested here, it may rank second in popularity among the exhibits.

Word of steel price reductions in this country has caused a decline in orders from abroad for hardware products, exporters said here last week. Buyers, who formerly took several months' supply of goods at this season of the year, are restricting commitments to immediate needs and advising producers that they will hold off on regular orders in the hope of purchasing at lower levels in the Fall.
The Greek Government formally announced today that Premier John Metaxas, who crushed a rebellion in Crete yesterday, would be Premier "for life."

HAVING started his career scooping up pennies from the floor of Nigger Mike's genius factory on Pell Street, where he played the piano, Harry Seymour is almost certain to find himself cast for any Warner picture with a piano in it.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As it was with Columbus and the egg, so it is often the case that the most obvious solutions of present-day problems are overlooked, and this is especially true of intellectuals, who sometimes fail to see the forest for the trees.

Chanel declares her Winter collection aims to clothe rather than astonish. Her street and sports suits show her typical silhouette, with slim skirts, often with stitched and pleated fronts, and short fitted jackets having wide waist-length revers, faced with checks or stripes, or matching waistcoat-blouses.

Robert L. Riggs gave one of the greatest performances of his tennis career today to win his second successive leg on the Seabright Bowl, the first player to do so since Vincent Richards repeated in 1926.
Charles Michelson, publicity director for the Democratic National Committee, said today that the United States could have a public debt of $90,000,000,000 and still be as solvent as Great Britain.

General satisfaction with the regulations promulgated by the Secretary of the Treasury under the new marking provisions of the Tariff Act was expressed by importers here last week. The regulations were issued in connection with the amended Customs Administrative Act which became effective last Monday.

Twenty steel companies representing a substantial part of the domestic iron and steel industry reported an aggregate net loss of $9,666,681 for the second quarter of 1938, with operations at 30.76 per cent of capacity, contrasted with a net profit of $69,493,007 for the same period a year ago, when operations averaged 84.55 per cent of capacity.

A grand' jury investigating political "war chest" contributions today absolved Charles Sawyer's campaign manager of "any culpability whatsoever" in charges of soliciting civil service workers in violation of State law.

The Apparel and Accessories Exhibit at the New York World's Fair 1939, "directed along competent and dignified lines, will offer an opportunity for arousing the public to a realization of the great artistry and skill in the American fashion field of today," Maurice Rentner, chairman of the Fashion Originators Guild, said yesterday.
Bat, sailed by B. C. Crabbe of the Toms River Yacht Club, took the historic Morgan Cup today in the thirtieth regatta held for his trophy.

WITH 1939 world-cruise circulars beginning to flutter out of travel bureaus, even stay-at-homes are dreaming of strange lands far away-of restless surf on white beaches, of elephants bathing, of slim girls dancing with flower bracelets on ankle and wrist. Lazily turning the pages of these brightcolored booklets,

A "Gay Nineties" costume ball for the benefit of South County Hospital will take place at the Dunes Club on Aug. 20. The event is being sponsored by Harold Knowlton, J. Banigan Sullivan and Robert S. Holding Jr. of the Dunes Club activities committee.

The average discount rate on the weekly Treasury bill issues hardened markedly in July to reach the highest figure since last April. In the continued absence of any quotable change in other short-term money rates, the weekly bill issues again gave the only indication of a money-market tendency.

Construction has been started by the Arthur D. Crane Company on two new homes at Lake Mohawk in Sussex County, near Sparta, N. J. On a slope at the intersection of Mohawk and West Shore Trails, a cottage is being built for Mr. and Mrs. Robert K. Campbell

A jury of mountain men, who for eleven weeks have listened to evidence and argument relative to the guilt or innocence of fifty-five Harlan County coal companies, operators and former peace officers, informed Federal Judge H. Church Ford tonight that they had "tried in every way but it seems like an impossibility to make a verdict."

There was a mild surprise for the crowd that witnessed the close of the fifth annual Long Branch Horse Show at the Raymar Farm today when Thunder Queen, owned by the Claredda Farm of Edward V. Quinn, gained the hunter championship, with Tom Mott Jr.'s The Hour held in reserve.

THIS year marks the fiftieth anniversary of Sir Henry Wood's first appearance as conductor of concerts in England. Since 1895 he has directed every program of the annual Summer Promenade series in London, the forty-fourth season of which opens next Sunday and continues until Oct. 1. As usual, the veteran leader will conduct the BBC Symphony Orchestra at these events.

The large brick residence in Scarsdale, Westchester County, on Olmstead Road and Brite Avenue, has been. purchased by Stoughton Walker from Samuel M. Chase. The house contains eleven rooms and four baths. The firm of George Howe, Inc., acted as broker.

Defective chimneys and flues, points out Harry E. Roethe in Safety Engineering, cause a large percentage of fires. They fall into two classes, one being those fundamentally wrong in construction and the other those which are defective through lack of care.

The views of the Committee on Administrative Law, named by the State Bar Association at its mid-Summer meeting early this month and headed by Edward Gluck of New York City, have been presented in a report to the Constitutional Convention, where the subject is now on the general order calendar.

A letter asking for a board of inquiry to ascertain the fitness of Lieutenant James O. Smith Jr. to hold his Reserve army commission is on file at Second Corps Area Headquarters on Governors Island, it was said there yesterday.

Miss Mary Elisabeth Pullman of New Rochelle, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. William Turner Pullman, was married here this afternoon in the garden of Crow's Nest, the Summer home at Rogers Rock of ber aunt, Mrs. Charles Elwell Perkins, to Thomas Howell Pace, son of Mr. and Mrs. Powers Pace of Pittsburgh and Atlanta.

The marriage of Miss Sarah Louise Lanctot, daughter of Mrs. Wayne Lanctot of this place, to Richard Wynkoop Rigg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Horace A. Rigg of Wayne, Pa., took place this afternoon in the Congregational Church here. The Rev. Clifford W. Hilliker officiated.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Bernice Glaser, daughter of Mrs. Samuel Glaser of the Bronx and the late Mr. Glaser, to William Miller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham J. Miller of this city.

FLORENCE. THE story of the Florence festival is not complete with a review of its music novelties. Hand in hand with them go the experiments in modern stage production that are a basic objective in the Florentine program.

Argentina's exports of cotton in the first six months this year amounted to 2,971 metric tons, compared with 9,408 for the same period in 1937, the Department of Commerce announced today. Germany is receiving most of the exports, having bought 2,842 tons this year, against 1,037 tons in the same period a year ago.

Dr. W. F. Vail's bay gelding Judge gave an excellent exhibition of trotting today, winning the Class A event. Cecil Hanover, another bay gelding from the Vail stable, was driven to victory in Class B by Mrs. Lloyd Vail in close heats. The Class C test was taken by the veteran campaigner.

Dr. William O. Jones, former chancellor of the University of Kansas City and of York (Neb.) College, died here today following a long illness. His age was 63. Dr. Jones, a retired United Brethren minister, held pastorates at Lincoln, Neb., Omaha and Winfield.
Black Mountain College in North Carolina will have one teacher to every three or four students next year with a staff of fifteen or sixteen members for an enrollment of between fifty and sixty.

The marriage of Miss Marion Lauren Pendleton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard F. Pendleton of Norwich, Conn., to the Rev. Victor Obenhaus, son of Dr. and Mrs. Herman Obenhaus of Oak Park, Ill., took place yesterday afternoon in the chapel of the Riverside Church, where the bridegroom is a member of the ministerial staff.

This is the week-end of the August "bank holiday," when all Britain takes three days off to bask in the Summer sun and put its troubles out of mind. Today a hot sun beat down on Southern England from an unclouded sky.
The Fascist newspaper II Tevere today applied the Fascist racist doctrine to Mayor Fiorello La Guardia of New York by saying he had no right to belong to "our race."

Issues vitally affecting the relations between workers and their employers under the Wagner act appear headed for Supreme Court review this Fall. They spring from three sources: The three-year-old schism in the ranks of organized labor.

HONG KONG.--War has brought prosperity to Hong Kong. Refugees from Canton have swelled the popunation of this city and near-by Kowloon from less than 800,000 to 1,400,000. Hong Kong's harbor is crowded with ships-most of them bringing munitions, war supplies,

ECHOES of the Lewis and Clark expedition sound "through Miss Darby's new story. It is a book which may well be given to those children whose imagination has been stirred by Julia Davis's fine narrative of that trip. "No Other White Man," or by Flora Seymour's "Meriwether Lewis," but it also stands on its own merits as an interesting story of St. Louis at the close of the War of 1812,

Henry Armstrong and Lou Ambers put in a brisk day's training yesterday, preparing for their scheduled meeting at the Polo Grounds on Aug. 10. Armstrong, who holds the world featherweight and welterweight titles, went through his paces at Dr. Joseph Bier's camp in Pompton Lakes, N. J., while Ambers did his work at Madame Bey's, in Summit. N. J.
THE astronomers and physicists met at Yerkes Observatory in Wisconsin recently to discuss among other things their knowledge of the planets. And extraordinary their knowledge was.

A COLLECTION of more than 1,000 rare musical compositions, written in the period from the fourteenth to the end of the eighteenth century, has been made by the Education Division of the Federal Music Project in this city, according to an announcement issued from project headquarters. A year of work by research experts of the project was required to complete the library.

Editor The New York Times Book Review: Arthur P. Coleman's review of my book "Towns and People of Modern Poland," in the June 26 issue of The Times Book Review, impels me to call your attention to 'several statements and deductions which I believe are not supported by fact.

With declines in four of its components checking its advance, THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity has dropped half a point for the week ended July 23, and now stands at 80.8, as against 81.3 (revised) for the previous week and 107.0 for the comparable week a year ago.

Utilities, dealers and other sales outlets, manufacturers and trade associations of the gas industry will combine their efforts, beginning tomorrow, in presenting to the public the new "Certified Performance" gas range, which meets twenty-two rigid specifications set up by. tile industry. Plans for promoting, advertising and merchandising the new range, which will be turned out by eighteen makers, have been under way for several months by the Association of Gas Appliance and Equipment Manufacturers.

Transfers and Assignments To take effect 8 A. M., Aug. 1: PATROLMEN--Arthur M. Ozab, from 43d Precinct to Quartermaster's Department, assigned to duty as chauffeur. Abraham I. Ebenfeld, from 77th Precinct to 75th Precinct.

His name is Joseph Gregg Moore and he comes from Gause, down in the Panhandle country of Texas. He looks so fragile that they call him the Thin Man and the Gause Ghost. And because Dolf Luque, the former Cuban pitcher and Giant coach, couldn't quite master the English pronunciation of Moore's first name and called him Yo-Yo, they also refer to him as Jo-Jo Moore.

Further leasings of moors for grouse shooting in Scotland include Grantually Castle, which has been taken by Major Edward Hubbard; Clunes, in Parthshire, by Quincey Bent, and Dalname, in Perthshire, by S. M. Mongonery.

Epithets of "carpet-bagger" and "political hitch-hiker," hurled at Senator McAdoo by other Democratic stalwarts, put new life tonight into a pre-primary battle which is veering toward Senate campaign committee investigators.

For two years or so prior to July of last year, the Russians showed a very stiff attitude toward border incidents with the Japanese-Manchukuoan forces. The record is full of firm demands by Moscow and conciliatory replies by the Japanese. Then came the "purge" of the Russian officers, in which it is reported more than fifty per cent of the leaders of the Soviet military machine Were removed by death or otherwise from their commands.

The Railway Express Agency, which is controlled by all the railroads, will take over the express operations of the Southern Railway and controlled lines tomorrow in accordance with authority granted by the Interstate Commerce Commission.
ARTISTS have one-man shows, authors can publish their collected works, but the composers of popular music never have a chance to hear their own work "all in a bunch," so to speak.
Mrs. Adele Clerc Ogden, widow of George W. Ogden, died here today at the age of 82 in the Ogden homestead in which she had lived for more than fifty years.
Tired and suffering from a fever of 100.5, Shirley Temple was put to bed in the royal suite of a hotel here today instead of "doing" Paul Revere's house and retracing. his famous ride.

One of the common, and often perplexing, problems of the midSummer border is how to treat the empty spaces left by the "disappearing act" of the Oriental poppies. As most gardeners know, these plants, which grow so vigorously during Spring and early

Funeral services for Henry Stanford Brooks, for many years an executive of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and secretary and a director of the Boys Club of New York, were held here this morning in St. James's Church.
Generalissimo Francisco Franco appeared tonight to have halted the government's Ebro River offensive with a tremendous concentration of men and planes, but he had failed to regain any lost ground.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I.--Tennis week, which marks the climax of the social season here, will begin tomorrow with the opening in the afternoon of the forty-eighth annual invitation tennis tournament held on the courts of the Meadow Club.

Traveling vacationists are fortunate in being able to concentrate their garden glory to Spring and Autumn, but the stay-at-homes, who require something besides green grass and quiescent roses during the dog days of Summer, have to apportion their plantings to a different scheme.

Dividends aggregating $1,123,600 for the semi-annual period ending June 30 have been declared by ten of the twelve Federal Home Loan Banks. In making the announcement yesterday, Preston Delano, Governor of the Federal Home Loan Bank System, stated that the two remaining banks declare dividends only once a year. on Dec. 31.
BRAUN--Dr. and Mrs. Tibor., announce the birth of a daughter on July 19 at X-Ray Hospital. BRYANT--Mr. and Mrs. George H., announce the birth of a daughter, July 26, 1938, at Polyclinic Hospital.

Canada Dry Ginger Ale, Inc., and its subsidiaries reported yesterday a net income of $332,479 for the nine months ended on June 30. This was after interest, depreciation, Federal income taxes and other charges, but before the Federal surtax on undistributed profits.

Denying the charge of John Roxborough, co-manager of Joe Louis, that newsreels of the recent LouisSchmeling fight were doctored in Germany to include shots of their first fight, which Max won, the German News Bureau here revealed that no pictures of the second battle were shown at all.

A seventy-six-acre farm on the Curley Hill Road in Plumstead Township, about four miles from Doylestown, Bucks County, Pa., has been sold by Mrs. Justin L. Peters of Philadelphia to Bayard D. Kunkle of the accessory and manufacturing staff of the General Motors Cqrporation.

The Indians clung to their spot one game behind the league-leading Yankees today by defeating the Senators, 8 to 5, for their fifth straight victory. It was the fourth consecutive triumph for Mel Harder, veteran pitcher, who recovered this season after a shaky start.
WAY back in 1912 this reviewer had the good for tune to spend three months among the cockneys round the Elephant and Castle, having taken a leaf out of Twelfth Night":

Competing in a light breeze that taxed the skippers and crews considerably, a fleet of twenty-three craft began the 'quest for the Atlantic Coast canoe-sailing championships yesterday in Sheepshead BaY, the events being divided into three classes. A. B and C.

The Communist slate, headed by Irving Potash, manager, was declared elected yesterday in the contest for officers, business agents and delegates conducted by the Furriers Joint Council of the International Fur Workers Union, C. I. O. affiliate.

Often there arises among horticulturists an argument as to how far the roots of trees spread in proportion to the growth of the tops, This is not merely of academic interest, for problems of soil-robbing, moisture supply for plants grown near trees, tree feeding and many others are involved in the correct answer.

THE FCC, contending that the Zenith Radio Corporation of Chicago has a program of research and experimentation which indicates "reasonable promise of substantial contribution to the development of the television broadcast art," has granted permission to construct an image transmitter.

Governor Nelson G. Kraschel tonight closed the National Labor Relations Board hearing in the Maytag strike at Newton, Iowa, because he felt it was a "disturbing factor" in the community and "might be delaying a settlement of the dispute."

Premier Benito Mussolini was not slow in picking up the gauntlet thrown down by Pope Pius in his speech at Castel Gandolfo Thursday and published yesterday in the Osservatore Romano, Vatican City newspaper.

THE Cutty Sark, the famous old, tea-clipper of the Eighteen Seventies which recently set out on her last voyage from Falmouth to Greenhithe to become part of the Thames Nautical Training College, is a mystery ship in spite of her fame.

Hank Greenberg banged his thirty-sixth and thirty-seventh homers of the year and rookie pitcher Harry Eisenstat contributed two brilliant jobs of relief hurling to give the Tigers a sweep of a double-header with the Athletics today. The scores were 10 to 7 and 8 to 7.

The need of industry for skilled workmen with increasing educational background, and education's desire for practical training of its students to fit the needs of industry, have brought about an integration of high school instruction with industrial apprenticeship in the Rockford (Ill.) senior high school and the machine trade industries of Rockford.
T. Frank Joyce, former newspaper man, wartime aviator and advertising and railroad executive, died today at his home in Cambridge after a short illness. His age was 48.
Another use for oil of cloves, besides easing an aching tooth, is described in a patent (No. 2,124,706) granted to Donald J. Maveety of Millburn, N. J..

Details of the proposed $3,849,460 additional WPA projects for the physical improvement of the four city colleges in 1938-39, which the Board of Higher Education voted to submit for approval to the Works Progress Administration, were made public yesterday.

Cool blue against the midsummer heat and cool green against the dry earth--these are Veronicas. The light grace of the spirelike racemes, usually blue or violet, but in rare instances pink or white, makes them combine well with other plants-whether in the garden or a flower arrangement.
Japan and Soviet Russia came to grips today in what the Tokyo War Office characterized as a "terrible fight" in which Japanese recaptured disputed territory along the Manchukuoan-Siberian border.

Hailed by his city "as a man who deserved to succeed" and honored by a decoration from the German Government and by the declaration of a civic holiday by many Michigan municipalities, Henry Ford today celebrated his seventy-fifth birthday.

The need for measures to stimulate the Australian Commonwealth's foreign trade is urgent. The Australian Ministers emphasized this in the recent fruitless London negotiations, which were partly designed to recast the Ottawa Agreement so as to facilitate the development of trade with non-British countries.

WHILE this newspaper was recently calling in specialists from all over the country every Sunday for hebdomadal editorial consultations on the state of the road, George Abbott was doing his best to revive the patient by planning a Fall tour for "What a Life," the Clifford Goldsmith comedy at the Biltmore Theatre. He is still planning it.

Bonds called last week for redemption before maturity were in relatively light volume and conmisted mostly of parts of outstanding issues. Payment dates were principally for August, with no new additions to the list to be retired this month.

NAUGHT so much enhances our complacency and feeling of being well-informed as to read opinions from cross-sections rather a long way off, and learn who in the South, the corn-brakes, Maine or elsewhere is viewed with revulsion and who, if anybody, is liked at all.

IN "Spain Between Death and Birth" Peter Merin has produced, by using the John Dos Passos formula, an individualistic study, a biased and at times brilliant expolse of the forces that had postponed for generations Spain's conflict of liberation.

Alvin (Jake) Powell, New York Yankee outfielder, was suspended for ten days by Commissioner K. M. Landis today. The action followed a radio interview yesterday in which Powell is alleged to have made a flippant remark that was taken to be offensive to Chicago's Negro population and raised a storm of protest in its wake.

THE first part of this story is the diary of Frank Cairns, whose young son has been killed by an unidentified hit-and-run driver. Cairns determines to find this man and kill him, and the diary tells of his search and of his carefully prepared plan for the murder.
Some 2,500,000 workers, it is estimated, have drawn the $180,000,000 of unemployment benefits paid out for varying periods of total or partial unemployment in the first six months of this year.

LONDON.-Cecil Rhodes's birthplace at Bishop Stortford, about thirty miles from London, has been opened as a permanent Rhodes Museum, furnished in the style of the time of his birth (1853) and filled with personal relics collected from all over South Africa and England.

James Gaspirno, a laborer, of Greenwich, Conn., was committed to Bellevue Hospital psychopathic ward at 5 o'clock yesterday morning. He had smashed a large plateglass window of a battery store in the Bronx and injured two patrolmen and a detective.

An independent Federal agency created by the administrator and acting under his direction is the most vital need for the success of the Wage-Hour Law, Mortimes Fishel, New York attorney, dedared yesterday.

Nearly every boat owner around Gravesend Bay will get into white cap and yachting duds this afternoon for a unique marine parade aimed to celebrate the revival of pleasure boating and fishing and to remind Brooklynites of the natural harbor that they have virtually at their front door.
Coalitions of the American Labor party and the Republicans on Congressional candidates will be few, Alex Rose, State executive secretary of the labor group, said yesterday.
Pope Pius's speech on race theories drew sharp rebuffs from the German press today. For instance the Angriff, Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels' paper, says:

Harvey McLean Voorhees, founder and president of H. M. Vorhees Bro., women's clothing merchants, of this city, died last night after a two years' illness. He was 72 years old. Mr. Voorhees started his merchantile career in Freehold as a boy.

When the four-engine Dieselpowered seaplane Nordmeer of the Deutsche Lufthansa lands at Port Washington tomorrow about 2 P. M. on its second Azores-to-New York survey flight of the Summer it will mark the 100th crossing or ship-to-shore flight over the Atlantic by Captain
At least one farmer was killed by a bolt of lightning in New Jersey last week. In spite of the frequency of fatal

Mr. and Mrs. Francis Bertram Elgas of the Croydon, 12 East Eighty-sixth Street, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Priscilla McLintock Elgas to Edwin Ely Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Woolsey Smith of Westfield, Mass. A granddaughter of the late Dr. Matthew J. Elgas, long associated with the Board of Education of New York City,

THERE'S a lull i the life of Mr. Bacon's witty verse. Brightness no longer falls from the air and something of a positive despondence and exasperation settles largely over the book. In the first of his few rhymed stanzas, he writes:

VIRGINIA BEACH, Va.--The duck, geese, snipe and coot hunting season in this area has been lengthened by fifteen days, according to recent announcement made by the Bureau of Biological Survey in Washington, D. C. The opening date will be Nov. 15 and the season will continue through Dec. 29.

Ted Adams of Columbia, Mo., outlasted C. Ross (Sandy) Somerville of London in a thirty-nine-hole duel to win the Canadian amateur golf championship today. It was Adams's first victory in a major tournament and Somerville's fourth defeat in the ten times he has reached the Canadian final. To win it, the 21-year-old high school teacher had to beat his rival at his own kind of game over the London Hunt and Country Club course,

THE just-established of dark papered or painted walls introduces a new idea in room settings: gradations of light and dark rather than of color. While this fashion is as yet seen only in ultra-smart interiors, its effect is approximated in less elaborate rooms.

Announcement today of the establishment of a non-profit educational motion picture corporation known as the Association of School Film Libraries, Inc., is considered by educators to mark fulfillment of a long-discussed need for a central source to which schools will be able to turn with confidence for information about educational films.

Sir Norman William Raeburn, one of the foremost Admiralty lawyers, was removed yesterday by the High Court as arbitrator in a shipping collision case on the allegation that he had said, "Italians are all liars in these cases and will say anything to suit their book. The same thing applies to the Portuguese."

By 9 o'clock of a sweltering Summer morning baby carriages are wheeled along an upper East Side block, mothers carry their infants, or lead small children from near-by streets, a tall thin girl comes alone from the bus stop-all headed toward the substantial modern building which is one of New York's ??ew health centers.

Mrs. Florence Terrell Hartshorn, daughter of Mrs. Alton T. Terrell and the late Mr. Terrell, was married to Clarence Alexander Earl Jr. of New York this afternoon at Overbrook, the home of her mother in near-by Orange. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Frank Loper.

Following a decline on Friday to new low levels for a year or longer the pound sterling and other important foreign exchanges recovered slightly yesterday. Compared with a week ago, the rates of most of the exchanges were down.

BRETTON WOODS, N. I.Theatre fare for White Mountain visitors promises to be interesting this week. The Yale Puppeteers will make their first and perhaps only appearance at the Chase Barn Theatre in Whitefield today. The Forty Niners will present at their Chase Barn Theatre on Tuesday S. N. Behrman's comedy "Biography," first produced by the Theatre Guild. Plays will be given nightly.

A number of reasons why the Constitutional Convention should act on the Real Estate Board of New York's appeal to insert in the State Constitution a provision creating a State board of tax appeals, to which protests can be carried when reductions are denied by the local board, are advanced by L. D. Garrett, president of the National Property Appraisal Service.

KINGS COUGHLIN, RICHARD GUSTINE (July 18). Estate, less than $20,000 personal. To brothers, Joseph Coughlin, 2,244 Nostrand Ave., and William Coughlin 431 Pulaski St., and sister, Margaret Lane, 199 Weirfield St. $1 each; sisters, Annia Von Lindern, 148-31 87th Ave., Jamaica, and Mary Kelly, 669 Bedford Ave., executrix, one-half of residuary estate each.

MR. ROOSEVELT'S breathing spell reached Times Square last week, after the usual delay crossing Sixth Avenue, and gave us a chance to catch up on our press-book reading. Perhaps you've never read a pressbook. Too bad.

The entrance of Secretary Ickes into Virginia's Eighth District primary campaign brought today a charge that he was guilty of "a vicious and uncalled-for attack upon the president of a great university."
Nine rules for a successful life were outlined by Frank P. Graves, State Education Commissioner, at a business college graduation here. They were:

A capacity audience of 11,000 persons attended a concert given in the Marine Stadium tonight by Paul Whiteman and his orchestra. Mr. Whiteman's program was largely made up of popular numbers, but it also included the orchestra leader's own arrangement of the classics and one swing tune, "Evolution of Swing."

Dr. Frank O'Hara, Professor of Economics at Catholic University since 1909 and founder of Columbus University, died early today in Providence Hospital here after a month's illness. He was 62 years old.

The records of the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce for the first five months of this year show a heavy decline in Japanese importation of American raw materials that are essential to the prosecution of war.
Dr. H. Windsor Wade, Rockefeller Foundation expert on leprosy, arrived today aboard the liner Empress of Asia and disclosed that he barely had missed being a passenger on the lost Hawaii Clipper.
O. O. McIntyre mirrored himself in his newspaper coleumn. But perhaps the most interesting fact concerning him is that millions of newspaper readers believed that he also mirrored them.

During these past weeks of active Anglo-French demonstration of friendship and solidarity and of no less active AngloGerman negotiation, Russia as a diplomatic and military factor in the Eurpean situation has seemed to be lost to sight.

Steps for a "great national retail demonstration" this Fall, which will link retailers throughout the country in carrying a message of confidence in American business to the consumer through institutional advertising and merchandising disI plays, will be considered by a meeting of a large committee of members of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, which has been tentatively called for next Thursday at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

A prospectus of the data and statistical tables in the new Lloyd's Register for 1938-39 covers the entire development of the world's merchant marine fleets since 1901, the period which saw the greatest growth in the annals of merchant shipping.

Colonel Alvin C. Voris, commandant of the Army Signal School at Fort Monmouth, N. J., will be placed on the retired list today after more than forty years in the army. He is being retired because of physical disability incident to his long career in the service.

As a result of the voluntary adoption of standards for advertising August fur sales, there has been a "marked change for the better in local advertising to date on August fur sales as contrasted with last year," it was reported yesterday by H. J. Kenner, general manager of the local Better Business Bureau.

A mass meeting of farmers of the inundated valley of the Colorado River held today, voted that an investigation of the Lower Colorado River Authority's management of the Buchanan Dam should be made and that it should be independent of that which has been ordered by Secretary Ickes.

ASK any informed person who is the richest actor in Hollywood and he will probably tell you: Harold Lloyd. Harold is the Rockefeller of film stars; his home, a forty-five-room mansion, is the show-place of the movie colony.

This drawing by Theodore Kautsky shows spectators traveling on two moving platforms, suspended high within the 200-foot sphere, to view Democracity, described as the city of tomorrow morning, and a related spectacle with a thousand heroic figures forming a mural visualizing the interdependence of mankind.

While admitting some doubts as to the permanence of the current improvement in business, Fenner Beane, member of the New York Stock Exchange, points out in its monthly review that conditions have improved in many individual industries, including especially the automobile equipment, tire, newsprint and railroad groups.

Henry W. Anderson of this city said today that a statement attributed to him in press dispatches from the American Bar Association session at Cleveland on Wednesday was "in conflict" with the position he took on railroads.

SYDNEY, Australia.--Australia's famous flying doctor service, which began when Dr. Clyde Fenton, who went into the Northern Territory in 1928, grew tired of trying to cover a trackless land twice the size of Texas in an automobile, now has added a women's division.

Fifteen hundred homes, as well as all the stores in the shopping district and police headquarters, were plunged in darkness at 10:30 o'clock tonight because of a defect in one of the power lines of the Public Service Corporation.
Take a walk down a busy street. One out of every 37 persons you meet will be a criminal. One out of every 650and it doesn't take long to meet that many in New York City-is or will be a murderer.

Tennesseeans are wondering whether the Volunteer State has ever seen anything quite like the present Democratic primary contest, which is leading up to the balloting on Aug. 4 with a flavor of the gall many fear may lead to bloodshed.

Apartment house rentals for Fall occupancy are showing a marked improvement in activity according to reports from various brokers. William A. White Sons report that the new seventeen-story Southmoor apartment house at 230 Central Park South is open for occupancy and several tenants have moved in.

A VISITOR from Iowa walked into a Broadway hotel last week and said to the clerk, "I want to reserve your best three-room suite for the first week in July, 1939." "I'm sorry," the clerk replied. "That suite is already taken." The city abounds in small portents like this of the huge housing demand that is expected to arise here when the New York World's Fair opens next April 30.

Although there have been a few cases of sabotage of trains on the main Palestine-Egypt line in addition to several cases of sniping in the last few days, the situation in Palestine is now characterized as calm. However, this does not mean that there is hope that conditions will return to normal soon; on the contrary, the general belief among officials is that the situation will become worse.

With tall standards of white lilies forming an aisle beneath a green and white bower in the garden of her mother's home, Miss Patti Warfield Edmonston, daughter of Mrs. Edgar Davis Edmonston of Guilford, this city, and the late Mr. Edmonston, was married this afternoon to First Lieutenant Thomas Leslie Crystal Jr., Sixth Field Artillery, U. S. A.

Miss Juliet Gulon Oakes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Oakes of this place, was married tonight to John S. Eells Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. John S. Eells of Ross., Calif. The ceremony was performed in the First Presbyterian Church here by the pastor, the Rev. Dr. Archibald Gordon Sinclair, who was assisted by Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin,
LONDON. URING my three happy visits to the United States I have found a great deal of public interest in the relations between capital and labor in Great Britain as compared with America.

More than 1,000 persons are expected to attend the Rural and Industrial Conference to be held at St. Francis Xavier University, Aug. 16-18. Besides delegates from Nova Scotia, New Brunswick, Prince Edward Island and Newfoundland, there will be 200 visitors from religious, educational and cooperative organizations in the United States.

Two new backs, Howard Yeager of Pasadena and Doug Locke of San Antonio, have signed contracts with the New York Football Giants for the coming campaign, it was announced yesterday by John V. Mara, club president.
A LONG - TALKED - OF traffic project -- the Battery - to - Brooklyn vehicular tunnel--claimed new interest a few days ago when Mayor La Guardia made a special trip to Washington to ask PWA aid in the

Apparently headed for defeat midway in the fifth set after being forced to match point, 18-year-old Joseph Fishbach rallied superbly to upset Wayne Sabin, the nation's sixth-ranking player, in the Eastern clay court tennis championship semi-finals yesterday at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club.

Miss Sally Estes Reimer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Adams Reimer, was married here this afternoon at the home of her parents to Burton William Teague, son of Mr. and Mrs. William T. Teague, also of this city, by the Rev. Francis Carr Stifler of Summit.

More than 300 persons attended the annual Wyantenuck Country Club men's golf tournanent ball tonight at the club house. Mrs. Robert Latimer Redfield Jr., who was in charge, also was chairnan of the tournament tea this afternoon at the club.

DETROIT. PRODUCTION of automobiles and trucks slid off slowly again this week as the industry moved closer to its Summer change-over period. The total was down about 5,000 units from the previous week.

As if encouraged by man's preoccupation with war against his fellow man, insect enemies of the human species have struck again this year with renewed vigor and on a wider front. No area of the country ever really is exempt at any time from the ravages of insect armies, but many regions have enjoyed intervals of comparative peace which make today's strife seem the more acute.

A number of deals involving industrial properties in Queens are reported by C. Grant Keck, broker, and vice chairman of the Queens by Industrial Commission. He points out that the borough is the scene of much activity in properties of that nature.

A total of $2,327,000,000 in monthly repayment credits was granted for home building and buying and the purchase of home furnishings throughout the country during 1937, according to the home building and home owning committee of the United States Building and Loan League.

Declaring the tax exemption extended to improvements on existing buildings had resulted in renovation work this year that may run as high as $75,000,000, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday that he would ask the Legislature at its next session to repass the enabling act under which the city is authorized to grant the five-year exemption.

FIVE American composers and two American soloists will take part in the "American Composers Night" at the Stadium tonight. Soloists for the week are Josef and Rosina Lhevinne and Arnold Belnick, boy violinist.

After the Browns had rallied in the ninth inning to tie the score, the Boston Red Sox scored a run in the twelfth to whip the St. Louis cellar dwellers, 5 to 4, today behind the excellent relief pitching of Jack Wilson.

THE famous diaries of Gouverneur Morris, who was United States Minister to France during the Reign of Terror, are to be published this Fall by Houghton Mifflin in full and unekpurgated .form under the title, "A Diary of the French Revolution," edited by Morris's great-granddaughter, Beatrix Davenport.

The Willow Brook Farms' Ash Wednesday defeated the Newbrook Stables' 2-year-old filly, Beckie Dale, in the feature event atthe weekly matinee sponsored by the Road Horse Association of New Jersey at Weequahic Park today. Driven by her owner, Walter Wilkins, Ash Wednesday scored in straight heats.

NEARLY every age, including our own, has had its utopian dreams and its odd manifestations of crackpot idealism. They hardly ever seem as laughable as they are, or as pitiful, until they have been dead for at least a generation. Thus at the moment we can look back with interest, and perhaps with complacence, upon the latter half of the nineteenth century in America.

John Edward Keron, banker and welfare leader, died today in Elizabeth General Hospital at the age of 76. Mr. Keron was vice president of the Union City Savings Bank, a former trustee of First Presbyterian Church, served many years as treasurer of the Family Welfare Society and was a founder of the Suburban Golf Club.

Ontario's gold mines produced bullion valued at $8,203,982 in June, a drop of $48,592 from the high record output of $8,252,574 in May, but still the second best monthly production in the Province's history.

Whatever were the motives behind the decision of Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain of Britain to ask Prague to accept Viscount Runciman as adviser, the immediate effect has been to cause the war c uds that were so ominously thickening over Europe in the last few weeks to recede-anyway, temporarily.

Miss Rosamund Roberts, appearing as Catherine of Russia in the pageant staged yesterday for the benefit of the Village Improvement Society, was voted the most beautiful in a group of twenty-five young girls who represented famous beauties of history and fiction. The Misses Anne Miner and Mary Grace Harris, as Florodora girls, received the second highest vote.

FOR going on twenty-five years, Richard Hallet has put he-men on paper--and he-men's women. Hair on chest as thick as a buffalo robe, more tattooing than paintings in the Louvre, his characters have sailed the seven seas, practiced the seven sins and have butrun the four horsemen of the Apocalypse.
Pressure to break down President Roosevelt's plan to bring many additional officeholders under merit rule will be resisted by the Civil Service Commission.

James J. Finnegan of 34-04 Broadway, Long Island City, Queens, said by his sister, Mrs. Maude Byrnes, to have been a chauffeur for eight years for members of the family of the late Thomas Fortune Ryan, was found dead yesterday morning on the roof of 42 West Sixty-first Street.
A huge and significant oil "slick" found on the ocean surface left searchers with scant hope today of finding the missing Hawaii Clipper. But the forlorn hunt continued.

Under the urge of increasing property values notable institutions of New York City move northward and even pass into suburban areas. Flashes of real estate news published in the last few days reveal this trend and illumine many a page of the colorful past of the metropolis.

The charge of defaulting a $4.50 bill, which caused the arrest of Mrs. Ray Reder of 301 Sterling Place, Brooklyn, at 1 A. M. on Thursday and the imposition of $500 bail at a cost to her of $10 more than she owed, will be dropped, it was announced tonight by Herman Zambrovsky, office manager of the Belmore Hotel here.

Pay increases for WPA administrative or supervisory employes will be granted he ??ter only with the approval of Harry L. Hopkins, National Administrator. No new jobs paying more than $2,600 a year may be created without his approval.

Thingumabob, rated as the fastest 2-year-old in the East, galloped to an impressive victory in the rich Arlington Futurity today, leaving nine other 2-year-olds trailing in his dust. The colt won by five lengths, while 25,000 spectators, who made him the favorite, cheered.

Playing the first match of their tour against a picked team representing the New York and Metropolitan District Association, the Canadian cricketers - from Toronto, Montreal and Hamilton won by 121 runs at Innisfail Park yesterday.
Dr. and Mrs. Eldon Leon Loblein of New Brunswick and Wave Crest, Bay Head, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss ??net Loblein, to John Van Rycken Williamson.
Vulgar and obscene magazines were denounced by the national board of directors of the Catholic Daughters of America at its semiannual meeting in the Hotel Traymore today.

Five hundred small steel companies have been asked by the Public Contracts Board to present data on prevailing wage rates, a request construed in some quarters to mean that the board may be considering demands of the small steel concerns for a wage differential on government contract work.

As many types of plant disease, especially those of fungous character, are carried in a dormant state upon the seeds themselves, many gardeners now pretreat seeds to afford added protection. This practwice destroys germ spores that may be lurking on the seed surfaces.
The climax of West Virginia's Congressional primary election comes Tuesday with ten Democrats and nine Republicans seeking the six nominations of their parties.

After a week's consideration of Secretary of State Cordell Hull's note to Mexico, President Lazaro Cardenas has made clear that he does not accept the basic principle set forth that full indemnity payment must be made at the moment of expropriation of any private foreign property according to established international usage.

The Board of Foreign Missions of the United Lutheran Church in America is out of debt today for the first time since it was organized twenty years ago, according to the Rev. Dr. Samuel Trexler, former president of the United Lutheran Synod of New York, who has just returned from a quarterly meeting of the board in Baltimore.
The Department of Commerce, which is probably the world's most up-to-date encyclopedia of current business information, is going to have a master index to make its data more accessible to the public.

Neither General Duval of the French Army nor Major Otto Welsch of the German finds much to praise in the performances of the aviators on either side in the Spanish civil war. The one officer expresses his views in a finely analytical book--"Les Lecons de la Guerre d'Espagne"--and the other in a critical article published in "Wissen und Wehr."

Detailed discussions of the part the student should play in the political life of his country will be a part of the program this week of the conference of the International Student Service at Les Avants sur Montreaux, Switzerland.
ALONG the shores of the Eastern Mediterranean, on the sands of IArabia and along the Nile, a new and challenging factor is arising in world affairs--the nationalism of the Near Eastern peoples.

SINCE teaching by radio is by its very nature a one-way process, it is an open question how much real education can be achieved when the flow of human relationships is all in one direction, Professor Henry Pratt Fairchild of the Sociology Department of New York University Graduate

The volume of real estate sales in the country for the three months of March, April and May shows an advance over each preceding month, according to the index prepared for the National Association of Real Estate Boards from reports by representatives in many metropolitan areas.

With Parliament out of the way until November, Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain today felt freer to push ahead with his double policy of trying to avert war and at the same time preparing Britain for it.

Accused of passing large quantities of counterfeit $5 and $10 bills in the Times Square area with the aid of passersby recruited chiefly in Forty-second Street, eight men and three women were arrested last night by Federal agents and detectives of the West Sixty-eighth Street police station.

Ownership of real property, particularly private homes, is a strong buffer against rising rents, high building costs and other characteristics of inflation, says W. R. Gibson, president of the Gibson Corportion, developers of Gibson, near Valley Stream, L. I., where, he states, more than 1,800 homes have been sold.

Frank L. Morris, former superintendent of the State Department of Standards and Purchase, died at his farm home near here today after a heart attack. He was 67 years old. Mr. Morris had been. Wyoming County Democratic Chairman for twenty years.

Sentiment with respect to the stock market was cautious last week and share prices averaged lower, but not until the index had touched a new high level for the year. When the market takes a rest period after a sustained advance it is natural to place the burden of proof for the immediate future on the bulls. And that is just about the situation at present.

Alfred Salmaggi and his New York Hippodrome Opera Company, including elephants, camels and living "props," invaded Randalls Island last night for a season of week-end operatic productions at popular prices. Before an audience of 5,000 persons, it started the schedule with Verdi's "Aida," with some startling innovations.

The first "good-will tour" of the Ten Mile River Trail, circling the 12,000-acre reservation of the Ten Mile River Boy Scout camps in Sullivan County, N. Y., was completed yesterday. Each of the seventy-eight scouts selected for the trip hiked more than forty miles and cooked ten outdoor meals during the five-day trek.

Sitting alone in the High Court, Sir Wilfrid Lewis, judge of the King's Bench Division, today concluded the twenty-four-day hearing of a lawsuit brought by Carl Frederik Glad of Copenhagen, Denmark, against two American financiers, William Rhodes Davis, negotiator of Mexican oil sales, and Henry, Warren Wilson. He reserved judgment, which will not be delivered until October.

The first year of operation of cooperative fraternity business management at Amherst College showed a net financial improvement for the thirteen fraternities of $12,000, after a deduction of $5,000, the cost of management.
A variation of the Christmas Club saving idea has been devised in connection with the World's Fair, it has become known through a report to Grover A. Whalen, president of the fair corporation.
Edison Hedges, New Jersey legislator from Atlantic City, established a world speedboat record today, piloting his Flying Eagle over the Chester River course at 42.714 miles per hour.

Father Bernard Hubbard, Alaska's "glacier priest," sailed 700 miles in a primitive forty-foot skin canoe through Bering Sea and the Arctic Ocean without encountering a single iceberg. But, Father Hubbard says, he and his party of eight men encountered such stormy weather on their twenty-day voyage that they never would have survived if they had had a more modern craft.

THERE has always been a youth problem since Cain slew Abel. At least, the problem existed in the minds of the older generation. The elders never have been, and probably never will be, able to bridge the gulf which time channeled between them and their offspring.

ROME--A great necropolis, which is supposed to contain the bodies of the 70,000 Carthaginians and Romans who fell at Cannae in 216 B. C., has been discovered in the zone where the great battle is said to have taken place, less than a mile from the right bank of the Ofanto River in the Apulia region.

As citizens of this State approached the end of a strenuous primary campaign tonight, Governor Stark stood accused by his predecessor, former Governor Park, of seeking to control the judiciary in a manner never contemplated by the framers of the Constitution.

Plans for a new teacher training program which will result in a year of experience with pay in the public schools of Long Island for students working toward a master's degree in education, are outlined in a letter sent last week to boards of education, superintendents of schools, supervising principals and college officials in the metropolitan area.

Plans recently filed here for new construction indicate a revival of building activity for the present year, the greater part being for medium-priced houses. Plans have been filed by the Walter Johnson Jr., Homes Co., for seven single family dwellings in the Brookdale section to cost $28,000,

The Yankees and White Sox rained blows upon each other with great fervor today, but, fortunately for the Yanks, the Sox do not do other things as well as they can clout a ball. As a consequence, Marse Joe McCarthy's champions stalked off with their second straight victory of the series, 9 to 6, while a tortured crowd of 7,000 was all for shooting the Sox on the spot.

Changes in the faculties of the various divisions of Rutgers University were announced today by Dr. Robert C. Clothier, president. There are nineteen appointments, most of them as instructors, five promotions and two resignations at Rutgers, the New Jersey College for Women and the College of Agriculture.

Miss Mary Margaret Stack was married yesterday morning in the Church of the Good Shepherd Brooklyn, to Charles Henry Phelan, The Right Rev. William T. Dillon dean of St. Joseph's College for Women, officiated. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and. Mrs. William J. Stack of Brooklyn. She is a graduate of St. Joseph's.

Miss Dorothy Mary von Lengerke, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carl von Lengerke of this city, and John garris Sloan of West Orange were married this afternoon in St. Andrew's Episcopal Church, South Orange. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. F. Randall Williams.

The marriage of Miss Margaret Louise Weeks, only daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward R. Weeks of the Red Spring Colony here, to Edwin Francis Hendrickson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Francis Hendrickson of Bridgehampton and New York, took place this afternoon at the home of the bride's parents.
Governor Earle came to the Capitol just before dawn today to sign the bills which his Democratic forces had finally rushed through a special session of the Pennsylvania Legislature on his call.

ECUADOR has issued a series of four coins in pure nickel for the first time. The denominations are the 1 sucre and the 20, 10 and 5 centavos. All coins bear the date 1937 and were struck by a private minting concern in Switzerland.

With President Roosevelt and many of his Cabinet and other aides on vacation, government employes in Washington are also enjoying or planning vacations. Under the Executive order signed two years ago, permanent employes are entitled to twenty-six days' annual leave.

Siding is often used for the exterior of a frame house. The dwelling, it is stated, will prove more satisfactory over the course of years if in applying the siding it is placed over sheathing. In some sections where climatic conditions warrant the omission of sheathing the siding can be applied directly to well-braced framing timbers.

Kansans will vote Tuesday in a peculiar Republican primary which some describe as a "test of tolerance" and others regard as simply an elimination to choose the party's strongest warriors against the New Deal.
Henry Bishop of Mount Vernon, N. Y., died today of a heart attack on a train on his way from Berlin to Copenhagen. He was accompanied by his wife and child.
WELLINGTON, New Zealand--With a view to establishing democratic equality in the government. New Zealand has instituted a novel system of paying the salaries of its legislators and officials.

Significant of the service that can be given to a community's needs in nature recreation by a natural history museum is the recreational program started this Summer by the Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia for the metropolitan area of that city.

NEW YORK became passingly aware of a once-romantic minority when fifty gypsies recently kept vigil while the "candle of the last breath" burned for one of their stricken youth. When death brought the traditional "black party" mass prayer, to be followed by "the feast of the forty-two candles," there was significance in the fact that mourners had to beg for funeral expenses. For evil times have fallen upon the gypsies.

The engagement of Miss Betty Carpenter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward N. Carpenter of Boston and Swampscott, Mass., to Lawrence F. Percival Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence F. Percival of Boston and Marblehead, Mass., has been announced by her parents.

The Cathedral of the Incarnation was the scene of the marriage here this afternoon of Miss Mary Elizabeth Hay, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Hay of Garden City, to Donald Clarence Voorhis of Rockville Center, L. I. The Rev. Frederic Bush officiated.

Curly-headed Johnny Revolta and broadshouldered Lawson Little battled to a draw at the half-way point in St. Paul's $7,500 golf championship today. Each had a thirty-six-hole total of 137 to lead a field of sixty-six qualifiers into tomorrow's final grind of thirty-six holes and a chance at first prize of $1,600. Revolta,

The attempted assassination of Major Gen. Blanton Winship, Governor of Puerto Rico, during a parade at Ponce celebrating the fortieth anniversary of the landing of United States troops has served, more than any other incident in recent years, to focus attention on political conditions in the islands.
New York State, completing its first month under a new law requiring blood tests of all persons contemplating matrimony, took tock today of a sharp decline in marriage license applications.

MOTOR manufacturers, with a few exceptions, are not bragging about their 1938 volume. What is the underlying reason? Nobody denies that business generally, and the automobile business particularly, went into a tailspin during the last quarter of last year.

Rear Admiral George Ramsey Clark, U. S. N., retired, of Washington, D. C., and Mrs. Clark are at the Commodore. Mrs. Vivian Spencer has left the Plaza for Montreal. Mr. and Mrs. Rees Townsend Scully of Pittsburgh are at the Biltmore.
Thomas H. B. Jacobs, mining and railroad engineer and former president of the Pennsylvania Joint Stockland Bank here, died yesterday at his home in Glenloch, near West Chester. His age was 74.

Dr. Harlan H. Horner, has resigned as acting assistant commissioner for higher and professional education after thirty-five years service in the State service. The resignation takes effect Nov. 1. When the late Dr. Andrew S. Draper came to Albany as head of the unified State Education Department he brought Dr. Horner with him. He had been secretary to Dr. Draper in the University of Illinois, and served for some time in that capacity in Albany.

Early reports reaching the United States after the German Army's invasion of Austria that the army's mechanized and motorized equipment was distinctly inferior and that tanks and trucks were subject to a high percentage of breakdowns are not borne out by later and more complete reports, in the opinion of military men here.

The American Federation of Labor is likely to file charges of unfair labor practices against employers if they obey orders of the National Labor Relations Board to bargain with rival C. I. O. unions, Joseph A. Padway, counsel for the A. F. of L., said today.

The eviction of a Quebec City Communist and his family from his house, Its padlocking and the subsequent arrest of its owner when he broke the padlock have brought Quebec Province's famous padlock law into renewed prominence this week.

The following story of the successful ascent, on July 21, of Mount Sanford, Alaska, described as the highest peak hitherto unclimbed on the North American Continent, was written for The Associated Press by Bradford Washburn, leader of an Alaskan expedition sponsored by the Institute of Geographical Exploration of Harvard University. Mr. Washburn also carried the flag of the National Jeographic Society.

Bookkeepers at a municipally owned and operated electric power plant prepared the July bills to consumers today and marked each one "paid in full." The Municipal Board, which manages the plant, declared a dividend, amounting to a month's free current to each of the 2,232 consumers.

Residential building in New York State continues to lead the nation in point of volume and value, reports C. J. Ryan, vice president in charge of the mortgage loan division of Investors Syndicate, Minneapolis.
Fulvio de Suvich, Italian Ambassador to the United States, sailed yesterday for Trieste on the Italian motor ship Vulcania on his annual leave of absence.

With a bank holiday in England and virtual absence here of either hedging or liquidating pressure, prices on the Cotton Exchange gained 5 to 7 points yesterday under week-end covering and mill purchasing. Following Friday's decline to low figures of the week, the rally left October cotton at 8.62 cents a pound, compared with 8.82 cents on the previous Saturday.

AT Huntington, L. I., a small newspaper, The Long-Islander, has recently celebrated its centennial. It carries proudly at its masthead a picture of "the good gray poet," with 1838 on one side and 1938 on the other and below it the legend, "Founded by Walt Whitman."

Although today is officially the last day for the filing of social security tax returns under Title VIII, the deadline has been extended to midnight tomorrow because the date falls on a Sunday, James J. Hoey, Collector of Internal Revenue, announced yesterday.
The last-place Phillies knocked Dizzy Dean out of the box in the fifth inning today and then went on to score their second straight victory over the Chicago Cubs by a 5-to-4 score.

William Williams, 37 years old, of 136 Arlington Avenue, Port Richmond, S. I., was held yesterday by Magistrate Alfred M. Lindau in Felony Court without bail for a hearing tomorrow on a charge of felonious assault.

A document that will have a most important bearing on the future development of Balkan politics is about to be signed by the signatories of the Balkan Entente (Greece, Rumania, Turkey and Yugoslavia) and Bulgaria,

Evidence that the property improvement credit plan, restored under the National Housing Act amendments early in February this year, is proving successful, was indicated yesterday by Stewart McDonald, Federal Housing Administrator.

If there appears to be a lull In dog-show activities just now it is only on the surface. There is a customary respite in July, but behind the scenes there is plenty of activity in preparation for the show season, which will be resumed in New England next month and swing into the metropolitan area in September.

The National Labor Relations Board announced today that the Ford Motor Company was served this morning with an examiner's report that it was guilty of labor spying and other anti-union activity at its Buffalo plant.

A new book on condemnation appraising by George L. Schmutz, Los Angeles valuation engineer, has been published by Prentice-Hall, Inc. Its title is "Condemnation Appraiser's Handbook" and it is said to enter territory never before covered in a systematic discussion of fundamental principles of real estate valuation.
Formation of a new School of Applied Social Sciences, a graduate division and election of a dean for the school were announced yesterday by the University of Pittsburgh.

Various viewpoints on public problems will be presented next week by speakers at the Summer conference of the Republican Program Committee, of which Glenn Frank is chairman. Most of the meetings will be in Thorne Hall on the Chicago campus of Northwestern University.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Hugo H. Kempf of East Orange of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Virginia Kempf, to C. Donald Price, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Price, also of East Orange.

Reporting a registration of 5,000 buyers for the two weeks in which the Fall furniture market has been under way here, officials of the New York Furniture Exchange yesterday said the showing which closed yesterday was one of the most successful held in the last half-century. Attendance at the July show last year was 4,674.

Dalhousie University, first undenominational university in the British Empire, will celebrate a centennial of teaching, at ceremonies to be held here from Aug. 16 to Aug. 18. Canadian leaders and scholars, lawyers, doctors and scientists from all parts of the word will gather here for the ceremonies.
The first comment on the note Cordell Hull, Secretary of State, sent to Mexico calling for arbitration of Mexican land expropriations, appeared in the newspaper Telegrafo today.

Consumers in this country have begun to worry less about how to pay coal, gas, oil and electricity bills, and are giving more attention to getting the most for their money, Allen P. Ames of Ames Norr, Inc., business promotion counsel, asserted yesterday.

Representative Clare E. Hoffman, Republican, who represents six southwestern Michigan counties in Congress, today challenged the National Labor Relations Board to a court test of its power to suppress free speech or interfere with a free press in violation of the first amendment to the Constitution.

A majority of the twenty-three recommendations sponsored by the Small Business Association have been achieved in the six months which have elapsed since the small business conference was called by Secretary Roper, according to Henry Modell, an executive of the Small Business Association.

The engagement and forthcoming marriage of Miss Hope Haney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis H. Haney of this place and Maplewood, N. J., to William H. West Jr. has been announced by her parents, at whose Summer home here the wedding will take place later in the season.

A GREAT many songs have been born and died, a good deal of swing has swung through the years in a long musical cavalcade since Irving Berlin wrote "Alexander's Ragtime Band" back in 1911, but the man who wrote that memorable tune has never allowed time and changing tastes to usurp his place in the front row of Tin Pan-America.

Dr. and Mrs. Arthur F. Chace of New York gave a buffet supper tonight at their Pine Point Lodge on the Upper St. Regis Lake for their son and daughter-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. J. Fletcher Chace, who were married recently.

Billy McGehee of New Orleans, Southern junior champion,won the Northern New Jersey tennis title today, defeating Eddie DeGray of Brooklyn in the final, 6-1, 6-3, 6-1. The match was played a day earlier than scheduled to allow McGehee to leave for the -national junior championships at Culver, Ind.

PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT is scheduled to broadcast from Canada twice on Aug. 18. The first program will originate at' Queens University, Kingston, Ont., where Mr. Roosevelt will receive in honorary degree.

The Kentucky Democratic Senatorial primary entered the home stretch with a new burst of spirit today as Governor Chandler, after a ten days' illness, said by his physicians to be due to drinking poisoned water, returned to the attack upon Senator Alben W. Barkley.

Harry Lundeberg, chief of the Sailors Union of the Pacific, threatened today to call a strike over the Maritime Commission's new plan of employing seamen on governmentcontrolled vessels. Lundeberg and Frank Barry, Atlantic Coast agent of the union, protested the plan to Emory S. Land, commission chairman, and other officials.

VIENNA'S short-wave station, which in the middle days of March was taken over by the German Reich and later disappeared for a time from the wave lengths, was picked up one evening recently as Nazi tunes interspersed with waltzes sped down the 11.79 megacycle lane from the former Austrian capital.

To provide additional stores for the rapidly growing communities in Forest Hills, L. I., the block front on the south side of Queens Boulevard between Seventy-sixth Road and Seventy-sixth Drive has been purchased by the Mar Gold Construction Corporation of Brooklyn, from the Cord Meyer Development Company.

An all-Russian program given by the Philharmonic-Symphony under the direction of Willem Van Hoogstraten attracted a large audience to Lewisohn Stadium last night. The program consisted of the overture to Glinka's "Russian and Ludmilla," the Fifth symphony of Tchaikovsky and the Scheherazade of Rimsky-Korsakoff-all music of great popular appeal.

The ninety-four insured savings and loan associations in New York State reported new high records for the first six months of 1938, it was announced today by Nugent Fallon, general manager of the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation.
EVER since the last expatriates lost the Old Deal dollar and went home, Kay Boyle has been our last real tie with the Hitler-darkened Europe that was once the last resort of a literary patriot.
While German military preparations on the Czech frontier and along the Rhine continue undiminished, and informed observers still fear a stroke that might lead to another European war,

PERIODICALLY, it. seems, the question, Have we an American art? is bound to be raised, provoked now by one thing, now by another. The current incentive to look into an always more or less baffling issue is provided by European estimates of work by some of our artists, published in French .and British papers.

The news from Harlem, capital of the $100,000,000 policy racket, is that there is a little boom in business just now. This balances with the news from downtown, where District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey's office is situated, the way night balances with day.
With the 1940 nominating conventions already on the distant political horizon, the inner circle of the New Deal has yet to produce a strong candidate to succeed President Roosevelt.

According to Mr. Gilbert H. Burck, writing in Scribner's, the Pennsylvania Special on June 12, 1905, made 127.2 miles an hour for three miles near Elida, Ohio. So The London Observer must be wrong when it hails the 125 miles an hour recently made fdr 306 yards by a London and North Eastern Railway train as the world's record for trains.

Plans have been completed for the wedding of Miss Ruth Charlotte Wiss, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Robert Wiss of South Orange, to Waldron M. Ward Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Ward of Summit. The ceremony will take place on the evening of Sept. 19 in Calvary Episcopal Church, Summit, with the rector, the Rev. Walter O. Kinsolving, officiating.
The first appreciable covering of Fall requirements by rural retailers was reported by wholesalers who were in the New York market last week.
The Soviet Union is now facing a situation similar to the so-called "scissors crisis" of the Autumn of 1923, which got its name from combined graphs of rising goods prices and falling food prices.
Thomas J. O'Reilly announces that Thomas C. Martin, who has been engaged for several years in the Connecticut real estate market, has rejoined the O'Reilly organization at 51 Chambers Street office.
A hurried evacuation of Nanchang, the capital of Kiangsi Province, began today. Chinese military leaders hinted they might burn the city before abandoning it to the Japanese.

Nanking, which suffered so atrociously from burning, looting and rapine after the Japanese captured the city, is now being afflicted with peddlers of narcotics who work openly under the protection of the Japanese Army, according to confidential reports sent here by foreigners still living in the former capital.
For the first time since the cosmic ray was discovered twenty years ago, scientists were able today to take a ray meter five miles into the air and watch it record the mysterious impulses.

The WPA's first excursion into large scale buying of consumer goods for the needy, which will be completed this week with the purchase of approximately $9,600,000 worth of men's clothing, has completely revitalized an industry which was among the first to suffer from the depression last year, clothing manufacturers and labor executives agreed yesterday.

A contamination, the source and nature of which had not been determined tonight, has taken the lives of several hundred fish in the Hackensack River below here in the last twenty-four hours and caused considerable anxiety among those who bathe in the river and drink its waters.

Japan has reached the point where the length of a match stick and the skin of a rat represent important economic factors in continuing the war with China. So do toothpaste and tinfoil, toy balloons and chocolate bars,

Allocations totaling $21,750.000 to finance its student-aid program were announced today by the National Youth Administration for the present fiscal year. New York City receives $1,299,696 and the balance of the State $915,049. New Jersey gets $484,653 and Connecticut $188,504.

Trading in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange in July was the largest in any month since last October and the heaviest in any corresponding month since 1933. On July 19 sales totaled 2,942,210 shares, the largest turnover since Oct. 21.
The mill towns of Lancashire, where much of the world's cotton is spun, have own method of taking their Summer holidays. Other people go to the seaside by families, but Lancashire goes by towns.

Mr. and Mrs. John C. Crowley of Bayside, Queens, have announced the engagement and approaching marriage of Mrs. Crowley's daughter, Miss Eileen Ferris Clare-Patton, to Donald Ross Hamilton, son of Mrs. Rollo A. Hamilton of Flushing and the late Rev. Mr. Hamilton. The wedding will take place on Aug. 20 in Bayside.

BERKIN--TANENBAUM--Mr. and Mrs. Barnett Tanenbaum of 1,094 Park Place, Brooklyn, announce the engagement of their daughter, Sylvia, to Mr. Ned S. Berkin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Berkin of 500 Eastern,Parkway, Brooklyn, N. Y.
SWING VS. SUAVITY: Dancing teachers, in New York last week for an annual convention, dismissed swing music and its accompanying dance steps as a reflection of present economic uncertainties.

Three tenants of the sixth floor at 566 West 159th Street were imprisoned from 10 to 11 P. M. last night in a self-service elevator in the building when the machine, outof-order, descended to the basement as they were attempting to reach their homes.

The Red Cross international committee announced here today that in the first two years of the Spanish civil war it had transmitted nearly 2,500,000 messages between members of families divided by the war.

Store and basement space aggregating 20,000 square feet in the building at 200 Madison Avenue has been subleased from Marshall Field Co. by A. Stein Co., garter, suspender and girdle manufacturers. The lessee formerly was located in the PenneyBuilding, 330West Thirty-fourth Street.
