Horace Conover's mare Lela Hanover easily took all three heats of the Class A trot, feature of the harness racing program at Borough Park today. Joe Scalera's mare Vololee annexed the first two heats of the Class B trot, but lost the third to Herbert Mobus's Linda Guy.
WASHINGTON.--One of the planks in the platform of W. Lee O'Daniel, Democratic nominee for Governor of Texas, is "More smokestacks and business men and less politics and Johnson grass."

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated July 28: CAPTAIN Ogan, J. V., 12th Naval District, to Aslatic Station. COMMANDER Hale, J. I., Norfolk Navy Yard, to Navy Yard, Portsmouth, N. H.

LAKE PLACID-Weeks of training under famous exponents of the figure-skating art have gone into the preparations for the annual midsummer figureskating operetta to be held on the ice sheet of the Olympic arena here on Thursday, Friday and Saturday as the crowning feature of the Lake Placid midsummer ice-skating season.

Reid Hall, center for American college women in Paris, has been honored with the Prix de la Bonne Volonte Franco-Americaine. The award is given to. commemorate the work in France of the American Good Will Committee, headed by Miss Anne Morgan.

CONTINUING a vigorous Summer program, the Art Association of Newport will open three shows simultaneously on Friday. In the association's main gallery are to be shown representative works by fifty artists, selected and arranged by the Walker Gallery of New York, including oils, water-colors and drawings,. many of them from private collections and some of them shown for the first time in this country.
PHOTOGRAPHERS engrossed by the many lighting problems of indoor and outdoor portraiture are welcoming a new multipurpose reflector screen that has just reached the market.

Football practice at Boston College will get under way on Sept. 1, according to a recent announcement by John P. Curley, graduate manager of athletics. Along with the announcement of the start of practice, Curley also made known the names of the five men who will assist Head Coach Gil Dobie in his third campaign.

Golfing form ran true throughout the New England amateur championship which ended today at the Country Club with Wilfred Crossley of Norfolk defeating Mel Merritt of Salem, 7 and 5, in the first all-Massachusetts final since 1931. Such a finish also had occurred at the Country Club seven years ago, when Joe Batchelder of Salem defeated Jimmy Dolan of Worcester.

In an old office building at 63 Vesey Street 3,600 WPA white-collar workers are busily engaged on the largest indexing job ever attempted in the history of the world. They are transferring the entire 1920 population census of the United States from musty old volumes to the last word in alphabetical cardindex systems.

Ever since Leon H. Adams, Burlington Township tenant farmer, received Tuesday a $5,050 Federal loan with which to buy a farm the Farm Security Administration office here has been besieged with all sorts of bids for "a quiet little place in the country." Adams was the first farmer in the Northeastern States to receive an FSA tenant-purchase loan.
The old Weed property at the corner. of High Ridge Road and Trinity Pass, Stamford, Conn., has been purchased by a client of Butler Baldwin, Inc., and Talbot J. Taylor Jr., co-brokers in the deal.

Charles Hilton, president of Browning, King Co. of this city, has leased the fifty-one acre farm at Eatontown, N. J., owned by the late Adam H. Groel. The residence is of the early Colonial type and is one of the oldest dwellings in Monmouth County, having been t erected in 1768.

Addition of a substantial mortgage lending business to a commercial bank's normal activities need not involve great difficulties, marked readjustments or undue expense, according to Robert V. Fleming, president and chairman of the board of the Riggs National Bank, Washington.
SIR JAMES DWYER, ambassador extraordinary and minister plenipotentiary to West Forty-fourth Street, runs a swell joint. It is called the Sawdust
Two champions retained their titles and new individual and relay champions were crowned today in the national A. A. U. men's swimming meett.
James C. Hawthorne, 38 years old, a carpenter of 219 South Cecil Street, Philadelphia, was drowned this afternoon in the Thorofare behind Longport, near here, as he rescued his young son.

The marriage of Miss Virginia Raeburn, who for some years has lived with her godparents, Mr. and Mrs. Frederie W. Rhinelander, to George Washington McKenzie Jr. of Brooklyn, son of Mrs. McKenzie and the late Mr. McKenzie, took place here in Kay Chapel, Trinity Church, today. The Rev. James Green, assistant rector, performed the ceremony.

The National Christian Council of China-has appealed through the Foreign Missions Conference of North America for six American physicians for war service in China. The council also seeks four British and two Canadian doctors.

PRESENTING living people on the screen, the cinema has found, is pretty dangerous business. Metro still shudders at the recollection of "Rasputin and the Empress," for which the studio neglected to get releases from the people involved before the film was made and consequently paid large damages ordered by the British courts.

To the Drama Editor: I am disturbed by "Shadow and Substance," which I saw last night; more accurately, by the degree it failed in living up to the evaluation you and your colleagues have placed upon it. * * *

Midsummer lethargy held the bond market yesterday, the trading pace being the slowest in six weeks, or since the impressive upswing in security prices began. Values, with the exception of a few speculative groups, held within a narrow trading range, the respective group price averages varying only slightly from the previous day's finals.

Jersey City and Toronto divided double-header today, the Little Giants winning the first game, 9 to 4, with Toronto taking the second, 6-2. The Jerseys reached a quartet of Toronto twirlers for a total of fifteen hits in the opener. blasting Earl Caldwell, who started, out of the box in the first inning.

Troop trains were ordered today to transport approximately 1,200 National Guardsmen to Memphis for duty at Thursday's Democratic primary, in which Governor Browning and E. H. Crump, national committeeman, are commanding opposing forces arrayed for a finish fight over supremacy in Tennessee.

An allweather four-lane toll "super-highway," running 162 miles between Harrisburg and Pittsburgh, will be financed jointly by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and the Public Works Administration at a cost of $58,000,000, it was said today by Administrator Ickes of the PWA.

Frederick L. Allen, vice president and general counsel of the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York, died today while returning to his camp at Lake Titus from a motor trip to Saranac Inn. His age was 74.

Among the passengers who arrived yesterday from Europe on the steamship President Harding of the United States Lines was Miss Frances Allen, an American citizen of Jewish descent, who operated one of the largest petit point shops in Vienna. She said that she had been forced to liquidate her stock, worth about $20,000, and "obtained practically nothing for it."

With Lefty Bob Weiland, the Bees' nemesis, pitching nine-hit ball, the Cardinals trounced Boston Club, 8 to 2, today, evening the four-game series at one each. While Weiland was striking out eight batters and aiding his own cause by making three hits himself, the Redbirds landed on Jim Turner for thirteen safeties,

Miss Eleanor De Witt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Doddridge De Witt of Glen Gardner, was married to Joshua Allan Rich 4th, New York broker and son of Mrs. May Anna Rich of New York, tonight in the Lower Valley Presbyterian Church at Califon. The Rev. Waldo Kihistrom, pastor of the church, performed the ceremony.

Aptitude tests recently given to more than 700 prospective college students by the American Schools Association, 30 Rockefeller Plaza, reveal that girls far surpass boys in the correlation of the desire for a specific career and the ability to fit smoothly into a chosen vocation.

There was no evident decrease In Dodger hospitality toward visiting clubs at Ebbets Field yesterday as the Grimes boys dropped their second straight to the league-leading Pirates, 9--2, making three official errors and several other sad moves in the process.

Kansas Republican leaders are approaching the eve of Tuesday's primaries greatly concerned over the possiability that Dr. Gerald B. Winrod, who has been termed the "Kansas Nazi," might win the party's nomnation for Senator.

It is too early, presumably, to say whether the Republican party is dead or only sleepeth, and certain recent developments have not tended to clarify the matter to any extent. It is of considerable interest, certainly, that in all the hurly-burly about primary elections very little has been said about Republican primaries, and the impression has got abroad that perhaps they were unimportant.
NEW COUNTRY, NEW TITLE: A native of Vienna, who since 1920 had been Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary in London of a
The Laura M. Bennett farm on Towners Road, Carmel, Putnam County, N. Y., has been purchased by Joseph Leonard of Long Island, reports Herbert J. Gebing, Carmel broker.
The Henry Hudson Parkway Authority announced that the twelve millionth automobile passed over the Henry Hudson Bridge spanning the Harlem River at 11:30 o'clock yesterday morning.

Contract provisions accepted as standard by the American Institute of Architects are embodied in the agreement for architectural services on housing projects prepared by the United States Housing Authority, points out William Stanley Parker, vice chairman of the institute's committee on housing.

TRENTON. SURVEY of the first six months of official inspection of motor vehicles in New Jersey indicates that the Motor Vehicle Inspection Division of the State Department of Motor Vehicles may become one of the department's most useful branches.

The troubles that attend picketing and secondary picketing in the United States are much less numerous in Great Britain. In fact it might be said that the British labor movement, of the present day, is comparatively peaceful.

Last Thursday at their sixty-first annual meeting, held at Cleveland, the American Bar Association considered and approved what may be regarded as a forward-looking report of their standing committee on Federal taxation, of which Robert N. Miller of Washington, D. C., is the chairman.

THIS is the third volume of the "Rivers of America," the series edited by Constance Lindsay Skinner, which was initiated by Robert P. Tristram Coffin's "Kennebec" in June of last year, and followed by Walter Havighurst's "Upper Mississippi" in December.

This department is designed to assist in the location of cornplete versions of poems and their sources, the names of authors, etc., which cannot be found through the usual channels of anthologies and books of reference. THE TIMES receives a great many more queries than it can publish. It endeavors, therefore, to select those of the greatest general interest. Queries should be addressed to the Editor of Queries and Answers, NEW YORK TIMES.

For the last decade one of the principal worries of the Japanese Government has been the possibility of the spread and triumph of communism in China. And now, by her one year of aggressive warfare against China, Japan has done more to spread and popularize communism in this country than the Chinese Communists were able to do in the previous ten years.

Joe Burk, the "robot sculler" from Philadelphia, and the big aggregation of oarsmen representing the Buffalo West Side Club made it almost a United States parade in the final events of the fifty-sixth Royal Canadian Henley Regatta today.

tedTurner, 31-year-old New Hampshire-born professional, today stuck a big feather in his golfing cap when he won the New Jersey State open crown over the watery fairways of the Braidburn Country Club, home course of Ralph Guldahl, national and Western open champion.

Political doldrums in Berlin and throughout the Reich-a period of waiting upon external developments while the golden grain of Germany's first great harvest in three years is safely garnered-that is the situation here as August comes in amid perfect sunshine from cloudless skies.

In the count of friends and foes as the Kentucky campaign between Governor Albert B. Chandler and Senator Alben W. Barkley for Senator Barkley's seat draws to a close, it is noted by observers here that more organizations, political and non-political, have to date sided with the Senator.

MONTREAL. CANADA, which became tourist conscious with the establishment of a Federal Travel Bureau at Ottawa three years ago, has now become tourist road conscious. She is building and has built many new highways to help the American motorist who visits Canada this Summer.

AMEO--If War Comes Tomorrow: Russian film*; Return to Life, Spanish war film, opens Wednesday. APITOL--Love Finds Andy Hardy: Mickey Rooney*; The Crowd Roars: Robert Taylor, opens Thursday. RITERION--Booloo: Colin Tapley, Jayne Regan. ITTLE CARNEGIE--South Riding: Edna Best, Ralph Richardson, opens tomorrow. MUSIC HALL--Algiers: Charles Boyer*; Mother Carey's Chickens; Ralph Morgan, Anne Shirley, opens Thursday.

The Frank Droesch realty firm of Jamaica reports the sale of the twelve family apartment house at 90 Ongley Street, Rockville Center, to Frederick Blanker of Howard Beach. The Droesch firm also sold the dwelling at 113-05 208th Street, Bellaire, for E. Barker to John Brady of Elmhurst;
Close-of-play scores in English first-class cricket started today follow:

Miss Ruth D. Bachelder, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert W. Bachelder of this town, was married to Evart M. Howland, son of Mrs. Evart M. Howland of Poughkeepsie, this afternoon in the Reformed Church here. The Rev. Martin A. De Wolfe, the pastor, officiated, assisted by the Rev. Rensel H. Colby of South Paris, Me., uncle of the bride.

Work upon the monumental Index of Christian Art, upon which the Department of Art and Archaeology of Princeton University has been laboring for two decades, has been accelerated by an anonymous gift of $100,000. Completion of the project is now expected in another ten years.

THE rumble of the tanks echoes throughout the world The mechanical monsters of the Japanese scuttle across the scorched earth of China; in Spain armored cars lumber through ruined towns. Germany's "Panzer" or armored divisions roar to mimic war; in the spiny peninsula of Italy the "celere" divisions--tanks, motor cycles, motorized artillery-practice the art of swift, implacable assault.
William Bankhead Lee, greatnephew of General Robert E. Lee, died today at his home at Widewater, Stafford County, after a long illness. His age was 36.

BRIDGEHAMPTON, L. I.--Hampton Playhouse, "Dracula." (No performance Wednesday evening.) CARMEL--Rockridge Theatre, "The Old Homestead." (Through Thursday.) CHAUTAUQUA--Repertory Theatre, "The Amazing Dr. Clitterhouse." (Thursday.)
NEAR the end of an introductory chapter which undertakes to explain briefly the implications and meanings of regionalism, the authors define a region as meaning, for their purpose,
Dr. J. R. Ebersole, first vice president and medical director of the Illinois Bankers Life Assurance Company, died at his home here last night at the age of 78.

GRANVIILE HICKS taught English at Smith College and was dismissed from an assistant professorship at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute. "Retrenchment," insisted the institute. "Because he's a Communist," charged Mr. Hicks's friends. This year he was engaged as a tutor at Harvard, but from the way some alumni and a few Boston politicians have been carrying on one might expect any morning to find that Mr. Hicks has set up a Soviet in New Lecture Hall,
There were twenty-two attendants at the marriage of Miss M. Le Moyne Noyes to A. Douglass Hall this afternoon in St. Bernard's Church here. The Rev. James P. Dargan performed the ceremony.
PARIS. THE visit of King George and Queen Elizabeth gave the luxury designers of Paris a splendid opportunity to exert themselves to the utmost.

Now that the quiet little battle scheduled to take place between Freeport and Brielle anglers has developed into a free-for-all tuna derby, clubs from Long Island to Cape May are trying to select four members to represent them.

One driving past the home of Mr. and Mrs. Leslie P. Dodge at Lake Mahopac, N. Y., might nod approvingly at the conservative planting in front of the house and yet be entirely unaware of the peaceful naturalistic garden at the rear.

In recent years it has been said that the British Empire was on its last legs, retreating before the onslaughts of militaristic powers. Germany on the Continent, Italy- in the Mediterranean and Africa, Japan in the Far East, all in turn or in concert flouted the interests of London with impunity.

Sustained buying activity in the wholesale markets here last week led to a moderate increase in production by apparel manufacturers, as favorable sentiment continued. Retail sales, however, continued to lag, according to an analysis of market trends prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., resident buyers. The report continues:
Steve Forsythe, swimming coach of Miami and New York, complained today that Bob Iiphuth, Yale coach, "seems to have a corner" on the A. A. U.'s selection of coaches to take aquatic teams abroad.

THREE would seem to be the right age for your ambitious and forward-looking tot to toddle into the movie studios and get started on a screen career. It's an early enough stage to correct one's initial mistakes, find out whether one's flair lies in stimulating the tear ducts or laughter of

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Albert B. Connelly of Wellesley Hills, Mass., formerly of Maplewood, N. J., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Clarice Connelly, to Van Holmgren Tanner, son of Dean Lydia H. Tanner of Weaver College, Ogden, Utah, and the late Dr. Joseph Marion Tanner, one-time president of the Utah Agricultural College at Logan, Utah.

BEGINNING on Tuesday night the center of the local dance scene will shift to the unfamiliar locale of East Twentyseventh Street, where, in the Davenport Theatre, a new African dancedrama called "Zungura," by Asadata Dafora, the author of "Kykunkor," will begin a run.

The Fourteenth Infantry of Brooklyn and the 165th Infantry of Manhattan, National Guard units forming the Ninety-third Brigade, ended a week of rifle practice and musketry drills at Camp Smith here today and made ready to march in review for Governor Lehman tomorrow before starting an extensive program of off-reservation manoeuvres.

Union printer baseball teams will gather in St. Louis Aug. 7 to 13 for the twenty-eighth annual tournament. Listed for the competition are Washington, Chicago, Cincinnati, Twin Cities, Baltimore, Boston, Pittsburgh, New York, Detroit, Indianapolis and St. Louis.
Suzanne Talbot's Winter millinery is colorful and varied. Felts are tucked, shirred and fluted. Trimmings consist of jewel-like flowers of silk or velvet combined with nacre;

On the anniversary of the partition of Teschen, Silesia, by the Council of Ambassadors on July 28, 1920, giving the major part of the city to Czechoslovakia, the Polish press recited its grievances against Prague.

THE announcement from Quito published in these columns last week that Ecuador will issue stamps to commemorate the South American country's participation in the New York World's Fair and the San Francisco Exposition next year is probably the first of a small deluge of similar announcements, in the opinion of philatelic observers.

The race meeting at Narragansett Park, Pawtucket, R. I., will get under way tomorrow with bright prospects despite a sharply revised program since the shake-up which recently took place in the organization. James E. Dooley, present head of the track, believes that more than a thousand horses will be on hand for the opening.

Thomas J. McGauley, attorney and Republican clerk of the judiciary committee of the Rhode Island Senate, announced tonight that Walter E. O'Hara, former managing director of the Narragansett race track, will enter the Rhode Island Gubernatorial race in November with a "square deal party" ticket.

The surprising coalition entered into last week by the American Labor party and the Republican organizations in Manhattan and Brooklyn was motivated by intensely practical considerations. Strategists on both sides see in it distinct advantage to their own causes.

Appetities grow jaded when the thermometer climbs and the air becomes heavy with moisture. They might be revived by some of the new delicacies in the food shops of the town's department stores. It is really astonishing how many new Foods are offered now.

IN case you haven't realized that the "Movies Are Your Best Entertainment," the motion picture industry is launching a $1,000,000 advertising and publicity campaign to convince you of the propriety of the slogan.

Pete Naktenis, 215-pound southpaw hurler, established a strike-out record for this season in the Eastern League by fanning fifteen Williamsport batters to pitch Albany to a 6-to-1 victory today. Allowing only five hits and walking three in the nine-inning contest, Naktenis fanned every player he faced at least once and in the second inning retired the side on strikes.

Contract for construction of a part of the Delaware Aqueduct in Westchester County, designed to augment the water supply of New em York City and cities and towns along the way, has been let to the Walsh Construction Company and associates by the New York Board of Water Supply, it was announced today at the offices of the company here.
The Democrats of Vice President Garner's home county in convention today endorsed him for the Presidency in 1940.

The officers of the 306th Infantry, part of New York City's contingent of the Organized Army Reserve, took over today the training of 2,020 young men, the Camp Dix regiment of the Citizens Military Training Corps.

The reasons banks and other lending institutions have not favored new dwelling loans under Title I of the National Housing Act were set forth yesterday by C. H. Minners, president of the Bankers Federal Savings and Loan Association, in reply to the recent criticism of the
HONOLULU. PEARLY dawn over grim Diamond Head; a lone, naked fisherman with his spear on a muddy shoal;
DURING the eleven years in which he was active In public school administration and local American Legion work, Dr. Gellermann tells us, his curiosity was aroused by the markedd difference"

Robert Daru, president of the New York County Criminal Courts Bar Association, announcing yesterday his approval of action taken by Frank J. Hogan, newly elected president of the American Bar Association, in creating a special committee on the defense of civil liberties, revealed that he had created a special committee to cooperate with the national committee.

Fifty-five warships went on parade today to prove to patriotic Britons that they are getting a lot of preparedness for their increased taxes. The Admiralty opened the gates of the three biggest dockyards at Portsmouth, Chatham and

Ruttenburg, the seat of one of the smallest Catholic Bishoprics in Germany, is in a state of great anxiety, awaiting further reprisals on Bishop Ludwig Sproll, who incurred Nazi displeasure by refusing to vote in the April plebiscite on Germany's absorption of Austria. The town, which is on the Neckar, south of Stuttgart, has a population of 9,000, 90 per cent Catholic.

THE death of Edgar H. Wells early this month marks the passing of a rare personality in the New York antiquarian book trade. For the past few years illness had compelled his retirement so that the management of his shop had to be carried on by other hands.

Miss Louise MacLean, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Donald Robert MacLean, was married to the Rev. Richard Irwin Porter, son of Mrs. William J. Coulter of Homestead, Pa., this afternoon in the First Presbyterian Church. Dr. James Gordon Hynes of Freeport, L. I., a classmate of the couple, officiated.
JUDGING by inquiries received, the first release from the recordings by Arturo Toscanini and the N. B. C. Orchestra turns what is usually the dullest record month of the year into the most important.
Dizzy Dean, not so chipper but undismayed by his failure to subdue the rejuvenated Phillies, said tonight his costly pitching arm "feels pretty good."
THE complete programs to be played by the New York Philbarmonic-Symphony Orchestra at the Silvermine Festival, Aug. 1821, in Silvermine, Conn., have just been announced.

Mr. and Mrs. Lewis H. Brown at a dinner last night at their home in Greenwich, Conn., announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Rosalind Brown, to Edward Townsend, son of Myron Townsend of Pelham, N. Y., and the late Mrs. Gertrude Barnard Townsend.

The following Foreign Service changes since July 22 were announced today by the State Department: Leland B. Morris of Philadelphia, Consul General at Alexandria, Egypt, assigned Consul General at Vienna. Donald C. Dunham of Cleveland, Vice Consul at Athens, assigned Vice Consul at Aden, Arabia.
BAR HARBOR, Me.--Six presentations at the Building of Arts will be features of the August social program here. The first will be tomorrow, a matinee appearance of Ted Shawn and his men dancers.

The Newark Bears increased their league lead to fourteen games today as they defeated the Buffalo Bisons in both portions of a doubleheader, 6-3 and 8-5. Joe Beggs, recently returned from the Yankees, made his 1938 debut for the Bears in the opener and allowed eleven hits but was effective with men on the bases. He made seven strikeouts, fanning the Bisons in order in the sixth with two aboard.

Clubhouse boxes were thronged today by members of society here for the races. Mrs. J. Averell Clark joined her father, Thomas Hitchcock; Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Butler of New York came from their Summer home at Cooperstown to be guests of Jerome Sayles Hess; Mr. and Mrs. Charles S. Bromley had as guests in their box Mr. and Mrs. John Blakely of Philadelphia.

A program of Argentine music will be heard around the world for the first time tomorrow afternoon when Andre Kostalanetz conducts the local radio orchestra. The bill will be broadcast over nation-wide hookups in Argentina, the United States and Canada.

WASHINGTON.--Federal department and bureau chiefs have begun one of their biggest tasks in yearsthat of scanning their respective personnel rosters to prepare reports to Congress on all aliens on their payrolls.

Miss Barbara Jean Graham, daughter of Mrs. David Graham of this city and the late Mr. Graham, was married here today at the home of Mrs. H. R. Dowswell to Alexander Lueke Junge, son of Mrs. Ernest H. Junge of Cleveland and Squirrel Island, Me. The Rev. Everett W. MacNair, associate pastor of the Ridgeview Congregational Church of this city, officiated.

A group of prominent women golfers discussed recently at the Quaker Ridge Golf Club the lack of interest among girls of the metropolitan district in golf tournaments generally and the junior metropolitan championship, which is scheduled at the Glen Ridge Country Club, Glen Ridge, N. J., Sept. 8, particularly.

The Eastern States Transportation Company, with main office in Philadelphia and branches in many cities in the East, has leased through David Cronheim, Newark broker, the garage at the southeast corner of Nye Avenue and Coit Street, Irvington, N. J., owned by the William L. Blanchard Company.

With the exception of a few counties in Texas, Oklahoma and Kansas the Dust Bowl is flourishing again, though wheat is selling around 60 cents instead of last year's dollar, and the prices for cotton and sorghum are low.

An evaluation of the Adolescent Court in Brooklyn, conducted as an experiment in scientific methods, has been made by Magistrate Jeanette G. Brill and E. George Payne, Professor of Education at New York University.

The action of Southern tobacco growers in going to court in rebillion against marketing quotas of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration is leading to speculation in this section as to what the grower of Winter wheat will do about the crop due to be seeded early this Fall.

Prosecuting attorneys from all parts of the country will study the latest developments in scientific crime detection and court technique at a week-long seminar beginning in Chicago tomorrow at the Northwestern University School of Law.

The Japanese beetle, now an "old story" in Southern New Jersey and around Philadelphia, is causing consternation this Summer in many gardens around New York where it is for the first time appearing in maximum numbers.

Carl Grimm, employed by the Newton Steel Company of Monroe, Mich., a Republic Steel Corporation subsidiary, told the Senate Civil Liberties Committee today that a company official had suggested just before the 1937 C. I. O. strike that an independent union be formed and recommended the name of a lawyer who addressed a meeting of employes and drew up the by-laws of the organization.

NORTH BEACH will be synonymous with New York in the minds of air travelers of Europe and America five years hence. The airport being built by the city between Bowery Bay and Flushing Bay has been accorded the support of domestic and foreign airlines to a degree without parallel.
Some of the newest and most efficlient fighting planes produced in this country are among the types being exported in quantity to foreign nations, it became known yesterday.

A recent survey of tax payments and earnings of forty properties in and around New York City by Burr Co., bankers of this city, reveals little likelihood of any marked building activity in the near future for large structures, although, it is stated, that the outlook for new apartment house construction seems brighter than for office and commercial buildings.

IThe Edgartown Yacht Club regatta ended today with a series of upsets. The regatta was the largest on record here. The favorites in the thirty-square meter and New York 32-foot classes failed to come through and perhaps the most spectacular race of the day was sailed by the old Seawanhaka schooner Daiquiri, owned by F. G. Crane.

Miss Kathryn Van Alstyne, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. C. Ward Van Alstyne of this city, was married to George Sterling Brady, son of Mr. and Mrs. George C. Brady of Darien, this afternoon in Grace Church, Norwalk. The Rev. Nelson Pearson officiated.

Announcement has been made by Allen Fletcher Johnson of this place, formerly of Lynehburg, Va., of the engagement of his daughter, Miss Susan Lanier Johnson, to James Alden Simpson, also of Greenville, formerly of Birmingham, Ala. The marriage will take place in the near future.

Mayor La Guardia disclosed yesterday that he had been rebuffed by Surrogate John Hetherington of Queens County on his request for a record of the qualifications of the man the Surrogate intended to appoint as successor to John Theofel, chief clerk of the Queens Surrogate Court.

Weather conditions returned nearly to normal yesterday with clear skies all day and a high temperature of 84 degrees, nine higher than the average for the date. The humidity was comparatively low, remaining under 50 per cent all afternoon.

The shocking treatment of the Jews in Germany and Austria and the wave of anti-Semitism which has been felt with varying force in other countries are among the most disturbing symptoms of the strange sickness that has come over the modern world.

Governor Earle, In deploying the Democratic legislative legions on Capitol Hill at Harrisburg this week to meet the "invasion" of the "Republican-dominated courts," set a precedent in this Commonwealth.

About 200 members of the younger set attended a midsummer dance, arranged by the Greenwich Cotillion at the Milbrook Country Club here last night. Miss Jean Bradley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel J. Bradley Sr., entertained at dinner at her home, later taking her guests to the dance.

Miss Jean Derby Ferris of this place and Glen Ridge, N. J., a descendant of Governor John Winthrop of the Massachusetts Bay Colony, was married here at noon today in the garden of Tide-Crest, the Summer home of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Henry Ferris, to Nils Anderson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Anderson of Plainfield, N. J.
LOOKING toward the early establishment of regularly scheduled transport service between the United States and Alaska, Pan American Airways announced last week that on Aug. 6 it would make

Galvarino Gallardo, a writer on international affairs, publishes an article today expressing the opinion that President Roosevelt's visit to the Galapagos Islands off the coast of Ecuador on the cruiser Houston is something more than a mere incident in the course of a pleasure trip, and therefore cannot be overlooked by the public in this hemisphere.

Leaving their overnight bivouac at Brown's Farm, the citizens military training camp regiment of 1,600 young men from the Second Corps Area "fought" their way through dense forest today to capture an important "enemy" supply dump near Plattsburg.

The engagement of Miss Ruth Randall, daughter of Mrs. Frank Randall of New Canaan, Conn., and the late Mr. Randall, to Carl Mayer, son of Mrs. Carl Mayer of Chicago and the late Mr. Mayer, has been announced by her mother.

THIS is the time of the year when music moves out of doors. Never in the history of the nation has there been so much of it in the Summer months. From coast to coast--bounded by the Lewisohn Stadium and Goldman Band concerts in the East and by the Hollywood Bowl programs in the West--symphonies and operas are being played to thousands of listeners.

The Cunard White Star motor ship Britannic is due today from England and France. Passengers are Donald Budge and Gene Mako, the Hon. Rupert Veneker, L. K. Elmhirst, Gordon F. Johnston and John T. Jones.
IN some miraculous fashion this book overleaps the mental barriers that stand between the East and the West and presents the essence of primitive Buddhism in a striking and comprehensible fashion.

TO the names of Ben Hecht and Charles MacArthur, Sam and Bella Spewack and other wellknown folk who write in collaboration might be added the names of Frank and Anne Hummert, whose prolific efforts are represented by a dozen serial scripts currently heard on the air.
Kurt Loewe, who was sentenced to fifteen years in prison Thursday by the Marseilles Military Tribunal after his conviction as a German spy, hanged himself in his cell today.

FLORENCE. THE second most discussed production at Florence was Jacques Copeau's staging of "As You Like It." Those who saw Reinhardt's memorable "Midsummer Night's Dream" in the same garden anticipated a natural sylvan setting for the romance of forest life.

Foreign exchange business here was restricted today by the impending holiday, and diminution of the recent demand caused a setback in the dollar which, after falling to $4.91 13-16 to the pound, closed at $4.9111-16.

MARTHA KELLER, as revealed in her sheaf of poems, "Mirror to Mortality," seems to be a rather unusual person. Apparently this is her first book of poetry, but she has been well represented in the magazines. Yet it is not ordinary magazine verse. Miss Keller shows maturity and independence of mind and, although she can write with much grace when it pleases her to do so,

The old adage, "out of sight, out of mind," too often applies to our climbing roses. During their brief period of bloom they usually dominate the garden. When they fade we are prone to forget them until late Summer or Fall-and then suddenly remember that they have not yet been pruned.

Tony Galento, recovering from a serious attack of pneumonia, threatened to "get up and go home" tonight from Orange Memorial Hospital. "I'm not a rich man. I have to get back and take care of my business," complained the National Boxing Association's leading challenger for Joe Louis's heavyweight boxing championship.

Mr. and Mrs. Harold Conant Payson of Portland have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Payson, to David Rait Richardson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Richardson of 300 Park Avenue, New York.

I have to get back and take care of my business," complained the National Boxing Association's leading challenger for Joe Louis's heavyweight boxing championship.

Leonardo Tapia, leader of a band of insurgents believed to have dynamited a train in the State of San Luis Potosi yesterday, was killed fighting with soldiers after the wreck, it was reported in dispatches received here today.
The Cubs announced today the purchase of Vance Page, right-handed pitcher, from Indianapolis of the American Association for Southpaw Pitcher Bob Logan and an undisclosed amount of cash.

WE still retain in this country a wholesome horror of the small American boy whose devastating knowledge of life has been acquired in the best hotels of two continents. It was implanted by Henry James as part of his discovery that the fact that Americans Visited Europe constituted a drama, and sedulously cultivated by Kipling and a host of lesser students of "the international situation."
Speed boat racing will gain a momentum this week that will continue for the next seven weeks into the finals at Detroit aNd Washington and the national outboard championships.

The Apawamis Club held a dinner dance tonight at its beach club on Manursing Island. Hosts included Dr. Alfred H. Blakemore, Dr. frank G. Carrol, Mr. and Mrs. John E. Smith, Mr. and Mrs. Stewart S. Hathaway and Mr. and Mrs. Valerie Hathaway.

Richard A. Chappell, of Atlanta, has been appointed Supervisor of the Federal Probation System, succeeding Col. Joel R. Moore, who helped establish it in 1930 and who resigned in March, 1937, to be an executive in the Michigan Prison System.
THE ninety-seventh season of the Philharmonic-Symphony, which begins on Oct. 20 at Carnegie Hall, is heralded with an announcement of soloists of the first few weeks.

Industrial financing featured the new issue market here in July for the second consecutive month. Offerings of all kinds of securities, however, were in substantially smaller volume than in June, but larger than in July, last year.

The last remaining portion of the old Clarke estate in the Northern Valley section of Tenafly, Bergen County, N. J., has been purchased by Harry f. Batchelder, builder, and he is dividing the tract into forty-five plots for improvement with dwellings to cost $7,200.

Reconstruction of the Theodore Roosevelt Apartments, comprising the blockfront on the west side of the Grand Concourse, between 171st and 172d Streets, Bronx borough, which has been under way since May, constitutes, it is stated, one of the largest rehabilitation projects of that type ever undertaken in this city.

IF the later works of G. B. Shaw have not fared too handsomely over here; an American premiere of a Shavian play is nevertheless an event to conjure with. Conjure, then, with this: on Aug. 15, at the Westport Country Playhouse, Lawrence Langner and Armina Marshall will offer the U. S. A. its first view of "The Millionairess,"which will adjourn the following week .to the Westchester Playhouse, Mount Kisco.

Some constructive solution for the redemption of the blighted areas in the majority of our cities should be forthcoming, points out Herbert U. Nelson, executive vice president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, as the result of the wide discussion now under way by various agencies in many parts of the country regarding the best means to relieve poor housing conditions.

BEFORE snow flies perhaps 30,000 dogs, many of them, of course, repeating from show to show, will compete for ribbons at some seventy outdoor dog shows. On close-cropped turf in many parts of the country specimens of the more than 100 breeds now recognized by the American Kennel Club will vie for the ribbons: blue, red, yellow or white, or the still more eagerly coveted winner's rosette of purple.

The Louisiana Democratic executive committee today rejected the papers of Robert H. Brothers of Shreveport, who sought to run as a candidate for the United States Senate, and declared Senator John H. Overton of Alexandria, incumbent, the nominee of the party.

THE opening exercises of the fifth annual Berkshire Symphonic Festival next Thurs day night at "Tanglewood," in Stockbridge, Mass., will celebrate the erection of the new music shed which henceforth will shelter the performances of the Boston Symphony Orchestra and its distinguished leader, Dr. Serge Koussevitzky, and constitute the permanent home of this festival.

CONSUMER response last week to the launching of August sales of furs and furniture ranged from "spotty" to "above expectations," with the consensus that in most sections these events got off to a fairly good start. Dollar volume figures, of course, will range materially under a year ago, due mainly to the price decline from 1937 levels.
The Department of Commerce announced today that Douglas G. Corrigan would receive only a

In the second round of the National A. A. U. one-wall handball singles championship at Ravenhall A. C., Coney. Island, yesterday, Harry Goldstein, defending champion and top-seeded player, was defeated by Sam Feuer, unseeded, 21-16, 12-21, 21-10.

Many of the Summer colonists here had parties at the supper dance tonight at the Fishers Island Club. Among .those who entertained were Mr. and Mrs. Alfred V. du Point, Mr. and Mrs. Pierre S. du Pont 3d, Mr. and Mrs. Lammot du Pont, Reynolds du Pont,
IT is not only hiking enthusiasts who will find Mr. Thoresby Jones's account of his personal explorations of the Welsh Border country a joy and a boon.

Charles E. Dexter Jr. of the Dexter Company, New York brokers, presents an interesting suggestion to owners of large non-income produring suburban or country estates who desire to liquidate their holdings.

War Admiral won on a rough and cuppy track before 15,000 persons today, when he gained a neck victory over William Ziegler Jr's Esposa, who just missed giving her owner a double stake viotory. Previously El Chico had carried the Ziegler Bilks to a six-length score in the $12,050 United States Hotel Stakes.

Cork flooring, according to buildings and building management, has many possibilities in modernizing apartment buildings and apartment hotels. When properly laid, it is vermin-proof" and water-proof, and it has a very desirable effect in silencing noises which may comonly be heard from the floor above.

Twentysix to one in the wagering, A. C. Compton's Gerald took the lead at the far turn and was never headed as he romped to an easy threelength victory today in the $5,000 added Rockingham Park Handicap, mile and a furlong high-spot of the closing day program. Gerald paid S54.20 to win.

Jobs have been found for 207 of the 1,140 persons interviewed by the committee of replacement, which represents New York Stock Exchange member firms, Robert P. Boylan, chairman, announced yesterday. The committee has been in operation only three weeks.

Frisco Dale and Dean Hanover flashed around Agawam Park's mile track today to set new records in Grand Circuit racing for this section before a crowd of 4,000. Frisco Dale, a chestnut stallion owned by Pearl Hungerford of Shelbyville, Ind., and driven by the veteran, Sep Palin, went the first mile of the 2:12 pace carrying a $1,200 purse in 2:00w, a pacing mark for this track. The old time was 2:02.

THE processing of prints-that strange and esoteric magic by which a mediocre negative is altered and refined and transmuted until a startlingly fine picture emerges from the darkroom-is easily within the scope of the novice equipped only to turn out contact prints.
Before a large gathering of socially prominent persons, the Minard estate, known as Great Marsh, was sold at auction this afternoon in the reception room of Mansion House, with Arthur C.

Catching the Queen Mary's upper works like sails, a sharp gust of wind this afternoon tore the giant liner from the grip of ten tugs that were edging her out of the drydock and sent her crashing, bow first, into the wooden jetty, almost cutting it in two.

THE country doctor of horse and buggy, or saddlebag, days is more or less a vanished figure. The modern medicos drive fast cars, one man can serve an extensive district, and, more important than his own transportation peihaps, an automobile will get the patient to a hospital if necessary.
New York and Chicago city directories are proving to be the most popular reading matter for thousands of Jews seeking American relatives who might help them to get out of Germany.

PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT--both in the present primaries and in the November election--is asking for a vote of confidence in the New Deal. By his own words the President opened the contest on the broadest grounds; since then indications have increased that the battle of this year is in reality the first phase of the 1940 campaign.

(All time is P. M., Eastern Daylight Saving, unless otherwise indicated; dial locations are in megacycles.) Today 7:50--Children's service from Dr. Barnardo's Boys' Garden City Church, GSG, 17.79; GSP, 15.31; GSO, 15.18; GSD, 11.75; GSB, 9.51--London.
Juan Jose Rocha y Garcia, former Spanish diplomat and statesman, died in Barcelona today after a long illness. He was 62 years old.

Little interest was taken in United States grain markets today. Outside trade was light and professional operations were reduced as the result of a holiday in Liverpool. The markets in that city and in Winnipeg also will be closed on Monday, tending further to restrict trading.

Johnny Burke, national intercollegiate champion, defeated T. Suffern Tailer, 2 and 1, to win the twelfth annual Newport Country Club invitation golf tournament. Burke, who also is Rhode Island amateur champion, didn't take the lead until the sixteenth hole.

QUEENS KEESE, WILLIAM H. (Nov. 3). Assets, $48,684 gross; $32,247 net. To widow, Katy G. Keese. Outstanding holdings in Jointly owned property, $41,891. John R. McMullen, attorney, 1 Broadway, Manhattan.

The resignation of the Cabinet was disclosed today in a move by the Ministers to give President Eleazar Lopez Contreras a free hand to reorganize the various State departments. The President's Lhree-year plan of governmental reorganization was launched early this month.
Japanese naval authorities accepted responsibility today for the slapping of Mrs. Florence Storms Massie, wife of Lieutenant Thomas H. Massie, American naval officer, on June 25.
The engagement of Miss Elizabeth Brewster Malburn to Stuart Salisbury Smith of Denver, Col., has been announced here by her father, William Peabody Malburn of Evanston, Ill.

Dollar sales of Physical Culture Shoe Stores in July were 28 per cent above those of July, 1937, preliminary estimates indicate, despite the fact that the concern's Summer sale price this year was $4.95, compared with $5.45 last year, L. A. Leopold, general manager, said yesterday.
The main political interest here is directed toward the arrival next Wednesday of Viscount Runciman of Britain as an advisor on the Sudeten German problem.
LAST week the Metropolitan Opera Association and the American Guild of Musical Artists were "happy to announce that after many interesting conferences both sides have reached an agreement."

The United States today had its Six-Meter team to face the Royal Northern Yacht Club for the BritishAmerican Cup when Paul Shields's Rebel and Henry Morgan's Djinn were named to complete the quota of four.

The commission appointed by President Getulio Vargas to decide the fate of 4,800 refugees from European countries soon will begin its study of those who arrived on tourist passports, good for only six months, but remained.

A man who described himself as 104 years old, and said that he had come to New York because he had not seen the metropolis since 1859, was taken to Broad Street Hospital, and later to Bellevue, last night, after passersby had noticed him near the Dey Street entrance of the Hudson tubes.

THE Dominican Republic's promised national independence commemoratives, issued on July 16, reached New York last week. Large in size and in values and colors of 1-centavo green, 3-centavo purple and 10-centavo orange, with the republic's flag in its natural colors on each,

Motion pictures of Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd's expeditions to the North and South Poles and of his transatlantic flight have been donated to the government and will be kept in the national archives.

Seymour Markowitz, 19 years old, of 104-59 116th Street, Richmond Hill, Queens, was killed about 6 o'clock last night when he was thrown from his motorcycle while riding through 119th Street south of 109th Avenue, near his home.

Fifteen Summer residents of Bar Harbor will open to the public the flower gardens of their private estates tomorrow for the benefit of the American Red Cross. A small admission will be charged, proceeds to go to the charitable organization.

A cooperative project between the Board of Education and Teachers College to help develop an integrated "school and community" program will be established experimentally this Fall, according to Dr. Wilbur C. Hallenbeck, Professor of Education, Teachers College.

BIALLA--SCHWARTZ--Mr. Max Platt announces the marriage of his daughter, Ida Platt Schwartz, to Mortimer W. Bialla, son of Ray M. Bialla, taking place July 31, 1938, Hotel Hamilton. COHEN--GURDIN--Announcement is made of the marriage on July 27 of Sybil Gurdin to Sidney Cohen.

In an attempt to over come the problems usually encountered in creating stores on Fifth Avenue, the Gotham Hotel is utilizing a number of novel construction ideas in erecting the five stores to be opened in that establishment on the Fifth Avenue frontage at the southwest corner of Fifty-fifth Street early in October, points out Arthur Collins of Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., agents for the stores.

Weather continued last week to hold down retail sales, but, with a few exceptions, the dollar declines from last year were moderate and more than offset by lower prices. Cash crops were being harvested in the South and Southwest, and early reports indicated that a substantial portion of the return was finding its way into retail hands. Better wholesale sales by jobbers serving rural districts confirmed this trend.
Within thirty days, transport airplanes winging down through Newhall Pass into the Union Air Terminal will glide along an invisible radio "track" just like toboggans along a slide.

THE eleventh annual Folk Dance and Music Festival will be held this Thursday to Saturday inclusive at Asheville, N. C. More than 1,000 musicians and dancers from the highlands of Western North Carolina will participate.

During the coming week London will become a center for dealing with problems facing the Jews on two fronts. The Evian conference will shift here preparatory to setting up machinery for relocating Jews and other refugees from Austria and

The unexpected thrust across the Ebro River this week by Loyalist forces in Spain, though minimized by the Franco side, seems to indicate that the Republicans are still capable of stubborn and effective resistance and to confirm the belief, widely held by European observers, that the Insurgents are not likely to win the war before Spring.
Philip Barbaro, barber, who gave a haircut to a friend after the closing hours prescribed by State regulation, won his fight today to cut hair whenever he is asked.
DEADWOOD, S. D.--From this town, on Aug. 4 to 7, will come the fifteenth annual denial, well documented and witnessed, that the Old West has "passed," as reports have had it for some time.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: My letter printed in THE TIMES of July 1 giving the framework of a new national housing industry to embrace the construction and sale of 5,000.000 individual homes during the next five years has happily elicited some interest and comment.

Now that German border fortifications are beginning to appear above the ground, the German Government issued a proclamation today declaring the entire western border region a "closed area," which nobody may enter without valid official identification papers.

This is a time of testing. Throughout the world new patterns of social life are being tried, old patterns discarded. This country has not escaped the compulsions of a universal reassessment, but so far the acceptance of change here has been well within our own tradition.
Unless the government establishes real competition within the petroleum industry by disintegrating monopolistic units and protecting the small independent operators,

The Metropolitan Gladiolus Socity will hold its ninth annual gladiolus show Aug. 10 and 11 at Rockefeller Center. Eighty-one different classes comprise the show schedule, with sections for amateurs as well as for commercial growers and advanced specialists.

The New York Chapter of the National Catholic Alumni Federation, in a reply to the appeal by Earl Browder, general secretary of the Communist party, and Harry Forbes, New York County executive secretary for cooperation between Catholics and Communists, quoted from the encyclicals of the Popes to show the Catholic Church has never been conciliatory toward communism.

MINDFUL of television's possibilities as an instrument of warfare, the United States Government is keeping a strict observance of television development here and abroad through technicians of the army and navy who expect that the new art will play an important rOle in future international conflicts, according to reports from Washington.
Widespread violence throughout Jamaica is expected Monday when descendants of former slaves attempt to celebrate the 100th anniversary of complete emancipation.

The resignation of the Cabinet was disclosed today in a move by the Ministers to give President Eleazar Lopez Contreras a free hand to reorganize the various State departments. The President's Lhree-year plan of governmental reorganization was launched early this month.
Japanese naval authorities accepted responsibility today for the slapping of Mrs. Florence Storms Massie, wife of Lieutenant Thomas H. Massie, American naval officer, on June 25.
The engagement of Miss Elizabeth Brewster Malburn to Stuart Salisbury Smith of Denver, Col., has been announced here by her father, William Peabody Malburn of Evanston, Ill.

Dollar sales of Physical Culture Shoe Stores in July were 28 per cent above those of July, 1937, preliminary estimates indicate, despite the fact that the concern's Summer sale price this year was $4.95, compared with $5.45 last year, L. A. Leopold, general manager, said yesterday.
The main political interest here is directed toward the arrival next Wednesday of Viscount Runciman of Britain as an advisor on the Sudeten German problem.

The twenty-three-story Hotel Victoria, on the northeast corner of Seventh Avenue and Fifty-first Street, is undergoing a major surgical operation which will split the hostelry into two separate entities independent of each other.

The monthend demand for credit was normal here, the market being eased by substantial repayments of Reich short-term liabilities and of the Gold Discount Bank's promissory notes. Today's day-to-day loan rate was 31/2 to 33/2 per cent.

Macmillan has ordered a fourth printing of "Fanny Kemble: A Passionate Victorian," by Margaret Armstrong, which was published a month ago. The Book Union selection for August is John Strachey's "What Are We to Do?" a history of the British and American labor movements.
Augustus Van Cortlandt of Sharon, Conn., was 83 years old yesterday and his son-in-law and daughter, Dr. and Mrs. Thomas T. Mackie, gave a birthday dinner here in his honor at Pine Cliff.

Faith in the leadership of Christ will give us unbounded confidence and unveil the mysterious shrouds of life, the Rev. Dr. William Hiram Foulkes said yesterday in his sermon at the West End Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue and 105th Street.

The Rev. David C. Mitchell of St. Mark's Lancefield. Church, Glasgow, Scotland, closing yesterday his series of sermons at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian ChUrch, Fifty-fifth Street, declared there were rampant today two forces which threaten the morality of the world. The first, he said, was war; the second, betting and gambling.

The corn market was on the downgrade last week, with the new-crop deliveries other than the December in new low ground for the season. Favorable weather and crop reports made sentiment extremely bearish and, while there was a fair export demand, the prospect of the 1938 harvest being well in excess of previous expectations overshadowed everything of a bullish character.

Morris Tremaine, Controller of the State of New York, will head a new title insurance company to be known as the Lawyers Title Corporation of New York, Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, announced yesterday.

American Light and Traction Company and Subsidiaries-Gross operating earnings for the twelve months ended June 30, 1938, $40,810,827, with net income $5,196,815, equal, after preferred dividends, to $1.53 a common share. This compared with gross of $40,219,331 and net of $5,998,484, or $1.88 a share, for the first. six months of 1937.

The season's rise on the Stock Exchange had been so extraordinary, both in scope of advance and in volume of transactions accompanying it, that it became and remained the day's outstanding financial phenomenon.

Lewis Oakley Brewster, 69 years old, retired vice president and general manager of the New York Insulated Wire Company and a member of one of this city's oldest families, died here today at the home of a son, William M. Brewster, at 1,261 Waverly Place.

A nonstop record for planes of its type wa, claimed today by Robert Bryant, 30 years old, Rock Hill (S. C.) sportsman flier, who landed his two-cylinder, single seater, cabin Aeronca monoplane at Central Airport here at 6:45 tonight.

Dr. Walter Channing Bailey of Cambridge, Mass., heart and lung specialist, died here today of a cerebral hemorrhage at the age of 67. He retired from active practice several years ago because of ill health.

Charges that the Administration's reciprocal trade agreement program is detrimental to the interests of American farmers were roundly denounced by Secretary Hull in a letter to Senator Pope of Idaho, made public today.
One of Spain's outstanding surgeons, Dr. Gomez Ulla, is reported to have been tried in Barcelona this week, together with some others, on a charge of high treason and to be awaiting sentence.
Mrs. Henry R. Rea has arrived from Farmhill, her home in Sewickley, Pa., and is at the WaldorfAstoria. Mr. and Mrs. C. Alan Hudson of Rumson, N. J., have left for the Seigrnory Club, P. Q.

Today will find a number of anglers flipping plugs, spinners and bugs over Lake George, which is now open for bass fishing. They say it takes quite some knowledge of bass lore to take big fish from this lake on artificial bait, which may account for the fact that it is a spot favored by a number of nance anglers we know.

The police have ordered the suspension for fifteen days of Diario de Hoy, a popular newspaper of San Salvador, according to reports here. No reason has been given for the order, but the suspension is believed here to be the result of the publication of an editorial praising democracy on July 14, Bastille Day.

Fred Jacoby Jr., North Bergen (N. J.) veteran, swept to victory today in two classes of the twenty-eighth annual Saranac Lake motor boat regatta. Jacoby, one of the nation's top ranking outboard drivers, clinched first honors in the professional Classes B and C, and placed third in Class A, won by Bob Meyer of Chicago. Jack Wood of Detroit led the field in Class F and finished second to Jacoby in Class C.
The racing association president, George H. Bull, gave the first of a series of four Sunday buffet luncheons today at the Saratoga Gulf Club, of which he is also president.

An of the Yankees, in addition to Henry Lou Gehrig, became men of great endurance today-as they struggled for nearly six hours to impress their importance upon the White Sox, and in the end they made it.

Colonel Robert James Blackham, M. D., paid his first visit to New York yesterday as surgeon of the Cunard White Star liner Laconia. He has more than twenty decorations and was cited five times in dispatches during the World War. During his career as a soldier in India he received many decorations.

Passenger traffic and revenues on the subway and elevated lines operated by the Interborough Rapid Transit Company during the fiscal year ended June 30 fell substantially below the totals for the previous fiscal period, according to a report made public yesterday by Thomas E. Murray Jr., Federal receiver for the company.

For the second time within two years the Kings County District Attorney's office is involved in court litigation over charges of "fixing" by high-ranking staff assistants, the latest instance being scheduled for a public hearing today in Brooklyn Felony Court with chief prosecutor William F. X. Geoghan admittedly seeking to "clean his own house."

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies, announced yesterday, are after deductions for operating expenses, normal Federal income taxes and other charges. Figures in many cases are subject to final adjustment.

The cornerstone of the "Man, His Clothes, His Sports Building" at the New York World's Fair will be laid tomorrow afternoon with Mayor La Guardia officiating. Representatives of many of the firms which will have exhibits in the building will be present and will include Robert C. Palmer, president of Cluett, Peabody Co., Inc.;

The Republic of Uruguay will announce today, through its Minister in Washington, Don Jose Richling, a formal offer, by means of a prospectus, to holders of outstanding 6 and 7 per cent bonds of the city of Montevideo,

The Canadian cricketers from Toronto, Montreal and Hamilton took on a picked team representing the Cosmopolitan, New York and Interstate Leagues in the second game of their tour at Commercial Field, Brooklyn, yesterday.
Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 37 per cent of capacity, unchanged from the preceding week but 5 points higher than the week before.

James M. Golding, assistant district attorney of Kings County and a past commander of the county American Legion organization, died yesterday morning in St. Catherine's Hospital, Brooklyn, of peritonitis.
John J. Slattery of Haddon Hall, Bronxville, N. Y., a retired member of the New York Curb Exchange, died at his Summer home here yesterday of a heart attack at the age of 52.

The army and navy search for the missing Hawaii Clipper continued today with ever-waning hope after an allday hunt by ships and seven planes yesterday had brought only terse reports of "nothing sighted."

The text of Assistant Attorney General Thurman Arnold's opinion as to alleged violations of the anti-trust statutes by the American Medical Association and the District of Columbia Medical Society follows:

Miss Florence Penick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sydnor Barksdale Penick of this place, has chosen Oct. 8 for her marriage to Giles St. Clair, son of Harry Hull St. Clair, also of Montclair, and the late Mrs. Ethel Erskine St. Clair. The ceremony will be performed in the First Baptist Church of Montclair by the pastor. the Rev. Dr. Albert Cohoe.

Henry Seinfel of 1,535 President Street, Brooklyn, first vice president and a trustee of the Brooklyn Jewish Center, died Saturday night in St. Mary's Hospital, Hoboken. He became ill the previous day in his office in Hoboken, where he was district manager for the John Hancock Life Insurance Company.

Lois Long, a writer, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. William J. Long of Stamford, Conn., was married to Donaldson B. Thorburn tonight at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Frank B. Hall Jr., in Searingtown, this place. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Theodore W. Luidens of Williston Park.

An official analysis of German industry for June shows that activity suffered more than the usual Summer and holiday setback. The number of hours worked increased 17.6 per cent in comparison with last year,

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 81.6, which compared with 81.5 the week before, 81.7 two weeks before, 81.2 three weeks before and 80.9 four weeks before.

A new translation of a Dutch land grant made in 1636, the year of the first white settlement on Long Island, may enable the city to save $11,481,963 in condemnation proceedings at Floyd Bennett Airport, Marine Park and in other Jamaica Bay shorefront areas to be developed by Park Commissioner Moses.

A town house on the East Side passed to new control when the five-story residence at 127 East Eightieth Street was bought by Mrs. Christine Fischer from Mrs. Allen Wardwell. It is a modern brick front house on a lot 20 by 100 feet and was erected several years ago from plans by Delano Aldrich, architects.

The guidons of winning companies in athletic competitions of the Camp Dix Citizens Military Training Camp were decorated with streamers as the feature of the third formal Sunday parade of the regiment this afternoon.

The order of Governor Kraschel directing Major General Mathew A. Tinley of the National Guard to close the hearing of the National Labor Relations Board at Newton in the case charging the struck Maytag Washing Machine Company with "unfair labor practices" threatened tonight to develop into a conflict of authority between the State and Federal Governments.

The Christian Church dare not neglect its ministry to the colleges and universities, where the lives of the next generation are being molded, the Rev. C. Leslie Glenn, rector of Christ Church, Cambridge, Mass., said yesterday morning in his sermon at the Episcopal Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

William Burns Weston of 134 Sutton Manor, New Rochelle, N. Y., died suddenly here last night of a heart attack. His age was 57. He had not been feeling well recently and had come to Manchester in the hope that the change of climate would benefit him.

Two men and a girl were knocked down by a lightning bolt that struck near a drinking fountain in the sand at Brighton Beach yesterday. The bolt came during a thunder shower that swept the city shortly after 4 P. M., with heavy rains in parts of Manhattan,'Brooklyn and Queens but only a small sprinkling in the Bronx.

John Hetherington, Queens County Surrogate, refused yesterday to be drawn into a controversy with Mayor La Guardia. On Saturday the Mayor assailed the appointment of John F. Cassidy of Long Island City as chief clerk in the Surrogate's Court.
The garden yawns still half-asleep; Shadows lie here square and deep. In shaded leaves the coolness lingers; Day-lilies spread their orange fingers. Plump cabbages are silver-blue.

District Attorney Edward J. Neary and a squad of detectives descended early today on what the prosecutor described as a "luxurious gambling establishment" said to have been patronized by wealthy residents of Long Island's North Shore. Seven persons were arrested and fifty men and women in evening dress were forced to leave the place.

Senator Bennett Champ Clark, who has faced New Deal threats, expressed confidence today that he would win in the Missouri primary next Tuesday. He also replied to criticism of his neutrality in the fight between Governor Lloyd C. Stark and Thomas J. Pendergast, Kansas City leader, over a Supreme Court nomination.

Almost a week after the attempted assassination of Governor Blanton Winship, the Nationalist party, in a lengthy statement signed by its Acting President R. Medina Ramos, says that although revolutionary means must be used in combating tyranny the Ponce shooting was not authorized by the party.

In a ceremony in front of the Little White House, Summer executive mansion of Governor and Mrs. Moore, Brig. Gen. Samuel G. Barnard of Haddonfield, who on Friday retired from active military service, was commissioned a major general today by the Governor. Mrs.

Fifteen hundred of Father Divine's followers marched along a devious route through Harlem and the lower west Bronx yesterday afternoon, while several hundred others rode in automobiles and buses in a parade demonstrating their adherence to the mystical, economic and "righteous government" principles of the Negro evangelist.

The holiday season is laying a restrictive hand on the financial markets here. There is no fault to find with underlying conditions in the securities markets, but business has dwindled to a mere trickle.

The world's wheat market showed a heavy undertone last week, with all deliveries on United States Exchanges selling at new low levels for about five years. There was a notable lack of rallying power, due largely,

A man can become very fond of his cat, sometimes too fond for his own good. Through love of feline pets one man was trying yesterday to remove the swelling from a badly discolored eye and wondering how to extricate himself from the clutches of the law, and another was recovering from a possible concussion of the brain.

Fifty-two persons were killed and seventy injured yesterday in the worst railway wreck in Jamaica's history. Preliminary investigation indicated that sabotage, feared because of Jamaica's tense labor situation, was not the cause of the accident. Further inquiries, however, will be made.
A $5,000 robbery, carried out after the victim had stopped his automobile for a red traffic light Saturday night, was under investigation today by detectives of the Nassau County Police.

Mr. and Mrs. Celestin A. Durand of Garden City, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Gladys Adelaide Durand, to George A. Corroon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Corroon of Massapequa Manor, Massapeaua. L. I.

Savings banks in this city will begin today publication of lists of depositors with accounts of $10 or more which have been inactive for at least fifteen years. Present provisions of the banking law require publication of such lists in August or September of each year.

The Cash Office of Foreign Credits in Budapest, Hungary, will announce today through its central paying agent here, the Schroder Trust Company, that it will redeem coupons dated Aug. 1 on the following bonds, at the rate of $8.75 a coupon detached from a $1,000 bond:

100-Meter Free Style-Peter Fick, New York A. C. 220-Yard Free Style-Adolph Kiefer, Chicago. 440-Yard Free Style-Ralph Flana*gan, Miami Biltmore Club. 880-Yard Free Style-Flanagan. One-Mile Free Style-Flanagan.

There is a rising tide of the yellow-skinned peoples of the East which may some day, and perhaps in our time, engulf the world in a clash of races, the Rev. Dr. Samuel Henry Prince, head of the Deapartment of Social Sciences, Kings College, Halifax, N. S.,

With the encouraging developments in trade and industry last month, the feeling has grown that the worst has been seen and that the country is headed for some measure of recovery, the National City Bank says in its Aug. 1 bank letter.

With Deputy Boxing Commissioner Tom Farley as an approving onlooker, Henry Armstrong, holder of the world featherweight and welterweight titles, went through training paces today for his lightweight title bout with Lou Ambers at the Polo Grounds Aug. 10.

Two men, both apartment house superintendents, who called a policeman' a "sissy" early yesterday morning and then proceeded to "toss him around" by pushing him from one to the other, were sentenced later in the day to serve two days in jail, by Magistrate Mark Rudich in Bridge Plaza Court, Brooklyn.

Comments by banks and the financial press here on business in the United States are reservedly optimistic. Those who regard Wall Street as an infallible precursor of cyclical trade movements emphasize that the midsummer rise in securities, although substantial, has so far suffered no noticeable setback, and they predict a lasting recovery for industry.

Frau Dollfuss, widow of the murdered Austrian Chancellor, and her three children arrived unexpectedly in Britain tonight. Speculation immediately was aroused over whether they intended to make their home here but the Home Office and other governmental authorities declined even to confirm their arrival.

Alfred Isaacs, 19, of 609 West 137th Street, Manhattan, drowned in East Chester Bay, where he had been bathing off Shore Drive, the Bronx. Harry Alferio, 34, of 85-01. Rockaway Beach Boulevard, Rockaway Beach, drowned while bathing in Jamaica Bay off Seventh Road, Broad Channel.

Lumber production in the week ended on July 23 was the highest for any week this year and new orders were the highest in fifteen months, except for the previous week and one week in April, 1937, the National Lumber Manufacturers Association reported today.

APGAR--At Peekskill, on July 30, Cecilia Bellefeuille, wife of James K. Apgar. Funeral private. Please omit flowers. BAILEY--Sunday, July 31, Dr. Walter Channing Bailey of Cambridge, Mass. Born Somerville, Mass., Oct. 8, 1870. Survived by wife and four children.

Eight persons were injured, four of them seriously, here today when a motor boat engine exploded as it was started at the dock of the Ward Oil Company on the Hudson River. The inside of the boat was ripped out with the explosion, but it did not take fire.

The whole art school of Cooper Union is being reorganized, it was learned yesterday. The work is being carried on under the leadership of Guy Gayler Clark, who took office as the Union's new art director on July 1.

The Cabinet committee that has been studying the question of the war debt to the United States has been instructed to prepare "constructive proposals" for consideration by the British Government, according to The Daily Telegraph.

The following were the best sellers for the week ended Saturday: NEW YORK Reported by the American News Company, Bloomingdale's, Brentano's, Doubleday, Doran Bookshops, Gimbel's, Macy's, Scribner's, Wanamaker's and Womrath's:

The newspaper Panama American suggests today that President Juan Demostenes Arosemena consult President Roosevelt on the question of the United States sharing part of the cost of concreting 300 miles of the National IIighway of Panama, which is part of the Pan-American Highway.

Politics invaded the Universal Esperanto Congress opening here today when the Italian delegates refused to speak. Cecil Goldsmith, the secretary, said their silence was the result of the participation of a representative from Barcelona, in Loyalist Spain.

George H. Arfman, formerly with Thomas Haab, is now with J. W. Sparks Co. The National Safety Bank and Trust Company Las announced the appointment .of Louis Rothstein, formerly of the Bachmann, Emmerich Factors Corporation, as a member of its credit department.

An elaborate program on which works by five American composers were listed was given by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night at the Lewisohn Stadium, under the auspices of Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians. Five conductors participated in the event, and there were two American soloists, Joan Field, violinist, and Milton Kaye, pianist.. Probably because of the rainy weather earlier in the day, the audience was not large.

The inquiry of the Temporary National Economic Committee, comprised of six members of Congress and representatives - of six administrative agencies, will center around an industrial practice. of cutting production rather than prices in. times of slackened 'demand,. in the opinion of leading industrialists who have discussed the matter informally with New Deal. policy-formers.
A Japanese army communique today said Soviet Russian troops had twice counterattacked Changkufeng and Shatsaopin, from where they had been dislodged, and were repulsed after hours of fighting.

Miss Louise Lillian Fargo, younger daughter of Mr. and Mrs. F. Miller Fargo Jr. or this city, has chosen Sept. 9 for her marriage to Gleed Thompson, son of Mrs. Cornelia G. Thompson of Santa Fe, N. M., and Roy S. Thompson of Denver, Col. The ceremony will take place in the garden of the Fargo residence. The Rev. Dr. John J. Moment, minister of Crescent Avenue Presbyterian Church, will perform the ceremony.

Mobile troops killed eight Arabs and wounded many others today when they met a roving band in the Jordan River Valley as Jewish-Arab clashes for the twenty-sixth successive day kept the Holy Land in a ferment.

Martin Conboy, chairman of the lawyers division of the Greater New York Fund, announced yesterday that 440 New York law firms and their employes had contributed more than $100,000 to date to the campaign. He said this represented an increase of 60 per cent over the profession's showing in the Emergency Unemployment Relief Campaign of 1932.

On the eve of the annual Race Week of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association, starting tomorrow and ending Saturday, some sixty boats took part in the invitation regatta of the Narrasketuck Club today.

Dividends declared this month were the smallest for any July since 1935, and the least for any month since April of this year. Payments of $190,228,957 were authorized by 837 companies, compared with $261,099,791 for 1,400 corporations in the preceding month; $281,481,096 for 984 concerns in July, 1937, and $172,504,763 for 785 companies in July, 1935.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $3,740,039,650. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and noninterest-bearing discount bills.
Toronto made it two in a row over Jersey City today by taking a 6-to-4 decision in a game cut to eight innings by rain. The second game of the scheduled doubleheader was rained out.

Ten Canadian Boy Scouts are spending two weeks at the Ten Mile River Boy Scout Camps of the Boy Scout Foundation of Greater New York, Ten Mile River, N. Y., it was announced yesterday. In turn, ten New York City Scouts have enrolled for a fortnight at Camp Tamaracouta, the Montreal Boy Scout camp at Mille Isles, Que.

The body of Louis Rosenfeld, police inspector of New York City, which has been in an undertaking establishment since his suicide here on Friday, will be taken to New York tomorrow morning. The Connecticut police will provide a military escort to the New York State line.

The National Conference of Investors, which has a membership of 11,000, will organize a New York State unit, it was announced yesterday by F. D. Russell, president of the Security Mutual Life Insurance Company, Binghamton, N. Y., and chairman of the unit's organization committee.
Holders of approximately $3,826,600 City of Warsaw, Poland, thirtyyear 7 per cent bonds of 1928, will receive today the first coupon payment on those bonds under an offer announced last May.

William Roseman sold to the Frelpark Realty Corporation, David Rose, president, a plot of thirteen vacant lots at the southeast corner of the Grand Concourse and East 163d Street, the Bronfx. The property fronts 142.5 feet on the Concourse and 225 feet on East 163d Street and adjoins the eight-story apartment house being erected by Samuel Derfner Son.
The money value of retail trade sales in June was 8.6 per cent above the total in June, 1937, following a decline of 8.1 in May.
