Leon Zolotkoff, former editor of the Jewish Daily News of New York, for which he has provided a column of comment since 1923, died at his home here this morning of pneumonia. Born in Russia seventy years ago, he came to this country as a youth and lived in Chicago until his removal to New York in 1913.
Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Jane Murchison Thomas of Atlanta to Erwin Tilson of New Haven, Conn. The marriage will take place in the Autumn.

Ricardo Castro Beeche, the Costs Rican Minister to Washington, sailed today with a plan for the adjustment of foreign loan bonds which are in default. If the plan is accepted by the council of Costa Rican bondholders in New York the envoy will go to London to seek agreement with the British bondholders.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Roland Kilbon of '993 East Nineteenth Street, Brooklyn, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Kilbon, to John Lewis Ames, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry L. Ames of Lynbrook, L. I., and Virginia.
The inJury-riddled Bees returned to the head of the second division today as Deacon Danny MacFayden and Lou Fette pitched 3-to-2 victories over the Cardinals for a Sweep of the twin bill.

The trade recession in Great Britain continues, While reports from the industrial centers fail to indicate any likelihood of an early reversal of the downward trend. Acceleration of rearmament has been insufficient to offset the contraction either in export orders or home demand.

Eddie Cantor, radio and screen comedian, will be honored at a testimonial luncheon on Wednesday for his work in raising more than $500,000 for the transfer of Jewish refugee children from Central Europe to Palestine while he was on a tour through England.
Frank Campbell and Cornelius Shields, the leaders in the -International Class series for the Bermuda Trophy, finished one, two in the regatta conducted by the Shore Acres Yacht Club today.

Philip Torchio, former Mayor of Bronxville, will retire tomorrow as vice president of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York. The company has a 70-year age limit, and Mr.. Torchio was born in Italy on Aug. 2. 1868.

The decision of the Democratic leadership in the State to fight the new State Constitution which the Republican-controlled Constitutional Convention will present to the voters this Fall has 'become increasingly apparent.

With the brilliant Texan, Cecil Smith, accounting for ten goals, the Monmouth County Country Club quartet subdued Evergreen Farms, 14-11, today. The winners' No. 3 gave a fine exhibition of accurate and lengthy hitting, contributing four points in the-third session.

In a letter to shareholders sent out yesterday, James H. Perkins, chairman of the board of the National City Bank, called attention to the difficulty banks found in earning money and disclosed that his bank had put into effect new economies and salary cuts in the "upper brackets" which would reduce expenses $1,125,000 a year.

Using sail when she could ana her motor when there wasn't any wind, William M. Young's sloop Venturon yesterday won the Bayside Yacht Club's race from Little Neck Bay out around Block Island and return.

John Zorian of Gainesville, Fla., unseeded entrant, accounted for a surprise in the eighth annual tournament for the Armenian tennis championship of America yesterday, when he defeated William Elias, Philadelphian, top-ranking player, in a five-set quarter-final match at the Arrowhead courts in the Bronx.

5th St, 329 E: Metropolitan Savings Bank to Stanton-Fifth St Corp, 270 Madison Ave; purchase money mtg $27,000 ($31). 46th St, 2-8 W; Mortgage Commission Realty Corp, trustee, to Herbert A. Wolff, trustee, 285 Madison Ave. Stanton St, 266; Metropolitan Savings Bank to Stanton-Fifth St Corp, 270 Madison Ave; purchase money mtg $27,000 ($31).

The trustees of the Century Shares Trust, in their report for June 30 last, put the liquidating value of each participating share at $21.95 after deducting the dividend of 42 cents a share payable today.

Twelve men at odds over the guilt or innocence of fifty-five Harlan County coal corporations, their officers and hired deputy sheriffs put aside their differences today and tried to relax in the Sabbath quiet of this little mountain town.

Two incidents between Czechs and Sudeten Germans were reported today. At Trautenau the police found a man seriously wounded as a result of having been stabbed twice in the back. They ascertained that he was a Czechoslovak subject of German descent named Adolf Mattes.

If the spirit of God has come into your soul, trust in Him and you will be saved, the Rev Dr. L. SaleHarrison of Australia said in his sermon yesterday at the First Bap- t tist Church, Broadway and Seventyninth Street. The test, he said, is whether you trust in Jesus.

In a contest studded with brilliant infield play on both sides and capped by a rainstorm that washed out the second half of a scheduled double-header at Ebbets Field yesterday, the Dodgers nosed out the Pirates, 4 to 3, in the final of the series with the league leaders.

Through an exchange arranged by-the English Speaking Union of the United States, Miss.Bargara J. Sindall, classics teacher at the Brearley School, 610 East Eightythird Street, will become a member of the teaching staff of the Godolphin and Latymer School, Hammersmith, London, for the next school year.

There will De no Spil of the Don Budge-Gene Mako doubles combination if the principal parties have anything to say about the matter-and they have. Yesterday morning the country's top-ranking tennis duo returned from a triumphant world tour aboard the Cunard White Star liner Britannic and scoffed at rumors that they were ready to sever their partnership.

Procedure doesn't mean much to the layman, but he is likely to be bored by it if he is a juryman. If he is a litigant it may cost him time and money. The lawyers play the game according to the rules. The results if ill are not their fault but that of the Legislature which establishes the lawyer's technique for him.

Governor Lehman reviewed the Fourteenth Infantry of Brooklyn and the 165th Infantry of Manhattan today at Camp Smith, New York National Guard training reservation here, where the units are entering their second week of field training.

The firm of Jenks, Gwynne Co. was dissolved on Saturday, the business being continued by A. M. Kidder Co. The latter firm announced yesterday that William P. Jenks, Arthur C. Gwynne, Percy D. Lown and John C. Botts, former partners of the dissolved firm,
The cotton market lost almost as much last week as it gained in the previous week.-- From Monday to Thursday, inclusive, small net losses were shown each day, after which the market steadied.

Julio de Osma, organizer, composer and founder of the Conservatory of Music at San Jose, Costa Rica, died today after a short illness. His age was 50. A native of Barcelona, he was noted for his Spanish songs.

Fay Templeton, star of many Gilbert and Sullivan operettas, is leaving her Pittsburgh home to live with relatives in San Francisco. Stricken with arthritis, Miss Templeton said: "I'm never coming back to Pittsburgh. People were nice to me here, but I've been alone a lot."

The third-place Cubs today gained their first victory in a four-game series with the last-place Phillies. Chicago split a double-header, winning the nightcap, 4 to 3, after dropping the twelve-inning opener, 8 to 5. The second game went only seven innings because of Philadelphia's Sunday law.
The Seabright Women's Challenge Bowl passed permanently into the keeping of Miss Alice Marble today. In a repetition of the one-sided victory of Robert L. Riggs over Elwood Cooke Jr.

The five Federal arts projects have contributed immensely to the cultural and educational advancement of the city in the last twelve months, according to the report of Paul Edwards, administrative officer of the projects, made public yesterday.
Establishment of a weather station at Wagner College, Staten Island, under the direction of the New York Weather Bureau was announced yesterday by Dr. Clarence C. Stoughton, president of the college.

Dr. Ray O. Miller, 60 years old, of 213 Madison Avenue, a physician who until recently had offices at 25 East Thirtieth Street, was killed last night at 11 o'clock in a leap from a third floor window at 730 Bergen Avenue, Jersey City. The or police, after finding a note asking that a brother in San Francisco be notified, listed the case as suicide.

Benjamin Schwartz, founder and director general of the Institute of Scrap Iron and Steel, who recently announced that he would retire as chief executive of the institute on Aug. 15, will become a vice president of theSchiavone-Bonomo Corporation on that date.

Valdine Conde, 9-year-old Canadian pianist, made a highly successful debut as soloist with the New York Civic Orchestra at its concert directed by Joseph Littau yesterday afternoon in the Federal Music Theatre.

Germany's wholesale price index stood at 105.7 on July 20, against 105.5 a week earlier. In the first six months of this year the highest point reached by the German wholesale price index was 105.8 on March 2.

The Bulgarian capital is wildly excited tonight as the result of the ending of a well-kept secret with the conclusion of a pact at Salonika, Greece, by which the Bulgarian Government recovered its military liberty and the right to rearm.
The Federation of British Industries in its business forecast for the third quarter is brief and cautious. Remarking the recent technical recovery in commodity and securities markets and the prospect

There is a natural and justifiable difference of opinion as to whether government should take over the distribution of'hydroelectric power, as it has done in the Tennessee Valley. There is less ground for divergent views as to the desirability of retaining under public control those water-power resources which are now within the public domain.

The stock market here this week was abnormally dull, with the stocks of even firstrank corporations not being quoted at times. Prices sagged, principally because of a lack of buyers, one offer of Reichsbank shares sending the price down 2 points.

THE austere members of the New York State Athletic Commission, General John J. Phelan, Colonel D. Walker Wear and Ex-Private Bill Brown, are in hot water again. They had an uncrowning session recently. They declared three pugilistic titles vacant, two of which seemed pretty well filled at the moment.

The lure of a preferred $15,000 salary for one season with the Pittsburgh Pirates has caused Byron (Whizzer) White, Colorado all-American quarterback, to reconsider his decision to forsake football for a Rhodes scholarship.
This week's increase of [Pound]6,201,000 in the note circulation of the Bank of England was approximately pound1,000,000 greater than that in the corresponding week last year.

An alliance in Queens between the American Labor party and the Democratic faction headed by James V. Sheridan, former county leader, was announced yesterday by Alex Rose, the Labor party's State executive secretary.

Activity improved in the New York dress market last week, with the higher brackets showing greatest activity. Some reorders arrived for fur-trimmed costume suits. Increasing interest in new colors was reported.

The Actors Fund of America will open tonight its first Summer campaign by taking up voluntary collections in all rural theatres to further the organization's charitable work. Regarded as an outcome of the increased expansion of the Summer theatre industry, the fund's campaign will continue through Saturday night.

Initiating a program looking toward simplification of the laws on the issuance and sale of securities, the Investment Bankers Association of America has appointed a committee to study the whole fabric of this legislation

Two teams tied at 67 for first place in the South Jersey proamateur golf tournament at the Atlantic City Country Club today. Sammy Byrd, former Yankee outfielder and now professional at the Philadelphia Country Club, and his amateur partner, William Goldthorpe of Woodcrest, tied with a pair from Jeffersonville, George Fazio, pro, and Douglas Bradley, amateur.

Entertainments were given at many homes today for out-of-town visitors. Mr. and Mrs. Fulton Cutting entertained with a luncheon at their place on the ocean for Mr. and Mrs. Harold Stirling Vanderbilt, who arrived on their yacht Vara.
Wall Street and the business situation in the United States still present problems which observers here are trying to solve, although not very successfully.

Hedging sales dominated he action of the oats nc and rye markets last week. While the crops of the two grains are estimated to be somewhat less than was estimated earlier in the season, they are regarded as more than am??le for all domestic needs.

The quest of man for a key to the baffling experience called life is more ancient than any recorded history, the Rev. Dr. Russell J. Clinchy of Washington said yesterday in a sermon at the Broadway Congregational Tabernacle, Broadway at Fifty-sixth Street.
President Roosevelt ended his fishing in waters of the Galapagos Islands today as the cruiser Houston sailed for Cocos Island, 380 miles to the northeast, en route to the Panama Canal.

A change in the status of the Twentieth Century Fund from that of a foundation disbursing grants to outside organizations to that of an institute devoted to economic research and the formulation of economic policies has been completed within the last fiscal year, according to the annual report of the fund, released for publication yesterday.

Services workers of five large downtown department stores today voted to strike at midnight Monday following a breakdown of negotiations for a new contract. Union officials estimated that 500 elevator operators, janitors, janitresses, porters-and maids would be affected.

Sufi Abdul Hamid, Negro cult leader who was known as "the Harlem Hitler," was killed yesterday with an aviation pilot when his plane ran out of gasoline and crashed in full view of thousands of Sunday afternoon motorists near the crowded Southern State Parkway north of Wantagh, L. I. Miss Kay Price, the Sufi's white secretary and press agent, was seriously injured in the crash.

The marriage of Miss Ruth Campbell, daughter of Mrs. John Joseph Campbell of 40 Fifth Avenue, to Leo Gerard Kennedy, son of Mrs. Patrick J. Kennedy of Jersey City, N. J., took place Saturda? in St. Ignatius Church; Baltim?The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Morgan A. Downey, assistant pastor.

With the Vatican engaged in a violent conflict with the totalitarian States over extreme nationalism, an olive branch was held out to the European dictatorships today from the Palace of the Popes in France.

The National Labor Relations Board announced today that the Sailors Union of the Pacific and the Marine Cooks' and Stewards' Association of the Pacific Coast, respectively, had been certified as the exclusive bargaining representatives for unlicensed personnel in the deck and engine departments on tankers operated out of Pacific ports by the General Petroleum Corporation of California, at San Francisco.

The Department of Justice today charged the American Medical Association and its affiliate, the District of Columbia Medical Society, with violation of the antitrust laws in attempting to prevent the functioning of the Group Health Association, Inc., by expulsion or threatened expulsion of physicians and surgeons employed by the health association.
The index of Ju French wholesale prices on July 23 Ju was 654, compared with 657 on July 16 and 658 on July 9. The decline in the index was due to lower levels for native products and foodstuffs.

In view of the improving safety record of air transport as a whole, accidents to passenger planes always come as a shock. In the case of the Hawaii sul Clipper, however, the shock is intensified by the extraordinary record which she and her sister Martin 130 flying boats have established on the longest overwater airway in the world,

Henry Steingass of Philadelphia, representing the Penn A. C., today captured the National A. A. U. junior 100-meter free style swimming title, feature event of the third annual Northern New York championships.

Following in the footsteps of John McDiarmid, the Princeton professor who guided him during the last collegiate campaign, Gerard Podesta of Montclalr yesterday won the Eastern clay court singles championship in impressive fashion at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club.

With Southpaw Marius Russo giving only two hits, Newark registered a 5-to-1 victory over Buffalo today in the first game of a scheduled double-header that was called because of a heavy rainstorm after six and one-half innings. The second game was postponed.
Stephen M. Hoye of 594 Fifth Street, Brooklyn, died here last night at the Hospital of St. Raphael. He never fully regained his health after an operation performed several months ago.

The stock market here was irregular last week. Improvement in international conditions, following efforts aimed at a peaceful solution of the Czechoslovak problem, found welcome on the Stock Exchange at the beginning of the week.

Mrs. Addie L. Harvey, descendant of eight colonial families and author of a history of the Penobscot Indians, died today at her home here at the age of 84. Mrs. Harvey came here from Maine eight years ago after the death of her husband, Francis L. Harvey.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I read with interest the letter of my townsman Scoville Hamlin in quest of "an adequate measure of cost." It is quite right that unfair rates and unfair methods of competition inevitably lead to consideration of the cost of production, which, like the "yardstick," is one of the elusive factors in our industrial economics.

The Department of Commerce has reported indications that farm living conditions have improved materially since 1930. It said a 1938 census survey indicated substantial increases in the number of farm dwellings lighted by electricity, vided with bathrooms and having radios.

Four generations were represented at a family dinner of twenty persons today at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Herman Buchtenkirch here, marking the sixty-fifth wedding anniversary of the couple. Mr. and Mrs.

Carlin Comforts, Inc, bedroom accessories, in 211-15 W 61st St; Adams Co, Real Estate, Inc, broker. Little Garden Fruit Shop, store at southeast corner of Madison Ave and 80th St, through William B. May Co; Contemporary Modes Sales Institute, Inc, in 417 5th Ave; Kay Electric Co, in 105 W 40th St; Albert B. Ashforth, Inc, broker.

Production of window and plate glass in the United States in the first six months this year dropped respectively 67 and 76 per cent below the same period last year, the Department of Commerce has reported.

The fall of wheat prices to the lowest levels since 1933 again brings home to the nation the persistence oi our farm problem. The immediate cause of the drop in prices is the prospect of a wheat crop in this country second only in size to the record yield of 1915, together with a world crop that promises considerably to exceed all previous records.
Supply contracts valued at $9,407,420 were awarded during the week ended July 28 by fourteen Federal agencies under the provisions of the Public Contracts Act, the Labor Department announced today.

Almost a quarter of the population of this city departed early today by train for an outing at Asbury Park under the sponsorship of the Donohoe League for Constructive Government: Twenty-three thousand persons boarded twenty-one sections of the train. Each section was made up of twelve day coaches.

Fighting continued today along the Ebro, Levant and Estremadura fronts in Spain, but there was little change in the situation. Gandesa, the chief objective of the Loyalist offensive across the Ebrc River, was being firmly defended.

Brokers and renting agents of apartment houses in scattered sections of the metropolitan area reported over the week-end numerous leases of suites. Many of the apartments will be occupied by the new tenants about Oct. 1.

Acting under a statute enacted by the 1938 Legislature, the Public Service Commission announced yesterday the establishment of a New York City commercial zone in which the operation of motor trucks will not be subject to commission regulation.

The Commodore Vanderbilt of the New York Central Railroad crashed into the rear of a sister luxury train, the streamlined Mercury, twenty miles east of here tonight, injuring more than a score of passengers.

The belief that the Senate Campaign Expenditures Committee would make a public statement on the hardfought Democratic primary in Kentucky before election day, next Saturday, was heightened here tonight.
Cliff Grover and Norman Smith sailed Teaser to another victory today to widen their lead in the Barnegat Bay fleet's championship series of the International Star Class Yacht Racing Association.

Several parties for Greenwich debutantes already have been arranged for the early Autumn season. On Sept. 14 a supper dance will be given by Mr. and Mrs. Sylvester P. Larkin in the garden of Homecrest, their place on North Street, to introduce their daughters, the Misses Hope and Shirley Larkin.

Two hold-up men sat through a performance at the St. George Theatre, 25 Hyatt Street, St. George, S. I., last night, then stopped in the manager's office and robbed him of the day's receipts of $1,500 before leaving.

John Foreman of Chicago and Thane Halstead of Oak Park, Ill., won the Northern New Jersey doubles championship in a match that started on the Westfield Tennis Club courts and ended at the Ilderan Outing Club, Rahway, ten miles away, today.
The Governors Island Yellows, defending titleholders, routed Fort Hamilton, 15-7, yesterday at Morris Memorial Field in their semifinal match for the Second Corps Area military polo championship.

Captain Hans Bertram of the German Air Service arrived in New York yesterday morning by plane from San Francisco. and put up quietly at the Shelton Hotel. He said he intended not to tell what he was doing until he got back to Berlin on Wednesday night, but the news leaked out.

Starting tomorrow no "Aryan" woman under 35 may be employed in any house or flat in Austria in which is living a Jewish man. No "Aryan" woman under 45 in the future may be engaged by any Jewish household.
The foreign exchange market here was quiet this week, with the franc rate fluctuating within narrow limits. There was a slight improvement at the end of the week.

The islands of tranquillity are like the lost Atlantis, or like that submerged city of Ys old fishermen think they see at twilight off the Armorican coast. Bombers park and reload on the bluefringed beaches of Majorca, last resort of the last Bohemians.

John Golden has decided on the week of Sept. 12 for the opening of Fred Stone in '"Lightnin'." By that time Mr. Stone will have portrayed Lightnin Bill Jones for four weeks on the Summer circuit, the patrons of the Players Theatre, Clinton, Conn., seeing him in the part this week.
Governor Gordon Browning denied tonight reports that he planned to send troops to Memphis for duty in Thursday's Democratic primary in the stronghold of E. H. Crump, his arch political foe.

The Most Rev. Duane G. Hunt, Bishop of Salt Lake, appealed at all masses in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday for spiritual and financial aid for his diocese of 80,000 square miles serving 5,000 parishioners with thirty-three priests.

The Giants bade a sad farewell to Bill McKechnie's Reds yesterday at the Polo Grounds. With a chance to gain ground in the scrambled National League race, the Terrymen went to pieces when air-tight play was demanded and lost in the eleventh inning, 7 to 6, to the dismay of 16,802 fans who sat through broiling sunshine, a soaking shower and premature dusk.
A new record for the Southern New York State archery tournament was set today in the sixth annual championship match when E. H. Myers of Jackson Heights made 176 hits and a total of 1,232 points.

Thewedding of Miss Mary Bassett Keyes, daughter of Mrs. Elizabeth N. Hotchkiss, to Walter Dimont Rector, son of Mr. and Mrs. Dimont M. Rector of Delanson, N. Y., will take place Sept. 10 in St. James Episcopal Church, Great Barrington. Dr. Remsen B. Ogilby, president of Trinity College, will officiate, assisted by the Rev. Edward C. M. Tower, rector of St. James.

With the Texan, Tom Mather, and the Briton, Ivor Balding, going strongly, the Ramblers moved steadily ahead of the Foxhunters in today's special match on Cochran Field of the Meadow Brook Club, scoring at least twice in every period but the first to win by 11--7.

A "Declaration of Independence for Youth," framed by the First Voters League, 565 Fifth Avenue, will be signed by a group of young men and women at City Hall today, in observance of the 160th anniversary of the signing of the original Declaration on Aug. 2, 1776.
The Greely, bearing the MacGregor Arctic Expedition, was released from the Baffin Bay ice pack this morning.

July was a bad month for the Browns, but they closed it today in great style, winning twice from the Red Sox. They took the first, 7 to 6, with a two-run rally in the ninth, and the second, 10 to 2, after piling up seven runs in the first inning.

Imports of gold in July amounted to $27,839,000, of which by far the larger part was received at San Francisco. Receipts at New York were $1,119,000, the smallest for any month since February and less than in any other July for the last five years.
Commodity prices were generally higher last week with the important exception of wheat, which sank to the lowest level since 1933, according to The Annalist.

Under normal circumstances, or if tension on the issue were less acute, the nationalities statute just released by the Czech Government would be recognized as a step of major importance in the creation of the new Europe which Woodrow Wilson dreamed of twenty years ago when he surveyed the wreckage of the old.

America's future welfare will depend upon the sense of private responsibility felt by citizens today, declared the Rev. Frank Curtis Williams of the First Methodist Church, Brooklyn, in a sermon yesterday morning at the Hanson Place Central Methodist Church, at St. Felix Street, Brooklyn.
Following the precedents for the late vacation season, the stock markets here this week were dull and uninfluenced by important developments.

Johnny Revolta of Evanston, Ill., who began picking up golf tricks as a caddie fifteen years ago and has developed into one of the country's top-notch fairway magicians, plucked the $7,500 St. Paul open championship and its $1,600 first money from under the noses of old man par and a fast field today.

The Rev. Dr. Clarence T. Brown, associate pastor of the Central Church in Orchestra Hall, and for half a century a Congregational clergyman, died today. He was the father-in-law of Dr. Charles W. Gilkey, dean of the University Chapel, University of Chicago.

At least ten persons were injured, three of them seriously, when an empty six-car Interborough Rapid Transit Company elevated train crashed into the rear of another three-car train carrying about seventy passengers as it pulled out of the 110th Street station into the sharp curve over Eighth Avenue at 1:20 o'clock this morning. At this point the tracks are 100 feet above the street.

Following a meeting of the State Racing Commission, Chairman Herbert Bayard Swope released the following statement today: "At a special meeting of the New York State Racing Commission, consisting of Herbert Bayard Swope, chairman;
Stocks lower on the week in less active trading; turnover, 7,691,220 shares. United States Government and corporation issues irregular; foreign bonds higher; transactions, $39,873,100.
The money market, responsive to the monthend demand for funds, was firmer last week. The discount rate on commercial acceptance was 21/2 per cent and day loans were quoted at 24, per cent.

Current signs of business improvement in the United States are of cardinal importance not only for this country but for the whole world. The precipitate drop of business in the United States during the past year has already been reflected in a decline of foreign industrial activity (outside of Russia) of about 8 per cent since last November, according to The Annalist's index.

The 107th anniversary of the declaration of Peru's independence was observed today in the traditional manner, but there was a greater degree of dignity and restraint than has sometimes been the case in the past.

Count and Countess Alfonso P. Villa, who had several guests at Fairholme for the week-end, gave a large luncheon today. Among their guests was Robert Grant, to whom Miss Elena Villa is engaged. Their wedding is expected to be one of the events of Tennis Week.

BED AND BOARD, by Virginia Bird Martin. (Farrar Rinehart, $2.) A first novel of married life in suburban America. FROM JUNGLE ROOTS, by Marcos Spinelli. (Covici, Friede, $2.50.) A novel about a boy born in the Matto Grosso jungle.

Mel Arnett of the home club, who tied Mark Flanagan for medal honors, met defeat in a first-round test today, bowing to Paul Cavanagh of South Bay, 5 and 4, as match play in the Suffolk County golf championships opened at Timber Point.

Alfred S. Farmer has resigned as sales manager of Lande Miskend, Inc., underwear manufacturers. Bruce A. Fleming has been appointed executive secretary of the refrigeration division of the National Electrical Manufacturers Association.
An appendectomy ruined today a study of Midwestern farming conditions being made incognito by "farm hand" John Pierpont Morgan 3d, 21-year-old grandson of J. P. Morgan, the New York banker.

The German National Gymnastic Festival, which in the last week has drawn to Breslau German-speaking persons from all parts of the world, reached a climax today when 200,000 participants, 40,000 of them from the Sudeten region of Czechoslovakia, marched past Chancellor Hitler and proclaimed their constancy to their "racial" origin.

An American boy, James Cahill of Indianapolis, won the world title for model airplanes in the international contest for the Wakefield Trophy, held at Guyancourt near Versailles today. A model belonging to a French boy took second place.

Tom Kerrigan, veteran home club pro, today shot dazzling 64, seven under par, to reduce by one stroke the Siwanoy Country Club course record that he established in 1926. He gave a flawless performance, recording seven birdies and equaling par figures on the remaining eleven holes.

Amid charges that high government officials are plotting against President Lazaro Cardenas and vituperative countercharges against laborunion pressure on politicians, President Cardenas is preparing to send his reply to the United States note that demanded immediate discussion of payment for American agrarian properties expropriated.

The Iowa-Illinois Five Point Plan, designed to. make it easier for advertisers and agencies to do business with dailies in the two States, becomes operative today. Seventyfour Iowa and Illinois dailies, members of either the Iowa Daily Press Association or the Daily Newspaper League of Illinois, are supporting the plan.

The French liner Normandie is due to arrive today from Havre via Southampton. Among her passengers are Armand -Barois, French Minister to Venezuela, John Roland Robinson, M. P. Achille Fould, French Deputy and former Minister;

Germany won the European zone Davis Cup final from Yugoslavia today when Henner Henkel, who has just recovered from an arm injury, fairly blasted Josip Pallada off the court to win the deciding match, 6--4, 7-5, 6-1.

Saint Ignatius Loyola was lauded as "a soldier of Spain who became a warrior of God" by the Rev. Peter F. Cusick, in his sermon yesterday morning at the Roman Catholic Church of Saint Ignatius Loyola, Eighty-fourth Street and Park Avenue, where the feast day of the saint was marked by celebration of a solemn high mass.

Four animated mechanical dioramas of Mount Wilson and Yerkes Observatories, developed by -the scientific and technical staffs of the Hayden Planetarium of the American Museum of Natural History under the direction of Professor William H. Barton Jr., executive curator, will be a feature of the planetarium's August presentation, "Exploring the Universe," it was announced yesterday.

The Maritime Commission faces a difficult task this week in awarding ten freighters of the American Republics Line and the three former Panama Pacific passenger liners California, Virginia and Pennsylvania for charter operation to Buenos Aires and other South American ports.

In spite of previous fears of a disturbance tomorrow on the 100th anniversary of the liberation of the Jamaican slaves, everything tonight seemed to be normal and the authorities believed that it would remain so.

James H. Higgins, former publisher and treasurer of The Boston Herald, who on July 12, 1912, effected a consolidation of The Boston Herald and The Boston Traveler, died this afternoon in Central Valley, N. Y. His age was 78.

Bainbridge Ave (12-3295), w s, 92 ft s of 198th St, 74x94; Ansal Realty, Inc, to Anna C. Krauss, 4,324 Carpenter Ave; mtg $77,925.. 166th St (9-2371), n e cor of Washington Ave, 86x50; H Z Realty Corp to Nuko Estates, Inc, 250 W 57th St; mtg $50,000.

Norma Shearer today announced her withdrawal from the role of Scarlett O'Hara in Margaret Mitchell's "Gone With the Wind," which David O. Selznick is to make as a motion picture. Attributing her decision to fan mail, in which a substantial number of correspondents voiced their opinion that she was unsuited for the part, Miss Shearer made her decision known through the M-G-M publicity department.

The young man standing on a seventeenth-story ledge of the Hotel Gotham last Tuesday, intent on suicide despite the pleas of relatives and friends, epitomized a universal tragedy, the Rev. Dr. William Ward Ayer, pastor of Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fiftyseventh Street, said in his sermon last night.

Life should be based on "an intelligent faith lying between scientific b unbelief and unreasoning, blind faith," the Rev. Dr. Frederick W. Norwood, special preaching missioner of the Free Church Council of Great Britain, said in his sermon yesterday morning at Riverside Church.
Anthony Orth of Wilmington today won two of the three inboard championships in the tenth annual regatta of the West End Boat Club on the Delaware River.

Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Quackenbush of Ridgewood, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Ann Quackenbush, to Jay Gorman, son of Jay E. Gorman of Jersey City, N. J., and the late Mrs. Gorman.

Rep to a resentative Clare E. Hoffman, who last week made public a letter to the National Labor Relations Board challenging its power to rule on matters affecting freedom of speech and of the press, today released a second communication, based on the board's answer.
Father Joseph Lynch, director of the seismological laboratory at Fordham, tells us that the only known earthquake which originated in New York City started in 1894 in a barroom on Tenth Street.
The lard and cottonseed oil markets have parted company in the last few months and put the former in a much better competitive position than for some time.

A MAGIC square, as most people know, is made by so arranging a progression of numbers in a square that each row, horizontal, vertical or diagonal, adds up to the same sum. Mystics, mathematicians and mere idle puzzlers have pored over these squares for centuries, but Claude Bragdon was apparently the first to put them to practical use.

As it to throw the tenth Malvern Drama Festival opening tomorrow into greater relief, London will have no opening this week. Malvern's first week will begin with five premieres, leading off with Shaw's political harleauinade, "Geneva."

Charles Andrew Ditmas, a descendant of one of the original Dutch settlers in the old Flatlands section of Brooklyn and a member of many patriotic and historical societies, died of a heart ailment at his home, 60 Amersford Place, Brooklyn, late Saturday night after. an illness of two weeks.

Miss Margaret Therese Moore, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Robert Moore of the Bronx. wa? married to Dr. Maurice Joseph Costello, son of Mrs. Maurice P. Costello, also of New York, and the late Mr: Costello, Saturday morning in the Church of Our Lady of Refuge, the Rev. Francis Kelly officiating.

Applications are now open for the followIng position in the City Service. Details are available at the office of the Municipal Civil Service Commission. Municipal Building, or In The City Record. There are physical and residence requirements.

With Elbridge T. Gerry scoring the winning goal one minute from the end of the final period, Aknusti of Long Island came from behind to defeat Monmouth County of Shrewsbury, 5 to 4, at the Burnt Mills Polo Club's Schley Field today in a national junior championship semifinal.

Mrs. Charles L. Hulswit, a prime mover in the "women's rebellion," announced here today that her organization would invade New York City to fight against the alliance there of Republicans and the American Labor Party. Recently she opened a nation-wide drive against New Deal candidates.

Signs of business improvement have multiplied in the past month, business confidence is strengthening rapidly and production and prices are turning upward, according to the American Federation of Labor's monthly survey of business published today.

Pestered by letter writers and visitors eager to provide names for new city high schools, Mayor La Guardia made public yesterday a note to James Marshall, president of the Board of Education, hinting strongly at just how he felt about the situation. The note read:

A giant medicine cabinet with a glass shelf strong enough to sustain a man's weight will be one of the features of the exhibits in the Hall of Pharmacy Building at the New York World's Fair, it was announced yesterday.

The Tri-State Dairy Committee, composed of representatives from Wisconsin, Minnesota and Iowa who met last week in Minneapolis, set $400,000 as the minimum goal for financing a national promotional campaign to expand the market for butter and other dairy products, according to Ralph E. Ammon, director of this State's Department of Agriculture and Markets.
Although comparative quiet has been restored here after last week's disturbances, a serious outbreak of rioting and looting occurred in Mandalay last night.
Japanese forces attempting to drive deep into Kiangsi Province from Kiukiang were reported today to have shattered three Chinese divisions in twenty-four hours.

New York City leads the rest of the United States in the application of the merit system in municipal employment, according to the fifty-fourth annual report of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, now nearing completion.

Announcement was made today by the National Labor Relations Board that it had dismissed the petition for investigation and certification of representatives of employes of the Century Woven Label Company, at Prospect Park, N. J.

Joseph Ward Lewis, lawyer and former city clerk and newspaper editor here, died today of cerebral meningitis at his home. His age was 71. Born in Great Barrington, Mr. Lewis was graduated from Wesleyan University in 1888.

Drawing will take place today for the special panel of 300 veniremen from which the jury will be picked for the trial on Aug. 15 of James J. Hines, Tammany district leader, and his co-defendant, Martin Weintraub, an attorney, charged with conspiracy in connection with the $100,000,000-a-year policy racket headed by the late Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer.
Joseph F. Cullman, oldest trustee of Mount Sinai Hospital and a member of its board for the last forty-one years, died yesterday at his residence, 146 Central Park West, at the age of 83.

With Merrill May collecting five consecutive safeties and featuring a 23-hit attack, Newark today romped to a 17-to-4 victory over Montreal, which has not won a game at Ruppert Stadium in nine starts this season.
The official Prager Press today welcomes the Salonika pact granting Bulgaria the right to rearm and states that the agreement will be a good example for Hungary to follow.
Professor Harold Henry Joachim, philosophical writer, Wykeham Professor of Logic at Oxford and a fellow of New College, 1919-35, died today at the age of 70.

Mr. and Mrs. Walter R. Harner of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Virginia Harner, to Lieutenant William T. Colman, United States Army, son of Mr. and Mrs. Shirley T. Colman of Dunkirk, N. Y.

A showdown on the conflict of authority between the State of Iowa and the Federal Government was postponed today, when Madison Hill, trial examiner of the National Labor Relations Board, delayed for forty-eight hours the hearing scheduled in the case against the Maytag Company, manufacturers of washing machines.

Chartered Investors, Inc., reported yesterday a net asset value of $5,489,628 as of June 30, equal to $8.77 each on 170,000 common shares, against $4,613,915, or $3.12 a share, on March 31, and $5,360,441, or $7.38 a share, on Dec. 31.

Chancellor Adolf Hitler's newspaper,- Voelkischer Beobachter, today took the occasion of this twenty-fourth anniversary of Imperial Germany's declaration of war on Russia to reiterate the repeated assertion that Germany did not want war then and does not now.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Aug. 1, unless specified: At San Diego: Arctic, Kanawha. At Washington: Potomac, July 30; Badger, Decatur, Herbert Leary, J. F. Talbott. At Norfolk: Rabbitt, Dickerson, Roper, Schenck, Tillman.

Sir Norman William Raeburn, a prominent Admiralty lawyer who on Friday was removed from the post of arbitrator in a shipping collision case because he was reported to have made contemptuous references to the veracity of Italians and Portuguese, tonight denied he had made such remarks.

Startling reports from Seoul, Korea, and Tokyo to the effect that Soviet airplanes bombed and machine-gunned Changkufeng and near-by points inside Korea are having an electrifying effect here. Russian retaliation for the Japanese capture of Changkufeng was not unexpected.

Mrs. Jean Flower, in 59 W 71st St; Harry S. Bernstein, in 215 W 83d St; J. Heine, In 60 W 68th St, Apartment Renting Co, Inc, broker. Gladys Weber, John Crane, in 19 E 98th St; Warren L. Marks, Daniel Brener, Inc.

Earl Baldwin, former Prime Minister, who in a speech some years ago said he was forced to keep his "lips sealed" on tremendous secrets of State making British rearmament a vital necessity, intends to be equally discreet concerning everything that happened during his entire public career.

Mrs. Jean Cochran Atwell, well known socially in New York City, won an uncontested, private-trial divorce decree here today from George J. Atwell Jr. The divorce was granted by District Judge Clark J. Guild on grounds of cruelty.

Railroad earning statistics for the first six months of the current year issued today by the Interstate Commerce Commission show net railway operating income for Class I roads at 76.5 per cent below the same period of 1937.

Mr. and Mrs. Leonard A. Hockstader gave a dinner tonight at Sarosca Farms, their home here, for Mr. Hockstader's mother, Mrs. Albert F. Hockstader of New York, in celebration of her ninetieth birthday.
Narragansett Park's first race meeting in almost a year got under way today, with Don Christmas's Accolade, a 9-to-1 shot, accounting for the $5,000-added Narragansett Handicap.

Leaders of the Women's Rebellion, angry at the local RepublicanLabor party alliance, called upon Kenneth F. Simpson, Republican county chairman and Republican National Committeeman, yesterday afternoon, to vent their wrath upon him only to be told, they said, that Representative James W. Wadsworth, up-State Republican conservative, had suggested the coalition.
Four six-meter yachts that excelled in tests last week and were chosen as the United States representatives to oppose a British team here early in September, began another series of trials today.
The Constitutional Convention, at 12:30 o'clock this morning, gave its approval, by advancing to third reading, the proposal for greater home rule for New York and the other cities in the State.

Evidence of frauds in the manipulation of insurance fund payroll audits was furnished yesterday to the District Attorneys of New York, the Bronx and kings Counties by Bernard Botein, general attorney for the State Insurance Fund.

Telephone - operating subsidiaries of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation in nine foreign countries 'reported yesterday an aggregate gain of 34,816 telephones for the first six months of 1938, about 4,400 more than were added in the same period of 1937.

Hot dogs, cocktails and other foreign-named delicacies lost their identities as such today through Fascist disapproval. The Merchants Confederation invited buyers, restaurants, coffee shops, beach resorts and similar establishments to drop these "exotic and foreign names."

Five Girl Scouts and a Scout leader, who will represent the United States at an international encampment from Aug. 11 to 29 at Adelboden, Switzerland, will meet for the first time at a luncheon today at the Belmont Plaza Hotel.

Hedging pressure and fairly general liquidation carried all deliveries of wheat, corn, oats and rye to new low levels for the season today. All except corn sold at the lowest levels on the Board of Trade here since- 1922.

The Commercial Investment Trust Corporation reported yesterday combined net earnings of $7,886,166 for half year, equal after preference dividends to $2.31 a share on 3,314,554 common shares, compared with $11,573,865, or $3.43 a share on 3,312,585 common shares, in the 1937 period.

IT was Hank Gowdy, Old. Goldenrod, who brought up the subject of superstition among ball players. In the olden days Hank caught for the Boston Braves when the late George Stallings was managing that club. Stallings, called the Miracle Man when his Braves of 1914 came from last place in late July to sweep over the Athletics in four games in the world series, was a great character.
The bodies of Mrs. Ann Bowman, a young widow, and Henry Murray, 28, were found today in the woman's trailer parked near the Allegheny County Airport.

Major Gen. Sir Frederic Manley Glubb, who, as chief engineer of Great Britain's Second Army, directed the construction of defenses at the second battle of Ypres during the World War, died here today at the age of 81.
Staten Island is to have a Weather Bureau all to itself, but we must not jump to conclusions.

Back to the hangar where he and his aides spent months in preparation for their world-circling flight, Howard Hughes returned today. A few minutes later he as plunged into another of the civic celebrations which have marked his crosscountry tour.

The twenty-third annual Race Week series of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association started here today and of the ninety-eight boats that started only fifty completed the four-and-three-eighths-mile triangular course.

Mr. and Mrs. Edward S. Slater of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Theona Slater, to the Rev. R. Kenneth Smelser, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roy C. Smelser of Altoona, Pa. The wedding will take place on Aug. 17. After Sept. 1 the couple will reside at Winnebow, N. C.

Among the contracts for commercial space reported by brokers yesterday was one for a large unit of space on the third floor of the building at 417 Fifth Avenue taken by Case Co., Inc., old lace and novelty importing firm. Albert B.

Detectives of the Missing Persons Bureau at 6 o'clock last night broadcast an eight-State teletype alarm for Patrolman Jacob Shaver, 32 years old, of 486 Greene Avenue, Brooklyn, reported as missing from his apartment since Sunday.

3d St, 227-9 E, 46x96.2; S. F. Construction Co to Maxkott Realty Corp, 347 E 10th St, mtg $58,200 and p m mtg $6,000; ($13). 47th St, 346 W, 25x100.5; Katharina Laub to Flora Snydecker, 2,406 Ave S, Brooklyn, and another, 1st mtg $11,875 and 2d mtg, $25,625 held by grantee; ($26).

Trading opened slow on most classes of locally dressed meats in the markets yesterday. Veal appeared to be in best demand at last week's close and most packers are completely sold out. Fresh pork cuts were steady to lower and other classes of traefer meats were little changed from last Friday.

The Alleghany Corporation, top holding company in the old Van Sweringen rail empire, was charged today by the Securities and Exchange Commission with making "false and misleading statements concerning its assets, liabilities, profit and loss and surplus accounts" in its financial statements for the years 1934 to 1937, inclusive.

Review of the first twenty of the 1,500 protested. Federal income. tax cases in this district was begun yesterday morning by the division of the technical staff. of the Bureau of Internal Revenue designated for duty here.

Democratic leadership at Albany is playing with a dangerous idea. That idea is to make a partisan issue of the work of the State Constitutional Convention. According to our dispatches, "it is believed that the Democrats do not want any number of really popular issues to be presented to the people in the Fall by the Republicans."
Pretournament favorites swept through the first round of the national junior and boys' tennis championships today after getting a late start because of wet courts.

As part of a program for Intensifying their campaign to increase trade between this country and Brazil, the Brazilian Information Bureau, at 551 Fifth Avenue, will set up an elaborate display of the commercial and artistic products of the country, next month.

Dr. Gustavus Adolphus Eisen, an authority on biology, archaeology, zoology, anthropology and other fields of learning, celebrated his ninety-first birthday yesterday. Dr. Eisen, who was born in Stockholm, Sweden, on Aug. 2, 1847, and came to this country at the age of 26, spent the day quietly.

Police Commissioner Valentine and 500 members of the Police Department, including members of the Police Square Club and the Shomrim Society, yesterday afternoon escorted the body of Inspector Louis Rosenfeld, 46 years old, of 1,650 Seventy-second Street, Brooklyn, to Mount Zion Cemetery, Maspeth.
1,200 men comprising the 113th Infantry, New Jersey National Guard, commanded by Colonel John F. Lee Jr. of Paterson, arrived here today for tactical manoeuvres, which will continue through Friday.
William A. Baker, an instructor in the New Jersey Reformatory and a former advertising executive, died of a heart attack in his office here this morning. He was 67 years old.

MANHATTAN BERNSTEIN, CLARA GROEDEL (July I 22). Estate, more than $10,000. To T. Henry Bernstein, son, 40 E. 66th St., household effects, two-thirds residue in trust with parts of principal at different periods and remainder in one-third residue: Eugene Traugott Bernstein. husband.

In bringing the catapult seaplane Nordmeer safely down on Manhasset Bay today at 2:05 P. M., Captain Joachim von Blankenburg, 39-year-old German commercial pilot, became a veteran of 100 flights over various parts of the Atlantic Ocean.

Theresa Helburn of the Theatre Guild's board of managers, who has been a director, producer, playwright and dramatic critic, finally got around to making her professional stage debut at the Westport Country Playhouse tonight when she appeared in the cast of "Suzanna and the Elders," by Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Langner.
The International Anthropological and Ethnographical Sciences convention, the largest international gathering ever held in Denmark, was opened today by King Christian.
The 1937-38 world carryover of United States cotton, including linters, was put today at the high record of 13,803,000 bales in the annual report of the New Orleans Cotton Exchange.

Mr. and Mrs. Seth W. Morton gave a small dinner tonight at their cottage for Mr. and Mrs. William A. Whittlesey, Mr: and Mrs. L. Rodman Mack, Mr. and Mrs. D. Walter Mabee, Mrs. Silas B. Mason, Mrs. Henry McComb Bangs, Mrs. E. Elkins Wetherill, George H. Bull, Spencer B. Eddy and Addison M. Kelly.

Miss Joyce Watson Applegate, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Everitt Applegate of this place, was married tonight in South Presbyterian Church, here, to William Klaber Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. William Klaber, also of Montclair.

New Jersey municipalities reported today through Local Government Commissionersioner Walter R. Darby that they collected $4,251,374 more in taxes in the first six months of this year than in the same period of 1937.

Announcement has been made by Mrs. Hurin Martin Clements of 325 East Seventy-ninth Street of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Elizabeth Martin Clements, to Newcomb Debevoise Cole, son of Mrs. Newcomb B. Cole of New York and New Canaan, Conn., and the late Mr. Cole.

Although the Mexican Supreme Court ruled on July 26 in an oil company case that the expropriation law does not violate the anti-monopoly laws and, therefore, is constitutional and that the Federal Oil Administration operating the expropriated properties is constitutionally legal, other companies' cases challenging expropriation are still before the Supreme Court and have not yet been ruled upon.
The Commodity Exchange Administration reported today a decline in trading in cotton futures on the three organized Exchanges in July.
Charles La Due, 65, of New Rochelle, N. Y., a retired New York business man, drowned today while swimming off Candlewood Island where he was spending the Summer.

The world Congress of the International Federation of Business and Professional -Women opened here today. Among the several hundred delegates from all parts of the world are fifty-one from the United States.

A panel of 300 blue-ribbon talesmen, from which will be selected the jury that will hear the evidence against James J. Hines, Tammany district leader charged with participation in the Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer policy lottery gang, was drawn yesterday.
Automobile production declined less than seasonally last week, and the adjusted index rose to 36.9. This compared with 36.3 for the previous week and 104.9 for the week ended July 31, 1937.

Colonel Bill Terry yesterday purchased Chalmer W. (Bill) Cissell from Baltimore and will lose no time sending him into action against the Cubs at the Polo Grounds this afternoon in an effort to solve the problem at second base and extricate the Giants from their slump.

The most bitterly fought primary campaign that Missouri has had in eighteen years came to a close tonight with both sides claiming victory in the principal contest, which may prove a test of strength between Governor Lloyd C. Stark and Thomas J. Pendergast, Kansas City boss, or, in the civic mind, a test of the supremacy of St. Louis or Kansas City.

The Federal Trade Commission reported today that the Borden Company, 350 Madison Avenue, New York City, had agreed to discontinue advertising alleged excessive valuations in connection with certain premiums to purchasers of its dairy products.

Control of The Brooklyn Daily Eagle, founded in 1841, was acquired yesterday by Frank D. Schroth, former publisher of The Scranton (Pa.) Tribune and formerly associate publisher of The Trenton (N. J.) Times.
The navy staged on the West Coast today a record-breaking mass flight of long-range bombing planes. The flight-was 1,400 miles from Seattle to San Diego, and was that of Patrol Wing One,

The official Weather Bureau thermometer in New York reached 88 degrees yesterday afternoon, making it the third hottest day this year. The hottest day was last Friday when the temperature reached 90 degrees.
Senator William H. Smathers, Democrat of New Jersey, said today that at the end of his term he was "definitely determined to retire to the comfortable and leisurely routine of private life."
An auctioneer's hammer today began beating the death-knell of the last of the pretentious wild-west shows, Colonel Tim McCoy's Circus, which was thrown into bankruptcy here on May 31.

KINGS ACKERMAN, HARVEY B. (April 4). Gross assets, $25,314; net, $23,562. To wife, Jennie W. Ackerman and daughters, Audrey Baedeker and Izotta Bush, onethird of residuary estate each. Chief assets, real estate, $3,750; stocks and bonds, $298; mortgages, notes, cash and Insurance, $21,062; miscellaneous property, $203. McDermott Turner, attorneys, 165 Broadway. Manhattan.
Firstday sales of the stamps of the new regular series to be issued during September were announced today by the Postoffice Department as follows:

General Jose Miaja's central Spanish Government Army stormed and cap- half tured the strategic bluff of Camarena, thirteen miles south of Teruel, today, forcing Generalissimo Francisco Franco to hurry troops from other fronts to defend his Teruel lines.

Applications for building permits in Queens during July,1938, totaled $55,042,232, the highest for any month this year since January, when plans aggregating $60,450,181 were filed, according to John P. Riley, superintendent of the Queens bureau of the Department of Housing and Buildings.

When the Group Health Association, a medical cooperative, was organized in Washington with the direct encouragement of the Farm Loan Board Bank, the Journal of the American Medical Association called upon the United States District Attorney and the corporation counsel for the district to take appropriate action against "unlicensed, unregulated health insurance and the corporate practice of medicine." Now the tables are turned.
Sir David Shackleton, one of the earliest Labor Members of Parliament, died at his home in Saint Annes, Lancashire, today. His age was 74.
The bond market on the New York Stock Exchange was listless yesterday, but many issues advanced. Total sales were $3,820,125, compared with $6,371,000 on last Friday.

Rigid enforcement of all Park Department regulations governing the beach and Boardwalk at Coney Island will begin tomorrow, it was announced yesterday by Police Captain John J. Martin, in charge of the area.

Engineers Public Service Company and subsidiaries report a consolidated net income of $3,648,898 for the twelve months ended June 30, equal after preferred dividend requirements to 69 cents a share on 1,909,968 common shares, as compared to $3,293,755, or 51 cents a share, the year before.

Receipts from the cigarette tax indicate- that the tax will yield about three times as much as was originally expected, Almerindo Portfolio, City Treasurer, announced yesterday. The total collected for the first three months is $2,316,179.22, it was announced.

The presidents of six leading commodity exchanges and officials of the Department of Agriculture began studying today methods of protecting the public from alleged frauds by so-called "commodity counselors."

Competitive scholarships have been awarded to members of the incoming class at the University of Pennsylvania. All will provide free tuition for four years if the academic work of the recipients is satisfactory.
Manhattan properties involved in the realty deals reported yesterday included several multi-family dwellings in Harlem, as well as business parcels in midtown.

Baseball Game Between the teams of the Department of Sanitation and Fire Department, on Wednesday, Aug. 3, at 2 P. M. Game to be played at the Parade Grounds, Parkside Ave., Parade Pl. and Coney Island Ave., Brooklyn.
The international stock market indices for July 30, with comparisons, are as "follows, the basic figure of 100 representing conditions on the last Saturday in 1927:
George Boarman, 81-year-old steamship line employee, boasted today that his "twenty-sixth child," born yesterday, is "beautiful-just like all the others."
Nearly $14,000,000 assets were revealed today in the trust estate created under the will of Henry H. Houston of Germantown, who died forty-three years ago.

Mr. and Mrs. Harvey Dow Gibson gave a dinner at Land's End, their home in Locust Valley, tonight in honor of Douglas Montgomery, and took their guests afterward to the Red Barn Theatre to 'see the opening performance of "Playboy of the Western World," in which Mr. Montgomery has the leading role.

Traffic fines for the first seven months of 1938 increased $290,427, or 39.5 per cent, over the same period last year, it was shown yesterday in the monthly traffic report by Chief Magistrate Jacob Gould Schurman Jr.

Dr. Warren W. Knox was named today director of the Division of Secondary Education in the State Department of Education, Commissioner Frank P. Graves announced. He will have charge of the curriculum development in secondary schools. Dr.

Steel production in the United States is scheduled at.39.8 per cent of capacity this week, against 37 per cent last week, a gain of 2.8 points, or 7.6 per cent, the American Iron and Steel Institute announced yesterday. It is the highest rate since 41.0 per cent reported for the week of Nov. 8, 1937.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Reading Lord Catto's remarks on the manner in which Great Britain should settle the war debts to the United States, as reported in THE TIMES of July 30, I was reminded of Secretary Hull's address before the State Bar Association of Nashville, Tenn., when he said: "Solemn contractual obligations are brushed aside with a light heart and a contemptuous gesture."
Frederick J. Siemer, owner and proprietor of the Hotel St. George here, a landmark of the Hudson Valley, died today following a heart attack. He was 65 years old.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated July 29: COMMANDERS Haas, W. S., upon discharge from treatment at Naval Hospital, Pearl Harbor, T. H., to home and relieved of all active duty.

Viscount Runciman's approaching visit is being greeted by the Henlein press as a victory for the Henleinist cause. An editorial by one of the principal Henlein delegates, who had been negotiating with Premier Milan Hodza, was published tonight in the party's official organ Die Zeit.
The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended July 27:

A union limited in membership to the employes of a single business is as valid under the Wagner Labor Aot as an A. F. of L. or a C. I. O. union, the United States Circuit Court of Appeals held yesterday,
Josef Von Sternberg has been signed by Metro to direct Hedy Lamarr in her first picture for that studio. Several stories are under consideration with executive decision expected this week.
Miss Margaret Elizabeth Bassick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. Roscoe Bassick of San Francisco, will be married on Aug. 20 to Robert Cushman Munier, son of Dr. and Mrs. Vincent Munier of New York.

Elwood Cooke Jr. of Portland, Ore., went out in the first round of the forty-eighth annual Southampton invitation tournament on the windswept turf of the Meadow Club today to furnish the climax to one of the strangest opening days of tennis in many seasons.

A legislative commission investigating court procedure reported today the acquittal of Mary Keenan O'Connor of murder charges in the death of a child was "largely the result of a compromise reached through considerations foreign to every concept of orderly legal process."
The application of the Nuremberg laws to Austria beginning today dislocated the female domestic labor market so completely that authorities made further concessions.

The American Medical Association, faced with a Federal grand jury Investigation because of its fight against a cooperative health group, virtually challenged the Roosevelt Administration today to a court struggle which may have profound effects on the future of American medicine.
A seven-run first inning enabled Jersey City to coast to an 8-to-6 triumph over Buffalo in the first 16 game of their three-game series tonight.
Warrington G. Lawrence of Roselle, N. J., a retired New York architect, died Sunday, after a week's illness, at Portland Me., where he was spending the Summer.

A crowd of 10,000 saw Grey Streak win the Steger Handicap, inaugural feature at Washington Park today, after a rousing stretch duel with Silverette, the favorite. Mrs. A. M. Creech's thoroughbred scored by a length, with Mar Le third.
The Works Progress Administration spent $156,459,132 in this city in the fiscal year ended June 30, Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somerveil, local administrator, announced yesterday.

Two members of the Congressional investigating committee joined in close questioning which took on the tone of criticism today during testimony by officials of the Tennessee Valley Authority regarding the $680,000 purchase of 550 acres of phosphate rock by the Authority last year in a deal that netted the International Agricultural- Corporation, the seller, a profit of more than $500,000.

Magistrate Irving Ben Cooper ruled in Long Island City Court yesterday that a city license was not required for the operation of the midget automobile races presented by Andy Idone at Sixtyeighth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Place, Glendale, Queens.

Calling on the wool textile industry to establish a merchandising and price policy which gives some consideration to profit, Arthur Besse, president of the National Association of Wool Manufacturers, sent a bulletin yesterday to members of the industry which cited Internal Revenue Department figures showing losses aggregating $98,094,000 in the ten years from 1926 ?? 1935.

An air of optimism prevailed among 3,600 retailers of musical instruments and supplies as they gathered today for the music industries convention. Reports of good business and prospects of further improvement were voiced by trade leaders viewing the 200 exhibits.

Blackstone, driven by the veteran Doc Parshall, won the National Pace that featured the Grand Circuit racing at Agawam Park today. Blackstone, a black colt that has been one of the outstanding pacers this season, won the first heat in 2:07 and covered the mile oval in 2:08 1/4 in the second.

To meet the requirements of her undeclared war with China, Japan has sent to this country in the last sixteen months $346,600,000 of gold. China's sales of silver to our Treasury have unquestionably been of help to that country in financing the war.

Governor Robert E. Quinn today sent letters to the Governors and Senators of fourteen States asking that they cooperate in a movement to make Narragansett Bay the center of a naval defense area which would protect New England, New York and neighboring States.
Charles E. Bedaux, industrial surveyor, will probably be retained by the Greek Government as adviser upon a vast reorganization project affecting the country's whole economic structure.

Six Arab rebels were killed and many wounded and two British soldiers were wounded, one seriously, in an engagement last night between British troops and Arabs in the Nablus area. There were also several cases of sniping at Jews by Arab terrorists in various parts of Palestine.

By radio telephone from the liner Manhattan, which is bringing him home, Douglas Gorce Corrigan backed Mayor La Guardia yesterday in a dispute between Brooklyn and City Hall over the Corrigan reception plans, which dispute came to resemble the fair traditional at Donnybrook in the land to which the young aviator flew "by mistake."
Dr. Melvin M. Franklin, Philadelphia physician who served as a Colonel with the United States Army in the World War, died yesterday at his Summer home here after a heart attack. His age was 64.
Among those reported yesterday as having purchased property on Long Island was H. V. Kaltenborn, radio commentator, who bought a country estate in the Old Field South development at Stbny Brook.

It appeared that the mechanical age had won another victory over Mother Nature yesterday when the Park Department put its garden on wheels on display for the first time this year for the children of the lower East Side.

Jamaica's celebration of the 100th anniversary of "Emancipation Day" was marked by perfect order throughout the island. Its keynote was set last night in a public meeting of a semi-religious character in the principal theatre in Kingston.

The Westchester County Park Commission told the County Board of Supervisors at its regular meeting here today that the cost of repairing the recent flood damage to the county park system would be 50 per cent greater if done as a WPA project than it would be if done with county funds.

One of the most powerful liquor rings that ever operated in the United States, before or since prohibition, was revealed yesterday when Federal Judge T. Whitfield Davidson opened a sealed indictment against 103 of the ring's alleged members.

The Socony-Vacuum Oil Company announced yesterday in connection with the declaration of a semiannual dividend of 25 cents a share on the capital stock that the consolidated net income of the company for the first six months of this year was approximately $19,000,000, including the equity in undistributed earnings of nonconsolidated affiliated company.
Headed by Miss Dorothy May Bundy of Santa Monica, finalist at Seabright, a field of thirty-two players started out today in the annual invitation tennis tournament at the Maidstone Club.

Heim is launching the "Schweppes bottle silhouette." It is particularly notable in evening gowns with narrow welldefined waist, fullness on the hips and a narrowing in effect toward the hem. Some day coats having full-length fur stole collars show this outline; lofty fur turbans suggest a cork.

With New York City issues leading the way, real estate bonds in forty cities in the Eastern part of the United States increased more than 2 1/2 per cent during July, according to the Burr Co. index, which covers 250 properties.

Emilio Pennelli, 12 years old, of 65 Wright Avenue, who earns money shining shoes, walked into the Montgomery- Street police station today and told Sergeant William McClellan he had found a wallet in Journal Square.
A seven-ounce bottle of beer, priced to retail at 5 cents, will be marketed this month in all boroughs of the city by the Edelbrau Breweries of Brooklyn, officials of the company announced yesterday.

Getting from Alicante to Barcelona in Spain these days can involve extraordinary peregrinations, as your correspondent discovered in his rather frantic efforts to get around and cover the Republican [Loyalist] offensive in Catalonia.
Fighting between police and waterfront strikers resulted in the injury of thirty-six persons today, five of them critically, amid showers of buckshot and the use of at least one bayonet.
The rate on Treasury bills continued its the average rate for the $100,315,000 bills sold today reaching 0.062 per cent, compared with 0.059 per cent last week.

A group of bituminous coal producers, including the Mallory Coal Company of West Virginia, failed today to win an order from the United States Court of Appeals to bar the Bituminous Coal Commission from making public their individual cost reports.

Duplicating last years performance, Alex Antonio of Linden, N. J., today annexed the medal in the qualifying round of the annual tournament of the National Left-handers Golf Association, a 3-year-old organization founded by Benny Richter, noted St. Louis southpaw pro.

Two Long Island outfits will meet on a New Jersey field today to decide one of polo's major titles. Bostwick Field and Aknusti, paired in the final of the junior championship, are to. clash at 6 o'clock at the Burnt Mills Club in Bedminster.

Gaston de Clairville is taking over complete charge of the millinery department of The Tailored Woman, 729 Fifth Avenue. Immediately after Labor Day the entire main floor of the store will be given over to the enlarged millinery department.

The Public Service Company of Northern Illinois is calling for redemption on Oct. 1 all the $18,876,000 first and refunding-mortgage bonds due on Oct. 1, 1956, at 100 and accrued interest, besides a premium of 10 per cent.

A novel undertaking of "German socialism" to provide capital for the construction of the "world's largest automobile factory" was initiated today when Dr. Robert Ley, head of the German Labor Front, announced a nation-wide savings campaign for the subsequent acquisition of the much-propagandized, popular-priced "Volksauto."
Maurice B. Ruderow, manager of the Merchantville-Pensauken Water Commission and one of Merchantville's founders, died today of a heart attack at his home at the age of 80.

Karl Eisner,. 30 years old, of 612 East Ninety-sixth Street, Brooklyn, a postoffice clerk, died shortly after 10 o'clock last night, eight hours after having been shot accidentally while at work in sub-station P, 321 Thatford Avenue. Brooklyn.

Arthur B. Hancock, wellknown Kentucky breeder, brought off an upset today when his Recussion, a daughter of Gallant Fox from Percussion, was a driving winner by a length at 30 to 1 to the surprise of virtually all concerned.

In a halfempty court room at the beginning of the twelfth week of their trial on charges of conspiring to nullify the Wagner Labor Act, the coal operators and former deputy sheriffs of Harlan County learned that the jury could not agree on their guilt or innocence.

George Bernard Shaw's new play "Geneva," which opened the tenth annual Malvern theatre festival tonight, is a riotous criticism of the methods of Geneva, and, according to the critic of The Times of London, "should be received with relief by thick-andthin followers of Shaw."
The island of Anticosti, which German capitalists recently tried to acquire reputedly as the basis of a pulp and paper industry, is to become a base for Canadian naval and air defense.

HERE is John Strachey again, lecturing on how communism alone can save the world. His fierce though elastic wisdom is applied this time to a history of the British and American labor movements. The title is "What Are We to Do?"*

Six Newspaper Guild members, cited for contempt of court in connection with the C. I. O. union's strike against The Hollywood Citizen-News, must stand trial, Superior Judge Emmet Wilson ruled today. mmet Wilson rulled today.

The War Department announced today the commissioning of eighty-two officers of the National Guard of the United States. Included in the list were Major Casimir J. Odrovonz, 107th Infantry, of Jackson Heights, L. I.; Captain Charles H. Ruston, 174th Infantry, of Niagara Falls;

With thousands of jobless workers complaining that they are not getting-their due in unemployment insurance, Paul Sifton, executive director of the division of placement and unemployment insurance of the State Labor Department, has handed in his resignation, effective at the will of the Industrial Commissioner, it was learned last night.
Mr. and Mrs.- Horace 0. Kilbourn of 125 East Seventy-fourth Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sarah V. D. Kilbourn, to Robert 0. Fickes of Westport, Conn.

Another consignment of $5,800,000 gold has been engaged in Japan for shipment here, it was announced yesterday at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The bank also reported the arrival at San Francisco of $5,433,000 gold from Japan.

A plan of reorganization for the United Telephone and Electric Company, submitted by the company's reorganization managers, and the declarations covering securities to be issued under the plan were approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Although the turnover was small in a slow session today, the Bourse was fairly firm and prices closed irregularly higher. The carryover loan rate on the fortnightly settlement remains at 2 per cent, and money was most abundant at that level.

" If railroad credit is to be worth anything at all in the future, an issue of bonds occupying as strong a position on every basis as do the Des Plaines bonds should at least receive new fixed-interest obligations, properly secured directly or collaterally, bearing interest at 4 1/2 per cent, and having maturity date not later than 1947,"
The steelhelmeted Mobile Guards, the cream of France's fighting forces. and her "reservoir of wartime officers," is being increased from 17,000 to 30,000, army orders disclosed today.
Twenty-two thousand home relief recipients will get false teeth as the result of a contract signed yesterday by the City Welfare Department and nine privately operated dental laboratories.

Soviet forces hurled back a Japanese division in the disputed Changkufeng zone on the Siberian-Manchukuoan border after a two-day battle in which artillery, tanks and planes were used, it was declared in a government communique issued here tonight.

For nearly five hours yesterday, District Attorney William F. X. Geoghan of Brooklyn stood in a crowded courtroom and heard a succession of witnesses give testimony naming two of his staff assistants in connection with an alleged conspiracy to "fix" a criminal case, placing one act of the conspiracy in the prosecutor's own office.

Albert Gross, 55 years old, an exconvict who frequents night clubs, was arrested yesterday on a charge of grand larceny made by a Brooklyn housewife. She said she had given him $750 in the Cotton Club, 200 West Forty-eighth Street,

Announcement has been made here of the marriage of Miss Annette Mary Reddington, daughter of Martin F. Reddington of Rye, N. Y., and the'late Mrs. Reddington, to George W. Fennell Jr., son of Mrs.. Fennell of Mamaroneck, N. Y., and the late Mr. Fennell, which took place Sunday in St.

The ten-room house at 29 Magnolia Avenue, Larchmont Manor Westchester County, was sold by the estate of Ethel Kingston to N. Kennedy. The dwelling, which is on a plot 50 by 100 feet, was formerly the home of Samuel Kingston, theatrical producer. John F.

On the eve of the annual general meeting today of the Theatrical Managers, Agents and Treasurers Union, Broadway press agents who are members of the organization were being urged yesterday to protect themselves against the "railreading" of the union's newly drafted constitution.

War to a finish against Henry E. Wallace, Secretary of Agriculture, was declared today by J. E. McDonald, Texas Secretary of Agriculture. Mr. McDonald announced he would lead the farmers of this State in a revolt against what he charged were dictatorial and high-handed practices of Mr. Wallace in sending two of his department's agents into the cotton belt of Texas to make speeches against the domestic allotment farm plan.

Because of a downpour shortly before concert time, last night's Lewisohn Stadium program by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under Willem van Hoogstraten, was presented in the Great Hall of City College.

Supreme Court Justice Francis G. Hooley in Brooklyn reserved decision yesterday. after hearing arguments on a motion- for a temporary injunction to restrain the city and William F. Carey, Commissioner of Sanitation, from proceeding with a plan to dump refuse in Jamaica Bay.

Labeling of weighted silk products with exact percentages may bring about misleading trade descriptions and advertising, G. H. Conze, president of the National Federation of Textiles, Inc., declares in a statement which will be presented to the Federal Trade Commission at a hearing in Washington today on the rules proposed by the commission to govern use of the word "silk" in the textile industry.
