Edward J. Timmons, the first police chief of New Rochelle, died here today at the home of his sonin-law, Councilman Herbert P. Milligan. He was 84 years old. Mr. Timmons had been ill of pneumonia since he suffered a fall last Friday.

After beating and choking his wife and attempting to throw her overboard, Robert Moore Duncan, 35 years old, an assistant professor of politics at Colgate University, disappeared from the liner Normandie and is believed to have committed suicide by jumping into the ocean, it was disclosed yesterday when the Normandie docked here.

With $10,000,000 in gold, representing about half the Mexican Government's total reserve now in deposit in the Federal Reserve Bank in New York, the government has started to move fiat money into circulation through government land banks in order to finance the wheat and cotton crops and to attempt to loosen credit restrictions.

All livestock uncovered a lower market trend today. Fed steers closed mostly 25 cents lower and fat lambs 35 to 50 cents off, the United States Department of Agriculture reported. Hogs sold actively on a weak to 10 cents lower market.

Ten manufacturers of millinery selling up to $7.50 a dozen met last night at the offices of the Eastern Women's Headwear Association, 1,440 Broadway, to discuss various means of ending evils in the industry.
A "stork derby" with sweepstakes prizes for prolific parents was proposed in the New South Wales Legislature today to boost Aus-. tralia's falling birth rate.

The C.I. O., the American Civil Liberties Union and other plaintiffs inan application to restrain Jersey City officials from enforcing ordinances regulating the distribution of circulars and the holding of meetings were charged here today by James A. Hamill, Corporation Counsel of Jersey City, with coming into Federal court with "unclean hands."
Japanese attacks are making little headway against Chinese positions southeast of Kiukiang and along the western shores of Poyang Lake, reports received here from the Yangtze front indicate.

The first payment in the WPA's purchase of $10,000,000 of surplus clothing for men and boys on home relief will be made by check at 11:30 A. M. today in the State procurement offices of the Treasury Department at 76 Ninth Avenue.

The railroads land the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen continued their debate today over the proposed 15 per cent wage cut. At the end of the meeting the two groups were about where they started on July 18.

Rear Admiral Forde A. Todd arrived aboard the cruiser Philadelphia today and was the honored guest at a large tea given at the Kebo Valley Golf Club. The other guests included Major and Mrs. George G. McMurtry, Mr. and Mrs. A. Barclay Ulman, Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Stevenson, Mrs.
The old and the new in army equipment were merged in a demonstration today for 457 members of West Point's first. class, here for a tenday inspection of the infantry's gr weapons and methods.

Edmund C. Tarbell, famous portrait painter, died in his home here today at the age of 76, after a brief illness. He had painted portraits of Marshal Foch, Calvin Coolidge, Woodrow Wilson, Herbert Hoover and other noted personages.

Joseph, on July 30, beloved husband of Sarah,' devoted father of Lena Ginsburg, Charles I., Birdie Hymes; Beadle Holland, Lillian Goldberg, Ben, Ida Steinman, Mildred. Shiva at late residence. 325 Riverside Drive.

After thirty-eight years of virtual nullification. the Puerto Rican Supreme Court today upheld a Congressional resolution of 1900 limiting to 500 acres the lands held by the agricultural corporations. Specifically the court ordered Rubert Hermanos, Inc.,

A banking group composed Blyth Co., Inc.; R. H. Moulton Co. and Kaiser Co. received the award yesterday of an issue of $3,000,000 general fund registered warrants of the State of California nn a bid of 100.041232 for 0.75s.

John Mark Fitzpatrick of 1,862 East Twenty-seventh Street, Brooklyn, a veteran of forty-nine years' service in the composing room of THE NEW YORK TIMES, died at 6:15 o'clock last night in the Brooklyn Hospital of an intestinal ailment.

Fashion Clinic, Millinery Merchandising Executives Association, Inc., Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, all day, beginning 9:30 A. M. Luncheon, 12:30 P. M. Luncheon meeting, Lions Club, Hotel Astor, 12:30 P. M. "Buy American Promotes American Jobs," Captain F. X. A. Eble.

The law of averages took a licking when two aces were scored within ten minutes today on the 167-yard second hole at the Ballston Spa Country Club. Playing with a fivesome, Club Champion Duane C. Fuller holed out a No. 3 iron shot from the tee.

Many State officials and leaders of the Republican and Democratic parties in New Jersey today attended a funeral service here for Jesse R. Salmon, long-time chairman of the Essex County Republican Committee.
The new apartment building on a plot 100 by 200 feet at 1,701-21 Avenue N, Brooklyn, was purchased by 1,717 Avenue N, Inc., represented by Moses H. Hoenig, attorney.

Tony Galento, heavyweight pugilist, who is recovering from a siege of pneumonia in the Orange Memorial Hospital, today issued a statement requesting his friends and admirers not to visit him until he regains his health.

Formation of the Dress Manufacturers Institute for workmen's compensation insurance, to survey accidents occurring during dress production, was announced yesterday by Louis Rubin, executive chairman of the Popular Price Dress Manufacturers Group.

Britain protested to Japanese authorities today against what was called the "increasingly belligerent attitude" of sentries guarding bridges from the International Settlement into Japanese - controlled sections of Shanghai.

The wholesale price level was slightly higher in the week ended July 30, according to the commodity price index compiled by the National Fertilizer Association. The index stood at 74.7, compared with 74.6 in the preceding week, 74.2 a month ago and 88.3 a year ago, based on the 1926-28 average as 100.

Half of Britain sizzled today in a heat wave while a large area was submerged by freak floods. A death toll of thirteen already had been tabulated as record crowds of vacationists in Southern England began the last day of the three-day bank holiday. Two of the deaths were from prostration in heat of 85 degrees.

The Government of Peru opened yesterday a Peruvian Information Bureau here at 21 West Street, under the direction of Luis M. Alzamora. Mr. Alzamora said the new organization would attempt to make Peru better known in this country and promote trade and cultural interchange between the two countries.

Six subsidiaries of the North Boston Lighting Properties have filed, under the Holding Company Act, declarations covering the issuance of 3 per cent notes evidencing loans by the parent company, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.
A six-story apartment house for sixty families in Elmhurst, Queens, was the largest project for which plans were filed in the city yesterday.

The number of commercial and industrial failures in the United States for the week ended July 28 was 219, which compares with 158 a year ago and 206 a week ago, according to figures released yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Joe Balestri, Washington bookbinder, played the waterlogged Edgewood Country Club course today in 36, 39-75 to take the lead in the first round of the fifteenth annual seventy-two-hole Union Printers International Golf Association tournament.

Submitting a financial report for the period from Feb. 14, 1934, to March 31, 1938, the Austin Silver Mining Company revealed yesterday current assets of $2,376, current liabilities of $84,178 and a deficit of $28,563 on March 31.

The Federal Maritime Commission is studying a plan for the centralizing at Hoboken of the terminal operations of the governmentowned merchant ship lines that serve the Port of New York, it was learned yesterday.

Major the Hon. Ambrose T. Gosling and Mrs. Gosling, who had been at the Madison, have returned to their home in Paget, Bermuda. Mrs. Page Morris, who has been passing the Summer in West Newton, Mass., has come to the RitzCarlton.

Dr. Frank M. Rochford, a specialist in diseases of children, who had been a member of the board of governors of the Misericordia Hospital for the last twenty years, died Sunday at his home, 476 Clinton Avenue, Brooklyn, after an illness of four days.

The British Dental Association at its annual conference here today urged the government to limit refugee dentists from Austria admitted to Britain to fifty. The action was taken after it was pointed out that the British Medical Association already had limited the possible number of Austrian doctors to be admitted to that figure.
The big guns of the Tigers were spiked today by Pitchers Lee Ross and Edgar Smith of the Athletics, who combined to blank Detroit, 4 to 0, with nine hits and end the Bengals' winning streak at eight.

Young matrons and debutantes of this and recent seasons are taking an active interest in the plans for "The Hampton Follies of 1938," to be presented by members of the Summer colony the nights of Aug. 25 and 26 in the auditorium of the Southampton High School for the benefit of the Southampton Fresh Air Home for Crippled Children.

The twelfth annual national contract championships under the auspices of the American Contract Bridge League opened in Convention Hall here today with an imposing field of entrants listed for the week of play.

Bricks from the eighty-year-old home of the late John D. Rockefeller at 4 West Fifty-fourth Street, which was torn down last month, will be used in a house his granddaughter, Mrs. David M. Milton Jr., the former Abby Rockefeller, is planning to build on the Rockefeller estate at Pocantico Hills, N. Y., it was learned yesterday.

Federal Judge T. Whitfield Davidson of Texas, who is sitting in this district temporarily, yesterday put the case of the government against four alleged German spies on the trial calendar for Aug. 22.
The midsummer conference of the program committee of the Republican National Committee, with 150 men and women present, began today.

The Securities and Exchange Commission issued today its first denial of an application for exemption from the provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act. The applicant was the Houston Natural Gas Corporation.
The largest wheat crop since the World War is expected this year in the Northern Hemisphere, according to estimates made by the International Institute of Agriculture in Rome.

Touched off by a bolt of lightning, an explosion destroyed two storage buildings of the du Pont Company's powder nills at Moosic, ten miles south of here, late this afternoon. Three workmen were injured, none seriously.

The Cunard White Star liner Aquitania is due today from Southampton and Cherbourg. Among her passengers are Countess Laszlo Szechenyi and three daughters, Lord Davies, Lord Queensborough and two daughters, V. A. L. Mallet, counselor to the British Embassy;

The four-story building containing two stores and fifteen apartments at 571-573 Hudson Avenue, southwest corner of Fourteenth Street, West New York, N. J., was sold by the Commercial Trust Company of New Jersey to the Fourteenth and Hudson Corporation, Jacob Weisberg, president.

Mayor Reading of Detroit has been warned by Secretary Ickes that bidding methods of construction industries in the Detroit area are in contravention of PWA requirements, seriously jeopardizing, if allowed to continue, pending allotments to the city and vicinity.

Five persons were killed today when their car collided with the Pennsylvania stream-lined Broadway Limited on the eastern outskirts of Gary. None of the train passengers was injured, but the locomotive was so badly disabled that it was necessary to transfer the passengers to the Liberty Limited for the remainder of the trip to Chicago.
Edward Oliver, Wilmington (Del.) professional, won the first annual South Jersey open . golf championship at the Atlantic City Country Club today.

The crash of two New York Central limited trains, the Mercury and the Commodore Vanderbilt, last night in a rear-end collision east of here left thirty-eight injured persons in hospitals today and others with minor hurts.

The first city-wide Summer conference of the Association of Christian Youth Movements of America, designed to reach the youth of the world with the Gospel, opened yesterday morning in the Alliance Auditorium, Eighth Avenue and Forty-fourth Street, and will continue for five days, closing Friday night.

Robert E. Neis, director and city purchasing agent of Monroe Mich., told the Senate Civil Liberties Committee today that an official of the Republic Steel Corporation paid $1,566.80 for the munitions purchased and used by the city police and special deputies during the 1937 "Little Steel" strike.

The Transit Commission reported yesterday that the elevated train crash at the 110th Street station of the Ninth Avenue line was due to "man failure" and not to any defects of equipment. Of the seventyfive or more passengers in the three-car train that was rammed in the rear by an empty train, ten were hurt and three had to be taken to Harlem Hospital for treatment. They were able to go home later.

When the seaplane Nordwind was catapulted from. the mother ship Friesenland at 7 o'clock last night it carried an unofficial passenger. This was Captain Hans Bertram of the German Air Service, who formed an addition to the plane's crew as a nonpaying guest, rated as a third pilot.
Compilation of Stock Exchange activities for the whole of July adds emphasis to the midsummer movement of investment prices which, in very unusual degree, has perplexed even Wall Street.

For weeks the friends of Governor Chandler have charged that the Kentucky WPA was being used for the advantage of Senator Barkley. The Barkleyites have replied that the State machine and, in particular the old-age assistance division of the State Welfare Department, is being used for the advantage of the Governor.

Debits to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended July 27, aggregated $6,918,000,000, or 15 per cent below the total reported for the preceding week and 17 per cent below the total for the corresponding week of last year.
M. S. Novik, director of the Municipal Broadcasting System, disclosed yesterday that the Federal Communications Commission had authorized the city's radio station;

The relief office for this township, which has been caring for 1,100 families comprising slightly more than 4,000 persons, closed its doors today by order of Mayor August F. Greiner, who said no more relief would be issued until the State contributed funds he said were overdue.
America's picked athletes dominated the international track meet in White City Stadium today in spite of the combined opposition from sixteen other nations.

An event of first-rate importance is the agreement just reached by Bulgaria and the states of the Balkan Entente. By this pact Bulgaria's neighbors abrogate the military clauses of the Treaty of Neuilly and the Convention of Lausanne,

For the second successive week and week-end as compared to the corresponding period of 1937 the death toll in motor accidents in New York City showed a marked increase, according to figures released yesterday by the safety bureau of the Police Department.

GOVERNORS ISLAND So much of paragraph 6, Special Orders 96, dated April 26, as continues Capt. William H. Colgan, Sn.-Res., on active duty with the CCC until Oct. 31, is amended so as to continue Capt. Colgan on active duty with the CCC until July 29.

Vigorous opposition to the proposed amendment to the State Constitution setting up a new and separate judicial district for Nassau and Suffolk Counties was made yesterday by the Board of Supreme Court Justices residing in Nassau County.
The Transit Commission reported yesterday that the elevated train crash at the 110th Street station of the Ninth Avenue line was due to "man failure" and not to any defects of equipment.
A lawn party will be given by the Art Association Wednesday afternoon. Mrs. Le Brun Rhinelander is the chairman. Mrs. Isabel Thorndike Phelps has been made chairman of the special prizes.

While pushcart vendors hawked plums and potatoes to teeming bargain-seekers just across Twelfth Street, four young men with pistols awed nineteen persons in the east side branch of the Bank of Naples Trust Company, 196 First Avenue, yesterday afternoon and vanished with at least $50,000 in cash.

The manufacturers' excise taxes, with a revenue of about $417,000,000 in the fiscal year ended June 30, expire at the end of the current fiscal year and may be permitted to lapse by Congress at the next session if a substitute can be found for this revenue, Treasury officials indicated today.
Rain interrupted the cricket match between Glamorgan and the Australians at Swansea today and there was no play after teatime. At that stage Glamorgan had 148 for five wickets.

A man who telephoned the Metropolitan Billiard Club, at 225 West Fifty-seventh Street, in the name of a member to ask if he could cash a check for $300 called at the fourthfloor club a few minutes later last night and robbed the safe of $317.

The Committee on the Municipal Court of the Bar Association of the City of New York announced yesterday that it had adopted a resolution urging all political parties and independent groups to nominate Justice Matthew M. Levy to succeed himself in the First Bronx Municipal Court District.

Editorial, art, photographic and business department employes of King Features Syndicate, which includes International News Service and International News Photos, have voted, 290 to 253, against naming the American Newspaper Guild to represent them in collective bargaining, it was announced yesterday by the New York offices of the National Labor Relations Board.

Harry Snyder of Montreal and Colonel A. J. MacNab Jr., president of the Campfire Club of America, returned yesterday on the French liner Normandie from a hunting expedition to British East Africa, where they obtained more than two tons of animal and reptile specimens for the American Museum of Natural History.
With increasing pressure for ready-to-wear deliveries a feature, the pace of Fall buying activity continued good in the wholesale markets here yesterday.

Jamaica Government Railways officials said tonight that they believed that the toll in Saturday's wreck of an excursion train would be set at between thirty and forty instead of the fifty to sixty previously believed killed.

The Federal Court of Appeals ruled today that American citizenship of a child born in the United States is not lost if the parents become citizens of another country, provided the child was an adult when the parents changed their citizenship.
The Senators upset the Indians today with a three-run outburst in the tenth inning that beat the Tribe, 11 to 8, and dropped it another half game back of the league-leading Yankees.
Governor Gordon Browning defied before a cheering crowd of thousands tonight a Federal court injunction to prevent his moving National Guard troops into the city for Thursday's Democratic primary.
William Frederick Swan, prominent insurance man and an official of the Ocean Accident and Guarantee Corporation, Ltd., died today in Hahnemann Hospital at the age of 69.

Captain Henry C. Jessup of the Lawrence Police Department announced today the retirement of four members of the force as part of a reorganization plan which will bring the department under State civil service.

Advertising linage in eight New York newspapers declined 16 per cent in July, according to a compilation yesterday based on Media Records figures. Totals were 5,751,706 lines for last month, against 6,847,989 lines for July, 1937. Losses ranged from 2.65 per cent for one morning newspaper to 39.94 per cent for an evening paper.

George N. White, associated with Brown, Harriman Co., Inc., investment bankers, of 63 Wall Street, died on Sunday at his Summer, home at Orleans, Mass., of a heart attack. He was 53 years old and lived at 62 Bank Street.

Hampden-Sydney of Virginia will be the first team played by the Rutgers football team in the new million-dollar stadium here, according to an announcement today by George E. Little, director of physical education. The game is scheduled for Oct. 22.

The State Executive Committee of the Socialist party, at a special meeting yesterday, voted to break off negotiations for a merger with the American Labor party as a result of the Labor party's alliances with the Republicans in Manhattan and Brooklyn and with the Sheridan Democrats in Queens.

Miss Helen LeCount Lefebre, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Scott Lefebre of 340 East Fiftyseventh Street, has chosen the afternoon of Sept. 5 for her marriage to Hughart Rea Laughlin, son of Mrs. H. Hughart Laughlin of Pittsburgh and the late Mr. Laughlin.

Abolition of the State Department's Office of the Historical Adviser and the creation of a new post of Editor of the Treaties was announced by Secretary Hull today. Discontinuance of the old office, effective immediately, followed the transfer during the last year of its most important functions to the national archives.
Miss Ellen Hanscom, daughter of Mrs. Arthur B. Hanscom of this city, was married this morning to Augustus Henry Able 3d of Melrose Park, son of Mrs. Augustus Henry Able Jr. and of the late Mr. Able.

One of the Interesting things about the off-shore fishing these days is the potential element of surprise. George Flemming of Oak1yn, N. J., put out from Brielle on Saturday with Captain George Whiticar for some tuna. He got not only his tuna but a nice white marlin for a bonus.

Maurice Walsh of Sunningdale and his amateur partner, Willie Turnesa, New York State and Westchester champion, led a field of thirty-one teams in the weekly Westchester Golfers Association pro-amateur best ball tournament with a 32, 31-63, nine under par, at Lawrence Farms today.

After a long delay, Donald Budge, the American and Wimbledon tennis champion, tomorrow will formally receive the James E. Sullivan Memorial Trophy for being this country's outstanding amateur athlete last year. He will get the trophy at a luncheon at the New York Athletic Club.
The sixth annual memorial mass for the eight firemen who were killed in the Ritz Towers fire Aug. 1, 1932, was held yesterday in the Church of Our Lady of Perpetual Help, 321 East Sixty-first Street.

It would be obviously impossible for Secretary Hull to answer all the misrepresentations and fallacies that are published regarding his reciprocal trade program, else he would probably be turning out a score of answers every day.

Fourteen United States Navy vessels widened their area of operations today in the fourth day of the search for the missing flying boat Hawaii Clipper, which vanished with fifteen persons on a flight from Guam to Manila.

Though he had expected to be the sole producer of "Sing Out the News, Max Gordon has decided to have a couple of co-producers by the name of George S. Kaufman and Moss Hart-who, as it happens, also are contributing material to the revue and acting as consultants in its preparation. The Messrs.
Willie Klein, veteran Wheatley Hills professional, was the outstanding golfer as the Long Island P. G. A. held another of its one-day tournaments at the Lakeville Club today.
The local District Attorney was directed today to defy the Legislature of Pennsylvania, in a court order by Judge Paul N. Schaeffer presiding over a grand jury scheduled to sit Aug. 8.
Byron (Whizzer) White, who toyed for months with the choice between professional football for $15,000 in one season or traveling to England and Oxford on a Rhodes scholarship,. is going to do both.
Stressing that a united front of Chinese political factions against Japan has been "solidly established," the official Communist or gan, The New China Daily News, said yesterday:

Mayor La Guardia announced last night that ground would be broken tomorrow for three large PWA projects involving a total of $28,579,404 in construction costs. The largest project is the new Criminal Courts Building and city prison on Center Street, across from the old Criminal Courts Building.

A horse show ball will be given at the Old Field Club here the night of Aug. 20 as a climax to the round of entertaining attendant on the North Shore Horse Show, which will be held Aug. 18, 19 and 20 on the club grounds. The horse show will benefit the Children's Cottages of the Church Charity Foundation of Long Island.
(Via Naval Radio).-Members of President Roosevelt's fishing party returned aboard tonight blaming sharks for their failure to catch fish in greater numbers.

Three educational and one charitable institution are to share in the estate of Ella Reussner, under her will, filed for probate yesterday in Surrogate's Court in Brooklyn. A transfer-tax affidavit indicated that the estate amounted to about $200,000. Miss Reussner, who lived at 389 Degraw Street, Brooklyn, died on July 23.
The Yankees and Pirates are odds-on favorites to win the championships in their respective leagues, according to the odds released yesterday by Jack Doyle, Broadway betting commissioner.

The Little Carnegie Playhouse was reopened yesterday to the tune of "South Riding" and a rather pleasant tune it proved to be. London Film's version of the novel by the late Winifred Holtby probably is not doomed to popular success.

Directors of the General Motors Corporation declared yesterday a dividend of 25 cents a share on the common stock, payable on Sept. 12 to stock of record of Aug. 11. Similar payments were made this year in June and March.

Sports-loving, politically minded Kentuckians said today that it was still "anybody's race" as contenders in the Barkley-Chandler Senatorial sweepstakes headed down the homestretch in a cloud of dust.

Although heavy rains fell over the week-end in sections east of the Mississippi River, where warm, dry weather is reported necessary for the cotton crop, prices on the Cotton Exchange eased yesterday to the lowest quotations of the movement and ended with losses of 11 to 14 points.

Employes of the Rutland Railroad were ordered today by Federal Judge Harland B. Howe to decide by next Thursday whether they would accept wage reductions. Issuing an order to Luis G. Morphy, receiver, Judge Howe said:

Virginia's two Congressional campaigns, marked by a statement by Secretary Ickes emphasizing the New Deal issue in the Eighth District by a criticism of Representative Howard W. Smith, ended tonight in last minute appeals for votes in tomorrow's Democratic primary.

Gertrude Lawrence, the actress, received a letter from Mayor La Guardia yesterday to be delivered to Mayor Angelo Rossi of 'San Francisco. She visited the New York Mayor at his Summer headquarters on the World's Fair grounds.

Walter Lewisohn, retired New York broker, a patient at Blythewood Sanitarium here for several years, died at the sanitarium last night from fumigating gas. Greenwich police under Detective Sergeant John J. Cullen, after three hours' effort using three tanks of oxygen, revived him, but he succumbed in a relapse.

Plans for a uniform, informative label for all goods sold by cooperatives are under way and will be acted upon at a joint meeting of representatives of five of the leading cooperative wholesales of the country to be held at Chicago on Sept. 12, Theodore Castner, buyer for the Eastern Cooperative Wholesale, with offices in this city, said yesterday.

The Germans have lost no time in profiting by their absorption of Austria to develop her shipping lines in the Mediterranean. The Schuldt Line of Hamburg already has organized a fortnightly service between Trieste and ports of the Levant.
Byron (Whizzer) White, who toyed for months with the choice between professional football for $15,000 in one season or traveling to England and Oxford on a Rhodes scholarship,. is going to do both.

The Germans have lost no time in profiting by their absorption of Austria to develop her shipping lines in the Mediterranean. The Schuldt Line of Hamburg already has organized a fortnightly service between Trieste and ports of the Levant.

William Copeland Dodge, who was elected District Attorney in 1933 as the regular Democratic nominee, had been a city magistrate since 1927, when he was chosen by Mayor James J. Walker to fill the vacancy caused by the retirement of Norman J. Marsh.

Stocks advanced moderately and closed higher, recovering Monday's losses; turnover, 817,640 shares. Japanese loans weakened sharply to new low of year, United States Government and other bonds steady and mixed; transactions, $5,048,100.

The annual sales of yearlings, which have been incidental to Saratoga racing for years, began tonight with a big attendance but desultory bidding. Fifty-three head passed through the ring, bringing a total of $58,500, or an average of about $1,104 per head.

Completion of an agreement on cosmetic advertising and labeling under. the Wheeler-Lea act has been reached between the Toilet Goods Association and the National Retail Dry Goods Association, it was learned here yesterday.

The noted physicist, Dr. Jean Perrinz, informed the French Academy of Science today that his collaborators had discovered what was believed to be the ninety-third chemical element-a substance heavier than uranium.

Voters in four States went to the polls yesterday to nominate candidates for Congress and State offices. In Virginia Representative Howard W. Smith, an opponent of some New Deal measures who was blacklisted by the C. I. O., defeated William E. Dodd Jr., son of the ex-Ambassador to Germany, who ran on a "100 per cent for Roosevelt" platform.

Apartment rentals listed by brokers and agent yesterday were principally in buildings east and west of Central Park. In the house at 32 East Sixty-eighth Street, Hamilton Fish Armstrong, editor of Foreign Affairs, leased a maisonette apartment from the estate of Grayson M.-P. Murphy, through Douglas Gibbons Co., Inc.,

Green St, 2001/2 202; 49.10x100: Lionel Goldfrank, et al, execrs, Max Goldfrank to 202 Greene St, Inc, 160 Broadway ($25). 51st St, 141 W, 25x100.5; Helen S Spengler to Cosmos Realty Corp, 64 W 52d St. 57th St, 48 W. 25x100.5; Guaranty Trust Co, et al, excrs, Geo D Cochran to Rosemary Cochrane, Fresden, Highworth, Wiltshire. England. one-fifth interest.

The preliminary hearing in Brooklyn Felony Court to determine whether William F. McGuinness, Assistant District Attorney of Kings County, and George Murphy, city-employed elevator operator, should be held for trial on charges of conspiracy to "fix" a criminal case,

G. B. Dealey, Texas newspaper publisher, whose sixty-four years of experience encompass an Alger-like rise from $3-a-week office boy to president and publisher of The Dallas News, arrived in New York yesterday on the Clyde Mallory liner Seminole, beginning a vacation tour of sections of the country he has never had time to see. He was accompanied by his wife, their daughter, Mrs. James M. Moroney, and granddaughter, Jean Moroney, all of Dallas.

Russell Hardy, special assistant to the Attorney General, who carried on the government's case against automobile finance companies, has resigned to enter private law practice in Washington, it was announced today.

Japanese dollar bonds slumped yesterday to new low levels for the year in fairly active trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Losses ranging from 1 to 4 points in both government and corporate issues of Japanese origin were directly attributable to the growing seriousness of the Russo-Japanese border skirmishes.
Dressed in gray shorts and an open-necked tennis shirt, King George thoroughly enjoyed himself today at the Suffolk Summer camp for boys that he founded at Southwold in 1920.

The Department of Press announced today that the Mexican reply to the United States note asking for international arbitration of the question of immediate payment to United States landowners whose property has been expropriated will be delivered to Ambassador Josephus Daniels tomorrow.

The Interstate Commerce Commission and the Reconstruction Finance Corporation look favorably upon the proposed sale of the Mobile Ohio Railroad to the Gulf, Mobile Northern by the Southern Railway, Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, said at his press conference this afternoon.
It is reported here that the Spanish Insurgent cruisers Almirante Cervera and Canarias were heavily attacked by government bombers off Cartagena, Spain, Sunday.

John Aasen, 8-foot-9-inch giant who once weighed 503 pounds and traveled with a circus for twenty-five years, died here yesterday in the Mendocino State Mental Hospital. Aasen, in retirement four years, had dwindled to 247 pounds.
Federal District Judge Harland B. Howe appealed today to fifty persons in his court room for suggestions to help solve the financial problems of the Rutland Railroad.
Mr. and Mrs. Arthur C. Lindeman this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Pat Lindeman, to Howard Grad, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Grad, also of Newark.

The Nationalists [Insurgents] today methodically developed the large-scale counter-offensive they launched yesterday. Before it is concluded, according to Generalissimo Francisco Franco's general staff, they will drive the Republicans [Loyalists] far beyond the positions they occupied eight days ago on the east side of the Ebro River.
Many Chinese officials here believe that the Russo-Japanese border clashes are a prelude to war, but others, including the normally best informed, think such a possibility is unlikely.

Five miles off Brielle, N. J., the 38-foot fishing boat Flamingo, with seven passengers who had left early in the day to escape the heat, and a crew of two, suffered a gas-tank explosion and took fire. Captain William Brown and his mate, John Brown, attempted unsuccessfully to fight the blaze.

J. G.Kuijt, a 60-year-old retired planter of the Dutch East Indies, sailed from here this afternoon on his thirty-eight-foot cutter rig for Zaandijk, near Amsterdam, The Netherlands, which he hopes to reach in thirty to thirty-six days.

Ground-breaking for the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company's housing project in the East Tremont section of the Bronx, scheduled for yesterday, was postponed pending approval of the contracts for, excavation now before the firm's board of design.

A special committee of three members of the Board of Regents with Chancellor Thomas J. Mangan and Vice Chancellor William J. Wallen as members ex officio, was announced today to consider plans to enable public school children to receive religious instruction.

Sammy Baugh, ace forward passer, signed a three-year contract today with the Washington Redskins, National Football League champions. Baugh had been a hold-out. Terms of his new contract were not disclosed, but owner George P. Marshall said Sammy would be a "bigger shot" in pro football than Byron (Whizzer) White. White,,
The ferryboat Queens went into service yesterday morning at Pier 3, East River, to give under-privileged children and mothers of the city a breath of fresh air and a pleasant river-and-bay excursion.

Mrs. Richard P. Davies of 82 Geranium Avenue, Floral Park, a Mayflower descendant, who was active in women's patriotic clubs, died today in the Lougen-Knickerbocker Hospital here, after an illness of several months. She-was 60 years old.

The Export-Import Bank, which is financed by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, has within the last year assisted financially to the extent of approximately $6,000,000 in the exporting of cotton to Italy, Warren Lee Pierson, president, said this afternoon at the RFC press conference.

A Weather Bureau technicality officially recognized yesterday New York's hottest day this year as the city sweltered in temperatures which reached 90 degrees in the afternoon, making it the ninth consecutive day in which the thermometer rose to 81 degrees or more. The temperature will probably climb again to 90 today.

Loans on securities to member firms increased $23,728,533 in July, it was announced yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange. The loan total at the end of July was $493,615,933, compared with $469,887,400 at the close of June.

The proposal of three Eastern railroads to discontinue free pick-up and delivery service was protested today to the Interstate Commerce Commission by a New York Central local of the Brotherhobod of Railway Clerks.

Miss Alice Stevens, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank M. Stevens of this city, gave a dinner last night in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria for her cousin, Miss Mary Stevens of Niles, Ohio, who will be married to James R. Bussey Jr. today in the Church of the Transfiguration.

" We will not take a cut; the fact that the railroads haven't the money is not our problem." This is the remarkable statement of A. F. Whitney, chairman of the Brotherhood of Trainmen. He must mhave spoken hastily.

Nothing more dangerous to the peace of Europe during the present tensions can be imagined than actual warfare in the Far East between Russia and Japan. In European diplomatic circles nobody, however, believes this will come to pass.

Daniel G. Dodge, 21-year-old beneficiary of a $10,000,000 trust fund left him by his father, John F. Dodge, automobile manufacturer, married this afternoon Miss Laurine MacDonald, operator of the Gore Bay, Ont., telephone office.

An application by a committee for debenture holders of the Midland Utilities Company for approval of a plan of reorganization was set down today for hearing on Aug. 19 by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Viscount Runciman left for Prague today on a mission that the British Government hopes will at least gain time and avert a possible explosion in Central Europe this year.

The amount of the issues managed by underwriters in the second quarter of this year was $314,460,000, of which $227,556,000 was handled by New York City firms, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

For improvement with attached one-story brick bungalows, twenty-two lots 20 by 100 feet each on the north and south sides of Sixtieth Avenue, 100 feet west of Main Street, Flushing, L. I., have been purchased by Said Homes, Inc., Brooklyn developers.

Justice of the Peace Arthur C. Kyle Jr., in court here today, criticized Magistrate Nicholas Pinto of Brooklyn for "passing judgment in advance" in the case of Mrs. Fay Reder of 301 Sterling Street, Brooklyn, who was routed out of bed and arrested in her home last Thursday at 1 A. M. for defaulting a $4.50 bill from a hotel here.

Russia threw six divisions and thirty tanks this morning into the battle at Changkufeng Heights at the Manchukuo border. Both sides claimed victory. Russia asserted enormous losses were inflicted on the Japanese by artillery and war planes.[Page 1.]

The network of fortifications Germany has been laying down so far at the most strategically important points of her borders is rapidly extending into a regular ring of steel and concrete along virtually the whole of her winding frontiers.

A decline of 386,000 in the number of unemployed workers in the United States was recorded between May and June, the National Industrial Conference Board reported yesterday. It estimated total unemployment in June at 10,981,000 persons.

FIELD, JACOB L. (July 14). Estate, less than $100. To Eugenia L. Field, widow, executrix. 210 W. 78th St., residue. KARP, HYMAN (May 26). Estate, less than $2,000. To Louis Karp, nephew, executor, 262 W. 107th St., residue; one minor bequest.

Alex Remeta, 17-year-old entrant from the Colonia Country Club, won the New Jersey State caddie championship and William Rullman of Old Orchard captured the State caddie master title over the Shackamaxon Country Club course today.

National Socialist party and Labor Front officials were jubilant tonight at the population's first response to the announcement of a nation-wide savings campaign for the later purchase of the popular-priced "Volksauto," which is also designed to provide most of the capital for the production of this automobile.

Sheriff Ralph E. Elsor of Youngstown, Ohio, told the Senate Civil Liberties Committee today that during last year's "Little Steel" strike he accepted two consignments of tear gas and munitions from the Youngstown Sheet' and Tube Company to the value of $1,715.

Stanley Bazarewski, 21 years old, of 217 Pennsylvania Avenue Brooklyn, blamed the Brooklyn Dodgers' loss of a double-header to the Giants on July 4 for his appearance in Queens Felony Court, Ridgewood, yesterday on a grand larceny charge.

There was a net decline of 6,850 telephones on lines of the Bell System during July, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced yesterday. July, 1937, had brought a gain of 22,700 stations.

Trading in bull, cow and veal was fair, other classes slow in local markets yesterday. Steer hinds and ribs were steady to slightly lower. Lamb weak to slightly lower, fresh pork cuts weak to lower, other classes steady. Hot weather coupled with the Jewish fast days slowed up kosher business almost to a standstill. Conditions, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:
Operators and investors were active in Bronx realty deals yesterday, when trading in a number of multi-family residential properties was announced.
Celebrating the Polo Grounds debut of Gabby Hartnett as their manager, the Cubs said it with home runs and other extra-base hits yesterday.

Announcement has been made here of the engagement of Miss Marcia Simmons, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Simmons of Albany, to James A. Warren, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard A., Warren of Coxsackie. The wedding is planned for next month.

Conclusion this week of negotiations over a proposed 15 per cent wage cut was held to be likely today by George M. Harrison, chairman of the Railway Labor Executives Association. The association has been meeting with the Carriers Joint Conference Committee, representing the railroads, of which H. A. Enochs is chairman.
ARE WE MOVIE-MADE? by Raymond Moley. (Macy-Masius, $1.) A summary of the parts of Mortimer J. Adler's "Art and Prudence" which deal with the study of motion pictures.
J. Richard (Dixie) Davis went into Supreme Court before Justice Ferdinand Pecora yesterday and said he was guilty of all thirteen counts in the policy racket indictment against him.

New light on the Soviet attitude in the Far Eastern conflict with Japan is thrown by an editorial in today's Journal de Moscou, a weekly French publication whose comment is generally understood to represent the views of the Soviet Foreign Office.

Matthew Woll, vice president of the American Federation of Labor, told the program committee of the Republican National Committee tonight that "big government" now was the real menace to American liberties and aspirations.

A charge of operating a house of prostitution against Florence Rose, 34 years old, of 32 West Eightieth Street, described as the sweetheart of Nick Montana, vice ring czar, now in prison, was dismissed yesterday in Women's Court by Magistrate Thomas Cullen for lack of evidence.

Slowness and dragginess featured the fed Steer trade today with prices fully 25 cents lower. Hogs also declined but fat lambs arriving in limited numbers sold actively and recovered part of Monday's 25- to 50-cent losses, according to the United States Department of Agriculture.

Charles E. Denney, co-trustee of the Erie Railroad, applied to the Interstate Commerce Commission today for ratification of his appointment by the Federal court for the Northern District of Ohio as co-trustees of the Nypano Railroad Company, an Erie affiliate.

In a two-to-one decision establishing a court precedent for jurisdictional contest between labor unions, the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals ruled that inter-union battles are not labor disputes within the meaning of the Wagner act.

J. P. Morgan and his son, Junius S. Morgan, who protested the $2,036,850 assessment placed on their joint properties in Glen Cove by the new Nassau County Board of Assessors, will receive no reduction, according to figures disclosed today in City Hall when the books were reopened to the taxpayers after having been ordered closed yesterday by Emil Podyn, chairman of the boa rd.
In the tropic setting of this island President Roosevelt signed today bills for bird refuges back home and approved routine recommendations which reached him from Washington.
Representative Ludlow of Indiana submitted to the Department of Justice today a draft of a proposed bil to permit Federal authorities to participate in investigation of lynchings.

A new rush by Europeans to convert their money into gold and American dollars broke over the foreign-exchange market yesterdays It rivaled in intensity the gold demand that arose in the late Spring but exceeded it in the demoralizing effect it had on the principal foreign currencies.
Still hopeful that fifteen persons aboard the missing Hawaii Clipper might be alive, drifting with ocean currents, navy officers ordered a widened search today by planes and surface craft.

Top teams in the English county cricket championship held their places today as the three-day series of matches ended. The Kent-Hampshire game had ended yesterday, the former victorious by an innings and 108 runs.
An anthology of some fifty Irish poems written before 1400 has been compiled, with an introduction by Sean O'Faolain, under the title "The Silver Branch." Viking will publish the book on Aug. 19.

A rise of 1 cent a quart in the price of milk set by the so-called independent distributors-as apart from that sold by the Borden Company and Sheffield Farms--has been effected, it became known last night. .
Two New York City firms have entered into stipulations with the Federal Trade Commission to discontinue certain unfair trade practices.

Aldus St, 1,032 (10-2755); Thelma Potruch to Renvar Realty Corp., 45 W 23d St, seven years, 5 per cent: 12,000. Morris Ave (11-3138), w s, 272 ft n of 183d St, 100x105; Bio Associates, Inc, to Metropolitan Life Insurance Co. 1 Madison Ave, due Oct. 1, 1948, at 4 1/2 to 5 per cent: $15,000.

Caleb Fellows Fox, Philadelphia banker, died after a long illness today in his home, Berthellyn, Elkins Park. He was 78 years old. The son of George S. and Amanda Fox, he was born in this city and studied at private schools.

With the citation of thirty-six more laundries accused of refusing to pay to women and minor employees the legal minimum wage for the industry in this State, the total of such violators since the wage went into effect last March 14 was brought to 316, Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner, announced yesterday.

Some of the army's most modern equipment was demonstrated here today for the benefit of 457 of West Point's first class. Tracer ammunition streamed in bursts of fire from the muzzles of .30 and .50 caliber machimne guns, guns capable of firing at the rate of 400 to 500 rounds a minute.

The Toledo News Bee, a Scripps-Howard newspaper, announced today that with its final edition of the afternoon it was suspending publication. The remaining afternoon newspaper here is The Toledo Blade, published by Paul Block.

Mrs. Basil de Selincourt has announced at Far End, her home at Kingham, Oxfordshire, England, the engagement of her daughter, Miss Anne Spring Denny Alsop, to Richard Watson Gilder, son of Mr. and Mrs. Rodman Gilder of this city and Syosset, L. I.

Vernon Kenric Melhado, president of the Bethlehem Chamber of Commerce, died suddenly here this morning of a heart attack at the age of 49. A former resident of Belmont, St. Andrew, British West Indies, Mr. Melhado was a graduate of Oxford, and served in the British army in the World War.

The marriage of Miss Lois Lilian Coffin, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. William Jay Coffin of Albany to John Robert Arscott, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Arscott of Lorain, Ohio, took place yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's aunt, Miss Lois Lilian Gaskill of 1,205 Glenwood Road, Brooklyn.
The Navy Department took steps today to list all aliens now employed, in any capacity, in the navy yards and other shore stations of the navy.
Ben H. Reese, city editor of The St. Louis Post-Dispatch for twenty years, was appointed managing editor today to succeed Oliver K. Bovard, who resigned last week. .

Vienna applauded Franz Lehar's operetta "Die Lustige Witwe" on Dec. 30, 1905. Two years later it was a reigning hit in New York under the title of "The Merry Widow." The Merry Widow waltz swept the country.
A new gambling decree, effective in Germany tomorrow but not applicable to Austria was announced here today by Minister of the Interior Wilhelm Frick.

The Utah Copper Company, a subsidiary of the Kennecott Copper Corporation, reopened on Aug. 1 its mine at Bingham, Utah, and two of its concentrating plants, it was reported yesterday at Salt Lake City. About 2,500 men who were laid off when the shut-down was ordered on June 15 have returned to work.

PATROLMEN--James P. McKeogh, from 13th Precinct to 18th Division, for 10 days, from 4 P. M., Aug. 1. William G. Weber 74th Precinct, assigned to tours, 8 A. M. to 4 P. M. and 4 P. M. to 12 midnight, for 30 days, from 8 A. M.. Aug. 3.

Mario Di Giorgio and Paul Surdi, both 20 years old and residents of New York, were held today in $5,000 bail each for the Federal grand jury when arraigned here before United States Commissioner Joseph Holland on charges of possessing and passing counterfeit $5 notes.

The Treasury's monthly statement on securities held as investments in trust funds and in accounts of certain governmental corporations and agencies on June 30, made public today, shows total investments in government securities of $4,185,538,000, compared with $4,090,025,000 on May 25.

Brig. Gen. Joseph Powell Tracy, U. S. A., and Mrs. Tracy have come from Washington to the Vanderbilt. Miss Elsie Howland Quinby, who had been visiting Mrs. Eugene Roberts in Budapest for several weeks, returned on the Aquitania with Countess Laszlo Szechenyi and Mrs. Roberts.

Ralph Strafaci of Shore View carded a regulation 36, 34-70, to captured the low gross prize in the Long Island Golf Association one-day tournament at the Woodmere Club today. Included in the field of sixty-six players was Frank Strafaci of Lakeville, the Metropolitan amateur champion and younger brother of Ralph.

Some 500 sailing fans, representing Great South Bay, Moriches Bay and Cedarhurst clubs, today watched the second of the six-day series of events marking the annual Race Week cruise of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association.

The Union Square branch of the Morris Plan Industrial Bank, which now occupies quarters in 17 Union Square, will move in the Fall to 5 Union Square as a result of a tenyear lease just closed through the Vance Stewart Company, brokers, and Carstens, Linnekin Wilson, Inc., manager of the,...
Orders for a flight of three B-17 airplanes, popularly known as "flying fortresses," from Miami, Fla., to Bogota, Colombia, were issued today by the War Department.

Mrs. Ado Thompson Miller of Findlay, Ohio, mother of Marilyn Miller, musical comedy star, filed a petition in Surrogate's Court yesterday for a construction of her daughter's will. Since the death of the dancer, in April, 1936, her estate has been subject to litigation in the courts.

1. State the number of lotteries it is claimed that defendant Hines conspired to contrive, propose and draw and assist in contriving, proposing and drawing, as alleged in paragraph 1 of the first count of the indictment, together with a description or outline of the object, method of operation and plan of each of such lotteries.

The daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,316,400 barrels, compared with 3,349,050 in the previous week, a decline of 32,650, according to the American Petroleum Institute.
Among the fiscal and financial experts of the New Deal there is a tremendous to-do at the moment over a document modestly entitled "A 1938 Memorandum Regarding the Federal Securities Act of 1933."

The international anthropologists' and ethnographers' convention opened today at Copenhagen University with twenty-one lectures. One lecturer was the exiled German anatomist, Franz Weidenreich, noted for his study of the oldest known human being, the Sinanthropus Pekinensis.
DORSA, THOMAS (Aug. 4, 1937). Assets, $15,596 gross; $11,136 net. To daughter, Theresa Fodera. Outstanding holdings in real property, $9,038. Schwinzer Burns, attorneys, 535 Fifth Ave., Manhattan.

Miss Elizabeth Caroline Kerbey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. McFall Kerbey of Washington, was married here last night to Garrett Traveller MacEwan, son of J. A. MacEwan and the late Mrs. MacEwan of Keyport, N. J.

The reaction of bankers to his recent letter warning that the government would go further into the banking business if they did not participate more in loans to business was "good," Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, said at his press conference this afternoon.

All deliveries of wheat and the deferred futures of corn sold at new low levels for the season in the early trading on the Board of Trade today, but there was no material pressure and wheat rallied 1 cent a bushel from the inside figures and closed 1/4 cent higher to 3/8 cent lower.

The number of out-of-town buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday fell slightly below that of the preceding week, but was a little higher than the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings in THE TIMES.

" Australopithecus Transvaalensis," the apeman whose remains were recently discovered by Dr. Robert Broom in Sterkfontein caves, is the genuine "missing link," in the opinion of Professor W. K. Gregory, American anatomist, who has come to South Africa to study it.
The liners Southern Cross and Pan America will sail from New York on Sept. 10 and 24 respectively for South American ports under the direction of H. F. Markwalter, operating agent.

Organized bar and grill owners of the metropolitan area have joined with retail liquor package store owners and with wholesale liquor dealers in the recently organized New York Joint Liquor Conference, Gerald F. Dunne, chairman of the conference, announced yesterday.

Vesta Hanover, not eligible for the Hambletonian, trotted away with the feature on today's Grand Circuit program at Agawam Park, the $9,120 National Stake for 3-year-olds. Vesta Hanover showed her heels in all three heats to such crack trotters as Champlain, McLin and Long Key.

A statement on the condition of New Jersey financial institutions as of June 30, issued today by the State Department of Banking and Insurance, listed resources of the banks as $1,422,715,679. The June, 1937, total was $1,452,810.210.

As the result of incessant rainfall since Sunday evening, the cities of Kobe, Osaka and Kyoto and the surrounding district are again seriously flooded. Rail service between Kobe and Osaka is interrupted. About 1,000 houses in Kobe are fully or partly inundated.

Absent Germany will dominate the Evian conference on refugees when it resumes its sessions here tomorrow. Unless Germany agrees to let refugees take a certain amount of their property with them and unless she cooperates in an orderly emigration of "non-Aryans" there will be little point in anything that the conference may arrange for their future welfare.

The dissolution committee of the directors of the Chesapeake Corporation at its meeting yesterday afternoon at the offices of J. W. Seligman to consider plans for dissolving the corporation, adjourned without having taken any action.

The defeat of two seeded players and the difficulty esperienced by Miss Dorothy May Bundy in both of her mar\tches featurred the second day of competition in the invitation tennis tournament at the maidstone club today.

Negotiations between Universal and W. C. Fields for the comedian to star in "You Can't Cheat an Honest Man" were near completion today at a reported figure of $150,000. The deal includes rights to the story, which is owned by Fields, and options on his services for further pictures.

Dr. Harry A. Curtis, TVA chief chemical engineer and head of the Fertilizer Department, accepted full responsibility in testifying before the Congressional Investigating Committee today for the deal that netted the International
Meade Coyle, 21-year-old Fordham University baseball player, suffered a fractured leg today while playing in a Northern League game between the Saranac Lake Red Sox and the St. Albans Giants.

With the interest of Long Island polo followers transferred for the moment to the national junior championship in New Jersey, the program at Meadow Brook today consisted of two members' matches and a round-robin.

Steel ingot production was unchanged last week, although the normal seasonal trend was downward, and the adjusted index rose to 54.1, its highest point since the week ended Nov. 20, 1937. The figure was 53.8 for the preceding week and 126.8 for the corresponding week last year.

More than 6,000 buyers have registered at the Fall market showings which opened yesterday, according to figures issued at the various headquarters today. Buyers, confident of a sharp upturn in Fall business, were covering cautiously, and were warned of possible delivery delays on some merchandise.

A repetition of the bombshell thrown into the millinery world by the appearance of the Eugenie hat in 1931 arrived last night when the "doll" hat, a tiny frivolous affair to be worn tipped over the eyes, held the center of attention at the Fall millinery fashion show at the Hotel Astor under the auspices of the Millinery Stabilization Commission, Inc.

With the temperature to cooperate in the creating of an authentic tropical atmosphere, "Zunguru," an African dance-drama by Asadata Dafora, opened last night at the Davenport Theatre in East Twenty-seventh Street. The audience was as large as the little auditorium could accommodate and filled with expectation, since Mr. Dafora was also the author and director of "Kykunkor," the first and most successful of the African dance-dramas.

Varying business and trade conditions in a dozen countries around the globe were reported on today by the Commerce Department, based on radiograms and telegrams received from American commercial attaches abroad. They are summarized as follows:

A net profit of $118,033 is reported for the second quarter of 1938 by the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company, after all deductions, equal to 78 cents a share on 150,000 shares of 5 1/2 per cent preferred stock, as compared to a net loss of $139,529 in the first quarter and to a profit of $2,022,112, equal to $1.14 a share on 1,590,720 common shares, in the second quarter of 1937..

District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey yesterday named his predecessor, William Copeland Dodge, and Magistrate Hulon Capshaw and the late Magistrate Francis J. Erwin as judicial officers who had been "intimidated,...

E. B. Hittleman, president of the Edelbrau Brewery, Inc., yesterday announced that the company's new five-cent bottle of beer has been named "Solo." The new container, which holds seven ounces of beer as against twelve ounces in the standard size bottle, he said, was designed to sell through regular beer outlets and to meet the requirements of those desiring a single glass of beer.

Chinese were reported today to have cut dikes of the mighty Yangtze River to halt the steady advance of Japanese against Hankow, China's provisional capital. Japanese spokesmen said a large area of farm land had been flooded when Chinese broke the river's retaining walls 125 miles downstream from Hankow.

Persons who have yearned to cool off in the Hudson River but for good reasons never have will be able to satisfy that desire after a fashion on Friday or Saturday, when the Park Department will open to the public something new in the way of public swimming pools.
In an exchange deal, the nine-story and penthouse apartment at 106-10 East Eighty-fifth Street has been sold by John P. Finneran, president of Donbert Estates, Inc., to Colonel J. Lester Eisner.

The Circus Fans of America left in the hands of a subcommittee today the problem of developing a program that would revive "big-top" entertainment and put it on a profitable basis. Melvin D. Hildreth of Washington, D. C., re-elected president,

A taxicab drivers' strike, said by the employers to be directed against the Transport Workers Union, a C. I. O. affiliate, made 700 cabs idle yesterday. The strike, which involves about the same number of drivers, was called by drivers of the Parmelee System Taxicab Company at three Brooklyn garages of the company.
Mayor La Guardia yesterday announced the promotion of two magistrates, Gustave W. M. Wieboldt and James E. Finegan, to places on the Court of Special Sessions.

Practices being followed by both sides in the hotly fought Democratic Senatorial primary in Kentucky have created a "deplorable situation" which "should arouse the conscience of the country," the Senate Campaign Expenditures Investigating Committee charged today.

" Music at Night," the second offering of the Malvern Theatre Festival, was hailed last night as another stage in J. B. Priestley's development as a major dramatist. The author juggles with time but does so with certainty of touch and direction enlivened by a humorous quality that produces an impressive effect.

Two New Jersey youths vacationing at this Chesapeake Bay resort were washed ashore near Turkey Point Lighthouse on the Eastern Shore after clinging to their capsized canoe for fifteen hours. The exhausted boys, Russell Smith, 20, of Haddon Heights and Robert Moser, 20, of Camden, rented a canoe and rowed across the upper bay.

A four-point campaign to stimulate business for the heating contractor has been launched by the Crane Company, Chicago, manufacturers of heating equipment, plumbing, valves, fitting and pipe, according to Russell G. Creviston, director of advertising and sales promotion.

The war between City Hall and Brooklyn over the honor of first receiving Douglas G. Corrigan, transatlantic flier homeward bound on the liner Manhattan, raged with advantage first to one side then the other yesterday.
Denny Galehouse kept twelve Boston hits well scattered today and the Indians took the opener of a fourgame series, 7-4, to move within a game and a half of the leading Yankees.

William A. Tremper, whose ancestors were among early New York settlers from The Netherlands, died at his home here yesterday at the age of 74. He was the son of Captain Edward Tremper, who was with Farragut at Mobile Bay and who escaped from Libby Prison during the Civil War.

The Football Giants yesterday became the first club in the National Football League to purchase a minor league outfit, John V. Mara, president of the New York team, announcing the purchase of the Stapleton franchise in the American Association.

The report for the last week in July by private member banks in the Federal Reserve shows little change in the trend of their loan account. Since Sept. 15 last year, when such loans reached their high point of the period, the account has decreased $1,888,000,000; it was reduced $160,000,000 during July.

Thomas A. Aspell, sales executive of the B. F. Goodrich Company, died yesterday after a year of ill health at the age of 54. Until recently he had been general sales manager of the company's original equipment tire division.
Charles E. Bedaux, scientific engineer, has been entrusted with the job of reorganizing the economic life of Greece.
Lord Queenborough arrived from England yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania, accompanied by his two daughters, the Hon. Audrey Paget and the Hon. Enid Paget.

Like the man in the song in vogue some years ago, Arthur J. Thorner Jr. of Detroit, the defending champion in the national left-handers' golf championship, walked right in and turned around and walked right out again.
Donald C. MacLean, administrative assistant of Erasmus Hall High School, died Monday night of a heart ailment in his home at 60 Buckingham Road, Brooklyn. He was 52 years old.

Captain Harold L. Winslow of the United States Steamship Lines was found dead of gas at 9:30 o'clock last night in his London Terrace apartment at 445 West Twentythird Street. He was 40 years old. Detectives said he had committed suicide.
As indicated hereabouts last Saturday, the American Theatre Council will hold another convention in September, the same being inspired by "the enormous success" of the four-day session in May, 1937.

Many small, informal dinners tonight preceded the opening of the second week of the Casino Theatre season, when the audience of Summer colonists witnessed a performance of "The Late Christopher Bean," with Pauline Lord.
Goose, the six-meter yacht owned and sailed by George Nichols, today won the right to represent the United States in the forthcoming Scandinavian Gold Cup races that start off here Aug. 27.

Johnny Vander Meer won his twelfth triumph of the season as the Reds nosed out the Phillies, 3 to 2, today. After pitching well for seven frames, Vander Meer allowed the Phils to tie the score at 1-1 in the eighth.

79th St, 55 W, 22.6x100.5; Mae V. Sullivan to Nellie E. Mordecai, 25 E 86th St; p. m. mtg, due and etc as bond, $17,000. 132d St, 155 W, n s, 25x99.11; Alice V. Murray to Joseph Scelza, 1 W 132d St; installment, 6 per cent. $2,981.

The combination of a $50,000,000 bond issue and a 1-cent increase in the present 3-cent gasoline tax was advanced today as a means of providing work for all employables now idle in New Jersey and financing the State's share of direct relief.
The supplement to the Franco-German trade agreement, the renewal of which was announced in Paris on July 20, was signed here today by representatives of both countries.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated July 30: MAJOR GENERAL McCoy, F. R., New York, N. Y., to retirement, Oct. 31. LIEUTENANT COLONELS Bradley, O. N.., Inf., General Staff Corps, three days' leave, Aug. 2. Brownell, G. S., Inf., Charleston, S. C., to 34th Inf., Ft. George G. Meade. Md.

Holders of Oliver Cromwell Hotel first mortgage 6 per cent bonds who did not assent to the plan of reorganization for this property have been asked to present their bonds and receive their distributive share of the funds on deposit with the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company.
The city is saving $18,000 a month through the transfer of 4,000 cases from home relief to the public assistance rolls of the Board of Child Welfare, it became known yesterday.

After an early decline on which the list sold at new low levels, with the October at 8.46 cents a pound, prices on the Cotton Exchange recovered yesterday to end unchanged to 2 points lower than on Monday.

Jackson Miller, a retired newspaper executive, who was controller of The Chicago Tribune from 1908 until 1911, died here yesterday of heart disease at his residence, 5,085 Broadway, after a long illness. He was 71 years old. He had lived in New York for twenty-five years.

In a case arising under the Wagner act, and of considerable interest from the point of view of judicial interpretation of that statute, the Circuit Court of Appeals in this city has set aside an order of the National Labor Relations Board.

Damages of $1,000,000 are demanded from the Committee for Industrial Organization by the National Association of Industrial Insurance Agents, in a law suit filed today in the Federal District Court alleging libel and slander on the part of the organization headed by John L. Lewis.

Des Moines, Iowa, awarded yesterday to Carlton D. Deh Co. $295,000 of airport bonds on a bid of 100.084 for 3 1/4s. The bonds are to be dated July 1, 1938, and will mature Dec. 1, 1943 to 1954, optional for call in 1941 at 104.

Tom Baker hurled Jersey City's Little Giants to their second straight victory over the Buffalo Bisons today, 4 to 1. Ollie Carnegie added to his home run lead in the fourth when he hit his thirty-first of the season over the left center field fence.

Federal Judge Phillip Forman dismissed today indictments against five defendants on trial in the government suit against the Whealton Company, of Camden; the Commonwealth Trust Company, of Baltimore, and several defendants who are charged with using the mails to sell alleged fraudulent stock and for conspiracy.
The Reichsbank's statement as of Aug. 1 shows the following changes from the preceding week in thousands of marks:
The text of the statement issued by the National Labor Relations Board announcing its decision to reopen hearings in the Maytag case in a Federal court room in Des Moines on Thursday morning follows:
Following yesterday's upheaval, the ranks of the favored array held firm through two rounds of singles today in the Southampton invitation tennis tournament on the turf of the Meadow Club.

Paul Edwards, administrative officer in charge of the five WPA Federal Arts projects in this city, announced yesterday that 300 employes now getting wages above the security scale or lacking relief status /would be demoted or dismissed under orders from Washington limiting the number of non-relief workers on WPA projects to 10 per cent of the total personnel.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Hugo von Ullrich of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth von Ullrich, to Malcolm Schaumann, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Malcolm Schaumann of Newark.

After twenty-eight unsuccessful attempts in twenty-seven years to obtain a regular position in the city's public schools, a substitute teacher, it was learned yesterday, has appealed to the State Commissioner of Education to direct the Board of Examiners to issue her the license she has sought perennially.
A Hitler decree today announces the establishment of the "Richard Wagner Research Institute," created to commemorate the composer's 125th birthday celebrated this year.

Several members of the Summer colony entertained with luncheon and dinner parties today, including Mrs. Joseph H. Hutchinson, Dr. and Mrs. Fritz B. Talbot, A. Atwater Kent and Mr. and Mrs. Dave Hennen Morris, who gave a luncheon at Bogue Chitto.
The Federal Government's expenditures ran $451,450,746 ahead of income during the first month of the current fiscal year, according to the Treasury's daily statement for July 30, made public today.

Those of you who fish, or plan to fish, out of any of the Rockaway ports have an opportunity to enter your catches in a new contest, with $500 in prizes to the lucky anglers. The money was donated by John R. Burton, president of the National Bank of Far Rockaway, who is interested in promoting the sport in that area.

The Senate approved the 12 per cent export tax tonight, thus completing legislative action on it, since the House passed the measure last week. This controversial measure is intended to bring the government 80,000,000 to 120,000,000 pesos in revenue in a year.

An American blind girl, weeping aboard her ship in the Thames, said tonight that she had appealed to President Roosevelt because British authorities refused permission for her "eyes"-a German shepherd dog guide-to enter England with her.

The French liner Normandie will sail today for Southampton and Havre. Among her passengers will be Count Rene de Saint-Quentin, French Ambassador to the United States; Mr. and Mrs. Jesse Jones, Stuart McDonald, Mrs. Ruth Baker Pratt, Captain Hans Elliott, Albert E. Lee, Armand Achille Fould, French Deputy, and Mme. Fould; David Sarnoff, Thomas J. Watson, Mr. and Mrs. Willis H. Booth and Mr. and Mrs. William W. Hoffman.

AS frontispiece to "The Horse and Buggy Doctor" * there is a photograph of a thin, cranky-looking man sitting up very straight. His mouth is set in a grim and no-nonsense-about-me line, and his neck is encircled by a stiff collar almost quaint enough for an ex-President.

The Rev. Edward B. Bunn, S. J., for three years Associate Professor of Psychology at Fordham University, has been appointed president of Loyola College, Baltimore, according to an announcement yesterday.

The New York-Philadelphia team of Mrs. Robert B. Fuller, Dr. Henry J. Vogel, Mrs. R. C. Young and Charles Goren held its lead of yesterday's first session of the mixed team-of-four play and won the first completed event in the twelfth annual national contract bridge championships in Convention Hall here today.

The Municipal Art Galleries, 3 East Sixty-seventh Street, will open today the thirty-third in the series of exhibitions of work by local artists. The first floor is given over to prints by eight exhibitors.

Mrs. Henry Austin Clark entertained with a reception and tea this afternoon at Four Acres for the patronesses of the recital to be given here by Hans Barth, pianist, next Tuesday at Mocomonto, the home of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney B. Wood.
Paced by terrific homers by Charlie Keller, who delivered with the bases filled, Frankie Kelleher and Mike Chartak, Newark crushed Montreal, 15 to 3, tonight for its seventh consecutive. victory.

Paul N. Dwyer, 18-year-old confessed double slayer, faltered today, a victim of nervousness and heat, as he was about to testify against former Deputy Sheriff Francis M. Carroll, now accused of a murder for which Dwyer went to prison for life.

Sydney Wooderson, world's fastest outdoor miler, has accepted a challenge to meet United States champions in America in October. He has stipulated that Glenn Cunningham must be among the competitors in the mile race to be held at Princeton.

Under a blazing sun, sixty-two women started play today in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association third annual two-day Scotch foursome tournament over the east and west nines of the Ridgewood Country Club,

Volitant won the main event today and the president of the Saratoga Association at once declared open house, since the son of Display bore the scarlet silks with black sleeves and cap of the Saratoga Stable.

The power of one of polo's smallest men, Pete Bostwick, well backed by Charley von Stade's play, surprisingly polished for a youth of his age, turned the scale in today's junior polo championship final and moved Bostwick Field into the long list of the winners of this old national title, succeeding Santa Barbara. Bostwick Field subdued Ebby Gerrys' Aknusti Side, 8 to 5.

Conferences called by Governor Kraschel, which have lasted all day, had failed late tonight to provide a solution of the difficulties caused by the strike at the plant of the Maytag company at Newton.

Tippy Larkin knocked out Eddie Zivic of Pittsburgh tonight in 1:25 of the first of a ten-round bout at Meadowbrook Bowl. Larkin weighed 136 pounds and Zivic 138. Larkin, the aggressor from the start, found the range of Zivic's jaw and landed a terrific right that drove the Pittsburgher into the ropes.

Exhibitions at the Berkshire Museum by Augustus Vincent Tack and Stuart C. Henry, curator of the museum, were opened this afternoon with a reception given by Miss Laura M. Bragg, director, and the trustees.

Commercial and industrial failures in the United States in the week ended July 28 increased in all five trade divisions as compared with the same week of 1937, according to the weekly summary prepared by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Victor De Villiers, well known as a writer on financial subjects, and two business associates were arrested yesterday by agents of Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. on Federal indictments of mail fraud.
New and striking evidence of the cleavage of political opinion today along economic lines is indicated in a cross-section survey just completed by the American Institute of Public Opinion.

Stung by a new version of the charges that while he was Foreign Secretary he had "let the United States down" in dealing with the Japanese invasion of Manchuria, Sir John Simon declared today that he had received a "personal message of congratulations" from Henry L. Stimson, former United States Secretary of State, for supporting the League of Nations resolution refusing to recognize territory acquired in violation of the Kellogg Pact.

The Gilbert M. Hitchcock Scholarship of $1,000 for study in the Columbia University School of Journalism has been awarded for 1938-39 to George H. Pipal of Humboldt, Neb., acting manager of The United Press bureau in Lincoln, Neb., it was announced yesterday.

Gordon D. Banker, organist and choir master of St. James's Episcopal Church, Elmhurst, Queens, died of a cerebral hemorrhage yesterday at the age of 48 in St. John's Hospital, Long Island City. He was stricken at his home, 40-15 Eighty-first Street, Jackson Heights, at 2:30 A. M.

William J. Durkin, a history teacher at Theodore Roosevelt High School, the Bronx, who had charge of the high school annex from 1926 to 1928, died on Monday at the age of 49 in his home at 1,919 Hennessy Place, the Bronx, of pneumonia, He was a brother of the late Martin T. Durkin, managing editor of The Times Picayune of New Orleans.

After two weeks of rising death rates, the city set a new low record for the year, 8 per 1,000 population, in the week ended last Saturday, it was reported yesterday by Thomas J. Duffield, Registrar of Records, to John L. Rice, City Health Commissioner. There were 1,145 deaths in the city during the week.
Francis H. Baldy of counsel to the Securities and Exchange Commission, withdrew today his request for a subpoena for Howard C. Hopson, former, head of the Associated Gas and Electric System.

The clash of Communist and right-wing members of the National Maritime Union last Thursday that resulted in the shooting of a man has caused a general breach in the ranks of the membership, it was learned yesterday. The union is affiliated with the C. I. O.
Officers in the Ecuadorian Army will not be permitted to marry until they reach the grade of captain, according to a recent decree.
Two parcels of two buildings each in the section just west of the theatrical district in midtown Manhattan changed hands in deals announced yesterday.

Playing no better than they had while tearing off seven of their eight games with the Browns and White Sox, but encountering infinitely stouter opposition, the Yankees in their gay dash through the West plunged to disaster today as the Tigers tripped the world champions in the opening clash of a three-game series, 4 to 3.

The merchants and residents of Long Beach, L. I., who last month applied for a temporary injunction in the Queens Supreme Court to restrain the Long Beach City Council from continuing to charge an admission fee to the public beach, lost their fight yesterday, when Justice Thomas C. Kadien denied their application.

Due to unexpected delays in offering dates, investment bankers now face an unusually active period in the field of new bond financing. The current wave of new offerings, which will, within the next ten days or so, approximate a total of $141,000,000,

Appointments were made with about 120 manufacturers and their representatives by buyers for the Read Drug and Chemical Company of Baltimore yesterday, following an advertisement by that concern for promotion merchandise at bargain prices.

The Gas House Gang ran completely out of gas at Ebbets Field yesterday, with the result that the Dodgers, zooming along on all cylinders, rolled over the Cardinals in both ends of a double-header. 6 to 2 and 9 to 3, to return to fifth place with a one-point margin over the Bees.
