Light may be thrown this Autumn on the controversy as to whether William Shakespeare actually wrote the works attributed to him, when the tomb of Edmund Spenser, poet. will be opened. Spenser was buried in the Poet's Corner of Westminster Abbey in 1599.

The six-family flat at 99 Old Bergen Road, Jersey City, N. J., was sold by the Hudson Savings Bank to Clemens A. Chalenski. In the sale the bank took back a purchase money mortgage for $5,000 due Oct. 1, 1943, at 4 per cent. The property is on a plot 33 by 93 feet.

The fifteenth music-memory contest of the Goldman Band will take place tonight at the Central Park Mall. The audience will be asked to identify excerpts of twenty-five compositions played by the band during the season.

The Postoffice Department will move its Clinton station from 1 Christopher Street to the building at 70 West Tenth Street, southeast corner of Sixth Avenue, where it has leased 2,220 square feet of ground floor space, it was revealed yesterday by J. F. Cahill Co., Inc., and Donald McIntyre, co-brokers, who negotiated the lease.

The Pennsylvania Legislature today ignored the advance defiance of Judge Paul N. Schaeffer and appointed a special committee of the House to take his grand jury investigation away from him "promptly."

A delegation of the New York City contingent of the Women's Rebellion, headed by Mrs. Charles L. Hulswit of Suffern, N. Y., their national leader, will call upon Kenneth F. Simpson, Republican County Chairman and National Committeeman, this afternoon and demand to know why he told them, as they contend, that Representative James W. Wadsworth first suggested the local Republican-American Labor party alliance.

The extreme right wing fascist leader, Roberto Farinacci, who can boast that Italian racism and anti-Semitism are in a certain sense his "invention" since he took up these problems before any one else in his newspaper,

Announcement has been made here of the marriage of Miss Vivian Shaw Kendall, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Waldo Shaw Kendall of Boston, to Dr. Ralph Leslie Hawkins of Sheridan, Wyo., which took place on Monday in the Leslie Lindsey Chapel of Emmanuel Church, Boston.

The Republican-controlled committee on public utilities for the second time within a month refused tonight to report out the Poletti proposal which would guarantee State control of the water-power resources on the St. Lawrence and Niagara Rivers.

The committee on stock list of the New York Stock Exchange directed yesterday that 400,000 more capital shares of Loft, Inc., be added to the list on official notice of issuance pursuant to options granted to the Phoenix Securities Corporation.

Mrs. Gertrude Dean Sill, wife of Richard Nicholl Sill, died today at her home here. She was born in Brooklyn and had been chairman of the Kenyon Players, one of Plainfield's Little Theatre groups, which was sponsored by the Monday Afternoon Club.

Surrogate James A. Foley signed an order yesterday authorizing a compromise agreement in the estate of John G. Lowe, retired Dayton (Ohio) manufacturer, by which his widow, Mrs. Edith F. Lowe of Denver, Col., is to receive $150,000 outright for her residuary legacy under her husband's will, together with personal effects valued at $41,000.

Buying habits and preferences of women in purchasing dresses, shoes, foundation garments and hosiery are studied and analyzed in a report by Crossley, Inc., research organization. Business women and housewives of all age groups were interviewed.

Enrico Venturi, 140, Italy, defeated Johnny Bellus, 137, New Haven, in the feature eight-round bout at Dyckman Oval last night before a crowd of 2,000. The winner closed with a rush to triumph in a close struggle.

Mrs. Alice Greenough Townsend of 1 Beekman Place and Oyster Bay, L. I., widow of Edward Mitchell Townsend, former senior partner in the textile firm of E. M. Townsend Co., died yesterday of heart disease in the New York Hospital after a brief illness.

A ruling that American citizenship of a child born in the United States is not lost if the parents become citizens of another country while the child is a minor was made yesterday by the Federal Court of Appeals of the District of Columbia in the case of Miss Marie Elizabeth Elg.

The following is appointed as an ununiformed fireman with compensation at the rate of $2,000 per annum, for a probationary period of three months, to take effect at 12:01 A. M., Aug. 3, and will be charged to the Code noted below. He will report to the Assistant Chief of Department for assignment to duty:

Cooperative efforts by all factors in the millinery industry to correct conditions which have hampered recovery were urged by speakers yesterday at an all-day merchandising clinic at the Hotel WaldorfAstoria under the auspices of the Millinery Merchandising Executives Association, Inc.

The recently published epistolary discussion between Deputy Mayor Henry H. Curran and Robert Moses, Commissioner of Parks, over floodlighting the statue of Henry Hudson at Spuyten Duyvil, provoked an anonymous writer to inform Mr. Curran that Hudson "never so much as saw the Hudson River or knew of its existence," and furthermore that "Robert Fulton was not the inventor of the steamboat."
Opposition to the Manhattan coalition of the Republican and American Labor parties continued to grow yesterday within the ranks of both groups.

The chess championship of the city in the Park Department's competition for boys and girls of the public playgrounds will be decided tomorrow afternoon at Heckscher Playground in Central Park when Victor Miletich, 16 years old, representing Tompkins Square Park, meets Harold Bernal, also 16, of Newtown (Queens) Playgrounds.

Wes Ferrell held the Browns to seven hits today as the Washington Senators won the first of a three-game series, 5 to 3, but the St. Louis club protested because of a mishap in which Umpire Harry Geisel was injured and carried from the field.

Mrs. Helene Fortescue Reynolds, whose husband charged her with consuming "most of the contents" of two bottles of champagne at their wedding reception, was prohibited today by a court order to remove her one-year-old son from Virginia.

Two squadrons of planes were sent to San Luis Potosi today to assist three columns of cavalry attempting to round up train wreckers and bandits operating there under Saturnino Cedillo, deposed Governor of that State.

Announcement that two of its major brands of whisky, Golden Wedding blended rye and Belmont bottled-in-bond bourbon, have been withdrawn from the protection of the Feld-Crawford price maintenance contracts in this area and that new contracts covering the brands mentioned and other products will be forthcoming Sept. 2, was made here last night by the Schenley Company.

Colonel Andres Urtecho, Minister of Foreign Relations during the Presidencies of Emillo Chamorro and Adolfo Diaz, died today. He was a graduate of the United States Military Academy at West Point and of the University of Pennsylvania.
The six-story apartment house at 76 Caryl Avenue, Yonkers, Westchester County, was sold by the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank to an investing client of Netter Netter, attorneys.

The tension worked up in Tennessee's bitter Democratic primary campaign eased considerably today with information from Nashville that Governor Gordon Browning apparently had abandoned any intention of sending National Guardsmen to Memphis in an effort to break the hold of his antagonist, Edward H. Crump, over the balloting on Thursday in powerful Shelby County.

A single upset marked today's second round play in the national junior tennis championship at Culver Military Academy when Larry Dee of San Francisco, seeded sixth, fell under Dan Canale's terrific volleys.

The city, seeking to protect present and future recreational facilities along the Brooklyn and Staten Island waterfronts from pollution, has made an urgent request to the Interstate Sanitation Commission to have the waters of the Upper Bay from the Narrows north to a point just below Erie Basin placed in Class A.
Earle W. Andrews, general manager of the World's Fair, has tendered his resignation from that office and hereafter will be associated with the fair as consulting engineer, it was reported yesterday.

The country looks upon graduates of the Plattsburg camps not only as trained leaders but as apostles of good citizenship, Colonel Thomas L. Crystal, commanding officer of the Twenty-sixth Infantry and camp commander,

The pianists, Josef and Rosina Lhevinne, who are celebrating their fortieth anniversary as man and wife and as collaborating artists, appeared as soloists last night at Lewisohn Stadium, attracting an audience of some 6,500.

Stocks traded on the New York Curb Exchange had an aggregate value on July 30 of $10,606,403,553, against $10,130,531,753 at the end of June. The average price of each share rose from $14.44 to $15.25.

A young couple were victims of a mysterious shooting while strolling in Virgil Place, near Pugsley Avenue, the Bronx, at 10:30 o'clock last night. The youth was wounded near the spine and in the shoulder, and the girl in the left thigh, by a man who stepped from a clump of bushes.

Miss Susan Minns, scientist, art collector, philanthropist and one of the first women to study at Massachusetts Institute of Technology, died today in her ninety-ninth year at her home here. She was said to be the oldest former student of M. I. T.
Turpentine firm, 23 1/4c: sales, 132 barrels; receipts, 567 barrels; shipments, 5,130 barrels; stock, 39,078 barrels. Resin firm sales, 253 receipts, 3,205; shipments. 3,022: stock, 194.986.
Countess Heinrich von Bernstorff, wife of the German Ambassador to Washington when the United States entered the World War, was named today principal beneficiary of an estate amounting to ??130,344.

The extent of this government's activities in the tense situation growing out of the Russo-Japanese border dispute is the "very special interest" it is taking in the varying reports from the Far East on the struggle of Russian and Japanese forces for possession of Changkufeng Hill, Secretary of State Cordell Hull said today.
In May the Department of Justice exhumed a Federal statute of 1870 which made it a Federal offense to conspire to deny to any citizen the rights guaranteed by the Federal Constitution or laws.

Five men narrowly escaped death when the WPA motor launch Primrose, at anchor off the foot of Thirty-sixth Street, Brooklyn, exploded at 10:30 o'clock yesterday morning and sank five minutes later in New York Bay.

After a lengthy debate shot through with partisan politics, the Constitutional Convention in committee of the whole today, by a vote of 84 to 65, gave its assent to the creation of a new judicial district which would become known as the Tenth and would be composed of the two counties of Nassau and Suffolk on Long Island, outside of the New York City boundaries.
The White Sox scored six runs in the third inning today to break their six-game losing streak by defeating the Athletics, 8 to 4, in the first of a five-game series.

The Electric Bond and Share Company reported yesterday net income of $10,113,865 for the twelve months ended on June 30, equal after preferred dividend requirements to 32 cents a share on 5,267,147 common shares, against $10,017,399, or 30 cents a share, in the preceding year.

The large waterfront industrial property formerly owned by the Chelsea Fibre Mills, Inc., on Newtown Creek, in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn, has been purchased by the Marthed Realty Corporation, which in turn has leased it to the Centaur Paper Mills Supply Company, Harry Pearlman president.

President Roosevelt has rejected suggestions that he make another "nonpolitical" swing through the Middle West before the November elections, has postponed until late in September his scheduled participation in the dedication of the Port Huron International Bridge and limited his itinerary on that occasion to a four-day round-trip jaunt from his Hyde Park home.

So far virtually all that we nave heard of Russo-Japanese clashes over the disputed hills of Changkufeng has come in official communiques from Moscow and Tokyo. It is easy to pick quarrels on the wild and vaguely defined frontiers where Siberia meets the anomalous States of Manchukuo and Korea, annexed but never fully conquered by the Nipponese Empire.
The league-leading Pirates ran into a superb four-hit pitching performance by Johnny Lanning today and dropped the series opener to the hustling Bees, 3 to 1.

An increase of 47 per cent in sales of American aircraft, aircraft engines and spare parts for the first six months of 1938, compared with the corresponding period of last year, was reported yesterday by Leighton W. Rogers, president of the Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The letter entitled "The Unwritten Constitution" seems to me to reflect all too well the false motivations for voting that are continually held up before the American public.

Mrs. Julius Walsh gave a luncheon at the Gideon Putnam today for Mrs. Arthur Boyd Hancock and Mrs. Silas B. Mason. Mrs. Charles H. Tuttle entertained Mrs. James McAffee of Toronto and Mrs. Richard Spaulding of Burlington, Vt.

Miss Margaret Middleton Bradford, daughter of Mrs. Russell Bradford of Southport, Conn., and New York, has selected Sept. 10 as the date of her marriage to Edouard Sandoz, son of Dr. and Mrs. Charles Edouard Sandoz of Cambridge, Mass.
The Forty Niners' fourth production of the season, S. N. Behrman's comedy "Biography," opened here tonight at the Chase Barn Playhouse. Jane Gordon played the leading role of Marion Proude.

State regulation of the hard coal industry and operation of idle mines by an "anthracite public authority" was proposed to the Legislature in a series of bills sponsored by Governor Earle's commission which investigated conditions in the mining fields.

Final settlement of that part of the reorganization plan of the Cleveland Terminals Building Company which involves the Terminal Tower was in sight today after the required majority of bondholders agreed on the plan, but will be delayed until the Federal Government's claim for back taxes of $871,000 against the Cleveland Terminals Building Company is disposed of.

Miss Edith Aiken Egleson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Ernest A. Egleson of this place, has chosen the evening of Sept. 16 for her marriage to Joseph W. Bower, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Bower of Montclair. The ceremony, which will be performed in St. Peter's Church here by the pastor, the Rev. Harold Onderdonk, will be followed by a reception at the Essex Fells Country Club.
The Radley College crew of Abingdon, England, is slated to visit this country for an international eight-oared race with Tabor Academy over the latter's course at Marion, Mass., on Aug. 24.

The pace quickened at the yearling sales tonight when sixtythree head passed under the hammer for a total of $128,275, an average of $2,036. The top price was for a brown colt by Blue Larkspur and out of Speed Boat that went for $13,000 and was . knocked down to Don Cameron, well-known trainer.

The approach to Germany on behalf of 500,000 future refugees was being prepared behind the scenes today as the delegates representing twenty-seven governments resumed the work begun at the Evian conference last month.

Freeman Bernstein, 69 years old, said to be an old-time vaudeville agent, was committed to the Tombs yesterday by General Sessions Judge James G. Wallace for arraignment next month before Judge Saul S. Streit as a violator of probation a 1936 bogus check charge.

An investigating committee of the special session of the Penhsylvania Legislature called on Judge Paul N. Schaeffer in the Criminal Court here today and asked him to make way for them. They succeeded only in making him mad.
Every year at just about this time both sport and commercial fishermen rise up and want to know what is "going to be done about the illegal activities of the bunker boats and trawlers."

Wheat futures advanced about 1 cent a bushel in the early trading on. the Board of Trade here today, due largely to sympathy with Liverpool and on buying induced by. the strained situation in Europe and the Far East, but the upturn was not maintained.

The, sixteenth regional trust conference of the Pacific Coast and Rocky Mountain States, which is under the auspices of the trust division of the American Bankers Association, will be held in the St. Francis Hotel, San Francisco,

ADELSTEIN--Abraham, beloved husband of Annie, dear father of Betty Rogers, May Crantson, Moe, Bertha Cohen, Rose Lifton and Herman. Services Park West Memorial Chapel, 79th St. and Columbus Ave., today, 11 A. M.
District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey, moving ahead with preparations of his policy racket case against James J. Hines, Tammany district leader, was attacked twice yesterday.

Living up to her heralded reputation by winning with ease, Thomas D. Taggart's Marica today finished two lengths in front of Norman W. Church's Patty Cake in the $5,000 added Mary Dyer Handicap, mileand-70-yard feature at Narragansett Park.

Edward S. Wagner, first vice president and treasurer of the Scott Paper Company, has addressed a letter to stockholders outlining a proposal to issue 30,000 shares of no-par $4.50 dividend cumulative preferred stock to be acted upon at a special meeting of stockholders on Aug. 15.

The International Student Service closed its seventeenth congress here today with a decision to carry on its campaign for the relief of Chinese and Austrian students. It also decided to send a telegram to the inter-governmental refugee committee in London on behalf of student refugees.
A further break in Japanese dollar obligations, even more severe than that on Tuesday, featured an otherwise dull session in the bond market on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.

Arthur C. Weil, who has a seat on the New York Stock Exchange and an office in the brokerage house of Halle Stieglitz at 25 Broadway, was haled yesterday before Federal Judge T. Whitfield Davidson after he had declined to produce the stub of a $1,000 check for the inspection of a grand jury, on the ground that its surrender might tend to degrade or incriminate him.

It is easy to imagine the mixed emotions with which Premier Hodza welcomes Lord Runciman as he arrives in Prague, quite unofficially but accompanied by a group of experts from the Foreign Office, and settles in for a long tussle with Czechoslovakia's central problem.
Among the security transactions in June reported by officers, directors and principal stockholders of issuers of registered securities, made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission,

Wlllett St, 97, 306 E 74th St Corp, Hiram S. Lewine, president, to Jack Kreiner, 428 2d Ave ($6.50). Willett St, 101, same to same. 14th St, 538 E, Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank to Beta Estates. Inc, 270 Bway; purchase money mtg $21,404 and building loan intg $4,500 ($21.50).
Rollie Stiles, veteran righthander, registered his twelfth triumph of the season today by blanking the Buffalo Bisons with six hits, 5--0, as the Jersey City Giants swept a three-game series.
Apartments in buildings on Park and Fifth Avenues and on the intersecting streets close to those thoroughfares drew many of the new East Side tenancies listed yesterday.

President Lazaro Cardenas snubbed Vicente Lombardo Toledano, head of the Confederation of Mexican labor unions [C. T. M.], today by refusing to appear on the balcony of the National Palace or to receive unionists demonstrating against the "reactionary press." The C. T.
NEWS OF METROPOLITAN REAL ESTATE

Investors figured as purchasers in several of the New Jersey realty deals reported yesterday. Stefania Gapinski, an investing client of J. I. Kislak, Inc., bought the six-family apartment house at 99 Old Bergen Road, Greenville, Jersey City, from the Hudson City Savings Bank.

The Procurement Division of the United States Treasury Department, which has been doing the purchasing of men's clothing for the WPA, will probably complete its task today or tomorrow, it was indicated yesterday. Yesterday's purchases of $722,299.44 brought the total amount of orders placed to $7,454,241, leaving about $900,000 worth of orders remaining to be placed.

A delay in the controversial Kansas City stockyards case was refused by Justice Butler of the Supreme Court today after counsel for livestock commission men had sought a stay in the proceedings and the government resisted the effort.

Boston Rd, 1.159 (10-2614); Empire City Savings Bank to Sarah Gershuny, 2,160 Clinton Ave. Netherland Ave (13-3426), e s, 265 ft s of 261st St, 69x119; Eileen Klein to Edna Lamb, 5,992 Netherland Ave. Arlington Ave (13-3408C), w s. 78 ft n of 231st St, 50x97: Elizabeth Langle to Augustinian Pathers of Our Mother of Consolation, 3,103 Arlington Ave.
Big Buck Newsom allowed the Senators six hits today as the Browns evened their current series with Washington. The score was 5 to 3.

Lady Cleveland, widow of Sir Charles Cleveland, who as the head of the Indian Criminal Investigation Department in the World War had charge of all espionage and counter-espionage work in that country, was stripped and searched at the German frontier, according to reports reaching here today.

Six human heads were received today by the authorities in Alagoas State. They were sent by members of the band of Virgolino Lampeao, Brazil's notorious bandit, who succeeded in evading the State police net when Lampeao was killed last week.

The Justice Department studied today the advisability of modifying a fiveyear-old consent decree restricting trade practices of the National Retail Credit Association. Conferences already have been held between government attorneys and representatives of the association, informed persons said, but no decision has been reached.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Dr. Hugh Cabot in your issue of July 25 says, referring to medical practice: "A guild has been evolved, and with it a tendency to diminish the number of physicians, to increase the cost of medical care and consequently to make it more difficult for the low-income groups to receive medical care.
Close of play scores in county circket matches started today: Middlesex 395 (Edrich 159, Robins 68, Compton 58, Sims 50, Hollies four for 95); Warwickshire 14 for one. at Birmingham.

After having spent fourteen weeks in Palestine the British commission for implementing the partition scheme, headed by Sir John Woodhead, has finished its task and its members sailed from Haifa today.

Mayor La Guardia delivered a slashing attack yesterday on State Senator A. Spencer Feld for having procured the reinstatement of a dismissed teacher after she had given him an assignment of back pay in lieu of a cash fee.

Herbert R. Pendleton, insurance broker and a descendant of early New Yorkers, died Tuesday in Jamaica Hospital, Jamaica, Queens, after a short illness, at the age of 66. His home was at 32 Ingram Street, Forest Hills, Queens.

W. Earle Andrews, former general Superintendent of the Park Department and right-hand man of Park Commissioner Robert Moses, yesterday surrendered his duties as general manager of the New York. World's Fair, to become consulting engineer to the organization.

The Bureau of Agricultural Economics estimated the 1938 wool crop today at 368,528,000 pounds. This is about 2,000,000 pounds more than in 1937 and about the same increase over the average for the last five years.

Following is a translation of the text of the Mexican reply to the United States note of July 21 asking international arbitration of the question of immediate payment of indemnity for nationalized American agrarian properties as handed today to Ambassador Josephus Daniels:

The new occupancy tax of from $1 to $6 imposed on business rentals has produced $507,267 from 236,687 returns, Almerindo Portfolio, City Treasurer, reported yesterday. Payments were due July 30 and delinquent returns will increase the total some. It.

With Charlie Keller and Frankie Kelleher taking the leading offensive roles, the Bears today extended their winning streak to eight games as they defeated Montreal, 6 to 3, behind seven-hit pitching by Atley Donald.
The Department of Parks filed yesterday plans for changes in the three-story public bath house at 326-28 Rivington Street at a cost of $100,000.
The Treasury today accepted the $1 bid of the city of New York for the old postoffice and courthouse on lower Broadway. This permits the city to proceed with its demolition.

Despite his indifferent play in all matches to date, Welby Van Horn, No. 1 junior from San Francisco, paced the national championship aspirants into the quarter-finals of the boys' and juniors' tennis tourney today at the Culver Military Academy, eliminating Robert Freedman, Springfield, Mass., 6-1, 4-6, 6-0, and William Power, Worcester, Mass., 6-4, 7-9, 7-5.

The third annual women's metropolitan Scotch foursome tournament, played over the east and west nines of the Ridgewood Country Club, was won today by the team of Mrs. Charles Leichner of Fresh Meadow and Mrs. De Witt Untermeyer of Hollywood, who added an 88 to yesterday's tally of 87 for a total of 175.

Labor's Non-Partisan League, headed by John L. Lewis of the C. I. O., has failed so far in its efforts to purge the House of Representatives of legislators it opposes. In primary elections to date, mem- c bers disapproved by the league have been uniformly successful in winning renomination.

The committee for holders of first and refunding-mortgage bonds of the West Ohio Gas Company, a subsidiary of the Midland Utilities Company, has filed a revised plan for reorganizing the West Ohio concern which would cut the

Representative Martin Dies of Southeast Texas swung into action yesterday as chairman of the Congressional Committee on Un-American Activities by serving a subpoena on George Sylvester Viereck, author and friend of the former Kaiser, as Mr. Viereck was packing for a trip to Europe.
Patrolman Joseph Conboy, 31 years old, of 2,632 Marion Avenue, the Bronx, a member of the stanchion repair division, was arrested last night on a charge of impairing the morals of a 5-year-old girl.
A number of rentals in the Washington Square area were listed by brokers yesterday in the reports of West Side leasing. The list follows:
Stocks erased opening gains and closed fractionally lower, gold shares strongest feature; turnover, 817,160 shares.

Admitting his fear of how "the fighting Irishmen in Brooklyn" would take his decision, Douglas Corrigan decided last night the battle between the boroughs for the privilege of the first welcome to him.

The Pegasus four and the Ox Ridge Hunt Club were successful today in their engagements in the Northeastern intracircuit tourney at the Blind-Brook Turf and Polo Club. Both teams won by one-point margins, Pegasus defeating the Blind Brook Raiders, 8 to 7, and Ox Ridge topping the Bethpage Polo Club. 6 to 5.

For the first time in more than-four years the Medal of Honor, awarded to United States soldiers, sailors and marines for extraordinary heroism in the line of duty, was awarded posthumously to Lieutenant Carlton B. Hutchins, U. S. N.. who was a native of Albany, N. Y.
Police Captain James Harten, aide to Mayor La Guardia, appeared for his official escort duties yesterday clad in a spotless white uniform patterned after the regulation blue attire of the police.

With play in the singles at a standstill for the day, two rounds of doubles were completed in the wommen's invitation tennis tournament at the Maidstone Club today, bringing the field into the semi-finals.

149th St, 414 W. 19x99.11: Graham P. Riley to Charles M. Grundy et al. 414 W 149th St, execr James P. Grundy, p m mtg 10 yrs, 5%; $11,000. Amsterdam Ave, 1,754, 25x100; 144 Claremont Ave. Corp. to Jacob R. Schiff, 575 Park Ave, installments. 6%: S6.000. Convent Ave. 408, 17x75: Lillie Aird to Jacob D. Goodman, 25 Eastern Parkway, Bklyn. p m mtg, 5 yrs, 5%: $5,500.

A wide variety of novelty merchandise was offered to buyers for the Read Drug and Chemical Company of Baltimore, who opened a mass buying session at the Hotel Vanderbilt yesterday. The buyers took notes and samples and will make final purchases on Saturday. Salesmen and manufacturers will be interviewed today and tomorrow.

A struggle of almost two decades between two unions for supremacy in the clothing industry ended here today when 900 employes of a large company, the last having a closedshop agreement with the United Garment Workers (A. F. L.), ratified a closed-shop contract with the Amalgamated Clothing Workers (C. I. O.).

To the accompaniment of a largescale hoarding demand for gold in London, the pound sterling yesterday again plunged downward in the foreign exchange market. Other foreign exchanges followed the lead' of the British unit, and the dollar reached its highest exchange value in more than a year.

Donald Budge, world's No. 1 amateur tennis player, received the James E. Sullivan Memorial Trophy in recognition of his athletic achievements and sportsmanship during 1937 at a formal presentation at the New York A. C. yesterday.

The Brooklyn Union Gas Company reported yesterday for the first half of 1938 a net profit of $658,870, equal to 88 cents each on 745,364 no-par capital shares, compared with $919,977, or $1.24 a share, earned in the corresponding period of 1937. Gross revenue was $11,483,910, against $10,955,649.

Conflicting testimony concerning what transpired on the night of June 8, 1937, under the Market Street Bridge in Youngstown, Ohio, when deputy sheriffs released tear gas and arrested fourteen men after two policemen had been beaten and one man shot, was offered before the Civil Liberties Committee today by Sheriff Ralph Elser and the Youngstown police on one side, and a dozen strikers on the other.

The $900,000,000 Standard Gas and Electric Company has been released from court jurisdiction under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act with the entering of a decree in the United States District Court at Wilmington, Del. The company has been in reorganization proceedings since September, 1935. The court, however, has reserved jurisdiction in certain matters.

Pope Pius today named Father Matthew F. Brady of Hamden, Conn., as Bishop of Burlington, Vt. The Rev. Matthew F. Brady, whose appointment by Pope Pius as Bishop of the Diocese of Burlington, Vt., was announced today, has been pastor of St. Rita's Church here for the mast five ears.
Calmly, deliberately, 19-year-old Paul N. Dwyer today accused Francis M. Carroll, father of his former sweetheart, of the two "death tour" slaying which the youth had previously confessed.

Selection of thirteen candidates as qualified to compete for places on the Citizens' Military Training Camp rifle team to be entered in the national matches at Camp Perry, Ohio, has been announced by Colonel Thomas L. Crystal, commanding officer, Twenty-sixth Infantry.
The Indians divided a double-header with the Red Sox today in blistering heat before 35,000 fans, leaving Cleveland two games behind the first-place Yankees.

Morris Abrams Dress Corp,. floor with 5,000 sq ft in. 260-62 W 35th St. completing the rental of this building; Urban Co, Inc, agents. Dr. Henry G. Bauman, dentist, through Samuel W. Cracowaner, in 580 5th Ave; The House of Fashion, Inc, dresses, additional space in 1 W 47th St; Ruford D. Franklin, owners' representative.
Health conditions among American wage-earners and their families are better than they ever have been, according to statisticians of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.

Viscount and Viscountess Runciman arrived at Wilson Statidn this afternoon and were met by the British Minister, Basil Cochrane Newton, the legation staff and Lord Runciman's own advance guard. Contrary to previous indications official representatives of the government were Present.

A banking group headed by Lehman Brothers and including First Boston Corporation, GLore, Forgan Co., Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and fifty-nine other firms, is expected to offer publicly tomorrow $37,500,000 of first mortgage bonds and serial notes of Indianapolis Power and Light Company.

The request of the City Council committee to investigate relief for an appropriation of $55,000 was rejected yesterday by the Board of Estimate. The funds were to finance a twenty-week inquiry by a large staff of attorneys, accountants and investigators.

Actual orders for wash goods and women's and children's apparel placed the first three days of the Fall market opening are from 15 to 20 per cent ahead of last year, exhibitors said today. Apparel floors in the Merchandise Mart reported sales as 18 per cent ahead of a year ago.

The Board of Estimate, overriding a protest that 95 per cent of the residents of Richmond were opposed to the project, approved yesterday an agreement with the State under which the State will build a $12,000,000 home to care for 5,000 feeble-minded children in the vicinity of Willowbrook Park, S. I.
The Athletics padded their batting averages today by battering four White Sox pitchers for thirty-four hits and two victories, 14 to 2 and 13 to 5.

Allen Klots in the Atlantic, Inflation, and Jimmy Fox in the Star, Nereid II, were among the winners today as lads and lassies under eighteen manned thirty-two boats for the second annual August regatta of the Junior Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound.

Officials of Shaker Heights, Ohio, will consider bids on Aug. 22 for $826,263 of refunding bonds. The issue will be dated Aug. 15, 1938, and will mature serially on April 1 and Oct. 1, 1940 to 1952. The bonds will bear interest at the rate of 3 per cent.

The Board of Commissioners of Jersey City have authorized the purchase of the plant and lands of the George Stratford Oakum Company at the northeast corner of Cornelison Avenue and Du Pont Street at the rear of the Medical Center, consisting of an area of 265,000 square feet.

A two-months dispute between the local hatters' unions and manufacturers over proposed wage cuts was ended yesterday by a decision handed down by the State Board of Mediation and Arbitration, ordering wage reductions ranging from 7 1/2 per cent to 10 per cent in all phases of the industry.
It was too hot for any great expenditure of effort, so the Giants defeated the Cubs at the Polo Grounds yesterday by the simplest and most efficient method they could devise.
Mme. Chiang Kai-shek said today that she would encourage the 30,000 women workers of the Hankow metropolitan area to leave the city before the Japanese offensive reached here.

For the first time since he founded his religious cult some fifteen years ago, Father Divine, Negro evangelist, is to have "a home of his own"--a fifty-room mansion complete with its own private telephone system and a dictaphone arrangement that will carry his message of peace to every part of the house.

France cornered the American cognac market yesterday. A ruling by Secretary Morgenthau denied American vintners the right to designate brandies produced in this country as cognac even though they possessed the taste, aroma and general characteristics of the French product.

Two years of service in the Foreign Office here will be required in the future before diplomats and consuls from Ecuador may fill foreign posts, according to a new law reorganizing the Foreign Service.

The Citizens Union joined with other civic groups and bar associations yesterday in urging all political parties and independent groups to nominate Municipal Court Justice Matthew M. Levy, the American Labor party designee, as candidate for a full term on the Municipal Court bench in the First Bronx District.

Captain John O'Leary, who has been commanding Traffic D of the Police Department's traffic division in Manhattan, has been appointed an Acting Deputy Inspector to take the place of the late Inspector Louis Rosenfeld as head of the Fourth Traffic District in Queens, Police Commissioner Valentine announced yesterday. Captain O'Leary joined the force in 1913.

Both Chinese and Japanese claimed victory today in a largescale air battle near Hankow, provisional Chinese capital. Japanese asserted that a Japanese air fleet engaged fifty-four Chinese planes, shot down thirty-two and destroyed seven more in a bombing raid yesterday on Hankow, which ended with only two Japanese craft missing.

On his own application, to take effect 12 midnight, Aug. 2: PATROLMAN-William G. Campbell, Mounted Squadron 2, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Aug. 26, 1912. Transfers and Assignments To take effect 8 A. M.. Aug. 3: CAPTAIN-John M. O'Leary, from Traffic Precinct D to Fourth District Traffic, designated as Acting Deputy Inspector. To take effect 8 A. M., Aug. 4: SERGEANT-George McNulty, from 19th Precinct to 18th Division.

The historic Kenner Stakes, which goes back to 1870, had one of its most thrilling renewals today when Bull Lea, Fighting Fox and Stormscud were noses apart in the order named at the end of the mile and three-sixteenths.

Robert Clifford Burnside, a member of the board of directors of the New York Board of Trade for the last ten years, died of pneumonia yesterday at his residence, 55 East Seventy-second Street. His age was 71.

Dr. Victor G. Heiser, former Director of Health of the Philippine Islands and author of "An American Doctor's Odyssey," has been appointed research director of the National Association of Manufacturers committee on healthful working conditions.

The Italian motorship Conte Di Savoia is arriving today from Mediterranean ports. Passengers are Frank Chapman Jr. and Gladys Swarthout, Giacomo Fara Forni, Bishop Joseph Bonner, Miss Viola Shafer, Count and Countess Bompiani, Bishop James Howard, Baron Francesco Tucci, Dr. Herbert Kalmus, Mr. and Mrs. George Armour and Mr. and Mrs. Harry Hatry.

Louis C. Loewenstein, a consulting engineer with offices at 21 West Street, -died suddenly yesterday of a heart attack in his apartment in the Hotel Bolivar, 230 Central Park West. He was born in Mora, N. M., sixty-two years ago.

Many members of the Summer colony attended the meeting of the Academy of American Poets, held this afternoon at Buonriposo, Summer residence of Mrs. Shepard Fabbri. Charles E. Burden Jr., secretary of the academy, presided. Robert P. Tristram Coffin was the guest poet. Miss Alice Mansur, Boston poet, gave an address on two contemporary poets, John Holmes and Winifred Wells.

Senator George L. Berry and his political mentor, Governor Gordon Browning, will go to the post in Tennessee's hardest-fought Democratic primary tomorrow with odds quoted against the chances of either to win renomination.

Twentysix additional non-Federal projects, including a school for West Milford, N. J., having an estimated construction value of $5,088,651 with PWA grants of $2,289,888 were announced today by Secretary Ickes. The West Milford school, for which the PWA granted $112,500, will cost $250,000.

Keeping his promise to return to the Lewisohn Stadium on what is hoped will be a clear night, Mischa Elman will appear as soloist with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra there tonight. He is scheduled to play the Tchaikovsky concerto. The entire program will be devoted to Tchaikovsky, with Alexander Smallens conducting the "Pathetique" Symphony and the Polonaise from "Eugene Onegin."

The protective committee for the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railway first and refunding mortgage 4 per cent and secured 4' per cent bonds, Series A, filed today with the Interstate Commerce Commission a demand that motions recently made by the protective committee for holders of Rock Island, Arkansas Louisiana Railroad first mortgage 4,2 per cent bonds be denied.

The frontier between Chile and Bolivia will undergo modification with mutual concessions, according to a statement given out here today revealing that the National Assembly of Bolivia has approved a protocol of May 1. 1907.

In a five-minute radio talk here this evening, Herman P. Kopplemann of Hartford, Democratic House member from the First Connecticut district, formally announced his candidacy for the Senate seat held by Augustine Lonergan, who was recently endorsed by Attorney General Cummings.

District Attorney William F. X. Geoghan of Brooklyn announced yesterday that his investigation into charges that his assistant, William F. McGuinness, and George Murphy, city-employed elevator operator, had conspired to "fix" a criminal case "is still open and will stay open until we have placed every iota of actionable evidence before the public."

Mrs. Alonzo Potter entertained with a luncheon today for Miss Henrietta Hoopes, whose exhibition of watercolors will continue until next Wednesday at Four Fountains, the studio of Mr. and Mrs. Lucien Hamilton Tyng. Miss Hoopes is visiting Mr. and Mrs. Potter at Westmoor.

Russia possesses the only map left real showing the Manchurian border as established by the Sino-Russian treaty of 1869, a high Chinese Government official said today in discussing the Changkufeng hostilities between Japan and Russia.

A law setting up a retirement and pension system for bank employes on the island was passed last night by the House of Representatives. This bill already has the approval of the Senate and now will go to President Laredo Bru for his signature.

Thomas J. Watson, president of International Business 'Machines Corporation, prior to- sailing yesterday on the Normandie for a European tour expressed himself optimistic about the revival of American business.

Plunged into another overtime battle and considerably irritated about the whole thing, what with the excessive heat and the taunts of 20,000 onlookers ringing in their ears, the Yankees laid violent hands upon one Harry Eisenstat in the eleventh inning today and by smashing three runs across the plate, two on Joe Gordon's fourteenth homer, walloped the Tigers, 10 to 7.

The first step in a program designed to effect write-downs aggregating well above $100,000,000 throughout the $700,000,000 Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation system was undertaken yesterday when the Cincinnati Gas and Electric Company, one of Columbia's largest subsidiaries, issued to shareholders a proposal to restate the capital represented by its common stock for the purpose of creating a capital surplus of $22,500,000.

The National Maritime Union, affiliate of the C. I. O., has called a general membership meeting for tomorrow night at the Manhattan Opera House, at which the results of the first election of officers since the formation of the union in May, 1937, will be announced.

Mrs. Helen Vinson Perry, actress wife of Fred Perry, the tennis player, has brought suit in Supreme Court to recover $33,000 from the New York Life Insurance Company whose negligence, she alleges, is.responsible for a loss she suffered.

Its annual music memory contest was held last night by the Goldman Band, Edwin Franko Goldman directing, on the Mall in Central Park. The program attracted an audience of more than 30,000, the largest that has listened to a concert by the band this season.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Aug. 3, unless specified: Dahlgren to Newport: Badger, Decatur.' Fairfax, Herbert, Leary, J. F. Talbott. Manila to sea, July 30: Canopus, Pigeon, .Stewart, S-36; 37, 38, 39, 40, 41. At San Francisco: Chester, Chicago, Indianapolis, Mindanao, Northampton, Quincy. Salt Lake City.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated Aug. 2: MAJOR GENERAL Cole, W. E., Fort Hayes, Ohio, to retirement, Sept. 30.

The Coast Guard will celebrate its 148th anniversary tomorrow. It was founded by the First Congress in 1790 as the Revenue Marine. Celebrations will be held on vessels of the service wherever they may be throughout the large part of the world they patrol.

Stipulations to desist from various false and misleading claims regarding medicinal preparations have been entered into with the Federal Trade Commission by four New York firms and one in Jersey City, the commission announced today.

A Vatican news service announced today a decree authorizing the beatification of Frances Xavier Cabrini, an Italian nun who worked and died in the United States, would be read next Saturday in the presence of Pope Pius.

Gathered off here tonight were most of the fifty-nine entries for the American Yacht Club's cruise. The others will arrive early in the morning for the harbor start at 10 A. M. on the first run, that of twenty-six miles over to Port Jefferson, L. I.

The veteran Sep Palin stole the show at the Grand Circuit meeting at Agawam Park today by winning two races. Palin piloted Her Ladyship to a straight heat victory in the Seven Oaks Dairy Stake, a 2:15 pace, and brought Hanover the Great to the fore in three successive heats in the 2:15 Rainault Trot.

Dr. Frank Quackenbush, Northport dentist, died of a heart ailment this morning in his sixty-fifth year at the Huntington Hospital. He was born in Paterson, N. J., son of David and Charity Ann Van Houten Quackenbush, on Sept. 3, 1873. He was a graduate of New York University.

The Board of Estimate authorized Corporation Counsel William C. Chanler yesterday to sell copies of the index to the city's Administrative Code to the public at $1 a copy. The index permits quick reference to the body of organic law applying to the city, and it is expected to be in wide demand among attorneys and others interested in the law.

Expressing gratification yesterday over the dropping in Monticello, N. Y., of the case against Mrs. Fay Reder, in which she was routed out of bed early last Thursday morning and arrested for nonpayment of a $4.50 hotel bill,

Herbert Bayard Swope entertained with a dinner last night at the Gideon Putnam for Mr. and Mrs. Warren Wright, Mrs. Dodge Sloane, Mrs. Frederick F. Alexandre, Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Louchheim, Dr. and Mrs, Charles H. Strube, Mr. and Mrs. Marshall Cassidy, Mr. and Mrs. Jackson A. Dykman, Mrs. George Lamaze, Dr. and Mrs. E. Terry Smith and Harry F. Guggenheim.

Jay Emanuel, Morris Berkov, Henry Marcus and Carl A. Kuhnle, investigators in the Department of Finance, invaded Long Island City and adjoining districts as far as Forest Hills on Monday and Tuesday, looking for vendors and storekeepers who might be selling cigarettes without the proper city tax stamps on the packages.
A motor tricycle and stereographic maps which bring boldly before the eye the contours of terrain are only a few of the military innovations which the modern army is testing, it was learned today.
Railroad managements and the Brotherhoods of Railroad Trainmen today ended ing their negotiations over the carriers' proposed 15 per cent wage cut, 1937, which the trainmen rejected.
The application of the German marriage laws to Austria Aug. 1 brought a multitude of applications to civil marriage offices here for the transformation of separations into complete divorces.

Voters of 197 municipalities located in thirty-two States during the month of July approved bond issues aggregating $9,566,229, as compared with $8,989,260 bonds approved in June, according to The Daily Bond Buyer. The total for July, 1937, was S10.017.836.

The Sixth Avenue elevated line is "an undue obstruction to traffic or the proper use and enjoyment of the public streets occupied thereby," according to a resolution adopted unanimously yesterday by the Board of Estimate after a short public hearing at City Hall.

Following the recent equalization of tin plate prices at Gary, Ind., and Pittsburgh, the Granite City .Steel Company is quoting tin plate at $5.45 per base box, at Granite City, Ill., a $2 a ton reduction from recent prices, retroactive to June 24, Iron Age says this week.

Fifteen thousand new WPA jobs, bringing the total in this city to 175,000, have been authorized by the Federal relief agency, Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress Administrator, announced yesterday.

Barcelona suffered a terrible bombing tonight. All the bombs fell inside the city in many streets. There must have been many persons killed and wounded here, but it has been impossible to get details.

C. K. Munro's "Coronation at Mrs. Beam's," the third in this week's Malvern drama festival series renews acquaintance with the inmates of Mrs. Beam's "select boardinghouse" on the eve of the coronation.

Nello (Flash) Falaschi, Santa Clara captain and quarterback in 1936, has signed with the New York Football Giants for the coming season, it was announced yesterday by John V. Mara, president of the club.

Testimony that operation of a north-bound automobile on the left or westerly side of the Lake GeorgeBolton Landing highway caused the collision resulting in the deaths of two young women July 16 was given by two witnesses at the opening of an inquest today in the office of District Attorney Fred M. Beckwith. Dr. Herbert A. Bartholomew, coroner, presided.

A total of 1,254 stock issues aggregating 1,427,048,784 shares and with a total market value of $44,784,224,215 were listed on the New York Stock Exchange at the close of business on July 30; it was announced yesterday.
James L. Conway, real estate trust officer of the. Guaranty Trust Company of New York, died yesterday morning at Westhampton Beach, L. I., of heart attack, at the age of 44. He was born in this city.

More than 100 members of the bar of New York City attended yesterday a memorial service for Benjamin N. Cardozo, associate justice of the United States Supreme Court, in the Wall Street Synagogue at 35 Maiden Lane.

At the observance of the feast day of St. Dominic in the Church of St. Vincent Ferrer, Lexington Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street, today at 10 A. M., a friendship dating back more than seven hundred years between members of the Dominican and Franciscan Orders will be renewed.
Maax Friedman, retired real estate man, died yesterday at his home, 65 East 193d Street. the Bronx. Born in Hungary seventy-three years ago, he came here more than fifty years ago.

Senator Bennett Champ Clark's overwhelming renomination in yesterday's Democratic primary in Missouri prompted one of his Senatorial colleagues to declare today that Mr. Clark is an outstanding possibility for President in 1940.

The grounds of the Art Association of Newport was the setting this afternoon for a colorful lawn party in behalf of the coal fund of the association. Mrs. Le Brun Rhinelander was chairman and assisting her as co-chairmen were Mrs. Francis L. V. Hoppin and Mrs. Lawrence Lewis Gillespie.

" Prologue to Glory," the WPA Theatre Project's play, was made available in book form early this week by two publishing houses. Random House included it in its "Federal Theatre Play Anthology" and Samuel French published an edition of the play as a separate title.
Producers representing 80 per cent of the volume of the toilet goods and cosmetic industry have accepted "full responsibility and liability" for the truthfulness and

The American Legion, Department of New York, will hold its annual convention at Endicott, N. Y., Aug. 11, 12 and 13 and it is expected that more than 30,000 members of the organization and its auxiliary will attend.

Fearing Soviet air raids, Japan blacked out the lights in Eastern cities and started the evacuation of civilians from towns in Northern Korea near the scene of the battle at Changkufeng on the Manchukuoan-Siberian frontier.

There is more than one issue involved in the controversy between Governor Kraschel of Iowa and the National Labor Relations Board, and it is important that they should not be confused. The first is the legal right of the Governor to keep the board from resuming its hearings in Iowa in the case of the Maytag Washing Machine Company, Whose employes have been on strike since early in May.

Warning against a spread of antiSemitism in this country, Eddie Cantor, comedian, bitterly denounced Henry Ford for accepting a decoration from the German Government last Saturday. He spoke at a testimonial luncheon in the Hotel Astor yesterday to honor him for his work in behalf of Jewish refugee children.

The Interstate Commerce Commission has informed the Lehigh Valley Railroad that it regards certain recent pledging operations on a Manufacturers Trust Company loan as "not strictly in accordance with the authority conferred by the order of Sept. 1, 1937," it became known today.

Mrs. A. M. Sobel of New York and Mrs. R. C. Young of Philadelphia won the women's pairs competition this afternoon with the huge score of 930 match points, leading the field by 113 points, in the second completed event of the National Contract Bridge Championships being played here this week in Convention Hall.

News that the American Kirakoram Expedition has succeeded in scaling the cone of K-2 [Mount Godwin-Austen] reached London tonight in a cable of less than a dozen words from Charles S. Houston, its leader.

The tendency toward better retail conditions which became apparent j in June was further strengthened in July, according to a mid-year summary of retail trade issued here today by Richard C. Patterson Jr., Assistant Secretary of Commerce.

Advance predictions that the three-day Boston Market Week exhibition of Fall women's styles arranged by the Wholesale Garment Association would do a volume of $750,000 were borne out tonight with word that a total of almost $700,000 was reached during the second day of the show today at the Hotel Statler.

The New York Central Railroad will file an application with the Interstate Commerce Commission in the next day or two asking permission to borrow $5,000,000 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, it was said at the office of the railroad yesterday.

Ten charitable and religious institutions share virtually all of the estate of Elizabeth Solomon of 3,495 Broadway, it was learned yesterday when her will was filed for probate in Surrogate's Court. The decedent died on July 11, leaving an estate formally valued at "more than$10,000."

Twenty-seven persons were injured, five seriously enough to require hospital treatment, when two buses collided at Hyatt and Bay Streets, in front of the Borough Hall, at St. George, S, I., during the rush hour yesterday morning.

The old master put the stamp of approval on his conqueror today, but refused to pick him to defeat twofisted Henry Armstrong in their lightweight championship fight in the Polo Grounds next Wednesday night.
Robert Stewart Mittrick, 4 years old, was fatally injured this evening when he fell from his tricycle on the sharpened branch of a newly clipped garden hedge.

The marriage of Miss Frances Clare Leigh-Mallory, daughter of Mrs. George Leigh-Mallory of Westbrook, Godalming, and the late Mr. Leigh-Mallory, to Dr. Glenn Allan Millikan, second son of Professor and Mrs. Robert A. Millikan of Pasadena, Calif., took place here this afternoon in the Church of Saints Peter and Paul. The ceremony was performed by the bride's grandfather, Canon Leigh-Mallory, and Canon H. E. Hone.
A splendid example of human progress would be the pictures of Japanese infantry advancing through the Yangtze flood waters.

Judge and Mrs. Alfred H. Townley of the Sherry-Netherland sailed last night on the Hansa to pass the rest of the Summer in Paris. Mr. and Mrs. Courtlandt D. Barnes Jr. have come from Wilton, Conn., to Hampshire House.

In the five years of its existence the Tennessee Valley Authority has paid $1,700,000 to land-grant colleges in eleven States in return for their cooperation in its fertilizer and soil conservation demonstration programs, according to testimony today before the Congressional Investigating Committee.

A new superliner of the 83,000-ton Normandie class will be considered for the North Atlantic trade by the French Line, it was announced yesterday by H. Morin de Linclays, general director of the company in the United States and Canada.
Four years ago Professor Enrico Fermi bombarded element 92, otherwise known as uranium, with neutrons, obtained an entirely new element and assigned it to the ninety-third place in the table.

Chalk up another victory for America's track and field athletes now touring Sweden. They won six of seven events in a meet here yesterday. Ben Johnson, New York Negro, annexed the 100-meter dash in 10.8 seconds; Fred Wolcott of Rice took the 110-meter high hurdles in 15.3 sends;
Creation of a new division of business review in the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce was announced today by Richard C? Patterson Jr., Assistant Secretary of Commerce.

Judge James M. Douglas, backed by Governor Lloyd C. Stark, swung to the front in Missouri's heated Democratic Supreme Court race when a heavy St. Louis vote offset an early lead gained by his opponent, James V. Billings, in T. J. Pendergast's Kansas City stronghold.

The Berkshire music festival's new $82,000 music shed will be formally dedicated tomorrow night with brief remarks by Miss Gertrude Robinson Smith, president of the corporation, and Bentley Wirt Warren, president of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, who is at his country place, Stonehill, Williamstown. Practically all of the 5,700 seats have been sold.

The proposed plan of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad Company for readjusting its fixed charges, although not developed in final form yet, does not involve a reduction or modification of the principal of any of its bonds, nor would it relieve the road "from the ultimate payment of any interest on any obligations," according to George -M. Schriver, senior vice president of the road.

General Candido Rondon was honored by the government today when he returned from his mission as a member of the Leticia Peace Commission which had been in session at La Victoria in the Amazon region for four years.

The Constitutional Convention in committee of the whole early this morning advanced the new judiciary article, which the committee has been debating for the last two days, by a viva voce vote to the order of third reading, placing it in line for final adoption by the convention.

Several taxpayers were among the Westchester properties changing hands in deals announced yesterday. The building with eight stores at 28 Garth Road, on the northwest corner of Ross Road, Scarsdale, was sold by the New York Life Insurance Company to the Gene Realty Corporation through John J. Reynolds, broker.

Taxicab drivers employed by the Parmelee system who went on strike at two garages in Brooklyn and one in Manhattan on Tuesday returned to work yesterday and will remain on their jobs while representatives of the company and the Transport Workers Union confer on a revised agreement covering wages and working conditions.
Bronx realty activity yesterday included the sale of a large apartment house, by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company and purchases of sites for improvement with small business buildings.

Governor Nels G. Kraschel, who last Saturday ordered the National Guard to close the National Labor Relations Board hearing on strikers' charges of unfair labor practices against the Maytag company, tonight directed Major Gen. Mathew A. Tinley to permit the company's plant at Newton to reopen at noon tomorrow.

The National Youth Administration found private employment for more than 100,000 youths of 16 to 24 between March 1, 1936, and June 1, 1938, according to a report today by Aubrey Williams, executive director of the NYA and assistant WPA administrator. In addition, jobs were found for 14,000 other young people.

Acting under the expressed commands of Republican leaders to the Constitutional Convention, the committee on public utilities, for the second time within two days, was forced today to reconsider its action in refusing to report out the Poletti proposal which would guarantee State control of water power resources on the St. Lawrence and Niagara.

A summons requiring Morris S. Novick, director of city station WNYC, to appear next Wednesday before the special investigating committee of the City Council with his records was obtained yesterday from Supreme Court Justice Peter Schmuck by Maurice Hellman, assistant to the committee.

The weekly report of crop conditions was issued yesterday by the United States Weather Bureau as follows In the Cotton Belt temperatures were mostly around -normal with substantial rainfall, widespread, except in parts of the Southwest.
Germany and France have reached an accord, it was announced today, in which Germany agrees to reimburse the French Government for any costs incurred from its guarantee of Austrian loans.

The appointment of a board to set minimum wage and maximum hour standards for the 6,397 women and minor workers in 257 confectionery plants in this State was announced yesterday by Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner.

Resale of a garden-type apartment house that had been acquired from a bank about a year ago featured the market in Brooklyn yesterday. The deal involved the four-story building, on a plot 140' by 151 feet, at 540 Ocean Avenue, which Royal Estates, Inc., represented by Emil Rogers, attorney, sold to Ocean Terra Realties, Inc., represented by Burt Franklin.

An effort by a Rockland County' tomato farmer to solve the shortage of farm labor by hiring seventeen Negroes from Virginia struck a snag when seven of the seventeen quit yesterday after getting some "Northern ideas" from local Negroes, it is charged.

Intervention by King George himself appeared tonight to be the only possible means by which Hazel Hurst, 22-year-old blind American lecturer, could enter England with her "eyes"-an Alsatian dog which guides her.

DABBLING with a dish of spaghetti at noon time, Uncle Mike Jacobs was in a sorrowful mood. The Japanese beetle has invaded his rose garden down in Jersey and, on top of that, Uncle Mike detects no great excitement among the populace over the approaching Ambers-Armstrong battle for the lightweight championship.

Alix has a varied collection featuring rainbow plaids for sportswear and sober plaids for town. Highland Mary suits have plaid kilted skirts and plain wool jackets trimmed with plaid; fantastic variations of the Glengarry are worn with them.

Harry W. Butterworth, textile machinery manufacturer, died this afternoon at Valevue, his former home in Rydal. He was stricken with bronchial pneumonia last Thursday while on a visit to Rydal to complete settlement on the recent sale of his homestead.

Wasting a great opportunity in the fourth inning, when a single, a double, a fielder's choice, a double steal and an intentional pass produced exactly nothing, the Dodgers subsequently tied the score against the Cardinals in the eighth, only to lose the decision in the tenth, 3 to 2, at Ebbets Field last night.

An application by the Los Angeles Stock Exchange for delisting of the registration of the $1-par value common stock of Kinner Airplane and Motor Corporation, Ltd., will be considered at a public hearing on Aug. 30 at Los Angeles, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

Francis E. Rivers, aide of District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey of New York, urged the program committee of the Republican National Committee tonight to include in its planning for the party the breaking down of political shelter for the rackets, which, he said, hold almost every large American city in their grip.

The forty-second annual golf and tennis tournament of members of the New York Stock Exchange will be held on Sept. 8 at the Fresh Meadow Country Club, Flushing, L. I., it was announcend yesterday by James McKenna, chairman of the arrangements committee.

A five-line communique printed in the entire Italian press today announces that a decree has been issued by the Minister of National Education closing all Italian schools for the next scholastic year to foreign Jews, whether permanent residents of Italy or not.
Four Homers Help Giants Crush Cubs ; Yanks Triumph ; Dodgers Lose

Gilbert Miller's plan to open his season with J. B. Priestley's "I Have Been Here Before" has drawn the fire of the Dramatists Guild. The Guild has written Mr. Priestley urging that he do not sign a contract with Mr. Miller because the latter is not a party to the basic agreement between the dramatists and the producers.

Fireman First Grade Alexander Stack, Headquarters Staff, Aide to Chief Medical Officer Joseph E. Smith (1), died Aug. 2. Funeral will take place from his late residance, 153 Lefferts Avenue, Brooklyn, at 9:30 A. M., Friday, Aug. 5. Interment at Holy Cross Cemetery, Brooklyn.

A decrease of 10,116,074 gallons of taxable motor fuel sales in May, as compared with May last year, was reported today by the State Tax Commission. The gallons sold totaled 149,709,373, an increase of 547,815 gallons over May, 1936. The tax collections based on the May sales amounted to $6,477,861.

Dr. John D. Stewart of 1,035 Park Avenue, who had been an attending surgeon on the staff of the New York Post Graduate Hospital for the last twenty-three years, died yesterday morning in the hospital, where he had been a patient for two months. He was born in Newark, Ohio, fifty-seven years ago.
About 150 samples of colors and fabrics used in the new Fall collections of nine leading Paris couture houses were displayed yesterday by the United Piece Dye Works, Inc.,

William and Chester Murphy of Chicago, runners-up to Sidney Wood and Joe Hunt at Seabright, were eliminated from the Southampton invitation tennis doubles today as eight teams advanced through two rounds to the quarter-final brackets at the Meadow Club.
Alvin Everett of Rome, Ga., and Alex Antonio of Linden, N. J., are the two survivors for the left-handed golfer's championship which was vacated yesterday by Arthur J. Thorner Jr. of Detroit.

Samuel Goldwyn will inaugurate a profit-sharing system among his upper-bracket creative employes, he announced today, when he engaged Robert Riskin as executive assistant. Riskin joins Goldwyn after a long association with Frank Capra at Columbia as a writer. He will be the first Goldwyn employee to work under the percentage system.
David Sarnoff, president of the Radio Corporation of America, sailed on the French liner Normandie yesterday for his annual pleasure and business visit to Europe. He will meet his family in England.
Deaths, heat prostrations, drownings and cessation of work by thousands of men and women marked the toll exacted by high temperatures which prevailed yesterday throughout most of the United States.

The New York Curb Exchange has received notice that the coupons due on Sept. 1 on the Baldwin Locomotive Works refunding mortgage bonds, 6 per cent convertible series, due on March 1, 1950, will be paid in preferred stock at the rate of one share of 7 per cent cumulative preferred stock, par value $30, for each $30 coupon.

The value of the collateral securing the three bond issues of the Alleghany Corporation as of Aug. 1 was substantially abovethatof May 1, but sill below 150 per cent of the face value of the bonds asstipulated in their indentures, according to the appraisal made by the Guaranty Trust Company, the trustee.

The Star Class fleet of Moriches Bay led by a slight margin- today after the third series of contests in the annual cruise of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association, in which some 156 boats competed.
The New York Roverettes conluered the Montreal Maroons, champions of the Province of Quebec, 4 to 0, in the feature game of the women's softball double-header at Madison Square Garden last night.
Plans for remodeling two dwellings in Harlem were announced yesterday when Charles Sherman bought from Sarah Neustadter the property at 1,827-29 Lexington Avenue, southeast corner of 114th Street.

It has been said that it is a poor rule which has no exceptions. Certainly the action of the British Ministry of Agriculture in refusing permission to the blind-leading German shepherd dog of Miss Hazel Hurst to land without undergoing the prescribed six months' quarantine would seem to be a case calling for such exception.

Revenues from consumers of electric light and power throughout the United States in April amouhted to $176,417,700, the Edison Electric Institute has reported. For the same month last year, revenues totaled $177,183,800.
The Florida Medical Association moved today to insure medical and surgical service for patients regardless of their financial status.

Back to his own shores comes Douglas G. Corrigan today. The young flier is assured of a heartfelt welcome from the people of New York and of the country as a whole. For his is the spirit of high adventure to which the American responds most completely, the embodiment of that combination of daring and mechanical resourcefulness which has played so large a part in our progress during the machine age.

Mrs. Walter W. Keith of Baltimore entertained with a luncheon yesterday at the Weylin for Mrs. Henry K. McHarg Jr. of Washington, D. C.; Mrs. Carroll W. Rosin of Baltimore and Mrs. S. Proctor Brady of New York and Baltimore.

Homer Martin, president of tne United Automobile Workers of America, and the suspended officials of the union's Tarrytown (N. Y.)-local agreed last night, following a long conference with Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora, to seek a settlement of their dispute out of court.
A three-run tenth-inning rally that included Goodman's twenty-seventh homer of the season with one on base gave the Reds a 6-to-3 victory over the Phillies today.
A total net profit of $2,421,711 for the first six months of 1938 was reported by the United Aircraft Corporation in its semi-annual statement made public today.
Dr. Curtis Manning Geer, Professor Emeritus of Hartford Seminary Foundation and dean for several years, died Tuesday at his home in West Hartford. He was 73 years old.

New contracts issued by the Schenley Company to retail package store owners on Sept. 2, will establish a minimum selling price sufficient to cover costs plus overhead and a suggested resale price which "will be fair to the consumer and afford a fair profit to the retailer"
The cruiser Houston, carrying President Roosevelt, headed toward Balboa, C. Z., tonight from Cocos Island, 540 miles west of Panama. She is scheduled to arrive tomorrow afternoon.

Prices on the Cotton, Exchange drifted into new low territory again yesterday and it was not until the December touched 81/2. cents a pound that the market developed resistance. The close was 3 to 5 points lower.

A wedding that attracted members of society of the North Shore Summer colonies and united two of the oldest families of Oyster Bay and Westbury took place at noon today, when Miss Nancy Gordon Milburn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Devereux Milburn, and Arthur Delano Weekes Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Weekes of The Anchorage, Oyster Bay, were married in the Episcopal Church of the Advent on Jericho Turnpike.
Edward Johnson, director and general manager of the Metropolitan Opera Association, sailed for Europe yesterday on the Normandie. At his request his name was kept off the list.

The Mexican Government flatly refused arbitration as suggested by the United States on American-owned farm lands expropriated by Mexico in a note handed to Josephus Dane iels, United States Ambassador, early today by Eduardo Hay, Foreign Secretary.

One hundred and fifty Republicans, holding in Chicago the midsummer conference of the party's .Program Committee, are described by one correspondent as being in a somewhat contradictory.frame of mind.
Moscow newspapers indicated today that the seriousness of the Far Eastern crisis had begun to be appreciated. Izvestia has a big six-column scarehead across three quarters of the front page:

American Labor party leaders, both here and up-State, are booming Thomas H. Holling, Democratic Mayor of Buffalo, for a place on the Democratic State slate this Fall, it was learned yesterday. Mayor Holling is very popular in up-State Labor party circles.

Holding that the National Administration had failed to establish "a well integrated, well rounded and carefully planned social security program," Edward S. Corsi, Republican chairman of the Constitutional Convention's committee on social welfare, today urged the national Republican party to adopt three "reform" proposals which, he held, would result in an effective administration of relief throughout the country.
The official news agency announces the City Council has expropriated the old synagogue and administrative buildings of the Jewish Cultural Society on Hans Sachs Platz.

The Federal Trade Commission today ordered the National Silver Company, 621 West Twenty-third Street, New, York, to discontinue certain practices held to be in violation of the Federal Trade Commission Act.

The last of three public hearings on a proposal to make an employer's violations of the State minimum wage and hour standards for the laundry industry a criminal offense punishable by. fine or imprisonment was conducted yesterday in the State Office Building by Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner.

Secretary of State Cordell Hull today coupled high praise of the Foreign Service with a vigorous challenge of suggestions that it was "composed exclusively of persons of the be-spatted and stuffed-shirt variety, whose most ardent work is collecting gossip at luncheons and cocktail parties or quarreling over questions of social precedence."

The Republican voters of Kansas did an admirable day's work on Tuesday when they wrote finis to the Senatorial aspirations of the Rev. Gerald B. Winrod. Not in recent years has a more authentic voice been raised in this country in behalf of religious, racial and social bigotry.

Louis H. Wells and John H. Leggett, both former members of the New York State Assembly, died today. Mr. Wells, who was born at Bethany eighty-three years ago, and was executive clerk of the State Senate, 1890-91, represented Genesee County in the lower house from 1914 to 1918.

Charles Willard Hill, a broker with offices at 1 Wall Street, New York, died unexpectedly today at his Snowy Range ranch Summer home, eighteen miles south of here. Mr. Hill arrived at the ranch yesterday to meet Mrs. Hill, who had been there since early Summer.
Rapping a total of twenty-eight hits, the Pirates overcame both the Bees and 95-degree heat in two contests today, 9 to 4 and 5 to 3, to widen their National League lead to five and one-half games.

Adolph M. Holstein, civic leader and Syracuse industrialist, died here today, after a brief illness, at the age of 79. Death was ascribed to circulatory trouble. Born in Warsaw, Poland, he came to the United States fifty years ago.

An unhappy Simone Simon sailed away from America yesterday on the French liner Normandie, declaring that she probably would never come back. Her last minutes on American soil were plagued by a courteous but insistent internal revenue agent who wished to know if

The Republican Congressional Committee of the Twenty-eighth New York (Albany County) District designated Dr. William Burgess Cornell, Menands, N. Y., psychiatrist, today as a candidate for the Republican Congressional nomination.

Roger K. Fawcett of the New York Athletic Club today won the Marshall marathon, feature event of the eighteenth annual T. Clarence Marshall trapshooting tournament, by shattering 497 of 500 targets. Fawcett topped a field of thirty-five leading shooters of the United States.

The Interborough News Company, engaged in the sale and distribution of magazines, newspapers, books and periodicals, was found guilty of violating the State Labor Relations; Act in a decision made public yesterday by the. State Labor Relations Board.

Miss Mary Annette Stevens, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Henry Stevens of Niles, Ohio, was married to James Robinson Bussey Jr. of St. Petersburg, Fla., yesterday afternoon in the Church of the Transfiguration. The Rev. Robert Murphy performed the ceremony.
A plan to unite Hungary's numerous Nazi groups-each of whose leaders has ambitions to become the Hungarian Hitler-was advanced today by the union of two major organizations.

While half a dozen men and women loitered in a cooling breeze about 6 o'clock last night on the dock of the volunteer life-saving station at East Fifty-first Street and the East River, down a flight of steps from Beekman Place, a distraught woman with a terrier suddenly threw the dog in the river and leaped in herself.

The weekly average of awards for engineering construction made during July, a four-week month, was $55,833,000, or 7 per cent above the weekly average for the five weeks in the same month last year, according to The Engineering NewsRecord.

The stock market here was quiet and generally steady today but the continued rush of Continental European hoarders to buy gold caused a flurry of activity in the bullion market and f2,977,000 of the metal was sold.

A challenge was issued to the National Labor Relations Board here tonight by Representative Clare E. Hoffman. He defied the board by assailing the Committee for Industrial Organization at a meetingi sponsored by an employer, the Clark Equipment Company, which gives work to about 1,000 persons in this community.

Small Montana, 111, from the Philippines, punched his way to an easy victory over the Canadian-born Japanese, Katsumi Morioka, 109 1/4 of Vancouver, B. C., in their fifteen-round flyweight elimination encounter at the Queensboro Arena last night and thus became the No. 1 candidate to meet Little Dado.
Following is the text of the substitute section dealing with review of administrative - board decisions. which was adopted by the committee of the whole of the Constitutional Convention early today:
The purchase by Frank Knox, president and editor of The Chicago Daily News, of Frank and Charles Ellis's interest in the newspaper was announced today.

ALMOST any one who enjoys so-called serious music ought to enjoy "The Orchestra Speaks,"* by Bernard Shore, first viola of the B. B. C. Symphony Orchestra. Mr. Shore writes informally of various conductors under whom he has played-Beecham, Mengelberg, Casals, Harty, Goossens, Barbirolli, Harrison, Wood, Toscanini, Koussevitzky, Coates, Sargent, Boult and about a dozen others.

Forty per cent of the 650,000 jobless workers who got State unemployment insurance checks in the first six months of 1938 received the top benefit of $15 a week, according to figures made public yesterday by the division of placement and unemployment insurance of the State Labor Department.

A plot of land about 82 by 86 feet, on the south side of Connecticut Street, 320 feet south of the corner of Washburn Avenue, in Corona, Queens, has been sold by Malano Rigopoules to Harry Tsikouris for cash. James J. Leibman represented the seller in the deal.

Output of coke pig iron In July, according to The Iron Age, totaled 1,201,785 gross tons, compared with 1,062,021 tons in June. Daily output in July was 38,767 tons, an increase of 9.5 per cent over June, while seventy-seven furnaces were making iron on Aug. 1, compared with seventy a month earlier.

Justice James C. McReynolds of the United States Supreme Court sailed yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania for an indefinite vacation, as he described it, "to London and the Continent, to get away from the heat and to get a rest."

William A. Lawrence, one of the proprietors of the old Lawrence Inn here on Boston Post Road, died early today in the Presbyterian Hospital in New York at the age of 46. He had been ill a month. He was born in the inn.
The War Department published today a list of first and second lieutenants appointed to the officers' reserve, including the following from New York and New Jersey:
