The Henry Street Settlement appealed for funds yesterday to send more children from lower East Side tenements on vacations at fresh-air camps maintained by the institution.

The State Tax Department announced today that many highways of Northern New Jersey had been closed to the erection of additional billboards in a move to present a "clean face" to motorists passing through the State en route or returning from the New York World's'Fair.

Earlier in the week when Magistrate Frank Oliver, sitting in Bronx Magistrate's Court, fined several persons who were brought before the him for indulging in rowdyism at Orchard Beach he was performing a labor' of love. For as far back...

The decline of more than $3 a bale from the high levels of a month ago brought prices for the near months on the Cotton Exchange around 8/2 cents a pound and for the second successive day the volume of resting orders exceeded the selling pressure.

Mauritz I. (Butts) Johnson of Greenwich, mechanical engineer and former athlete at Greenwich High School and Cornell University, died. today at the Winchester Sanitarium, West Haven, Conn, at the age of 28.

The weekly one-day tournament of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association resulted in a tie for low-gross honors between Mrs. Joseph F. Holleran of Greenwich, who carded 43, 39-82, and Mrs. Henry Dietrich of Green Meadow, who posted 41, 4182, over the St. Andrews Golf Club course today. In a matching of cards Mrs. Holleran emerged as the winner of the prize.

With farms in producing areas near New York now harvesting vegetable crops and local waters supplying peak-of-the-season quantities of fish in an unusually wide variety, by far the greater amount of the city's food supply is now coming from near by. This makes for a long lit of bargains in vegetables and fish, as long-distance transportation charges are eliminated.

Fresh acts of terrorism in Palestine today resulted in the loss of seven lives and injury to eleven persons. When a truck was blown to pieces by a land mine concealed under a road near Ramathkovesh on Sharon Plain, six Jewish laborers, including two women were killed and eleven were injured.

On June 30, a total of 26,297 employes or former employes and dependents of deceased employes of the General Electric Company owned or had subscribed for $28,954,390 par value of G. E. Employes 5 per cent bonds, as compared to 21,992 and $25,053,940, respectively, a year before, a gain of 19.6 per cent in number and 15.6 per cent in amount.

The Curtiss-Wright Corporation and its subsidiaries showed a net profit in the first half of this year of $2,181,862 after depreciation, taxes and other deductions, according to the statement issued yesterday by Guy W. Vaughan, president.

Chartered bank deposits with the Bank of Canada increased $2,963,000 and Dominion Government deposits declined $2,267,000, compared with the previous week, it was reported today in the bank's statement for the week ended on Aug. 3. The reserve in sterling and

The three apartment buildings! known as 381-3 Park' Avenue and 101-5 East Fifty-third Street, forming the northeast corner of Park Avenue and Fifty-third Street, were sold at auction in the Vesey Street rooms yesterday.

Thirty-five boys of the Henry Street Settlement in New York City enjoyed themselves playing baseball, cooling off under sprinklers on the lawn and romping in the hayloft on the estate of Mrs. Felix Warburg here today. The settlement has been

Leaders of editorial opinion representing both the Christian and Jewish viewpoints stressed yesterday the need for emphasizing democratic principles as the most effective means of combating current problems inherent in anti-Semitism and all forms of totalitarianism.

Lamport Ave (18-5562), 450 ft w of Fort Schuyler Rd, 50x100; Dorothy Feldman to Joseph Failla, 72 Lamport PI. Seward Ave (14-3573), s s, 250 ft e of Castlehill Ave. 50x100; Maurice D. Phillips to Henry Pargment, 1,571 University Ave. Aldus St (10-2755), s e cor of Longfellow Ave, 88x114; Thelma Potruch to Rivoli Management Corp. 292 Madison St.
The most spirited bidding so far during the yearling sales took place tonight when forty-seven head passed under the hammer for a total of $121,100, an average of about $2,577.

Stewart Browne, dean of the dwindling corps of civic organization leaders who for years appeared regularly at Board of Estimate meetings, usually in the role of indignant objectors, died yesterday in French Hospital, at the age of 84.
A shipment of 2,000 to 3,000 sub tropical fish for the New Yorl Aquarium and the Boston Aquarium will arrive today abroad the Medina of the Mallory Line at the Spring Street pier, Hudson River.

Lehman Brothers head a nationwide banking group, including the First Boston Corporation, Glore, Forgan Co., Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and fifty-nine other investment firms, which will offer to the public today $32,000,000 of first mortgage 33/4 per cent bonds, due on Aug. 1, 1968, and $5,500,000 of serial notes. due Aug. 1, 1939 to 1948, of the Indianapolis Power and Light Company.
Friends of Lotte Lehmann, German-born opera singer, said today she had told them as she left for the United States that she would "do everything possible to be a real American citizen."

Two speakers at a public meeting of the program committee of the Republican National Committee departed tonight from the previously universal rule to keep all utterances at the midsummer conference academic and impersonal.

Business in the Pittsburgh district showed further improvement last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. The rate of gain, however, was considerably slower than in the two preceding weeks.

An incation that Congress may retain the manufacturers' excise taxes, which expire at the end of the current fiscal year, was given today by Roswell Magill, Acting Secretary of the Treasury, at his press conference. These taxes yielded more

The International Association of Machinists charged in a statement today that "attempted raids" by the Committee for Industrial Organization on the American Federation of Labor "have created a condition in some communities bordering on anarchy."

The twelve Federal Reserve Banks showed current net earnings of $4,606,309 in the first half of this year, the Federal Reserve Bulletin said today. The New York bank had current ?et earnings of $1,759,738.

Brig. Gen. Sir Henry Page Croft, chairman of the British Empire Industries Association, arrived here today on the Empress of Australia "to hear what Canadians think of the chances of immigration." A few weeks ago in the British House of Commons,

The Third Army war games which started yesterday in the Gulf Coast littoral initiate the most intensive twelve months of field exercises and training in our army's peacetime history. It is not alone the tense international situation that is responsible for the increased attention being paid
Donald L. Barnes, president of the last-place St. Louis Browns, admitted frankly today that he was in a quandary about night baseball at Sportsman's Park.

A renewed effort to submit a constitutional amendment limiting the service of the President-to one term of six years will be made by Senator Burke when Congress reconvenes. Stopping over inWashington for a few hours, Senator Burke declared he would reintroduce in January the same resolution he has had pending for four years.

Dr. Edward Broquet, who had practiced medicine for more than fifty years, most of the time in the Bronx, died yesterday at his home, 267 Alexander Avenue, the Bronx, after a short illness. He was 80 years old.

A curb on "degree chasing" among teachers who neglect their classroom duties while seeking academic laurels was urged yesterday by Edward F. Ahearn, president of the Hartford (Conn.) Board of Education, at a luncheon meeting of a Teachers College conference of school board members and school administrators in the Eastern States.

Steer hind and rib business at a complete standstill in local markets yesterday, and probably the least number sold so far this week in recent history. Trading in veal still fair, other classes slow. Lamb market was sharply lower, fresh pork cuts weak to sharply lower. Veal hindsaddles steady, other classes weak.

The fortieth anniversary of the arrival at Montauk Point, L. I., from Cuba of Colonel Theodore Roosevelt's famous Rough Riders d and other troops of the Ameriean forces serving in the Spanish-American War is to be observed with appropriate exercises, it was announced yesterday.
Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Aug. 4 unless specified: At San Francisco: Aylwin, Dale, Dewey, Farragut, Hull, MacDonough, Monoghan, Phelps, Worden.

High temperatures without needed general rains in the Prairie Provinces of Canada have lowered crop prospects over much of Saskatchewan and in parts of Alberta, although weather conditions have tended to retard the development of rust infestation prevalent in Manitoba and Eastern Saskatchewan,

Eighteen acres of Brighton Beach, covering about six city blocks along the beachfront,, will be purchased by the city and added to Coney Island beach, if plans by Robert Moses,- Commissioner of Parks, now before the City Planning Commission, go through, it became known yesterday.

Ray L. Thomas, attorney for two "independent" unions in the "Little Steel" strike last Summer, and who was the reputed mainspring of the backto-work movement, testified before the Senate Civil Liberties Committee today that he had armed employes and advised them to "go in shooting" if necessary.

The Rev. Francis Albert Christie, former professor at the Harvard Divinity School, died here yesterday after a brief illness at the age of 79. Born here, a son of William and Elizabeth Neil Christie, he attended the local high school and was graduated from Johns Hopkins in 1887. He also studied at Amherst College and at Heidelberg and Berlin universities.
Loew's, Inc., declared yesterday a dividend of $1 a share on the common stock, payable on Aug. 25, compared with 50 cents a share paid on June 30.

The first week of Chicago's Fall market opening that started last Monday and ends tomorrow has exceeded all expectations in the number of outof-town merchants and buyers attending, and in the volume of orders
Mr. and Mrs. Eugene F. Moran of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marion Moran, to William Brendan Mattimore of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Mattimore.

That Mexico intends to continue expropriation of United States - owned lands while the controversy over Indemnity payments for farms already nationalized continues, was Indicated by the publication today in the official gazette of a decree by which 1,800 acres of pasturage in the State of Jalisco belonging to Dora and Oscar Newton, United States citizens, were taken.

The Constitutional Convention, in committee of the whole, advanced to third reading today a broad proposal- for a social welfare article in the new State Constitution; but it defeated by the margin of one vote a section which would have given the Legislature permission to establish in the future a health insurance system in the State.

Fifty-six contract bridge pairs started competition in the masters' pair event this afternoon in Convention Hall here. It was the largest entry yet recorded for this title in the annual national contract bridge championships. The winners will not be decided until Sunday.

Richard Armstrong, former chairman of the Virginia Commission of Fisheries and member of a family distinguished in business, military affairs, church work, and education, died tonight at his home on Armstrong's Point near here. Mr.

A bad attack of jitters that overtook him on the thirty-sixth green when he had to sink a four-foot putt today cost Alvin Everett, 29-year-old Rome (Ga.) power house employee, a chance to win the national lefthanders' golf championship.

Cash prizes to customers, accompanied by cut prices, an alleged project of the Big Bear, a large New Jersey retail grocery chain, was termed a lottery here today by D. Frederick Burnett, State Alcoholic Beverage Commissioner.

John Holley Clark Jr., counsel for holders of $740,000 of certificates in the $1,400,000 mortgage on the Lido Club Hotel of Long Beach, L. I., opposed yesterday in Brooklyn Supreme Court a motion by the Long Beach on the Ocean, Inc. owner
The Marine Corps announced the following changes for the week ended Aug. 3: COLONEL Larsen, H. L. promoted to Colonel, rank from June 29.

Broome St. 75, 24.8x100; Chester F. Eklund to Burke Estates. Inc. 1,451 Broadway, ano, mtg $7,000, deed dated Sept 8, 1933. Broome St, 294, 25x75: John H. Breen, ref. to Central Savings Bank, foreclosure ($2). Morton St, 50, 18.2x100; May Conroy to Cojay Corp, 150 Broadway.

Douglas Corrigan can spread his wings again. The Commerce Department's ban on his flying activities ended tonight. The Department, to "punish" him for flying to Ireland without its approval, suspended his pilot's certificate, but the punishment worked out this way:

Displaying his adeptness at riding out a'horse in a driving finish, Ruperto Donoso today scored with Herman Phillips's Samakov in the Newport Purse, mile and a sixteenth feature at Narragansett Park, to pay $8.40 for $2.

McGraw-Hill will publish in September "The Ruling Class," by Gaetano Mosca. This is a translation of the author's "Elementi di Scienza Politica" which Vilfredo Pareto regarded as the crowning achievement of modern political science and which he took as the point of departure for his own sociology.
Sporadic fighting continues in the vicinity of Changkufeng and Soviet artillery resumed its attack there at 4:30 this morning in a bombardment lasting about an hour, but there is

The Federal Reserve Board's seasonally adjusted index for industrial production rose from 77 in June to or more" for July, according to the board's study of business conditions made public today in the August issue of the Federal Reserve Bulletin. The index was at 76 in May.

Judge Charles J. Brown today acquitted Al Spohrer, former Boston Braves catcher and now head of a district office of the unemployment compensation commission, of larceny charges which Spohrer's attorneys. Sam Weiner and John Brennan,

More than 26,000 men were locked in mimic war tonight along the muddy banks of a turgid stream here as the army's largest peacetime manoeuvres started at five widely separated points in the South and Southwest.

Endorsement by the American Labor party of Representative Joseph A. Gavegan, incumbent Democrat, in the Twenty-first Manhattan District, was announced yesterday, bringing the total of local Democratic Representatives with Labor endorsement to six.

The Cincinnati Gas and Electric Company has filed a declaration covering a proposed reduction in the capital represented by its outstanding common stock from $30,000,000 to $7,500,000, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today. The difference would be

H. W. Warley, president of the Maritime Association, urged the State Department yesterday to increase import rates on freight from Australia entering the United States by way of Canadian ports so that competitive freight entering directly through ports of the United States would obtain an advantage.

The average weekly earnings of employes of twenty-five industries covered by a monthly survey of the National Industrial Conference Board rose 39 cents in June, as compared with May, it was announced yesterday.

Basil Harris, vice president of the International Mercantile Marine Company, arrived last night on the United States liner Manhattan. Accompanied by his wife and two sons, Richard and Basil Jr., he has been away since June 15, touring England, France and Switzerland.

Lumber output increased less than seasonally last week and the adjusted index eased to 67.3 from 67.8. The figure was 87.2 for the week ended July 31, 1937. Shipments were higher in the week, according to the reports wired especially to THE NEW YORK TIMES by the various regional associations. Orders, however, declined.

Although Walter Huston has not yet definitely agreed to play Peter Stuyvesant in "Knickerbocker Holiday," it is confidently expected here that he will send his signed contract from California within a few days. His engagement
Senator George L. Berry and his political benefactor, Governor Gordon Browning, appeared early today as the chief victims of Tennessee's hard-fought Democratic primary.

Nick Kenny, composer and radio columnist, acts as master of ceremonies in the Loew's State vaudeville bill this week. Other acts include Jerry Cooper, radio singer; Barto and Mann in a comedy dance routine; Francis Faye, singer of

Miss Dorothy May Bundy of Santa Monica and Mrs. Sarah Palfrey Fabyan of Boston, members of the Wightman Cup team, both went down in stunning defeat today in the women's invitation tennis tournament at the Maidstone Club.

The Provident Institution for Savings sold to the Fleet Realty Company the two five-story brick flats at 70-74 Paterson Plank Road, near Hague Street, Union City, for a consideration shown as $25,000. The buildings occupy a site 91 by 44 feet. The bank took back

Transfers and Assignments To take effect 8 A. M., Aug. 5: SECOND GRADE DETECTIVE-George V. Grundelman, from 18th Division, 11th Detective District to 77th Precinct, designation as second grade detective revoked. PATROLMEN-Max Levy. from 17th E.
A fox naval council has been called, presumably to discuss offers received for building the two 8,000-ton cruisers with which the Chilean Navy will begin its program of modernization.

A check for $1 and two bonds for $100,000 each were sent to the Treasury Department yesterday by Joseph D. McGoldrick, City Controller, as a final step in the long drawn dut negotiations for the demolition of the old postoffice on Lower Broadway and restoration of the site as part of City Hall Park.

Three men accused of operating a bingo game for a philanthropic purpose without first having obtrained a permit from the Department of Public Welfare were arraigned yesterday before Magistrate Jacob Eilperin in Bridge Plaza Court, Brooklyn. They pleaded not guilty, were found guilty and were paroled until Tuesday for investigation and sentence.
Conflicting price movements characterized slightly more active trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.

Awards for engineering construction totaling $57,454,000 in the current week represent a rise of 30 per cent above the $44,041,000 reported in the same week of last year, according to the Engineering NewsRecord.

Leon Tuchmann, a retired clothing merchant, who in 1930 gave $50,000 to the endowment fund of Yeshiva College, died yesterday in his home at 215 West Nineteenth Street after an illness of several weeks. He was 78 years old.

Demands that all information regarding campaign receipts and expenditures be filed by Saturday were made today upon Robert A. Taft and Arthur H. Day, Republican candidates for the Senate from Ohio, by the Senate Campaign Investigating Committee.

A petition was circulated today on the Board of Trade requesting the directors to call for a ballot vote of the membership on a proposal to suspend the operations of the "to arrive" rule from Sept. 1, 1938, to June 1, 1939. The "to arrive" rule governs

Eddie Rack, McKeesport (Pa.) apprentice, won the Walter Hagen Trophy emblematic of the Union Printers International Golf Association championship, today with a 311 total for the seventy-two-hole event.

Renewed charges that public funds were being used for political purposes in Kentucky came today from rival Democratic campaign camps. The New Deal's champion, Senate Majority Leader Alben Barkley, up for renomination in Saturday's voting, said that Governor A. B. Chandler, his opponent, had failed to keep his 1935 promise to reduce State expenses.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total bills discounted for the system as a whole to be at the lowest point of the year to date.

An amnesty bill granting pardons for common crimes up to July 4, last. was approved by the Cuban Senate this morning and sent to President Federico Laredo Bru for his signature. The House of Representatives where the bill originated had already approved the measure.

Molyneux's enormous collection stresses magnificent evening materials and great novelty in daytime details. Black predominates for daytime, but there are also many suits of smooth wool or tweeds in brilliant colors or plaids.

Zionism in Brazil received a d blow today when Minister of Justice Francisco Campos barred the Brazilian Zionist Federation in accordance with the law dissolving all foreign societies decreed early this year.
Paul N. Dwyer acknowledged late today that not until he became a prison "lifer" for the strangulation of Dr. James G. Littlefield did he attempt to implicate Francis M. Carroll in the crime.
Harry Kelley, veteran right-hander, pitched shut-out ball for seven innings today and then eased up as the Senators took the finale of a three-game series with the Browns, 10 to 4.

Excitement was caused today in Horni Dvoriste, on the German-Czech frontier, when a man with full military equipment I jumped from a moving train and ran toward the Czech line. German frontier guards pursued and caught him.
Nathan Kaufmann, a founder of the Kaufmann Baer Company, Pittsburgh department store, died after a short illness on Wednesday in Aix-les-Bains, France, according to word received here last night.
Samuel F. Spangler has purchased through the Robert E. Farley Organization a wooded plot on the corner of Candlewood Lake Road and Mountain Drive, Candlewood Lake Club, Brookfield, Conn.

Unlike the weather, the Giants have had a very annoying habit of blowing hot and cold of recent weeks. Yesterday was one of their frigid days as the New Yorkers were figuratively snowed under by the Cubs, 6 to 0, for New York's twelfth stut-out of the season.

The Prudential Insurance Company of America sold to a client of Isidor Tankus, attorney, the sixstory automatic elevator apartment house at 1,265 Olmstead Avenue, northwest corner of Newbold Avenue, the Bronx.

Bulgaria's recently ','legalized" rearmament will be financed largely by France, it was revealed today. A group of French bankers is visiting Bulgaria at present, and a loan of 1,000,000,000 levas bearing 5 1/2 per cent interest and payable in twelve years it expected to result.

The commotion in the London gold market, during which, under sales running above $25,000,000 in two days, the price of gold per ounce in-sterling advanced to the highest of the year, led to the usual excited inferences. Further revaluation of European currencies must be impending.

Grover A. Whalen, president of the World's Fair Corporation, yesterday announced the election by the board of directors of Commander Howard A. Flanigan, former administrative assistant, as vice president, and the election of Miss Mary Louise Jorzick, former assistant secretary, as secretary of the corporation.

The cost of public relief during June continued to rise just as it had done for the previous eight months, the Social Security Board announced today. In June the total costs to the Federal, State and local governments, including earnings under the Works program, reached $249,218,000, or an increase of $1,341,000 over May.

Dr. Harry A. Curtis, chief chemical engineer in charge of the Tennessee Valley Authority fertilizer works at Muscle Shoals, admitted today that the part of nitrate plant No. 2 not used for fertilizer experiments is not being kept in stand-by condition for national defense as required by the TVA act, and that it would take $1,000,000 to put it in such condition as to make it quickly available for producing munitions.
The neighbors had not seen Mrs. Isabelle Best, 41 years old, of 115 Parkside Avenue, Brooklyn, for two weeks.

A public hearing, to be held in Albany on Aug. 10 on the subject of mandatory registration of trade marks by States, has reopened a question, which most advertisers thought had become dormant following the recent convention of the National Association of Secretaries of State at Louisville.

Five distributors of gasoline and other petroleum products in the metropolitan area have acted to set minimum resale prices under the Feld-Crawford Fair Trade Act, it was announced yesterday by Charles J. Bensky, counsel to the Petroleum Dealers Chamber of Commerce, and Aaron J. Plavnick, executive secretary.
Their start was bad but the track was lightning fast today, and once the Yankees gained momentum, the result was practically inevitable.

Continued deflation of bank loans and investments, but at a reduced pace, was revealed in the condition statement for the week ended on Wednesday of the reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City, issued yesterday.

With a drop in the temperature beginning late yesterday afternoon, the Weather Bureau announced last night that the back of the eleven day heat wave was definitely broken, and that today's temperatures would be close to normal.

Lord Dunsany's fourteen-year-old play, "Alexander," was produced for the first time at the Malvern Theatre Festival last night. It begins with Alexander the Great brooding over the fallen statue of Xerxes and shows how, against his will, he is led to abandon help to Apollo and ends with the discovery of his body lying neglected, as the' statue of Xerxes was neglected.

Lance M. Harris has been appointed general manager of Hearns Newark Department Store and on Sept. 1 will take over the duties of Arthur Price, who has resigned that post to join the Richards Grape Products Corporation as vice president. Mr. Harris has been with

Mr. and Mrs. John Thomas Smith entertained with a dinner tonight Certosa for their son-in-law and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. Bernard M. Shanley 3d, who are passing tennis week with them. The occasion marked Mr. Shanley's birthday. Others in the party were Miss Eleanor Hoguet and Miss Gretchen

The Securities and Exchange Commission called today upon the principal public utility holding companies of the nation to file by Dec. 1 plans, either finally or tentatively, under which their properties might be economically and geographically integrated in accordance with the provisions of the "death sentence" section of the Public Utility Holding Company Act.
Six teams that included some of the nation's ranking golfers finished in a tie for the medal in the annual John G. Anderson Memorial tournament at the Winged Foot Golf Club today.

The Panama Pacific liner City of Los Angeles, which is scheduled to sail tomorrow on the first voyage of a new passenger and freight service between New York and the Pacific Coast, arrived here yesterday morning from Baltimore and docked at the Chelsea piers.

Chairman John J. Phelan and Dr. William H. Walker of the New York State Athletic Commission gave Henry Armstrong a close examination 'today and pronounced the featherweight and welterweight champion ,ready to go after Lou. Ambers's lightweight crown in the Polo Grounds next Wednesday night.

The Constitutional Convention tonight has before it "without recommendation and solely for the consideration of the convention" the proposal introduced by Supreme Court Justice Charles Poletti to protect the power resources and sites of the State upon the St. Lawrence and Niagara Rivers, as well as other power sites the State may acquire, against falling into the hands of private utility interests.

Guarino Cataldo, 41 years old, of 369 Thirty-sixth Street, Brooklyn, was held yesterday in $25,000 bail for trial Monday by Judge Matthew T. Abruzzo in Federal court, Brooklyn, on a charge of passing a counterfeit $10 Federal Reserve

Morley W. McBrayne of West Chester, Pa., amateur, and Bred S. Tomlin, Glassboro, N. J., professional, shattered 200 straight targets apiece today in the Brandywine classic, a feature of the eighteenth annual T.
Favorites fell rapidly by the wayside today at Culver Military Academy as the national boys and juniors' tennis tournament reached semifinal play.

On the eve of Kentucky's red-hot Senatorial primary a final survey of public opinion in the State shows Senator Alben W. Barkley, the New Deal candidate, still out in front of Governor A. B. (Happy) Chandler for the Democratic nomination.
Everett Worthington of 15 Oak Lane, Scarsdale, died of a heart attack yesterday at the wheel of his automobile at Fifty-seventh Street and Tenth Avenue. He was an industrial designer. His age was 47.
John E. Edgerton, former president of the National Association of Manufacturers, died at his home here tonight after an illness of three weeks. His age was 58.

The indications are for partly cloudy weather, possibly with local showers, and moderate temperatures today and for showers tomorrow with little change in temperature, according to the map charted at the United States Weather Bureau at 7:30 o'clock (E. S. T.) last night.

Speculative interest in the markets was small yesterday, and price changes were relatively unimportant. The stock market closed irregular, slightly higher on the average. The turnover on the Stock Exchange was only 609,000 shares, or about 200,000 less than Wednesday's volume. Bonds were dull and mixed; one of the features of the day was the recovery in Japanese issues.

The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders dated Aug. 2: REAR ADMIRAL Wilcox, J. W. Jr., detached as chief of staff and aide President Naval War Col, lege, Newport, R. I., in August; to duty as commander special service squadron.

The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation warned the banks of the country today against taking excessive risks on loans. The warning appeared in the corporation's semiannual fiscal statement after a series of demands had been made by Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, for--a liberalization of banklending policy.

Deeply tanned by the wind and sun, President Roosevelt looked extremely fit when he received newspaper correspondents today aboard the U. S. S. Houston after his nineteen-day Pacific fishing cruise from California to Galapagos Islands. He greeted the reporters with laughter and good humor and told them 'fish stories.

Renting of private houses formed the bulk of realty activity in Manhattan yesterday. The five-story American basement dwelling at 323 West Eighty-ninth Street was leased by Harry P. Nelson, Inc., as broker, for the Bank for Savings. It will be altered and operated as a rooming house.

Mrs. Martha Sager has sold, through the Bulkley Horton Company to Sam Shapiro for occupancy, the dwelling at 1,311 Carroll Street, Brooklyn. The two-story residence at 9,730 Avenue L has been sold by Samuel Hurwitz, as broker, for Albert Schlamowltz to a client for cash.

News from Berlin that zones all along the frontiers have been closed by decree while a steel network of fortifications is being rushed to completion is bound to give rise to disturbing speculations. For years the sorest grievance

Western farmers are assured of a price for their 1938 wheat on the basis of 80 cents a bushel for No. 1 Northern wheat, delivered at Fort William. That is the fixed minimum price the Canadian Wheat Board is authorized to pay for deliveries from the crop now ripening.

The wholesale Garment Association tonight concluded its most successful Boston Market week with volume of business booked at the three-day session hitting an all-time high of $750,000, 50 per cent higher than last year's mark.
Governor Frank F. Merriam today bluntly charged the C. I. O. with causing much State and national labor strife and said he had no sympathy with the organization.

Donald C. Bakewell, vice president of the Blaw-Knox Company, has been elected to the board of directors. E. Coyne Maloney has been admitted as a general partner in Block Maloney Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange. Mr.

Retail prices of foods declined in the month ended July 12, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The bureau's index, based on the 1923-1925 average, was 80.0, as compared with 80.2 on June 14 and 85.9 on July 13, 1937.

The Works Progress Administration extended its "buy and give" program yesterday to include $1,500,000 to $2,000,000 worth of sweaters, middies, skirts and jackets, blouses, raincoats, reversible coats and utility dresses. Men, women and children on home relief will benefit by the government's new purchase of surplus garments.
Frank Ruffu, a real estate operator and brother of the late former Mayor of Atlantic City, Anthony M. Ruffu, died tonight at his home here at the age of 68.

The ice and th navy today assigned Rear Admiral John W. Wilcox Jr. to command the Special Service Squadron, reliving Rear Admiral Yancey S. Williams. The change of command becomes effective this month.

Richard F. Green, grandnephew of the late Governor Robert S. Green of New Jersey, announced today he would enter the Democratic primaries next month as a candidate for the House of Representatives from the Sixth Congressional District on a New Deal platform. Donald H.

United States exports to sixteen countries the with which reciprocal trade agreements have been made increased in the last fiscal year 66.2 per cent over the average annual exports for the 1934-35 pre-agreement period, the Department of Commerce announced today. In the same period,
The Provident Institution for Savings of Boston petitioned today the United States District Court to authorize reorganization of the Boston Providence Railroad under the Bankruptcy Act.

Former Sheriff Lee Combs died in the City Hospital of wounds suffered in a shooting affray in which two other politically prominent citizens of Breathitt County were wounded on Main Street here tonight.
The War Department issued the following orders dated Aug. 3: BRIGADIER GENERALS Abernathy, R. S., 14 days' leave, Aug. 17. Abernathy, R. S., retired for age, effective Aug. 31.

The New York Hippodrome Opera Company begins its season of openair operas at Jones Beach Stadium tonight, presenting Verdi's "Aida." The cast includes Anna Leskaya, Helene Hartman, Sydney Rayner, Mario Cozzi, William Wahlert, Nino Ruisi, Silvio Giorgini and Gian Castro. Giuseppe Bamboschek

Noonday throngs in Eighth Avenue near Fiftieth Street ducked for cover yesterday when a patrolman fired four shots while pursuing a youth whose actions while trying to pawn articles aroused the suspicions of the pawnshop proprietor, who called the policeman.

23d St, 409-21 E, 43x80; for i-story garage and service building; Guaranty Trust Co, 1,140 Broadway. owner; Charles M. Schultz, engineer; cost, $15,000. Alterations 8th Ave, 47-9; to 5-story stores and apartments: estate of Marx Ottinger (Leon Ottinger, executor, 31 Nassau St) Schwartz Gross, architects; cost, S5.000.

Royal Dutch Airlines whose routes cross the North Sea area on the east coast of England that has been forbidden to civil aircraft during the coming three days of aerial manoevres has notified the British Government that they will defy the ban and fly their planes through the "war zone."

Funeral services for Captain Harold L. Winslow, master of the Panama Pacifio liner Pennsylvania, were held. last night at the McCormick Funeral Parlor, 225 Tenth Avenue. The Rev. Thomas Whelpley, rector of the Chelsea Presbyterian Churcl, conducted the service and the American Legion ritual was conducted by a uniformed guard from Roosevelt Lines Post.

Probably the only person in Puerto Rico who rather hopes for a hurricane this season is D. S. MacKiernan, research meteorologist of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, who has established headquarters at the United States Weather Bureau here to study upper air conditions during a storm.

A special committee of the Pennsylvania Legislature, with power to imprison for refusal to answer, was unable today to make District Attorney Carl B. Shelley of Dauphin County disclose the case which he has prepared for the grand jury.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The letter of Lyle H. Olson in your issue of Aug. 1 lists some of the important factors to be considered in working out a representative measure of cost.

Bespectacled Danny MacFayden hurled the Bees to 4 to 3 victory over the league-leading Pirates today, giving him his tenth victory of the season and his fourth straight. He allowed twelve hits but held the Pirates in check in the pinches.

Polo's important high-goal season is closing in with the arrival on these shores of foreign stars who are to compete and with the opening of the open championship test matches scheduled Sunday at the Sands Point Club in Port Washington.
John J. Van Valkenburgh, consulting civil engineer and balloonist, was found dead in his office on Waverly Street last night apparently from a heart attack induced by the heat. His age was 83.

Senator Clark's nomination in 1932 was unexpected. For months his renomination in 1938 has been regarded as certain. His mighty majority in Tuesday's primary is as much of an honor to the Missouri Democrats as it is to him.

Douglas Corrigan, the jaunty youth who still declares that his flight to Ireland was all a mistake, received an ear-splitting welcome as he sailed up the bay on the United States liner Manhattan early last evening and disembarked on his native soil eighteen days after his unheralded take-off.
The police assigned to handle the crowds expected to attend Brooklyn's celebration in welcome of Douglas Corrigan today were listed yesterday as follows:

Tonight's concert in the new music shed at Tanglewood, Stockbridge, was an outstanding event of the Berkshire season. It was the start of the fifth annual music festival and all of the eighty boxes were occupied.
An attempt by police court officials to hide the identity of the wife of a metropolitan magistrate charged with a motoring offense in the magistrate's court caused a furor here today.

Charles W. Weston, senior vice president of the Manufacturers Trust Company, died here this afternoon at the Mountainside Hospital after a two days' illness. Mr. Weston, who lived at 79 High Street, Montclair, was 62 years old.

The combined effects of the month-end currency demands and the excess of Treasury bill issues over redemptions cut down excess reserves of the member banks of the Federal Reserve System by $120,000,000 in the current statement week.
Nicholas Zographos, head of a Greek gambling syndicate, said tonight he would be forced to close his operations at Deauville and Cannes and probably move to some other country.

Postmaster General Farley, in a letter made public today by Archibald McNeil, former National Committeeman, termed the fight for the Democratic Senatorial nomination in this State one which Connecticut Democrats themselves would have-to settle. The letter, dated July 13, said:...

The tennis stock of Sidney Wood, the California gold mine operator, took a marked rise today. With one of the most accomplished exhibitions of volleying seen on any court at any time, the former Wimbledon champion defeated Bryan M. Grant Jr. of Atlanta, 7-5, 8-6, to gain the semi-final round of the Southampton invitation tournament at the Meadow Club.
With Rip Radcliff and Gerald Walker pacing in their 31-hit attack, the White Sox beat the Athletics in both games of a double-header today, 8 to 2 and 7 to 3.

The fishing seems to be getting better every day, and now that the first broadbill swordfish has been taken off Montauk, we can consider the season open. There is more to Major H. Franis Jaeckel's broadbill catch than the mere taking of a fish.
The exchange of notes between Washington and Mexico City makes it clear that our Government and the Government of Mexico are in complete disagreement on a fundamental point.

For improvement with a two-story taxpayer, the vacant plot at the northwest corner of Sutphin Boulevard and Eighty-ninth Avenue, Jamaica, L. I., has been leased for a long term by Courthouse Realties, Inc. Construction of the building, which will be directly opposite the new General Courts Building, will start Aug. 15. It will front 125 feet

The skeletons of eight men, believed to have been members of an expedition led by the German explorer Friedrich Leichareit, which left Moreton Bay on the Queensland coast in 1848 to cross the Austrialian Continent
District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey and Lloyd Paul Stryker, counsel for James J. Hines, Tammany district leader, engaged yesterday in a bitter oral battle before Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora.

The bodies of Paul Doucet, 50 years old, and Antonio Dissert, 27, both of Fall River, Mass., were found in Manhasset Bay, Port Washington, by a boat of the Nassau County Police Department early this morning.
The Coast Guard announced the following changes during the week ended Aug. 3: CHIEF WARRANT OFFICERS Chief Elec. H. L. Scales, New Orleans Division, to Headquarters, report not later than Aug. 8.

During the week ended Aug. 3 member bank reserve balances decreased $114,000,000. Reductions in member bank reserves arose from increases of $49,006,000 in money in circulation, $29,000,000 in Treasury cash, $43,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve Banks and $8,000,000 in non-member deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts and a decrease of $9,000,000 in Reserve Bank credit, offset in part by increases of $23,000,000 in gold stock and $2,000,000 in Treasury currency.

Representative Martin Dies of Texas, chairman of the Congressional Committee on Un-American Activities, disclaimed today any intention of inconveniencing George Sylvester Viereck, author, whose sailing for Europe last night was halted by a subpoena from the committee to testify before it Aug. 18.

The Cabinet Council tonight published a new nationalities statute hailed by the government as providing generous settlement of the claims of the nation's minorities groups, embracing 7,000,000 citizens.
Dr. Heinrich Held, former Bavarian Premier, died in the Merciful Brethren Hospital at Regensburg, his home town, today at the age of 70.

The Alexander Smith Sons Carpet Company of Yonkers, N. Y., one of the world's largest makers of floor coverings, will end its association of ten years with W. J. Sloane, its selling agent, on Nov. 1 and will set up its own sales deapartment, it was announced yesterday. The Smith company also
The problems of youth were faced today at Cornell University's fifth annual Summer session conference by some 350 educational delegates from New York and other Eastern States.

J. Smith Ferebee is going to try to get in some, golf between dawn and dark tomorrow--144 holes of it-and has wagered $2,500 and 1,200 acres of a Virginia plantation he can complete the marathon at an average of 95 strokes, or under, for the eight rounds.

Negotiations are under way between Selznick-International and Warners -by which the latter studio will take over 'Gone with the Wind." It is learned that since I Norma Shearer's withdrawal from the role of Scarlett O'Hara, Metro has decided against sponsoring the film. The conversations Between

Miss Vivian Svenson, daughter of Mrs. Harry Svenson of Liberty and the late Mr. Svenson, was married to George B. Cooke, son of County Judge and Mrs. George L. Cooke of Monticello, this morning in chapel of St. Joseph's Seminary in Callicoon by the Rev. Harold Blake, a member of the faculty.

After four hours of debate, the Constitutional Convention in committee of the whole near midnight voted to advance to third reading in amended form a proposal introduced by the Committee on Industrial Relations giving constitutional sanction to statutory provisions insuring workers on public contracts of the eight-hour day, five-day week and prevailing rate of wages.

GOVERNORS ISLAND Ist Lt. Dominic S. Messina, Med.-Res., Sherman, N. Y. (D), 23d General Hospital, is ordered to active duty Aug. 6, at Plattsburg Barracks, N. Y., for training with the 196th Infantry Brigade.
Joseph G. Shannon, A. G. Newmyer, In 150 Central Park S: Edward A. Fargo, in 103 E 86th St, Mrs. Frank Lazette, in 156 E 79th St; Mrs. Fern . Rix, in 156 E 52d St; Douglas L. Elliman Co. brokers.

On Tokyo's initiative the Soviet and Japan began peace talks yesterday on the Manchukuoan border affair. Tokyo proposed cessation of hostilities and mutual withdrawal from the disputed territory until a joint commission could decide where the boundary lay. Moscow, however,
The Rev. John N. Wolf, for many years a Bible teacher and an active mission worker, died here yesterday at the Yonkers Professional Hospital after a year's illness at the age of 59.

Dr. Louis Shepard de Forest, former Yale Medical School faculty member, one of the oldest practicing physicians of the city and of the alumni of Yale College, died today in his home here after a long illness. He was 81 years old.
Stocks eased and closed irregular after moderate gains; turnover, 609,600 shares. Japanese loans rallied 1 to 4 points, other bonds were irregularly lower; transactions, $5,718,000.

MANHATTAN Estate, more than $10,000. To William Robbins Barnes, husband, petitioner, 55 E. 76th St., household furnishings, personal effects, stock of 55-57 E. 76th St. and any other real property, also life estate in residue; C. Montgomery Barnes, stepson,

Gilbert C. Close, confidential secretary to President Woodrow Wilson from 1918 to 1920, married Mrs Marva D. House of St. Louis in a private ceremony here yesterday. Mr. Close, who accompanied President Wilson to Europe and was entrusted with the first copies of the Treaty of Versailles while it was in

The general level of wholesale prices declined in the week ended on July 30, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The bureau's index, based on the 1926 average, was 78.6, compared with 78.7 on July 23 and 87.5 on July 31, 1937. Declining market prices of farm products again accounted for the drop.

The Governors Island Quartet conquered the favored Blind Brook Shamrocks, 10-6, today at the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club to gain the final of the annual Northeastern intracircuit championship. Although given two goals by handicap, the army players found no need for them.
Department store sales here last week were 16.6 per cent above the preceding week, but 10.5 per cent below a year ago. Cumulative sales for four weeks were 3.6 per cent below a year ago.

In publishing on July 27 the fact that District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey had subpoenaed financial records of a number of individuals and firms in the electrical industry, THE NEW YORK TIMES used the name of Joie Rao, a gangster. On the subpoena issued by the District Attorney there appeared the name of Joseph Rao without further identification.

Public and professional interest in the wheat market was at a minimum today. Prices backed and filled within a range of about 3/4 cent a bushel and closed 1/4 to 1/2 cent lower on the Board of Trade here. Unsettlement in the foreign exchange market resulted in practically eliminating the export demand for either domestic or Canadian grain.

A band of 3,000 Chinese guerrillas was reported by the Japanese today to be surrounded and facing annihilation by Japanese forces in the Hangchow area, 100 miles southwest of Shanghai, territory nominally under Japanese control.

Plans are being considered in Japan to establish an air service between Tokyo and the Japanese mandated islands in the South Pacific by way of the American-owned island of Guam, the Commerce Department reported today.

The Great South Bay Star Class fleet improved its position in the daily series of races with the Moriches Bay fleet for the Commodore George Corry Trophy when its representatives finished first, third and fourth today.
William Green, president of the A. F. of L., today announced tentative plans to form one international union for unlicensed seamen employed on American and Canadian merchant ships.

The labor controversy here, which caused Governor Nelson G. Kraschel to send National Guard troops to the city and to try to prevent the National Labor Relations Board from holding a hearing in the State of Iowa, came to an anti-climax today.

The new floating baths moored in the Hudson River off West Ninetysixth Street will be opened to public use at 10 A. M. today without ceremony by the Department of Parks. The baths are made up of three old barges, now rebuilt and refitted.

Proud and haughty, stiff but beautiful, Harold S. Vanderbilt's Class M sloop Prestige swept across the finish line today far in the lead of the rest of the fleet on the American Yacht Club's first cruise run, that from Rye, N. Y.
With Beethoven's Ninth Symphony sounding its tremendous theme of joy and the brotherhood of man, the Berkshire Symphonic Festival began its fifth year here at Tanglewood tonight.

A National Labor Relation Board trial examiner recommended today that the Corning Glass Company withdraw recognition of nine independent unions and reinstate fourteen workers at the Macbeth-Evans division at Charleroi, Pa.

The German Labor Office announced today that during June 310,000 jobs were looking for workers without being able to find them. Because of the labor shortage, women, who during the great unemployment were consigned to the kitchen, are again being employed in increasing numbers both in shops and offices.

Miss Ida Mae Allen, daughter of former State Senator Mark W. Allen of West Brighton, S. I., and of the late Mrs. Bessie Vorhees Allen, was married last night to James William Lockwood in Trinity Methodist Church, West New Brighton, S. I. The ceremony was performed

Brown Brothers Harriman Co., paying agents, announced yesterday that $125,000 of Robert Bosch Aktiengesellschaft in Stuttgart 7 per cent mortgage bonds due in 1050 had been drawn by lot in Stuttgart for redemption on Oct. 1, 1938.

A charge of operating a public nuisance made against Andy Idonis, formerly track manager of the Farmer's Oval, Ridgewood, Queens, was withdrawn yesterday in Long Island City when the approximately fifty complainants told Magis- I trate Frank Giorgio that they would take civil steps to stop the racing t of midget automobiles on the track.

A modern $450,000 structure will soon replace Brooklyn's historic Health Department Building at its present site on Flatbush Avenue Extension and Fleet Street. According to Goodhue Livingston Jr., secretary of the department, orders have been issued to all divisions of the Health Department to vacate the old building by Aug. 17.

The fifth annual Bennington festival opened here tonight in the Vermont State Armory before a capacity audience in spite of the heat. The program was a joint one by Eleanor King, Louise Kloepper and Marion Van Tuyl.

New York Giants vs. Pittsburgh Pirates, at Polo Grounds, 157th Street and Eighth Avenue ........................3:15 P.M. Brooklyn Dodgers vs. Cincinnati Reds, at Ebbets Field, Bedford Avenue and Sullivan Place, Brooklyn ........... 3:15 P. M.

The strike or lockout of special guards at the Polo Grounds, home of the New York Giants baseball club, who have kept a picket guard around the ball park since the opening of the season, April 19, was settled yesterday at the offices of the State Labor Relations Board, 366 Broadway.

In a strongly "But Worded editorial in the Giornale d'Italia, today, Virginio Gayda, who is often Premier Benito Mussolini's copies mouthpiece, defines Italy's attitude maps toward the Russo-Japanese clash.

To collect specimens for groups in the Akeley African Hall of the American Museum of Natural History, William D. Campbell, field representative, will leave New York tomorrow on board the Conte Di Savoia for a six months' expedition in Africa, covering more than 20,000 miles by motor truck.

MOTHER CAREY'S CHIICKENS. from screen play by S. K. Lauren-and- Gertrude Purcell based on the novel by Kate Douglas Wiggin and the play by Mrs. Wiggin and Rachel Crothers; directed by Rowland V. Lee: produced by
Bank clearings failed again this week to equal the level of the corresponding period of 1937, although two outside centers reported increases. The long series

There was a further score for the younger school of trainers today when W. J. (Buddy) Hirsch's Soldierette won easily in the $5,800 Schuylerville Stakes, a sprinting test confined to juvenile fillies. It was a simple victory.

Returning from a two-day trip yesterday, Fred J. Lichtman, Newark leather manufacturer, and his wife discovered that their home at 331 Cumberland Road here had been ransacked and at least $7,000 worth of jewelry, silverware, cutlery and clothing had been stolen.

The Hellenic Eastern Orthodox Church, at 319 East Seventy-fourth Street, more popularly known as the Hellenic Cathedral, was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Anna Epiphany Spetseris, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas J. Spetseris of Long Island

What with the committee for Brooklyn wrangling for one sort of welcome, and the committee for Manhattan holding out for something else, and the fog rolling over the sea so that you couldn't rightly see a thing that was close beside you, the clan of Corrigan had a hard time of it yesterday to give young Douglas Corrigan the welcome home that was due him.

The corportions which last year reported net income earned. in 1936 had gross income of $104,762,144,000, as compared with gross income of $67,192,417,000 for those corporations which reported net income for the preceding year, the Treasury announced today.

Chief Counsel, owned by B. C. Mayo of Tarboro, N. C., and driven by Doe Parshall, today was a straightheat victor over The Widower, owned by W. F. Hetherington of Rhinebeck, N. Y., and reined by Vie Fleming, in the National 3-yearold Pace Stake, feature event of the Grand Circuit meeting.

The Board of Education of the State of Louisiana has invited bids for a new issue of $6,000,000 of educational and charitable institution bonds. The bids will be considered on Aug. 16. The bonds will be dated Aug. 1, 1938, and will mature serially on Aug. 1, 1942 to 1966.

Deaths in the United States from diphtheria reached an all-time low in 1937, The Journal of the American Medical Association reported today. It said the drop to 568 deaths in ninetythree cities reporting last year, as compared with 4,078 in eighty-eight cities in 1923, made it "evident that the various elements of the diphtheria-prevention program have been extraordinarily effective."

Miss Carolyn. Winston, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick Henry Winston of Chapel Hill, N. C., who has made her home here for several years, was married here at noon today in St. Dominic's Church to Roger Goiran, son of Henri Goiran, French Minister to Mexico, and Mrs. Goiran. Mgr. Charles J. Canivan, the rector, performed the ceremony.

Ralph Betts Ferris, naval architect and marine engineer, who with his brother, Theodore E. Ferris, designed the Morro Castle and other coastwise vessels, died yesterday at Orange Memorial Hospital after a ten-day illness. Mr. Ferris,

Viscount Runciman began his mission today by formal visits of some twenty minutes each to Foreign Minister Kamil Krofta, Premier Milan Hodza and President Eduard Benes accompanied by his staff. This evening he conferred for 1 1/2 hours with the Henlein party deputation consisting of Franz Peters, Ernst Kundt, Heinrich Schicketanz and Dr. Wilhelm Sebekoysky.

An agreement whereby Britain will raise contributions toward the cost of housing her troops in Egypt was initialed by Viscount Halifax, Foreign Minister, for a and Mahommed Mahmoud Pasha, Egyptian Premier, at the Foreign mak Office today.
The Federal Trade, Commission announced today that two New York cosmetic manufacturers have entered into stipulations to cease certain misrepresentations in advertising their products.

Navy officials announced this morning that the search for the missing Hawaii Clipper had been definitely abandoned as hopeless, one week 'after the ill-fated flying boat with fifteen people aboard mysteriously vanished en route to Manila without even a warning of trouble.

Miss Barton Green of Jacksonville, Fla., gave a luncheon yesterday at the Stork Club for Mrs. Jorge R. Andre, Mrs. Wallen Grove, Mrs. Herbert Whiting, Mrs. Allessandro Pallavicini, Mrs. Leonard Thomas and Mrs Alice A. Andre.

Frederick Boyd Stevenson, reItired editor and lecturer, and for twenty-seven years on the staff of The Brooklyn Daily Eagle, died on Wednesday night at his home, 1,859 Stuart Street, Brooklyn. His age was 79.

A plan for the reorganization of the Chicago, Indianapolis Louisville Railroad Company, better known as the Monon, which virtually would strip the Southern and the Louisville Nashville roads of their control of the Monon was recommended today to the Interstate Commerce Commission in a report submitted by Milo H. Brinkley, I. C. C. examiner.

A collection of model handbags especially designed for the occasion by leading American creators was the outstanding feature of a showing of coordinated accessories presented at the Hotel Astor last night under the auspices of the National Authority for the Ladies' Handbag Industry.

A mother and her 14-year-old daughter were killed and four other persons were injured late -today when two automobiles collided at Harding Highway and Courses Landing Road, five miles east of Penns Grove.

Carrying on a tradition which has lasted for seven centuries, Franciscan and Dominican Fathers joined yesterday in the observance of the feast day of St. Dominic at a solemn high mass in the Churchof St. Vincent Ferrer, Lexington Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street.

Dr. and Mrs. Edwin Albert Riesen- yard feld of this city and Beverly Hills, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Ernestine Riesenfeld, to William Ludwig, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles-Ludwig of New York.

Fatal accidents in New York City dropped 10.4 per cent in the first six months of 1988 as compared with the same period of 1937, the Greater New York Safety Council reported yesterday. There were 1,841 accidental

Traditional services to commemorate the anniversary of the destruction of the temple in Jerusalem will be observed by the Spanish and Portuguese congregation at Central Park West and Seventieth Street tomorrow evening at 8:15 o'clock, and on Sunday morning from 7 to 10:30, it was announced yesterday.

Lord Queenborough of England and his two daughters, the Hon. Miss Audrey and the Hon. Miss Enid Paget, who are visiting Mrs. William Starr Miller, were the guests of honor at a dinner given at her Summer home tonight.
President Roosevelt today sent a message to the tenth world convention of the Christian Endeavor Union, comprising 10,000 delegates from all parts of the world. The message said:

Martin Hannon, 39-year-old WPA worker who gave his home as 41-11 Fuller Street, Flushing, was sentenced to serve thirty days in jail after he pleaded guilty to a charge of soliciting alms when he appeared yesterday before Magistrate Jenkin R. Hockert in Flushing court.

The dispute between the Department of Hospitals and Local 814 of the Brotherhood of Teamsters and Chauffeurs, A. F. of L. affiliate, which led to the union's refusal to move furniture and equipment to the city's hospitals, has been settled, Dr. S. S.,Goldwater, Commissioner of Hospitals, announced yesterday.

Theodore S. Haight, retired leather manufacturer, died at his home here yesterday afternoon after long illness. For many years Mr. Haight operated the American Hide and Leather Company here., Mr. Haight was born seventy-four years ago in Brooklyn, son of the late Samuel Haight and Mrs. Helen Vassar Haight. Since childhood he had lived here.

The Crucible Steel Company of America, New York, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering an issue of $10,000,000 of ten-year sinking fund, 4 1/2 per cent debentures, Series A, due on Aug. 1, 1948.

Two young unemployed architectural designers, Herbert W. Newmann and Herbert Struppmann, both of New York City, won the first prize of $1,500 in The Ladies Home Journal's national competition for small-house designs, it was announced yesterday.
Men's clothes are to have a building of their own at the New York World's Fair. Men's sports will also be featured, with an athletic arena seating 3,000 persons.
The bushmaster snake, which the American Museum of Natural History has been exhibiting proudly for the last two months, surprised every one yesterday by laying an egg.
Lieutenant Douglas Cleland of the Canadian military riding team scored in the Dublin Horse Show today. He rode a faultless round, taking a trophy presented by the Defense Minister.

Led by Ben Johnson and Ray Malott, the touring American track and field team opened a two-day meet with Europeon athletes today by taking five of seven events. Johnson, former Columbia University captain from Plymouth, Pa., won the 100-meter dash in 10.5 seconds, and Malott, unbeaten thus far on the tour, captured his specialty, the 400 meters, in 48.6 seconds.

The cities of Tokyo, Yokohama, Osaka and Kobe as well as practically all of Japan were thrown into semi-darkness to night as a partial light control went into effect, presumably as a measure against possible Soviet air attacks. The evening's business in cafes and other establishments was disrupted.

Albert Howard, 24 years old, an admitted criminal from boyhood, had confessed that in a period of one month this Summer he held up twenty-five retail liquor stores for a total of $2,300, pretending each time he held a pistol in his Docket.

A committee, headed by Gardner B. Perry, filed yesterday an application with the Interstate Commerce Commission to represent the holders of the refunding and improvement 5 per cent bonds of the Erie Railroad Company now operating under Section 77 of the Bankruptcy Act. It is estimated that

Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt have as guests at their cottage, Cady Hill, Miss Gloria Baker and Henry J. Topping Jr., who flew here today. With Mr. and Mrs. Frederick M. Alger Jr. of Detroit, they watched the races from the Vanderbilt box.

William McC. Martin Jr., presldent of the New York Stock Exchange, will make his first public address since his election to the post a month ago, at the first dinner meeting of the recently organized New York Financial Writers' Association.

Russell R. Brown, president -of the American Distilling Company, and Gene Tunney, chairman of the board, have resigned from the Distilled Spirits Institute, trade association of the liquor industry, it was announced yesterday.

The Royals snapped Jersey City's winning streak at three straight and their own losing streak at five today when they downed the Little Giants, 4 to 2. Harry Smythe, veteran left-hander, went the route for Montreal. He did not issue a base on balls.

Lieut Col. Albert Edward Bates, for many years a Salvation Arpny leader, died yesterday of a heart attack in his office at the Salvation Army headquarters, 120. West Fourteenth Street. He was 61 years old.

This ancient gateway to the Scottish Highlands today paid tribute to the Dionne quintuplets of Callander, Ont. Pipes skirted under the brow of lofty Ben Ledi. heralding Provost Alex Lyle's presentation of five tiny silver shoulder brooches and an address from the magistrates and councilors of the village whose namesake is the home of the quintuplets.

Pleading for tolerance as a "basic element in human life," Dr.. Niels H. D. Bohr, noted Danish physicist and winner of the Nobel Prize, warned the International Anthropological and Ethnographical Sciences Convention here today against nationalist theories of race culture.

Paul Edwards, administrative officer in charge of the five WPA Federal Arts Projects in this city, began yesterday an independent investigation into charges that Communists dominate the activities of the arts projects.

Settlement yesterday of an anti-trust suit by the State of Texas against Swift Co., Chicago meat packers, will permit the company to expand its cottonseed oil business in the Southwest, Swift officials said today.

Equipoise, second to Sun Beau as the world's leading money-winning race horse, died tonight at the C. V. Whitney farm near here. In his six years of racing the chestnut son of Pennant-Swinging won $338,610 and held the world's record of 1:342-5 for the mile, set in 1932 at Arlington Park.

The railroad wage dispute entered the mediation stage today as members of the Carriers Joint Conference Committee and the Railway Labor Executives Association concluded negotiations without reaching an agreement.

Death Announced Fireman Henry W. Hutton. formerly a member of Eng. Co. 260, residing at 106 Newell St., Greenpoint, Brooklyn, died Aug. 2. Funeral will take place from his late residence, at 2 P. M., Saturday, Aug. 6. Interment at Evergreen Cemetery, Brooklyn.

The hillbilly is losing the accent of his ancestors, an investigating linguist said today, but President Roosevelt is not. In a report to the National Parks Service on the speech of folks in the Great Smoky mountains of the South, Joseph H. Hall, said:

Applications by the Boston Stock Exchange for authority to extend unlisted trading privileges to Baldwin Locomotive Works voting trust certificates for $13 par value common stock and Homestake Mining Company $12.50 par value capital stock were not approved today in decisions by the Securities and Exchange Commission, which passed on sixteen such applications.

Contracts for a "Winter Wonderland" in the amusement area of the New York World's Fair, complete with an Alpine village, ski and toboggan slides and a daily snowstorm, were signed yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, president of the Fair Corporation, and R. J. Sipchen of Chicago.

Close-of-play scores in English county cricket matches started yesterday and the Australia-Scotland game started today follow: Middlesex, 395 and 129 for four wickets; Warwickshire, 206 (Croom 68, Dollery 62, Robins four for 56); at Birmingham.
Pearl White of "Perils of Pauline" fame died today at the American Hospital after an illness which had kept her in bed for three weeks. Her age was 49.

The stock markets here were quiet and generally steady today. Gilt-edge issues were off slightly. Among the foreign loans Japanese bonds were steadier and German issues were dull. Transatlantic shares improved in late dealings and United States Steel and International Nickel advanced.

The immensity of the refugee problem was emphasized again today by an official estimate that 660,900 persons now in Germany and Austria must find homes in other countries with the least possible delay.

Military headquarters here today issued orders to all provincial chiefs to take drastic measures to break up any protest strikes as a transportation walkout in Oriente Province threatened to tie up highway traffic at the end of the island.

A spectacular two-alarm fire: in the film-reclaiming plant of the Warner Brothers Cellulose Products Company at 791 East Forty-third Street, Brooklyn, caused the death of one man early yesterday and aroused hundreds of residents in

Odd-lot dealers and specialists of the New York Stock Exchange reported that they received from customers 5,957 more orders to sell than to buy in the week ended on July 30. They reported 109,858 more shares ordered sold than in the buying orders.

The repeat performance of the Tchaikovsky violin concerto, promised by Mischa Elman but postponed several times because of the unfavorable weather, materialized last night at the Lewisohn Stadium before an audience estimated at 9,500. The program, devoted to the

Fed steers and yearlings sold fully steady today in a little more active trade due to a reduction in receipts. Other classes of cattle, however, continued weak and in instance lower. Hogs broke again even though supplies were curtailed, and lambs closed sharply down, the United States Department of Agriculture reports.

Leasing of large upperfloor spaces featured the business rental reports submitted yesterday. In the building at 521-31 West Forty-third Street, the Celanese Corporation of America, Inc., took a unit comprising about 20,000 square feet of space for warehousing purposes.

Mayor La Guardia expressed disapproval yesterday of that section of the judiciary article, now before the Constitutional Convention, which calls for review of semi-judicial decisions by administrative boards; "The provision

BLAME this on Dizzy Dean or Dr. Alexis Carrel. It's a problem that scientists will have to solve in the long run. But the mere mention of it will have the old-timers throwing up their hats and giving three quavering cheers for the great athletes of other days.

William Babington Maxwell, the novelist, died here today at the age of 72. Mr. Maxwell began writing at the start of the century and produced a book a year until 1913, when he reached the peak of his reputation with "The Devil's Garden," although

A "great national retail demonstation" in which stores will unite to bring to the attention of the public the role they play as "institutions of service for the 130,000,000 consumers of the country" was enthusiastically approved 'by merchants and retail representatives at a meeting held yesterday under the auspices of the National Retail Dry Goods Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The region north and south of Gandesa on the Ebro River front is still the most interesting theatre of military operations in Spain. The fighting there has been severe for several days as attack and counter-attack continue, but neither side seems to have made much progress.

Mike (Kid) Frattini, 147, welterweight champion of Italy, outpointed Bobby Pacho, 145, Mexico, in the main ten-round bout at the Fort Hamilton Army Reservation in Brooklyn last night. A crowd of 6,000 saw Frattini, who outboxed his rival most of the way, avenge a setback sustained at the hands of Pacho earlier this season.
The Federal Trade Commission charged a conspiracy to fix prices against four firms that are said to control substantially the entire output of calcium chloride in the United States.

The engagement of $2,847,000 gold abroad for shipment here--$1,327,000 in Canada and $1,520,000 in England-was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. In London the hoarding scramble for gold continued strong, but the price of the metal did not rise. Instead gold was available
Dr. Arthur L. Swift, a retired New York dentist and for many years a leader in his profession, died at his home,' 23 Stamford Ave., Shippan, this afternoon. His age was 76.

A petition was presented today to the directors of the Chicago Board of Trade asking for a ballot vote of the membership on an amendment to the rules reducing commission rates on cash wheat to arrive from the present 1 1/2 cents to 1 cent a bushel.

Mozel Ellerbe of Tuskegee Institute today was declared winner of the 100-meter dash in yesterday's track and field meet between the United States touring team and Germany after officials had examined photographs of the finish.

The Rev. Issac Loeb Epstein rabbi, of this city, died suddenly yesterday morning of a heart attack at Monticello, N. Y., where he was vacationing. Rabbi Epstein, who made his home at 205 Henry Street; was 53 years old.

Sir Robert MacLeod Hodgson, British Agent at Burgos, the Spanish Insurgent capital, has been instructed to remind Generalissimo Francisco Franco that he has not yet sent any comment on the British plan for withdrawal of foreign combatants from both sides in Spain, although more than a month has elapsed since the note was delivered by the Non-Intervention Committee.
The natives of the gulf districts of New Guinea, it is reported, are suffering from a recurrence of a collective mania which first attacked them in the year of the Versailles treaty.
The Mengel Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday bookings and billings for July and seven months and unfilled orders as of July 31, last, as follows:

The indications are for partly cloudy weather, probably with local showers and thunderstorms today and tomorrow. Little change in temperature is expected, according to the map charted at the United States Weather Bureau at 7:30 o'clock E. S. T. last night.

Business in the stock markets here was restricted today to end-of-the-account -adjustments. There were few outstanding movements, although the general undertone was firm. Gilt-edges were idle and foreign bonds were inactive.
Pullman, Inc., reported yesterday for the three months ended on June 30 a consolidated net profit of $216,349 after charges,
The new type Fokker-Wulf quadrimotor plane is expected to start from Berlin within a fortnight for a direct non-stop flight to New York, it was reliably reported today.

In an automobile accident on the Harlem River Speedway at 172d Street, James R. Morgan, 40 years old, an automobile mechanic of 1,887 Walton Avenue, the Bronx, was killed instantly at 11:30 o'clock last night when the machine he was driving turned over after having been in collision with a northbound car driven by Robert C. Archambault, 37, of 501 West 110th Street.
Vermont cracked down today on out-of-State couples coming here to be married to avoid marriage laws in their own State.

Ex-Premier Leon Blum, who was close to the origins of the Franco-Soviet pact, said in his newspaper, Le Populaire, today that if the Russo - Japanese conflict should extend to a point involving European action France would be obliged to give assistance to Russia.

Premier Benito Mussolini today approved the new uniforms prescribed for Italy's civil employees and ordered that they be worn beginning Oct. 28, the sixteenth anniversary of the Fascist march on Rome.
John C. Reed, Atlantic City attorney, died unexpectedly today at his Summer home at Hockessin, His age was 69.

Johnny Adams, his leg broken in a fall from a 30-to-1 shot, today faced virtually certain loss of his American riding championship. The 1937 jockey king was injured yesterday when Sparking Spic stumbled as the field swung out of the chute in the second race.
There was a large assembly of the members of the Art Association and their guests present this afternoon at the reception and tea that marked the opening of three separate art exhibitions.
There is reason to believe that the Palestine problem will not be settled for a long time and that the present state of the country may become chronic.

President Roosevelt got back on the job today and after working on his mail, began a tour of inspection of the canal and its defenses, and included a section of the national highway of Panama, which is part of the Pan-American system.

Investment of European funds in United States securities is as old as the country, by and large, as any one familiar with the financing of construction of railroads in this country knows, but in the last few days there have been moves intended to facilitate distribution and exchanges of such securities on the foreign market.

A comedy of errors, Homeric in proportion, came to a gloriously fitting climax yesterday when this most cosmopolitan of cities turned out to welcome a son of Erin named Douglas Corrigan for becoming a hero through a classic Irish bull.
The city of Chicago retained yesterday all bids unopened for $2,200,000 of water-revenue certificates. The city, however, will consider bids on Aug. 19, for $4,700,000 of similar certificates.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial "Why Not Make It Short?" in THE TIMES of July 30 clearly illustrates the need of brevity in the new State Constitution. But to state that our Federal Constitution "is in good working order" seems to reveal an unfamiliarity with that document.

Carrying through with its plan announced last week of reporting the daily volume of stock transactions on the New York Stock and Curb Exchanges within three weeks instead of four after the period covered, the Securities and Exchange Commission submitted today its report for the week ended on July 16.

M. J. MacNamara, vice president of National Distillers Products Corporation and vice chairman of the board of the Distilled Spirits Institute, declined to comment yesterday on the resignations of Rus, sell R. Brown, president of the American Distilling Company, and of Gene Tunney, chairman of. the board, from the distillers' trade association.

The United States Circuit Court yesterday upheld a decision of a lower Federal court which denied the trustee of the estate of the late William Waldorf Astor the right to recover some $10,800,000 assessed against the estate as an inheritance tax.
Mr. Hore-Belisha, Britain's dynamic Secretary of War, continues to modernize the British Army and to rejuvenate Tommy Atkins and Colonel Blimp.

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks, 1,172,000 bales, against 1,174,000 a week ago, 1,157,000 two weeks ago, 1,133,000 three weeks ago and 780,000 a year ago; of which American 676,000 bales, against 685,000 a week ago, 696,000 two weeks ago, 707,000 three weeks ago and 278,000 a year ago.

On the picturesque marine stage here tonight, where J. J. and Lee Shubert and Fortune Gallo abruptly terminated an operetta schedule recently, Alfredo Salmaggi and New York's Hippodrome Opera Company launched a season of grand opera production at popular prices.

William Ziegler Jr. has an excellent chance of winning the two big stakes which will feature the Saratoga program tomorrow as his colt, El Chico, and his filly, Esposa, are certain to rule the choices in the Saratoga Special and the Merchants and Citizens Handicap, repectively.

No perplexing question of principle entered into the primary campaign of the Tennessee Democrats. They were merely called upon to take sides in a personal quarrel. National Committeeman Crump, the Memphis boss, and Governor Browning, for whom he garnered in '36 60,000 out of 61,000 votes in his little kingdom, had come to hate each other.

Dr. F. H. Newton, a prominent Dallas physician; his brother, Will Newton, and Maurice Jackson, a Negro cook at the Newton home, were exonerated by the grand jury today of kidnapping charges in connection with the alleged confinement of Mickey Ricketts, former yard boy at the Newton home.
John A. Johnson, carpentry contractor and builder, died yesterday German Poet, at his home, 824 Fifty-first Street, Veteran Brooklyn, after a short illness. He was 73 year old.
" The Last Trump," James Bridie's comedy of mankind's reactions to the approach of Judgment Day, was well received at the Malvern Festival tonight.
The liner City of Los Angeles will sail today for California via the Panama Canal on the first voyage of the new Panama Pacific Line service. She will be in. command

Miss Virginia Ione Taylor; daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rutherford Hayes Taylor. of this place, was married here tonight in the Wyoming Presbyterian Church to Frank J. Mischo Jr., son of Mrs. Mischo of Short Hills and the late Mr. Mischo. The pastor, the Rev. Ralph H. Read, officiated.

A court action that ultimately may bring under legal attack the recent conveyance by Howland Spencer of his 500-acre estate, across the Hudson River from President Roosevelt's home, to followers of Father Divine was begun yesterday in Supreme Court by the liquidators of the Straus National Bank and Trust Company.

Sharply conflicting versions of the strike warfare at "Stop Five" in Youngstown, Ohio, on July 19, 1937, in the course of which two steel strikers were killed and thirty-six persons injured, were offered to the Senate Civil Liberties Committee today.
