Crosby Ave (18-5399); e s, 50 s of Merry Ave, 50x100; Michael W. Casey to HOLC. Olmstead Ave (14-3611); n e cor of Homer Ave, 29x99; Signey O. Raphael to HOLC. Owners Loan Corp. Home St, 795 (10-2672); William J. Colgan, referee, to HOLC.

There will be no relief or reconstruction reprisals in the way of withholding Federal funds from Puerto Rico as a result of the attempt on Governor Blanton Winship's life, according to Secretary of the Interior Harold L. Ickes.

Bishop Thomas E. Molloy of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn has received the thanks of Cardinal Goma of Toledo, Spain, for money and religious articles being collected in the diocese for Catholics in Spain. The Cardinal also wrote recently to the Rev. Pablo Ramis of St. Peter's Church, 117 Warren Street, Brooklyn, chairman of a committee in charge of the collecting.

LIEUTENANT--Wlliam F. Gaffney, from 4th Division to Telegraph Bureau, designated as acting captain, for 26 days, from 8 A. M., Aug. 6. PATROLMAN-John L. Crehan, from 84th Precinct to 19th Division, office of the chief Inspector, for 19 days, from 8 A. M., Aug. 13.

The Massachusetts Federation of Labor today called upon President Roosevelt to remove Edwin S. Smith and -Donald Smith from the National Labor Relations Board "because of their perversion" of the National Labor Relations Law.

St. Louis took advantage of errors by Shortstop Scharein in the first two innings to score two runs and beat the Phillies, 3-0, in the opening game of the series today. Lon Warneke pitched for the Cardinals and held the Phillies to six hits.
A sewerage system for Essex Fells, was one of sixty-eight non-Federal projects approved today, with grants amounting to $3,538,132 toward an estimated construction cost of $7,862,532.

Urged on by the ear-splitting exhortations of an all-time record ladies' day crowd that numbered 62,753 and converted Cleveland's huge stadium into a riot of noise and color, Oscar Vitt's Indians made a desperate attempt to nudge themselves back into the American League pennant fight today.
A decision on the release of fourteen members of the Loyalist Washington-Lincoln Battalion from San Pedro de Cardena concentration camp near Burgos, Spain, is expected next Monday.

Friscodale, chestnut gelding owned by Pearl Hungerford of Shelbyville, Ind., sprang one of the biggest surprises of the Grand Circuit season at Agawam Park today by defeating Billy Difect, 1937 world champion 3-year-old pacer.

Charles Hopkins, the Federal Theatre's State producing director at the Theatre-of-the-Four-Seasons, Roslyn, L. I., will quit that job the middle of this month to assume the post of repertory producer for the thirteen Middle Western States, with headquarters in Chicago, according to John McGee, associate national director of the Federal Theatre.

Five Manhattan properties were sold at auction in the Vesey Street salesrooms yesterday, and a fifth scheduled sale was adjourned to a later date. The property whose sale was adjourned is known as 9-11 East Fifty-sixth. Street and 8-10 East Fifty-seventh Street.

United States Senator Sherman Minton of Indiana, author of the Senate bill to curb false newspaper reports, which he introduced and then withdrew, will explain his attitude toward the press to newspaper workers of New York City next Saturday afternoon.

Leave of absence, with pay, for five days, from 9 A. M. Aug. 11, is granted to Fireman First Grade Robert V. Reilly, H. L. Co. 7, for the purpose of attending the State convention of the American Legion at Endicott, N. Y., as a duly elected delegate of Manhattanville Post 1,057, providing he produces satisfactory proof of such attendance.

Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on July 30 amounted to 588,703 cars, the Association of American Railroads. announced today. This was 7,821 cars, or 1.3 per cent, more than for the preceding week,

A young German with the first name Joshua has asked legal permission to change the name because it "sounds Jewish." His father objected on the ground that it was tradition in the family to have a son named Joshua;

Elaborate preparations are under way for the reception of Admiral Nicholas Horthy, Regent of Hungary, who will be the German Government's guest for three days beginning Aug. 22. It will be in the nature of a formal State visit and will mark the first event of its kind under the National Socialist regime, as the admiral is a ranking head of State.

The fate of the sailing vessel Admiral Karpfanger, former German training ship, remains a mystery, reports from Magallanes indicated today. The Chilean navy ship Galvarino scouted the ice-bound channels- near Cape Horn but found no trace of the missing craft.
A revised list of dates set by the American League today for the playoff, of postponed games and schedule changes follows:
Mr. and Mrs. Dion K. Dean of Rahway have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ruth Orr Dean, to Dwight Benedict Herrick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Benedict Herrick of Elizabeth.

Apparently facing too much weather competition, the "cool mass" that the Weather Bureau believed would bring relief to sweltering New Yorkers after twelve consecutive days of abnormally high temperatures gave up its march across the country yesterday and dwindled to a small high pressure area which settled in the region of the Great Lakes, where it brought lower temperatures.
The demand for neutrality is spreading over the face of Europe. Science has shown how the human body develops antitoxins to overcome disease.
Comment on the reception by the city to Douglas Corrigan, the transatlantic flier, will be heard in a number of the pulpits tomorrow.

Tallying five runs in the ninth to tie the score, four on Joe Cronin's homer, the Red Sox picked up another run in the tenth to down the Tigers, 9 to 8, today. It was the third straight defeat for Detroit.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week totals $19,256,648, to be represented by two States and seventy municipalities, compared with the revised total of only $10,331,764, for this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date now stands at $25,182,252.

The Republican Program Committee warned today that "present trends" threaten the country with a "two-fold disaster, a breakdown of its economic system and the disintegration of responsible and effective government."
John Francis Neary of 115 Chestnut Street, Englewood, N. J., a New York patent lawyer, died Thursday of a heart attack at Hot Springs, Va., according to word received here yesterday.

The local Criminal Court and the Pennsylvania Legislature have decided to pass the week-end waiting for each other's next move in the two weeks' battle to determine which shall investigate the corruption charged against Governor Earle and his administration.
The Fifth Avenue branch office of Wm. A. White Sons has been moved from 41 to 55 Fifth Avenue, where larger quarters have been taken to care for increased business.

State and municipal financing in July aggregated $54,903,227, as compared with $51,655,968 in July, 1937. The total for the first seven months of 1938 was $779,313,138, against $673,284,969 in the same period of last year.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Aug. 5, unless specified. At San Francisco, Aug. 3: Aylwin, Dale, Dewey, Farragut, Hull, Monaghan, MacDonough, Phelps, Worden. Canal Zone to Pensacola via Colon and Old Providence: Houston, McDougal. San Pedro to Navy Yard, Mare Island: Grebe, Sirius.

Douglas Corrigan can fly sideways, too, he revealed yesterday morning. His mistake in going to Dublin, when all the time he thought he was heading in the opposite direction, was not the first time he fumbled his navigation.

In an effort to get George J. Weppler out of the job of clerk of the Fourth District Municipal Court, which he has insisted on retaining for three years without pay, Paul J. Kern, president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, asked District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey yesterday to consider prosecuting the clerk on a misdemeanor charge.

The Hudson River Trolley Line, which did much to build up Northern New Jersey between Paterson and the 125th Street Ferry slip here, passed out of existence today after thirty-five years of operation, surrendering with ceremony to a bus line paralleling the tracks whereever possible.

The Savings Banks Association of the State of New York announced yesterday that member banks in this city made 3,897 mortgage loans, totaling $58,292,846, during the year ended June 1, 1938. Most of the money was used to finance individual homes, the average for all loans being slightly under $15,000.

Inventories held by wholesale houses have dropped to a point low enough to indicate to experts of the Department of Commerce that these will constitute a buying market which will contribute to accelerated business in the Fall.
James D. Black, former Governor of Ken bourville, Ky., today of pneumonia. The 88-year-old jurist had spent three days under an oxygen tent.
Tonight's soloist at Lewisohn Stadium is Arnold Belnick, 13-year-old violinist, who will play the Bruch G minor with the PhilharmonicSymphony under the direction of Alexander Smallens.

The Oxford-Cambridge cricketers engaged in the first official match of their tour today, opposing the Kingston Club, oldest cricket organization in the West Indies, which is celebrating its seventyfifth anniversary.
Fifteen Italian sailors were killed and twenty were injured in a fireroom explosion aboard the Italian cruiser Quarto in the port of Pollenza, Island of Majorca, it was announced today.
Dr. Eduard Benes, president of the Czechoslovak Republic, will appear on the Knopf publishing list later this year with the publication of "They Gave Us a Country."
A crowd of workers today wrecked machinery at a $2,000,000-State building project on which they were employed.
Pittsburgh at New York-Tobin (9-5) vs. Gumbert (9-8). Cincinnati at Brooklyn-Walters (8-12) vs. Hamlin (7-7) or Butcher (4-4). St. Louis at Philadelphia-Davis (8-5) vs. Hollingsworth (5-9).
The Commodity Credit Corporation reported today it had lent $21,738,266 on 44,826,737 bushels of corn through Aug. 4.

Apartment houses overlooking Central Park added the names of numerous tenants to their rosters, according to lists issued yesterday by brokers and renting agents. Some of the suites will be occupied by the new tenants on Oct. 1.
Douglas Corrigan, who flew to Dublin by "mistake," will receive a hero's welcome in Boston Monday on his arrival at the airport, probably at 1 P. M.

Operations of the Crane Company and its subsidiaries in the twelve months ended on June 30 resulted in a consolidated net income of $3,880,944 after depreciation, all taxes and other charges, but before surtax on undistributed profits, according to the financial statement announced yesterday by Charles B. Nolte, president.

" Alexander's Ragtime Band" was played at the Roxy yesterday and at its finish the score stood: Irving Berlin, 26; Opposition, 0. Few sentimental gestures have been more expansive, few more lavishly produced than this motion picture tribute to Tin Pan Alley's most famous lodger.
A number of small residential properties passed into new ownership in the Westchester realty deals announced yesterday.

An overbid grand slam contract gave the Four Aces a scant margin of victory over the Mrs. Culbertson team in their knockout match this afternoon at Convention Hall in the master's team-of-four bridge contest and carried Oswald Jacoby, Howard E. Schenken, David Burnstine and B. Jay Becker into the semi-final round scheduled for tomorrow.

Trading in veal fair, other classes slow with practically no steer hind-rib business and some houses unable to move fresh pork at any price, in local markets yesterday. Veal and calf steady; other classes either weak or lower.
The House of Representatives tonight accepted the resignation of its President, Antonio Martinez Fraga. The resignation was presented last Tuesday.

Douglas Corrigan heard a symphony concert-with Irish selections predominating--for the first time in his life last night at the Lewisohn Stadium and, to the delight of 4,000 to 5,000 fellow listeners and the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, found it "very eddcational and interesting."

Promises that statements containing receipts and disbursements of committees working in support of the rival Republican candidates for the Ohio Senatorial nomination would be in the hands of the Senate Campaign Expenditures Committee by Sunday came today to the committee.

Herman L. Weckler, who has been in charge of industrial relations for the Chrysler Corporation, has been appointed to the newly created position of vice president of the corporation in charge of operations, it was announced yesterday by K. T. Keller, president.

Claire Hyman, 9 years old, of 2 Stratford Place, was the first girl, and Pierre Grimes, 13, of 132 West Ninety-sixth Street, the first boy to enter the Park Department's new floating swimming pools in the Hudson River at Ninety-sixth Street when the reconditioned barges were opened for pubilc use at 10 A. M. yesterday.
The following table shows the fifteen most active stocks traded in on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday; also the new highs and lows for the last three days:

While Viscount Runciman's.staff democracy continues to work in close contact with the Henlein party leaders, the British negotiator in the CzechSudeten German dispute confined himself today to purely formal visits.

Cotton-mill. activity was unchanged last week when a seasonal drop was anticipated and the adjusted index spurted to 121.2, the highest point since the week ended Oct. 2, 1937. This compared with 110.8 (revised) for the previous week and 139.9 for the week ended July 31, 1937.
The board of managers of the New York Produce Exchange approved yesterday the new contracts for trading in shelled peanue futures. Trading in the new contracts will begin on Aug. 15.

The defeat of Governor Gordon Browning and his political ally, Senator George L. Berry, was so decisive in yesterday's Democratic primary as to discourage any further immediate steps to try to retain their power in Tennessee.

Infantile paralysis has become epidemic in six districts of England and Wales. Two deaths today at Worthing, one of the latest places affected, brought the total of deaths to eight since the disease broke out early in July at Halstead, Essex.

A total of 124 commercial-vessels of 519,965 tons was under construction in United States yards on Aug. 1, for classification with the American Bureau of Shipping, it was announced yesterday. They represent an increase of twentythree ships and 197,336 tons over last year.

Reporting output of motor cars this week at 14,771 units, Ward's Automotive Reports said today that weekly production was close to its bottom for 1938. After next week, it said, assemblies should be on a constantly rising plane for some time.
William J. Moxley, former Representative from the Sixty-fifth district, died yesterday in the home of his son, George T. Moxley, at Lake Geneva, Wis. He was 87 years old.
Net asset value of the Investment Company of America on July 31 was $19.26 a common share, compared to $18.19 on June 30 and $61.16 on July 31, 1937.

Advocating the use of newspaper advertising to keep the public informed as to newest methods in the science of healing, Dr. Clement J. Joynt addressed 1,000 delegates to the American Progressive Chiropractic Association convention today.
The State Board of Medical Examiners announced today that 171 of 193 candidates passed the June examinations for license to practice medicine in New Jersey.

No political candidates for any office have as yet been endorsed by the American Federation of Labor, it was said yesterday by George Meany, president of the State federation, and Thomas J. Lyons, president of the Central Trades and Labor Council.
Hazel Hurst, 22-year-old blind American lecturer, sailed for the United States tonight after spending just ten minutes on English soil from which the government barred her faithful dog guide Babe.
Lieut. Col. Carl F. McKinney. Infantry. is detailed as Chief of Staff. 78th Division, in addition to his other duties, Vice Colonel Walter S. Sturgill, Field Artillery, relieved.

Awards for small-arms marksmanship were presented to Treasury Department agents in law enforcement and protective duties today by Roswell Magill, acting secretary, following conclusion of the third annual shoot here.

Wilmer Allison, veteran internationalist from Austin, Texas, stroked his way into the final round of the Canadian tennis championships today with a 6-0, 6-1, 0-6, 6-1 victory over Bobby Murray, Montreal Davis Cup star.

The Securities and Exchange Commission suspended today the effectiveness of a registration statement filed by the Breeze Corporations, Inc., of New Jersey, on Nov. 10, 1936, covering a proposed offering of 201,000 shares.
Henry Harrison Snedeker, New York lawyer, member of the old local Township Committee and Masonic leader, died yesterday at his home here. His age was 74.
Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of carded gray goods as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:
Word comes from Liverpool, Nova Scotia, that the first tuna of the season was taken by Maurice Wertheim of New York and tipped the scales at 565 pounds.

Mr. and Mrs. William Ziegler Jr. gave a dinner tonight at their cottage for Mrs. C. Oliver Iselin, Mr. and Mrs. Federico G. Pohndorff, Mrs. Edward Murphy 2d, Mr. and Mrs. Edmund Tweedy, Robert White and Charles F. Noyes of New York. The Tweedys are their house guests for a week.
Trustees of the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railway Company objected today to independent reorganization of the Rock Island, Arkansas Louisiana Railroad Company, a subsidiary.

Led by Marcel Melliand of Heide berg, publisher of the internationally known Melliand Textile News, sixty textile industrialists representing twelve European nations ar rived yesterday on the HamburgAmerican liner Deutschland for a study tour of the United States
Agricultural cooperative associations throughout the country are repaying their members more than $25,000,000 annually, the Farm Credit Association reported today after a survey.
The July traffic figures for the Panama Canal, made public today by the War Department, showed a continuance of the decline which was first manifest in April.

Morris Bernhard, chairman of the board of directors of the Consolidated Trimming. Corporation, 27 West Twenty-third Street, manufacturer of upholstery and drapery trimming, died yesterday at his home, 2 East Eighty-sixth Street, after an illness of several weeks. He was 76 years old.

Emil Lehman, 48 years old, .a realty broker associated with Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., of 67 Wall Street, plunged to his death yesterday afternoon from a window in a -vacant apartment on the seventh. floor of 140. West Fiftyfifth Street.

A meeting of Little Entente statesmen is scheduled for Aug. 21 at Bled. The Rumanian and Czechoslovak Foreign Ministers will attend. The meeting takes on special importance in view of the recent Salonika pact linking Bulgaria with the Balkan Entente.

Martin Johnson, the explorer, who died on Jan. 13, 1937, as the result of injuries received in an airplane accident, left a net estate of $141,984, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday. His widow, Mrs. Osa Johnson, who was injured in the same accident, is the principal beneficiary.
Dr. William James A. O'Hara, a leading physician and surgeon here and an organizer of St. Vincent's Hospital, died today in the hospital after a brief illness. His age was 74.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it has granted the Genesee Valley Gas Company, Inc., now in reorganization, exemption from certain provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935, with conditions.

Brooklyn's headlong flight toward the first division took a Corrigan turn at Ebbets Field yesterday as the Dodgers wound up in sixth place after starting the afternoon in fifth. They lost to the Reds, 4 to 1, with a typical Flatbush inning that saw a man who had struck out score the deciding run.

Inauguration of a permanent program of between-season employment for needy farmers was announced here tonight by Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, as the first step of President Roosevelt's "frontal attack" on the South's inequality of income.

A decidedly better undertone ruled in most sections of the bond market at the close yesterday, after considerable irregularity in early trading. Taking its cue from the improvement in share prices the main body of secondary and speculative issues responded to a fairly brisk demand during the afternoon.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Aug. 3:
Sale of the city's $5,310,000 tax lien against the surface car properties of the B. M. T., scheduled for yesterday, has been postponed until Nov. 1. Readvertising of the sale was started Aug. 1.
A cocktail party on the Sagamore Hotel Terrace preceded the exhibitors dinner tonight, one of the festivities in connection with the fifth annual Sagamore horse show continuing through Sunday.

In an effort to dethrone the Governors Island Yellows as the Second Corps Military Area polo champions, the West Point Officers have made an important change in their line-up for the title game tomorrow at Morris Memorial Field.

Miss Elizabeth Alden Fish, daughter of Harry Potter Fish of 140 West Fifty-eighth Street, has chosen Aug. 31 for her marriage to John Alden Stanton, son of Dr. and Mrs. Frederick Lester Stanton of 180 East Seventy-ninth Street. The ceremony will take place in the Riverside Church.

Bernard Toplitzky, a promoter, now being sued by Helen Vinson Perry, was arrested today by District Attorney's investigators on charges of swindling a jewelry concern of $12,000 by obtaining three diamond bracelets on credit and then pawning them at less than half their value.

The Maytag Company sent about 275 special delivery letters this afternoon to its workers alleged to have participated in a sit-down strike at the factory recently, informing them of an investigation to assist it "in properly and fairly judging the action it should take."

Miss Charlotte Glutting of Rock Spring led a field of forty-five players to gain a one-stroke victory with 40, 41-81 on the Yountakah Country Club course today in the weekly one-day tournament of the New Jersey Women's Golf Association. Her nearest rival was Mrs. Wright D. Goss Jr., who returned 42, 4082.

THERE ought to be a law. There ought to be a law forbidding novelists to write novels about novelists. All the custom does-whether you have in mind a character in "Point Counter Point" or a character in "Cakes and Ale," or characters in any number of other novelist-infested novels-is to bring down the general level of public esteem, reverence and veneration toward novelists. And novelists, above all people,

Wholesale houses which have been taking part in the dry goods, apparel and general merchandise market opening activities here this week have booked business estimated at $30,000,000 since Monday, according to the Association of Commerce.

Bernard Talimer, retired newspaper executive, died early this morning in his apartment at the Hotel Traymore here after a long illness. He was 69 years old. He arrived here about a month ago from the Hotel Warwick, Philadelphia.
Mussolini has frowned on Fascists without neckties. Prominent members of the party got into the habit of discarding cravats

The volume of new bond financing this week rose to $40,578,500, consisting of only three individual loans, compared with only $6,828,000 in new issues marketed last week. During this week last year $2,288,000 in bonds were placed on the market.
The transfer of the civil branches of the Chinese Government from Hankow to Chungking is virtually completed.

After ten days' savage fighting the Republicans [Loyalists] have abruptly ceased all activity on the Ebro front. The Nationalists [Insurgents], however, continue to shell concentrations of Republican troops, but their infantry has not yet received the order to advance.
A veritable cloudburst today halted play in the national boys and juniors tennis championship at the Culver Military Academy and turned the courts into quagmire.

Miss Dorothy Workman and Miss Barbara Winslow of California, conquerors of Miss Dorothy Bundy and Mrs. Sarah Palfrey Fabyan in the quarter-finals, reached the final round of the women's invitation tennis tournament at the Maidstone Club today.
Dublih's great horse show week reached its peak today when the international military jumping competition for the new gold trophy presented by His Highness the Aga Khan was won by the Irish riders.

Thirty thousand persons cheered a game old man to the echo tonight as Maxie Rosenbloom, fifteen years a great boxer, gained a draw in ten rounds with young and clever Bob Pastor. Rosenbloom came in at 184 3/4 pounds and Pastor scaled 180 1/2.

Harold-Halsted of the Westhampton Beach Yacht Squadron, although third today in the International Star Class series that is a feature of the annual race week cruise of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association, continues to lead the fleet.
Trapped in a hotel room, Earl Young, 28, of Lebanon, Pa., desperado wanted in four States for robbery, kidnapping, rape and murder, was shot to death here today by two city policemen.

The serious water shortage brought about here last night when a 24inch water main near the new freight station burst was relieved this morning when two smaller mains were put into operation, and the city received a low-pressure supply of water.
Half of the 10 per cent wage reduction made on April 1 by the Brown Shoe Company will be restored to its 10,000 employes on Aug. 15, John A. Bush, president of the firm, announced today.

George Herman (Babe) Ruth, rushed by motor cycle escort from Ebbets Field, where he had been coaching the Brooklyn Dodgers, gave his 22-year-old adopted daughter,:Julia, 500 cubic centimeters of his blood in a transfusion at 6 o'clock last night at the Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital, 210 East Sixty-fourth Street.

The stage was set today for the most significant match of the American tennis season as Robert L. Riggs Jr. of Los Angeles and Chicago and Sidney B. Wood Jr. of Southampton gained the final round of the forty-eighth annual invitation tournament at the Meadow Club.

Stocks closed strong with gains of 1 to 3 points in largest trading since July 29; turnover, 1,169,940 shares. Bonds closed firm in, largest dealings of the week, United States Government issues irregularly higher; transactions, $6,154,075.

Fall style shows, market-week events and more trade gatherings helped to maintain buying this week close to the previous week's proportions in the principal wholesale markets, according to the weekly survey by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Through a combination of filmy fog and heat haze, with naught but occasional feathery breaths of air, the fleet of the American Yacht Club came to Duck Island Roads tonight on its second cruise run, from Port Jefferson, L. I.

The cost to Japan of the campaign in China was illustrated graphically in the weekly report of gold movements by the Department of Commerce, which showed today that Japan shipped to the United States in the week ended July 29 gold worth $5,874,400, or more than half of the $9,215,714 in gold received in this country in that week.
Heavy "enemy" bombers, testing Great Britain's aircraft defenses in the biggest war games ever held by the Royal Air Force, scored direct hits today along the eastern coast.

A sale of all the capital stock of Corporate Administration, Inc., by Arthur A. Ballantine as trustee for the Continental Securities Corporation to Edward G. Leffler for $5,000 was approved yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Peter Schmuck.
Mr. and Mrs. Matthew C. Fleming of 1,060 Fifth Avenue are at Jasper Park Lodge, Jasper National Park in Alberta, Canada.

The National Mediation Board will meet in Chicago on Thursday to begin inquiries into the proposed 15 per cent wage reduction by railroads which has brought strike threats on behalf of 900,000 railway workmen. Dr. William M. Leiserson.
The Chrysler Corporation accepted today the invitation of the Chicago Stock Exchange to list its common stock, Arthur M. Betts, chairman, announced.
Robbers with a taste for antique silver- and -painted porcelain made off with $26,900 worth of jewelry and art objects from- the homes of two prominent Hartsdale residents, it was disclosed today.

After opening bids from 424 man- ley ufacturers of women's coats and dresses, WPA executives and Treasury Department officials made a preliminary inspection yesterday of 8,000 garments submitted as samples in the government's projected purchase of $2,000,000 worth of women's apparel.

Here is the procedure in tabulating tomorrow's primary returns in Kentucky: Counting starts one hour after the polls close at 4 P. M., local time. Most of the State is on Central standard time. Louisville does not begin the count until 7 P. M.

The Gulf States Utilities Company of Beaumont, Texas, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, under the Holding Company Act, a declaration covering issuance of $10,000,000 of firstmortgage and refunding 4 per cent bonds, Series D, to be issued upon consummation of a plan for acquisition of the Gulf States of Louisiana Steam Generating Corporation and the Baton Rouge Electric Company.

Floyd B. Odlum, president of the Atlas Corporation, testified today that his corporation and its subsidiaries owned $22,295,000 of Utilities Power and Light Corporation debentures due in 1959 and $7,366,000 of those due in 1947.

Department store sales for the week ending July 30 were 11 per cent lower than for the same week last year and for the four weeks ending July 23 were 10 per cent below the figures for the comparable period a year ago, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

A referendum, the results of which will be of the greatest importance to the diary farmers of New England and New York, will be held throughout the milksheds serving New York and the metropolitan area on Aug. 20, the Agricultural Adjustment Administration announced today. Its result may also be of importance to the millions of milk consumers in the area.
Roy Joiner, veteran Jersey City southpaw, halted Montreal with six hits tonight to lead the Little Giants to a 6-2 victory.

The Securities and Exchange Commission issued today its findings and opinion on its approval, previously announced, of the plan of organization submitted to it by reorganization managers for the United Telephone and Electric Company.

The American Federation of Actors, filing charges with the Labor Relations Board, accused the Ringling Brothers and Barnum and Bailey Circus today of having "illegally, fraudulently and discriminatorily." discharged about 1,200 union employes.
Rudolf Binding, poet and novelist, died yesterday at his home Starnberg Lake after a brief illness. His age was 70.
The Browns eyed seventh place today after taking the first contest of a four-game series with Connie Mack's Athletics, 9 to 2.

Four months have passed since the State Constitutional Convention met at Albany, and during these four months the people of New York have at least had the benefit of a continuing seminar in the problems of self-government.
Formation of an international trustee organization to serve as an intermediary is believed to have cleared away the last obstacles to listing of United States stocks on the Paris Bourse.

Major Gist Blair of Washington and Mrs. Blair were hosts to Governor Lewis O. Barrows and Mrs. Barrows today upon their arrival here to greet Rear Admiral Forde A. Todd, commander of the cruising division of the United States Navy,

The value of new orders booked for electrical goods during the second quarter of 1938, as reported by seventy-eight manufacturers, was $157,315,411, William L. Austin of the Bureau of the Census, Department of Commerce, reported today.

Bucharest on an August day is very hot and dusty. The heat is steamy, like the current brand of Manhattan weather, but the dust is Balkan, blown in from prairies old but untamed and from unpaved lanes wandering among the city streets to remind you of the Balkan town of yesterday. It is a place of confusing contrasts.

Kermit Roosevelt, who announced on July 20 his resignation as vice president and director of the International Mercantile Marine Company and affiliated concerns, announced yesterday that he had rejoined the Kerr Steamship Company as vice president.

All the fierce jealousies of reception committees magically faded away in Brooklyn yesterday when Douglas Corrigan returned in triumph to the starting point of his "accidental" flight to be set straight, amid rousing cheers, as to which direction is west, and which east.

Howard H. McClintio, engineer, and one of the founders of the McClinticMarshall Construction Company, which made the locks for the Panama Canal, died tonight. He was 72 years old and had been ill only two days.

Daniel W. Wister, 27 years old, of 5,430 Germantown Avenue, Philadelphia, son of Dr. and Mrs. James W. Wister of the same address and a cousin of the late novelist, Owen Wister, died of a heart attack early this morning as he was paddling a canoe on Rancocas Creek near here.

The circus industry has stuck in some mudholes this season out of which even the biggest elephants couldn't pull it. One show folded up after a strike, the merits of which were not determined. by the NLRB but whose results were shocking to all who were once small boys.

The prosecution, trying to convict Francis M. Carroll of murder,. read today before a sensation-hungry court room audience five love letters his daughter Barbara wrote to Paul N. Dwyer, the youth who confessed strangling Dr. James G. Littlefield and went to prison for life.

Three New York couples were divorced through decrees granted here today. Mary Seften Thomas Blom divorced Frans Blom, a Danish archaeologist. They were married on June 15, 1932. The ground was cruelty.
Nineteen timber-toppers provided keen competition over difficult jumps today in the knock down and out sweepstake at the opening session of the fifth annual Sagamore Horse Show.
Franklin D. Roosevelt 3d was made a member in good standing of a political club today, although he is 21 years, less 17 days, too young to take an active part in politics.
The Department of Commerce reported today a sharp decline in gold imports in the week ended on July 29. Imports for that week amounted to $9,215,714. The previous week they amounted to $18,983,304.
The press room in the head telegraph office here, opened by Emperor Franz Josef forty years ago, is being dismantled.
Harry R. Roder, 38 years old, of Barrington, started today serving a sixty-day sentence in the county jail at Camden, thirty days of which are to be as proxy for his wife. Catherine.

Prices on the New York Cotton Exchange continued under pressure yesterday and closed with net losses of 8 to 9 points. Selling became sufficiently heavy in the last half hour to fill buying limits at 8.50 cents a pound for the December and closed the List at lowest figures since the middle of June.

Sterling and other European exchanges turned weak again yesterday, after their rally on Thursday. The pound sterling went down to $4.89 3-16, which was 14 cent above the low mark of last Wednesday, and closed at $4.89 9-16, off 1/2 cent.

Chain store organizations figured in several of the commercial leases listed yesterday, when they took ground floor quarter for additional units. The firms involved are retailers of men's and women's clothing and accessories, shoes, and a bakery chain.

The reapportionment proposal, drafted by the Republican-controlled Committee on the Legislature and its Organizations, is expected to be brought up for discussion on the floor of the Constitutional Convention some time during the next week.
Signs of an industrial revival in Canada have become visible in the last month, according to A. E. Arscott, general manager of the Canadian Bank of Commerce, Toronto.
Spirited price-cutting, involving slashes of more than 35 per cent on the retail price of some products, developed on liquor brands of the Schenley Products Company here last night.

Patrolman John McDonald, 37 years old, of the Fort Hamilton station in Brooklyn, committed suicide yesterday by shooting himself in the right temple in a bar and grill at 8,219 Fifth Avenue, Brooklyn, between Eighty-second and Eighty-third Streets.
THE tall young fellow had a fine coat of tan. It was easily seen that he hadn't spent the last three weeks in a city cellar. "Just got back from Maine," he said, mopping his brow.

Gutzon Borglum, who during the past twelve years frequently com plained of interference with his work on the Mount Rushmore national memorial, today received virtually dictatorial powers to com plete carvings of the heads of four Presidents on Granite Mountain, near here.
I dreamt of gold and woke to find A strip of sun like orange rind, A rooster farther down the lane, Gold-painted like a weather-vane.
Three men, two of them armed with sub-machine guns, held up an assistant cashier of the First National Bank of Wood River today and robbed him of $34,000.
Douglas Corrigan stopped In the middle of his big day for luncheon at the Advertising Club and packed it with perhaps the greatest throng in its hero-welcoming history.

Announcement by Admiral Land, chairman of the Maritime Commission, that training schools for seamen will be established on the Atlantic, Pacific and Gulf coasts is a welcome indication of the progress, slow but sure, being made in the commission's attempt to provide a "trained and efficient personnel" for our merchant marine.

Judge Harry H. Porter, chief justice of the Municipal Court of Evanston, Ill., told the Natiogal Woman's Christian Temperafice Union tonight that "60 per cent or more" of the 39,700 deaths and 1,400,000 injuries in 1937 auto accidents were "traceable to the use of alcohol at the wrong time and place."

The Lone Star Gas Corporation of Wilmington, Del., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering $20,000,000 of fifteen-year 3 1/2 per cent sinking-fund debentures due on Aug 1, 1953, and 730,000 shares of no-par common stock, including scrip certificates for fractional shares to be reserved for conversion of $10,000,000 of the debentures.

Eldridge St. 197, 24.6x100xirreg; Michael H Cardozo Jr., ano, trustee, to Dorothy Joseph, 134 E 24 St; ($7.50). 12th St, 23 W, 25x103.3; Wm. D. Fricke, et al. trustee, to 12th St Building, Inc, 245 W 14th St. mtg $28.750: ($36). 35th St, 261-7 W, 76x98.9; Eliz. Richmond to Mole Realties. Inc. 521 5th Ave.

The round-the-world flight of Howard Hughes and his four companions, and the unheralded flight of Douglas Corrigan to Dublin, Ireland, helped to cause a 3.7 per cent increase in air express shipments in and out of New York City during July, compared with July last year, according to a report issued yesterday by the air express division of the Railway Express Agency.

Answering China's request for aid against the Yellow River floods the League of Nations transit committee in its report to the League Council today said that for the League to do this work under its own responsibility it would have to send a delegation to China to draw up plans and supervise their execution.
Wheat futures in North American markets with the exception of the October delivery in Winnipeg, sold at new low levels for the season today.

The City Department of Markets will continue to seek passage by the City Council of its bill to license retailers of gasoline within the city's jurisdiction, it was learned yesterday, despite the fact that an end of unstable marketing conditions is held in the trade to be virtually assured by the action of major distributors in setting minimum resale prices for. their. products under the Feld-Crawford Fair Trade Act.

An auditor employed by the State Insurance Fund, carrier of workmen's compensation indemnity, and four contractors were arrested yesterday as the first suspects to be named in the investigation ordered by Governor Lehman into charges to of grafting, fraud and other irregularities against the.fund.

Federal Judge Patrick T. Stone today tentatively set Sept. 26 as the date for retrial of fifteen oil company executives and three corporations, whose conviction on charges of gasoline price-fixing he recently set aside.

W. D. Taunton, for fifty-seven years a newspaper man in Nova Scotia, died today. He was best known in later years as the writer of "Secret History of the Week" in the Halifax Herald under the initials "I. C. R."

Unrest is growing in North China as the Soviet-Japanese conflict on the Manchukuoan-Siberian border continues. Reports from trustworthy sources confirm that many Japanese troops have left North China.

Mr. and Mrs. John I. Snyder gave a supper dance tonight at their home here, 154 Calhoun Avenue, at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eleanor Snyder, to John W. Scott, son of Mrs. John Walter Scott and the late Captain Scott, U.S.A., of Collingswood, N. J.

Senator Edward R. Burke of Nebraska took sharp issue with a policy of silence, which he attributed to Under-Secretary of State Sumner Welles, on persecution of minorities abroad, and appealed for the United States to "arraign before the bar of public opinion" the German Government for its "horrible, terrifying, diabolical barbarities against the Jewish people," in an address at the Bryant. College commencement exercises here today.

John Roosevelt, like his father. is a pretty good fisherman. The President's son landed five barracudas ranging from fifteen to twenty-five pounds and a twentypound bonita ten miles off Bermuda today. His wife caught a twentythree pound barracuda.

Twenty-six thousand sweat-soaked troops-many of them stripped to the waist against the intense heat-marched and "fought" and bivouacked across 1,200 square miles of pine forest, gall berry "flats" and dusty Southern roads today as the army's annual mimic war moved slowly toward its climax.

The daily rate of shipments of rayon yarn by American producers during July was the largest for any month in the history of the industry, according to The Rayon Organon, published yesterday by the Textile Economics Bureau,

The Flushing Savings Bank, 137-83 Northern Boulevard, Flushing, L. I., has received permission to change its location to 137-77 Northern Boulevard, it was announced today by the State Banking Department.

The estate of Cortlandt F. Bishop has sold the stock of the corporation of the American Art Associa tion-Anderson Galleries, Inc., one of the country's oldest and important galleries for the auction of art and literary property, it was announced yesterday.

There was a round of entertainment today throughout the colony for tennis week guests. The Misses Jeanne and Patricia Murray, debutante daughters of Mrs. John F. Murray, gave a dinner with dancing tonight in the Merry-Go-Round Room of the Seven Ponds Inn for members of their week-end house party at Lighthouse Farm.

John Henry Gray, retired contractor and civil and consulting engineer, who invented the Gray. Column widely used in skyscraper construction, died here today at his home, 234 Cleveland Street. His age was 74.

A 350-pound, heat-crazed grizzly bear clawed her way from a steel-barred cage in the Highland Park Zoo today and terrorized residents of the park district or five hours before she was shot and killed.

Lieut. Col. Francis J. Popham and Thomas Mason McQuaker, directors of the National Group of Trust Units, Ltd., of London, will arrive here on the Queen Mary on Monday morning to formulate plans for the investment of substantial funds in United States securities.
In a speech opening the fifteenth German radio exhibition, said to be the largest ever held, Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels announced completion of a "people's radio" to sell at 35 marks.

Turpentine, 22 3/4c nominal; no sales; receipts, 457 barrels; no shipments; stock, 40,153 barrels. Resin firm; sales, 427; receipts, 2,265; no shipments; stock, 197,387. Quote: B. $3.50; D. $3.85; E. $4.25; F. G. $4.70; H. I. K. M. $4.70-75; N. $5.45-50; WG. $5.65-70; WW. $6.35; X. $6.40.

Military authorities in Santiago reported that the majority of the taxi, truck and bus drivers, who staged a strike throughout Oriente Province in protest against the new highway tax, returned to work today.
Whether World War veterans have a. preference in reinstatement over others on a suspended list is shortly to be determined by: the courts.

J. Smith Ferebee, footsore, weary and slowed down to a walk, won his wager of $2,500 and a half interest in a Virginia plantation today by playing 144 holes of golf between sun-up arid darkness, with no eighteen-hole round of more than 90 strokes on Olympia Fields' rugged acres.

The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "The wool market is definitely much slower. It also is lower. Some belated purchases on the part of mills both here and in the West have been close up to last week's level, but on the whole the market is off quite 5 per cent from the peak and in some descriptions it is down 7 1/2 per cent, more especially on medium wools.

Another unit in the chain of more than thirty food markets operated by United Premier Food Stores, Inc., will open in Paterson, N. J., in September as a result of a lease closed by J. I. Kislak, Inc., broker, in cooperation with Harry Smith and Daniel Berliner.

In a story on the end of the strike or lockout of special guards at the Polo Grounds in yesterday's NEW YORK TIMES it was reported that, the regular guards, being union members, refused to join the William J. Burns Detective Agency because of "its strike-breaking activities."

Criticism of the Tennessee Valley Authority for entrusting top administrative jobs to "unqualified" men was voiced by Senator James J. Davis, Republican of Pennsylvania, and Representative Charles Wolverton, Republican of New Jersey, at today's session of the Congressional Investigating Committee.

Before 8,500 spectators, the largest turnout since the sport was introduced into Madison Square Garden, the New York Roverettes crushed the Montreal Maroons, 11 to 2, in the feature game of the women's softball double-header last night.

Simulating the antics of circus animals and characters, with a special presentation of "Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs," 'forty boys and girls of school age put on yesterday the annual Summer circus program of the Educational Alliance, at 197 East Broadway.

The Passenger Ship Bill, introduced in the Assembly this afternoon recognizes that "the practice of maintaining passengers aboard passenger ships in the waters of these islands is free of objection in the case of ships lying outside the harbors of Hamilton and St. George."

A shipment of more than 1,000 tropical fish from Florida waters arrived yesterday at the Aquarium on the Clyde freighter Medina. Christopher Coates of the Aquarium said some of the fish had been put in special quarantine tanks of water taken from the bay, which would kill their lice.

Despite a day of effort President Lazaro Cardenas was barely able to get a quorum in the Chamber of Deputies today in order to get Congressional passage of a resolution approving the Mexican note to the United States in which the United States request for international arbitration on indemnity for seized United States property was refused.

Fred S. Tomlin, Glassboro, N. J., professional, broke 200 straight targets for the second day at the T. Clarence Marshall trap-shooting tournament today to establish a new world record of 702 for consecutive breaks of registered targets.
7th Ave, 41; to 5-story, stores and apartments: estate of John O. Grode (Elizabeth G. Ritter, administratrix, 360 Lookout Ave, Hackensack, N J), owner; Harry E. Warren, architect; cost, $25,000.

Exchanges of checks at the principal clearing houses of the country in July totaled $24,010,035,444, a net loss of 8.9 per cent from the previous month. Compared with July of last year the decline was 16.6 per cent.

Knockouts from the heat, play-offs that required six extra holes, a twenty-four-hole match and defeats of favorites were among the features that made today one of the most memorable days in the history of the John G. Anderson memorial tournament, annual fixture at the Winged Foot Golf Club.

The Allis-Chalmers local of the United Automobile Workers Union dropped a Circuit Court injunctional action, scheduled to be heard today, by which it had sought to prevent George Kiebler, administrator appointed by Homer Martin in the union's factional fight, from interfering in affairs of the local.

The French Government warned civil airlines today that French anti-aircraft batteries had been ordered to fire on any foreign plane attempting to cross the Spanish-French frontier without specific authority.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:
A tract of four acres, fronting on Cold Spring Road, Syosset, L. I., has been sold by the Kenosset Realty Corporation to. Charles L. Harding Jr., through Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc.

The Sisters of St. Dominic at St. Joseph's Health Resort and Mountain Schools, St. Joseph's, Sullivan County, N. Y., have issued invitations to the celebration of the Golden Jubilee of the Religious Profession of Mother M. Polycarpa, the Mother Superior for many years of the thirty-two nuns at St. Joseph's, This will take place Monday, Aug. 15, which is the Feast of the Assumption.
Racing skippers put last-minute touches on their craft tonight for another try at numerous cups in forty-one events tomorrow in the Miles River Yacht Club's seventeenth regatta.

With one mighty swing of his bat yesterday Bob Seeds fashioned a victory for the Giants over the Pirates in the first of the three battles between the rivals for the National League lead before a Ladies' Day gathering of 18,535 at the Polo Grounds.
Yorkshire and Middlesex, pacemakers in the English county cricket championship, drew further ahead today with clean-cut victories over Leicestershire and Warwickshire, respectively.

In announcing his second venture into the profit-sharing field, Myron Selznick today disclosed a revision in his plans when he stated that William Powell will be associated with Carole Lombard and that instead of a new corporation being formed the picture will be made by Ernest Lubitsch, Inc.

The statement issued today by the Republican Program Committee read: The Republican Program Committee, at the conclusion of its sessions in Chicago, issued the following summary statement, indicating the present stage of its work, the end-result at which it is aiming and the broad framework of purposes within which it is doing its work.

Miss Nancy McKee, daughter of Mrs. William Litchfield McKee and the late Mr. McKee, was married here this afternoon at the home of her mother to Vincenzo de Luca of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carlo de Luca of Naples, Italy. The Rev. John D. Gregory performed the ceremony.

Recent partial relaxation of the criterion applied by bank examiners to the loan account of banks led to some misgiving as to whether precautions hitherto taken by banks regarding character of loans applied for would also be relaxed.
Soviet artillery blasted at Japanese positions along the Siberian frontier last night while the Japanese Foreign Office radiated optimism that the border clash soon would be settled peaceably.
Shareholders of the Iowa Southern Utilities Company have approved a plan of recapitalization for the company calling for reclassification of capital structure, it was announced yesterday.
Two bright-eyed babies, a sister and -brother, were abandoned by their mother in a matron's room of the Brooklyn Family Court yesterday when the father failed to appear on charges of non-support.

Back at the turn of the century, when Dwight Davis was in his prime as a tennis player, customs were a bit different from the present arrangement. A titleholder did not play in the annual tournament, but stayed out until it was over.

William F. McGuinness, Assistant District Attorney of Brooklyn, and George Murphy, city-employed elevator operator, were ordered yesterday by Magistrate Vincent J. Sweeney in Brooklyn Felony Court to stand trial on charges of conspiracy to "fix" a criminal case, and immediately thereafter District Attorney William F. X. Geoghan announced that recent disclosures had implicated two others in the alleged conspiracy.
Salvation Army members from the Eastern United States will attend three days of services at Ocean Grove, N. J., beginning this noon.
Gustavo Capanema, Minister of Education, today named a National Council of Social Service. The council was decreed last month by President Getulio Vargas.

Germany had greater quantities of raw materials on hand in the first quarter of 1938 than in the comparable period in 1937, the Commerce Department reported today. These materials included those produced in Germany and those imported.

Doris Humphrey and Hanya Holm shared the second program in the Bennington Festival here tonight, assisted by members of their regular concert groups and also by apprentice groups who have been working with them this Summer at the Bennington School of the Dance at Bennington College in the preparation of the new compositions presented on this occasion.

A Rooseveit for President Club in 1940 was started here today. First announcement of the new organization was made in a news release prepared by Harry Kirtland and mailed to 700 newspapers in all parts of the United States.

Five youths in a motor boat found today a body in the Hudson River which parkway police identified as that of Hartwell Cragin, New York salesman and former army officer, who fell from a pleasure boat Tuesday night.

Thirteen students at the Citizens Military Training Camp here were named today to compete for the rifle team which will represent the Second Corps Area C. M. T. C. camps at the Camp Perry (Ohio) national rifle matches opening Aug. 21.

The story of the Starrett Brothers, builders, and of. modern building construction as exemplified in their own projects costing $1,500,000,000, is told in Paul Starrett's autobiography, "Changing the Skyline," which Whittlesey House will publish on Aug. 22.

Jackie (Kid) Berg, veteran English battler, gained the decision over Pete Cara, Bensonhurst welterweight, in the main bout of eight rounds last night at the Coney Island Velodrome. The winner scaled 144 1/2 pounds, his rival 138 3/4.

Five tankers left Mexican ports yesterday with government gasoline and crude oil indicating that the difficulties of W. R. Davis, American independent operator, over the government contract for the purchase by Germany, Italy and Sweden of $10,000,000 worth of petroleum, with 60 per cent of the payment in machinery and 40 per cent in cash, have been overcome, at least temporarily.
Several properties in Harlem passed to new control in deals announced yesterday. Two were sold by a savings bank to investors.

Crowding along the sidewalks of Douglas Corrigan's route up Broadway and filling every available inch of space at windows and doorways of the buildings in the financial district, hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers gave ample backing yesterday to Mayor La Guardia's remark to the young flier:
Gross assets, $7,874; net, $7,333. To Arthur Almquist, son. Chief assets, real estate, $7,874. Milton, Pinkus, attorneys, 250 Fulton Ave.. Hempstead, N. Y.

The crew of the Olympian, operated by the Chicago, St. Paul Pacific Railroad, was blamed today by the Safety Bureau of the Interstate Commerce Commission for the crash in which the train smashed head-on into a special Civilian Conservation Corps train in Montana, June 25, killing one person and injuring eighty-two others.

The Navy Department announced today that it had received a letter from the Army Council of the British Ministry of Defense thanking Admiral Harry E. Yarnell, commanderin-chief of the Asiatic Fleet, for cooperation and counsel that he gave the British general officer commanding in the Shanghai area during the period when the International Settlement and the property of foreign nations were in danger.

An open-air vaudeville program is being arranged for next Wednesday night at Randalls Stadium. Contracts are expected to be signed between Allyn Jennings, general superintendent of the Park Department, and Harry Young, who -will sponsor the entertainment.
William T. Wardhaugh, president of the Consolidated Pencil Corporation, 170 Fifth Avenue, died in his office yesterday. He was in his sixty-third year.

A nationwide drive to remove a seasonal surplus of milk lifted the milk sales of members of the National Association of Chain Drug Stores 31 per cent above a year ago, and brought the volume to 44.4 per cent above 1936 sales, Fred Griffiths, president of the association, reported yesterday. The drive was staged in the period from June 10

Lamb prices firmed up today when supplies were materially reduced. Hogs were fairly active and strong to higher due to comparatively small receipts even for Friday, the United States Department of Agriculture reports. There was no pep in the cattle market, but as supplies were below normal the clearance was fairly good.

Hoping to "shame" his debtors into squaring their accounts, Robert Bierbaum, owner of a grocery and butcher shop at 3,800 Westfield Avenue, has posted a large sign in his window bearing the names of ten, their addresses and the amounts they owe and above the list: "Notice-Owing to bad debts this store is forced to close."

The Informazione Diplomatica, the Italian Foreign Office's official organ, says most emphatically that Rome has no intention of persecuting the Jews. The principal objective of the racist campaign, it declares, is to strengthen the Italians' pride of race so as to prevent the creation of a race of half-castes in the colonies where millions of Italians ultimately will reside.

The Berkshire symphonic festival continues tomorrow night, and if the weather remains good, a larger crowd than attended the opening night is expected. Serge Koussevitzky and the Boston Symphony Orchestra will play a substantial program: Haydn's Symphony in E flat No. 99, Debussy's "La Mer" and Sibelius's First symphony.

Senator Alben W. Barkley, backed personally by President Roosevelt, still ruled as the favorite tonight as Kentuckians prepared to go to the polls tomorrow in one of the most important primary elections in the United States this year.
A gala reception and entertainment at the Yankee Stadium last night attended by more than 30,000 ended the day's activities for Douglas Corrigan.
A home run by Jack Sturdy in the eighth inning with one mate aboard broke a deadlock and gave Rochester a 6-to-4 victory over the Bears tonight.

Yesterday, for the second time in little more than six months, men picketed the five entrances to the 375-acre Woodlawn Cemetery with red-and-white placards proclaiming that employes at the cemetery, one of the largest in the city, were on strike.

Record high temperatures affected retail trade here this week and the comparative showing was not quite as good as that of the preceding week. Department store executives estimated the decline in volume at around 9 per cent, against a drop of 7.4 per cent for the last week of July.

After a series of turbulent outbursts which at times threatened to lead to an exchange of fisticuffs upon the floor, a meeting of the National Maritime Union ratified last night an election of officers which placed five men, unofficially designated as "anti-administration," upon the national executive council of nine.

Two men were arrested yesterday; on charges of attempted extortion after they had been wounded, according to the police, during a freefor-all pistol battle in the tavern of Anthony Marano, 21-01 Twentyfourth Avenue., Astoria, who drew a pistol and started firing when seven men entered and ordered him to "pay up" or have his place r wrecked.

The Securities and Exchange Commission set today a hearing for Aug. 29 on a declaration by the Dayton Power and Light Company and an application by the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation relative to the sale by Dayton to Columbia of 42,500 shares of Dayton's common stock for an aggregate consideration of $2,550,000.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated Aug. 4. BRIGADIER GENERAL Gasser, L. D., General Staff Corps, one day leave, Aug. 4.

The highest bidding so far this season at the yearling sales took place tonight when Arthur B. Hancock and others disposed of fifty-nine yearlings in the Fasig Tipton paddocks. A total of $232,650 was realized, an average of about $3,943 a head.
The premiere performance of the opera "Rosalind," by Florence Wickham, formerly of the Metropolitan Opera Company, was heard tonight in the open-air Rockridge Theatre by a capacity audience of 1,500.

The Commonwealth Edison Company of Chicago filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering $33,000,000 of first mortgage 3 1/2 per cent bonds, Series I, due on June 1, 1968, and between $39,251,600 and $50,208,745 of convertible debentures, 3 1/2 per cent series, due on July 1, 1958.

C. I. O. maritime unions complained to the newly organized Maritime Labor Board today that the Maritime Commission had committed anti-union acts. The Maritime Labor Board was set up in an effort to settle labor disputes in the merchant marine.

The 1,374 bond issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange, aggregating $49,408,996,523 par value as of July 30, had a total market value of $44,561,109,796, a gain of $804,594,787, according to a compilation by the Exchange issued yesterday.

In freeing Bulgaria from the most humiliating clauses of her post-war treaties, Balkan statesmanship last week demonstrated, for the second time in two years, that oppressive treaties can be revised by peaceful negotiation.

W. R. Newsome, owner of the Bob White farm on the old Belden Hill Road, Wilton, Conn., has sold seven -acres of the property to G. F. Beers of Atlanta, Ga., who will erect a fourteen-room stone colonial-type home, with large barn and outbuildings.

The Rumanian-American Telephone Company announced today that it would hold an extraordinary general meeting on Aug. 22 to decide on raising its stock capital from 1,000,000,000 to 1,500,000,000 lei (from about $7,000,000 to $10,500,000).

WHISPERS are being heard in the spots that swing is dying. Early bookings in the hotels and cabarets disclose that the after-dark music fare will lean to the sweet melodies devoid of what has often been just loud raping of good tunes.

Many informed persons in Mexico, including several close to the government, are of the opinion that the present European situation and the danger of war are exerting a direct influence that may become decisive upon Mexico's relations with the United States.
Ballard School Y. W. C. A. will offer a course in home and personal affairs intended to train young women to use business and professional methods in social and home affairs.

Miss Marion Seaver Fiske, daughter of Mrs. Floyd W. Fiske of this place and the late Mr. Fiske, was married here this afternoon to Glenn S. Wilder, son of Mr. and Mrs. John M. Wilder of Troy, N. Y., in the First Congregational Church by the Rev. Don Ivan Patch.
BARNETT-GOLDEN-Mrs. Herman Golden announces marriage of daughter, Anlta, to Daniel Barnett, son Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Barnett, New York, taking place today.

Although not yet completed, five p of the new apartment buildings in the Jackson Heights section of Long Island built on land sold by the Queensboro Corporation, show a good percentage of suites already leased, reports Robert R. Lassiter, vice president of the Queensboro Corporation.

South American ocelots make nice pets, said Mrs. C. Ellsworth Burt of New York City, who is visiting here, but they bring embarrassing moments. Mrs. Burt entered a restaurant with Grumpy, her eightmonths-old ocelot, in leash.

The green-hatted Pete Bostwick galloped through rain today to another polo tournament victory as his Bostwick Field team defeated the Foxhunters in the final of the Hempstead Cups event at the Meadow Brook Club. A strong second-half drive on Whitney Field brought an 8-to-5 verdict.

Unfavorable weather yesterday, for the second time, caused postponement of plans of the interAmerican escadrille to make a mass flight over New York City in observation of the birthday of Simon Bolivar, South American liberator.

An augmented board of C. I. O. union strategy tonight looked to further conferences with company representatives for negotiations toward settlement in the Maytag labor controversy. James J. Matles, of New York City, director of organization for the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America, arrived today to aid the Maytag local.

With the publication of the latest report in a series which when finished will cover soil conditions in the 102 counties of Illinois, the University of Illinois announced yesterday that its College of Agriculture had completed the survey of the soils of nearly two-thirds of the counties.

Good and bad luck was the special lot of William Ziegler Jr. today when his El Chico set a new record for the Saratoga Special, only to be followed by Esposa being virtually left at the post in the Merchants' and Citizens' Handicap, which was captured by Mrs. Elizabeth Graham Lewis's Great Union at 20 to 1.

Manager John Burns of Toronto was knocked out and carried from the field in a collision with Joe Greenberg at first base during the game with the Orioles today. He was reported not seriously injured but was sent to a hospital.

Since 1927 the Mexican Government :has expropriated farm land valued at $10,000,000 owned by United States citizens. In accordance with the present government's social program, these lands-along with large estates expropriated from Mexican owners-have been distributed among the Mexican farmer peons.

Mrs. Grace Meneely, 74 years old, widow of Andrew H. Meneely, bell manufacturer of Watervliet, N. Y., was killed in a head-on automobile collision on Willis Avenue, near Willets Point Road, here this evening. Five others injured in the crash were taken to the Nassau Hospital, Mineola.

Miss Helen Ball, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. John F. Ball of Rochester, N. Y., and Bernard Dennihan of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Dennihan of Fitchburg, Mass., were married here yesterday morning in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

A situation in which the crews of several radio patrol cars hunted for James Damma of 177 Thompson Street, while he in turn was hunting them, followed an assault at about 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon at Ninth Street and Third Avenue. Damma, driving by in his automobile, saw the victim, Charles English, 20 years old,
An interior decorator consultant points out that two kinds of temperature must be taken into consideration when the family modernizes its house for Summer comfort.

Vacation in the country-the real country-would be incomplete without the native. The native is a kind of contemporary ancestor. He can do all the things our grandparents were able to do. He knows where the fish are, whether in salt water or fresh, and can catch them. He can predict the weather, sometimes correctly.

With its immediate attention centered on adherence to four rules, the trade practice bureau of the Association of Fun Coat and Trimmings Manufacturers has been established, according to notification received yesterday by members of the organization.

Mail requisitions increased in volume last week over the preceding week, according to an analysis of wholesale market activity especially prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buyers.

The Foster Wheeler Corporation, including its English and French subsidiaries, reported yesterday for the six months ended on June 30 a net profit of $77,214 after depreciation, Federal income taxes, surtax on undistributed profits and other charges.

Retail trade showed a moderate improvement on the week, and, while sales were still well below those of a year ago in terms of dollar volume, the declines were not as sharp in a number of districts. Weather,

The development of civil and military aviation in the United States inspires the visitor from foreign shores with a "deep sense of admiration," according to Guido Mattioli, biographer of Benito Mussolini and member of the Royal Italian Air Force, who Is touring this country.
A day that proved even steamier than Friday, though with a maximum temperature of only 82, at 3 P. M., yesterday marked the thirteenth of the non-stop heat wave.

ON three successive Sundays we have examined--in considerable detail and with a painstaking wish that all phases might be exemplified in our mosaic--the mass of European critical opinion expressed apropos of this Summer's American shows in Paris and London.

The estate on Jerome Avenue, Deal, N. J., known as one of the show places of that section and formerly owned by Max Cohen, rent proprietor of a New York gown shop, has been purchased by Jaques Salz of Salz Brothers, Inc., fountain pen manufacturers.

Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons announced yesterday that 100 men and seven women had been admitted to the first-year class for the next academic year. The new students are graduates of forty-nine American colleges and reside in twenty-two States and Puerto Rico.

Arnold Belnick, 13-year-old violinist of remarkable talent, was heard last night at Lewisohn Stadium in a concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony conducted by Alexander edge Smallens. The boy, a pupil of Ronald Murat, has appeared in this city and its environs, but his recent winning of the Sealtest Rising Musical Star Contest brought him further measure of deserved recognition.
"WATERWAY," by the Australian novelist Eleanor Dark, is so well executed a story that it would be a joy to read it for its literary excellence alone.
Extension of the public school by removal of all barriers to free education, "whether economic or social," was advocated today before the conference at Cornell University on the problems of youth.
Gordie Kerr, Windsor (Ont.) speedster, established a new Dominion native record for the 100-yard back-stroke today in the closing event of the Canadian amateur swimming championships.

THE most surprising thing to be noticed on Broadway is the quiet absorption in chess-and checkers that you can see any time in a penny arcade right next to the din and jostling of Times Square- so we read in the text of this newest guide to New York City; and here are the earnest contestants before us, in Nils Hogner's clever little cartoon.

New navigation tables which will make it possible for aerial and ocean navigators to compute positions with a maximum error of 1-10 of one mile within a few seconds, as against the present process involving up to fifteen minutes of time, will soon be completed by a "white collar" Works Progress Administration project in Philadelphia.
The Yankee steam-roller keeps rumbling along, and neither the forlorn Indians nor a passing shower that interrupted the battle forty-one minutes could do a thing about it to day.

R. CLAPP'S poems are a sort of contemporary "Essay on Man" in harsh and fragmentary language, and it is interesting to observe the contrast. Pope's early eighteenth-century poem was direct in title, simple in verse, sensible and orderly in its plan.
SOUTHAMPTON.-As in previous seasons, various outstanding artistic and musical projects as well as philanthropic undertakings have been planned for the late Summer.

An unidentified man about 60 years old was rescued from the Hudson River at 7 o'clock last night by Oscar Nelson, a barge captain, after he had fallen from the stringpiece of the bulkhead at the foot of West Thirty-third Street.

The clash of authority between Governer Nelson G. Kraschel of Iowa. and the National Labor Relations Board in connection with the Maytag Washing Machine Company's labor controversy has served to drtamatize an increasingly important issue involving a conflict of powers of the Federal and State governments.

LONDON. LEONIDE MASSINE and Paul Hindemith have come together to some purpose. Their first combined venture, "Nobilissima Visione," was launched at Drury Lane, and its reception was so cordial that it must strengthen the partnership between composer and choreographer.

The condition of Julia Ruth, 22-year-old adopted daughter of George Herman (Babe) Ruth, was said to be satisfactory yesterday morning at the Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital, after she had received about a pint of blood from her father in a transfusion last night. The young woman is suffering from a glandular ailment of the neck.

Miss Julia Myder, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Myder, Greenwich, was married to Frank Kordas Jr., son of Mrs. Frank Kordas and the late Mr. Kordas of Greenwich, in St. Mary's Catholic Church here this morning. The Rev. Michael Malley, assistant pastor, officiated.
Complete commercial fertilizers in some favorite form-tablet, pulverized, or in cartridges to be attached to the hose-are part of the equipment of most up-to-date gardeners.

A HUNDRED years ago daring railroad pioneers laid out a route to the West across Pennsylvania. It was not thought in those days that locomotives could ever be built to haul freight and passengers across the Alleghenies and so the backers of the railroad made surveys for the most level route possible through Pennsylvania.

The marriage of Miss Marjorie Presswell, younger daughter of Mrs. William Lawrence Presswell of London and the late Mr. Presswell, to Alan Dalrymple Warren, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Smith Warren of Bronxville, took place here this afternoon in Christ Episcopal Church.
BAR HARBOR.-The seasonal fancy-dress ball, an outstanding event on the annual social calendar of Mount Desert Island, is scheduled for Wednesday, Aug. 17, at the Bar Harbor Club.
OF the huge corpus of Greek plays known to have exlisted only a small percentage has come down to us, and we have complete tragedies from only three pens.

Pointing out that Park Commissioner Moses has announced that within two weeks he intends to file applications to prevent the further industrial development of the Brook lyn and Queens portion of Jamaica Bay by rezoning it against industrial use, Howard Gregory, Brooklyn industrial broker, urged yesterday that the proposed change be thoroughly investigated before being put into effect.

A warning to little business men not to join groups which have the blessing of the Secretary of Commerce or other government officials, was given by Judge Raymond Tiffany, general counsel of the National Small Business Men's Association, in an address here tonight.
Claud Mullins, Metropolitan Magistrate, today replied to charges that an attempt had been made Thursday to suppress his wife's name in a speeding charge at his Southwestern Police Court.

Commander Jesse L. Kenworthy Jr. today became the commanding officer of the naval air station at Lakehurst. Commander Charles E. Rosendahl, who will become executive officer aboard the U. S. S. Milwaukee soon, turned over the position to Commander Kenworthy at the regular Saturday morning inspection in the hangar..

The new suspension bridge over the Connecticut River between this city and Portland, the. longest bridge in New England, was formally opened to travel this afternoon when Governor Wilbur L. Cross cut a forty-foot blue ribbon stretched from side to side of the bridge and held in place by Mayor Charles A.

A CODE of fair practices to control the traffic in theatre tickets was adopted by the Council of the Actors Equity Association on July 26, the provisions of which will become effective, as far as the public is concerned, for the theatrical season of 1938-39 beginning Sept. 1, 1938.
David Guest, brilliant young Cambridge mathematician and son of Dr. Haden Guest, Labor politician, was killed fighting with Spanish Loyalist forces, according to information received here today.

With the World Youth Congress convening at Vassar College Aug. 16-24, the first group of delegates, those from Chile and other South American countries are due to arrive in New York tomorrow, the vanguard of the representatives of fifty organizations with a combined membership of 15,000,000 young people.

Judge James T. Cross denied a motion today by Mrs. Bertha Gott Smith to have her earstwhile husband, Alfred E. Smith Jr., held in contempt of court for failure to make payments under a separation agreement.

Brokers and builders throughout Queens and other suburban areas of Long Island report that the present Summer, both in construction and home buying, has been the busiest season in all departments of realty activity that has been experienced for several years.

Tonight's symphony concert at Tanglewood, the second in the series, was again a society event of importance. Mrs. George Rockwood of Rosemary Lodge, New Lebanon, N. Y., gave a dinner at the Lenox Club and later the guests were in her box at the concert.

ALONG, leisurely story of a little girl in Leeds whose father was determined she should be a lady sounds moderately dull and unimportant, but actually it is good fun. It is well written, with sly understanding of various kinds of climbers, and it has more variety than you might suspect when you pick it up.

Seeking to rid the Adirondack and Catskill parks and the highway and parkway systems of the State of "eyesore" advertising signs, Lithgow Osborne, Conservation Commissioner, announced today that during the next two weeks he would attempt to bring before the Constitutional Convention his proposal to afford constitutional protection against such advertising.

Mrs. Elizabeth Yetman, 39 years old, was fatally shot tonight, police said, as she shielded her daughter from a rejected suitor, Frank Cheeseman, 21, of near-by Neptune. Police said Cheeseman entered the Yetman home at 162 Ridge Avenue about 10:30 P. M. and went immediately to the second floor bedroom of Ann Clark, 20, daughter of Mrs. Yetman by a previous marriage.

Employes on tugs of the Gowanus Towing Company, Inc., of Brooklyn will hold a secret election within fifteen days to determine whether they want to be represented by Associated Marine Workers, Local 1, Inland Boatmen's Union of the Committee for Industrial Organization, or by Local 333, International Longshoremen's. Association of the American Federation of Labor, or neither, the National Labor Relations Board said today.

William W. Cohen, chairman of the Mayor's committee on municipal athletic activities, announced yesterday that the postponed baseball game between the municipal teams of New York and Philadelphia would be played on the Athletics' field in Philadelphia tomorrow afternoon with Mayor La Guardia and Mayor S. Davis Wilson of Philadelphia in opposite cheering sections.
