WHAT can a man do with ten billion dollars? Very little, obviously, He can't spend much of it; he can't invest it permanently; he can't give it away without creating vested interests;
Miss Mary Elizabeth Hyer and Leonard F. Beckers were married here this morning in St. Bernard's Church by the pastor, the Rev. Clarence A. Heavey.

A journey through Southwestern China by T. V. Soong, former Finance Minister and brother-in-law of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, reflects the importance attached to that section now that the Japanese are battering at the interior of the country. The following article deals especially with the development of the southwestern province of Yunnan as a communication link it the out side world.

Three figures, so high up in the network of cables on the Williamsburg Bridge that they looked as tiny as birds on a telegraph wire, enacted a drama yesterday morning that kept thousands of persons on the bridge and along the riverfront of the lower East Side watching tensely.

The following dispatch was written by Charles S. Houston, leader of the American Karakorum Expedition to K2 [Mount Godwin Austen], who on Aug. 3 announced that the group had reached the summit of K2's cone, approximately 26,000 feet above sea level and the highest man has ever climbed.

With the opening of the Bureau of Internal Revenue office in the new Federal Office Building at 90 Church Street, New York, this week, the arena for hard bargaining with the Federal Government over income and estate taxes was moved close to home for taxpayers in New York State.
IN a week of varied concerts Lewisohn -Stadium will play host to what is likely the largest number of assisting artists ever to appear there within an equal space of time.

THESE are perilous times in the cinema, days of turmoil and threats and conflict. For years many of the more forward-looking citizens have had bicycles and sabers cached in their garages awaiting the hour when the prophetic "comes the revolution" took form and they could ride

Thomas J. Young of Collingswood, N. J., today won the 1938 T. Clarence Marshall trap shoot handicap, bringing the eighteenth annual Yorklyn tournament to a close. He shattered 142 of 150 clay birds from twenty yards to pace a field of 158 gunners.

The Bennington festival completed its first cycle of recitals tonight with the presentation of new works by Charles Weidman and Martha Graham, who were assisted in their performance by members of their concert and apprentice groups from the Bennington School of the Dance at Bennington College.

Eight persons were dead today after torrential rains in this threshold of the Great Smoky Mountains National Park. Two families met death as the frame home of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Ball was swept away yesterday by a swollen mountain stream.
A two-mile-an hour breeze slowed competition in the sixth annual Marblehead Class model yacht regatta at Hampton Manor Lake today. Leading in the first round, with perfect scores of 100, were:
The first Paris openings show several migled influences, producing a rich and varied 1939 Winter style-scape. Intricate and elaborate trimmings, accessories and jewelry are featured.

THE cry is ringing out of every studio today, "What can we do to rehabilitate the motion picture industry?" The directors, and their associates, feel they must assist in answering this grave question.

THE more sensible policy, on vacation eve, would have been to resign this column to a No Sunday Article dealing with the encounter between Briar, our city-bred Airedale, and an anonymous but devastatingly accurate Westport skunk.

J. Smith Ferebee's program today included eighteen holes of golf--"for fun instead of work." The 31-year-old investment broker, who yesterday played 144 holes to win complete ownership of a $30,000 Virginia plantation and $2,500 in side bets, had an eighteen-hole match this afternoon.
The output of canned fishery products and by-products in twenty-six States and Alaska in 1937 was valued at $141,710,000, the Bureau of Fisheries announced today.

Going into the final round of the President's pair event in the National Bridge Tournament being held here, Arthur Dickman and Amby Casner of New York, playing in Section A, led the field of thirtytwo pairs, with a score of 366 for the two qualifying rounds.
Smoke on 1940's political horizon appeared in Texas last week as rumblings of a boom to have John Nance ("Cactus Jack") Garner nominated as the Democratic Presidential candidate were heard.

Colonel Maxwell Murray, Fifth Field Artillery, U. S. A., and Mrs Murray of Madison Barracks, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anne Howard Murray, to Second Lieutenant Robert Whitsett van de Velde, Fifth Field Artillery, U. S. A.

Precedent points to major expansion in heavy construction activity in the next two to four years, James H. Manning, president of Ulen Co., said yesterday. By early Fall he expects $1,500,000,000 of added construction work to be effective through the allocation of Public Works Administration funds.
ASADATA DAFORA, who made a considerable stir with his native African dance-drama, "Kykunkor," in the Spring of 1934, has tempted the fates wit a second work in the same medium.

The Czechs, always cautious, are indulging in no undue optimism concerning Viscount Runciman's visit. Both in official circles and in the press one senses a strong suspicion of British motives in sending this "unofficial official."

Thomas Kilgallon, 23 years old, who refused to give a home address to the police, was ordered held without bail yesterday for a hearing on Aug. 10 by Magistrate Richard F. McKiniry in Felony Court on charges of grand larceny and possession of burglar's tools.

FOR the seventh consecutive month June showed a reduction in traffic deaths in New York State, according to figures made public last week by Robert J. Maloy, statistician of the Bureau of Motor Vehicles.

RODUCTION continued its downward trend at automotive plants here this week. The Ford Motor Company, closed for a two weeks inventory and vacation period, is expected to resume production about Aug. 15 and- possibly build between 15,000 and 20,000 current models before closing for changeover.
The State Department issued the following statement tonight concerning the search for the missing Hawaii Clipper:

Virginia's two Congressional primaries this week were won by Democrats whose records in the House showed many anti-New Deal votes. The two victors were also backed by the Byrd organization in those distriets.
Today's death toll in Palestine included three Britons, two Arabs and one Jew while dozens were wounded in terroristic incidents reported from nearly all parts of the country.

Discovery of dwelling places, temples, pottery and metal work of an ancient civilization in Peru was reported yesterday by Dr. Wendell C. Bennett, assistant curator in the anthropology department of the American Museum of Natural History.

The United Automobile Workers of America's executive board tonight removed from office and expelled from the C. I. O. union three of four suspended international vice presidents. The fourth was suspended from office for three months.

PERU minted large quantities of 50-soles gold pieces in 1930 and 1931, but .did not release them for general use. About this time most countries were going off the gold standard and Peru decided to hold these coins until gold became more standardized.

More than 15,000 men under arms will begin patrolling the streets in the International Settlement and the French Concession tomorrow morning in an effort to prevent an outbreak of terrorism leading up to the first anniversary on Saturday of

This department is designed to assist in the location of complete versions of poems and their sources, the names of authors, etc., which cannot be found through the usual channels of anthologies and books of reference. THE TIMES receives a great many more queries than it can publish.

Slightly less than half of the total current earnings of all member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 1937 was derived from interest and discount on loans, according to a study of operating ratios of the banks published in the August Federal Reserve Bulletin.

Central factor in the negotiations between Australia and the United States for a trade agreement is the wool tariff, it is considered here. As the result of preliminary conversations the Australian Government is convinced the State Department believes that the United States wool tariff is "an imposition upon the American public,"

Funeral services for Edward Victor Evans, general credit manager for the American Company, were held today at the Protestant Episcopal Church of St. Paul, 820 Hudson Street. The Rev. Henry Baldwin Todd, rector of the church, officiated.

Dr. Glenn Frank, chairman of the Republican National Program Committee, put into a radio talk tonight some of the heat carefully eliminated from the public statement issued by the committee yesterday at the close of its midsummer conference in Chicago.

Home construction is steadily advancing following the decline last Winter and early in the Spring, reports the Federal Home Loan Bank Board in announcing that advances by savings and loan associations in the country for the purchase, construction, reconditioning and refinancing of homes showed an increase of 2 per cent in June over May.

With formidable reserve strength massed on the Ebro front, the, full force of the Nationalist [Insurgent] counter-offensive began to make itself felt at dawn today when their heavy artillery and bombing planes started to work on the Loyalist positions between Mequinenza and Fayon.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Aug, 4: COMMANDER Morning. T. S., Med. Corps, Naval Hospital, Pearl Harbor, T. H., to Naval Hospital, Philadelphia. Pa. LIEUTENANT COMMANDERS

J. Howard McGrath, United States District Attorney, today announced he would seek to drop all the indictments involving the Narragansett race track brought'by a special Fedneral grand jury investigating political contributions, and that the existing statutes were so contradictory that he did not feel justified in seeking new indictments.

Expert pistol shats representing the Second Corps Area, which includes New York, New Jersey and Delaware, competed on the Camp Smith range here today in the annual inter-divisional matches for the Paul Revere, the Old Oaken Bucket and the Stark trophies.

Chauncey B. Downes, district agent of the New York Telephone Company, died yesterday at the Englewood Hospital after an illness of six weeks. Mr. Downes, who has been connected with the company for thirty-four years, was a member of an old New York City and Westchester County family.

The recent spirited defense by Secretary of State CordellHull of the reciprocal trade agreement program has again focused national attention on the foreign commerce policy of the Roosevelt Administration.

The Horseshoe Harbor Yacht Club today celebrated its golden anniversary to the accompaniment of thunder, lightning and bucketsful of rain, which would have been all right if the wind had obliged, but it didn't.

An estate valued at $275,000 for former Senator David Aiken Reed of Pennsylvania is nearing completion on a wooded forty-two-acre tract that formerly was a part of the vast holdings of the late Alfred H. Mulliken in New Canaan, Conn.

ONE of the strangest talents functioning hereabouts is that of Albert Stillman, who is the Music Hall's staff poet. You've probably wondered who writes those vaguely metaphysical lyrics that members of the Glee Club burst into occasionally-well, Mr. Stillman is your man.

The Rochester Red Wings scored their fifth straight victory and their second in a row over Newark today when they downed the league leaders, 3 to 2. Old Silas Johnson was the star of the game as he put down a threatening Newark uprising in the ninth.

This might be described as a "cruise of good intentions." Ever so many skippers are like the woodsmen who couldn't see the forest for the trees. Season after season these yachtsmen have been laying courses down Long Island Sound to New London for the June regatta or to Newport for the cup races, or to Block Island, Edgartown or Nantucket because they are vacation rendezvous.

An attack on dictatorships, though not by name, was made by Joseph E. Davies, United States Ambassador to Belgium, today when he presided over the Royal National Welsh Eistedfodd [music festival] here.

With the announcement yesterday that Senator Sherman Minton of Indiana would be the guest speaker at a luncheon in the Astor Hotel on Saturday, opening the first annual meeting of the National Board of Governors of the American Press Society, it was disclosed that the society will be sponsor for a series of forum meetings on topics of interest to newspaper workers during the Fall and Winter.

An additional appropriation of 10,000,000 pesos (approximately $3,240,000), has been asked of the Argentine Congress to be expended in combating the locust pests, the Department of Commerce was informed today.

Through alternate bursts of hot sunshine and heavy showers, an estimated 15,000 to 20,000 persons marched yesterday from Eighth Avenue arid Fortieth Street to Madison Square in the fifth annual peace parade under the sponsorship of the American League for Peace and Democracy.

Merwin K. Hart, president of the New York State Economic Council, called for the defeat of three proposed amendments now before the New York State Constitutional Convention in an open letter yesterday to each delegate to the convention. Mr. Hart said these amendments "would open up fresh fields of publie spending,

The touring Australians defeated Scotland by 61 runs in a one-day cricket match at Glasgow today. The Aussies compiled 143 runs against the Scotsmen's 82. W. J. O'Reilly, New South Wales school teacher, led the bowlers, taking seven wickets for 39 runs.
