GIVE the people opera and they will develop a taste for it. So students of the American musical scene have contended for some time, and some individuals and organizations have tried or are trying to do something about it.
Mischa Elman, violinist, will give recitals Dec. 2 and 5 in Havana, Cuba, under the auspices of the Pro Arte Musical Society of that city.

Many sports events will feature August at this resort. Next Saturday play will commence in the annual women's golf championship tournament of the Fishers Island Club. Mrs. Charles V. Benton of Yonkers, N. Y., is chairman of the women's golf committee of the club.

Mr. and Mrs. Max Jacobs of the Bronx have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Lois Jacobs, to Dr. Joseph Schultz of this city, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Schultz. Miss Jacobs attended Hunter College and received a master's degree from Columbia University. Dr.

WHILE Goldsmith and his companions were celebrating the success of his comedy "The GoodNatured Man" in his chambers in Brick Court, the Middle Temple, it is said that Blackstone was trying to write the fourth book of his "Commentaries" on the floor below.

For several days tenants in the five-story tenement at 247 East Ninety-fourth Street had been made frantic by meowing, morning, noon the cat. Last night, in desperation, the cast. Last night, in desperation, they called in Police Emergency Squad 6.

An aged Catholic priest who called Pearl White his benefactress today pronounced the funeral oration for the film star of the old silent thrillers. She was buried in the presence of only a dozen of her intimate friends.
Criticism of "a few justices of the Supreme Court" and of the Board of Elections was expressed in the annual report of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, which was made public yesterday.

New York's retail shops and stores never let up in their presentation of new things. Midsummer finds them at their annual nadir, when stocks of Summer merchandise are being cleared through sales, to make room for new Fall goods soon to put in an appearance. Yet even now a shopper on weekly rounds finds things that were not there a week ago.

Harry T. Peters, chairman of the bench show committee of the Westminster Kennel Club, yesterday announced the board of judges for the sixty-third annual exhibition to be held in Madison Square Garden Feb. 13, 14 and 15.

A dispatch from Rangoon tells of serious rioting at Mandalay between Buddhists and- Mohammedans. Do those two names of cities stir up any memories? Do they suggest the paddles chunking, the temple bells a-calling and the dawn coming up like thunder out of China 'crost the Bay?

From the slow start to the strong finish, the stock market last week ignored the poor showing of leading commodities. At its highest level yesterday, THE NEW YORK TIMES index of fifty stocks reached 103.23, or 0.71 point under the year's high to date, touched on July 25.
The wholesale fur district, lying just below the wholesale clothing district on Seventh Avenue, is as busy these Summer days as an excited anthill. The Winter's fur styles are being shown.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Aug. 5. Governor George H. Earle and his administration are back in the hands of the Pennsylvania courts again two weeks after he called the Democratic Legislature into special session and directed it to rescue him from the Republican Judiciary.

IN one of his intuitive flashes, Wilde said: "Every great man nowadays has his disciples, and it is always Judas who writes his biography." He had his Judas. Indeed, he had a plurality of them, judging by the haste with which the men who had known him kept rushing into print, each casting the onus of betrayal upon the other.

Mayor La Guardia, in a letter sent to all delegates of the Constitutional Convention, the text of which was made public here today, bitterly assailed the proposed Home Rule Article to. the State Constitution and contended that, if adopted, it would "freeze" certain "political hacks" on to the payroll of New Yok City.

A galaxy of fashionable society attended today's racing. Mr. and Mrs. Jackson A. Dyckman gave a luncheon at the Gideon Putnam for Mr. and Mrs. Gaines Gwathmey, Mrs. Wesson S. Seyburn, Mrs. Frederick F. Alexandre, Mrs. Dodge Sloane, Milton Holden and Douglas W. Paige.

Miss Fredericka Fry's aged bay gelding Watchme captured two blue ribbons during the second day of the fifth annual - Sagamore Horse Show today. In the Adirondack open jumping class, with the bars at four feet three, Watchme placed ahead of the Rochester Cavalry Troop's China Girl, Dan Conway's and Frank Snyder's Pardner and the 121st Cavalry's Bridesmaid.

Principals-Lou Ambers, Herkimer, N. Y., world lightweight champion, vs. Henry Armstrong, Los Angeles, world featherweight and welterweight champion. Title at Stake-World lightweight championship. Length of Bout--Fifteen rounds to a decision.

ESCANABA, Mich. ATTIRED like the rivermen of old in lumberjack shirts, stag pants and calked boots, about forty birlers from the Middle West, Pacific Coasf, Maine. and Eastern and Western Canada will compete in the second annual revival of the world's championship log rolling tournament in this one-time rip-roaring lumbering center on Aug. 12 to 14.

With the approach of the season for late Summer and Autumn flower shows, the problem of how best to keep cut flowers fresh assumes added importance. Often the coveted blue ribbon is lost merely because an entry must be penalized by the judges for "poor condition."

Mrs. Samuel Seabury was the guest of honor at a surprise garden party given yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Lockwood on Pudding Hill Lane by members of the Garden Club of East Hampton, in celebration of Mrs. Seabury's recent election as president of the Garden Club of America.

While on parole for having forged a $10 home relief check last year, Edward A. Bernett Jr., 19 years old, a Negro laborer of 87C St. Nicholas Avenue, was charged with the same type of offense yesterday in Felony Court before Magistrate Richard F. McKiniry.

Miss Phyllis Matilida Hannemann, daughter of Mrs. Carman Hannemann of this place and the late Mr. Hannemann, was married this afternoon at her mother's home here to Dr. John Philip Harney, son of John A. Harney of Hartsdale and the late Mrs. Harney.

King Boris, it is reported, will leave tomorrow for Italy, where he will join his wife and children and then go to Paris and London. It is declared that in the British capital he will discuss the prospects for a [Pound]10,000,000 loan to Bulgaria.
A former soldier who pilfered articles of clothing while he was in the military service has sent $50 to the War Department to ease his stricken conscience. The money was mailed from Detroit.

Officials of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration said today that a decline in cotton prices this week had brought the government "dangerously close" to a situation that would require it to provide price-stabilizing loans on this year's crop.
Secretary Ickes and his bride visited the Indian school here today and received gifts of small carved totem pole pins.

Sale of the Riverside Drive block front between Eighty-sixth and Eighty-seventh Street, with the announcement that an eighteen-story, and penthouse apartment house, to cost more than $2,500,000, will be erected on the site at once, was made yesterday by the Wood, Dol. son Company, brokers in the trans action. The deal, the firm states.

Mr. and Mrs. John Roberts Coffin will entertain at luncheon for sixty guests at the Point Judith Country Club tomorrow in compliment to Mrs. Coffin's son and daughter-inlaw, Mr. and -Mrs. John Gardner Kellogg of Sewickley, Pa., who are visiting them at Rosemary Cottage.

Mr. and Mrs. William Robertson Coe, who have been traveling in the Scandinavian countries, are now at Baden Baden, Germany. They will return to New York Aug. 29 and shortly afterward go t6 their ranch near Cody, Wyo.
The State Labor Relations Board reported yesterday that 106 new cases had been filed in July, bringing the total since the board's establishment thirteen months ago to 1,886.

War Secretary Leslie Hore-Belisha, who has just swept through army red tape to give immediate promotion to more than 2,000 officers, had their names announced in the official Gazette, effective Aug. 1.

TO produce the highly specialized type of negative required for projection printing, a new line of photographic chemicals, the first to place full emphasis on the control of gamma and printing density, has been introduced nationally by a Western firm.

IT is half a century, now, since. Bryce penned his classic description of the American Commonwealth. It is trite to observe that that half century has witnessed momentous changes in the character and circumstances of the American nation, that science and technology have created a new structure for society, and that many things once familiar have come to seem strange.

Patrick J. McDermott of Brookville made a valiant effort to capture the jumper championship of the tenth annual horse show of the Southampton Riding and Hunt Club today, but failed by five points, the laurels going to the May Top Stable's Golden Brew.
The Works Progress Administration announced through the National Research Project today that the amount of labor required to produce a bushel of corn has declined about 17 per cent in a generation.

The International Student Service at its annual assembly here today accepted the invitation to hold its next conference at Cornell University about Sept. 10, 1939. This congress has not been in the United States since 1931, when it met at Mount Holyoke.

The cost of a complete sewage disposal program for the entire city, designed to help control the pollution of harbor waters, is estimated at more than $158,800,000 in the annual report of the Department of Sanitation, made public yesterday.

LONDON-Although many people fear that another conflict would bring the United Kingdom even nearer the edge of starvation than it was during the World War, littie has yet been done to encourage: British farmers to grow more food.

Mrs. Sarah Sweetgail was beaten on the head and robbed yesterday morning by two unidentified men who forced their way into her apartment. on the top floor of a five-story tenement at 1,020 Gerard Avenue, the Bronx, while she was asleep in a bedroom.

Representatives of the National Association of Manufacturers of Pressed and Blown Glassware and of the American. Flint Glass Workers Union, announced today that they had reached an agreement on wages, hours and working conditions for the machinists' department of the industry.

IN the hope of preventing an interregnum between the termination of bureau of Air Commerce regulations and the assumption of aviation control by the Civil Aeronautics Authority on Aug. 23, Edward J. Noble, chairman of the recently appointed group, and his five colleagues are now busily engaged in familiarizing themselves with their new tasks.

Agnes Hand, daughter of Mrs. Thomas Hand of Paterson and the late Mr. Hand, to Robert Desmond Lockhart-Mummery, son of Mrs. Evelyn Cynthia Kari LockhartMummery of London and John the Percy Lockhart-Mummery, London surgeon, took place here this afternoon in the rectory of St. Peter's Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Regis Larkin, pastor of the Church of the Sacred Heart, Bay Head.

Arab Nationalist and Jewish leaders have been meeting in New York in the hope of finding a solution to the disturbing Palestine situation. The Arab approach to the problem is presented here by the director of the Arab National League.
Today's turnover of gold here amounted to [Pound]742,000, which was smaller than recent daily totals, but large for a Saturday. It brings the week's aggregate above [Pound]13,500,000.

Award of ten travel fellowships to scholastic representatives of ten Latin-American republics was announced yesterday by the Institute of International Education under a plan jointly sponsored by governmental and educational agencies and the Pan American Airways System.

More than 3,000 reservations have been made by members of the Seventy-eighth Division to attend the annual reunion of the "Lightning Division" at Camp Dix Aug. 12, 13 and 14. On the last day of the reunion, Sunday, memorial services will be held in honor of the several thousand members of the division who were killed in France.

A recommendation that a charter be granted to the Associated Hospital Service of Philadelphia was made to Common Pleas Court No. 5 today, bringing 3-cent-a-day hospitalization one step nearer realization.

WHILE sitting out one of yesterday's showers, Manager Bill McKechnie and Coach Hank (Old Goldenrod) Gowdy were discussing Bob Feller's pitching performance against the Yankees in Cleveland on Friday. "I never saw the boy pitch," said Mild Will. "Gave eleven bases on balls, did he?"

THE racing season of the little boats, manned by youngsters who will be big yacht skippers of tomorrow, is in full swing along the Atlantic Coast. Tiny craft careen, their lee rails foaming, while their commanders of 15 lean up to windward with all the nonchalance of a Vanderbilt or an Adams.

In a year of Spectaeular political campaigns esewhere, New Jersey, which will have a primary election which will have a primary election Sept. 20 and will elect a United States Senator in November, preserves an ominous calm. Although the time for filing Senate nominating petitions will expire in fifteen days, the Democratic party still is without an aspirant for the candidacy.

Miss Jane Ferris, daughter of Mrs. Julia Bolster Ferris of Northampton, Mass., and of Frank A. Ferris of Providence, R. I., was married today at her'mother's cottage on Juniper Point, West Boothbay Harbor, to James A. Fryatt of New York, son of Mrs. Walter Fryatt of Portland, Me., and the late Mr. Fryatt.

The Summer fur sale of the Hudson Bay Company opened here this week with a good attendance and advances on most offerings. The following quotations were recorded, compared with May prices: beaver, firm; mink, advanced 5 per cent;

HOLLYWOOD is watching with interest the success or failure of the recently com pleted 16mm. feature-length film, "Pinnochio," the initial offering of a newly formed studio, Towers Productions, which enters the field of competition against its more pretentious 35mm. counterparts.

Germany's latest, fastest and largest all-metal land plane, a twenty-six-passenger, four-motor monoplane of the Condor type, stood in its Bremen airport hangar tonight, poised for a non-stop flight to New York.

Special steel sash putty, advises the Metal Windows Institute, should be used when glazing steel casement or other metal windows. Ordinary putty will not form a tight bond with steel and breaks off within a comparatively short time.

The former four old brownstone dwellings, one of which was once occupied by General McClellan of Civil War fame, at 33-39 East Twenty-second Street have been renovated and remodeled into one building of forty suites consisting of two and one-half and three rooms with all improvements, including elevator.

Beginner's English classes at Columbia University are a barometer of political unrest throughout the world, according to Miss Amy T. Shaw, instructor, who has been teaching the language to foreigners for seventeen years.

Dr. Karl Ritter, German Ambassador to Brazil, left for Berlin today. He said he would return to Brazil after attending the Nazi convention at Nuremberg. Dr. Ritter was sent here to conclude a new treaty with Brazil to replace the barter and trade pact that expired in 1937.

New York City's "Fighting Sixtyninth," at its annual encampment at Camp Smith, played host today to Douglas Corrigan, transatlantic flier. Behind blaring bugle and rumbling drum, the old "Sixty-ninth," now the 165th Infantry, United States National Guard, came down the line past the reviewing stand where young Corrigan, clad in a green shirt, green tie and his now famous old brown windbreaker, stood at attention.

Mr. and Mrs. Harry Lee Brittingham of South Orange, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Brittingham, to R. Manning O'Connor Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. R. Manning O'Connor of Short Hills, N. J., formerly of Chicago.
Mr. and Mrs. August Hafner of Malba, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothy W. Hafner, to Miguel A. de Capriles of Hempstead, L. I., formerly of this city.

INCREASINGLY are fairs and important expositions featuring the world of travel. Sweden had a notable tourist display at its Spring show in Stockholm and there will be a tourism division at the Canadian National Exhibition opening Aug. 26 in Toronto.

WHEN Captain Hans Bertram of the German air services arrived New York-from the Coast recently on his eastward flight around the world using only commercial l airlines, the progress and feasibility of around-the-globe air-passenger service was again demonstrated.

PARIS. THE reprinting of "Rim baud," by Jacques Riviere (Emile-Paul, 234 pp., 18 fr.), makes us feel afresh how much we lost when the war stupidly cut off one of our keenest essayists and most original thinkers from a brilliantly begun career.

The following revised list of double-headers was announced yesterday by the National League through The Associated Press: At New York-Today, Pittsburgh. At Boston-Today, Chicago (moved back from Aug. 5); Aug. 13, Brooklyn; Aug. 14. Brooklyn; Sept. 16, Pittsburgh.
It will be another month before arrangements are complete for listing United States stocks on the Paris Bourse, it was said in financial circles here tonight. The organization,

Just before the dusk of July 9, while New Yorkers were excitedly awaiting the take-off of Howard Hughes and his crew on an around-the-world flight, a young airman 'in an old plane landed at Roosevelt Field and said he had just flown non-stop from California.

The State Racing Commission today revised the Winter schedule of Florida's two horse tracks to provide for a week earlier opening of Hialeah Park and corresponding changes in the split season of Tropical Park.

After Ohio National Guard troops entered the Youngstown "Little Steel" strike zone on July 21, 1937, police and guardsmen began a series of indiscriminate raids and arrests and sometimes released strikers only when they promised to return to work, according to statements made by members of the Steel Workers Organization Committee before the Senate Civil Liberties Committee today.

Some interest in shipping and legal circles has been aroused by recent court disputes involving cases concerning the ownership of Spanish merchant ships in British ports, contested by the two warring Spanish governments.

ADELSON-MINKOWITZ--Mr. and Mrs. George Minkowitz, 2.390 East 21st St., Brooklyn, announce the engagement of their daughter, Eleanor, to Mr. Howard A. Adelson, son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Adelson, 2,701 Avenue R, Brooklyn.

This week's Northport regatta for inboards on Saturday is benefiting by the change of date from July 30 and is attracting drivers from Midwestern and Southern cities who will use the North Shore event as a curtain-raiser for the national championships in the 91 and 135
Connie Mack's men pounded three of Sergeant Gabby Street's pitchers for thirteen hits today as the Athletics won, 8 to 4, and increased their margin over the last-place Browns to four full games.

Champion Nornay Saddler, smooth foxterrier owned by James M. Austin of Westbury, L. I., and handled by Len Brumby, was named best in show from an entry of 567 dogs in the Lackawanna Kennel Club exhibition today.

TAKING off from Seattle without fanfare or elaborate ceremonies, a "Baby Clipper" of Pan American Airways yesterday pointed its nose toward Juneau, Alaska, on the first survey flight over an air route planned eventually to link the United States and its largest territorial possession.

The Agriculture Department reported today that American farmers sold $155,000,000 more agricultural products abroad during the fiscal year ended June 30 than during the previous twelve months. The largest gain was in wheat, and the sharpest decline was in cotton.

LOANDA, Portuguese West Africa.-The visit of General Antonio Fragoso Carmona, the President of Portugal, to this colony attracts attention to a country that, owing to lack of communications, has been regarded as a sort of African Tibet.

DEATH is never far away from the army of divers walking the sea floor about North Australia in the unending search for pearls. They have to face attacks by sharks; but these are by no means the worst of their dangers.

Emil (Dutch) Leonard watched the first two men he faced line out singles today. Then he settled down, retired the next fifteen men in order and pitched the Senators to a fivehit, 7-1 victory in the first of their series with the White Sox.

Youthful tennis stars from the Golden West smashed and volleyed their way to top honors today in final matches in the week-long national junior tennis tournament. Climaxing spectacular play, unseeded Dave Freeman, Pasadena, Calif., upset the favorite, Welby Van Horn of Los Angeles, for the junior title. Freeman went four sets to win, 6-0, 6-2, 2-6, 6-0.

SIMON LAKE invented the "Lake type" of submarine. Some of his patents are basic in submarine construction. He is a strong, stocky, bullheaded, red-headed man who is blessed with that supreme, instinctive self-confidence that only the truly creative ever know.

ON April 22, 1915, the prevailing wind over the French fields was from the east. The Canadians and the French and British colonial troops in the trenches around Ypres were resting or were asleep; there was no "big push" on and only the desultory, routine shelling of the Western Front disturbed their rest.
Lured by a $5,000 amateur handicapping prize and a double feature, a crowd of 31,400, one of the largest in the track's history, swarmed into Washington Park today.
The engagement of Miss Ruth Mann to Herbert Carlin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Carlin of Brooklyn, has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Mann of 110 Riverside Drive.
CHAAUTAUQUA-Repertory Theatre, "The Comedy of Errors." (Thursday.) COOPERSTOWN--The Duke's Oak Theatre, "Macbeth." (Thursday).

Accompanied by a promise that the Soviet Union will purchase $40,000,000 of American goods within the next twelve months, the trade agreement between the United States and the Soviet was renewed today for another year, the State Department announced. Identic notes,

Considerable activity in the Westfield section of New Jersey in the sale of homes is reported by Herbert B. Smith Co., brokers. At the Park Acres development the firm states that four completed homes and one under construction have been sold.

Virgil (Fire) Trucks, 19-year-old pitcher for the Andalusia club of the Alabama-Florida League, converted from an outfielder less than a year ago, has struck out 350 batters in his 230 innings of mound duty.
WASHINGTON. - The Treasury has found a new use for the Coast Guard air force-spotting illicit distilleries. The planes are useful in spying out stills operating in isolated sections of the country.

ALTHOUGH the curtain does not go up on the Broadway season much before September nowadays, theatrical gossip takes no holiday. In spite of the burning heat along tha Times Square beaches the gossip is more cheerful just now than it has been since prosperity turned the corner nine years ago and completely disappeared from view.

More fog, calms and three thunder squalls, two of which burst with wind blasts, were some of the endurances fifty-seven racing craft on the American Yacht Club cruise had to go through today on the run from Duck Island Roads, over off the Connecticut shore.

William D. Winthrop of 6,203 Twenty-third Avenue, Brooklyn, a supervisor of the Consolidated Edison Company, who had been with that organization and the New York Edison Company for twentyfive years, died yesterday in St. Joseph's Hospital, Far Rockaway, after a brief illness.

Miss Margaret Henry, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dandridge Yuille Henry of Brookneal, Va., was martried to Aubrey Philip Ottarson Jr. of Nashville, Tenn., yesterday afternoon at the home of her brother and sister-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. Edward M. Henry, 1,073 East Thirtyninth Street, Brooklyn.

The, Toronto Lakesides broke a Canadian record in the 400meter intermediate relay today when they raced home in 49.4 seconds in the Canadian women's track and field championship meet. It was the final event of the meet. The previous record was b2.4 seconds.

Counting upon a pick-up in foreign trade, which they expect will manifest itself in a moderate way this month and gather momentum through the balance of the year, both exporters and importers last week started expanding their plans for Fall activity.
The Davis Cup candidacy of Robert L. Riggs Jr. practically went over the top today as he defeated his most formidable rival for the No. 2 singles berth without the loss of a set.

Miss Barbara Winslow of Hollywood won the women's East Hampton invitation tennis tournament at the Maidstone Club today. In the final round the young California defeated Miss Dorothy Workman of Los Angeles in bitterly close sets, 6-4, 6-4.

Heartened by the good results obtained in August home wares sales, retailers in many instances have reshaped their sales expectancy for September to the belief that next month will show a gain in dollar volume of 2 to 5 per cent over the same month a year ago.

The automotive industry and its suppliers showed a small -but none the less visible improvement in the second quarter of 1938, compared with the first three months despite the fact that factory sales of cars and trucks in the United States and Canada declined from 668,317 units in the first quarter to about 832,716 in the second quarter, a drop of 35,600, or 5.3 per cent.

The Third Army war games-one phase of which is being played out here across more than 120,000 acres of cut-over woodland-have demonstrated the increasing efficiency of the National Guard of the Southern States, in the opinion of officers here.

With the end of balloting just one day away, Harry Kipke, the former-Michigan coach, today held a margin of more than 69,000 first-place votes and a total of 4,547,129 points in the poll to name the coach of the college all-stars who will meet the Washington Redskin eleven Aug. 31.

A man later identified by his fingerprints as Frank Shinkus, 35 years old, of 266 Cherry Street, was shot and seriously wounded last night after he was alleged to have held up Solomon Greenspan in his drug store at 226 Third Avenue near Nineteenth Street and robbed him of $66.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In view of your editorial in support of my water-power proposal, I am moved to address this letter to you to state why I think the proposal is of great significance to every person in the State, from the householder to the industrialist.

New York's pre-marital law, effective July 1, has brought up many questions new to prospective brides and bridegrooms. And the 'sharp drop in applications for marriage licenses noted throughout the State indicates that all the answers are not yet clear in everybody's mind.

Mrs. Flora Blanchard Reed, former civic leader here, died early today at her home in Little Falls, N. Y., where she had been living for the last five years. Her age was 67. While residing here, Mrs. Reed was a member of the Municipal Playground Commission, aided in organizing the Home and School League and was active in Red Cross and church work.

Miles Collier of Tarrytown, N. Y., drove his tiny streamlined car to victory today in the third annual 75-mile automobile race through the streets of this St. Lawrence River resort village. Second place went to Lemuel Ladd of Boston, last year's winner, who finished 2 minutes and 34 seconds behind Collier. Sam Collier,

Bearing out the assertion of Major Charles D. Bles, post surgeon at Camp Smith here, that the Guardsmen from the metropolitan area can stand the heat much better than the up-State boys, 2,300 members of the Fourteenth Infantry of Brooklyn and the 165th Infantry,

Mail and passenger traffic at the Newark Airport reached a new record in the first five months of 1938, although air express business fell off slightly, it was announced today in the office of Mayor Meyer C. Ellenstein.

Miss Mary Rose Byrne, daughter of Mrs. Daniel P. Byrne of this place and the late Mr. Byrne, was married here this morning to John James Ferguson, son of Mrs. Bernard Ferguson of Flushing, Queens, and the late Mr. Ferguson, in the Church of St. Mary of the Isle.

Mr. and Mrs. William Simpson who are occupying their new home, formerly the Hodenpyl estate on Piping Rock Road, were hosts tonight at a dinner-dance which served two purposes, that of honoring Miss Elena Villa and Robert Grant 3d, whose marriage is to take place in Newport on Aug. 20, and as a house-warming.

Curt Davis's ninth-inning relief hurling aided the Cardinals in a 7-to-6 victory over the last plac Phillies today. The former Phillies' player relieved Bob Weiland with one out in the final inning and retired the last two batters to give the Cardinals their second straight in the series.

INDICATIONS are that the future of super-power broadcasting in the this country will not be determined by the Federal Communications Commission before next year, according to a report from Washington at the conclusion of a tenday hearing on the application of WLW, Cincinnati, for renewal of its 500-kilowatt experimental license.
MANY year ago Dr. Otto Neurath, a social scietist of international reputation, organized with Dr. Rudolf Carnap, now of the University of Chicago; the late Dr. Mortiz Schlick; Dr. Philipp
This is the tenth of a series of articles describing small gardens in and around New York which have been planned and planted by their owners.
A NEW musical institution on the local scene is the Americal Conservatory of Music Drama and Dance, 114 East Sixty-fourth Street, which was founded in June.

The Panama Pacific Line's new service to California via the Panama Canal started at 10 A. M. yesterday when the liner City of Los Angeles, a rebuilt cargo-passenger vessel, sailed from the West Twenty-first Street pier, used until. last April as the eastern terminal of the liners California, Virginia and Pennsylvania.

A commission of 60 cents, added to his regular wage more than a year ago, cost a laundry driver his right to $27 in benefits under the complex provisions of the State Unemployment Insurance Law. it has just been learned.

The forty-ninth mid-Summer series which made Marblehead famous with a world record for contestants last year, got under way auspiciously today when 380 yachts crossed the three starting lines. This was eleven less than the first day figure last year.

Permission has been granted by the Greenwich Zoning Board of Adjustment and Appeals to the heirs of the Joseph Christiano estate to sell their property on West Elm Street to John Chutick of New York City for the construction of a sixstory apartment house to accommodate seventy-two families.

Building activities in Montclair during the first half of this year fell sharply below the figures for a year ago, according to the report of until Building Inspector John Picken. Only about 30 per cent as much building was done this year on a basis of valuation as during the period from Jan. 1, 1937 to July 1, 1937.

The positions of directors of personnel in various government departments and agencies, under President Roosevelt's extension of the merit system in government posts, are viewed by the Civil Service Commission as extremely important, the commission said today.

In some ways late mid-Summer is almost as much of an in-between season in the garden as late Winter. Seeds of some species of flowers can be planted and a limited amount of transplanting done; and, of course, the current insects and disease pests must be combated.

The "blue-ribbon" jury, resorted to by District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey in the Hines case, is an institution that was written into the statute books by the State Legislature in 1901 for the express purpose of creating a list of jurors of superior intelligence to judge complicated or important criminal and civil cases.
The fifth annual Mount Holly horse show will take place next Saturday on the estate of Robert B. Lamb here. Part of the proceeds will benefit the local Nursing Association.
PROBABLY inspired by the fact that it is all slightly mysterious, the Times Square talk comes sooner or later to that play on which Jed Harris is laboring through these sultry days and nights.

NEWPORT.-Next week is to be flower week in this city. For three days, beginning on Wednesday, the Newport Horticultural Society, made up for the most part of the gardeners on the large estates, and the Newport Garden Club, made up of Summer residents and other flower enthusiasts, will hold sway at the Casino at the annual flower show.

Frank O'Hara, broker of Jackson Heights, L. I., reports that last month was the best July for apartment rentals his office has experienced in its eighteen years of existence. He says apartment rentals for July this year were 25 per cent ahead of those for the same month last year.

Three years ago-Aug. 14, 1935-President Roosevelt signed the Social Security Act and placed the United States among those nations seeking, through governmental effort, a systematic scheme of security against "the major hazards and vicissitudes of life."

What is annually considered the high point of the Saratoga season is the forthcoming Saturday when' the Travers, the oldest race renewed in the United States, is again run at the famous up-State course.

Frank S. Coan, general secretary of the English-Speaking Union of the United States, announced yesterday that ten scholarships had been awarded by the English- ton, Speaking Union of the British Empire, in cooperation with other orranizations, to English teachers and writers for study and travel in the United States.

Contracts have been awarded by Charles F. Noyes for the erection of two new buildings in the downtown section of Manhattan. Both are two-story structures, one being on three lots at 219-21 Pearl Street and 2 Platt Street, and the at 793 Broadway, on a plot 25 by 92 feet.

With the development of concrete highways and roadside stands the "pansy farmer" has been added to the list of horticultural specialists. Gardeners who go motoring in early Spring stop to exclaim at the floral carpets of innumerable thousands of gay-colored blooms displayed in simple board frames or open beds.

Add to the indices of depression and prosperity the reading of library books. In Chicago, according to Chief Librarian Carl B. Roden, the general circulation during the first six months of 1932 was 7,227,292. Recovery in 1937 sent the figure down to 4,847,555.

Representatives of six counties entered the competition for the Genesee Cup as the annual meeting of the New York State Chess Association began today at the Cazenovia Seminary junior college. The list included last year's champions from Schenectady, and also teams from Broome, Madison, Monroe, Oneida and Onondaga.
An attack upon the American Bar Association by Lee Pressman, general counsel of the Committee for Industrial Organization, is carried in The C. I O. News appearing today.

Harness horses from the stables of William Parkhurst of Maplewood scored a sweep at the weekly matinee at Weequahic Park today, winning all four events. Wraith, black pacer, took the afternoon's feature, defeating Ash Wednesday,

Many owners of old homes have discovered that extensive rewiring is necessary as the majority of homes more than ten years old were wired for lighting purposes only. Today they are forced to carry an appliance load that is too much for efficiency.

Accelerated aging tests are being made by the National Bureau of Standards in Washington to fiber building boards to determine whether it is good economy to -substitute them for more costly materials in low-cost house production.

WE have come to the time of year when play going in England is sicklied o'er with the pale cast of learning. The Open Air Theatre in Regent's Park has exchanged the Athens of Nick Bottom for the Athens of Lysistrata.
President Roosevelt headed toward Pensacola, Fla., tonight on the last -leg of a vacation cruisee which started three weeks ago today. The homeward run is slightly more than 1,100 miles.

Leonard T. Grant, 33, of Dedham, former New York University football star, was instantly killed today when a bolt of lightning struck the fourth fairway of the Norfolk Golf Club, stunning his three companions in a foursome and a player on the adjoining ninth green.
The Central Republic Trust Company, which is liquidating the assets of the old "Dawes Bank," paid a total of $990,925 to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation in the quarter ended on July 31.

Johnny Vander Meer of nohil, no-run fame has come up with another "no" that apparently has halted a move to build a park in his honor in his home town. "No soap," was his comment on a Vander Meer Park proposal. "I don't want to be pointed out as the guy who keeps the tax rate up 30 or 40 points for the upkeep of a park named after me," he told a close friend.

The Congressional investigation of the Tennessee Valley Authority and its administration, now completing its third week of public hearings here, has been a surprise in one respect. So far, at least, it has not been a "whitewash," as a good many people expected, but a real investigation within- the limits imposed - by its small appropriation and consequent lack of investigators and accountants.

UP in the northeast corner of Asia two armies face each other across two rivers-the Amur and the Ussuri, which form the border between Manchukuo and Siberia. Recently these armies have been clashing again, adding to the long series of warlike "incidents" which have heightened tension between Tokyo and Moscow.

MIDDLEBURY, Vt.-The country store where the women folk exchanged fresh eggs and farm produce for groceries, yard goods and crockery, and the men played checkers on the cracker barrel, toasted their feet on the baseburner stove, and argued about whether Abe Lincoln was leading the country to perdition, has become a museum piece.

THE slow and often dishearteing struggle of New York State civic bodies for safer and more beautiful motorways by means of railroad grade;rossing elimination and billboard control appears to have made large- gains 'during the Constitulional Convention at Albany.

The American Dahlia Society, at its twenty-fourth annual dahlia show in the ballroom of the Hotel Concourse Plaza, 161st Street and Grand Concourse, on Sept. 20 and 21 will have a new section for amateurs who have never received an award at any American Dahlia Society show.

President Roosevelt's commission to study the British Trade Dispute Act was the "brain child" of Tom M. Girdler, chairman of the board of the Republic Steel Corporation, according to an editorial in The C. I. O. News.
LONDON. RETURNING to England from the Continent, one is constrained to question the theory that accelerated communications tend to diminish mental barriers.

The Circuit Court of Appeals remanded yesterday to the Board of Tax Appeals for rehearing a tax action against Rafael Sabatini, author of historical romances, involving $24,745 deficiency and penalty taxes on his income. The court directed the board to determine whether Mr. Sabatini had been deprived of any legal rights.

Prices on the New York Cotton Exchange displayed stubborn resistance yesterday around 8 1/2 cents a pound for the December delivery and, in the face of. a sharp decline in Liverpool and continuance of favorable weather, the list ended 4 points higher to 1 point lower on the day.

As early as last March it was rumored in Washington that the department of Justice intended to proceed against the American Medcal Association and its affiliate, the District of Columbia Medical society, on charges of interfering with the activities of the Group Health Association, Inc., a medical Cooperative.

Spring an upset, Bravo, a son of Volomite, raced to victory today in the $5,000 one-mile Hanover Shoe Farm Stake for trotters, a high spot of the final day's program of the Grand Circuit meeting at Agawam track.

An average humidity of 76 per cent, 12 per cent above normal and the highest in many years; a total rainfall of 5.82 inches, 1.39 inches above normal, and only 59 per cent of the total possible sunshine were some of the weather features that distinguished July.

The first reorders on August sale coats and suits were received last week and indicate the beginning of an encouraging consumer response covering many types of garments, according to Samuel Klein, executive director of the Industrial Council of Coat,. Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, Inc.
Completely restored, Generals House, the residence of the commanding generals at Governors

The Jewish War Veterans of the United States urged Henry Ford to repudiate the award of the Grand Cross of the German Eagle conferred on him on July 30 in observance of his seventy-fifth birthday. The demand was made in a telegram to the automobile manufacturer by Harry H. Schaffer, national commander of the organization.

William D. Campbell, field representative of the American Museum of Natural History, sailed on the Italian liner Conte di Savoia yesterday on a six months' expedition to Africa to collect specimens to be added to groups in Carl Akeley African Hall at the museum.

The Council of American Master Mariners announced yesterday its support of Rear Admiral Emory S. Land, chairman of the Federal Maritime Commission, in demanding that masters of government-owned merchant ships retain final authority in the- selection of their sea-going, personnel.
An audience larger than that of the opening night turned out for the second program of the Berkshire symphonic festival at Tanglewood here tonight.

EVERY August anglers from far and near gather at Mobile to take part in the Alabama deep-sea fishing rodeo. From Fort Gaines, on historic Dauphin Island, as base, the fishing boats ply into the waters of lower Mobile Bay, Grant's Pass,

PHOENIX, Ariz.--Once again the River Conference called by Governor R. C. Stanford of Arizona in an attempt to settle the long-standing controversy over the waters of the two great Southwestern rivers, the Colorado and the Rio Grande, has been abandoned with nothing even approaching a settlement of the interstate and international question.

Evidence that the Manhattan foreclosure situation, as measured by the number of completed auctions, continues to Improve is provided by the monthly report on such sales issued yesterday by the Real Estate Board of New York.

Miss Ethel Prosser and David Sherman Baker Jr. will be married here the afternoon of Aug. 20 in the Round Hill Church. The Rev. George B. Langdon of the Pomfret (Conn.) School, where Mr. Baker was formerly a student, will perform the ceremony.

Columbus and Southern Ohio Electrio Company and SubsidiariesTwelve months to June 30: Net income after operating expenses, taxes and charges, $2,623,223, pared with $2,637,306 in the preceding twelve months.

Tenyear-old Barbara Jean Boycott of Glen Ridge, who gained her riding knowledge from her father, Lieut. Col. Cecil M. Boycott, former U. S. Army polo star, won the saddle horse championship at the third annual North Jersey Charity Horse Show today at the Lake Swananona Country Club.

LAKE PLACID.--The ninth annual Lake Placid Horse Show, sponsored by the Lake Placid Horse Show Association, Inc., of which George M. Holley of Grosse Pointe Farms, Mich., is president, will open here at the outdoor ring on Friday evening under floodlights, to continue through Saturday and Sunday afternoons.

The arrest early today of Willie Weber, 30 years old, an alleged peddler of narcotics, started wide activity among Federal agents which resulted in three other arrests of persons suspected of complicity in a huge narcotics ring.

Appeals to recipients of old-age benefits in Ohio to vote for the renomination of Governor Martin L. Davey in the Democratic primary next Tuesday will be investigated by the Social Security Board to see whether the Federal Social Aid Law has been violated, the board announced today.

Rain washed out yesterday's game between the Giants and the Pirates at the Polo Grounds and manufactured a double-header today that is likely to draw a crowd of 50,000. There were about 10,000 in the stands a minute before Harry Gumbert and Jim Tobin were scheduled to start their pitching duel when the announcement came through the loudspeaker that the two teams would play two contests today, starting at 2 P. M.
Cautious and patient, Frankie Parker won the men's singles title of Canada today by extracting errors from Wilmer Allison's-driving net game on the clay courts at the Toronto Lawn Tennis Club.

Mrs. Edith Kermit Roosevelt, widow of President Theodore Roosevelt, celebrated her seventyseventh birthday today at a supper given by the Edith Kermit Roosevelt Women's Republican Club of Oyster Bay in the American Legion clubhouse.

After interviewing more than two hundred manufacturers and salesmen, buyers for the Read Drug and Chemical Company of Baltimore yesterday placed orders for substantial quantities of merchandise in the novelty and promotion-goods fields.
The Coast Guard reported tonight that a sixty-four-foot cabin cruiser, the Intrepid III, sank five miles southeast of Crossrip Lightship in Nantucket Sound, but that all aboard were saved.

Major Albert W. Stevens, famed stratosphere flier and aerial photographer of the army, and Ruth E. Fischer of Dayton, Ohio, were married last night at the Rockville Presbyterian Church by the pastor, Rev. Henry Pasma.

TO the New England photographs which the public has already welcomed,' Samuel Chamberlain has now added a charming little specialized collection from Cape Ann. Here are the famous wharves of Gloucester, and the scenes that the artists paint out Rockport way.

COINCIDENTAL with moving into its new modernistic studios last week, comes the an nouncement of WEVD's extensive plans for its University of the Air programs in the Fall. WEVD's new home is located at 117-19 West Forty-sixth Street, housing four studios, the largest of which occupies two floors and accommodates an audience of 100 people.

Before even one match could be completed, showers forced a halt in the opening program of the Eastern grass-court tennis championships today at the Westchester Country Club. Tourney officials have packed tomorrow's schedule so that play will begin at 10 o'clock, if the weather permits.

As a result of the unusually active opening in August furniture sales, retailers will come into the market this week to cover their Fall requirements three weeks earlier than had been expected, reports in the local trade indicated yesterday.

ABINGDON, Va.-Thousands of visitors, including some of the nation's authorities on folklore, are expected to gather on White Top Mountain in Southwest Virginia for the White Top Folk Festival on Thursday, Friday and Saturday. The contests will be open to all folk musicians.

THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity has resumed its advance, with five of its components showing increases for the week ended July 30. It now stands at 81.7, compared with 81.1 (revised) for the preceding week and 107.7 for the corresponding week a year ago.

One of the well-known landmarks in upper Manhattan, the Paterno Castle overlooking the Hudson River at an elevation of more than 150 feet just north of 181st Street is about to be torn down and the site, in addition to the large vacant plot north of the Castle will be improved with five twelve-story detached apartment houses.

Evangelista Bello, a chauffeur, was shot and seriously wounded late today in a clash between transport workers and police in Santa Clara. Bus, taxi and truck drivers in the cities of Santa Clara and Cienfuegos joined the protest strike against the new highway tax today.

The engagement of $1,935,000 of gold in England for shipment here was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. This engagement brought the total of gold obtained abroad last week for shipment here to $14,183,000, of which $5,800,000 was engaged in Japan, $4,496,000 in England and $8,887,000 in Canada.

Reorganization of secondary education in the nation to include two years of college work as part of the public school system was urged last week by Dr. George D. Strayer, Professor of Education in Teachers College, speaking in Columbia University's McMillin Theatre at a conference sponsored by the college for school board members and school administrators.

SINCE the days of Plato and Aristotle men's minds, have sought to unravel the knotty problem of aethetic-"beauty." An enormous amount of writings has poured from the presses some tackling the problem directly, that is, working from the particular object of, art to an elaboration of aesthetic theory;
The newest creations of the world's gladiolus hybridizers will be shown here next Wednesday and Thursday at the ninth annual show of the Metropolitan Gladiolus Society, staged at Rockefeller Center.

THE heat wave continued to take toll of retail trade last week, with the result that the comparative showig with a year ago was not quite as good as that reported for the preceding week. The feature of the week, however, was the good response to August homewares promitions.

The Aircraft nine of Buffalo scored a 2-to-0 victory over Canandaigua tonight to win the New York State semi-pro baseball championship. The title carries with it the Honus Wagner Trophy and $1,000 in prize money.

To take effect 8 A. M., Aug. 8: LIEUTENANTS--Joseph H. Brink, from 11th Precinct to Telegraph Bureau, designated as acting captain. Assignment to desk duty discontinued. Emil C. Blumler, from 42d Precinct to 15th Division. assignment changed from desk duty to supervisor of patrol in uniform.

Recent action of the Export-Import Bank of Washington in opening new credits for financing exports to Latin America, to meet intensified competition from Europe, has paved the way for a longterm development of the United States' marketing frontiers to the south, in the opinion of exporters here.

The Republican National Committee called upon the Civil Service Commitsion today to protect Federal workers from a "shakedown" which it said had been undertaken by Oliver A. Quayle Jr., treasurer of the Democratic National'Committee.

Bill McKechnie's Reds defied the weather, the Dodgers and the record books at Ebbets Field yesterday, and hurdled over the Cubs to take undisputed possession of third place only a game and a half behind the second-place Giants in the National League standing.

ABEL--Dr. and Mrs. Harold A., announce the birth of a son, Robert Adolph, at Lenox Hill Hospital. BARDIN-Mr. and Mrs. Harry Bardin joyfully announce the arrival of Stuart's sister, Helene Ruth, on July 30, at LyingIn Hospital.

As the fighting on the Manchukuoan border was at its height Emperor Hirohito gathered up seventy-five gold articles in his palace and sent them to the Bank of Japan. That institution is now spending 300,000,000 yen of the carefully hoarded 800,000,000 yen gold reserve in order to meet the costs of the warfare in China, and a national campaign is under way to gather in privately held metal.

A large Summer home at Lake Packanack, near Boonton, N. J., has been purchased by Charles M Schwab 2d, nephew of Charles M. Schwab, chairman of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation. With the house he acquired a large plot fronting on Oakwood Drive and overlooking the lake from the North Shore and commanding an extensive view of the Passaic County mountain region.

Fighting Squadron 5 of the Aircraft Carrier Yorktown and Marine Fighting Squadron 1 of the fleet marine force at Quantico, .will make demonstration flights at the National Air Races at Cleveland Sept. 3-5. Both are noted in naval aviation annals.
Serious exploration work preparatory to the first deep drilling tests of possible petroleum deposits in Cuba has gotten under way since passage of the recent Petroleum Bill.

Boston University's new $1,150,000 home for its College of Business Administration, ground for which has been broken, is part of a picture of expansion now going on among educational institutions In and near Boston.
A series of guided tours for Summer college students and others interested in the study or teaching of painting, sculpture, music or drama was anonunced yesterday by the WPA Federal Arts Projects.
NOW that Czechoslovakia's problems bid fair to remain indefinitely among the thorniest in Europe, this profound study of the most dangerous of the lot of them acquires peculiar timeliness.
DECORATING boats, from small cabin yachts to ocean liners, is a field of action for many an interior designer. Planning the appointments of a small privte boat. of course, is one thing.

With the third anniversary of the Social Security Act one week off, Joseph B. O'Connor, acting regional director of the Social Security Board, reported yesterday that the board had given $29,566,442 to State agencies for assistance to the needy aged and blind and to dependent children.

The almost unanimous support of the Spanish Nationalist [Insurgent] cause by Catholic ecclesiastics throughout the world is indicated in a book to be published soon at Burgos, it was learned by this correspondent during a recently concluded visit 'to Rebel Spain.

In all the years I have spent in Moscow I have never known such a controversy as that now raging over interpretation of Thursday's conversation between Maxim Litvinoff, the Soviet Foreign Commissar, and Mamoru Shigemitsu, the Japanese Ambassador, on the- fighting on the Manchukuoan-Siberian frontier.

The Public Works Administration announced Presidential approval today of ninety-eight additional nonFederal projects, having an estimated construction cost of $13,018,148, for which the PWA made grants totaling $5,849,154.

To the Drama Editor: It is obvious to any observer that the Summer theatre, despite the ridicule of the comic-strip boys and critical Nathanarchists, is deeply rooted in the affections of those thousands who seek green pastures in preference to hot sidewalks when comes the torrid season.
Building wreckers are reputed to be unsentimental fellows, not given to emotional thoughts of the memories they cart away with the brick and rubble f some historic landmark.

RUFFORD ABBEY, the his toric home of Lord Savile and virtually the last of the privately owned great estates in the Robin Hood country, is to be sold. Held by the Savile family since the sixteenth century, it was once numbered among the many proud houses concentrated in that part of the Midlands known as "The Dukeries." Most of those great places have been broken up in recent years.
Word reached Mexico City today of the slaying of two Federal teachers and the wounding of two others at Zinaparo, Michaocan State, by opponents of the government's program of socialistic education.

Joseph Wilson Fifer, Governor of Illinois from 1889 to 1893, veteran of the Civil War and long a picturesque figure in the political life of the State, died this morning at his home here where he had been bedfast since last March, when he fell and broke his ankle. He would have been 98 years old on Oct. 28.
Steve Wozniak of Buffalo, N. Y., defending champion, won the national A. A. U. long-distance swim at Rocky Glen today. He set a new record of 1 hour 46 minutes for the five-mile course.

Although many prospective debutantes of the Autumn season on the North Shore and members of their families are passing this month in Newport, Saratoga, Eastern watering places and Europe, they will return in September to prepare for one of the busiest society programs in several years.

The George R. Decker residential estate. at Shrewsbury, N. J., has been purchased by Charles W. Bennett of Detroit, reports the Joseph G. McCue Agency, brokers in the transaction. The property includes two and one-half acres on the southeast corner of Sycamore Avenue and Hope Road, one mile west of the village center of Shrewsbury.
Mr. and Mrs. F. Trubee Davison of Locust Valley, L. I., are here on their yacht, Water Gypsy. Mr. and Mrs. William Hale Harkness are here on their yacht Ardea.

Two more veteran members of the Chicago Cardinal National Football League team, Jack Robinson and John Reynolds, have been released, Owner Charles W. Bidwill has announced. Robinson, a tackle, was claimed by Pittsburgh on waivers and Reynolds, a center, was released outright. Robinson was released outright.

Vocational Adoption, an incorporated organization that helps underprivileged boys in getting a proper start in life, announced yesterday that a "vocational adoption day" would be held in the Fall, when an effort would be made to demonstrate to the leading business executives of the city what the association already has achieved in placing boys in worthwhile positions.

Every few days trucks heavily loaded with New York's license plates for 1939 roar out of the gates of Auburn Prison, bound for motor vehicle bureaus and county clerks' offices throughout the State. Issuance of the new "tags" will begin early in December, although the present plates will be legal until Jan. 31.

I WAS just starting out trout fishing one day last week when I saw from a headline in an afternoon paper that war in Europe was just about a dead certainty-anything within twentyfour to twenty-six hours.
Seabiscuit, 1937 handicap champion of the American turf, faces two match races in fifteen days in his quest to pass Sun Beau's money winning record.

How long Soviet Russia and Japan can continue skirting the edge of war without going over no one can say. Longer, probably, than any other two countries for reasons peculiar to themselves and revealing as to the Far East.
The recent trade estimate, placing world stocks of American cotton on July 31 at the record figure of 13,400,000 bales, implies that we are as far from balancing supply with demand as in 1932.

PARIS. AFTER bringing to Paris the Berlin Philharmonic for a couple of concerts, Furt waengler has just returned to the Opera for a couple of German "Tristans" with singers from various points of the Reich.

Since yesterday afternoon an "attacking" force of 475 aircraft under the command of Sir Edgar R. Ludlow-Hewitt, Air Chief Marshal, has been hammering with considerable success at Britain's new defenses in fourteen counties between the Humber and the Thames.

About 700,000 Americans, the largest number in history except in war time, are receiving military training this year under the direction, wholly or in part, of army officers. If the navy, marine corps and coast guard were added, the total would be between 850,000 and 900,000.

Gordon Stanley (Mickey) Cochrane, who managed the Detroit Tigers to American League pennants in 1934 and 1935, was removed tonight as the leader of the club, a victim of what Owner Walter O. Briggs termed "baseball."

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Aug. 6, unless specified: L L At Newport: Badger. Decatur, Honolulu, Herbert, Leary, J. F. Talbott. Chefoo to Chinwangtao: Alden, Barker, Whipple. Baltimore to Bermuda: Dickerson, Schenck. Ichang to Chungking: Luzon, Tutulla. Arkansas, Charleston to Guantanamo. Astoria, at Navy Yard, Puget Bound, July 29.

John, beloved husband of Alice (nee Kerrigan). Member of the Old West Side Catholic Club, Holy Name Parish, 96th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Funeral from his late residence, 1,928 University Ave., Bronx, on Monday, at 9:30 A. M.; thence to the Church of the Holy Spirit, University. Ave.

Miss Ruth Westcott, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Westcott of Atlantic City, N. J., was married here yesterday morning in the Park Avenue Presbyterian Church to Frank Schmitt of Philadelphia. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Harry Bertrand Taylor.

The desire of politicians for power, for control of the machinery that harvests the crop that all politicians care about-the jobs crop-was more of an issue in the primary elections held this week than the political philosophies and projects of the New Deal. Striking triumphs for political machines were recorded, but no momentous victories for political principles.
A Soviet Russian air raid this afternoon on Korea brought a Japanese army communique which declared it only a question of time until the Japanese would retaliate.

LONDON.-The recent sale of Jonas Hanway's umbrella at a London auction room has revived Hanway's fame as the philanthropist who introduced umbrellas into the rainy streets of London about 1750 and so saved thousande of Londoners from pneumonia and rheumatism.

Out of a total Republican vote of about a quarter of a million in last Tuesday's primaries, Dr. Gerald B. Winrod, free-lance Wichita minister who had been termed the "Kansas Nazi," received only a little more than 50,000 and finished a poor third in the race for nomination for United States Senator.

The Reconstruction Finance Corporation will finance the purchase at par and accrued interest of $1l,433,675 of new first-mortgage 4 per cent bonds provided in the plan of the insurance group committee for reorganization of the Denver Rio Grande Western Railroad if the Interstate Commerce Commission and the court approve that plan within a reasonable time, Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the RFC, recently assured the railroad.
OSCILLATING between a torrid city and the verdure and music of the Berkshire Symphonic Festival, there comes to mind a remark that Sibelius made one day in a place a considerable distance away.

The government today authorized expenditure of 148,250,000 francs (close to $4,073,000) for French representation next year at the New York World's Fair. Of this, 64,650,000 francs (about $1,776,000) was set aside for construction and decoration of a French Government building
Logan Pearsall Smith, United States author, is seriously ill here from pneumonia which he contracted while visiting Thingvellier. Logan Pearsall Smith has spent most of his life in Britain.

When President Roosevelt lands at Pensacola on Tuesday he will be ending a tour that started out, political writers thought, to be a "purge." The President was expected to take part in half a dozen nomination fights, throwing his influence to the support of faithful New Dealers and against candidates whom the President calls "yes but" Democrats.

SNOW WHITE AND THE SEVEN DWARFS in Wanda Gag's own translation, illustrated by her inimitable drawings, is an event and a particularly welcome one in a year when thousands of people, young and old, have been made Snow White conscious.

TOPEKA. A PEN-PORTRAIT of Alfred M. Landon as he is today probably should dwell upon the unique position which the 1936 Republican Presidential nominee occupies in his party and in the ever-changing panorama of public affairs.

As civilization proceeds men deliberately create certain conditions, only to find something uncomfortable in them and then have to find a remedy. Such a circle, having brought the modern city and built canyoned skyscrapers with walls insulated against its noise, is bringing more and more demand for air conditioning office and business buildings.

A veteran of many a golfing war, J. Wood Platt, and youthful James (Sonny) Fraser of the Seaview Club, prime favorites from the beginning, advanced to the final round of the John G. Anderson Memorial Tournament at the Winged Foot Golf Club today.
ALTHOUGH it is Irish to the core, "Pray for the Wanderer" belongs to a sophisticated tradition. No mellowtongued peasants-hardly even a priest-can be found anywhere in its pages.

The War Department today tightened its regulations concerning army lobbying for legislation. "Except as authorized by the War Department, efforts to procure or influence legislation affecting the army or to procure personal favor through legislation are forbidden," said a circular revising an existing regulation.
TIME is a merciless judge of fame. Often a man who seemed supreme in his day must drop in rank as the centuries pass and yield his niche to an old competitor he was sure he had surpassed.

Harold Halsted of the Moriches Bay Star fleet brought his Chuckle III in second today and thereby retired the Corry trophy. Halsted won the eleven-year-old cup in 1934 and 1936. Chuckle III has not finished worse than third throughout the five days of race week competition on Great South Bay.

Miss Dorothy Myra Martin of Plainfield, and her sister, Miss Norma Marie Martin of Syracuse, N. Y., daughters of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Martin of Syracuse, formerly of Plainfield, were married at a double wedding ceremony this afternoon in Trinity Reformed Church, this city. The Rev. Dr. John Y.

At a tea given here today in their Sumher home, Beacon Heights, Mr. and Mrs. Giles Monro Hubbard of Pelham Manor, N. Y., announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Elizabeth Hubbard, to Arthur Knox Jr., son of Arthur Knox of New York and Norfolk and the late Mrs. May Barnard Knox.

Dr. Jean Sibelius, Finnish composer, has accepted the honorary presidency of the Henry Hadley Foundation, Inc., according to a cablegram received from Finland yesterday by Mrs. Grace D. Vanamee, president of the foundation.

Gladioli, beautiful as they are, seldom appear at their best. Because they are so often seen in tall vases, standing in corners or towering alone on a center table-ready to be blown over by the first puff of a breeze through door or window-with no relation to the design of the room, their use indoors has been limited.
An anonymous donor has given the Central Park Zoo a tiglon, it was announced yesterday by the Department of Parks. A tiglon is a hybrid of lion and tiger, and is very rare.

BRIGHTER television images are promised as the result of the invention of a new "cooled tele-eye" or cathode ray tube which is described in a patent (No. 2,124,224) granted to John C. Batchelor, New York City.
TO RESIGN: One of most colorful of the nation's legislators announced last week his intention of resigning. "I would have resigned this year,"

IF a young gentleman named Tyrone Power, recently arrived in town, had been discovered at the corner of Broadway and Forty-fifth Street one day last week, proclaiming, in a manner reminiscent of the Count of Monte Cristo rising from the sea, that the world was his, no one of generous disposition could have taken a reasonable exception.

Securities traded on the New York Curb Exchange of companies that are in bankruptcy, receivership or reorganization have been listed as follows: Arcturus Radio Tube Company common; Grand National Films, Inc., common;

America's greatest light-harness horses will compete this week at the Good Time mile track in Goshen, N. Y., picturesquely nestled among the Orange County hills. The annual Grand Circuit meeting will start tomorrow afternoon at 2 o'clock, to continue through the week, the daily programs to consist of four races, with total purses aggregating nearly $100,000.

COLLEGE professors strike a uniformly lower average than students, and house wives universally occupy first place on the "quiz" program, topping lawyers, teachers and others in professional life, according to no less an authority than Professor Quiz, who ought to know, since he has been described as the "man who knows all the answers."
Music Hall of the Air presents Henrietta Schumann, pianist; Viola Philo, soprano, and a string quartet in an hour concert: WJZ, 12:30 P. M.

Mineral wool purchased last year by American builders and home owners would completely insulate a home two miles wide, one mile deep and a mile and a half high with a four-inch blanket of heat and cold protection on all side walls and roof.

A concentrated and energetic movement to make pleasure boating more convenient for yachtsmen was launched yesterday by the appointment of a new national committee in the American Power Boating Association for the development of municipal boat basins.

Milk said to keep sterile and fresh at room temperatures without spoiling for as long as three and four months has been developed in the laboratories of the E. I. duPont de Nemours Co. of Wilmington, Del.

WHILE reports of world unrest sweep down the megacycle lanes from Manchukuo, Hankow and Madrid, and ambitious nations on the Continent pour a steady stream of propaganda into mighty radio beams, the Scandinavian countries, like peoples on some other planet, speak down the wave-lengths with reassuring tones.

Jean Dupuy of France today scored an easy victory in the international championships for Class X outboard motor boats. Dupuy finished the twenty-four-kilometer course far ahead of all other contenders in 18 minutes 34 1-5 seconds.

The men's shirt trade was thrown into confusion last week by unofficial reports that the new shrinkage rules on cotton-textile fabrics also apply to finished garments. As a result, the National Association of Shirt and Pajama Manufacturers has arranged to meet with the National Retail Dry Goods Association on the subject.

Woody Abernathy, veteran Buffalo outfielder, was operated on today to relieve a fracture of the skull received during a Syracuse-Buffalo International League baseball game and his physicians said his condition was "reasonably good."

The first comprehensive statistics analysis of the social and economic background of students aided in this city by the National Youth Administration was made public yesterday by Miss Helen M. Harris, regional director of the Federal agency.

Mrs. Emma C. Bergdoll, mother of Grover Cleveland.Bergdoll, World War draft dodger, filed suit in Delaware County Court today against her daughter-in-law to recover $60,000 in securities and property described as a 'loan."
George Bernard Shaw, who, by his own account, was something of a playwright in his day, has done it again. He has produced a new play.

THE Postoffice Department announced last week that firstday sales at Washington on July 28 of the 6c redorange John Quincy Adams "Presidential" stamp totaled $13,931.04, including $6,185.82 at the Philatelic Agency. This represents 232,184 copies, of which 97,428 were used on first-day covers.

Colonel Harry B. Salter, chief auditor of New Jersey since 1917 died at Fitkin Memorial Hospital Neptune Township, tonight follow ing an emergency operation. His age was 65. Dr. George N. J. Sommer of Trenton, who had been treating Colonel Salter since he was stricken at his Summer home in Sea Girt on July 29.

FLORENCE. OF the various problems presented by the topic of "Modern Taste and Old Music," debated at the "Third International Musical Congress" held in conjunction with the Florence Festival, the least theoretical and most appreciated was the question of the art of regie in the mounting of old works.

Sigma Mines, Quebec, established new high records in production and tonnage handled in July. the figures being $150,928 from 19,215 tons for an average recovery of $7.85 a ton. Production in June was $146,315 from 18,535 tons for an average of $7.89.
