Warner Oland, famous as an actor in Hollywood Oriental roles, died today at 3 P. M. (9 A. M., E. S. T.), at the age of 57. Death came at a Stockholm hospital where he had been ill of pneumonia.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Frank Graves of 16309 Crocheron Avenue, Flushing, of the engagement of their niece, Miss Kathleen CuthbertVines, to Francis H. Pfaff, son of Mrs. Edward Franz Pfaff of Spuyten Duyvil and the late Mr. Pfaff.

America's 150-year-old patent system will be subjected to searching examination by the Department of Commerce in cooperation with the Department of Justice and Federal Trade Commission In the "monopo]y" investigation by the temporary national economic committee, it was learned today.

The New York Central Railroad asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today for authority to borrow $5,000,000 from the National City Bank of New York for improvement of its lines and repair of its rolling stock.

Samuel Kahn, president of the Market Street Railway Company, sent yesterday a letter to the manager of utilities of the city and county of San Francisco, offering to recommend to Market Street Railway stockholders the sale of the company's operating properties to the city for $12,500,000.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Allen Taylor in a recent letter to THE TIMES denies that the Kellogg-Briand pact makes war an "illegal thing." Then he must take up the cudgels with former Secretary of State Stimson, whose phrase it is; with M. Briand, who said that henceforth war was "branded with illegality";

So much of paragraph 30, Special Orders 168, dated July 21, 1938, as relates to 2d Lt. Robert Parkinson, F.A.-Res., is revoked. (2d M.A.). 2d Lt. Nathaniel Goodrich, F.A.-Res., 332 E. 19th St., New York City, 566th Field Artillery, is ordered to active duty Aug. 7 at White Plains Military Reservation, Great Bend, N. Y., for training. Date of rank: July 24, 1938. He will revert to an inactive status Aug. 20.

IT is not new for the characters of a novel to be taken from life, but it is unusual for a novel to be adapted by its author into a play and to have the very people about whom she wrote take their character parts.

Again, as before the World War, Germany is beginning to bristle with fortifications along virtually all her winding frontiers. They mark the final stages of her rearmament and make good the boast of her spokesman that Germany is one vast fortress able to defy any threats of invasion.

Byron Scott Dickson of 354 West Twenty-third Street, pianist and basso, died Wednesday night in St. Vincent's Hospital of.heart disease. He was born in Greenwich Village fifty-three years ago. During two seasons he toured with David Bispham.

Mr. and Mrs. Frederick H. Leonhardt of Douglaston, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothea Louise Leonhardt, to Dr. Edward Stroh Jr. of this city, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stroh of Sunbury, Pa.

AFTER seeing a demonstration in Detroit of the Hudson 112's dual-braking system, Joseph A. Anglada, consulting automotive engineer of New York, remarked recently that he found "nothing left to be desired" in the car's equalized hydraulic brakes backed up by a reserve mechanical brake operating from the same pedal.
With a total of 111 boats sailing over three different courses, the eighth weekly regatta of the Barnegat Bay Yacht Racing Association saw several thrilling finishes today.
Mistah Crump don't 'low no easy riders here; Mistah Crump don't 'low no easy riders here. We don't care what Mistah Crump don't 'low;

Dr. Jerome Kaufman purchased a new five-room home on Lakeview Drive in the Westminster Ridge section of White Plains from the County Housing Corporation, builders. It occupies a plot 75 by 140 feet. The latter also sold to Robert Disney Schroeder a five-room house on Hall Avenue, in the same section, on a plot 90 by 150 feet.

IN the hottest of Summer days dresses for cool Autumn weather are born. Their very freshness of line and newness of color and decoration bring comfort to the heart of the fashion writer; she thinks rather of crisp breezes than sweltering streets as she views them-to be sure, airconditioned showrooms facilitate her mental gymnastics.

A glider pilot was struck and killed by his own craft today a moment after he bailed out in midair. His parachute brought his body to earth. The pilot, Werner Belchs, was forced to leave his glider during a thunderstorm after he had reached 17,700 feet in an altitude record attempt.

While Georgia's bitter United States Senatorial campaign increased in intensity, interest centered today on President Roosevelt's visit to his adopted State during which he will make two speeches next week.

Two hundred Americans are going to Nova Scotia this week to study the widely discussed adult education and cooperative movement which is directed by St. Francis Xavier University and supported by Catholic and Protestant groups alike.

Estate. not more than $2,500 real and not more than $2,000 personal. To daughter. Jeanie A. Martin, 202-22 45th Drive, Bayside, executrix, $50; son. Henry E. Luebbers. 104-39 204th St., Hollis, $1; residue in equal shares to grandsons, Charles A. and Jean A. Martin, 202-22 45th Drive, Bayside.
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. and her 18-day-old son, Franklin 3d, left Pennsylvania Hospital today. for the home of Mrs. Roosevelt's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Eugene du Pont,

Declaring that the need for improved relations between management and employes and management and consumers is being slowly recognized, Lieut. Col. Ralph K. Strassman, vice president of the Ward Wheelock Company, Philadelphia advertising agency, yesterday asserted that industry is beginning to assume its social responsibility.

The Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary, steaming for a record crossing and due to dock here early tomorrow, has set a new mark for the best day's run westbound. The ship traveled 790 miles from noon Friday to noon yesterday at an average speed of 31.6 knots, according to a radio message sent yesterday to the offices here by Commodore Robert B. Irving, master of the ship.

Certain London hospitals have been forced to limit the admission of infectious cases owing to a shortage of nurses. The number of women entering the nursing profession has become fewer every year since the war, and of those who do enter it 50 per cent now leave without completing their training.
Stephen Williams Carey Jr. of Montclair, N. J., and Falmouth, a sportsman and philanthropist, died suddenly last night at his Summer home in the Quissett section of mouth. His age was 71.

An air attack-by fastflying and well-armed Jersey mosquitos-disrupted the routine of the C. M. T. C., for coast ar tillery training here today. Mosquitos have plagued the Fort Hancock reservation for several weeks but today invaded the place in unprecedented numbers.

The Canadian fishing seems to be just about as spotty as our own, when it comes to fresh water. One friend of ours just came back from a trip to Quebec where he found the water low and clear, and the trout unwilling to rise to a fly except early in the morning and late in the afternoon.

IN less than a month speed pilots from all over the country will be winging their way to Cleveland for the eighteenth annual air races. The dates have been set as Sept. 3, 4 and 5 for the 1938 event, minimum cash prizes and international trophies have been announced by the Henderson brothers--Clifford W. and Philip T.--as urs totaling $102,750.

OFFICIALS of the American Contract Bridge League have made a determined effort to attract public attention to the national tournament now going on at Asbury Park, N. J. Much more thought than in former years was given to advance publicity.

AFAINT ray of sunshine breaking through the dark financial clouds hovering over the railroads was seen by officials of Eastern railroads as they scanned the first reports on the effect of the new 2 1/2-cent a mile coach fare which became effective July 25 for an eighteen-month trial period.

The above dwelling, recently completed in the Mayfair Acres community near North White Plains, Westchester County, and purchased by William M. Terry, presents an interesting example of small-home possiabilities erected on a good-sized plot. The house was built and designed by the Homecraft Associates, developers of the property in Greenburgh Township. It occupies a landscaped plot of one-third of an acre Dn Plymouth Road. The house contains five rooms with tiled bathroom and complete cellar,

AS the vacation season nears its peak so many photographers are taking landscapes that it is a rare mountain or valley near any popular resort that will not, after the Summer is ended, be preserved as a snapshot in some family album.

Danny M. Endweiss, representing the Newark Athletic Club, won the national junior A. A. U. three-meter diving title today. Endweiss, a member of the Yale University swimming team, scored 104.30 points to beat his nearest competitor, Dan Davis of the St. George Dragon Club, Brooklyn, who totaled 100.69.

Paul Brummer, 50, veteran endurance swimmer, today completed a seventeen-mile swim across Lake Champlain. The New Yorker entered the water at Port Kent, N. Y., yesterday afternoon and, after swimming for 12 hours 43 minutes, came ashore early today.
Of the sixtyeight years that have passed since Italy: became a unified kingdom with Rome as its capital, by far the greater part has seen the church and State in sharp conflict.

Father Divine's "angels" have just acquired a 500-acre estate opposite President Roosevelt's family seat on the Hudson River, and a fifty-room Harlem residence for the Negro preacher-thus indicating that their movement is enjoying a lusty expansion.

THE original conception of the Central Pacific, which, with the Union Pacific, was to complete the first through railway route across the United States, was Theodore Dehone Judah's.

A "more aggressive and vigorous attitude" toward gambling, particularly the numbers racket, was urged on Essex police officials today by William A. Wachenfeld, Prosecutor. He denied that his move had resulted from a recent conference here with investigators for District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey of New York.
Stephen Williams Carey Jr. of Montclair, N. J., and Falmouth, a sportsman and philanthropist, died suddenly last night at his Summer home in the Quissett section of mouth. His age was 71.

An air attack-by fastflying and well-armed Jersey mosquitos-disrupted the routine of the C. M. T. C., for coast ar tillery training here today. Mosquitos have plagued the Fort Hancock reservation for several weeks but today invaded the place in unprecedented numbers.

The dates have been set as Sept. 3, 4 and 5 for the 1938 event, minimum cash prizes and international trophies have been announced by the Henderson brothers--Clifford W. and Philip T.--as urs totaling $102,750.
With the shift in the style of attractions at Jones Beach and Randalls Island from musical comedies to grand operas, there is also a shift in the personnel of the dance.
A proposal to restore the two-thirds rule in the 1940 Democratic convention may become a rallying point for anti-Administration Democrats if President Roosevelt stands for a third term.

In a provocative article in the current Harper's, Roy Helton raises two questions regarding President Roosevelt's goal of an annual income of $100,000,000,000 for the American people to be achieved within the next decade.

RELEASE of the "B" section of advance pages of the American Standard Postage Stamp Catalogue discloses that the world's rarest piece of postal paper, British Guiana's octagonal 1-cent magenta of 1856, continues to be priced at $50,000.
Bonds called last week for redemption before maturity were in the largest volume in several weeks, both in the number of individual calls and the size of some of the single retirements.

TOWN HOME: Father Divine, Negro evangelist, was presented last week by his followers (who call him "God") with a fifty-room town home. The brownstone Harlem mansion, at 122d Street and Madison Avenue, has a telephone and dictaphone system to carry the Father's message-"Peace, it's wonderful!"--throughout the building.

SPONSORED by the New Hudson River Group, a Westchester Outdoor Sculpture Show is under way in the garden of the Southern Colonial House, River Road, Scarborough-on-Hudson, to be current until Aug. 14.
Further benefits in treating lobar pneumonia with rabbit serum, rather than with horse serum, are reported in The Journal of the American Medical Association.

The Marine Midland Trust Company has brought suit in Colombia against the Department of Tolima for deposit of revenues as collateral for the department's external twenty-year 7 per cent bonds outstanding in the amount of $2,112,000.

Charles Michelson the Democratic party's publicity director, said today that the only result of the Republican Program Committee's meeting at Chicago was to show that "the minority party hasn't the slightest idea where it is going or how it shall get to any destination."
The first issue of La Difesa della Razza [the Defense of the Race] a fortnightly magazine for the propagation, of the new Fascist race theories, was put on sale throughout Italy today.

Liquidation carried all deliveries of grain futures to new low levels for the season today on the North American exchanges. September wheat at the extreme sold down to 63 1/2 cents a bushel, a new low since early in 1933, while December corn touched 50 1/2 cents, new ground since 1934.
ATHENS.- Vast changes have come over Greece since the successful revolution, headed by General John Metaxas with the consent of King George II, on Aug. 4, 1936.

Any answer to the question, "How long will the breathing spell in Europe last?" must be so hedged with qualifications and take into consideration so many factors that it can scarcely be clear cut. It seems, first,

The 389th Infantry, United States Army Reserve, under the command of Colonel Franklin A. Loomis of Binghamton, N. Y., will begin two weeks training today at Fort Niagara, N. Y. The commissioned and enlisted personnel consists of up-State New Yorkers.

Under an order entered by the Federal Trade Commission, Askin's Retail Stores, Inc., 425 Fourth Avenue, New York, is required to cease and desist from "certain unfair methods of competition" in connection with the sale of wearing apparel and other merchandise.

LAREVUE INTERNATIONLALE DE MUSIQUE, published in Brussels, made its first appearance in June. Its founders are Jean Absil, professor of the Royal Conservatory of Brussels; Dr. Stanislas Dotremont, professor at the Ecole superieure d'humanisme, and Charles Leirens, director of La Maison d'Art. A list of collaborators contains the names of many musicians, critics, writers of international repute.

Edwin S. Smith, member of the National Labor Relations Board, characterized as "reckless and untrue" today statements made about him by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, in a speech to the Massachusetts State Federation convention at Worcester yesterday.

An inconspicuous funeral was held here today for Baron Zeffner-Spitzenberg, Vienna University professor, leading monarchist and confidential advisor of former Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg. He died in the concentration camp in Dachau, Germany, to which he was sent in March.

Miss Leila Porter Decker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin Walter Decker of this city, was married this afternoon to Wilson Losee Anderson, son of Mrs. James Smith Anderson of Newark. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Frank Kingdon, president of Newark University, in Calvary Methodist Church, here, of which he is the former pastor.

Ralph M. Bashore, State Secretary of Labor and Industry, today accepted an invitation of Secretary Perkins to serve on a committee to draft legislation to supplement the new Federal Wage ,and Hour Law. Mr. Bashore said the committee would try to determine which- industries could be considered "interstate"' under 'the new Federal act,.

Flight Lieutenant A. J. Holmes, the Sussex cricket captain. has accepted the invitation to go to South Africa as manager of the M. C. C. team during the Winter, it was announced recently in - England.
The Oxford-Cambridge cricketers showed the way in their match with the Kingston eleven today, declaring at 273 for five wickets in the first innings.
Miss Carol Durham, daughter of Mrs. Leicester Durham and the late Mr. Durham, was married in St. John's Church here today to Robert C. Plumb, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Plumb of Briarcliff Manor.
"STOREVIK" is the name of an island in a Norwegian fjord; and the book is complete in itself. But readers of "Northern Summer" must at once be given the glad news of renewed acouaintance.

This correspondent has just come back from visiting the American continet at the front line beyond the Ebro and he found them occupying much the same terrain as that in which they suffered a bad defeat at the beginning of April.

Dr. J. Eastman Sheehan, plastic surgeon, of 833 Fifth Avenue, sailed on the Italian liner Conte di Savoia yesterday to resume work as consulting surgeon in charge of the General Mola Hospital at San Sebastian, Spain.

For sixteen years prior to 1934, Treasury Department regulations for the administration of revenue laws declared that a corporation realized no gain or loss from the purchase or sale of its own capital stock, commonly called "treasury stock."
John Carson, consumers' counsel of the National Bituminous Coal Commission, today urged consumers and dealers of domestic sizes of coal to purchase now at least a part of their Winter requirements.
Sydney Wooderson, world mile record-holder, failed today in attempting to set a new mark for 1,500 meters. He was clocked in 3:49, compared with Jack Lovelock's universal standard of 3:47.8.

WHITE MOUNTAINS, N. H.-Sky rides by moonlight will be featured this week at the Aerial Tramway, Franconia Notch, for ascent of Cannon Mountain, 4,000 feet above sea level. Picnic suppers will be given by several parties on the summit.

The Good Humor man ahs run afoul of the Federal Trade Commission. The commission announced today that it had issued a complaint charging the Good Humor Corporation of America of Maspeth, L. I., with furnishing to others the means of conducting lotteries in the sale of the frozen confections.

On an "art journey" with visits to the art museums of Boston and Harvard scheduled for tomorrow and Tuesday, a group of teachers in training at the State Teachers College, Kutztown, Pa., are engaged in what is said to be the only experiment of the type in Pennsylvania's teachers colleges.

ATLANTIC CITY.-The Atlantic City festival of music and allied arts, a community enterprise sponsored by musical groups of the resort, will present its first concert next Saturday night at the Hotel Chelsea.

Miss Caroline Schroeder Johnson, daughter of Mrs. Moulton K. Johnson of Washington and Jamestown and the late Captain Johnson, U. S. N., and a granddaughter of the late Rear Admiral Seaton Schroeder, U. S. N., became the bride of Gardiner Emmons of Boston, son of Mrs. Robert Wales Emmons, this afternoon in St. Matthew's Episcopal Church at Jamestown. The Rev.

County chairmen, representing organizations of the Citizens Military Training Camp Association in New Jersey and civilian aides to the Secretaries of War of New York and New Jersey were guests of honor this afternoon at a review of the Camp Dix CMTC Regiment.

FLAVIUS JOSEPHUS: HIS TIME AND HIS CRITICS. By Leon Bernstein. 8vo. New York: Liveright Publishing Corporation. $5. A biographical study. THE EARLY WRITINGS OF FREDERICK JACKSON TURNER. Compiled by Everett E. Edwards. 12mo. Madison, Wis.: The University of Wisconsin Press, Bascom Hall. $3.50.

Many members of the Summer colony and their house parties attended the annual ball held tonight in the Colonial ballroom and the Japanese Room of the Meadow Club to mark the conclusion of the club's invitation tennis tournament. The visiting tennis stars were the guests of honor at the ball.

The warfare between Walter E. O'Hara, the ousted general manager and president of the Narragansett Racing Association, and Robert Emmet Quinn, Democratic Governor of Rhode Island, probably is about to enter upon a new phase.

The ninth annual New York State women's golf championship will be played over the Cherry Valley Country Club course starting Tuesday and continuing through Saturday, with Mrs. Harry McNaughton, the former Miss Marion Turpie, the champion, on hand to defend her laurels.

The International Wool Secretariat, cooperative publicity and research organization of the South African, Australian and New Zealand wool growers, has proposed to the Associated Wool Industries in America that it take over part of the latter's publicity and educational work for wool products in the United States, it was learned here today.

A young Hindu woman has replaced Miss Madeleine Slade, daughter of a British rear admiral, as the personal attendant of Mohands K. Gandhi. She is Dr. Sushila Nayar, who is a graduate of the Hardinge Medical College at Delhi.

Lou Fette, the 31-year-old big league sophomore, tossed a six-hit game and drove in the only run with a single today to give the Bees a 1-to-O decision over the Cubs. The defeat dropped the Cubs from a tie for third with the Reds to fourth place in the National League.

The New York Football Giants have acquired the services of three more newcomers for the 1938 National League championship season, it was announced yesterday by John V. Mara, the club's president. With the receipt of the new contracts,

IT has been my good luck to know many of the people in the world's news. Most of them have had an uncanny news sense. Mary Garden was such a person. For years she put streamer headlines across Chicago's front pages. No opera season ever opened without a statement from her.

THE names of Dvorak and the Czech Philharmonic Orchestra on an album may be regarded as a guarantee of something worth while, and when that of Pablo Casals is added to the combination, no excuse for apprehension remains.

Levy Douglas Wines, retired high school educator and civic leader, died today at the age of 86. He was in the Mathematics Department of the high school here for fifty years, and for forty-eight years had been treasurer of the University of Michigan School of Music.
Continuing the Atlantic survey flights of 1938, the four-engine Dieseel-powered monoplane Nordwind of the Duetsche Lufthansa is due to land in Port Washington, L. I., tomorrow at 1 P. M.

Wilberforce James Whiteman, 80-year-old father of Paul Whiteman, orchestra leader, formerly called the king of jazz, declared yesterday that during the forty years he had been director of music in the public schools of Denver, Col., he had never allowed one note of jazz to be played in the schools.
The theft of jewelry valued at $30,000 from Mrs. Orson D. Munn, wife of the editor and publisher of The Scientific American, was revealed here tonight.

A happy and excited brideto-be, Miss Eileen Wallace, 24, of Peterhead, Scotland, rode across Northern Manitoba today in a train en route to Churchill, where she will board the Arctic supply boat Nascopie and be taken to Arctic Bay to meet her fiance, Alan Scott.
Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Henry Talbot Myers of this place, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lenora Elizabeth Myers, to Charles Ford Reese of Baltimore, Md.

An armistice seemed to have been in effect yesterday in the liquor price war that began Friday when the Schenley interests withdrew two of their major whisky brands from the protection of the Feld-Crawford act price maintaining contract.

THE remaining eighteen values of Peru's picturesque series arrived last week from Lima, supplementing the five described in these columns on July 3. Of the newcomers, eight are for ordinary postage and ten for airmail use. Denominations, colors,

The annual "In-the-Garden" Fashion Show is planned for Aug. 16, with a number of the younger set of the Summer colony modeling styles. Miss Sophie Trasel of Haverford, Pa., is in charge of committee arrangements. Mrs. A. Mansfield Patterson of New York will announce the events.

APICIUS, the Roman gourmet, is reputed to have set out promptly in search of African shrimp when he heard that they were bigger than those in his own waters. His epicurean journey strengthened the precedent for those travelers whose routes are
In marked contrast to the disappointment in the Middle West over wheat yields and prices is the optimism among livestock men, both producers and commission agents.
Some perspiring political candidates, many of them still in the midst of hot campaigns, got cheering news from the Senate Campaign Expenditures Committee today.

Word was received here today of the sudden death at his home in Wheeler, Ala., of Colonel Joseph. Wheeler Jr., veteran of the Spanish-American and World Wars and the son of the famous Civil War Confederate leader, General Joseph Wheeler.

Viscount Runciman, British mediator in the Czech-Sudeten German dispute, lunched today at the British Legation, where he met Hugh R. Wilson, United States Ambassador to Germany, with whom he conversed at length.
Finding the heavy track to his liking, A. Compton's Sun Egret romped home an easy winner in the $5,000-added Roger Williams Handicap before a crowd of 18,000 at Narragansett Park today, to pay $6.20.

The State Medlation Board made new efforts to settle the Woodlawn Cemetery strike yesterday as cemetery officials renewed their charge that the United Cemetery Workers, Local 293, a C. I. O. affiliate, had repudiated a valid contract in ordering the walkout.
Seven times this rainy, squally afternoon world records for speed boating were broken in a phenomenal series of piloting performances on the Charles River Basin, and six of them will go on the books.
Former President Herbert Hoover said today that the way for the nation to meet what he termed the two dominant issues of the moment was to "replace this rubber-stamp Congress with independent men."

Miss Frances Colby, only daughter of Mrs. Amelia Brinsmade Colby and the late Commander Fred B. Colby, United States Navy, was married at the First Congregational Church, Washington Green, this afternoon to Jerome SullivanBlack of St. Paul's School, N. H., grandson of the late Fred W. Church of Hudson, N. Y.

Hammering eighteen hits off five pitchers, the Red Sox walloped the Tigers, 14 to 8, today. The victory assured Boston of taking the three-game series, which ends tomorrow, and ran Detroit's losing streak to four straight.

THE title of this sheaf of poems is not to be construed as ironically as it sounds. Raymond Holden is not concerned with a March of the Ants, that sardonic orchestral suggestion in "He Who Gets Slapped." Mr.

Already distinguished as the first fighter in ring history to hold the world featherweight and welterweight crowns at one time, the dynamic Henry Armstrong, California sensation, will strive on Wednesday night to attain a position that has no parallel in the annals of the ring sport.

Senator Alben W. Barkley was pressing forward early today to a larger and larger majority in Kentucky's Democratic primary, carrying the colors of President Roosevelt and the New Deal toward apparent victory over Governor A. B. (Happy) Chandler, his challenger for nomination to the Senate.

The first year of operation of the Consumer Retailer Relations Council has "demonstrated that consumers and retailers can work together on a program of mutual benefit," Harold W. Brightman, chairman of the council, declared in the first annual report of the organization.

With a strike of about 1,000 sailors deferred today until Tuesday, officers of the Canadian Seamen's Union and the Canada steamship lines prepared tonight to open negotiations for a labor contract on the Great Lakes and the St. Lawrence River.
TO live in Venezuela is to learn not to complain of the high cost of living in New York. Dollar for dollar, item for item, one will find prices about twice as high as up north.
LONDON. IS any special knowledge needed for the writing of a novel? This question has been discussed in the three last issues of The Times Literary Supplement. Richard Aldington.

One of the longest and, at the same time, least-known land frontiers in the history of political geography is that which in the later nineteenth and early twentieth century marked the boundary between China and Asiatic Russia.

Island Bird spread proud sails tonight before the admiration of hundreds of boat owners who watched the craft duplicate last year's feat and capture the coveted Governor's Cup in the Chesapeake Bay log canoe race.

Miss Dorothy Elizabeth Deishley, daughter of Mrs. Josephine D. Williams of Columbus, Ohio, was married yesterday morning to Edward J. McGoldrick Jr., son of State Supreme Court Justice and Mrs. Edward J. McGoldrick, of this city, in the rectory of the Church of Our Lady of Lourdes, West 142d Street.

Ratification of the proposed agreement between the National Maritime Union and the American Merchant Marine Institute was recommended yesterday by a coastwise conference of national officers and port agents of the union after a four-hour discussion at its headquarters, 126 Eleventh Avenue, the C. I. O. affiliate announced.

IN the current (thirty-third) ex hibition by self-formed groups of New York artists, at the Municipal Art Galleries, the print display on the ground floor rather runs away with the honors Eight makers of graphics are represented, including Fritz Eichenberg Hugh Miller and Dan Rico.

A happy and excited brideto-be, Miss Eileen Wallace, 24, of Peterhead, Scotland, rode across Northern Manitoba today in a train en route to Churchill, where she will board the Arctic supply boat Nascopie and be taken to Arctic Bay to meet her fiance, Alan Scott.
Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Henry Talbot Myers of this place, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lenora Elizabeth Myers, to Charles Ford Reese of Baltimore, Md.

An armistice seemed to have been in effect yesterday in the liquor price war that began Friday when the Schenley interests withdrew two of their major whisky brands from the protection of the Feld-Crawford act price maintaining contract.

THE remaining eighteen values of Peru's picturesque series arrived last week from Lima, supplementing the five described in these columns on July 3. Of the newcomers, eight are for ordinary postage and ten for airmail use. Denominations, colors,
Mr. and Mrs. Robert Schey gave a dinner at the Maidstone Club today for Mr. and Mrs. William Carter Dickerman, Dr. and Mrs. John F. Erdmann, Mr. and Mrs. A. Wallace Chauncey and others.

Lou Ambers drove through a five-round session with his sparring partners today and will have only one more ring workout before he defends his lightweight title against Henry Armstrong at the Polo Grounds on Wednesday night.

The mystery of Esposa's bad start in the Merchants and Citizens Handicap yesterday was explained today by Jockey Nick Wall. He asserted that the famous mare, who was practically left at the post, had been trained to walk quietly into the gate and stop.

Over the objections of the AmericanSouth African Line, Inc., which wanted an exclusive subsidy, the Maritime Commission today granted two steamship companies applications for operating-differential subsidy agreements on the trade route from Atlantic Coast ports to South and East Africa.

NEWARK, N. J., Aug. 7.-Four laborers were injured seriously this afternoon when a brick wall they were demolishing at the Columbian Laundry at 280 South Twelfth Street here collapsed. The men were standing on scaffolding about twenty feet from the floor. It broke as the wall caved inward and they fell to the floor in a shower of bricks.

Bad weather forced a halt to Britain's mock aerial warfare today after it had caused six real casualties. A Royal Air Force bomber, participating in air defense exercises with 900 warplanes, crashed and caught fire, killing its five occupants, during the night at Great Barton village, near Bury St. Edmunds, Suffolk.
Avoiding controversial subjects for the time being, Walter Wanger has announced two films to follow "Trade Winds," which Tay Garnett will direct' with Joan Bennett and Fredric March.

Clyde R. Jeffords, for the last nineteen years head of the Latin department of the Newtown High School, Elmhurst, Queens, died suddenly yesterday of a heart attack at his residence, 161-43 Eighty-sixth Avenue, Jamaica, Queens. He was born in Ann Arbor, Mich, sixty-one years ago.

The engagement of Miss Elsie E. Kingsbury, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Percy C. Kingsbury of this city, to Louis Frederick Lubrecht, son of Dr. and Mrs. James L. Lubrecht of Lock Haven, Pa., has been announced.

Even as the airplane flies, it's a long, long way from the frontier in Europe where the Teutons jostle the Slavs and the frontier in Asia where the Slavs, diluted in the interval but still there, face up to the new outposts of the Japanese.
Surveys certainly reveal strange but interesting matters, and the investigators of the Conservation Department recently uncovered an old statute that tends to rob them of some revenues.

French foreign trade figures for July were better than those for June. The import surplus was reduced to 1,216,000,000 francs, compared with 1,520,000,000 francs in June, and the high record of more than 2,000,000,000 francs in December, 1937.
Duties on imports of distilled liquors and wines declined approximately $5,000,000 in the last fiscal year, compared with the previous year, James H. Moyle, Commissioner of Customs, announced today.

The National Labor Relations Board announced today that a total of 15,561 cases under the Wagner act had been handled by it since the Fall of 1935. Of these, 11,765 cases have been closed, leaving 3,796 cases pending as of July 1, 1938. The total number of cases involved 3,776,959 workers, the board said.

Ken Murray, the comedian of musical comedy, variety, radio and the films, will be making his dramatic stage debut this Fall. Laurence Schwab has engaged Mr. M. for the leading role in "Once Upon a Night," the Milton Lazarus comedy which is scheduled to open at the Morosco the week of Sept. 12.

Plans are completed for the entertainment of more than 5,000 persons from all parts of New England at the exhibition of home-made products which opens at the Chase Homestead here. tomorrow morning. The Craftsmen's Fair, which will continue for a week, is the fifth staged by the League of New Hampshire Arts and Crafts.

The engagement of Miss Jean Whaples to Dr. George Crawford of this city, son of the late Dr. J. Lynn Crawford of Cedar Rapids, Iowa, has been announced here by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Heywood H. Whaples of Farmington, Conn.
Douglas is not a common Irish baptismal name, and it is something of a coincidence that one Irishman is Douglas Corrigan and another Irishman is

More than 100 men and women from nineteen States, Canada and New Zealand who are interested in traffic safety on the highway from a standpoint of teaching and administration will begin here tomorrow sessions of the National Institute for Traffic Safety Training.

The general plan of reorganization for the Prudence Company, Inc., proposed last April by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, has been approved by Judge Grover M. Moscowitz, according to an announcement by Jerome Thralls, special representative of the RFC.

Earl Burgwaldt, 18 years old, of 839 Sixty-ninth Street, Brooklyn, was drowned this afternoon while bathing in Davis Pond, near here. His father, John C. Burgwaldt, who was swimming about fifty feet away when the youth suddenly went down, made an unsuccessful effort to locate the body.

The 227,000 delegates who attended the 478 conventions and seventy exhibits held in New York City during the fiscal year ended April 30, 1938, made direct expenditures of upward of $20,000,000, according to the annual report of the convention and visitors' bureau of the Merchants Asosciation, issued for publication today.

Displaying entirely too much power for the opposition. the Burnt Mills Polo Club defeated the Pelicans by the score of 7 to 5 at Schley Field today. After an even first period and a scoreless second session, Burnt Mills took the lead in the third with two goals and set the pace for the rest of the game.

The Irish Mail steamer Cambria arrived today at Kingstown with three survivors of the British trawler Alcazar, which sank after a collision with the Cambria in a thick fog between the Irish and Welsh coasts.

Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 40 per cent of capacity, up 3 points from the rate in the two preceding weeks and a gain of 8 points from the rate of three weeks before.
Mr. and Mrs. Henry O. Talmadge of New York entertained at the weekly buffet supper at the Bar Harbor tonight in honor of Mr. and Mrs. A. Barclay Ulman, their house guests.
Philadelphia's share in the Pennsylvania gasoline tax paid by the city's motorists has shrunk from one-half of the receipts to less than an eighth, the Bureau of Municipal Research reported today.

A young but distinguished native of the cool mountains of Southwest China, her first Summer in New York City, complicated by a heavy fur coat which cannot be taken off, was revealed yesterday as another victim of the current. heat wave.

Announcement was made here to day of the marriage on July 27 of George Holborn Snowden of 155 West Fifty-fifth Street, New York, son of Mrs. Mary Wynne Snowden of Field Point Road, Milford, and Miss Louise Adele Weider of New York City.

The Annalist Weekly Index of Wholesale Commodity Prices was 80.3 on Saturday, a loss of a full point compared with the preceding week. Grains suffered most; wheat dropping to the lowest point since the early part of 1933 on large crop prospects.

Perhaps the most beautiful modern expression of the Christian grace of hospitality is seen in the opening of the doors of the nations to the refugees of other lands, said Dr. Samuel Henry Prince, Professor of Sociology at Kings College, Halifax, N. S., in his sermon yesterday morning at St. Stephen's Protestant Episcopal Church, 128 West Sixty-ninth Street.
A prediction of firmer opposition to Administration legislation in the next session of Congress came today from Senator Burke, Democrat, of Nebraska, often a critic of Rooseveltian Policies.

The cotton market last week continued the decline which began after the issuance of the acreage report by the Department of Agriculture on July 8. At the low point of the week prices were 3/4 cent a pound below the high for July. Active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange last week showed net losses of 17 to 21 points.
Four States will hold primaries Tuesday. Idaho voters will nominate candidates for the United States Senate, for two seats in the House of Representatives and for Governor.

Mayor La Guardia has asked the PWA to cancel its offer of a $2,715,500 loan for use in constructing the new Hunter College administration building because the city can get the money independently at a lower interest rate, PWA officials disclosed yesterday.

Summertime heat is. poor. justification for allowing the fires of devotion to burn low, the Rev. R. Moffat Gillon said in his sermon yesterday morning at the West End Collegiate Reformed Church, West End Avenue at Seventy-seventh Street. Mr. Gillon is pastor of the Bruntsfield Church of Scotland, Edinburgh.

Christians should be so loyal to their faith that they may be recognized as different from non-Christians, said the Rev. Dr. William J. Shergold of the Congregational Church, Dorking, England, in a sermon yesterday morning at Holy Trinity ProtestantEpiscopal Church, Clinton and Montague Streets, Brooklyn.

In your issue of July 24 Godfrey N. Nelson discusses a proposal by Representative Emanuel- Celler for the limitation of income tax rates to stimulate investments in business enterprises. I do not propose to debate any of the principles advanced either by Mr. Nelson or Mr. Celler, but it seems to me that the personal income tax is less objectionable than the corporate income tax.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 81, which compared with 81.6 the week before, 81.5 two weeks before, 81.7 three weeks before and 81.2 four weeks before.
Supply contracts valued at $8,595,641 were awarded during the week ended Aug. 4 by fourteen Federal agencies under the provisions of the Public Contracts Act, the Labor Department announced today.

Looking back to the. part he played in the investigation of the Industrial Commission of 1898, E. Dana Durand, 66-year-old member of the United States Tariff Commission, says he is somewhat skeptical as to whether the present Temporary National Economic Committee, sometimes called the "Monopoly Committee," can do in a short period the kind of a job it has undertaken.

A violent campaign of agitation against the Czechs has broken out as the result of a reported assertion during the recent Sokol festivals in Prague that there were half a million Czechs in Vienna, which was practically a Czech city.
Chinese sources reported today that secret negotiations had been exposed by which-separatists were plotting an independent South China government pledged to close cooperation with Japan.

A few days ago the Attorneys General of fifteen different States, the Assistant Attorneys General of eight other States and the Solicitor General of New York met in Cleveland and formulated the following brief statement of the objectives of their conference:

Lancelot Nogben's new book, "Science for the Citizen," now a leading best seller in England, is to be published in an American edition by Knopf on Sept. 26. More than 40,000 copies have been printed thus far of the English edition, published in May.

Echoing a proposal advanced two years ago by the Rev. Dr. Frederic S. Fleming, rector of Trinity Parish, for a "moratorium on sermons," the Rev. David W. Norton, rector of the Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity,. Marlboro, Mass., declared yesterday afternoon at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, that many members of the clergy would welcome a sermon moratorium in midsummer.

Administration farm officials will learn this week whether they must poll farmers on the question of setting up a marketing quota on this year's corn crop. They will get their tip from a Federal crop reporting board's forecast, to be issued Wednesday, on the size of this year's corn crop.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, in addresses here and at East Hampton today, called for a new alignment of Christian faith and ideals to combat racial and religious persecution in the totalitarian countries and declared that public opinion must force nations to. renounce war, if there is to be any real guarantee of world peace.

Leaders of four powerful unions of the Committee for Industrial Organization today voted, after a forty-eighthour closed conference, to withdraw from Harry Bridges's C. I. O. Industrial Union Council-and charged, simultaneously, that the latter has worked hand in glove with the Communist party to the detriment of labor.

Moves toward church unity were denounced and contemporary "ideological programs" called in fundamental rebellion against the will of God in the annual statement of the Rev. Dr. Frederic S. Fleming, rector of Trinity parish, in its annual year book, made public yesterday.
Mr. and Mrs. Norman Kimball of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Janet Kathryn Kimball, to John DePew Miller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold J. Miller of Utica.

MUNICIPAL CHIEF MARINE ENGINEER (DIESEL)--Certifications will also be made from the resulting eligible list to fill vacancies in the position of marine engineer (Diesel). Vacancies--One In the Department of Public Works at $2,900; two as marine engineer (Diesel) in the Department of Public Works at $2,340 per annum.

Dr. and Mrs. Herbert Willey Meyer entertained at a large cocktail party today for exhibitors and judges of the fifth annual Sagamore Horse Show which was concluded this evening with a twilight party at the Sagamore Golf Club.

A home run by Frankie Kelleher in the overtime eighth inning enabled the Newark Bears to score a 3-to-2 victory over the Rochester Red Wings today in the nightcap of a double-header and gain an even break after dropping a 7-6 decision in the opener.

The French wholesale price index for July 30 stood at 652, compared with 654 a week earlier and 657 two weeks earlier. The slight decline in the index is ascribable chiefly to seasonal influences and results principally from the usual Summer cheapening of vegetables.

Prospects of a sharp rise for the Fall in the apparel and home accessories fields were seen today at the close of the first week of the women's, children's and infants' wear and accessories market and the china, glass, pottery and giftware shows.

Senator Barkley's comfortable lead over Governor Chandler is a victory for the Administration and the New Deal. It is true that the Governor himself in his campaign tried to blur this issue as much as possible. But as his success would have been hailed as a vital setback for the Administration, his defeat must be set down as a Roosevelt triumph.
A bitter political debate on the highly controversial subject of reapportionment is expected to hold the center of interest this week -at the Constitutional Convention.

The problems to be solved in the Far Eastern incidents between Russian and Japanese troops have caused some preoccupation here. Such international events do not create a favorable climate for prosperity in financial affairs.

The traditional services. of. the Fast of Ab, or the Black Fast, were observed in synagogues here yesterday. These services commemorate the anniversary of the destruction of the first temple in Jerusalem in the year 586 B. C. by Nebuchadnezzar and of the second by Titus- in 70 A. D.

Shad fishing, an industry that formed an important part of the springtime life of early New Yorkers, made a tremendous upward rise during the Spring of this year, according to a report of the Bureau of Fisheries of the Department of Commerce, quoted in a dispatch from Washington by The Associated Press.
Recent weeks have witnessed a slight improvement in orders placed with certain French industries, particularly textiles and chemicals, although metallurgy remains depressed.

The White Sox and Senators each went on seventeen-hit batting sprees today to split a double-header, the White Sox unleashing their big attack in the first game for a 14-to-5 triumph and the Senators in the second to win, 12 to 5.

Sherman Stearns and Morrie Elis of New York won the masters pair championship here today in a field of 52 pairs competing in the twelfth annual national contract bridge championships. They had a score of 1,506 1/2 match points.

Dr. Harold Dickinson Senior, former Professor an Anatomy and director of anatomical laboratories at New York University, died here Saturday in the French Hospital after a long illness at the age of 67.

While crowds filling the Coney Island beach watched in fear, Louis R. Purchase, 24-year-old airplane pilot. successfully made a forced landing at 1:50 P. M. yesterday in Dreamland Park, virtually the only unoccupied space along the entire beach front.
A Soviet army communique yesterday announced that Siberian territory had been "cleansed" of Japanese troops near Changkufeng heights. This was the result of a bitter threeday battle.

Liquidation was under way in oats and rye here last week. Oats closed with net losses of 7/8 to 1 1/4 cents compared with a week ago, with September at 22 3/4 cents, December 23 3/4 cents and May 25 3/8 cents a bushel. Rye was 2 3/4 to 3 1/4 cents a bushel lower.

Thirtyone outstanding candidates of the Camp Dix Citizens Military Training Camp regiment received medals at their final Sunday review this evening before about 8,000 relatives and friends of the 2,020 boys from New Jersey, New York and Delaware who will end their thirty-day training period on Wednesday.

In a tribute to Douglas Corrigan, transatlantic flier, the Rev. Dr. Christian F. Reisner, pastor of the Broadway Temple Methodist Church, at 174th Street, declared in his sermon last evening that the aviator was a refutation of all the gloomy forebodings concerning modern youth.

Cleveland Graphite Bronze Company-Quarter to June 30: Net profit, $70,380, after depreciation, but before-Federal income taxes, equal to 22 cents a share. Six months to June 30: Net profit, $2,456, after depreciation, but before Federal income taxes.

The directors of the Wisconsin- Council of Agriculture, said to represent 80,000 farmers in the State, adopted a sweeping protest today against operations of the National Labor Relations Act and the Wisconsin Labor Law, which they charged harmed the farmers' interests.

An agreement intended to end racial unrest in Harlem by guaranteeing to Negroes at least one-third of all white-collar jobs in Harlem retail establishments was announced yesterday by the Uptown Chamber of Commerce, acting for hundreds of independent and chain stores, and the Greater New York Coordinating Committee for Employment, representing more than 200 Negro organizations.
Despite the somewhat alarming news from the Far East, the feeling of disquiet concerning European affairs and the great "gold rush," the stock markets here have preserved commendable calm.

Arthur P. Korach, in 49 E 96th St; Frederic K. Huber, in 17 E 96th St; Mrs. V. W. Faesy. in 103 E 86th St; Alexander Leopold, in 136 E 36th St; Douglas L. Elliman Co., brokers. W. Donaldson, in 15 W 55th St, through Pease Elliman; Edward C. Ballou, in 340 E 57th St, through William A. White Sons;

Down in Sullivan Street, in the Lower West Side Playground of the Children's Aid Society, a stout boy of 12 regularly plays second base when a game of stickball is on. His name is Dante Piccoli. Up to a few years ago he was timid, his athletic prowess was limited and the other boys jeered at his excess weight.

The Giants experienced all the sensations yesterday of the man who opened a door, stepped in and then discovered that he had fallen down the elevator shaft. Instead of vaulting lightly nearer the top of the National League standing the New Yorkers hurtled downward, victims of a double defeat by the leading Pirates before 50,468 disapproving onlookers at the Polo Grounds.
Pirates Top Giants Twice Lead By 6 1/2 Games; Dodgers Take Two: Yanks Win

Employe groups in all branches of business and government throughout the city have contributed. $1,000,000 to date to the Greater New York Fund, Douglas P. Falconer, executive director of the campaign, announced yesterday.

American Business Shares, Inc., a mutual investment fund sponsored by Lord, Abbett Co., in its report for the first six months of this year, issued yesterday, shows an asset value for the capital stock of $3.31 a share, with investments valued at market quotations on June 30.

The marriage of Miss Margaret Josephine Anderson, daughter of the late Mrs. Neville T. Russell of East Orange and William T. Anderson of Essex Fells, to Ernest Everett Teed, son of Mrs. Ernest Royal Teed of Livingston, took place this afternoon in First Presbyterian Church, Orange.

Although the Dutch foreign exchange and gold markets had a series of nervous days this week owing to the sharp rise of the United States dollar and the keen demand for gold bars and coins, financial circles here suspect that this boom is only short-lived and consider it as just one of the many speculative seesaw movements which have repeatedly upset the foreign-exchange markets since the tripartite monetary agreement went into effect.

With burly Red Ruffing combining an eyedazzling two-hit game with Lou Gehrig's eighteenth home run and devastating doubles by Twinkletoes George Selkirk and Robert (Red) Rolfe, Marse Joe McCarthy's marauding Yankees ended their Western tour with a grand flourish today by thrashing the Indians, 7 to 0.

The need for proper identification and certification of rayon merchandise is stressed in a report of the Consumers Advisory Committee on Textiles of the Women's National Institute, which will be made public today by Mrs. Gertrude E. Fox, chairman of the committee. The report recommends testing and certification methods similar to those used in the "Crown Quality Control Plan" of American Viscose Corporation.
Mr. and Mrs. John James Ferguson, who were married Saturday in the Church of St. Mary of the Isle, Long Beach, L. I., are motoring to Canada on their wedding trip.

Erwin Blask of Germany claimed a new world record in the 16-pound hammer throw on a toss of 190 feet 8 5/8 inches today. The previous record was 189 feet 6 1/2 inches, established by Pat Ryan of the United States on Aug. 17, 1913.

Although Joseph Lanzetta, 12 years old, made elaborate plans for an unannounced departure on the liner Conte di Savoia to see his mother in Italy, he made one or two miscalculations and, as not infrequently happens in such cases, fell into the hands of the police instead.

The Japanese vessel Canberra Maru hurried toward Douglas Reef today to search for the missing Hawaii Clipper, but naval authorities expressed doubt that the craft would be found afloat because of a typhoon raging in the area.
A Signal Corps field telephone switchboard of a new type is one of several new items of equipment or new methods of procedure now being used in the Third Army manoeuvres here.

The four expelled and suspended officers of the United Automobile Workers of America turned to the rank and file membership today with an appeal for a special convention to oust the union's controlling international officers .

Winning both games of a double-header is an "iron man" feat, Buck Newsom of the Browns discovered today. He tried it, but after whipping the Athletics, 5 to 3, in the opener, Newsom weakened and was sent to the showers in the fourth inning of the second game, with Philadelphia leading, 7 to 0.

OUR cousins the English are said to have gone to their bookstores and bought 150,000 copies of Geoffrey Garratt's "Mussolini's Roman Empire,"* the American edition of which is published today. It isn't a particularly searching or surprising book, but it must have made some of the purchasers squirm. Mr. Garratt has an embarrassing thesis.

The completed half-year's results in our foreign trade harmonize in a striking way with the course of our home industries. Whereas merchandise exports for the past six months were in value the largest of any year since 1930 (when average prices of goods were 15 per cent higher), merchandise imports were smaller than in any corresponding period, except for the "depression years" 1932 to 1934 inclusive, since prewar days.

Douglas Corrigan, transatlantic flier, spent his last day in New York City yesterday making courtesy calls on persons who had contributed to the success of his reception. He visited the Empire State Building, Fort Hamilton, the navy yard in Brooklyn and Roosevelt and Mitchel flying fields and was the guest of honor at the home of George U. Harvey, Borough President of Queens.

Miss Muriel Elizabeth Saulpaugh, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert E. Saulpaugh of this place, has completed plans for her marriage to Leonard Hill Clark, son of Mrs. Ridgley C. Clark of Seymour, Conn., which will take place Aug. 27 in the Church of the Messiah, Rhinebeck, N. Y. The Rev. Dr.

The Dutch ar- hopeful regarding the outlook in the near future for the markets and trade in the United States. Increased activity in the steel, copper, textile and chemical industries, it is held, has improved materially the prospect for the automobile industry.

Modern mankind's conception of God is so often destroyed by the mpact of reality that it leads many men and women to say they can no longer believe in Him, the Rev. Dr. Russell J. Clinchy of Washington said in a sermon yesterday at the Broadway Congregational Tabernacle, at Fifty-sixth Street.

A Nationalist [Rebel] communique issued here tonight declared that six Republican [Loyalist] brigades, comprising 12,000 to 15,000 men, had been trapped or "destroyed" by the Nationalists in the counter-offensive that started yesterday on the Ebro River front.

Up until the time Policeman Lloyd Weisch changed trains last evening enroute home from the Washington Park race track, where he won $170 on the horses, the world seemed pretty bright. Thereafter things took a turn for the worse.

Foreigners who have entered Brazil illegally must regularize their status within 120 days or be subject to fine, imprisonment and deportation. Instructions to this effect were released last night by the Commission for the Permanency of Foreigners in Brazil, which is now in session.
That savings banks continue to find a ready market for their realty holdings in this city was indicated over the week-end when banks disposed of several properties in Manhattan and the Bronx.

The outcome of the Democratic Senatrial primary in Kentucky had apparently boiled down today to the question of the size of Senator Alben W. Barkley's majority over Governor A. B. (Happy) Chandler, his opponent in the hard fought nomination race which ended with yesterday's .voting.

The combined forces of rain, business recession and labor troubles this Summer have given the circus business the worst drubbing in its history. Veteran circus men and close observers predict the sawdust rings will be back "bigger and better" next year.

Austin Corbin of Newport, N. H., son of the late Austin Corbin, banker and railroad president, died suddenly yesterday of a heart attack at the home of friends in Kerhonkson, N. Y., according to an announcement made here last light. He was 64 years old.

The entertainment of tennis week guests continued today at various estates throughout the colony. The Misses Anne and Charlotte McDonnell gave a large buffet luncheon today at the ocean-front home of their parents, Mr. and Mrs. James F. McDonnell, for Miss Edwina Atwell. who is visiting them.

Members of the Quaspeck Casino, who for three years have had the exclusive use of the club's beach, bathing pavilion, parking grounds and restaurant, found picnic parties in possession of the grounds today, the beach overrun with strangers and collectors assessing all and sundry, including formerly privileged members, 50 cents to park and 25 cents to bathe.

The Economist's index of British commodity 4 prices, based on the average of 1927 4 as 100, stood at 72 on Aug. 3, cornpared with 72.2 a fortnight before, 1 72.9 a- month before and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before suspen- f sion of gold payments by Great Britain.

Sub-par practice rounds indicate the Butterfield course will be in for a severe blasting tomorrow when ninety women golfers, headed by Miss Marion Miley of Lexington, Ky., will begin the first eighteen holes in the Women's Western Golf Derby, a 72hole medal play event ending Thursday.

In the middle of Jacob Riis Park beach in the Rockaways, only a few hundred feet from where three persons were killed by a lightning bolt just fifty-two weeks ago, death struck from the skies again yesterday to take the same toll, injuring fifteen more and felling scores.

The first half of the fifth annual Berkshire Symphonic Festival came to an end this afternoon with a series of performances that were as polished and as stirring as those that marked the first two concerts.

In his remarkably comprehensive "Science for the Citizen," an encyclopedic volume which is selling like a novel in England and which is to be published here in another month, Professor Lancelot Hogben presents science not as Huxley's organized common sense but as "organized workmanship"--something which has helped to make this chaotic world what it is today and which can be applied to save it from destruction.

After losing five straight games, Jim Turner came back today with a five-hit shut-out that gave the Bees an easy 5-0 triumph over Chicago in the nightcap of a double-header. The Cubs won the first game, 7 to 4.

The decline in the price of cottonseed oil and grains last week was largely responsible for a moderate recession in lard futures here. While considerable liquidation developed at times, the offerings were absorbed by brokers representing packing interests, and net losses at the close of the week were only 12 1/2 to 22 1/2 cents for 100 pounds.

A committee of Republican women will be formed to support Representative John J. O'Connor, Democrat, for renomination in the Sixteenth Congressional District, it was disclosed yesterday. Mr. O'Connor, who has been designated by Tammany for renomination in the Democratic primary, was placed on the Presidential "purge" list decause of his successful leadership in the fight against the reorganization bill.
At 2 o'clock this morning the Tass Agency office issued a communique concerning the interview last night between the Japanese Ambassador, Mamoru Shigemitsu, and Foreign Commissar Maxim M. Litvinoff.

Invitations have been sent out by Mr. and Mrs. Wesley Motley Angle of this city for the marriage of their daughter, Miss Eleanor Angle, to Thomas Thatcher Richmond, son of Mr. and Mrs. L. Martin Richmond of Glen Head, L. I., and Bridgewater, Vt.
Members of the Summer colony flocked to the Surf Club at Newport Beach tonight to attend the first of two "old-fashioned beer garden" concerts to be given by the Providence Symphony Orchestra.

The German trade press is pessimistic in its cornment on the international coal agreement, declaring that the Reich cannot make any concessions which would mean sacrificing its recent export gains, as compared to Great Britain.
The continued stock market fall which brought the average of standard industrials 19 points below the year's highest was the week's main topic in business circles here.

Dr. Frederick Tilney of 907 Fifth Avenue, New York, since 1914 Professor of Neurology at the Colleg of Physicians and Surgeons, Columbia University, died at his home on Center Island today at the age of 63. For several months he had been suffering from heart disease.

In July, 1937, Ray W. Sweazy, 22year-old stenographer, of 643 South Tenth Street, Newark, dined at the White House with President and Mrs. Roosevelt as one of the representatives of a youth organization.

Lady Chilton, wife of Sir Henry Getty Chilton, British Ambassador to Spain, will arrive today on the Queen Mary with her brother and sister-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. Howard O'Brien. They will be at the St.

Boston will turn out tomorrow afternoon to greet Douglas Corrigan in a citysponsored reception that police believe will exceed the tumultuous welcome given eleven years ago to Charles A. Lindbergh after his solo transatlantic flight.

A full-fledged economic depression is worrying Mexico, according to usually accurate business barometers. The causes are disputed, but government expropriation of the foreign-owned oil industry and its attendant international complications, labor troubles and a drop in the tourist trade variously are assigned as leading factors.

The Federal Trade Commission announced today it had modified its definition of cutlery stainless steel, as set forth in an order issued in the case of the National Silver Company, New York, on Feb. 17, 1937.

A somewhat grotesque machine, designed to keep sewer cleaners out of sewers, has been tested and approved by his engineers, Stanley M. Isaacs, Borough President of Manhattan, announced yesterday. Mr. Isaacs forecast that in a few years the unpleasant task of cleaning Manhattan's 560 miles of storm sewers would be done by machine.

Troops fired on members of the Sugar Workers Union - and farm workers after these two groups had halted their quarrel long enough to shoot at soldiers in the town of Aguabuena in the State of San Luis Potosi, the newspaper Universal reported today. Four members of the sugar union were killed.
Most of the de luxe cabins of the German cruise liner Reliance were ruined today by a fierce- fire that burned out the vessel amidships and killed one crew member.

The Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary is due to arrive early today from Southampton via Cherbourg with many celebrities on board. Among them are Secretary of Commerce Daniel C. Roper, William A. Julian, Treasurer of the United States;
Montreal and Jersey City split a double-header today, the Littile Giants coming back to take the nightcap, 3-1, after they had dropped the opener, 4 to 2.

In a dull market with many sellers and few takers, stock prices here last week declined' almost without a break, bringing the average of prices to almost exactly the level reached in the semi-panic on July 18.
A conspiracy to separate the Azerbaijan Soviet Spcialist Republic from the U. S. S. R. was reported today by the newspaper Bakinski Rabotnik of Baku, capital of Azerbaijan.
Canadian paddlers, winning seven of the eleven events, captured major honors today in the first annual international St. Lawrence River canoe championships.

The last Lutheran church in Moscow was closed today. Members of the Church of Peter and Paul thought a final farewell service would be permitted this morning, but when the worshipers arrived they found the doors locked.

The bodyless tail, fifty-one and a half inches wide, of a blue marlin told the story here today of a swordfishing expedition that ran into an unexpected thrill, but lost the bulk of its prize to a savage array of sharks.

Louis C. Kuhn of 63 South Oxford Street, Brooklyn, founder and first president of the Brooklyn Insurance Brokers Association, died Saturday night after a long illness. A son of John Randolph Kuhn, an organizer of the Brooklyn Bar Association, he was the president of an insurance brokerage and underwriting firm bearing his name.

Article VI, Section 1, of the State Constitution provides among other things that the Legislature may alter the judicial districts once after every Federal census or State enumeration, each district being bounded by county lines, and thereby reapportion the justices to be thereafter elected in the districts so altered.

Hundreds of monopolies that existed in the furnishing of supplies, materials and equipment for city use have been broken up by the Department of Purchase since 1934 and now few if any remain, Russell Forbes, Commissioner of Purchase, informed Mayor -La Guardia in his annual report, made public yes terday.
Governmental efforts to lift the prices of grain are regarded by a majority of speculators and others as being a signal failure, judging by the action of the markets in the last few weeks.

Mr. and Mrs. Samuel D. Riddle gave a dinner tonight for Mr. and Mrs. Arthur B. Hancock, Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Strube, Mrs. Julius S. Walsh, Mrs. Silas B. Mason, Mrs. C. Oliver Iselin, Mrs. William A. Prime, Mrs. E. Elkins Wetherill, Carter Bowie, Herbert Bayard Swope and E. C. Potter.
The following table shows the fitteen most active stacks traded in on the New York Stock Exchange last week; also the new highs and lows and total number of issues for the last three weeks.

So far this year, New York City newspapers are making a better lineage showing than the average for the country as a whole, according to a compilation for the sevenmonth period based on Media, Records figures.
The cricket test between All Jamaica and All Barbados at Commercial Field, Brooklyn, yesterday, resulted in a victory for Barbados by 55 runs.

Arnold Constable Co. is carrying on extensive inside improvements in expectation of an increase in business this Fall. Thomas C. Read has been appointed manager of the rug and drapery department of Kerrison Dry Goods Company, Charleston, S. C., succeeding R. L. Templeton.

After the end-of- i July settlement conditions in the money market became somewhat easier although the available funds remain rather scarce. Call money is quoted at 23 per cent, against 21/2 per cent a week ago, while trade acceptance and Treasury bills remain at 21/2 per cent.
Paced by the veteran E. W. Hopping and the youthful Jay K. Secor, the Eastcott four triumphed over Aknusti, 10 to 5, in the weekly highgoal polo match at Bostwick Field today.

The Tenth Destroyer Division of the United States Navy is scheduled to arrive here September 2 on what is described as a cruise for reservists. It is understood the ships will touch no other Latin-American ports.

John Har-. ris, who has spent most of his life in Africa as a missionary and traveler, has written a letter to The Times of London appealing for funds to collect data on Ramonolwana Senan, a Bechuanaland native, who, Sir John believes, is 140 years old and the oldest known livina man in the world.

James W. Mellen of Los Angeles has filed charges with the Senate Campaign Expenditures Committee that employes in the office of the Internal Revenue Collector at San Francisco have been "shaken down" for the campaign fund of Senator McAdoo.
The perfection of.a mixture of oxygen and helium as an air supply has made possible a new deep sea diving record by United States Navy divers,. the department announced today.
Constantin Sergeivitch Stanislavsky, one of the greatest masters of Russian drama and a founder of the Moscow Art Theatre, died here today of -a heart ailment.
With the maturing of the class of '18's twenty-year endowment nsurance policies for $68,000; Princeton University has realized--the first returns on its unusual system of alumni contributions.

Finley Pogue Mount, president of the AdvanceRumely Corporation, manufacturers of agricultural implements, died today at his Summer home at Burt Lake, Mich. His age was 71. He had been suffering from a heart ailment.
The Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary broke the speed record for the westward crossing of the Atlantic at 1:32 o'clock this morning when she passed the Ambrose Channel lightship.

Senator James J. Davis of Pennsylvania, Republican member of the congressional committee investigating the Tennessee Valley Authority, announced today that he had engaged an independent investigator to help him get at the facts regarding the bookkeeping and accounting methods employed in sustaining the famous TVA "yardstick" of electric power rates and regarding the government's expenditures in the multiple-purpose TVA program.

The Federal Sweets and Wafer Company, manufacturers of candy and biscuits, has purchased the major portion of the plant of the Standard Textile Products Company of Clifton, N. J., and plans to employ about 300 persons with the starting of production in the Fall.

The Public Service Commission has authorized the Yonkers Electric Light and Power Company to issue not to exceed $9,515,000 of twelve-year 3 1/2 per cent debentures due in 1950 and to be guaranteed as to principal and interest by the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc.

The plan of the Lehigh Valley Railroad Company for temporary financial assistance involves the extension for ten years of three underlying bond issues aggregating $33,500,000 and the payment of only 25 per cent of the next five interest maturities on the company's general consolidated mortgage bonds, of which $72,336,000 is outstanding.

Although retail apparel business lagged last week, due to weather conditions, a good volume of mail requests arrived in the New York wholesale market favoring reorders for items featured in August fur and cloth coat promotion and calls for back-to-school apparel and Fall accessories.

The German wholesale price index on July 20 stood at 105.7, against 105.5 on July 13. In the first seven months of this year the highest point reached by the German wholesale price index was 105.8, on March 2.
Paced by Mozel Ellerbe of Tuskegee Institute and Michigan's Bill Watson, the touring United States team won eight. of the eleven events in which it was entered in a track and field meet today.
Chief of Police John Malley said tonight that an ordinance warrant had been served on Dr. J. W. Bryan, the Louisville physician who diagnosed Governor Chandler's recent illness as "poisoning."

President Roosfelt attended church service. aboard the cruiser Houston today while the vessel steamed northwestward toward Caribbean waters. The service was conducted by Lieutenant H. R. Trump, navy chaplain.

The following were the best sellers for the week ended Saturday: NEW YORK Reported by the American News Company, Brentano's, Doubleday, Doran Book Shops, Gimbel's, Macy's, Scribner's, Wanamaker's and Womrath's:

Lewisohn Stadium began its last full week of concerts last night with Joseph Emonts, 'cellist, as soloist, and Alexander Smallens conducting. The program opened with the Strauss "Don Juan" and closed with the Tchaikovsky Fifth symphony.
What is usually one of the dullest seasons for the financial markets is being enlivened by a fresh and almost frenzied international rush to buy gold in the London bullion market.

The unsuspecting Palestine public today learned that the British Colonial Secretary, Malcolm MacDonald, had spent the last two days in this country conferring with High Commissioner Sir Harold A. MacMichael and heads of public security forces here.
The Education Department announced today twenty-one winners of special State scholarships provided for children of veterans who died as a result of World War service.

The Governors Island Yellows captured the Second Corps Area polo championship for the third year in a row by routing the West Point Officers, 13-5, yesterday at Morris Memorial Field. Brig. Gen. Evan H. Humphrey, the new Corps Area Commander, reviewed the quartets. His wife, Mrs. Clara S. Humphrey, presented the coveted Commanding General's Trophy, symbolic of the title, to the winning team and silver trophies to the players.

Christ is the supremely unique person in history, and for that reason is also the supremely universal person, declared the Rev. Dr. Frederick W. Norwood, Special Preaching Missioner of the Free Church Council of Great Britain, in a sermon yesterday at the Riverside Church.

The Tuskeges Institute of Alabama successfully defended its team championship today at the women's national A. A. U. track and field meet, which saw the crowning of six new champions and the equaling of a world's record in the 50meter dash.

THERE was a discussion as to whether or not Lou Ambers could claim the welterweight title in the event that he won from Hammering Henry Armstrong in their lightweight championship bout on Wednesday night at the Polo Grounds. One of the debaters said that the Boxing Commission had a rule providing that only one title could be fought for at a time.

Spurting from a one-hole deficit to a two-hole lead between the seventh and eleventh holes in the afternoon round, the Hickory Club team, composed of Richard (Dick) Chapman, Connecticut State champion, and Jack Creavy, former New York State titleholder, today annexed the John G. Anderson memorial tournament, annual best-ball fixture at the Winged Foot Golf Club.

The Tigers made their first start under their new manager, David Delmar Baker, a winning one, by defeating the Red Sox, 7 to 3, today. Hank Greenberg smashed his thirty-eighth homer in the opening inning with two men on the bases, while Charley Gehringer also aided the Detroit cause with a four-bagger starting the seventh.

The veteran Pittsburgh fullback, Bill Stapulis, is the latest player to accept an invitation to appear with the Eastern College All-Stars in their benefit game with the New York Football Giants at the Polo Grounds on Sept. 7, it was announced today by Andy Kerr, who will coach the collegiate squad.

Michael Manno, 52-year-old cabaret proprietor, and his daughter, Josephine, were held up by several thieves early yesterday while returning to their home, 1,727 East Ninety-third Street, Brooklyn, and robbed of $1,000.

King Boris, traveling incognito as Count Rilsky, left for Italy today where he will stay at the Italian royal family's Summer residence with his wife and children, who are already there. It is believed that en route he will stop off to see Regent Paul of Yugoslavia.

Government agents questioned at length yesterday the four alleged members of a ring said to have sold narcotics at wholesale in various large Eastern cities, and as a result additional arrests were predicted. The arrests were made here and in Philadelphia and Newark on Saturday.
Shirley Temple returned home today from a cross-country vacation tour and received-such.an ovation that..her train-mate, Eddie Cantor, was forgotten by the swarm of autograph hunters.

Attempts by leaders of totalitarian States to find peace by means of armament and the establishment of a strong spirit of nationalism will ultimately prove futile, since true peace is to be found only- in God, the Rev. Joseph A. Tytheridge said yesterday in a sermon in St. Patrick's Cathedral.
Polo came back today to the picturesque field of the Sands Point Club, where Westbury and Greentree staged the fastest and most interesting game of the season.

The American Youth Congress issued a statement yesterday denying charges which, it asserted, had been printed in the Catholic press, that the World Youth Congress to be held from Aug. 16 to 24 at Vassar College was "irreligious" and "communistic."

Most Christians who have practiced their religion according to the denominations to which' they happen to belong have failed to "bear witness for Christ" and have neglected the fundamental principles for which He stands, the Rev. Dr. J. Alfred Kaye of London said yesterday in his sermon as guest preacher at the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street.

The engagement was announced today of Miss LeBrun Cruger Rhinelander, daughter of Mrs. LeBrun Rhinelander of New York and Newport and Philip Rhinelander 2d of Oyster Bay, L. I., to William G. McKnight Jr. of New York and Rumson, N. J.

Philip Halpern of Buffalo announced that he would introduce this week in the Constitutional Convention at Albany an amendment. to strengthen the grand jury system because of the recent attempt of Governor Earle of Pennsylvania to stop a grand jury investigation in that State by legislative enactment.

Essentially to correct legislation of the last session that eliminated Columbia University from participation in the management and support of the School of Tropical Medicine here, Governor Blantom Winship today issued a call for a special session of the Puerto Rican Legislature to meet on Wednesday.

The Star Class, which has been staying away from the Weekly specials in droves because of their private eliminations, turned out for the Orienta Yacht Club's regatta today and swelled the number of starters to ninety-eight for one of the year's banner Sunday fleets.

With the cooperation of the Soviet Government, the Soviet trade unions have offered a permanent refuge for some of the 600 German and Italian wounded who are now in France from the International Brigades of the Spanish Loyalist Army.

This week's money market here has been liquid, with day loans on Saturday at 2 3/8 to 2 5/8 per cent. The flow mainly was owing to liquidation of Boerse securities by industry, which lends this cash to the market until needed.

Belrod Press, printers for the coffee trade, floor in 113 Wall St. from the estate of Nathaniel P. Rogers; Alfred L. Doyle, broker. Thomas Y. Crowell Co., publishers, additional space in 432 4th Ave.; Cross Brown Co., broker.
