Chess players from Rochester are setting the pace in the annual inter-county matches for the Genesee Trophy at the annual meeting of the New York State Chess Association at Cazenovia Seminary Junior College.

Congress adjourned today without ratifying the treaties of peace, conciliation and arbitration signed at Buenos Aires, giving Costa Rica the doubtful distinction of being the only country that has not approved the peace pacts of the Americas.

Life is not a game and handicaps have not the same significance that they have in athletics, the Rev. Matthew H.. Imrie declared yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue at Ninetieth Street.
Vows to God and church are above the claims of patriotism and devotion to one's country, the Rev. Father Severo Ramos acknowledged in a letter to Bishop A. J. Willinger of the Ponce diocese.

The British freighter Lake Lugano was sunk in Palamos harbor on the Catalan coast this - morning by Rebel planes from Majorca. Once again the method of attack seems to remove any doubt as to the deliberateness of aggression, for it was done in three raids;
Tom Flynn of the home club paced the field into the quarterfinal round as play in the annual Long Island Tennis League championship was resumed at the Bayside Tennis Club yesterday.
Mr. and Mrs. G. Forrest Butterworth Jr. of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Isabel Imlay Butterworth, to Cabot Ward Low, now residing in Burbank. Calif.

News of the death of Mrs. John B. Sherwood, founder of the organization which made Colorado vacations possible for business girls, was received here today. Mrs. Sherwood died yesterday at Blue Bird Cottage, Boulder, Col., where many of the girls spent their vacations. She was 92 years old.

Eduard C. Lindeman, director of the WPA recreation program, reported today that a study of expenditure trends in 148 representative cities over a period of the last three years, showed an Increase of 22 per cent in municipal appropriations devoted exclusively to recreation.
Birth and death rates in up-State New York were the same for June this year as for June a year ago, it was announced today by the State Health Department.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $3,790,333,650. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and noninterest-bearing discount bills.
China Girl, big bay mare owned by the Rochester Gavalry Troop, performed ?? at the fifth annual Sagamore Horse Show today, taking the jumping championship and the open jumper stake.

The Phillies ended a six-game losing streak today by taking the first game of a double-header from the Cardinals, 6 to 3. The second game was stopped by rain at the end of the seventh with the Cardinals on the long end of a 5-to-1 score.

For the third successive week Clifford E. Grover of Newark and Norman B. Smith of Philadelphia sailed the Teaser to victory in the Grover Trophy series for international Stars. In the sixth Sunday race over the Seaside Park course today, Teaser finished 1 minute 24 seconds ahead of Charles T. Kline Jr., in Whisper.
There was a fine west southwest breeze today for the joint regatta of the American and Shelter Island Yacht Clubs out in Gardiners Bay.

Jack Cooper, the white-haired Kansas City grandfather who won the national title in the sensational 225 Class last season, began to read handwriting on the wall this hot afternoon on the Charles River Basin.

It was with considerable relaxation of financial activities that August began. That is not unusual in the traditional holiday month, especially when accompanied by such paralyzing heat as this present season had brought with it.
The Reich's official steel report for July mentions signs of reanimation in exports. For certain kinds of steel Germany's actual sales increasedwhich is abnormal for July.

Major W. A. Welch, chief engineer and general manager of Palisades Interstate Park System, announced today that katydids had appeared in Bear Mountain Park, which, according to weather prophets, means that the first frost will appear in this section of the Hudson Valley the middle of September.

The practically leaderless Dodgers came from behind twice yesterday to beat the Reds in both ends of a double-header, 11-10 and 6-3, thereby sending a pop bottle-throwing crowd of 18,138 away from Ebbets Field in a delirium of joy as dusk was falling. The Reds fell into a third place tie with the Cubs.
The jewelry valued at $30,000 stolen Friday evening from the Orson D. Munn home on Gin Lane here, had been taken out of a safe-deposit vault only a few days before, it was revealed today.
Miss Gloria Callen, 14-year-old Nyack, N. Y., high school girl, today won the National A. A. U.

Completing what they termed "a most satisfactory training tour," Colonel William R. Jackson and Colonel Alexander E. Anderson, with their respective commands, the Fourteenth Infantry of Brooklyn and the 165th Infantry, the "Fighting Sixty-ninth", of Manhattan, moved out of Camp Smith today for the home armories by train and army trucks after fourteen days on the reservation and in the bivouac area.

To win the crowd at the crowd's price ?? to lose the crowd, and thus it is foolish and lind to lower the standards and cheapen the price of Christianity, the Rev. C. Leslie Atkins declared yesterday morning at the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue between Eleventh and Twelfth Streets.
Joseph A. Hunger, violin repairman, is betting $1.50 against $2,500 that he knows the value of ancient fiddles. Mr. Hunger bought a battered violin from a second-hand dealer.

Temptation of civilization has come to- such heights that the tendency seems to be to sit back and forget God, the Rev. E. D. Jarvis of Glasgow, Scotland, said yesterday morning in the--Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at. Fifty-fifth Street.

Fourteen lambs which changed hands back in Colonial days brought a crossing of fingers in the State Conservation Department today. The lambs, according to an agreement discovered by Dr. C. W. Greene of the department's Long Island biological survey staff, were the price paid by residents of the town of Southampton, L. I., to the Colonial State of New York for perpetual rights to fish and hunt.

Thirteen R. O. T. C. cadets from schools in New York and New Jersey have been selected as members of the Second Corps Area R. O. T. C. rifle team, it was announced yesterday at the United States Army headquarters on Governors Island.

Mr. and Mrs. Van Devanter Crisp of Upper Brookville, L. I., have arrived at the club for the season and are occupying the Roberts cottage. Mrs. F. deForest Stewart is here from Cold Spring Harbor and has opened her cottage.

Mrs. Kathryn Davids Donis, 30year-old widow, was found dead yesterday shortly before noon in her room at 102 East Thirty-sixth Street, just east of Park Avenue. She had shot herself in the right temple, according to the police.

Funeral services were held at noon today in the Chapel of Mount Sinai Cemetery for Bernard Talimer, former treasurer of the Philadelphia Public Ledger and brother-in-law of the late Adolph S. Ochs. Mr. Talimer died on Friday in the Hotel Traymore at Atlantic City.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Maxime Frederick, daughter of Mayor and Mrs. Halsey A. Frederick of this community, to Peter Beverley Robinson of Toronto, Canada, son of Mr. and Mrs. Christopher C. Robinson of Geneva, Switzerland, took place tonight in the garden of the Frederick home on Laurel Hill Road.
Mrs. Knopf Waite of Orange has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Marjorie Waite, to Donald Dey Johnston, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Appleton Johnston of New York.
Johnny Cabello of Harlem and Phil Siriani of the Bronx, junior lightweights, will furnish the action in the feature eight-round fight at the Queensboro Arena tonight.

His Irish eyes smiling, Douglas Corrigan today dropped in on the city he visited seven years ago "flat broke," this time to receive the acclaim of thousands for the courage that took him across the Atlantic.

Mayor Frank Hague, State Democratic leader, was quoted at City Hall here today as being hopeful that United States Senator John Milton would decide before the end of the present week to file his petition for the Senatorship to fill the unexpired term of Governor A. Harry Moore, ending in January, 1941.

Daniel Fairchild, six times Rhode Island amateur golf champion, starting with a championship at the age of 16, died here today of pneumonia at the age of 47. He was proprietor of a household furnishing business and was well known as a contract bridge player.
The German press continues to feature the Russo-Japanese border incidents and, as is to be expected in view of the Berlin-Rome-Tokyo antiComintern pact, to place all responsibility on Moscow.

Harrison Serrell, for ten years a customer's man for the firm of Baker, Weeks Harden, 52 Wall Street, was killed shortly before noon yesterday in a fall from a hallway near his office on the twentythird floor.

An amazing performance by Dr. M. J. Weller, an amateur fifteenhandicap player, who, ordinarily, has difficulty in breaking 90, enabled him and Leon Pettigrew to win principal honors in the Long Island Golf Association's weekly amateur-professional best-ball tournament at Wheatley Hills today.

Miss Emily Cunningham, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip D. Cunningham of this place, will be married to James Taylor Clark 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. James T. Clark Jr. of Newark, on Sept. 7 in St. Mary's Church here.

George L. Thoenebe, retired manager of the branch of the Bank of Manhattan Trust Company at Beach Eighty-fourth Street and Rockaway Beach Boulevard, Rockaway Beach, died suddenly yesterday of a heart attack at his home, 229 East Seventy-fifth Street, Arverne, in his seventy-second year.

The 413-acre plantation known as Huntlands, about four miles from the town of Middleburg in the Piedmont hunting section of Virginia, has been sold by the Bank of New York and Trust Company, trustee, to Colin J. MacLeod ofChestnut Hill, Mass., announces Previews, Inc.
Many novel costumes were worn tonight at the fancy dress roller skating party given at. Newport Beach under the direction of Mrs. Daniel W. Jones. It was the first party of its kind this season.

A change in the State Insurance Law to permit life insurance companies to buy land in cities of 300,000 or more and erect. low-cost housing projects was recommended yesterday by Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance.

Bowing to demands of New York Republicans, the Republican-controlled Reapportionment Committee of the Constitutional Convention voted tonight to accept an amended proposal which restored an Assembly district to New York County and brought its quota up to the seventeen seats originally allotted under the measure.

Two young Soviet deserters who reached the Japanese lines before dawn yesterday said in an interview that more than 140 Russian war planes were in the Korean sector, where frontier disputes have flared into intermittent conflicts.

A Detroit "save the circus" committee, aroused by the suspension of some circuses and by the fact that none is scheduled to show here this season, is taking. steps to prevent a recurrence of such a dearth of "big ton" entertainment next Summer.

A grand jury yesterday continued piling up evidence for the trial. of James J. Hines, Tammany district leader, with the examination of four significant witnesses. Hines, charged with being a' part of the Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer policy racket, is scheduled to go on trial next Monday.

Bainbridge Av, 3,038 (12-3334) : Helena M. Curtin to Lilian Kain, Millbrook, N.Y. Park Ave, (11-3039).e s 25 ft of 185th St, 50x100; Joseph V. Casson to John Pieper, 3,418 Barker Ave. 3d Ave, 3,265, (9-2368) Henry Lichtig referee, to North Side Savings Banl, 3.230 3d Ave.

Thunderstorms late yesterday afternoon and evening in the metropolitan area caused considerable property damage and brought to Times Square one of the worst traffic jams in recent years. Two lifeguards were struck by lightning at Wildwood, N. J., and another man was hit by a bolt at Linden, N. J.

Josef Hofmann's appearance as soloist with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at Lewisohn Stadium was postponed until tonight. The downpour before last night's concert necessitated the presentation of a substitute program in the Great Hall of City College. An audience of moderate sized braved the rain to hear the concert indoors.

Mrs. Helen F. McRedmond of 1,250 Franklin Avenue, Bronx, since 1920 co-leader of the Democratic organization of the Fourth Assembly District, Bronx, died yesterday of the effects of a stroke in the Elizabeth Horton Memorial Hospital, Middletown. N. Y.

Miss Margaret Stewart Douglas, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Stewart Douglas of this city, will sail Sept. 13 for Iraq, where she will be married shortly after her arrival to Erik Borge Juhl Roos of Baghdad, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Roos of Cranford.

A drop of more than $30,000,000 in the value of the foreign trade of the United States was disclosed in figures made public today by the Department of Commerce for the month of June in comparison with June, 1937.

Dr. E. D. Downing of West Virginia, one of the favorites, eliminated Henry Steglich of the Long Island Tennis Club, 6-1, 6-2, at the Cosmopolitan Tennis Club yesterday in the first round of the men's singles division of the twentysecond annual New York State open Negro championships.

The first tropical storm of the 1938 hurricane season late today was reported passing to the north of St. Thomas, in the Virgin Islands. But during the day alarm was sufficient to cause anxiety because it was the anniversary of the destructive San Ciriaco hurricane of 1899.

Officials of trucking companies in the Middle Atlantic States told an Interstate Commerce Commission examiner today that trucks had lost business because of failure to offer competitive rates on some commodities.
The Police Athletic League's sixth series of boxing exhibitions will be held tomorrow night at 8 o'clock, at Public School 53, in 168th Street between Findlay and Teller Avenues, the Bronx.

Jack (Fat) Harris, singing waiter, and Harry Margolis, singing bartender, both well known in Newark nightclub life, were held here today in bail of $3,500 each for the Federal grand jury when they were arraigned before United States Commissioner J. F. Holland on charges of selling and possessing narcotics.

The recent technical recovery in commodity and stock markets and the prospect of renewed activity in the United States following President Roosevelt's second pump-priming program has imparted a much-needed stimulus to confidence,

Yorkshire registered its sixteenth victory in twenty-two games in the English county cricket championship today, increasing its lead over the second-place Middlesex eleven. The Yorkshiremen defeated Derbyshire by 210 runs in two days, one day ahead of schedule.

To round out its program of social benefits already in force, the Shell Union Oil Corporation has adopted a retirement pension plan for its 27,500 employes in the United States and Canada, R. G. A. van der Woude, president, announced yesterday.

The Insurgent Defense Ministry issued an order today calling for a new class of recruits from among those born in the first three months of 1920, who ordinarily would report for military training in 1941.
Threat of the Canadian Seamen's Union to tie up Great Lakes and St. Lawrence River vessels of Canada Steamship Lines faded today with the signing of an agreement adjusting the dispute.

The forecast of the Department of Agriculture, released at noon yesterday, putting the yield of this year's domestic cotton crop at 11,988,000 bales, or about 500,000 bales more than the trade had expected, if borne out by the final figures, means that there will be little likelihood of a reduction in the record carryover from previous crops at the close of the present season on July 31, 1939.

Substantial progress has been reached by the Department of Justice toward an agreement with the Ford and Chrysler interests on many of the important points in the antitrust proceedings concerning automobile finance companies affiliated with these large concerns, it was ascertained today.

Thousands of gladioluses, including some new varieties, will compete in eighty classes for a series of prizes at the ninth annual show of the Metropolitan Gladiolus Society that will open tomorrow on the eleventh floor of the RCA Building in Rockefeller Center. The show will continue through Thursday.

Measures against foreign Jewish physicians in Italy are foreshadowed in a list, described as incomplete, appearing in the newspaper Tevere today, of twenty-six Jewish practitioners who have transferred their activities to Rome from abroad within the last few years.

A banking group headed by Lehman Brothers received yesterday the award of a new issue of $4,000,000 of Cleveland, Ohio, refunding bonds, on a bid of 100.03 for a combination of interest rates, which gave the city a net interest cost of 2.9753 per cent.

Battling it out with Zoic, Hall and Warrenden's Natty Boy today came on under a rousing ride by Bobby Dotter to win the Quick- Step Handicap, Six-furlong feature at Narragansett Park. Zoic was second and Zevson third.

Charles William Baker, former president and chairman of the board of the American Zinc, Lead and Smelting Company, died yesterday after an illness of two months at his home, 325 West End Avenue. He was born in Bedford, Ohio. seventy-five years ago.

George Densing, Clerk of this township, appeared somewhat puzzled and not a little skeptical today concerning the report of the discovery of an old agreement between Southampton and the colonial State of New York which would permit native residents the right to fish and huit without paying the $2.25 State license fee.

Bad weather prevented us from visiting Peary Monument. Secured our narwhal group for the Smithsonian Institution and two cute walrus pups for Dr. Mann of the Washington Zoo. Reached our farthest north twenty-five miles south from Cape Sabine, Ellesmereland. Hoisted the New York World's Fair Flag for 1939.
The two recently remodeled apartment houses at 234 East Eightyeighth Street and 508 East Eightythird Street are now 100 per cent rented, according to Schindler Liebler, agents. .

Hearing of the strange disease that has brought death to six children in Owosso, Mich., in eight days and sent five others to the hospital, Millard N. Besse, 35, of Boston, today offered himself to the Boston City Health Department as a "human guinea pig" for experimentation.

The determined drive of Administration officials in Washington to force through at the next session of Congress legislation to tax future issues of Federal, State and municipal bonds and provide for reciprocal taxes on public employes has brought about a nationwide crystallization of opinion in opposition to such a move, it was revealed yesterday.
Sale of the famous Roycroft properties founded by the late Elbert Hubbard, writer and philosopher, was approved today by Federal Judge John Knight.

The number of commercial and industrial failures in the United States for the week ended Aug. 4 was 238, which compares with 156 a year ago and 219 a week ago, according to figures released yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

An explosion occurred on the mezanine floor of Edward's Dresses, Inc., store at 16 East Fiftieth Street, opposite St. Patrick's Cathedral, at 1:45 o'clock this morning when three policemen discovered the body of Sig Friedman, 41 years old, a partner in the firm, who had committed suicide by gas poisoning.

The weekly pro-amateur best-ball tournament of the Westchester P. G. A. resulted in a threeway tie among Phil Turnesa of Harbour and Paul Pederson of Tamarack, who posted 30, 36-66; Rod Munday of Metropolis and Dr. John L. Harris of Sleepy Hollow, 31, 35-66, and Jack Sabol and A. J.

Winning ten games and losing one, the New York Curb Exchange has topped the Lambs Division of the Wall Street Soft Ball League. Gude, Winmill Co., with nine wins, no defeats and one tie, topped the Bulls; Goldman, Sachs Co., with eight wins and three losses, led the Bears and W. E. Hutton Co., with seven victories and two defeats, headed the Wolves.

Hundreds of small business establishments on City Island which depend upon the Summer trade are facing ruin and residents of the resort have been inconvenienced "immeasurably" by traffic conditions in the area, according to many letters sent to Borough President James J. Lyons or the Bronx, Park Commissioner Robert Moses and Police Commissioner Valentine.

The Treasury is preparing for a review of the whole question of Federal taxation at the next session of Congress, and, a Treasury official stated today, will be prepared to discuss almost any question which may arise.

Trading opened exceptionally slow on most classes of traefer meats. Traefer veal and lamb carcasses were steady; other classes were either weak or lower. Early trading in kosher meats showed improvement and prices were higher. Conditions, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture. follow:

Surrounded by pictures of himself in various stage roles, Cornelius Donnelly, 60 years old, was found dead in a gas-filled one-room apartment at 317 West Fiftieth Street shortly after noon yesterday, a suicide, according to the police.

Present and prospective stamp collectors and others interested in the nation's postage stamps from the first two issues in 1847, a five-cent Benjamin Franklin and a ten-cent George Washington, through the Presidential series of 1838, will have an opportunity to see them all this year.

East Broadway. 189, 26.1x75: Cortland Ave Holding Co to Bowery Savings Bank: p m mtge, due Aug. 15, 1939; int per bond: $4,000. 95th St, 215 E. 27x100.8: Albert Blaire to Bowery Savings Bank; p m mtge, due Aug. 1. 1943; int Per bond: $12.800.

This tiny town in the valley of the Tioughnioga River, with a population of slightly more than 300, brought more than 4,000 persons to John J. McGraw Field today in an extraordinary tribute to the man who piloted the Giants for thirty years.

" Finis" was written to the hardfought Kentucky Democratic Senatorial primary early today when Governor A. B. (Happy) Chandler conceded the renomination of Senator Alben W. Barkley and promised to support him actively in the general election.

Joe Louis, world heavyweight champion, interrupted a vacation yesterday to watch the final workout of Lou Ambers at Summit, N. J., where the Herkimer boxer prepared for the defense of his lightweight crown tomorrow night in the Polo Grounds against Henry Armstrong, world featherweight and welterweight titleholder.

Miss Helen Genevieve Smith, daughter of Mrs. James Alexander Smith of 390 Riverside Drive, formerly of Yonkers, and the late Mr. Smith, was married to Dr. Francis Montgomery Yager of Evanston, Ill., last night in the Broadway Presbyterian Church by the pastor, the Rev. Dr. John H. McComb.
The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended-Aug. 3:

Fireman Daniel J. Cogan Jr., 42 years old, of 486 Seventh Street, Brooklyn, lost his right leg yesterday when he suffered an attack of vertigo and fell under the wheels of a northbound train in the Independent Subway station at Seventh Avenue and Ninth Street, Brooklyn.

The rush to buy gold was resumed today as a result of sharp appreciation of the United States dollar against the pound sterling, and the price of bar gold rose 1 1/2d to 142s 3d a fine ounce (including 1/2d-an-ounce premium over dollar parity), which was the highest quotation in official dealings since March, 1937.

The annual Grand Circuit meeting of light harness horses over the triangular mile of Good Time Park opened today with four races, which initiated a series of historic events that will last through Friday. The high point will come Wednesday with the trotting of the thirteenth Hambletonian Stake for 3-year-olds.

Benjamin Reiss, 46 years old, president of the Master Electrical Contractors Association of Brooklyn, who is suspected by District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey of being a principal in the rigging of bids on public and private electrical contracts, was sentenced yesterday to nine months in, the penitentiary by Justices Bayes, Flood and Perlman in Special Sessions.

The Four Aces, Oswald Jacoby, David Burnstine, Howard Schenken and M. D. Maier, with B. Jay Becker as alternate, all of New York, rang down an early curtain on the masters' team event in the National Contract Bridge championships here today by piling up the huge score of 9,900 points for fifty-four boards of play against Fred D. Kaplan, A. M. Barnes, Charles Lochridge and Morrie Elis, also of New York.

Irregular price movements characterized slower trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The modest improvement in most of the higher grade loans in the corporate list and in United States Government obligations was more than offset by sharp declines in a few selected railroad and local traction issues.
Because of rain only two doubles matches could be completed in the Long Island Tennis League championship tourney at the Bayside Tennis Club yesterday.
James J. O'Shea, proprietor of O'Shea's Village Restaurant and an elder brother of John Vincent O'Shea, Acting Mayor of Babylon, died yesterday of a heart attack at the age of 44.

On the last run today of the American Yacht Club cruise, from Gardiners Bay out in the jaw of Long Island to New London, W. H. Wheeler Jr.'s Class Q sloop Cotton Blossom, R. W. Bartram Jr.'s Gypsy, G. R. Corwin's Night Hawk and Gilbert Warner's Wasakawere the winners.

Sir Earle Page, Australia's Minister of Commerce and Deputy Prime Minister, urged today a trade agreement between the United States and the whole British Empire. Addressing a luncheon attended by prominent businessmen, Sir Earle said:

Frank A. Fox, 40 years old, an auditor of the State insurance fund for workmen, pleaded not guilty yesterday before General Sessions Judge Wallace on the indictment alleging he extorted $500 last Sept. 29 from Isidore Swerdloff to conceal the full list of employes of his concern, I. Swerdloff Sons, scrap metal dealers, at 415 East Fourth Street.

THE four great railroad nabobs of the Pacific Coast are now memorialized-without any excess reverence, it is pleasant to report-in a most interesting book by Oscar Lewis.' Collis P. Huntington, Leland Stanford, Mark Hopkins and Charles Crocker: these were the four, the "Big Four."*

The Maharajah of Bhavnagar arrived from England yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary, accompanied by the Maharani and their two sons, as well as by Anantrai Pattani, Prime Minister of Bhavnagar, and Mme. Pattani.

Karl Gunnar Myrdal, Professor of Economics of the University of Stockholm, has accepted the invitation of the Carnegie Foundation to conduct a two-year. study of the Negro problem in the United States. He will sail on the liner Kungsholm Sept. 1.

Pamela Hansford Johnson, the young English novelist whose "World's End" was published last Winter, has a new novel on the Carrick Evans Fall list. It is called "The Monument" and the scene is contemporary London.

With the assertion that the Public Service Commission does not act upon applications "perfunctorily or rubber-stamp an issue" merely because it has been registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Milo R. Maltbie, chairman of the State body, authorized yesterday the New York Steam Corporation, a subsidiary of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., to issue and sell $27,982,000 of 3 1/2 per cent first mortgage bonds.
One item in the Queen Mary's new record will seem to many landsmen even more impressive than the actual time and speed.

More than half the women workers in the confectionery industry in this State work less than twenty-six weeks a year, while the average annual pay of those who do have employment more than half the year is only $653.99, it was reported yesterday by the Division of Women in Industry of the State Labor Department.
Two disastrous fires swept widely separated sections of the Philippine Islands today, leaving thousands homeless and causing damage estimated at $1,150,000.

Antonino Ajello, master candlemaker whose sweet-scented tapers, made from a secret family formula, have gone around the world, died yesterday at his home, 733 East 232d Street, the Bronx. He was 78 years old.

Stanley Ogilvy of the Larchmont Yacht Club had his hands full today piloting his Jay home first in the Star Class race In the second very light weather regatta of the Eastern Yacht Club midsummer series.

The five-story apartment structure known as the Richards Court apartment at 275 Harrison Avenue, Jersey City, N. J., was sold by the Reforso Knitting Mills, Inc., Dominick Piscitello, president, to the Fee-Simple Estates, Inc.

Settlement of the seven-weeks' Eagle Pencil Company strike, involving about 1,000 employes, was announced yesterday in statements by Samuel Blumberg, counsel for the company, and Local 1,224 of the United Electrical Radio and Machine Workers of America, C. I. O. affiliate.

Mayor S. Davis Wilson almost stole the show today, at the annual baseball game between Philadelphia and New York City employes, by making a surprise announcement that he intended taking a two-month vacation.

Ohio election officials built almost unprecedented defenses tonight against vote frauds in tomorrow's primary. Secretary of State W. J. Kennedy and election boards detailed exceptionally large squads of watchers to the State's 8,601 precincts to insure an accurate count of the anticipated record vote of 1,450,000.
With initial Fall buying about completed in most lines, activity in the wholesale market here yesterday was relatively small.
The steamer Canberra Maru was reported today to have reached Douglas Reef and found no trace of the Hawaii Clipper, which disappeared July 28 while flying from Guam to Manila.

Armed detectives tonight captured a couple sought in several robberies here, and Captain of Detectives John A. Cooney said that the man identified himself as Charles Bird and the woman as his wife, Barbara.

Anthony E. Santasiere of the Marshall Chess Club of New York, a former State champion, and Donald MacMurray of the Manhattan Club were winners in the first round of the annual title tournament at the meeting of the New York State Chess Association today at Cazenovia Seminary Junior College.

Shadow of the Pequot Yacht Club, skippered by Robert Gordon, was the leader with 16 points after the first two races of the tenth annual invitation series for the Commodore Robert Law Trophy, held by the Indian Harbor Yacht Club today.
A census of distribution which was taken in Eire (formerly the Irish Free State) shows that the annual value of retail trade totals $311,500,000 and that of wholesale trading $186,475,000.

Peter Behan at 104 years' of age was "too old to celebrate" his birthday today but still young enough to swing a scythe -with agility. "I just can't stop working," he said as he looked up from his mowing.

A reciprocity agreement under which out-of-State speeders arrested by State police in States along the Eastern seaboard will no longer be required to cool their heels in a police station while waiting for bonds to be posted was announced today by Michael A. Connor, Motor Vehicles Commissioner.

Four of the five persons who remained in Rockaway Beach Hospital over Sunday night after being shocked by the lightning bolt at Jacob Riis Park beach that killed three persons Sunday afternoon were released yesterday.

A safe built of crystallized iron in 1860 that once belonged to the United States Government and had not been opened in years revealed among its secrets when it was opened yesterday by an expert locksmith an application for a patent for buoying up vessels over shoals or in shallow waters, filed on March 10, 1849, by "A Lincoln, Springfield, Ill."

Despite the fact that a group of insurgent members seized temporary control of The Pilot, weekly organ of the National Maritime Union, while it was being made-up by its editors on Thursday night and inserted a front-page editorial, the union circulated the newspaper yesterday without comment.

The engagement of Miss Paula A. Mendelsohn, daughter of Mrs. Arthur C. Mendelsohn of 25 East Eighty-sixth Street and the late Mr. Mendelsohn, to Charles B. Moss, son of Mr.. and Mrs. Benjamin S. Moss of this city and Hewlett Bay Park, L. I., has been announced by her mother.

As the third anniversary of the enactment of the Social Security Act approaches, there are doubtless millions of people in this country who believe that the Government of the United States has under lock and key in Washington a large reserve fund which will continue to grow with the years and ultimately pay the old-age pensions to which every contributor to this fund is entitled upon retirement.

Charles Richardson, 18 years old, read about how J. Smith Ferebee of Chicago played 144 holes of golf in one day. "Why, I can do that easily," he boasted. Caddies at the Stayton Meadows course chipped in $10 that said he couldn't.

A collision of two automobiles yesterday at Sixteenth Avenue and Sixtieth Street, Brooklyn, injured neither driver but so shocked a woman pedestrian that it caused her death, apparently from a heart attack, according to the police.

Because of showers last weekend, the schedule of operas for Randalls Island for this week-end has been revised.-It was announced yesterday by Alfredo Salmaggi that his New York Hippodrome Opera Company will give "Traviata" at Randalls Island next Saturday evening and "Cavalleria Rusticana" and "Pagliacci" next Sunday.

In his inaugural address of 1789 Washington dwelt upon "the expediency of giving effective encouragement * * * to the exertions of skill and genius" in producing inventions. Congress responded with laws of unprecedented liberality.
Daniel C. Roper, Secretary of Commerce, returned yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary from a vacation in Scotland, accompanied by Mrs. Roper.
Members of the new Civil Aeronautics Authority, which will regulate commercial and private. aviation just as the Interstate Commerce Commission controls the railroads, were sworn into office today.
Miss Margaret E. Harris of this place has chosen the afternoon of Sept. 1 for her marriage to Allan Edward Schoff, son of Mr. and Mrs. Horatio C. Schoff of Cadillac, Mich.

Mayor Frank Hague was the center of attack and defense here today in briefs filed by plaintiffs and defendants in a Federal court injunctive action started by the C. I. O., the American Civil Liberties Union and others against Jersey City officials on a "free speech" issue.

AJELLO-Antonino, Aug. 8, beloved husband of Adeline Ajello. Funeral, 10:30 A. M., Friday, from late residence, 733 East 232d St. Requiem Mass, 11 A. M., at the Church of the Immaculate Conception, Stone Hill Road and White Plains Ave. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

Jesse R. Salmon, former chairman of the Essex County Republican Committee, left approximately $299,000 in cash on deposit in twenty-eight saving banks in northern New Jersey, it was disclosed today when his will was filed for probate with Surrogate Fred Herrigel.

Mrs. Ina Gerschefski of Bridgeport, Conn., is-the winner of the composition contest of the Silvermine Music Festival Association, it was announced yesterday by the judges. Her husband, Edwin, who is better known as a composer and whose works have had some performances in recent years, received honorable mention in the contest.

Presiding Justice John Warren Hill in Children's Court postponed yesterday until next Monday his decision on what should be done with Joseph Lanzetta, 12 years old, of 79 Old Broadway, who was found on the Italian Line pier Sunday hoping to stow away to Italy to see his mother.

The pound sterling, continuing its descent toward its old parity of $4.8665, reached yesterday $4.88, its lowest price since March 8, 1937. It closed at $4.88 1/8, off 15-16 cent from last Saturday's final price.

Despite the fact that the odds were estimated at 5,000 to 1 against each, an optimistic gathering of 147 golfers teed off in the seventh annual World-Telegram hole-in-one tournament today. The object was to repeat the feat of scoring an ace in five attempts at the Leewood Golf Club's 163-yard ninth hole.

Malcolm MacDonald, British Colonial Secretary, arrived here by Royal Air Force plane this afternoon en route to England from a secret visit to Palestine. He will spend tomorrow testing the local reaction to the new Constitution which will restore partial self-government to Malta early next year.

The average rate on the Treasury's weekly bill issue sold today was 0.044 per cent, the lowest in more than a month, the Treasury announced tonight. The average rate last week was 0.062 per cent, 0.059 per cent two weeks ago and 0.054 per cent three weeks ago.

Action of the Chrysler Corporation in setting a press preview for its four lines at the early date of Aug. 19 may force other manufacturers to bring out their 1939 models earlier also and stimulate the appearance of advertising copy several weeks to a month before its normal time, according to comment in advertising circles yesterday.

MANHATTAN DODGE, EDWARD L. (July 3). Estate, less than $10,000. To Laura A. Burrows, executrix, 339 Taylor St., West New Brighton, S. I. GOLDSTEIN, AARON (July 28). Estate, $6,000. To Celia Goldstein, daughter, 221 W. 82d St., $5,000; Molly Goldstein, widow, executirx.

A selfappointed opponent of Mayor Frank Hague was frustrated in his attempt to denounce the Mayor in a speech in Journal Square tonight when the elements and the Jersey City police conspired against him, according to his interpretation of the situation.

A vigorous denial of reports published in French and other newspapers that war supplies and volunteers were still pouring over the frontier to help the Barcelona government was issued by the Quai d'Orsay today.

Lazarus Constantinou, Lakewood restaurateur and former chef in the old Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in New York, died yesterday at the Paul Kimball Hospital after a brief filness. Mr. Constantinou; who operated the French restaurant, was in his seventy-fourth year.

Mrs. Marie Y. De Carie, Dr. Michael Canick, Marie Muselle, in Southmoor House, 230 Central Park South; Bernard R. Cahn, in 340 E 57th St; John W. Evans, in 222 W 11th St; John M. Glasgow, in 33 E 22d St: Dr. Andrew Paul, in 39 W 55th St; Win. A. White Sons, brokers.

Magistrate Charles Solomon warned members of the Workers Alliance yesterday in Bridge Plaza Court, Brooklyn, that they are "not making friends but enemies' for the people on relief"' by conducting what he termed unnecessary demonstrations at home' relief stations.

A recommendation that President' Roosevelt' appoint Felix Frankfurter, Professor of Law at Harvard University and one of the original New Deal advisers, to the United States Supreme Court to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Justice Benjamin Cardozo was made here today by Senator Norris of Nebraska.

Indications that President Roosevelt would make known his opposition to the candidacy of Senator Walter George of Georgia while traveling through that State were given here today with the arrival of Washington officials to be on hand when he lands from the cruiser Houston tomorrow afternoon.
Edward H. Morse, president of the Morse Business College, died here suddenly today following a heart attack. His age was 69. He was born in New London, a son of Captain Stephen Remington Morse.

Pointing out that Foreign Commissar Maxim M. Litvinoff had first told Ambassador Mamoru Shigemitsu that all the Japanese troops had been driven across the border and then had demanded that the Japanese evacuate troops from Russian soil, the Foreign Office today issued a resume of the second Litvinoff-Shigemitsu conversations as follows:
Optimistic communiques on the progress of the campaign against highway accidents featured today the opening here at the University of Michigan of the National Institute for Traffic Safety Training.

A son of Jack High named Highscope captured the Troy Claiming Stakes today over the same track on which his sire conquered his arch rival, Blue Larkspur, a decade ago. Ridden by Harry Richards and favored at 3 to 1, Highscope carried George D. Widener's colors to a two-length victory in 1:061-5 over a fast track.

THE Detroit ball club is the property of Mr. Walter O. Briggs, the big body man, and nobody should try to tell him how to run his own business. He hired Gordon Stanley Cochrane. He fired Gordon Stanley Cochrane. That's his business.

The Yankees came home yesterday after one of the most successful trips in the history of the club. Five and one-half games ahead of the second-place Indians after winning twelve of fourteen games in the West, the McCarthymen now hope to set out to clinch their third straight American League pennant.
The town is still; the huddled homes are spilling Their mutiIated dower thriftlessly. An icy cataclysm of rain is chilling The shell-maimed feet of those who could not flee.

Within the next eightdays Lufthansa. will attempt a transatlantic flight from Tempelhof Airport to New York with a passenger plane. The route will be via Lisbon and the flying time is expected to be .less, than twenty-four hours, although no: attempt will be made at a record.

The steamship American Trader of the United States Lines, due today from London, has among her passengers J. A. Hind, Mrs. Harry Wright, Miss Elizabeth Roemer, Mr. and Mrs. William H. Don and Captain and Mrs. B. M. Comerford.

Leaf tobacco production in Australia for the 1937-38 season is estimated at 7,000,000 pounds, compared with 5,145,154 pounds produced in the 1936-37 season and 5,557,504 pounds recorded in the 1935-36 season, according to a report to, the Department of Commerce today.

The procurement division of the United- States Treasury Department yesterday-completed its purchase of men's clothing for the WPA, with total orders amounting to $8,254,500 and covering more than 1,000,000 units.
Samuel M. Rankin, former manager of mail and express traffic of the Pennsylvania Railroad, died today, his sixty-seventh birthday. He had been ill several months.

Frank E. Gannett, president of the Gannett Company, publisher of newspapers in New York, Connecticut and Illinois, arrived here today from New York to be the guest of Lord Beaverbrook, owner of The Daily Express. Mr. Gannett crossed on the Normandie.

The new laws which a special session of the Pennsylvania Legislature wrote in five days for the admitted purpose of stopping a local grand jury investigation of State officials under Judge Paul N. Schaeffer were declared unconstitutional by the judge here today.

The Cord Meyer Company sold to the Letab Manor Building Corporation the plot at the northwest corner of Case and Ninety-fourth Streets, Elmhurst, L. I., for improvement with two-family brick dwellings.

Miss Patty Berg, gifted player from Minneapolis, fired a blistering 73, seven strokes under women's par and only three above men's figures, in the first 18 holes of the 72hole derby of the Women's Western Golfers Association at Butterfield Country Club today. It is the longest medal play event for women golfers.

As the site for an elevator apartment house to accommodate fiftytwo families, a plot 100 by 110 feet on the south side of Eighteenth Avenue, 142 feet east of Ocean Parkway, Brooklyn, has been purchased by M. Frank Co.

A special meeting of shareholders of the General Finance Corporation has been called for Aug. 27 in Detroit to. consider changes in the articles of incorporation to enable the company to broaden the scope of its financing activities beyond the automobile finance field, and permitting it to engage in business as an insurance agent and broker.

Dr. Harry A. Curtis, chief electrical engineer in charge of the TVA fertilizer works at Muscle Shoals, denied today there was "anything crooked" in the deal by which the Authority on his recommendation bought 570 acres of phosphate rock land for $680,000 giving the International Agricultural Corporation of New York a $530,000 profit.

Mr. and Mrs. Loring Washburn of Old Orchards, Greenwich, Conn., and Riverdale-on-Hudson, have announced the engagement of Mrs. Washburn's daughter, Miss Mary Aylett Royall, to Thomas Kimberly Chalmers of this city.

R. G. Menzies, Attorney General of Australia, left for home tonight with the request that "we should concentrate more and more on the devising not only of the machinery but of the point of view which will preserve the essential unity of the imperial structure as a whole."

Although the immediate effect of the government's cotton crop estimate of 11,988,000 bales yesterday was to bring slight reductions in gray goods and to keep buying of both gray and finished goods small, traders said that there is little danger that the large crop will cause serious interruption of the improvement in cotton goods which began some months ago.
Dr. Charles Wells Cropper, who came here from Baltimore in 1875 "to spend a few weeks" and who remained here for sixty-three years, died today of a heart ailment at the age of 90.

John G. Sullivan, a civil engineer, died last night at his home here at the age of 75. A native of Bushell's Basin, N. Y., and graduate of Cornell University, he was connected with several railways before joining the Canadian Pacific Railway.

captain Robert Croft Bourne, Conservative member of Parliament who probably would have been the next Speaker of the House of Commons, collapsed and died of a heart attack while walking on the hills of Argyllshire, Scotland, it was learned today. His age was 50.

Sales of General Motors cars in July to dealers in the United States and Canada, together with shipments overseas, totaled 90,030, compared with 226,681 in July a year ago, the corporation announced yesterday.

The marriage of Miss Marguerite Ballantine, elder daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert W. Ballantine of this place, to Emlen Williams Holmes, son of Jabish Holmes of 7 Gracie Square, New York, and the late Mrs. Holmes, took place here this afternoon at Trinity Episcopal Church. The Rev. Alexander R.
The touring Philadelphia Cricket Club today defeated the Halifax Independents by an innings and 76 runs in the opening match of their Nova Scotia series.

The long-expected change in policy in Brazil's exchange regulations materialized today. The Bank of Brazil increased the dollar selling rate to 17.7 milreis instead of 17.6 milreis, which rate had been maintained unchanged since Dec. 27, 1937.

The Agricultural Adjustment Administration reported today that the quantity of sugar charged against 1938 quotas for all offshore areas, including all - duty countries, amounted to 3,049,474 short tons from January through July.
Fifteen Shanghai organizations cabled President Roosevelt today in support of the Chinese Government's protest against the new policy of the Municipal Council in handling alleged terrorists.

Craig Wood of Rumson and Victor Ghezzi of Deal and their respective partners, Mrs. Charles Harding and Miss Janet Douglas, both of Rumson, tied today with scores of 77 in the New Jersey Professional Golfers Association mixed Scotch foursomes at the Montclair Golf Club.
Governor Lehman was reported as resting comfortably at his home here today with his right knee in a cast. He injured it in a fall as he was walking to his swimming pool Saturday at about 7 P. M.

A jury hearing the trial of Francis M. Carroll for the strangulation of Dr. James G. Littlefield was told twice today that 19-year-old Paul (Buddy) Dwyer accused the former deputy sheriff of the slaying before going to prison for the murder.

Although his National Guard observer reported to him that troops were not needed in Canton, Ohio, during the "Little Steel" strike, Governor Martin L. Davey-sent the guardsmen into that area soon after his agent left the vicinity, according to testimony and records put before the Senate Civil Liberties Committee today.

Damage actions by individual liquor package store owners against the Schenley Products Company for alleged failure to enforce FeldCrawford price maintenance contracts were forecast here yesterday by Gerald F. Dunne, chairman of the New York Joint Liquor Conference, composed of package store retailers, bar and grill owners and wholesalers.
The Beneficial Industrial Loan Corporation and its subsidiary corporations reported yesterday a consolidated net income of $3,101,358 for the six months ended on June 30.
Strictly good, choice and prime steers sold steady, but common and medium kinds were weak and in instances lower on a slow and draggy trade, according to the United States Department of Agriculture.
Edward W. Loth, veteran architect and secretary of the City Planning Commission, died Saturday at his home after a brief illness. His age was 81.
The Treasury is acting within the law when it hires aliens as "stool pigeons" in narcotic cases, R. N. Elliott, Acting Controller General, ruled today.

ALL THE YEAR ROUND, by Dorothy Aldis. (Houghton Mifflin, $2.) A light novel. BETWEEN SLEEPING AND WAKING, by Dorothy Charques. (Macmillan, $2.50.) A novel of England, by the author of "The Tramp 'and His Woman."

Judge Loraine Mix ordered the impaneling of a special grand jury today to investigate charges that Governor A. B. (Happy) Chandler was poisoned at -a hotel here while conducting his unsuccessful campaign for nomination to the Senate against Senator Barxley.

Unlike many great artists, Stanislavsky was abundantly reverenced in his own day. Forty years ago, when the incipient Art Theatre drew the exalted spirit out of Chekhov's "The Sea Gull," Moscow knew that something great was stirring.
The touring team of the Brooklyn Cricket Club lost to the Toronto and District eleven today in the second match of its trip. The visitors scored 166 against Toronto's 184 for 7.

Labor's Nonpartisan League, headed by John L. Lewis, declared tonight that Governor Nelson G. Kraschel of Iowa had "forfeited the backing of labor throughout his State" by using the National Guard to force a settlement of the Maytag strike' at Newton, Iowa.
One of the hardest mimic wars in the army's history ended on a comic opera note today with parts of both forces retreating at the same time.

Arrangements are being made for Alan Dinehart's return to the Broadway stage in October as star, co-author and director of a comedy entitled "Thanks for My Wife." It will be presented under the auspices of Joe Glick, former general manager for Jed Harris. The play, originally the work of Joseph Carole, had a Coast tryout late last Spring.
Miss Louise Dallas, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. C. Donald Dallas of this place, has completed plans for her marriage to Stanley J. Keyes Jr., son of Mrs. Keyes of Rye and the late Dr. Keyes.
Several internationally known athletes who will compete in two American championships arrived yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary after her record-breaking crossing.

The visit of Malcolm MacDonald, British Dominions Secretary, to Palestine provided both Jews and Arabs here with something new to talk and write about. Each side is speculating and interpreting the visit from its own particular viewpoint.

Transfer To take effect 8 A. M., Aug. 9: PATROLMAN-Paul J. Flynn, from Precinct 79 to Precinct 78. Temporary Assignments PATROLMEN-Thomas T. Van Etten, from 18th Precinct to 19th Division, for duty in Raided Premises Squad, for 7 days, from 8 A. M., Aug. 9.
Mrs. Jessie Talley Cramp, widow of John F. Cramp, formerly associated with Cramp Shipbuilding Company, died yesterday at her home in Chester.

If Governor Chandler, for all his professions of loyalty to the President and the New Deal, had defeated Senator Barkley in the Kentucky Democratic primaries last Saturday, the setback both to Mr. Roosevelt and to his regime would have been tremendous.

Two six-story tenement buildings, one costing $340,000 and another $196,000, in the Bronx and Brooklyn, respectively, were among the projects for which specifications were filed in the city yesterday.
The wholesale commodity price index compiled by the National Fertilizer Association declined in the week ended Aug. 6 to 74.0 from 74.7 in the preceding week.

Louis-Weber, Brooklyn's reputed policy king, and thirteen aides including two brothers were sentenced in Brooklyn Court of Special Sessions yesterday to terms ranging from three months in the workhouse to indeterminate terms in the penitentiary.

Legislation to strengthen the control of Congress over the campaign expenditures by candidates for Congressional seats is likely to be recommended at the next session, Senator Morris Sheppard, chairman of the Senate Campaign Expenditures Investigating Committee, said today.

The Japanese advance on the Wuhan cities [Hankow area] has been halted by striking Chinese successes on the front both north and south of the Yangtze River, according to official reports reaching here from the fighting zones last night.

The Eastern grass court tennis championships, in semi-progress at the Westchester Country Club, loomed as a serious challenger of the Longwood Bowl tournament for the season's stormyweather sweepstakes this afternoon as rain drenched the heavily scarred turf for the third successive day.

The first foreign delegation to the World Youth Congress at Vassar College opening on Aug. 16 arrived yesterday on the Grace liner Santa Lucia. There were twenty-six delegates on the ship, twenty-two from Chile, one each from Nicaragua, Peru and Colombia and an independent delegate from Paraguay.
Aviation sources said today that Marshal Italo Balbo, Governor - of Libya, would take off from Tripoli for Berlin tomorrow on a non-stop flight intended to emphasize Italo-German collaboration.

The New York Curb Exchange has been notified that, since the profit-and-loss statement of the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria Corporation shows no income available for debenture interest in the first six months of the present year, no interest will be paid on Sept. 1 on the 5 per cent sinking-fund debentures due in 1954. They are to be dealt in "flat."
Richard A. Werneke, a leader in Indiana Democratic circles many years, died of a cerebral hemorrhage here last night at the age of 56.
Patrolman Francis V. S. Crane, 35 years old, of 87-54 139th Street, Jamaica, who disappeared last Wednesday and was reported missing last Friday, sent in his shield and his resignation yesterday.

Ed Danowski, the former Fordham star, will be back in the lineup of the New York football Giants again, it was announced yesterday. For several weeks there was speculation whether Danowski would return to the professional gridiron, but all doubt was dispelled following a conference between Danowski and John V. Mara, president of the Giants.

The procurement division of the Treasury Department, acting "primarily as an interested shipper" rather than as a government agency, filed today with the Interstate Commerce Commission a brief supporting that part of the I. C. C.'s motor carrier

Turpentine nominal, 22%c; no sales; receipts, 700 barrels: shipments, 135 barrels; stock, 41,117 barrels. Resin firm: sales, 771; receipts, 2,475; shipments, 1,403; stock, 198,030. Quote: B, 83.50; D. $3.85; E, $4.25: F, G, H, I, K, M, $4.62%; N, $5.45; WG, 85.70; WW. X. $6.35.

California-Oregon Power Company--Twelve months to June 30: Net income after operating expenses, taxes and charges, $900,916, compared with $1,111,004 in twelve months to June 30, 1937; gross revenues $4,628,753, against $4,619,649.

Deaths 'Announced Retired Lieutenant Harry N. Morris, formerly a member of Engine Co. 298, residing at 17 St. Charles Pl., Brooklyn, died July 28. Retired Fireman Dixon McQueen, formerly a member of Engine Co. 51, residing at Glenwood, L. I., died July 22.

Miss Muriel Grossman was married to William Herbert Irwin of this city last evening at the home of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Grossman of J37 Riverside Drive, by President Justice Pelham St. George Bissell.
With an unusually strong demand for $1 shirts for sales purposes, manufacturers yesterday attempted to start moving up the wholesale prices on these goods, it was learned in the local market.

A varied entertainment will be presented the night of Ayg. 27 at Four Fountains, the studio of Mr. and Mrs. Lucien Hamilton Tyng, by Queena Mario of the Metropolitan Opera and a group from her art colony in Bethel, Conn.
Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain is interrupting his holiday in Scotland tonight and returning to London to consult his doctor, it was stated officially today.

John S. Zinseer, president of Sharp Dohme, Inc., manufacturers of pharmaceutical products, told Federal Judge Oliver Dickinson today that the company's business would "be ruined if the A. F. L. strike continues much longer."

Tomorrow at 4 P. M. the police will return, after an absence of twenty-five years, to the Traffic Court Building at 300 Mulberry Street. The occasion will be the opening of the temporary headquarters of the Mercer Street station during the demolition of the present station house and the construction of new precinct headquarters.
Postmaster General Farley called upon Democrats tonight to work hard in the November elections. He was guest speaker at a dinner here.

Mrs. Della Forker Chrysler, wife of Walter P. Chrysler, automobile manufacturer, died at 7 o'clock toaight at their home on Kings Point Road from the effects of a cerebral hemorrhage suffered at 2 o'clock this morning. She never regained consciousness after the stroke.

A legal manoeuvre, which if successful will put an effective end to a City Council committee's efforts to investigate city relief, was instituted yesterday in Supreme Court by Acting Corporation Counsel Frederick v. P. Bryan on instructions from Mayor La Guardia. The Mayor has consistenitly opposed the inquiry since it was proposed.

Lewis Liberman, Camden attorney and former police judge, was found unconscious today in the Collingswood Garage where he kept his automobile. He was at the wheel of the car, overcome by carbon monoxide fumes. The motor was running and the garage door was open only-a few inches.
Catholic nuns are gradually being removed as nurses in hospitals and homes throughout Austria. Simultaneously they are being replaced by lay teachers in schools.

A strip of land approximately onehalf mile in length on the northern side of Northern Boulevard, east of Manhasset, L. I., has been donated to the incorporated village of Munsey Park by Munsey Park, Inc., developer.

The Constitution Convention early this morning placed its stamp of approval on a civil service plank limiting examinations in the civil service to citizens of the United States who have been residents of New York State for at least two years.

While the little bearded gnomes of the Catskills played furiously at ninepins in a torrential rain this evening, Father Divine, the Negro preacher, completed one stage of his triumphal ascent to his Krum Elbow "heaven" opposite President Roosevelt's family seat, and flung to 2,500 "angels" from Harlem a message of peace which bristled with sharp thrusts at New Deal policies.

Federal Judge T. Whitfield Davidson of Texas, who is sitting in this district temporarily, held George C. Dix, a New York attorney, in contempt of court yesterday and reprimanded him for quoting Lester C. Dunigan, Assistant United States Attorney, as having said:
To meet the costs of her war with China, Japan again dipped into her dwindling store of gold yesterday and arranged for the shipment of $5,800,000 of the metal to this country.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Because some people may have failed to observe your news provided by Mex-' icb's reply to Secretary Hull's note, THE TIMES being the only newspaper to obtain and carry it in full, I desire to congratulate you and your correspondent, Frank L. Kluckhohn.
Forty-six yearlings from Willis Sharpe Kilmer's Court Manor Stud were sold tonight for $107,300, an average of about $2,333 per head.

Greta Garbo will return to Metro on Nov. 1 to resume her career, which will embrace two films for the 1938-39 season. The first will be "Love Is Not So Simple," translated from Melchior Lengyel's Russian "Ninotchka," a story of Czarist intrigue.
After a half-mile chase through the Bronx during which six shots were fired, the police arrested two men and a woman last night on charges of being collectors of policyslip money.

A government prediction today that the cotton crop this year would be 700,000 bales larger than expected sent prices dropping close to the level at which the government must make price-bolstering loans to farmers.
Scientists are unable to agree upon the reason why New York City's estimated 70,000 hay fever victims are having their sniffles, snuffles and sneezes ahead of time this year.

A four-foot bull snake, a nonpoisonous and harmless reptile, was taken from the cornice of the apartment house at 872 Madison Avenue between Seventy-first and Seventy-second Streets yesterday. morning.
Industrial activity in Great Britain improved slightly in July, according to the Ministry of Labor's report tonight. Unemployment decreased by 29,796 to 1,773,116.
" Master of Destiny" the late Dr. Frederick Tilney called a book of his on the brain. The title crystallized an interest in the central nervous system which was both materialistic and romantic.
State Senator Thomas C. Desmond warned today that appeals for new laws and regulations might furnish a wedge for "regimentation" of business and later for "economic dictatorship."
All members of President Federico Laredo Bru's Cabinet have presented their resignations. This was reliably learned tonight,. although no official confirmation was forthcoming.
Mr. and Mrs. Antonio Lazo of Greenwich will give a tea dance on Sept. 8 at the Field Club, Greenwich, to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Madge Stearns Lazo.

Fishing off Montauk Point these days is getting more and more like prospecting, for you can't tell what you'll strike. For years a number of anglers have spent weeks during the season trying to land a blue marlin or a broadbill, and some of them never so much as sighted the former or hooked the latter.
A new self-regulation code for the combed and carded yarn industries of the South was announced here today by a committee which has been working on it for several months.

With a new record for the westbound Atlantic crossing to her credit, the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary will be run for the eastbound record on her return voyage, Commodore Robert B. Irving, master of the ship, indicated yesterday.

Charges that New York City milk dealers "have already started a campaign to scuttle" the Federal State milk marketing program, "and are attempting to brow-beat farmers into voting against it" were made today by Leon A. Chapin, Franklin County dairy farmer.

The bankrupt New Haven. Railroad lost a preliminary skirmish today in a State's rights battle centering in the road's determination to abandon passenger service and eightyeight stations on its Old Colony division, in Southeastern Massachusetts.

Representative John J. O'Connor, veteran Tammany Democrat, last night assailed Kenneth F. Simpson, Republican County Chairman and national committeeman, as the only Republican leader in the nation not eager to give him a Republican endorsement this Fall.
The Irish Banking Commission in a 684-page report today urged the nation to reduce the State debt, which has grown from $50,000,000 in 1924 to $365,000,000 this year.

Washington at New York-Kelley (5-4) vs. Chandler (10-2). Cleveland at St. Louis (2)-Feller (11-6) and Whitehill (6-3) vs. Hildebrand (8-6) and Cox (0-1). Detroit at Chicago - Kennedy (10-6) vs. Knott (3-2).

Park Commissioner Robert Moses submitted to Mayor La Guardia yesterday the Park Department's plans for building fifty-eight miles of bicycle paths within and, in some instances, connecting the parks of the five boroughs.

2d Lt. William H. Siegel, Engr.-Res., 325 Madison St., New York, N. Y., is ordered to active duty with the CCC for six months, effective Aug. 9, at Headquarters Trenton District, CCC, Trenton, N. J., for assignment and duty in connection with CCC activities. Date of rank: June 27, 1938.
Norman Thomas, Socialist leader, said here tonight that although Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City was "not the future Fuehrer of America," he had blazed a trail for one.

The Provident Institution for Savings in the Town of Boston, holder of all the funded debt of the Boston Providence Railroad Corporation, lessee of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad, filed today with the Interstate Commerce Commission a copy of a petition in bankruptcy for the Boston Providence.

Highly organized and increasingly effective Chinese control of North China provinces nominally under Japanese occupation was reported by Captain Evans F. Carlson of the United States Marine Corps upon his return here yesterday from a three and a half months' journey with the Chinese Army through Shensi, Suiyuan, Shansi, Hopeh and Shantung Provinces.

Representative John J. O'Connor, veteran Tammany Democrat, last night assailed Kenneth F. Simpson, Republican County Chairman and national committeeman, as the only Republican leader in the nation not eager to give him a Republican endorsement this Fall.
The Irish Banking Commission in a 684-page report today urged the nation to reduce the State debt, which has grown from $50,000,000 in 1924 to $365,000,000 this year.

Washington at New York-Kelley (5-4) vs. Chandler (10-2). Cleveland at St. Louis (2)-Feller (11-6) and Whitehill (6-3) vs. Hildebrand (8-6) and Cox (0-1). Detroit at Chicago - Kennedy (10-6) vs. Knott (3-2).

Park Commissioner Robert Moses submitted to Mayor La Guardia yesterday the Park Department's plans for building fifty-eight miles of bicycle paths within and, in some instances, connecting the parks of the five boroughs.

2d Lt. William H. Siegel, Engr.-Res., 325 Madison St., New York, N. Y., is ordered to active duty with the CCC for six months, effective Aug. 9, at Headquarters Trenton District, CCC, Trenton, N. J., for assignment and duty in connection with CCC activities. Date of rank: June 27, 1938.
Norman Thomas, Socialist leader, said here tonight that although Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City was "not the future Fuehrer of America," he had blazed a trail for one.
Officials said today that the Commodity Credit Corporation might announce soon a revision in its wheat-loan program that would make some No. 4 Winter wheat eligible for loans.

Dr. Adolph G. De Sanctis of 975 Park Avenue and Sayville, L. I., has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Vivian Evelyn De Sanctis, to John L. Farrell, son of Mrs. James Farrell of Philadelphia and Ocean City, N. J., and the late Mr. Farrell.
Arkansas, Idaho, Ohio and Nebraska hold primaries today to nominate candidates for State officers, Representatives in Congress and, except in Nebraska, for Senator.

Frustration of a carefully-laid plot to wreck the coal mining industry in the Donetz Basin was reported today by the Ukranian newspaper Socialist Donbas, which said the five ringleaders had -been sentenced to death.

The fifteen-story apartment building at the southwest corner of West End Avenue and Eighty-third Street, known as 475 West End Avenue, was among the three Manhattan properties sold at auction yesterday in the Vesey Street salesrooms.

Debits to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended Aug. 3, aggregated $7,612,000,000, or 10 per cent above the total reported for the preceding week and 15 per cent below the total for the corresponding week of last year.

Automobile production was reduced sharply last week, with indications that some 1939 models would be introduced much earlier than expected. To offset this change in program the adjustment for seasonal variation has been moved forward.

Buyers for Glosser Brothers of Johnstown, Pa., were in the market yesterday for $250,000 worth of merchandise for use in the concern's third celebration sale, beginning Aug. 31, and marking the anniversary of rehabilitation of the city following the 1936 flood.

Tonsillitis confined the Dionne quintuplets to bed tonight, causing anxiety to Dr. Allan Roy Dafoe. Keith Munro, business manager for the children, speaking for Dr. Dafoe, said all of them have a tonsil condition which makes them susceptible to throat troubles.
Steel operations in the United States this week are scheduled at 39.4 per cent of capacity, compared with 39.8 per cent last week, a decline of 0.4 point, or 1 per cent.
E. W. Moore, retired newspaper publisher, died yesterday. He was 84 years old. Mr. Moore was born in Rochester, N. Y., and came to Michigan in 1883 as owner of The Battle Creek Journal.

A part of the 400,000,000-franc loan recently floated, partly in Indo-China for the defense of France's Eastern possessions will be devoted to fortifying Cam Ranh Bay in Annam, French Indo-China, for use as a naval base.

After day-long bombardments the Russian right wing in the Changkufeng area was. reported preparing for another attack on the Japanese. The latter reported repulse of the enemy at the other end of the front, and said their men still held the disputed heights.

Mr. and Mrs. John J. Campazzi of Jackson Heights and Forest Hills, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Julia Agnes Campazzi, to John Denis McMahon, son of Mrs. Denis E. McMahon of Elmhurst, Queens, and the late Dr. McMahon.
A telephoned warning from California yesterday enabled New York police to thwart an attempt at suicide by Duncan Draper, 43 years old, of 400 East Fifty-second Street.

East Broadway, 189, 26.1x75; Bowery Savings Bank to Cortland Ave Holding Co, 19 5th Ave ($8). 95th St, 215 E, 27x100.2; Bowery Savings Bank to Albert Blaire, 2,846 W 32d St, Brooklyn ($13). 100th St, 65 E, 20x100.11: Isidore Mitchell to Grbriel Stein. 116 John St ($5).

District Attorney William F. X. Geoghan filed yesterday in the Brooklyn Court of Special Sessions an information charging William F. McGuinness, suspended assistant, and George Murphy, suspended court elevator starter, with eleven overt acts in connection with the alleged conspiracy to obstruct justice.

An arrangement has been made by Paramount Pictures, Inc., to purchase an interest in the Allen B. Du Mont Laboratories, Inc., holders of basic patents for television transmitting and receiving, according to an announcement
Ed Oliver, 22-year-old Wilmington, Del., driving range proprietor, today. won the Central Pennsylvania open golf tournament at the Reading Country Club for the second time in three years.
Concerns engaged in the food business, either as retailers or in the operation of restaurants, figured in a number of the commercial rentals announced yesterday.

Viscount Runciman rapidly is earning a clamlike reputation here. The sparsely worded communique issued by his mission Saturday evening mentioned he had lunched at the British Legation, but it carefully avoided saying anything about the luncheon's most important feature-the presence of the American Ambassador, Hugh R. Wilson from Berlin.

James J. Farrell Jr., president of the American South African Steamship Company, conferred yesterday with counsel on the decision of the Federal Maritime Commission which awarded subsidies to his company and to the Seas Shipping Company, operator of the Robin Line in the African trade.

Mrs. Clara A. C. Bradin, long identified with charitable and musical activities in Newark, died here yesterday at the home of a daughter, Mrs. Oscar A. Kincaid, in her eightysixth year. She was the widow of Dr. Edward De L. Bradin of Newark and a daughter of the late Mrs. Alexander Clark.

William C. Shaller, secretary of the Y. M. C. A. of the Oranges for the last thirteen years, died yesterday at his home here at the age of 59. Mr. Shaller was born in India, where his father was an army officer.
The Pirates, who raised their National League lead to six and one-half games on an Eastern swing, won't schedule any more exhibition games this year.

An arrangement has been made by Paramount Pictures, Inc., to purchase an interest in the Allen B. Du Mont Laboratories, Inc., holders of basic patents for television transmitting and receiving, according to an announcement

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Aug. 5:; COMMANDER Andrus, C. L. Med. Corps, the New York; to Naval Hospital, Annapolis, Md. LIEUTENANT COMMANDERS Thomas, R. W., Med. Corps, Washington, D. C., to the Rigel. Gilbert, M. N., Mare Island, Calif., to the Argonne.

The Western New York Pennsylvania Railway Company and the Pennsylvania Railroad applied to the interstate Commerce Commission today for permission to abandon 12.3 miles of the New Castle branch line, as no longer self-sustaining.

Labor leaders here are drafting a resolution that all United States businesses in Latin America be forced to pay wages equal to those in the United States for the same types of work. It will be presented to the "Constituent Assembly" starting in Mexico City on Sept. 5 for the purpose of forming a Latin-American labor union.

The sixty-six public utility holding companies to which the Securities and Exchange Commission sent letters on Thursday requesting that tentative or final plans for their geographic and economic integration under the Holding Company Act be filed by Dec. 1 were as follows, the addresses being in New York City unless otherwise specified:

Teams from New York, Baltimore, Cincinnati and the Twin Cities of Minneapolis and St. Paul won their first starts today in the union printers international baseball tournament. The New Yorkers blanked Pittsburgh, 6 to 0, in a contest cut to six innings by agreement.
Ed Oliver, 22-year-old Wilmington, Del., driving range proprietor, today. won the Central Pennsylvania open golf tournament at the Reading Country Club for the second time in three years.

James J. Farrell Jr., president of the American South African Steamship Company, conferred yesterday with counsel on the decision of the Federal Maritime Commission which awarded subsidies to his company and to the Seas Shipping Company, operator of the Robin Line in the African trade.

The Western New York Pennsylvania Railway Company and the Pennsylvania Railroad applied to the interstate Commerce Commission today for permission to abandon 12.3 miles of the New Castle branch line, as no longer self-sustaining.

Labor leaders here are drafting a resolution that all United States businesses in Latin America be forced to pay wages equal to those in the United States for the same types of work. It will be presented to the "Constituent Assembly" starting in Mexico City on Sept. 5 for the purpose of forming a Latin-American labor union.

The sixty-six public utility holding companies to which the Securities and Exchange Commission sent letters on Thursday requesting that tentative or final plans for their geographic and economic integration under the Holding Company Act be filed by Dec. 1 were as follows, the addresses being in New York City unless otherwise specified:

Teams from New York, Baltimore, Cincinnati and the Twin Cities of Minneapolis and St. Paul won their first starts today in the union printers international baseball tournament. The New Yorkers blanked Pittsburgh, 6 to 0, in a contest cut to six innings by agreement.

Thomas F. McWalters, a 53-yearold veteran golfer, thrice champion at the Forest Hill Field Club, won the New Jersey honors in The World-Telegram hole-in-one tournament staged at McWalters's home course today.

A government army began another unheralded offensive on the Catalan front in Northeastern Spain today when troops crossed the Segre River between Lerida and Balaguer and advanced "deep" into Insurgent territory.

Alvin (Bo) McMillin, Indiana University coach, has been chosen to direct the Collegiate All-Stars against the Washington Redskins, champions of the National Football League, in the fifth annual charity game at Soldier Field the night of Aug. 31. The game annually attracts more than 80.000 spectators.

Two weeks before publication, Houghton Mifflin have ordered two large printings of their big Fall novel, "... and Tell of Time," by Laura Krey. This brings the total number of copies already printed to 35,000.

Private funeral services for Mrs. Walter P. Chrysler, wife of the automobile manufacturer, who died Monday night at their home at Kings Point, L. I., will be held today at 11 A. M. in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church, Park Avenue and Fiftieth Street. Burial will be in Sleepy Hollow Cemetery.
Certain misleading representations in the sale of radios and radio accessories have been discontinued by the RCA Manufacturing Company of Camden, N. J., the Federal Trade Commission announced today.
An increase of 2 1/2 cents a pint in the retail price of light cream and 3 cents for heavy cream was ordered by the State Milk Control Board today, to be effective Aug. 16. The action,

The General Motors Corporation filed today seven appeals with the Union County Board of Taxation on the $6,114,525 valuation municipal assessors placed on the land, buildings and personal property of its assembly plant at Linden.

Pensioned On their own application-to take effect 12 noon. Aug. 16: LIEUTENANT-Charles Daly, 46th Precinct, at $2.000 per annum. Appointed March 5. 1906. PATROLMAN-Patrick 3. McGrath. Quartermaster's Department, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Dec. 29, 1903.

TWO games today. One here and one there. It will take some scurrying to be able to sit in on both. There's the Hambletonian in the Land o' Goshen and the Ambers-Armstrong battle at the Polo Grounds. Weather permitting, of course.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Suzanne Paris, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic Andre Paris of this place, formerly of Princeton, N. J., to Henry Clay McCormick, son of Mr. and Mrs. John H. McCormick of Williamsport, Pa.

For three months Governor Earle of Pennsylvania has been trying to stave off investigation by a grand jury of charges of criminal misconduct made against him and thirteen of his associates by his former Attorney General, fired for making them.

Lucius P. Ordway Jr., Arthur J. Goldsmith and Byron G. Webster are expected to join Fuller, Rodney Co. about Sept. 1, when Redmond Co., their present connection, will dissolve and Fuller, Rodney Co. will become Fuller, Rodney Redmond. Franklin Q. Brown,

The New York Public Service Commission issued a report yesterday characterizing expenses of $7,775,888 made in connection with six bond issues of the Consolidated Edison System, aggregating $260,000,000, as "unreasonable and unjustified."

The Constitutional Convention tonight adopted in final form the Schenck proposal which prohibits the Legislature from ever requiring that municipal utility plants be operated on a non-profit-making basis. The vote on its passage on the third reading calendar was 110 tb 30, with the delegates splitting on economic rather than party lines.

Tonight in the Polo Grounds the sensational Henry Armstrong will undertake to write a unique page in boxing history.
