The doughty little Negro warrior from the West Coast will seek to lift the world lightweight title from the brow of Lou Ambers, who steps boldly forth to make his third defense of a ring crown rich in tradition.

The Greater New York Co-ordinating Committee for Employment announced yesterday from its offices at 132 West 138th Street that it would launch a city-wide drive to open more jobs for Negroes on a basis similar to that agreed upon with merchants in Harlem as a result of the committee's efforts.

The second battle over the Ebro has been as ferocious as the first, and as spendthrift of human life. If the casualties on either side are only half as great as reported by the other, the Ebro should be called the River of Blood. More and more,

While the police of this village were recording a cryptic account of the sudden death of a Steam locomotive engineer at Nassau Hospital here this morning a new chapter was being written to the long saga of the heroism of railroad men.
Southpaw Larry French handcuffed the Reds with a 3-to-0 shutout today and helped the Cubs into third place in the National League before a Ladies' Day crowd of 16,303.

Home financing operations of the Federal Housing Administration during July showed substantial gains over July, 1937, and operations of the first seven months this year also have recorded increases over the comparable period last year, the FHA announced today.

Movie makers and exhibitors have put up $1,000,000 for their greatest good-will and business drive. The campaign, opening tomorrow, marks the first time every producer and showman ever has been solidly behind one thing.

Notification of a court action against the New York State Athletic Commission, questioning its authority to vacate the world lightheavyweight title of John Henry Lewis, has been served, it became known yesterday.

In an airplane dash of more .than 1,200 miles into the Arctic on a rescue mission, I landed here this morning with my mechanic, Brother Beaudoin, only to find that Dr. Melling, Ir charge of the hospital, was critically ill.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Arthur L. du Buse of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Grace Adelaide du Busc, to R. Alan Ronnebeck, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Hermann Ronnebeck of Middlesbrough-onTees, England.

Willis B. Richards of 515 Front Street, Plainfield, N. J., died yesterday in the ferry station of the Central Railroad of New Jersey at the foot of Liberty Street. Dr. Tomosulo of Broad Street Hospital pronounced him dead, apparently from a heart attack.
Frank L. Slazenger of 103 East Eighty-fourth Street, New York, retired sporting goods dealer and manufacturer, died suddenly today of a heart attack while visiting friends here. He was 75 years old.

After a barrage of testimony designed to support Paul N. Dwyer's accusation that not he but Francis M. Carroll garroted Dr. James G. Littlefield, 67, the prosecution today rested its case against the 43year-old former deputy sheriff.

Patrolman Harold Maguire, 36 years old, who has been on the police force for ten years, was arrested yesterday and suspended after he had fired three shots at a man who dodged among a large crowd at White Plains Avenue and 225th Street, the Brbnx. Maguire was charged with felonious assault and intoxication.
The main body of domestic corporate bonds suffered a mild sinking spell yesterday with secondary railroad and local traction issues bearing the brunt of the selling.

Despite the fact that for the sixteenth successive day the temperature rose above 80, New York-City had a measure of relief yesterday as the moisture content of the air dropped during the hottest part of the day and brought the humidity average to 70 per cent of saturation.
The Department of Agriculture, afraid that the dreaded Japanese beetle may reach these shores, has sought public cooperation by asking people to keep a lookout.

It may take 1,000 years for one monolith of Stonehenge, ancient Druid monument, to regain its former weathered appearance after being daubed with green paint, the prosecutor told the Salisbury County police court today at the trial of four 20-year-old army second lieutenants who admitted having painted the monoliths and having placed "china utensils" on their tops.
Final unofficial returns today gave to Senator Alben W. Barkley a majority of 70,785 over Governor A. B. Chandler in Saturday's Democratic Senatorial primary.
A large contingent of midshipmen, as guests of the city, were present tonight at the opening performance of the third week of the Newport Casino Theatre season.

Stocks recovered and closed firmer at irregularly lower levels after early losses; turnover, 829,750 shares. United States Government issues higher; corporations irregularly lower; second-grade rails and tractions weakest; others mixed; transactions, $5,414,800.
It was announced yesterday that a son was born to each of the twin daughters of former Governor and Mrs. Nathan L. Miller last Saturday at the Doctors Hospital.
Jonas Monheimer of 2,710 Holmes Street, Coney Island, formerly a printing company executive and a resident of Coney Island for fortyseven years, died yesterday at his home at the age of 85.

If the bronze, pigeon-size eagles atop the ornate lamp-posts surrounding the Bronx County Court House could talk, they would help the Bronx police and the custodian of the court building immeasurably.

After a conference with Foreign Minister Georges Bonnet, Finance Minister Paul Marchandeau and Pierre C. Fournier, Governor of the Bank of France, over the currency situation, Premier Edouard Daladier today made an optimistic declaration.

Although trading was virtually halted in most lines of cotton goods by Monday's estimate by the government of a cotton crop of 11,988,000 bales, wholesale buying offices reported yesterday that many jobbers have permitted moderately large amounts of their needs to accumulate, and this buying will probably be released in the next three weeks.

George F. MacNaughton, a Republican delegate to the State Constitutional Convention at Albany from the Forty-sixth Senatorial District, died suddenly at his home here this morning of a heart attack. He was 61 years old.
Three of the recently arrived foreign players here for play in our national polo championship got into action today at the Meadow Brook Club where three games were played.
Eael Whitehill handcuffed the Browns with nine hits in the nightcap of double-header today, giving the Indians a split with an 8-to-1 victory. St. Louis took the opener, 4 to 3.

The grain markets developed a much firmer undertone today; although all deliveries of wheat and soy beans and the deferred futures of corn dipped fractionally in the early trading to new low levels for the season.

The Finance Committee of the Chamber of Deputies today approved a bill authorizing the Federal government to float a loan up to $30,000,000 in the United States to aid the municipal government of Buenos Aires.

The weather man again played havoc with the junior crew races for the Commodore Robert Law Trophy at the Indian Harbor Yacht Club today. It had been planned to hold the three final races during the morning and afternoon, but only one was held, due to the light winds, and Newton Gordon of Pequot for the second successive day piloted Shadow to victory.

Activity in Manhattan realty reported yesterday was largely confined to the leasing of private residences on the East Side. Flintlock Realty Company, of which J. P. Morgan is president, rented to Mrs. Mary Gibbons the four-story dwelling at 27 East Thirty-fifth Street.

The speed of the four Star Class yachts from Long Island Sound again was the feature on the third and final day of the Eastern Yacht Club regatta today, with Stanley Ogilvy's Jay of Larchmont, although second to John Abberley's Rhythm of Pequot by some 5 minutes, taking the series prize by a wide margin over the rest of the internatioaal fleet, which numbered a full score.

Six crews of three girls each sailed the first three in a series of six races for the Morgan Bowl off here today. The winner will represent Great South Bay in the Mrs. Charles Francis Adams Bowl series, emblematic of the national women's sailing championship.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John Andrew Larkin of 1,040 Park Avenue of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Vera Larkin, to Edward Henry Beck, son of Mrs. Edward H. Beck of 64 East Eighty-sixth Street and the late Mr. Beck.

Miss Louise F. Hatry, daughter of Mrs. Howard W. Blake of 565 Park Avenue and of Harry A. Hatry of 907 Fifth Avenue, was married yesterday at noon to George C. Jellenik Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Jellenik, also of New York.
Shipments of $6,586,000 of gold were engaged in England yesterday for shipment here as the flight from sterling drove that currency down to $4.87 3/8, its cheapest quotation since Nov. 9, 1936.

More than 27,000 regulars and National Guardsmen from eight Southern States prepared for departures to home stations tonight as high ranking officers of the Brown and Blue forces, "enemies" in the six-day mimic war just ended, analyzed one of the most difficult and realistic manoeuvres in the army's history.

Six Federal indictments charging corrupt practices through political contributions of the Narragansett Racing Association, Inc., Walter O'Hara and others were dropped by District Attorney J. Howard McGrath today with the consent of Judge John C. Mahoney.

As darkness fell upon the muddy, lacerated turf of the Westchester Country Club, Sidney B. Wood Jr. made his exit from the Eastern grass court tennis championship this evening in one of the season's most jolting reversals.
The engagement has been announced of Miss Mary Frances Wills, daughter of Mrs. Frances Johnson Morin of this city and of Van Leer Wills of Grand Rapids, Mich., to Richard Francis Barrett of New York.

A projectile from one of Captain William Thomas Sampson's guns fired in the Spanish-American War more than forty years ago today was found embedded in the walls of El Morro, the 400-year-old fort at the harbor entrance now under repair.
Tuffy Leemans, one of the. leading backs of the National Football League, has forwarded his signed contract to the New York Giants, it was announced yesterday by John V. Mara, club president.

Charles H. Hubbei, who had planned to give in Journal Square tonight the anti-Hague speech that was rained out last night, called the whole thing off and disappointed a crowd' of about 300 persons who had assembled in the square to see what luck he would have with the police here, who had not granted him a permit to speak.

One hundred and twenty-five men who are students, faculty members and staff workers at the Immaculate Conception Seminary of Darlington, near here, have recovered from attacks of food poisoning, it was learned today. They were taken ill after supper Saturday night.

The Government's estimate Monday of almost 12,000,000 bales for the new cotton crop is very far from a record figure. Production last year was close to 19,000,000 bales, while in every year from 1924 to 1933 our output has been larger than the 1938 estimate.

The Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary is sailing today for Cherbourg and Southampton. Passengers are Dr. and Mrs. J. Bentley Squier, J. Verbruggen, Belgian Consul General at Batavia, and Mrs. Verbruggen; Dr. and Mrs. Perry C.

Fresh from a reception in Boston. Douglas Corrigan came here today for five hours' tumultuous celebration of his single-handed transatlantic flight, before flying to Baltimore for further civic greetings tonight.

Patrolman William E. Lohman of the Sixty-sixth Precinct in Brooklyn, who had a rather creditable record to show for the twenty-nine years he has served in the Police Department, learned yesterday why Commissioner Valentine decided last Thursday to reject his application for permission to retire at the age of 56 on a pension of $1,500 a year.
Peter J. Hayes, chief clerk of the Court of Special Sessions, died yesterday morning at his home, 3,260 Perry Avenue, the Bronx, following a long illness. He was 44 years old.

The United Association of Dress Manufacturers early this morning, after a stormy meeting in the Hotel New Yorker, chose as their arbitrator Adolph Feldblum, an attorney and former impartial. chairman of the dress industry. The.

William H. Burke, 50 years old, a postoffice clerk, who had been a Federal employee since 1909, fired three shots into his head yesterday afternoon from a .45 caliber revolver. He died after being rushed to Bellevue Hospital.

Although the salt water situation is just about as satisfactory as anyone could wish, the fresh water brotherhood has been confronted with high water, low water, muddy water and warm water, one after another.

The downward trend of the furniture industry, which began early in 1937, "not only has been halted, but has been definitely reversed" by the results of the 1938 furniture markets, according to the market bulletin issued yesterday by Seidman Seidman, accountants.

The uncomfortable heat of the last few weeks failed to discourage the attendance of more than 9,000 students in the Summer tutorial schools of the Board of Education who will complete their course next Wednesday.

Charges of political activity in the administration of the Social Security Board's old-age assistance program in Maine by the State Administration Board have been laid before the Federal agency, it revealed here today.

Back from their triumphant smash through the West, the Yankees prepared for a grand entry into the Stadium yesterday. But directly after they had bowed acknowledgment to the plaudits of a gathering that numbered 7,167, a number of things unexpectedly went wrong.

Commercial and industrial failures in the United States in the week ended Aug. 4 increased in four trade divisions, as compared with the same week of 1937, according to the weekly summary prepared by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Many women at a luncheon yesterday in the Hotel Roosevelt pledged their support to national rededication, a movement whose aim it is to arouse a deeper consciousness of the fundamentals of American liberty.

The daily average gross production of crude oil in the United States last week was 3,317,850 barrels, compared with 3,316,400 in the previous week, an increase of 1,450, the American 'Petroleum Institute reported yesterday.
Two important factors in highway safety-the road and the driverwere under preliminary discussion at the second day's session of the National Institute for Highway Safety Training here today.

MANHATTAN BRENNAN, MARY A. (June 26). Estate, less than $5,000. To James C. Brennan Jr., Edward F. Brennan, sons, and James C. Brennan, husband, executor, all of 600 W. 150th St., residue equally. NICOLAIDES, KIMON (July 18). Estate, less than $5,000. To Anna E. Nicolaides, widow. executrix. 870 W. 181st St.

Noel' Art Studios, Inc. in 225 5th Ave. Radco Mfg Co, Inc, in 17-23 W 60th St. Lewis DeGruchy, Inc, ladles wear, in 2 W 47th St, John Butler and Charles Harrison, novelties, through Williams Co, Inc. in 42 W 33d St; The Cross Brown Company brokers.

Francis H. Reddy of 713 Tenth Avenue, said to have been an associate of the late Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, was remanded to the Tombs yesterday in default of $20,000 bail when he pleaded not guilty before General Sessions Judge James G. Wallace to an indictment charging seconddegree manslaughter after the theft of a police radio car, and criminal negligence.

More than 90 per cent of 5,000 automobile drivers recently licensed in all parts of this State-have reported satisfaction with the examination for a license and with the examiners who gave the tests, according to results of a survey announced yesterday by the State Motor Vehicle Bureau.

The Real Estate Bureau of the State Banking Department sold nineteen properties in its custody for $522,500 from January through June, bringing the total of such sales since the bureau was organized in 1934 to $7,103,260, it was announced yesterday by William R. White, State Superintendent of Banks.

Hundreds of guests have been invited to attend the ball to be given here next Saturday night by Mr. and Mrs. Henry B. H. Ripley at Beach Bound, their Summer estate, to introduce their daughter, Miss Lesley Hyde Hope Ripley to society.

Mrs. Sadie Lasky, 40, of 830 Albany Avenue, Brooklyn, was killed five miles north of here this afternoon when a truck carrying six tons of hay upset into a driveway in which she was standing with Mrs. Sadie Kazden, 35, of 643 Hawthorne Street. Brooklyn, who is in serious condition in Monticello Hospital.

Public hearings on the proposed removal of the Sixth Avenue elevated line will be held before the Transit Commission Aug. 22, it was announced yesterday. The Board of Estimate has already declared the line an obstruction to traffic.

A tenState "cornfield conference" in Indianapolis, followed by a rally expected to draw 50,000 persons, is planned for Aug. 26 and 27 by Midwest Republicans, the Republican National Committee announced today.

Movements of vessels follow; all dates are Aug. 9 unless specified: At Pensacola: Houston, McDougal. At San Diego: Cincinnati, Wasmuth. San Francisco to San Diego: Aylwin, Dewey, Dale, Farragut, Hull, MacDonough, Monaghan, Phelps, Worden.

The two rival investigations into Governor Earle's administration by the grand jury of Dauphin County and by his own legislative majority were both suspended today under rulings of the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania.

A plan to extend free high-school education to all children now deprived of it and to give a Bachelor of Arts degree to graduates, at a total expense "not far in excess" of present cost of educating 65 per cent of the nation's youth of secondary school age, was advanced yesterday.
Primary elections were held yesterday in Ohio, Idaho, Arkansas and Nebraska. In all except Nebraska, the New Deal figured as an issue to some extent.

Republic Steel Corporation employes who organized the "back-to-Work" movement in Canton, Ohio, during the Little Steel strike of 1937, received as high as $1,200 and $1,300 a month while they were seeking to interest other employes, it was testified today before the Senate Civil Liberties Committee.

The thirteen two-story taxpayer buildings at 47 to 71 East Main Street, Bayshore, L. I., comprising the block front from Bayshore to Third Avenue, have been purchased from the Emigrant Industrial Savings bank by David S. Meister, eporator, it was announced yesterday.

Miss Virginia Winmill, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Winmill of this place and New York, and Robert H. Radsch, also of New York, whose engagement was announced early last month, will be married on Sept. 24 in St. James Church here.

Two Jackson Heights and Flushing merchants paid fines of $5 and three paid fines of $2 yesterday before Magistrate Jenkin R. Hockert in Flushing Court when they pleaded guilty to failing to have cigarette tax stamps on packages of cigarettes in their stores.

The number of out-of-town buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday showed a slight gain over the preceding week, but was a trifle under the corresponding week of last year, according to the listings in TWE TIMES.
Three men charged with distributing circulars on parked automobiles in Jamaica were fined by Magistrate Jenkin R. Hockert in Flushing Court yesterday when they pleaded guilty.
America's touring track athletes won five of the seven events in which they participated today during an international track and field meet at Turku. A crowd of 7,000 saw the competition.

The American documentary film "The River" was given its first showing tonight at the annual moving picture exhibition, where it was well received. Large audiences witnessed two simultaneous performances of the film, which was termed one of the best documentary pictures shown here thus far.

Shelling of the Rashin Railway, reports of which were received here yesterday, led State Department observers to speculate on the danger of the development of a local struggle into a general war should shelling and bombing be extended to the city of Rashin, a scant thirty. miles from the Soviet border.
Hog prices broke generally 25 to 50 cents today, the down-turn being the most severe for any period recently, the United States Department of Agriculture reports.

The Exchange has stricken from listing and registration certificates of deposit for the Wabash Railway Company refunding and general mortgage bonds designated as Series A 5 1/2 per cent, Series B 5 per cent, Series C 4 1/2 per cent and Series D 5 per cent. They are due,
A number of leases for quarters in buildings on Park Avenue featured the contracts for residential space reported by brokers yesterday.
Preliminary estimates of next year's regular working budget were presented to the Cabinet today by the Finance Minister.

Josef Hofmann made his first appearance under the moon and the stars last night when he was piano soloist at the Lewisohn Stadium with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Willem van Hoogstraten conducting.

Two days of jubilation such as this Rip Van Winkle country never before saw in all its history reached a delirious climax today when Father Divine and his Harlem "angels" took formal possession, on the water's edge, of that verdant promontory on the Hudson River which Hendrick Hudson named in 1609 Krum Elbooge, or Crooked Elbow.

A contra-seasonal increase in steel ingot output last week sent the adjusted index forward to its highest point since the week ended Nov. 13, 1937. It now stands at 59.3, compared with 54.1 for the preceding week and 128.4 for the week ended Aug. 7, 1937.

Of the twenty-four formal protests filed today at the annual "grievance day" session of the Glen Cove Assessment Bureau, twenty-three were on Pratt properties, taxpayers who seldom have complained of the valuations placed on their more than 2,000-acre holdings by the city assessors.
Russ Bauers, 6 foot 3-inch question mark of the Pirates' pitching staff, put the Cardinals through a two-hit wringer today as Pittsburgh's National League leaders squeezed out a 1-to-0 triumph.

A plan of reorganization for the Denver Rio Grande Western Railroad which would divest the Missouri Pacific Railroad of its 50-per-cent stock interest by declaring the stock valueless was recommended to the Interstate Commerce Commission today n by Examiner M. S. Jameson., The other half of the common stock is owned by the Western Pacific Railroad Corporation.

Firing a well-played 79, one over women's par for the Cherry Valley course, Miss Betsy MacLeod of Buffalo today led a brilliant field home in the qualifying round of the annual New York State women's championship.

After an early decline to about the low records touched on Monday after the unexpectedly large government crop estimate, prices on the Cotton Exchange steadied again yesterday and ended unchanged to 2 points lower.
The conference of the International Danube Navigation Commission, with the participation of Britain and France, continued today.
Federal income tax records have been thrown open by President Roosevelt for use by a Congressional committee which is investigating charges of "un-American activities."

The annual shower of Perseid meteors, which visit the earth each year in greatest numbers during the second week of August, will be seen in a spectacular phase for the next few nights, it was announced yesterday by officials of the Hayden Planetarium of the American Museum of Natural History.

Mr. and Mrs. William T. Adee, socially prominent young couple, lost their lives in a fire that swept their home near here early this morning. After an investigation firemen said today that the cause of the blaze probably never would be known as it almost completely destroyed the building.

A device which may possibly revo lutionize measurement of radio audiences will be introduced in about two months by the A. C. Nielsen Company, research organization of Chicago, it was learned here yesterday.

In the Thames River today the New York Yacht Club fleet assembled for its annual cruise. A meeting of the captains, as the owners of the vessels are called, was held at 6 P. M. on Fleet Captain Vincent Astor's Nourmahal, which provided more room than the deck of Commodore W. A. W. Stewart's schooner flagship Queen Mab.

Brig. Gen. Archibald Campbell, U. S. A., retired, and Mrs. Campbell of 11 1/2 East Eighty-seventh Street, this city, and Roroyare, Cold Spring, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Charmian Campbell, to Henry MacDonald of Forest Hills, Queens.

Calling the times a "heavy historical cocktail," Salvador de Madariaga, former Spanish Ambassador to the United States, declared yesterday in a broadcast from Geneva that Western democracies must give up imperialisms to bring about a new deal in world affairs.

Clarence E. Dobbin, Deputy. Superintendent of School Buildings, announced his retirement yesterday after thirty-eight and a half years' service in the Bureau of Construction and Maintenance of the Board of Education.

Plans for the liquidation of $23,800,000 of debentures of thirteen mortgage companies, of which the Maryland Casualty Company is guarantor of / the interest but not of the principal, were announced yesterday when more than 10,000 known holders in all parts of the country were asked by that company to submit tenders on their holdings before Sept. 9.
A new and dangerous phase in the trend of feeling of Iraqi Arabs regarding Palestine has now developed.

The United States Lines flagship Manhattan will start her seventh year of service in the transatlantic trade when she sails at noon today from Pier 59, Hudson River, with 540 passengers en route to Cobh, Plymouth, Havre and Hamburg.

Behind magnificent three-hit pitching by Marius Russo, Newark registered a 4-to-1 victory in the second game of a double-header tonight after dropping the first, 5 to 2, to Toronto. The triumph was Russo's fifteenth.
Donald MacMurray of the Manhattan Chess Club is setting the pace in the annual championship of the New York State Chess Association at the Cazenovia Seminary Junior College.

Abraham Skolnick, 68 years old, of 52 Runyon Street, was shot fatally here this afternoon by an unidentified Negro woman in the basement of a second-hand furniture store at 161 West Market Street, according to police.
Miss Patty Berg of Minneapolis, nipped at the wire for three years in a row, maintained her lead in the Women's Western medal-play golf derby at the Butterfield Country Club today.

Evidence of "an eagerness on the part of business to find a justification for renewed confidence" and indications of "some definite improvements in demand and production, and more especially in morale," were shown by a survey just completed by George A. Sloan, chairman of the Consumers Goods Industries Committee, and issued yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. George Babcock Ogden announced today at a luncheon given at their home here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Judith Ogden, to William Doolittle Getman, son of Dr. and Mrs. Albert A. Getman of Syracuse.

A man believed by police to be a song writer shot and killed himself early yesterday morning on a lawn in Central Park, about 500 feet from the Fifty-ninth Street and Seventh Avenue entrance. He fired a shot from a .22-caliber rifle. The bullet entered between the eyes.

Price-cutting which began last week on several brands of liquor distributed by Schenley Products Company spread yesterday to include a number of brands which were nt affected by the company's withdrawal of Feld-Crawford price contracts.
Diplomatic circles here attach significance to a meeting of Ambassador Shigenori Togo and Foreign Minister Joachim von Ribbentrop that took place yesterday at the latter's country seat near Berlin.

Let now the willow weep no more That wept within his mind, But bear the long leaves that it bore, Left for a while behind, While he lies easy in a place Where beds need little change, And where the bedfellow to face Shall not be lost nor strange.
The Republican majority in the Constitutional Convention defeated today an attempt by Democrats to require personal registration in up-State rural counties.
United States Ambassador Alexander W. Weddell presented Senator Thomas F. Green of Rhode Island to President Roberto M. Ortiz this afternoon and they had a long conversation.

Ten Bronx properties, mostly dwellings, were sold at auction yesterday in the sales rooms at 3,208 Third Avenue. Among the purchasers, as plaintiffs, were the Home Owners Loan Corporation, which bought in five homes;
" Arms and the Man,' the fifth "Forty Niner production of the season opened tonight at the Chase Barn Playhouse as one of the features of the Craftsman's Fair being held at the Chase Barn this week.

While her husband slept in their apartment at 136 Waverly Place at 10 o'clock yesterday morning, Mrs. Anna D. Collins, 50 years old, wife of Detective James Collins of the Beach Street station, shot herself in the head with his service revolver.
Soviet artillery pounded the whole four-mile Japanese front today. The bombardment was the most intensive since the fighting on the ManchukuoanSiberia border started last month.
Mexico's 12 per cent export tax was put into effect today with provisions virtually empowering the Treasury to make concessions to industries that it believes cannot bear the increase.

Hand labor won a victory over the machine in the WPA yesterday when Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, WPA Administrator, announced that machine preparation of WPA payrolls would be discontinued next Monday.
William S. Murray, Republican State Chairman, today called upon county chairmen to cooperate in a drive to "get out the first voters" in the Fall election.

The Constitutional Convention, in committee of the whole, advanced to third reading tonight the proposal of the committee on suffrage, which would eliminate from the oath of office the declaration that the public official has not accepted any bribe in connection with his position.

A frank defense of the patronage policies of the Roosevelt administration on the ground that it is "proper and essential" that jobs "which closely touched matters of policy" should be filled with those in sympathy with the administration's purposes was advanced by James A. Farley, Postmaster General and chairman of the Democratic National Committee, in the current issue of The American Magazine.

Details of the five twelve-story apartment buildings which Dr. Charles V. Paterno will build on the site now occupied by his famous castle on Washington Heights were filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings.

Colonel Charles H. Rice, commander of the Sixteenth Infantry, and Colonel Julius Ochs Adler, commanding the 306th Infantry Reserve, awarded 138 gold, silver and bronze medals tonight to the victors in an extensive athletic competition held by the Camp Dix Citizens Military Training Camp Regiment.

Clark Twelvetrees, 34-year-old actor, the former husband of Helen Twelvetrees, film actress, died early yesterday morning in Bellevue Hospital of injuries received Sunday night in a fall on the sidewalk at 149 East Thirty-third Street.

Mabel Walker Willebrandt, former assistant attorney general, was named chairman today of the American Bar Association's Committee on Aeronautical Law. She is the first woman to hold an important committee chairmanship in the sixty years of the association's existence.

It was reported in political circles today that during Regent Nicholas Horthy's forthcoming visit to Berlin Chancellor Adolf Hitler will give him a solemn pledge to respect the present Hungarian frontiers, similar to the pledge Hitler gave to Premier Mussolini of Italy respecting the South Tyrol frontier during the German Chancellor's Rome visit.

The National Labor Relations Board today ordered the Newport News Shipbuilding and Drydock Company to disestablish an employes' representative committee, on the ground that it was a company-dominated labor organization.
Fourteen ticket sellers at the Roosevelt Stadium, home grounds of the Jersey Giants, went on strike here this evening shortly before the team was to play a double-header with Rochester.
President Federico Laredo Bru today confirmed the resignation of the entire Cabinet, which occurred late yesterday, and asserted that it was merely a reorganization measure.
Pittsburgh and Indianapolis were eliminated today from the union printers' international baseball tournament, the first casualties of the week-long event.

Rudy York's twenty-third homer of the season, coming with two on in the ninth inning, broke up a pitching duel between Jack Knott and Tommy Bridges today and gave the Tigers a 4-to-1 triumph over the White Sox.
Failure of tung oil shipments to arrive from Hankow has shot prices of the oil skyward in Hong Kong, the Commerce Department announced today.

The news that the contracting governments had accepted the recommendation of the International Rubber Regulation Committee and decided to continue control for another five years, up to December, 1943,

Members of Local 179 of the C. I. O.'s Textile Workers Organizing Committee picketed today three silk throwing plants where strikes were called after the union and companies failed to reach new agreements.
President Roosevelt, deeply tanned and invigorated by his three-week fishing cruise in the Pacific, returned to the United States late this afternoon.
John L. (Lou) Houston wound up his career as a mail carrier today by walking the last eleven miles of a 100,000-mile trip started thirtyfour years ago. Houston, appointed

Exchange Telegraph says Acting Minister of Justice Buhl officially announced today that a petition for the separation of Count Court Haugwitz-Reventlow and the former Barbara Hutton had been granted on the basis of a private agreement between the parties announced in London July 29.

Offering will be made today by Hession, Maher Griscom of 24,900 shares of $10 par value capital stock of Tim-Bo-Lok Corporation of Hawthorne, N. J. The stock, which is offered by means of a prospectus, will be priced at $10 a share.

President Roosevelt's return to the political wars, after his Pacific fishing cruise of the last twentyfour days, carries him at once into two States where his personal popularity is still at high levels.

Dr. Walter Judd, returning to the United States from his post as head of the Fenchow Hospital in Shansi Province, North China, said today the Japanese had become "defensive" in attitude, although their campaign against China was still an offensive one.

The marriage of Mrs. Dorothy Milburn Auchincloss of 1,331 Madison Avenue, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. John G. Milburn Jr., to Frank Ford Russell, son of Frank H. Russell of Newtown, Bucks County, Pa., took place here yesterday afternoon in the chapel of Christ Methodist Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street. The Rev. Dr. Benjamin F.

What really passed between Captain Fritz Wiedemann, personal aide to Chancellor Hitler, and Viscount Halifax, British Foreign Secretary, when they met in the latter's home a few hours before the departure of the British sovereigns for Paris on July 19 has never been satisfactorily explained.

Having cultivated the habit of coming from behind the Dodgers spotted the Phillies four runs yesterdayatEbbetsField and as easily as the visitors forged to the front Brooklyn proceeded to pull even until a spirited four-run attack in the sixth clinched the verdict, the final count being 9-??.

Over the signature of Senator Joseph F. Guffey, letters by the tens of thousands have been sent in the last few days to Democratic jobholders and WPA workers in Pennsylvania requesting financial help for the Democratic State campaign this Fall.

A suave young man, neatly dressed and wearing no hat, held up the night clerk of the Hotel Monterey, Broadway and Ninety-fourth Street, at 4:50 o'clock yesterday morning and escaped with $250 or $300 from the cash drawer. The robber answers the description of the man who held up the hotel two weeks ago, obtaining $75.

Mayor Wilson tonight suddenly canceled plans for a two-month "leave of absence." His action followed published reports that he intended to retire from office because he had heard that the grand jury now investigating vice and crime in Philadelphia might soon return indictments against him and other city officials.
Raymond T. Parker has been elected an assistant treasurer of the Fidelity-Philadelphia Trust Company.

Puerto Rico proposes to proceed against insular monopolies under her own laws, according to Attorney General Fernandez Garcia. He will send Enrique Cordova Diaz, a Department of Justice representative, to Washington to study procedural methods.

Following the pattern set by "Boy Meets Girl," James Cagney and Pat O'Brien will be featured in "Boy Meets Sally," a revision of the Marilyn Miller-Joe E. Brown "Sally" made in 1930, Warners disclosed today.
The largest assemblage of Army Air Corps planes to participate in a single manoeuvree will gather in Los Angeles on Sept. 20, the War Department said today.

Miss Jean MacMillan Buck, daughter of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Oscar M. Buck of this place, was married this afternoon at the home of her parents to the Rev. George Hugh Birney Jr., son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Birney of Akron, Ohio.
Phil Siriani, 133 1/4, Bronx, outpointed Johnny Cabello, 131 3/4, Puerto Rico, in the main eight-rounder at the Queensboro Arena, Long Island City, last night. A crowd of 2,000 was present.

Handcuff, 9-to-2 shot, enhanced her claim to the 3-year-old filly championship when she raced through Saratoga's mud today to capture the historic Alabama, first run in 1872 when it was one of the sporting events established at this old course to help heal the breach between the North and the South.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The municipal government has provided that all citizens be entitled to free ambulance service in emergencies. As practiced. any person giving a name, address and telephone number can summon an ambulance.

With the Royal Pavilion crowded to the doors, the annual international masters tournament of the British Chess Federation started today. Owing to the strength and number of the .entries, it was decided to play the tournament in two sections of twelve players each.

The mission headed by Viscount Runciman of Britain continued today to surround its activities with a maximum of obscurity. The daily communiques headed "From the Runciman Mission" consist of about four sentences merely recording the facts of the establishment of various contacts.
Five taxicab drivers were under arrest on disorderly conduct charges today as the aftermath of a street demonstration last night against strict enforcement of anti-gambling laws.
Among the conclusions reached during a brief stay in Europe-such a stay as this writer has just completed-a few survive the return voyage and remain clear and outstanding.

The new Civil Aeronautics Authority held today its first meeting and appointed Paul J. Frizzell, deputy general manager of the Home Owners Loan Corporation, as secretary, and Charles Stuart Guthrie, assistant general counsel of the Securities and Exchange Commission, as general counsel.

Despite the Salonika pact, which officially established friendly relations between Bulgaria and her neighbors of the Balkan Entente [Rumania, Yugoslavia, Greece and Turkey], it appears that Bulgaro-Rumanian relations are none too cordial.

The New York Fire Department will stage four performances of "The Midnight Alarm" in Madison Square Garden to obtain funds to send the department's band and glee club to the national convention of the American Legion in Los Angeles, Commissioner John J. McElligott announced yesterday.

With threats of American retaliation still ringing in their ears from yesterday's bitter debate, the Assembly completed today its second reading of the bill to prohibit passenger ships from being used ?? hotels while in port and Its passage now seems assured.

A donation of $100 from Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, wife of the President, was announced yesterday by officials of the World Youth Congress, which is to open a convention at Vassar College, Poughkeepsie, N. Y., on Tuesday.

Robert Irwin is to be called for trial in the Fall in General Sessions, it was announced yesterday in District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey's office, on one of the first-degree murder indictments in the so-called triple Gedeon slaying.

William McC. Martin Jr., president of the New York Stock Exchange, and Paul V. Shields, chairman of the Exchange's committee on public relations, were the guest speakers at a dinner meeting of the recently organized New York Financial Writers Association held last night at the Casino in the Air of the Belmont-Plaza Hotel. Mr.

The Constitutional Convention just before midnight tonight adopted in final form the taxation article of the proposed new State Constitution. The vote was 128 to 9. The present Constitution has no taxation section, and all present tax regulations are statutory.

After arriving here by plane from Chicago, Helaine Judith Colan, 4 months old, whose left eye was removed three months ago to save her life, was taken to the Wheeler Eye Institute of the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center yesterday afternoon, where specialists will determine whether her right eye can be saved.
Warren Lee Pierson, president of the Export-Import Bank of Washington, will leave Thursday for a trip through Central and South America. He expects to be gone about two months.
Plant biologists at Cambridge University, England, have developed a new type of wheat averaging a 10 per cent higher yield than the

Earlier indications that a tremendous low-density globe of scattered stars surrounds our own disk-shaped galaxy, the Milky Way, are being confirmed at Harvard Observatory, Dr. Howard Shapley, its director, reported to the International Astronomical Union today.

Experts in the field of government finance have no doubt the Federal Government would reap more in increased tax receipts than it would lose in higher interest costs if the tax-exemption feature of government securities were abandoned., There are many buyers of government securities, it is said, who derive little benefit from the taxexemption.
The Chinese Government today gave to the League of Nations a report from a British surgeon, H. Talbot, on nineteen Chinese casualties that he had examined in the military hospital at Nanchang.

Dr. John Henry Steidel, assistant medical superintendent of the Trudeau Sanatorium and former president of the Saranac Lake Medical Society, died here today at the age of 39. He had been in failing health for the past two years.

After an ownership of less than two months, the 25-35 Steinway Avenue Realty Corporation has sold to an investing client of Milton Lefenfeld the four-story tenement 1,448 Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn. The building, which is assessed for $33,000, contains eight apartments and one store.
The scandals unearthed in this year's primary elections forecast a probable effort to strengthen the control of Congress over the campaign expenditures of candidates for national office.
The ties which bound the Democratic party in Monroe County to the American Labor party were severed today by the action of the Democratic executive committee after three hours of deliberation.

The Rev. Lloyd E. Coblentz, a Baltimore clergyman for forty-two years, died today at his home at the age of 73. He was born Nov. 20, 1864, near Middletown, Md. He was graduated from Franklin and Marshall College in 1886 and from the theological seminary at Lancaster in 1889.
The State Commission for the Blind urged parents today to have their children's eyes tested and a physical examination made before the schools open next month.

As a precaution against a possible. epidemic of typhoid fever in Brooklyn and Queens, the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity disclosed yesterday that one of its largest pumping stations in Queens would remain closed indefinitely because of the danger of contamination from a near-by dump of the Department of Sanitation.

Walter O. Briggs Jr., treasurer of the Detroit Baseball Club, confirmed today a statement by Mickey Cochrane, deposed Tiger manager, that Cochrane's two-year contract had been abrogated by mutual consent, and disclosed that Cochrane's salary had been $36,000 a year.
Death Announced Retired Fireman Matthew J. McGuire, formerly a member of Hook Ladder Co. 129, residing at 34-05 30th St., Long Island City, died Aug.. 3.

A new court ruling and a later opinion by the State Attorney General have altered the situation regarding the proposal before the Constitutional Convention for limitation of advertising along roadways and in parks.

Continued hot and humid weather in the metropolitan area has resulted in a sharp increase in the sale of electric fans, and this has been reflected most noticeably in the popular-priced numbers sold by chains and independent drug stores, it was said yesterday at selling offices of large producers.

Waterfront police precincts were asked to watch the shore for a small blue silk hat bearing a diamond and crystal brooch valued at $2,000, owned by Mrs. Ogden Reid of 15. East Eighty-fourth Street, wife of the editor of The New York Herald Tribune, according to a teletype alarm sent out by Police Headquarters yesterday.

A field of 113 competed in the metropolitan amateur one-day tournament at Quaker Ridge today, with a young Yale southpaw alumnus, Bert Kohlman of Woodmere, L. I., carrying off low gross with 38, 3674.

Studies Fabrics to Save Them Endless experimentation with the composition ?? antique textile fabrics is necessary for their preservation, George C. A. Barbour, president of the Allied Textile Research Society, said yesterday in addressing members of the Lions Club on this subject at a luncheon in the Hotel Astor.

A $235.000 building loan on the 6-story apartment house under erection on the n e cor of 206th St and St. George Crescent, Bronx. has been arranged by Jacob Emil Leitner. Inc. broker. The Gelson Realty Corp, Joseph Geltman, president, is the ownar of the structure.
Money in circulation in the United States on July 31 amounted to $6,451,875,132, or about 49.57 per capital, the Treasury Department announced today.

Ecuador, authoritative persons disclosed today, has signed a reciprocal trade agreement with the United States. A formal announcement will be made soon, perhaps upon President Roosevelt's return this week-end from his tropical voyage.

Dissension within the ranks of the Republicans and American Laborites in upper East Side Manhattan districts has considerably lessened Republican prospects of electing their candidates in the Seventeenth Senatorial and Twentieth Assembly Districts of Manhattan, it was learned yesterday.

Reports from Washington concerning the tax plans of the Treasury tend to confirm the worst fears of the State Attorneys General. The Treasury Department evidently subscribes to the elaborate opinion of the Department of Justice, forwarded to it, that the Federal Government has a supreme power to tax the States without their consent, while the States have no reciprocal power to tax the Federal Government unless the latter permits it.

Declaring that the forced landing of an airplane towing an advertising banned last Sunday constituted a grave danger to Coney Island bathers, Mayor La Guardia directed Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine yesterday to suspend all city permits for such commercial flying.

Continued hot and humid weather in the metropolitan area has resulted in a sharp increase in the sale of electric fans, and this has been reflected most noticeably in the popular-priced numbers sold by chains and independent drug stores, it was said yesterday at selling offices of large producers.

Waterfront police precincts were asked to watch the shore for a small blue silk hat bearing a diamond and crystal brooch valued at $2,000, owned by Mrs. Ogden Reid of 15. East Eighty-fourth Street, wife of the editor of The New York Herald Tribune, according to a teletype alarm sent out by Police Headquarters yesterday.

Studies Fabrics to Save Them Endless experimentation with the composition ?? antique textile fabrics is necessary for their preservation, George C. A. Barbour, president of the Allied Textile Research Society, said yesterday in addressing members of the Lions Club on this subject at a luncheon in the Hotel Astor.

A $235.000 building loan on the 6-story apartment house under erection on the n e cor of 206th St and St. George Crescent, Bronx. has been arranged by Jacob Emil Leitner. Inc. broker. The Gelson Realty Corp, Joseph Geltman, president, is the ownar of the structure.
Money in circulation in the United States on July 31 amounted to $6,451,875,132, or about 49.57 per capital, the Treasury Department announced today.

Ecuador, authoritative persons disclosed today, has signed a reciprocal trade agreement with the United States. A formal announcement will be made soon, perhaps upon President Roosevelt's return this week-end from his tropical voyage.

Dissension within the ranks of the Republicans and American Laborites in upper East Side Manhattan districts has considerably lessened Republican prospects of electing their candidates in the Seventeenth Senatorial and Twentieth Assembly Districts of Manhattan, it was learned yesterday.
The Erie Railroad reorganizations case was set for initial hearing today by the Interstate Commerce Commission on Aug. 18 before P. A. Conway, examiner, at the offices here.

THE most striking pieces of fiction published thus far this week seem to be "Voices in the Square,"* a first novel by George Abbe, a young instructor in English at Iowa State, and "Storevik,"t a translation from the Norwegian of Gosta af Geijerstam.

A public hearing on the application by the Railway Audit and Inspection Company, Inc., of 75 East Forty-fifth Street for a renewal of its license as a private detective agency will be held on Aug. 22 at 2 P. M. in the State Office Building by Abraham S. Wechsler, chief of the Division of Licenses of the Department of State.
Greyhound, 1:56, idol of the trotting worla, did not fail his innumerable admirers at Good Time Park today. The world champion captured the Trotting Derby, a free-for-all test, in two straight heats.

A field of 113 competed in the metropolitan amateur one-day tournament at Quaker Ridge today, with a young Yale southpaw alumnus, Bert Kohlman of Woodmere, L. I., carrying off low gross with 38, 3674.

GOVERNORS ISLAND Capt. Adial R. Lewis, FA-Res., 155 East 48th St., New York, N. Y., is ordered to active duty, Aug. 7, at Pine Plains Military Reservation, Great Bend, N. Y., for training, Date of rank; July 10, 1938. He will revert to an active status Aug. 20.

Professor Frobenius often had been a guest of the former Kaiser Wilhelm, before whom he lectured on archaeology. Results of his expeditions to Africa were recorded here in the Institute of Cultural Morphology.

The number of Class I railroad employes at the middle of July was 929,477, a decrease of 20.86 per cent from July, 1937, and of 1.61 per cent compared with June of this year, the Interstate Commerce Commission reported today.

The Fifth Japanese Naval Squadron, recently assigned to harass the South China coast, today carried out the second installment of its threatened ten-day schedule of aerial attacks on Kwangtung Province.
Willard F. Deputy of Laurel, Del., long a leader in the Democratic party in this State, died today at Beebe Hospital, Lewis, Del., where he had been a patient four months. He was 61 years old.
Rochester and Jersey City divided a double-header tonight, the Red Wings taking the opener, 1 to 0, with the Giants coming back to win the second game, 2 to 1.

The special Senatorial Campaign Expenditures Committee will probably request a more detailed expense account from Mayor S. Davis Wilson of Philadelphia, Chairman Sheppard said today. Mayor Wilson opposed Governor Earle for the Senatorial nomination.

Miss Doris Stevens, chairman of the Inter-American Commission of Women, left by airplane this morning for the Dominican Republic at the invitation of President Trujillo to confer with him and other high officials of the Republic on "next steps" for the emancipation of women.

Surrey climbed to third position in the county cricket championship today with a 200-run victory over Middlesex, in the runnerup position. Lancashire dropped to fourth, although victorious on the first innings over Nottinghamshire.

Two upsets marked competition in the second round of the twentysecond annual New York State open Negro championships at the Cosmopolitan Tennis Club yesterday. Teddy Cousins of West Virginia, ranked sixth in the men's singles division, was beaten by John Grayson of New Rochelle, 6-3, 6-1.

Thomas L. Evans, commercial agent of the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad Company at Cincinnati, will retire on next Monday after fifty-two years of railroad service, it; was announced yesterday. William J. Nolan,
A $1,500,000 project to house 500 families has been submitted to the Finance Department, it was learned today. Other lowcost housing projects, ranging up to $1,000,000 each, have been submitted.

Total short position on the New York Curb Exchange on July 29 was 13,992 shares, compared with 15,439 shares on June 30, the Exchange reported yesterday. In only eight issues were there short positions of 500 shares or more,

The strike of 800 employes of the American Safety Razor Corporation, 315 Jay Street, Brooklyn, which began July 1, was settled yesterday with the signing of an agreement between the company and Local 231 of the United Razor Workers Union, C. I. 0. affiliate, at the company's Manhattan office, 22 East Fortieth Street.

The Red Sox staged a seven-run rally in the seventh inning today to capture the first game of a series with the Athletics, 16 to 4. Rookie Jim Tabor provided the big blow of the seventh by hitting a home run with the bases filled.
Veal business continued to hold up. Other classes of traefer meats were slow. Beef lamb and fresh pork cuts were weak to slightly lower, veal hindsaddles were steady.

The International Ladies Garment Workers Union, third largest C. I. O. affiliate, with a membership of 250,000, moved closer yesterday to withdrawal from the C. I. O. when it was learned that none of its affiliated locals would participate in the meeting called by the C. I. O. in New York to form a permanent State-wide organization similar to the New York State Federation of Labor, A. F. of L. affiliate.

The Sharon Steel Corporation on Sept. 1 will place in operation at its Sharon, Pa., works a plant to manufacture insulation blocks from spent pickle liquor, an end-product of steel production previously of no use which had to undergo treatment before it could be released into streams.

The National Labor Relations Board today announced certification of the Screen Writers Guild, Inc., as the exclusive collective bargaining agency for screen writers employed by thirteen Hollywood motion picture producers.
Virginius J. Mayo of this city has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Virginia Mayo, to G. Farrington Fiske of Sherborn, Mass.

Stockholders of the New York and Queens Electric Light and Power Company have received warrants to subscribe to the 8,772 additional shares of 5 per cent non-cumulative preferred stock, the issuance of which has been approved by the Public Service Commission.

A reduction in interest charges and in mortgage debt of the Toledo Edison Company will be effected with the offering to the public today of $30,000,000 first-mortgage 3 1/2 per tent bonds due in 1968 and $6,500,000 of 4 per cent sinking-fund debentures due in 1948.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Aug. 6: COLONEL Harris, G. W.. Inf., three months and 28 days leave. Oct. 3. Gruber, E. L. (F.A.), General Staff Corps, three days extended leave.
France's crack Alpine troops, heavily supported by artillery and aviation, forced "invaders" from the east back from a strategic Alpine pass today in the first day of a four-day program of war games.

A banking group composed of Shields Co., Fenner Beane, Morse Brothers Co., Inc., and B. J. Van Ingen Co., Inc., submitted the highest bid yesterday for $825,000 of public improvement bonds of Memphis, Tenn.
Virginius J. Mayo of this city has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Virginia Mayo, to G. Farrington Fiske of Sherborn, Mass.

Stockholders of the New York and Queens Electric Light and Power Company have received warrants to subscribe to the 8,772 additional shares of 5 per cent non-cumulative preferred stock, the issuance of which has been approved by the Public Service Commission.

A reduction in interest charges and in mortgage debt of the Toledo Edison Company will be effected with the offering to the public today of $30,000,000 first-mortgage 3 1/2 per tent bonds due in 1968 and $6,500,000 of 4 per cent sinking-fund debentures due in 1948.

MANHATTAN AXEL, HELEN A. (Jan. 25, 1938). Gross assets $4,648, net $1,964. To Leon A. Axel, husband, $10,000 and one-half residue; six others were bequeathed onetwelfth residue each. Chief assets, stocks and bonds. $2,437. Morris Deutsch, attorney. 185 Madison Ave. BORLAND, MARGARET W. (June 20, 1937). Gross assets $4,134, net $3,399. To Alexander M. Christie, nephew. Chief assets, mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $4,134. Clarence W. Gaylor, attorney. 15 Broad St.

Lieut. Col. George Huntington Throop, who was in charge of engineering supplies for the Second Army during the World War. died here early this morning in the Veterans' Administration Facility following a heart attack.
Charles Wetherbee, former vice president and superintending engineer of the old Bath Iron Works, Ltd., died suddenly at his home tonight of a heart ailment. His age was 62.

Mayor La Guardia established a the precedent in municipal government yesterday when he directed that Fireman Edward Thompson, one of a group of young lawyers in the Fire Department, be assigned to prosecute fire law violators in court, wearing his uniform.

Two Wards Island property owners who brought suits charging that the Triborough Bridge was erected on part of their land were awarded yesterday nominal damages of $1 for each of their parcels occupied by the city by Supreme Court Justice Charles B. McLaughlin.
France is preparing to make a new effort to renew negotiations for a settlement with Italy which have been abandoned since May.
Without ceremony, content to note only the fact, "Tobacco Road" reaches its 2,000th performance tonight-or only 532 performances behind the all-time consecutive run of "A-'s I-h R-e."

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Aug. 6: COLONEL Harris, G. W.. Inf., three months and 28 days leave. Oct. 3. Gruber, E. L. (F.A.), General Staff Corps, three days extended leave.

William C. Austin, an expert scales repairer, of 1,754 Weirfield Street, Ridgewood, Queens, amazed Municipal Court Justice Harold J. Crawford in Ridgewood yesterday when he insisted that he owed his landlord $84 instead of $48 which the landlord was seeking to collect.

The Boys Athletic League held its first tug-o'-war contest yesterday afternoon at its playground at 26 Washington Street. James Moore, the league's program director, said he hoped that in succeeding years the contest would reach such proportions that its winners could justly call themselves city champions.

Three Soldieris Medals, the army's highest peacetime award, given for acts of bravery, were presented this morning in a colorful military ceremony at Fort Slocum on David's Island, in Long Island Sound.

Secretary of Commerce Roper said that a check-up of economic statistics today showed "that the improved business morale which was in evidence a month ago has been translated into definite business progress."

" A Gentleman From Montana," by Lewis Ransom Foster, appeared today to be Frank Capra's final picture on his Columbia contract. Negotiations are under way with Samuel Goldwyn for the loan of Gary Cooper for the title role, and if he can be secured Jean Arthur will be cast opposite him.

Viscountess d'Alte entertained with a dinner and musical at Eaglestone, the Summer residence of her sister, Miss Frances Coleman, this evening. A large group of the Summer colony attended. The musical program was rendered by Harold Peterson, baritone, with Miss Ethel Cave-Cole at the piano.

Congress passed today a meansure authorizing the government to expropriate properties of the Electric Bond and Share Company. The vote was 40 to 1. The measure includes a grant of power to negotiate a loan to pay indemnity.

Most sections of the bond market on the New York Stock Exchange rallied yesterday, although the gains were not large. Sales eased slightly, amounting to $5,020,800, compared with $5,414,800 on Tuesday.

Mr. and Mrs. Baisley P. Elebash of New York entertained at a mint julip party at the Pillars this afternoon. Their guests were Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Ellis, Mr. and Mrs. F. Peavey Wells, Mr. and Mrs. John J. Hicks Kerr, Mrs. G. Howard Ingalls, Miss Polly Ingalls, Miss Rea Delamater, William F. White, Ernest Iselin Jr., Henry Redmond and Charles Delamater.
More than a ton of marihuana weed, worth at least $250,000 if converted into cigarettes has been pulled up and destroyed during the past week in Point Pelee National- Park, authorities said today.

In the belief that inferior goods have hampered sales, a group of fourteen millmen, manufacturers and retailers of boys' and students' clothing, meeting yesterday at the Aldine Club under the auspices of the Boys Apparel Buyers Association, decided to establish a minimum test for wearability in their products.

The Westhampton Beach crew, captained by Miss Patricia Hansen, carried off the Morgan Bowl today and thus won the right to represent Great South Bay in the Mrs. Charles Francis Adams Trophy series in September.
A series of earthquakes today destroyed three towns, causing undetermined deaths and injuries and damaged buildings in Quito, the capital, and Guayaquil, the country's main port and largest city.
In this space yesterday were set down four conclusions as to the present situation in Europe, of which the first-the open dependence of British economy on ours--Was discussed in some detail.

More than seventy-five persons interested in compulsory trade-mark registration in the State were given an opportunity this afternoon to state their views at a hearing conducted by Miss Doris I. Byrne, executive deputy secretary of State.

Ruth Copeland Studios, floor in 137 W 23d St. through Morgan Barry, Inc, agent, Charles G. Keller, broker. Standard Thread Co, Inc, floor in 48 W 37th St, Al Martin, men's shirts, through Albert M. Greenfield Co, Inc, in 48 W 48th St: Evnrdrest Co, Inc. housecoats, in 125 W 33d St; Adams Co, Real Estate, Inc, broker.

Hogs led a sharp decline of livestock prices today' that continued one of the most pronounced breaks the meat industry has witnessed in months. Dropping 25 to 50 cents, hogs reached the lowest level since Spring and the lowest for August in four years. Most of the sharp upturn the market scored late in May and June has been lost.
Mrs. Carrie Loucks McBrier, wife of Edwin M. McBrier, retired F. W. Woolworth Company executive, died of a heart attack yesterday at her home here.
Representative D. Worth Clark, conservative, who on occasion has opposed President Roosevelt's policies, widened his lead tonight over Senator James P. Pope, New Dealer, who sought renomination.

The demand for gold from the European Continent subsided somewhat today, although sales still were substantial at ??1,519,000. The price of the metal, which has been soaring for several days, fell 1 1/2d to 142s 6d a fine ounce owing to the United States dollar's reaction in foreign exchange to 4.88 3/8 to the pound sterling.

Buyers attending the annual Fall market week of Butler Brothers, dry goods and general wholesalers, have bought little in staple lines, but have ordered freely of fastmoving and novelty merchandise, T. C. Cooper, general manager, declared yesterday.
Dr. Simon L. Ruskin, nose and throat specialist, has purchased the house at 32 East Sixty-seventh Street through the Payson McL. Merrill Company.

If and when the city appropriates funds for the decoration of subway stations with murals and sculpture the Interborough's stations may have to muddle along without this esthetic touch, if the committee which has been sponsoring subway ait has its way.
Luncheon, Rotary Club of New York. Hotel Commodore, 12:15 P. M. "Americanism vs. Radicalism," Representative John O'Connor.

Miss Virginia Winmill, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Winmill of this city and Warrenton, Va., whose marriage to Robert H. Radsch, also of New York, will take place on Sept. 24 in St. James Church, Warrenton.

Rain at the last minute prevented the Dodgers and Phillies from going through with their scheduled contest under the floodlights at Ebbets Field last night, much to the disappointment of some 12,000 Flatbush fans.
Thirty acres of land in Fort Salonga, L. I., has been acquired by the Walter C. Hewitt Organization from the estate of Edison Bradley, Julie Fay Shipman, executrix.

Mrs. W. D. Goss of Baltusrol, N. J., defending champion, defeated Mrs. M. S. Bentham of Saucon Valley, 6 and 5, today in the first round of the annual women's invitation tournament at the Shawnee Country Club.

With another demonstration of her remarkable windward ability, the yawl Baruna, owned by Henry C. Taylor of Cold Spring Harbor, L. I., led the New York Yacht Club fleet here from New London today on its first cruise run. Incidentally,

Sam Chapman celebrated his return to the Athletics' line-up with a home run in the sixth with Bob Johnson on base to give the Mackmen a 5-3 victory over the Red Sox today. He was benched several days ago because he wasn't hitting.

EVEN if a FaZtboot trip down the Mississippi is distinctly out of your line, don't be too quick to pass over Major R. Raven-Hart's "Down the Mississippi."* It happens to be something particularly choice, about as choice a book of its kind as could be imagined-intelligent, lively and immensely informative. It is hard to see why,
Stocks of domestic and foreign refinable crude petroleum at the close of-the week ended July 20 totaled 288,514,000 barrels, according to data compiled by the Bureau of Mines.
Holding the record for the westward crossing of the Atlantic to New York, the Cunard White Star. liner Queen Mary sailed yesterday for Cherbourg and Southampton, carrying 1.143 passengers.

First Lieutenant Joseph E. Heller, Med.Res., 504 Grand St., New York, N. Y., Field Artillery Group, is ordered to active duty for six months, effective Aug. 15, at Headquarters Schenectady District, CCC, Schenectady, N. Y., for assignment and duty in connection With CCC activities. Date of rank, Aug. 15, 1938.
ALONE THROUGH THE FORBIDDIEN LAND, by Gustav Krist. (Harcourt, Brace, $3.50.) The adventures of a young Austrian in Asia.

Rain which started falling shortly after 8 o'clock last night as the first battlers were scheduled to enter the ring at the Polo Grounds, caused a postponement of the world lightweight championship bout between Lou Ambers, the titleholder, and Henry Armstrong, featherweight and welterweight champion.
United States Senator Edward R. Burke, Democrat, of Nebraska, sailed yesterday on the Manhattan of the United States Lines to attend the Inter-Parliamentary Congress at The Hague.

Captain George B. Gale, known to three generations of Atlantic City visitors as skipper of one of the party sailing yachts at the Inlet Yachting Center, died of a heart attack today at his home in Brigantine. He was 70.
New York City yesterday had its first day of "normal" weather since July 25. And for the first time in fifteen days the temperature failed to go above 81 degrees.
Tension among the Jewish population of Palestine is kept up both by terror and sabotage and the threat of the loss of their political position established here.
One of the speakers before the National Institute for Highway Safety Training, now meeting in Michigan, emphasized the importance of

Bertram Browner, 11-year-old son of Mr. and Mrs. William B. Browner of 260 West Walnut Street, Long Beach, who was dead when his mother went to wake him this morning, died of acute glandular strangulation, according to an autopsy this afternoon at Meadowbrook Hospital here.

The United States Government intervened yesterday in the situation that has long marked the stormy relations between employers and the Communist-controlled Fur Workers Union, C. I. O. affiliate, in this city.

Morgan, Stanley Co. made available yesterday an explanation of the genesis and purpose of a memorandum originally drawn up last March and submitted to the Securities and Exchange Commission by the bankers "for discussion," embodying their views as to how the Securities Act and other legislation might be amended to improve or simplify laws, rules and procedure governing the issuance of securities.

Former President Herbert Hoover scanned election returns from Idaho, Ohio and Arkansas today and observed: "These primary returns indicate to me that more than 50 per cent of the Democrats are against the notion of rubber stamps in Congress.

A building and permanent loan of $385,000 hars been obtained by the Sun Rise Realty Corp., Julius S. Wikler, secretary, from the Equitable Life Assurance Society on the eight-story apartment now in the course of construction on the northwest corner of the Grand Concourse and E 172d St.

Residents here inspected today a tablet erected on the site of the western terminal of the first steam railroad passenger service in the United States. The marker was dedicated last night at 803 Crane Street with exercises celebrating
James Lawson, civil engineer well known in the United States and Canada, died yesterday at his home here. His age was 87.

56th St, 9-11 E, and 8-10 E 57th, 50x200.10; one 5-story, one 6-story, stores; one 2story, stores, and one 5-story apartment and stores; City Bank Farmers Trust Co against Park Avenue Operating Co; due, $1,222,034; taxes, $5,395; adjourned to Aug. 17.

A large field of more than thirty-eight teams turned out for the weekly one-day pro-amateur best-ball tournament of the Westchester County Amateur Golf Association, held over the Sleepy Hollow course today.

In an upset, John Grayson of New Rochelle was eliminated from the New York State open Negro championship by Charles F. Jones of New York yesterday at the CosmopoIitan Tennis Club. Jones gained the fourth round by defeating Grayson, 6--4, 3-6, 6-4.

Robert Archambault, 37 years old, of 501 West 110th Street, a car inspector for the Independent Subway, was discharged by Magistrate Thomas A. Aurelio in Homicide Court yesterday when the magistrate found there was no evidence of culpable negligence to sustain a charge of homicide against him.

With Martha Raye weaving punchdrunkenly through scenes of unapologetic slapstick, no script could have been expected to survive anyway, so "Give Me a Sailor," at the Paramount, apparently was made without a script-which didn't solve the problem, either.
Following their protest to the Associated Gas and Electric Company and Northeastern Water Companies, Inc., over the inclusion in a proposed plan of reorganization of

For the information of stamp collectors desiring to obtain issues of the army-navy series of commemorative stamps, or of the 1922-23 regular series, the Postoffice Department announced today that the former soon will be removed from sale at its philatelic agency, and that several stamps of the latter series are approaching depletion.

A highly disturbing piece of news in THE TIMES yesterday was the report that the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity has decided to keep one of its largest pumping stations in this city closed as a precaution against a possible epidemic of typhoid fever in Brooklyn and Queens.

Shipments of finished steel products by the United States Steel Corporation in July totaled 441,570 tons, a decrease of 36,487 tons front 478,057 tons shipped in June and 745,182 tons below shipments of 1,186,752 tons in July, 1937.
Marvelle Christopher Webber, former president of the Vermont State Board of Education and a widely known lawyer, died of a heart attack at his home here last night at the age of 70.

Witnesses before the Senate Civil Liberties Committee today declared that Major Harry Curley, a retired army officer, had bossed the special Massillon city police during the 1937 "Little Steel" strike, and one testified that Major Curley had said he was "going to clean out the union gang" on the night when two men were killed and seven wounded in the vicinity of the Steel Workers Organizing Committee offices.

As an indication of the caution which still prevails in retail purchasing, despite the apparent upturn in general business, one manufacturer of men's furnishings, querying his accounts, found that they had planned on buying 80 per cent of their Fall, 1937, quota for the coming season. This was on the basis of dollar volume, and since prices are down considerably would bring the unit purchases closer to 90 per cent. They indicate,
Five teams-St. Louis, Baltimore, Detroit, New York and Washingtonremained in the running tonight for the twenty-eighth annual union printers' international baseball championship.

The British Union-Castle liner Llandaff Castle, 10,876 tons, was held up yesterday in the Strait of Gibraltar by the armed Spanish Insurgent trawler Inasi while en route to East Africa with 240 passengers, according to passengers landing here.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In his letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES entitled "Birth Rate and Prosperity," Dr. Joseph A. Maffongelli has raised some issues very vital to the American people. Take the following question for example:

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Aug. 9: BRIGADIER GENERAL Gasser, L. D., General Staff Corps, four days' leave, Aug. 9. LIEUTENANT COLONELS Busbee, C M., F. A., General Staff Corps, five days' leave, Aug. 15.

A new money offering will reach the market today when an underwriting group headed by Morgan Stanley Co., Inc., and including Bonbright Co., Inc., Brown Harriman Co., Inc., the First Boston Corporation and Smith, Barney Co., will offer publicly $10,000,000 of first and refunding mortgage bonds, 31/4 per cent series, due 1968, of Public Service Electric and Gas Company. The bonds are priced at 104 3/4 and accrued interest.

Department store sales showed less than the usual seasonal decline from June to July this year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today, and as a result the board's adjusted index rose from 82 to 85 per cent of the 1923-1925 average.

The government's impression concerning the Runciman commission's work here was evinced in an official broadcast tonight, in which it was intimated that Viscount Runciman's conversations in his second week here could be expected to enter the stage of concrete negotiations.

Specialists who will endeavor to save the remaining right eye of Helaine Judith Colan, 4 months old, who was brought here by plane from Chicago on Tuesday, decided not to examine the child yesterday because of a slight cold she had contracted.

Plans for the construction of a Brazilian Pavilion at the World's Fair, containing a tropical garden and many other unusual features, were announced yesterday by the Brazilian Ministry of Labor, Industry and Commerce.

Louis H. Pink, State Insurance Superintendent, approved yesterday the principle of a merit rating plan for automobile accident insurance, which has been worked out by the leading insurance companies and rating agencies in cooperation with the State Insurance Department.

Dr. Robert Donnelly Schimmelpfennig of 65 North Fullerton Avenue, for nineteen years roentgenologist at Mountainside Hospital, died early this morning of a heart attack at his Summer cottage at Belmar, N. J. He was 56 years old.

Alexander Smallens will conduct the Philharmonic- Symphony Orchestra in an all-Stravinsky program tonight at Lewisohn Stadium. The concert will present the "Firebird" Suite, "Symphonie de Psaumes" and "Les Noces."

Quite unofficially, the old postoffice on Park Row was being razed yesterday by workmen of John J. Abramsen Co., Inc., of 864 Whitlock Avenue, the Bronx. The city had not been notified that its bonds and $1 check had been approved and accepted by the Treasury Department in Washington, therefore the activity of the wreckers was only "preliminary. "
Point by point Francis M. Carroll today repudiated 19-year-old Paul N. Dwyer's declaration that the former deputy sheriff killed Dr. James G. Littlefield and his wife.

Arturo Venegas, leader of the Chilean delegation to the World Youth Congress at Vassar College, has been released by immigration authorities on Ellis Island with permission to enter the country as a visitor, it was announced yesterday.

The Duke Power Company, a utility company incorporated in New Jersey and operating in North and South Carolina, filed today an appeal with the Essex County Tax Board for the cancellation of a $15,000,000 personal property assessment levied by the Newark Tax Board.

What amounts to a constitutional guarantee against bond defaults by the various localities in the State, counties, cities, towns and villages was approved today by the Constitutional Convention, which in committee of the whole advanced to third reading the proposed local finance article.

The "divine call" that impelled the ten walking Weavers to hitch-hike the 400 miles from Baltimore to bring the gospel to Boston had been answered today. John J. Weaver, 45, a converted circus rider; his wife, eight children and rolling baggage had reached their destination and spent a night in a house for the first time in nearly two months.
The Department of Agriculture announced today an official forecast of a 2,566,221,000-bushel corn crop, making unnecessary a referendum among farmers on the application of marketing quotas.

Montfrrey, foremost industrial center of Mexico, 150 miles south of the United States border, has become the focal point of a struggle by the Northern Mexican States to force a modification of the central government's more radical policies and to break the backbone of what are here termed the "revolutionary" C. T. M. [Mexican Federation of Labor] unions headed by Vicente Lombardo Toledano.

Although there has been less rainfall in the cotton belt than for several weeks, complaints of weevil activity from various areas had a strengthening influence yesterday on prices on the Cotton Exchange here and the list ended with gains of 7 to 10 points.

Three brands of scotch, Martin's V. V. O., distributed by McKesson Robbins; Peter Dawson, sold by Julius Wile Sons Co., and Grant's scotch, handled by Austin Nichols Co., felt the pressure of pricecutting in the retail liquor market yesterday when retailers offered them at $2.79.

John W. Lane, who as a New Jersey Assemblyman sponsored the bill paving the way for the development of the Port of Newark, died today at the Palmer Nursing Home in Summit, N. J. Mr. Lane, who resided here with his son, Cecil F. Lane, was 77 years old.
