The following table shows the fifteen most active stocks traded in on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday; also the new highs and lows for the last three days:

To the tunes of "Home, Sweet Home" and "Auld Lang Syne," played by theSixteenth Infantry Band, 2,020 Citizens Military Training Camp candidates left here and marched to the railway station this morning,

The Workers Alliance of America, an organization of relief workers and unemployed, which claims it controls 2,000,000 votes in forty-six States, announced today that it will ask every candidate for Congress to state his position on the relief and recovery problem, particularly as respects the WPA.

The Municipal Division Council, for which plans were approved in May by the board of governors of the Investment Bankers Association of America, now has been formally organized, it was announced yesterday by John S. Linen, chairman of the municipal securities' committee of the association.
Joseph M. Roebling of New York entertained at a luncheon before the races today Mr.'and Mrs. Rufus C. Finch, Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Tatum and Mrs. Ferdinand W. Roebling Jr. of New York.

Lotte Lehmann, German soprano of the Metropolitan Opera Company, arrived yesterday on the French liner Champlain with her three stepsons, Ludwig, 23; Hans, 20, and Peter, 19. Mme. Lehmann said that she, her stepsons and her stepdaughter Manon, 22, who arrived recently, were on the German quota and would apply for United States citizenship.

Lancaster M. Greene, trustee, announced yesterday that the Henry George School of Social Science had purchased from the New York Telephone Company the five-story building at 30-32 East Twenty-ninth Street.

Civil Service employes of the State Liquor Control Board, supposedly free from political domination, were added today to the list of other Federal, State and WPA workers whom Democratic leaders are attempting to bludgeon for campaign funds.

Radio Night, and elaborate program scheduled for the Lewisohn Stadium last night, was postponed because of rain. At the first drizzle, which fell a few minutes after 8 o'clock, there were already about 3,000 people in the audience, most of whom went to the Great Hall of New York City College, where a substitute orchestral program was given.
Nearly 1,000,000 men, about equally divided between Russia and Japan, face each other on the border between Siberia and Korea, according to the best information obtainable here.

A. E. Newman, formerly manager of the conduit and wire and cable sales section of General Electric Company, Bridgeport, Conn., has been appointed manager of the company's wiring materials sales section, it was announced yesterday.

The Bronv Housirig Corporation of 551 Fifth Avenue filed yesterday plans for two two-story dwellings to cost $7,000 each and thirteen twostory houses to cost $5,000 eachThe $7,000 houses will be erected on Wickham Avenue, near Bussing, and the others on Edson Avenue, at Pitman. G. I. Prowler is the architect for the project.

RKO-Radio Pictures will release fifty-four feature-length films and 199 short subjects during the 19381939 season, it was announced yesterday by Ned E. Depinet, vice president in charge of distribution.
Not yet official, but regarded as likely, is a report that Guthrie McClintic will acquire "Mamba's Daughters," the Du Bose and Dorothy Heyward play that Sam H. Grisman recently relinquished.

Dr. William H. Mace, dean emeritus of the University of Syracuse, died today at his Summer home here. He had spent the Summer months here for the past thirty years and enjoyed good health until a few days ago. His age-was 85.

It is good news for Ohio and for all persons who believe in good government that Governor Davey of Ohio has been defeated. Yet it is unpleasant to notice by how small a margin of votes he failed to be renominated for a third term. His two misadministrations were not rebuked at the polls as they should have been.
President Roosevelt at a Warm Springs, Ga., luncheon publicly endorsed Lawrence Camp for Senator, over Senator George, who has opposed New Deal programs.

A total value of $11,131,425 was reported yesterday in the first accounting filed in Surrogates' Court for the estate of Arthur Lehman, brother of the Governor and senior partner of the investment banking firm of Lehman Brothers, who died on May 16, 1936.

Appointment of thirty-two faculty assistants and the award of sixteen scholarships at Fordham University for the year 1938-39 were announced yesterday by the Rev. Gustave Dumas; dean of the graduate school. The list, representing eleven departments, follows:
The body of William W. Gilmore, 72 years old, of 285 Post Avenue, was found hanging from a beam in a shed adjoining the Quaker Cemetery here this morning. Gilmore,

Starting in the first round, when Miss Barbara Hunter of the Knollwood Club defeated Mrs. Henry H. Dietrich of Green Meadow, the former Miss Betty Pietsch, one-time Metropolitan and Westchester champion, upset followed upset in the opening match-play stages of the annual New York State women's golf championship on the Cherry Valley course today.

Wheat prices were on the upgrade today, and for the first time in five days no new low levels were established for the season. Houses which frequently act for mills and exporters were good buyers of futures, and the trade had reports of a much better domestic demand for flour.
The large automobile plants in and near Detroit have started intensive operations which will grow in volume until a majority of them will be back to normal.
Electric power production increased last week against a seasonal easing and the adjusted index rose to 95.1 from 93.6. The figure was 106.8-for the week ended Aug. 7, 1937.

For the first time since the signature of the Anglo-Italian agreement last April the British Government has been forced to take public diplomatic action over stories of continuing Italian intervention in Spain.

The announcement last night in Moscow of a truce between Russian and Japanese forces relieves a tension which has been rapidly increasing. With guns pounding over a lengthening front and the curtain lifting to reveal airplanes, artillery and tanks in businesslike action on the Manchurian border, it has been difficult to believe that we were witnessing just another incident on a long-disturbed frontier.

Simon Schuster report that "The World Is Mine: The Extravagant Story of a Modern Monte Cristo," by William J. Blake, has ex-hausted two printings within a week of publication. The book is in its third printing.
Nature has smiled upon the great dust bowl and temporarily ended the "blows" which in the last eight years have threatened to deplete 97,000,000 acres of its valuable top soil.

Hope is high here that Southeastern Colorado's section of the dust bowl may again bloom green with old-time bumper crops, planted on limited acreage, the result of the combined educational and material aid given farmers in Baca, Powers, Bent and Kiowa Counties by both the Federal Soil Conservation Service and the State Agricultural Department.

A Catholic Youth Organization in Manila, modeled after the New York society, has been formed by Manila Council 1000, Knights of Columbus, under the direction of its chaplain, Father George J. Willmann, S. J., formerly director of the Jesuit Seminary Fund and Jesuit Philippines Bureau, with offices at 51 East Eighty-third Street.

More 'than one-third of the students who answered a questionnaire on-school failures at the Summer session of Erasmus Hall High School in Brooklyn blamed themselves for inability to pass regular School courses, it was revealed yesterday.

The resignation of Alan White, assistant general manager in charge of merchandising for the Namm Stoke, Brooklyn, to join the merchandising department of the Schenley Products Company, was announced yesterday at a farewell luncheon tendered Mr. White by directors and members of the executive committee of the store.

Members of the Department whose daughters have graduated from High School, as of June 1938, commencement, are requested to forward a report, on Aug. 15, to the Office Chief of Department. giving the marks received in each subject, together with the final average received upon graduation. Negative reports are not required in this instance.

Finance Commissar Arseny Gregorevitch Zvereff announced before the joint session of the Supreme Soviet (Parliament) today that 27,000,000,000 rubles had been allotted this year to the defense commissariats. There was great applause.
The election of F. L. Suter as first vice president of the Armstrong Cork Company was announced today by H. W. Prentis Jr., president.

The dream of every philatelist came true today for Warren R. du Bois. Three months ago he bought a collection from an estate for $300. Included was a one-cent blue issue, which he catalogued and marked for sale at $3. It went unsold.
Ambassador Joseph P. Kennedy today purchased a submarine harpoon gun such as is being used by Riviera sportsmen this season and his son, Jack, will take it home as a gift for President Roosevelt.
Based on the report of the Department of Agriculture, released after the close of the markets yesterday, the principal grain crops generally made favorable progress in July.
Jay E. Crane was elected yesterday treasurer of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey. He succeeds R. P. Resor, who has retired.

The leasing of a large suite of rooms in the Yorkville section of Manhattan featured apartment renting yesterday, when a duplex of fifteen rooms and seven baths was taken by Perry E. Hall, vice president of Morgan Stanley Co., investment bankers, in the building at 10 Gracie Square.
President Federico Laredo Bru announced tonight a Cabinet composed of seven Secretaries who were in the Cabinet that resigned two days ago and six new members.

The true purpose of the visit paid yesterday to Count Galeazzo Ciano, Italian Foreign Minister, by Jules Blondel, the French Charge d'Affaires in Rome, was to lodge a protest against the decision of the Italian authorities to refuse passports to 8,000 Italian tourists who intended to go to France Aug. 15 for their holidays.
Puerto Rico's income tax should be the same as the Federal tax, Governor Blanton Winship told a special session of the Legislature opening today.
That Mrs. Willis Sharpe Kilmer has the best horse of her career was demonstrated today when Lucky Omen, a son of Gino from Sun Miss. decisively won the Northumberland Handicap. Mrs.

When Judge-elect Brown Taylor takes over his duties in General Sessions Court here Sept. 1 the slate will be clear in so far as his debtors are concerned. "Since some of you who still owe me may feel embarrassed to have matters in my court,"

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it would enter an order approving the application of the Indianapolis Light and Power Company for exemption from provisions of the Public Utility Act requiring the filing of a declaration with regard to the issuance of $32,000,000 in thirty-year 3 3/4 per cent first mortgage bonds and $5,500,000 in ten-year serial notes.

Light-tackle enthusiasts will be glad to hear that the famous Catalina Tuna Club of Avalon, Calif., will offer two trophies for the largest marlin and tuna taken on regulation tuna-club heavy tackle on the Atlantic Coast of North America. Van Campen Heilner,

Thirty-six non-Federal projects having an estimated construction cost of $6,645,159 today were added to the 1938 program of the Public Works Administration, which allocated to them grants totaling $2,935,837.

Miss Georgette Whelan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Smith Whelan of 1,220 Park Avenue, has chosen Sept. 8 as the date for her marriage to Guy Gerard Rutherfurd of Allamuchy, N. J. The wedding will take place in this city. The place for the ceremony has not yet been selected.

Eugene B. Clark, president of the Clark Equipment Company, denied today that his firm had any connec,tion with the meeting here Aug. 3, at which Representative Clare E. Hoffman of Michigan issued a challenge that the National Labor Relations Board stop him from

Mrs. Grace Milgram, assistant secretary of the Workers Defense League of New Jersey, solicited signatures for an anti-Hague petition at homes and on the streets of Jersey City today in a test of her right to do so without a permit from the police. Mrs. Milgram,

Miss Bernice Offenberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Otto Offenberg of this city, was married last night in the Terrace Club of the St. Moritz to Dr. Robert Tepper, also of New York, by the Rev. Dr. Nathalie Frischberg.

Behind the speed-ball pitching of Miss Thelma Golden, who permitted only two safeties and struck out fifteen, the Langley-Lakesides of Toronto, one of the leading teams in Canada, blanked the New York Roverettes, 2 to 0, in the star contest of the women's softball doubleheader at Madison Square Garden last night.

William Shillaber, retired lawyer and formerly treasurer and part owner of the old New York Globe, died Tuesday after a heart attack at the Lake Placid Club, it was learned here yesterday. He was 70 years old.
The Securities and Exchange Commission announced the following hearing dates today:

Scores of friends and business associates of her husband, Walter P. Chrysler, automobile manufacturer, attended the private funeral services yesterday for Mrs. Chrysler in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church on Park Avenue.

Charges of communist influence within the National Maritime Union, C. I. O. seamen's affiliate, which resulted recently in open physical clashes at the union hall, were repeated yesterday by spokesmen of a group of Negro members.

Matthew Kenny, secretary of James J. Hines's Monongahela Democratic Club of the Eleventh Assembly District, was dismissed from a contempt-action yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora at the request of Assistant District Attorney Sol Gelb without comment.
Superior Oil Company of California capital stock, $25-par value, has been listed on the New York Curb Exchange in the amount of 425,027 shares.
Physicians attending David Rubinoff, violinist, said today that, barring another relapse, he would be able to leave Harper Hospital soon. Mr.

Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens, who announced recently his readiness to run for Governor as the candidate of a new Conservative party, was endorsed last night by the Taxpayers Group of New York at a meeting at the Hotel Commodore.

The Associates Investment Company reports for the first half of 1938 a consolidated net income of $1,946,416, compared to $2,771,215 in the 1937 period, which is equivalent to $2.87 a share on the common stock after preferred dividends.

Improper pronunciation and failure to maintain classroom discipline were held today by the New Jersey Commissioner of Education, Charles H. Elliott, to constitute sufficient cause to dismiss a school teacher.

This is one of those stories not often believed true, But it is. It concerns a 7-year-old boy to whom was assigned a job as a laborer on a WPA project. When he didn't go to work, he received a letter asking him to explain why.

A complaint accusing the National Transportation Company, operator of the Parmelee taxicab system, of labor espionage and the fostering of a company union was filed with the State Labor Relations Board yesterday by the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O. affiliate.

Two county cricket matches scheduled to start today were delayed a day by rain, while in another contest Northamptonshire had scored 134 runs for five wickets against Essex when rain interfered. No play was possible at Lord's between Middlesex and Kent and at Cheltenham between Gloucestershire and Nottinghamshire.
A Freeholders' meeting today balloted, 15 to 11, to lift the ban on fishing from bridges that gap tidewater streams feeding the back-bay waters near here.

The estate of Mme. Marie De Cartier, wife of Baron Emile De Cartier, Belgian Ambassador, was worth $245,339 last July 21, according to an accounting filed in Surrogate's Court yesterday by Bronson Winthrop, executor and trustee.

Representatives of the New York needlework trades, who are interested in building up Puerto Rico's second industry with an estimated output of $20,000,000 annually, will sail for Puerto Rico tomorrow, according to word received today from Edward J. Leon, their attorney.

In an article in the current issue of I The American Magazine, Postmaster t General Farley speaks of "men like Dr. Morgan, who think they are pursuing the only pure course by refusing to acept recommendations from Senators and Congressmen" in the matter of appointments.

The body of Alfred Irene du Pont, former head of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., who died at his Florida home in 1935, will be moved, probably next month, to a new mausoleum erected at a cost of $400,000 on the Nemours estate near here.

Japan's action against China was defended today by Felix Antonio Hernandez, well-known Salvadorean writer, in an article published in La Prensa. He recommends that Salvadoreans study the case of Japan with regard to her stand against communism.

The fight over control of the State's water-power resources was renewed today in the Constitutional Convention as the Democrats, in a party conference, agreed to go along with the proposal sponsored by Charles Poletti, and as former Supreme Court Justice Joseph M. Proskauer, counsel to the Niagara Hudson Corporation, presented his side of the case to the delegates in the lobby of the Assembly chamber.
Dr. and Mrs. Everett C. Jessup of Minima, Roslyn, .L. I., will give a tea dance to introduce their daughter, Miss Mary Constance Jessup, on Sept. 16 at the Piping Rock Club, Locust Valley.

The teaching profession in New York City, with its security of tenure and pension rights, is luring an increasing number of men into its ranks since economic conditions have made employment in other fields uncertain, figures made known yesterday at the Board of Education indicated.

Belief that the upward trend in furniture prices, forecast at the trade opening here last month, has begun to materialize was expressed here yesterday by furniture producers and retailers following an announcement by the Bassett Industries of Bassett, Va., of a 10 per cent advance in prices of their lowend lines.

Douglas Corrigan today came to the capital to receive, as he had re-. quested, a "dignified" reception almost entirely devoid of paper snowstorms but one as prolific of jests on his "wrong way" flight as the wits of Washington could make it.

A resolution suggesting that the United States grant independence to Puerto Rico and pardon Puerto Ricans now serving sentences at the Atlanta penitentiary has been introduced in the Cuban House of Representatives by Dr. Jose Pascual, a National Democrat.
Eight additional results were recorded in the international masters tournament of the British Chess Federation at the Royal Pavilion, the third round of which was contested today.
The statement of the Central Bank of Argentina for July 31 shows gold reserve ratio to notes in circulation at 122.14 per cent, compared with 122.59 per cent on July 15.

Evans Dunn, assistant general counsel of the Tennessee Valley Authority, denied today that he had shielded or protected any one, or held back any material or relevant evidence in his conduct of the condemnation proceedings in the Berry marble claims last year.
Twelve persons were killed, their bodies burned beyond recognition, in the crash of a three-motored Hungarian passenger plane near here today.

Private Donald H. Link, 21 years old, of Salem, a member of Company I, 114th Infantry, New Jersey National Guard, was found hanging from the center pole of a vacant tent at the National Guard encampment here this morning.

Former State Senator Walter S. Mack and Assemblyman Abbot Low Moffat repudiated yesterday the candidacy of Bronson Trevor of 11 East Ninety-first Street, for whom petitions are being circulated naming him as a candidate for member of the Republican State Committee from the Fifteenth Manhattan Assembly District, against Kenneth F. Simpson, the incumbent.

For winning the most points in deoorative arrangement classes at the Williamstown Garden Club flower show last night, Mrs. Carl W. Johnson received a trophy presented by Mrs. George Alfred Cluett. Second and third prizes were won by Mrs. Cluett and Miss Florence Cluett.
Paraguay in a plebiscite today approved by a 10-to-1 vote the Bolivian-Paraguayan Chaco peace treaty. The plebiscite was to ratify the treaty, signed July 21 at Buenos Aires.

The Constitutional Convention, in a "never again" mood, advanced today to third reading an amendment which provided that the next convention be held in 1959, an off year, in order to avoid the shadow of politics in a Gubernatorial year.

The Eastman Kodak Company reports a net profit of $7,051,673 for the twenty-four weeks ended on June 11, equal after preferred dividends to $3.05 a share earned on 2,250,921 no-par common shares, compared with $11,475,066, or $5.01 a share, earned in the comparable period of 1937.

Senator Morris Sheppard, chairman of the Senate Committee to Investigate Senatorial Campaign Expenditures, said today that he believed that political candidates were within their rights in soliciting funds from WPA employes, provided that they did not attempt to coerce them.

John D. M. Hamilton, chairman of the National Republican Committee, asserted to a thousand women from Connecticut cities and towns this afternoon in Wilcox's pavilion at Savin Rock that under Republican auspices the American working man was protected in his industrial and economic competition better than by any other party.

The membership of the First National Institute for Traffic Safety Training moved to the 1,200-acre General Motors proving ground in this village in a body this afternoon. They had an eye-opening demonstration of safety driving and safety testing practically applied.

The Interstate Commerce Commission granted authority today to the Public Service Consolidated Transport, a New Jersey corporation operating street car and bus services in Southern New Jersey in both interstate and intrastate commerce, to issue $1,224,000 in serial equipment promissory notes.

The Boston Yacht Club's single contribution to the midsummer series today was a fleet of 417 large and small yachts sailing gayly away on the wings of a moderate southeaster: The mark came within twenty boats of establishing a new world's record, which stands at 436, made last year.

Leander B. Faber, official referee, denied yesterday the city's motion to dismiss certiorari proceedings by which the B. M. T. is seeking a review of the action of the State Tax Commission in levying franchise taxes on the company's surface car properties in 1917.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today the adoption of a new rule, to be called Rule U-3D-13, under the Holding Company Act which exempts certain limited acquisitions of utility assets made by electric and gas companies in registered holding companies.

Fred Hoch, merchant here for forty-four years, died at his home, 172 West Main Street, today. He was to have sailed July 2 to join his wife, Mary, in Germany for his first vacation in many years, but he became ill on that day.
In the last forty-eight hours Insurgents operating on the Estremadura front in Southwestern Spain have advanced fifteen miles.

The Works Progress Administration, to which New Yorkers have looked as a first line of' defense against mosquitoes, admitted yesterday that it had abandoned one phase of the battle despite a sharp increase in the mosquito population.

The Jinx which followed Miss Patty Berg through three women's Western golf derbies, apparently had been lost today as the Minneapolis girl, runner-up in the event for the past three Summers, turned in her third straight sub-par round, a 75, for a 54-hole total of 226 strokes.

Trading Improved on steer hinds and ribs but prices were very uneven In local markets yesterday. Veal and calf business slowing up other classes slow. Fresh pork prices weak to lower, other classes mostly unchanged. Early trading in kosher meats indicated beef to be strong to slightly higher and other classes strong to sharply higher. Conditions, as reported by the United States Department of Agrlculture, follow:

Gathering a point in each of the fourth and fifth rounds, Anthony E. Santasiere of the Marshall Chess Club of New York took the lead today in the annual title tournament of the New York State Chess Association.

The House of Deputies passed on second reading a reform Constitution bill and sent it to the Senate, where its passage is almost certain. Fifty-eight delegates will be chosen in November to form a body to discuss constitutional reforms.

In a most extraordinary exhibition of something or other, all more or less foreign to the exacting manner in which the great American game of baseball is supposed to be played these days, the Yankees and Senators battled each other for three hours it the Stadium yesterday when, with both sides apparently at the end of their resources, chunky Harry Kelley finally found a way out of the difficulty.
The Vienna police chief issued drastic traffic regulations today, prefaced by an announcement that street accidents in May showed a total of eighteen killed and 507 injured in 514 aocidents.

Weather clear, track fast. Not like last year on Hambletonian Day, when a thunderstorm came rolling down the mountain, blew all the tents apart, dispersed the horses and spectators and forced a postponement.
Mediation of the railroad wage dispute will be started at 11 o'clock tomorrow morning here.
The moon is a ghostly wind that blows Down from the sky, and it drives the sea Back and forth in a ceaseless tide With the might of its sorcery.

The statement of the United States Rubber Company for the six months ended on June 30, made public today, shows a consolidated deficit of $239,213 after charges, taxes, minority interest and an adjustment of $1,775,365 to put inventories at market prices.

Zinc production in the United States in July was 30,362 tons, compared with 30,799 in June and 49,181 tons in July last year, according to the American Bureau of Metal Statistics. Shipments in July were 33,825 tons, against 29,248 in June and 49,701 in July, 1937.

The German Government today announced the award to James David Mooney, president of General Motors Overseas Corporation, of the Order of Merit of the German Eagle, first class. The award was among seventy-eight decorations listed in the Official Gazette.
An Italian woman and her son petitioned Secretary Morgenthau for aid to day to save their life savings, two gold bricks, from seizure.

Governor Earle's use of the Pennsyl- h vania Legislature to curtail the powers of the grand jury has had a salutary effect in this State. The grand jury here is protected only by statute. Some time may not political passion induce the New York Legislature to repeal or mutilate that statute? It won't do to sit comfortably, confident that what has happened in Pennsylvania can't happen in New York.

William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation, confirmed yesterday a report that the official conduct of Milton Solomon, former Deputy City Controller in charge of the Emergency Tax Division, and two civil service employes immediately under him had been under investigation by his office for several months.

A suit to enjoin the new American Federation of Labor Seaman's Union from taking over the membership and jurisdiction of the old International Seamen's Union was filed yesterday in Supreme Court by Gustav H. Brown on behalf of himself and all other -officials and members of the older organization.

The twomonth-old Japanese naval and military drive up the Yangtze River toward Hankow appears to have been ordered halted, according to foreign naval reports received In Shanghai from the Kiukiang area today.
Justo Suarez, noted Argentine lightweight boxer, died at 12:50 A. M. today of tuberculosis in a sanitarium where he had been under treatment. He was 29 years old.

Additional engagements of $1,860,000 in gold in England for shipment here were reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, although the pound sterling rallied in the foreign exchange market from its recent acute weakness.
Edwin Harris, distinguished Dickensian, died here today in Kent, the setting for many episodes in the novelist's stories. His age was 79.
Lon Warneke rationed the ravenous Pirates on four hits for seven innings today to give the Cardinals a 5-to-0 triumph when rain halted the first game of a scheduled double-header.

ADEE-Sally Comly, suddenly, at her resldence, Monroe, N. Y., on Aug. 9, beloved wife of William T. Adee, and daughter of Katherine V. W. Comly and the late Gerrard Comly, in her twenty-sixth year. Funeral services at St. Mary's, Tuxedo, 11 A. M., Thursday, Aug. 11, 1938.

The police found yesterday the dark blue sedan used in the $50,000 hold-up of the Banco di Napoli at First Avenue and Twelfth Street on Aug. 1. Since the evening of the hold-up it had been standing in a parking lot at Irving Place and Eighteenth Street, nine blocks from the bank.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following order today, dated Aug. 8:

The defeat of Senator James P. Pope, ardent New Dealer, in yesterday's primary in Idaho was regarded in Washington today as the first real blood drawn by either side in the Democratic party's bitter family row, now prevalent throughout the country.

Carl Wilde, Federal referee in bankruptcy, said today an order would be entered to dispose of the assets of the Stutz Motor Car Company as a result of a hearing on a creditor's petition for the sale. The date for the sale will be set later.

Miss Mildred S. Childress Cole, daughter of Mrs. Herbert Claiborne Cole of New York and the late Dr. Cole, was married yesterday afternoon in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church to Samuel Stanhope Labouisse, son of Mrs. Samuel Stanhope Labouisse of New Orleans and the late Mr. Labouisse. The Rev.

Jersey City's Giants collected thirteen hits for an easy 11-to-1 victory over the Rochester Red Wings today. The Little Giants belted Si Johnson, veteran Rochester right-hander, for six runs in the first three innings.

Thousands of gladiolus blooms of every shade, a number of them from gardens in Vermont and Ohio, filled the exhibition hall in Rockefeller Center yesterday at the opening of the ninth annual show of the Metropolitan Gladiolus Society.

Mrs. Bruce Bromley, an ardent Republican worker for Mayor La Guardia in his 1933 and 1937 campaigns, was appointed as a member of the Board of Child Welfare by the Mayor at the Summer City Hall yesterday.

Longwood Ave (10-2696), n s, 41 ft w of Dawson St, 78x107; Julia Lorber to Ezra Holding Corp. 152 W 42d St, mtg $77,000. Cruger Ave, 2,765 (16--4509), Samuel S. Goldberg to Belle Weisberg, 2,765 Cruger Ave.
A 17-yearold Californian went out on the turf of the Westchester Country Club this morning and proceeded to put Montebello on the tennis map in capitals.

The aged Bechuanaland native to whom Sir John Harris referred in a letter to The Times of London was identified here as Ramonotwane, not Ramonolwana, whose age, as the result of an investigation by The

In connection with the call for tenders on $23,800,000 of debentures of thirteen mortgage companies of which the Maryland Casualty Company is the guarantor of interest, but not of principal, on the issues in question, it was explained yesterday that the corporation /had undertaken not to pay more than liquidating value for any debentures until a court ruling has been obtained on this point.
There was pleasant news for the Giants on the score board at the Bees' field today when, shortly after 3 o'clock, the big white numerals revealed that the Pirates had been shut out by the Cards.
Joseph V. Nichols, for thirty years attached to the chief clerk's office of the Police Department, died yesterday in Holy Family Hospital, Brooklyn.
A request for the public to count meteors tomorrow and Friday nights was issued-today by Dr. C. P. Olivier, director of the American Meteor Society.
Movements of vessels follow. All dates are Aug. 10, unless specified:
An important extension of the Netherlands airlines, connecting Australia and Java with the Eastern Asiatic continent, was announced today.
The body of the Tashai Lama, who died nine months ago while en route to Tibet, remains unburied at Kantse on the Tibetan-Chinese border.

With the completion of an 840mile long-distance telephone line extending through the heart of the most productive region of Argentina, President Ortiz and the Governors of four provinces started nation-wide telephone service in Argentina yesterday, according to an announcement here by the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.
The Cubs took a tighter hold on third place today by defeating the Reds, 6 to 3, in the second game of the series.

Cross Keys, paired with Dixieland as the D. B. Midkoff entry, today led thirteen rivals to the wire in the Betsy Williams Stakes, a $5,000 added six-furlong dash for 3-yearold fillies, feature at Narragansett Park.

The death of Major Morris S. Daniels Jr., U. S. A., at Honolulu yesterday, was announced here by the War Department today. Last stationed at Fort DeRussey, he was commissioned as a reserve officer in the World War and won a commission in the regular army.

McLin, bay son of Mr. McElwyn and Ethelinda, she by the immortal' Peter the Great, today won the thirteenth trotting of the Hambletonian Stake, classic of the light harness turf, in two straight heats.

Mr. and Mrs. Michael M. van Beuren won first place in the main exhibit of the Newport Flower Show which opened at the Newport Casino this afternoon. Mr. and Mrs. G. J. Guthrie Nicholson lost the award by a half point.

Stockholders of the Phillips Petroleum Company will get the right to subscribe to the new issue of $25,000,000 of 3 per cent convertible debentures to be dated Sept. 1, 1938, at 100 per cent of par value, according to a letter sent them yesterday signed by Frank Phillips, chairman, and K. S. Adams. president.
Mrs. Wilfred J. Funk entertained with a beach supper tonight in front of Cobble Court, her home. The guests included several older friends as well as a group of younger members of the Summer colony.

Up-State sentiment for drafting District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey for the Republican nomination for Governor is increasing daily, according to reports received at the party's State headquarters, it was learned yesterday.
William R. H. Trowbridge, London banker, formerly of this city, died in London Sunday of a heart attack at the age of 72, according to an announcement made here today.

The Soviet Union and Japan agreed yesterday to call a halt to their fighting along the Manchukuoan border. The armistice was to take effect at 11 o'clock last night, New York time, with the rival forces retaining the positions held twelve hours before the cessation of hostilities.
Premier Prince Fumimaro Konoye today asked the initial session of the National General Mobilization Council to draft two clauses of the National Mobilization Act for enactment by Imperial ordinance.

Joseph V. Connolly, general manager of the Hearst Newspapers, announced today the appointment of Merrill C. Meigs as publisher of the Chicago American and Harry A. Koehler as publisher of the Herald and Examiner. Mr. Meigs and Mr. Koehler succeed Emanuel Levi, who resigned as publisher of both papers.

The touring Oxford-Cambridge team of England was all out for 355 runs in the first innings as its first fourday match against Jamaica started at Sabina Park today. The collegians, who won the toss, elected to bat first on a perfect wicket. The weather was good, although rain threatened occasionally.
Amendments to the New York Stock Exchange rule covering commissions charged by members on transactions in foreign markets were adopted by the board of governors yesterday. As amended,

A demand for investigation of the actions of Edwin S. Smith, a member of the National Labor Relations Board, was made here last night by Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, a union affiliated with the American Federation of Labor.

James J. Connors, Collector of Customs at Juneau, Alaska, reported to the Treasury Department today that because of the expansion of Alaskan mining industries the Territory had increased its purchases of merchandise from the United States in the fiscal year 1938 by more than $4,000,000 over 1937.
The Browns had a ball game in the bag today-until the ninth inning when Fred Johnson weakened and was pounded for five runs to give the Indians a 9-to-6 victory.

The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company will introduce its new Double-Eagle Air-Wheel tire, using rayon instead of cotton as a basic material, in a full page in one national magazine next week. Two other magazines will also be used, with newspaper plans still indefipite. Currently,
Allen Co. announced yesterday that they had purchased and placed 44,000 shares of Marine Midland Corporation and a block of Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation stock.

After stipulating that the Labor Stage, Inc., producers of "Pins and Needles," must comply with the city building and fire laws, Mayor La Guardia signed a local law yesterday exempting the organization from payment of a $500 yearly city license fee.

Shields Co., B. J. Van Ingen Co., Inc., Morse Bros. Co., Inc., and Fenner Beane are offering today at prices to yield 0.40 to 2.70 per cent, according to maturity, $825,000 city of Memphis, Tenn., 2.60 per cent public works bonds. The issue is due Aug. 1, 1939 to 1968 inclusive.
The White Sox pummeled three pitchers for fifteen hits and then put down a late Detroit rally today to win, 8 to 7. The defeat was the first for the Tigers under Del Baker's management.

J. S. Bata, Czech .shoe magnate, has just declared in the magazine Zlin: "I would not be ashamed to be a Jew despite all the attacks of the German press. I would feel equal with all people. But I am no Jew."

At the end of 36 holes of play, the Long Island Golf Association best-ball team title was still undecided tonight. Ray Outhier, U. S. G. A. public links official in the metropolitan district, and his partner, Steve Frahm of Clearview, posted a net of 132 for their two rounds over the Sands Point Club course.

The need for parks, playgrounds and play areas in the congested section of the lower East Side from Twelfth Street to Corlears Hook was stressed in communications to Mayor La Guardia, Borough President Stanley M. Isaacs and Park Commissioner Robert Moses from the community affairs committee

The United States and Great Britain today reached a partial settlement of the dispute about sovereignty over the tiny Pacific islands of Canton and Enderbury by agreeing formally that each should have equal privileges in using the islands for commercial air transport and communications facilities.

The report of the Western Union Telegraph Company, Inc., for the first six months of this year, issued yesterday, shows a net loss of $1,518,701, after taxes, depreciation, interest and other charges. This contrasts with a net income of $2,132,233, equal to $2.04 a share on the outstanding capital stock, earned in the first half of 1937.

New business of the steel industry thus far in August has been running in excess of the July weekly average, which in turn exceeded that of June, according to Iron Age. "While automotive buying for initial production of new models has contributed somewhat to the better volume," it says,

In a strongly worded condemnation of Manhattan Borough President Stanley M. Isaacs, Jeremiah F. Cross, retiring State Commander of the American Legion, will tell the opening session of the twentieth annual State convention here tomorrow that the Legion plans no further efforts to oust Simon W. Gerson, Mr. Isaacs's Communist assistant.

Stockholders of the Allegheny Steel Company and of the Ludlum Steel Company, at special meetings held yesterday in Pittsburgh, Pa., and at Pompton Lakes, N. J., respectively, approved the merger of the two companies into the Allegheny Ludlum Steel Corporation, with total assets of about $32,000,000 and working capital of $10,000,000.

The two-family residence at 1,572 Fifty-fifth Street, Brooklyn, has been sold by Harry A. Huff to an investing client of Frank J. Scalise ,for cash. Assessed at $7,000, the dwelling contains eleven rooms and two baths.

The State Athletic Commission, in response to a writ of certiorari served on behalf of John Henry Lewis, whose light heavyweight title the board has declared vacated, will be asked to show cause for its action Monday in the Supreme Court, Major Gen. John J. Phelan, chairman, revealed yesterday.

Walter R. Darby, State Municipal Finance Commissioner, has notified William A. Wachenfeld, District Attorney of Essex County, that an audit by an accounting concern disclosed "overexpenditures and expenditures without appropriation" of at least $1,214,000 by the Newark City Commission in 1937.

Robert Gordon's Shadow of the Pequot Club, Fairfield, with a total of 40 points, won the series of five races in the tenth annual junior competition for the Commodore Robert Law Trophy, staged by the Indian Harbor Yacht Club of Greenwhich.

The name Henry Fitz means little today. Yet Fitz was as much a part of old New York as Phineas T. Barnum. For Fitz was an optician and lens-maker-the foremost in America. In 1846 he made a 12-inch lens and mounted it for astronomical observation. Newspaper editors wrote in awe of this colossus.
Miss Miss Frieda S. Miller, second woman to head New York's Labor Department, took the oath of office today within a few minutes after her formal appointment by Governor Lehman.
More than 500 over-the-counter securities dealers and investment bankers of Chicago heard some advice from government officials today as to how they should conduct their business in the future.

The International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., reported yesterday for the first six months of this year a net profit of $16,732,251, after deductions for income and franchise taxes, depreciation, depletion and other expenses.

Edward E. Bartlett Jr. has been elected chairman of the board of the New York Stock Exchange Building Company and William McC. Martin Jr., president. Arthur A. Harris, former secretary, has been elected vice president and John Dassau treasurer. Mr. Dassau is also treasurer of the Exchange.

The city-owned ferryboat Colonel Clayton has been transformed into a floating "college" until the end of this month and will operate every morning from Monday through Thursday as "Clayton College" to stimulate among immigrant mothers an interest in citizenship and civic affairs.
Greentree, an open championship contender, played as a unit for the first time today at Mitchel Field and turned back a high-goal White quartet, 12 to 9, in an interesting match.

Dr. John L. Rice, Commissioner of Health, said yesterday he was not making any independent investigation of reports that seepage from a land dump of the Department of Sanitation might be polluting the underground waters at the city's large Jameco pumping station at Rockaway and Baisley Boulevards, Queens.
A new attack on the constitutionality of the devaluation of the dollar by the Roosevelt Administration was begun today in a suit filed in Federal District Court here. George A.

Derbyshire climbed into fifth position ahead of Essex in the English county cricket championship today with a six-wickets victory over Worcestershire. It was the only match concluded, a day ahead of schedule.

One of the most remarkable nonstop transatlantic flights in the history of aviation was completed with the routine efficiency of a commercial trip yesterday when four German fliers landed at Floyd Bennett Field in a standard commercial twenty- six - passenger Lufthansa plane, the Brandenburg, a little less than twenty-five hours after a secret take-off from the military airdrome at Staaken, near Berlin.

A clock which tells the current time in leading cities of the world, high and low tides at the principal ports, all the calendar calculations, the movements of the sun, moon, earth and other planets and many other chronological facts,

Harry Bacharach, president of the Public Utility Commission of New Jersey, announced today that as a result of negotiations with the New Jersey Power and Light Company electric rate reductions totaling $283,000 a year would become effective Sept. 1 for customers of the company.

Indication that most State and municipal employes have little to fear as to the possibility of retroactive Federal taxation of their salaries was given today by Roswell Magill, acting Secretary of the Treasury.

Senator James J. Davis, Republican of Pennsylvania, expended $18,421 in his successful campaign for renomination, according to a report filed today with the special Senate Committee to Investigate Senatorial Campaign Expenditures.
Every week the immense role that relief is playing in partisan politics becomes increasingly obvious. Fewer pains are being taken each day even to disguise the fact.
Barring several adjourned games, seven rounds of the annual tournament for the championship of the New York State Chess Association were completed today at the Cazenovia Seminary Junior College.

As an earnest of the fresh fields it wishes to conquer, the Berkshire Symphonic Festival began the second half of its fifth season at Tanglewood here tonight with two large segments from the music-dramas of Richard Wagner.

Movements of vessels follow; all dates are Aug. 11 unless specified: Newport to New London: Badger, Decatur, Fairfax, Herbert, Leary, J. F. Talbott. Acushnet, Washington to Naval Operating Base, Norfolk, via Indian Head, Aug. 10. Astoria, San Francisco to San Pedro, Aug. 9.
State Industrial Commissioner Elmer F. Andrews announced yesterday that 106 plans for factory buildings to cost $1,069.435 were filed last month in this State outside of New York City.

Regardless of the outcome of pending negotiations for the unification of rapid transit lines, the La Guardia administration intends to press for the removal of the Sixth Avenue elevated line, it was disclosed yesterday.

OLIVER ST. JOHN GOGARTY'S "I Follow St. Patrick"* contains at. least as much about St. Patrick as. about Gogarty--and more- about Ireland than either. Your reviewer thoroughly enjoyed reading it. For it is a genial and discursive .book, witty-in spite of some rather solemn museum passages-and learned; and, of course, intensely patriotic.
Governor George H. Earle tonight in a radio speech called upon District Attorney Carl B. Shelley of Dauphin County to arrest him tomorrow.

Walter William Strickland, Britiish baronet who waived his title in 1923 to become a citizen of Czechoslovakia, died here today. He was 87 year old. He was known as "the wandering baronet" because of his extensive and continuous travels.

St. Ann's Ave, 471 (9-2273); 471 St. Ann's Avenue Corp to Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank; $27,737. Webster Ave (12-3360): e s. 170 ft n of Gun Hill Rd, 100x112; Aranbel Garage, Inc, to State Mortgage Commission, installments, 41/2 to 5 per cent; $60,000.

Mediation of the railroad wage dispute was started today at the Drake Hotel. This is the second step provided by law in disputes carrying the'possibility of a strike that might tie up the nation's railroads.
FOUR'S A CROWD, from a story by Wallace Sullivan; screen play by Casey Robinson and Sig Herzig; directed by Michael Curtis; a Warner Brothers production. At the Radio City Music Hall.

James Fulton Little of Maplewood, vice president and chief actuary of the Prudential Life Insurance Company, died tonight in the Orange Memorial Hospital of a streptococcus infection after an illness of three weeks. He was 66 years old.

The Austrian Communist party has issued a manifesto to the Austrian people, the text of which is published in the Rote Fahne here. The manifesto urges the Austrian people to withstand the Nazi terror and continue to fight for independence and the right of self-determination. Advocating the closest cooperation among all classes, it continues:

By unanimous vote the Constitutional Convention adopted in final form today the anti-discrimination clause for the new State Constitution. It acted after Justice Harry E. Lewis, Republican, of Brooklyn, chairman of the Bill of Rights Committee, amended the proposal on the floor to make the clause apply only to civil rights.

Malcolm MacDonald, Dominions Secretary, who returned yesterday from a trip to Palestine, in a radio talk today said that the pacification of Palestine will not be accomplished quickly. "Maybe," he said, "it can not fully be accomplished until our policy has been finally settled and carried into effect."

With a lack of new building construction as the only obstacle to a revival of mortgage investment in broker. Manhattan realty, the flow of funds into new mortgage loans in the borough this year bids fair to equal last year's record volume.

The all-Stravinsky program given last night at Lewisohn Stadium by the Philharmonic-Symphony, the chorus of the Art of Musical Russia and several soloists, all under the direction of the capable Alexander Smallens, attracted an audience of 4,000.
Building projects submitted yesterday by architects included plans for a small office building on Platt Street in Manhattan and for a group of dwellings on Fentron Avenue, the Bronx.

Fairly general liquidation developed in the markets for wheat and corn today, reflecting a bearish construction placed on the Department of Agriculture's estimate of the crops issued late yesterday. September wheat and all deliveries of corn dropped to new seasonal low levels on the Board of Trade here.

Miss Patricia Bull, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Melville Bull, is leaving today for Newport, where she will visit Miss Lesley Hyde Hope Ripley for the week-end and subsequently for the duration of tennis week.

A first mortgage loan of $230,000, running for ten years with interest at 4 per cent, has been arranged by John F. Bottomley, Inc., and Julian Crawford, cobrokers, with a savings bank on the recently completed apartment *t 2,013 Creston Avenue, the Bronx, for Irving Fish. The mortgage will be reduced by quarterly payments of $1,150 during the first five years and $1,725 during the remaining five.
Governor Lehman today canceled all engagements for the next two weeks, his secretary, Walter C. Brown, announced.

Logan Pearsall Smith, American author, who has been ill here of pneumonia, now is recovering. It is understood that it will be some time before he regains sufficient strength to return to his home in London.

With live models, the defense staged a weight-lifting show before an amused court room today trying to prove that Paul N. Dwyer, 19, was not too frail to have carried the body of the man he accuses Francis M. Carroll of having murdered.

Senator Logan predicted today that Kentucky delegates to the 1940 Democratic convention would boost Senator Barkley for the Presidential nomination. He added that he had no knowledge of whether Mr. Barkley. would desire the nomination. Mr. Logan said,
Turpentine steady, 22 1/2c; no sales; receipts 384 barrels: shipments 110 barrels; stock 42,267 barrels. Resin firm; sales 120; receipts 2,039;,shipments 325; stock 204,668.

Cold storage holdings of fishery products in the United States on July 15 were 12 per cent higher than a year ago and 31 per cent greater than the five-year average, the Commerce Department reported today. Holdings on that date totaled 66,711,000 pounds, as compared with 59,330,000 pounds on July 15, 1937, and the five-year average of 50,828,000 pounds.

Hamilton Terace. 6, 16x100; Jeribull Holding Corp to Lenon Holder. 233 W 128th St: mtg $6,000 and p m mtg $2,000 ($3). Henry St. 253, 28x4.; 26 Montgomery St Corp to 253 Henry St Corp, 176 Rivington St; mtg $8,750 ($5).

After a brief respite from humid heat Wednesday evening, followed by early morning rainstorms, the thermometer climbed again to a maximum of 88 degrees yesterday afternoon. Damage of property and disruption of subway service marked the downpour in Manhattan and the Bronx.
Convicted of an attempt to smuggle money abroad Frau Luise Guttman, 54-year-old Czechoslovak, was sentenced here today to six months' rigorous imprisonment.

The following Marine Corps changes for the week ended Aug. 11 were announced today: COLONEL Fegan. J. C., Washington, D. C., to command Fourth Marines, Shanghai, China, to sail from San Francisco Sept. 23.
The weekly statement of the Bank of France, issued today, shows the following changes, in francs:

An increase of 852 tons in production of Canadian newsprint in July to 202,546, compared with 201,546 in June, the Newsprint Association of Canada reported today. Shipments dropped from 208,476 tons to 205,490. A year ago production was 316,194 tons and shipments 293,671.
Careful shopping for this weekend's food supply should result in one of the marketer's smallest food bills of the entire year, with bargains to be found in several categories of prime .importance.

Capt in Alfred Henke and his three German companions joined the select circle of aviators who have flown the North Atlantic nonstop and landed at their preannounced destination when they put their four-engined monoplane, Brandenburg, down yesterday afternoon at Floyd Bennett Field.

The Trimingham Brothers' Solenta, British representative in the International Gold Cup series for six-meter class yachts, which will be held on Long Island Sound off the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club starting Aug. 27, was shipped for New York today on the Furness liner Queen of Bermuda.
There is no doubt that Europe is suffering from acute political jitters. It is a state of nerves common to all countries, whether democratic or autocratic, neutral or possible aggressors.

To the bulletins that have appeared from time to time on the assorted projects of the Playwrights Producing Company, add this: "Knickerbocker Holiday," the Maxwell Anderson-Kurt Weill musial comedy, will begin a tryout in Boston Sept. 26 and have its premiere at the Ethel Barrymore Theatre here on Oct. 10.

With the lightweight championship fight between Lou Ambers and Henry Armstrong set for Madison Square Garden next Wednesday night and safe from further interruption by the weather, both fighters resumed training yesterday.
With Buck Newson and Les Tietje hurling steadily, the Browns took a double-header from the Indians today, 8 to 7 and 8 to 2.

Tom M. Girdler, chairman of the Republic Steel Corporation's board, in a statement prepared for the Senate Civil Liberties Committee, today charged the committee with painting a "one-sided" picture of his company's controversy with the Committee for Industrial Organization.

Many members of the Summer colony and their guests attended the large reception and tea given this afternoon at Four Fountains, the studio of Mr. and Mrs. Lucien Hamilton Tyng, to open the annual exhibition of paintings, etchings and water colors by Southampton artists.
The Wendel Foundation sold to the 82-84 Mangin Corporation the one-story garage on a plot 80 by 200 feet at 82-86 Mangin Street, running through to 75-79 Tompkins Street.

Samuel Carson Pirie, member of the New York Yacht Club, a prominent Corinthian sailor for many years, and chairman of the board of Carson Pirie Scott Co., one of the largest Chicago department stores, dropped dead of a heart attack this evening on one of the piers of the Newport shipyard. His age was 74.

Dr. Charles Ralston Hughes, ear, nose and throat specialist and a wellknown yachtsman and aviation enthusiast, died last night in an ambulance while being taken to Bryn Mawr Hospital from his Summer home in Betterton,
Mayor La Guardia has approved a request by Sanitation Commissioner William F. Carey that $15,000 from unexpended surpluses in the budget of his department be used for the purchase of mosquito poison.

Tom McNamara of Mount Vernon, whose association with golf dates back to 1892 when he began caddying at Brookline, Mass., unfurled the winning shot today in the Westchester division of the seventh annual World Telegram hole-in-one tournament at the Leewood Golf Club.

Seven lawyers have been assigned by Judge Todd of the Ponce district to defend eight of the nine nationalists who have been charged with murder as the result of the shooting on July 25 when an attempt was made on the life of Governor Blanton Winship. The defendants will plead tomorrow.

Twelve-year-old youngsters from all parts of the nation, who are ending. six weeks of study in Teachers College's Summer demonstration school, summed up their impressions of New York yesterday in a propaganda play given at Lincoln School, 425 West 123d Street, that sharply criticized slum conditions and praised city housing projects.
The Right Rev. Carl Joseph Alter, Bishop of Toledo, Ohio, returned yesterday on the Italian liner Saturnia after spending four weeks in Spain behind the Franco lines.

Trading in steer hinds and ribs was fair, but prices were sharply lower in local markets yesterday. Lamb business improved considerably and prices were strong to sharply higher Bulls were weak. cow weak to lower, veal and calf steady to slightly higher. Fresh pork cuts steady to sharply lower. Kosher lamb opened higher,

Just one month after the day Soviet troops occupied and began fortifying Changkufeng heights, on the Manchukuoan - Siberian frontier, silence fell at noon yesterday when Japanese and Soviet buglers trumpeted the call, "Cease firing."
The home town of Hulon Capshaw, New York magistrate whose name was injected by District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey into the policy racket investigation, rallied to his defense today.

SOME day some desperate fight promoter will stick to his program through a fair-to-middling rain and it will be learned, possibly with surprise, that the ferocious gladiators and the fight fans can live through inclement weather just like football rooters and players. Or golfers and golf galleries. Or even diamond heroes and baseball fans.

The largest write-down in utility history-$434,130,478-was approved yesterday by shareholders of the United Corporation at a special meeting held in Wilmington, Del., by a vote of 69 per cent of the corporation's outstanding voting stock.

MANHATTAN BRADLEY, EMMA H. (Oct. 22. 1937). Gross assets, $67,674; net' $58,705. To Constance H. Benson, niece, specific legacies and life estate in residue; sixteen specific bequests. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $53,057. Olcott, Paul, Havens Wandless, attorneys, 70 Pine St.

Because of the light it throws on Mr. Roosevelt's present standards in the matter of what constitutes a good Democrat, it is interesting to look back over the record of Senator Walter F. George, whose candidacy for re-election the President now openly opposes.

The Bethlehem Shipbuilding Corporation of Quincy, Mass., has received a $10,156,000 contract for the construction of four cargo vessels for the account of the American Export Lines, Inc., Admiral Emory S. Land, chairman of the Maritime Commission, announced today.

MIANHATTAN BERNHARD, MORRIS (Aug. 5). Estate, more than $10,000. To Rosa Goldman Bernhard, widow, executrix, 2 E. 86th St., household effects and life estate in residue; Joseph Bernhard, son, executor, Stepney, Conn., Class B Consolidated Trimming Corp. stock, personal effects and remainder in residue.

The first annual Devon Yacht Club regatta will be held this week-end. Yachtsmen are coming from Connecticut and other Long Island yacht clubs to participate in Star Class and Cape Cod knockabout races which will be held all day Saturday and Sunday morning.

With the approval of Police Commissioner Valentine and the cooperation of the chaplains and honorary surgeons of the department, the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association has quietly established in its offices at 63 Park Row a "social welfare clinic" to provide help in solving the physical, mental and financial problems of its members.

Mrs. Anne Franklin Sears Scully, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Taber Sears of 1,060 Park Avenue, and Moreau Yeomans, son of Dr. and Mrs. Frank Clark Yeomans of 555 Park Avenue, were married yesterday afternoon in the Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street, by the Rev.

Governor William Langer has announced to North Dakota farmers that the State mill and elevator at Grand Forks would pay 65 cents a bushel for No. 1 amber milling durum, which he declared was 17 cents above card prices.

The report of the Pacific Gas and Electric Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on June 30, issued for publication today, showed a consolidated net income of $23,761,027 after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges. This net was equal,

The Manhattan Railway Company stockholders protective committee mailed yesterday a letter to shareholders requesting authority to represent them in filing claims against the Interborough Rapid Transit Company estate. The claims arise out of the 1922 readjustment plan between Interborough and Manhattan shareholders.
After being forced down last night by fog at Igloolik on my flight from Churchill, I took off again this morning and reached Arctic Bay in 4 hours 25 minutes.

James Roosevelt admits in an article to appear in Collier's for Aug. 20 that he solicited insurance during the first four years of his father's Administration, frankly aware that "my name got me into a lot of places I might not have got into if my father -hadn't been President."
Announcement of a sharp increase in automobile factory schedules brought only minor improvement yesterday in sales of the various cotton fabrics used by the automobile industry.
We spent the past two days at Montauk in the hope of getting some excitement out of the broadbill, marlin or tuna that have been stirring the Long Island anglers from their midsummer lethargy.

The business end of dramatic production was discussed here today by regional directors of the Federal Theatre Project at the opening of a three-day national policy board meeting, which will be continued. in New York tomorrow and Saturday.
All boxes were filled again at the opening tonight of the second series of three Boston Symphony concerts at Tanglewood, in Stockbridge. There were many visitors present.

President Roosevelt bluntly asked Georgia voters today to end the sixteen-year service in the Senate of Walter F. George as "a dyed-in-thewool conservative," opposed to Administration objectives for improving social and economic conditions in the South, and proposed that they replace him with Lawrence Camp, Federal District Attorney from Atlanta.

A. HALL Co., by Joseph C. Lincoin. (Appleton-Century, $2.50.) A new Cape Cod narrative. I FOLLOW SAINT PATRICK, by Oliver St. John Gogarty. (Reynal Hitchcock, $3.) An account of a journey over the Irish countryside in the footsteps of St. Patrick.

Harry Guy Taylor, Commissioner of the Western railroads and chairman of the Western Association of Railroad Executives, died today at his home, 999 Michigan Avenue, in Evanston. He had been ill of heart disease for some time. His age was 58.

Mr. and Mrs. William H. Davis of 130 East Seventy-fourth Street have returned from a three months' stay in Europe. They will leave Sept. 1 for a visit in California. Demetrios Siciliands, the Greek Minister, has come from Washington to the St. Moritz.
In his latest declaration on British foreign policy before the House of Commons, Prime Minister Chamberlain expressed the following sentiments:

Violent anti-Czech speeches were delivered today at the funeral at Gutwasser of Wenzel Baierle, a Sudeten German who was fatally stabbed Sunday in a beer hall quarrel by an Austrian emigre of the German race. The victim was called a "martyr" in the funeral orations.

Supreme Court Justice Joseph B. Perskie reserved decision today on an application for an order approving the exchange of $110,000 in defaulted Asbury Park bonds for refunding bonds which Asbury Park had issued under an agreement with its creditors to replace all its defaulted bonds.

The general level of wholesale prices declined in the week ended on Aug. 6, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The bureau's index, based on the 1926 average, was 78.4, compared with 78.6 on July 30 and 87.4 on Aug. 7, 1937.

Although the tumbling prices on German stock exchanges have clearly shown the growing concern of German business over the economic trend, the Labor Office announced a new employment record today with 20,700,000 employed and only 218,000 unemployed during July.

The prospects that the battle between the Chinese and Japanese forces for the Hankow area will be a struggle equal in size to any engagement in the war so far have been increased by the acceleration recently of military, political and economic preparations for the defense of the area.

In an exhausting two-hour struggle in melting heat and humidity, Wilmer Allison, former national titleholder, staved off defeat by the margin of two strokes today to eke out victory over Wayne Sabin in the Eastern grass court tennis championships at the Westchester. Country Club.

The Bermuda Trade Development Board in a statement issued here yesterday pointed out that the provisions of the act of the Bermuda Legislature which would bar the use of ships as hotels during their stay in Bermuda ports would affect ships of all flags.
A par-equaling 71 brought John Burke of Georgetown University, intercollegiate champion, the medal in the annual Green Meadow Club invitation golf tournament today.

Accessory departments in local stores will be merchandised on the basis of "expecting a slight decrease, but hoping for a gain," according to retail executives. Wherever possible, initial commitments of the usual size have been made.

The factors making for increase and decrease in excess bank reserves canceled each other in the week ended on Wednesday, leaving the total figure unchanged at $2,920,000,000, or $230,000,000 under the recent high point.

Despite prolonged efforts to save his life, Samuel Salzberg, 39 years old, of 92-12 Avenue L, Brooklyn, died at 7 o'clock last night in BethEl Hospital, Rockaway Parkway and Avenue A, of a staphylococcus infection.

A slight improvement in installment buying in those industrial centers which in the last few months had suffered severe sales declines was reported here yesterday by one company specializing in this form of commercial credit.

A. H. Freeman. Inc, smokers' articles, store in 213 Greenwich St; Philip Brooks Co. publishers, in 17-19 W 34th St; Kingston Manufacturing Corp, boys' pants, in 1,140 Broadway; The Cross Brown Co, broker.

Miss Anna E. Clemency, for the last twenty years principal of Public School 169, Seventh Avenue and Forty-third Street, Brooklyn, died yesterday after a four months' illness at the home of a sister, Mrs. J. Carl Rueger of 1,815 Avenue R, Brooklyn.
Oratory in the Constitutional Convention has been costing State taxpayers five cents a word, delegates were told today by Chief Judge Frederick E. Crane, the convention's chairman.

William E. Batterson, Past Master of Mizpah Lodge of Masons, Elmhurst, and Past Regent of Newtown Council of the Royal Arcanum, died Wednesday night of pneumonia at his home, 90-20 Corona Avenue, Elmhurst.

On the tenth fairway of the Raritan Valley Country Club, where twentyfive years ago, at the same hour, he was knocked down but not injured by a thunderbolt, John A. Maxwell, local undertaker, was killed by lightning this afternoon.

The fight between Kenneth F. Simpson, Republican National Committeeman, and John J. Knewitz, the Republican county chairman of the Bronx, resulted last night in intervention by the party's State chairman, William S. Murray.

Retail prices in July recorded the smallest monthly decline since the current downturn began on Sept. 1 of last year, dropping only 0.2 per cent from July 1 to Aug. 1, according to the Fairchild retail price index, issued yesterday.
A detachment of 196 golfers, including most of the country's best pros, toured the Oakwood course for ten hours today in Cleveland's $10,000 open, but only six were below par 71.

T. Suffern Tailer of Meadow Brook, former metropolitan amateur champion, shot a 72 today in the qualifying round of the threeday annual tournament of the National Golf Links of America to lead the field and break the club's record for amateurs, which C. E. Van Vleck had held with a 73 since 1929. T. P. Boardman,
Larry Sovik, five times Syracuse city champion, won the qualifying medal of the Syracuse Yacht and Country Club's ninth annual invitation tourney today with a parequaling 72.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Gustav Schwab of 26 East Eighty-first Street of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Caroline Ogden Schwab, to Gordon Page Williams, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roger H. Williams of 35 West Ninth Street and Saugatuck, Conn.

A new Home Rule amendment for cities was adopted by the Constitutional Convention in Albany last night, and with the leaders battling to keep the session at work, the Labor Bill of Rights amendment also was accepted. [Page 1.]

Japanese air raiders today exacted a heavy toll of dead and injured in a swift attack on Wuchang and Hanyang, two of the three Wuhan cities, the other being Hankow. Unofficial estimates said 400 persons had been killed or Injured.

Completely revised proxy rules, the first major change since the original rules were issued on Sept. 24, 1935, were announced today by the Securities and Exchange Commission. They broaden substantially the amount of information which must be made available to persons whose proxies are solicited and have the general effect of putting "teeth" in the rules.
Detroit was eliminated from the Union Printers' International Baseball tournament today and Washington, D. C., St. Louis and Baltimore thrown into a three-way tie.

Two timekeepers on Fayette County Works Progress Administration projects were suspended today as State WPA officials opened an investigation of the hiring and firing of a 7-year-old boy from a road-laboring job.

Felix Cummings, 28 years old, and George Lewis, 26, were put to death in the electric chair at Sing Sing prison tonight for the fatal shooting of Ralph Nische, a waiter, in a restaurant hold-up at 1,942 Fulton Street, Brooklyn, on Jan. 7, 1936. The prisoners walked to the death chamber with the Rev. John McCaffrey, Catholic chaplain.

Joseph J. Rhoads, who retired May 1 as assistant to the general superintendent, northern division of the Pennsylvania Railroad with offices in Oil City, died today at his home in Miller Park. He would have been 70 years old on Aug. 23.

Playing today over the Siwanoy Country Club course, with Winter rules prevailing because of the ravages of rain, a small field of thirty-seven starters in the weekly one-day Westchester and Fairfield Women's Golf Association tournament was led by Mrs. Russell Holman of Innis Arden and Mrs. E. M. Bulkley Jr. of the home club, who ended the round in a deadlock at 41, 45-86.

Ernie Lombardi's home run gave the Cincinnati Reds an 8-to-7 fourteen-inning victory over the Cubs today, their only one of the series, and kept Chicago from a second-place tie with the idle New York Giants.

Mrs. Catherine Elizabeth Baker, piano and violin concert artist, died last night at her home, 114 Highland Avenue, following an illness of six years. Her husband, the late William H. Baker, was president of the Merritt-Chapman Scott Corporation.

The Hoboken Manufacturers Railroad Company filed today a complaint with the Interstate Commerce Commission asking that the Eastern trunk line railroads be compelled to share the freight rate increases granted by the commission last Spring.

Dollar volume of manufacturers of millinery during May and June declined 14.3 per cent from the same months of 1937, according to figures issued yesterday by the Millinery Stabilization Commission, Inc.

Sailing today from the port of Corpus Christi with a cargo of 90,000 barrels of crude oil, the Japanese tanker Itukusima Maru expected to make delivery at Yokohama, Japan, in twenty-six days, according to Captain T. Hara.

The Certain-teed Products Corporation entered into an agreement with the Celotex Corporation on June 10 to provide for the use of Certain-teed's excess manufacturing capacity by Celotex at a return of about cost plus 10 per cent for fifteen years from July 1, 1938,
Governor Lehman predicted today that the "great achievements" of the next decade will be toward a solution of the problem of efficient distribution.

The membership of George M. Sidenberg was transferred yesterday to Thomas Sidenberg. The Exchange has been notified that the Cuba company proposes to change the par value of its common stock from no par to $1.

William T. Adee and his wife, the former Sally Comly, who were burned to death when their house was destroyed by fire Tuesday, were buried here today in the churchyard of St. Mary's Episcopal Church. More than 20 persons,
Five manufacturers and distributors of concrete pipe and other concrete products were ordered today by the Federal Trade Commission to cease alleged unfair practices.

Band Ordered The members of the Department Band shall be directed to report to Captain Julius A. Unrath at the Twelfth Regiment Armory, Columbus Ave. and 62d St., Manhattan, at 9:45 A. M., Friday. Aug. 12, for rehearsal.

The successful flight of the four-motored Condor land plane to New York in record time and according to the schedule previously laid down was hailed with pride and jubilation tonight in German official quarters, in the press and among the public generally.

Dr. Eduard Prokosch, Sterling Professor of Germanic Languages at Yale University, was injured fatally here this afternoon when a light sedan he was driving crashed headon into a ten-wheel semi-van truck. He died four hours later in New Haven Hospital.

The hurt bewilderment of a 21year-old Brooklyn youth, on learning that an $800 accident award that the city had been holding in trust for him for nine years had shrunk to $291.80 in cash plus a mortgage certificate of depleted value, brought him yesterday a letter from Mayor La Guardia with a promise of assistance.

In the fifth match of its tour, the Brooklyn Cricket Club today defeated an eleven representing the Grace Church C. C. on the grounds of Upper Canada College. Brooklyn won with 204 for 9 wickets, against the home team's 166.

J. P. Morgan Co., as paying agents, will notify today holders of Nord Railway Company 6 1/2 per cent bonds, due Oct. 1, 1950, that $601,000 of these bonds have been drawn by lot for redemption at par on Oct. 1, 1938, out of moneys in the sinking fund.
With Monty Stratton pitching four-hit ball, Chicago's White Sox, aided by some sloppy Tiger fielding, pounced on three Detroit hurlers for 12 hits today and won, 13 to 1.

The New York State Electric and Gas Corporation has received from the Public Service Commission authority to increase from $75,000 to $125,000 notes to be issued in payment for advances by consumers at $1,200 a mile of extension of rural electric lines.

The third "Governor's Day" was held at the "Little White House," today, and after it was over the Democratic party-was still looking for a candidate for the United States Senate to oppose W. Warren Barbour, who is unopposed for the Republican nomination.

Today at about 5:15 P.M. 10,000 persons watched Thingumabob, potential juvenile champion and priceless colt of the Manhasset Stable, prance to the post. At 5:25 1/2 the field was off and Thingumabob was on his way to what his admirers felt would be imperishable glory.

Contemplated expenditures in industrial building in the State outside New York City totaled $1,069,435 for July, a rise of 30 per cent over the 14-year-average for the month, the State Industrial Department said today.

A Japanese mail plane en route from Tokyo to Paroa, New Zealand, was forced down by engine trouble Wednesday at a point given as 143 degrees 10 minutes east longitude and 25 degrees 17 minutes west latitude, according to a message sent to the Japanese mandated government of the South Sea islands.

Table arrangements of gladiolus blooms at the ninth annual show of the Metropolitan Gladiolus Society attracted the attention of visitors yesterday at the closing session in the exhibition hall at Rockefeller Center.

A banking group headed by Lazard Freres Co. obtained yesterday $1,100,000 serial dock bonds of Providence, R. I., on a bid of 100.11 for 1 3/4s. The bonds, which will be dated Sept. 1, 1938, and mature $55,000 serially on Sept. 1, 1939 to 1948, were reoffered at prices to yield from 0.25 to 1.90 per cent, according to maturity.
The Athletics made it two straight over the Red Sox today with a 5-to-3 victory behind the six-hit pitching of George Caster.

Olney M. Raymond, Brooklyn attorney, has purchased form Emily Steinback the four-story dwelling at 235 Garfield Place, Brooklyn, in the Park Slope section, through the John Pullman Real Estate Company, Inc.

The Holland-America liner Nieuw Amsterdam, arriving today from Rotterdam and way ports, has among 1,000 passengers Dr. and Mrs. David Allan Robertson, Mr. and Mrs. Chester Lauck, Mr. and Mrs. Meredith Willson, F. R.

A mystifying series of burglaries in which $50,000 in motion-picture film was stolen, led to the indictment of six men yesterday by the New York County grand jury and the arrest of five of them. The film, 2,500,000 feet in length, was stolen between June 28, 1937, and last June 5-from the Star Safety Film, Inc., at 630 Ninth Avenue.

District Attorney Charles P. Sullivan of Queens yesterday applied for space in the World's Fair in order to install a branch of his office for "prompt and speedy prosecution" of any crimes that may occur within the fair grounds.

Japanese bonds rose sharply today following news of the armistice between Russia and Japan. The truce imparted a better tone to the stock markets here, but business was almost at a standstill. Gilt-edges were firm, but transatlantics fluctuated,

Stewards at Narragansett race track announced today they had suspended Jockey Lucien Laurin, 26-year-old rider from Montreal, after, they said, a "buzzer" had been found in his possession just before the start of today's races. He was to ride one horse.
7th Ave, 1,845: 6-story apartment, 100.11x 100: Bowery Savings Bank against Edgeworth Management Corp; due, $198,111; taxes, etc. $5,147: to plaintiff for $90,000.

A banking group headed by Morgan Stanley Co., Inc., and including twenty-eight other investment houses, will offer today a new issue of $27,982,000 New York Steam Corporation first-mortgage 3 1/2 per cent bonds due on July 1, 1963. The bonds will be priced at par and accrued interest.
Mrs. Teresa Little, mother of Louis (Lou) Little, football coach at Columbia University, died late tonight at her home here. Her age was 72.

The question of whether an avowed Communist should be allowed to hold an appointive office in the New York City Government today overshadowed all other issues at the annual convention of the New York State Department of the American Legion, with Mayor La Guardia and the department commander, Jeremiah F. Cross, publicly debating the issue at a luncheon.
