120th St, 102 W. 18x100.11: Mildred Howard to Jacob D. Goodman, 271 W 125th St, p m mtg pr mtg $8.000, 5 yrs 5%; $3,000. 2d Ave. 192, 17.3x78; Erwin Hubsch to Harmil Construction Co. 105 Court St. Brooklyn, pr mtg $22,500, installments, 6%: $1,900.
Because of bad weather and a rough sea, several sailing parties that had been arranged to witness the Astor Cup race of the New York Yacht Club were canceled.

Consideration was being given yesterday by large producers of cigarettes to the advisability of an advance of 15 or 25 cents in the wholesale price, which, on the "Big Four" brands, now is $6.25 per helm thousand.

Because in previous political campaigns almost all candidates have pasted posters on city lighting poles, Deputy Commissioner John E. Eastmond of the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity warned political organizations yesterday that, under Section 121 of Article X of the Penal Law, such affixing of posters is punishable by six months' imprisonment or a fine of $250, or both.

The first important expansion of loans in several weeks was shown in the condition statement of reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City issued yesterday. For the week ended on Wednesday the banks reported a rise in the total of their loans and investments of $39,000,000 to $7,527,000,000.
Price competition in the retail grocery field is easing off in many sections of the country, according to reports reaching grocery wholesalers and manufacturers here yesterday.

John Becker, a retired lieutenant of the New York Police Department, died at the home of friends here today of a heart attack at the age of 70. He had been suffering from a cardiac ailment for a long time.

In contrast to the big crowds that have greeted other fliers landing here after long-distance flights, only 2,000 persons were on hand yesterday to greet the four German aviators who flew from Berlin to Floyd Bennett Field in less than twentyfive hours.
In a gentle breeze and a slight sea, the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary covered 685 miles up to noon today, over a twenty-two-hour day, having cleared New York Harbor at 1 P. M. yesterday.

Miss Patty Berg of Minneapolis, after three years as runner-up in the event, captured the Women's Western Golf Association derby for the first time today, completing the seventy-two holes in 308 strokes.

Reverting to a theme that used to be one of his favorites but that in recent months has been lacking in his speeches, Premier Benito Mussclini again expressed the conviction today that a European war was approaching. Haranguing troops at the end of the army manoeuvres, he said:

President Roosevelt went out on the rear platform of his car late tonight to ask a crowd of 15,000 at the station to send representatives to Washington who would work for his social and economic objectives.
Thomas Fogarty, illustrator, who was a teacher of illustration at the Art Students League, New York, from 1903 to 1932, died today at his Summer home here after a long illness. He was 64 years old.
Philadelphia at New York (2)Williams (0-7) and E. Smith (2-6) vs, Ruffing (15-3) and Hadley (5-3). Cleveland at Chicago (2)-Harder (9-9) and Galehouse (4-4) vs. Lyons (5-8) and Rigney (5-5).

A policy of cooperation with consumer or other "public study" groups which provide an open forum for discussion of "hidden taxes and all trends and measures affecting the cost of living" was announced here yesterday by the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea

Dubious concerning their chances for victory, members of the German Davis Cup tennis team arrived yesterday aboard the North German Lloyd liner Europa and quickly headed for Boston to begin preparations for the interzone cup final to be held at Brookline, Mass., next Thursday to Saturday.

The first challenge of the validity of the State Homework Law, passed by the Legislature in 1935, was won by the State Labor Department on Aug. 2 when the State Board of Standards and Appeals upheld the right of the department to revoke a homework permit held by a women's clothing manufacturer, it was announced yesterday.

Frederic W. Ecker, Alfred H. Meyers and Hubert F. Young, a committee representing first-mortgage bondholders of the Spokane Interna-tional Railway, appealed today to the Interstate Commerce Commission to reopen its proceeding in the reorganization of that railroad.

A sharp recession in bank transactions this week made the volume the smallest for any full six-day period since the week of April 13. The decrease lengthened the distance between the corresponding positions for this year and last year.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Aug. 9: COMMANDERS Kilduff, W. D., orders June 24 revoked, to continue duty First Naval District. Crosby, P. T., Med. Corps, Tutulle, Samoa, to duty Naval Hospital, Chelsea, Mass. LIEUTENANT COMMANDER Brady. A. R., Pensacola, Fla., to duty involving flying in Patrol Squadron 4.

John I. Snyder, director of the TVA land acquisition department, told the Congressional investigating committee today that he informed David E. Lilienthal, TVA director, that the $5,000,000 marble claims of Senator George L. Berry and associates had no real value,

Poland these days is the weathercock of Europe because of the ring of danger in which the country is set. Unlike most of the other large nations, Poland has no exits. Toward most of her neighbors she feels either dislike or distrust.

Substantial increases in most industries and moderate gains in the volume of originating shipments last week raised business in the Pittsburgh district to the Highest level since the final week of March, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh.

Former Representative William D. Upshaw of Georgia, once dry candidate for President, who was a college mate of Senator Walter F. George, yesterday sent the following telegram to his Mercer University college "chum":

During the week ended Aug. 10 member bank reserve balances decreased $28,000,000. Reductions in member bank reserves arose from increases of $64,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve Banks and $10,000,000 in Treasury cash,

Many parties are on the week-end social calendar here. Mr. and Mrs. Edward Livingston Smith of New York are giving one of the largest events tomorrow after the races for a group including Prince and Princess Serge Poutiatine, Miss Adele Colgate, Mr. and Mrs. F. Skiddy von Stade,...

A net profit of $1,646,421 was earned by the Colgate-PalmolivePeet Company in the first six months of this year, it was reported yesterday by E. H. Little, president of the company, in his first report to the stockholders since he took office on April 27.

The Rev. William Koellhoffer, a member for many years of the faculty of St. Benedict's Preparatory School here and secretary to Abbot Patrick O'Brien of St. Mary's Benedictine Abbey in Newark, died today in St. Michael's Hospital here after an operation. He was 57 years old.
Douglas Corrigan returned to this airport this afternoon to make a personal check-up on the reassembled "crate" in which he made his recent famous solo flight to Dublin.
Further engagements of $3,462,000 gold abroad for shipment here were reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York as renewed weakness overtook the foreign exchange market.

College Ave (11-2784), s e cor of 171st St, 125x150; 306 Realties Inc to Mollie Rappaport, 1,846 Andrews Ave. Webster Ave (12-3360), e s, 170 ft n of Gun Hill Rd. 95x111; Mortgage Commission Realty Corp, trustee, to Aranbee Garage, Inc, 3,510 Webster Ave; mtg $60,000.
The skeletons of six sacred bulls worshiped by ancient Egyptians have been discovered in Sharkia Province in Lower Egypt, the government antiquities department announced today.

Mr. and Mrs. John Oswald MacIntosh of Germantown have announced the engagement of Mrs. MacIntosh's daughter, Miss Miriam Selina Tilden, to Major Robert Dennis Ambrose of the Rajputana Rifles, British Army, son of the late Dr. and Mrs. Thomas Ambrose.

Demands for steel for world-wide rearmament resulted in record production of pig iron and crude steel in 1937, creating entirely new marketing and tariff conditions in many countries, the Tariff Commission reported in a voluminous survey made public today.
With one of the games finishes witnessed in a long time, Mrs. Mortimer May of the Inwood Club today destroyed Mrs. Marion Turpie McNaughton's title to the New York State golf championship.

A shipment of 300,000 American magazines, more than half of which have come under a recent customs ban, will be allowed to be sold in Australia because they left before the ban was imposed, but no further importation will be permitted, including a large shipment due soon.

Poland's decision, announced today, not to stand for re-election to the Council of the League of Nations when her term expires in September is taken as practically clearing the way for the application of the covenant against Germany in the event of an attack on Czechoslovakia and also as hinting that Poland fears such an attack may come this Fall.
One of these days, perhaps, the news of non-stop flights across the North Atlantic will be recorded alongside "ship news" in the relatively obscure after-pages of daily newspapers.

The membership of the Boy Scouts of America reached 1,186,557 in June, against a 1937 figure of 1,075,636, it was announced yesterday. The increase of 10.3 per cent includes Scout Leaders, Scouts and Cubs- boys between the ages of 9 and 11.
James M. Halsted, member of the stock brokerage firm of McQuoid Coady, 111 Broadway, Manhattan, died here today at the home of his brother-in-law, Dr. James Ewing, of a heart ailment. His age was 59.
Small craft have come forward with a rush in yachting events the last few years, but the smallest ever to capture one of the Astor Cups did so today.
Following is the statement of T. M. Girdler, chairman of the Republic Steel Corporation, submitted to the Senate Civil Liberties Committee and put in the record:
Jersey City and Toronto divided a double-header today, the Little Giants coming back to win the second, 3 to 2, after dropping the opener, 5 to 3.

Thomas Caldwell Ridgway, a leader of the legal profession, noted for his work in revising and codifying the statutory law of California, died today in St. Vincent's Hospital. A streptococcus infection, following an operation for appendicitis performed July 31, was the cause of death. He was 59 years old.

An amendment to a registration statement filed today with the Securities Commission disclosed that 70 per cent of the proceeds of the proposed Argentine Government's bond issue of $25,000,000 will be lent to the city of Buenos Aires for street improvement purposes.
Edward Haley, 25 years old, of 1293 Fifth Avenue, Neptune City, was killed early today when a truck he was driving was in collision with an automobile at Eighth Avenue and F Street here.

The Public Service Commission announced yesterday the filing of an amended rate schedule by the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., converting its rate for light, heat and power for wholesale uses from an annual to a monthly basis.

The following Coast Guard changes for the week ended Aug. 10 were announced today: Doyle, Comdr M. A., promoted to Captain (E). Martinson, Lt. Comdr. A. M., the Mohawk, to headquarters. permanent board.
The War Deapartment released the following orders today, dated Aug. 10: COLONELS Hester, J. H., Inf., General Staff Corps, 4 days leave, Aug. 16.

Lumber production advanced contraseasonally last week, and the adjusted index rose to 71.4, a new "high" for the year. The figure was 67.3 for the preceding week, and 91.8 for the week ended Aug. 7, 1937.

Customers' orders to sell handled by odd-lot dealers and specialists on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on Aug. 6 exceeded by more than 5,000 their orders to buy, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

The Republic Steel Corporation complained to the Labor Relations Board today that it had been denied constitutional rights, and the C.I.O. met the protest with an assertion that the company merely was seeking "special consideration."

George Raft was suspended by Paramount today for refusing to report for work in the long delayed "St. Louis Blues." The studio charged that the actor approved the script and agreed to appear in the film, but on Tuesday notified the studio that he had changed his mind.

Gold imports into the United States in July this year amounted to $63,879,655, against $175,623,720 for that month last year, the Department of Commerce reported today. Japan and Mexico were the chief sources, Japan shipping $28,669,620, while Mexico supplied $11,172,448.

The Hamburg American Line ordered ten new cargo vessels last year with a total tonnage of 48,000 as part of a general replacement program, it was announced yesterday in the annual report of the board of management.

German radio listeners heard an on-the-spot description of the landing of the Brandenburg yesterday. The National Broadcasting Company was transmitting to Germany the regularly scheduled German hour program over its shortwave station, W3XAL.

Temporary Assignments For sixteen days, from 8 A. M., Aug. 16: LIEUTENANTS-Michael J. Flynn, from 14th Precinct to 3d Division, assigned to duty as Supervisor of Patrol in uniform. From commands indicated to 19th Division, Office of the Chief Inspector:

Said to be one of Germany's largest and fastest land planes-if not the largest and fastest-the Brandenburg is an all-metal, lowwing monoplane powered by four engines. Except for the number of engines, it is more nearly comparable to the Douglas commercial

German chemists of the I. G. Farbenindustrie have developed a substitute for helium that is even more satisfactory than that gas for airships, C. G. Grey, editor of The Aeroplane, reports in today's issue of the magazine.

Miss Susan Bloomingdale, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel J. Bloomingdale of Rye, was married this evening to Richard Charles Ernst, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard H. Ernst of New York, at the Century Country Club here. The Rev. Dr. Nathan A. Perilman of Temple Emanu-El in New York, officiated.

Each of the following Reserve Officers, assigned or attached to the 61st Cavalry Division, is ordered to active duty, Aug. 28, at Fort Ethan Allen, Vermont, for training with the 61st Cavalry Division: 1st Lt. Benjamin Lewis, Cav.-Res., 1,045 Anderson Ave., Bronx, N. Y.
The Wheeling Steel Corporation has asked for bids upon an expansion project at Martins Ferry, Ohio, which may amount, with other improvements by the concern, to more than $2,000,000. .

The statement of the Anaconda Copper Mining Company for the six months ended on June 30, made public today, shows a consolidated net income of $4,010,363 after charges and taxes but before mine depletion, equal to 46 cents each on the 8,674,338 capital shares outstanding.
Apartment leases reported by brokers and renting agents yesterday included several contracts for suites in buildings in the Chelsea section of Manhattan.

Last week the ratio was 18.8 per cent, the lowest of the year to date, against 21 per cent two weeks ago. The Feb. 17 ratio, 33.6, was the highest of the year. The highest for 1937 was 43.5, reported on Nov. 25, and the lowest was 16.6, on Aug. 5.

Miss Catherine Beirne Roper, daughter- of Commander Clifford H. Roper of the Naval War College and Mrs. Roper, has selected Aug. 20 as the date for her marriage to Lieutenant Clark Paul Jeffers, U.S.N., attached to the Naval Hospital at Bremerton, Wash.

Price cutting developed yesterday in some sections of Brooklyn on gasoline and other petroleum products of the Sun Oil Company. The company last week made known its intention of signing Feld-Crawford price maintenance contracts in the metropolitan area and dealers were advised that the 1 1/2-cent rebate would be discontinued when the 17-cent minimum resale price became effective.

The Edek Corporation and its affiliate, the Edek Oil Company, both of New York, have filed registration statements covering 1,000 shares of $1par common of the former, which is optioned to the parent company, Investors Fund of America, Inc.,
Fourteen years ago a Democratic Yankee came to a neighboring county in your State in search of a pool of warm water wherein he might swim his way back to health.

In view of scores of bathers at Sea Gate, George Peck, 40 years old, of 2,665 Grand Concourse, the Bronx, swallowed twenty-five poison tablets yesterday afternoon and died an hour later in Coney Island Hospital.

A 5-year-old girl who had been thrown from a pier into the East River fifteen feet below at Thirtieth Street was rescued from the water by a man who had been swimming near by shortly after 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon.

Foremost among the Scribner September publications are two historical works, "The Building of the British Empire," by JamesTruslow Adams, and "The March of the Iron Men," by Roger Burlingame, and, among fiction, "The Dynasty of Death," a novel by Taylor Caldwell. The first,

It was not done with mirrors. That much is guaranteed. But the totals that the Yankees and the Senators compiled at the Stadium yesterday before the bewildered gaze of 5,965 persons seemed to supply no other explanation than that glassware was used.

Mrs. Helen Z. M. Rodgers of Buffalo presided this morning over the Constitutional Convention as it sat in committee of the whole. She was called to the chair by Chief Judge Crane and thus became the first woman in the history of the State to preside over a Constitutional Convention.

The Gulf States Utilities Company of Bealmont, Texas, filed today a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission under the Securities Act of 1933 covering a $10,000,000 issue of first mortgage and refunding 4 per cent bonds, Series D.

Mayor La Guardia was accused yesterday in Supreme Court of claiming more power than he has under the City Charter in order to block a City. Council investigation into WNYC, the municipal broadcasting station, and thereby create a precedent which would stalemate the Council's relief inquiry.

John Hamilton is whistling again. He says that Senator Pope's failure to be renominated is "a stunning blow" to the New Deal. To other observers it may look more like a good joke, in which the Republican National Committee possibly had a hand.
Awards of $76,431,000 for engineering construction in the current week, representing a rise of 69 per cent over the corresponding week of last year, are reported by The Engineering News-Record.
Ferdinand Charles Lau, metallurgist, died yesterday in the West Suburban Hospital. He was 79 years old and his home was in Oak Park, Ill.

The Atlanta Constitution, one of the first newspapers in the country to boom Franklin D. Roosevelt for the Presidency, assailed the President's appeal for the defeat of Senator Walter F. George in the September primary.

Tammany Hall and its erstwhile allies, the Kelly and Flynn organizations in Brooklyn and the Bronx, today provided the bulk of the votes for blocking in the Constitutional Convention a broad proposal which would have required a public official called as a witness to waive immunity or forfeit his office.
A number of the Loyalist Washington-Lincoln Battalion returning from Spain will find it virtually impossible to return to the United States because they are aliens.
Precipitate declines in both the import and export trade of the United States with Japan and China were shown for the first six months of this year.

Twenty charitable institutions will share in the estate of Leon Tuchmann, retired clothing merchant, whose will was filed in Surrogates' Court yesterday. Mr. Tuchmann died on Aug. 8, leaving an estate valued at more than $100,000. He was 78 years old.

John J. Crowley, a WPA worker who feels he is getting old at 55, yesterday offered one of his eyes to Helaine Judith Colan, 4 months old, while consultants at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center endeavored yesterday afternoon to save her remaining right eye against a malignant cancerous disease.

The Spanish Insurgents are studying the new non-intervention formula and the delay in their reply is because of the complicated nature of the proposal and the necessity for gauging all possible effects, Sir Robert Hodgson, British agent at Burgos, reported to the Foreign Office today.

National banks on June 30 had loans and discounts, including overdrafts, of $8,334,624,000, compared with $8,631,366,000 on March 7, a decline of about $297,000,000, Marshall R. Diggs, Acting Controller of the Currency, announced today.

A total of fifty-three yearlings passed through the sales ring tonight, bringing the sum of $122,050, an average of $2,303 a head. Of principal interest to bidders was the disposal of nineteen youngsters bred by C. V. Whitney.
More than 100 members of the general executive board of the International Union of Operating Engineers, an affiliate of the American Federation of Labor,
Brig. Gen. William F. Schohl, commander of the Fifty-second Field Artillery Brigade of the New York National Guard, died early today in the Veterans Hospital at Batavia.

With the return of President Roosevelt to the United States, James H. Fay, Deputy Collector of Internal Revenue for the Third New York District, announced yesterday his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for Representative in the Sixteenth Congressional District against Representative John J. O'Connor.

The Petroleum Corporation, an investment trust, declared. yesterday a special dividend of one share of common stock of the Consolidated Oil Corporation for every five shares of the capital stock of Petroleum Corporation held.

The Insurgents launched another heavy attack today against a part of the Ebro River sector, but reports still indicate that their great counter-offensive, expected for ten days, has yet to materialize.

Edward T. Miller, St. Louis attorney and general counsel for the-St. Louis-San Francisco Railroad Company, died today in a hospital here at the age of 67. Mr. Miller was stricken with a heart attack a week ago while playing golf here.

Woolen goods mills were busy this week on fairly substantial orders booked last month and it was reported that they have enough business in hand to maintain current operations for four to six weeks, when the Spring season will start in men's wear, the New York Wool Top Exchange Service reported yesterday in, its weekly summary.
The Bureau of Biological Survey announced today the creation by Presidential order of the Fort Tyler migratory bird refuge off the east shore of Long Island, N. Y.

Mrs. Edward B. Hall of 340 East Seventy-second Street has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Martha Hall, to Kingsley Mabon, younger son of Mr. and Mrs. James Brown Mabon of 420 Park Avenue.
Ken Ash limited the Newark Bears to five hits tonight and the Buffalo Bisons conquered the league leaders, 8 to 1, in their homecoming game before 5,500 fans.

John Chandler of New Jersey, the New England titleholder, upset John McGriff, the fourth-seeded entrant from Portsmouth, Va., 6-1, 6--3, in the quarter-final round of the annual New York State Negro open tennis championships yesterday at the Cosmopolitan Tennis Club. Another Southerner, Dr. E.

Samuel Insull, who once controlled a $1,000,000,000-utility organization, had an estate valued at only $1,000 when he died in Paris on July 16. This was disclosed today when his will was filed in the Cook County Probate Court.
Shipments of steel office furniture during June totaled $1,591,399, compared with $1,292,861 in May and $2,281,450 in June, 1937, according to the Bureau of the Census.

The six lots known as 174 to 188 Eighteenth Street, Jersey City, have been acquired by the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad, thus making the railroad the owner of all of the property on the six blocks bounded by Sixteenth and Eighteenth Street, Jersey Avenue and Henderson Street.

Routes by which motorists bound from Brooklyn, Queens and points on Long Island to the RoCkaways may avoid traffic tie-ups while the work of widening the Beach Channel Bridge'is in progress were suggested yesterday by Police Commissioner Valentine.
The Osservatore Romano, authoritative Vatican organ, today protests strongly against the Italian press boycott of the speeches in which Pope Pius has denounced the new fascist racial theories.

The estimated liquidating value of the debentures of thirteen mortgage companies, compiled by the debtor companies and by Maryland Casualty Company, guarantor of interest but not of principal, was made public yesterday by the companies involved.
Early Tuesday morning the State Constitutional Convention, perhaps exhausted by its long labors, approved two amendments to the civil service section of the Constitution.

Recognizing that the surfeit of promotional "weeks" each year may militate against the success of any one individual event, the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America plans to approach its "Nationally Advertised Brands Week," Feb. 9 to 18, from two angles.

Conflicting price trends characacterized quiet trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. A brisk rally in Japanese dollar bonds followed cable advices of a Russian-Japanese truce, prices in those issues soaring 1 to 4 points.

The life-long dream of the men who go down to the sea in ships-a capacity catch of fish with every cast of the net-came true late Wednesday night for Captain Louis B. Richmond, 75-year-old skipper of the small motor skiff Scud, but with tragic consequences.

The Gulf States Utilities Company, a subsidiary of the Engineers Public Service Company, notified yesterday all preferred shareholders of the Baton Rouge Electric Company, another Engineers Public Service subsidiary, of an offer to exchange each share of $6 preferred stock which they own for one share of $6 preferred stock of the Gulf States Company, plus $20.25 in cash.

Reports on the progress of President Roosevelt's 1938 relief-recovery program to be submitted to him after his return here tomorrow will show that, while Federal money has begun to flow into business and consumption channels in increased volume through four of the relief and recovery agencies, the big outpouring is yet to come.

A five-day meeting of Japanese diplomats who hold posts in the Near East, just been concluded here after discussing Japanese diplomacy and consular work in the Balkans, Egypt, Syria and Irasq under the chairmanship of the Japanese Ambassador to Turkey, has provoked an official note from the Turkish Government to the Japanese Ambassador.

Joe Jacobs, manager of Tony Galento, the National Boxing Association's No. 1 challenger for Joe Louis's heavyweight world title. announced tonight Galento would meet John Henry Lewis, light-heavyweight champion, Feb. 22, at Atlantic City. Galento,
The six-acre estate of Mrs. Henry Gassaway Davis, on Middle Neck Road, Sands Point, L. I., has been enlarged by the purchase of an additional parcel of one and onehalf acres from Mrs. Benjamin V.

After an early improvement which carried the list more than $1 a bale above Monday's low records, prices on the Cotton Exchange eased yesterday to close 1 to 3 points lower. Trading was the smallest in some time and the setback in the stock market offset many private reports of weevil damage in Eastern sections of the belt.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: THE TIMES of Aug. 7 contained a news item entitled "Fight on Pollution to Cost $158,800,000," and the story included a brief summary of the Sanitation Department report for 1937.

The cattle market displayed an improved tone today and in instances sales on fed steers and yearlings were strong to a shade higher, the United States Department of Agriculture reports. Lambs sold actively and strong but the hog market continued to drag at weak to slightly lower levels.
It is reported here that Greta Garbo, who is in Paris, is seeking cancellation of her contract with MGM to take up film directing in Stockholm.
Captain Alfred Henke, pilot of the Brandenburg, broadcast over National Broadcasting Company networks their account of the flight.
One frequent passenger to Europe who has been news for a great many years is this year more news than ever.

Chartered bank deposits with the Bank of Canada declined $1,125,000 compared with the previous week, while Dominion Government deposits increased $254,000, it was reported today in the bank's statement for the week ended Aug. 10.

The first break in the hot, sticky weather which has prevailed locally for over three weeks brought some late action into the wholesale markets yesterday. Fresh pork cuts were considerably more active and early observations indicated a better cleanup trade than in several weeks. Bull and cow business continued slow; other classes were in fair to good demand.
Loft buildings and housing properties and hosing properties in Brooklyn proved attractive to the investors, according to transactions announced yesterday by brokers.

Collection ratios on open-credit accounts receivable of department stores showed a decrease of 2.6 per cent for June from the same month of 1937, but no change was recorded from May of this year, the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce reported today.

An agreement whereby 1,800 truck owners in the Associated Trucking Industry, Inc., of Rochester became members of the New York State Motor Truck Association, Inc., was announced yesterday at the association's offices at 60 Hudson Street.

Miss Susan Lanier Johnson, daughter of Allen Fletcher Johnson of this city, was married to James Alden Simpson, also of Greenville, formerly of Birmingham, Ala., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Frank Rush Simpson, yesterday afternoon in Christ Episcopal Church by the rector, the Rev. Robert T. Phillips.
The entire blockfront on Bridge Plaza North, from Crescent Street to Twenty-seventh Street, Long Island City, has been sold by the East River Savings Bank to the Queens Bridge Realty Corporation.
Following an explosion of the boiler in the heating plant, fire swept a one-story frame and sheet metal structure occupied by the Hulse Brothers Laundry on Montauk Highway here this afternoon.
Two towns in New Jersey and two in Connecticut were reported yesterday by the Automobile Club of New York to have "speed or traffic light traps in their immediate vicinity."

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks 1,191,000 bales, against 1,172,000 a week ago, 1,174,000 two weeks ago, 1,157,000 three weeks ago and 765,000 a year ago; of which American 674,000 bales, against 676,000 a week ago, 685,000 two weeks ago, 696,000 three weeks ago and 269,000 a year ago.
The Baltimore Ohio Railroad, pursuing its efforts to borrow $6,000,000 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, has offered to pledge additional collateral.

Miss Josephine Emerson Croswell of this place, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Albert Church Croswell of Rutherford, was married in the Church of the Holy Innocents here tonight to John Croft Myers of Salisbury, Conn., and Merion, Pa.

The low bid submitted by contractors yesterday for the rehabilitation of St. Mary's Park, St. Ann's Avenue, between 143d and 149th Streets, the Bronx, was that of Frank Mascali Sons, Inc., of 4,634 Third Avenue, the Bronx, with $96,929.

Gilbert Miller's plans have furtherentered the realm of uncertainty, chiefly because of his protracted differences with the Dramatists Guild. Frederick Lonsdale, a Guild member, said in Newport, R. I., that it is not definite that Mr. Miller will produce his new play, "The Gardener," which the Miller office has had on its schedule as long ago as last Spring.
The Newark Bears outlasted the Bisons for an 11-to-10 victory tonight after calling on five pitchers, three of them in the ninth, to halt a late Buffalo surge.

Manufacturers' sales of electrical machinery, apparatus and supplies during June were down 33 per cent from June, 1937, according to reports from eighty-seven companies to the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce of the Department of Commerce. June sales rose 4 per cent from May, without adjustment for seasonal variation.

President Roosevelt overlooked one allotted chore at the Barnesville REA project exercises. By his side as he spoke yesterday was an open switch which he was to throw to send electric current coursing through- 144 miles of wire and light an REA sign on the field.
President German Busch today announced appointment of the following Cabinet, predominantly Socialist, to succeed that which resigned yesterday.
In retaliation for a similar measure applied a week ago by Italy, the French Foreign Office suspended today authorizations for French nationals to travel in Italy.

Michael J. Hartneady, Secretary of Mines in the Cabinet of Governor George Earle and president of District 7, United Mine Workers of America, for twenty-six years, died at his home in Nesquehoning, below Hazleton, today following a heart attack. He was 59 years old.

The Manchukuoan-Siberian frontier armistice was welcomed in German official quarters, where it was ascribed in a measure to German intervention undertaken by Joachim von Ribbentrop, Foreign Minister, in his recent interview with Ambassador Shigenoro Togo of Japan.

Revocation of automobile drivers' licenses for the first seven months of this year totaled 3,580, a decrease of 103 from the corresponding period of 1937, it was announced yesterday by Charles A. Harnett, State Motor Vehicles Commissioner.

A plan to extend the length of the Berkshire symphonic festival, now in its fifth season, to three weeks is being discussed by officials and friends of the undertaking, it became known today. A decision is expected when the boards of the festival corporation and of the Boston Symphony Orchestra hold a joint meeting.
The National Cash Register Company sold $6,000,000 of 3 1/4 per cent debentures due on Aug. 1, 1953, to an insurance company on Aug. 2.

The Senators pounded four Red Sox pitchers for a 13-to-1 victory today. Dutch Leonard allowed Boston only seven hits. Leonard had a shut-out until the ninth, when Joe Vosmik doubled, went to third on an infield out and scored on Dutch's wild pitch.

Plans for a decentralization of the Federal Theatre Project to permit the performance of plays in remote parts of the country where legitimate performances have rarely been seen were announced yesterday at a meeting of the national policy board of the project at 1,697 Broadway.

The Commodity Credit Corporation announced today that "advices of cotton loans" received by it through Aug. 11 showed loans of $238,734.631 on 5,464,956 bales of cotton disbursed by the corporation and agencies.

The French Government, alarmed by reports of huge military movements under way in Germany, today sought information on Chancellor Adolf Hitler's intentions through French diplomatic representatives abroad.

The secret police have banned the Readers Digest, a monthly United States publication, indefinitely from Germany, as well as "all foreign translations and editions" of Kurt Schuschnigg's book "Dreimal Oesterreich" ("My Austria"), by the former Austrian Chancellor, the Official Gazette said today.

Czechoslovakia is keeping calm in the face of constant reports of increasing German military activity on the frontier. Although every precaution against surprise was taken long ago, information now available in political quarters suggests that the object of Germany's rather over-demonstrative military preparations is not invasion, but rather an effort to keep the Czechs' nerves on edge, with a consequent provocation of incidents between Czechs and minority Germans in the frontier areas.

Helaine Judith Colan, 4 months old, has more than an even chance of retaining sight in her remaining eye, a specialist reported yesterday. Eyesight, if the doctors enable her to keep it, will be in the nature of a gift from medical science to the child, rather than a birthright.
Over a thousand Scottish moors, overlaid with peat and often covered with heather, wealthy British and United States sportsmen participated today in the most expensive sport in the world.

Youth Sunday will be observed in this city tomorrow as a prelude to the second World Youth Congress which will be held at Vassar College, Poughkeepsie, N. Y., opening Tuesday. Many churches will hold special services.

Whether it is baseball or bridge, bad distribution can ruin some mighty fine playing. The Yankees made twenty-one hits in their double-header with the Athletics at the Stadium yesterday but spread them around in most injudicious fashion.
Senator James P. Pope, a New Dealer who was defeated for renomination, disclosed today that friends had suggested that he make an independent campaign.

Mrs. Katherine Miskell, widow of an Oklahoma oil man, was found dead today in her suite at the Whitehall Apartments. Circumstances of the death prompted police and the coroner's office to start an investigation.

Once more this week the President returned to his contention that "the South presents right now the nation's No. 1 economic problem." The sixtypage report now submitted by the National Emergency Council at his request makes clear beyond doubt the relative poverty of that section.

Faced with the fact that there are more than 3,000,000 foreigners resident in France and that the crime record and hospital and other social charges among them are very high, the Ministry of the Interior, in a note issued today, explained that it had been forced to increase the frontier police force to deal with immigrants and especially to catch those who make a clandestine entry.
Hugh W. Jackson, owner of Ariel Toy and employer of Jockey Lee Hardy, made clear in a statement today that he will stand behind his rider, who has been grounded.

Ky Laffoon of Chicago led by two strokes today in the $10,000 Cleveland open golf tournament at the Oakwood course. Laffoon went along quietly on the first nine and took a 5 on the par 4 tenth, but then began clubbing par and finished with a 69, two under par, for a two-day total of 139.

Last night's concert at Lewisohn Stadium, under the direction of Alexander Smallens, presented the compositions of three regular members of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra. These were an interlude by Bruno Labate, first oboe player; an etude by Fiorillo, transcribed by Arcady Dubensky, one of the violin section, and "Manhattan," by Theodore Cella, the orchestra's first harpist.
Teams from Washington, D. C., and St. Louis won their way today to the finals of the union printers' international baseball tournament.

A total of fifty-nine yearlings passed through the sales ring tonight, bringing the sum of $126,150, an average of $2,138. The Old Hickory Farm, Inc., Paul T. Chinn, president, totaled the highest of the breeders, offering thirty-seven youngsters that averaged $2,043 a head for a total of $75,600.

With President Roosevelt's appeal for the defeat of Senator George causing varied reactions in all corners of the State, political forces were being marshaled in Georgia today for a bitter struggle in the Democratic Senatorial primary.

Charges that the rate schedule for storage of goods at the foreign trade zone on Staten Island gives the company leasing the property an unfair competitive advantage over warehousemen of the city will be carried to Mayor La Guardia next week, E. W. Ford, chairman of a special committee of the Warehousemen's Association of the Port of New York, Inc., announced yesterday.

The flight of European capital into gold and dollars, which has been stirred up by the fear of war and of further currency collapses, drove the price of gold in London yesterday to the highest levels in twenty-one months and forced the pound sterling down to its cheapest quotation in more than three years.

Estate, $3,000. To Marshall W. Briard, North Union St.. Rockland, Mass.; Harold G. Briard, Fairview Farm, Nantucket, Mass.; Gilbert E. Briard, executor, 1,932 Kenmore PI., Brooklyn, one-third residue each.

Walter (Rabbit) Maranville, twenty-seven years in baseball, resigned tonight as manager of the slumping Royals of the International League. First Baseman Alex Hooks, in his first year with the Royals, was selected to pilot the club through the rest of this season.
Secretary of Commerce Roper reported to President Roosevelt today that the business situation was encouraging, and his department issued a bulletin showing a general improvement in business in July.

Cotton mill activity last week held to the level of the two preceding weeks, although a slight increase was seasonal, and the adjusted index eased to 120.7 from 121.2. The figure was 131.5 for the week ended Aug. 7, 1937.

Pitcher Wesley Ferrell, given his unconditional release by the Senators, today said he doesn't intend to play any more baseball this year. "I told him," said Clark Griffith, president of the Senators, "about two of. three parties that seemed to be interested in him, but he didn't seem to be interested."

Tension between Russia and Japan increased today with a border incident on Sakhalin Island, north of Japan, where Russia and Japan divide control. At an isolated post of the Russo-Japanese boundary troops of the Commissariat of Internal Affairs were said to have shot and wounded two Japanese policemen.

The "Supreme Court" of the Constitutional Convention, the group of nine named to decide on the manner in which the proposals of the convention will be submitted to the people, has reached a tentative agreement on the submission of at least four proposals. This list of four is to be expanded.

" Gross misrepresentation" to make financial investments of fluctuating market value appear to be savings bank accounts have induced residents of New York State to turn over more than $100,000,000 to at least 300 banks elsewhere in the country, Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., declared yesterday.
Thirteen Bronx properties were sold at auction in the salesrooms at 3,208 Third Avenue yesterday, seven of which were bid in by the Home Owners Loan Corporation, as plaintiff.

From his hospital bed here, Governor Kraschel today ordered martial law lifted in Newton as soon as local authorities agreed to all but one of the military commission's recommendations concerning the three months' old labor dispute between the Maytag Company and the C. I. 0.

The Public Works Administration announced approval today of eightty-two non-Federal construction projects with an estimated construction cost of $24,963,727, bringing the total of approved non-Federal projects to $1,004,257,230.

The Netherlands authorities attached yesterday two lighters at Dordrecht containing 4,000 barrels of gasoline each shipped originally from the Mexican refineries of the Mexican Eagle Oil Company, owned by British and Netherland capital, on the ground that the gasoline had been seized illegally by the Mexican Government, according to cabled dispatches received here.
Three savings banks and trust companies in New York City have asked permission to open branch offices, it was announced today by the State Banking Department.

Mark Stuart, former metropolitan amateur champion, who fell ill in the second round of the John G. Anderson Memorial Tourney at Winged Foot last week, gained the semi-finals of the Green Meadow Club's annual invitation golf competition today.
Cuba observed today the fifth anniversary of the fall of President Gerardo Machado's regime by suspending business and closing governmental offices throughout the island.

President Roosevelt returned to Washington today in high spirits, apparently unmindful of the criticism resulting from his speech in Georgia aimed at the unseating of Senator George in the New Deal's Democratic Congressional primaries "purge." He was tanned, and apparently a little heavier as a result of his long sea voyage.
After a long debate the Chamber of Deputies last night authorized the Federal Government to negotiate a loan up to $30,000,000 to aid the municipal government of Buenos Aires.

Appearing tonight before a large crowd in the-Point Pleasant Borough School, Summer colonists of this district gave their 1938 version of the "Bay Head Bubbles," since 1903 an annual event of the North Jersey coast.

Charles Rosenthal, former president of the Kane Realty Company, Inc., has formed a new organization to be known as Charles Rosenthal Company, to conduct a general realty brokerage business at 113 West Forty-second Street.

At the organization meeting of the board of directors of the Crown Zellerbach Corporation held yesterday immediately after the stockholders' meeting,. I. Zellerbach, who had been president of the corporation since its organization and who recently completed fifty years of service with the corporation and its predecessors, assumed the office of chairman of the executive committee. On his recommendation...
The Toledo Edison Company will redeem on Oct. 13, at 105 and interest, all of its outstanding first mortgage 5 per cent bonds, due on Nov. .1, 1962. Payment will be made at the Chase National Bank.

Col. Robert P. Marshall, FA-Res., having been ordered to active duty at Pine Camp} New York, is, at his request, relieved from further active duty, effective Aug. 11, and will proceed to his home, 1,160 Park Ave., New York, .N. Y.

Osler F. Potter, dean of Northwestern Illinois newspaper men and since 1920 telegraph editor of The Journal Standard, died today at the age of 79. Born in Ireland, he came as a boy to Freeport, where his father, John Potter, was for many years publisher of The Freeport Bulletin.

The Brooklyn Cricket Club today wound up its tour with a record of one match won, two lost and two drawn. Today's game with the Dentonia Park eleven resulted in a draw, Brooklyn tallying 179, Dentonia Park 174 for 7.

New York City had its first really "comfortable" day yesterday since July 24. There were cooling breezes, the humidity was comparatively low and for the first time in nineteen days the thermometer failed to reach 80 degrees.
The Cubs personally probed the pennant proceedings today and found that two of the Pirates' best pitchers could be touched for sixteen hits, sufficient to win, 9 to 3.

Evidence, much of it documentary and all of it involving alleged Nazi activities in the United States, was produced today before the special House committee investigating unAmerican activities in the United States.
The National Cotton Board of Argentina has recommended the adoption of mechanical picking methods to increase cotton production in the country, according to the Argentine Information Bureau.

Julia, Barcelona's only elephant, died today just as much a war casualty as if she had been a combatant. War rations were too much for this famous successor to the even more famous elephant named Avi, who was the joy of Barcelona's children for most of the first two decades of the present century. Avi died during the World War.

Under the influence of lower prices abroad, a break in the stock market and a continuation of favorable weather in most producing sections, prices on the New York Cotton Exchange turned downward yesterday and lost all of the recent recovery.

R H Pennell, in 510 Hillcrest Ave, Westfield, N J; F R Risley, in 953 Carlton Rd; L W Williams, in 840 Shadow Lawn Drive; W N Boyd, in 816 Oak Ave; C C Holmes, in 645 Raymond St: W A Morton, in-659 Forest Ave; Lewis Roberts, in 229 Cowperthwaite Pl; J. T. Dimon, in 128 So Euclid Ave; Walton R Dunn, in 11 Stanley Oval; T B N F Reynolds, brokers.

" THE NAZI PRIMER"* is a strange, betraying and distorted book. And yet-because it shows the astonishing version of history the youth of that land of joy--and concentration camps is being forced to learn-it is about the most significant commentary on Nazism the world at large has received from within the Reich in a long time.

Keith H. Rapp, 28, arrested in Memphis, Tenn., and returned here on a charge of writing a letter threatening the life of President Roosevelt, was sentenced today to the Mendocino Hospital for the Criminally Insane.

Thomas Harlan Ellett of New York City won today the Treasury's $9,000 prize contest for designing the new $450,000 postoffice to be built at Covington, Ky. Mr. Ellett won $4,500 for his design and will receive an additional $4,500 as a fee for consulting with the Treasury in preparing working drawings and specifications based on his design.

The Village Board announced today that Daniel Hogan, Village Clerk since the community was incorporated in 1931, had been dismissed at a special meeting last night. Mr. Hogan, formerly a general in the Irish Free State army, sent his resignation to the board Wednesday, but the board refused to accept it at last night's meeting.

This has been a day of heavy fighting on three Spanish fronts. In the southern part of the Ebro River sector the Rebels made a powerful attack against Hills 698 and 705, capturing them at a great cost, according to tonight's Barcelona War Ministry communique; then losing them in a "brilliant" counter-attack by government forces.

On their own applications-To take effect 12 noon, Aug. 16: PATROLMEN-Anthony J. Padrucco, 18th Precinct,. at $1,500 per annum. Appointed June 30, 1909. George B. Burling, 102d Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Feb. 10, 1904.

Against a strong breeze and rough sea the Queen Mary covered 730 miles from noon Thursday to noon today, beating the Normandie's best daily eastward run by two miles. Her official average speed was 31.739 knots.

The Treasury has spent $1,232,558,598.28 in the first three years of the Social Security Act, as against receipts of $887,946,271.71, said Roswell Magill, Acting Secretary of the Treasury today. The third anniversary of the act will be signalized Monday by President Roosevelt in a fifteen-minute radio broadcast.

Round one in the five-round battle for fifth place in the National League went to Casey Stengel's Bees today as they scored a 2-1 triumph over the Dodgers, who had entered the series only one percentage point above Boston.
The Peconic Bay. weakfish derby is now a thing of the past, and although the contest was strung out a bit longer than scheduled, due to a lack of big fish, the winners have now been named.

The report of the International Hydro-Electric System and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on June 30, issued yesterday, showed a consolidated net income of $998,244 after operating expenses, taxes and charges, compared with a net of $1,865,120 in the twelve months ended on June 30, 1937.

S. A. Makofski of Rensselaer, N.Y., carded a 70 today to capture the modal in the qualifying round of the men's annual international invitation golf tournament of the Hotel Champlain golf course. Makofski had a one under-par 35 on each nine.

Pitts Duffield, publisher, editor and former English teacher at Harvard, died today in Paris. His age was 67. He was formerly president of Duffield Co., publishers, and had been associated with The New York Tribune, New York Globe and The New York Commercial Advertiser.

Better late than never, the steps being taken in Paris and London to facilitate loans and finance trade among the Balkan States have much to do with the decided improvement in the atmosphere along the lower Danube. In a Summer when the whole world seems blanketed by a "Bermuda high" and most of the international weather prophets predict storms, this is the one area where the temperature drops toward normal.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week totals $22,792,221, to be represented by two States and seventy-three municipalities. This compares with the revised total of $27,630,184 for this week.

" Roots in the Sky," the novel that won its author, Sidney Meller, the Phelan Award; is the story of a European 'family who, migrating from Russia to California, try to adjust themselves to their new world. It will be published by Macmillan on Aug. 30.

Although there has been some recovery from the severe fall of prices on the Berlin Stock Exchange Tuesday, there is an aftermath here in the explosion of the assumption that National Socialist Germany, The Times of London says, had invented a system of State capitalism and exchange control that insulated her from world fluctuations.
Colonel William A. Smethurst, an official of the Baldwin Locomotive Company, died yesterday in the Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center after a long illness at the age of 65.

As often happens after splurges or upsets in golf tourneys, today's semi-final round in the New York State women's championship produced lopsided matches that left two metropolitan district players in the running for the title held up to yesterday by Mrs. Harry McNaughton, the former Marion Turpie.

Unless war breaks out in the meantime, in which case, presumably, the ceremony will be postponed, the Ara Pacis, most celebrated of Augustan monuments, will be rededicated in Rome on Sept. 23, two thousandth anniversary of the birth of the Founder of the Roman Empire.

Spokesmen for taxpayers' organizations and civic groups in Brooklyn and Queens appeared before the Transit Commission yesterday in opposition to the city's $23,057,000 plan for the elimination of Long Island Railroad crossings on Atlantio Avenue between East New York and Jamaica.

Most classes of domestic bonds drifted yesterday to substantially lower levels in slightly more active trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Lack of near-by support rather than liquidation seemed to be the determining market influence as total transactions amounted to $5,463,800, compared with $4,909,70 on the preceding day.

New low prices for the season were established today in leading world markets for wheat. While there was no material pressure, there was a notable lack of aggressive support in the early trading and prices at the extreme were down around 1 cent a bushel from yesterday's finish.
Mr. and Mrs. J. Denniston Lyon entertained with a dinner tonight at Sandymount for Mrs. Henry R. Rea of Sewickley, Pa., and Palm Beach, who has joined them for a visit.

Eugene W. Ritter, since 1934 head of R. C. A. Manufacturing Company's research and engineering at the tube making plant at Harrison, N. J., has been appointed general manager of the plant, it was announced yesterday by Robert Shannon, vice president and general manager of the company. D. F.
Miss Louise Blakiston Grayson, daughter of the late Mrs. Blakiston Grayson and the late Theodore J. Grayson of this city, was married this afternoon to Louis Haskell Allen
Increased sales of gold kept pace with a higher price for the metal today, [Pound]1,994,000 being sold in the open market at 142s 8d a fine ounce, the highest quotation in nearly two years.

The Municipal Court Committee of the Bar Association of the City of New York announced yesterday its opposition to the proposal to make the Municipal Court of New York City a constitutional court. This proposal has passed the committee of the whole of the Constitutional Convention and is now a waiting final action by the convention.

The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "Manufacturers have shown comparatively little interest in wool this week and the market is a bit easier, on the whole, although concessions are made most reluctantly and there is some irregularity in prices made.

Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Aug. 6 amounted to 584,050 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 4,653 cars, or 0.8 per cent, fewer than for the perceding week, 182,132 cars, or 23.8 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week last year and 144,243 cars, or 19.8 per cent, fewer than in the corresponding week two years ago.

Continuing his victorious march in the international masters tournament of the British Chess Federation at the Royal Pavilion in the brilliant Cambridge University star assumed the sole possession of the assumed the sole possession of the lead in Section A over the field of twenty-four competitors.
Hallett Thompson, 67 years old, a retired actor, attempted suicide yesterday in his apartment at 552 Riverside Drive by slashing his ] wrists and arms with two razors.
Making their way out through Block Island and Vineyard Sounds, the racers of the New York Yacht Club today reached this V-shaped harbor.

Strong adverse criticism of detention arrangements in the Domestic Relations Court at 1,118 Grand Concourse, the Bronx, was expressed in a report today by John L. Schoenfeld of the State Commission of Correction.
William H. D. Koerner, illustrator and artist, died at his home in Interlaken near here last night. He was resident here for the last twenty years. He was born in Clinton, Iowa, Nov. 19, 1878.
The Queen Elizabeth, 85,000-ton companion ship of the Queen Mary, will be launched by Queen Elizabeth on the afternoon of Sept. 27 at John Brown's yard, Clydebank.

Taxes paid by New York State employers on industrial and commercial payrolls for the first half of this year brought $62,817,611 into the unemployment insurance fund, according to statistics made public yesterday by the division of placement and unemployment insurance of the State Labor Department.

Major John J. McGarry, a member of the staff of Governor Wilbur L. Cross, former Sheriff of Windham County and twice Mayor of this city, died yesterday in the Day-Kimball Hospital after an illness of several months.

Reports of continued shipments of gold from Japan to the United States call attention to the growing economic strain in that nation. In the past six months more than $100,000,000 in gold has been sent to this country, and in the past year and a half more than $350,000,000.

Dr. Thomas W. Chandler, first world's champion middleweight boxer, trainer of John L. Sullivan, veterinarian and retired hotel proprietor, died here last night. He would have been 83 years old on Sept. 8.

With more t than 6,000 persons already employed at the navy yard-estimated as a larger number than in wartimesnavy yard officials today said that they would hire twenty to fifty shipworkers a week and at least 100 steel workers at once if they could be found.

The General Realty and Utilities Corporation and subsidiaries, exclusive of the Lefcourt Realty Corporation, reports for the six. months to June 30 a net profit of $293,474 before income taxes and depreciation, compared with $304,114 in the first half of last year.
Two ships of the Midshipmen's Practice Squadron, with 700 midshipmen on board, will anchor in the Hudson at 10 A. M. today off Pier 99, foot of West Fifty-ninth Street.

The following members, having been tried before Francis X. Giaccone. deputy fire commissioner. on dates specified, for violation of Rules and Regulations, 1937. the following decisions are rendered by the fire chief and commissioner:

Fourteen religious vacation schools of the Brooklyn Catholic Charities and the Confraternity of Christian Doctrine of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn ended their annual Summer sessions yesterday.

Fifteen utilities in the Consolidated Edison System agreed yesterday to a $487,898 settlement of a deficiency assessment of $705,217 which the city imposed on the companies in a dispute over the application of the 1934 emergency tax of 1 1/2 per cent on gross earnings.

Success of the army manoeuvres in Mississippi was reported to General Malin Craig, Chief of Staff, by Major Gen. Van Horn Mosely, commanding the Third Army, who telegraphed to headquarters as follows:
Twenty-four employes or sons of employes of the General Electric Company have received $4,550 from the General Electric Educational Loan Fund and the Gerard Swope Fund at Union College.

Miss Marian Munroe, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John Munroe of this place, was married here tonight to Angus A. MacInnes Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. MacInnes of Little Neck Hills, in the Congregational Church by the Rev. Malcolm K. Burton of the Second Congregational Church, New London, Conn.

The marriage of Miss Eleanor Talcott Fisher, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Galen M. Fisher of Orinda. Calif., formerly of Pleasantville, N. Y., to Dr. Robert Gordon Johnston of New Haven, took place here this afternoon in the Marquand Chapel

Ferdinand Smith, Negro vice president of the National Maritime Union, was charged yesterday with participation in strike-breaking activities in the Pacific Coast maritime strike of 1934 and faced possible suspension from office.

Lloyd G. Ensign, export of oil field materials, in RCA Building, Rockefeller Center. Max Waller, furs, In 134-40 W- 29th St; Harry Metz, furs, in 236-40 W 27th St; Simon Reich Reico Sales Corp, hardware, in 457-9 Broome St; M L Hess, Inc, brokers.
Miss Elizabeth Jane Hart and Paul Gannon Downey, whose engagement was announced in April, will be married on Sept. 21 in St. Joseph's Church here.

The German plane Brandenburg will take off from Floyd Bennett field for its non-stop return flight to Berlin some time today. Although all preparations were timed so as to permit a departure between 8 and 9 A. M., Flight Captain Alfred Henke said that if weather conditions were favorable, he and his crew of three would first make a test flight, then refuel and start back to Germany around noon.

The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today the plan of Gulf States Utilitiep Company, a subsidiary of the Engineers Public Service Company, to offer 6,209 of $6 preferred shares for the outstanding 6,209 $6 preferred shares of Baton Rouge Electric Comany.

Mr. and Mrs. Jorge R. Andre of 277 Park Avenue, who are in Newport, will leave Monday for Cape Cod to visit Mr. and Mrs. M. Taylor Pyne for a. fortnight. Miss Alice Andre will pass next week with Mr. and Mrs. John Jacob Astor in Newport. Sir Stephen Bull, Bart., of London is at the Plaza.
The theft of jewelry valued at $1,150 and $60 in cash from the home of Mr. and Mrs. Louis T. Dougherty at 220 St. Clair Avenue here was reported today.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: The world series is not so distant and I will be out there pulling for the Yankees to hammer the Pirates out of the picture in four straight games- but I will carry with me a fear which has beset me at every world series game since 1912.

The Securities and Exchange Commission today denied the applications for registration respectively as broker and dealer of L. P. Atwater, Tulsa, Okla., and the Continental Royalties Corporation of which Mr. Atwater is president and general managing officer.
Public utiltiy bond financing featured the new -issue market this week as the flotation of three major issues in that group swelled the total of new offerings for the period to $83,707,000.

Verdi's opera "La Traviaia" was presented here tonight on the mammoth marine stage on Zachs Bay by Alfredo Salmaggi and his New York Hippodrome Opera Company before 3,000 persons who filled the Jones Beach Marine Stadium. Judging by the applause, the work was a pronounced success.

Columbia University's baseball course ended its second year yesterday on a note of intimacy, with Vernon (Lefty) Gomez, star pitcher of the New York Yankees, delivering a confessional valedictory in which he admitted that he had considerable trouble with his curve ball and a "bad arm."

In the belief that District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey is likely to be drafted for the Republican nomination for Governor, influential members of the Democratic State organization contemplate asking Governor Lehman to run for reelection instead of being a candidate for the short Senatorial term, as he has announced he will be.
To care for the bumper crop and the record carry-over of bread grains, Field Marshal Hermann Goering has commandeered all available storage space and ordered the construction of new silos.

Miss Jessie Simpson, 20-yearold beauty contest winner and model, who lost both legs in a train accident in Hackensack more than a year ago, opened a beauty shop on Prospect Court here a week ago and is confident of making a success of the venture, despite the handicap of artificial legs, she said today.
The eight-story building containing forty-three apartments and five stores at 175 Henry Street, corner of Jefferson Street, has been sold by the Green Wood Cemetery to Limited Equities, Inc.

The purchase and quick resale of a Manhattan corner was announced yesterday when an operator bought from a bank the eight-story offices at l19-121 Fifth Avenue, northeast corner of Nineteenth Street,. and immediately resold it to an investor.
Al Davis, 135 1/4, East New York, gained the decision over Al Ragone, 129, Greenwich Village, in the main bout of six rounds at the Long Beach Stadium tonight.

Two men narrowly escaped drowning early this -evening when a cable ferry, plying between shore and an island in the middle of the Delaware River, just north of the city line, was torn loose by the current of the swollen river and overturned.

A survey of the working capital position of fifty major and fifty moderate-sized United States corporations conducted by the investment management firm of Young Ottley, Inc., asserts that banks in the United States will be unable to count on industry as a source of demand for the greatly increased loans urged on them recently by the RFC.

The three members of the National Mediation Board continued their efforts today to bring about a settlement in the railroad wage dispute. In the morning the board met with the railroads and in the afternoon with a subcommittee of the Railway Labor Executives Associations.
Miss Betty Naudin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Naudin of this place, was married here today in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church to John Francis McGrath Jr., son of Judge McGrath of Waterbury,

Silver Prince, son of Mr. McElwyn and Fay Worthy, owned by E. J. Merkle of Columbus, Ohio, and driven by Ben White, today won the 3-yearold trot, feature event of the getaway Grand Circuit racing program at Good Time Park.

Dr. Merle E. Frampton, director of the Department for the Education of the Handicapped in Teachers College, Columbia University, has been invited by the Argentine Government to direct the planning of an extensive program for rehabilitation and teaching of the physically and mentally handicapped in that nation.

Employes of the Metropolitan Engineering Company and the Metropolitan Device Corporation, with offices at 1,250 Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn,. rejected both the A. F. of L. and the C. I. O. in a National Labor Relations Board election yesterday.

At Arrowhead Inn tonight Mr. and Mrs. Richard E. Dwight of New York, week-end guests of George H. Bull, gave a dinner for Lady Thornton, Miss Elizabeth Rumsey, Mrs. Charles L. Hoffman, Mr. and Mrs. Henry Leroy Finch, Mrs. Edwin A. Strong, Mrs. E. Elkins Wetherill, Mr. and Mrs. Edward Henry Delafield and Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Wellington.

In a will written in 1936, State Senator Julius S. Berg, who committed suicide in his office on July 20 while a grand jury was scrutinizing his record, left $6,500 in personal property to his wife, Rose, it was learned yesterday. The will mentioned no real property.
RECENT LITERATURE AND RELIGION, by John Rothwell Slater. (Harper, $2.) This book comprises the 1938 Ayer lectures delivered before the Colgate-Rochester Divinity School.

The outer structure of the Apparel and Accessories Building at the New York World's Fair is expected to be finished by Nov. 15, Joseph Love, president of Apparel and Accessories Associates, Inc., announced yesterday.

Samuel Aitken, vice president of Moore McCormack, shipping operators, of 5 Broadway, and an executive of several associated companies, died suddenly yesterday afternoon while on his way to the Whitehall Club, 17 Battery Place, to have luncheon with business associates. His age was 58.
Russo-Japanese dispute, although apparently eased, is expected in informed quarters to hasten the President's selection of an American Ambassador to Moscow..

As instructors to the 200 New York and New Jersey youths now attending the Citizens Military Training Camp at Fort Hancock, Sandy Hook, N. J., twelve United States Army Reserve officers of the 530th Coast Artillery (anti-aircraft) Regiment will report at that army reservation Aug. 19, it was announced yesterday at headquarters of the Second Corps Area, United States Army, on Governors Island. Lieut. Col. Will I. Levy of Manhattan heads the group. Others are:

" Guided" by Running Deer, an Onondago Indian youth, a covered wagon drawn by four weary-looking horses wound its swaying way yesterday through lower Manhattan, Fifth Avenue and up the New Jersey Palisades, carrying twentyfour underprivileged boys and girls on their way to Summer camps,

A new "controlled" waterway, linking Long Lake in Northwestern Ontario with Lake Superior, is within six months of completion. The project was undertaken a year ago by the Ontario Government and the Ontario Hydroelectrio Power Commission.

Charles Harris Whitaker, architect and editor, died late Wednesday at his home at Drovers Rest, Va., after a long illness. He was 66 years old. He specialized in the study of printing and his collection of lithographs illustrative of various processes is now in the Library of Congress.

A Giant club won a baseball game at Shibe Park today for the first time in twenty-five years. By the slender margin of 1 to 0 the Terrymen downed Jimmy Wilson's futile Phillies on the initial visit of the Giants to this park since the Phils' recent abandonment of Baker Bowl.
A report presenting 1937 monthly inventory and sales figures for deapartment and specialty stores was issued yesterday by the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

Attorney General B. Fernandez Garcia and a majority of the members of both houses of the -Legislature-the latter according to newspaper polls-as well as. Puerto Rico's spiritualists, oppose the legislation to restore the death penalty recommended by Governor Blanton Winship.
Margaret Neidert, 19, her right leg amputated and near death from an automobile mishap, was married in a flower-banked hospital room today to John Hilgert, 25.

WRONG address. The mail should have been directed to Mild Will McKechnie and Old Goldenrod Gowdy, c/o the Cincinnati Reds, Crosley Field, Cincinnati, Ohio. But since it came here, it will be exposed here.
The commander of the Japanese Army in Northern Korea in a special press communique today said:
High winds and heavy rains swept Pinar del Rio Province tonight, but the cyclonic disturbance that caused them passed westward beyond the tip of the island without striking it.

Final arrangements for the merger of Grand National Pictures, Inc., with Educational Pictures, Inc., were completed last night at a meeting here between E. W. Hammons, president of Educatonal, and Lloyd Wright and Edward L. Alperson, trustees for Grand National.

Douglas Corrigan was back in the air late this afternoon at the controls of the reassembled "crate" in which he made his famous transatlantic solo flight to Dublin. He made a fifteen-minute test hop over the Long Island area surrounding this airport after the Department of Commerce had consented to a six weeks' renewal of the experimental license for his $900 plane.

The Florida Racing Commission today reinstated Don Meade, top-notch jockey, who was suspended on March 4, 1936, for betting on horses that ran against his mount. Meade's reinstatement will become effective Dec. 19, 1938, opening date for Tropical Park at Coral Gables, Fla.
The ninth annual Lake Placid Horse Show opened under floodlights tonight at the Lake Placid Club, where many of the Horse Show Association members annually pass the Summer.
Stocks closed lower for the fitfh consecutive session, losing' fractions to 2 points, in the heaviest trading since July 27; turnover, 1,479,690 shares.
Martial law, effective in Tunis since the disturbances of several weeks ago, will be raised tomorrow.

The South is a land abounding in real and potential wealth, yet beset by so many drawbacks as to keep it the "Nation's No. 1 Economic Problem," the National Emergency Council said in a report on economic conditions in the territory, made public today.

Robert L. Riggs Jr., John Kramer and Joe Hunt of California and Wilmer L. Allison Jr. of Texas advanced to the semi-final round of the men's Eastern grass court singles championship at the Westchester Country Club today.

Radio lights, a new method of seeing through miles of the thickest fog or clouds, were announced today at Purdue University. The lights are planned to enable a pilot to "see" the runway of a field miles away and to land on that strip no matter how completely the ground is obscured.

Rochester's first labor parade in fifteen years, set for Sept. 1, will be limited to A. F. of L. unions. A motion sponsored by the Rochester Typographical Union, which would have extended participation in the parade to C. I. 0. members, was ruled out of order at a meeting of the Card and Label League tonight.

The first step preparatory to the erection of the large apartment community planned by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company on the old Catholic Protectory grounds in the Bronx was taken yesterday when steam shovels began excavating the site for the first unit and grading the property for roads and sewer mains.

The United States Lumber Company, a New Jersey corporation with its principal place of business at Scranton, Pa., filed today an application with the Essex County Tax Board for the cancellation of a $7,000,000 personal property assessment levied by the Newark Tax Board.

Most favorites advanced today through the first and second rounds in the Syracuse Yacht and Country Club's ninth annual invitation golf tourney. Par, a stubborn opponent in the qualifying tests, collapsed against the assault of some of the nation's best amateur linksmen.

Francis M. Carroll, former deputy sheriff, was convicted tonight of first-degree murder in the garroting of elderly Dr. James G. Littlefield, a crime for which 19-year-old Paul N. Dwyer is serving a life sentence.
Completion of initial Fall purchases was responsible for slowing of activity in most wholesale markets this week, according to the weekly summary of Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

The eight-room colonial dwelling at 29 Claremont Road, Greenacres, Scarsdale, N. Y., on a plot of a quarter-acre, has been sold by R. W. Milbank Jr., to Edwin F. Armstrong, through Myron L. Blum Co., Inc., brokers.
William Taylor, former District Attorney of Delaware County and former president' of the Delaware County Bar Association, died last night after a long illness. He was 62 years old.
Another Japanese raid on Hankow and Wuchang yesterday caused casualties estimated at nearly 1,000 and wreaked great destruction.

The National Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers reported today that the recession in sales volume among men's apparel stores has been "somewhat checked" during the past thirty days, as compared with the same period last year.

The name of Mayor Fiorello La Guardia of New York was put on the invitation list for the Pennsylvania American Legion convention here late last night, but a half hour after he had left Scranton for home his name was taken off the list and Legionnaires announced that they did not care to have him with them next week.

Henry Williams Sage, a member of an old American family and former president of the National Steeplechase and Hunt Association, died shortly before midnight last night after a long illness at his home in Jericho, L. I. His age was over 60.

Reports that the negotiations had been started between Germany- and the United States for an agreement providing for reciprocal transoceanic air service, to be operated by planes of the Lufthansa and some American company, were denied today by Colonel J. Monroe Johnson, Assistant Secretary of Commerce.

Judge Wallace in General Sessions appointed yesterday a commission to examine Julius Weber, 37 years old, of 38 Sickles Street, Brooklyn, as to his sanity. Counsel for Weber had entered a formal not guilty plea for him on a first-degree murder indictment in the shooting of Patrolman Harry J. Padian on July 6 in the prison ward of Harlem Hospital.

Taxpayers' suits which opened legal proceedings aimed to restrain the city from dumping refuse and garbage on West Island in Jamaica Bay were lost yesterday afternoon when Supreme Court Justice Francis G. Hooley in Brooklyn handed down a decision in which he refused to enjoin the dumping or to interfere in the purchase of equipment by which it will be carried on.

Alvin H. Turton, 40 years old, of 12-02 116th Street, College Point, Queens, who said he was a cashier for the Frederic H. Hatch Company, investment brokers, was held by the police for questioning early this morning after a woman who was riding in his car was drowned when it plunged into the East River at Twenty-third Street.
Seabiscuit and Ligaroti met in a sensational race at a mile and an eighth today and while the former won by a head, much mystery attended the $25,000 match.

Harmon Fitch of Winston-Salem, N. C., and Ernest McCampbell of Tuskegee, Ala., gained the final round of the men's singles division in the New York State Negro open tennis championships on the Cosmopolitan Tennis Club's courts yesterday.

Yesterday's apartment rental reports revealed a continued demand for accommodations in East Side locations. A large number of the listings of new tenancies were in buildings on the side streets between Washington Square and Yorkville.

Albert A. Cole, 84 years old, claimant of the title of the nation's oldest active grocer, who once lamented with President Roosevelt that the day of the small country store was fading, died in his home here today after an illness of several months.

Imports of gold rose last week to $21,098,816, the highest in four weeks. The Department of Commerce said today that shipments included $3,840,000 from Sweden, $4,860,258 from England, $4,043,288 from Canada, $1,708,315 from Mexico and $5,874,820 from Japan.

An official letter from Mayor La Guardia asking the Lord Mayor of London tc attend the World's Fair next year was presented at Mansion House, the Lord Mayor's official residence, today by Henry H. Curran, Deputy Mayor of New York.

An appropriation of $500,000 for 1938, more than three times that of last year, has been made for courses to train foremen and other supervisors for WPA projects, it was revealed last night by F. C. Harrington, chief engineer and assistant administrator of the Works Progress Administration in Washington.
The Indians and White Sox battled nearly six hours today to divide a doubleheader, the Tribe taking the opener in ten innings, 12 to 9, and the Sox the nightcap in the ninth, 6 to 5.
Richard A. Van Namee, for sixtysix years a member of the editorial staff of The Lowville Journal and Republican, died tonight at his home here at the age of 80.

Henry Samuel Denny was killed yesterday when his car crashed into a tree as police believed he swerved to avoid a child playing in the road. Mr. Denny was thrown clear of the wreck, but a piece of the broken steering wheel pierced his neck, causing almost instant death.

Robert Suhay and Glenn Applegate, New York gunmen convicted of murdering W. W. Baker, Federal Bureau of Investigation agent, were hanged at the Federal penitentiary here, early today in the first double execution in Kansas in more than seventy years.
