Bernard' E. (Ben) Smith, stock broker of Bedford Village; H. L. McLean of Montreal and Armonk, and Mr. McLean's pilot, G. D. Preston, escaped injury tonight when McLean's plane struck a ditch and nosed over in a landing at the Westchester Airport here.

Lower prices were the rule in the securities and commodity markets yesterday. Stocks were depressed from the start and made their poorest showing soon after midday when leading issues were down 1 to 3 points.

Mayor La Guardia joined Grover A. Whalen, president of the New York World's Fair, 1939, yesterday in the ceremonial final riveting marking the completion of the steel framework of the "big apple," the name given by ironworkers to the huge Perisphere at the fair grounds, and its companion piece, the "splinter" or Trylon.
Secretary of Commerce Daniel C. Roper disclosed today a conviction of high-placed English friends that Europe will pass through the crisis of war threats in the next thirty days.

A shaggy malamute dog's appetite for seal meat took him on a 250-mile ocean cruise on a cake of ice. The story was told today by Father Bernard R. Hubbard after he and his companions arrived in their big walrus skin canoe from Barrow.

The first picture for Peter Holden, the lad from "On Borrowed Time," will be Booth Tarkington's "Little Orvie," RKO has decided. Shooting should get under way in December with George Haight as producer.

Ten Canadian Scouts, wearing the official uniform of the Montreal Scout camp, Tamaracouta, were welcomed here yesterday by officials of the Boy Scout Foundation, the Boy Scout Federation of Greater New York and the Canadian Club in a program of sight-seeing and entertainment which will last until their departure for Montreal tonight..

Instead of Chinese terrorists creating the first disturbances on the anniversary of hostilities in Shanghai it was armed Japanese thugs, as well as uniformed Japanese soldiers, invading the United States defense sector who stirred up trouble of the most serious rature.

Predicting a "steady rise until November or December" in automobile production, Ward's Auotomive Reports estimated today this week's assemblies at 13,790 units. This volume, it said, would be "the lowest total for any week this year."
The arrest of Michael Ebenchuck, 21 years old, on a charge of va grancy led him not to the workhouse but to a reunion with his father, who has sought him for nearly ten years.
The voyage of the Brandenburg was a magnificent performance, to which THE TIMES yesterday gave due praise.

Although the sales experience of local department stores varied sharply this week, with some showing gains over a year ago, the average for the city was estimated unofficially at 9 to 10 per cent below last year.

Isidore Nagler, American Labor party candidate for Representative in the Twenty-third Congressional District against Charles H. Buckley, Democratic incumbent, announced yesterday failure of negotiations for a coalition with the Bronx Republican organization, headed by John J. Knewitz, longtime political foe of Mayor La. Guardia.

World stocks of refined copper on July 31, excluding consumers' stocks at their plants or warehouses, were 523,196 tons, compared with 551,495 at the end of June, a decline of 28,299, according to the Copper Institute. In July blister stocks declined 11,707 tons, making the net decrease in copper stocks last month, 40,006 tons.

Eight rebels, presumably followers of General Saturnino Cedillo, were killed in a battle with federal troops near Las Cruces, according to dispatches today from Dolores Hidalgo; in the State of Guanajuato. Others of the band fled.

Cutting of prices on gasoline spread yesterday in Brooklyn to include some brands price-fixed last week by major distributors under the Feld-Crawford act. The practice was started earlier in the week by Sun Oil Company outlets, not controlled by the company, which has not signed a price-maintenance contract.

An accounting of the estate of Mrs. Edgar F. Luckenbach, wife of the shipping executive shows a balance of $29,642 after the deduction of $2,053 for the expenses of the administrator, Mr. Luckenbach. The schedule was filed today at the office of Surrogate Leone D. Howell here.

Here are some statements made in the National Emergency Councils report to the President on economic conditions in the South: The paradox of the South is that while it is blessed by nature with immense wealth, its people as a whole are the poorest in the country.

In the South, as elsewhere, the two most important economic endowments are its people and its physical resources. The 1937 census estimates showed that the thirteen Southern States had more than thirty-six million persons.

The decline in newspaper linage throughout the country last month was the smallest in several months, amounting to 15.7 per cent, according to Media Records figures for fifty-two cities. Linage amounted to 83,652,929 as against 99,206,283 in the like month of last year.
John Roosevelt and his bride sailed for Boston today aboard the steamer Lady Drake after a threeweek honeymoon here.

Two policemen and two other men well known to the police were arraigned yesterday in Felony Court, Brooklyn, on charges of grand larceny growing out of a scheme to mulct furriers in this city of large amounts of money by the pretended sale, at low prices, of furs that turned out to be nonexistent.

The hog market cleaned up fairly well today in a slow trade. Prices remained at the low spot of the week, or 75 cents to $1 under last week's close, the United States Department of Agriculture reports. Fed steer and yearling supplies were too small to fairly test values and other slaughter classes were generally steady. Lambs sold firm to higher in active trade.

Delegates continued yesterday to arrive for the opening session of the second World Youth Congress, which is scheduled for Monday night at the Municipal Stadium on Randalls Island. At least 500 representatives from more than fifty countries will attend the sessions, which after Monday will be held at Vassar College.

The Interstate Commerce Commission increased today from $16,000 to $22,000 the amount to be paid to Jerome N. Frank, now a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission, for his services as counsel for trustees of the Missouri Pacific Railroad.
Arnold Denker of New York won the New York State chess championship tonight when a victory over Howard Grossman of New York gave him a point total of 7 1/2-1 1/2.

Supreme Court Justice John Mac Crate, in Brooklyn, denied yesterday the petition of a group of Bensonhurst residents for per-mission to incorporate under the name of the "U. S. A. Democracy, Inc.," with the purpose -of establishing "American centers of activity for civic and social culture."
Bucky Walters, throwing just where he wanted to, outpitched fill McGee tonight and beat the Cardinals for his fifth victory as a Red, 3 to 2, in the fifth night game of the season here.

Many younger members of society have gone from this city and from Summer homes in surrounding districts to Newport for the ball to be given there tonight by Mr. and Mrs. Henry Baldwin Hyde Ripley to introduce their daughter, Miss Lesley Hyde Hope Ripley.

Miss Bertha Chapman, director of the Ann Reno School, 32 West Eighty-sixth Street, died Thursday night in Stroudsburg, Pa., after an illness of a week, according to word received here last night. She was in her seventieth year.

Senator Donahey of Ohio, Democratic chairman of the Joint Congressional Committee investigating the Tennessee Valley Authority, left here this afternoon for Washington, where he will confer with President Roosevelt tomorrow morning.
British troops, after intensive activity in the hills of Northern Palestine, reported today they had successfully routed two Arab bands. Five Arabs were reported killed.
The British motor-car industry, threatened with the loss of some of its home markets by rising imports, particularly from Germany, will soon be able to seek greater protection.

With yesterday's wordy war between Mayor La Guardia and State Commander Cross apparently forgotten for the time being, the State Department of the American Legion today rushed through a short business session and then paraded, 20,000 strong, through two miles of streets crowded by an estimated 100,000 persons.
Fritzie Zivic, 146 1/2, Pittsburgh, outpointed Joe Pennino, 149, South Brooklyn, in the star bout of eight rounds at the Coney Island Velodrome, Brooklyn, last night.
Longshoremen and truck drivers employed at the Long Island City plant of the National Sugar Refining Company were called on strike yesterday by their A. F. of L. unions.

One of the most open renewals in the history of the Travers, oldest horse race run in the United States, is scheduled for tomorrow, with nine named for the mile-anda-quarter test, which was inaugurated in 1864.
Crown Zellerbach Corporation has declared a dividend of 12 1/2 cents on the common stock. A similar dividend on this stock was paid on July 1.

Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Charles Albert Knox of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Knox, to Proctor Mayo Lovell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Maitland Clair Lovell of Springfield, Vt.

The motorship Wyatt Earp, supply ship of the fourth Lincoln Ellsworth expedition to the Antarctic, arrived yesterday at the seaplane base at Floyd Bennett Field, Brooklyn. Supplies will be loaded today and tomorrow and the vessel will leave on Monday for Cape Town, South Africa, where Commander Ellsworth now is.

The United States liner President Roosevelt, arriving today from Hamburg and way points, has among her passengers ninety-six delegates to the World Youth Congress meeting at Vassar College next week. The delegates represent eighteen countries.
Builders have acquired plots in the Bronx for improvement with two apartment houses and a dwelling.

Department store sales in the United States averaged 12 per cent lower in the week ended Aug. 6, as compared with the corresponding period of 1937, according to figures issued today by the Federal Reserve Board. For the four-week period ended Aug. 6 sales were down 11 per cent.

The three Little Entente States, it was indicated today, are scrambling in a race with Germany for new agreements with Hungary. They want to build a political and economic buttress against allurements that Germany is expected to offer to Hungary soon.

Gloria Williams, 22 years old, Negro, of 106 Warren Street, was arrested this morning for the hold-up slaying of Abraham Skolnick, 68, of 52 Runyon Street, who was shot four times Tuesday afternoon in the basement of a furniture store at 161 West Market Street.
Australia's hopes for an unhindered march through the final American zone Davis Cup competition were set back today when the favorites broke even with Japan in the first two singles matches.

The American Trust Company of San Francisco has obtained $2,826,182 of registered warrants of the State of California on a 0.75 per cent interest basis, plus a premium of $449.36. The warrants will be dated Aug. 15 and will mature on or about Feb. 2, 1939.
Mrs. John F. Erdmann and Mrs. Dudley Roberts Jr. were honor guests tonight at a birthday dinner given by Mr. and Mrs. John L. Kuser at the Devon Yacht Club.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

Government officials in Washington are already claiming as their own the modest recovery of business which has been in progress during recent weeks and are attributing it to the new pump-priming program. But in order to make this claim stick, it is necessary for them to rely on the argument that the prospect of future spending has had an important psychological effect on business sentiment.
The new operators of Roycroft Properties, art and literary crafts colony founded by Elbert Hubbard, started reorganization of the colony today with the designation of executive personnel.

The Rev. Dr. Lewis Seymour Mudge will retire on Aug. 24, his seventieth birthday, as stated clerk of the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America, its highest fulltime salaried office.

Miss Elena Teresa Villa, who will be married Aug. 20 to Robert Grant 3d of Jericho, L. I., was guest of honor at a dinner given by Mr. and Mrs. John Jacob Astor at Chetwode tonight. Mrs. Astor is to be one of the wedding attendants.

Authority granted by the Costa Rican Congress to expropriate electric light and power properties of the Electric Bond and Share Company is seen as another threat to the good-neighbor policy by The Panama Star-Herald.

Details of court room accommodations for reporters and others at the trial of James J. Hines, Tammany district leader, charged with participation in a policy racket, which begins Monday, were worked out yesterday by Supreme Court

After expressing doubt that "there is any such organization" as the forty-year-old United States Volunteer Life Saving Corps, Magistrate Overton Harris in Yorkville Court yesterday held a lieutenant of -the service in $1,000 bail for Special Sessions on a charge of endangering the life of a minor.
In the hardest blow that a mid-Summer regatta has experienced in many years, the Long Island Sound quartet of Star boats prevailed today in the Corinthian Yacht Club series.

It is now generally admitted that the appointment of Simon W. Gerson, a Communist, to a public office in the Borough of Manhattan was a political blunder which injured the city administration in the eyes of persons who are far from being professional Red-baiters.

Just as in the political field there is a tendency to take the recurring threats of war calmly for the reason that people have become used to living under the well-nigh constant threat of war in Europe, so in finance the markets take more quietly prospects that once would have paralyzed them.

Before a crowd of 9,000, the largest this season, the New York Roverettes gained an even break with the Langley-Lakesides by defeating the Toronto team, 2 to 1, in the feature contest of the women's softball double-header at Madison Square Garden last night. The game was the second and final one of the series between the teams.

Gross assets, $27,625; net, $24,061. To Ella Collins, sister, and John Dempsey, brother, one-half each. Chief assets, mortgages, notes, cash and Insurance, $27,325. Harry Herschman, attorney, 457 W. 151st St.

The fourth of seven men indicted by the Federal grand jury of the Northern Illinois District for mail fraud, in connection with Attorney General Bennett's investigation of Victor De Villiers Co. of 120 Wall Street, financial consultants, was arrested at his home here yesterday.

One woman and three men were slightly injured and about twenty other passengers shaken yesterday when two surface cars, a Flatbush Avenue trolley and a Nostrand Avenue shuttle, collided at Flatbush Avenue and Avenue H. Brooklyn.

Three members of the Medical Society of the District of Columbia filed in the Federal District Court today a suit to restrain the Group Health Association, Inc., formed to promote group hospitalization, from engaging in the practice of medicine.
The Rev. Leo Edward Hughes, editor in chief of The Torch, a national periodical of the Dominican Order, has been appointed pastor of St. Dominic's Church, Detroit.

A .plan for settling labor disputes within the framework of an industry is being tested by the State Labor Department at the suggestion of William H. Davis, chairman of the State Mediation Board and a member of President Roosevelt's commission to study employer-employe relationships in Great Britain and Sweden.

The daily volume of stock transactions on the New York Stock and Curb Exchanges for the account of all members in the week ended on July 23 were announced today by the Securities and Exchange Commission as follows:
Leaders in the English county cricket championship held their places today, although Yorkshires' margin over the second-place Middlesex eleven was reduced.

The official newspaper Izvestia features alarming news from its correspondents in Prague, Paris and London about the growing German-Czech tension and the German "test mobilization." The London correspondent declares:

Charles Moran Jr., and Thomas W. Phelps to be admitted to Francis I. du Pont Co.; M. Donald Grant to be admitted to Fahnestock Co.; Lucius P. Ordway Jr., Arthur J. Goldsmith, Byron G. Webster, Franklin Q. Brown, Lee Warren James and William Dewey Loucks to be admitted to Fuller, Rodney Co.; B. Henry Sincere to be admitted to Sincere Co.

King Carol today signed a law which divides Rumania into ten - provinces, replacing. more than seventy-two districts as administrative units. In the palace throne room, the King administered the oaths to ten Provincial Governors he appointed.

Joseph W. Catharine of Brooklyn, president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, announced yesterday that the forthcoming thirty-first annual convention of the organization in Milwauikee during the week of Nov. 7 will be of special interest because thirtytwo men who are still in the real estate business and who attended the meeting in Chicago thirty years ago, when the national association was formed, will be present as honor guests of the organization.
Horses from the local stables of Mrs. Ralph K. Trix of Detroit and Lake Placid dominated the saddle classes at the ninth annual Lake Placid Horse Show today.

A plan to secure professional supervision for the 85 per cent of building, which, it is said, does not receive architectural service, is outlined in a report issued by the small house committee of the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects. Harvey Stevenson is chairman of the committee.

Safe from further interference by the weather, Lou Ambers of Herkimer, N. Y., and Henry Armstrong of Los Angeles will meet in their postponed fifteen-round battle for the lightweight championship at Madison Square Garden Wednesday night.

King Carol today signed a law which divides Rumania into ten - provinces, replacing. more than seventy-two districts as administrative units. In the palace throne room, the King administered the oaths to ten Provincial Governors he appointed.

WOMEN ask, "What shall we have for dinner tonight?" Men ask, "Where is all that money you had last week?" And now five agencies of the United States Government have compiled figures on family incomes and expenditures which promise to answer the old questions: What do Americans eat? What do they pay for food?

Terrazzo, points out a household decorator, was old before America was discovered. It was known to and used extensively by the early Venetians, and many patterns designed by them are still copied today.

A description and to a certain extent an evaluation of the work of the Tennessee Valley Authority in the field of education is contained in the latest issue of the Bulletin of the Bureau of School Service of the University of Kentucky.

Major Frank C. Love of Syracuse, a wound-scarred veteran of the World War, assumed command of New York's American Legion tonight as the organization rededicated itself to a fight on subversive foreign "isms."

An "unprecedented" speed-up in the PWA's system of passing on application for project loans and grants has enabled that agency to dispatch a total of 3,028 contracts to applicants whose projects have been approved in the less than forty days since the new PWA program was authorized.

Are any of the programs or agencies instituted by the National Administration during the last few years as means of assisting the unemployed and unfortunate to escape use in the election campaigns this year?

RECENT events in Germany signalize a progressive and rapid extension of State control over the people's activities. These events, coupled with developments in the Soviet Union, invite the question whether National Socialism as practiced in the Reich and the type of collectivism at present in effect in Russia do not have more similarities than dissimilarities.

The index of machine tool orders again recorded an increase in July, rising to 89.6 from 70.2 in June, according to figures issued today by the National Machine Tool Builders Association. The index for July, 1937, stood at 170.1.

ALL THROUGH THE NIGHT, by Conway Washburne. At the Theatre-in-the-Dale, Marble Dale, Conn. (Wednesday.) BRIGHT REBEL, by Stanley Young, with John Cromwell, Francesca Bruning and Merle Maddern. At the Chapel Playhouse, Guilford, Conn. COWBOYS AND INDIANS, by Gerald Sykes. At the Monomoy Theatre, Chatham, Cape Cod, Mass. (Wednesday.)

Miss Marion E. Smith, assistant chairman of the Republican National Committee in charge of women activities, announced today that the first meeting of the National Federation of Women's Republican Clubs would be held Sept. 23 and 24 in Chicago.

Douglas G. Corrigan, without even attracting the attention of passers-by, returned to a somewhat deserted City Hall yesterday morning for the first time since his official welcome by many thousands eight days ago.
Senator George prepared today to take the stump on Monday for the first time since President Roosevelt in a Barnesville speech Thursday asked that he be. defeated.

Patrolman Oliver P. Swank, 37 years old, attached to the Liberty Avenue station, Brooklyn, was arrested yesterday at his home, 243-55 Mayda Road, Rosedale, Queens, on a charge of grand larceny, based on the complaints of furriers who were swindled of large sums of money.

King Carol today signed a law which divides Rumania into ten - provinces, replacing. more than seventy-two districts as administrative units. In the palace throne room, the King administered the oaths to ten Provincial Governors he appointed.

This is the eleventh of a series of articles describing small gardens in and around New York which have been planned and planted by their owners. By KATHARINE B. STORM "What a cool and comfortable garden to live in!" is the first thought that comes to the visitor to the modest place of Glen R. Gardner in Bronxville, N. Y. A leisurely trip through it emphasizes this initial impression.

NEWPORT -Newport opens her annual Tennis Week on Monday, one of the gayest weeks of the Summer. The occasion is the annual invitation tournament of the Newport Casino, the tournament that often indicates the winner of the national singles later on.

Bonds called last week for redemption before maturity were in smaller volume than in the preceding period. Except for two large public utility bond retirements the calls were principally for small amounts of municipal bonds. Payment dates were nearly all for future months.
CITIZEN OF GENEVA: Selections From the Letters of Jean- Jacques Rousseau. By Charles William Hendel. 420 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $3.50.

MOST people know very little about Rumaniaa country whose beautiful, forceful and somewhat enigmatic Queen Mother has recently died, whose King has had notorious love affairs, whose capital is Bucharest and whose oil wells and peasant costumes are vaguely famous.
Willey Eley, New York middleweight boxer, died in a hospital today from injuries suffered in a bout with Buzz Barton of Jamaica last night.

Federal savings and loan associations in metropolitan New York are maintaining a substantial gain in residential financing over the 1937 volume, according to Harold N. Brodhead. Reviewing reports from ten representative Federal associations, he reports a 15 per cent gain in home loan volume for the first six months of the present year as compared with the same period of 1937.

The WPA intends to spend $200,000,000 in this city next year on a program which Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress Administrator. regards as "the most forward step in planning construction and white-collar activities in New York City in 150 years."

Pigiron production in Sweden in the first half of 1938 amounted to 348,000 tons, compared with 313,000 tons in the same period last year, according to statistics reported to the Department of Commerce today by the United States commercial attache at Stockholm.

The super family Bible, baptismal certificates and school records are being prerented by applicants making claims for lump-sum payments under the Federal old-age insurance program, according to Leonard F. Sawyer, manager of the Social Security Board's field office here.

AFTER sixteen years of tolerant service, Lord Cromer has just retired from the office of Lord Chamberlain of His Majesty's Household. To Americans, meagerly acquainted with the intricacies of royal administration, he is known chiefly as the official censor of plays produced in England.

THE Silvermine Guild Music Festival Association, Inc., sponsored by the Connecticut State Federation of Music Clubs and the Silvermine Guild of Artists, announces the complete programs for the annual festival to be held at Norwalk, Conn., from Aug. 18 to 21, as follows:

The Cubs unloaded a powerhouse attack again today to crush the leagueleading Pirates for the second straight time, 11 to 5, although the great Dizzy Dean and his $185,000 arm failed to last the full nine innings.
THE air parade over the North Atlantic was continued last week when the German fourengined, all-metal, low-wing Condor monoplane landed at Floyd Bennett Field to end a flight from Berlin.

William Henry Muzzy, a patent attorney and an inventor whose improvements on the cash register and automobile made possible the modern product, died late today in his home at 111 Gates Avenue. He was 66 years old.

A number of rare books used in teaching the children of the pioneers of New England in the eighteenth century have been added to the collection on display at the historic school house in York Village, Me., as one of the features of the "Relive the Days of Our Forefathers" celebration in ,the village yesterday and today.

Gifts to education amounting to more than $2,000,000 include the Emily and Ernest Woodruff Foundation, the Frank B. Cotton bequest to the University of Texas and the John A. Roebling gift to Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, according to figures presented in School and Society.
THEODORE BARRIERE: DRAMATIST OF THE SECOND EMPIRE. By Edwin Colby Byam. 8vo. Paper covers. Baltimore, Md.: The Johns Hopkins Press. 53. A biographical and critical study.

A number of properties in Putnam County, N. Y., were reported yesterday as sold by Morris H. Bannister, Peekskill broker. Among b them was the 100-acre farm, north of Oscawanna Lake, formerly owned by the estate of Morris Barger.

Tommy Goodwin of the Winged Foot Golf Club and former New York State champion, continuing his exceptionally fine play, defeated Dr. T. J. Conte, also of Winged Foot, by 6 and 5 today to advance to the semifinal round of the annual men's international invitation tournament

An unusually large number of buyers are planning early return trips to the New York wholesale market in response to consumer demand for new Fall merchandise, according to a summary of business developments especially prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., resident buyers.

Wood and teakwood which once comprised part of a gun and guncarriage used during the 1812-14 war to repel American invaders, have been converted into small gifts for President Roosevelt. Kingston war veterans will make the presentation through Mayor H. A. Stewart when the President visits here Thursday to receive a D. C. L. degree at Queen's University.

DEWITT, Ark., Aug. 13.--The Arkansas County Democratic Central Committee, meeting here to certify Aug. 9 primary returns, unanimously adopted a resolution condemning "Federal officials" who "use their positions to influence voters in Democratic primaries in the various States."

The eight old-law tenements at 527-541 East Seventy-second Street, near Marie Curie Avenue, are being remodelled into four apartment buildings to contain suites of three and four and one-half rooms. The City Mortgage Company, George Palen Snow, president, is the owner. Scacchetti Siegel are the architects.

HERE is a book which, as Miss Thompson says, "had to be done." And she was the person to do it. For years the desperate plight of the refugees driven from authoritarian States, notably Germany, has outraged her deeply, and drawn from her utterances throbbing with passionate indignation.

Paul Emery, farmer, believes the Greeley AAA office has set itself a difficult problem in figuring out his 1939 wheat allotment. He said that he received this letter from the office: "Mr. Wheat Grower: From information on file in this office it appears that the average planting of wheat on your farm x x x is 0 (correct) acres.
The text of Senator Wagner's statement today, assailing Section 25 of the judiciary article of the proposed new State Constitution, dealing with review of decisions of State agencies, is as follows:

The Browns continued their winning stride today as they gained a. 6-to-3 victory over the Tigers to give Bill Cox his first triumph since coming to St. Louis from the White Sox. He allowed nine hits, the same number permitted by his opponent, George Gill.

Of late there has been an increased interest in the growing of espaliered fruit trees. A number of nurserymen list trees already trained to formal shape, which the gardener need only plant against a wall in order to obtain a quick yield.
WHITE MOUNTAINS, N. H.,--Prominent on the program in the White Mountains for this week is the sixth annual flower show of the White Mountain Garden Club at the new Town Hall in Franconia.
CERTAINLY St. Patrick is the most celebrated of the Apostles to Western Europe: a large part of the English-speaking world goes green-accoutered on March 17, the anniversary of his death.

Evidences of a steady rise in home construction were indicated in an announcement just made by Morton Bodfish, executive vice president of the United States Building and Loan League, that during the month of June, the savings, building and loan associations of the country made new construction loans aggregating $30,053,500 and modernization loans to the value of $6,516,400. These represented the largest sums advanced for such purposes since last September.

A twelve-foot granite obelisk will be dedicated Monday on the Arctic barrens near the spot where Will Rogers and Wiley Post crashed to death in an airplane three years ago. Standing far from the busy world which accorded fame to both men, the monument will be seen by few.

The astronomers think in light-years, and when the distance that a ray of light can cover in a year becomes too small a yardstick for their distances, they invent more formidable terms. They measure duration by thousands of millions of years-in their thoughts a million years is only a tick of the great clock.

Buildings of the future planned for air conditioning on both a satisfactory and economical basis will undergo some radical changes in design, according to A. Warren Canney, air-conditioning consultant of this city.

Although unaccompanied by heavy selling, the stock market last week experienced the widest decline since the week ended on March 26. Euorpe's last war scare caught the market in an uncertain mood and the path led downward. Bonds declined in sympathy with stocks. Except for a further slide in prices on the Berlin Boerse, the European stock markets took the war situation calmly.
Midsummer with its scorching days-when, too often, most gardens are habitable only in early morning and evening-is the season when shady gardens are most fully appreciated.

AMID a celebration to be attended by President Roosevelt and Lord Tweedsmuir, Governor General of Canada, the Thousand Islands Bridge over the St. Lawrence River, connecting the United States and the Province of Ontario, will be formally dedicated next Thursday.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Frank Atherton Ketcham of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Joan Ketcham, to DeWitt Clinton Howell Jr., son of Mrs. E. Barnum Howell of Pelham.
HOUSING COMES OF AGE. By Michael W. Straus and Talbot Wegg. Illustrated. 259 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $2.75.
The Rev. Francis A. Walsh, professor of philosophy and former regent of the seminary at Catholic University, died last night at Providence Hospital after an emergency operation. His age was 54.

A sandhog stricken with the "bends" at his Harlem home last night was rushed to the best available treatment-the "medical lock" at Forty-second Street and First Avenue, in eleven minutes by a police radio car.

PETOSKY, Mich.-On Thursday and Friday the annual Hiawatha Indian Pageant will be staged by Petosky's birch-bordered lake, at a typical Indian village constructed among the cedars with tepees, relics and rustic bridges.

The Board of Education, which has been trying unsuccessfully for several years to expand the physical structure of the school system, will try to win approval of voters for a new program Sept. 7, when a referendum on two building projects will be held.

Announcement has been made of the engagement and approaching marriage of Miss Anne Parker Tenney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James B. Tenney of Tucson, Ariz., to Robert Childs Bacon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick T. H. Bacon of this city. The wedding will take place on Aug. 29 in Guayaquil, Ecuador.

More than a score of exporters and importers from this city will go to Washington tonight to attend public hearings on the proposed reciprocal trade agreement with Venezuela opening tomorrow before the Committee for Reciprocity Information. Briefs outlining major points on which American exporters seek concessions were filed with the committee a week ago yesterday.

Commenting upon the large number of families of low incomes who are able to purchase homes under the FHA easy payment conditions Herbert U. Nelson, executive vice president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, calls attention to the fact that the time will soon come when insured mortgage financing cannot be secured on older houses except on those that have previously been mortgage-insured.

IT isn't that Oscar Hammerstein 2d dislikes Hollywood. It's merely that he prefers the Broadway where the name of Hammerstein has been a fixture these many years-where, indeed, a single Hammerstein used regularly to provide enough excitement to account single-handed for a whole theatrical season.

Jack Cooper of Kansas City came through today with a straight-heat victory in the 225-cubic-inch hydroplane class, the feature event of the New York State inboard motor-boat championship regatta held under the auspices of the Northport Yacht Club.

In the State of Minas Geraes, hills upon hills of iron spread over a vast area in that mountainous State awaiting the day when dynamite will blast them open and railway and steamship haul the ore away. For long an unsolved problem in Brazil's economic life and the source of many controversies, the conversion of Brazilian iron into a tangible asset now appears near realization.

RADIO reception should be greatly improved during the next five or six years, according to Dr. A. G. McNish of the Carnegie Institution of Washington and Dr. Harlan T. Stetson of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

Miss Maud Green, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas S. Green of Loudonville, was married this afternoon in the garden of her parents' country home in Center Berlin, to Richard Park, son of the Rev. and Mrs. Charles E. Park of Boston.

PROMISING speed fans nothing but his "best effort in what I consider the fastest car ever built," John R. Cobb, wealthy British race driver, who arrived in New York recently, flew immediately to Utah, where his weird, bug-like car was waiting for him.

The cost of bathtubs today is about 63 per cent of the base price in 1926, points out the Plumbing and Heating Industries Bureau. Among the materials available for renovating the bathroom, it is pointed out that attractive plumbing fixtures in tastefully matched sets may be obtained, also improved showers, faucets and valves; quiet water closets;
Objections of former Khedive Abbas Helmi Pasha II of Egypt may prevent the marriage of his son, Prince Abdul Monheim, to one of the three unmarried sisters of King Zog of Albania.

Mrs. Helen Bellati, 50 years old, of 449 Robinson Avenue; Lawndale, a suburb of Philadelphia, was killed instantly this afternoon on the Black Horse Pike, five miles southeast of Hammonton. She was being driven home from a vacation at Wildwood by her daughter, Mrs. Beatrice Reese, 29, of same address, when left rear tire burst and the car overturned Mrs.

Arnold Denker of the Manhattan Chess Club of New York, former star player on De Witt Clinton High School and New York University teams, and now in his twentyfifth year, today was hailed as champion of New York State.
KNIGHTED on the advice of Prime Minister Ramsay MacDonald and winner of a Nobel Prize, Sir Norman Angell is accepted throughout the world as the Prose Laureate of Peace.

Two new destroyers to be built by the Federal Shipbuilding and Drydock Company at Kearny, N. J., will be named the Plunkett and the Kearny. Another to be built at the Puget Sound Navy Yard will be called the Monssen.

THE Paderewski Fund Prize Competition has announced a prize of $1,000 for (1) a work for chamber orchestra, from fifteen to twenty minutes long; (2) an equal prize for a "concerto or other serious work for a solo instrument with symphonic orchestra," not less than fifteen minutes long.
LONDON-The Carlsberg Fund in Copenhagen has been asked to help pay for statues. of Hamlet, Ophelia and Shakespeare to be set up at Elsinore, which Shakespeare made famous as Hamlet's home town.

John P. Frey, vice president of the American Federation of Labor, told the Special House Committee Investigating Un-American Activities in the United States today that Communists held many key positions in the C. I. O.

Mr. and Mrs. William W. Ogle of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Louise Evans Ogle, to Raymond Rees Campbell, son of Captain and Mrs. E. S. Campbell of East Orange, N. J. The wedding will take place in the early Spring.

Working ten hours a day, four men, the four members of the Commission for the Permanency of Foreigners in Brazil, have in a few days decided the fate of several hundreds of foreign exiles from among several thousands who entered Brazil on tourist visas and continued to remain illegally after the expiration of the six months allotted them.

Officers of the State National Guard, commanded by Major Gen. William N. Haskell, completed at Camp Smith today their study of tactical manoeuvres to be employed in effecting a river-crossing next week while conducting their war games over an imaginary front of twenty miles in Northern Westchester, Putnam and Dutchess Counties.

Miss E. Elizabeth Larned, daughter of Right Rev. and Mrs. John Insley Blair Larned of Dongan Hills, S. I., was married yesterday afternoon in St. John's Episcopal Church, Clifton, S. I., to John Stowell Davidson, also of Dongan Hills.

Well-at first glance your evidence reads aright: Our decadence apparently heads for the troglodyte. Lost in a spiritual fog We seek our ideal in the Banderlog. And yet I cannot forget That among the Broadway plays the greatest crowds flock to see Is a tender fantasy about a little boy, and his "Gramp" who chased Death up a tree.

DIRECTOR W. S. VAN DYKE II has become accustomed to being told, "You're it." The game has been going on for twenty-three years, ever since Van Dyke became one of D. W. Griffith's many assistants during the filming of "Intolerance" in 1915. He was then an actor.

The Rev. Terence Connolly, Professor of English in Boston College, set Dublin talking yesterday when at the Abbey Theatre festival lecture at the Gresham Hotel he asked questions on what exactly W. B. Yeats meant by his new play, "Purgatory."

Racing the last mile and a half through. heavy fog, Francis Darrah of Boston. today broke his course record to win the third annual eight-mile race to the summit of Mount Washington. Darrah's time was hour 15 minutes 27.2 seconds. He set -the record for the -stony, 22-degree course of 1.16:18 two-years ago.

A test case under the Workmen's Compensation Law that may vitally affect the relationship between the Western Union Telegraph Company End its hundreds of branch office managers in small communities has resulted from an accident in which a messenger boy was injured here last Nov. 27.

Conducting a five-year study of the social significance of adult education in the United States to discover the meaning and estimate the worth of adult education as a social movement among the other social movements, the American Association for Adult Education recently published the eleventh of a series of books and pamphlets which have grown out of the study.

Senate investigators will continue until after the November elections to look into charges of political abuses in nine States, Chairman Sheppard of the Campaign Expenditures Committee announced today.

The possibility of the creation of a number of Ministers without portfolio who would, in actual practice, become the chief executive power of the Japanese Government is filling the metropolitan press of the empire again and is to be heard 'wherever the politicall minded gather.

Eager to come to grips with the problem of world peace and other matters of vital importance to the young people of the world, ninetysix delegates to the Second World Youth Congress arrived yesterday on the United States liner President Roosevelt and proceeded to International House, 500 Riverside Drive, where they will remain until Tuesday.
Work on the $5,000,000 grade-crossing elimination project at Elizabethport, tied up since Aug. 5 because of a labor dispute, will be resumed on Monday. Two hundred men will go back to work.

A general upswing in industrial activity was forecast by electrical equipment manufacturers here last week on the strength of an increasingly active demand for the motors and generators used extensively in operating production machinery of all kinds. A rise in such sales in the past has heralded a pick-up in manufacturing activity, it was pointed out.

Leaping from a plane over the Royal Air Force field at Netheravon, Wiltshire, shortly after midnight this morning, Gwynne Jones, 28-year-old Welsh parachutist, established what is held to be a world record night drop, 20,000 feet.

A barn dance will be held in the open patio of the Atlantic Beach Club next Friday night as the third in a series of informal Friday evening parties arranged for this month. The patio will be decorated with corn stalks, Autumn foliage and other materials to suggest a rustic scene. Members and their guests have been requested to attend the dance in typical farm costumes.
The American Bureau for Medical Aid in China announces that delivery of four new ambulances to the Chinese National Red Cross in Hong Kong has been completed

Dissension within the United Automobile Workers of America, which led this week to the expulsion of three international vice presidents and the suspension of a fourth, is a vital factor in a complicated and confusing situation that reaches far beyond the union and the automobile industry.

Freight rate differentials, the nation's reciprocal tariff policy and "too damn much politics" were comments made today by Southern leaders referring to the report of the National Emergency Council as to what ails the South.

The assertion that anti-New Deal Republicans did not propose to be "sold down the river" by Kenneth F. Simpson, New York County Republican chairman, was made yesterday by Major William Lathrop Rich in a letter to Douglas L. Elliman.

The freshman who goes to the University of Oklahoma this Fall with a high school diploma but still not quite prepared to cope with the harder studies of a college curriculum will get ready for university courses through a "remedial program."
Mrs. Thomas B. Ford of this city has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Marguerite Mary Ford, to Joseph F. X. Myles, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Myles of Springfield Gardens, L. I.

Making his final appearance of the season at Lewisohn Stadium, Alexander Smallens last night directed the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra in an all-Russian program. The intermission divided the post-Revolution from the preRevolution music.

In asking Georgia to deny another term to Senator George "because he cannot possibly, in my judgment, be classified as belonging to the liberal school of thought," the President made clear several things more important than his wish to gain another 100 per cent Senate supporter of the remainder of the New Deal program. Among the more important implications of his Barnesville speech are:
THE Postoffice Department last week released advance photographs of the "Presidential" 10c salmon and 11e blue stamps to have first-day sales at Washington on Sept. 2 and 8, respectively.
EMOTION AND THE EDUCATIVE PROCESS. A report to the American Council on Education. Edited by Daniel A. Prescott. 293 pp. The American Council on Education. $1.50.

The dramatic flying visit of Colonial Secretary Malcolm MacDonald to Palestinedramatic partly because it was done with so little fuss-has reminded Great Britain that she has the most intractable of all her imperial problems on her hands in the Holy Land.

National Dog Week will be observed this year Sept. 19-24 and canine organizations throughout the country will aim to bring before the general public the seven objectives of the work, which are as follows: 1. A good home for every dog.
Today's arguments between the Dodgers and Bees provided only an even break for both clubs, but furnished a tremendous lot of entertainment to more than 16,000 fans, 9,381 of them paying patrons.

TOURISTS visiting New York City this Summer will crane their necks, click their cameras and cast a last fond glance at some of their favorite landmarks. Next year new piles of steel and concrete, or green trees and open parks, will take possession of four historic sites that today fill pages in city guide books. Paddy's Market, as it used to

William J. Pickett, assistant Professor of Mathematics at Cooper Union and first president of the Men's Faculty Club of that institution, died Friday in St. Luke's Hospital after an illness of several weeks. His age was 57. He lived at the Hudson View Gardens. 183d Street and Pinehurst Avenue.

The marriage of Miss Louise Matthies to Brian Chandler Bellows Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Bellows of Maplewood, took place here this afternoon at Five Trees, the country home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. William H. Matthies of Hackensack. The Rev. James Moore, pastor of the Methodist Church here, performed the ceremony.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Margaret Brown, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Randolph Brown of McIntosh, Fla., to William Beverly Webber of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank H. Webber of Batavia. N. Y.

MORNING EVENTS Class 21, Open Jumpers-First, Wide Water Farm's ro. g. Blue Steel; second, Anne Wright's b. m. Royal Cockade Boy; third, Deborah G. Rood's br. g. Fred's Friend; fourth, Martin J. Aylward's ch. g. Flash.

THE Malvern Festival opens at the beginning of next week, and the London stage is putting up an excellent show of being in a state of breathless expectancy; at any rate, it goes on withholding from dramatic critics the least shadow of a reason for their existence.

The Interstate Commerce. Commission today authorized an additional payment of $5,500 to Ernest A. Green, a lawyer of St. Louis, for his services between Dec. 30, 1937, and June 30, 1938, as co-counsel for trustees of the Missouri Pacific Railroad in reorganization proceed??ings.

Jefferson County farmers organized today to combat a plague of grasshoppers which threatened to destroy their crops. Oscar W. Sellers, County Farm. Bureau agent, said farmers faced the loss of thousands of dollars if the advance, of the grasshoppers was not halted.

Wartime Premier W. M. Hughes, now Minister of External Affairs, has caused a stir by an extraordinary speech in which he termed the Dominions Office as obsolete as a muzzle-loading rifle or a hansom cab because the conditions warranting its existence had disappeared.

After exactly a year of strife, silent sawmills and idle men still mark the warfare between the American Federation of Labor and the Com-' mittee for Industrial Organization for control of the lumber industry in the Pacific Northwest. On its first anniversary the conflict shows no sign of cessation in the immediate future.
Miss Jean Annette Sharkey, daughter of Mrs. Benjamin Sharkey of Englewood, was married tonight to William Rhodes Parsil, son of Mrs. William R. Parsil and the late Mr. Parsil of Maplewood, N. J.

Miss Marion Martin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Asa Earl Martin of this place, was married here this afternoon in the Nittany Lion Inn to Robert Bruce Blum, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herman Blum of Philadelphia.

Colonel Robert P. Marshall left Pine Camp today to return to his home at 1,160 Park Avenue, New York, in the middle of the two week's training period of the 391st Field Artillery Regiment, organized reserves, of which he is commander.

A new section is about to be opened for development at Packanack Lake, in the Boonton section of Passaic County, N. J., and plans are being made for the construction of several cottages for occupancy next season.

LONDON. EVEN with Darryl Zanuck descending on Mayfair at teatime in full polo rig, except for horse, Eddie Cantor and film revivals (if Eddie will pardon the bracket) have shared the recent attention of London pretty evenly between them.
Through more than 100 projects of various kinds, the Works Progress Administration is giving material assistance in crime prevention, Harry L. Hopkins, WPA Administrator, announced today.

Several hundred members of the Summer colony and their week-end house parties attended the annual midsummer ball held tonight at the Southampton Beach Club. White floodlights, simulating moonlight, Illuminated the terrace and breakers in front of the clubhouse and red, blue and white floodlights were used in the lighting of the pool off the rear terrace.

For the second year, students from thirty schools geographically distributed from Boston to Los Angeles who entered college without taking the regular entrance examinations have made slightly higher grades than an equal number of students who came in by the old way.

Pressing resolutely onward in the matter of nailing down the 1938 American League pennant, the Yankees hammeredd Connie Mack's Athletics at the Stadium yesterday and did it so thoroughly as to convince a gathering of 9,232 that Marse Joe McCarthy is not apt to let his mallet slip many more times this season.

The engagement of Miss Carolyn A. Coon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Coon of this place, to Donald C. Creasy, son of George H. Creasy of New York and the late Mrs. Creasy, has been announced by her parents.

The recurrent battle over whether the Democratic party shall be a willing instrument of President Roosevelt's New Deal reached new intensity last week. The President, refreshed by a vacation cruise, marched into Georgia.

A CONVICTION that radio drama lends itself better to a narrative than to a strictly dramatic form, was the inspiration for the "first person singular" technique employed by Orson Welles, actor-producer of the Mercury Theatre, in the current series of Monday night performances on WABC's stage.

The Senators today scored their second straight victory over the Red Sox, 4 to 1. Monte Weaver, mixing wide curves with a zipping fast ball, held Boston to seven hits, all of them singles. In the first inning the Senators tallied three times on four straight singles and an error by Cronin.

A continuation of the season's most favorable weather in nearly all sections had a depressing influence on prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday. Despite the fact that near deliveries ran below the theoretical government lending figure, persistent selling pressure limited recoveries and closed the list at the bottom with losses of 3 to 4 points.

The Federal Home Building Service Plan, which has been in process of development for more than two years, is now achieving definite results, officials declared yesterday in announcing that a total of 170 lending institutions have been approved and are offering the service in fortynine cities; Organizations are being formed in many other communities.

The- 1938-39 Scottish Football League season was ushered in today with a deluge of goals, 56 being scored in the ten first-division matches. It was a great start for the eight and one-half month campaign.

Signs that this is the beginning of the end of Summer are these: the phlox is blooming, and tomorrow college shops in department stores all over town are opening. Before the ink was dry on last June's final exam papers the store people were beginning to order the clothes and accessories for these shops.

The new city building code, which became effective last January, is likely to undergo several amendments, according to the annual report of the research bureau of the Merchants Association of New York, announced yesterday.

Earnings of the chemical industry showed a slight improvement in the second quarter of 1938 but remained substantially below results for the same period a year before. The net income of sixteen principal companies for the quarter totaled $16,808,540, a gain of $540,668, or 3.32

Shipments of copper and other metals used in war were stepped up sharply here last week, customs brokers who handle shipping arrangements for exporters reported yesterday. In addition to metals, machinery suitable for the manufacture of war equipment, airplanes and engines and a number of other products have been going out in growing quantities since the middle of last month.

Harmon Fitch of Winston-Salem, N. C., won the men's singles final in the New York State Negro open tennis championships on the courts of the Cosmopolitan Tennis Club yesterday. Fitch conquered Ernest McCampbell of Tuskegee, Ala., 6-1, 3-6, 6-4, 6-3, to take the honors.

Scientists are pondering over mysterious blood-red stretches of water appearing along the Pacific Coast in the past few weeks. Early in June,.off La Jolla, home of the Scripps Institute of Oceanography, the blood-like condition of the water became so dense that it interfered with fishing activities.

For the first time in forty years of colonial relationship to the United States, the Filipinos, at the behest of their President, graciously made a sincere gesture of gratitude to America by celebrating the anniversary of Manila's occupation by American troops, on Aug. 13, 1898. Reflecting a new and vastly more cordial note, Commonwealth President Manuel L. Quezon told a huge crowd:

A picture of wide gains in Soviet Russia since the 1917 revolution was drawn by Deputies at a meeting today of the Soviet of the Union, one of the two houses of Russia's new Parliament, in debating on a unified State budget for 1938. These are some of the things reported:
THE Fifth Berkshire Symphonic Festival, and the third of these festivals to be given by the Boston Symphony Orchestra, directed by Serge Koussevitzky, comes to an end this afternoon.

Billy Burke, the 1931 national open champion, cheered the home folks today by shooting a 34, 35-69 in the $10,000 Cleveland open golf tournament to take a place beside Ky Laffoon of Chicago at the head of the parade.

Dublin Venture, the towering gray gelding owned and ridden by Miss Deborah G. Rood of Wilmington, Del., today was awarded the hunter championship of the fourteenth annual horse show of the East Hampton Riding Club. The exhibition was held on the attractive grounds of the organization.

When President Roosevelt and Premier Mackenzie King of Canada dedicate the new international bridge across the St. Lawrence River at the Thousand Islands Aug. 18, they will add another stone to one of the most amazing structures in history-the American-Canadian border.

The administrative committee of the American Labor party has decided to substitute James H. Fay for Byrnes MacDonald as candidate for Representative in the Sixteenth Congressional District, Alex Rose, State executive secretary, announced yesterday.

Michael Lynch, 31 years old, of 506 West 172d Street, a motormanswitchman employed by the I. R. T. was instantly killed shortly before 8 o'clock last night when an empty eight-car train he was operating crashed into a "dead" train on the center track of the White Plains Avenue Division elevated line south of 222d Street and White Plains Avenue, the Bronx.

A marked increase in the public health facilities in the United States has resulted from the provision of funds for this purpose under the Social Security Act, said the United States Public Health Service today on the third anniversary of this legislation's passage.

Plans for the establishment of a Pan-American school of agriculture as a unit of the Louisiana State University College of Agriculture, to open in September, 1939, and to be devoted to a study of the farm problems of South and Central American countries, ?? been announced by Dr. James M. Smith, president of the university.

Wyoming voters will make their choices purely upon State and local issues when they go to the polls Tuesday to select nominees for Congressional, State and county offices.

By thoughtlessly letting a liquid get hotter than the experiment called for, Purdue University chemists have uncovered a process which scientists predict will start rich new industries ultimately worth billions of dollars.

THE Postoffice Department's success in selling more than a million dollars' worth of mint postal paper to collectors and dealers during each of the past four fiscal years is exciting the envy of some of the governments abroad.

MANHATTAN ALBAUOH, OLIVD (July 26). Estate not more than $6,000. To Gordon A Mac Donald, Bellwood, III., and Philip W Clancy, Beverly Hills, Caallr., Done-Half personality. William Le Baron Sands, 139 W. 82d St. executor.

Favored by at least another week's stay at home before plunging into the West for their fourth and final trip of the season, Bill Terry's Giants will return to the Polo Grounds Tuesday to stage what virtually amounts to a "do-or-die" stand.
SYRACUSE.-New features of the New York State Fair are expected to attract more than 500,000 visitors to this, the oldest State fair in the country, when it opens here on Aug. 29 for a two weeks' run.

Miss Elizabeth Ladd, daughter of Dean Carl E. Ladd of the State Colleges of Agriculture and Home Economics at Cornell and Mrs. Ladd, was married today to Lieutenant Ferdinand J. Tate, U. S. A., son of Mrs. Ferdinand Tate of Eunice, La. The Rev. Father Donald M.

The Agricultural Adjustment Administration reported today that sugar delivered to United States markets under the quota law in July amounted to 635,133 short tons, raw value. Deliveries in the same month last year amounted to 613,864 short tons.

IT was Charley Berry who said that he knew where to find Sam Chapman. That seemed logical on two counts. Charley is a coach with the Athletics and Sam is an outfielder on the team. A coach should know where a player is at any given moment. Also, Charley was an AllAmerica end when he played football for Lafayette.

Five persons were killed and eight injured early today when a northbound international limited Sunshine train crashed head on into a special southbound Sunshine limited three miles from Queretaro. The trains were operated by the Mexican Government.

NOBODY bathed in the ocean and "going to the seashore" was not a popular pastime 125 years ago in France, according to the historical research made by experts of the Trouville Regional Museum, which is devoted to the history of sea bathing. Included within it is a collection of bathing suits, among them "those that grandmother wore." Old engravings, paintings
WASHINGTON.-Under the direction of Colonel E. R. Warner McCabe, Assistant Chief of Staff, Army G2 officers are working overtime these days to keep abreast of foreign military developments.

YENAN, China.-Politics in China have taken many a strange turn, and it is not altogether surprising that a little walled city in North Shenai should have become the center of a system of political training that may well decide the war.

The garden of Shore Meadows, the home here of Mr. and Mrs. Stanton Mott, was the setting this afternoon for the marriage of their daughter, Miss Helen Raegener Mott, to Ernest Wilhelm Stawitz of New York, son of the late Dr. and Mrs. Paul Stawitz of Wiesbaden, Germany.

THE World's Fair is already having an effect on business. The fact is that clubs which survive largely on the cash of tourists have in numerous instances touched a new low this Summer. Although the constant rain on the Eastern seaboard probably discouraged visitors, the consensus is that out-of-towners are saving their pennies for next year when Grover A. Whalen's project at Flushing will be thrown in as one of Father Knickerbocker's attractions.

The flower show at the New York State Fair atSyracuse, to be held for two weeks, beginning Monday, Aug. 29, will for the first time combine the regular shows of the Empire State Gladiolus Society, the New York State Federation of Garden Clubs, the Hudson River Conservation Society, the Associated Garden Clubs of Central New York and similar organizations.

Crumbs of comfort are not to be despised in times like these. Just because it is a world given over to undeclared wars in Spain, to incidents that are bloody wars in China, to heavy artillery fighting that is not war on the Siberian border, we are justified in looking for compensation of some sort.

Daily average sales of general merchandise in small towns and rural areas last month were about 7.5 per cent under July, 1937, according to estimates released today by the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce.
Gifts totaling $93,663.19 have been made to the University of Rochester in the current calendar year, Raymond L. Thompson, the treasurer, reported today.

Credit for the sharp gains in sales of phonograph records this year is being claimed in part by radio set manufacturers, who said last week that both the tone and volume control of records, provided for in many radio sets, has been responsible for renewed consumer interest.

MEXICO CITY-BOUND tourists, traveling over the Pan-American Highway out of Laredo, Texas, find it easy to pass through Huichihuayan without stopping, usually without even dropping below fifty miles an hour. The only advance indications are the corn-covered hills of the Huasteca Indians and a small sign, "Poblado Proximo"--"village near."

The fury of this week's German campaign against Czechoslovakia can have only two explanations: either Germany is again meditating invasion or wants Viscount Runciman to think so. As usual the Henleinist whispering propaganda is cooperating closely with Dr. Joseph Goebbels's propaganda machine.

Viscount Hailsham, British Lord Chancellor, visited the Royal Mint, on the east side of Tower Hill, at high noon the other day, and bore away a handsomely tooled leather wallet. This he conveyed to Buckingham Palace, where His Majesty King George VI took it with due ceremony from his hands and gave him another, a little the worse for wear.

WASHINGTON-As the first results of its drive to rehabilitate the American merchant marine, the United States Maritime Commission reports that in the last year it let more contracts for new vessels than were let during the entire life of the 1928 Shipping Act, superseded by the Maritime Act of last year.

IT seems to be ordained that the Autumn jacket suit shall be an ensemble-namely, dress and jacket; where there is a skirt the designer has, nine times out of ten, provided for a blouse. Instead of making a dull picture, the result is just the opposite. In the majority of cases, dress tops are either in a contrasting color or of a different fabric from the skirt.

Carola Goya has been engaged as soloist for the final concert of the Summer season by the National Symphony Orchestra in Washington on Wednesday evening. She will present seven dances, which will occupy half the program. Hans Kindler will conduct. Miss Goya is the first dancer to appear at these concerts.

Flooding of basements by the backing up of flood water in sewers can be prevented by the installation of a new type of drainage control valve which offers the double protection of an automatic check valve and a manually operated gate valve, states the Plumbing and Heating Industries Bureau.

THERE have been so many Hollywood stories, keyed from rank romance to bitter satire, that a new one should have a definite claim to originality. "The Root of the Lotus" has, though, rather a thin one. It presents the private life

ON BOARD THE QUEEN MARY, Aug. 13.--The Queen Mary again broke the record for a daily run on the eastward voyage, making 737 miles from noon yesterday to noon today. The average was 32.04 knots. The Cunard White Star Line announced last night that at noon yesterday the Queen Mary had covered 2,152 miles at an average of 31.65 knots.
The new six-story apartment house under erection at 155-65 West Twentieth Street, corner of Seventh Avenue, is nearing completion and is expected to be ready for occupancy Sept. 1.

More than $4,500,000 was received by government agencies as dividends on their investments in 1,343 savings and loan associations during the first half of 1938, the Federal Home Loan Bank board reported yesterday.

Japanese troops who landed above Kiukiang on Wednesday to reinforce the drive toward Hankow have been checked in their advance on Juichang, 100 miles southeast of Hankow, according to Chinese military reports. It is declared that the Japanese were checked in the hills a few miles northwest of Juichang.

IT has been raining in the Dust Bowl this year. Crops in the southern part of the Bowl are the best since 1932 and hope runs high this means the end of a dry cycle. There are green fields and hopeful faces. But beyond those fields and behind those faces the land and the people are deeply scarred. Fifty years of exploitation and seven years of drought have left their mark.
Fred B. Schrader, Bell Telephone Company official, who retired three years ago, died yesterday at his home here after a long illness at the age of 67.

Handicapped children have shown marked physical improvement as a result of their work in the WPA art project class at the Convalescent Home for Hebrew Children at Rockaway Park, Long Island, according to the observation of the medical staff.

More New Yorkers are becoming modern Magellans this Summer than ever before. In their exploring they are finding not only that the world of yachting is round, but they are discovering that metropolitan waterways are not bounded on the north, east, west and south by Long Island Sound. There are other cruise routes to try, just as fascinating, just as full of sightseeing thrills.

Notwithstanding the many fire-resisting devices provided in recent years, the National Fire Protection Association points out that fires cause a damage loss to homes in this country of practically $100,000,000 a year.

The nose-dive in prices of principal farm commodities during the past week promises to be a severe strain on the Administration's farm program as laid down in the Agricultural Adjustment Act of 1938. Secretary Wallace says the act contains the "correct and enduring approach" to the nation's farm program.

FIVE years ago two gentlemen with an idea and some ready cash with which to finance their industrial dream opened a unique type of motion picture theatre in Camden, N. J. It was a theatre which catered exclusively to the automotive public, who drove their cars into a huge lot on which stood a giant motion picture screen.
STANISLAVSKY is dead. This is somehow incomprehensible. His name has always been so closely connected with the theatre that it is impossible to separate the two. He was known as a

Miss Evaline Igleheart, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Austin S. Igleheart of Round Hill Road, will be introduced to society on the night of Sept. 9 at a large dinner to be given at the Indian Harbor Yacht Club here by her parents.

Two men were drowned yesterday morning about 2,000 feet south of Johnson's Dock, Meadow Mere, in Jamaica Bay. According to witnesses, one of them, an elderly man, stood up in their rowboat to drop a crab trap overboard. He fell into the water.

Weather report: Fair wind and fair weather for the Huguenot Yacht Club's annual regatta today. Huguenot, one of the oldest clubs on Long Island Sound, often draws flat calms for the one Yacht Racing Association championship event it runs each year, but today the jinx was laid out for the benefit of 121 starters in the sixteenth regatta in the title series.

A British officer motoring from Bethlehem to Jerusalem was shot dead by an Arab band this afternoon. While cycling from the Jewish colony of Ramatayim to the Jewish colony of Petah Tikva today, Benjamin Babayoff and his wife were fired at from an orange grove, and both were killed.

The companion ship of the Queen Mary, which will be named the Queen Elizabeth on her launching by the Queen on the afternoon of Sept. 27 at John Brown's Clydebank yard, will be ten feet longer than the Queen Mary.

If there's a role in a movie script that calls for some one to play a district attorney, a special prosecutor or a crusading lawyer all out of righteousness and justice, it's five to one the casting director will pick up his phone and put in a call for Walter Abel.

Although the extent of the mobilization for the manouevres in Germany has seemed here to be unjustified, in contrast with the German Government's frequent declarations regarding its pacific intentions and also with Germany's lack of capacity to pay for such luxuries, the view is taken that there is no use in protesting or even in getting alarmed.

" Skippy," a three-year-old waif who was found ill and undernourished in a chicken coop, was receiving unaccustomed attention today in a city hospital. In the floods of 1936 he became separated from his parents in Harpers Ferry and eventually was
A gondola belonging to the late Prince Alexis Mdivani, first husband of Countess Barbara Hutton Haugwitz-Reventlow, was auctioned today for 1,600 lire, the oar and bright red cushions included.

Republicans and Democrats, liberals and conservatives, are asserting in increasing numbers, it was brought out today, that there is danger to the present structure of the State government in Section 25 of the judiciary article of the proposed new State Constitution.
THAT marriage is not what it's cracked up to be is the gist of this entertaining anthology, wholly concerned with the institution of matrimony as an idea and as a fact. Indeed,

SOME measure of improvement was noted here and there in retail trade for the week but the pick-up was not very large, due to weather conditions, the season of the year and to a certain let-down in buying sentiment. Apparel business was off and housewares volume only fair despite intensified promotions.
More mothers than ever before are surviving childbirth in England and Wales, while deaths among children less than a year old are only slightly higher than the low record of 1935.

BETWEEN SLEEPING AND WAKING. By Dorothy Charques. 303 pp. New York: The Macmillan Company. $2.50. THE most striking feature of Dorothy Charques's 1937 novel. "The Tramp and His Woman," was its intensity of feeling. Its people,
ALTHOUGH August Derleth, the author of several published novels, has been writing poetry for a decade or more, these eighty-seven titles mark his first appearance in book form as a poet.

Time has in no way diminished the infinite uses of herbs but has brought to light more applications and modern uses for these practical and historical plaants. As long as man can remember herbs have provided in manifold ways food, medicine and esthetic enjoyment. Recently another utilizatiion has been discovered that should prove particularly interesting not only to professional: horticulturists but to every amateur back-yard gardener.

With circuses, large and small, folding under the combined ravages of bad business, bad weather and, in at least one case, labor trouble, "Laugh, Clown, Laugh!" played in dirge time truly has become the theme song of the big top this season. Only this time it is the owner,

A central bureau to which grocery manufacturers can submit proposed labeling, advertising and promotional plans for a check against possible infractions of the Federal Wheeler-Lee Act and the revised Pure Food and Drug Act, is contemplated by the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc., for the service of its members it was learned last week.

LATER THAN YOU THINK. By Gawen Brownrigg. 360 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $2.50. TO make automobile racing interesting to one who knows little and cares less about automobiles is a feat of magic depending on intense love and knowledge of motors.

THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity advancedto the year's "high" during the week ended Aug. 6. It now stands at 83.1, compared with 81.7 for the preceding week and 108.2 for the corresponding week a year ago.
The mail went through today on horseback just like it did seventy years ago when Southeastern Kentucky roads were full of rocks and mud was deep.

Miss Ruth Isabella May, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Milne May of Andover, was married here today in the First Congregational Church to Randall L. Holden, son of Mrs. George Parker Holden of Yonkers, N. Y. The Rev. Herman C. Johnson of the First Congregational Church performed the ceremony.

In some of their variations, stock dividends will probably continue to plague our courts until such distributions are declared either wholly free of the income tax or unconditionally taxable. For a long time the' Treasury Department ruled that stock dividends generally were nontaxable; but that ruling proved

President Roosevelt's month of travel, which took him on a campaign trip across the continent and a vacation of sea fishing and sun tan, brought no net change in his national popularity with American voters, according to the institute's latest momthly Presidential index.

Margaret Mitchell's title might have been aptly applied to a recent report of soil experts who have been studying the effects of wind erosion at Goodwell, Okla. They estimate that the winds in the dust bowl area of the Great Plains carry off, in a bad year, as much topsoil as the floods of the Mississippi River and all its tributaries manage to sweep away in a thousand years.

Miss Helen Hoffman Simpson, daughter of Mrs. Hazen Simpson of this village and the late Mr. Simpson, was married to Alfredo Lapolla of Jersey City, N. J., today at the home of her mother by the Rev. Francis J. Boyle, assistant pastor of the Church of the Assumption.

Demand by European hoarders today pushed the price of geld up to 143s 9d a fine ounce, the highest in three years, and in the short Saturday session a total of [Pound]1,385,000 was sold. It is estimated that since the middle of July, when the price stood at 141s 2d more than [Pound]30,000,000-of gold has changed hands.

Raymond Patriarca, 29, of Providence, awaiting trial for two robberies, was arrested at the Narragansett race track at Pawtucket, R. I., today, five hours after two armed and hooded bandits had held up a jewelry store in Boston and escaped with diamonds valued at $20,000.

About 34,600 dwelling units were constructed in urban areas of New York during the first half of 1938, according to estimates today by the Bureau of Labor Statistics. In the first half of 1937 the total was 24,708 units.

STRANGE buildings are rising on the Flushing. meadows where the New York World's. Fair is taking shape. New buildings, new in conception and form as well as new in materials. A cross between functional architecture and fair architecture, some have called the general pattern.
Mrs. Agnes Pearson Reynolds, wife of the Rev. Dr. Charles Lee Reynolds, secretary of the Church Extension Board of the Prpsbytery of Newark, died of a heart ailment late last night at her home here.

Mrs. Myra Houlroyd Reeves, whose husband, Paul Reeves, was slain by Miss Margaret Drennan in Iselin a year ago, was injured critically early this morning when she jumped out of the automobile of Joseph K. Sherwood, 30 years old, of 628 Northwood Avenue, Linden, as they were riding through Port Monmouth on their way to visit friends at Highlands.

Elimination of numerous timehonored slogans and themes and a marked toning down of claims in advertising copy, particularly in drug and cosmetic field, since enactment of the Wheeler-Lea law, were noted yesterday by executives in the field.

The trial of James J. Hines, Tammany leader of the Eleventh Assembly District will begin tomorrow in Supreme Court before Justice Ferdinand Pecora. It will be the first time in the history of the city that a man of such political prominence has faced the charge of to sharing in the operations and profits of a gang of professional criminals.

Among the musical features this week at Chautauqua, N. Y., are the Chautauqua Symphony Orchestra, today; the opera "La Tosca" tomorrow evening in the Norton Memorial Hall; the symphony orchestra, on Tuesday evening, with Donald Dickson, baritone, and Austin Conradi, pianist, as soloists; the

THE coincidence of the deaths of Pearl White and Warner Oland in Europe last week within forty-eight hours of each other brought not only a nostalgic sadness to the hearts of many veteran film fans, but also impressed countless others as a singular twist of fate.

The Weather Bureau advised ships in the path of a tropical disturbance in the Gulf of Mexico today to use caution and warned small craft from Pensacola, Fla., to Brownsville, Texas, not to venture far into the Gulf.

SIX of the eleven members of the art faculty of the New School for Social Research, for the year 1938-39, were represented in the exhibition of American art at the Jeu de Paume this Summer: Yasuo Kuniyoshi, Marguerite and William Zorach, Harry Sternberg, Berenice Abbott and Eliot Elisofon.

Seven hundred first and second class midshipmen from Annapolis tanned and robust after an 8,500,mile, two-month cruise to Europe, arrived in New York yesterday aboard the battleship Texas and the training ship Wyoming.

The National Labor Relations Board lost today another phase of its legal battle to compel the Fansteel Metallurgical Corporation of North Chicago to rehire ninety discharged employes who participated in a sitdown strike at the plant in February. 1937.

DANCING America, setting the pace for the tune-smiths of Tin Pin Alley, is anxious to trip the light fantastic to simpler music and less intricate dance steps, in the opinion of Meredith Willson, composer-arranger, who predicts the return to popularity of the Virginia Reel and other community dances within a year.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The statement of H. I. Katibah in THE TIMES of Aug. 7 makes clear why proposals for a round-table discussion between Zionists and Arabs in Palestine have never succeeded.
