The new building code, under which all residential building in New York is now being done, was characterized yesterday by Arthur E. Allen, Long Island architect, as the "greatest measure of public protection since the enactment of the Pure Food Laws."

Consumption of crude rubber by manufacturers in the United States in July amounted to 32,209 long tons, compared with 30,629 in June and 43,703 in July, last year, according to the Rubber Manufacturers Association.

A machine which records lightning bolts as inky scratches stood ready today to put the "history" of Western New York's next electrical storm on paper. Every lightning bolt within fifteen miles of this city is recorded on a device constructed by the Niagara Power Company.

THE thirtieth annual Stockbridge Art Exhibition is scheduled to open with a varnishing day on Friday, Sept. 9, and will continue through Sept. 25. The exhibition, essentially a Berkshire affair, is open to artists who have at any time lived or worked in the vicinity.

When some of Italian journalism's big guns such as Virginio Gayda went out of their way a few days ago to assure Japan of the Fascist Government's sympathy and moral support they did something that approaches complete superfluousness.
Mrs. William Hockenjos of Lake Hopatcong, N. J., today eliminated Mrs. W. D. Goss of the Baltusrol Country Club (N. J.), defending champion, from the annual women's invitation tournament here.

Word has been received here of the engagement of Miss Helen Safford Bonnell, daughter of Mrs. Henry Houston Bonnell of Chestnut Hill, Philadelphia, and the late Mr. Bonnell, to David Cook Scott Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Scott of Providence, R. I.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Aug. 11: COMMANDERS Boak, J. E., Philadelphia, Pa., to the Phoenix and on board when commissioned. Peterson, E., Med. Corps. the Oklahoma, to duty Naval Hospital, Brooklyn, N. Y,, about Sept. 1.

The movement headed by Father Divine, New York Negro evangelist, continues to grow; another "heaven" for his followers, on the Hudson opposite the estate of President Roosevelt, has just been purchased.

Red Bank's ninth annual national sweepstakes regatta scheduled Saturday and Sunday on the North Shrewsbury River, by its addition of two new inboard championships, has climbed to a new high ranking among speed boat events. Probably its entry will even surpass last week's Charles River fixture at Boston.

Members' games, including a roundrobin which brought twelve players into action, comprised today's polo at the Meadow Brook Club. Many of the high-goal stars who are to play in tomorrow's test matches joined in the informal play.

A fleet of 115 sailed in ten classes under perfect conditions as the Seaside Park Y. C. celebrated its fortieth anniversary today in conjunction with the running of the thirtyeighth annual Sewell Cup regatta of the Barnegat Bay Y. R. A.

Wheat futures fluctuated in an erratic manner today within a range of 1 cent a bushel, advancing slightly in the early trading on scattered buying and in sympathy with corn, but weakening in the latter part of the session.
Work is expected to begin early in the Fall on the construction of a county girls' vocational school here, toward which the Public Works Administration has approved a $120,330 grant.

Three hundred attended tonight the annual Western New England men's tennis tournament costume ball at Wyantenuck Country Club. Costume judges were Mrs. John B. Hull Jr., wife of the club president; Frederick A. Pearson and H. Gray Treadwell. Mrs. Robert Latimer Redfield Jr. of New York was general chairman of the dance.

The British-American Utilities Corporation of Buffalo was one of sixty-six public utility holding companies asked by the Securities and Exchange Commission to outline their "integration" plans. Stephen T. Lockwood, BritishAmerican president, laughed:
The final invitation regatta of the Babylon Yacht Club this season was marked by a fairly large fleet, clear skies and a brisk northwester today.
HOW TO WRITE AND SPEAK EFFECTIVE ENGLISH. By Edward Frank Allen. 329 pp. Cleveland and New York: World Syndicate Publishing Company. 89 cents.

Colonel M. E. Gilmore, regional director of the Public Works Administration, forecast yesterday that the Federal "pump-priming" program in New York City would create 75,000,000 man-hours of direct and indirect employment on forty-one schools, hospitals, health centers, courts and other approved projects.

ARNOLD DOLMETSCH celebrated his eightieth birthday last February on a day culminating in a concert of his own compositions and the presentation by the French Ambassador of the Cross of the Legion of Honor to the composer.

The German land plane Brandenburg had crossed the Atlantic and was on the last laps of its return flight to Berlin early this morning. The plane made a perfect take-off from Floyd Bennett Field at 9:02 yesterday morning.

When Japan moved last week to the verge of war with Russia the question most often heard was How can Japan possibly fight two wars at once? With her gold reserve depleted, her factories bare of raw materials and her prices rising as fast as her exports were falling, it seemed obvious that she was

L. Joseph Robertson, 20 years old, of Bala-Cynawyd, Pa., son of Lawson Robertson, college and former Olympic track coach, and Paul McVicker, 21, of Bala, Pa., Summer residents here, were fined $75 each by Police Court Justice George Brownmiller today on charges of common thievery, to which they pleaded guilty.

A downward trend in building volume during the first half of 1938' compared with the like period of 1937 is shown in a report issued recently by E. M. Craig, secretary of the National Association of Building Trades Employers, Chicago.

Miss Virginia N. Humphreys, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Horatio Norsworthy Humphreys of 275 Clinton Avenue, Brooklyn, was married yesterday morning to John J. Cooke son of Mrs. John Joseph Cooke of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Cooke, in the Queen of All Saints Roman Catholic Church, Brooklyn.
Robert Frost will lecture at the formal dedication of the new Robert Frost Poetry Library at the University of Wyoming in Laramie early in November.

The Royals provided a story-book finish against Jersey City tonight to give Alex Hooks a victory in his first game as manager of the club. Montreal scored a ten-inning 11-10 victory over the Little Giants for Hooks, who replaced Rabbit Maranville.

SMILING HILL FARM. By Miriam E. Mason. Illustrated by Kate Seredy. 311 pp. Boston: Ginn Co. $1.60. "SMILING HILL FARM" sets a new high level in the class of books that for years have been known as "supplementary readers,' and dismissed at that.

Chinese guerrillas captured, the Japanese-occupied Hungjao Airdrome, five miles from Shanghai, in a midnight raid last night and held it until nearly dawn. At the airdrome they hoisted the Kuomintang (Chinese Nationalist) flag over the spot where the incident that started the Chinese-Japanese fighting in the Shanghai area occurred on Aug. 9 last year.

Mrs. Margaret Fagan, 35 years old, whose address was given as West Washington Boulevard, Chicago, was taken to Bellevue Hospital early yesterday morning suffering from an overdose of either poison or alcohol, the police said.

An auction of sculpture, ceramics and wood carvings was a feature today of a Westchester outdoor sculpture show, which opened on July 14 under the sponsorship of the New Hudson River Group on the River Road property of Mrs. Frank A. Vanderlip, honorary president of the group.

Miss Elizabeth Anne Blauvelt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Elvin Blauvelt of Paterson, was married this afternoon at the Summer home of her parents at Franklin Lakes, N. J., to Andrew William Patten, son of Mrs. Andrew W. Patten of Carbondale, Pa. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Howard A. Adair, pastor of the Eastside Presbyterian Church of this city.

A 15 per cent wage reduction for employes of the Chicago, North Shore Milwaukee Railroad was ordered today in Federal court here to become effective at midnight tomorrow. The order affects about 1,300 workers and brings the possibility of a strike. The employes, members of

Stressing the need of transportation legislation by the next Congress, George H. Davis, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, announced today that the chamber was calling a conference on transportation to be held on Sept. 14 and 15.

Maple Lane Farm, the Home here of Mr. and Mrs. William Cullin Morris Butler, was the setting this afternoon for the marriage of their daughter, Miss Julie Hamilton Butler, to Arthur Brown Deisroth of Hazleton, son of Mrs. Arthur Deisroth and the late Mr. Deisroth.

Racing on the final day of the midsummer Corinthian Yacht Club regatta today was continuous from 9 o'clock in the forenoon until after 6 o'clock in the evening, and included sail-offs of more than a score of classes.

Students of New Jersey College for Women will work for distinction in five fields during the coming year, according to an announcement made today by the office of the registrar. Undergraduates who specialize in the fields of Sociology, French, English, Economics and History have been approved by the

The gift and allied markets which closed today at the Merchandise Mart showed an increase of 15 per cent over the 1937 attendance figures, with a registration of 2,734, and showed a 7 per cent increase in dollar volume.

Evidences' of increasing activity both in rentals and sales are being felt in many sections of Westchester County. One of the interesting announcements of the past week was that six of the proposed fourteen garden-type apartment houses in the Fort Hill Village community have been opened for inspection and rentals are being made for September occupancy.
Transfers and Assignments To take effect S A. M., Aug. 16. PATROLMEN--From Borough Headquarters Squad, Brooklyn-Richmond, to 15th Division, assignment to duty in plain clothes continued:

BARROFF-SILBERSTEIN-Mr. and Mrs. Sol D. Silberstein of New York City and West End, N. J., announce the engagement of their daughter, Babette, to Edward Barkoff, son of Mrs. Rebecca Barkoff of Montreal.

The certificate holders of 358 certificated mortgage issues of the Lawyers Mortgage Company will benefit to the extent of approximately one-half million dollars as a result of a recent decision rendered by Justice Alfred Frankenthaler of the Supreme Court of the State of New York, New York County, it was announced yesterday.

Judge Thomas J. S. Waxter, Baltimore relief director, stated today that Mrs. Hattie Read, a Negro, had repaid in full $148.80 she received on relief in 1933-34, explaining that she had to pay her debts to enter Father Divine's Krum Elbow "heaven."

Vladimir Matchek is due to arrive here tomorrow, the tenth anniversary of his assumption of the leadership of the Croat peoples, following the death of Stefan Raditch. He will have negotiations with leaders of the Serbian opposition, which is preparing a triumphant reception for him.

FROM Fort Bennington, Ga., where West Point cadets have been studying the practical side of military technique, an announcement that the army is experimenting with a type of stereoscopic photography for aerial map making has been issued.

In its recent survey of realty con editions throughout the country by the National Association of Real Estate Boards, the interesting fact was revealed that practically 37 per cent of the cities in the United States have comprehensive plans under way for revising their existing city plan.

The battle between shore sports fishermen and commercial concerns engaged in netting mossbunkers, over alleged illegal scooping of fish near shore beaches, reached a high point here this week when members of the Ocean Grove Fishing Club undertook to gather pictorial evidence to support charges of irregular operations against the commercial fishermen.

Chief Justice F. R. Latchford of the appellate division of the Ontario Supreme Court died today. He had been in ill health for several weeks and seriously ill three or four days. His age was 84. The chief justice was a lawyer and politician before his appointment to the bench in 1908.

Norna VI, the six-meter racing yacht, which is owned by Crown Prince Olaf of Norway, and which will be sailed in the Scandinavian Gold Cup races off Oyster Bay on Aug. 27, arrived from Oslo yesterday aboard the Norwegian American liner Oslofjord. The skipper,

WHETHER or not you regard it as good news, swing is thriving. Though prophecies of doom have been many and its obsequies celebrated on countless occasions in the past four or five years, swing is very much alive and kicking, to the embarrassment (but not discouragement) of the prophets and grave-diggers. Indeed, the world of jam, jive, jitter and related
Serge Koussevitzky and the Boston Symphony Orchestra bracketed the sixth symphonies of Beethoven and Tchaikovsky for the fifth program of the Berkshire Symphony Festival at Tanglewood here tonight.

In. view of the forthcoming German army manoeuvres great importance is ascribed to the fact that the Czechoslovak minister to Berlin, Dr. Vojtech Mastny, has arrived here and has had long conferences with Premier Milan Hodza and Foreign Minister Kamil Krofta, after which he called on President Eduard Benes with the Foreign Minister.

VISITORS to Radiolympia, the annual radio exhibition held in London, will be invited to face the BBC television cameras, so that their friends may see them on demonstration receivers in different parts of the building at Olympia. The exhibition, the seventeenth to be organized by the Radio Manufacturers Association, will be held from Aug. 24 to Sept. 3.

THERE'S an art in not listening, according to a headline in The Radio Times, journal of the British Broadcasting Corporation, in which a correspondent, C. B. Rees, emphasizes the value of listening to the radio with intelligence.

The Committee for Industrial Organization is a dictatorial group acting without the consent of the membership of some of its organizations, John M. Bruce, general organizer of the United Association of Plumbers and Steam Fitters, asserted in an address today.

President Roosevelt's quest for a Congress that will do his bidding-an objective amply demonstrated on his political "march through Georgia" has raised anew the question as to exactly what he wants in the way of further New Deal legislation. Repeatedly in recent months
The Dutch elm disease, which has of late attracted so much attention in the press, well emphasizes the necessity of thinking of the future when trees for landscape planting are selected.

IN an effort to facilitate traffic on heavily traveled routes in the metropolitan area, engi neers are opening new links and suggesting alternate roadways convenient for pleasure-bound motorists. New bridges have been built, old structures widened and many miles of new highways opened in Westchester, New Jersey and Long Island.

MUCH is to be learned from mediocrity. We make this declaration boldly in the face of a peculiarly unbrilliant week in the cinema, when the temptation to diverge from the realistic consideration of things as they are into the purely escapist realm of generalities and polite abstractions is well-nigh irresistible.

The fourteenth annual home show of the Elizabeth, N. J., Chamber of Commerce will be launched next Saturday with the opening for daily inspection of two dwellings; one a $12,000 home at 40 Trotter Lane and the other a $5,250 house at 655 Cartaret Street.
The police today held three German civilians who made a forced landing in their bi-motored private plane in a field in the heart of the Maginot Line area.

One hundred and fifty WPA workers employed in the central kitchen of the child nutrition project in Long Island City have had their wages cut from $16.50 a week to $13.95, it was learned yesterday at the offices of Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress Administrator.

When 900 bombers and pursuit planes engaged in a mock trial of strength on the east coast of England a few days ago as a test of the defensive powers of Britain's growing air force, far more was at stake than in the usual military manoeuvres.

Ten recent college graduates, three from the Eastern seaboard, have been declared winners in a national competition for Alfred P. Sloan Foundation Fellowships in taxation and public expenditure at the University of Denver.

Some startlingly revolutionary styles for the "woman of tomorrow" may be on view at the World's Fair, for Vogue Magazine, inspired by the Fair's "World of Tomorrow" theme, announced yesterday that it had commissioned eight industrial designers-men who have streamlined everything from locomotives to dishwashing machines-to evolve the fashions for a few centuries hence.

Mineral production of Canadian mines continued to show increases in July, and in many new monthly records were established. Perron Gold Mines produced bullion valued at $119,703, the highest recovery since the mine began operations in 1934.

Two twenty-one gun salutes, one fired by a Canadian battery at near-by Hill Island and the other by a United States battery at Madison Barracks on adjoining Wells Island, will signal the start of the two-hour ceremony here Thursday when President Roosevelt and Prime Minister William MacKenzie King will open the new international bridge in this Thousand Islands area.

ONE of the most interesting of operatic stagings is that of the recently completed Richard Wagner Festival in the Zoppot Forest in the Danzig Free State. The festival presented the entire "Ring" and "Lohengrin" in the natural setting of the woods.

A famous and highly popular race for power cruisers will be resumed next month on the Hudson River by the Colonial Yacht Club. This is the Bear Mountain event for the huge Jules Heilner perpetual trophy. Despite the upset condition of Colonial Y. C. affairs as a result of its ousting from its home at
For the secondd successive day the Indians and White Sox broke even in a double-header, the Tribe taking the opener, 13 to 4, but losing the second, 2 to 1, today.
The Question of Teachers To the Music Editor: I read with interest the article in THE TIMES'S Magazine Section of July 31 entitled "Outdoors, Indoors, Music Conquers America."

The offices of the New York unions mentioned by John P. Frey, vice president of the American Federation of Labor, in -his testimony yesterday before the Dies committee in Washington were closed yesterday and the' men named by him as Communists or their sympathizers could not be reached for comment.

IF you can't think of anything else to do with a roomful of people some evening you might inflict a bit of mental torture upon them. Distribute pencil and paper and demand that each defenseless guest write down the name of his or her Congressman.

Exhibitors and guests attending the ninth annual Lake Placid horse show were honored tonight at a dinner dance at the Hotel Marcy and on conclusion of the show tomorrow afternoon will be guests of the Lake Placid Horse Show Association, Inc., at a "floating cocktail party" aboard a steamer on a cruise

Close of play scores in firstclass cricket matches started today follow: Middlesex 267 (Edrich 71, Wellard seven for 140); Somerset 53 for four, at Lord's. Derbyshire 233 (Townsend 76, Voce five for 42); Nottinghamshire 52 for three, at Nottingham. Warwickshire 201 (Wyatt 81 not out, Wilkinson five for 58); Lancashire 25 for none,- at Birmingham.

WASHINGTON.-With a capacity of 10,000,000 volumes, wice that of the present building, the Library of,Congress will open next October its new $9,000,000 annex. Transfer of some of the collections from the crowded main building has already begun.

James Lawrence Fly, general counsel and secretary of the Tennessee Valley Authority, told the Congressional Investigating Committee today that it was he who suggested the conciliation agreement in the Berly marble claims in 1936, although he said that Senator George L. Berry himself first proposed that a third party be brought into the case.

DESPITE recent negotiations by the British for the purchase of American airplanes, England exported no less than 608 aircraft to its dominions and to at least twenty other countries during the last year of record, it was revealed yesterday by figures made public by the British Board of Trade.

The Medical Society of the District of Columbia told the Department of Justice today that it did not consider itself amenable to the anti-trust laws, a violation of which had been charged against members of the society by the department earlier this month in connection with the society's opposition to a hospitalization group.

The Holland-American Line announced yesterday that Queen Wilhelmina of The Netherlands had conferred upon Commodore Johannes Jacobus Bijl, commander of the flagship Nieuw Amsterdam, a knighthood of the Order of Orange Nassau .
Robert L. Riggs Jr. will defend his eastern Grass court tennis championship tomorrow against Joe Hunt in an all-California final at the Westchester Country Club.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Petition Flied-By SAMUEL LORBER, president of Samuel Lorber Co., Inc., 2,107 Broadway-Liabilities $164,152, assets $5.25, exclusive of securities pledged with the Empire Trust Co, as collateral on a claim of $40,736.

FRED STONE will celebrate his six ty-fifth birthday next Friday. He has been a trouper for fifty-eight years, and the other day at his home in Forest Hills he recalled highlights of his theatrical career and noted some of the changes which have occurred during his lifetime, not only in the amusement world but in the country.
Supply contracts valued at $16,258,052 were awarded during the week ended Aug. 11 by fifteen Federal agencies under the provisions of the Public Contracts Act, the Labor Department announced today.
John Law rence Spellman, public relations manager of the Illinois Bell Telephone Company, died tonight in his home here after an illness of two months. He would have been 54 years old on Aug. 30.

Golden booty from the bottom of the sea, recovered from the 139-year-old wreck of the British frigate Lutine, spurred the hopes of brokers at Lloyd's today that the salvaging of the long-lost hoard may be imminent.

Retail sales in most districts continued to fall behind a year ago last week, but in a few sections volume was even with that of last year and in others the decline narrowed. Hot weather helped clear Summer stocks, but hampered promotions of fur coats and Fall merchandise.

Dr. James R. Angell, retired president of Yale University, will give an address on "The College of Tomorrow" on the ne campus of Colby College next Saturday. He will be the principal speaker at exercises marking the starting of building operations for the new plant.

The tenth annual women's New Jersey Shore fifty-four hole medalplay golf tournament, which was postponed July 25 because of heavy rains that left many golf courses in the metropolitan district unplayable, will be held tomorrow, Tuesday and Wednesday over the Deal, Rumson and Hollywood layouts in that order.

Today a year has passed since the stock market reached its high point for the Summer of 1937 and began its precipitate decline. Since then the country has seen stock prices fall by more than a half, industrial production decline by over a third and unemployment increase by 80 per cent.
James McCutcheon Co., New York specialty-shop, has entered into a stipulation with the Federal Trade Commission "to cease misrepresenting wearing apparel," it was announced today by the commission.

MUCH of the romantic nonsense that has been written about the exploits of the conquistadores in Mexico has tried to perpetuate the legend of their heroic and glamorous character. Occasionally there is a dissenting voice which recalls the inhuman cruelties and barbarous practices of the invaders.

THE SECOND ADMIRAL. A Life of David Dixon Porter. By Richard S. West Jr. 376 pp. Coward-McCann, Inc. $5. IRASCIBLE, bluff, frank and vigorous David Dixon Porter was the second of three officers of our navy-Farragut, Porter and Dewey-who have been granted the title of "Admiral of the Navy."

An article, complete with plans and description of the army's new M-1 Garand semi-automatic rifle which is replacing the old Springfield and which has been regarded by many army officers as quite secret, appears in the August number of The American Rifleman.

Buffalo and Newark traded heavy punches in their double-header tonight and won a knockout victory apiece. The Bisons, scoring five runs in the first inning, took the opener, 9-2, and the Bears duplicated that lead-off feat to take the full-length floodlight game, 10-2. Johnny Marcum, making his

IN Summer driving, when discomfort from the burning sun prompts a motorist sympatheti cally to remember the warmth of his tires, the advice of rubber company engineers is only "proper inflation." It is a bugaboo, they say, to worry about increased pressure. Extremes of Summer heat push up the pressure gauge reading four to five pounds-still well within safety limits.

THE Italians are building an electrical air ferry to the top of Theodul Pass on the Swiss frontier. It is to be a big ferry, capable of carrying thousands of persons from the valley to the top of the pass in a few hours. The Italians say it is to develop Alpine siding and Italian resorts. But four miles away in
Fifteen more wounded veterans of the Washington-Lincoln Brigade arrived yesterday in the steamship President Roosevelt of the United States Lines from Havre, France, returning from the Spanish front.

In commemoration of its fiftieth anniversary the West Side Federal Savings and Loan Association will issue on Wednesday a booklet outlining its history since its inception in 1888. Dr. Herman L. Reis, president of the association, is the author.

Objections to three primary designating petitions were filed yesterday with the Board of Elections. One of these objections was to the petition of Meyer Goldberg as candidate of the American Labor party for Assemblyman in the Sixth Manhattan District.

Paul Shields's Jackrabbit of the Shelter Island Yacht Club, and Gorham Godwin's Hi Hat of Devon divided honors, the first two in the series of three races for the Mrs. Cortlandt Godwin Trophy in the annual Devon Yacht Club regatta, Gardiners Bay, today. The final contest will be held tomorrow morning. Rough water last night prevented the Westhampton Yacht Club craft from competing. The summaries:

Goodhue House, the fifteen-story apartment building under erection at the southeast corner of Madison Avenue and Thirty-fifth Street, opposite Altman's, is near completion and is expected to be ready for occupancy next month.
In the sweltering dog days of late Summer one is not likely to give much thought to flowers for Winter window gardens. But with September just around the corner, and cooler nights-believe it or not!-

The marriage of Miss Dorothy Polk Whiting, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Percy Hollister Whiting of this place, to Thielo Gray Howland, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathaniel J. Howland of Bayside, L. I., took place this morning in St. James Church here. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Orrin Francis Judd, pastor of the church.

Miss Lesley Hyde Ripley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry B. H. Ripley and Miss Hope Bacon Saunders, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Truman Laurance Saunders, two young women who have been popular members of the younger group in this city for several Summers were introduced to society here tonight.

The antiComintern pact which unites Germany, Japan and Italy in a common front against the spread of bolshevism was subjected to an acid test this week. That test, it would seem, put a different aspect on the tripartite accord from what Japan evidently envisaged at its conclusion in November, 1936, and when Italy became a party to it a year later.

John Franklin Hitchcock, president of Irvington Motors, Inc., died last night at the White Plains, N. Y., Hospital following a nervous breakdown. He was 35 years old. His residence here was known as Haddon Park.
Mrs. Emeline Harriman Olin, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Oliver Harriman, died here this morning at Bayview, her Summer home. She had been ill only a brief time.

The East Elmhurst American Legion Post 96 has purchased its new Memorial Hall on a plot 60 by 100 feet at 106-108 Astoria Boulevard, East Elmhurst, L. I., from the Home Owners Loan Corporation, reports Frank O'Hara, Inc., broker, who closed the deal.
A home, according to the Federal Housing Administration should be viewed as a long-term investment. Like any other owned investment, a good home, it is pointed out, pays dividends.
Production of shoes in July reached 30,000,000 pairs, compared with 26,677,000 pairs in June and 34,842,000 pairs in July, 1938, according to estimates in the trade yesterday.

MAPLEWOOD is a township in the northern corner of New Jersey, just south of the Oranges and a half hour's train ride out of the Hoboken terminus from which ferryboats ply the Hudson to New York City. It has a population of 23,000
LOS ANGELES, Calif., Aug. 13.--David Edstrom, Swedish-American sculptor, died last night in the California Hospital following a heart attack which occurred three days ago. His age was 65.
The expenditure of $7,500 a century ago will be commemorated with the pageantry of the frontier this month at St. Joseph and Platte City, Mo.

LOS ANGELES-Californians to the number of 789,104 have found the Townsend Old Age Revolving Pension Plan far too remote for their present mood. They have signed and just filed with ?thorities the largest initiative petition in the history of the State, calling for a vote upon the latest of seventeen old-age pension plans which have

Joseph E. Davites, United States Ambassador to Belgium, is stopping at Claridge's after a visit to Wales, where he spoke at the Cardiff Eistedfodd. Mrs. Bryon Clark has returned to London after seven months' absence in the United States.

(All time is P. M., Eastern daylight saving, unless otherwise indicated; dial locations are in megacycles.) Today 6:00-Concert to the United States, TGWA, 15.17-Guatemala. (Also Monday and Friday, same time.) 8:00--Hungarian folklore melodies, HAT4, 9.12-Budapest.

The press of the nation is "big business" owned by men who, in his opinion, "would not scruple to throw this country into fascism rather than surrender their privileges," United States Senator Sherman Minton, Indiana Democrat, said yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the American Press Society in the Hotel Astor. The speech was broadcast nationally.

Sylvia Sidney, American motion - picture actress, was married to Luther Adler, New York actor, at Caxton Hall in London early this morning. The bride, who is 28 years old, and the bridegroom, 35, entered the hall through the workmen's entrance.

PARIS.-France has changed the law blamed for cutting down the size of the nation's farm families. One of the last decrees issued under the special powers that expired last month was one by Paul Reynaud, Minister of Justice-a measure expected to do much to combat the declining birth rate among the French peasantry.

New principles of design, modern construction techniques and new materials have aided substantially in reducing the cost of erecting factories in this country, according to Albert Kahn, industrial architect, who estimates that today a plant can be erected for far less money than was required in 1929.

Miss Elizabeth Adams, director of the Department of Adult Education of the Central Branch Y. W. C. A. in Brooklyn, died on Friday at the Brooklyn Hospital after an illness of several months. She was 32 years old and lived at 59 Pineapple Street, Brooklyn.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I. - A strenuous social program will fill the remaining weeks of the Summer. House parties in particular are expected to be numerous for the coming week-end, with entertainment at various estates for out-of-town guests who will arrive here for the marriage on Friday of Miss Beatrice Patterson to Rodman Wanamaker 2d. Not only are several important musical events on the calendar, but an unusual sports program as well.

Two long-term prisoners, both trusties, escaped today from the county prison farm at Holmesburg. The fugitives are James Franklin van Sant, 30, and John Murray, 26. Van Sant had served seven years of a fifteen-to-thirty-year sentence for robbery.
An escaping hold-up man jumped on Fred Wong's automobile and ordered him to get going. But the traffic light above stayed red and Wong stayed put, although the man hit him with his gun.
An opponent for Germany in the interzone final of Davis Cup play will be decided tomorrow, when Australia and Japan end their North American zone series.

America's in well-balanced array of track and field athletes established a clear lead today over Germany's best, most of them members of the 1936 Olympic team, in the first half of the two-day competition In the Olympic Stadium.

Louis F. PHONE O'Neill, Albany attorney, died today at the age of 64. He was a law partner of Assemblyman George W. Foy and for more than forty years had been associated with the late Supreme Court Justice Alden Chester.

The foreign exchange market here was fairly active yesterday, but price changes were negligible for the most part. Foreign currencies continued to be quoted at the low levels of the week. The pound sterling closed at $4.87 1/4, unchanged from the preceding day, and the French franc eased 1-16 point to 2.72 7-16 cents.

Copper is being extensively used in the plumbing installation in the Scarsdale Manor apartments nearing completion on Garth Road, just south of the Scarsdale station, Westchester County. Reuben Henri Bowden, architect, states that specifications call for all mains, risers and branches in the structure to be made of that metal.
There is a clear field next week for "She Too Was Young," by Hilda Vaughan (wife of Charles Morgan, drama critic of the London Times) and Laurier Lister, opening at Wyndham's on Tuesday.

FAILURE, until recently, to recognize the need for illumination of the highway in a modern manner--"especially where existing lighting facilities have become obsolete after thirty years of service"is listed as one cause for night accidents in the thirteenth annual report of the State Bureau of Motor Vehicles, just out.

Officials of fifty locals of the United automobile Workers of America rejected tonight a proposal to ask John L. Lewis and other executives of the Committee for Industrial Organization to intervene in the union's factional dispute.

REPORTS of improvement in automobile sales in July were confirmed this week with the announcement by General Motors that its retail deliveries for the month were 178,000 units, as compared with 176,000 in June.

That the Tennessee Valley Authority will extend the "deadline" for deposits with it of bonds of the Tennessee Public Service Company was indicated yesterday when it became known that to date only 63 per cent of the outstanding 5 per cent first-mortgage bonds of the

Two hundred and seventy-two officers and civilian employes of the Third Naval District were getting settled last week-in their new quarters on the fourteenth and fifteenth floors of the new Federal Office Building, 90 Church Street.

British automobile manufacturers are alarmed at the increasing competition of German cars in the export markets. Their latest reports from India, Burma, Ceylon, Australia and South Africa show that German automobile exports to those countries so far this year greatly exceeded those for the same period of 1937.

The York Giants went on what was for them a hitting rampage at Shibe Park today as they beat the lowly Phillies in the first game of a doubleheader, 11 to 1, before 10,000 fans, but unfortunately they concentrated too much power in that contest, and as a consequence dropped the second, 4 to 2.

The Guidance Laboratory of Teachers College, Columbia University, which treats all human ailments outside the realm of medicine, extended its services last year to 27,488 persons, a 50 per cent increase over 1936-37, it was announced yesterday in the annual report of its director, Dr. Esther Lloyd-Jones.

Japanese and Soviet commanders of the opposing troops on the border of Manchukuo and Siberia met yesterday and signed an agreement for the ending of hostilities in accordance with the arrangement made by Ambassador Mamoru Shigemitsu of Japan and Foreign Commissar Maxim Litvinoff of Russia in Moscow.

Donald M. Lay Jr., Bellerose, seeded first, and Spencer Peets, Great Neck, ranked fourth, gained the final of the singles division of the Long Island League championships at the Bayside Tennis Club yesterday.

LONDON . FRANK HARRIS'S life of Oscar Wilde, published in America twenty years ago, was not then issued in an English edition, as there was no doubt that libel actions would have been brought against it and would have been successful.

Mr. and Mrs. William K. Krepps gave a tea a' their home here today at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Krepps, to Louis Ottmann Wheeler, son of Mr. and Mrs. I. M. Wheeler of Rye and New York.

This department is designed to assist in the location of complete versions of poems and their sources, the names of authors, etc., which cannot be found through the usual channels of anthologies and books of reference. THE TIMES receives a great many more queries than it can publish. It endeavors, therefore,

Alvin H. Turton, 40 years old, of 12-02 116th Street, College Point, Queens, was held in bail of $1,000 yesterday by Magistrate Leonard McGee, in Felony Court, for a hearing tomorrow in Homicide Court on a charge of homicide growing out of the death of a woman who was drowned when the car in which they were riding plunged into the East River at Twenty-third Street. Turton was driving the car,
The C. I. T. Safety,Foundation reported yesterday that in the first six months of 1938 traffic deaths fell 29.3 per cent in forty cities of 100,000 to 500,000 population.

Bonds drifted irregularly lower yesterday in the slowest trading on the New York Stock. Exchange in almost two months. The two-hour turnover in bonds was $2,223,500, compared with $3,054,000 on the preceding Saturday.

TO have one novel accepted for publication in two countries by three different publishers is something of a record. The holder of that record is Gawen Brownrigg, whose novel, "Later Than You Think," has just been published here by Alfred A. Knopf. More than a year ago this novel was accepted for publication by an English publisher, and a first edition was

A new symbol of the long peace and friendship between the-United States and Canada will be dedicated on Thursday, when the Thousand Islands International Bridge, an eight-and-one-half-mile crossing over the St. Lawrence River and part of the Thousand Islan is, comprising five large spans and connecting highways, is officially opened.

LONDON, Aug. 13.--The village of Wold Newton counted up a small fortune brought by a two-foot snowfall. Visitors flocked to the hamlet, near Bridlington in Yorkshire, in buses that solicited business with such provocative signs as:...

Where W. Lee O'Daniel is going to raise a revenue of about $40,000,000 to pay every person in the State of Texas over the age of 65 years the State's-share of a full $30 pension has most thinking people of Texas wondering a little, and then poring over last month's newspapers and campaign literature to see just what the Governor-designate had to say about it at that time.

The fortified city of Cabeza del Buey, twenty-two miles west of Almaden's rich mercury mines in Southwestern Spain, fell to the Insurgents today. A reinforced government army, however, kept the door to Almaden closed with new defenses in the mountains. Heavy fighting still raged in the vicinity.

NEW impetus was given to an already reviving sport last week when the Park Department submitted to Mayor La Guardia its plans for building fifty-eight miles of winding bicycle paths within, and in some instances connecting, the parks in the city's five boroughs.

The Dramatists Guild's dispute with Gilbert Miller has had no effect on the producer's plan to present J. B. Priestley's "I Have Been Here Before" in New York some time in September after a brief run in the provinces here.

Development of a tire for passenger automobiles using a rayon cord base instead of cotton will provide a vast market for rayon and eat deeply into the use of cotton in that field, according to traders in both rayon and cotton fabrics who studied the plans announced last week by Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company for introduction of such a tire.

Dr. Houston Peterson of Rutgers University has been appointed Professor of Social Philosophy in Cooper Union, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Edwin S. Burdell, director of Cooper Union. Dr. Peterson will have charge of the free public lecture forum which is a feature of the Union's activities during the academic year.

Dr. and Mrs. George Gray Ward of 956 Fifth Avenue are sailing Tuesday on the Nieuw Amsterdam for their annual trip abroad. They will visit in England, Scotland and France before returning here late next month. Mrs. Rudolph C. Culver of 142 East Seventy-first Street, with her daughter, Miss Elizabeth Culver, and son, Charles F. Culver, is at the Manoir Richelieu, Murray Bay, P. Q.

THE man who gets the news picture has chosen a "career of danger and daring," as every one must realize. Solely as a record of exciting adventures, hair-raising feats, the story of the news camera man would be good reading. It is a story,

With the new City Charter adding fresh duties to its already heavy responsibilities, the New York City Plan Commission continues its task of sifting a myriad of proposals for permanent improvements that represent an annual capital expenditure of almost $150,000,000.

The full force of President Roosevelt's efforts to "purge" the Democratic party of opponents of the New Deal will be turned upon Representative John J. O'Connor of New York and Senator Millard E. Tydings of Maryland.

In the presence of a large throng of dog lovers assembled under widespreading shade trees on Mrs. G. J. Guthrie Nicholson's picturesque Glen Farm estate, the rare spectacle of a Bedlington terrier taking a best-in-show award was enacted today to climax the thirty-fourth annual Rhode Island Kennel Club allbreed exhibition.

Two members of the United States Army Air Corps, Lt. Col. William C. Ocker and Second Lieutenant George R. Smith of Brooks Field, Texas, have invented a radically new type of airplane propeller which makes less noise, vibrates less and in which less strain is set up in the blades, according to a patent (No. 2,125,948) just granted to the two aviators.

Miss Evelyn Waring Remington, daughter of Mrs. J. Percy Remington of this city, was married this afternoon to Dr. Herbert Stocktill Gaskill, son of Mrs. Herbert W. Gaskill of Bowling Green, Media. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Robert G. Metters, assisted

New low records for July were established by this city in the general death rate, infant mortality, tuberculosis, pneumonia and appendicitis death rates, it was reported yesterday by Thomas J. Duffield, Registrar of Records of the Health Department, to Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner.
BRIDGE players competing in a national tournament usually take their bidding and play so seriously that their nerves become frayed and their tempers short. Many contests,

A little incredulous over its good fortune, Britain has lived through nearly half of the fateful month of August and still there is no world war. Thus far holiday spirits have been in the ascendant over the mesmerizing influence of that August of twenty-four years ago which set all Europe aflame; at English seaside

" Unless a sound policy of economy and diversion is followed to settle relief problems a vigorous public protest is inevitable," Donald R. Stevens, president of the New Jersey Taxpayers Association and member of the State Unemployment Relief Commission, said in statement today warning that new taxes or bond issues must be avoided.

Loans aggregating more than $2,000,000 have been made this year by insurance companies and savings banks for financing the construction of ten six-story apartment houses in the Queens Boulevard section of Forest Hills, L. I., reports the Cord Meyer Development Company, which sold to various builders nine of the apartment house sites.

LONDON. LORD RUNCIMAN'S mission to Czechoslovakia makes him look a little like a contemporary Atlas who bears on his broad shoulders the whole weight of Europe. On his efforts to bridge the gap between the Czechoslovak Government and- its Sudeten Germans, the fate of Europe seems at the moment to rest.
ARCTIC MISSION: A plane hummed across the wild, almost unknown land of northern Canada last week. At the controls was a Roman Catholic priest, Father Paul Schulte, the "flying padre." He had taken

ARK Commissioner Robert Moses, whose assaults on the status quo seldom fail to grip the public imagination, revived an old and burning question last week by proposing to add more than a third of a mile to the 13,000,foot strip of sand known around the globe as Coney Island Beach.
The Was Department released the following orders today, dated Aug. 12: MAJOR GENERAL Elmbriek, S. D., General Staff Corps, nine days' leave, Aug. 12.

The Federal Housing Administration points out that home builders who hope to finance the construction of a home by borrowing 90 per cent of the appraised property value from a private lending agency, while making the minimum down payment of 10 per cent under the FHA program, must submit plans for the dwelling to the FHA prior to construction.

Apparently the Japanese-sponsored Nanking Reformed Government as well as the Japanese-sponsored Greater Shanghai Municipal regime are being used to cloak and excuse aggressive actions in this area. This was manifested this afternoon when official Japanese Army and embassy spokesmen denied all knowledge or responsibility for flights over Shanghai's

WHAT is described as "the most extensive utilization of radio as a classroom aid yet undertaken by any American school system" will get under way this Fall when New York City's Board of Education and WNYC, the municipal station, will cooperate in a program designed to realize the full potentialities of school-room broadcasting.
The first day of an uneasy weekend passed today with a watchful British Government still trying to fathom the meaning of the extraordinary military activity now going on beyond the Rhine.

The following dispatch is from the leader of the 1938 New Guinea expedition. Mr. Archbold. research associate of the Department of Mammals, American Museum of Natural History, and the members of his expedition expect to spend about two years in a study of mammals, birds and plants in. New Guinea.

Herman Mulock Jr. of Newark, whose parole from State prison last Summer created a State-wide sensation, including charges that political influence had been brought to bear to obtain the young man's release, was arrested here tonight as a parole violator.

Showing superior team play and keeping their opponents disorganized, the Monmouth County Country Club poloists of Eatontown today routed the Blind Brook riders of Port Chester, N. Y., 11 to 5, to win for the second successive year the Rumson Country Club's twelvegoal tournament.

A British handwriting expert comments disparagingly on modern scrawls as contrasted with the beauty and legiability of some of the specimens exhibited recently at a London museum. Penmen as far back as the sixteenth century could be as legible as daylight when they chose.

Without being extended, T. Suffern Tailer of Meadow Brook won from' Ellis Knowles of Apawamis, 5 and 3, in the final of the annual three-day invitation tournament of the National Golf Club today, to repeat his victory of last year.
Labor Department officials estimated today that as many as 4,000,000 workers-about 1,750,000 more than Congress counted on-might obtain shorter working hours ultimately under the new Wage-Hour Law.

One of the largest dwellings to be erected on the Old Short Hills Estates, N. J., forming part of the large Short Hills property owned by Joseph P. Day is under construction for C. A. Kirkland of East Orange, who is associated with the American Insurance Company of

Americans returning from abroad these days bring back views of the European situation as various and confused as the opinions held by the Europeans they have met. On one point, however, professional and amateur observers are in complete agreement. All were immensely struck by the effect produced by the visit of the British sovereigns to Paris.
THE problem of what to do with the experienced conductors who are refugees from European dictatorships, especially from Germany and Austria, has been taken up by at least one manager of artists.

Plans have been completed for a concert on Nov. 13 to dedicate the new stage in Casino Hall Auditorium on the campus of Georgian Court College here. Miss Jessica Dragonette, soprano, an alumna of the college will be featured on the program.

FEW motorists touring Eastern Canada between Aug. 26 and Sept. 10 will miss the annual Canadian National Exhibition at Toronto. Through more than a half century this many-sided fair has been developing into one of the biggest shows of its kind in the world. This year, it is announced,
Miss Sally Salminen, former New York servant girl who wrote the prize novel "Katrina," denounced the German Nazis' program on her return to her Aaland Island home recently after a visit to Germany.

A squad of forty players is expected to be on hand tomorrow at the Blue Hill Country Club in Pearl River, N. Y., when the New York Football Giants begin training for the benefit game with the Eastern All-Stars at the Polo Grounds on Wednesday night, Sept. 7.

Another day of fine weather yesterday gave New York further relief as the humidity fell as low as 38 per cent, a point reached at 5 P. M., when the temperature went to 85. The day's lowest temperature was 63 at 6:15 A. M.
The Brooklyn Real Estate Board announces the recent election of fourteen new members, of which seven are in the Class A series and seven in the active associate class.

A pictorial booklet has been issued by the Lackawanna Railroad describing the suburban life characteristics in the various home communities along its line. The title of the booklet is "You'll Get More Out of Life in the Lackawanna Suburbs."

MIDSUMMER finds the broadcasters busy arranging their Fall schedules, clearing the way for the return of many of radio's perennial favorites following vacations from the microphone. The ethereal curtain rises
When government-appointed experts in New York-recently inspected 8,000 samples of women's coats and suits to be bought with WPA funds they were doing a pioneering job in only one sense.
Toronto medical research men, one of them Sir Frederick Banting, were reported today to have discovered a new physiological fact in their study of artificial respiration for drowning persons.

The decision of Secretary Wallace not to call for a quota on corn marketings has been greeted with general approval by farmers in Missouri and Kansas. While corn prospects in general are the best in years, the production in the two States will not be burdensome because of the limited acreage.

THE FBI has added recently to its files a full set of the latest tire tread designs of the Fisk Tire Company. Outdoing fingerprints, tire prints point to the weight and make of a criminal's car. G-men, not to mention garage men, also can tell the car's habits and defects from its "trail." This intimate information includes bad

Governor Earle took off today on a month's airplane vacation trip of 10,000 miles to Central and South America, after expressing confidence that he and other Pennsylvania Democratic leaders would be "vindicated" of charges made in the Spring primary.

The visit to Brazil this month of the United States Export-Import Bank president, Warren Lee Pierson, is welcomed by United States and Brazilian business men, who expect he will remove obstacles to Brazilian-United States trade development.

Trade association executives here were concerned last week with the dual problem of developing procedure to conform with the Wage and Hour Act and studying the possibility that methods already have been worked out for circumventing its purpose.

A fireman is always a fireman, at home or abroad. When John Black, deputy chief of the North Arlington Fire Department, who is spending his vacation here, saw flames spurting from a combination apartment and bathhouse on the Boardwalk tonight, he joined members of the local depart?? the blaze.

AN unusual short-wave experiment was picked up recently when a Labrador wireless operator, evidently looking for novel entertainment in his lonely observation post, was heard telephoning a request by amateur radio for special music to be shortwaved from a St. John's, Nfld. department store.

Arbitration machinery will be set up next week to settle the century-old Chaco dispute between Bolivia and Paraguay in accordance with the treaty of peace the two former enemies ratified on Wednesday.

A large representation of the Summer colony of Mount Desert Island and its resort centers turned out this afternoon for the recital by Jose Iturbi at the Building of Arts. The Spanish pianist presented the Sonata in F major by Mozart, Etudes Symphoniques by Schumann, Fantaisie - Impromptu, and Scherzo,
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J.-Boating will hold a prominent place in the entertainment scheduled here during the next few weeks.

The Association of State Civil Service Employes issued a statement yesterday, asserting that the Kenyon proposal to amend the State constitution by giving preference in appointments to veterans of all wars was a "raid" on the merit system.

Governor Wilbur L. Cross has accepted the honorary presidency of the Silvermine Guild Music Festival Association. The Governor desires, it was said, to encourage a cultural movement of this magnitude.
THE Youngstown (Ohio) Symphony Society will give seven concerts during the season of 1938-39, its thirteenth. Bidu Sayao, soprano, will be soloist at the first concert on Oct. 13;...

N. C. Prior, builder of a large home community in Teaneck on Park Avenue south of Fort Lee Road between Queen Anne and Teaneck Roads, announces that a new group is under construction to meet the steadily increasing demand for dwellings just under the $6,000 price class.

LAKE PLACID.-One-half of the proceeds of the fourth annual flower show, which, sponsored by the Garden Club of Lake Placid, will be held in the Olympic Arena here next Friday, Saturday and Sunday, will go to aid the Lake Placid General Hospital and the remainder will be applied to projected civic improvements.

WITHDRAWAL: "Man Mountain Dean," one-time contender for the world's heavyweight wrestling championship, famous for his 302 pounds, recently entered the Georgia Democratic primary race, hoping to win a Legislative seat.

LONDON.-Ordinarily the London Mint strikes about 100,000,000 pennies a year, but the quantities produced in 1864, 1922 and 1933 were so small that pennies of those years now rank as collectors' pieces. About 3,500,000 pennies were struck in 1864, 16,000,000 in 1922 and only four in 1933.

Joseph Bernstein,. past master of King David Masonic Lodge, Astoria, and a founder of the Steinway Merchants Association, died Friday night at his home, 30-78 Thirty-sixth Street, Astoria. His age was 50.

Walter L. Dusenberry of 1,218 Schenectady Avenue, Brooklyn, was injured critically tonight when his glider crashed from 100 feet at the field of the Air Hoppers Club, an organization of gliding enthusiasts, on Bethpage Turnpike, two miles south of here.

Prison doors clanged today behind Francis M. Carroll, sentenced to pass the rest of his "natural life" in the penitentiary here for the murder of Dr. James G. Littlefield. In the same cell block was Paul N. Dwyer, also under life sentence for the same murder.

Twelve hundred marksmen from the United States, Canada, Mexico and Cuba participated today in the seventh annual international police pistol tournament being held at the police range here. The contest will continue tomorrow.
DRUCKEER--KATZ--Mr. and Mrs. Harry Katz of Paterson announce the marriage of their daughter, Frances, to Mr. Arthur Drucker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Chester Drucker, on Aug, 9.

F. E. A. Kitto, Cambridge varsity player in the international masters' tournament of the British Chess Federation at the Royal Pavilion, tied J. F. O'Donovan, another Cambridge expert, for first place by winning his match in the sixth round today.
Dr. James H. Dwinelle of Rye, a well-known physician, has purchased the parsonage and grounds owned by the Stanwich Congregational Church at East Stanwich, Greenwich. The property was sold

ANDERSON-Mr. and Mrs. Wallace W., announce birth of a daughter, Aug. 11. 1938, at Polyclinic Hospital. BAUM--Mr. and Mrs. Adolph Baum of 562 West 164th St. joyfully announce the arrival of Michael's brother. CAMP-Mr. and Mrs, John, announce birth of a son, Aug. 7, 1938, at Polyclinlc Hospltal.
The Alps claimed three more climbing victims this week, bringing the total of deaths since January to ninety, of whom seventy-three were men and seventeen women, Three guides were included.

A total of 67,571 persons visited the American Radiator Company's exhibit illustrative of home comforts at 40 West Fortieth Street during its first year, announces A. R. Herske, general manager. A space aggregating 30,000 square feet is devoted to the educational, technical and product displays.

Miss sack Winifred Agnes Quinn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James J. Quinn of this city, was married this morning to John Patrick Finneran, son of James J. Finneran of East Orange and the late Mrs. Finneran. The wedding took place in St. Rose of Lima Church here.
The fifty-nine strikes in which the Division of- Industrial Relations of the State Labor Department intervened during June involved 7,811 workers.

Stocks moved narrowly and closed generally lower with fractional losses; turnover, 396,200 shares. Czechoslovak loans weak. United States Government and other bonds irregularly lower and dull; transactions. $2,223,500.

The growing enrollment of American colleges in the Near East is responsible for the fact that many new teachers are being sent out to Greece, Bulgaria and Turkey this month. Joining them will be those members of the faculties who have spent the Summer vacation at home.

THE object of those who prepare record lists being what it is, one may be pardoned mild surprise to find that Tartini's most celebrated piece should have had to wait till this year for an American issue.

Governor George H. Earle has succeeded thud far in blocking a grand jury investigation of the graft and bribery charges brought against his State Administration. But the price he has paid, in his desperate resistance to the inquiry, has been a crushing loss in political prestige.

Mrs. Mortimer May of the-Inwood Club today completed the greatest week of her comparatively short tournament career as a golfer when she won the New York State wo- the men's championship over the Cherry Valley course.

Large companies, which have been spotting their sales efforts since the first of the year in the most profitable areas, such as the South, Southwest and Coast, reported last week that beginning next month they would resume intensive drives in the industrial centers.

Work on Brown University's new chemical research laboratory, one of the most complete of its kind, has been finished so that scientific equipment can be installed and the building made ready for the beginning of classes in September.

Fifty-five Austrian Jews, deprived of their livelihood and homes, arrived here yesterday on a Finnish liner but were forbidden to come ashore because of alleged irregularities in their passports. The refugees include ten women and three children.

The New York Women's Bar Association, of which Jenet K. Brown is president and Jeannette H. Harris secretary, announced yesterday adoption of a resolution urging all political parties to nominate a woman for Supreme Court Justice in the First Judicial District.

To the Art Editor: PERHAPS, like most of your readers, I have been stimu lated by your articles on what constitutes American art. Being an American artist myself, I have taken the question seriously. After reading what you wrote I found myself scribbling down on a piece of paper qualities found in all art and then trying to find what made those qualities particularly American or not American.

The Nova Scotia Government was criticized yesterday in a resolution at the United Mine Workers District 26 Convention here for "failure" to provide relief for the almost workless town of Thorburn, N. S., where 1,000 people depended upon a mine.
Jockeys George Woolf and Noel Richardson were suspended today for "foul riding" as an aftermath of yesterday's eventful match race in which Seabiscuit beat Ligaroti by a head.

Jack Zorian of Gainesville, Fla., won the singles title by defeating Garo Artinian of New York, 6-2, 6-1. 6-4, in the final round as the eighth annual national Armenian tennis championships came to a close yesterday on the Arrowhead courts.

CURRENT exhibitions not previously commented upon include two group shows and one solo. One of these consists of an extraordinary assortment of prints and small pieces of sculpture, at the redecorated Weyhe Gallery; a second is made up

The versatile Mrs. Katherine Rawls Thompson of the Miami Beach Swimming Club, who has won national championships in free-style sprinting, breast stroking, fancy diving and medley competition, romped off with top honors in the women's long distance swimming competition in Playland Lake today.

Charles A. Goss, Chief Justice of the Nebraska Supreme Court for the last eleven years, died at the Passavant Hospital here today, Justice Goss, who was 74 years old, suffered a stroke ten days ago while visiting his daughter, Mrs. John B. Pollock of this city. His wife died in the same hospital of the same ailment in December, 1936, while visiting here.

ADAMS-On Friday, Aug. 12, Elizabeth, daughter of John D. and Mary C. Adams. Services at the Church of the Saviour, Pierrepont St. and Monroe Place, Brooklyn on Monday, Aug. 15, at 2:30 P.M. Interment private; please omit flowers.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 13.--Two thousand mosquito-eating minnows, raised on the Georgia coast, have been placed in stagnant waters here to aid in eliminating the insect pest, it was announced yesterday by John A. C. Nyhen, director of the Board of Health's fly and mosquito control division.

Mark Stuart of Winged Foot, former metropolitan champion, won the Green Meadow club's annual invitation tournament with a thirtyfoot putt on the twentieth green this afternoon after John Burke, the medalist, had squared their finalround match with a birdie 3 at the eighteenth.
Washington retained its championship today by defeating St. Louis, 19 to 3, in the final of the Union Printers International baseball tournament.

Mr. and Mrs. W. Lysle Alderson of 31 East Seventy-ninth Street and Cape Cod, Mass., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Alderson's daughter, Miss Betty Ward, to Whitney Trowbridge Kelsey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Trowbridge Kelsey of South Orange, N. J.

Stating that the third anniversary -of the Social Security Act found the country "social-security conscious," Arthur J. Altmeyer, chairman of the Social Security Board, said today that this widespread and wideawake interest promised a continuance of the progress made since the act was signed on Aug. 14, 1935.

Tonight's Horse Show Ball at the Maidstone Club, which followed the fourteenth annual Horse Show given by the Riding Club of East Hampton, was a brilliant event. Miss Lois Warner and Everett Maloney were junior chairmen of arrangements and were aided by Mrs. Harry L. Hamlin, chairman of the Riding Club's house committee.
NEWS from Rome tells of Italy's latest experiment in outdoor Summer opera. Like the Summer symphony concerts in the Roman Forum, the site chosen is another august monument: the Baths of Caracalla.

Thanksgiving won the historic Travers before 20,000 persons today as tragedy struck again for the second time within three days. Samuel D. Riddle's Hauca, favorite for the Spinaway, secondary feature to the Travers, broke a leg at the far turn, and had to be destroyed.
Izzy Bellis, tennis star of the University of Pennsylvania, won both the men's and boys' singles championships in the Middle States Coast tennis tournament today.

Thirty-four racers of the New York Yacht Club were down along the coast tonight making their way slowly here on the long run of their cruise, 104 miles from Vineyard Haven. At last report, A. L. Loomis's new International twelvemeter sloop, Northern Light, which secured a jump at the start, was leading.
ONE of the most tragic and affecting episodes that has ever occurred ir. the life of an American man of letters happened within easy reach of Times Square.

Three boys in a homemade canoe made a daring midnight voyage into the head of Deschenes Rapids in the Ottawa River and rescued two men and a woman whose canoe had upset. Jack Skelly, Jack Morris and Mrs. C. Patterson, sister of Morris, were crossing from Deschenes on the Quebec side of the river to Britannia, just west of Ottawa, when their canoe was pulled into the rapids and upset.
Two Americans were among sixteen persons killed today when a Czechoslovak air liner crashed on a mountain top here in a fog and exploded. It was Czechoslovakia's worst aviation disaster.
The marriage of Miss Martha Warren Brewster, eldest daughter of Supreme Court Justice and Mrs. O. Byron Brewster of this village, to George Alexander Welch, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Welch of

Home financing operations under the Federal Housing Administration program during July as well as during the first seven months of this year were well ahead of the corresponding periods of last year, according to a report issued yesterday by the FHA.

LINVILLE, N. C.-Linville, high up in the mountains of Western North Carolina, is celebrating this Summer its golden anniversary as a resort. The entire program this season is centering around the anniversary theme. Features listed for the coming weeks include: Aug. 19-20,
CHAUTAUQUA-Repertory Theatre, "French Without Tears." (Thursday.) CRAGSMOOR-Cragsmoor Players, "Fly Away Home," with Barbara Brown. (Tuesday.)

A Christian basilica of the fourth or fifth century, which may be on the site of St. Paul's overnight stop on the Island of Samothrace, has been discovered on the island by a New York University exploratory archaeological expedition.

Work will start tomorrow on the demolition of a number of buildings covering approximately one mile of the projected route of the easterly by approach to the Triborough Bridge in the Bronx, it was announced yesterday by Wreckers Excavators, Inc., of 100 Fifth Avenue, which was awarded the contract last week for the work on a bid of $44,600.

Miss Anne Somerville Grosvenor, daughter of Mrs. Charles S. Whitman and the late Edwin P. Grosvenor, Is to be guest of honor at a barn dance which former Governor Whitman of New York and Mrs. Whitman are to give for her on Thursday night at their Summer home, Seabeach. Her party will be one of the events of Newport's Tennis Week.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today the appointment of Thomas J. Lynch as its counsel in connection with the forthcoming joint congressional departmental monopoly investigation. Mr. Lynch, a native of Ohio, has been a member of the commission's legal staff since October, 1934, and assistant general counsel in charge of litigation since March, 1936.

BAR HARBOR, Me.--A combined social and sports program is scheduled on Mount Desert Island and its resort retreats, including Bar Harbor, Northeast, Seal and Southwest Harbors, for the remainder of the month.

Announcement was made today of the engagement of Miss Kathleen L. Barthen, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Charles L. Barthen of this place, to Richard Gorman Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Gorman of Lynchburg, Va.

The Hugo Stinnes Corporation and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for 1937 a net profit of $715,851, including an excess of $591,977 of par value over the cost of the notes and debentures purchased for cancellation, and after taxes, interest, depreciation, minority interest and other charges.

Senator La Follette said today that he would campaign for the candidate nominated by the Progressive party to oppose Senator Duffy, a Federal Administration supporter seeking re-election. His announcement, made in an interview, apparently indicated an end so far as Wisconsin politics are concerned to the political semi-alliance he has had with the Washington Administration. When Mr.

The present upset condition in the liquor market impugns neither the wisdom nor practicability of the Feld-Crawford Price Maintenance Act, Crichton Clarke, counsel to the American Fair Trade League, national organization supporting price maintenance legislation, said here yesterday.

The Westbury Kennel Club has completed its list of judges for its fifteenth annual show to be held on the Phipps Polo Field in Westbury, L. I., Sunday, Sept. 25. The list is headed by the veteran Frank F. Dole, who will name best in show.

DUBLIN. THE Spring lists have been chiefly interesting for personal books. Among these have been autobiographies from Lord Dunsany, Shane Leslie, Walter Starkie; from people and professions so widely different as a farmer-poet, Patrick Kavanagh, whom Harold Nicolson has hailed as an Irish Bobby Burns; a famous jockey.

Little Frankie Strafaci, North-South and Metropolitan amateur champion, defeated Chuck Kocsis and Ray Billows, members of the 1938 United States Walker Cup team, in quick succession today to reach the final round of the Syracuse Yacht and Country Club's ninth invitation golf tourney.

THIS is both an important and a very refreshing book. It is important because it deals with fundamental problems facing both our own and world civilization today, doing so with experience, knowledge and

Two New England estates were reported yesterday by Previews, Inc., as having been sold. One is the twelve-room old colonial dwelling, erected about 1750 and recently renovated, with fifty acres of land at Wayland and Great South Bend Road, Lincoln, Mass., the other is the former estate of Florence Woods of Brookline, Mass., at Dover, N. H., comprised of a tenroom house, built in 1772, with eighteen acres of land.

After more than two years of civil war in Spain the commanders of both armies are just now claiming that their respective forces are stronger and more numerous than ever and that victory is certain to lie finally with their side.

The formula employed by the FHA in selecting "good" mortgages for insurance, a procedure which has kept the administration's net charges to the Mutual Mortgage Insurance Fund to date to a small fraction of 1 per cent on gross business of more than $1,000,000,000, was described yesterday by Ernest M. Fisher, director of the division of economics and statistics.

DINING clubs and exclusive restaurants now seek in their decoration an effect of quiet sophistication rather than startling modernism or a too formal period appearance. To achieve this end fabrics, color and lighting are made to create something of the dramatic spaciousness of stage or motionpicture settings or the sleek compactness suggestive of the interior effects of airplanes or motor cars.

Mr. and Mrs. Robert. T. Stone and Miss Edyth McCoon of Broadview Lodge gave a large party after the races today for Mr. and Mrs. Thomas M. Keresey, H. Don Keresey; John Warburton and Edward Wiegand of New York.

American Public Service Company and subsidiaries- Three months to June 30: Net income after expenses and charges, $92,061, compared with $89,922 in 1937 period. Six months to June 30: Net $182,863, against $60,316 in the first half of 1937.

THE Budapest String Quartet will present a series of five late afternoon concerts next season at Town Hall under the auspices of the League of Music Lovers, to take place on Nov. 5, 12, 19, Dec. 26 and Jan. 2.

FOR a month now we have been pegging away at the subject of American art asking, in the first place, whether it really does exist, and, if so, why the European critics have been able to discern such scant evidence of the fact. Today the discussion continues.

Orange-colored sodium lights will illuminate Admiral Wilson Boulevard in Camden, between the airport and Twelfth Street. beginning next Wednesday night, State Highway Commissioner E. Donald Sterner announced today.

More intensive competition in the New York retail clothing market during the Fall season, as the result of new set-ups in several leading stores, was predicted here yesterday by executives in the field. Indications are that the specialty chains carrying branded clothing will be most affected.

Poland is not forming a neutral bloc between Russia and Germany from the Baltic to the Black Sea, including the Scandinavian countries, official circles here are anxious to let it be known, despite Foreign Minister Josef Beck's visits to the capitals of the countries in that area.

Word came here today that Mrs. George Drexel Biddle was at a ranch near Cody, Wyo., establishing residence under that State's sixty-day divorce law. At his automobile sales office in Merion, Mr. Biddle confirmed the report that his wife was in Wyoming, but declined to discuss the rumor of an impending divorce.

Turner Valley oil fields would be of great value to the British Empire in event of oil curtailment of imports from the United States and the Far East, Air Marshall Sir Edward Ellington of London, England said on his arrival here last night.

THIS week, which brings the close of the twenty-first season of concerts at Lewisohn Stadium, also brings Josef Hofmann tomorrow in a second appearance, Harold Bauer on Wednesday night and Alexander Hilsberg, a conductor from Philadelphia, in his local debut.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Sanford D. France of Brooklyn of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen France, to Connell L. Luke of Chatham, N. J., and New York, son of Professor and Mrs. George L. Luke of Moscow, Idaho.

LOS ANGELES. WITH one announcement, John K. Northrop, who resigned last year from a vice presidency in the Douglas Aircraft Corporation, has simultaneously projected his once potent name back into the aircraft industry, and spurred the day when Diesel engines will be in use in America's airplanes.
Harold C. McKenney a Federal narcotic agent, announced today the smashing of a Western New York marijuana ring with the arrest of twelve persons.

Editor The New York Times Book Review Wouldn't it be wiser for Katharine Metcalf Roof to read Margaret Armstrong's biography of Fanny Kemble before criticizing either its author or the central figure around which this colorful and charming. story is written?

A dinner-dance on the outdoor terrace at the Beach Club, Belle Haven, here tonight, was attended by more than 200 members and guests. John C. Newington of Serena, Field Point Park, entertained, in honor of Mr. and Mrs. JohnWhitney, and Mr. and Mrs. C. Shelby

The Staten Island C. C. scored a notable victory over the veteran St. George eleven in a New York and Metropolitan District Cricket Association match at Livingston yesterday. Batting first the veteran St. George team was dismissed for 50.

In its effort to foster a distinctively American theatre, the WPA Federal Theatre Project will concentrate next season on plays dealing with regional history, problems and people, the national policy board of the project decided yesterday at the closing sessions of a three-day meeting.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates being Aug. 13 unless specified: At New London: Badger, Decatur, Fairfax, Herbert, Leary, J. F. Talbott. Bushnell, at Canal Zone. Blue, Norfolk to Boston. Houston, Pensacola to Hampton Roads, Aug. 11.

William Pierson Hamilton stated today that he had "advanced the necessary funds" for the publication of a newspaper, the first issue of which will appear here next Thursday. The paper, a weekly to be called The Mount Desert Herald, will cover Mount Desert Island and the resort centers of Bar Harbor, Northeast Harbor, Seal Harbor, Southwest Harbor, Somesville and

The Bureau of the Census of the Department of Commerce reports that asphalt roofing sales in the sixmonth period ending June 30, 1938, increased more than half a million "squares" over the first six months of 1937.

Mrs. Imogen B. Emery, new chairman of the national defense committee of the Daughters of the American Revolution, said today that many apparently harmless organizations were carrying on unAmerican activities under deceptive cloaks.

To visit Battery Park on a hot Sunday morning is to see a vivid cross-section of New York's inhabitants in the most exciting phase of anybody's holiday-boarding ship for a voyage to strange scenes and different climes.

The Governors Island Yellows continued their unbeaten stride in the Eastern Polo League championship by conquering the Bethpage Knaves, 7--3, yesterday at Morris Memorial Field. The victory was the fourth in as many starts for the winners, who are tied with the Blind Brook Knights for the circuit leadership.

George F. Chapman, Spanish-American War veteran, died yesterday at his residence here. His age was 69. He was former commander of Hudson Moore Camp, United Spanish War Veterans, and was for years treasurer of the Veteran Firemen's Association.

Bill Cox in the International, Feather, Durbin Hunter in the Star, Foo, Emil Mosbacher Jr. in the Atlantic, Rhapsody, Bob Fraser in the Victory, Blackjack and H. S. Hendricks in the fourth-division handicap boat Sayonara II, were among the winning skippers in the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's special regatta today.

Denmark consumed more tobacco in 1937 than during any previous year, and the outlook for 1938 is most favorable, the American commercial attache reported today to the Department of Commerce. Cigarette consumption during 1937 increased to 1,506,835,000 units and this trend has been maintained during the early part
Dr. Edwin Beer, urological surgeon and an authority on tumors of the bladder, died Saturday night at his home, 1,100 Park Avenue, after an illness of about a year. He was 62 years old.

The following were the best sellers for the week ended Saturday: NEW YORK Reported by the American News Company, Brentano's, Doubleday, Doran Book Shops, Gimbels, Macy's, Scribner's, Wanamaker's and Womrath's:

Jean Richard, who rose from bus boy to head chef and steward of Delmonico's restaurant in New York and owner of his own night club on the Palisades, died at his home on Hudson terrace here Friday night at the age of 85 after an illness of three days.
Only by renewed faith in Jesus Christ can the ills of the world be cured, for these ills are basically spiritual, the Rev. -Dr. Clarence H. Krumbholz, executive secretary of the -Inner Mission Board

Miss Eliza Buffington, 55 years old, an artist, was found-dead yesterday in i the bathroom of her home here.
