Gas was escaping from a small heater, a container of water apparently having boiled over, extinguishing the flame. Dr. H. Raymond Mutchler, Morris County Physician, expressed the opinion that Miss Buffinrgton might have injured herself fatally in falling.

President Rafael Leonidas Trujillo Molina and Doris Stevens of New York, chair.man of the Inter-American Commission of Women held an extensive conference today at the President's offices, concerning the legal position of Dominican women and Inter-American feminist projects.

The Thrift Construction Company, builders, sold to the Kenroff Realty Corporation the new one-story taxpayer containing eight stores and occupying the blockfront on Roosevelt Avenue, between Warren Street and Junction Boulevard, Queens.

The German wholesale price index on Aug. 3 stood at 106.1, against 105.9 a week before. In the first seven months of this year the highest point reached by the German wholesale price index was 105.9, on July 27. The lowest was 105.3, in the first two weeks of June.

Home runs by Ken Keltner and Earl Averill paced the Indians to a 6-to-4 triumph over the White Sox today and gave them the deciding game of the five-game series. Keltner got his twentieth fourbagger of the season in the second inning with one on base, and Averill collected his twelfth of the year in the eighth with the bases empty.
Progovernment youth organizations paraded today in celebration of the eighteenth anniversary of Poland's victory over a Bolshevist army at the gates of Warsaw.

Mrs. Calvin Coolidge attended the Berkshire music festival concert at Tanglewood, Stockbridge, this afternoon. She motored over from Northampton with Mrs. Florence B. Adams, and they were the guests of Mrs. Lucy Wadhams Dodge of Guestwick, Pittsfield.

By the slim margin of a last-minute goal, Old Westbury successfully started preparations for the defense of its national open polo championship at the Meadow Brook Club today, while Greentree, with G. H. (Pete) Bostwick excelling, handily galloped to an impressive triumph in another exhibition match at near-by Bostwick Field.

A new phrase, "the third Europe," is creeping into the news often enough to catch the attention of those straining to hear the undertones in the present tumult. As the Germans loudly beat the drums for the big war rehearsal, and rumors and alarms agitate a dozen frontiers, it becomes more insistent.

The city must cut its capital outlay expenditures drastically for the next six years, Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick declared in a report to the Board of Estimate, City Council, City Planning Commission and Budget Director, which was made public yesterday.

Many dinner parties preceded the lecture on "The Crisis of Liberty" given by Mgr. Fulton J. Sheen of the Catholic University in Washington tonight in the auditorium of the parochial school in Hill Street.

Following is the text of Governor Lehman's letter to Senator Wagner: My Dear Senator Wagner: There is now before the Constitutional Convention on third reading a provision for judicial review on the facts, as well as on the law, of virtually all decisions of administrative officers, boards, commissions, departments and agencies of the State, or of its municipalities or other civil divisions, made in the exercise of a judicial or quasi-judicial function.

The Hon. William Waldorf Astor, son of Viscount and Viscountess Waldorf Astor, has returned to the Waldorf-Astoria after visiting Vincent Astor at Vineyard Haven, Mass. Viscount Bridgeman of London is at the Ambassador.

A State-wide alarm was broadcast today for two unidentified men who kidnapped a 50-year-old resident last night, drove him thirty miles and abandoned him bound and gagged in a cemetery before escaping with his new automobile and $50.

Agreement of Hungary and the Little Entente on the treatment of minorities now depends on only four adjectives, it was reported today. After leaving unanswered for several months the Little Entente's suggestion that Hungary should formulate a declaration on the treatment of minorities to which both she and the Little Entente States would adhere, it is understood that Hungary finally has sent her reply.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It would seem that the Department of Justice has confused the issues involved in the operation of Group Health Association, Inc., in the District of Columbia, and other similar groups, and in turn this confusion seems to have spread to various commentators.

The British expedition seeking to recover the sunken frigate Lutine's gold has decided that the 1857 map, upon which its search has been based, is inaccurate and will try a new area in the three or four weeks remaining before the Autumn storms force it to abandon operations for this year.

Ferns and trees of a "Lost Eden" in South America, studied by Professor Edward W. Berry of the Johns Hopkins University, have yielded ninety-three species hitherto unknown to science, he has reported to the Geological Society of-America.

On Aug. 4 the Constitutional Convention adopted, by a vote of 84 to 33, a so-called "anti-bureaucracy" section which makes all decisions on both law and fact by any State officer or agency reviewable by the courts.

Robert Berger, 14, of Omaha, won the annual all-America soap box derby, today, barely edging Richard Ballard, 21, of White Plains, N. Y., in a photo-finish in the deciding heat. Ballard, who is a younger brother of Robert Ballard, who won last year's derby, was first announced as the winner and was 'introduced over the radio as the new champion.
Development of an excellent shipping demand for cash oats, the best in more than

Laden with two auxiliary airplanes, the Wyatt Earp, base ship to be used by Lincoln Ellsworth on projected expedition to Enderbyland, an uncharted icy domain of 750,000 square miles in the Antarctic, will sail before dusk today from the seaplane base at Floyd Bennett Airport on the first leg of the polar voyage.

Mrs. F. Haven Clark of Boston and this place, mother-in-law of John Roosevelt, youngest son of the President, tonight announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Sally P. Clark, to George Xavier McLanahan of New York and Watch Hill, R. I.

The Queen Mary passed Bishops Rock at 1:42 P. M. today, establishing a record for the eastward crossing of the Atlantic of 3 days 20 hours 42 minutes from Ambrose Light, and clipping 1 hour and 25 minutes from the record set by the French liner Normandie on Aug. 8, 1937.
Paced by Harry Frank and Collister Johnson, the Burnt Mills Polo Club four defeated the Mixed Grill team, 7 to 2, on Schley Field today.

Judge Henry Ellenbogen of Pittsburgh, chairman of the National Committee on Social Legislation of the National Lawyers Guild, recommended today to the committee that it endorse a proposal for abolition of all State taxes for unemployment compensation and for retention of the Federal 3 per cent tax.

There is a widespread conviction in official quarters and among the Czechoslovak public that this week will bring a grave strain on Czechoslovakia from Germany. Exactly what form it will take is not known, but the belief that it will fall short of military invasion is still absolutely maintained.

All deliveries of lard and clear bellies sold here last week at new low levels for the season and since 1934. The break in grains, hogs and cottonseed oil was largely responsible for the recession in lard.

The creation of an Imperial Peace Cabinet along the general lines of the Imperial War Cabinet to formulate a joint foreign policy for the whole empire was suggested today by Scrutator in The Sunday Times.

Ellsworth C. Dent, with R. C. A. Manufacturing Company since 1936, has been appointed head of the R. C. A. Victor educational department, which has been expanded to coordinate merchandising of all products applicable to the school market.

Miss Isabella T. McMaster of Carlisle has chosen Saturday as the date for her marriage to Dr. Craig R. Thompson of Cornell University, Ithaca, N. Y. The ceremony will take place at Green Hill, the home of her uncle and aunt, General and Mrs. Rufus H. Lane, at Falls Church, Va.
Sir Cedric Hardwicke, new director of the Malvern Summer Theatre Festival in England and now appearing in New York in "Shadow and Substance," was here today for the Mohawk Drama Festival.

The weight of excessive supplies of cash wheat available for world consumption in the 1938-39 crop year was plai--ly in evidence in the market last week. Prices in North America, Liverpool and Buenos Aires dropped to new seasonal low levels, and since 1935 or earlier.

Miss Clara Volpe 22 years old, of Elmsford, N. Y., was fatally injured and six others received minor injuries today when an automobile in which Miss Volpe was riding and driven by James Heine. 27, of White Plains, collided with another automobile driven by Douglas A. Shepardson, 25, of Wallingford, Conn.
A welcome clarification of the status of seamen on Government-owned ships is given in a recent letter from Admiral Land, chairman of the Maritime Commission, to the New York Maritime Council.

Gypsy brides are going at bargain prices this year. A report from the annual Gypsy festivities at Kraljevo, Serbia, said that a vivacious brunette brought the highest bid of $6.40. Other brides went for as low as $3.60 and $4.

Three boys and a girl, winners of a recent contest in which more than 230,000 American high school pupils were asked to put down on paper and canvas their conceptions of "The America I' Want," arrived in New York yesterday for a week's visit and, incidentally,
Josef Hofmann, pianist, will make his second appearance as soloist at Lewisohn Stadium tonight, playing the Schumann concerto. The Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra,

The sound of shots and frenzied shouts transmitted over the radio a few minutes before 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon gave the first alarm of the shooting at the Police Department memorial services at the music shell, just north of the Mall, in Central Park.

The stock market last week suffered its first severe reaction of the Summer, or since the advance set in on June 20, and, while war clouds contributed somewhat to the unsteadiness of prices, the decline must be set down as purely a technical correction.

Open orders and reorders arrived in good volume in the New York wholesale market last week. Although reports of August sale resuits have been spotty, stores in the Middle West and South seem to have shown fairly satisfactory figures.

Announcement that the excess reserves of the Federal Reserve member banks were unchanged during the week ended last Wednesday calls attention to the vast unused credit resources of our banking system.

The report of the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on June 30, issued for publication today, shows a net income, after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges, of $11,733,585.

Two men named as Communists yesterday by John P. Frey of the American Federation of Labor are not members of the Mine, Mill and Smelters Workers Union, C. I. O. affiliate, as Mr. Frey reported, Reid Robinson, president of the union, declared tonight.

Senator George L. Berry came here today with an offer to testify before the Congressional committee investigating the TVA, which has been concentrating its attention for several days and will continue this week on the agency's conduct of the Berry marble claims.

Those who want religion to help them toward success in business were chided yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Frederick K. Stamm, pastor of the Clinton Avenue Community Church, Brooklyn, in a sermon at Christ Methodist Church, Park Avenue at Sixtieth Street. Members of the Central Presbyterian Church united in the worship.

The Cash Office of Foreign Credits at Budapest, Hungary, will announce today through its central paying agent here, the Schroder Trust Company, that it will redeem coupons dated Aug. 15, 1938, on the City Savings Bank Company, Ltd.,

Plans for the improvement of quarantine service provided by the Federal Government to ships of all flags at ports of the United States were announced yesterday. The Maritime Association of the Port of New York has been designated as the agency that will supply data on which the proposed improvement will be based.

Frank J. Hanold, partner in the firm of Townsend Townsend, manufacturers of granite memorials, died yesterday at his home, 41 Grand Place. His age was 66. A native of Brooklyn, he had lived in this community for forty years.

After their long struggle against tide and vacuum on the New York Yacht Club's patience run of 104 miles here from Vineyard Haven, out on the island of Martha's Vineyard, the race committee, before daylight this morning, identified the blinking lights that came in past the finish line.

In a letter to W. Kingsland Macy, Republican leader of Suffolk County, made public today, Samuel Seabury endorses the creation of a Tenth State Judicial District, consisting of Nassau and Suffolk Counties. The plan has been fostered by Mr. Macy in the State Constitutional Convention and advanced to the third reading as an amendment of the judiciary article.

This week will witness the formation in London of a company whose object is to issue bearer certificates representing United States stocks. These certificates will be negotiable in Paris as well as in London and various Continental European markets.

Newark's league-leading Bears coasted to an 8-to-2 victory over the Buffalo Bisons today in the rubber game of the current series. Marius Russo racked up his sixteenth triumph of the season against three losses. He allowed only six hits.

Operators of the Orangeburg dogracing track, closed more than a year ago by order of Governor Lehman for alleged violation- of New York gambling laws, announced today that the track would be reopened on Wednesday night under a system of "purchased options," which, they think, does not come within the provisions of the State ban on gambling.

A number of very ardent anglers are putting away their rods these days to get in some practice with the shotgun before next Monday rolls around, bringing with it the Grand - American Trapshooting Tournament, to be held at Vandalia Field. Dayton. Ohio.
Numerous families and groups had luncheons on Bailey's Beach today, while at the same time there were home luncheons in honor of weekend and tennis week guests.

Modern indifference to Christ constitutes a greater peril to religion than any anti-religious ideology, the Rev. Dr. C. Leslie Atkins, pastor of the Purley Congregational Church, Purley, England, said in a sermon yesterday at the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue between Eleventh and Twelfth Streets.

Miss Frieda Miller, whose appointment to fill out the unexpired pointment to fill out the unexpired term of Elmer F. Andrews as Commissioner of Labor is effective this morning, announced yesterday that she had named Miss Kate Papert to be acting director of the Division of Women in Industry and Minimum Wage.

With Lou Gehrig back in a role which some had feared he had outlived, the Yankees wrenched two more games from the Athletics at the Stadium yesterday and nothing apparently could have been more pleasing to a crowd of 33,922. For it seems the folks who gather on the east bank of the Harlem have taken a sort of second liking to Lou.

George T. Davis, attorney for Tom Mooney, told a mass meeting here today that Mooney would "walk the streets a free man within six "Mooney will be free, either by action of the United States Supreme Court or by the election of a Democratic Governor,"

Mr. and Mrs. George Edwin Hodge of this city have announced the engagement of Mrs. Hodge's daughter, Miss Margaret Chambliss Cooley, to John L. Dupree of Bridgeport, Conn., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. John L. Dupree of Brownsville, Tenn.
Miss Hazel. Hurst, 22-year-old blind girl of Oneonta, N. Y., whose e "Seeing Eye" dog Babe was refused admission into England, returned yesterday on the American Merchant of the United States lines.

Tax Counsel, Grade 4 (Certification will also be made to Grade 3 positions). Salary: ;3,000 and over for Grade 4; 42,400 to $3.000 for Grade 3, per annum. Vacancies: Three at $4,000, one at $3,500; one at $2,500. Subjects and Weights: Education and experience, weight 4; written test, weight 4; may consist of more than one part; oral test, weight 2, consisting of various factors mentioned below;

TWO small books* this morning, one a bold statement on the refugee problem, the other a collection of pious and not very glittering political generalities. The author of the first is one of the most distinguished of modern American journalists, Dorothy Thompson. The author of the second is also Dorothy Thompson.

The Soviet Foreign Office charged tonight that the Japanese force broke the armistice Thursday afternoon by advancing 110 yards on the northern slope of Changkufeng beyond the position occupied when the fighting ceased on the Manchukuoan-Siberian frontier.

Four matches were played in the national A. A. U. one-wall handball doubles championship yesterday at the Manhattan Beach courts. Walter Cohen and John Macco eliminated Felix Balletta and William Schaefer, 21-6, 21-20; Larry Mandel and Cy Lieberman conquered Arthur Daub and Clifford Egenspeiner, 21-12, 21-12;

In an effort to avert the "traditional" Fall strike in the painting industry, the Painters Union announced last night that it would seek no change in the wage and hour provisions of its present contract, which expires on Aug. 25.

Mayor La Guardia said yesterday he did not care to discuss his views on rapid transit unification and the future of the five-cent fare with the special committee named by the Democratic delegates to the Constitutional Convention "until the convention has taken final action on the judiciary proposal and has definitely decided to permit the present spoils provision to remain in the home-rule amendment."

The marriage of Miss Lulu Vargas Vila, daughter of Mrs. Josefa Tinedo de Vargas Vila of 215 West Ninetyeighth Street, formerly of Caracas, Venezuela, and the late Jose I. Vargas Vila, to Charles Henry Lee Jr. of this city, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lee of Santiago, Chile,

There is now a tank trap within 500 yards of the League of Nations Palace. It is part of a comprehensive series of such traps that the Swiss authorities have now completed here-one on every road leading into Geneva.

A blast of uncertain origin early today fired a 50,000,000 cubic foot gas well in the East Jackson field and it soon passed out of control. The explosion which touched off the runaway blaze roused near-by sleepers about 1 A. M. Within the first few minutes the fire melted away valve controls at the outlet of the well casing.

MANOEUVRES AND ALARMS It would be astonishing if Hitler acted to confirm the alarmist rumors that have been circulating in Europe during the past three weeks. The nervous crisis produced by predictions of an imeninent coup in Czechoslovakia indicates that we live in a world in which any report is credible because the most incredible action is possible.

Miss Fredericka Fry's chestnut mare True Mark won the hunter championship as the Lake Placid horse show ended today. Silver Leaf, gray gelding from the Sifton Stables in Toronto, was the reserve champion.

Myron Selznick and Janet Gaynor have completed basic negotiations for the formation of a company to produce pictures starring Miss Gaynor, from which she will receive a percentage of the profits. Production activities will begin in five weeks when Miss Gaynor returns from a vacation in Honolulu, at which time details of the agreement will be worked out. "Forever,"

Secretary Wallace is working on a proposal to place at least 100,000,000 bushels of surplus American wheat in world markets by means of an export subsidy, according to informed officials. Details of the proposal are being guarded closely, it was said, and have been discussed only with a few other Agriculture Department officials and with Secretary Hull.

A leap from the window of his sixth-floor room resulted only in a possibly sprained right ankle last night for a man listed by the police as Kurt Stein, 35 years old, of the Hotel Webster, 40 West Forty-fifth Street.

The French wholesale price index showed a noticeable decline at the beginning of August and stood at 640 on Aug. 6, compared to 652 a week before and 654 two weeks before. The decline was due mainly to seasonal influences, for while imported products declined slightly, the native foodstuffs index fell sharply.

Burton A. Zorn, general counsel for the State Labor Relations Board, has informed the School Employes Union, Local 74, of the Building Service Employes International Union, A. F. of L., that closed-shop agreements covering school custodial employes are legal, provided the union involved is the bona fide representative of a majority of the workers.

Every artist in the country will have an equal chance to have his work represented at the New York World's Fair, Grover A. Whalen, president of the fair corporation, said yesterday in making public plans for the fair's exhibition of contemporary American art.

Cotton stocks at Bremen amount to 231,300 bales, against 121,000 at the same time last year. The new decline in cotton prices caused no surprise here, emphasis being put on the large stocks on hand in the United States despite the lowered production, the setback in consumption in Japan and the unsatisfactory outlook in Great Britain.

The former Myra Reeves, tragic figure of the Margaret Drennan murder trial, remained unconscious in a critical condition in Monmouth Memorial Hospital tonight, more than thirty-six hours after what was described as a jump from a moving automobile.

The season's last concert of the Goldman Band, Edwin Franko Goldman, director, will take place tonight on the Central Park Mall. The concert will consist of works by Goldman, Mendelssohn, Bach, Wagner, Liadov, Rogers, Mussorgsky, Gliere and Respighi.
Frank J. Hogan, president of the American Bar Association, announced the personnel of the new committee on the defenses of liberties vouchsafed by the Bill of Rights.

Georgetown University, oldest Catholic university in the United States, has named a committee to arrange for the celebration of the sesquicentennial of its founding in 1789 by John Carroll, first Archbishop of Baltimore.

Naval reductions by the United States after 1922 cost $277,695,000 and had "no useful result," Admiral William D. Leahy, Chief of Naval Operations, declared before the Wisconsin department of the American Legion today.

The Rev. Daniel A. McGuire, who was ordained on June 11 in St. Patrick's Cathedral, preached his first sermon at solemn mass there yesterday. Contending that every human being is potentially a member of "the mystical body" of Christ, he urged Catholics to do all in their power to bring men "back to God" by spreading the Catholic doctrines of truth and peace.

NEVER discuss amateurism. The best any debater can get is the worst of it. Such discussions raise quarrels, leave scars, lead nowhere and decide nothing. The word "amateur" is misused, root and branch. It traces back to the Latin "amo," first conjugation, denoting love of or fondness for some object, and that might be a game in the sports field.

St. Anthony's shrine, maintained by the Franciscan friars on the Mount of the Atonement, at Graymoor, near here, was visited today by nearly 5,000 pilgrims from the United States and Canada for the closing services of the novena in honor of the Assumiption of the Blessed Virgin.

A message from President Roosevelt on the occasion of the twentyfifth anniversary of the Ladies Auxiliary of the Veterans of Foreign Wars of the United States was made public yesterday by the organization. The auxiliary will hold its national encampment next week with that of the parent body in Columbus, Ohio. Thursday, Aug. 25, has been set aside as Silver Jubilee Day by the auxiliary.

Unless the city gives full protection to Philco radio plant workers, their homes and their families against "a campaign of terrorism instigated by a small minority group," the radio company will be driven from Philadelphia by labor trouble, James M. Skinner, president of the Philadelphia Storage Battery Company, told Mayor Wilson in a letter today.

Is John Milton, appointed a Senator for New Jersey to serve until the next general election, to be a candidate for the unexpired term or isn't he? There are plenty of askers, but he won't answer. The Jersey primary election comes on Sept. 20. Aug. 29 is the last day for filing nominations.
Seven men and a woman already have entered the annual Bendix Trophy race from Burbank to Cleveland next Sept. 2, Cliff Henderson, director of the National Air Races, announced today.
The twenty-four contestants in the international masters tournament of the British Chess Federation rested today. The seventh round is scheduled for tomorrow.

Speaking today at an outing of Oswego County Republican organizations Senator Thomas C. Desmond of Newburgh, who is receiving mention as a possible Republican candidate for Governor, declared that his party could "win back" New York State this year if it offered a progressive platform and "forward-looking" candidates.

Early morning attacks by terrorists today included an attempt by a gang of 200 armed Arabs to surround the tiny Jewish colony of Shimroon, near Nahalal, in Northern Palestine, which Jewish supernumeraries prevented by a timely onslaught on the attackers, who were repulsed.

The marriage of Miss Diana Levitow, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernhard Levitow, to Lester A. Blumner, son of Mrs. Samuel Blumner of New York and the late Mr. Blumner, took place yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's parents, 121 Quentin Street,

Cotton prices last week declined into new low ground for the current movement, which began early in July. At the close on Saturday active deliveries on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net losses for the week of 29 to 36 points. In the preceding week they lost 17 to 21 points.

Completing his seventy-fifth round of boxing in preparation for his lightweight title defense against Henry Armstrong at Madison Square Garden Wednesday night, Champion Lou Ambers today went four hard sessions with Luther White of Athens, Ga.
British steel output in July amounted to 683,200 tons, reflecting holiday stoppages, and it compared with 776,100 tons in the preceding month and 1,059,200 in July, 1937.
The ork of dredging the channel of he Chiquimulilla River will begin as soon as machinery arrives, as all ??chnical studies have been comleted.

The Social Security Board reported today a decrease from June to July of 1 per cent in the number of cases receiving general relief from public funds. There was an increase of less than 1 per cent in the amount of obligations incurred for relief, according to reports received from thirty-three States covering 108 urban areas.

Three seamen, arraigned before Magistrate Gasper J. Liota in Essex Market Court on charges of malicious mischief for allegedly smashing, early yesterday morning, two large plate glass windows and a glass door panel in offices of The Daily Worker, Communist newspaper, at 35 East Twelfth Street and 50 East Thirteenth Street, were held in $300 bail each for hearing today.

The Pirates took a champion's hitch in their belts today and shut out the Cubs, 2 to 0, behind the sometimes shaky but generally effective pitching of big Russ Bauers and Mace Brown. Their victory ended a three-game losing streak and kept them four and a half games up on the Giants.
Walter Blackburne, a Philadelphia merchant for more than thirty years, died yesterday at his home, Mount Pleasant and Valley Roads, Villanova, after a year's illness. He was 72 years old.

J. Edward Murray, president of the Bromo-Seltzer Company of Canada and the United States, died today of pneumonia after a brief illness at his Summer home at Big Bay Point, fifty-five miles north of Toronto. His age was 47.

Dr. Henry Schultz, Professor of Economics at the University of Chicago, declared today after an eight-year investigation of crop production that the present trend of consumption doomed to failure the compulsory scarcity program of the Agriculture Adjustment Administration.

The Toronto Globe and Mail says today in a copyright story from North Bay, Ont., that Oliva Dionne, father of the quintuplets, would be willing to give up his business of selling souvenirs and to submit himself and the rest of his family to the same restrictions imposed on the five daughters if he were allowed to live in a new home with them.
Completion of the liquidation of two banks in New Jersey and one in New York State was announced today by Marshall R. Diggs, Acting Controller of the Currency.

The Reds won the first game from the Cardinals, 5 to 4, today as Paul Derringer marked up his fifteenth victory of the season, but lost the second game, 8 to 1. Derringer fanned nine Cards in the opener as he allowed twelve hits. Craft hit a homer with a mate aboard in tle sixth to decide.

Miss Audrey Delacroix deWilde, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. H. Malcolm deWilde of this place, was married here tonight in the First Church of Baldwin, Methodist, to Joseph Lawrence Utter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence L. Utter

Miss Alice Haskell Munson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel G. Munson of Queens Village, L. I., was married here this morning at the Summer home of her parents to Maximilian T. Keil, son of Mr. and Mrs. Emil M. Keil of Brooklyn. The Rev.
In the substantial movement of private capital toward the United States in the last few months British investment trusts figured fairly prominently as buyers of United States securities.

Twenty-four Spaniards who had arrived here aboard a trawler that they had seized from the Insurgent naval base at El Ferrol, Spain, left today for Barcelona with what they termed "valuable military information for the government."

Mr. and Mrs. Gorham H. Godwin gave a cocktail party at the Devon Yacht Club this afternoon in honor of visiting yachtsmen here from other Long Island and Connecticut clubs for the first annual Devon Yacht Club Star Class Regatta, which ended this afternoon.

Setting a new mark in aviation history, the German plane Condor, with Captain Alfred Henke and his crew aboard, completed today the first roundtrip flight to New York and broke all speed records for such distances when they crossed the finish line of the Tempelhof Air Field at 9:57 this morning, 19 hours 54 minutes after leaving New York.

Praise for Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City for preventing Norman Thomas, Representative Jerry O'Connell and others from speaking in his city recently without municipal permits was voiced here today by former Governor Harold G. Hoffman in an address before several hundred of his former war comrades of the Twenty-ninth Division.
The financial markets were grateful for the Russo-Japanese truce this week, as the first encouraging development in the international situation for some time.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $3,840,249,650. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and noninterest-bearing discount bills.

The cornerstone of the first house in Van Houten Fields, a self-liquidating, non-profit homestead association for city workers, was laid here this afternoon by Ralph Borsodi, founder of the movement. About 200 persons were present.

The special polo at the Sands Point Club today produced little in the way of competition, did furnish a glimpse of the speed of the Aknusti side formed for the national open championship. Riding with Ebby and Bobby Gerry, Captain Pat Roark and Ray Guest, Aknusti rolled up and down the field at its pleasure, piling up fifteen goals and permitting only one, during the fifth period, to the Ramblers.

Mid-season crowds again flocked to the beaches yesterday as the temperature soared. The Weather Bureau held out little hope for an end to the current heat wave. Fair weather was the prediction for today.

It is not often that New York has the opportunity to welcome the "young gentlemen of the Regiment," as Rear Admiral Henry B. Wilson used to call the Annapolis midshipmen. Hence the arrival of the Midshipmen's Practice Squadron is all the more an event for the people of this city.
Cavalry troops fought skirmishes tonight as Brown and Blue forces in the Third Army maneouvres fenced for strategic positions in the first day of actual "combat."

The Rev. John A. Bell in a sermon yesterday morning in Grace Episcopal Church, Broadway and Tenth Street, described the power of Christ as simply the power of Faith, faith in renunciation and of reassurance.

A Virginia woman's handbag with $2,500 in jewelry and cash washed through a drain to the beach today and was recovered intact. As Mrs. Mary Osterman of Warwood, Va., guest at a hotel here, emerged from a basement restaurant under the Boardwalk, she stepped through a low doorway and her bag slipped from under -her arm into the opening of a wooden sluice box,' used to drain water from low street ends into the ocean.

Cosmo Sirignano, 30 years old, of 216 Twenty-second Street, Brooklyn, was arrested yesterday and held in $2,500 bail in Coney Island magistrates court on a charge of taking money from many Coney Island residents on a promise of obtaining jobs for them at the New York World's Fair.

American High Commissioner Paul V. McNutt today termed the recent fortieth anniversary celebration of the American occupation of the Philippines "one of the most impressive celebrations of any kind that I have seen anywhere."

Bronzed Adrian Quist carried Australia into the interzone final of the 1938 Davis Cup competition today when he defeated Japan's. No. 1 star, Jiro Yamagishi, 6-4, 6-4, 2-6, 9-7, in the deciding match of the American ev Zonea final series.

Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, announced yesterday that the Jewish children who were among the Austrian exiles expelled from Burgenland by Nazis and set drift on the Danube four months ago will be cared for by sev the Youth Aliyah (immigration) of movement and sent to Palestine before Sept. 30.

Bancel La Farge, artist and mural painter, died at his home here today after an illness of several months. He was 72 years old. With the artist at the time of his death were his wife, Mrs. Mabel Hooper La Farge, and his four sons, L. Bancel, Edward H., Henry A. and Thomas S. La Farge.

The two Americans tentatively identified as Dorothy Cohen and Moritz Abeles of New York who were among sixteen persons killed on Saturday when a Czechoslovak airliner crashed on a mountain top at Kehl, Germany, in a fog and exploded were Dr. and Mrs. Milton Mauritz Abeles of 229 West Seventyninth Street, it was confirmed yesterday.

The budget was voted unanimously today point by point in both houses of the Supreme Soviet, after each had been addressed by Finance Commissar Arseny Gregorovitch Zvereff. It was passed substantially as presented, but expenditures were increased to 124,000,000,000 rubles, against receipts of approximately 126,800,000,000 rubles.

Opposition to the reapportionment and pension proposals now before the State Constitutional Convention was expressed here yesterday by civic organizations. Ten civic groups banded together to condemn the reapportionment plan, and the Citizens Budget Commission and the Merchants Association assailed the civil service proposal.

Vernon Hazen Brooks of Port Chester, N. Y., died last night at the United Hospital, Port Chester, after several months' illness, at the age of 32. Mr. Brooks was a graduate of the Port Chester schools and Columbia University College of Pharmacy, where he received his B. S. degree in 1928.
The Seigniory Club presented a gay carnival scene last night during the annual Venetian Night entertainment.

A round of luncheons, dinners and informal parties has been arranged by residents of this place and the surrounding district for exhibitors and guests from many Eastern States who will be here for the three-day North Shore Horse Show, which opens Thursday at the Old Field Club.

Chartering of corporations continued to slacken in July, according to figures issued today by the Division of Corporations of the Department of State. In July last year 1,313 new concerns were formed and this year only 1,235, a difference of 78.

The Jersey City Giants humbled the seventh-place Montreal Royals twice today, 6 to 2 and 3 to 2. Although outhit in the opener, the Little Giants bunched their blows and shoved five runs across in a big fifth inning to give Rollie Stiles his thirteenth victory of the year.

C. D. Sturtevant, president of the Bartlett Frazier Company, grain brokers and commission house, announced today that the firm would transfer control of the operation of several of its branch offices to Thomson McKinnon on Aug. 20 and confine its leased-wire facilities to territory within which it operates terminal elevators.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 80.2, which compared with 81 the week before, 81.6 two weeks before, 81.5 three weeks before and 81.7 four weeks before.

The holiday season was reflected in reduced activity on the Bourse, although franc weakness at the beginning of the week was the signal for animated transactions in international securities at higher prices, while rentes and other French securities declined.

French war veterans will benefit from an entertainment to be known as a "Night in France," which will be given tonight on the Marine Roof of the Hotel Bossert in Brooklyn. Among the patrons and patronesses are General and Mrs. John J. Byrne and Major and Mrs. James Demarest of New York, Major and...

Tommy Goodwin of the Winged Foot Golf Club, former New York State amateur champion, defeated S. A. Makofski of the Rensselaer Golf Club, the medalist, 6 and 5, today to win the annual men's international invitation tournament over the third oldest golf course in the United States at the Hotel Champlain.
The wedding of Miss Esther Porter, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. David R. Porter of Mount Hermon, to J. Francis Power of Seattle, took place at her parents' home today.

With well-filled classes in twentyfive events the first annual horse show for the benefit of needy horsemen was staged by the Professional Horseman's Association at Meadow Farm today. Many of the top-ranking hunters' and jumpers in the metropolitan area competed.
Dr. Richard O. Snyder heard the heart attack from which Clarence A. Zimmer died. Dr. Snyder, called yesterday to treat Mr. Zimmer, who had complained of chest pains, described the sudden end:

Oliver H. P. Garrett, scenario writer and former newspaper reporter, has finally completed revising his first play, "Waltz in Goose Step," nee "Gentleman in High Boots," and plans are now going ahead for a presentation this Fall.

A great deal of knowledge with but little understanding is a most disturbing characteristic of our time, declared the Rev. John Thorn Golding of the cathedral staff in a sermon yesterday morning at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. This, he said, applied to various fields-literature, art, science and the field of social and political problems.

A long and tedious job of picking twelve blue-ribbon jurors and two alternates to hear the evidence against James J. Hines, a Tammany district leader, will be begun in Supreme Court before Justice Ferdinand Pecora today.

Despite a substantial recovery on Thursday and occasional gains later, last week was another to bring heavy losses to the stock market here, the industrial-share average declining no less than in the preceding week.

One of the girl triplets born early yesterday morning in Williamsburg Maternity Hospital to Mr. and Mrs. George Yerks of 118 McKinley Avenue, Brooklyn, died shortly after 10 o'clock last night. The two other babies are doing well and have better than an even chance to survive, officials at the hospital said. The mother, they declared,

The engagement of Miss Virginia Evans Gregory, daughter of Julian A. Gregory of this place and East Orange, N. J., and the late Mrs. Gregory, to Albert Loring Perry, son of Mrs. Albert Loring Perry, also of East Orange,

Laconia Ave (16-4364), w s, 65 ft s of Waring Ave, 33x100; Schapowal Construction Corp to Anna Capozzi, 1,067 Stell Pl. Murdock Ave (17-5118), w s, 25 ft n of Penfield St, 25x75: also Penfield St, n s, 75 ft w of Murdock Ave, 45x53; also Penfield Ave, n s, 316 ft e of Baker Ave, 50x100; Filomena Schiavone to Michele Cerreta, 4,707 Murdock Ave.
" People who would overthrow the United States by opposing its Constitution and government are not entitled to the protection of our army and should lose their right of free speech,"
The clown was right, we said. The rain, it raineth every day. Noah was making his usual remark to his wife as they sat

Failure of the Board of Education to cooperate in providing recreation facilities was charged yesterday by Park Commissioner Robert Moses. Mr. Moses listed ten closed playgrounds and twenty closed swimming pools under control of the school authorities that he contended should be opened to the public.

The study of war game problems just ended at Camp Smith here, after a week of conferences on tactics supplemented by historic examples illustrating the principles of troop leading, has paved the way for a broader series of exercises that will be opened in the field tomorrow when Major Gen. William

Fred Guild of New York, defending champion, today went into the semi-finals of the Vermont open tennis tournament with an 8-6, 6-3 victory over Everett Collins of Springfield, Mass. He will meet Roger Bracket of Brattleboro, who eliminated John Amrol of Concord, N. H., 6-0, 6-1, tomorrow.
HERE I STAY, by Elizabeth Coatsworth. (Coward-McCann, $2.) A novel set in Maine in 1817. IN DEFENSE OF MRS. MAXON, by George Agnew Chamberlain. (Bobbs-Merrill, $2.) A light novel.

The Weather Bureau ordered warnings down on the Texas coast tonight as the center of a tropical storm passed inland near Lake Charles, La., and said warnings would also be lowered on the and Louisiana coast.

The Yankees lost the services of one pitcher, Joe Vance, yesterday but almost immediately picked up another when Manager Joe McCarthy announced the signing of Wesley Ferrell, temperamental right-hander whom the Senators released outright last Friday.

Alfred M. Lilienthal, president of the First Voters League, urged the press, radio companies and civic organizations yesterday to help the league in its effort to get young people to register and vote.

Leo Diegel, Philadelphia golf pro, who was kept out of the final round of the $10,000 Cleveland open tournament by an auto accident last night, suffered a concussion of the brain, contusions of the head and right hand and a possible fracture of the right thumb, Dr. J. T. Vitkus said today.

The Committee for Industrial Organization asserted today that the Western Union and Postal Telegraph Companies were planning to use a provision of the Wages and Hours Act "as a cover for a general 8.3 per cent wage reduction."

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Adrienne Lande, daughter of Mrs. Joseph Lande of this city and the late Mr. Lande, to Herbert Warren Rubin, son of Dr. and Mrs. Solomon H. Rubin of Brookline, Mass.

The reception for Vladimir Matchek, Croat leader, on his arrival in Belgrade to confer with leaders of the Serbian opposition was an enthusiastic mass demonstration against the regime of 'Premier Milan Stoyadinovitch.

The arrival of the German plane Brandenburg at its destination on schedule impressively emphasizes the fact that transatlantic flights have at last become casual. The days when aviators wishing to cross the Atlantic waited at the flying field for weeks for weather reports sufficiently favorable to risk the gamble are no more.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies, announced yesterday, are after deductions for operating expenses, normal Federal income taxes and other charges. Figures in many cases are subject to final adjustments.

General liquidation by holders of grain futures resulted last week in an enlargement in trading on the Board of Trade. Daily average sales were about 35,300,000 bushels, against about 28,000,000 the preceding week and 54,300,000 a year ago.

Howard Mansfield of 535 Park Avenue, a member of the New York bar for sixty-four years and of the law firm of Lord, Day Lord for thirty-seven years, died- yester day at his Summer home in Seal Harbor, Me., according to announcement made here last night He was 89 years old.
Douglas Corrigan's transatlantic "crate, " a 1929 Curtiss Robin, was viewed by several thousand persons here today after it went on exhibition on the lawn in front of the operations building at noon.

With no more effort than it took to beat the forlorn Phillies in both ends of a twin bill today at Shibe Park, the Giants crept closer to the Pirates and further away from the threatening Cubs. And some 12,000 overheated and sadly disillusioned fans will testify it took absolutely no effort to beat the Phils.

A crowd estimated at close to 40,000 persons attended the annual German Day of Long Island at Camp Siegfried here this afternoon. Fritz Kuhn, leader of the German-Amercan Volksbund, and Ernst Mueller, president of the German-American Settlement League, were the principal speakers.
Development of individual initiative to prevent a "breakdown of personal and family responsibility" was urged tonight by Mark Graves, State Tax Commissioner.

The Bureau of Dairy Industry of the Agriculture Department has applied for public service patents on a process for making synthetic fiber, having the appearance of wool, from casein, a milk by-product. Stephen P. Gould and Earl O. Whittier supervised the experiments.

David Conklin Kipp, for forty years superintendent and for the last three years vice president of the Kensico Cemetery at Valhalla, died today of a heart ailment on his seventy-first birthday at his home on Grasslands Road here.

Barney Neufeld, beauty salon, store at 211 W. 58th St.; Lewis H. May Co., broker. A. Burde, embroideries, in 129 W. 27th St.; A. Hermalyn, wearing apparel, in 27 W. 24th St.; S. Klein, cosmetics, in 36 W. 33d St.; Jacob Blecker, iron works, in 350 8th Ave.; Harold Weston, window displays, in 136 W. 21st St.; S. N. Hartley, neckwear, in 258 W. 28th St.; Lewis H. May Co., brokers.

While some 500 Annapolis midshipmen and 650 enlisted men, on shore liberty after an 8,500 mile training cruise, swarmed off their ships yesterday to view New York, their call was repaid, with ample interest, by about 2,800 New Yorkers, who deserted their familiar

The motion-picture industry and its employes have contributed $60,556 to the Greater New York Fund, J. Robert Reuben, vice president of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer and Chairman of the motion-picture division of the campaign, announced yesterday.

Just recovered from an illness, attributed by some of his followers to poisoning, Governor Chandler of Kentucky passed through Ottawa over the week-end on his way to Lake Desert, Quebec, on a fishing holiday.

The Senate neglected to give a vacation this Summer to Senator Sheppard of Texas, the oldest man in point of service in Congress. The 63-year-old chairman of the Campaign Expenditures Committee is one of the few members of Congress who have remained in Washington since adjournment.
At midnight last Thursday a taxicab struck an elderly man at Park Avenue and Seventy-second Street, and he was rushed to the Lenox Hill Hospital with a crushed leg. He died Friday afternoon of shock.

Charles F. Guild and Alden S. Blodget, formerly partners of Herrick, Berg Co., are now in the main office of Orvis Brothers Co. Ralph T. Dimpel is now in charge of the unlisted securities department of F. L. Salomon Co.

Miss Eileen Creevey and Newman Arnold Hall were married today at Esperanza, the Summer home of the bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. George Mason Creevey of New York. The ceremony was performed by Dr. Edward S. Parsons of Jaffrey, N. H., retired president of Marietta (Ohio) College.

Assailing chiselerss who hang around the magistrates' courts" as the "worst kind of parasites," Magistrate Charles Solomon in Bridge Plaza Court, Brooklyn, yesterday held Abraham -Hirsch, 40 years old, of 25 Cook Street,

Completing their chores just ahead of the Sunday curfew law by taking the second game of a double-header, 6 to 4, following Freddy Fitzsimmons's three-hit 2-to-0 victory in the opener, the Bees tonight found themselves still a game ahead of the Dodgers in the fifth-place battle.
Yellow Cab drivers voted unanimously at meetings tonight to strike at 6 A. M. tomorrow. With about 1,000 drivers affected, the management indicated that all cabs would be taken off the streets.

Harcourt A. Morgan, chairman of the board of the Tennessee Valley Authority, in a letter to be mailed today to holders of the 5 per cent bonds of the Tennessee Public Service Company, announces that the TVA has extended to Aug. 30 the time for depositing bonds with its agent, the Guaranty Trust Company.

Robert T. Hurley of this city, formerly Police Commissioner of Connecticut and until recently a member of the arson squad of the National Board of Fire Under- bia writers, died late last night in St. Francis Hospital, Hartford, after a six weeks' illness. His age was 69.

A defense of the prodigal son was offered yesterday by the Rev. Dr. John C. Schroeder, Professor of Homiletics at Yale Divinity School, in a sermon at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church at Seventythird Street.

The Treasury Department's statement that it had spent $344,612,327 more than it collected in the first three years of the Social Security Act was termed a "monstrous deception" yesterday by Abraham Epstein, executive secretary of the American Association for Social Security.
With crops good and a substantial carryover of wheat and fodder cereals, the Reich is under no compulsion to import grains; but it will almost certainly do so ,in order to build up reserves.

Loans and discounts of State banks rose in 1937, according to a committee report of the State Bank Division of the American Bankers Association. At the end of the year loans and discounts of the 10,119 State-supervised banks amounted to $13,108,126,000, a gain of $236,533,000 or 1.8 per cent over the end of 1936. Total investments were $14,

The six teams that tied for first in the qualifying round of the annual John G. Anderson Memorial golf tournament at Winged Foot ten days ago, each with 70, played off for the honors today over the same course, with the Ed Thorp Memorial Medal at stake.

Purchase by the City Art Museum of a black tom cat at a cost of $14,000 has started a pretty rumpus here. Since the acquisition of the fifth century B. C. Egyption figure in bronze, only fifteen inches high, many persons have attacked the judgment of the museum in spending that much money for a cat.

Two days of pistol shooting by 1,200 policemen from the United States, Canada, Mexico and Cuba ended this afternoon as the seventh annual international police pistol tournament closed here. Class 1 championships, for State and municipal police, went to the Pennsylvania State Motor Police, who shot 1,188 out of a possible 1,200.

Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 40 per cent of capacity, unchanged from the rate of the week before. Since early in June there have been no declines in the rate, except for the week containing Independence Day.

Blazing away with two shotguns on the Mall in Central Park, a police-hating maniac wearing crude steel armor wounded two members of the force and three civilians and. terrified a crowd of 3,000 yesterday at the annual memorial service of the Police Honor Legion.

Mount Hope P1, 125 (11-2805); Jakybovitz Haber, Inc, to Irving Trust Co, extends mtg to Aug. 1, 1941, at 4 1/2 to 5 per cent; $127,080. Mount Hope Pl, 125 (11-2805); Jakybovitz Haber. Inc. to Lillian Siegel, 4,996 Broadway; installments, 6 per cent; $15.000.
In less than a month and a half of the new fiscal year the Administration has incurred a net budget deficit of $455,468,036, which is $150,635,039 greater than the deficit at the same time last year.
Nearly 5,000 people from many parts of New England and the Atlantic States crowded the auditorium at today's closing services of the Northfield General Conference founded by Dwight L. Moody.

The sudden decline of the franc at the beginning of last week caused some nervousness in financial circles. The relapse does not seem to be attributable to fears concerning France in particular. This is a holiday season,

Rapid social changes require rapid readjustments and it is the duty of religious leaders to help facilitate such readjustments, declared the Rev. Dr. James Palmer, a member of the Biblical Seminary faculty, in a sermon yesterday in North New York Congregational Church, East 143d Street, near Willis Avenue, the Bronx.
The eleven-game winning streak of the New York A. C. baseball team was snapped yesterday as the Winged Foot players bowed by 6--5 to the Bronx Giants at Travers Island.

A Japanese Army major was detained today within the International Settlement as a suspected troublemaker in disorders that have marked the first anniversary of the outbreak of Chinese-Japanese hostilities in the Shanghai area.

Expressing full agreement with the stand of Senator Wagner, Governor Lehman declared today that adoption of the administrative law section by the Constitutional Convention would mean turning over to the courts functions which could better be carried on under the supervision of the Legislature and responsibilities which the judges were not equipped to carry.

Hosiery shipments in June showed a less than seasonal decline from May, the total of 9,660,289 dozen pairs being off only 4.3 per cent, as compared with a usual decline for the period of about 12 per cent, according to figures issued for publication today by the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers.

The State Department was accused today by John Hamilton, chairman of the Republican National Committee, of making "literally hundreds of deceptive and, in some cases, inaccurate statements" in memoranda issued in behalf of the Reciprocal Trade Agreement program.
The newspaper Prensa today urged revision of the 1916 treaty between the United States and Nicaragua granting perpetual rights for construction of an Atlantic to Pacific canal across Nicaragua.

Miss Marjorie Jeanne Putnam, daughter of Mr. and Mrs., Hobart Hayes Putnam of this place, has chosen the afternoon of Sept. 23 for her marriage to James Lawrence Maxwell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard W. Maxwell of Red Spring Colony, Glen Cove.
Little, Brown has ordered another 50,000 copies of the world's bestselling cook book, Fanny Farmer's "The Boston Cooking School Cook Book." The total printings number 1,886,000.

Dr. Abraham Z. Idelsohn, organizer of the department of Jewish music and liturgy at the Hebrew Union College here, died today in Johannesburg, South Africa, where he has been living since his retirement. t His age was 56.
Announcement has been made by Mrs. Samuel Picard of this city of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Elise Nordmann, to Joseph A. Rosenthal, son of Mrs. Herman Rosenthal of Asbury Park.
Miss Leba Fierst, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry P. Fierst, was married here this afternoon in the garden of her parents' home to Alfred Berman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Isaac Berman of Toronto.

Rudolph Caracciola, German automobile driver, won the annual Acerbo Cup classic today when he drove the 412.800 kilometers (256.501 miles) in 3 hours 3 minutes 45 seconds, averaging 134.783 kilometers or 83.770 miles per hour. P. Farina of Italy was second and Vittorio Belmondo, also of Italy, third. Caracciola drove an Alfa Romeo, Farina an Alfa Dorse and Belmondo an Alfa Romeo.

Jim Dante, Suburban pro and president of the New Jersey P. G. A., and Philip Axt, home club star, captured the Forest Hill Field Club's first pro-member golf tournament today by shooting a spectacular best ball of 63, eight strokes under par.
At 6 o'clock this morning Vienna Nazi leaders broke the first ground for a new garden city on both sides of the main road from Vienna to Italy, about ten miles southwest of the city.

A new six-story elevator apartment house at 2,319 Morris Avenue in the West Bronx has been purchased by Samuel Miller, an investor, from the builders, the Fanruth Realty Corporation, Louis Minoff, president.

Stocks sharply lower with widest losses since the week ended on March 26; turnover, 5,523,760 shares. United States Government bonds irregularly higher. Corporation issues lower. Japanese issues rallied; transactions, $28,368,125.

People go to the country to get back to nature-at least that is what they say. They can get fairly close to nature right here in New York City at almost any time of year. The city is a camp, set on or into the earth, like a hunter's lodging for the night or a savage's dwelling.

R. B. Mildon, vice president of Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company in charge of the Pittsburgh district works, announced yesterday the consolidation of the transportation and generator divisions of the company.

Last week's stock prices dropped below the level of 1936 when many concerns were inadequately occupied and dividends averaged 30 per cent less than now. On the basis of the cyclical theory--which partly has justified itself in Germany as fully as in the United States-this Boerse collapse would be taken as the precursor of a trade slump, all the more so because bonds also declined.
Half a dozen new faces in the Senate and a score or so in the House are already assured at this halfway point of the 1938 nominating campaign.

Spanish Insurgent southern forces today reached the border of Ciudad Real Province, a government stronghold since the start of the civil war, as they pushed their campaign through Spain's richest mining region.

The Berkshires Symphonic Festival came to an end at Tanglewood here this afternoon. Ideal weather prevailed, and the attendance was more than 6,000 again. The seats in the music shed were filled, and a scattering of visitors sat and reclined on the lawns around the shed.
Camps, cottages and hotels all were represented today by members of the Summer colony thronging the boxes for conclusion of the ninth annual Lake Placid horse show.

Pilot Tom Lamb's skill in pancakingg" his seaplane into heavy brush was credited by his three passengers today with saving them from serious injury when the plane stalled yesterday soon after taking off from Cumberland House. Sask.

Conditions in the steel industry continue to show slow improvement, declares the magazine Steel. Although the comparatively sharp rise of recent weeks has been checked, this is considered merely a corrective measure.

117th St, 160-162 E; Joseph Harris, referes, to East River Savings Bank, ioreclosure ($11). 122d St, 333 E; John Curclo to Northeast?? Dispensary; mtg $9,475, held by grantee ($10). 10th Ave, 639; Tanrose Realty Corp to Moe B. Scheyer, 1,185 Park Ave; mtg $27,160 held by grantee ($28).

Sir Landon Ronald, distinguished British conductor, died today after a long. illness at the age of. 65. Favorite of Queen Victoria In 1891, at the age of 18, Landon Ronald first was engaged by Sir August Harris to conduct the music for grand operas then being presented in London's Covent Garden. After three years there,

An account of the discovery of a world-wide series of great underwater canyons, formerly believed to exist only off Eastern North America, is contained in the current issue of the Geographical Review, publication of the American Geographical Society of New York.

The message and mission of the Christian Church in the modern world is far more important than the number of Christians belonging to the church, the Rev. Dr. J. Alfred Kaye, pastor of the New Court Congregational Church in London, declared yesterday at the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street.

Remarkable persistence is shown here in the belief that the Anglo-American trade pact will include an agreement for stabilization of dollar and sterling exchange at the old parity, or even lower for the pound.

Eugene J. Leahy, Frank Philgus, Walter Baer, in 50 E 78th St; Mrs. Julia L. Beveridge,- in 815 Park Ave through R. C. Overton; Elliott V. Wright, Sandford T. Johnson, Irving Bachrach, in 220 W 98th St; Borchard Management Corp, broker.
A national campaign to press questions of foreign policy into the coming Congressional elections was started today by the National League of Women Voters.

Members of Colonel Theodore Roosevelt's famous Rough Riders of '98 and other veterans of the SpanishAmerican War paid tribute to their leader and swapped yarns of forty years ago when they held their first reunion today on the site of old Camp Wikoff.
Ernst Tolier, exiled German poet and dramatist, today outlined plans for a campaign in America and Europe to obtain food for civilian Spain.

Miss Charlotte Glutting of Orange, N. J., won the Lenape Trophy in the final of the women's invitation golf tournament today at the Shawnee Country Club by defeating Mrs. William Hockenjos, Lake Hopatcong, 1 up.
The frontier region is not unduly excited over the German military manoeuvres and the work on the fortifications opposite France.
Mrs. Isabel, Downey, a widow who claims direct descent from William Penn, today faced eviction from the home in.Fairmount Park where five generations of her family have lived.

Ten young men and a woman saw their dream come true here yesterday with the opening of "Tompkinsville," one of the first cooperative housing projects on the continent. The woman was Mary Arnold, formerly of New York
Percy Kynaston, veteran New York player, won the Powelton Club invitation tennis tournament for the third successive year today, defeating Larry Krieger

The Monmouth County Country Club's annual ten-goal tournament got under way today with the Monmouth Freebooters routing the Norwood Polo Club of West Long Branch, 13--7, after leading by 6-5 at the half-way mark.

Opposition of both producers and large motion-picture houses in the leading cities to commercial films indicates that this form of advertising has about reached its peak and will gradually decline, according to opinions expressed currently in advertising circles. In some cities organized protests by local newspapers against these shorts has led theatre operators to drop them.

H. G. Wilcox, engineer for New York and Pittsburgh capitalists, today reported having encountered an ore shoot two hundred feet from the surface of the Flagstaff mine, north of Ketchikan. Eighteen men have been at work on the project since last November.

A story of every one else running out of the way, or standing dazed, not realizing what was happening, but of policemen charging straight at crazed Charles Sanfillippo, their revolvers blazing until empty and then grasped as bludgeons, was told by witnesses of yesterday's attempted wholesale police assassination in Central Park.

Helen Hayes, star of "Victoria Regina," which is to open on Oct. 3 at the Martin Beck Theatre, New York, for a return engagement, disclosed here tonight that she had abandoned her plan to leave the stage for a year after closing in Laurence Housman's play and that she would appear on Broadway next season as Portia in "The Merchant of Venice."

Some 85,000 sport fans crowded into the Olympic Stadium today to pee the second and final day's events in the German-American track and field meet. The United States team went into the last day with a lead of 58 points to 49 for the Germans, who never seriously threatened, and the invaders won handily with 122 points against 92.
George Morris, aged 65, of Peru engineer of a westbound Wabash Railroad passenger train which struck a motor car here yesterday killing the Fireman, Frank C. Donat. also of Peru,

Arrivals by land and sea swelled the ranks yesterday of the delegates to the second World Youth Congress, which will be formally opened tonight at a mass meeting and pageant in the Randalls Island Stadium and will continue through a week of deliberations at Vassar College, Poughkeepsie.

The veteran Harry Kelley pitched and batted the Selators to a 7-to-1 victory over the Red Sox today. The result gave Washington a sweep of the three-game sries. Kelley was so effective that only three Bostonians faced him in seven of the nine innings. He allowed five hits and drove in three runs on two blows.

George H. Bull, president of the Saratoga Racing Association, gave a luncheon at the Saratoga Golf Club today for Mr. and Mrs. Walter J. Salmon Sr., Lady Thornton, Mrs. C. Oliver Iselin, Lord Queenborough, Mr. and Mrs. E. Howland Graham,
Robert L. Riggs Jr. and Miss Alice Marble, both of California, are the Eastern grass court tennis champions for 1938. In the final round of the tournament at the Westchester Country Club today,

The cotton market here is passing through a period of marked depression, with no buyers. The general verdict of the brokers is that Liverpool is taking only high grades, with no demand for medium and low grades. The situation is seriously affecting a majority of the growers here, since a large proportion of this year's crop, is unusual poor quality.

James Williams, world champion parachute jumper, was killed today during a provincial exhibition at Lons le Saunier. Williams, who held the record for the altitude jump, had leaped from an airplane 3,000 feet up and his parachute failed to open.

What the whole world needs is to "see" Jesus, the Rev. R. G. Le Tourneau of Peoria, Ill., said in his sermon yesterday morning at Calvary Baptist Church, Fiftyseventh Street between Sixth and Seventh Avenues.

The Board of Trade's index of wholesale prices for July, based on the average for 1930 as 100, was 100.6, against 100.7 for June and 111.5 for July, 1937. The index numbers by groups of commodities compare as follows for a month and a year ago:

The State Board of Law Examiners, composed of John Kirkland Clark of New York, Philip J. Wickser of Buffalo and Rollin B. Sanford of Albany, announced today a list of 675 law students who had passed the June bar examinations.

Finishing just inside the -time limit, Clifford E. Grover of Newark and Norman B. Smith of Philadelphia brought the Teaser home first by the wide margin of seven minutes thirty-three seconds in a fleet championship contest for the International Star Class sloops today.

A small army of peace officers from three States combed a ten-squaremile area in the wilderness of extreme Southwest Arkansas today for Floyd Hamilton, Southwestern "bad man," and a desperado companion believed to be Ted Walters. Hamilton and his companion fled to the thickly wooded section following a gun battle with State police yesterday.

Buck Newsom's one-hit pitching gave the Browns a 7-to-1 victory over the Tigers in the first game of today's double-header, but a Detroit rally, tying the count 3 to 3 as the aftermath was called on account of darkness, kept the cellar occupants from sweeping the three-game series.

The Annalist's weekly index of wholesale commodity prices was 79.3 (1926=100) last Saturday, compared with 80.3 in the preceding week and 94.8 a year ago. Prices are now the lowest since the week ended Dec. 25, 1934, when the index was 78.5. The index follows:

Charges that Harry Bridges, leader of the Committee for Industrial Organization on the West Coast, was being advised, instructed and protected by "an outstanding official" of the Labor Department were filed today with the Special House Committee investigating un-American activities by Edward F. Sullivan, one of its investigators. Mr. Sullivan appealed to the committee for a "fearless" investigation of the accusations.

A huge sign, printed in Spanish, has been placed on the Pan-American Highway about ten miles south of the United States border, where all Mexicans going toward the United States can read: "The money you spend outside of Mexico, your children will lack later."

The city's voluntary hospitals urged Governor Lehman yesterday to investigate charges that insurance companies handling workmen's compensation were "chiseling" on hospital bills, withholding payments and generally seeking to have hospitals provide bed care for compensation cases at less than cost.

If the world were brought to the bar of the church's judgment it would be condemned as short-sighted, untrue to its own science and blind and afraid to face the real areas of its own trouble, the Rev. Dr. Albert W. Beaven, president of the Colgate-Rochester Baptist Divinity School of Rochester, N. Y., declared in his sermon yesterday morning at the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue at Twenty-ninth Street.
Miss Amy L. Harvey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jesse A. Harvey of Richford, Vt., was married here yesterday to Joseph Harrison. Supreme Court Justice Newton Porter officiated.
Corn, oats, rye and soy beans joined with wheat in sinking to new seasonal low levels last week, and only corn showed any material disposition to rally from the inside figures.

Forty-one men, most of whom admitted they had no homes, were arrested at 4-A. M. yesterday morning in a round-up of loiterers in Central Park. One of the group, particularly neat in appearance, later protested to Magistrate Overton Harris in Yorkville court
Rescue parties continued through desolate mountain country of Veracruz State today toward the spot where an airliner crashed and burned Friday with eleven persons aboard.

Although most of the London press this morning continued to take a calm view of the start of the huge German military manoeuvres, the gravity of the situation was emphasized by two newspapers with such varying viewpoints as the Conservative Daily Telegraph and the Liberal News Chronicle.
A benefit has been arranged by the Youth Consultation Service of the Church Mission of Help in the Diocese of Long Island to celebrate twenty years of consistent service by the organization.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Aug. 15, unless specified: At San Diego: Altair, Neches, Aug. 14. Bermuda to Baltimore: Dickerson, Schenck. Bermuda to Norfolk-Roper, Tillman. At Navy Yard, Washington, Aug. 14Cuvahoga. Potomac.
President Roosevelt's address tonight, on the occasion of the third anniversary of the Social security Act, was as follows: The Social Security Act is three years old today.

Under a starlit sky 500 delegates representing organizations claiming a membership of 40,000,000 young persons in fifty-five nations staged an elaborate program of folk dances, songs and pageantry last night as the Second World Youth Congress formally opened in the municipal stadium at Randalls Island, before a capacity audience of 23,000 persons.

PRINCIPAL PHYSICIST (any specialized branch) $5,600 a year; SENIOR PHYSICIST (any specialized branch), $4,600 a year: PHYSICIST (any specialized branch). $3,800 a year; ASSOCIATE PHYSICIST (any specialized branch), $3,200 a year.

MADE on Earth,"* a collection of extracts from letters, diaries, poems, newspapers and such, is one of the most edifying handbooks of the season. The compiler is that worthy English anthologist Hugh Kingsmill. The following is a partial index to its treasures.
Nine persons were killed in a spectacular airplane crash in Rio de Janeiro Bay today while crowds were watching from piers. The low-winged passenger plane, operated by the Condor Line.

Mrs. Averell Dougherty heads a group of Summer colonists arranging the piano recital by Mme. Yolanda Mero Thursday night at Four Fountains, the studio of Mr. ??nd Mrs. Lucien Hamilton Tyng. Mme. Mero is a founder and executive director of the Musicians Emergency Fund and chairman of the Women's National Radio Committee.
The Nash-Kelvinator Corporation announced yesterday the appointment of William A. Blees as general sales manager in charge of sales and service of the Nash Motors division of the corporation.

Franco Cortese won the Italian Automobile Sporting Federation Cup in the annual six-hour race today. Driving an Alfa Romeo, he traveled 669.09 kilometers (414.4 miles) at an average speed of-111.5 kilometers (69.13 miles) an hour.

Greyhound, the big trotting champion from the stable of Edward J. Baker of St. Charles, Ill., carried off- the $4,000 all-age Matron Stake in two straight heats today as the five-day Grand Circuit meeting opened at the Illinois State Fair.
District Attorney Dewey yesterday asked talesmen at the trial of James J. Hines whether they were acquainted with any of the following persons, whose names, he said would figure in the trial:
Edward J. Hunter, secretary of the Registration Commission and former newspaper man, died tonight after a long illness, at Women's Homeopathic Hospital. His age was 57.
The sale of an apartment property on Washington Heights and leases of housing and business parcels in scattered sections featured realty activity reported yesterday in Manhattan.

Three navy men were killed today when a torpedo bomber from North Island crashed one mile east of Rosedale Field, on Camp Kearny mesa, navy officials reported. The dead were Mike Frank Moscicki, pilot, aviation mechanist's mate, second class; Don Fay Smith, radio man, third class; Ralph Thomas Carter, aviation chief ordnance man.

It seems probable that the bottom of this renewed depression was reached in June, Colonel Leonard P. Ayres, vice president of the Cleveland Trust Company, declared in an issue of that institution's Business Bulletin, released yesterday.

The Legislature today passed the Passenger Ships Bill barring shiphotels from the Hamilton and St. George harbors. An amendment was passed reserving the bill for scrutiny by the British Colonial Office in order to avoid any international complications.

Treasury agents who boarded a freighter in Boston last month in search of narcotics they believed had been hidden in her hold remained on that vessel when it came to New York early this month, but were unable to find the supposed contraband.
Miss Madeleine Carroll, motionpicture actress who played the feminine lead in "Blockade," returned yesterday from a three-month visit to France and Italy aboard the French liner Normandie.

President Federico Laredo Bru today vetoed the Amnesty Bill recently approved by Congress and returned it to that body with suggestions for modifications, it was announced, following a Cabinet meeting.

With the traditional poker face of the old school politician, James J. Hines, Tammany leader of the Eleventh Assembly District and in recent years the power behind the throne of "the Hall," went on trial yesterday as a protector of the gambling racket with the philosophical observation that "young men are always cruel."

Bob Burns, who has been borrowed from Paramount for one picture, has been assigned by RKO to "Little Orvie," by Booth Tarkington, in which Peter Holden, of Manhattan's "On Borrowed Time" company, will make his debut.

The Ford Motor Company filed 573 specific objections today to the intermediate report of Tilford E. Dudley, trial examiner, on the hearing conducted by the National Labor Relations Board at the company's St. Louis plant.

Farm Administration officials said late, today a drop to 8.20 cents a pound in the average closing price of cotton on the ten designated spot markets apparently made 1938 cotton loans mandatory under the new Farm Act.

A broadening of the Communist movement in the United States was projected to include drives within the major political parties, pressure on President Roosevelt to drive him further to left in his policies and support for Governor Earle of Pennsylvania, the House Committee Investigating Un-American Activities in this country was told today by John P. Frey, vice president of the American Federation of Labor.

The Securities and Exchange Commission denied today an application of the San Francisco Stock Exchange for the extension of unlisted trading privileges to the common, prior preference, preferred and second preferred stocks of the Market Street Railway Company, and at the same time indicated it would entertain an application by the Exchange for a rehearing on the denial of extension of unlisted trading privileges to one class of the Market Street Railway securities.

Six jurors were selected yesterday to try James J. Hines, Tammany district leader, who went on trial before Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora as a lone defendant fighting an indictment that named nine men as members of the Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer policy racket.

Mr. Dewey: I think perhaps if the court will permit me, I will come up and turn my back on the court right here. If any one cannot hear me, I will appreciate it if you will make some signal of some kind, so I will speak louder. I can talk as loud as I have to, but I do not want to break your eardrum unless necessary.

Though a thermometer at the Blue Hill Country Club registered 110 degrees in the sun and there was scarcely a breath of air stirring today, the New York Football Giants, forty-three strong, started training for their 1938 campaign, which opens Sept. 7 with the annual contest against the Eastern College All-Stars at the Polo Grounds.

Announcement was made late today that the negotiating committees of the Dyers and Printers Employers Association and the Federation of Dyers, Finishers, Printers and Bleachers of America, at a conference at the Alexander Hamilton Hotel here, had agreed upon the major points of a new contract for the local dyeing industry.

With the most ambitious program in its history, the New York State Communist party announced plans yesterday to raise $280,000 for the organization's activities in the coming year. The drive, announced by Israel Amter, State chairman and candidate for Governor,

Patrick Cardinal Hayes, the Most Rev. Stephen J. Donahue, Auxiliary Bishop; the Most Rev. Bartholomew J. Eustace, Bishop of the Diocese of. Camden, N. J., and many other high dignitaries and priests of the Catholic Church participated in ceremonies of the jubilee celebration marking the fiftieth anniversary of the profession of faith of Mother M. Polycarpa, at St. Joseph's Sanatorium near here today.
Murray Moore Storke of New York died here today in the cottage he had rented for the Summer, after an illness of several months. He was 63 years old.

Mr. and Mrs. Henry Morgenthau Jr. and their three children, who have been living at Cap d'Antibes for the last three weeks, keeping pretty much to themselves, left today by automobile for Briancon, en route to Geneva and Zurich.

Stockholders of the Scott Paper Company approved yesterday at a special meeting in Philadelphia a proposed reduction in the authorized preferred stock from 133,305 to 130,000 shares. The directors met later to establish a series of $4.50 cumulative preferred shares, of which 30,000 will be issued to finance plant extensions.

Dr. Abram T. Kerr, anatomist and secretary of the Cornell University College of Medicine, died here today at the age of 65. He had been affiliated with Cornell in an administrative capacity since 1900.
