The American Federation of Labor challenged today the authority of the National Labor Relations Board to designate a collective bargaining agency for a large area, as it did in the Pacific longshoremen's case.

W. G. Youngholm, Eastern regional sales manager of the Realsilk Hosiery Mills, Inc., of Indianapolis, was honored last night on the occasion of his fifty-second birthday at a "testimonial meeting" of more than 150 salesmen of the company in the metropolitan area in the Hotel New Yorker.

A large bandit gang operating in the State of Michoacan attacked a railroad gang killing twenty-six workers as the group proceeded to .work at Chaparro Hacienda,. according to reliable reports sent today to rail union offices and the headquarters here of the Federation of Mexican Workers from Acambaro, State of Guanajuato.

A charge that Lord Rothermere was encouraging Germany to attack Czechoslovakia was one of the highlights of an exchange of correspondence made public today between the publisher and Wickham Steed, former editor of The Times of London.

Several sales of properties in Connecticut were reported yesterday by Reed G. Haviland, broker. At Wilson Point two acres overlooking Long Island Sound were sold by the Wilson Point Company to Grace Howe.

Building projects submitted yesterday included plans for numerous houses in scattered sections of Queens, where one of the largest developments calls for the erection of a sixty-family house in Elmhurst to cost $300,000.
For the first time since last October farm prices in Wisconsin showed a slight upward trend in July, the State and Federal Crop Reporting Service said today.

Faced with what they contend is one of the most serious Swiss cheese surpluses in recent years, more than sixty farmers, cheese dealers and cheese makers, from Southeastern Wisconsin met with State Department of Markets officials this afternoon in an effort to work out a solution to their problem.

Former Governor Harold G. Hoffman said today he would not do anything further in behalf of Herman G. Mulock Jr., who was paroled from prison fourteen months ago by the Court of Pardons after serving seven years of a life sentence for murder and who was returned to the prison here yesterday after being arrested at Spring Lake on a charge of issuing a worthless check.

The defense and the prosecution in the trial of James J. Hines each will have a private office off the court room throughout the legal battle, it was assured yesterday. At the opening of the session Lloyd Paul Stryker, chief of defense counsel,

Just when it looked as if the 66 made by Gilbert Tompkins and Charles H. Mayo Sr., representing the Lido Club, was going to stand up for low score in the weekly Long Island Professional Golfers Association amateur-pro competition yesterday, along came Artie Warholic of Clearview and Joe Phillips of Oakland to tie them.

Ist Lt. Wallace R. Wobcke, Qm.-Res., l91 Harrison Ave., Jersey City, N. J., is ordered tot active duty Aug. 14, at Headquarters Third Military Area, 1,180 Raymond Boulevard, Newark, N. J., for training. Date of rank, June 19. He will revert to an inactive status Aug. 27.
Mrs. Pauline Lennards Palmer, the artist, died this morning in Trondheim, Norway, according to word received here today. She had been ill for less than ten days with pneumonia.

The Heckscher Camp at Adams Corners; eight miles northeast of here, was ordered closed for the season today because of an outbreak of typhoid fever in the camp. The decision to close was made after a conference between Dr. Frederick M. Rauch, camp medical officer and health officer of the town of Putnam Valley in Putnam County, and State Health Department officials.
Luncheon meeting, Lions Club, Hotel Astor, 12:30 P. M. "Army Life in India," Major William James Campbell. Metropolitan Museum of Art, 3:30 P. M. "The Egyptian Collection," Edwin L. M. Taggart.
William F. Weed, formerly of Weed, Hall, Berndt Co. of Detroit, is in charge of the-new office of A. M. Kidder Co.,-which is to be opened today in the Ford Building, Detroit.
William J. Austin has been appointed by Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc., as manager of the company's national accounts, it was announced yesterday.

Mrs. Nelson I. Asiel entertained today at a luncheon at the Gideon Putnam for Mrs. Ferdinand W. Roebling Jr., Mrs. Edward Livingston Smith, Mrs. Kirkwood E. Jewett, Mrs. Charles Presbrey, Mrs. Josiah T. Semans, Mrs. Julian Peabody, Mrs. Paul C. Downing, Mrs. John H. Griffin Jr. and Mrs. Luther A. Wait.

A new "prophesying" instrument intended to supplement existing weather bureau apparatus in foretelling fluctuations of temperature was demonstrated yesterday by its inventor, Professor Charles M. Heck, head of the Physics Department of North Carolina State College, who has been making a "heat survey" for the last four days from various levels of the Empire State Building.

The River Parkway Apartments, a group of four six-story elevator houses with landscaped center garden on the square block bounded by Laurel Hill Terrace, Amsterdam Avenue, 186th to 187th Street, in the Washington Heights section, are 90 per cent rented, Morris Shaknow, president of the Shaknow Realty Corporation, builders, reported yesterday.
W. Roy Manny, who owns an adjacent waterfront estate, has bought the vacant property formerly occupied by the Victoria Hotel and three cottages in Park Avenue, Larchmont, Westchester County.

Judge William Rogers Clay of the Kentucky Court of Appeals died today at his home here after a long illness. He was 73 years old and had returned to his home yesterday from a Louisville hospital, which he entered a month ago for an operation and treatment for a throat infection.

The publishing firm of Covici, Friede, Inc., has been taken over by its chief creditors, according to an announcement made yesterday by the Viking Press, which said that Pascal Covici had resigned from his former firm to join the Viking Press in an executive and editorial capacity and that he had taken with him John Steinbeck, author of "Of Mice and Men."

Alligator fishing became the favorite sport today at Huguenot Lake, in front of the New Rochelle Senior High School. Police officials and game wardens received reports of the capture of five since Thursday evening.
A registration statement covering $30,000,000 of convertible debentures was filed today with the Securties and Exchange Commission by the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company.

By settling their boundary dispute without the intervention of other nations, Costa Rica and Panama, two of the smaller democracies of Latin America, are expected to set a good example to other nations.

Frederick Clifford Earl, one of the best known bankers in North Jersey, died at his home on Navesink River Road here this morning following a heart attack. He had been in ill health for several years. His age was 65.

Leopold Stokowski, director of the Philadelphia Philharmonic Orchestra, returned yesterday on the French liner Normandie after six months in Europe and North Africa. He refused to mention the name of Greta Garbo or to discuss the possibility that he and the actress might marry.

Scores went up with the thermometer in the Westchester Professional Golfers Association weekly pro-amateur tourney at the Quaker Ridge Golf Club today. However, Mike Turnesa, Fairview pro and a member of the famous Elmsford golfing clan, scored a subpar 69, which enabled him and his brother Willie of Briar Hills, State amateur champion,

A sharp increase in tariffs on assembled automobiles, most of which come from the United States, was included today in new import rates announced by the Mexican Government to become effective Aug. 30.

Calvin Truesdale,.A. C. Bostwick's home at Jericho, L. I.; Douglas L. Elliman Co, Inc, broker. George J. Garon, 112 Webster Rd; Joseph Udice Jr., at 80 Nelson Rd; Scarsdale rentals by Raymond R. Beatty Management, Inc, broker, for HOLC.

In the steam of a torrid evening, Bernard Shaw's "The Millionairess" is not so hot. Lawrence Langner, who arranged the American premiere at the Country Playhouse this evening, believes that the weather and the short rehearsal period are against it. But even in the Arctic Circle in midwinter Mr. Shaw could not be held entirely innocent.

Extreme caution is marking the first stages of the "battle" which began here early yesterday morning between the Brown enemy force and the Blue defending force, each consisting of 13,000 regulars and National Guardsmen in the Third Army manoeuvres.

Among the contracts for commercial space reported by brokers yesterday was one signed by Turf and Tanbark, Inc., publishers, for space in the Time and Life Building, Rockefeller Center. The lessee's former quarters were at 103 Park Avenue.

Another six weeks of existence was granted to the Queens gypsy camp yesterday by Magistrate Savarese in Long Island City Court when he adjourned a hearing of proceedings to Sept. 28 to permit counsel for the land owner and the gypsies to take the matter before the Board of Standards and Appeals.

Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson authorized yesterday a Manhattan Railway Company stockholders' protective committee of which Nathan L. Amster, president of the Manhattan is chairman, to intervene in the Interborough Rapid Transit Company receivership to protect the interests of holders of the Manhattan's 7 per cent modified stock.
Light has been thrown on the lives of prehistoric American Indians by the discovery of a great kiva, or temple, and village in Colorado, the Field Museum of Natural History reported today.

The possibility that one of the civilian victims of the gun battle on the Mall in Central Park Sunday was wounded by a police bullet arose yesterday following the removal of a single slug from the abdomen of Louis Popernick, 51 years old, of 1,072 Third Street, Brooklyn, at City Hospital.
There is now some "possibility" that King George and Queen Elizabeth will visit the United States and Canada some time next year, The Evening Standard said today.
Melvyn Douglas's family was a foursome today. A daughter was born yesterday to Mrs. Douglas, Helen Gahagan of the stage. The couple have a 4-year-old son, Peter.

This city's Mayor "Emeritus," Samuel A. Carlson, known for his work in municipalowned utilities, has stirred this Republican stronghold by announcing that he was considering running for Congress from the Forty-third District as an "independent candidate to represent the progressive rather than the reactionary viewpoint."

Freckles became an asset yesterday afternoon at the lower West Side Center of the Children's Aid Society, 219 Sullivan Street, when, in the finals of a city-wide competition, 10-year-old Eileen Eaton and Thomas Shannon, 11, were chosen as the first-degree freckles champions of New York City.

Miss Edith Aiken Egleson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Ernest A. Egleson of this place, has chosen Sept. 16 as the date for her marriage to Joseph W. Bower, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Bower of Montclair. The ceremony will take place in St. Peter's Episcopal Church here.
His job and his future were very much on John Roosevelt's mind today as he and his bride, the former Anne Lindsay Clark of Nahant, returned from their Bermuda honeymoon.

The claim of the Washington Administration to a supreme taxing power over the States is destructive of the whole foundation of our constitutional government, Austin J. Tobin, secretary of the Conference on State Defense, told the delegates to the convention of the Municipal Finance Officers Association in an address here this afternoon.

Corquet is keeping Secretary Hull in trim through the hot Summer months. He works days, evenings and Sunday mornings, but he usually takes time off about 5 P. M. each day for a highly scientific game of the lawn sport.
The Committee for Industrial Organization was certified as the collective bargaining agency for two additional groups of workers today, by action of the National Labor Relations Board.
That the Catholic clergy in the Sudeten area are following the lines laid down by Cardinal Innitzer of Vienna by making their peace with nazism once again was confirmed today by reports from Bruenn.

The Jersey City Giants hopped on Lefty Ken Raffensberger and Si Johnson, who relieved him, for four hits and three runs, more than enough to win, as they took a 5-2 decision from the Red Wings in ten innings tonight.

The Toronto Maple Leafs and Newark Bears shared the spoils of a twilight-floodlight double-header tonight before a crowd of close to 10,000 fans. Joe Sullivan blanked the Bears with six hits in the opener, 5-0, for his fourteenth of the campaign, while Jack Haley also registered triumph No. 14 for the Bears in the nightcap, 6-5.

Chinese troops have reoccupied Shahochen and Nanchangpu, about twelve miles south of Kiukiang, according to a Chinese Central News dispatch yesterday from Teian. Japanese forces, hard pressed by the Chinese, were said to be falling back on Kiukiang, abandoning large quantities of supplies and equipment.

The two-weeks-old Lawyers TitleCorporation gave a reception yesterday to its president, William D. Flanders, senior deputy administrator of the Federal Housing Administration, at the company's offices at 141 Broadway.

Two games were concluded in the English county cricket competition today, one day ahead of schedule. The champion Yorkshire eleven defeated Leicestershire by an innings and 141 runs and Glamorgan triumphed over the last-place Northamptonshire eleven by seven wickets.
MANHATTAN ARNSTEIN, GOLDIE L. (Aug. 8). Estate, $300. To Julius M. Arnstein, husband, executor, 1.370 University Ave., residue; one other bequest.
After a further decline into new low ground 'for the movement, prices on the Cotton Exchange recovered yesterday to end with gains of 2 to 3 points.

Six Jews were killed and two, both women, were seriously injured near Haifa this afternoon when a bus going to Mount Carmel was ambushed by Arabs while passing through a forest. It is believed several of those killed were Jewish special policemen.
The Public Works Administration soon will place State quotas on loans and grants in an effort to equalize participation in its 1938 construction program.

The Department of Justice formally denied today that there was any connection between its actions in relation to the Sinclair Oil interests and the fact that James Roosevelt sold Harry F. Sinclair an insurance policy in 1937.

After dipping last week to 0.044 per cent, the average rate on the Treasury's weekly bills went up on the issue sold today to 0.047 per cent, the department announced tonight. The average interest rate the week before last was 0.062 per cent.

The Board of Trade's figures for July are as follows: Total imports, [Pound]73,938,000; exports of British products, [Pound]37,469,000; re-exports, f4,555,000; total exports, f42,024,000; excess of imports, [Pound]31,914,000.

Frank Jackson defeated Phillip Reed to advance to the second round of the national tennis tournament for Negro players on the course of Lincoin University today. Nine first-round matches were played in the men's division while fourteen were completed in the women's section.

Representatives of the workers in the flint glass industry and their employers closed heir annual collective bargaining conference in the Hotel Marlborough-Blenheim here today with the adoption of a resolution opposing reciprocal trade treaties.

The Rumson Country Club quartet survived its first-round test in the annual ten-goal tournament of the Monmouth County Country Club by routing the Ramblers, 9-3, today. The victors tallied four times in the second session.

Although there are no reports of further hostilities in the Changkufeng sector, the basic problems that caused the recent outbreak of hostilities remain unsolved. Tt is more than likely that a successful conclusion of the border dispute will be reached only after a protracted series of conferences and negotiations.
Figures made public today by the State Tax Department show 620,579 gallons of tax-paid liquor were sold in New Jersey last month, an increase of more than 160,000 gallons over July, 1937.

Cotton exports from Brazil amounted to 11,362 metric tons in April, compared with 12,827 tons in the preceding month and 11,682 tons in April, 1937, the United States commercial attache at Rio de Janeiro reported today to the Department of Commerce.
A handful of independent drivers were rushed today as a strike of 1,000 Yellow Cab drivers left Philadelphia's taxi transportation virtually at a standstill.
Joseph A. (Jumping Joe) Dugan, former star third baseman for the New York Yankees, considers James J. Hines the "finest man in the world" and is proud to be his intimate friend.

A bee was blamed today for an automobile accident in which five persons were injured, two seriously, near here last night. State police quoted Mrs. Esther B. Picou, 40, of Syracuse, as saying she lost control of her car when a bee struck her in the face.

The Madrid section of the Spanish Popular Front adopted unanimously today a resolution declaring Waldo Frank, American writer, "a good friend of the Spanish Republic, whose cause this illustrious author sincerely supports."

Lon Warneke returned to his old stamping grounds today and, backed by a barrage of fourteen hits, including home runs by Joe Medwick and Lynn Myers, hurled the Cardinals to a seven-hit, 8-to-4 victory over his former Cub colleagues.

Led by Shortstop Rabbit Warstler, who blasted a triple and two singles in four trips to the plate and scored two runs, the Bees today bagged thirteen hits off two Philly pitchers and won from the tail-enders, 5 to 3.

United States Senator John Milton came to his law office here today from Sea Girt, where he has been convalescing after a recent operation. It had been expected that he would announce whether he would be a candidate to succeed himself, but he made no announcement and refused to meet reporters or discuss politics.

Several causes for encouragement in the nation-wide warfare on highway accidents are to be found in the National Institute for Traffic Safety Training, which will conclude its two weeks of sessions at Ann Arbor on Saturday.

Senator McKellar will appear tomorrow at his own request, before the Special Committee investigating Senatorial campaign expenditures to testify on the primary election in Tennessee, Chairman Sheppard of the committee announced today.

The Agricultural Adjustment Administration announced today that it would pay to the nation's wheat farmers a subsidy of 26 to 30 cents a bushel for compliance with a planting program calling for a 31 per cent reduction in acreage next year.

Louis Johnson, Assistant Secretary of War, said in an address here tonight that "in keeping with a program of less war and fewer casualties, the War Department is substituting machines for men whenever possible."
Allen B. Endicott Jr., Federal referee in bankruptcy, took under advisement today a $500,000 offer to settle one phase of the involved $9,535,261 William Fox bankruptcy.

The tenth annual New Jersey Shore tournament held under the auspices of the Woman's Metropolitan Golf Association, which was scheduled for July, finally got under way today over the Deal course with a small but select field of forty-eight entries.

Mrs. Carolyn Dexter Yale, a leading club woman of Flushing, died early yesterday at her home, 147-32 Sanford Avenue, Flushing, after a long illness at the age of 61. She was the wife of William T. Yale, Flushing builder and real estate owner.

In a reminiscent mood John Golden yesterday glanced at the calendar and thought the combination of twenty years and twenty days since' he first presented "Lightnin' " on Broadway (Aug. 26, 1918) suggested an appropriate time to disclose the first revival of the play with Fred Stone heading the cast.

Brooklyn at New York-Tamulis (6-7) vs. Gumbert (10-9). St. Louis at Chicago (2)-McGee (4-10) and C. Davis (8-5) vs. Lee (14-8) and French (9-16). Cincinnati at Pittsburgh - R. Davis (7-7) or Walters (9-12) vs. Blanton (9-2).

The Goldman Band, directed by Edwin Franko Goldman, closed its twenty-first season of outdoor concerts in New York with a program on the Mall in Central Park last night. An audience of more than 20,000 turned out for the concert and bade Dr. Goldman and his musicians a warm farewell.

Daniel George Dodge, 21-yearold heir to the Dodge automobile fortune, was drowned in Georgian Bay near here today when he jumped from a boat as he was being taken to a hospital for treatment of injuries received in a dynamite explosion.

Harold S. Vanderbilt, with his sloop Prestige, today won the King's Cup, most coveted prize in large boat American yachting. It made the sixth time the thrice defender of the America's Cup had taken one of the contests.

It would be an ironic denouement of the Good Neighbor policy of the Roosevelt Administration if a course of action intended to strengthen the ties between Mexico and the United States should end in closer relations between Mexico and the fascist nations.
The Home Owners Loan Corporation sold the two-story building containing four apartments at 68 East Fifty-first Street, Brooklyn, to a client of M. C. O'Brien, Inc., broker in the deal.
The voulme of department store advertising linage decreased in July to 1,742,334 from 1,868,078 in July a year ago, according to a compilation made public yesterday by Media Records, Inc.

The Supreme Court upheld today the State Tax Department's levy of $123,406 as a transfer inheritance tax on a trust fund set up by George L. Hartford, founder of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, two years before his death in August, 1917.

George Myatt, speedy third baseman of the Jersey City team, was recalled by the Giants yesterday, it was announced by Secretary Edward T. Brannick, and will play third base for the Giants at the Polo Grounds today in the opening of the series with the Dodgers.

The twenty-sixth annual golf championship for members of the New York Athletic Club started today at the Winged Foot Golf Club with forty-eight entrants qualifying in three flights. Tommy Goodwin, former New York State titleholder and winner of the international tourney at Lake Champlain yesterday,

Manufacturers using copper, brass, aluminum and other non-ferrous metals are reducing their inventories and will have to buy soon, according to a survey by the George Birkenstein Corporation, Chicago dealer in non-ferrous metals.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. D. Samuel Gottesman of 730 Park Avenue, this city, and Lawrence, L. I., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Miriam Gottesman, to Ira D. Wallach, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Wallach, also of New York.

Death Reported Retired Lieutenant George Friton, formerly a member of Hook and Ladder Co. 33, residing at 133 E. 233d St., Bronx, died Aug. 14. Funeral will take place from the Concourse Funeral Home, East Tremont Ave. and Grand Concourse, Bronx, at 10:30 A. M.. Wednesday. Aug. 17.

Two upsets were recorded in the international tournament of the British Chess Federation at the Royal Pavilion today when, after a day of rest, play was resumed in the seventh round. J. F. O'Donovan of Cambridge University sustained his first defeat in Section A at the hands of E.

Turpentine firm, 22c; no sales; receipts 528 barrels; shipments 647 barrels: stock 42,919 barrels. Resin firm; sales 614; receipts 1,956; shipments 3,126; stock 207.685. Quote: B. $3.50; D, $3.85; E. $4.20; F. G. H, I, K. $4.57 1/2; M, $4.60; N. $5.40; WG, $5.60; WW and X, $6.35.

Mrs. Dorothy C. Osborn of New York obtained a divorce today against Minott A. Osborn, former director of the United Hospital Fund in New York City. It was made known that the couple had entered into an agreement for the custody and support of their children. Mrs. Osborn charged cruelty.
Frau Engelbert Dollfuss, widow of the murdered former Chancellor of Austria, has received an immigration permit to visit the United States in a few weeks, according to reports here today.

Exhaustive questioning conducted with Chesterfieldian courtesy marked the examination of talesmen yesterday at the opening of the trial of James J. Hines before Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora.

President Roosevelt, in a nationally broadcast address tonight marking the third anniversary of the Social Security Act, promised expansion of the program to include "all those who need its protection." He warned the country, however, not to be "misled by those who advocate short-cuts to Utopia or fantastic financial schemes."

The opening day's gallery at the twentysecond annual invitation tennis tournament of the Newport Casino was not as large as usual on an opening day, due to the heat. Nevertheless there was a fair crowd in the morning and an even larger one of Summer colonists, their guests and others in the afternoon.

Gilbert I. Ross, consultant on business administration, has resigned as vice president and chief engineer of the Lasley Company to become president of Ross, Wells Co., which he has formed with Robert H. Wells, management consultant.
The option for the purchase of Anticosti Island, in the Gulf of St. Lawrence, is still in force and is held by A. Meidle of Amsterdam, who interested a German syndicate in negotiations last Fall.
Sand sharks, seen every year off the North Shore bathing beaches and estate lands, appeared this afternoon in Long Island Sound, according to Mrs. Arthur Loew, whose estate includes a marine basin.

John H. Hayes, president of the Hospital Association of New York State, replied yesterday to the demand of Leon S. Senior, general manager of the Compensation Insurance Rating Board, representing insurance companies handling workmen's compensation, that the city's voluntary hospitals' bed rate of $5.50 a day for compensation cases be arbitrated.
Announcement of the appointment of John (Jack) Zeller as general manager of the Tigers was made today by Walter O. Briggs Sr., president and owner.
The wholesale price level last week was the lowest reached since December, 1934, according to the commodity price index compiled by the National Fertilizer Association.

The New York Maritime Council appealed yesterday to the National Labor Relations Board for a ruling on the claim of the National Maritime Union to the right to represent merchant seamen on ships recently taken over by the Federal Maritime Commission.

The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Aug. 10; Increase of $24,000,000 in commercial, industrial and agricultural loans, $20,000,000 in loans to brokers and dealers in securities and $58,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted.
Captain William Dougherty of the United States Lines will be in command of the liner President Roosevelt when she sails tomorrow for Plymouth, Havre and Hamburg. It will be his first command.
Police Recorder Frank Romano of this city fined a Jersey City man $1,200 today and sentenced him to 120 days in jail for four motorvehicle violations.
The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday that consolidated earnings for the first six months of this year were $3,507,320.

Edward Tuck, American philanthropist and resident of Paris for more than fifty years until his death there on April 30 at the age of 95, left an estate of more than $2,600,000, according to a petition filed in Surrogate's Court yesterday by the Chase National Bank, executor of the estate.

Alexandre Nones, a business broker in Baldwin, L. I. filed yesterday with the clerk of the Brooklyn Federal Court a petition in voluntary bankruptcy indicating that he had 368 creditors with claims ranging from $4 to $100,000 in various parts of the country.

The art committee of Guild Hall, headed by Henry Theodore Leggett, is entertaining tomorrow afternoon with a preview and tea when an exhibition of oil paintings by Nan Greacen goes on view in the Marjorie Woodhouse Gallery. Miss Greacen is in private life Mrs. Rene Faure, the daughter of Edmund Greacen.

Six Brooklyn residents vacationing at Cleverdale on Lake George narrowly escaped death by drowning this afternoon when an outboard motor boat in which they were riding was capsized by waves on the wake of a speeding g power boat.

A German steamer, the Theresa L. M. Russ, arrived here today and landed Captain Jean Bonifacio, three other officers and the ten members of the crew of the French steamer Artois, which was sunk last night thirty-five miles southeast of Gibraltar after hitting a floating mine.

A seven months' strike conducted by Local 1225 of the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America, C. I. O. affiliate, against the S. W. Farber Company, metal manufacturers, 141 South Fifth Street, Brooklyn, has been settled, it was announced yesterday.

Twenty-six bids for a site for a contemplated new building to house Postoffice Station F were opened yesterday in the office of Postmaster Albert Goldman at the General Postoffice Building, Thirtythird Street and Eighth Avenue.
Lovers of art learned with dismay early this year that no formal exhibition of contemporary American painting was planned for the New York World's Fair.
In the Federal Wage-Hour Bill as it emerged from conference, there appeared a sentence that was not to be found in either the Senate or House version of the bill:

Miss Carrie L. Hulse, about 55 years old, a retired nurse and well-known resident here, was killed today when a gas cooking stove evidently exploded in the kitchen of her frame bungalow at Roanoke Heights.
Trading was good to very slow in local markets yesterday. Veal hindsaddles were sharply higher. Lamb carcasses stronger retail but steady wholesale. Other classes showed little change.

The Cunard White Star liner Aquitania is due to arrive today from Southampton via Cherbourg. Among her passengers are Mr. and Mrs. J. C. Penney, R. H. McKenzie, Mme. Y. Yoshida, wife of the Japanese Ambassador to Great Britain; Mrs. L. W. Bonney, Arthur Murray, Mr. and Mrs. Hugo Knudsen, Mr. and Mrs. W. W. Jaeger, Philip R. Mather, Joshua C. Chase and Mr. and Mrs. E. A. Maitland.
New Anglo-Japanese friction arose today as British naval officials accused Japanese of discourtesy to the Union Jack and molesting a British tugboat captain.

Dr. Frank Hancock, one of seventeen American surgeons who volunteered for service with French troops in July, 1917, died today at the age of 65 after a long career in medicine here that included service as Norfolk County Health Commissioner.

The Attorney General's office has obtained since Jan. 1 $271,453.25 from delinquent employers subject to the Unemployment Insurance Law. The July collections were $39,148.74, according to a report today to Paul Sifton, executive director of the Division of Placement and Unemployment Insurance.
Five firemen were slightly injured last night while fighting a twoalarm fire in a row of taxpayers at Forty-sixth Street and Greenpoint Avenue, Sunnyside, Queens. The damage was estimated at $30,000.

A resounding call to the people of Georgia to join him in a "lastditch" fight for the right of free suffrage and against "one-man control of the Democratic party" was Senator Walter F. George's answer today to the attempt of President Roosevelt to drive him from his sixteen-year-old seat in the United States Senate.

22d St, 33-39 E, 98x98.9; 33 E 22d St, Inc, to American Bible Society, 450 Park Ave; due as bond, 5 per cent; $27,500. Same property; same to Isidore Solomon and another, 25 E 86th St; mtg. $112.500, due Feb. 11, 1939, 6 per cent; $30,000.

Finishing strongly, Enrico Ven turi, 140, Italy, gained the decision over Maxie Fisher, 133, Newark N. J., in the main bout of eight rounds last night at New Dyckmar Oval. The loser held the advan tage for the first three rounds, then gave way before Venturi's aggressiveness.

Operating employes of the North Shore Railroad prepared today for a strike vote at midnight tomorrow. Union officials predicted that, unless the receiver of the company agreed to submit its demand for a 15 per cent cut to arbitration, the 1,300 emploves would cease work.
A substantial upturn in new orders booked by lumber mills since late June was reported today to the Department of Commerce by the Lumber Survey Committee.
Some time within the next few days a letter will be laid on the President's desk. Perhaps it has been laid there already. It is not addressed to the President.

Word was received here last night of the death yesterday at his home in Woodbury Falls, N. Y., of Dr. Worthington Seton Russell, who retired in 1924 after many years as Professor of Materia Medica at the New York College of Dental and Oral Surgery. Dr. Russell;

Mail orders received in the merchandise markets here were described as light to "just fair." Retail stores ordered only minor fill-in quantities, although orders of this nature were spread over nearly all lines.

A declaration by the West Penn Power Company, a subsidiary of the American Water Works and Electric Company, covering the issue and sale of $17,000,000 of its 3 1/2 per cent first-mortgage bonds, Series J, due on Aug. 1, 1968,

Dr. Charles V Paterno, New York City builder, will start construction within two weeks of his chateau on Round Hill, Greenwich. It is estimated to cost $60,000. A slight modification will be made in the plans because of zoning restrictions.

The International Housing and Town Planning Congress, Including engineers and technicians from all parts of the globe, opened its meetings here today with a discussion of the immediate need of building underground cities for the protection of civil populations from air attacks.

It would be an ironic denouement of the Good Neighbor policy of the Roosevelt Administration if a course of action intended to strengthen the ties between Mexico and the United States should end in closer relations between Mexico and the fascist nations.

The Fourth-Seventh Royal Dragoon Guards today bade farewell to its horses. The regiment, to be mechanized immediately, held the last of a series of mounted parades that stretched back over 250 years of history.
Tomorrow is a holiday in the Dominican Republic for the inauguration of the new President, Jacinto B. Peynado, to succeed Rafael Leonidas Trujillo Molina, who has served for the last eight years.

A communique was issued today in the names of Vladimir Matchek, leader of the Croat Peasant party, and leaders of the united Serbo-Croat Democratic Opposition announcing as the objective of the coming political campaign the abolition of the existing "dictated Constitution" and the summoning of a national constituent assembly.

The Commodity Exchange, Inc., announced yesterday that the contracts covering raw silk futures, in which trading was started on July 26, will provide for the inclusion of raw silks of Italian and Chinese origin besides Japanese.

A third printing of "The Coming Victory of Democracy," Thomas Mann's defense of the democratic ideal, has been ordered by Knopf. This printing of 5,000 copies brings the total for Dr. Mann's newest work to 17,400 printed since its publication in June.

Debits to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities, for the week ended Aug. 10 aggregated $6,326,000,000, or 17 per cent below the total reported for the preceding week and 16 per cent below the total for the corresponding week of last year.

Traffic accidents and the number of persons killed and injured in them continued to decline last week and week-end as compared with the corresponding periods of 1937, the safety bureau of the Police Department announced yesterday. The tabulation for the weekly periods follows:...

The nation's oldest organization of dancing teachers, the American Society of Teachers of Dancing, opened its sixtieth annual convention yesterday at the Hotel Astor. More. than fifty delegates from all parts of the country were present. Philip S. Nutt of Vineland, N. J., president of the society, presided.

France's Navy Minister, Cesar Campinchi, today made the dedication of a monument to Napoleon the occasion for an attack on dictatorship. "We must be defiant of personal affairs," M. Campinchi declared. "It is danger for a State to rest upon a single man.

Miss Margaret Bernadette Maguire, daughter of Edmond Hugh Maguire of this place and Brooklyn and the late Mrs. Maguire has become engaged to Harold Vincent Seiferd, son of Mrs. Louis Seiferd of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Seiferd.
The Republican majority at the Constitutional Convention first gained, and then lost, a vote today, so that its strength remained at 90, or a margin of five.

Supreme Court Justice Francis G. Hooley, sitting in Brooklyn, denied yesterday the application of Walter Hurst, former Deputy County Clerk of Richmond, for a certiorari order reviewing the action of Vincent K. Drury, Richmond County Clerk, in removing Hurst from his post.

As Senator George takes up the President's challenge, and Senator Tydings and Representative O'Connor await it in its personal form, the period seems a good time to review certain aspects of the Democratic breach.

A single national system of unemployment compensation with only one pool of reserve funds and one tax rate for all industries and all States, was urged by James W. Horwitz, Assistant Professor of Business Statistics at the Harvard Business School, in a report published today by the school's bureau of business research.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Petitions Filed--By ABRAHAM GOLDBERG, leather cutter, 1,525 Hoe Ave.-Liabilities. $1,916; no assets except insurance. DAVID KAMINOWITZ, unemployed salesman, 2,185 Valentine Ave.-Liabilities, $6,120; no assets except insurance.
Bond prices closed a shade easier yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange in the slowest trading for a full five-hour session in more than twenty years.

The appointment of Thomas Jefferson Wertenbaker, Edwards Professor of American History at Princeton University, as Harold Vyvyan Harmsworth Professor of American History in Oxford University for 1939-40 was announced here today. This is the second time he has taught in a foreign country.

A series of thefts from -the Union. Club, Park Avenue and Sixty-ninth Street, was revealed yesterday when the police arraigned Anthony Rocofort, 36 years old, of 241 East 110th Street, before Magistrate Rothenberg in Felony Court.
Members of a touring American swimming team, making their first appearance in Germany, won two contests outright today and tied for first with a German for another in a six-event meet.

F. R. Tripler Co. will add a "young man's" department for the Fall season, Oscar Carlson, vice president, announced yesterday Suits, styled to Tripler specifications, will be offered in two price ranges "under $50," he said.

Mr. and Mrs. Clarence E. Meyer of Springville, N. Y., and Yokohama, Japan, have announced the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Miss MaryLouise Meyer, to Halsey Lawrence Beemer. The wedding will take place on Aug. 30 in Christ Church, Yokohama.

The marriage of Miss Helen McClure Berry, daughter of Mrs. Gordon L. Berry of this city and the late Mr. Berry, to Heinz Siegfried Werner Bluhm, son of Mrs. Friedrich W. P. Bluhm of New Haven, Conn., and the late Mr. Bluhm, took place last night in the chapel of Riverside Church.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The American Defense Society wishes to call your attention to a phase of the so-called Halpern grand jury amendment which your recent editorial does not cover, and to point out to you some of its defects.

Representatives of New York interests in the island's needlework industry today discussed with Governor Blanton Winship the possibility that the enforcement of the Wages and Hours Law might throw between 60,000 and 100,000 persons out of work.
Lupe Velez obtained a divorce today from Johnny Weissmuller. The actress testified in Superior Court that the Tarzan of the films was "very insulting,"

Douglas Corrigan discussed his plans with Mayor La Guardia yesterday during a farewell visit at the Bummer City Hall in Queens. The transatlantic flier said he was considering several offers for the publication of his life story. He expects to make a decision on these offers today before he starts on a transcontinental tour.

Mrs. Peter Sinnott of 888 Grand Concourse, Bronx, wife of the Bronx building contractor who is chairman of the Bronx County Democratic Committee of the Fifteenth Assembly District, died yesterday in the Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center after a long illness.

Surpassing a rate of operations equivalent to 40 per cent of theoretical capacity for the first time in 1938, the steel industry has attained a milestone that was striven for in the Spring, when it would have meant profits for stockholders,

A controversy between two stockholder groups over whether the Reynolds Investing Company, Inc., of Jersey City, should be reorganized under Section 77b of the Federal Bankruptcy Act was aired today in Federal Court before Judge Guy L. Fake.

A high temperature of 93.4 degrees yesterday gave New York City its hottest day of the year and, while the humidity average was not as high as on several occasions in the past month, it was so high in the warmest hours that the Weather Bureau admitted the city probably suffered its most uncomfortable period of the Summer.

Miss Jane Bulkley Welch, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dean Welch of this place, will be married to Francis Edgar Clifford of Arlington, son of Mrs. John R. Clifford and the late Mr. Clifford of Fairport, N. Y., on Oct. 1. at the home of her parents.

Although most of the principal foreign currencies continued to creep lower yesterday in relation to the dollar, a lull developed in the demand for gold in the London bullion market. The takings at the time of price-fixing in London amounted to only $5,157,750,

State Senator Perley A. Pitcher, Republican floor leader at the Constitutional Convention, announced after a party conference late tonight that he had the necessary eighty-five votes lined up to pass the Republican reapportionment proposal. The debate on the measure is scheduled to start tomorrow on the general orders calendar.

The directors of the Canadian Industrial Alcohol Company, Ltd., announced today that the offer made to them by Hiram Walker-Gooderham Worts, Ltd., to exchange 100 shares each of C. I. A. Class A and B stocks for eleven preferred and three common shares of Hiram Walker had been withdrawn.

Five years ago Jack Hagen, veteran pro, caused a mild sensation in golf circles by scoring an ace a hole-in-one competition. Since then just two others have duplicated this unusual feat in The World-Telegram's annual tournament.

The widespread determination of retailers to hold down Fall purchases, and the absence of appreciable reorders, have failed thus far to bring any weakness in merchandise markets, and buyers yesterday said they expected the price trend in most lines to hold steady for the Fall season.

Gerald Balding, who has been named field captain of next year's British international polo team and was recently raised to a ten-goal rating on the British handicap list, arrived yesterday on the French liner Normandie to join the polo colony on Long Island that is preparing for next month's championship.
Connecticut will not recognize the Reno-divorce of Harold V. Harris, Bridgeport attorney, John W. Banks, State referee, indicated in a report filed in the Superior Court today.

Forty thousand Belgian soldiers were massed along the German frontier tonight for manoeuvres. The Belgian war games, along both The Netherlands and German borders, will begin tomorrow and continue through Aug. 22.

Politics split the committee investigating the Tennessee Valley Authority at today's session when Republicans and Democrats clashed over a plan of the Democratic majority to postpone public hearings on the power question, especially the TVA yardstick rates, until after the Congressional elections.

Be cause of military activities and prevailing adverse factors, the outlook in the cigarette trade of Central China is not reassuring at present, according to a report received today by the Department of Commerce from the American Commercial Attach at Shanghai.
The German Fall manoeuvres, which are officially termed manoeuvress in small units" but which have created a new war scare both within Germany and abroad, began as scheduled promptly at dawn today.

The War Ministry communique again tonight brought the news that the Loyalist lines were holding on every Spanish front. Barcelona government circles feel still easier about Estremadura, in Southwestern Spain, where Loyalist reinforcements are reported now firmly in line and the terrain is said to be well fortified.

The Metropolitan Golf Association held its annual caddy and caddy masters' championship at the Inwood Country Club today, with the Fairfield titleholder, Robert Walsh of Brooklawn, in Connecticut, taking the caddy honors and Victor Conte of Westchester Hills the masters laurels.
The mechanical coin bank that rewards depositors with some amusing action was not invented by an ingenious Yankee, but was known to the Chinese about 2,000 years ago.
The Cold Spring Harbor crew finished first in the opening race of a series of five for the junior championship of Long Island Sound off this port today.

Professor Oliver J. Caldwell was reunited with his wife here today after a three weeks' journey from China. Professor Caldwell was head of the English department of Nanking University for three years.

A few strictly choice and prime medium weight and weighty steers sold steady early, but the rank and file of fed steers, yearlings and heifers were 15 to 25 cents lower with instances where more loss was apparent at the close, the United States Department of Agriculture reports.

A series of bulletins containing specific suggestions on organizing local campaigns is being prepared by the National Retail Dry Goods Association for the use of stores in the "great national retail demonstration" which will be staged late next month.
Canadian National Railways officials said today that seven climbers in two strings had scaled Mount Robson, 12,972-foot peak that reaches higher than any other in the Canadian Rockies, this weekend.
Sebastian Fazetta, 72 years old, of 89 Monroe Street, was struck and killed by a hit-and-run driver about 10 o'clock last night as he was crossing South Street near Jefferson Street.

Dr. Frank A. Gough, orthodontist, died early yesterday at Northeast, Pa., where he was spending the Summer. Dr. Gough, who had been in ill health for several months, was 66 years old and maintrained offices at 184 Joralemon Street, Brooklyn.
Authorities here tonight were trying to find relatives of Goodman A. Benson, 67, railroad signalman, who died in his signal tower here Saturday with $5,500 in his clothing. Coroner Rodney C.
Some very soft spots have developed in the gypsy bride market. A dispatch from Belgrade, Yugoslavia, says the top quotation at the
Pontiac dealers in the United States reduced their used car stocks from 40,240 on Jan. 1 to 22,825 on Aug. 1, H. J. Klingler, general manager of the General Motors division, announced yesterday.

The Associated Gas and Electric Corporation announced yesterday that the Federal Court for the Northern District of New York had dismissed a petition for the Northeastern Water Companies, Inc., to reorganize under the bankruptcy law.

The number of commercial and industrial failures in the United States for the week ended Aug. 11 was 221, which compares with 153 a year ago and 238 a week ago, according to figures released yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.
Huston Quin, attorney and former Mayor of Louisville, died yesterday at the Norton Infirmary at the age of 62.

The Reds scored six runs in the seventh and ninth innings today to come from behind and humble the Pirates, National League leaders, 6 to 2. The defeat cut Pittsburgh's lead over the idle Giants. who are in second place, to four games.
Huston Quin, attorney and former Mayor of Louisville, died yesterday at the Norton Infirmary at the age of 62.

The Reds scored six runs in the seventh and ninth innings today to come from behind and humble the Pirates, National League leaders, 6 to 2. The defeat cut Pittsburgh's lead over the idle Giants. who are in second place, to four games.

Broadening of the base for income taxes to produce additional Federal revenue was pictured today as a probable necessity by Senator Harrison, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, if business did not improve by the first of next year.

Playoffs in the Wall Street Soft Ball League will be held at Innisfail Park today, Thursday and next Tuesday, with the ultimate winner to meet the champion of the LaSalle Street Soft Ball Association of Chicago in New York on Sept. 10.

Zasu Pitts, in Hotel Savoy-Plaza, 5th Ave and 58th St. A. S. Rott. in 40 W 67th St; Sidney Levy, in 315 W.102d St; Charlotte Walker, in 23 W 73d St; Mrs. Mae Lutz. in 200 W 108th St; Apartment Renting Co, Inc, broker.

With J. Donald Budge, the national champion, who will make his first singles appearance of the American season here, among the entries, the twenty-second annual invitation tennis tournament of the Newport Casino started today.

Princess Juliana and Prince Bernhard left today on a ten-day automobile tour of Germany and Italy, leaving their baby daughter, Beatrix, behind with her grandmother, Queen Wilhelmina. They arrived tonight at Aachen, Germany, where Prince Bernhard's mother is taking treatments.

George Rublee, Washington lawyer and new director of the inter-governmental refugee committee, arrived in London today ready to seek concessions from Germany-and to offer compensation in return-on behalf of more than 600,000 future refugees.

3d Ave (11-2911), w s, 150 ft s of 171st St. 50x159; Covan Realty Corp to J. E. A. Realty Corp, 1,170 Bway; mtge, $30,000. 226th St (17-4862), n s, 225 ft w of Paulding Ave, 50x109; Nicholas Marinelli to Emma Marinelli, 953 E 226th St.

Operations in the steel industry are scheduled this week at 40.4 per cent of capacity, a gain of 1 point, or 2.5 per cent, over last week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. This is the highest rate since the week of Nov. 8, 1937, when the rate was 41 per cent.

The demolition of the grim old Postoffice Building on lower Broadway, the site of which is to be landscaped as part of City Hall Park, was begun officially yesterday afternoon, when Mayor La Guardia, assisted by Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick, ripped up with a crowbar a plank in the mailloading platform on the Mail Street side of the building.

More than 2,000 newspapers will be used to carry advertising for the $1,000,000 promotional program for the motion picture industry, scheduled to start the first week in September, according to Donahue Coe, Inc., advertising agency handling the preparation and placement of copy.

Announcement was made yesterday of the placing of many orders for steel and pipe. The United States Pipe and Foundry Company received a $175,000 order from Chicago; the Alco Products Division of American Lo comotive Company received an

BEHOLD the lordly Yankees, some parasangs ahead of their puffing pursuers in the American League race. In classical language, it looks like a shoo-in, a lead-pipe cinch. At that, the Ruppert Rifles only recently, began to fire in volleys. They held their own with the Indians when they were only campaigning as snipers.

The great American game of baseball that even children on the streets play with consummate ease was mangled by the experts of the New York chapter of the Baseball Writers-Association on their annual outing at the Crescent A. C. today.

Letters have been mailed to 5,000 manufacturers, soliciting bids on miscellaneous garments to be purchased by the WPA for distribution to the needy, it was announced yesterday by T. J. Forde, procurement officer for New York State.
Dr. Thomas Carlisle Hebb, Professor of Physics at the University of British Columbia since 1918 and head of the department since 1920, died today in a hospital here at the age of 59.

E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. declared yesterday an interim dividend of 75 cents a share, payable on Sept. 14, compared with dividends of 50 cents each paid on June 14 and March 14. The company received dividends on its General Motors investment equivalent to 22 1/2

The State National Guard's war game was set in motion early today when Major Gen. William N. Haskell, commander of the Blue army, made up of an imaginary reinforced brigade composed of 38,000 troops, organized his force into three columns on the Dutchess and Putnam County boundary line at Beacon and Wappinger Falls as the first move in the mimic war.

Automobile production eased further last week to what was estimated as the "low" for 1938. The factor for seasonal variation was lowered to 48.3, since the industry appears to be operating some six weeks ahead of last year's schedule.
By GEORGE P. SINNOTT 92d St. 314 W. 5-story dwelling. 20x110.1x irreg; 212 W 71st St Corp against Josephine B. Campbell; due, $34,929; to plaintiff for $10,000.

The investigation of alleged misrepresentation by certain financial institutions soliciting savings deposits accounts, ordered by John J. Bennett Jr., State Attorney General, will begin at 10:30 o'clock this morning.
The-police will-destroy 707 seized illegal slot machines, valued at $53,025, at the property clerk's storehouse, at the foot of Thirty-sixth Street, Brooklyn, beginning at 10 A. M. tomorrow.

Josef Hofmann, who appeared in an outdoor concert for the first time in his career at the Lewisohn Stadium last Tuesday night, returned for a second appearance, last night and again attracted an audience of 19,000.
Arthur George Swallow, retired New York exporter of hardware, died here today at his home at the age of 59. He was born in Brooklyn, a son of Joseph G. and Ada Reynolds Swallow.

Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Story Forest of Minneapolis have announced to friends here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lydia Mortimer Forest, to Louis Clark Grinnell, son of Mrs Maurice W. Grinnell of New York and the late Mr. Grinnell.

Wheat markets in North America were on the downgrade again today. Futures declined slowly to new low levels for the season, and closed at the bottom. Net losses on the Board of Trade here were 1 1/4 to 1 3/8cents a bushel.

Back at his desk after a week-end cruise down the Potomac, President Roosevelt conferred today with government officials on varied topics ranging from naval construction programs to administration of the Wages and Hours Law.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Aug. 12. REAR ADMIRAL Brinser, H. L., Washington, on Nov. 17, to duty as member General Board, Navy Dept., Washington, D. C.

Lord Carnarvon, who has been passing some time in Newport, is expected to arrive today at the St. Regis. Mr. and Mrs. John G. W. Husted have left the Pierre to go to their Summer place in New London, Conn.

Miss Dorothy Travis, 30 years old, was found dead of gas yesterday morning in an apartment she had sublet forty-eight hours before at 160 East Forty-eighth Street. The police listed the case as a suicide.

The century-old Colonial farmhouse with five acres of land on the Half Mile Road, Middletown Township, N. J., has been sold by Mrs. Robert Bedle to William Boland of Eatontown, it was reported yesterday by Ray H. Stillman, broker, who negotiated the deal.
Miss Jane Wyeth and Dr. Richard van Dyck Knight, whose engagement was announced in February, will be married here on Sept. 3 in Christ Church.

The Trace Call filly Spot News, owned by Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt, won again today in the thirty - sixth Kentucky Claiming Stakes, a five and a half furlong dash for juvenile fillies. She now has taken two in a row at Saratoga and gained a popular triumph as Raymond (Sonny) Workman rode her through the stretch first by two lengths at 18 to 5.
The Harris Trust and Savings Bank of Chicago received yesterday the award of a new issue of $200,000 of court house and bridge bonds of Greene County, N. Y., on a bid of 100.227 for 2s.

Senator Harrison of Mississippi took issue today with the authors of the report on conditions in the South which was issued last week by the National Emergency Council. Asked for comment on the report, which was highly critical, he said:

Today, for the second time, Lightweight Champion Lou Ambers ended training for his fifteen-round title defense against Henry Armstrong at Madison Square Garden Wednesday night. Amobers boxed two rounds against Slugger White,

Guy N. Collins, chief botanist for the United States Department of Agriculture's Bureau of Plant Industry, who introduced the avocado pear in this country, died yesterday at his home in Lanham, Md. He had just passed his sixty-sixth birthday anniversary.
Dispatches from Prague yesterday described the Czechs as waiting for provocation. Evidently the Germans are going to let them wait. The day set for "something -to happen" has passed without incident.

3d St, 131 W; Celestina De Lorenzo to Allesandro Rinaldi, 113 Thompson St; mtg $7,000 ($1). 5th St, 537-9 E; Adolklien Realties, Inc, Fred Straus. president, to Kurt Gruenbaum, Frankfort-on-the-Main, Germany (50 cents).

Perserverance again proved its value and Walter Frankenheimer of East Hampton, L. I., returned to his anchorage at Montauk Saturday with a 432-pound broadtail swordfish. For the past six weeks this angler has been putting out of Montauk, fair weather and foul,

The Constitutional Convention defeated tonight a motion by Lithgow Osborne, Conservation Commissioner, to discharge from the Committee on Highways, Parkways and Grade Crossings a proposal which would have permitted the Legislature to limit the erection of signboards and other advertising devices in the Adirondack and Catskill Parks and on the State's parkways and scenic highways.

Patrick Connor, who for many years was chief of the Weather Bureau in Kansas City, retiring in 1928, died here today at his home after an illness of six weeks. He was born in Dublin, Ireland, eightyone years ago.
The Maple Leafs lost the seven-inning twilight part of a scheduled double-header with the Newark Bears tonight, 6 to 4.

While the value of residential contracts awarded during July rose as compared with the same month last year, that of all types of construction dropped considerably, a report issued yesterday by the F. W. Dodge Corporation disclosed.

Two mysteries, each connected with the Police Department, were presented yesterday, but left unsolved, by Mayor La Guardia. The first developed at 10 A. M., when the Mayor arrived at police headquarters, Manhattan, for an unexpected visit.

An exhibition of work by artists of the New York State and New Jersey Federal Art Projects (exclusive of New York City) opened yesterday afternoon with a preview at the Federal Art Gallery, 225 West Fifty-seventh Street, and will be open to the public, beginning today, until Sept. 8.

Sumner Welles, Under-Secretary of the Department of State, sailed on the Holland America liner Nieuw Amsterdam yesterday accompanied by his family. He said he would be away about two and a half weeks and had planned the short trip solely for a badly needed rest.

The Canadian Pacific liner Duchess of Atholl, her bow slightly damaged above the waterline, was on her way to New York from Montreal last night after having been in collision early yesterday morning with the freighter Domby, near Father Point,

Careless of men as the gods of Epicurus, the weather-bosses went on too long a picnic, sitting on cakes of ice and claret-cupping. In charge of the works they left a 'prentice urchin, highbrow, pragmatical, curious, earnest and absent-minded.

The fifth annual "campaign to consumers" of the Advertising Association of Great Britain is now under way. Copy is appearing in all the London and provincial morning and afternoon newspapers and those provincial weeklies which are affiliated with the association.

Good pitching by Howie Krist, Bob Bowman and Nubs Kleinke netted the Red Wings a double victory over Jersey City tonight, 6-2 and 5-2. Kleinke's eight-hit performance in the nightcap netted the Bladesmen their ninth twin triumph of the season and their thirty-ninth victory of the home campaign.

Mrs. Harry L. Hamlin gave a dinner tonight at the Hedges Inn for Kenneth Chorley of New York, Amagansett, and Williamsburg, Va. Mrs. Shepard Krech was hostess today at the tea which opened the exhibition of oil paintings by Nan Greacen in the Marjorie Woodhouse Gallery at Guild Hall.

In a doubleheader interrupted four times by rain, the Cardinals made it two out of three victories in the series against the Cubs that ended with an even break today. St. Louis won the second game, 5 to 2, after Chicago had come from behind to take the opener, 5 to 4, in eleven innings.

Miss Blanche Goodell of Ecorse, Mich., daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles C. Goodell of Sturgis, Mich., was married to the Rev. Percival C. Bailey of Springdale, Conn., today in St. Steven's Episcopal Church here. The Rev. Bates G. Burt of Pontiac officiated.

Charges of kidnapping under the Lindbergh Law were filed today against two former convicts who were captured last night in Northern Minnesota, accused of the abduction of a St. Paul society girl and her escort.
Pedro Montanez, 136, Puerto Rico, was credited with a knockout victory over Ray Napolitano, 143 1/4, Williamsburg, last night in their listed ten-round feature tussle at the Queensboro Arena when

Thirty-one men and women, accused of allowing their dogs to be on the streets unmuzzled, were fined $2 each yesterday by Magistrate Blanchfield in Coney Island Court, Brooklyn. The magistrate read to the defendants two newspaper clippings, one of Which related that five persons had been bitten by dogs in Queens.

The report of Sears, Roebuck ?? for the twenty-four weeks ended on July 16 shows a consolidated net profit of $7,118,888 after depreciation, interest, special reserves, contribution to the employes' savings and profit-sharing pension fund and normal Federal income taxes.
The report of the Detroit Edison Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on July 31, issued yesterday, show's a net income of $7,061,190 after all operating expenses, taxes and charges.
While some nervousness still gripped the gold market yesterday, there was a respite for a second day from the panicky buying which has characterized the London market in the last two weeks.

Secretary Hull proposed in an internationally broadcast address tonight the adoption by all nations of a seven-point program based on "world law and international order," which he said was essential to check and reverse the present ominous drift toward international anarchy and armed conflict.
Dr. Reynal Hyman Chase, 30 years old, a New York City physician, surrendered to the District Attorney's office here today under an indictment charging him with being a "consort to bigamy."

A general pick-up in business during the Fall months is expected by approximately 98 per cent of the retailers answering in a survey made by the National Retail Dry Goods Association among typical department and specialty stores throughout the country, the association reported yesterday.

Problems of the consumer and producer will have a major place on the discussion agenda at the nineteenth annual meeting of the American Trade Association Executives, to be held in Pittsburgh Sept. 22, 23 and 24, according to the program made public yesterday.

Apparently deserted by their mother, according to the police, a year-old baby boy and a 3-weeks-old baby girl were found yesterday in a meagerly furnished, two-room apartment at 249 East Eighty-fourth Street under the care of a 12-yearold girl, who received 25 cents yesterday to care for them.

Smaller supplies gave a better tone to the cattle market today, and scarcity strengthened prices on strictly choice and prime medium-weight and weighty steers, the United States Department of Agriculture reports. The top moved up 10 cents to $12.60.

Adolph Fitz, a classified advertising salesman for THE NEW YORK TIMES and an employee of this organization for twelve years, died Monday afternoon in Evangelical Deaconess Hospital, Brooklyn, after an operation for peritonitis, the result of a stomach ulcer. Mr.

The special Senate Campaign Investigating Committee decided today that if a letter, over Senator Guffey's signature, soliciting contributions for the Pennsylvania State Democratic Committee, was sent at the direction of a federal official or employee, it constituted a violation of the Federal Criminal Code.

Temporary Assignments PATROLMEN--Charles Thomas, 32d Precinct. assigned to duty in plain clothes in precinct for 16 days, from 8 A. M., Aug. 16. Anthony F. Becker, from Traffic Precinct P to 19th Division, duty in Raided Premises Squad for 15 days, from 8 A. M., Aug. 17.

State's Attorney J. Bernard Wells announced today at conclusion of the injunction suit brought by the Securities and Exchange Commission against William P. Lawson, self-suspended Police Commissioner, that evidence in the case would be presented to the grand jury probably tomorrow.

Three residences in various parts of Westchester County figured in sales reported yesterday. The new one-family dwelling at 111 Bajart Place, Yonkers, was sold by the C. D. Building Corporation to Samuel Gattegno. Lester A. Kent was the attorney for the seller and Sidney Zneimer represented the purchaser.

Middlesex stayed in line with the pace-making Yorkshire eleven in English county cricket today with a 263-run victory over Somerset. The White Rose County had defeated Leicestershire by an innings and 141 runs yesterday.
Thousands of North Shore commuters had to find new means of traveling to and from Chicago today as a strike, called early this morning, shut off their regular methods of transportation.

Letellier-Phillips Paper Company, Inc., New Orleans, La., was ordered by the Federal Trade Commission today to cease and desist from certain alleged unfair methods of competition which tend to give it a monopoly in the buying and selling of waste paper, rags and other waste materials in Southern States.

The First Avenue boys and girls in the vicinity of Twenty-first Street, who have been feeling the oppressive heat and who are without a street sprinkler on their street, staged a sit-down strike yesterday afternoon in an effort to bring the matter to the attention of Mayor La Guardia, whom they wish to see.
Breaking smoothly and swiftly, Esposa went right to the front today in the thirty-sixth Champlain Handicap and never left the result in doubt for the whole of the mile and a furlong.

The PWA passed the 4,000 mark today in approved projects under the 1938 Relief-Recovery Act when Harold L. Ickes announced Presidential approval of eighty-nine additional projects with an estimated construction cost of $19,280,839, involving PWA loans of $95,500 and grants of $8,676,368.

The Summer session of the WPA adult education program of the Board of Education will close today with a new record for attendance Activities will be suspended until the Fall term, which will open on Sept. 12.

William H. Terry, manager of the New York Giants, moved a step nearer possession of the estate "Annswood" today when Magistrate W. J. Bacon granted him a writ of forcible entry and detainer against Clarence Saunders.

Bonds maintained a steady to firm undertone and closed higher in slightly more active trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The turnover was $4,426,000, compared with $3,203,500 on Monday.

William F. McGuinness, suspended assistant district attorney, and George Murphy, suspended court elevator starter, were formally arraigned yesterday in the Brooklyn Court of Special Sessions on a charge of conspiracy to obstruct justice. Both entered pleas of not guilty and the trial was set down for Sept. 6. In the meantime the defendants are continued in $5,000 bail.

The pick-aback seaplane Mercury, which was launched in midair by the flyingboat Maia, is to attempt a non-stop flight of more than seven thousand miles, and accordingly her second transatlantic flight with the mails, arranged for this week, has been postponed.

The increase in the benefits- to be paid wheat growers by the Government, from this year's 12 cents a bushel to 26 to 30 cents in 1939, reflects the concern of the Administration over the prospect of a large surplus from this year's crop and the accompanying low prices.

Thomas E. Dewey, New York County District Attorney, asked the Supreme Court today to let stand the conviction of Charles (Lucky Luciano) Lucania and five others sent to prison two years ago in a vice drive.

The right of the courts to review decisions and rulings of the State Athletic Commission was raised yesterday in Supreme Court when John Henry Lewis, Negro boxer formerly recognized here as the world's light heavyweight champion, asked that a commission ruling vacating his title be reversed.
Several interesting deals have just been concluded in the West Side section of Manhattan. Through John J. Meenan, Inc., brokers, the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank has sold to an

Formation of the New York Stock Exchange firm of Elfast, Frisk Co., to transact a complete brokerage business in the United States and in Europe was announced yesterday. It has offices in the Rockefeller Center here and in Stockholm, Sweden.

Isaac R. Halliday has been appointed president of the Stock Clearing Corporation to succeed Lawrence G. Payson, resigned. The New York Stock Exchange also announced yesterday the appointment of Ivan Wright to its executive staff.
All the seeded players, including several from the New York district, reached the third round in the national tennis tournament for Negro players on the Lincoln University courts today.
The Athletics fell on young Jim Bagby for five runs in the first inning today and eventually scored nine times more to beat the Red Sox, 14 to 11, before a perspiring gathering of 1,800 persons.

With the German military manoeuvres arousing uneasiness here, it became known today that the construction of strategic roads in Bessarabia and Bukovina, envisaged by the general staff years ago, was now to be carried out.

Senator Clark of Missouri declared tonight that attempts in the last session of the Senate "to set up indi met with "such universal opposition that their passage seems impossible." He spoke on the Constitution at the convention of the Knights of Columbus.
Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh landed in their black and orange monoplane at the Warsaw airport tonight on a surprise flight from Britain to Moscow by way of Hanover, Germany.
Noting that home sales have continued at a brisk pace during the Summer months, the Queens County Savings Bank reported yesterday a number of sales of such properties.
By agreement with the Civil Service Commission and with the approval of the President, the Tariff Commission has put practically its entire expert personnel under civil service rules.
Hector Poirier, a machinist for THE NEW YORK TIMES for the last nineteen years, died Monday in his home at 32-23 Jordan Street, Bayside West, Queens. He was 62 years old.

Through its good neighbor policy the United States has made a definite contribution to world peace by changing the picture which the nations to the south formerly had of us as "a rather bullying big brother," Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt told the Second World Youth Congress meeting at Vassar College tonight.
A report of strong sentiment in the West for a third term for President Roosevelt brought renewed discussion among politicians today of the possibility he may run.

Governor Lehman has requested Borough President James J. Lyons to submit to him the names of three men to serve on an unofficial commission to study the feasibility of reopening the New York, Westchester Boston Railroad, it was learned yesterday.
Final arrangements for the meeting of the maturity on Jan. 1 of its outstanding 4 1/2 per cent convertible debentures have been completed by the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.

The International Harvester Company cut operations sharply today at its Chicago tractor works and its Milwaukee plant. The Milwaukee plant was closed in July but reopened Aug. 1 with about 4,000 employes. The curtailment reduced the force to about 700.

Hearings on a petition of a group of preferred stockholders of the Reynolds Investing Company, Inc., of Jersey City, on a plan to reorganize the concern Were put off today by Federal Judge Guy Fake until Sept. 20.

Joseph J. Mooney, chairman of the executive committee of the board of directors of the Brooklyn Federal Savings and Loan Association, died on Monday at his home, 751 Westminster Road, Brooklyn, at the age of 78.
Chuck Klein's single off Milt Shoffner in the eleventh inning scored Hershel Martin from second with the run that gave the Phillies an uphill 7-to-6 victory over the Bees today.
Spanish Government reinforcements in troops and artillery were reported tonight to have blocked, at least temporarily, the Insurgent drive on the Almaden mercury mining center.

A reduction in the rate of interest to be paid on the Baltimore Ohio Railroad's outstanding bonds was discussed yesterday by the directors in the light of its obligations to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.
Jack Hagen, 58-year-old Oceanside pro, is 1938 hole-in-one champion of New York golfers, as he was in 1933. Five years ago he won The World Telegram ace tournament with an ace.
The navy disclosed today that seven men were killed in three accidents to naval aircraft in the San Diego area yesterday. Earlier announcements had put the total of deaths as five.

St. Louis tempers, inclined to be a little short in the Summer anyway because of the heat that often blankets the Mississippi, are shorter than usual now because the City Art Museum has recently paid $14,000 for a bronze cat. Persons on relief and others have found fault with the purchase of the Egyptian figure,
A modern hotel is being constructed on Obersalzberg to house Chancellor Hitler's personal guests. It will be connected with the main motor road, 300 feet below, by an elevator.

The Securities and Exchange Commission entered Attorney General John J. Bennett's investigation of solicitation of deposits from residents of New York State by alleged misrepresentations on the part of local agencies for out-of-State banks when the inquiry opened yesterday in the State Office Building, 80 Centre Street.
Political prejudices, fixed opinions, business worries and personal worries of talesmen impeded the selection of the jury yesterday to try James J. Hines.

The juvenile "racket" of unsolicited windshield wiping, on which police have "cracked down" several times in recent years, has reappeared in the last two months on a number of fronts throughout the city,

Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain, after visiting his nose specialist with Lord Horder, physician of King George, left London today to resume his vacation, but this time he has not gone so far afield as Scotland, whence he returned unexpectedly last week.
John Frederick Godigkeit, chief of the North Merrick Fire Department since January, died today at the York Hospital, Manhattan, after a long illness at the age of 32.

Steel-ingot output last week held to the previous week's level, although a nominal easing was indicated seasonally. The adjusted index rose to 59.4, a new high since the week ended Nov. 13, 1937, compared with 59.3 for the preceding week and 128.7 for the week ended Aug. 14, 1937.

A third "Nationally Advertised Brands Week" will be celebrated Nov. 5 to 12, when limited price chain stores throughout the country add their efforts to those of the food and drug field in promoting advertised products.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Aug. 14: LIEUTENANTS, COLONELS Cook, E. L., Med. Corps, one month and sixteen days' leave. Sept. 14. Summers, I. B., Adjutant General's Dept., four days' leave, Aug. 21.

Dr. Allen Knight Chalmers of New York, chairman of the Scottsboro Defense Committee, went before the State Board of Pardons today to request that the five remaining prisoners in the sevenyear-old case be liberated into the committee's custody but encountered an unexpected complication.

EARLY in the Summer a friend whose judgment is usually trustworthy sent me a note about as follows: "When the d-v-l are you going to wake up and read James R. Ullman's 'The Other Side of the Mountain'? Even if it already is a couple of months. old, it is good readingcertainly a lot better than some of the current works you've been reporting in the c-l-mn."

An investigation to determine the reasons for the sudden closing of Williams, Bailey Benjamin, 1 Wall Street, over-the-counter securities dealers, on July 27 has been started by Attorney General Bennett, it was disclosed yesterday.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Aug. 13: COMMANDERS Reinecke, F. G., Fourth Naval Dist., to the Capella and in command when commissioned. Fortescue. T. A., Med. Corps, to duty First Naval Dist., instead Norfolk, Va.

Few changes in general business conditions were noted in reports from a number of countries issued by the Department of Commerce today. Slack trading and manufacturing schedules were offset in part, however, by the effects of armament orders, public works programs and agricultural improvement.

Mrs. Emma Wyman Chase Colligan, who appeared with Maurice Barrymore, Mrs. Patrick Campbell, Mrs. Leslie Carter and other great actors, died last night in her home here. She was the wife of Walter E. Colligan.
Miss Yssabella Gertrude Waters, a former executive of the Henry Street Settlement in New York for thirty years, died at her home here tonight after a brief illness.

Edward Cook Moore Jr., retired lawyer and brother of John C. Moore, president of Tiffany Co., left a net estate of $2,171,814 when he died on Aug. 15, 1937, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday. His brother is the principal beneficiary.

William A. Bayless Jr. has been named to represent the International Textbook Company, Scranton, Pa., on the West Coast and in the Middle West, succeeding Lawrence W. Tice, who becomes assistant manager of the college textbook department.

A blue ribbon jury, made up chiefly of men of business and containing a lone registered Democrat, was completed yesterday in Supreme Court for the trial of James J. Hines, Tammany district leader, on the charge that he was a part of the late Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer policy racket.

The fact should not be overlooked that the Republican party, which only a year ago was protesting vigorously and properly against a proposal at Washington to pack the courts, is now busily engaged at Albany in packing the Legislature. There is no other way to describe accurately the proposed reapportionment amendment on which debate was begun yesterday in the Constitutional Convention.

Robert Whalen, Democrat of Albany, sponsor of a clause on administrative law for the new Constitution which is opposed by Governor Lehman, Senator Wagner and others, issued a reply today to Senator Wagner's criticism of his proposal.
