The offering, scheduled for next week, of about $72,250,000 of securities of the Commonwealth Edison Company will pave the way for one of the largest public-utility refunding operations of the year, it was disclosed yesterday.

The Census Bureau reported today that cotton consumed in July amounted to 449,511 bales of lint and 61,805 bales of linters, compared with 442,742 and 56,106 in June this year and 583,011 and 70,695 in July of last year.

President Getulio Vargas is the author of a book, "Brazil's New Policy," soon to be released. It is a five-volume work, in which President Vargas reviews Brazil's political history, especially since 1930, when he became President.

Twenty-two cooperative milk producer associations have qualified to vote in the New York Milk Market Referendum on Thursday, Friday and Saturday of this week, the Agricultural Adjustment Administration announced today.

More than 5,000 knitgoods workers in the metropolitan area and New Jersey, members of the Knitgoods Workers Union, Local 155, will stop work at 10 A. M. today to attend a series of mass meetings called by the union to ratify a new agreement with the United Knitwear Manufacturers League.

Several of the high-goal players who are on teams entered for the open championship which brings the polo season to its climax next month took part in two members' games at the Meadow Brook Club today.

The Radley College crew of Abingdon, near Oxford, England, arrived here yesterday aboard the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania for its eight-oared race against Tabor Academy at Marion, Mass., next Wednesday.
" Bachelor Born," the first play to be presented by the Forty Niners at the same time as its Broadway run, opened here tonight at the Chase Barn Playhouse.

The possibility that a single board may be appointed to study conditions in all textile industries for use of Commissioner Elmer F. Andrews in putting into force the Wages and Hours Act was discussed among textile merchants and trade association officials yesterday, and it was predicted that such a development would create numerous problems.

The Constitutional Convention adopted today an amendment to the Poletti water power proposal which virtually nullified its aims and then refused, by a 76 to 73 vote, to advance the amended measure to third reading.

The marriage of Miss Margaret Louise Alexander, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Alexander of this place and New York, to Hans F. Frese of New York, took place here today at the home of the bride's parents.

The Wyatt Earp, base ship of the projected expedition which Lieut. Commander Lincoln Ellsworth will lead to Enderby Land, an unexplored area of 750,000 square miles in the Antarctic region, sailed yesterday at 12:30 P. M. from the seaplane base at Floyd Bennett Airport for Cape Town, South Africa.

Bearish sentiment which has prevailed in the grain trade for several geeks received today a severe jolt on the AAA announcement that it would increase substantially the total benefit payments to farmers in an effort to bring about compliance with the 1939 wheat and corn acreage reduction campaign.

A proposal to consolidate the Chicago North Western Railway Company and the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad Company into a new and closely integrated system has been laid before the managements of both roads for comment before formal submission to the Interstate Commerce Commission, it was learned today.
A group of Kansas legislators told the Supreme Court today that the proposed child labor amendment "had lost its potency by reason of old age."
The Spanish Government has overcome what threatened to be a serious internal crisis, it was announced early today, with the resignation of two members of the Cabinet.
Miss Elizabeth Dehnert, one of the few remaining charter members of Christ Church, on East Nineteenth Street, died on Monday at her home, 324 Cornelia Street, Brooklyn, in her eighty-eighth year.

15th St. 207 E, 36.3x103.3: Woodlawn Cemetery to Clarence M. Weil, 305 73d St, Brooklyn: p m mtg, $49,000 ($45). 33d St, 403 W, 27x19.9; Bertha C. Desraismes to 682 6th Ave Corp, 137 W 116th. St ($3). 38th St, 130 E. 20x24.9; Harry I. Phillips, indiv and as executor, Mary G. Phillips to Mary E. T. Corr, 35 E 39th St; mtg, $12,500 ($7.50).

Startling upsets by a pair of unseeded San Francisco girls and Miss Nancye Wynne, 21, of Australia, featured today's play as the fourteenth annual Essex County Club women's invitation tennis tournament moved into the quarter-final round.
A reorganization plan for the Chicago Great Western Railroad which reduces the railroad's capitalization by about $76,900,000 was approved today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

Taking the witness stand at his own request before the Congressional investigating committee, Senator George L. Berry defended himself today against charges of bad faith in pressing his marble claims against the TVA.
The reports of twelve commercial paper dealers to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York show a total of $210,700,000 Of open-market paper was outstanding on July 31.
Stocks closed moderately higher, in quiet trading; turnover, 614,300 shares. United States Government issues higher; other bonds steady and mixed; transactions, $4,426,000.

A sharp note of protest from International Settlement authorities today accused Japanese of having participated in terrorist activities throughout the Settlement last week-end. The note directed special attention to three incidents:...
Although defeated for the first time today, P. M. List of Berlin, one of the German representatives, held first place in Section A of the British Chess Federation's international tournament.

The German Bishops Conference, which began yesterday under the presidency of Cardinal Bertram of Breslau, will be in session until Friday. Cardinal von Faulhaber of Munich and Cardinal Schulte of Cologne are attending, as are all the other members of the German Bishops College excepting the Archbishop of Paderborn, who was detained by illness.

A few important events focused political attention here today. They were the unexpected return of President Eduard Benes from his country residence to confer with Viscount Runciman, unofficial British mediator; Lord Runciman's talk with Sudeten party delegates and the meeting of the Supreme Defense Council.

As a concrete indication of the improved relations with Brazil the United States is receiving "sight exchange" against importation of goods, whereas the best terms other countries get are ninety to 120 days, George F. Baumeister, vice, president of Ulen Co., said yesterday on his return from the South American republic.

Among those reported yesterday as having signed contracts, for residential space was John L, Clark, president of the Transamerican Broadcasting and Television Corporation, who leased an apartment at 2 Beekman Place through Butt, Gilliam McVay, Inc.; broker, and Albert B. Ashforth, Inc., agent.

Senator Gillette, opposed by a White House favorite - Representative Wearin - in Iowa, found it winning strategy to pretend that the President was neutral, despite the pro-Wearin activity of his son-secretary, Administrator Hopkins, Thomas G. Corcoran and others.
Wentworth Byron Winslow, a Christian Science healer in New York for thirty years, died Monday at his home, 80 Ibis Street, Forest Hills, Queens, at the age of 57.

Kermit Hurst, 21 years old, hanged himself yesterday morning in his room at the William Sloane House of the Y. M. C. A., 356 West Thirty-fourth Street, after writing a note that said: "I am tired of it all.

Edward H. Thiesing, Cincinnati pharmacist, died at his home today at the age of 78. Mr. Thiesing was graduated from the Cincinnati College of Pharmacy in 1880 and opened his first store in 1884. He retired in 1922.

Minimum prices which will be guaranteed to Western growers by the Canadian Wheat Board on grades other than No. 1 Northern (already fixed at 80 cents a bushel) were approved today by the Dominion Government on recommendation of the board.

The customary orders granting furloughs to Jewish soldiers and sailors for observance of Rosh haShanah and Yom Kippur have been issued by the War and Navy Deapartments, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Cyrus Adler.

In a program of songs that leaned rather heavily on sentiment, twentytwo boys and girls, the latter ineluding neighborhood prima donnas, competed yesterday afternoon in the Manhattan finals of the children's amateur singing contest held in Washington Square Park under the auspices of the Park Deapartment.

The complete list of the Hines jury with brief sketches of the members follows: No. 1.-Elliott R. Brown of 780 Madison Avenue, foreman of the jury, is a security salesman with Green, Ellis Anderson, 100 Broadway.

Griffith Stadium was a very disordered place today while the onrushing Yankees flattened the Senators in both ends of a double-header and increased their first-place lead over the Indians to eight full games.

Bertha Ambunn, 42 years old, here only a few months from Germany, leaped to death from the seventh floor of the apartment house at 225 West Eighty-sixth Street, according to police, just after 2 P. M. yesterday.
Mayor La Guardia mopped a perspiring face and Police Commissioner Valentine squirmed uncomfortably on the police bench-a combination of the heat and foreboding.

Leaders of the Constitutional Convention have set Friday as the day on which to end their labors. On the following Thursday the delegates will return to Albany, clerks will drone through the old and the proposed new sections of the State's basic law, and the convention will adjourn sine die on the following day.

A danger of civil war among Jews in Palestine was envisioned here tonight by Vladimir Jabotinsky, leader of Zionist Revisionists, extremist group, in the most sensational declaration made at the "Emergency Conference" of Zionists being held here. Not only in Palestine, he said, "but also abroad there now exists the great menace of civil war between Jews.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Aug. 16, unless specified: New London to New York via West Point, 'Aug. 19: Badger, Decatur, Fairfax, Herbert, Leary, J. F. Talbott. At Navy Yard, Washington: Milan, Aug. 15; Kewaydin.

Howie Yeager, unheralded when he came into the New York Football Giants' camp yesterday, was the talk of the squad at the end of the double drill today. Despite the intensive heat, the ' Giants spent over five hours on the field in their first full day at the Blue Hill Country Club, where they are preparing for the clash with the Eastern allstars in the Polo Grounds on Sept. 7.
Among the East Side properties reported yesterday as having changed.-hands was the four-story building at 1,109 Lexington Avenue, near Seventy-seventh Street.

The daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,359,900 barrels, compared with 3,317,850 in the previous week, an increase of 42,050, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

Douglas Corrigan, wearing his famous leather jacket, paid a short visit to the Constitutional Convention tonight and received a warm welcome from the delegates, who interrupted a debate on the reapportionment proposal to greet him.

Princess Herzeleide, granddaughter of former Kaiser Wilhelm, was married to Prince Charles Biron de Courland today in the Potsdam garrison church with many of Germany's former royal family in attendance.
Broadway, Fourth and Fifth Avenues furnished the major share of the leasing contracts announced yesterday. Among the rentals was one involving a large store in the

A field of 132 took part in the seventh semi-annual tournament of the Eastern Men's Apparel Golf Association at Winged Foot today, with principal honors going to Julian Frankel of the Goodall Company.

Three policemen and two other men charged with taking part in a scheme to defraud three furriers of $14,800 by an offer to sell nonexistent furs were named yesterday by the Kings County Grand Jury in an indictment charging six counts of grand larceny and three of conspiracy.

The stock market here was quiet and generally dull today, and most sections lost ground. Gilt-edge issues sagged, while foreign bonds were weaker for the most part. Transatlantic stocks reflected Wall Street's lethargy and prices were set back.
The Constitutional Convention again rejected today the Hirschberg proposal that the ban on gambling be removed from the State Constitution.
Formation of a General Council for Jewish Rights was announced jointly yesterday by the American Jewish Committee, the American Jewish Congress, the B'nai B'rith and the Jewish Labor Committee.

Three United States-owned agrarian properties, comprising 5,055 acres, have been expropriated in addition to one already reported since President Lazaro Cardenas refused to arbitrate on indemnity payments for American lands already seized.

The Ohio Oil Company has called for redemption on Sept. 15 at $110 a share 30 per cent of all the issued and outstanding shares of its 6 per cent preferred stock pro rata from holders of record on Aug. 15, or their assigns, it was announced yesterday.

The Horn Hardart Company yesterday opened a new Automat at 102-6 West Fifty-seventh Street. A plot with fifty-five feet of frontage there was purchased by the Horn Hardart Company through Tankoos, Smith Co., and improved with a two-story restaurant building which is air-conditioned.

In a quiet sort of way Philip Dunning has for several months been nursing plans for a show unlike any other that comes to mind. It would consist of scenes from eight or ten memorable Broadway plays of recent years-the first scene of "Once in a Lifetime," for instance, and excerpts from "Within the Law" and "One Sunday Afternoon."
Karl Karch of Bayside, preparing for the National Public Links championship at Cleveland next week, today shot a par 72 at Seawane to capture low gross in the Long Island oneday amateur tournament.

The "newspaper decision" in the first round of the Democratic Senatorial primary fight in Georgia goes to Senator George. This was the overwhelming verdict of State observers today as they took another glance at the rising thermometer and looked for the most hotly contested political race since the days of Tom Watson.
The Church of the Most Holy Rosary of Jersey City, N. J., has awarded the contract for erection of a two-story school and auditorium building to the D'Elia Building Company of Jersey City.

Leslie HoreBelisha, British War Secretary, continued today his campaign to modernize the British Army by retiring thirteen general officers to make room at the top for men schooled in the compact, mobile army of today.
The tiring Pirates called out the reserves today, shook themselves out of a slump and behind the steady pitching of Cy Blanton whitewashed the slugging Reds, 10 to 0.
The National Retail Credit Association reported today average decreases in collections, credit sales and total sales in forty-two cities during July, as compared with the same month last year.
Could joy be had in Sicily? Or peace in far Cathay? Could happiness be found, should I Who've chartered a green dragon fly Turn his swift course that way? In what bright land could hope be found?
After dipping below the mandatory loan level of 8 1/4 cents a pound on Monday, prices on the Cotton Exchange rallied 10 points yesterday and ended with gains of 6 to 7 points.
The army reported today that bandits had been dispersed in the State of Durango by troops of the Fortieth Battalion who killed the leader, Rosendo Rodriguez, who was described as "an assassin."
Following is the text of the radio address of Secretary Hull: All nations have a primary interest in peace with justice, in economic well-being with stability, and in conditions of order under law.

Shortly before the deadline at 12 o'clock tonight for the filing of petitions for the Sept. 20 primary, David S. Murden of Peekskill entered the race for the Republican nomination for county president of Westchester by filing a petition its bearing 1,258 signatures.

Thousands assembled in Zagreb station today to give an enthusiastic welcome to Vladimir Matchek, Croat leader, on his return from Belgrade, where he conferred with leaders of the Serbian democratic opposition.

Elmer F. Andrews, former Industrial Commissioner of New York State, was sworn in at noon today as Administrator of the new Wages and Hours Law in the presence of Secretary Frances Perkins and other Labor Department officials.

" Hotel Imperial," which Marlene Dietrich refused to do three years ago and which was subsequently shelved when Margaret Sullavan, who replaced Miss Dietrich, broke her arm, has been revived by Paramount, with the possibility that Isa Miranda may play the lead.
The players participating in the annual invitation tennis tournament at the Casino will be guests of honor tomorrow at a luncheon given by Mrs. Frederick Mitchell Gould at her home, Gould Villa.

While the thermometer inside Grant's Tomb hovers high in the eighties this week, elaborate and expensive plans are well under way to make that famous monument the first scientifically air-conditioned tomb to be found anywhere in the world.
Howland Spencer, who recently sold his Krum Elbow estate to followers of Father Divine, failed to appear before Judge J. Gordon Flannery of Dutchess County today to explain his financial condition.

Deluged with tear gas and allegedly jostled by a threatening crowd, a party of raiders led by Robert Furnell, private investigator for the Citizens Protective League, retreated after an attack on an alleged gambling and horse-race betting center on Pacific and Missouri Avenues here late today.

Announcement has been made of the marriage of Mrs. Edith Clarke Needles of Roanoke, Va., widow of Arthur Chase Needles and daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. William Edward Clarke of Omaha, Neb., to Edward Fleetford Sise of Montreal, which took place here Monday morning in the chantry of St. Thomas Church.
William Harvey J. Ely, State WPA Administrator and former State Senator from Bergen County, may become the Democratic candidate for election in November as United States Senator from New Jersey.
The House Committee Investigating Un-American Activities voted at an executive session late today to inquire immediately into charges that Labor Department officials had given "aid and advice"

Baroness Stina Gripenberg of Finland, who has completed a year's work at the Scripps Institute of Oceanography at La Jolla, Calif., on a fellowship from the American Association of University Women, described briefly the work she came to this country to do, at a tea yesterday in honor of three Finnish women, at headquarters of the New York Newspaper Women's Club, 22 East Thirty-eighth Street.

As the National Committee of the Communist party in the United States made public its 1938 election platform yesterday, the party's State Executive Committee formally ratified a slate of 110 candidates, including a full State ticket and candidates for legislative offices in all Greater New York districts.
A miscellaneous lot of 37 yearlings passed through the sales ring tonight for a total of $66,425. Twelve head from Meadowview brought $35,025.
A number of multi-family dwellings and an industrial property were among the parcels in the Bronx reported as having changed hands yesterday.

The Interstate Commerce Commission employed today its broad powers under the Motor Carrier Act for the first time to stop destructive rate wars in the trucking industry by establishing minimum rates in the New England and Central States regions, the two most important transportation areas of the country.

For two days, with the temperature soaring, Frank Mancuso, 45 years old, of 569 Madison Avenue, Paterson, N. J., sat in General Sessions while Assistant District Attorney Robert H. Thayer offered proof that he was a fake "job fixer."

Paul Moss, Commissioner of Licenses, notified second-hand car dealers yesterday that in the resale of a car they must inform the prospective purchaser whether the car has been used as a taxicab and the last previous registration of the car, regardless of the State.

Pitchers Mary Skorich and Vera Vinning allowed only two hits and fanned twenty-three batters as the Num Num Girls of Cleveland, world champions, topped the New York Roverettes, 2 to 1, in the feature contest of the women's softball double-header at Madison Square Garden last night. Five thousand attended.
Chesapeake Ohio Railway net income, which turned in May, continued to climb in July, figures released today show.

The Christian Herald Corporation, former publisher of The Christian Herald, was worth $430,884 in 1928 when its assets were transferred to the Christian Herald Association, Inc., according to a referee's report filed yesterday in Supreme Court.
Miss Matty L. Cocke, president emeritus of Hollins College for Women, and daughter of its founder, the late Charles Lewis Cocke, died yesterday afternoon at her home on the college campus.

Colonel Bill Terry, who is not one to fear changing horses in midstream, made another one of those spectacular shifts in his battlefront yesterday for which he long has been noted when drastic action is demanded.

With the time for filing designating petitions for party nominations and party positions expiring at midnight last night at the Board of Elections, popular Interest centered in the contest of Representative John J. O'Connor, one-time friend of President Roosevelt and now on the Presidential "purge" list.
Associates of Leon Trotsky said today that he is writing a biography of Joseph Stalin, who exiled him from Soviet Russia ten years ago.

Miss Lucia Houston Hobson, daughter of Mrs. Richmond Pearson Hobson of 59 East Fifty-fourth Street, New York, and of the late Rear Admiral Hobson, one of the naval heroes of the Spanish-American War, was married at noon today in Elkton, Md., to William Earle Dodge Stokes Jr. of New York.

A strong possibility that President Lazaro Cardenas's supporters will seek a second six-year term for him if President Roosevelt gets a thirdterm nomination has developed as a result of the meeting of Cabinet members and other high officials with the President last night.

Jack ?? 17-year-old hopeful from ?? Calif., went on the ?? court of the Casino and ?? Bernard Destremeau, the ?? ranking player of France, the Newport invitation tennis ?? today as Donald Budge, ?? national champion, made his first singles appearance of the American season.
The twenty-first annual season of the concerts at the Lewisohn Stadium will close tonight with a program presented by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, directed by Willem van Hoogstraten.
Emanuel I. Fuld, a night proofreader for THE NEW YORK TIMES for twelve years, died yesterday morning of coronary thrombosis in his apartment at the Hotel Lincoln. His age was 61.
George R. Rayner, vice president of the Carborundum Company, died in his home in Lewiston Heights yesterday at the age of 67.

These are great days for the surf anglers, particularly those who go to the New Jersey coast for their sport. According to reports received during the past two days, the surf from Point Pleasant to North Point is practically alive with small blues, weakfish and striped bass.

Kate Mendelssohn Szekely, 18 year-old Hungarian pianist and a descendant through her mother of the great German composer, Felix Mendelssohn, arrived from Europe yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania.
Paul Tidden, music teacher and retired concert pianist, died on Monday in his home, 310 East Seventy-fifth Street. His age was 77.
Father Andreas Hlinka, 73year-old leader of the Slovak Catholic People's party and outstanding figure of pre-war and post-war political life in Slovakia, died tonight at his home at Ruzomberok.

A banking group composed of Phelps, Fenn Co., Kean, Taylor Co.; and Campbell, Phelps Co., Inc., received the award yesterday of $500,000 State of West Virginia road bonds, on a bid of par for $220,000 as 2s, maturing June 1, 1939 to 1949; $40,000 as 1 3/4s, due June 1, 1950 and 1951, and $240,000 as 2s, maturing on June 1, 1952 to 1963.
Louis Adolphe Martin Jr., Professor of Mechanics at Stevens Institute of Technology in Hoboken, died today in Newton Memorial Hospital after a long illness. He was 57 years old.

The Griesedieck Western Brewery Company of Belleville, Ill., has filed a registration statement covering an issue of 30,000 shares of $25-par 5 1/2 per cent cumulative preferred stock, to be offered at $25 a share, an aggregate of $750,000, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

With commitments stepped up slightly as compared with the preceding month, local industrial purchasing agents are still operating cautiously in placing advance orders, a canvass disclosed here yesterday.

The engagement of Miss Mary Louise Blight, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur H. Blight of this place, to John F. Vance of New York, son of the Rev. John L. Vance of Rock Island, Ill., and the late Mrs. Vance, has been announced by her parents.

Many young matrons and debutantes of this and recent seasons in Southampton and adjacent resorts are working toward the success of the "Hampton Follies of 1938," a musical comedy revue, which will be given the nights of Aug. 25 and 26 in the auditorium of the Southampton High School for the benefit of the Southampton Fresh Air Home for Crippled Children.

Mrs. Edith Virginia Stewart Willey, long active in Woman's Christian Temperance Union work in Washington among United States marines, died yesterday in her home, 2 Harvest Street, Forest Hills, Queens. Her age was 76.
IT'S a comfort to know that the Madison Square Garden roof doesn't leak. This time Lou Ambers and Hammering Hennery Armstrong will climb into the ring and get it over with, weather or no.

A legal test of the recent city ruling forbidding airplanes to trail advertising banners over the city began in Supreme Court, Jamaica, yesterday with the signing of two show-cause orders by Justice Charles W. Froessell.
The old Postoffice and Federal Building has long been friendless. Still, as it is being pulled down, one may regard it,

A rise of 43 points in its index of business activity is reported by The Annalist, published today. The index rose to 78.6 for July, from 74.3 in June and the year's low point of 73.8 in May, but is still far below the 1937 high mark of 111.2 for August last year.

Joseph J. Kelly, former president of the Board of Mercantile Appraisers and for many years Republican leader of the Forty-fourth Ward, died in the Presbyterian Hospital yesterday. He was 61 years old.

President Roosevelt extended his "purge" of conservative elements of the Democratic party today to include Representative John J. O'Connor of New York and Senator Millard Tydings of Maryland, saying that both, "after giving the New Deal lip-service in 1936, turned around and knifed it in Congress in 1937 and 1938."

Two sales of property in Putnam County, in which the buyers paid cash, were reported yesterday by Herbert J. Gebing, broker.

Williams, a home in Strathmore, Manhasset; Dr. E. W. Scott, at 85 Abbey Rd, Munsey Park, L. I.; rentals by the Fred A. Weeks Co, Inc.

" Count" Boris Dobrzynski, who said he once was an officer in the Russian Imperial Army, testified in habeas corpus proceedings today before Supreme Court Justice Gerald Nolan that he was willing to leave the United States and never return if granted release from Sing Sing prison.
The Maritime Commission has made an agreement with the Moore McCormack Company of New York, to take over the charter of the American Republic Line between East Coast ports in North and South America.

The French liner Normandie sails today for Havre via Southampton. Passengers include Senator Alben W. Barkley, majority leader of the United States Senate; Lieut. Gen. Sir Reginald Hildyard, K. B. C., Governor General and Commander in Chief of Bermuda, and Lady Hildyard, and R. H. J. Hildyard;

Driven by rain from the outdoors to the comfortable confines of aircooled Madison Square Garden, Lou Ambers, world lightweight champion, will defend his crown tonight against Henry Armstrong, Coast Negro who holds the world featherweight and welterweight titles, in a bout scheduled for fifteen rounds.
Under the direction of officials from Washington, the immigration laws of the Dominican Republic will be studied and possibly revised with a view toward an ultimate invitation to desirable settlers.

Attacks on the present industrial and economic system and promises for the future of the cooperative movement now in progress in the Maritime Provinces, together with a statement that the movement, sometimes called the most

92d St, 23 E, 4-story dwelling, 20.4x100.8; Emily R. N. Wells against Column Holding Corp; due, $21,142; taxes, etc., $2,494; to plaintiff for $20,850. 18th St, 406 E, 5-story tenement, 25x92; Irving Trust Co, administrator, against George A. Molleson; due, $7,893; taxes, etc., $485; to plaintiff for $4,000.
General Evangeline Booth will remain as leader of the Salvation Army another twelve months after Christmas Day, when she will be 73 and due to retire under the Army regulations, it was learned today.

MANHATTAN DROEGE: OTTO H. (July 15). Estate, about $1,000. To Anna L. Droege, Window, executrix, 220 E. 72d St. LUDLAM, JOSEPHINE C. (Aug. 6). Estate, more than $10,000. To Carroll C. St. John, son, Salem, Va., $10,000, life estate in one-half residue;
United States track and field stars, who helped beat Germany's aces in a dual meet last week-end, took eight out of fourteen events today before a crowd of 20,000.

Three men were seriously burned and a building was destroyed today by fire when a gasoline tank near which they were working, exploded in the pump house at the monastery of the Society of the Atonement at Graymoor.
In discussing the budget the Supreme Soviet has given its best imitation to date of representative government. For the first time since the revolution the

Frederick W. Peabody of Ashburnham, Mass., a retired lawyer who had led an organized demand for the revision of war debts owed to the United States, died Monday in a private hospital in the Bronx after an illness of four years. He was 76 years old.
A financial group here today concluded an agreement with the Argentine Government regarding an extensive scheme of land reclamation in lower reaches of the Parana River on the Rio de la Plata.

Sister Alfredina, former supervisor of education for the Sisters of Christian Charity in the East and assistant to the Mother Provincial at the motherhouse at Mendham, N. J., died in the convent of St. Ann's Academy today. She was 54 years old.

The chief importance of the address delivered last night by Mr. Hull lies in its timing. In making an occasion to restate the attitude of the United States toward what is going on in the world, the Secretary of State chose a moment when the tension in Europe is coming to a head.

4:00-4:30 P. M.-From Nova Scotia: Right Rev. James Morrisson, Bishop of Antigonish, at Rural Conference--WJZ. 4:30-4:45 P. M.-"Children's Art Festival," James J. Lyons, Bronx Borough President; Rockwell Kent, Artist-WMCA. 6:45-7:00P. M.-"Social Security Act's Third Milestone," Joseph B. O'Connor, Acting Regional Director, SSB-WOR. 8:30-9:00 P. M.-Whiteman Orchestra; Raymond Scott Quintet-WABC. 8:45-9:00 P. M.-"The Constitutional Convention," Assemblyman-Irwin Steingut of New York-WMCA.

The sudden decision by the Argentine Government yesterday to call off, at least for the present, the issuance of its $25,000,000 of 4 1/2 per cent bonds here, which had been scheduled to reach the market tomorrow, took the investment community, as well as the underwriters for the loan, by complete surprise.
A warning to mothers that whooping cough continues unusually prevalent in the city was issued yesterday by Dr. John L. Rice, City Health Commissioner.
Mrs. Payne Whitney will give a luncheon at her cottage tomorrow in celebration of the birthday of her son, John Hay Whitney, who is expected to arrive from New York earlier in the day.

8th Ave, 2,438: to 5-story tenement and stores: Kay Fire Retarding and Construction Co, 290 Lenox Ave, owner: O. L. Spannhake, architect; cost. $20,000. 47th St, 308-10 West; to two 5-story tenements and stores; 308 Realty Corp. 11 West 42d St, owner; M. Glick, engineer; cost, $25.000.

The Agricultural Department is viewing the possibility of the infestation of Bermuda by Japanese beetles seriously and has decided to send a plant pathologist, J. M. Waterton, to Washington and New York to confer with Federal and State officials.
The jobs of 117 "special investigators" were abolished today. Chief of Police James A. McMenamin ordered the badges of the men and women appointees taken up "because of lack of funds."

The Standard Oil Company of Indiana notified today the Chicago Stock Exchange that the directors had authorized the acceptance of the exchange invitation to list the corporation's common stock on the Chicago Stock Exchange and that the application was in process of preparation, it was announced at the exchange.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The President's speech at Barnesville yesterday clearly discloses his idea of what he would like to have happen during the balance of his term.
Louis F. Mitten, president of the Aviation Golf Club, Inc., was elected today as municipal manager of Bendix, the nation's smallest municipal manager community.

About 2,500 scientists have flocked to Cambridge for the annual meeting of the British Association for the Advancement of Science, opening tomorrow. Included are such international figures as Professor Niels Bohr, Danish Nobel prize winner; Professor Erich Regener, German cosmic ray authority, both known for their work on the atom; and Dr. Leopold Ruzicka, Swiss pioneer in the synthesis of male hormones.

SINGLES Second Round Mrs. John Van Ryn, Austin. Texas. defeated Miss Barbara Winslow, Hollywood, 6-4, 7-9, 6-1; Miss Dorothy Bundy, Santa Monica, Calif., defeated Miss Eleonora Sears, Beverly Farms, Mass., 6-0, 6-1; Mme. Rene Mathieu, France, defeated Miss Dorothy Wightman, Brookline, Mass., 7-5, 6-1.
Clarence B. Shepherd, 29 years old, of Paris, Idaho, died today of injuries received in an explosion of oil fumes aboard the submarine Nautilus, navy intelligence officers announced.

Lack of wind spoiled the scheduled run today of the New York Yacht Club fleet from Marblehead to the easterly entrance of the Cape Cod Canal. The squadron run over the fortysix miles was to have been for the United States Navy Challenge Cups.

Miss Dorothy Fox Gerster, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John C. A. Gerster of 18 East Seventy-eighth Street, will be married next Wednesday afternoon to Thomas Kirby Schmuck Jr., son of Mrs. Kinsey Schmuck of St. James, L. I., and Mr. Schmuck of New York.
Lord Haldon, whose family once owned most of Torquay, the fashionable seaside resort in Devonshire, but who had been destitute in recent years, died in London today at the age of 42.

Grand Concourse, 1,505 (11-2835), Sun Rise Realty Corp. to Equitable Life Assurance Society, 393 Seventh Ave; installments at 6 per cent until May 1, 1939, thereafter 432 per cent; $385,000. Hoe Ave, 953 (10-2742), Samuel B. Katz to Union Square Savings Bank, due as per bond; $30,000.

An application by the Toledo Edison Company, a part of the Cities Service system, for exemption from the provisions of the Holding Company Act of the issue and sale of $30,000,000 of first-mortgage 3 1/2 per cent bonds, due 1936, and $6,500,000 of 4 per cent sinking fund debentures, due 1948, was granted conditionally today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

COMMERCIAL PAPER Yesterday. Monday. For the best names ..... 1% 1% The quotations are for four-six months' paper. Buyers' Registrations Drop The number of out-of-town buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday showed a decrease compared with both that of the preceding week and that of the corresponding week of last year, according to the listings in THE TIMES.
Great Brittain, jittery from recurring war fears, warmly welcomed tonight the speech of Secretary Hull, which was interpreted here as raising a danger sign against German ambitions in Central Europe.

From his hospital bed a young camp worker said today that he lit the dynamite fuse which led to the death of Daniel George Dodge, 21-year-old heir to a $9,000,000 Michigan motor fortune, at Mr. Dodge's direction.

GOVERNORS ISLAND Col. John P. Bubb, Infantry, will proceed on or about Aug. 14, from Newark, N. J., to Camp Moore, Sea Girt, N. J., for the purpose of observing and supervising the training of the 1,229th C. A. S. C. Unit, and upon completion of this duty,
Dr. Harry Koster of Broklyn has purchased the large brick residence at 26 Maple Street, Brooklyn, near Prospect Park, which was owned and occupied for many years

Following is the list of designees filled yesterday with the Board of Elections by the Democratic, Republican, American Labor and Socialist parties for nomination in the September primaries. Where more than one name appears in a district, a contest is denoted. Asterisk denotes incumbent.

The Joint Board of the Millinery Workers Union, a unit of the United Hat, Cap and Millinery Workers Union, an American Federation of Labor affiliate, called out 1,000 workers engaged in the manufacture of children's headwear yesterday in a dispute over a new contract with contractors.

Mayor La Guardia served notice yesterday that street peddling was on its way out in New York City when he signed a local law banning hawkers from streets in the Rockaways where traffic regulations are in force.

The former Brill residence at 40 Riverside Drive, northeast corner of Seventy-sixth Street, has been sold by the estate of Max Brill, one of the founders of Brill Brothers, clothiers, through L. J. Phillips Co., brokers.
Dignity and simplicity marked the dedication today of memorials to Dalhousie University's origin, unveiled as a feature of the centennial reunion.

Charles K. Doyle, referee in the bankruptcy of the Steinway Railway Company of Long Island City, announced yesterday that the properties of the company, which operates a system of surface car lines in Queens, would be sold at public auction Monday.

For the second day in succession Miss Maureen Orcutt of White Beeches, women's metropolitan and Eastern golf champion, paced the field today to gain a three-stroke lead in the tenth annual New Jersey shore 54-hole medal play tournament.
Boris Skoutelsky, formerly chief counsel of the Soviet Trading Agency in London, died here today of a heart attack. He was 49 years old.

The Labor Non-Partisan League of Connecticut voted unanimously at its State committee meeting today to favor State and national office nominees this Fall who were genuine New Dealers. The board pointed out, however, that full endorsements can come only at the league State convention in this city Oct. 1.

MANHATTAN COHN. ANNIE (March 17, 1936). Gross assets, $20,493; net, $18,107. To United Home for Aged Hebrews, $300: Daisy Shubert, daughter, $3,000; Herbert Schubert and Ruth Cohn, grandchildren, $1,000 each;

Mrs. Louis Lombard of New York and her daughters, Miss Lois Lombard and Mrs. Thomas Allen 3d, were honored at a tea given this afternoon by Mrs. Francis W. Rockwell, with whom they are staying at Pittsfield. Mrs. Brace W.

New life insurance for the first seven months of this year was 23.5 per cent less than for the corresponding period last year, and the amount for July was 28.9 per cent less than for July of 1937, according to a report sent by the Association of Life Insurance Presidents to the United States Department of Commerce yesterday.

15th St, 420-32 W, 125x103.1; 422 W 15th St, Inc :(Philip Herman, president) to Mutual Life Insurance Co; p m mtg due as bond, $70,000. 15th St. 207 E, 36.3x103.3: Clarence M. Weil to Woodlawn Cemetery (a corp), 20 E 23d St; p m mtg due July 1, 1943, 4 per cent; $49,000.

Despite the heat and humidity, which was terrific, a field of 100 players turned out today for the one-day tournament of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association, which was a tribute to the Women's National Golf and Tennis Club course, scene of the event.

Several hundred thousand men, women and children attempted to obtain relief and sleep last night on beaches in the metropolitan area as the city suffered another night of high temperatures, high humidity and no breezes after a scorching hot day, preceded by the hottest night of the year.

The Radio Receptor Company, i Inc., engaged in the manufacture of special radio equipment, filed suit yesterday under the Sherman Anti-Trust Law for treble damages of $720,000, alleging the Bendix Radio Corporation, the Bendix Aviation Corporation and General Motors Corporation had conspired to monopolize the industry.

C. Shelby Carter, a member of a committee headed by Gardner B. Perry for Erie Railroad 5 per cent refunding and improvement bonds, said yesterday that the Interstate Commerce Commission had set a hearing for tomorrow on the application of the committee for authority to act.
Stockholders of Wilson Co. have just received by mail a three-ounce tin of the company's deviled ham, accompanied by a small card elaborating the merits of the product.

German stock exchanges, which have been going down since the middle of April, suffered another serious slump today. Losses of 4 to 5 points, particularly among heavy industrials and "armament values" were not uncommon and in some cases reached 7 to 9 points. Some shares offered could not be sold at any price.

The New York Stock Exchange committee on member firms has ruled that Phillips Petroleum Company rights to subscribe to convertible 3 per cent debentures may be dealt in either on a national securities exchange or over the counter, at the discretion of members.

Six safeguards necessary to maintain the credit of American cities were outlined today at the annual conference of the Municipal Finance Officers Association of the United States and Canada by Frederick L. Bird, director of municipal service for Dun Bradstreet, New York. He told the 300 delegates that the safeguards were to be found in few cities.
The Japanese command sent reinforcements up the Yangtze River today to renew the stalled drive against Hankow, about which the Chinese were said to have deplayed 1,000,000 defenders.

The building at 225 West Seventyninth Street has been leased for a long, term by Dublin Properties, Inc., John P. Carway, president, operating the Dublin House, restaurant. The building will be altered to double the space occupied by the restaurant.

A demonstration of the future possibilities of radio was given at the World's Fair grounds yesterday morning -when radio waves were used to heat the last rivet driven into place on the steel framework of the Radio Corporation of America's exhibit building.

Death Announced Retired Engineer of Steamer Albert Hunter, formerly a member of Engine 258, residing on Highway Ave., Congers, N. Y., died Aug. 7. Name Corrections The names of the following ununiformed firemen are corrected as follows:

Miss Charmian Campbell, daughter of Brig. Gen. Archibald Campbell, U. S. A., retired, and Mrs. Campbell of New York and this place, will be married to Henry MacDonald of Forest Hills, Queens; on Saturday at noon in the Church of Our Lady of Loretto.

Commercial and industrial failures in the United States in the week ended Aug. 11 increased in two of the five trade divisions, as compared with the same week of 1937, according to the weekly summary prepared by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Possession of telephones with either listed or secret numbers was primarily responsible for the appearance on the jury panel of the twelve jurors chosen yesterday to try James J. Hines. Tammany leader, on an indictment charging him with conspiracy in the policy racket.

After examining vouchers received today from the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company, Senator La Follette, whose committee is investigating the "Little Steel" strike, stated that the committee was sending two investigators to Youngstown for a further examination of the company's records.

Contracts were signed yesterday for a return engagement of Fortune Gallo's San Carlo Opera Company at the Center Theatre in Rockefeller Center. Because of previous bookings, the season will be limited to seventeen days.

A sentence of three to six years in Sing Sing was imposed by Judge Nott in General Sessions yesterday on Rabbi Zeide M. Schmellner, 60 years old, formerly of 80 Riverside Drive, who was convicted June 23 in frauds against co-religionists totaling $635,000.

The Hippodrome Opera Company will present "Carmen" at Randalls Island next Saturday evening and "Rigoletto" on Sunday night. In the cast of "Carmen" will be Hilda Kutsukian Kosta as Carmen, Daisy Sciortino as Micaela, Sydney Rayner as Don Jose, Mario Cozzi as Escamillo and Nino Ruisi as Zuniga.

The Rev. Matthew A. Flanagan, pastor of St. Raphael's Catholic Church, Blissville, Queens, died Monday evening on the steps of the rectory at 192 Greenpoint Avenue. Earlier in the day he had suffered a heart attack.

Duke and Duchess Ludwig Wilhelm of Bavaria have returned from a visit in Canada and are at the Sherry-Netherland. Mr. and Mrs. J. Macy Willets, who have been passing the Summer at Cassilis House, New Marlboro, Mass., are expected to arrive today at the Carlyle.

Cleveland set down the last-place Browns, 9-6, today and gave Mel Harder his tenth victory of the season. Sammy Hale's home run with the bases unoccupied in the fourth paced the Indians' twelve-hit attack on Les Tietje, Ed Cole, Russ Van Atta and Buck Newsom.

Although the Bermuda Legislature's ban on the use of cruise ships as hotels while in Bermuda harbors will not become effective until Dec. 1, the Furness Bermuda Line notified its agents yesterday that "ship-hotel" bookings on the liners Queen of Bermuda and Monarch of Bermuda would be dropped immediately.
Movemente of vessels follow; all dates are Aug. 17, unless specified: At San Diego. Trenton, Whitney. New York to Hampton Roads, Texas, Wyoming.

The stock market failed yesterday to retain much of its early strength and closed irregular. Trading on the Stock Exchange amounted to only 595,000 shares. This turnover and those of 614,000 on Tuesday and 593,000 on Monday represent the smallest three-day volume since the present advance in share prices began on June 20. Bonds were higher,
The Newark Bears overwhelmed the Toronto Maple Leafs in both ends of a double-header tonight for a record of sixteen triumphs over the Leafs in twenty-one games this season.

The Silvermine Musio Festival, under the auspices of the Silvermine Artists Guild, opens this morning at Silvermine, Conn., with a concert by the Roth String Quartet, which will play works by Haydn, Debussy and Schumann, At 11:30 A. M.,

Herbert N. Fell, executive secretary of the Thrift and Security Foundation, who returned recently from England, where he made a survey of the thrift movement, said yesterday that the most impressive thing about thrift in England was the spirit of genuine cooperation
Stocks of domestic and foreign refinable crude petroleum at the close of the week ended on Aug. 6 amounted to 287,406,000 barrels, according to data compiled by the Bureau of Mines.
Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh landed at Central Airport, Moscow, at 8:30 this evening, after a brief delay at Mogilev, near the Polish border, for refueling.

McKesson Robbins, Inc.; Glenram Wine and Liquor Company and Long Island Wine and Spirits Company have been appointed wholesale distributors in New York City for products of James Barclay Co., Ltd., subsidiary of Hiram Walker-Gooderham Worts, Inc.

Miss Maureen Orcutt of White Beeches beat Mrs. Harry McNaughton of Sound View in an 18-hole play-off today over the difficult Hollywood links to take first honors in the New Jersey shore golf tournament. Miss Orcutt scored a 79 on the extra round, Mrs. McNaughton an 80.

It would be a strange sequel to the alarms of recent weeks if the German war manoeuvres helped to turn the tide against war. So far only 300,000 reservists in addition to the standing army of about 1,000,000 have been called to the colors.

William Roberts, receiver for the Manhattan Railway Company, filed an appeal yesterday in the United States Circuit Court from the decision of Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson permitting the receiver for the I. R. T. to abandon the 999year lease and operation of trains on the Manhattan's elevated lines.

Cruise ships operating from New York to Bermuda will not be withdrawn because of the action of the Bermuda Legislature in banning the use of the ships as hotels during their stay in port, according to shipping men.

Dean K. Worcester, vice president of the New York Stock Exchange, and Robert L. Fisher, secretary, submitted their Tesignations, effective Oct. 1, the Exchange announced yesterday. The former has been associated with the institution since August, 1929, and the latter since September, 1933.
Governor Moore moved today in two directions to ease the problem of financing unemployment relief.

The strike that broke out last week in the factories of Yee Tsoong Tobacco Company, the former British American Tobacco Company, was settled yesterday through the intervention of the garrison headquarters.
EVEN in as frank an age as this, books of a confessional nature are rare enough that one must sit up and take notice when they appearand when they are not simply shoddy or sensational.

The family of Admiral Robert E. Peary, discoverer of the North Pole, presented to the town today a range finder on Jockey Cap. Mrs. Marie Peary Stafford, daughter of the explorer, told the assembly that while he lived in Fryeburg her father was "free from the struggle that carried him along on his career."
Looking fit and declaring he felt well, General John J. Pershing arrived in Paris today for his annual tour of inspection of American war cemeteries in France.
ABRAMS--Araham, Aug. 17, age 68 years, beloved husband of Mollie, dear father of Sidney, Joseph, Gertrude and Frances. Funeral today, 2 P. M., from Midtown Chapel, 171 West 85th St.
The Cuban Government will spend $6,000,000 to aid the unemployed, according to Colonel Fulgencio Batista, Chief of Staff. Economies will be made in government expenditures to raise
Chambers of commerce, manufacturers and merchants on the Ecuadorean coast have telegraphed a petition to the Constitutional Congress to repeal the law requiring licensing of imports.

Like a lecturer describing his journey to some strange and faraway place, District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey outlined his case against James J. Hines yesterday and gave Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora and the jury a

District Attorney Dewey out-I lined his case against James J. Hines yesterday as follows: May it please the Court and the gentlemen of the jury: If anybody has any difficulty in hearing me, I hope you will speak up and tell me to talk a little louder.
The American Agricultural Chemical Company of Delaware and subsidiaries had a profit of $1,401,076 for the fiscal year ended on June 30, it was announced yesterday.

Pig iron production in Czechoslovakia in June amounted to 110,300 metric tons, slightly higher than production in May, but 19 per cent below the record made in June, 1937, the Department of Commerce reported today.
With the thermometer almost 10 points under the 100 level for the first time this week, Coach Steve Owen today stepped up

When President McKinley dedicated the Grant Monument he naturally termed it "beautiful." New Yorkers of that time and later didn't agree with him. It came to be known as Grant's Tomb. They didn't and they don't love to meditate among tombs.

If one were to judge by appearances, Lou Ambers won all by himself in his lightweight championship fight with Henry Armstrong at Madison Square Garden last night. The smiling warrior from Herkimer, N. Y., was considerably marked up, it is true, but his face was serene indeed, compared to the battered visage that Armstrong presented.

Governor George H. Earle of Pennsylvania, here on a vacation trip, And Josephus Daniels, United States Ambassador, spent forty-five minutes today conferring with Eduardo Hay, Foreign Minister, and Ramon Beteta, his Under Secretary.

SING YOU SINNERS, story and screen play by Claude Binyon; music and lyrics by James V. Monaco and John Burke; with song "Small Fry" by Frank Loesser and Hoagy Carmichael: directed and produced by Wesley Ruggles for release through Paramount. At the Paramount.

The action of the Interstate Commerce Commission in raising the freight rates charged by motor trucks in New England and the East Central States marks another stage in the Government's efforts to bring stability into the nation's transportation system.

Beginning today, and continuing through tomorrow and Saturday, about 60,000 farmers in New York, New England, parts of Pennsylvania, New Jersey and Maryland, all of whom supply milk to New York State consumers, will vote on the question of whether they want the price of their milk raised and pegged by combined Federal and State control.

The following members of the department, having been tried before Francis X. Giaccone, Deputy Fire Commissioner, on July 6, 1938, for violation of Rules and Regulations, 1937. the following decisions are rendered by the fire chief and commissioner:

Old Westbury, which will defend its national open polo championship next month, rode in its regular team order against Aknusti at Meadow Brook today and went extremely well to win, 14 to 6. As during their successful season last year,
Winning every track race, the touring American track and field athletes, competing in the fifth meet of their German tour, captured ten of fourteen events before a cheering crowd of 20,000 today.

Senator Alben W. Barkley, majority leader in the Senate, who was nominated recently after what he described as "a cat fight" in Kentucky, sailed on the French liner Normandie yesterday to attend sessions of the Inter-Parliamentary Union at The Hague.

Ground was broken. yesterday in the triangular Laurel Hill War Memorial Park as work began officially on the first segment of the $1,800,000 Queens Connecting Highway, which, when completed, will link four boroughs and facilitate traffic of the Queens-Midtown Tunnel, the Brooklyn Crosstown Express Highway, North Beach Airport and the World's Fair.

The practice by certain manufacturers of nationally advertised hosiery of permitting their products to be offered as advertising premiums by various other manufacturers was condemned yesterday in a statement issued by the National Retail Dry Goods Association on behalf of hosiery buyers representing metropolitan retailers and buying organizations for stores throughout the country. The statement cited,

Henry Tatnall Brown, member of an old Quaker family and president of Brown Bailey Company, paper box manufacturers, died last night in Pennsylvania Hospital from complications following an operation. He was 67 years old.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Louise Leonard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm W. Leonard of this place, to Edward P. Harrison, son of the Rev. and Mrs. Edward Stacy Harrison of Avon, Mass.

The Cabinet approved today a broad program drawn up by five of the most important Ministers to speed the campaign in China with more drastic economic control at home and greater pressure by the armed forces.

Miss Imogen Elizabeth Averett, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Wise Averett of this place, was married to Elden Washington Christopher, son of Mrs. Thomas William Christopher of Northumberland County, here today at the home of the bride's parents.

By a strange twist of fate, the twenty-first season of concerts at Lewisohn Stadium came to a close on the day of the death of Adolph Lewisohn, donor of the stadium, who was an invariable visitor at the opening concert of each season, and would usually speak a few words of welcome to the audience.
Robert Lawrence, three times Mayor of Middletown, N. Y., and a former Alderman, died at his home in Middletown Monday at the age of 89. When he was Mayor he broke ground for the present City Hall.

A further abatement of the rush for gold and dollars continued yesterday in the foreign exchange market as a still calmer view was taken of the international political situation. Trading approached a more normal basis and price changes in the principal foreign currencies were mixed.

Nearing the end of a week's flight over commercial air routes to test for hay fever-bearing micro-organisms in the upper air, Oren C. Durham, chief botanist for Abbott Laboratories, Inc., of Chicago, yesterday reported having found air above the metropolitan area freer from these irritants than above Mid-Western cities, particularly Cleveland and Omaha.

Probably the two most interested spectators in -the court room drama yesterday were two women who sat near each other but whose interests lie in opposite directions. One was Mrs. Geneva Cox Hines, wife of James J. Hines, and the other Mrs. Frances H. Dewey, wife of the District Attorney. For Mrs.

Henry Armstrong did it last night! The doughty little Negro from California became the first fighter in all ring history to hold three titles at the same time when he hammered his way to the decision over stout-hearted, courageous Lou Ambers in fifteen rounds of as fast, furious and savage fighting as has ever been seen here before a gathering of 20,000 frenzied fans in Madison Square Garden.

Manufacturers and resident offices here were encouraged this week by the optimistic attitude of out-of-town men's wear retailers, who predicted an excellent Fall season, despite slow business in the last two weeks. In general,

Police chiefs of the Swiss cantons decided today that more than 1,000 refugees who had crossed the Swiss frontier illegally from German Austria would be tolerated for the present. A warning was issued, however, that all would be sent back if the flood of refugees continued.

The sudden change in the attitude of national advertisers in the last month to six weeks has forced advertising agencies to cram production work on copy normally taking several months into one month or less, agency men reported yesterday.

Before a brilliant audience, which suggested a first night at an opera and which packed a modernistic motion picture theatre, Lord Rayleigh formally opened this year's meeting of the British Association for the Advancement of Science with an address in which he absolved science of any blame for having made war more terrible.
The status of the Ernest Hemingway play, "The Fifth Column," which Joseph Losey and D. A. Doran expect to sponsor, seems to be uncertain at the moment.

Dr. Rubert S. Royce of 200 Greene Avenue, Brooklyn, a practitioner in that borough for fortyseven years, died on Tuesday, his seventy-third birthday, after an illness of many weeks.

The Bureau of Agriculture Economics predicted today that heavy production of dairy products and accumulation of large surpluses probably would prevent normal seasonal price rises this Fall and Winter.

The special House committee investigating un-American activities heard charges today that public funds were, being used to finance communism in the United States; that prominent Federal officials were members of the American League

With Si Johnson hurling effectively in the nightcap for a 3-2 victory, the Rochester Red Wings split a double-header with Jersey City tonight. The Jerseys took the first verdict. 7 to 1, behind the airtight pitching of Roy Joiner.

The Constitutional Convention early this morning adopted the Housing Bill it will present to the people this Fall; but before it did so, it amended the bill to death, in the eyes of its original sponsors.
Mrs. Cornelia Livingston Crosby Pell, widow of the Rev. Alfred Duane Pell, died at her home here today of a stroke which occurred two days ago.

The work of the Department of Hospitals will be "seriously crippled" on Aug. 27, when 3,289 WPA workers, including physicians, nurses and orderlies, will have to be withdrawn from assignments in the twenty-six city hospitals, Dr. S. S. Goldwater, Commissioner of Hospitals, warned yesterday.

The Board of Examiners reports that there have been placed, as of Aug. 16, 1938, upon the eligible list of holders of license as teacher of health education in day secondary schools other than junior high schools the names of the following applicants, who have been granted said license:
Philip Hitsman, 93-year-old veteran of the Civil War, is dead. He had lived here for the last seventy-four years and had long been chief constable of the village.

New Fall and Winter fashions have moved far away from the classicism that leaned toward a monotonous uniformity in recent years, and will offer the welldressed woman an unprecedented combination of brilliance and luxury, according to David Nemerov, executive vice president of Russeks, who returned, from Paris yesterday on the Italian liner Rex.

Sale of the British subsidiary of R. Hoe Co. to R. W. Crabtree Sons, Ltd., was approved by the shareholders of the Hoe company at a special meeting yesterday. The price, on which the purchasers have the option to pay [Pound]75,000 in notes, approximates [Pound]470,170.

The four and five story buildings at 9 and 11 East Fifty-sixth Street, together with the rear six and two story structures at 8 and 10 East Fifty-seventh Street, were sold at auction yesterday in the Vesey Street salesrooms.
Woodward Hudson, president of the Boston Maine Railroad when it was under Federal control during the World War, died late today at his home here. His age was 80.

The heat wave that has hovered over New York City abated yesterday, but the gain in comfort from lower temperatures was somewhat offset by high humidity. The moisture content of the atmosphere averaged between 75 and 80 per cent of saturation.

Two dealers in General Motors automobiles denied in testimony yesterday before the Federal Trade Commission at 45 Broadway that they had been forced to buy parts and accessories for such cars only from the General Motors Corporation.

The Chilean Army team, which is scheduled to sail today from Santiago for New York, is the first of two teams which will make the 10,000-mile voyage from Chile to take part in the military jumping contests at the National Horse Show, to be held at Madison Square

Estate, $626. To Anna Neubauer, sister, executrix, 100 E. 5th St.. Paterson, N. J. EDEY, MARY (Aug. 2). Estate, more than $10,000. To Endowment Fund of St. Thomas Church, Association for the Employment of Industrious Poor, Salvation Army, Speyer Hospital for Animals, $10,000 each;
Charles W. Hunt, from 1924 until 1932 a member of the Federal Trade Commission, died at his home here last night. He was 74 years old.

Allan S. Haywood, regional director of the C. I. O. for New York, said yesterday at his office, 1,133 Broadway, that the State convention of the C. I. O. called for Sept. 16 and 17 in this city might not endorse any candidates in the forthcoming elections, but that the C. I. O. would try to elect someone "to keep Representative John J. O'Connor at home."

Miss Ramona Antuna, daughter of Mrs. Bernardo Antuna of this place and the late Mr. Antuna, was married tonight in Mount Carmel Church here to Armando Alverez Pedroso of Havana. The Rev. Aloysius Bendola officiated.

Middle age is still good for civic uses. A middle-aged jury is tackling the important issues in the Hines trial. For the twelve regular jurors and two alternates the average is fortyseven years. The oldest man is 60. The youngest is 29, and there are a couple of others under 40.

Reconsideration of a proposed milk marketing order for the New York metropolitan area was asked today of Secretary of Agriculture Henry A. Wallace by Governor A. Harry Moore on the ground that it would

The annual report of the Legislative Service Bureau of the Merchants Association, made public yesterday, showed that in the association's fiscal year ended April 30 the bureau reviewed more than 9,000 measures introduced in or adopted by Federal, New York State and New York City legislative bodies. Each of these measures. affected business, the bureau said.
A supper was given by Mr. and Mrs. Morton G. Clark of Westerleigh, S. I., last night in the Rainbow Room of Rockefeller Center. Their guests included Miss Margaret Mabon and Henry N. Whitney.

GOVERNORS ISLAND Col. Carlos Brewer, Field Artillery, is assigned to duty as Organized Reserves Camp Commander, Pine Plains Military Reservation, Great Bend, N. Y., vice Col. William H. Shepherd, Field Artillery, relieved.
A final formality in the civil rights injunction suit of the C. I. O. and associated organizations and individuals against Mayor Frank Hague and members of his administration was disposed of today.
Better arrangements having been made for weather, the first outdoor variety show was put on at the Randalls Island Stadium last night before an appreciative audience.

Mrs. Fletcher Chapman, who had been director of the Rehearsal club, 47 West Fifty-third Street, hence its foundation twenty-seven years ago, died early yesterday morning in the Porter Hospital, Middlebury, Vt., after a brief illness, according to an announcement made here last night. She was 6 years old.

Donald M. Nelson, vice president of Sears, Roebuck Co., was named today by Elmer F. Andrews, Administrator of the Wages and Hours Law, to head the textile industry committee which will recommend standards to be fixed.

The world record of 1:58 1/4 for pacing mares was tied today at the State Fair's Grand Circuit races by Her Ladyship, bay mare owned by the Hotel Baker Stables of St. Charles, Ill., and driven by Sep Palin, veteran reinsman. The record was established by Miss Harris M. in 1918 and equaled by Margaret Dillon in 1922.
Pensioned On his own application, to take effect 12 noon, Aug. 16: PATTROLMAN--Charles R. Fetscher, 62d Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Jan. 3, 1905.
Tennis form finally caught up toay with the two San Francisco girls who have been providing a ries of upsets in the Essex Club's omen's invitation tournament.

A vote for the proposed Federal-State milkmarketing agreement was urged upon milk producers today by Governor Lehman. The vote will be taken tomorrow , Friday and Saturday. Minimum prices for milk delivered to the New York City market would be established by the agreement..

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: One of the most important matters now pending before the Constitutional Convention is the housing amendment submitted by Joseph Clark Baldwin 3d. Under this amendment the State and its subdivisions would be in a position to start a comprehensive large-scale public housing program which might wipe out the slums of our cities within one generation.
Jean LaJeanne, 29 years old, a sailor, of 25 South Street, and John Block, 22, who said he had no home, the "singing gunmen" who perpetrated a series of hold-ups in the city in the last month,

Miss Freda Coumy, operator of a private kindergarten at 114 East Sixty-fourth Street, was held in $7,500 bail for the grand jury yesterday by Magistrate Rothenburg in the Felony Court on her notguilty plea to alleged aggregate thefts of $3,000 in dividend checks that had been mailed to Mrs. Helen

Over-the-counter trading practices have been reduced to a uniform code by a committee of the National Security Traders Association, and the plan has been submitted to members in the hope of general adoption. If approved, it would cover intercity deals of the association's 2,100 members, who represent 1,400 security houses in all parts of the country.

Charges that, despite official French denials France is again sending considerable help in arms, ammunition and men to the Spanish Loyalists appear in the Italian press, which has unleashed a violent attack against what it terms "the alarmist manoeuvres of Paris and London Bolshevist circles."
Orders for paper in most lines have shown a sharp increase in the last week, but the increase is seasonal and the volume is running behind that of a year ago, it was reported yesterday.
The Rev. Dr. Joseph M. Rowland, Methodist editor, author and lecturer, was killed in an automobile accident near Amelia, Va., this afternoon. His wife and her mother,
Mr. and Mrs. Walter E. Knowlton have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Edith Mae Knowlton, to Robert E. Blackford, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Blackford Jr. of Hackensack.
Vice and crime flourished in this city during the last two years as a

Emile Vandervelde, Belgian Socialist and former Premier, asserts in an article published here in the magazine Hoy today that the democratic nations should ignore the interests of their capitalists in order to keep oil from the Fascist nations.
The Red Sox broke a six-game losing streak today with 21 hits and a double victory over the Athletics, 4 to 3 and 5 to 0.

While F. E. A. Kitto, Cambridge varsity player, held his lead in Section B, P. M. List of Germany was tied for first place in Section A by E. Klein of Austria as a result of play in the ninth round of the annual congress of the British Chess Federation in the Royal Pavilion tonight. All three have 7-2 point totals.
A silent though definite issue in the fast-boiling Democratic Senatorial primary campaign in Georgia is the personality of Walter F. George, whom President Roosevelt would

Several sets of plans for tenement houses and dwellings in Queens were among projects submitted yesterday by architects. Plans also were placed on record for altering buildings in Brooklyn. The plans follow:
After an unpromising start, and several dizzy. spells on the part of another southerly breeze, the racing fleet of the New York Yacht Club arrived here today on the final run of the annual cruise.

Three French Ministers -- Camille Chautemps, Vice Premier; Oscar Frossard, Minister of Public Works, and Jean Zay, Minister of Education -- will climb Mont Blanc Saturday and Sunday to take part in the inauguration of Vallot hut at a height of 12,526 feet.

Sister Marie Louise, the former Mary Cowen, member of the order of Sisters of Notre Dame de Namour for fifty years, died in Asheville, N. C., today, according to word received here. She was 69 years old.

Announcement has been made to friends here by Mr. and Mrs. Donaid Markle of The Eyergreens, Jeddo, Pa., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Orme Markle, to Charles Embrie Rockwell of Smithtown, L. I., and this city.

The firmer tendency in Wall Street and the improved international situation made for a better tone in the stock market here today. Gilt-edge issues behaved uncertainly, but among the foreign bonds German and Japanese loans were firm.

Lou Ambers weighed 134 1/4 pounds and Henry Armstrong scaled 134 for their fifteen-round bout at Madison Square Garden last night. Billy Cavanagh was the referee and the judges were George Lecron and Marty Monroe. The fight by rounds follows:

Luncheon, Rotary Club of New York, Hotel Commodore, 12:15 P. M. "Slums of New York," Harry Manuel Shulman. Metropolitan Museum of Art, 3:30 P. M. "Development of Modern Painting," Edwin L. M. Taggart.

Evidence that the seasonal peak in apartment renting is approaching was provided yesterday when reporting brokers listed a large number of persons as having signed leases for residential space in apartment houses in scattered sections of the city.

While Chinese troops continued to check the efforts of Japanese land forces to push southward from the banks of, the Yangtze into Kiangsi Province and to balk Japanese thrusts westward north of the river in East Hupeh and Western Anhwei Provinces, Japanese warships became increasingly active above Kiukiang as the spearhead of the offensive against Hankow.

A ragged blue coat, a patchwork quilt, a cracker box, a frozen-fish container and a sugar sack stained with blood were the clues on which detectives based their hopes today of sifting out the identity of Cleveland's "torso killer."

Pointing out that the recovery pace in steel operations and new business has slackened a bit, The Iron Age in its weekly review states that fundamental conditions are still encouraging for a continued upward trend of at least moderate proportions. The publication, however, attributes the gain of 1 point to 41 per cent for this week over last week largely to the building up of stocks of raw steel by some companies.

Purchase of from 10,000 to 12,000 light native cowhides in the Chicago packer hide market yesterday by Japanese interests brought the total of such takings by Japan in the last three weeks to about 40,000 hides, and traders here said that Japan has become the foremost export market for American hides since the first of this year.

George Weinberg of 286 Fort Washington Avenue, a confederate of the late Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer in the operation of the numbers racket in New York, who pleaded guilty to the indictment and appeared as a witness for the State, testified as follows: Direct examinatin...

Major Ian Hay Beith, author of "The First Hundred Thousand" and other war books and plays, under the name of Ian Hay, sailed yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania after spending forty-eight hours in New York.
Close of play scores in English cricket matches, started today, follow: Essex 108 (Robbins four for 22): Middlesex 237 for six (Edrich 82, Allen 53, Compton 71 not out). at Lbrd's.
Miss Martha Hall and Kingsley Mabon, whose engagement was announced last week, obtained a license yesterday at the Municipal Building and said they would be married on Sept. 16 in this city.
Among the books announced by Knopf for Fall publication are "Science for the Citizen," a study of science in the light of social progress, by Lancelot Hogben;

The Jones Beach Surf Fishing Club here, which has built up a membership of more than five hundred because of the surf-fishing facilities at Jones Beach, is trying to persuade the Long Island State Park Commission to lay out a parking field especially for the use of fishermen, according to Edwin C. Buckley, president of the club.

After five days in the capital, marked by extension of his primary "purge" to New York and Maryland, President Roosevelt was heading tonight for Canadian soil to extend a friendly hand and personally give effect to his good neighbor policy.

Rockland County Republicans were disturbed today when it became known that Howard P. Jones of Pomona, the Republican nominee for' the Assembly, had also been named by the American Labor party for the post and that furthermore: he had accepted the Labor party designation.

W. G. Van Schmus, general director of Radio City Music Hall, returned from Europe yesterday on the Italian liner Rex after an unsuccessful search abroad for new talent for the hall. All the talent, he said, "appears to be right here in America."

A letter protesting 'he "commercialization" of Palisades Interstate Park and the "high-handed" methods of the park administration was sent today to Governor Lehman by Ray K. Masters, WPA Administrator of Rockland County.

It was only after considerable difficulty in persuading them to appear at all, that the Sudeten German delegates tonight went to Kolowrat Palace to read their reply to the government's proposals embodied in its draft of a nationalities
John M. Callahan of Cincinnati was elected today president of the International Association of Printing House Craftsmen at the closing session of their convention.
Delegates voted as follows as the housing article was adopted in final form by the Constitutional Convention early this morning:

Wilfrid Brunder, 133 West 121st Street, 42-year-old native of the British West Indies who quit working as a shipping clerk in the cloak and suit business in 1923 to become a policy banker, was called as the first witness.
President Roosevelt today directed that three merchant liners now named for States be renamed in honor of South American countries at whose ports they will stop.

Prices on the New York Cotton Exchange steadied again yesterday and under persistent trade calling ended with net gains of 3 to 7 points. October proved the strongest month under buying by spot houses, whereas limited selling orders appeared to be centered in
Interest abroad, particularly in the United States, in the 1940 Olympic Games already has reached a high point, it was learned today in official quarters, and inquiries are increasing daily..
Low bids on several Coast Guard projects in the New York and New Jersey area were announced today by the Treasury Department.

Five motions to make effective the reorganization plan for the closed Lawyers Mortgage Company were presented yesterday to Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler and adjourned for a hearing on Sept. 7.

George R. Fearon, up-State Republican leader, made a bitter attack on Senator Robert F. Wagner on the floor of the Constitutional Convention today and called for a coalition of conservatives in the Fall elections.
Douglas Corrigan continued his national tour with amazing accuracy today and crossed paths here tonight with Presid nt Roosevelt.

Mrs. Grace Edith Van Antwerp Waterman, widow of Theodore H. Waternman, died today in her seventy-ninth year. She was the daughter of a Netherlands family that settled in New York in the seventeenth century.

After deliberating twenty-six hours a Federal court jury tonight convicted two companies and two individuals in cases involving charges of conspiracy and use of the mails to defraud, and acquitted one defendant.

New orders of stock sash, doors and frames during July increased 47 per cent over June and 6 per cent over July, 1937, according to figures issued yesterday by the National Door Manufacturers Association.

Four men were arrested tonight on charges of forgery and fake registration of cattle involving what State troopers and - State agents said was a conspiracy to defraud the State of thousands of dollars through a "racket" in claims for
The Reichsbank's statement for Aug. 16 shows the following changes from the preceding week in thousands of marks:

George Lansbury, former British Labor leader, arrived here this afternoon. He received newspaper men and told them that he was now visiting the Balkans after visiting Scandinavia in order to exchange views that would be useful

A penthouse restaurant, one side of which faces a roof garden, was opened yesterday in the county court house, Foley Square, especially for the jurors who will determine the guilt or innocence of James J. Hines, Tammany leader, on trial charged with conspiracy in the policy racket.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated Aug. 16: COLONELS Rogers. J. A., F.A., one month and one day leave, Aug. 29.

A gang of Arabs last night attacked the prison labor camp at Athlit, wounded the British superintendent and an Arab guard and then kidnapped Moses Leizerovitz, Jewish police inspector; his wife, two sons and Eliah Kortziner, the inspector's brother-in-law.

Alphonse L. McCormick, county detective on the staff of District Attorney Charles P. Sullivan of Queens, died yesterday in a hospital at Winsted, Conn., of pneumonia after an illness of several weeks.
Back in the days of the World War Mrs. Elmer F. Andrews learned about government workings while serving in the purchasing department of the Chemical Warfare Service.
