William Harvey J. Ely of Rutherford, State WPA Administrator, was named as the Democratic State organization's candidate for United States Senator this afternoon by Charles Quinn, secretary of the Democratic State committee.
DESIGNING WOMEN, by Margaretta Byers. (Simon Schuster, $1.96.) The art, technique and cost of being beautiful. THE EVOLUTION OF FINANCE CAPITALISM, by George W. Edwards. (Longmans, Green, $4.)

Miss Marsyl Stokes, daughter of Mrs. Henry Drummond-Wolff, is to give' a cocktail party for a group of her young friends in the Summer colony on Sunday at Bois Dore, the home of Mrs. William Fahnestock, where she has been a house guest since her arrival from England.

Following is a comparison for New York City and the counties -of Westchester, Nassau and Suffolk of the present representation in the Legislature and the proposed representation under the Republican reapportionment measure, advanced to third reading today in the Constitutional Convention:

Frederick W. Kehl of Madison, Wis., believed by friends to have been the oldest active dancing master in the United States, died here today at the home of a son, Dr. S. C. Kehl. Mr. Kehl was 76 years old.

Following instructions issued by Mayor La Guardia last May, the Board of Education at a meeting yesterday requested the Corporation Counsel to take steps immediately to transfer to the. Department of Welfare the operation of free bus service for parochial and other non-public school children.
Mrs. Edith McClelland, 29 years old, of 66 Edmund Street, Lynbrook, gave birth to triplets this afternoon at the Nassau Hospital here. The babies, two girls and a boy,
The last wish of a sculptor that his heart be buried in front of a war memorial that he executed in Edinburgh has been refused by the corporation of that city. it was learned here today.
The two houses of Russia's Supreme Soviet Parliament, sitting in joint session, today elected a Supreme Court of forty-five members.

One-sixteenth of all the persons who hold regular jobs in this country work for some agency, of government, according to a study made public yesterday by the statistical division of the National Industrial Conference Board.

Rembrandt's portrait of his wife, Saskia, has been sold to the National Gallery by the Duke of Buccleuch, it was learned today. The price was not revealed, but it is understood that it was approximately ??20,000.

For the fifth consecutive year the world stocks of motor vehicles, excluding motor cycles, has moved upward to a new total, Secretary Roper stated today. American cars account for Nor 81.7 per cent of the registrations.

A banking group composed of Lehman Brothers, the First Boston Corporation, Morse Brothers Co., Inc., and Brown Groll received yesterday $855,000 Auburn, N. Y., school and refunding bonds on a bid of 100.23 for 1.60s. The bonds,

Clarence Sackett, lawyer and former official stenographic reporter for United States courts in New Jersey, died here last night at his home. Mr. Sackett was born seventy-eight years ago in New York a son of William E. and Josephine Findlay Sackett.
Governor Leslie A. Miller was assured of renomination today. Returns from 350 of the State's 683 precincts gave him 9,697 votes to 3,985 for Gus Engelking, rancher, in yesterday's Democratic primary.

Iron workers swung red-hot rivets into place as electric hammers chattered yesterday to bring to near completion the base structure of the "Road of Tomorrow," the major part of the exhibit of the Ford Motor Company for the New York World's Fair.
The German Foreign Office said today in its official organ, Diplomatische Korrespondenz, that Secretary Hull showed a "narrow mental horizon" in his international radio broadcast last night.
The defending women's champion, Miss Mary Arnold of Los Angeles, was eliminated from the sixteenth annual national public courts tennis championships today by Miss Catherine Malcolm of Chicago.
Stocks eased and closed irregular after early gains; turnover, 595,950 shares. United States Government and other bonds irregularly higher; transactions, $4,977,400.
State rights were emphasized today by Senator Walter F. George, who is on the New Deal "purge" list, in a campaign address assailing Administration "bureaucracy."
Richard A. Brace, former State Assemblyman from Montgomery County, died yesterday at his home here. He was 77 years old.

Joseph L. Buttenwieser of 885 ark Avenue, real estate operator and philanthropist, died suddenly yesterday of a heart attach in the ??oland Springs House, South Poland, Me., where he had been accustomed to pass his vacation. He was 73 years old.

Under the Influence of continued hot weather trading was almost at a standstill in practically . all classes of fresh meats in local markets yesterday. The lamb market was sharply lower. Cow, veal and calf about steady, other classes weak to lower.

Thunder from the skies silenced the thunder of the, Yankee bats today. A violent electrical storm that began just after Dutch Leonard started warming up brought torrents of rain that washed away the encounter with the Senators.

Pope Pius today firmly rebutted attacks made last week by Fascist extremist newspapers, which charged that Catholic Action was really a political rather than a religious association and as such entirely distinct from the church. Addressing a group of girl members of Catholic Action, he reaffirmed that the church and Catholic Action were indivisible.

Jane Toppan, often referred to as "one of the most notorious poisoners of the world," died today in Taunton. State Hospital, where she had been an inmate for more than thirty-six years. She was 84 years old.

While representatives of fourteen countries on four continents reported on the conditions existing among the youth of their homelands and their views of the way to world peace, spokesmen for the Second World Youth Congress, in session at Vassar College, defended it today from accusations that it was a "front organization" for communism.

The Spanish Government today asked the British committee of investigation on air bombardments of civilian centers to make a report on recent bombings of Alicante, important Mediterranean port of government Spain.

The Bureau of Air Commerce today announced the appointment of a special board to investigate the disappearance on July 28 of the Pan American Airways Hawaiia Clipper between Guam and Manila. The members are Robert D. Hoyt, Philip C. Salzman and William T.

More than 6,000 workers in the B knitgoods industry, members of the Knitgoods Workers Union, Local 155, an affiliate of the International Ladies Garment Workers, ratified yesterday the agreement reached by the union with the United Knitwear Manufacturers League.

The will of Mrs. Emeline Harriman Olin, filed for probate today, shows a personal estate of about $200,000. To the Salvation Army and the Army and Navy Y. M. C. A. of this city was given $10,000 each.
The Tigers captured both ends of a double-header with the White Sox today, taking the opener, 4 to 3, and the nightcap, 3 to 2.

Plans for modernizing the fivestory houses at 2,315-17 Third Avenue, between139th and 140th Streets, the Bronx, were announced in connection with the sale of the property by Sadye Goldman to the Vividon Realty Corporation.

The Monmouth Freebooters downed the Rumson Country Club's polo quartet, 9 to 3, today to gain the semi-finals of the Monmouth County Country Club annual ten-goal tournament. George Oliver sparked the winners with five goals.

The, capture of a man charged with holding up Barbieri's restaurant, 126 William Street, soon after 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon was effected by two employes of the place, who chased the hold-up man through the crowded finanoist district and seized him after he had fled into a subway station, through several cars of an I. R. T. train, out again and into a telephone booth in a cigar store at 140 Fulton Street.

All classes and grades of slaughter livestock showed some price improvement today and trade was active in all branches. Cooler weather, as well as smaller receipts in the aggregate at principal markets, served to stimulate the trade the United States Department of Agriculture reports.
Dr. C. O. Hilton of Newark advanced to the fourth round of the national

Counsel for the Missouri Pacific Railroad Company filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission 321 specific exceptions to the report filed by Richard Townsend, examiner, in proceedings to determine whether the preferred and common stocks of the Missouri Pacific should be suspended or withdrawn from the New York Stock Exchange.

George Weinberg, a quiet-lipped gangster with flickering eyes who handled the operations end of the policy racket for Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, pointed a quavering finger at James J. Hines, Tammany district leader, yesterday and named him as the man who agreed, for pay, to "fix" courts in behalf of a rich illegal lottery.

An organ, valued at $61,000, removed from the one-time castle of Dr. C. V. Paterno on the Hudson River in New York City, which is to be demolished to make room for a modern apartment house, was stored away today in the crypt of St. Paul's Episcopal Church here to await installation in the proposed new $200,000 edifice.
Three train wrecks along the PeipingHankow Railway have been reported in the past week as a result of increasing activity of Chinese guerrillas along that line.

The Washington of the United States Lines is due to arrive today from the Channel ports. Passengers are P. A. S. Franklin, chairman of the International Mercantile Marine Company, and Mrs. Franklin; Charles R. Hook, Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, Miss Marion Dickerman, Mr. and Mrs. Stewart M. Lowry, Walter J. Pickering, James Cahill, George Brandt, Mrs. Ernest Thompson Seton, Captain Mark Boatner, Bishop Harold G. Reynolds, Mrs. Morgan Hamilton and Mrs. Thomas H. Bevan.

Mr. and Mrs. William Castle Herrick entertained at dinner last evening at their Summer home for Mr. and Mrs. Rodney S. Jarvis, Mrs. Kirkwood E. Jewett, Mr. and Mrs. D. Walter Mabee and Kirkwood E. Jewett Jr. of New York.

Prince and Princess Irbain-Khan Kaplanoff entertained with a reception and tea this afternoon at the Southampton Beach Club for Mrs. James H. Caldwell and Mrs. William J. Hutchinson, who are at the Irving for a short stay, and for Miss Lelia Sinclair of Baltimore, who is visiting Arthur Sinclair at his Summer home.
Secretary Wallace. announced today that he hoped to have a plan perfected within a week to subsidize the export of about 100,000,000 bushels of surplus wheat during the current wheat year.

Leon Jouhaux, general secretary of the French Federation of,Labor, embarked here yesterday on the liner Paris for Mexico City, where he will take part in the World Labor Congress, scheduled for Sept. 7 to 12.

The annual fancy dress ball was held at the Harbor Club this evening for the benefit of the Mount Desert Island Hospital. The motif of the affair called for "anything from Arabian Nights" characters to "Modes of 1950."
Harry Langdon, who has been absent from the screen for five years, was signed today by Hal Roach to replace Stan Laurel, who has been placed under permanent suspension.

Mayor La Guardia watched the novel spectacle of a concrete cutting machine grinding 707 slot machines to small bits at the rate of four a minute yesterday morning in the Police Department garage, foot of Thirty-sixth Street.

Attorneys representing a group of stockholders of the Missouri-Kansas Pipe Line Company, announced today that they had sent a letter to directors opposing a compensation plan which they said would be offered to William G. Maguire,

Miss Miriam Selina Tilden, daughter of Mrs. John Oswald MacIntosh of Germantown, Philadelphia, and the late Herbert M. Tilden, was married here today in St. James's Catholic Church to Major Robert Denis Ambrose of the Sixth Rajputana Rifles. British Army.
A considerable improvement in the accident record of the railroads through May compared with the same period last year was reported today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.
Unionport Rd (15-4256), e s, 125 ft n of Sagamore St. 14Tx99; Belhar Corp to 1,954 Unionport Corp. 1,018 E 163d St; mtg $192,060.

Walter S. Holcomb, brother of Connecticut's wartime Governor, Maris H. Holcomb (1915-1921) and gate's Attorney for Litchfield county from 1917 to 1934, died today in a Torrington Hospital where he had been ill for several months. His age was 84.

A possible clue- to the fate of a missing Russian transpolar plane sent members of the Rogers-Post memorial expedition to Oliktuk today for a search near the mouth of the Colville River, 125 miles east of here.
Adolph Menger, 55 years old, a grocery store owner here, was killed instantly early this morning when he was struck by an automobile near his home during a heavy rainstorm.

A hearing scheduled for Friday at the Securities and Exchange Commission's offices here on an application of the committee for debenture holders of Midland Utilities Company for approval of a reorganization plan was postponed by the commission today until next Tuesday because of the death of John M. Shannahan, one of the trustees-of the estate of the Midland Utilities Company.

Miss Theona Slater, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward S. Slater of Greenwich, was married to the Rev. R. Kenneth Smelser, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roy C. Smelser of Altoona, Pa., today in the Swedish Evangelical Church here.

Business is better than it was several months ago, but the improvement is slower than on previous occasions when comparable sums of taxpayers' money were being spent to stimulate an upturn, Henry H. Heimann, executive manager of the National Association of Credit Men, asserted yesterday.
West Broadway, 351-3, Laurence G. Mintzer and another to 351-353 West Broadway Holding Corp, 551 5th Ave, two-fifths interest ($15).

Both the French Embassy and the Commission of Foreign Diplomats, which administers the Peiping diplomatic quarter, tonight lodged strongly worded protests with Japanese authorities against the detention of two members of the French Embassy's military guard.
The first issue of a magazine titled American Lady is scheduled to reach the newsstands today. Mary T. Gronich of The Current Digest magazine is publisher and Grace F. Caldwell editor.
Turpentine firm, 22 1/4c: sales, 22 barrels: receipts, 487 barrels; shipments, 35 barrels; stock, 44,016 barrels. Rosin firm; sales, 450; receipts, 2,362; shipments, 3; stock, 212,798.

William Kolarik, 36 years old, of 37-57 Ninety-third Place, Jackson Heights, Queens, pleaded guilty yesterday before General Sessions Judge Allen to thefts aggregating more than $10,000 from Travel Advertising, Inc., at 30 Rockefeller Plaza, when he was its president.
The Alabama Board of Pardons denied pleas of two of the "Scottsboro rape case" Negroes for freedom today.

Savings banks continued yesterday to dispose of realty holdings in scattered sections of Manhattan. A lower East Side deal involved the two five-story tenements at 112-14 Monroe Street, which were sold by the Central Savings Bank to a client of Mathias Sternberg, attorney.

Mrs. Daniel Dodge, widow of the heir to the motor car fortune who was drowned in Georgian Bay Monday after a dynamite explosion, said today that she believed her husband was thrown overboard by a lurch of the motorboat.
Representative John J. O'Connor, placed on the Administration's "purge" list by President Roosevelt, will carry the war to his political enemies tonight in a nation-wide radio address.

For the first time in weeks, the government war commiunique tonight registers a victory on the Estremadura front in southwestern Spain. Rebel troops that had crossed the Zujar River near the Castuera-Puebla de Alcocer road were reported driven back across the river.

Brooklyn at New York-Pressnell (10-11) or Mungo (4-9) vs. Hubbell (13-9). Boston at Philadelphia-MacFayden (10-5) vs. Passeau (9-13). Cincinnati at Chicago-Derringer (15-9) vs. Root (4-3). Pittsburgh at St. Louis--Bauers (8-8) or Klinger (8-4) vs. Weiland (11-9).

Considerable mystery has been attached in banking circles over the nonappearance in any of the Federal Government's gold tables of a considerable amount of gold due late last week to arrive on the Pacific Coast from Japan. Apparently this metal has been placed under earmark for future use by Tokyo.

The Central Railroad of New Jersey has put before holders of large amounts of its bonds and before the trustees for the bonds a proposal to dispose of certain lands now pledged as security for the issues. Under the proposals, lands which are of no use to the railroads would be relinquished, with an estimated saving of $400,000 annually in taxes. The lands,
John N. Shannahan of Indianapolis, public utility executive, died of heart disease late yesterday at Belgrade Lake, Me. His age was 66.
Mrs. Ida L. Churchill of this city died on Monday at her Winter residence in St. Petersburg, Fla., acI cording to word received here today. Her age was 84.

Canada's exports of domestic products in July had a total value of $66,915,722, compared with $99,157,775 in. uly, 1937, the Department of National Revenue announced today., Decreases were recorded in the exports of all the principal commodities.

Religion, education and economics were brought together in the second day of the Rural and Industrial Conference at St. Francis Xavier University here, where the Extension Department has for eight years promoted the growth of cooperatives in the Maritime Provinces brough study clubs among the people.
A highway bridge for Kearny, N. J., was one of forty additional non-Federal projects for which the Public Works Administration today made loans totaling $185,000 and grants amounting to $3,193,356.

Auguste J. Grenet, leading pricemaker of American race tracks, who made the odds for most of the bookmakers at the metropolitan courses, died late Tuesday night of a heart attack in Saratoga Springs, N. Y., in a cottage he had rented for the racing season. He was 77 years old.
A new and intricate Kind of lawcircumventing wagerless bet attracted a small army of lawenforcers when dog racing was revived here tonight.

Two New York department stores have entered into stipulations with the Federal Trade Commission to discontinue certain misrepresentations in advertising and selling women's apparel, the commission announced today. Arnold Constable Co.,

The three-story factory building and five garages on a plot 50 by 100 feet at 571-5 Liberty Avenue, Brooklyn, were sold by M. Shepeloff to the Addis Manufacturing Company, manufacturers of confectionery novelties. George L. Miller, broker, negotiated the deal.

A number of dwellings and several vacant plots figured in the deals on Long Island reported by brokers yesterday. Included was the six-family house at 47-07 Fortyseventh Avenue, Long Island City, which was purchased by Stephania Kasprzycka through Harold I. Cross, broker.
The Republican reapportionment bill was advanced to third reading late this afternoon in the Constitutional Convention by a vote of 91 to 57.
The German and Italian military delegates who came here to participate in the St. Stephen's festival were today were received by Admiral Nicholas Horthy, Hungarian Regent.

For the first time in more than two weeks buying activity in the wholesale furniture market here declined this week, a direct result, manufacturers said, of the uhfavorable weather which has affected sales at retail.

Albert Gross, 39 years old, of 250 St. Nicholas Avenue, was arrested outside the city Health Building yesterday by Detective Lieutenant James J. McCoy, who charged him with petit larceny by fleecing pharmacists on promises of getting them jobs in the State Board of Pharmacy and in the city's civil service.

The government today threatened to put the entire port district of Marseilles under military rule unless longshoremen and employers settle differences that have resulted in loss of thousands of tons of perishable freight in the last two weeks.
United States swimmers split with German stars in six events in the Americans' second meet of a European tour today.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Aug. 15: LIEUTENANT COMMANDER Miller, T. C., Chaplain Corps, San Diego, Calif., to the Wright.

W. F. Stroud, 29 years old, a bookkeeper employed by Jonas Shoppes, Inc., 370 Seventh Avenue, was arrested last night on a charge that he had absconded with $3,300 of the concern's money from its Richmond (Va.) branch.

With the logical winners coming through all along the line, J. Donald Budge, the national champion, led the advance to the quarter-final round of the Newport invitation tennis tournament today on the rain-drenched turf of the Casino.

Two seconds and a third place scored by Bob Gordon and his defending champion Pequot Yacht Club crew brought them a slim lead for first place in the series for the Long Island Sound junior yachting championship off the Pequot Club today.

FURNITURE MAKERS DISTRIBUTORS. INC., 202 Canal St.-By Meinhard-Greeff Co., for $150: Lisson Mclen Co., $66; Anniston Mills, Inc., $206; Emerson-Steuben Mills, $54; Twenty-first Street Upholsterers Supply House. 525.

It was on the eighth hole at the Echetah Country Club. A slice carried Lonnie Minor's ball into the rough. The caddie investigated sufficiently to find the ball wrapped around by the rattlesnake's body, and eight rattles buzzing.
The Browns knocked three Cleveland pitchers around for sixteen hits today, with Beau Bell contributing four, and came out on top, 10-7.
Ira Hutchinson outpitched Max Butcher of the Phillies today to gain a 3-to-O shut-out for the Bees. The game was called at the end of the eighth because of rain and darkness.

Phillip Coffin Jr., former Assistant Attorney General of New Jersey, and N. Frank Whealton of Philadelphia tonight were found guilty of fraudulent marketing of oil securities by a jury before Judge Phillip Forman in Federal court here.

Discovery today of marihuana valued at $10,000 growing near the corner of Grand Avenue and Olive Street, in the center of the city, duplicated a discovery made in Hamden last week, and solved the riddle of "reefer" cigarette smoking by school children here in the last two years.
Hugo Freidmann, New York importer, won the admiration of the French police and considerable personal satisfaction today by capturing

The City Planning Commission at a meeting yesterday in City Hall gave preliminary authorization to Park Commissioner Moses to proceed with the drafting of plans for the park to be developed along the East River between Grand and Montgomery Streets and between the East River Drive and the river.

There were two big surprises in the thirty-sixth Catskill Handicap today, the first the victory of the Wheatley Stable's Merry Lassie and the second the disqualification of Go Home from the show position for an offense which may or may not have occurred.
The first sailing of the American Republics Line under the management of Moore McCormack between ports on the east coast of North and South America will be on Oct. 8, it was announced yesterday.

President Roosevelt today announced the reappointment of Orville Wright, Dr. Joseph S. Ames, Edward P. Warner, Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh and Commander Jerome C. Hunsaker as members of the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics.

There were two big surprises in the thirty-sixth Catskill Handicap today, the first the victory of the Wheatley Stable's Merry Lassie and the second the disqualification of Go Home from the show position for an offense which may or may not have occurred.
The first sailing of the American Republics Line under the management of Moore McCormack between ports on the east coast of North and South America will be on Oct. 8, it was announced yesterday.

The first clear-cut evidence of the intention of two of the country's largest public utility holding companies to comply with the integration provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act appeared yesterday when it became known that the Cities Service Company had entered into negotiations looking toward the sale of its utility properties in Michigan and Ohio to the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation.

The Italian cotton market showed marked improvement in 1937, compared with 1936, the Department of Commerce announced today, recording a larger consumption of raw materials, a larger production of yarn, fabrics and manufactures in general,

Miss Margaret Lynn Hefferan and Charles J. McLachlan were married 'yesterday morning in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral by the Rev. John C. McCarthy. The wedding took place in a floral setting of Easter lilies and white dahlias against a background of palms.

The marriage of Miss Yvonne Georgette Muser, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Max Muser of 1,391 Madison Avenue, to Robert Windate Mortimer Given, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest D. Given, also of this city, took place yesterday afternoon at the Westbury Hotel, 15 East Sixty-ninth Street.

Lloyd Paul Stryker's opening address to the jury in the trial of James J. Hines yesterday follows: May it please Your Honor, Mr. Foreman and Gentlemen of the Jury: I listened, of course, with interest to Mr. Dewey's opening. I felt that perhaps it would assist you in understanding the brief

There is a possibility that many opposed to the President's Democratic party "purge," now broadening, will do two things which will aid Mr. Roosevelt in enlarging the size of the New Deal rubber-stamp in Congress. One is that his opponents will mistake their own indignation for a popular uprising against the President.

The Philadelphia Federal Reserve Bank's monthly statement said today that manufacturing industries in Delaware reported an increase of 3 per cent in employment and payrolls from June to July. Working time also indicated a marked expansion in plant activity.
George Preston and Eddie DeGray of New York won the men's doubles of the Powelton Club invitation tennis tournament Sunday by default from Larry Krieger and Robert Peelor of Poughkeepsie,
The leagueleading Pirates shook off a spell of lethargy at the last minute today to protect their five-game lead over the Giants with a 4-to-3 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals.

Mr. and Mrs. Peter A. B. Widener 2d will return from Europe tomorrow. They will be at the SavoyPlaza. Mrs. F. Raymond Holland has returned to 277 Park Avenue after a visit with her father, Poultney Bigelow, in Malden-on-Hudson.

There is a possibility that many opposed to the President's Democratic party "purge," now broadening, will do two things which will aid Mr. Roosevelt in enlarging the size of the New Deal rubber-stamp in Congress. One is that his opponents will mistake their own indignation for a popular uprising against the President.

The Philadelphia Federal Reserve Bank's monthly statement said today that manufacturing industries in Delaware reported an increase of 3 per cent in employment and payrolls from June to July. Working time also indicated a marked expansion in plant activity.

William Elliott of 502 Park Ave nue, New York, a retired banker, died today in Southampton Hospital after a short illness at the age of 80. He had been passing the Summer at the home of a son, William Elliott Jr., of East Hampton.
Miss Virginia Hegarty, daughter of Daniel A. Hegarty of Philadelphia, will be married to John A. Bigelow 3d of this city on Aug. 27 in the Church of the Transfiguration.

Walter L. Dusenberry, division manager in New York City of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, died early today at the Meadowbrook Hospital here of injuries he received on Saturday when he crashed in a glider at the Airhoppers Gliding and Soaring Club near Hicksville, L. I. Mr. Dusenberry, a licensed pilot and long an enthusiastic flier, lived at 1,218 Schenectady Avenue, Brooklyn. His age was 44.

Lily Pons received an ovation unequaled here for twenty-five years when she gave her farewell recital at the Colon Theatre this afternoon. She sang selections from Mozart, Rossini, Liszt, Debussy and others.
Freeport almost added an exciting chapter to its fishing history Tuesday, but a porgy in the boat is better than a blue marlin on the line.

The eslimated operating revenues of ninety-one class I railroads, representing 80.2 per cent of the total operatingg revenues, were about $50,200,000 lower in July than in the same month last year, the Association of American Railroads anaounced today. Operating revenues last month were reported as $240.

Six charitable institutions are named among the beneficiaries of the will of Mrs. Mary Edey, widow of Charles L. Edey, broker, who died on Aug. 2 at Southampton, L. I., in her eighty-third year. Her will was- filed for- probate in Surrogate's Court yesterday. The value of the estate was not disclosed.
Undaunted by the tense international situation and apprehensions aroused both in Germany and abroad by intensified German military preparations and the continued crash on Gerrman

Wheat prices continued on the upgrade today and while there was a fair volume of business most of it was of a professional character. Strength in large measure was in sympathy with advances in Kansas City and Minneapolis.

DU CRET, ARTHUR F. (Aug. 14, 1937). Gross assets, $59.583: net. $54,534. To sons, Sheldon A. and Herbert S. Du Cret, one-half of residuary estate each. Chief assets, real estate, $12,500; stocks and bonds, $17,682; mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $11,784; miscellaneous property, $17,616. Henry S. Hendricks, attorney, 7 Dey St., Manhattan.
A fairly broad investment demand made itself felt yesterday in bond trading on the New York Stock Exchange as prices in most groups recorded substantial improvement in slightly more active trading.

Anthony Berbrick, 33 years old, of 148-40 Ninetieth Avenue, Jamaica, Queens, was held without bail for the action of the Nassau County grand jury by Judge Joseph Lebkeucher in First District Court here this morning on a charge of first degree burglary.

Officials of the Central Park Zoo proudly surveyed a new and extremely welcome addition yesterday afternoon-Bwana, a strapping, 400pound lion bred in the jungles of Tanganyika, East Africa. For Bwana, although a bit timid now, is expected to play a stellar role in the lion house in the next year or two.

John Marks, 38 years old, of 420 East Eighty-sixth Street, who was a disbarred as a lawyer last June for taking fees in a case when he should have turned them over to a client, was held in $2,500 bail for the grand jury in Felony Court yesterday for the alleged theft of $7,663 in bonds from an estate of which he was counsel before his disbarment.
Two interesting suburban waterfront estates are about to be sold under the auctioneer's hammer, together with their furnishings and collections of antiques.

The open split between liberal and conservative Democrats in the Constitutional Convention was accentuated early thTs morning when John T. Dooling, chairman of the Tammany Hall law committee, and Presiding Justice Francis Martin of the Appellate Division, First Department, assailed Supreme Court Justice Charles Poletti for a radio speech he had made last night.

Electric power production increased last week against a downward seasonal trend, and the adjusted index rose to 96.0, its highest level this year. The figure was 95.1 for the preceding week, and 109.6 for the week ended Aug. 14, 1937.
A hearing was opened in Utica today before Ernest I. Edcomb, official referee, with the aim of halting by injunction the purchase of the Consolidated Water Company by the city of Utica.

After an ownership of more than forty years, the two three-story buildings at 429-31 Second Avenue were sold by the estate of John B. Green to Abraham Pollack for cash over a purchase-money mortgage of $7,000. The buyer has been a tenant in the building for twentynine years.

Paced by their newly acquire third sacker, the streamlined George Myatt, who certainly dashes around like a young man in a great hurry to get some place, the Giants yesterday launched what they fervently hope will be the forerunner of that big September push to another National League pennant.

The physical fitness of Charles Harrison, 56-year-old president of the Star Stitching Manufacturing Corporation, 575 Eighth Avenue, led to the capture of an alleged payroll thief just before noon yesterday. Despite the heat, Mr. Harrison raced down five flights of stairs to the building's fourth floor landing and caught a suspect after the robber had snatched $920 in $10 notes from a $4,000 payroll Mr. Harrison was sorting.
The board of directors of the Wentworth Manufacturing Company has declared a dividend of 10 cents on the common stock. The last payment on this stock was 10 cents, on Sept. 1, 1937.

A miscellaneous group of yearlings, brood mares, weanlings and horses in training passed through the sales ring tonight, attracting only a small number of bidders and bringing $39,500 for forty-four lots.
The body of Mgr. Andreas Hlinka, leader of the Slovak autonomy movement, who died yesterday, was embalmed today. It will rest in a Rozmberk cemetery until a mausoleum is built.

For the second time within a month the Constitutional. Convention refused today to advance to third reading the Feinberg proposal that would require a mandatory earmarking of the first 2 cents. of the four-centa-gallon gasoline tax for the exclusive use of-highway construction and maintenance.

Doing all their scoring in the third and fourth innings, Cincinnati mixed Harry Craft's thirteenth homer and eleven other hits with a pair of Chicago errors today to defeat the Cubs, 8 to 4, and take third place away from Gabby Hartnett's charges.

Admiral Charles Pipon Beaty-Pownall, who played a considerable part in the capture of German territory in the Cameroons during the World War and was an aide de camp to King George V, died in Alton, Hampshire, today at the age of 66.

SINGLES Fourth Round J. Donald Budge, Oakland, Calif., defeated Archie Henderson, Chapel Hill, N. C., 6-4, 6--3; Wilmer Allison, Austin, Texas, defeated John Van Ryn, Austin, Texas, 6-2, 9--7; Bryan M. Grant Jr., Atlanta, defeated Jack Kramer, Los Angeles, 5-7, 6-4, 6-2; Yvon Petra, France, defeated William Murphy, Chicago, 6-4, 6-4.

Monroe St, 95, 24.6x100; 95 Monroe Street Corp. to Anna Spellens, 1.542 Madison Ave; pr mtg, $7,000, 3 yrs, 6%; $3,500. 65th St, 52-56 W, 75x100.5; pr mtg, $246.000, also property in Kings County, 56-65 Street Corp to Montrose Industrial Bank. 781 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn; demand 6%: $15.000.

Miss Priscilla Muriel Howes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Franklin J. Howes of this place, has completed plans for her marriage to James H. Braddock, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold B. Braddock of Montclair, which will take place on Sept. 17.
Mrs. Katharine Seelye Wallace, special of Benjamin D. Wallace, special adviser. on international trade policies of the Tariff Commission, in Washington, died today after along illness.

It took the combined efforts of a squad of patrolmen and firemen tonight to rescue Skippy, an airedale, from a fifteen-foot crevice in an abandoned stone quarry at Bergen Turnpike, near Hamilton Avenue.

Three national trade associations will assist in the national 'retail demonstration which will be staged by stores of all types under the direction of the National Retail Dry Goods Association during the week of Sept. 19, the N. R. D. G. A. announced yesterday.

THE trouble is that one thing leads to another. It was as hot as usual and in walked a chunky chap with a briefcase under his arm and a threatening look in his eye. He wasted no time in plunging into his opening address. "How come," he said somewhat belligerently, "you wrote that polo is the only sport that has no amateur rule?"

The Czech Consulate in Vienna has in its custody several automobiles that belonged to Vienna residents of Czechslovak citizenship. The consulate has issued an appeal to the unknown owners to give orders for their disposal.
Mgr Edward J. McGoldrick of Brooklyn, N. Y., seriously ill the past two weeks in Ballyshannon Hospital, Donegal, received a chance for recovery today.

Adolph Lewisohn, New York investnment broker and philanthro-. pist, died today at his Summer home on Upper Saranac Lake. He was 89 years old. Members of the family said death resulted from a heart attack. With him when he died were his son and daughter-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Lewisohn, and several grandchildren.
The Constitutional Convention was urged today by Governor Lehman to defeat the proposal which would give preference to war veterans in civil service appointments.

Judge Samuel K. Dennis sentenced Charles Bird, Midwestern desperado, to forty-five and a half years in State prison today after the slight, 26-year-old gunman pleaded guilty to seven robbery charges under which he might have been sentenced to 140 years.

A hearing will be held at the Securities and Exchange Commission offices here on Sept. 20 on the application of the New York Stock Exchange to strike from listing and registration the no-par value common stock of The Advance-Rumely Corporation, La Porte, Ind., the commission announced today.

Hopeful that children would no longer have to stay away from school because they had nothing to wear, the WPA began delivery to the Welfare Department yesterday of 102,000 sets of WPA-made clothing for distribution to needy elementary and high school students.

Fifty is the dangerous age for men. Then comes a crisis in life that is adolescence in reverse, Dr. W. R. Brown, British psychologist, told the British Association for the Advancement of Science meeting here today. It is the time, he said, when men go to psychoanalysts to have their conflicts and complexes ironed out.

Upsetting predictions of a split over the controversial issue of a program for world peace, the American delegation to the Second World Youth Congress now in session at Vassar College reached unanimous agreement today on a seven-point program closely resembling that enunciated on Tuesday by Cordell Hull, Secretary of State.

Another tall structure will rise in the vicinity of Rockefeller Center, it was learned yesterday, when John D. Rockefeller filed plans for a nine-story office building at the southwest corner of Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street.

Edgar B. Dunlap, counsel for the Georgia office of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, announced late today that he had acceded to demands from Washington to resign because of activities in behalf of Senator George.

Long George Gill effectively scattered eight hits and big Hank Greenberg emerged from a batting slump to drive in three runs, as the Tigers whipped the White Sox, 5-1, today to sweep a three-game series.

A British military column was ambushed this afternoon by a gang of well armed Arabs near Acre. The troops assisted by aircraft fought back and in the battle at least twenty-seven Arabs were killed by the fliers and ten more by the troops.

A young man described by the police as John Bellinger, 33 years old, of 320 East Fifty-fifth Street. awoke Father Joseph H. Sheehan at the Church of St. John the Evangelist at 351 East Fifty-fifth Street early this morning and said he had just shot a girl, his friend.

The City Planning Commission, one of Mayor La Guardia's pet city agencies, was attacked yesterday by several members of the Board of Estimate, who charged that the commission was trying to rob Borough Presidents of their best engineers to set up its own staff.

The Inland Steel Company made another move today in its fight against orders issued against it by the National Labor Relations Board. The company filed with the Labor Board at Washington a 173-page document in which it demands that the board set aside orders that would compel the Inland company to recognize a C.I. O. union as the sole bargaining agent for its employes.

Although consumption of Lake Superior iron ores increased from 1,471,660 gross tons in June to 1,674,721 tons in July, supplies at furnaces and at docks on Lake Erie increased during the month from 34,329,223 to 35,846,160 tons, the Lake Superior Iron Ore Association reported today.

During the week ended Aug. 17 member bank reserve balances increased $39,000,000. Additions to member bank reserves arose from decreases of $37,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve Banks and $16,000,000 in non-member deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts and increases of $19,000,000 in gold stock and $5,000,000 in Reserve Bank credit, offset in part by increases of $19,000,000 in money in circulation and $19,000,000 in Treasury cash.

A definite shortage of desirable merchandise in the men's clothing field will develop around October, manufacturers confidently predicted here yesterday. Retailers agreed in part with this assertion but said the possible scarcity of stocks depended to a great extent on early Fall retail trade.

The Commerce Department announced today that the Mexican Government has fixed valuations on export commodities for the purpose of levying the 12 per cent ad valorem export tax which is to be effective from Aug. 10 to Sept. 20 or until amended by subsequent announcements.
The Hupp Motor Car Company announced today that its directors had elected S. L. Davis of Chicago as president to succeed Tom Bradley, resigned.

The aviation fete today at Tushino, near Moscow, to celebrate the Soviet Union's annual Aviation Day, was witnessed by Joseph Stalin and other government leaders and Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh, who sat with the aviation group of Soviet Deputies in the pavilion.

Governor Lehman has appointed four executives of savings banks in this State as trustees of the general insurance guarantee fund of savings bank and life insurance, it was announced yesterday by Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance. They are Andrew Mills Jr.

After lengthy discussions the delegation from the American Association for the Advancement of Science and the British Association for the Advancement of Science have agreed on a first step in establishing an Anglo-American accord for the social interpretation of science.

After holding within unusually narrow limits, prices on the Cotton Exchange ended yesterday with losses of 3 to 7 points. Spot interests executed a large quantity of small hedging orders reflecting an increase in the outturn from gins as cotton picking progresses.

Trial Decisions The following members having been tried before Francis X. Giaccone. Deputy Fire Commissioner, on July 25, 1938, for violation of Rules and Regulations, 1937, the following decisions are rendered by the Fire Chief and Commissioner:

By a vote of 124 to 24, the Constitutional Convention approved today the Fertig transit unification clause. This would permit New York City to issue up to $315,000,000 of bonds, without regard to its debt limit, to buy the privately operated transit lines in the city.

The touring Australians defeated the army by an innings and 67 runs today in a two-day cricket match at Aldershot. It was their final first-class match before the start of the final test match against England Saturday.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated Aug. 17: LIEUTENANT COLONELS Shipp. W. E., (Cavalry) General Staff Corps, one day leave, Aug. 20.
Greentree had a field day in a tune-up match for the national open championship at Meadow Brook's Whitney Field today as It routed the Optimists, 18 to 4.

Accused of having attempted to obstruct justice by an effort to dissuade a witness from appearing in court, Louis Kassman, a bail bondsman, of 258 Roebling Street, Brooklyn, was paroled for a hearing Sept. 1 yesterday in Bridge Plaza Court, Brooklyn, by Magistrate Jacob Eilperin.

With Miss Mary Skorich giving five hits and fanning twenty-one, the Num Num Girls of Cleveland, world champions, defeated the New York Roverettes, 1 to 0, in the star contest of the women's softball double-header at Madison Square Garden last night.

The Cuban Government tonight announced a program to combat the island's economic crisis. Following the first meeting of President Federico Laredo Bru's new Cabinet, attended by Colonel Fuigencio Batista, chief of staff, seventeen measures were announced, to be put into effect immediately.

Not so many years ago it began to look as though wood were going out of style, except as used in trees. Some one even suggested that artificial trees might do better in Central Park than the real ones.

A nation-wide oratorical contest for young Republicans with prizes of a value of $15,000 to stimulate the interest of youth in "Republican and true American principles" was announced today by John D. M. Hamilton, chairman of the Republican National Committee.

Piloting his own plane Premier Mussolini left Rome at dawn flying to Italy's strongly fortified strategically important Pantelleria Island, about forty-five miles from Tunis, less than twenty-four hours after Air Marshal Italo Balbo had reported to him on his meeting with Chancellor Hitler and Air Minister Hermann Goering.

Two of the darkest of dark horses, Gene Kunes of Chicago and Ed Oliver of Wilmington, Del., turned in 67s to lead a smashing attack on par in the first round of the Canadian open golf championship today.

Father Andreas Hlinka, known to his countrymen in the United States and at home as the apostle of Slovak independence, passes from the scene at a crucial moment in the history of his country, when the home rule movement he led for forty years has assumed a form and a character which threaten the existence of the Czech Republic.

Pynson Printers announce that they have completed arrangements for the publication of their most ambitious work to date. It is "The Technique of the Woodcut and the Wood-engraving," compiled by the widely known craftsman, Hans Alexander Mueller.

With the conclusion of the Third Army war games, which ended in a draw today, there is a wide diversity of military opinion concerning the value of the exercises. Undoubtedly the days spent in the field have given the junior officers and soldiers training and experience of much value, but the general officers have had little opportunity to benefit.

President Roosevelt's pledge to Canada has been cordially received in Great Britain, but there is a note of warning in several newspaper editorials to the effect that the United States has not abandoned its traditional policy of isolation.
Following are the texts of the addresses here today of President Roosevelt and Premier Mackenzie King in connection with the dedication of the new international bridge:

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. J. Spencer Weed of this place of the engagement of Mr. Weed's daughter, Miss Janet Weed, to Charles Goetz of Washington, D. C., son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur H. Goetz of Racine, Wis.

The result of the second Senate election according to Premier Eamon de Valera's plans for a vocational chamber again showed political rather than vocational results. The Senate will have a majority for the government.

The Giants' pennant chances for 1938, already considered in serious jeopardy, suffered still another crushing blow last night when it was learned that Carl Hubbell, their ace left-hander, was suffering from an arm ailment which may put him out of action for the balance of the season.

Mayor La Guardia, who was criticized at the recent State convention of the American Legion because of the retention of Simon W. Gerson, a Communist, on the staff of Stanley M. Isaacs, Borough President of Manhattan, will attend the national convention of the Legion in Los Angeles next month.

Sales of wool goods this week fell below the weekly average for July, the New York Wool Top Exchange Service reported yesterday in its weekly summary. Men's wear mills started to book business on tropical worsted and other lightweight cloths for the coming Spring and Summer seasons, but initial business was not large, since not all the lines were ready and cutters were planning to sample all offerings and make comparisons before ordering.

Colonel George Moor Russell, United States Cavalry, died last night at Walter Reed General Hospital. He came here for treatment from New York, where he was on duty with the Organized Reserves. His age was 60.

Byrne E. Baldwin and Ralph B. Johnson of New York, stock brokers, and William C. Schmidt, an investment counselor, also of New York, were elected today directors of the Reynolds Investing Company, Inc.,

The increase in the amount of outstanding loans, which had been resumed in the preceding week, continued in the week ended on Wednesday, the condition statement of the reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City revealed yesterday.
The stock market here was quiet and generally steady today. Gilt-edge issues were uncertain. Among foreign bonds, Chinese loans advanced.

John R. Hill, long associated with the F. W. Woolworth Company, died at his home here today after a brief illness. Mr. Hill was born 68 years ago in North Bloomfield and came to Rochester as a young man.
Henry Witthack, Civil War veteran, died Wednesday night at his home, 31-18 Thirty-fourth Street, Astoria, Queens. He was 91 years old.
About $84,000,000 in gold has been segregated by Japan in a revolving fund for the financing of its foreign trade. Some of the gold already has been transferred to this country.
With the departure for Germany of Baron Redesdale, it was disclosed today that his daughter, Unity Mitford, one of Chancellor Hitler's most ardent British champions, was ill of pleurisy at Baireuth.

Transfers and Assignments To take effect 8 A. M., Aug. 19: LIEUTENANT-Walter J. Miller, from Traffic Precinct G to Traffic Precinct H, assigned to desk duty continued. THIRD GRADE DETECTIVES--From 18th Division, 8th Detective District to precincts specified, designation as third grade detectives revoked: ed:

Rayon loom activity or the week ended Aug. 13 showed very little change in operations on most' items, pigment taffetas being an exception, according to figures issued yesterday by the National Rayon weavers Association, Inc.

Announcement has been made of the marriage of Mrs. Dorothy Benjamin von Lar, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred H. Benjamin of 229 East Seventy-ninth Street, to William J. Harding Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Harding of 440 Park Avenue, which took place last Saturday in Elkton, Md.

One of the things discussed by President Roosevelt with Roswell Magill, Acting Secretary of the Treasury, when they took lunch together on Monday, was the President's plan for legislation to remove the present tax exemption from State and municipal wages and securities, Mr. Magill said at his press conference today.
The Board of Transportation awarded to Rusciano Son, Inc., yesterday the contract for construction of the second section of the Fulton Street subway extension in Brooklyn.

While admitting serious damage by grasshoppers and rust to the Canadian wheat crop, Paul Bredt, president of Manitoba Pool Elevators, Ltd., said today that the situation was "so spotty" it was difficult to tell the outcome.

A clock with ninety-three dials,' built at the suggestion of the late King Albert of Belgium by his clockmaker, Lodewyk Zimmer of Lierre, Belgium, was placed on exhibition yesterday at the Museum of Science and Industry in Rockefeller Center.

The Board of Education; at a meeting that lasted two and a half minutes yesterday, approved a Public Works Administration grant of $256,725 for the general construction of new Public School 213, at Hegeman Avenue, Vermont Street and New Jersey Avenue, Brooklyn.

The French liner Ile de France, arriving today from Havre and Southampton, has on board Deems Taylor, Martin Beck, Walter L. Johnson, president of the New York Cotton Exchange; L. T. Beale, Hugh Grant Strous, Louis Ruppel, Paul P. Cret, M. G. St. Germain, Dora L. Miller, Florence Cavanaugh, Mrs. Ben Levy, Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Kinkade, Mr. and Mrs. C. G. Burden and Mr. and Mrs. J. Lawrence Sellman.

Some indications of continued activity in automobile production was given yesterday when local distributors of parts and accessories reported that manufacturers had received calls from car makers for small additional quantities.

Many dinners were given tonight at Arrowhead Inn in connection with the eighth annual Turf Writers dinner dance. George H. Bull, racing association president, presented plaques to the four who contributed the most outstanding services to American racing in 1937, Herbert Bayard Swope, New York State Racing Commissioner;
President Roosevelt told Canadians today he did not think the Supreme Court would mind if he accepted an honorary degree from Queen's University here.

The weekly statement of the Bank of Canada today showed that the bank had become completely government-owned with capital and rest fund totaling $6,348,000, a decrease of $5,100,000 from the previous week.
The Federal Government sold a bank at auction today to a group of professional bill collectors. The-highest bid, at the end of a three-hour sale, was $3,460 for assets with a face value of $112,637.

With public construction 53 per cent above a year ago, engineering awards for the current week total $44,479,000, an increase of 3 per cent over the corresponding week in 1937, but a decrease of 42 per cent front the high volume of a week ago, according to The Engineering News-Record.

The Educational Supply Company of Racine, Wis., stipulated with the Federal Trade Commission today that it would discontinue certain misleading representations in advertising a correspondence course in commercial art.
The Eastchester Savings Bank sold to Lawrence J. Dingee the three-family house on a lot 25 by 100 feet at 224 North Terrace Avenue, Mount Vernon, N. Y., through Harry D. Cole, broker.

Buying of wheat futures which brokers credited to mills and to exporters, accompanied by reports that the domestic flour business was the best in some time, more than offset bearish foreign news in the market today.
William G. Maguire, president of the Missouri-Kansas Pipe Line Company, said today that directors were not considering employing him as general manager or granting him special options to buy stock.

German overtures for a trade treaty with the United States met with a cold reception here today when Secretary of State Cordell Hull said in effect that the Administration, dedicated to multilateral trade treaties, was not interested in bilateral exchange agreements.

Australia's young tennis stalwarts, Adrian Quist and Jack Bromwich, all but shut the door on Germany's Davis Cup hopes today, winning without the loss of a set the two singles matches that opened the interzone final between the two nations.
The Asbestos Corporation, Ltd., has declared an extra dividend of 50 cents and a quarterly dividend of 50 cents on its stock. The corporation paid similar amounts on June 30.
One thing hard to understand about Mr. Roosevelt's latest purge is that the purging should have begun the minute the President

Two American youths who fought for a time with the Loyalists in Spain testified today before the House committee investigating un-American activities that many of their companions were virtual prisoners and could not come home in spite of their wish to do so.

The marriage of Miss Patricia Marie White, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Mathias White of this place, to Everett Joseph LeMoult, son of Mr. and Mrs. Adolph LeMoult, also of Larchmont, took place here today in St. Augustine's Church.

Cornelius V. Whitney of New York, a director of Pan American Airways Corporation, bought 15,000 shares of Pan American $5-par common stock in March, according to his amended report for the month, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

Sea-beach, the home of Mr. and Mrs. Charles S. Whitman, was the setting tonight for a colorful barn dance given by Mrs. Whitman's daughter, Miss Anne Somerville Grosvenor, for a group of 200 members of the young married set and the debutante group.

Miss Marjorie Ivory Berkhan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Joseph Berkhan of this place, was married here early this morning in St. Joseph's Church to Arthur Cyrus Goerlich, son of Mrs. Harry Goerlich of New York and Corn-wall, Conn., and the late Mr. Goerlich. The Rev. Joseph L. McCann performed the ceremony.

The German Minister, Baron Ruedt von Collenberg-Boedigheim, conferred at the Mexican Foreign Office this morning and subsequently informed his colleagues that he had been "called to Berlin by Hitler."

The general level of wholesale prices declined in the week ended on Aug. 13, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The bureau's index, based on the 1926 average, was 77.9, compared with 78.4 on Aug. 6, and 87.5 on Aug. 18, 1937. Weakening prices for farm products and foods largely accounted for the drop.

Governors Island eliminated the Monmouth County Country Club from the loser's annual ten-goal tournament today by defeating the Jersey team, 7 to 5. The game was an even affair in the first half, the score being 2-all at the end of the third chukker.

The Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association announced today modified capital loans. The new loans take two general forms: "long-term" or five-year amortized loans, and "accounts receivable."
LIKE the crops, third basemen come in cycles. So do shortstops and second basemen, for that matter. But just now there seems to be a bumper crop of good third basemen standing in the field.

Judging from the reaction of the principal parties involved in Wednesday night's lightweight championship battle between Henry Armstrong and Lou Ambers, the boxing business must be a very taxing one indeed, for yesterday nothing could be heard from Armstrong, Ambers or Promoter Mike Jacobs save the crying desire for complete rest. est.

Julius Williams, a red-haired Negro election captain for Tam-many District Leader James J. Hines, was jailed as a material witness yesterday after he had accused the office of District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey of duress and denied that he had testified before a grand jury that his political boss got him a $30-a-week job in the policy racket.

The housing amendment which has now been adopted by the Constitutional Convention is well worth the approval of the people of the State, even though it falls short of the hopes and expectations of some of the advocates of a progressive housing program for New York.

Mrs. Anne Gallagher Durkin, the mother of the late Martin T. Durkin, managing editor of The New Orleans Times Picayune, died yesterday at her home, 1,919 Hennessy Place, the Bronx, after a long illness.

While the world, in view of the approaching European showdown on Czechoslovakia, is still agitated about the extent and import of the German Army manoeuvres, Germany herself is showering honors and attentions on General Joseph France Vuillemen, commander of the air force of France, Czechoslovakia's ally, and incidentally is showing him the present as well as the potential might of the German air force.

Williams, 46 years old, of 276 West 117th Street, said he quit the numbers game after his activities as a collector got him a sentence of sixty days. Unable to recall how he supported himself when he first got out of jail, Williams said he had been a partner of Claude Bowes in a barber shop from 1932 to 1934.

The proposed sweeping curb on the acts of administrative agencies of the State and its subdivisions through court review was modified in the Constitutional Convention today, and then adopted, along with the rest of the new judiciary article of the proposed new Constitution.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: A letter from American Defense Society printed by you on Aug. 16, concerns the so-called Halpern amendment, advanced to third reading by the Constitutional Convention, which provides as follows:

" You have reached the dangerous stage in which all men think well of you," said Dr. H. A. Innis, head of the Department of Political Economy of the University of Toronto, in an address today before an audience of a thousand persons assembled at the Rural and Industrial Conference at St. Francis Xavier University.

The following Marine Corps changes for the week ended Aug. 17 were announced today: LIEUTENANT COLONELS Ruportus, W. H., 4th Marines, Shanghai, China, to Marine Barracks, Washington, D. C., via Steamship President Coolidge due to arrive San Francisco Sept. 12.
Narrower declines from a year ago are shown in the report of department-store sales for last week in most centers in this district as against a year ago.

Although she had to drive most of the night and morning to get here from the New Jersey Shore tournament, Mrs. Marion Turpie McNaughton, golfing ace of the Sound View Club of Lond Island, today took a long lead in the third annual women's invitation fifty-four-hole medal play tournament on the famous Ekwanok course.

The proposed sale to the Gulf, Mobile Northern Railroad Company of the $7,839,500 of general mortgage 4 per cent bonds of the Mobile Ohio Railway Company owned by the Southern Railway Company is progressing satisfactorily, according to Ernest E. Norris, president of the Southern Railway, who was here yesterday to attend a meeting of the executive committee.

In the first awards for women's and children's coats and suits made by the Procurement Division of the United States Treasury for distribution to the needy, 9,589 surplus garments were bought for $48,575, the local office announced yesterday.
President Roosevelt's visit to Canada today will be ranked by Canadians as one of the most significant events in the Dominion's history.

Federal grand jury yesterday in a superseding indictment added the names of a New York City patrolman, who had already been arrested, a secret service agent and a supposed whisky distributor to a list of 103 alleged members of a citywide liquor ring.

The long anticipated meeting between Viscount Runciman and Konrad Henlein occurred at Rothenhaus Castle near Komautau today. The meeting was arranged ten days ago for one day this week but the actual date and hour were only fixed yesterday after the near breakdown in all negotiations between the Henleinists and the government.

The West Side continues to set the pace in the number of apartment rentals consumated, judging by reports received from brokers yesterday. Among the structures in that vicinity reported as receiving new tenants are London Terrace, 5 West Eighty-sixth Street;
State Department officials interpreted President Roosevelt's speech at Kingston, Ont., today as an extension of the Monroe Doctrine to Canada.

At Bonny Bank, Great Barrington, this afternoon, Mrs. John H. C. Church was hostess at a tea and reception. At the tea tables were her two daughters, Mrs. Donald M. Weston of Pittsfield and Mrs. Delano de Windt of Great Barrington and her niece, Mrs. Durant Rice of Dedham, Mass., who is at Shangola.

The American Labor party's designating petitions for county and legislative posts were rejected today by the Suffolk County Board of Elections, R. Ford Hughes and Robert H. Hairston, Commissioners. Insufficient number Of signatures was given as the reason.

Charged with misappropriating "more than $1,000" of the welfare funds of the Enlisted Men's Club of this army post, Private Paul D. Funderburke of Charlotte, N. C., assistant to the chaplain, was under military arrest today pending a court martial before officers of the headquarters staff of the Second Corps Area.

JOHN HYDE PRESTON'S "The Liberals" is an absorbing and vigorously written novel about people who find they cannot practice moderation to excess. They have fine hearts. They are full of good-will. All they ask is a chance to go about their business, their writing or their love affairs without too much interference from the outside.

Although the Senators tried manfully to toss two more games into the Yankees' laps today, they succeeded only in giving the world champions and Wes Ferrell the opener, 6-5, in eleven innings, the veteran Harry Kelley hurling a six-hit, 6-3 triumph in the nightcap.

The property at 401-03 Grand Street, at the corner of Rodney Street, Brooklyn, consisting of a two-story building with two stories and an apartment on an irregular plot 25 by 100 by 75 feet, has been sold by Jacob Altman for cash to a client of Samuel Hurwitz, broker.
David E. Lilienthal, director of the Tennessee Valley Authority, defended his conduct of the Berry marble claims before the Congressional investigating committee today.

The simultaneous appearance in Zurich today of the Premier of Government Spain and the Spanish Insurgent representative in London inspired reports that the two had met as representatives of the warring Spanish factions.
Mitchell Hepburn, Premier of Ontario, said today that his government never would give its consent to development of the St. Lawrence River as a waterway and a source of electric power.
Democratic objects of the President's "purge" and others who fear they may soon be included should gather hope from what has happened in New Jersey.

Well handled by Miss Peggy Melville, the roan gelding Blue Steel today negotiated the outside course of the North Shore Horse Show in such convincing style that he captured the blue ribbon in the chief event of the program.

James Roosevelt admits in a sees ond and last explanatory article to appear in Collier's for Aug. 27 that he asked in a telegram to his father's secretary, "especially good care" for two of his important insurance customers who called on the President-elect late in 1932.

The Austin Company, Cleveland, national engineering and building concern, yesterday announced plans for the establishment of its own construction organization in England, to be known as Austin Engineers Builders, Ltd., with Allan S. Austin as managing director.

The Bankers Trust Company as trustee under the mortgage securing Great Northern Railway Company first and refunding mortgage 4 1/4 per cent bonds due in 1961 has notified the Stock Exchange of receipt of $40,847,000 St. Paul, Minneapolls Manitoba Railway Company consolidated mortgage bonds extended to 1943,
Herbert Bayard Swope, chairman of New York State Racing Commission, received from turf writers tonight a plaque for having made the "greatest contribution to racing" during the past year.

More sales of. houses in Manhattan by banks were reported yesterday by realty brokers. The Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank sold to a client of Simon Metrik the six-story tenement house for twenty-four families at 38-40 West Ninety-eighth Street.
Lumber production declined contraseasonally last week and the adjusted index dropped to 69.3 from 71.4. This compares with 92.4 for the week ended Aug. 14, 1937.

How to make the American Theatre Council an organization which would function the year around and serve as an active clearing house on all matters pertaining to the legitimate stage will be the keynote of the council's second convention on Sept. 13 and 14 at the Astor.

President Roosevelt's attempt to purge Congress is "an escalator to dictatorship" and a challenge to American representative government, Representative John J. O'Connor, chairman of the House Rules Committee, charged last night in a nation-wide radio broadcast.

Appointment of Walter R. Greenlee, vice president of the Schenley Products Company, as director of sales and advertising for the company was announced here yesterday by Lewis S. Rosensteil, chairman of the executive and finance committee of Schenley.

Two men were fined today and two other men received suspended sentences on disorderly conduct charges arising from an egg and vegetable attack June 4 on Norman Thomas, Socialist party leader, when he attempted to speak at a Socialist party meeting in Military Park.

Not long ago we criticized harpooning as a sportsman's means of taking game fish, and since that time we have received scores of letters from anglers who agreed with us and one from an angler who didn't.

A new coarse in selling gas and gas appliances will be offered by the American Gas Association beginning Nov. 1. Atkins Brothers, wholesale distributors of dry goods and clothing, who have been at 204 Ann Street, Hartford, Conn., for fifty-five years, will move on Sept. 1 to the four-story and basement building at 112-114 Allyn Street.

The British passport officer in Vienna, Captain Thomas Kendrick, was arrested by secret police yesterday at Freilassing and no explanation has been given. He was brought to Vienna and is now in the Hotel Metropole, Gestapo [secret police] headquarters here, where former Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg and other distinguished prisoners are understood to be detained.

Although bank clearings rose from the low level of last week, the volume for the current period continued under the total for the same week last year. The drop, however, was considerably smaller than that reported a week ago.

Leaders in many walks of life will attend the funeral today for Adolph Lewisohn, investment broker and philanthropist, who died Wednesday night at his Summer home on Upper Saranac Lake at the age of 89. Services will be held at 11 A. M.
Cincinnati's rampant Reds, paced by Buck McCormic and Paul Derringer, trounced the Cubs today, 9 to 1, and tightened their grasp on third place.

Mr. and Mrs. Harry Payne Bingham and Mr. and Mrs. David K. E. Bruce gave a dinner, followed by a supper dance, tonight at their home on the ocean for Miss Beatrice Willing Patterson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Stuart Patterson of Philadelphia and Duneside,
The Federal grand jury in Brooklyn yesterday handed to Judge Matthew T. Abruzzo an indictment charging Charles H. Kadel with impersonating a Federal officer and extortion.
Jim Bagby registered his first major league shut-out today, allowing the Philadelphia Athletics only three hits and giving the Red Sox a 2-to-0 victory, their third in a row.

The Chemical Bank and Trust Company has announced that the Port of New York Authority series FF 3 per cent bonds, due March 1, 1941, in definitive form, are available for delivery in exchange for the outstanding temporary bonds.

Effecting a crossing of the Croton River last night near Woods Bridge in the face of artillery, machine gun and infantry fire, the advance patrol troops of Major Gen. William N. Haskell's Blue Army of an imaginary strength of 38,000 men have succeeded in forcing the Red "enemy" army to a point nearly 15,000 yards south from the river banks where it was entrenched early yesterday.

John Rylowicz, also known as John Reo, 39 years old, who formerly lived at 132 West Fifteenth Street, New York City, was put to death in the electric chair at Sing Sing Prison tonight for the murder of two women.

An Austrian and a German in Section A and an Englishman and a German in Section B were tied for the lead in their respective divisions at the close of play tonight in the tenth and semi-final round of the British Chess Federation tournament at the Royal Pavilion.

The entire new civil service plank of the State Constitution was defeated early this morning, as the result of opposition to the provision in it for extension of preference in the civil service to all- veterans, instead of lust disabled veterans.

The New York Steam Corporation filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a supplement to its prospectus covering $27,982,000 of 3 1/2 per cent first mortgage bonds due in 1963, stating that the legality of the guarantee of these bonds by the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., had been challenged by an unnamed attorney.

Foreclosure proceedings were instituted yesterday in Supreme Court by the Harlem Savings Bank against the Library Square Realty Company, owner of the eleven-story building at 54 West Fortieth Street which has housed the National Republican Club for many years.

Frank W. Tompkins, founder of the first department store on Staten Island and member of an old Richmond County family, died Wednesday night in his home, 169 Kingsley Avenue, Westerleigh, S. I., after a three-year illness.

Scores of tributes were paid yesterday to Adolph Lewisohn. Some of them follow: PAUL FELIX WARBURG, chairman of the business men's council of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies of New York

An enthusiastic crowd of 3,000 saw the United States swimming stars in the third meet of their tour of Germany today. Peter Fick of the New York A. C. won the 100-meter free style, first on the program, with the German Fisch tied with Takashi Hirose of Hawaii for second. Fick was timed in 1:00.4, with Fisch and Hirose clocked in 1:00.7.

Ten formal declinations of party primary designations were filed yesterday with the Board of Elections. Midnight tonight is the deadline for declinations. After that a four-day period is allowed in which to substitute new designees to run in the party primaries next month.

William Anthony Aery, director of education at Hampton Institute here, has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Elizabeth Chase Aery, to Roland Ebeltoft Olson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lauritz M. Olson of Lake Park, Minn.

The Silvermine Guild Music Festival, in its second year this Summer, began today with a program that was considerably more ambitious than the one concert of last year. Concerts by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra of New York from tonight through Sunday, chamber music programs by the Roth String Quartet, lectures and an art exhibit were among the events on the agenda.

Intercoastal freight rates on most commodities shipped east in the intercoastal trade will be increased, effective Aug. 31, by the Intercoastal Freight Shipping Association, following the increases by the transcontinental railroads.
Bob Weiland was invincible after his first pitch today as his Cardinal mates played heads-up ball to drub the, Pirates, 5 to 1, giving the big left-hander his twelfth victory of the season.

The time within which the Commodity Credit Corporation will purchase from banks and other approved lending agencies eligible paper as evidence of loans to producers under the 1937-38 corn loan program has been extended without change in conditions from Sept. 1 to Nov. 1, the corporation announced today.
A banking group headed by Phelps, Fenn Co. received yesterday the award of two issues of bonds aggregating $3,165,685 of Minneapolis, Minn.
Plymouth car sales in the metropolitan area, based on new car registrations, led all other makes during ??he first seven months of 1938, it was announced yesterday by Chrysler New York Company, Inc.

Mme. Antoinette Szumowska Adamowska, concert pianist and only woman pupil of Ignace Jan Paderewskidied here today at the home of her son-in-law and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. Guido Pantaleoni Jr., at the age of 70.

Joseph A. Padway, American Federation of Labor counsel, said today that he has written a set of proposed amendments to the Wagner act aimed to reduce the authority of the National Labor Relations Board and to strip it of judicial powers.

Scholars and philosophers have dreamed and written about the Good Life. This business man lived it. As the long peace comes and those benign and fruitful years, that old age rich in the spirit of youth, are ended, it is a pleasure to remember that he who gave and worked so much for the happiness of others lived one of the happiest of lives.

The theory of infallibility of the courts was sniffed at in the Constitutional Convention today by Charles B. Sears, presiding justice of the Appellate Division of the Fourth Department and chairman of the Judiciary Committee of the convention.

A shift in the wind to northwest yesterday afternoon brought New Yorkers a respite from heat and humidity. Until the change in wind the mercury had climbed until it reached the high of 84 degrees at 2:10 P. M. The humidity,

A charming, at times heartbreakingly human, little comedy about life in a musical family of attractive daughters which occasionally is ruffled by the drama of a masculine world outside, "Four Daughters," at the Music Hall, tempts one to agree with Jack Warner's recent assertion in the advertisements that it is the climax of his career.

A first mortgage loan of $90,000 for 5 years at 41/2 per cent interest was arranged by Robert E. Hill. Inc. with a savings for the Morbridge Realty Corp on the property at 2,676 Morris Ave, the Bronx.
Administration control of the strategic House Rules Committee is at stake in President Roosevelt's fight to unseat Representative John O'Connor of New York.

Following is the text of President Roosevelt's address at Queen's University today: To the pleasure of being once more on Canadian soil, where I have passed so many of the happy hours of my life, there is added today a very warm sense of gratitude for being admitted to the fellowship of this ancient and famous university.

Henry Guggenheim, former Ambassador to Cuba, won the eighteenth Consolation Stakes today, but lost his horse, the Stimulus colt Touch and Go. This six-furlong test is for those 2-year-olds who have been nominated for the big juvenile stakes of the meeting only to be found wanting. It is run in two sections, of which this was the first.

A detailed complaint against the operation of the Japanese-dictated censorship of Shanghai's mails was filed today with the United States Consulate General by the Chinese-American Publishing and Bookselling Company here.

Buck Newsom held the Indians to five hits today and the Browns took advantage of Bob Feller's wildness to win, 9-1. Feller retired with none out in the fifth after successive doubles by Ralph Kress and Billy Sullivan and a walk to Don Heffner. Ken Jungels and Willis Hudlin finished the game.

Alexander Jay Bruen of 19 East Eighty-third Street has announced the engagement of his sister, Miss Evelyn Louisa Bruen, to John B. Trevor Jr., also of this city. Miss Bruen is a daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Jay Bruen and a niece of Mrs. Henry M. Robertson, Edward C. Fiedler and the late Mrs. George E. Ide.

The development of managerial policies permitting advance planning and the budgeting of production and sales, as a means of keeping manufacturing and employment leveled out throughout the year, is recommended by Samuel Sidd, chief of the planning board of W. F.

All killing classes of cattle closed the week active and strong; prices were generally 15 to 25 cents higher than low time last week on strictly good, choice and prime steers and yearlings. Lambs also sold strong to higher with the top today at $8.60, the United States Department of Agriculture reports.

Slightly cooler weather stimulated trading to some extent. Liberal supplies of veal, calf and lamb forced prices lower on these classes, while other classes showed little change in price. Kosher business was confined largely to lamb at lower prices, but demand was slightly improved.
After rising irregularly for more than two months, business in the Pittsburgh district declined a little last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh.

Miss Marie Nolan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas D. Nolan of Mountain Lakes, N. J., was married here yesterday in the Corpus Christi Catholic Church to Ernest Lewis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry T. Lewis of Colorado Springs. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. John Gross.
