Word has been received here of the marriage in Salisbury, England, on July 28 of Miss Audrey Priscilla Radcliffe, daughter of Mrs. Clifford H. Radcliffe of Salisbury and the late Mr. Radcliffe, to Richard Kendall Irons, son of Mr. and Mrs. H. G. Irons of Wilmington, Del.

While District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey concentrates his attention on a $20,000,000 policy lottery racket in court the highly contagious gambling virus is reaching epidemic proportions outside the court room.
All Venice has only one topic of conversation tonight-reports of a reconciliation between Count Court Haugwitz-Reventlow and his wife, the former Barbara Hutton.

President Roosevelt carried his good neighbor policy to Canadian soil today to extend the Monroe Doctrine to the Dominion of Canada and to become the first Chief Executive of his country to proclaim publicly that the United States would not tolerate an attempt by any non British foreign power to penetrate the borders of the Dominion.

Further testimony that dealers in General Motors automobiles were not compelled to buy parts and accessories for such cars exclusively from General Motors Corporation was heard yesterday by John L. Hornor, trial examiner for the Federal Trade Commission.

Eyre Saitch of New York reached the semi-final round of the national tennis tournament for Negro players by winning two matches on the Lincoln University courts today. Saitch, 1926 national titleholder, disposed of Ernest McCampbell of Tuskegee, Ala., 6-4, 6-4, and also put out Warren Weaver of Baltimore, 6-4, 6-0, in the quarterfinals.

Engagements of gold in England for shipment here continued yesterday on an increased scale, with $2,300,000 taken; an engagement of $4,400,000 in Canada also was reported by the Federal Reserve Bank here.

Stocks closed firm and mixed, in the slowest trading since June 17; turnover, 446,610 shares. Traction issues were sharply higher; United States Government and other bonds steady and mixed; transactions, $3,996,525.
The "confidential" memorandum to members of the Temporary National Economic Committee by A. A. Berle Jr., assistant Secretary of State, parts of which have appeared publicly in the last few days,

Two important rule changes to benefit the offense are listed in the 1938 Spalding's Intercollegiate Football Guide, released yesterday. This year, when a forward pass is grounded in the end zone, the ball will be returned to where it was put in play, except on fourth down, when such an incompletion will result in a touchback, as heretofore.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Louis Libman of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Bernice Libman, to Seymour Dudley Lewis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Israel Lewis of Brooklyn, N. Y.
Open Jumping--First, Philip J. Bliss's ch. g. Modernistic; second, Philip J. Bliss's ch. g. Will Gallop; third, Frank T. Powers's ch. g. Kinnegad; fourth, Philip J. Bliss's gr. g. Greyflight.

While throngs on Broadway looked on, the funeral cortege of Ben Leider, the first American to die fighting for the Spanish Republic, moved solemnly through Times Square early last night to Carnegie Hall.

Labor and industry in the United States are still in "a state of armed warfare" compared to the industrial peace that exists in other Democratic countries of the world, in the opinion of Edward J. Mehren, former president of the Portland Cement Association, who returned yesterday from a year's survey of labor relations in foreign lands.

The five-story club building at 24 East Thirty-eighth Street, which until January, of this year was under lease to the Dartmouth Club, now at 30 East Thirty-seventh Street, was sold at auction yesterday in the Vesey Street salesrooms. It was bought in by the Chase National Bank, as plaintiff, for $93,000.

With generally favorable conditions continuing as harvesting proceeds in Canada, the fulfillment of earlier hopes for good crops of the main staples in every Province e seems assured, according to the Bank of Montreal in its current crop report.

A record of the world of the present era, as it may be envisioned from such characteristics as its books, dress, social attitudes, scientific achievements and religious philosophies, will be buried on the site of the World's Fair in the hope that it will give to historians 5,000 years hence a picture of the middle twentieth century, it was announced yesterday.
Robinson Godfrey Jones, former superintendent of Cleveland schools and widely known educator, died today at the age of 66. He began his career as a country school teacher in 1887.

The Giants' prospective drive toward the top cooled out quicker than the weather at the Polo Grounds yesterday as Colonel Bill Terry's somewhat bewildered champions blew the concluding game of the series with the Dodgers, 5 to 3.
A spirited advance in New York City traction bonds featured an otherwise dull and uninteresting session in the bond market yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.

Boats fishing in near-by waters brought a surprisingly large supply of fish to Fulton Fish Market this week, a supply that tops all records for August boat unloadings. As a result prices on locally caught fish are lower this week.

At the moment when the Sudeten Germans have refused the Czechoslovak proposals and Rebel Spain has in effect rejected the Non-Intervention Committee's plan for the withdrawal of foreign "volunteers," Premier Edouard Daladier declared today that "the gravity of these international difficulties is being exaggerated."

In the first press comment since Secretary of State Cordell Hull's speech, the Gazzetta del Popolo prints a two-column editorial today criticizing all the American's seven points. After sarcastically pointing out that "from Wilson's fourteen points we have now climbed down to Hull's seven," the newspaper continues:
The Virginia Electric and Power Company is considering refunding its $37,500,000 of 4 per cent first mortgage bonds due in 1955, it was announced yesterday.

A field of forty-four starters was led by Mrs. Edward B. Stevens of Round Hill in the weekly one-day tourney of the Westchester and Fairfield Women's Golf Association over the Green Meadow course today. The low gross victor returned a card of 42. 41-83.

A British building syndicate which has erected more than 10,000 small homes in England during the past decade has closed a deal for the purchase of the Queens Valley Golf Club property in Forest Hills and plans to develop a new residential center there.

Paul M. Benedict, former Chicago, New York and Springfield, Mass., business executive, died here yesterday at his home. His age was 52. He had held positions with the Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railroad, the Anaconda Copper Company and the Bozaart Rug Company.

J. Donald Budge, national tennis champion, had his closest call in two years of play on American turf today as he gained the semi-fina round of the Newport invitation tournament with Joe Hunt of Los Angeles, Frank Parker of Beverly Hills, Calif., and Sidney B. Wood Jr. of New York.

The Corona Zephyr, a new lightweight portable typewriter, claimed to be the lightest and smallest model on the market, will be featured in the forthcoming advertising campaign of L. C. Smith-Corona Typewriters, Inc., it was announced by the company yesterday.

President Roosevelt has made an admirable choice in his selection of the civil members of the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics. The committee, with its magnificent research facilities at Langley Field, Va., both in the form of physical equipment and able personnel, is the fountainhead of our, technical advancement in the air.
A cottage and ten acres on Cedar Swamp Road, Brookville, L. I., have been sold by George V. Bailey to a Roslyn client of Harold R. Young, broker.
Because a long location schedule could not be completed before Winter sets in in the Payette River country in Idaho, Metro has called off filming "Northwest Passage" until next Spring.

A check-up of 1,150 penny weighing machines in the I. R. T. and B. M. T. subway and elevated stations, in Grand Central Terminal and Hudson Terminal and in midtown stores disclosed that more than one-third of them were inaccurate, William Fellowes Morgan Jr., Commissioner of Markets, said yesterday.

Part of the world has "gone mad" and those sections still in possession of their reason will have to work together to keep it, Dr. Mary E. Woolley, president emeritus of Mount Holyoke College, declared yesterday on her return from Europe on the United States liner Washington.
The Hon. William Waldorf Astor, who has been visiting in Washington and Richmond, Va., will return today to the Waldorf-Astoria. He will sail Wednesday for his home in London.

Eleven educational, charitable and religious institutions are to share in the estate of Harry R. Ferguson who died on July 30, according to his will filed yesterday in the Surrogate's Court in Brooklyn.

The flip of a switch today transformed 200 acres of Monroe County farm land on the shores of Lake Ontario into a research laboratory to determine the efficiency of electricity as the farmer's operating agent.

George Finlay of Cambridge, Mass., medalist, and Alex Antonio of Roselle, N. J., national left-handed golf champion, will meet tomorrow in the upper bracket of the semi-final round of the New England left-handed golf tournament.

Judge William O'Dwyer in Kings County Court dismissed an indictment yesterday charging Miss Marguerite Schlossman, 22 years old, of 225 Parkside Avenue, Brooklyn, with taking part in a conspiracy for one person to represent another in a legal action.

George Washington Anspake, an actor who made his first appearance on the stage of the Bowery Theatre in the Eighteen Eighties, died Wednesday, according to an announcement from the Actors' Fund of America. He was 81 years old.

Luncheons featured the opening of the three-day horse show here today. Ward Melville, president of the show committee, and Mrs. Melville were hosts in the tackroom of Wide Water, their estate here, at a luncheon during the intermission.

From the standpoint of the American consumer, or, for that matter, from the standpoint of the efficient utilization of resources, the Administration's agricultural program grows daily more baffling. Secretary Wallace's latest proposal to subsidize the export of 100,000,000 bushels of wheat must add to the general bewilderment.

The History of the Recorded Word Exhibition in THE NEW YORK TIMES Annex, 229 West Forty-third Street, has acquired a copy of a rare sixteenth-century book which contains the first known direct allusion to the lead pencil, it was announced yesterday.

Supreme Court Justice George H. Furman in Brooklyn, reserved decision yesterday on an application for an order directing William F. Carey, Commissioner of Sanitation, to recognize the Sanitation Benevolent Association and to grant it the same rights and privileges afforded other organizations in the Department of Sanitation.

Miss Dorothy Lawson Hawkins, assistant librarian at Vassar College since 1928, died last night. Miss Hawkins was born in Wilmington, Del., and was graduated from Smith College in 1912, studied at New York State Library School and received her Master's degree in library science at Columbia University.

Plans are nearing completion for the public offering of $4,500,000 of St. Clair County, Ill., 4 per cent bridge revenue bonds to finance the construction of a bridge over the Mississippi River from East St. Louis, Ill., to St. Louis, Mo., it was, disclosed yesterday.

A possibility that Eugene Talmadge might win the Democratic Senate nomination in Georgia from both Senator Walter F. George and Lawrence Camp, his "100 per cent" New Deal opponent, has been growing steadily in the minds of Georgians since President Roosevelt's intervention in the primary contest a week ago.

Voting on the proposed Federal-State milk marketing agreement to fix minimum prices to producers began among 56,000 dairy farmers in New York State and six other States that supply the New York metropolitan area yesterday.

A crowd of 7,000, the largest in the history of boxing at the Fort Hamilton Army Reservation, last night saw Joey Fontana, popular Bensonhurst featherweight, out-point George Foran of England in the main bout of eight rounds. The victor scored frequently with a left jab to his rival's face. Fontana weighed 128 pounds, Foran 126.
The Department of Agriculture reported today stocks of old wheat in the United States on July 1 were 154,072,000 bushels.

Leaders of the Committee for Industrial Organization discussed affairs of the United Automobile Workers of America for three hours today without any apparent progress toward a solution of the union's problems.

Mrs. s Elizabeth F. Bumiller Clarke Beard of 340 East Seventy-second Street, New York, received a divorce here today from Jeremiah Robinson Beard. Mrs. Beard charged cruelty. Custody of their 4-year-old daughter, Susan, and a property settlement were arranged by an agreement.

The Japanese War Office today issued a "stand by" order to all members of the recruit division of the nation's fighting forces. There were no official figures, but it was estimated 1,000,000 men would be affected.

The Mid - Continent Petroleum Corporation and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for the six months ended on June 30, a net profit of $1,042,574 after Federal and State income taxes, depreciation depletion, leaseholds abandoned and surrendered, and other charges.
Following are digests of the testimony yesterday by Wilfred Brunder, former policy banker, and Camille Monsanto, Leon Gomez and William Edwards, who were seized in a policy raid in 1932:

Funeral services for Joseph L. Buttenwieser will be held at 2:30 P. M. today at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street. Mr. Buttenwieser, real estate operator and philanthropist, died Wednesday while on vacation at Poland Springs, Me.

If we could only believe the prophets of fashion instead of the reporters of politics, we could look forward to a Winter of brilliance and luxury. How different are the tales brought home from the gay salons of the Paris openings and the stories relayed from the dreary vestibules of Foreign Offices!

American Woolen Co. store for blanket division in 40 Worth St; Charles G. Edwards Co, broker. Fashionette Shop, dresses and millinery, store at 28 W 57th St; Lillian Kamin, shoe and hosiery shop, part of store in same building; William A. White Sons, brokers; J. G. White Realty Co, agent.

The Constitutional Convention adopted a clause under which the Legislature would be permitted to establish a State system of health insurance, and approved in final form the proposed Social Welfare Article. [Page 1.]

James T. MacMurray, Mayor of Plainfield for six years, from 1925 to 1931, and former city clerk for twenty-two years, died today in the Palmer Nursing Home, Summit, N. J., where he had been a patient since z 1. .
William T. McKibben, who, until his retirement several years ago, had served for many years as general superintendent of the Underpinning and Foundation Company, Inc., 155 East Forty-fourth Street,

The Securities and Exchange Commission refused today to permit John A. lawson, Clayton J. Howel and George F. Manzelman to solicit deposits of 6 per cent, twenty-year first mortgage, sinking fund gold bonds of the Utilities Elkhorn Coal Company or to solicit authority to act as a protective committee in connection with the reorganization of the company.
The second new housing project in a week was announced here today, the two marking the first large home-building activity here since the beginning of the depression.

The Buffalo Bisons landed on Jersey City's Giants for twenty-four hits and a 21-to-6 victory tonight. The affair ended with Jersey City, after exhausting five pitchers, hauling Tom Winsett in from the outfield to take a crack at flinging in the eighth inning., In that chapter the Bisons tacked seven runs onto a scoring bombardment they had begun with five-run outbursts in each of the first two frames.

Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, regional director of the Social Security Board, with Miss Marion Dickerman and Charles R. Hook, fellow members of the commission sent to Europe by the President to investigate industrial conditions, returned yesterday on the United States liner Washington.

The preliminary report of the Associated Gas and Electric Corporation and Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on June 30, issued yesterday, shows a consolidated net profit of $88,139 after expenses and charges, compared with a revised consolidated profit of $2,072,033 in the twelve months to June 30,-1937.

As a further measure of "German socialism" Chancelor Hitler issued a decree today facilitating the liquidation of all debts owed by morally worthy racial comrades who either went bankrupt or lost real estate through mortgage foreclosures before Jan. 1, 1934, because of the previous economic depression or their zeal for the Nazi movement but who may now be growing prosperous again.

Here are some of the vital paragraphs of the two addresses made in Ontario yesterday by President Roosevelt. At Queen's University We in the Americas are no longer a faraway continent, to which the eddies of controversies beyond the seas could bring no interest and no harm. Instead, we in the Americas have become a consideration to every propaganda office and to every general staff beyond the seas. seas.

Mr. and Mrs. E. V. Quinn's Claredda Farm entries won the Major portion of honors as the Pocono Mountain Horse Show began a three-day stand today. Representatives from the Shrewsbury, N. J., stables captured three blues in the seventeen classes contested.

Funeral services for Joseph L. Buttenwieser will be held at 2:30 P. M. today at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street. Mr. Buttenwieser, real estate operator and philanthropist, died Wednesday while on vacation at Poland Springs, Me.
Lew Feldman, 135, Brownsville, easily outpointed Jose Santos, 128, Portugal, in the star bout of eight rounds at the Coney Island Velodrome last night. A crowd of 2,800 saw Feldman triumph.
The Federal Trade Commission accused seven Middle Western manufacturers of corn cribs and silos today of conspiring to fix prices unlawfully.
Mr. Edgar H. Dunlap, counsel for the Georgia office of the RFC, has been working for the renomination of Senator George. The two duties are plainly incompatible.

President Roosevelt on returning to his home here today indicated that no enlargement of the Monroe Doctrine was implied when, in his address at Queens University yesterday, he pledged that the United States would not stand idly by if Canada were attacked by a foreign power.

The report of the Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit System, including Brooklyn Queens Transit System, for July, issued yesterday, shows a net loss of .$124,464 after operating expenses, taxes and other charges. This contrasts with a net income of $64,316 in July, 1937.
The stock markets here were active and generally steady today, although several issues underwent profit-taking for the end of the account. Giltedge issues were dull.

The fine health of a 9-year-old British boy whose vegetarian parents restricted him to a meatless and fishless diet has led one of Britain's foremost physiologists to believe he has located the "most perfect boy."
Colonel B. Q. Nones and his radio operator, Private Richard Fletcher, escaped unhurt today when their plane overshot the Ocean City Airport here and landed in a bog. The plane was not damaged much.

Assailing the "narrow, short-sighted" policy of almost all the nations in dealing with refugees, James G. McDonald, former High Commissioner of the League of Nations for Refugees, said tonight that the problem could be solved if the British Dominions and the countries of Central and South America would follow the lead of the United States.
The State Department recognized the faster pace of modern communications today by establishing a new Division of International Communications to handle problems arising from this subject.

The Civil Aeronautics Authority has postponed from Monday to Oct. 3 the date when all air carriers are required to file copies of their tariffs showing rates, fares and charges as well as pooling, interline arrangements and other agreements.

The Securities and Exchange Commission Announced today a public hearing here on Sept. 22 on the application of the Baltimore Stock Exchange to strike from listing and registration the no-par value capital stock of the Consolidated Textile Corporation of New York City.

President Manuel Quezon, in an address today to 40,000 students on his sixtieth birthday, warned that national disintegration was inevitable under independence without a complete moral and spiritual regeneration.
Miss Rose Scolgo, 25 years old, of Bethlehem, was drowned in the Delaware River at Roxbury, twelve miles north of here, this afternoon when a boat in which she and three companions were riding upset.

Policy banks dominated by George Weinberg, lieutenant of Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, gave $15,000 to the Democratic campaign in 1933, and one of them paid $125 a week to the political club of James J. Hines, Tammany district leader charged with furnishing political protection for the racket, witnesses testified at the trial of Hines in Supreme Court yesterday.

Despite the fact that she took four more strokes than she needed yesterday when playing conditions were abominable compared to what they were today, Mrs. Marion Turpie McNaughton of the Sound View Club of Great Neck, L. I., lost practically no ground in the women's invitation fifty-four-hole medal play golf tournament, annual fixture at the Ekwanok Club.

The Educational Alliance presented its third annual hobby contest yesterday afternoon on the roof at East Broadway and Jefferson Street. Among the 200 hobbies were a good deal of high-pitched singing and the Big Apple.

A taxicab strike may have stagnated traffic on the streets of this fair city today, but there was no stagnation of Yankee traffic on the bases of Shibe Park. The Bronx Bombers, continuing their onward rush toward their third straight pennant, exploded fourteen hits for twenty-one bases in a 5-2 victory over the Athletics before a Ladies' Day crowd of 12,000.

Judge Arthur H. James, Republican nominee for Governor, charged here tonight that the Democrats planned to finance their campaign with money "grabbed penny by penny and dollar by dollar from the pay envelopes of men and women on the public payrolls, maced and extorted from men and women who at best receive barely enough to keep body and soul together."

The rush for apartments in Manhattan shifted yesterday to the East Side where brokers and renting agents added many new names to the tenant rosters of buildings there. On Thursday the pace was set in the renting of suites in buildings on the West Side.
Yesterday's weather was the most pleasant in about a week, with the average temperature of 74 degrees only 1 above normal. The high was 83 at 4:30 P. M. and the low 66 at 7:30 A. M.

A banking group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and including Lehman Brothers, the Bancamerica-Blair Corporation, Stone Webster and Blodget, Inc.; Darby Co., Inc.; E. H. Rollins Sons, Inc.; Estabrook Co. and Schmidt, Poole Co. obtained yesterday $4,700,000 of 3 per cent water revenue certificates of indebtedness of the city of Chicago.
Licenses for the export of aircraft and munitions totaling $10,831,149.45 were issued to United States manufacturers in July, according to statistics made public today by the State Department.

The National Labor Relations Board disclosed today that the Weirton Steel Company hearing in Pittsburgh had been postponed again and that Edward G. Smith, trial examiner, had been relieved of the case.

The unexpected "breathing spell" experienced this week in the market for new issues of securities as a result of the calling off of the $25,000,000 Argentine loan will be short-lived, as corporate borrowing will be resumed next week on a substantial scale if present plans of underwriters materialize.

Having temporarily at least lost their magic charm over the Dodgers, the Giants turned their undivided attention upon the Phillies at the Polo Grounds yesterday and in the course of a couple of hours were pleased to learn that here was something that still worked.

When President Roosevelt said in his address at Kingston that "the people of the United States will not stand idly by if domination of Canadian soil is threatened by any other empire" he did not go beyond the long-established facts of our position.

Retail trade in this area was below a year ago this week by a smaller percentage than last week, according to estimates of store officials, Who put the loss at 7 per cent, compared with a decline of 8. per cent officially reported by the Federal Reserve Board for the previous period.

I. J. Singer's new book, "The River Breaks Up," will be published by Knopf on Sept. 12. Like "The Brothers Ashkenazi," Mr. Singer's highly successful novel of two years ago, this collection of short stories has for its background the teeming world of the Polish Jews during the period of transition from the beginning of the present century up through the war and revolution.

During the afternoon testimony yesterday a well-dressed man in the third row of the spectators' section got so lost in contemplation of the court-room scene that he absent-mindedly pulled a eigarette from his pocket and started to light it, Justice Pecora himself was the first to notice it.
Thornton Lee held the slipping Indians to seven scattered hits today and the Chicago White Sox pounded two pitchers for thirteen hits to win, 7-2.

Officials of the new Thousand Islands International Bridge said today that Miss Mary J. Hodgson of Philadelphia, Pa., was the first to cross from the Canadian to the American side as a regular tollpaying customer.

Ten mortgage loans, aggregating $54,000 on the ten 1-family dwellings under construction at 33d Ave, between 205th and 206th Sts, Bayside, L. I., have been obtained for School Homes, Inc, by James C. McCormick. The Gramatan National Bank and Trust Co of Bronxville was the mortgagee.

The B. M. T. might increase business if it hired a few good musicians to serenade its subway and elevated passengers, Magistrate Jeanette Brill observed in Pennsylvania Avenue Court, Brooklyn, yesterday when she suspended sentence on two men charged with playing banjos on the Jamaica line.
Dr. Walter Livingston Wright Jr., president of Robert College and the Istanbul Woman's College; in Istanbul, Turkey, has become virtually a commuter between Istanbul and New York City.

Secretary of Finance Eduardo Suarez has promised to transmit orders to border and seaport customs stations exempting American tourists returning home with up to $100 worth of Mexican goods from paying the 12 per cent general export tax recently established without warning.
Ormonde Butler Haycock, former Canadian figure skating champion, died at his Canandaigua, N. Y., Summer home, it was learned here today. His age was 58.

Leader of the English county cricket competition with two more weeks left to play, Yorkshire is almost a certainty to win its twentieth championship. The White Rose County placed first in 1937 after a tight battle with Middlesex.

Leander W. Riddle, a sportsman and member of the textile manufacturing family that gave its name to Glen Riddle, Delaware County, died of pneumonia today at his Summer home in Berlin, Md., at the age of 69. He became ill after falling from a fishing boat on Monday.

Mournful accounts of those two "Black Wednesdays" in Harlem when the planets and the fates conspired with Dutch Schultz to write the last chapters to a brilliant Harlem success story were interwoven yesterday in testimony given before the Hines jury by the parade of Negro witnesses.

Continued cooler weather brought more action into the local wholesale markets yesterday. Steer hinds and ribs were strong to slightly higher, veal weak, calf lower, lamb steady, pork steady to higher. All kosher markets opened slightly more active, although business was still considered slow during early trading.
Andrew C. Vauclain, tool room foreman of the Baldwin Locomotive Works, died of a heart attack today at the company's Eddystone plant. He was 65 years old. Mr.

Father Charles E. Coughlin of Detroit renewed yesterday his criticism of President Roosevelt, whom he once supported, and endorsed "the principles behind" the candidacy of Representative John J. O'Connor of New York, whom he once assailed.

The second day of the second annual Silvermine Guild Music Festival today boasted another full program. A concert by the Roth String Quartet again began the proceedings in the morning, and a program in the evening by the PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra of New York, under Josw Iturbi's direction, brought the day's events to a climax.

Freddy Frankhouse and Cookie Lavagetto shared the acclaim of more than 25,000 wildly enthusiastic Ebbets Field fans last night as the Dodgers took a thrilling eleveninning battle from the Bees by a 1-0 score and regained fifth place in the National League by a mere fraction.

After an ownership of half a century, the Volkening family has sold the building on a lot 25 by 75 feet at 220 Lafayette Street, just south of Spring Street. The buyer, D. A. Galgano, Inc., funeral directors, will alter the property and occupy it for parlors and a chapel. Ralph H. Haas was the broker in the deal.

Playing before a big gallery, Eyre Saitch of New York reached the final round in the national tennis tournament for Negro players by defeating Teddy Cousins of Institute, W. Va., on the Lincoln University courts today, 6-4, 7-5, 1-6, 6-4. Saitch, 1926 national singles champion, outmanoeuvred his Southern opponent in the back court.

Fill-in orders represented the bulk of wholesale volume last week, the lull in buying evident in the preceding week being carried over in most lines, according to the weekly summary of conditions issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. Continued heat held retail sales down, especially on furs and Winter coats, as customers balked at trying on heavy apparel in the humid weather.

Thomas K. Heath, partner of the late James McIntyre in the famous blackface team whose act, "The Ham Tree," convulsed generations of Americans, died last night at his home here on the anniversary of his partner's death. He was 85 years old.
The electric output of the Commonwealth Southern Corporation system for July totaled 621,288,532 kilowatt-hours, compared with 717,796,651 kilowatt-hours in July, 1937, a decrease of 13.4 per cent.
Mrs. Jules Sandoz, widow of the Western Nebraska pioneer rancher who was the central figure in the novel "Old Jules," died at a hospital here today. Her husband died in the same hospital in 1928.

The YP-5, a 75-foot converted rumrunner now used by the naval torpedo station here as a diving boat, lay 80 feet under water in the east passage into Narragansett Bay tonight as a result of being struck by a 21-inch practice torpedo on the outer range this morning.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Nathan Ottinger's letter on public housing, published in THE TIMES of Aug. 16, is to the point. I would like to add some comments-on THE TIMES'S editorial of July 29.

Accomplishing its final objective at noon today in the most complicated manoeuvres ever attempted by the State National Guard units in a mimic war, Major William N. Haskell's theoretical command, a reinforced division of 38,000 troops of the Blue army, completed its part in the annual war games.
At exactly 3:23 this afternoon the delegates to the Constitutional Convention threw away their calendars and ended their task of drafting amendments to the State Constitution.

Word has been received here of the marriage of Mrs. Elizabeth Houghton Wharton of Boston and this city to her former husband, James B. Wharton of North Plain, Conn., which took place Monday afternoon in the Municipal Building of Hartford.

Judge Nott in General Sessions declared a mistrial yesterday in a trial which had been completed, except for his charge, when one of the two women jurors in the case was absent from the jury box. The missing juror was on trial herself at the time in Magistrate's Court on the charge of. dropping a "slug" instead of a nickel into an East Side I. R. T. subway station turnstile.

International friendship services will be held by several churches tomorrow as an aftermath of the dedication by President Roosevelt and Premier Mackenzie King of Canada, of the Thousand Islands bridge linking Canada and the United States.

Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Aug. 13 amounted to 589,561 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 5,511 cars, or 0.9 per cent, more than for the preceding week, but 184,221 cars, or 23.8 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week last year and 146,936 cars, or20.0 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week two years ago.

The demand for gold abroad lessened somewhat yesterday, and the principal foreign exchanges moved ahead moderately. No gold was engaged abroad for shipment here, but the Federal Reserve Bank reported the receipt of $4,625,000 of gold from England and $4,387,000 from Canada, a total of $9,012,000.

The Public Works Administration today allotted grants totaling $4,529,894 and loans amounting to $166,000 for thirty-three additional non-Federal projects having a total estimated construction cost of $10,066,370.

The "last of the David Harums," arriving by horse, buggy, truck and trailer for the World Horse Traders Convention in this hamlet of 300 population, sharpened their wits today in anticipation of the big auction tomorrow, while George Kame, tobacco-chewing bachelor, founder and president of the group, chuckled gleefully:

A rustic atmosphere pervaded the Atlantic Beach Club tonight when many members of the club and their guests attended a barn dance. One of the largest parties of the evening was the dinner given by Mr. and Mrs. Hamilton Pell in celebration of Mrs. Pell's birthday.

Mayor La Guardia expressed astonishment and pleasure yesterday to find in his morning mail a remittance of 50 cents from Rome, Ga., in payment for a night's lodging at the Municipal Lodging House several years ago.

A New York syndicate headed by Bernard Reswick has purchased from the Bayonne Housing Corporation the five apartment buildings on East Eleventh and Twelfth Streets and Avenue E, Bayonne, N. J., for cash over a mortgage of $410,000.

Bonds worked irregularly higher yesterday in somewhat more active trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Speculative interest was centered in local traction issues and a long list of secondary railroad bonds as substantial gains were scored in both of those groups.

The Bridgeport Hydraulic Company won today its long legal fight to build the Saugatuck Valley reservoir when Judge Edwin C. Dickenson ordered the discontinuance of eleven miles of highway in Weston and Redding in a decision handed down in Superior Court.
The State Labor Department's experiment with a new formula for industrial peace helped to return 200 striking employes of the Woodlawn Cemetery to their jobs yesterday.

St. John's Episcopal Church here was the setting this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Priscilla Hakes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Otto Fitzalan Hakes of Fredonia, to Edward Walter Williams, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Gilbert Williams of Brooklyn. The Rev. Leslie Chard performed the ceremony.

The order setting minimum wages and maximum hours for the 22,000 women and minors employed in the laundry industry in New York State will become "mandatory" next Monday, with violations by employers punishable by fine and imprisonment, it was an- that nounced yesterday by Miss Frieda S. Miller, State Industrial Commissioner.

The $180,296 certificated mortgage covering the fifty-seven family apartment house at 2,813 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn, has been sold by the Fulton Service Corporation, comprised of the certificate holders, to the Lenox Flatbush Corporation.

Following up its own charge that a conspiracy of gamblers, police and public officials existed here during 1936-37 to protect vice and crime, the special October Grand Jury today demanded the immediate dismissal of eleven police officers and patrolmen and the suspension of four others.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Aug. 17: CAPTAIN Gill, C. C., the Astoria, to 11th Naval District.

Frederic Prokosch, author of "The Seven Who Fled," returned yesterday on the Ile de France after an absence of fifteen months in England and on the Continent of Europe. He spent several months in Cambridge studying Chaucer manuscripts and visited France, Austria and Germany.

Elmer F. Andrews, Administrator of the Fair Labor Standards Act, received from thirteen representatives of the textile industry, labor and the public today suggestions for defining the boundaries and extent of the industry preparatory to setting up machinery for determining the minimum wage standards.

Chairman Alfred Rheinstein of the New York City Housing Authority made public yesterday a letter to Borough President Harvey of Queens, contradicting the implication of Mr. Harvey Wednesday that he had been tricked into approving the closing of several streets in the vicinity of the Queensbridge housing project.

Pushing out from Hwangmer Dy paths along slopes of the mountains flanking the highway on the north instead of by the main road the vanguard of 1,000 Japanese troops yesterday reached Lungtou, ten miles from Kwangtsi and the farthest point of the advance toward Hankow on the north bank of the Yangtze River, according to information in military circles here.

The Italian liner Rex will sail today for Mediterranean ports. Her passengers include Augusto Russo, Italian Ambassador to Soviet Russia; Percy Chandler, president of the International Utilities Corporation; Vice Admiral Constantinos Frangopoulos of the Greek Navy;

KINGS BRAINE, EMMA W. (June 5, 1937). Gross assets, $535,087; net, $502,862. To Greenwood Cemetery and cousin, Elizabeth Hoag, $1,000 each; cousin, Marie L. Jewett, residuary estate. Chief assets, real estate, $5,250; stocks and bonds, $470,666; mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $10,521; transfers, $48,650. Good Kent, attorneys, 44 Court St.
Robert S. Pirie, son of John T. Pirie, president of Carson Pirie Scott Co., has been appointed manager of the company's New York office, it was announced today.
Directors of the Commonwealth Edison Company announced today subscription rights to stockholders to purchase $39,251,600 of new convertible debentures.

Eastern contestants dwindled to one survivor today as California performers took charge of the national public courts tennis championships. New York City was chosen as the scene of the 1939 public courts tournament, to be held in the third week of August.
Two railbirds were having a conversation about horses and were kind enough to let a late arrival tune in on it. From that point the conversation. went approximately as follows:

A bridge and connecting ramps carrying Maywood Avenue across Route 4 in Bergen County between Arcola and Hackensack will be opened to traffic tomorrow, eliminating an exceptionally dangerous grade intersection in the PatersonGeorge Washington Bridge highway, E. Donald Sterner, State Highway Commissioner, announced here today.

Foremost among the many factors which make the Georgia Senatorial primary campaign any man's race at this stage is the uncertainty as to the stand of the only two political organizations in the State that are worthy of the name.
Home runs by Long Tom Winsett and Babe Herman paced the Jersey City Giants to an 11-to-7 victory over the Buffalo Bisons tonight. Winsett also hit a single and drove in a total of five runs.

Tommy Goodwin, who won his first golf prize seven years ago when he captured the medal in the annual New. York Athletic Club championship, advanced to the semi-finals of. the organization's twenty-sixth title tournament at the Winged Foot Golf Club today.

Harry Cooper of Chicago, defending his Canadian open golf championship, equaled Mississauga's course record with a six-under-par 66 today, and little Paul Runyan of White Plains, N. Y., and big Sam Snead of White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., missed that mark by one stroke each as they virtually turned the title tourney into a three-man affair.

The securities division of the Wisconsin Banking Commission announced today that it would hold a meeting on next Thursday on its order revoking the license of H. M. Byllesby Co., Chicago, to deal in securities in the State.

James F. Seymour, retired telegraph dispatcher of the New York Fire Department, died yesterday at his home, 3,769 Willett Avenue, the Bronx. Mr. Seymour, who became ill last October and who retired from active duty in June, was 64 years old.

Mrs. Frederick Hobbes Allen of Pelham Manor, N. Y., and Newport, R. I., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Priscilla Alden Allen, to Francis Jackson Hallowell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Hallowell of Dedham, Mass.

Magistrate James A. Blanchfield in Coney Island Court yesterday suspended sentence on two women who wept when he gave them the option of $5 fines or two days in jail for disorderly conduct on the Boardwalk Thursday.

Secretary of the Interior Harold L. Ickes as administrator of the Puerto Rican Reconstruction Administration today ordered that all work on the School of Tropical Medicine and the University of Puerto Rico be stopped at noon tomorrow and not be resumed until the Legislature passes a bill giving Columbia University a part in the direction of the School of Tropical Medicine.
King Leopold received a tumultuous welcome today in the Cantons of Malmedy and Eupen when he came on an inspection tour of Belgian military manoeuvres.

Without the loss of a set, Australia swept into the Davis Cup challenge round today when its unbeaten doubles team of Adrian Quist and Jack Bromwich easily scored the Antipodeans' third straight victory of the five-match interzone series with Germany.

Leonard Martin of Apawamis, a former metropolitan champion, led a field of 135 in the Maidstone Club's seventh annual Maidstone Bowl golf tournament today to capture the qualifying medal with a 72, one under par.

A weekly radio program sponsored by the State Bureau of Motor Vehicles and intended to reduce the number of deaths and injuries from automobile accidents will go on the air from Stations WOR, WGY and WHAM for three months beginning tomorrow morning.
Howard Hughes lifted his eight-ton round-the-world airplane off the runway at Grand Central Air Terminal at 6:22 o'clock tonight, bound for New York through the substratosphere.

The Maritime Commission acquired two three-masted, square-rigged sailing ships today for training the merchant marine personnel. The ships were the Tusitala and the Joseph Conrad. The Tusitala, once owned by James A. Farrell, former head of the United States Steel Corporation, was bought from the Marine Liquidating Corporation of Fall River.
Bids on $300,000 contracts for permanent landscaping of the east and west boundaries of Flushing Meadow Park, the site of the World's Fair, were received by the City Parks Department yesterday.

The first appearance here of a touring American track and field team drew a crowd of only 2,000 today, for the Viennese team obviously was no match for the Americans, who won ten of the eleven events.

David E. Lilienthal, TVA director, denied to the Congressional investigating committee today that he had received any money or had been influenced by political pressure in connection with the marble claims made against the TVA by Senator George L. Berry and associates.

Canada is the only direct link with the Old World in the Western Hemisphere. Except for a few small islands, it constitutes all the territory in the Americas that is included in the British Empire system.

John B. Hayward has been appointed supervisor of patent developments of International Business Machines Corporation. He previously was connected with the company's patent department in an advisory capacity.

Shot down on Hollywood Boulevard late today as pedestrians scurried for shelter, Mrs. Emita Krueger, a member of the McCormick harvester family and wife of Karl Krueger; conductor of the Kansas City Philharmonic Orchestra, was near death from two bullet wounds tonight.

Allen W. Dulles, attorney and former diplomat, was selected yesterday as the official Republican candidate to oppose Representative John J. O'Connor for the Republican nomination for Congress in the Sixteenth Manhattan District in the September primary.

Alexander Pompez, who is 48 years old, described himself as a sports promoter when he took the witness stand late in the day. He was the lessee of the Dyckman Oval at 204th Street and Nagle Avenue, he said.
Net profit of the Paraffine Companies, Inc., and domestic subsidiaries was $1,255,001 for the fiscal year ended June 30, according to a report issued yesterday.

The two four-story apartment houses at 1,683-93 sixty-fifth Street, Brooklyn, on a plot 240 by 100 feet, have been purchased by the Manhattan Engineering Corporation, Jacob J. Greenbaum, president, from the Nagin Realty Corporation.

The Federal Government and the government of the State of Sonora have come into open conflict, according to dispatches received by the newspaper Universal. Federal agents are seeking to establish peasants on communal farms, while the Governor of Sonora, General Roman Yocupicio, is seeking to protect small individual properties.

At a preview of the four automobiles manufactured by the Chrysler Corporation-Chrysler, De Soto, Plymouth and Dodge-held here today, K. T. Keller, president of the corporation, revealed that it had spent $15,000,000- for jigs, tools and equipment to give the 1939 models an entirely new treatment in body styling, interior finish and mechanical refinement.

The Constitutional Convention adjourned yesterday, having debated since earl April questions of far-reaching importance to the people of this State and having decided in the end to submit fifty-seven proposals to the electorate in November.

Emil Mosbacher's Susan just nosed out Cornelius Shields's Aileen in the weekly yacht race for Internationals off the Larchmont Yacht Club today. Susan beat Aileen across the finish mark by two seconds. Charles Stuart's Ariel was third,

The Ebro bridgehead hold is unchanged and is stronger than ever. It will take a truly powerful Rebel offensive to reduce the government's positions. All their attacks to date have failed to bring any important gains.

The Disasbled American Veterans of the World War today elected Owen A. Galvin, Minneapolis attorney, as National Commander. They chose Boston for next year's convention and tentatively awarded the 1940 session to Tacoma, Wash. Mr. Galvin defeated Michael A. Whalen of Detroit and William E. Dodd of Jersey City, N. J.
The Bureau of Mines estimated today that the market demand for domestic crude oil September would be 3,444,000 barrels daily.
Cotton mill activity increased more than seasonally last week, and the adjusted index rose to 127.6, its highest point since the week ended Sept. 18, 1937.

It will be blonde Miss Alice Marble, the former national champion, against 21-year-old Miss Nancye Wynne, the spectacular newcomer from Australia, in both finals of the Essex County Club's invitation women's tennis tournament tomorrow.

The Interstate Commerce Commission today granted authority to the Norfolk Portsmouth Belt Line Railroad Company to issue at par promissory notes for not more than $700,000, to be used as collateral for bank loans with which to pay at maturity on Oct. 1 $450,000 of notes and to redeem prior to maturity $250,000 of general and refunding 5 per cent mortgage bonds.

Four members of the six-man American team that won first prize in the Wakefield International Model Aircraft contest in Paris July 31 stopped in New York yesterday long enough to tour the World's Fair grounds and buildings before continuing to their homes in various parts of the country.

The House committee investigating unAmerican activities voted today to hand over to Attorney General Cummings evidence offered yesterday at the hearing charging that Communist organizations in this country had been recruiting here for the Spanish Loyalist forces.
Pensioned On his own application, to take effect 12 midnight. Aug. 17. PATROLMAN--William J. Tjarks, 75th Pct., at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Jan. 17, 1908.

Midshipmen from the Naval Academy numbering 124 "invaded" West Point today to inspect the army's school and attend a round of social functions, They arrived in six destroyers, which anchored in the Hudson River.

Nathan Alderman, a partner of the A. O. Plastering Corporation, 236 East Ninety-third Street, Brooklyn, and Abraham Auerbach of 558 Barbey Street, Brooklyn, an employee, were robbed of $3,300 in cash yesterday afternoon by two thugs, who jumped on the runningboard of their automobile on Eighty-fifth Street, near Bay Parkway, Brooklyn.

The Philco Radio and Television Corporation of New York began suit yesterday in Supreme Court to restrain Maurice Shapiro and Harry Krantz, doing business as Rite Radio Stores, from selling its products below scheduled prices.

A finger-sized mercury vapor arc lamp, capable of an intense brilliance equal to one-fifth of the sun's surface brightness, has been developed for commercial use, the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company announced yesterday.
Judge Thomas F. Moran, who in twentyseven years on the Washoe County District Court bench granted divorces to many prominent persons, died here early tonight. His age was 74.

High-goal activity on Long Island today consisted of a round-robin on the Mitchel Field turf among three teams that comprised many poloists who will compete in the national open championship next month at the Meadow Brook Club.

Thurman Arnold, Assistant Attorney General, asserted tonight that the American people must decide whether they wanted to save their competitive business and industrial system. Only by building up an adequate enforcement system for the anti-trust laws, he said, would the competitive system be removed from danger of collapse.
The Postoffice Department and the Civil Service Commission are collaborating in the formulation of the examinations under which postmasters must qualify in the future for appointment "without term."

Bruce T. Bair, retiring commander of the American Legion in Maryland, said today that if President Roosevelt is successful in defeating Senator Millard E. Tydings, the American Government would become a dictatorship.

The last of the detachment of Iowa National Guard troops sent here a month ago to preserve law and order in the Maytag Washing Machine Company controversy left Newton today as martial law was lifted in Jasper County.
Joseph P. Kennedy, United States Ambassador to Great Britain, on Sept. 2 will lay the first stone of the Seabury Memorial at St. Andrew's Cathedral, Aberdeen, Scotland.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: Last week you printed a letter entitled "It Shouldn't Happen-,"with the subheading "Clearview's Once Velvet Greens Found Scarred by Chemicals." The writer claimed to be an "old greens-keeper." Accordingly, his comments appeared to have authority.

Great Britain has issued 825 certificates for the immediate transfer to Palestine of Jewish children from Germany and Poland, according to an announcement yesterday by Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America.

Winging to Memphis by plane, Carl Hubbell probably will know some time today whether his famous left arm, which suddenly has given way at the elbow, will throw any more screwballs for the Giants this season or go in for major repairs until another campaign rolls around.
The Montreal Royals surprised the Newark Bears to take both ends of a double-header tonight.

In an exciting finish to an unevenly played match, Sidney B. Wood Jr. gave a masterful exhibition of volleying to defeat Joe Hunt of Los Angeles today in the semi-finals of the Newport invitation tennis tournament at the Casino.

The last chapter of an old romance is to be written tomorrow when the effects of Miss Fanny M. Read, who died seven years ago, and the antique furnishings of the old American Hotel, a landmark here, are to be sold at auction.

The engagement of Anne Child, daughter of the late Richard Washburn Child, Ambassador to Rome, and Mrs. Edmund William Pavenstedt, to Charles Barstow Wright Dick, son of Langhorne Dick of Chestnut Hill, Pa., was announced here today. The marriage will take place early in the Autumn in New York.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith was named today by Representative Hamilton Fish Jr., Putnam County Republican, as "my candidate" for the Republican nomination for United States Senator to oppose Senator Robert F. Wagner.

Miss Ursula E. Lowrie and Edmund Spencer Burn were married this afternoon in the Congregational Church: of Easton. The ceremony was performed by the pastor, the Rev. Donald Frazier, who was assisted by the Rev. Rival J. Hawkins of the United Congregational Church of Bridgeport.
A second meeting here between Count Court Haugwitz-Reventlow and his estranged American-born wife, the former Barbara Hutton, ended quickly tonight.
Three merchandise creditors of Gloria Vanderbilt- Sonia Gowns, Inc., 23 East Fifty-sixth Street, filed a petition in bankruptcy yesterday against that company.
J. Edgar Hoover ordered seven highranking agents transferred today. Those affected by his order were: W. G. Banister, assistant agent-incharge at Newark, to Butte, Mont., as agent-in-charge.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Aug. 19, unless specified: Chinwangtao to Chefoo: Alden, Barker, J. D. Edwards, Whipple. At Naval Operating Base, Norfolk: Salinas, Aug. 18; Brooklyn, Kewaydin. Baltimore to Norfolk: Dickerson, Schneck, At Norfolk: Roper, Tillman.
Bobby Doerr today ended a pitchers' battle between Fred Ostermueller and Monte Weaver when his single with two out in the tenth gave the Red Sox a 4-3 victory over the Senators.

The names of thirty-nine persons who have passed the June optometery licensing examinations of the State Board of Examiners and will receive licenses to practice optometry in the State, were announced today by the State Education Department. Licenses will be issued to the following:

The European Danubian Commission, which is administering the Danube River from Galti to the Black Sea, closed its meeting at Sinaia today. It was attended by representatives of Great Britain, France and Rumania, Italy failing to send a representative.

Adolph Lewisohn, who died Wednesday at his Summer home on Upper Saranac Lake,-was eulogized in Temple Emanu-El yesterday before 1,500 persons, including many recipients of his benefactions, who came to pay final respect to the philanthropist.

Two robbers hijacked a truck in Cortlandt Alley shortly after noon yesterday, held the driver a captive for three hours after shifting cotton goods valued at $4,400 to their own car and then abandoned the truck and its driver in Brooklyn.

Thirty-eight acres of land and buildings west of Blatchley Road and north of Cove Road, overlooking Long Island Sound at Darien, Conn., have been sold by the estate of C. Ida Hoyt to Sarah Pyle Smart of Darien. Reed G. Haviland was the broker.
The British Foreign Office today demanded that Germany release Captain Thomas Kendrick, British passport officer in Vienna who was arrested by German Secret Police, and explain his detention.

MANHATTAN EAGAN, ANNE M. (June 26). Estate, more than $10,000. To John T. Eagen, stepson, executor, 2 Beekman Pl., life estate in 75 per cent residue; Helen A. Walbaum, sister, executrix, 424 E. 52d St., 25 per cent residue in trust, and 40 per cent remainder of trust; Gordon F. Walbaum and Alan Walbaum, 424 E. 52d St., remainders of 35 per cent and 25 per cent respectively; three other bequests.

The Brooklyn Catholic Diocese has awarded a contract for additions and alterations to Ansonian Hall, in Brooklyn, according to Brown's Letters, Inc. The building is at 105-7 Greene Avenue. The work will be done by the Patrick Construction Corporation from plans by Henry V. Murphy.

Fifty embattled housewives, many with babies in their arms, carried their protest against city garbage dumping near Lefferts Boulevard and Sunrise Highway, Queens, yesterday to the extent of blocking the laden trucks arriving at the lot.
Tomorrow it will be just six months since the chilly night in February when Anthony Eden walked across Downing Street for the last time as His Majesty's Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs.

The Boerse, which suffered a sensational slump until yesterday, has staged an equally sensational recovery. On a still restricted turnover prices climbed an average of 5, and jumps of 6, 7 and 8 were not unusual. But recovery proceeded amid violent fluctuations and major gains were considerably reduced at closing.
Following is a summary of some of the principal proposals of the new State Constitution which will be presented to the voters of the State for adoption:...
Herbert Hanley Hall, Arctic fur trader and son of the late R. H. Hall, onetime Hudson's Bay Company fur trade commissioner for Canada, died in a hospital here last night.
The State Banking Department announced today it had received for examination the organization certificate of the Ascension Parish Elmhurst Credit Union of Elmhurst.

The East Side boys and girls who staged a "sit-down strike" last Tuesday afternoon in the middle of Twenty-first Street, between First and Second Avenues, to bring to the attention of Mayor La Guardia the fact that they wanted a street sprinkler, won their point yesterday.

The Constitutional Convention voted today to forbid the practice of proportional representation in the State. This was done by amending the proposed suffrage article of the new State Constitution so that it specifically states: "No election for any office to be filled by the people of the State or any of its subdivisions shall be conducted by any system of proportional representation."

Band Order The members of the department band, except those mentioned in Paragraph IV, Special Order No. 81, dated April 28, 1938, shall be directed to report, in full uniform, to Captain Julius A. Unrath as follows: Monday, Aug. 22, 1938, at 8 P. M., station WNYC, Municipal Building, Manhattan. Tuesday, Aug. 23, 1938, at 10 A. M., at station WNYC, Municipal Building, Manhattan.
France and Switzerland strengthened their border patrols today to block an increasing flow of refugees from Germany and German Austria along secret routes.

Judge Samuel K. Dennis sentenced Mrs. Barbara Bird, wife of Charles Bird, Midwestern desperado, to thirty days in jail upon her conviction of being an accessory in one of her husband's seven hold-ups here in recent weeks.

Admiral Nicholas Horthy, Hungarian Regent, will extend his perogatives by assuming the rank and rights of grand master of the Royal Order of St. Stephen-the highest Hungarian order which was started by Empress Marie Theresa-whose grand masters were always kings of Hungary.
W. J. Hunter bought from the Rainbow Holding Company the house at 77 Duffield Drive, South Orange, N. J., through Mrs. C. Sanders, broker.

The Cubs will lay their fading pennant hopes on the line against Pittsburgh tomorrow and shoot Dizzy Dean and his $185,000 arm against the Pirates in a long gamble on battling their way back into the National League championship fight.

Mr. and Mrs. Elisha Dyer are at the Plaza. Mr. and Mrs. Arthur C. Twitchell Jr. have returned from their wedding trip and are at the Madison before going to West Hampton Beach for the rest of the season. Mrs. Twitchell is the former Miss Kate Sanford of Loudonville, N. Y.

Late tonight hundreds of Arab rebels descended from the hills surrounding Hebron, besieged the town of 17,500 population, occupied the postoffice and attacked other government offices and police headquarters.

Representing the first export of locomotives from this country to South America which the ExportImport Bank has assisted in financing, seven steam locomotives built by the Baldwin Locomotive Works for the Chilean State Railway are being loaded on the steamer M. S. Belnor at Eddystone - on - the - Delaware for Valparaiso.

Miss Elise S. Plankinton of this city and Port Washington, daughter of Mrs. Plankinton Plaut, who is now in London, was married on Thursday in Elkton, Md., to Angus Duncan Mackintosh of this city, according to word received by friends here yesterday. No announcement had been made of the engagement W of the couple.
A complaint was issued today by the Federal Trade Commission charging seven Midwestern manufacturers of wire portable corn cribs and silos of conspiring to fix and maintain uniform prices.
H. P. Childs, vice president of the Missouri Kansas Pipe Line Company, announced yesterday that directors at a meeting on Thursday voted to offer William G. Maguire,
William H. Sawyer, inventor and associate of the late Thomas A. Edison, died at a hotel here today as he was observing his ninety-third birthday.
John Charles Thomas, the singer, who races boats in Chesapeake Bay regattas, was elected president of the Talbot Country Club today. He succeeds R. R. Spring, who had served six years.

Four hundred persons, among them several men and women active in Jewish charitable and welfare organizations in New York, attended a funeral service yesterday afternoon for Joseph L. Buttenwieser, real estate operator and philanthropist, in Temple EmanuEl.
The New York Hippodrome Opera Company performed Gounod's "Faust" on the marine stage in Zach's Bay here tonight, before an audience of about 5,000.

The large gallery of coatless men who have been enjoying the view of the Supreme Court steps from a vantage point in the Foley Square Park supplied a flourishing market yesterday for softdrink vendors.

Ward's Automotive Reports today estimated the week's assemblies in the automobile industry at 23,940 cars and trucks, compared with 13,790 last week. The publication credited most of the rise to the resumption of operations at the Ford Motor Company. The output for the week a year ago was 93,339 units.

Homer Martin, president of the United Automobile Workers of America, warned leaders of the Committee for Industrial Organization yesterday that his union was "autonomous" and that its members would not be bound by the dictates of outsiders "who presume to sit in judgment on us."

Fourteen of the eighty-seven American prisoners in the Nationalist [Insurgent] concentration camp at San Pedro de Cardena, near Burgos, will be put across the French frontier at Hendaye just as soon as fourteen Italians held by the Republicans [Loyalists] at Almeria can be shipped to Marseille, it was announced today by Claude G. Bowers, Ambassador to Spain, after a conference here with International Red Cross officials.

Winfield S. Hitch.ner of Ocean City, Cape May County Treasurer, his assistant, Miss Louise Carlsen of Ocean City, and Sarah Sherzer of Cape May Court House were jointly indicted today on a conspiracy charge involving the disappearance of $10,000 scrip.

A sale of horses in training, featured by the disperal of Mrs. C. Oliver Iselin's stable, brought Saratoga's annual series of horse auctions to an end tonight. Thirty-two head of racers changed hands tonight for $55.325, an average price of $1,729 a head.

Imports of textile machinery into Canada increased sharply during the twelve months ending in May, the Commerce Department is informed. Imports were valued at $5,098,804, compared with $3,494,220 for the preceding year, an increase of about 46 per cent.
Germany acted to give all Jews names easily recognizable as Jewish by decreeing today that after Jan. 1 every Jew with a non-Jewish first name must add Israel or Sarah.

The Acting Controller of the Currency today announced that authorizations in the week ended on Aug. 18 for payment of dividends by receivers in five insolvent national banks will result in the distribution of $303,000 to 14,244 claimants who have proved claims aggregating more than $4,070,400.

Contending that present fares are "reasonable maximum fares," a group of New Jersey officials urged the Interstate Commerce Commission today to deny an application by the West Shore Railroad for increased charges on its ferries between Weehawken, N. J., and New York City.
The committee on organization of the Distilled Spirits Institute today accepted Gene Tunney's resignation from the institute.
The United States Maritime Commission announced today signing of an agreement with the Dollar Steamship Lines, Inc., under which it plans to acquire about 90 per cent of the company's voting stock.

The first witness when the Hines trial was resumed at 10:14 yesterday morning was Edward Grant, the grand jury stenographer who recorded the questions put to Julius Williams and the answers the witness made when he appeared before the grand jurors on July 15.
A number of deals involving Long Island properties made through James C. McCormick, Long Island City broker, were reported yesterday by the Long Island Real Estate Board.

M. Frank Whealton of Philadelphia and Philip L. Coffin Jr. of Puerto Rico, a former assistant attorney general of New Jersey, were sentenced to serve terms in a Federal penitentiary today for an oil stock fraud the government charged swindled buyers out of about $600,000. Two companies jointly convicted with the men were fined.
Kenneth H. Condit has been appointed executive assistant to Virgil Jordan, president of the National Industrial Conference Board, Mr. Jordan announced yesterday. Mr.

Dr. George O'Hanlon, medical director of the Medical Center here, issued a second appeal for blood donors today in an effort to save the life of Hudson Grauert, 27, of Weehawken, grandson of the late Mayor Emil Grauert of that town. Grauert has bacterial endocarditis.

The jingle of harness and the creak of taut traces have been largely replaced on the practice fields of the army by the metallic rumble of trucks and the smooth roar of gasoline engines; but still "those caissons go rolling along" in the pages of The Field Artillery Journal.

After giving himself up to a priest who took him to the police, John Bellinger, 33-year-old clerk, who confessed that he shot and killed a 25-year-old girl, his friend, early yesterday morning, was held without bail. later in Homicide Court for a further hearing Sept. 2.

While wheat futures dipped about 1/2 cent a ??ushel in the early trading today on the Board of Trade, there was no material pressure on the market, and it took little buying to lift Prices more than 1 cent from the ow point with the close at net gains of 5/8 to 7/8 cent, the latter on the May.

Michael R. Shehan, 62 years old, foreman of the stereotyping department of THE NEW YORK TIMES, lost his life in Beach Lake, in Wayne County, this afternoon. Whether he was stricken with a heart attack or drowned will be determined by a post-mortem, county authorities said.

President Roosevelt's pledge to support Canada against any aggression and his warning to "every propaganda office and every general staff beyond the seas" that America, by virtue of her world-wide interests, resources and democratic sentiments, was "a vital factor for world peace" produced a profound impression here, not only in official quarters but also among the public.

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks 1,163,000 bales, against 1,191,000 a week ago, 1,172,000 two weeks ago, 1,174,000 three weeks ago and 752,000 a year ago, of which American 658,000 bales, against 674,000 a week ago, 676,000 two weeks ago, 685,000 three weeks ago and 258,000 a year ago.

It is not necessary to agree at all points with Mr. Berle's "confidential" memorandum to the members of the temporary National Economic Committee to recognize it as a document that may perform an important service.

John D. Rockefeller is preparing to carry out an extensive tenementdemolition operation in Harlem and has notified the tenants in the buildings he owns at 400 to 432 West 124th Street to vacate by Oct. 1, it was learned yesterday.

The United States flag service between New York and ports of the east coast of South America, which was started on July 2 under the receivership of Roscoe H. Hupper following the bankruptcy of the Munson Line, will be continued without interruption when the American Republics Line starts its new service on Oct. 8, it was announced yesterday.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week totals only $6,790,661, to be represented by fifty-four municipalities. This compares with the revised total of $24,594,221 for this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date now stands at $25,238,613.

On his sixty-fifth birthday Fred Stone, the former song-and-dance man now appearing at the Mohawk Drama Festival here in "Lightnin'," was honored today with gifts, congratulatory telegrams and a dinner given him by the festival company and staff.

The Premier of Japan thanked Italy today for her attitude toward the war in China and suggested that a "universal civilization" could grow from friendly Italian-Japanese cooperation to combat communism, which he gave as a principal reason for the China campaign.

Large-space newspaper and magazine campaigns for men's Fall hats will be released soon after Labor Day, with prospects that the budgets for the balance of the year will be slightly ahead of 1937, according to advertising agencies yesterday. Manufacturers are showing a restrained amount of optimism, it was said, but are keeping their budgets flexible to meet changing conditions.
The commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "The wool market has been extremely dull this week, except in a very few spots where moderate business is reported, more especially in pulled wools.

The recent opening of the grouse season in Scotland brought out some startling figures. The expense is astonfishing, for an enthusiastic and wealthy grouse hunter thinks nothing of paying as high as $35,000 for a season's rental of his grousing moor.

Miss Peggy Myra Perris, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Perris of Heswall, Cheshire, England, was married here yesterday at noon in the Church of Saint John the Evangelist to Edward Ehrbar, son of Mrs. Edward Ehrbar of 30 Sutton Place and the late Mr. Ehrbar.
Philadelphia and Camden children took first honors in Wildwood's annual baby parade as ideal weather prevailed, with 10,000 persons on the boardwalk witnessing the long procession.

Miss Marjorie Elaine Grimm, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles J. Grimm of this town, was married this afternoon in Christ Episcopal Church, here, to, Dr. William A. Anderson, son of Mr. and Mrs. W. E. Anderson of Glenside, Pa. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. George R. Hewlett.

Because of their "desperate need for additional revenue," Class I railroads asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today to continue in effect the increases In freight rates on bituminous coal that were granted last Oct. 19, which terminate on Dec. 31.
Two castles and a hunting lodge in Austria are available for the Duke and Duchess of Windsor in place of Mittersill Castle which burned down recently.

Miss Elena L. Villa, daughter of Count and Countess Alfonso P. Villa, and Robert Grant 3d, who' are to be married tomorrow at Fairholme, the Villa Summer home, and other members of the prospective wedding party were honored tonight at a young people's dinner given by Mr. and Mrs. Beverley Bogert at Anglesea. Miss Lesley Bogert is to be one of the bridesmaids.
The British Chess Federation's international tournament, in session since Aug. 8, was concluded today at the Royal Pavilion, and ties marked the finish in each division.
The United States War Department is believed to have been responsible for the shelving of the Royal Netherlands Indies Airways plans for a Batavia-Manila air service.

The Interstate Commerce Commission recommended today a final plan for reorganization and consolidation of the Akron, Canton Youngstown and the Northern Ohio Railroads under Section 77 of the Bankruptcy Act.

Although Great Britain has made marked progress in the last decade in clearing out slums and replacing them with low-cost houses, the new so-called model homes show up unfavorably when compared with the small houses being erected in this country, according to Joseph Mason, Eastern editor of The American Builder, who has just returned from a trip to that country and to Europe to study housing progress.

Challenging the primary petition of David S. Murden of Peekskill, candidate for the Republican nomination for County President of Westchester, the Republican county organization filed charges today with the Board of Elections and District Attorney Walter A. Ferris that more than half the 1,258 signatures on the petition were forgeries, were improperly attested or were the names of enrolled Democrats or persons who could not be found at the addresses given.
It never fails! When we put out from Freeport the fishing is good off Montauk, and when we go to Montauk the Freeport boats bring in record catches.

Mr. and Mrs. Franklin W. Robinson of New York were dinner hosts at Beau Geste, in Northeast Harbor, tonight for Mr. and Mrs. nou O'Donnell Iselin, Mr. and Mrs. and John D. Rockefeller Jr. and Dr. and Mrs. Fritz B. Talbot. Mrs. Rollin S. Saltus of Mount Kisco, N. Y., also entertained at Northeast Harbor.

Norman O. Haynes, 33 years old, a Negro, of 304 West 147th Street, pleaded not guilty to a charge of assault on the high seas yesterday before Commissioner Martin C. Epstein. He was held in $5,000 bail for a hearing on Aug. 30.
The officers of the army are publicly supporting President Maximiliano Martinez, as indicated by a statement issued by the government press bureau today.

Led by big Hank Greenberg, who drove three homers to bring his season total to 41, the Detroit Tigers swept a double-header with the St. Louis Browns today, taking the opener, 8 to 7, and the nightcap, 7 to 4. The victories extended Detroit's streak to five straight.
Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of carded gray goods as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:
Under the chaperonage of advance man Charles Washburn, the tour of Alfred Lunt and his wife, Lynn Fontanne, in "Amphitryon 38" and "The Sea Gull" will start on Oct. 3 at the Colonial Theatre, Boston.

An iliuminating footnote to the present state of Europe. and Britain's position in it was written today when the Home Office announced a new drive for volunteers for her lagging civilian defense against bombings.

Scott Candler, acting manager of the Atlanta Loan Agency of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, today disclosed an exchange of correspondence with Jesse Jones, chairman of the RFC in Washington, in connection with political activities in Georgia and the forced resignation as counsel for the government agency's office here of Edgar B. Dunlap because of his support of Senator Walter F. George's candidacy.
Cornell University will eventually receive the estate of Mrs. Rollie Borden Low, who died a resident of Pau, France, on Aug. 4. Her will was filed yesterday in Surrogate's Court.

A second auditor for the State Insurance Fund was arrested yesterday in the investigation ordered by Governor Lehman and conducted by Bernard Botein, general counsel to the fund, into frauds in workmen's compensation insurance.

Mayor La Guardia declined to comment yesterday on a statement of Jeremiah F. Cross, past commander of the New York State American Legion, that some Legionnaires might attack him for alleged communistic sympathies when he attends the national convention of the Legion in Los Angeles next month.

Mr. and Mrs. Walter Hoving entertained with a large dinner tonight at the Port of Missing Men, their home at North Sea. Among their guests were members of their week-end house party, Mr. and Mrs. J. Henry Alexandre, Mrs. Joshua S. Cosden and Charles Baskerville.
The Commerce Department said today credit difficulties curtailed wholesale and retail trade in Mexico during July. A report from the American commercial attache at Mexico City said:
The British Association for the Advancement of Science held an inquest today over one of the oldest and deadest Englishman. He lived in Swanscombe, now a part of London, 250,000 years ago.

A large English residence on a plot of one acre on Bellevue Ave in the grounds of the Westnue, in the ground of the Westchester Country Club, Rye, has been sold by Frances B. Patterson to a client of Prince Ripley, Inc.

Herman F. Moosbrugger, for thirtytwo years a member of the board of managers of the New Jersey State Village for Epileptics, and president of the board for twentyseven, died today in Somerset Hospital after an appendectomy.
Mrs. Elma Thomasson Chapman, composer, died last night in this city. This Summer she won a prize in the Alumni Association of the New England Conservatory of Music of Boston.
The Illinois State Fair's five-day Grand Circuit race meeting closed today with Dean Hanover winning in straight heats in one of the featured events, the $1,900 free-for-all trot.

The Securities and Exchange Commission issued today corrected daily figures on odd-lot transactions on the New York Stock Exchange for the week ended 6n Aug. 13, and also the daily odd-lot transactions for yesterday.
Building construction of all types in Illinois during July increased 6 per cent in value of projects as compared with the same month last year.

All slaughter classes of livestock sold actively at generally steady prices, the United States Deapartment of Agriculture reports. Lambs. however, firmed up with the late crop at S8.65. Supplies of fed steers and yearlings were exceptionally small, with no top steers Dr yearlings available.

THE South wins the literary civil war again this morning with another long, lesiurely and elephantine novel in homage to the Old Days. It's called "... and Tell of Time,"* and it may be just the book you've been looking for ever since you finished an earlier long, leisurely and elephantine novel about the South whose title escapes me at the moment. Anyway, this is really more a memoir than a novel.

State Democratic leaders, here for a meeting of the State Democratic Committee, opened today a campaign for the election as United States Senator of William H. J. Ely, former State WPA Director. Attorney General David T. Wilentz, elected chairman of the committee, declared the campaign would be carried into every county in the State.

Miss Harriet Louise Dal- d las, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. a Charles Donald Dallas of New York a and Katonah, was married here this afternoon to Stanley J. Keyes Jr., son of Mrs. Keyes of New York and Rye and the late Dr. Keyes. Cybotium ferns, lilies and wild smilax decorated St. Matthew's Church, where the ceremony was performed by the Rev. Arthur Ketchum.

Marketing activities of the beet sugar producers are assuming unusual importance as a major price factor in the sugar market, according to a survey entitled, "Sugar on the Bargain Counter," which has been prepared by Commodity Research Bureau, Inc.
