That Puerto Rico should be exempt from the Wages and Hours Act is the inference to be drawn from a statement issued yesterday by Labor Commissioner Prudencio Rivera Martinez.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated Aug. 18: MAJOR GENERAL Gibbins, H., the Quartermaster General, sixteen days leave, Aug. 19. COLONELS

Miss Lillian Elena Williamson, niece of Mrs. William Herman Collinge of Point Beach, Milford, Conn., and New York, was married wa here today to SamueI Sibley Dennis 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Sibley Dennis of West Roxbury. The Rev. Roger Bennett of Wellesley performed the ceremony in the Agora Society House of Wellesley College.
Notwithstanding the opposition of Premier Hepburn of Ontario, the State Department intends to urge the negotiation of a treaty with Canada for the development of the St. Lawrence waterway.

The marriage of Miss Beatrice Willing Patterson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Stuart Patterson of Philadelphia and Southampton, to Rodman Wanamaker 2d of New York and Philadelphia, son of the late Mrs. Archibald C. Thompson and of the late Thomas B. Wanamaker, took place here this afternoon in St. Andrew's Dune Church.

Mr. and Mrs. Amory S. Carhart gave a luncheon at the Trackside Terrace Restaurant before the races today for Mr. and Mrs. William B. Street and Mr. and Mrs. John A. Hinckley, Mr. and Mrs. J. William Y. Martin, Richard Wallace and William Doller, all of Warrenton, Va., and New York.

John Williams of New York City pleaded not guilty to a charge of violating the State securities laws when arraigned today before County Judge Edmund K. Jarecki. The Court continued the hearing to Sept. 15 and set bail at $5,000.

Department store sales in the week ended Aug. 13 were 12 per cent below those of a year ago, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The decline was identical with that in the previous week and with that for the four weeks ended Aug. 13.

Speed-boat drivers from Florida to New England and from the -Missouri and Mississippi Rivers took possession of the local waterfront today in last-minute test spins for the eighth running of the National Sweepstakes Regatta, which will open tomorrow morning.
War Admiral will run again tomorrow in another of Saratoga's weight-for-age tests. It gives Samuel D. Riddle's 4-year-old champion an opportunity for an easy victory under 126 pounds.

Each of the following Reserve officers, now on active duty with the CCC, is continued on active duty until the date set opposite his name: 1st Lt. William T. Levine, Med.-Res. (2d M.A.), March 2, 1939. 1st Lt. Willard P. Darlington, CA.-Res. (3d M.A.), March 7, 1939.

Restricted exclusively to tax-exempt issues for the first time this month, new bond financing this week aggregated only $7,940,685, consisting of nine State and municipal loans. This compares with a total of $83,707,000 in new bonds marketed last week, and with $16,925,000 offered during this period last year.

An increase of $1,523,303 in contributions- of its churches, which number 8,883 was made in the last fiscal year by the Presbyterian Church in - the United States of America, the headquarters of which are in the Witherspoon Building here. Contributions of all the churches amounted to $40,551,108 for the year ended on March 31, according to an announcement today by the Rev. Dr. Seymour Mudge, retiring State Clerk.

A curious impression was created on Czech citizens today when they were informed of their government's intention to appoint a number of Germans to higher official positions-through a communique from the Runciman mission.

David Niven has been "written out" of the cast of Samuel Goldwyn's "The Lady and the Cowboy," the third performer to be dropped from the picture, which has been before the cameras for fifty-nine days.

Mrs. Mary Alice Tirrell, State president of the Women's Relief Corps during the World War, died yesterday at her home, 4,064 Bronx Boulevard. Had she lived, she would have celebrated her seventy-third birthday today.

Two cup events stood out today on the second program of the ninth annual North Shore Horse Show, held on the grounds of the old Field Club, and the results pointed to the likely winners of the hunter and saddle title.

Supreme Court Justice Thomas J. Cuff denied an application by mortgage certificate holders for the appointment of a receiver in foreclosure for the Lido Beach property of Long Beach on the Ocean, Inc., owners of the Lido Country Club at Lido Beach, Long Beach, in an opinion made public today.
There is a sour tradition that most babies come unwanted. It is not the experience of the Tennessee rural doctor who was picnic

Three met-apparently soldiers-who were sintenced to death by a court-martial for espionage, were guillotined here this morning. They were Karl Wieshoff of Werne, Westphalia; Peter Heinz of Zeweri, near Treves, and Wilhelm Braun of Duerckheim in the Palatinate.

Although the weather throughout the Cotton Belt continued yesterday to be the most favorable in several weeks, prices on the New York Cotton Exchange stiffened in sympathy with the advance in the stock market and because of receipt of many complaints of unfavorable progress of the crop in both eastern and western sections.
Among the contracts for commercial space reported by brokers yesterday were two for large quarters in buildings in Newark, N. J., and another for considerable space in a showroom in Long Island City.

Negotiations are under way between the United Mine Workers of America and the Good-Will Fund, Inc., of Boston for. an agreement under which the fund shall finance a study to determine the feasibility of instituting some form of group medicine for the union's members in the Eastern Appalachians.

The marriage of Miss Eleanor Randall Doolittle, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis J. Doolittle of Maplewood, to David James Schauffler of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward W. Schauffler of Toronto, took place this morning in the Church of the Holy Communion, South Orange. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Grant Knauff of Knoxville, Tenn.

While Chancellor Hitler displayed his newly acquired military might in the mobilization of more than a million men this week, the governments of the other great powers sat back, wondering what his intentions were

A political heat wave such as is seldom experienced in this section of the country has been enveloping the Southeast during the last week as a result of President Roosevelt's open drive to "purge" at least three of its better-known legislators from the Democratic party and, incidentally, the United States Senate.

The engagement of Miss Margaret Kennedy Kelly, daughter of Mrs. Cornelius F. Kelly of Muckross, this place, and Larchmont, N. Y., and the late Mr. Kelly, to Edward J. Kelly, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter H. Kelly of Amsterdam, N. Y., has been announced.

The Workers Alliance, whose membership consists chiefly from persons on the WPA rolls and which has been termed communistic by witnesses at various inquiries, will raise -a $50,000 campaign fund here among WPA workers to help elect candidates pledged to amplified relief, the general executive board of the organization announced yesterday.

Referring to the Peekskill Hollow Brook as a "polluted brook" The Health News of the State Department of Health in its August issue, released today, declares that the stream, "by exclusion of other sources," would seem to have served as a vehicle- of infection -in the three definite cases .of typhoid developed recently at the Heckscher Camps at Adams Corners here.
There is a saying that American manufacturers never turn eyes to the export field until the domestic market goes to the bow wows.

On information received by the authorities here that Arab terrorists contemplate an attack upon Jerusalem, orlers have been issued that all roads outsidee the urban areas throughout :he country be under curfew from 6 P. M. to 5 A. M.
One of the largest apartment houses to be built in Newark, N. J., in many years is nearing completion at 19-21 Lyons Avenue, in the Weequahic Park section.

The picture of a threshing machine powered from an old-fashioned steam engine was printed in Middle Western newspapers recently as a novelty. And yet that was a common sight in the country less than a generation ago.

Philip Meehan, alias Philip Smith, characterized by police as a memBer of the Bird gang of Ohio, hanged himself in his cell in City Hall this morning, four hours after his arrest in a raid on a West Philadelphia apartment house.

All branches of artistic endeavor, from buffoonery to serious sculpture, will be represented in a "carnival of the arts" to be presented in Washington Square next Friday afternoon and evening under the auspices of the five WPA Federal Arts Projects in this city.

Tomorrow will be a big day for a little girl who lives in the reflected glory of an older sister. She is Princess Margaret Rose, whose sister, Princess Elizabeth, may become Queen, and the big day is her eighth birthday.

GALLUP, N. M.-Red men and white men are crowding into this Western frontier town this week for the intertribal ceremonial, Wednesday through Friday. More than 7,000 Indians from thirty-one tribes are camped on the outskirts of town, trading, visiting and waiting for the largest Indian show in the United States to begin.

Mrs. Gurdon Caswell Wolfe of Pittsford, N. Y., and Lyme, N. H., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Alice Louise Wolfe, to William Livingston Yeager, son of Mrs. Henry Clarence Yeager of Lancaster, Pa.

The De Sales baseball team of Manhattan captured the Class B city championship yesterday by defeating the Condors A. C. of Flushing in a well played contest at the Yankee Stadium. The Manhattan contingent, behind the good pitching of Dan O'Donoghue, shut out the Queens nine, 3 to 0.

ONE dark, one fair two beautiful young women mystify their acquaint ances and the reader with something that turns out to be less black than it looked at first. Mr. Chamberlain is perfectly fair to the reader. You know from the start why Mrs. Maxon is a recluse, why she killed Hugh,

History and Biography THE TRAGIC PENINSULA. By Christ Anastoff. 8vo. St. Louis, Mo.: Blackwell Wielandy Company. $3. A history of the Macedonian movement for independence since 1878. THE PAGEANT OF JAPANESE HISTORY. By Marion May Dilts. 12mo. New York: Longmans, Green Co. $3.

THE fifth annual South Carolina Singing Convention, one of the "largest festivals of the South, took place last week in the huge Textile Hall of Greenville, S. C. For two whole days until midnight, approximately 10,000 men and women of seven States--mostly workers from cotton mills and farms -- sang old-time Southern hymns of the evangelical churches.

Trapped by policemen after he had held up a taxi driver and robbed him of $4.75, Frank McNamara, an ex-convict, 27 years old, of 592 Ninth Avenue, shot himself dead yesterday morning. The hold-up occurred at Fortyfourth Street and Tenth Avenue shortly after 3 A. M. McNamara, who was riding in a taxicab driven by Adolph Adler of 16 Elliott Place,
The oldest Lilly of them all stayed up late tonight as the many members of the family greeted relatives and friends and watched flickering fireworks.

Definite indications that the upturn in general business has extended to installment sales of consumers' durable goods were reported here yesterday by Arthur 0. Dietz, president of Commercial Investment Trust, Inc.

The pulse-stirring incantations of the actioneer -- "How-much-am-I-bid?" and "Who'll-say-another-dollar?"--soaring above the blended clatter of horses and humans, wheedled extra greenbacks from canny horsemen, ordinarily slow about parting with cash in a horse deal,
TOURISTS to Mexico are discovering that nowhere can they get closer to the people and learn more about them than at Toluca on market day.

Bonds called last week for redemption before maturity were in relatively small volume, consisting principally of small amounts of municipal bonds and several entire issues of Federal Land Bank bonds Payment dates were fixed for future months, particularly in October.
The benefits to which the President called attention in his address last week commemorating the third anniversary of the Social Security Act are undeniable.

The annual golf tournament of the Brooklyn Real Estate Board will be held on Thursday, Sept. 22, at the Garden City Country Club, Garden City, L. I. Jerry V. Meserole is chairman of the golf committee. The tournament will be followed by a dinner.

AT the last but one of the Boston Symphony performances at the Berkshire Symphonic Festival a situation arose which is frequent today at orchestral concerts, but nonetheless deplorable for that. We mean the ridiculous banning and absence of applause between the movements of symphonies.

The Newbrook Stables' noted 3-year-old trotter Sun Dial, driven by Albert Boylan of this city, set a new record when he was clocked in 2:07 in a speed test which featured the Weequahic Park matinee today.

A $25,00 Congressional investigation, rhich started out to expose the workings of Hitler sympathizers in ie United States, turned this week Ito a forum for hazing Stalin suporters. In the course of the pro:edings several who said they were inocent bystanders got messed up bit, but for the most part they ok it smiling.

Captain Thomas Kendrick, British passport officer in Vienna, whose arrest stirred the British Government to make diplomatic representations, was "arrested because there were proofs of his conducting espionage," it was officially announced today.

Miss Ruth Miller Norton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Allen Norton, was married here today at Grassmere, the Summer home of her parents at Highland Lake, to Douglas Emery Mathewson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Mathewson of New York.

Harry Goldstein and George Baskin, the defending champions, survived the second round of the National A. A. U. one-wall doubles handball championship tournament yesterday. The titleholders, representing the Trinity Club, eliminated Bernard Seligson and Harry Socee of the Sea Gate A. C. at Manhat tan Beach, 21-10, 21-13.

Village affairs naturally seem small potatoes to one who goes to them from the majestic botherations of a great city. Let us dip into an exchange which happens to come from a venerable settlement on Cape Cod but which, in essentials, might cover the doings of almost any American small town.

The Army and Navy Union will open its national convention here on Wednesday for four days at the Hotel Jefferson. More than 1,000 members from all parts of the country are expected to attend the gathering which will be the Golden Jubilee Anniversary of the organization.

John D. M. Hamilton, chairman of the Republican National Committee, will attend a Westchester County Republican rally and barbecue on Sept. 10, at Schmidt's Farm, Hartsdale, according to a telegram of acceptance sent by Mr. Hamilton to party leaders here.

Material accumulating since last January at New York University for a new kind of library may make New York the center of world knowledge of international transportation, it is hoped by Dr. H. B. Dorau, chairman of the Department of Public Utilities and Transportation.
William W. Mitchell, manager of the Chester branch of the Ford Motor Company, died at his home in Swarthmore today after an illness of several months. He was 45 years old.

Mr. and Mrs. George Hallam Sicard of this city, who are now at Green Pastures, their Summer home in Barneveld, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Esther Benedict Sicard, to George Everett Beilby Jr. of Albany.

KNOWN yesterday to Americans as chairman of the United States Steel Corporation. Myron C. Taylor is known now to the world as chairman of the Evian conference and the American member of the Intergovernmental Committee for Refugees, which is at work in London.
TWO new adhesives from Loyalist Spain are evidence that the republic's postal authorities still find time to print postal paper-the main reason for doing so, it is suspected, being to raise money.

Mr. and Mrs. Morgan Akin Jones, who have been visiting in Nantucket and Cape Cod, are returning today to the Carlyle. Their son, Sherman Armstrong Jones, will marry Miss Curtis Farrell tomorrow in St. Thomas Church.

ALTHOUGH Howard Hughes turned down more than 1,500 requests by collectors that he carry postal covers for them on his round-the-world air journey, he did take several hundred with him "to provide souvenirs for those persons without whose aid and cooperation the flight would have been impossible," it was announced last week by Albert I. Lodwick,

Although this is the hey-day for the salt-water angler, we cannot ignore the fact that there are still a few die-hards left who confine their fishing activities to fresh water, and further limit their freshwater fishing to trout.

The Federal Housing Administration announced yesterday that it had insured the first loan on a large rental housing development in Brooklyn with the granting of insurance on a mortgage of $575,000 on Sunlit Gardens, Inc., on Ocean Avenue between Avenues X and Y.

With the near approach of the Autumn field-trial season for pointers and setters, the semi-annual problem of conflicting dates again is presented. Each year new organizations spring up, and the field is becoming more crowded, with not enough week-ends available to satisfy every one.

In the self-assured manner of an opera star, Miss Beverly Auerbach, 14-year-old high school pupil, captivated an audience of 500 persons and became a city champion yesterday afternoon with her singing of "Il Bacio" at the annual singing contest conducted by the Department of Parks on the Mall in Central Park.

From an ancient and battered packing case discovered in the storerooms of the Library of Congress at Washington has come a long-hidden collection of notes and unpublished poems by Walt Whitman which, according to The Associated Press,

When President Roosevelt, in speaking on the third anniversary of the Social Security Act this week, warned that there were no "short cuts to Utopia" through such legislation, he was not giving vent to any vague generality.

To offset the loss in silk yarn sales in China, exporters of Italian silk yarns are testing Chile as an outlet for their abundant stocks, according to a report from the American Consulate General at Santiago, Chile.

With the aid of a record-smashing performance in the 400-meter relay, America's touring swimmers took a 24-18 lead over Europe today in the first half of their international meet in the Olympic Swimming Stadium.

The Jersey City Giants battered Buffalo's pitchers for the second successive time tonight to rout the Bisons, 12 to 2. Tom Baker turned in a fine mound performance as he granted the Bisons only four hits and made four himself. The Jerseys pounded four Bison flingers for fifteen hits, including homers by Les Powers and Babe Herman.

Thomas G. Grace, New York State FHA director, announced yesterday that the insurance of mortgages on residential construction issued through the New York, Jamaica and White Plains offices of the FHA during the first seven months of the present year increased 84 per cent over the same period of 1937.
Montreal's seventh-place Royals made it three in a row over the league-leading Newark Bears today by taking the first game of a double-header, 3-2, but dropped the nightcap by 5-4.

A number of interesting facts regarding the personnel background of several realty firms throughout the State have been discovered by Frank S. O'Hara, president of the Real Estate Association of the State of New York, who is sponsoring a "father and son dinner," to be held on the opening night of the association's convention in Syracuse, Sept. 15-17.

The visit of Warren Lee Pierson, president of the Export-Import Bank of Washington, who will arrive here Thursday, is regarded by many in Brazil as a step toward greater trade development between the United States and Brazil.

After a three-year lapse, Frank Jackson of Lynchburg, Va., regained the singles tennis championship for Negro players in the national tournament, which came to a close on the Lincoln University courts today.
A WOMAN'S A FOOL-TO BE. CLEVER, by Dorothy Bennett and Link Hannah, with Ian Keith, Vera Allen and Haila Stoddard. At the Chapel Theatre, Great Neck, L. I.

The annual session of the Middlebury College Bread Loaf Writers Conference opened this week at Bread Loaf Inn when the director, Theodore Morrison, welcomed sixty writers and would-be writers enrolled for the two-week period.

The following foreign service changes since Aug. 5 were announced today by the State Department: Howard Elting of Chicago, vice consul at Batavia, Java, designated third secretary of legation at The Hague.

An audience of approximately 6,000 persons last night enthusiastically applauded the performance of Bizet's "Carmen," at Randalls Island Municipal Stadium, presented by the New York Hippodrome Opera Company under the direction of Alfredo Salmaggi.

The "insurgent bloc" of the United Automobile Workers of America voted unanimously here tonight a resolution urging John L. Lewis, chairman of the C. I. O., to appoint a director for the international with full power to administer all its affairs until adjournment of the next regular convention of the union.

WEATHER conditions continued to upset trade calculations in the week and from most sections of the country reports told of further easing. The New England area appeared to go ahead, along with various agricultural areas. But typically industrial sections lost further ground.
BALBOA, Canal Zone, Aug. 20.Governor George H. Earle of Pennsylvania and Mrs. Earle arrived here today by plane after a flight through Mexico and Central America.

A half share in a valuable collection of the papers of James Boswell, Scottish companion and biographer of Dr. Samuel Johnson, was awarded today by the Edinburgh Court of Sessions to Lieut. Col. Ralph Heyward Isham of New York.
Miss Ethel Prosser and David Sherman Baker Jr. had twenty-one attendants at their marriage here this afternoon in the Round Hill Community Church.

Thomas Callahan, 42 years old, of 154 Rogers Avenue, Brooklyn, was crushed to death at 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon between a Department of Sanitation truck on which he had be working, and the doorway of the Municipal incinerator at Fifty-fifth Street and Twelfth Avenue. Callahan, a loader, stepped off the truck as it was entering the building.

SIGNS point to an active last quarter of 1938 with the Congressional political campaign stirring activity in that department of broadcasting known as "public affairs." Much spellbinding is expected, spurred by the Gubernatorial campaign and the election of two Senators in New York State.

IT is good to learn that the announcement in these columns last week concerning the future of the Bennington School of the Dance and its annual festivals was altogether erroneous and that, instead of discontinuing its activities, the project is to go forward on a "bigger and better" basis.

The FHA stresses the desirability of the home that is planned for efficiency and privacy. In attaining these two qualities it is frequently possible to save money. This is often done, in the case of a singlestory house, by grouping the plumbing.

The Morses of this village have been cultivating the same farm for five generations and have made a reasonably good living from it. Julius G. Morse, Representative in the Legislature, and his 14months-old daughter, Carol Jean, are the fourth and fifth generations to live in the 93-year-old farmhouse.

THE Lambeth Walk has taken the town by storm. Originally introduced by the energetic Gertrude Lawrence and Prince Serge Obelensky at the St. Regis Roof, one of the last outposts of civilization and a favorite retreat of the international set, the importation from London's Cockney quarter is spreading faster than any dance in recent years and bids fare to better the Big Apple in general public acceptance.

THE past week has been an eventful one in the movies. Looking about us at the week's end, metaphorically mopping the departmental brow, we are happy to note the unwonted spectacle of three important films on local screens, which is morethree more, to be exact-than we could say for last week.
Running with beautiful action that carried him more than eight yards every second, Sydney Charles Wooderson, 23-year-old Briton, today established new world records for the halfmile and 800 meters.

The light cruiser Helena will be named for the capital of the State of Montana at launching ceremonies in the New York Navy Yard, Brooklyn, at 11 o'clock next Saturday morning. Slightly different in detail of construction and armament from the Brooklyn and Honolulu, also built here, the ship will bear their general definition as a 10,000ton warship costing $15,000,000.

THE spacious days of Queen Elizabeth, like the plays of Shakespeare, which were to be their chief literary ornament. have too often seemed to us to have come about spontaneously, the result of some mysterious combustion not readily explainable.

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 20.--A lone United States citizen, acting without diplomatic aid, today walked into the office of Ignacio Garcia Tellez, Secretary of the Interior, and before he left the Secretary had sent a telegram to the city of Nuevo Laredo, ordering, officials to remove the huge sign on the Mexican side of the border warning Mexicans not to spend money outside of Mexico.

The foreign policy of the United States took two steps this week out of the realm of hazy understanding toward a somewhat more clearly defined picture of what President Roosevelt and his Secretary of State, Mr. Hull, consider essential primary principles.

The Cincinnati Reds, who are scrapping to get into first place, and the Cardinals, just scrapping, split an exciting double-header today. The Reds won the opener, 4 to 2, and Lon Warneke pitched the Cards to a 5-4 victory in the nightcap for his twelfth success of the year.
Miss Eleanor Karr, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund J. Karr of this place, was married tonight to Guy Emery Shipler Jr., son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Shipler, in St. Paul's Episcopal Church here.

OVER considerable periods they are allowed to rest in peace. But now and then some one sufficiently high up will venture a remark that, reported in the public prints, jumps to wide circulation; and then the lid is off again.

THAT gifted and discriminating baritone Charles Panzera makes another of his too-occasional and always-satisfying domestic appearances this month with two songs by Henri Duparc--"Soupir" and "Chanson Triste." Duparc and Panzera make an ideal combination.

WHITE MOUNTAINS, N. H.--The White Mountain resorts and cottage colonies this week-end are enjoying a round of activities, climaxing a week of sports and charity events. Dances will conclude the week next Saturday at the Sunset Hill House and at the Lookoff, Sugar Hill; the Alpine, North Woodstock; the Forest Hills, Franconia; the Crawford House; Gray's Inn and Eagle Mountain House at Jackson, and the Waumbek at Jefferson.

NEWPORT, R. I.--For the golfers of the Newport Summer colony all eyes will be on the result of the weekend tournament to be played at the Newport Country Club tomorrow. It will be the second annual competition for the Sopwith Challenge Cup, and there are indications of a large entry.

On Albany's Capitol Hill, where each Winter the Legislature meets to exercise its control over the affairs of the Empire State, a convention has been in session since April 5 to propose changes in the rules by which the Legislature shall be guided. Those rules are embodied in the State Constitution, which, unlike the Federal Constitution, periodically undergoes a wholesale revision--or attempted revision.

Miss Catherine Beirne Roper, daughter of Commander Clifford H. Roper, U.S.N., of the Naval War College, and Mrs. Roper, was married today to Lieutenant Clark Paul Jeffers, Medical Corps, son of Clark P. Jeffers of Evanston, Ill., in the presence of many members of the naval colony here.

TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 20.--The Republican candidate for the Presidency in 1936, further enforcing his statement that he would not accept the nomination "in the remote contingency" it was offered to him in 1940, has now written his impressions of his losing fight and the lessons he learned from it.

In a 16-yard event at 50 targets over the traps of the Bergen Beach Gun Club yesterday, R. H. Helsel scored with 49. In a shoot-off for the handicap cup, A. Bennett triumphed by breaking 24 out of 25. Bennett also placed third in the 50-target test, in which Doerrer was runner-up with 48.
The Pirates extended their National League lead to five and one-half games today by defeating the Cubs, 5 to 2, while the Giants were bowing to the Phillies.

Miss Virginia Marie Bradley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Bradley of Maplewood, was married to Dr. Robert J. Amberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Amberg of Maplewood, this morning in Our Lady of Sorrows Church, South Orange.

LONDON, Aug. 20.--Within the next few weeks Germany's new submarine fleet will be numerically greater than Britain's, according to Lieut. Comdr. Kenneth Edwards, naval correspondent for the Sunday Times.

ONE of the main problems delaying the arrival of television how to broadcast television images over long distances withou the use of relay stations and expensive cables or "pipes"--appears to have been solved, it is indicated in a United States patent (No. 2,125,977) granted to Dr. Vladimir K. Zworykin of Philadelphia. The patent is assigned to the Radio Corportion of America.

Demand for gold declined appreciably today in the bullion market here; although the turnover of [Pound]442,000 was substantially above the usual Saturday volume. The price based on upply and demand was 1d lower at 142s 5 1/2d a fine ounce. The premium over the dollar shipping parlty remained 1/2d, the dollar rate at the time the price of gold was fixed being $4.883-16 to the pound sterling.

President Roosevelt, on his trip to Canada last week, dedicated the swiftly built Thousand Islands Bridge, linking scenic resort areas of New York State and Ontario Province. He spoke, however, not of the impressive main suspension span but rather of the water that flows beneath it.
AHEAD, Pinchi, the numbers runner, pushes through the malodorous murk of the hallway and up a flight of stairs. He is a small, brown, bespectacled man.

We print today the first of four papers by Alfred E. Landon. Our readers will form their own judgment of them, nor shall we try to anticipate. it; but we may be allowed to say that he seems to be a game sportsman, unsoured by a tremendous political disaster and free of that itch for the Presidency that has been thought incurable.
PRELIMINARY reports on August passenger-car sales, based on returns for the first ten days of the month, indicate that the upturn which began late in June is continuing.
SOFT-BONED and slack fibered travelers," says Margaret Halsey, "is an almost photographic description of Henry and me.
SIGRID UNDSET has done a remarkable thing in this short work. She has written a novel about a happy marriage, one that stays happy for more than two hundred pages! It is to take heart.

President Roosevelt's addition of the name of Representative John J. O'Connor to the now famous "purge" list has assured an interesting contest in Manhattan's Sixteenth Congressional District. Tammany Hall is standing stanchly behind the O'Connor candidacy despite efforts of the New Deal to win support for James H. Fay, Deputy Internal Revenue Collector, who is running against Mr. O'Connor in the Democratic primary with the President's blessing.
Mrs. Mabel Otis Reynolds Brennard, wife of Dr. Everett C. Brennard, died today at her home on the grounds of the United States Veterans' Hospital, Newington, where her husband is a staff physician.

MONOPOLIES with varying degrees of control, inflexible price structures, coercion of independent business men, and private control of what might be termed "economic toll bridges" have been familiar features of American life since Ida Tarbell wrote the history of the Rockefeller dynasty. The power of great organizations to levy what are in effect taxes is commonplace.
The marriage of Miss Jane Otterson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Otterson to James J. Corrigan, both of this city, took place this afternoon in St. Joseph's Church.

Although tax revenues have more than doubled since Chancellor Hitler came to power the Reich Government is still spending at a rate of more than 1,000,000,000 marks monthly above its income, thus raising the public debt that much.

THE municipal authorities of Viareggio have proposed that the name of Torre del Lago be changed to Torre Lago Puccini, in perpetual commemoration of the popular operatic bard who lived his most productive years in this Tuscan village in a simple Bohemian life among hunters and fishermen.
ALTHOUGH the state of somnolence which has been afflicting Soviet fiction since the beginning of "spy hunts" and "purges" still continues a few books which

THIS person and that, including Arthur Hopkins, has fancied the notion of co-starring Cornelia Otis Skinner and Brian Aherne in a revival of "The Beaux' Stratagem." But if it does come to pass-and it would be the first glimpse of the Farquhar play here since The Players' revival in 1928-it seems now that the revivalists will be Helen Bonfils and George Somnes, with the latter serving also as director;

Representatives of the Transit Commission and the La Guardia administration will insist, at a meeting Thursday of delegates to the Constitutional Convention, that the transit unification amendment be submitted to the voters as a separate proposition, it was disclosed yesterday.
Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Aug. 20, unless specified: At Chefoo: Alden, Barker, Whipple, J. D. Edwards.

Sir Orme Rowan-Hamilton is big, blond, clean shaven and very British. When he is working, he is Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of Bermuda and looks the part in the black gown and powdered wig of an English jurist.

The tenth annual horse show for the benefit of St. Peter's-bythe-Sea Episcopal Church took place this afternoon at the Point Judith Polo Field. Mrs. John C. Norris of Philadelphia promoted the event, assisted by Mr. and Mrs. Philip S. P. Randolph and Mr. and Mrs. Charles F. Thatcher.

Promotion of an "automatic degree-day system" for reminding consumers of the necessity for refilling coal bins, was started among anthracite retailers last week by the Anthracite Industries, Inc., as a means of building sales volume.

Some of the first Fall shoes and handbags in the shops now show that designers have grown a lot wiser in the last year or two. Makers of these accessories still: turn out bags and shoes in the new shades-notably plum brown and rust-specially made to go together, but this season there is a difference.

Miss Ruth Bybee Milliken of Hyannisport, Mass., and George Arthur Murphy of Now York were married hers this afternoon in the Hay Memorial Chapel at the Westminster School by the Rev. Henry DeWolf de Mauriac. The bride's brother, Arthur Milliken, is headmaster of the school.
A bone specialist ordered an operation today for Carl Hubbell, depriving the New York Giants of their ace hurler in the thick of the fight for the National League pennant.

The policy of allowing students to work directly with experts on the international application of such subjects as social security, legislation for women and children, and the use of new inventions for modern living will be carried out in a course in Human Needs and Their Satisfaction Through the Medium of International Organization next Fall at the Geneva College for Women in Switzerland.

MADRID'S short-wave station, EAQ, which has been silent for the past month during evening hours, now appears on a new frequency of 9.87 megacycles. Broadcasts in English, which lately have centered around Nationalist drives in Southern Spain, have been tuned in clearly on the new Spanish wave between 7:40 and 7:55 o'clock, daylight time.

Miss Marguerite Eleanor McQuat, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James McQuat of San Francisco, Calif., was married today to Wardell Jennings of New York, son of the Rev. Webster Wardell Jennings, rector of St. Luke's Episcopal Church, San Francisco, and Mrs. Jennings, in Calvary Episcopal Church, Cairo, N. Y. The ceremony was performed by the bridegroom's father in the church where, forty years ago, he preached his first sermon.

George Schrafft, the young Newton, Mass., sportsman, is leading the point-scoring parade of the country's 225-cubic inch craft, according to tabulations of Racing Commissioner Charles F. Chapman of New York. He has won tallies in eight races this season, more events than any rival, and now is credited with 2,227 scoring points.

Packaged proprietary medicines may be eliminated from the limited price chain stores of Los Angeles, if a test case scheduled to be heard on Friday in that city upholds recent actions of the District Attorney there in removing these items from stores, it was learned here yesterday.

The Progressive party will fight to prevent passage of the proposedConstitutional Amendment banning proportional representation, as adopted by the Constitutional Convention, Maurice P. Davidson, chairman of the party, announced yesterday.
At the conclusion of their Summer exhibition on Aug. 28 the Lyme Art Association will open (on Aug. 31) the sixth annual Autumn show, at the Post Road Galleries. It will continue through Sept. 25.

This country continued last week to drain the diminishing gold stocks of European nations. With engagements in England amounting to $8,058,000 yesterday, the week's takings from that country mounted to $12,858,000, raising the total since the hoarding movement got under way on July 26 to $39,646,000.

Miss Margaret Christopher, daughter of Mrs. Thomas Christopher of this place, and Dr. Joseph E. Funk, son of Mrs. Joseph A. Funk of Laurelton, L. I., were married here this morning in St.-Mary's Roman Catholic Church.

At this season of the year, when shrub borders show but little color, if any, and even the flower borders are likely to be a bit "off," the colorful and spirelike blooms of the butterflybush or buddleia are a welcome sight in the garden.

Sheriff George W. Lyle said today that Lorenzo Cerruti, a 50-year-old ranch worker, had confessed dynamiting the Mountain View Bank of America branch yesterday because the bank foreclosed on his property four years ago.

Summer camps for boys and girls in this country are well known, but not many persons know that in recent years women--grown and sometimes married women-have been establishing camps where they could escape for a time from humdrum life and store up experiences of comradery and relaxation that contrast sharply with their daily routine.

Miss Charmian Campbell, daughter of Brig. Gen. and Mrs. Archibald Campbell of Cold Spring and New York, was married to Henry MacDonald, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Michael MacDonald of Forest Hills, here at noon today in the Church of Our Lady of Loretto by the Rev. Leo Ryan, the pastor.

New York's newest educational foundation is just completing its first year of experiment at a gigantic task, that of helping to make America a nation of economic literates. Financed by a $10,000,000 gift from the motor car magnate whose name it bears, the Alfred P. Sloan

A map prepared by the Intelligence Department of the Fourth United States Marines, stationed in Shanghai, indicates that huge Chinese forces are still operating in areas listed by the Japanese as "occupied."

THE Philharmonic-Symphony Society announces six Satururday morning young people's concerts for the season 1938-39, the sixteenth, to be held at Carnegie Hall at 11 o'clock. The concerts will take place Nov. 19, Dec. 17, Jan. 14 and 28, Feb. 18, and March 18.
The Public Use of Art Committee, which last Spring sponsored an exhibition of art for the subway, is going to sponsor a children's art festival on the Mall in Central Park Sept. 6 and 7.

The Rev. William Francis Edmondson, priest of St. Anthony's parish here, died suddenly yesterday after a heart attack. His age was 40. Born in Ottawa and a graduate of Ottawa University, Father Edmondson completed his theological studies in Augustine Seminary, Toronto, and at Edmont6n.

INCREASING use of tinted eyeglasses by motorists for day driving and for protection from headlight glare at night lends particular pertinence to revelations just made by the National Bureau of Standards under the forbidding title of "Spectral-transmissive properties and use of colored eye-protective glasses."

Joseph Ward, 48 years old, a station guard employed by the I. R. T., of 1,946 Amsterdam Avenue, was stabbed and seriously wounded at 6 P. M. yesterday during an altercation on the elevated platform at 242d Street and Broadway, the terminus of the Broadway line.

With Town Supervisor Bert C. McCullough, and Mayor William H. Johnson of Mamaroneck in attendance, ground was broken last week in Westchester County for another large-scale housing development financed by private capital and Federal Housing Administration mortgage insurance.

Dublin Venture, standing seventeen hands in his show plates, a genrally consistent performer, was awarded the hunter championship today of the ninth annual North Shore Horse Show, held on the grounds of the Old Field Club. Miss Deborah Rood of Wilmington, Del., owns the big Irish gray and always pilots him.

Formal openings of two important traffic bridges in the South are scheduled for the next few weeks. One spans Albemarle Bound in North Carolina and the other connects Port Arthur and Orange in Texas, crossing the Neches River. Details on the two new highway links follow.

Mrs. Jean Tell Fradkin of 160 Central Park South has reported to the police the loss of jewelry she valued at between $10,000 and $11,000, it became known yesterday. The jewelry disappeared from her stateroom aboard the Queen of Bermuda three hours after she sailed from here on Aug. 13,

Hailing the change in the housing bill passed in amended form by the Constitutional Convention as an example of what can be done by a united front in realty circles, the Real Estate Taxpayers Federation issued yesterday a statement in which it declared the organization was withholding judgment on the proposed housing and other amendments to the basic law of the State.

An eight-State police alarm has been broadcast for Moe Howard, partner in the Glanzberg Express and Trucking Corporation, of 271 Heyward Street, Brooklyn, who has been missing since about 5 P. M. last Monday.

There are several thousand cheerless families in this city today who share in one of the great tragedies of the Spanish civil war-the absence from home of thousands of children exiled to foreign countries, where most of them still remain.

JIMMY STEWART'S first ambition as a small boy was to be a magician. Seeing him, suddenly and dramatically. an important Hollywood figure, there are many who would say that, along with motion-picture success, he has attained his boyhood dream.

Retail trade, although hampered by extreme hot weather in many districts, showed some improvement on the week, and the loss from last year was narrowed. Fall promotions met poor results but in several areas, late Summer merchandise was sold actively.

With the start this month of the 1938-39 crop year millions of bushels of wheat and thousands of bales of cotton have begun to pour into the markets from the farms. For the first time since recovery from the depression's low point began, August threatens to open a year of declining farm prosperity.

The marriage of Miss Eugenia Pauline Fischer, daughter of Paul M. Fischer of this place and the late Mrs. Eugenia McChesney Fischer, to Lieutenant Alvar B. Sundin, U.S.A., son of Mrs. Carl Sundin of New Bedford, Mass., and the late Mr. Sundin, took place here tonight in the Central Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Morgan P. Noyes, the pastor, performed the ceremony.

A "farmers' holiday," during which farmers throughout the three prairie provinces would refuse to market wheat until the Canadian Wheat Board increased the set price of grain to $1 a bushel, has been proposed by Frank Eliason of Saskatoon, secretary of the United Farmers of Canada, Saskatchewan section.

Trading in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday was extremely dull and the turnover was the smallest since May 28. A steady undertone prevailed throughout the session and price changes at the close were negligible for the most part. Trading in United States Government issues was light, with fractional changes the rule.

St. Louis is somewhat famous for its art disputes. Some time before the World War a German sculptor was engaged to prepare a statue for a South Side park in which the theme of the freedom of the press was to be emphasized.

Leading by 85 runs, but with only half of the opposing team dismissed, the champion- Hudson County eleven of the Brooklyn C. C. had to be content with a draw against Union County in the New Jersey State Cricket League fixture on the grounds of Stevens Institute today.
Running to cover as peasants with their few possessions on their backs flee invading armies, many persons with liquid assets have joined the gold rush that has almost made London. a new Klondike.

With Deacon Danny MacFayden at the controls and the Dodgers in a mild State of confusion the Bees yesterday shuttled back into fifth place by registering a 3-2 decision over the Flatbush boys at Ebbet Field.
